**Comprehensive Mirror of Perfected Immortals Through the Ages, Fascicle One**
**The Yellow Emperor**

The Yellow Emperor, surnamed Gongsun—after the Zhou established the five ranks of nobility, the surname Gongsun emerged. The Yellow Emperor was styled Xuanyuan, having grown up by the Ji River, and thus took Ji as his surname. The basis for this in ancient records is unclear.

He was the second son of Shaodian, lord of the Youxiong state. Fu Xi begot Shaodian, and Shaodian begot Shennong. When the Yellow Emperor ascended the imperial throne, he resided within the fief of Youxiong. His mother was a woman of the Xiqiao clan, named Fubao. One night, she saw a great bolt of lightning encircling the pivot star of the Northern Dipper, illuminating the outskirts. Moved by this, she conceived. As the pivot star descended, he was also named Tian Shu. After twenty-four months, she bore Xuanyuan at Shouqiu—a place beyond the eastern gate of Lu.

From birth, the Emperor was divinely inspired. As a child, he was precocious and quick-witted; as a youth, he could speak; in maturity, he was earnest and astute; and in adulthood, he was wise and discerning. His countenance was dragon-like, his forehead broad as the sun, his eyes like rivers, his temples high, his complexion dark, and his shoulders broad.

He first studied under Da Xiang and grew up by the Ji River. At fifteen, his thoughts penetrated all things, and he received the state of Youxiong, inheriting the lands of its former lord in Xizheng County, Zheng Prefecture. For crafting the *xuan* (imperial chariot) and *mian* (crown), he was styled Xuanyuan; for ruling by the virtue of earth, he was called the Yellow Emperor.

He obtained Shelong, who distinguished the East (explained below); obtained Zhu Rong, who distinguished the South—the Heart Star, where fire resides in the due south, the great illumination. *Rong* means radiance, the office presiding over fire, hence the title Zhu Rong. The character is composed of *nan* (south) and *wu* (noon), signifying the search for the south. *Qiu* (to seek) implies direct alignment: brightness and darkness, thus south as yang and north as yin.

He obtained Huofeng, who distinguished the West—*you* (酉) as the rooster, which gazes east at dawn while its body faces west. *You* is named for the hour it enters, and its latter half signifies the west. He obtained Houtu, who distinguished the North—*bei* (north) means yin and the back, hence the term.

The names of the four directions: *dong* (east) means movement, for the sun rises and all things stir. The character *dong* combines *ri* (sun) piercing wood, evoking the sun’s emergence through the branches of Fusang, the mythical mulberry. The sun’s origin lies tens of thousands of *li* east of Fusang.

The Emperor wed Leizu of the Xiling clan at Daliang, taking her as his primary consort. She bore his eldest sons, Xuanxiao and Changyi.

Initially, he rejoiced in the world’s devotion, nurturing correctness and delighting in fate, seeking ease and following the natural order, ushering in the era of Honghuang to unify the people. At that time, people transformed without coercion, strove without reward, their hearts joyful and unfeigned, their affairs plain and unadorned—this was the beginning of Great Purity.

Plowmen did not encroach on boundaries; fishermen did not dispute shores; markets required no advance deposits; shops closed not their doors. Merchants and travelers yielded wealth to one another; outer gates remained unbarred—this was called the Great Unity.

After ruling the realm for fifteen years, the Emperor grew concerned for the people’s disorder. He exhausted his wisdom and strength to govern the masses, cultivating virtue in full. He examined his merits and virtues, devoting himself to laws and teachings.

At that time, the Empress Yuan of Xiling first raised silkworms to produce silk—*The Records of Ritual* states: "The Empress offers sacrifice to the First Silkworm, the Lady of Xiling." Ge Zhichuan’s *Western Capital Records* says: "Within the palace stood the Altar of the First Silkworm, where the Celestial Elder and the Five Sages assisted in governance and transformation."

The Emperor took the trigrams of Fuxi, modeled and employed them, and based on the sixty-four hexagrams revered by Shennong, he composed the theory of the eight trigrams, calling them the *Eight Cords*, seeking the meaning of their doubled hexagrams. There were ministers at the time: Cao Hu, who crafted robes; Bo Yu, who made skirts; and Yu Ze, who fashioned shoes. The Emperor, following their innovations, created crowns and ceremonial caps—*crowns* denoted civilized attire, while *mian* (ceremonial caps) were a distinct name for crowns, their form higher at the back and lower at the front, resembling a nodding posture, hence called *crown-mian*. This began the replacement of fur and leather garments, as the saying goes: "The Yellow Emperor let robes and skirts hang loose, and the world was governed."

The Emperor used this to distinguish nobility from humility, ordering men and women to dwell separately, taking as model the principle of Heaven’s supremacy and Earth’s subordination. Observing floating leaves and rafts, he had three ministers—Gong Gu, Hua Di, and another—assist in crafting boats and oars, as the saying goes: "Split wood to make boats, carve wood to make oars." This was derived from the hexagram *Huan* (Dispersion), meaning dispersal and great communication, used to cross what was impassable.

The Emperor also observed the image of tumbleweeds to create carts. At that time, divine horses emerged from the marsh, named Marsh Horses—one called *Jiguang*, another *Jiliang*—originating from the ancient state of Da Feng in Bozhou to the east. These were patterned horses with white bodies and red manes, and riding them granted a lifespan of a thousand years. They appeared in response to sagely governance. Today, the *Feilong Bureau* has a *Jiliang Stable*, owing to this. Xue Zong said: "They are the same as the *Teng Huang*." Ge Zhichuan said: "*Teng Huang* is the horse; *Jiguang* is the beast." Thus, the beast and horse differ. Here, *Jiguang* is taken as the horse, *Teng Huang* as the beast, while Huichuan’s account diverges. There was also the beast *Teng Huang*, yellow in color, resembling a fox, with two horns on its back and dragon wings—one version says: "dragon-winged with a horse’s body." It was also called *Cheng Ruo*, *Fei Huang*, *Gu Huang*, or *Cui Huang*, originating from the land of Japan, with a lifespan of three thousand years and the ability to travel ten thousand *li* in a day. Riding it granted a lifespan of two thousand years. *The Six Statutes* states: "The dynasties of Song, Qi, Liang, and Chen all had offices for *Chefu* (Chariot Bureau) and *Cheng Huang* (Riding Yellow); today, the *Taipu Temple* has a *Cheng Huang Bureau*, continuing this tradition."

The Yellow Emperor obtained and rode it, thereby traveling the Six Directions, as the saying goes: "Riding the eight-winged dragon, he roamed the world," hence his movements and sojourns were without fixed abode. The Emperor first taught people to ride horses, and his minister Zhi domesticated oxen for use. *The Genealogies* states: "This is what is meant by 'harnessing oxen and riding horses, drawing heavy loads to distant places,'" derived from the hexagram *Sui* (Following), adapting to what is fitting.

His minister Huang Yongfu first created the pestle, as the saying goes: "Cut wood for the pestle, dig earth for the mortar," to aid the multitudes. This was derived from the hexagram *Xiao Guo* (Small Exceeding), meaning to exceed yet communicate. The Emperor made *chong* (a cooking vessel) to record classics, first ordering the casting of cauldrons to cook rice, then steaming rice and boiling congee, replacing the practice of eating raw flesh and drinking blood. His minister Hui first crafted the bow, and Yi Mou made arrows, as the saying goes: "String wood to make the bow, carve wood to make arrows." *The Records of the Grand Historian* states: "The Yellow Emperor made them." The efficacy of the bow and arrow was used to awe the world, derived from the hexagram *Kui* (Opposition), meaning discord and restraining disorder.

The Emperor first built houses, constructing palaces to avoid cold, heat, dryness, and dampness, calling them *gong* (palaces), meaning to dwell within. As the saying goes: "Upper beams and lower eaves to await wind and rain," derived from the hexagram *Da Zhuang* (Great Strength), meaning greatness and strength. The Emperor also ordered the construction of walled cities for habitation, beginning the replacement of dwelling in nests and caves. He further established multiple gates and watchmen’s clappers to guard against violent intruders, derived from the hexagram *Yu* (Preparation), to prepare for the unforeseen.

He also changed the ancient practice of clothing the dead in straw, burying them in coffins and outer coffins, derived from the hexagram *Da Guo* (Great Exceeding). He performed fasting and purification in the central palace, by the Luo River, sitting in the Black Retreat Stone Chamber with Rong Guang and others in inner contemplation. Suddenly, a great bird placed a diagram before the Emperor, which he received with two bows. This bird resembled a crane, with a parrot’s head, swallow’s beak, turtle’s neck, dragon’s form, paired wings, and fish tail, its body adorned with five colors, its three patterns forming characters. The front pattern read *Shen De* (Prudent Virtue), the back *Xin Yi* (Trust and Righteousness), and the side *Ren Zhi* (Benevolence and Wisdom).

The Celestial Elder said: "This bird has the front of a unicorn, the rear of a deer, a snake’s neck, dragon patterns on its back, proper footing, and a martial tail, possessing nine treasures: first, *Bao Ming* (Embracing Destiny); second, *Xin He Du* (Heart in Harmony with Measure); third, *Er Cong Da* (Ears Keen and Penetrating); fourth, *She Qu Shen* (Tongue Flexible and Extending); fifth, *Cai Se Bei* (Colors Complete); sixth, *Guan Ju Rui Gou* (Crown Tall and Sharp-Hooked); seventh, *Jin Mu Xian Ming* (Golden Eyes Bright and Clear); eighth, *Yin Ji Yang* (Sounds Resonant and Soaring); ninth, *Fu Da* (Abdomen Large). It is also called *Ou*; the male is *Feng*, the female *Huang*. Standing five to six *chi* tall, its morning cry is *Deng Chen* (Ascending Dawn), its daytime cry *Shang Xiang* (Auspicious Omen), its evening cry *Gui Chang* (Returning Prosperity), its dusk cry *Gu Chang* (Establishing Constancy), and its night cry *Bao Zhang* (Preserving Longevity). All correspond to the pitch pipes. When seen, the world is at peace."

The Yellow Emperor said: "This bird departs to dwell among the Nine Yi when chaos arises. It emerges from the Land of Gentlemen in the East and the Cinnabar Cave Mountain." His minister Ju Song and Cang Jie observed bird tracks and created writing—this was the beginning of script. Earlier scholars debated the origin of writing, some saying it began with the Three Sovereigns, others with Fuxi, or that it arose with Heaven and Earth. Here, following Sima Qian, Ban Gu, Wei Yan, Shi Bing, and Fu Xuan, who state: "Cang Jie was a minister of the Yellow Emperor," this account is recorded. Other scholars’ views on Cang Jie lack definitive evidence.

The Yellow Emperor cultivated virtue and righteousness, and the world was greatly ordered. He summoned the Celestial Elder and said to him: "I dreamed that two dragons presented a white diagram from the River, offering it to me. I dare ask you about this."

The Celestial Elder replied: "This is the sign of the River Diagram and Luo Writing soon to emerge. Heaven may be granting them to Your Majesty. Try fasting and observing." The Yellow Emperor then fasted in the central palace, wearing yellow robes, a yellow crown, riding a chariot drawn by yellow dragons, and bearing banners of entwined dragons. With the Celestial Elder and the Five Sages, he journeyed between the River and Luo.

Yet the dream remained unfulfilled. The Emperor then submerged a jade disk into the River, and a great fog enveloped the land for three days. Arriving at the Spring of Cui Ma, a giant perch swam upstream in the River. He sacrificed three animals to it, and immediately a heavy rain fell for seven days and nights. A yellow dragon emerged from the River, bearing a diagram on its back.

The Yellow Emperor said to the Celestial Elder and the Five Sages: "Do you see what is in the River?" The Celestial Elder and the Five Sages stepped forward, knelt, and received it. The diagram was resplendent in five colors, a white chart with indigo leaves and vermilion script, which he presented to the Yellow Emperor. Unfurling it, he named it *The Record of Interwoven Patterns*. He commanded his attendants to copy it and display it throughout the land.

The Yellow Emperor said: "This is called the River Diagram and Luo Writing." That autumn, having obtained the dragon and phoenix’s diagrams and writings and Cang Jie’s script, he created characters to replace the governance of knotted cords, crafting written contracts—this was derived from the principle of *jia*. *Jia* means "to store and arrange," and from the regulation of all matters—from the institution of robes to the creation of writing—nine achievements are recorded, as documented in Huangfu Mi’s *Imperial Generations and Remnants*. The Yellow Emperor’s accomplishments, as described in contemporary records and various texts, are listed above to clarify them. However, in the *Appended Statements* of the *Book of Changes*, these nine achievements are attributed to a lineage from the Yellow Emperor to Yao and Shun, as some earlier scholars argued they were not unique to the Yellow Emperor. Yet according to Huangfu’s records and the texts cited here, all nine were first established by the Yellow Emperor for practical use, while later sages like Yao and Shun merely emulated and refined them.

Thereupon, the Yellow Emperor defined the names of all things, composed the explanation of the eight trigrams, calling them the *Eight Searches*. He was also named Emperor Hongshi and Guicangshi, and the work he created was titled *The Guicang Book*—this was the beginning of the *Book of Changes*. After the Yellow Emperor instituted robes and skirts, he designed a dragon-patterned garment, embroidering the sun, moon, and stars upon it to symbolize Heaven, hence the ode *Dragon’s Inner Garment*. He took Lady Nüjie as his consort. Later, Lady Nüjie saw a great star like a rainbow descending upon Hua Islet; she was moved by it and conceived, giving birth to Shaohao. (Note: Lady Nüjie was not Leizu.) The Emperor also took an ugly woman named Mumou as a consort, who instructed the palace women in virtuous conduct, composing the *Ode to the Six Virtues*. He further took Feixiu as his wife.

At that time, the common people savored their food, admired their clothing, delighted in their customs, and rested content in their dwellings, free from envy or desire. Neighboring states were visible to one another, the cries of roosters and dogs audible across borders, yet even in old age, people did not travel between them, for there was no need. This was the era of the Yellow Emperor’s governance, when the people’s hearts were at ease—an age of perfect order.

At that time, the wind did not howl through the branches, called the "joyous wind of all under Heaven." Rain did not shatter clods of earth; instead, a light rain fell every ten days, aligning with the patterns of Heaven, and a heavy rain every fifteen days, harmonizing with the celestial movements. They took fine grain as their staple, called "great millet," its ears extraordinary. They drank from sweet springs, whose waters were as flavorful as wine, suitable for nourishing the elderly. They enjoyed the fragrance of the five *zhi* herbs—rare plants that grew in gardens, such as purple *zhi*, black *zhi*, and five *zhi* grasses, all divine medicines for immortals.

At times, aquatic creatures surged in the waters, and mountain chariots filled the fields. His virtue moved Heaven, and auspicious yellow stars appeared—celestial omens called "extraordinary stars," shaped like the moon, aiding its light, named the *Jing Star*. There were also crimson and azure vapors intertwined: within the crimson vapor were two stars, and within the azure, one star—three stars in total. A strange plant grew in the courtyard: each day, one leaf sprouted until the fifteenth day, when fifteen leaves had grown; from the sixteenth day, one leaf fell each day until the thirtieth, when all had fallen. In shorter months, one leaf remained unfallen, called *mo jia*, clarifying the moon’s phases—also known as the *calendar pod*. The Emperor cast mirrors to reflect this, creating the fifteen-faced divine mirror, a treasured relic.

At that time, Da Nao discerned the essence of the five phases and the ancient pointer of the Northern Dipper. He created the ten celestial stems of *jia* and *yi* to name the days, established the twelve earthly branches of *zi* and *chou* to name the months, paired them with birds and beasts to form the twelve branches, and combined them to create the sixty-year cycle—this was the invention of the *jiazi* system. Observing Fuxi’s three lines forming trigrams and the eight trigrams combining into the twenty-four solar terms, the Yellow Emperor created the calendar to determine the years. He revered Da Nao as his teacher, assigning three branches to each direction and establishing the sequence of first, middle, and last months—thus originating the methods of yin and yang.

Hearing this, the Yellow Emperor donned yellow robes, a yellow sash, and a yellow crown, fasting in the central palace. Then, phoenixes blotted out the sun as they arrived. The Emperor descended the steps, faced east, and bowed twice, touching his forehead to the ground, saying: "Heaven bestows great favor; how dare I not accept its mandate?" The phoenixes alighted in the eastern garden, perching upon the parasol trees and nesting in the towering pavilions. They ate only bamboo fruit and drank only sweet spring water. When they drank, they danced and sang, their voices like the sounds of reed pipes and flutes.

The Emperor then dispatched Ling Lun (as recorded in the *Han History: Treatise on Pitch Standards*) to the west of Daxia (Daxia lies ten thousand *li* west of Chang’an), to the valley of Ranyu beneath the northern slopes of Kunlun, in the Lazy Valley. There, he gathered bamboo from the Zhonglong, selecting stalks with even thickness and hollows, cutting two nodes seven *cun* and seven *fen* apart. When blown, they produced the sound of the Yellow Bell, the pitch standard for the eleventh month—the month when, at the winter solstice, yang begins to stir, marking the inception of all things. This reflected the era of perfect order, the vital breath of Heaven and Earth.

What is meant is that the Yellow Emperor could regulate the movements of the sun and moon and harmonize the qi of yin and yang, creating the twelve pitch standards—six yang (male) and six yin (female) tones. As the *Book of Jin* states: "The pitch pipes were one *chi* long, with six holes, embodying the sounds of the twelve months. Bamboo was chosen for its natural roundness and purity, while jade was selected for its firmness, steadfastness, warmth, and luster."

At that time, there was a descendant of Nüwa named Rongcheng, who excelled in understanding musical tones and first devised the pitch standards and calendar. The epoch began in the *dinghai* year (the *Basic Annals* records it as *xinmao*; now, according to the *Veritable Records of the Primordial Origin* and the chronological tables, the winter solstice fell on the star behind the Southern Dipper). The Emperor also consulted Tianlao and obtained the *Celestial Records of the Sun, Moon, and Stars* to mark the seasons.

There was a minister named Lishou, skilled in mathematics, who first developed methods of calculation and enumeration. Minister Ling Lun established systems of weights and measures—*quan* (weights, i.e., scales) and *liang* (measures, i.e., pecks). The Yellow Emperor captured Chiyou and thereby gained clarity in celestial patterns. As the *Guanzi* states: "Chiyou had retainers, and only afterward did [the Emperor]..." The Emperor also obtained a sacred tripod and thus began reckoning the solar cycles by counting rods. Thereupon, he aligned with the celestial and terrestrial principles, encompassing the sun, moon, and stars, and created the *Gaitian* instrument to observe the celestial phenomena. He calculated the divisions of the stars and used the twenty-eight lunar lodges to define the twelve celestial divisions: *Jiao* and *Kang* as the *Shouxing* division, *Fang* and *Xin* as the *Dahuo* division, *Wei* and *Ji* as the *Ximu* division, *Dou* and *Nü* as the *Xingji* division, *Xu* and *Wei* as the *Xuanyang* division, *Shi* and *Bi* as the *Kezi* division, *Kui* and *Lou* as the *Jianglou* division, *Mao* and *Bi* as the *Daliang* division, *Zi* and *Shen* as the *Shichen* division.

As recorded in the *Zuo Tradition* (Duke Zhao, first year): "In ancient times, Gaoxin had two sons. The elder was called Kuafu, and the younger was called Shichen. They lived in Guanglin but could not get along, daily waging war against each other. Later, they were separated—Kuafu was moved to Shangqiu to preside over the *chen* star, and the Shang people followed the *chen* star, hence the *Shang* star. Shichen was moved to Daxia to preside over the *Shen* star, and the Tang people served the Xia and Shang dynasties accordingly." From this, it is clear that the name *Shichen* only appeared during the time of Gaoxin. How, then, could it have existed earlier during the reign of the Yellow Emperor? Perhaps later generations altered the name of one of the celestial divisions to clarify ancient matters.

*Jing* and *Gui* formed the *Chunshou* division, *Xing* and *Zhang* the *Chunhuo* division, and *Yi* and *Zhen* the *Chunwei* division. He established the stars of the inner and outer heavens and composed books on divining the sun and moon. This marked the beginning of celestial observation, all derived from the *River Chart*.

He also appointed Xi and He to observe the sun, Chang Yi to observe the moon, and Gui Yuqu to observe the stars. The Emperor devised methods of divination and composed books on solar omens to discern fortune and misfortune.

The Yellow Emperor’s abundant virtue attracted perfected beings to wander by the Jade Pool, a manifestation of his supreme power. A auspicious beast appeared in his park—the *xuanleng* beast. As the *Central Candidate* of the *Book of Documents* states: "Its body resembled a deer, its tail a cow, its hooves a wolf, and it had a single horn. The tip of the horn bore flesh, signifying its harm to no living thing. Its voice matched the Yellow Bell, and its patterns were resplendent." The male was called *qi*, the female *lin*. They were born of fire and soared upon earth. In spring, their cries were called *guihe* ("returning grain"); in summer, *fuyou* ("nurturing the young"); in autumn and winter, *yangxin* ("nurturing trust").

The Emperor also encountered giant insects—cicadas and mole crickets as large as sheep, and some as large as oxen. There was a worm called *wan*, as large as a rainbow, corresponding to the reign of the virtue of earth. There was also a beast called *xi*, resembling a lion, which devoured tigers yet remained docile around humans, sometimes entering dwellings. People feared and resented it, so the Emperor memorialized Heaven and banished it to the northern wilderness.

Because of the auspicious signs of the *jing* clouds and the propitious *qing* clouds, he used clouds to name his officials. The offices were thus named after clouds, hence the *Jinyun* official. Some say: "The Emperor refined the golden elixir, and the *jinyun* auspice appeared, so he styled himself the *Jinyun* Clan. *Jin* refers to a cloud with more red than white." Thereupon, he established offices and assigned duties, naming them after clouds: spring officials were the *Qingyun* ("Azure Cloud") officials, summer officials the *Jinyun* ("Vermilion Cloud") officials, autumn officials the *Baiyun* ("White Cloud") officials, and winter officials the *Heiyun* ("Black Cloud") officials. The Emperor took the clouds as his teachers.

He appointed four historiographers—Ju Song, Cang Jie, Lishou, and Kong Jia—to oversee records and documents. As the *Rites of Zhou* states: "They managed household registers and population records." He also tasked Cang Jie with overseeing rituals. Kong Jia first created trays and basins to replace the crude cups and goblets, composing the *Pan Yu* ("Trays and Basins") chapter, which expounded the sincerity of trays and basins. The Emperor established the methods for headscarves and low tables, recording them in the classics.

The Yellow Emperor’s writings were profound and orderly, and the historians called them the *Fen* ("Great"). *Fen* means "great." Kong Anguo said: "They were lost in the Qin burning and cannot be recovered." There was a minister named Shi Yu who first created painting. A man from Jinan named Gong Yudai presented the *Yellow Emperor’s Bright Hall Diagram*, which featured a raised passageway with a tower accessed from the southwest—this was the origin of towers. The Emperor built it according to the diagram and named it the *He Gong* ("Harmonious Palace"), where he could observe the conduct of his officials. He then established the deliberations on the Bright Hall to observe the worthy.

At that time, an immortal elder emerged from the foot of Mount Qi, known as Qibo. He was skilled in explaining the properties and flavors of herbs and served as the great physician. The Emperor requested him to oversee medicines. The Emperor then refined the properties of the hundred herbs tasted by Shennong to treat illnesses, composing the *Internal and External Classics*. There was also Leigong, who expounded on the methods of roasting and broiling and determined the efficacy of medicines. Ministers Bian Que and Yu Fu established the *Mai Jing* ("Pulse Classic") to treat the ailments of the people. The Emperor discussed pulse methods with Bian Que and compiled the *Plain Book* in two parts—the *Upper* and *Lower Classics*. As Han-era physician Chunyu Yi of Linzi could predict the life and death of illnesses, he relied on the *Pulse Classic*. The Emperor questioned Qibo about pulse methods and composed the *Plain Questions*, along with the *Inner Classic* (now extant in two versions, each in nine scrolls). Later generations revised them. According to the preface of the *Plain Questions*, Qibo was its author.

The present scroll count appears largely deficient, with the *Eighty-One Difficulties* later supplemented and revised. It is also said that the Heaven-sent Plain Girl was tasked with treating human ailments, and upon the Emperor’s inquiry, the *Plain Questions* was composed. The Emperor questioned Shaoyu on acupuncture and moxibustion, thereby establishing the *Classic of Acupuncture* and the *Mingtang Charts*, marking the inception of acupuncture and medicinal therapies. When the Yellow Emperor governed the realm, he first adopted the central color as his title, initially residing in the state of Youxiong. He was known as the Youxiong Emperor, just as Zhuanxu was the Gaoyang Emperor, Diyu the Gaoxin Emperor, and Tang Yao the Taotang Emperor. He disdained warfare.

During the eighth generation of Shennong’s lineage, when Yugang’s rule began to decline, the feudal lords encroached upon one another. As the Yellow Emperor was titled after the central region, the four directions usurped their own designations, each adopting the color of their respective quarter. Historical records note their existence without specifying their names: the Green Emperor Da Hao, the Red Emperor Shennong, the White Emperor Shaohao, and the Black Emperor Zhuanxu. These were the descendants of the Four Emperors who presumptuously claimed imperial titles. The feudal lords collectively plotted against them, and the border cities were thrown into alarm.

The Emperor then ceased the construction of terraces and pavilions, reduced expenditures on extravagance, trained his troops, and fortified his camps. He inquired of the chiefs of Mount Shouyang in Hezhong Prefecture, who were unsettled in their dwellings, and ordered the mining of copper from Mount Shou to begin forging blades and crafting crossbows. Later, on Liubo Mountain in the Eastern Sea, he obtained a strange beast resembling an ox, with a dark-green body, no horns, and a single foot, capable of moving in and out of water. When it spewed water, winds arose; its eyes shone like the sun and moon, and its roar was like thunder. It was called the *kui* ox. The Emperor ordered it slain, and its hide was stretched over a drum, whose sound carried five hundred *li*. *The Genealogies* states: "The Yin shaman Xian first created the drum"—this is incorrect. The Emperor commanded his soldiers to blow horns in the manner of dragon roars; this marked the origin of drums and horns. He then ordered the creation of *cuju* games to train warriors in striking balls. *Records of the Western Capital* states: "The *cuju* field is the ball field." The Yellow Emperor declared: "When the sun is at its zenith, one must burn; when the blade is drawn, one must cut." Kuang Qujian heard this and said, "These are the words of the Yellow Emperor."

In the twenty-second year of his reign over the realm, Chiyou suddenly defied the Emperor’s commands. Among the feudal lords, he was the most violent, with eighty brothers, all possessing bestial bodies and human speech, copper heads and iron brows. They did not eat the five grains but devoured sand and swallowed stones. Chiyou first crafted armor and bells; the people of the time, not recognizing them, called them copper heads and iron brows. Li Taibai said: "The southerners, seeing the northerners’ wheat cakes and dried provisions, did not recognize them and called them sand-devouring and stone-swallowing." Disregarding the Emperor’s commands, Chiyou devised the Five Cruelties to harm the common people. On Mount Gelu, he smelted metal to forge cold-forged mirrors, armor, swords, and weapons such as halberds, great crossbows, and other arms, terrifying the realm and defying the Emperor’s authority. The Emperor sought to subdue him and summoned the feudal lords, yet after fifteen ten-day periods, he could not overcome the foe.

Reflecting on worthy sages to aid his rule and punish the unjust, the Emperor dreamed of a great wind sweeping away the world’s dust and grime, and again of a man wielding a thousand-jūn crossbow, herding tens of thousands of sheep. Awakening, he pondered: "The wind is the herald of governance; the grime, the earth’s impurities to be cleansed—surely there must be one surnamed Feng, named Hou. The thousand-jūn crossbow requires strength to shoot far; herding tens of thousands of sheep marks a skilled shepherd—could there not be one surnamed Li, named Mu?" From these two dreams and earlier visions of dragon spirits, the Emperor composed a book on dream interpretation and commanded his ministers to seek such men. They found Feng Hou by the sea’s edge and Li Mu in the great marsh. Feng Hou was first appointed to govern the people as Attendant-in-Ordinary, later rising to Chancellor, while Li Mu was made General—thus began the offices of Chancellor and General. With Da Hong as his chief aide, the Emperor aligned with the patterns of Heaven and Earth, the principles of light and darkness, and the discourse on life and death, forming his council of strategists.

The Emperor consulted Zhang Ruo on military strategy, who replied, "None surpasses Li Mu." Skilled in astronomical reckoning, Li Mu authored thirteen scrolls on the art of war, which proved invaluable. The Emperor then drilled his troops in martial arts to suppress the rebellious. He established the Three Dukes’ offices, mirroring the Three Terraces of the heavens: Feng Hou corresponded to the Upper Terrace, Tian Lao to the Middle, and the Five Sages to the Lower. (The *Six Strategies* of Taigong states: "Feng Hou, Li Mu, and the Five Sages form the Seven Dukes." The Five Sages were five individuals.) The Yellow Emperor then selected four men who aligned with his vision, appointing them to govern the four quarters.

At that time, a precious tripod was unearthed, and its arrival was hailed as "divine calculation." He also enlisted Feng Hu as a general, crafting the Five-Tusk Banner and beacons for warfare, and composed five scrolls on military strategy. Appointing Shen Huang as another general, the Emperor entrusted his son by Lady Fei Xiu—who favored nets and bows—to the role of Grand Marshal and Frontline Commander. Zhang Ruo and Li Mu served as Left and Right Commanders of the marching army, while Rong Guang was named Grand Marshal, overseeing the Six Armies and the Nine Laws of the realm (Rong Guang is also called Chang Guang). True Left and Right Grand Inspectors were appointed to oversee the myriad states. Minister Long Yu, brave and righteous, was also made a general.

When the Emperor marched forth, his army encamped for defense. He conspired with Yu Gang to strike Chiyou. The Emperor’s forces were adorned with jade, and he donned a yellow crown, riding an elephant-drawn chariot drawn by six dragons, with Tai Yi and Tai Yi as his charioteers. The Banners of Intertwined Dragons led the way, the Five-Tusk Banner guiding their course, fixing their direction. As the Emperor advanced, five-colored clouds like golden branches and jade leaves hovered above him, resembling blossoming flowers. Thus, he fashioned the flower canopy (the precursor to today’s ceremonial umbrellas).

The Yellow Emperor clashed with Chiyou on the fields of Zhuolu (a city in the south of Shanggu Commandery). Unable to prevail, Chiyou conjured a hundred-mile fog that enveloped the land for three days. The Emperor’s troops were disoriented, so Feng Hou, modeling the Dipper’s mechanism, crafted the south-pointing chariot to distinguish the four directions. (Cui Bao’s *Records of Past and Present* states: "The Duke of Zhou created the south-pointing chariot." However, it existed earlier, and the Duke of Zhou merely restored it.) The Emperor fought again but could not triumph. Retreating to the slopes of Mount Tai, he fell into a melancholic slumber.

He dreamed of the Queen Mother of the West, who dispatched a Daoist clad in a black fox-fur robe to present him with a talisman, saying: "Tai Yi leads, Tian Yi follows—he who obtains this shall prevail in battle." Awakening, he pondered its meaning but did not fully grasp it. Summoning Feng Hou, he recounted the dream. Feng Hou declared, "This is a celestial omen; victory is assured. Offer prayers at the sacred altar." The Emperor complied, prostrating himself twice in reverence. Indeed, he received a talisman, three inches wide and a foot long, its azure surface inscribed with blood-script characters. He wore it at his waist, gazing heavenward and sighing over his past failures. Through his earnest devotion, he moved Heaven, and a dense fog descended for three days and nights. Then, a woman with a human head and raven’s body appeared. The Emperor bowed deeply in obeisance. The woman said, "I am the Dark Lady. Ask what you will."

The Emperor replied, "Chiyou oppresses the people and ravages all things. I wish to defeat him decisively." The Dark Lady taught him the Three Palaces’ secret strategies, the Five Notes’ tactical subtleties, and the arts of yin and yang (these are the Dark Lady’s military techniques, later employed by Li Jing as the Nine Heavens’ Dark Lady method). She bestowed upon him the *Yin Talisman Scripture* of three hundred words, which the Emperor studied for ten days before subduing Chiyou. She also granted him the *Five True Writs of the Numinous Treasure* and the *Military Pledge Rites*. Wearing these, he vanquished Chiyou.

The Emperor then commanded Feng Hou to expound upon the *River Chart*, creating the "One Hundred and Eight Configurations," known as the *Art of the Hidden Stem* (dun jia). (During the Duke of Zhou’s time, it was simplified to seventy-two configurations. Zhang Liang of Han, alongside Xiang Yu, remarked: "The Four Elders... eighteen configurations." The *Divine Dragon-Borne Chart* states: "Concealing the stem (jia) gives rise to the name *dun jia*." One configuration is recorded in the *Jie Tie*.) This system predicted the outcomes of battles between host and guest. The Yellow Emperor also composed the *Sixteen Divine Calendars*, detailing methods such as Tai Yi and the Six Ren. He further elucidated the Dao of the Six Jia and yin-yang, creating the *Diagrams of Victory and Defeat’s Hidden Mechanism*, the *Essentials of Military Strategy*, and the *Three Scrolls of the Yellow Emperor’s Art of War* (as Song Wu’s tradition holds, these were revealed by a divine being). The *River Chart’s Military Decisions* records that the Yellow Emperor received a military talisman from the Queen Mother of the West, along with the *Complete Guide to the Commander’s Yearly Fate*, the *Tai Yi Military Calendar*, the *Twelve Scrolls of the Yellow Emperor’s New Military Applications*, the *Six Scrolls of the Yellow Emperor’s Xia Clan’s Military Omens* (later revised during the Xia dynasty), the *Two Scrolls of the Yellow Emperor’s Eighteen Battle Arrays* (later revised by Zhuge Liang into the Eight Arrays), the *Three Scrolls of the Yellow Emperor’s Questions to the Dark Lady*, the *Twenty Scrolls of Feng Hou’s Solitary Void Decisions*, the *Fourteen Scrolls of Wuchengzi’s Dark Military Disaster Omens*, and the *Three Scrolls of Gui Yuqu’s Art of War*, along with one scroll of diagrams (alternatively titled *Gui Guzi’s Military Strategies*).

All the aforementioned texts originate from the Yellow Emperor, though later generations expanded and revised them.

Thereupon, the Yellow Emperor adopted the strategies of the Five Tones to deliberate on matters of attack and warfare. He again led the feudal lords to campaign twice against Chiyou in Jizhou. Chiyou commanded *chimei* and *wangliang* spirits, summoning the Wind Earl and Rain Master to bring forth a great gale from the heavens, while ordering the Responding Dragon to store water for an assault on the Yellow Emperor. The Yellow Emperor entreated the Wind Earl, Rain Master, and all the female demons of the world to halt the rain. In the eastern wilderness, at the northern corner of the mountains, he gathered the troops of the Li, Tu, and Qiang, driving the Responding Dragon to the southern pole. There, he slew Chiyou and his father, preventing their return, which caused drought below—wherever they dwelled, no rain fell.

Chiyou was defeated at Guquan and executed in central Jizhou, a place henceforth named the Wilds of Severed Reins, located in Yanchuan. After capturing and killing Chiyou, the Yellow Emperor relocated his people: the virtuous to the village of Zoutu, while the wicked were bound in wooden restraints. The Emperor ordered Chiyou’s likeness painted on banners to suppress evil spirits, naming them the *Chiyou Banners*. Chiyou was slain on the eastern hill of Mount Li in the northern corner of the eastern wilderness, and his restraints were cast into the great wilderness atop Mount Song. Later, these restraints transformed into a forest of maple trees. As the *Classic of Mountains and Seas* states: "On Mount Rongtian grows a forest of maples, formed from Chiyou’s shackles."

Chiyou’s body was dismembered, head and torso sundered. Moved by pity, the Yellow Emperor commanded that his head be buried in a mound at Shouzhang County, located in Zouzhou. The mound rose a *chi* in height. The locals regularly offered sacrifices in the tenth month, whereupon a crimson vapor like silk would appear—called the *Chiyou Banner*. His shoulder and spine were interred in a mound at Shanyang County, located in Chuzhou. The shoulder and spine refer to his viscera.

The Yellow Emperor recovered Chiyou’s military texts: one scroll of the *Secret Arts of Marching* and two scrolls of *Chiyou’s Art of War*.

The Yellow Emperor established his capital at Zhuolu, in Shanggu Commandery. Zhuolu is a place name; *Dulu* is also called *Zhuolu*, though records err in transmission. The Yellow Emperor later contended with Yu Gang for dominion over the world. Yu Gang, relying on his descent from the Divine Farmer, resisted him. The Yellow Emperor first employed banners of *peng*, *ya*, *ying*, and *zhe* birds—as the *Six Codes* states: "Today’s *ma’e* banners"—while using bears, brown bears, and tigers as vanguard. They battled on the plains of Banquan, a place name in Shanggu Commandery (now Mazhou), and after three engagements, he prevailed. He then drove northward against the Xunzhai Rong—who were the Xiongnu. Any feudal lord who refused allegiance, the Emperor led his forces to subdue.

Here follows the translation:

---

In fifty-one engagements, the world was largely pacified. For his merit in suppressing rebellions, the Emperor commanded Qi Bo to compose martial music and drumming, known as the *Xiao Rao* songs, to serve as military alarms. The melodies *Tong Gu Qu*, *Ling Kui Hou*, *Peng Ya Zheng*, *Shi Zhui Ya*, *Zhuang Shi Nu*, and *Xuan Zhu Lu*—these were to exalt martial virtue and were called *Kai Ge* (triumphal songs). As the *Six Codes* states: "Zhang Qian of the Han obtained these from the Western Regions—eight pieces in all, remnants of military music known as *xiao jia*." The *jin nao* resembled a bell but had no clapper; it was held by a handle and used to halt the drums.

Thereupon, all feudal lords revered Xuanyuan as Son of Heaven. The Emperor ascended the throne in the *jiyou* year, succeeding the lineage of the Divine Farmer. As fire generates earth, the Emperor ruled by virtue of earth and was styled the Yellow Emperor. He took his place at the center, governing the four quarters. After breaking through mountains to open roads, he never rested in one place. He ordered Feng Hou to carry the tally books and Bo Chang to bear the sword. Each day, they set out from the Flowing Sands and returned by evening to the Shady Shores, covering ten thousand *li* in a single breath before circling back to the slopes of Zhuolu. The Emperor then summoned the hundred spirits to court and questioned Feng Hou, saying: "I wish to know where the rivers discharge." Feng Hou replied: "There are five rivers in all, each originating from the wilds of Kunlun. The Yellow River issues from the southeastern foothills of Kunlun—this is one of them." (The other four rivers are described in *Dongfang Shuo’s Record of the Ten Continents*.)

The Emperor ordered Jian Hai to pace the distance from the eastern to the western extremities, measuring five *yi*, ten *xuan*, nine thousand eight hundred and eight *bu* (one account says one *yi*, thirty-three thousand *bu*). From south to north, he measured two *yi*, three thousand one hundred and three hundred *bu* (one account says two *yi*, twenty thousand *bu*). From the easternmost Tai Huan to the westernmost He Guo, the east-west span was twenty-eight thousand *li*; from south to north, twenty-six thousand *li* (a *xuan* being ten thousand *li*). In the time of the Divine Farmer, the world spanned nine thousand ten thousand *li* east to west and eight thousand ten thousand *li* south to north, extending beyond the Four Seas. Wei Zhao’s commentary on the *Book of Han* dismissed such vast distances beyond the seas as implausible. Your servant, Yang, records in the *Daoist Canon* that the Divine Farmer rode a dragon to traverse distant realms, while the Yellow Emperor rode a horse to govern the lands within the Four Seas. The *Huainanzi* states: "From the northern to the southern pole is two *yi*, thirty-three thousand five hundred and seventy *li*." The three Huainan scholars studied the Dao, and this claim of extreme distance likewise echoes the *Daoist Canon*.

The Yellow Emperor first delineated territories and divided the realm into provinces. He commanded the great ministers of the hundred commanderies to bestow teachings of virtue, first arranging *gui* jades upon orchid and cattail mats. They ground various treasures into powder, mixed them with the glue of *chenyu* elm, and used the paste to demarcate lands, distinguishing ranks of nobility and the differences between Hua and Rong. (This is recorded in the *Changes* and *Records of Ritual*.) The Emperor traversed the world, and those who governed a hundred-*li* domain numbered ten thousand—these were the present-day counties and towns. Thus it is said: "First among the myriad things, the ten thousand states all found peace."

There was Qingniao Zi, who understood the principles of geomancy, and the Emperor consulted him to establish the classics. The Emperor also questioned Di Lao about the advantages and dangers of the five directions. At that time, a propitious herb named *quyi* grew in the imperial courtyard; when flatterers entered, it would point at them, so that none dared approach. A foreign land presented a divine beast called *Bing Lu*, resembling a deer with a single horn. When brought to court, it would gore any minister who was not upright.

Rongcheng Zi, a descendant of Nüwa who had attained the Dao, understood the laws of sound. He first created the calendar for the Yellow Emperor, beginning the cycle in the *dinghai* year. By this time, he had crafted the *sheng* pipe to imitate the phoenix’s cry. Su Nü arrived from Guangdu and taught the Emperor to play the fifty-string *se* zither. (The *Right Historian’s Investigations* notes: "This refers to the *qin*, not the *se*.") The Yellow Emperor reduced it to twenty-five strings, the *se* being seven *chi* and two *cun* in length. Fu Xi had played the *qin*, and Nüwa had harmonized with it. The Yellow Emperor’s *qin* was named *Hao Zhong*, and he composed the *Qing Jiao* melody.

The Emperor first established the seven emotions and practiced the ten virtues: the ruler benevolent, the minister loyal; the father kind, the son filial; the elder brother good, the younger brother respectful; the husband righteous, the wife obedient; the elder compassionate, the younger compliant—these were the ten virtues, marking the beginning of the Emperor’s creation of rites and music.

In the Eastern Sea stood Mount Du Suo (or Mount Du Shuo, possibly an error), so named because one crossed it by means of bamboo cables. On the mountain dwelt the deities Shen Tu and Yu Lü, who could repel malevolent spirits. The Emperor instituted the rite of exorcism in their likeness. He appointed Rongcheng Zi as his music master and composed the *Cloud Gate* and *Great Display*, as well as the *Xian Chi* music. He then performed music in the wilds of Dongting, at the Northern Gate. When it was played, yin and yang harmonized, the sun and moon shone brightly, and customs were pacified. (In the second year of the *Zhide* era of the Tang, a stone chime was unearthed beside Dongting; it bore ancient seal script and was identified as a musical instrument from the time of the Yellow Emperor. In the second year of the *Yongfeng* era, Magistrate Kang Tongzhong of Baling sent the herbalist Shi Jide, who had discovered an ancient chime while gathering herbs in Dongting Village. The chime bore seal script, and Prefect Li E of Yuezhou presented it to the court. This confirms the *Zhuangzi*’s account of the Yellow Emperor performing music at Dongting, which was no idle claim.)

When the Yellow Emperor was to convene with the spirits on a western mountain, he rode a chariot drawn by six dragons, with the *Bi Fang* bird yoked alongside. Chiyou led the procession (Chiyou being a banner), the Wind Earl swept the path, the Rain Master sprinkled the road, and phoenixes soared overhead. Upon reaching the mountain, he gathered the ghosts and gods. The Emperor played the *Hao Zhong* *qin* and performed the *Qing Jiao* melody. (Shi Kuang, skilled in the *qin*, was once pressed by Duke Ping of Jin to play the *Jiao* melody. Reluctantly, he played once, and clouds arose from the northwest; he played again, and a great wind rose, followed by heavy rain. The duke was terrified and fell ill.) The Emperor ascended the sacred peak of Kunlun and offered a grand sacrifice to instruct later generations—this was the beginning of the *feng* and *shan* rites.

At that time, there was a divine being, the Queen Mother of the West, the essence of *Taiyin* and daughter of the Heavenly Emperor. She had the body of a human and the head of a tiger (the *Classic of Mountains and Seas* says "tiger-faced"; another account says "tiger-colored"), a leopard’s tail, disheveled hair, and a *sheng* crown upon her hoary head. She was skilled in whistling.

Dwelling in stone cities and golden terraces, she made her abode in caves, seated upon the Mount of Lesser Breadth. Three azure crows ever brought her sustenance.

This divine being, the Queen Mother of the West, admiring the virtue of the Yellow Emperor, rode a white deer to present him with a white jade ring. Another divine being arrived from the south, also riding a white deer, and offered black silk—this was a sign that the Emperor’s virtue had reached even the earth’s tithes.

The Yellow Emperor practiced music to dance with the host of spirits, and was moved by thirty-two black cranes that soared and danced at his side. On the western mountains, he tasted a fruit resembling the plum in flavor and the crabapple in form, its blossoms crimson and bearing no pit; thus, it was named the *shatang*. Those who ate it could cross waters without drowning.

The Emperor erected a terrace in the land of Woren, west of the Queen Mother’s mountain, naming it the Terrace of Xuanyuan. He then rested upon the Mound of Mingbo, in the wilds of Kunlun. The Emperor journeyed to the land of Huaxu, where Fuxi was born—a land of wind, and the home of Fuxi’s mother. He later traveled to the land of Tiandu and dwelt there, which was later called the land of Xuanyuan (and in later times, Tianzhu, twelve thousand *li* from Chang’an). The astrologer’s records place it beyond the seas—this is fanciful.

He then journeyed west to the Barren Mountain and the Women’s Kingdom, and again roamed the Kunlun Palace by the Red Waters. Gazing north and south, he returned but left behind his Dark Pearl. He sent the keen-eyed Li Lou to seek it, but he failed; then he sent Wang Xiang, who retrieved it. Later, the daughter of the Meng clan, named Qixiang, stole the Dark Pearl—an emblem of the Dao—and cast it into the sea, becoming a water spirit. The *Shu Tao Hang* states: "In Chengdu Prefecture, there is a shrine to Qixiang." Tang Ying, in his *Ancient History*, notes: "The daughter of the Meng clan stole the Yellow Emperor’s Dark Pearl, drowned in the river, and transformed into this spirit. She corresponds to the Zhen constellation above and extends to the Ox mansion." Guo Pu’s *Rhapsody on the Yangtze* says: "Qixiang obtained the pearl and dwelt in Zhong." The present shrine on the Yangtze’s shoals is that very place.

The Emperor, on his royal progress, traveled east to the sea and ascended Mount Huan. By the seashore, he encountered the divine beast Baize, which could speak and comprehend the essence of all things. He inquired of it concerning the affairs of ghosts and spirits throughout the world—how from ancient times, the refined *qi* became beings, and wandering souls wrought transformations, numbering eleven thousand five hundred and twenty kinds. Baize recounted them all, and the Emperor commanded that they be depicted in illustrations and shown to the world. He then composed an exorcism text to invoke against evil.

As the Emperor journeyed, his primary consort, Leizu, died upon the road. He sacrificed to her and made her the ancestral spirit. He ordered his secondary consort, Mumo, to oversee her rites along the way and perform seasonal sacrifices, thus appointing Mumo as the Fangxiang—facing her direction—to guard the funeral, also called the Fang Sang. Today, when people set out on a journey, they first offer wine and food to the road, calling it the "ancestral farewell." *Zu* means "to send off." Yan Shigu’s commentary on the *Book of Han* states: "The Yellow Emperor’s son became the road spirit"—this is erroneous. Cui Hao’s *Monthly Ordinances* also claims the Yellow Emperor’s son, which is likewise baseless. None of these accounts are reliable; *zu* here refers to Leizu.

When the world was fully pacified under the Yellow Emperor and auspicious omens had converged, he ascended to perform the *feng* rite upon Mount Tai and the *shan* rite upon Mount Tingting (a lesser peak at the foot of Tai). He also performed the *shan* upon Mount Jiji, inscribed his achievements upon the lofty peaks, and instituted seasonal sacrifices to the Flame Emperor. He observed the heavens, examined the earth, constructed palaces, designed garments, calibrated the *qi* and musical pitches, and established the hundred crafts.

Through accumulated merit and virtue, Heaven bestowed upon him the imperial carriage and axe, the canopy and feathered banners, and the soldiers of the celestial spirits. The Yellow Emperor composed the *Inscription of the Xuanyu*, and when his affairs were complete, he established the pitch-pipes to determine surnames—Confucius and Jing Fang both practiced this, recording the bells and refining the sounds.

The Emperor had four consorts: Leizu, Mumo, Feixiu, and Nüjie. They bore him twenty-five sons, of whom twelve (or thirteen, by some accounts) received surnames: Ji, You, Qi, Ji, Teng, Zhen, Ren, Gou, Xi, Gu, Xuan, and Yi. (The *Records of the Grand Historian* states sixty-one surnames, differing only in the Li surname.) The claim that the Yellow Emperor’s surname was Gongsun spans eighteen generations over fifteen hundred years, while the twelve surnames and thirteen generations span one thousand and seventy-two years. Some histories record twelve surnames, omitting De and Zhuan to signify their obscurity. Ji, Qi, Teng, Ren, Xi, and Gu were those of virtue and renown.

The assertion that the Yellow Emperor’s surname was Gongsun, though handed down in ancient histories, is ultimately untenable. The Yellow Emperor was born a bear and grew up by the Ji River; thus, he should have taken Ji as his surname. When King Wu of Zhou called himself the nineteenth-generation descendant of the Yellow Emperor, a scion of the Ji surname, this confirms the Yellow Emperor’s Ji surname—it is not so. Moreover, the Zhou truly established the five ranks of nobility—duke, marquis, earl, viscount, and baron—and the descendants of nobles often took "Gongsun" as their surname, meaning "the grandson of a duke." Thus, those who combined "Gong" and "Zi" into a surname, along with eighty-five other clans, were not contemporaries of the Yellow Emperor.

The Yellow Emperor had nine sons, each enfeoffed with a state (as Pan Anren’s poem attests, though its origins are unknown). His primary consort, Leizu, bore two sons, Xuanxiao and Changyi, neither of whom ascended the throne. Xuanxiao attained the Dao and became the water spirit of the north. Changyi dwelt by the Weak Waters, while Shaohao, the Yellow Emperor’s youngest son—born of the consort Nüjie—was styled the Lord of Metal and Heaven and later succeeded to the throne.

The Yellow Emperor’s daughter drowned in the Eastern Sea and transformed into a bird named Jingwei, which ever carries twigs and stones from the western mountains to fill the Eastern Sea.

Changyi married the daughter of the Shu Mountain clan and begot Zhuanxu, who ascended the throne as the Lord of High Brightness, the Yellow Emperor’s rightful grandson.

Huang Gong Tuoba, the younger son of Changyi, was enfeoffed in the northern lands. As the Yellow Emperor’s virtue was of earth, he transformed customs, taking "earth" as *tuo* and "lord" as *ba*, thus adopting the surname Tuoba.

Yuqiang, a descendant of the Yellow Emperor who did not ascend the throne, also attained the Dao and dwelt in the north as a water spirit.

Minor Lord of Brightness had seven sons. In the time of Zhuanxu, one of them was deemed virtuous in conduct and was granted the surname Man; the rest remain unrecorded.

Once the world was ordered and all things and implements were in place, the Yellow Emperor sought the hidden and inquired of the Dao, aspiring to attain longevity and enduring vision—what is called first governing the age and then ascending as an immortal. At that time, there was a potter named Yuzi who encountered a divine person who taught him the method of fire. From it arose five-colored smoke, which he could follow up and down. Having mastered the Dao, he departed as an immortal, journeying to the Flowing Sands to feed on flying fish. He briefly died for two hundred years, then revived and composed the *Sandbank Hymn*, which reads:

*Green leaves blaze, a thousand years unfurled,*
*Ten thousand ages briefly die to feed on flying fish.*

There was also the son of Wu Guang, eight feet and seven inches tall, a divine immortal who, by the Xia era, had no fear of cold. He cultivated his nature, played the zither, and by virtue of the Dao enjoyed eternal life. There was Chi Jiang Ziyu, who ate no grains but fed on a hundred herbs to prolong his years. In the time of Yao, he served as a carpenter, able to rise and descend with the wind—already two thousand years had passed. There was Master Rong Cheng, skilled in the arts of supplementation and guidance, who preserved life and nurtured qi. The spirit of grain did not die, and he could restore white hair to black and fallen teeth to growth. The Yellow Emperor admired his Dao and constructed the Five Cities and Twelve Towers to await divine persons.

He then sought the Dao, traveling to Mount Hua and Mount Shou, and eastward to Mount Tai. There he encountered strange beings and communed with divine immortals. He sought divine persons on Penglai and, upon his return, received the myriad spirits at Bright Court, Zhongshan, Ganquan, Hanmen, and Gukou—all north of Chang’an in Ganquan and Yunyang.

The Yellow Emperor then performed the round-mound sacrifice to Heaven, intending to seek the supreme Dao. He took the Nine Primal Masters as his teachers and, in the first year of the Earthly Sovereign’s reign, on the first *yin* day of the first month, fasted at Mount Shou in Puyi County, Hedong. He continued his travels to seek the true Dao, appointing Fang Ming as his charioteer, Chang Yu as his outrider, and Zhang Ruo and Miao Liao as his guides. (Miao is pronounced *xi*; Liao is pronounced *shu*. Another version writes *peng* for Miao, meaning "companion," and *kun* for Liao, meaning "harmonious.") They arrived at the wilds of Xiangcheng, where the Seven Sages all lost their way. They encountered a boy herding horses, and the Yellow Emperor asked him, "How should one govern the world?" The boy replied, "Governing the world is no different from herding horses—simply remove what harms them." The Yellow Emperor hailed him as Heaven’s Master and withdrew.

When he reached Yuanyuan, the land had an undying tree. Those who ate its fruit and leaves never died. There was a cinnabar spring whose waters granted longevity. A giant serpent harmed the people, but the Yellow Emperor repelled it with realgar. The serpent lingered for a time before retreating. (The *Record of Foreign Lands* states it lingered for nine years.) The Emperor commanded his three sons to practice consuming it, and all lived for three hundred years.

By the time he reached Hongdi, ascending Mount Juci in Yangdi, he met the Great Courtyard Lord of Mian County (a divine being of Chen) and also encountered the Yellow Canopy Youth, from whom he received the *Divine Mushroom Charts* in seventy-two scrolls. Arriving at Mount Dai, he met Huang Zizhong and received the *Nine Eggplant Master’s Formula*. (Another version states he met the Central Yellow Perfected One on Mount Kongtong. Another says the formula originated on Mount Kongtong in Yuanzhou. Ying Shao claims it was in Longyou, which is incorrect.)

He ascended Mount Kongtong and met Guang Chengzi, inquiring about the supreme Dao. (Zhuangzi writes it as Mount Kongtong; Sima Biao’s commentary says Kongtong is the mountain beneath the Dipper. Another version places it thirty *li* east of Yucheng in Liangguo. Yet another says there are three Kongtong Mountains in the world, and the one in Ruyin is where the Yellow Emperor sought the Dao. Another states the Kongtong in Longyou is the true site where the Yellow Emperor sought the Dao; today, the mountain has a Hall of Seeking the Dao, and at its foot stands the Xuanyuan Temple.) It is noted that the Yellow Emperor’s meeting with Guang Chengzi to inquire about the Dao did not occur in only one place; later, all such sites were named Kongtong, and these records are preserved together. Guang Chengzi did not answer. The Emperor withdrew, relinquished the world, built a solitary chamber, spread white cogon grass, and waited three months before returning. He asked again about the Dao of cultivating the body, and Guang Chengzi then bestowed upon him the *Scripture of Spontaneity* in one scroll.

The Yellow Emperor set aside the dignity of emperor and king, adopting the pattern of the boar and piglet. He ascended Mount Ji and Mount Wangwu, opened the stone coffer, and uncovered the jade tablets, obtaining the *Commentary on the Nine Cauldrons’ Divine Elixir*. Traveling south to the Yangtze, he climbed Mount Xiongxiang (Mount Xiong is in Zhaoling, Changsha; Mount Xiang is in Yiyang, Changsha), then went to Mount Tiantai, where he received the *Divine Elixir of Golden Liquor*. Eastward to Mount Qingqiu, he met the Master of the Purple Palace and received the *Inner Writ of the Three Sovereigns*—a large-character text. (The *Baopuzi* states it comprises twenty scrolls, used to summon the myriad spirits.) He gathered the five sacred mushrooms from the dark ravine, ascended Mount Yuanlong, and rested beneath the *Jianmu* tree, where the hundred spirits ascend and descend. He plucked the *ruogan* mushroom (another version says flower) and drank the waters of the cinnabar spring.

Southward to Mount Qingcheng, he paid respects to the Central Yellow Elder. He then ascended Mount Yuntai and met Master Yu, from whom he received the *Dragon Harness Scripture*. He inquired of the Central Yellow Elder about the Dao of the True One. The Elder said, "You already rule the world; do you still seek long life and immortality? Is this not greed?" Despite repeated objections, the Elder eventually transmitted the Dao, and the Emperor bowed in gratitude.

Afterward, he passed by Mount Lu and, in order, offered sacrifices to the envoys of the Qingcheng Elder.

The emissary of Mount Lu held a rank equivalent to that of Imperial Censor and oversaw the Dao of all immortal officials, serving as the inspector of the Five Peaks. Furthermore, the Lord of Gangshan was enfeoffed as the Controller of Destinies of the Nine Heavens, who presided over the register of life and death. The Yellow Emperor, observing that each of the Four Peaks had auxiliary mountains while the Southern Peak stood solitary without support, presented a memorial to the Supreme Dao Lord of the Three Heavens, designating Mount Huo as the Heir Apparent and Mount Qian as the deputy of Mount Heng to complete the system. He then appointed ministers to assist in governance.

The Emperor personally ascended the mountains and sketched their forms to create the *True Forms of the Five Peaks*. He traveled to refine cinnabar in the Hall of Jinyun, where he compounded elixirs upon the earth. At that time, clouds neither red nor purple appeared, and thus the place was named Jinyun, and the mountain came to be called Mount Jinyun. The Emperor concealed the *Illustrated Charts of Military Victory and Defeat* and the *Writings of the Six Jia and Yin-Yang* within Mount Miao. He harmonized auspicious omens at Mount Fu, where he attained the Dao of immortality.

He served the Primordial Sovereign of the Great One and received essential records on cultivating the Dao and nurturing life from the Mysterious Maiden, while the Plain Maiden transmitted the method of "returning essence to replenish the brain." The Mysterious Maiden bestowed upon the Emperor the *Divine Formula of Compliance*, which he concealed within Mount Kongtong. The Emperor refined his astronomical calculations under Shanji and Limu, recorded the principles of bodily application with Qibo and Leigong, and studied ancient prognostications with Master Feng Hou.

Having received the Mysterious Maiden’s transmission of the *Classic of the Hidden Talisman*, the Emperor was able to inwardly align with celestial mechanisms and outwardly harmonize with human affairs. His governance extended south to Jiaozhi, north to Youling, west to the Flowing Sands, and east to the Coiled Tree. The Emperor declared his intent to relinquish the world, saying, "I have heard of letting the world be, not of governing it. I have wearied the world for too long and shall now rest my chariot in the Dark Garden to return to my true nature."

After completing the Feng and Shan sacrifices, the Emperor mined copper from Mount Shou and cast the Nine Tripods beneath Mount Jing, symbolizing the Great One. The tripods, placed in the prefecture, embodied divine substance and refined essence. He lived for three hundred and sixty years before ascending as an immortal to Mount Jiuyi. Three thousand six hundred years later, Emperor Yao governed the world. When the great floods raged and the people suffered, Yu took pity and was miraculously born on Mount Shiniu. It is said that a woman of the Youdi tribe, while drawing water at dusk, found a stone like a pearl, cherished it, and swallowed it, becoming pregnant. After fourteen months, she gave birth to a son. When he grew, he understood the sources of springs, and thus he was named Yu; later generations called him the Divine Yu. The site is now known as Shiniu in Shiquan Prefecture.

The golden tablets inscribed with jade-like characters were the Yellow Emperor’s bequeathed admonitions. He also inscribed one copy of the *Five Sacred Talismans of the Numinous Treasure* on a golden tablet and concealed it within Mount Wanwei. The Emperor often cast vessels of gold, each inscribed with ancient characters to record the years and months. When he performed sacrifices, fragrant winds would arrive, spirits would gather, and his resolve to transcend the mortal realm was fulfilled.

He left his cap, sword, and the black jade pendant at the precipitous summit of Mount Kunlun by Dinghu Lake, establishing a hall below—this was the Terrace of Xuanyuan on Mount Kunlun. At that time, Ma Shihuang, skilled in veterinary medicine, possessed the wondrous thought of divine penetration. A dragon descended into his courtyard, prostrated itself, and opened its mouth. Shihuang examined it and said, "This dragon is ill and seeks my healing." He then threaded a needle through the dragon’s mouth, upper and lower, and administered a decoction of licorice boiled in cow’s milk. The dragon’s illness was cured, and Shihuang ascended as an immortal upon it.

Upon hearing this, the Yellow Emperor chose an auspicious day to divine the date of his return home and ascension. He obtained the cyclical sign *wuwu*. Indeed, a dragon arrived, its whiskers hanging down to welcome him. The Emperor mounted the dragon, accompanied by his friend Wuweizi and seventy-two officials and attendants. Those minor officials who could not ascend clung to the dragon’s whiskers and the Emperor’s bow, weeping and wailing. The bow was thereafter called *Wuhao*, and the site of the tripod-casting became known as Dinghu.

Later, his minister Zuo Zhe carved a wooden likeness of the Yellow Emperor and led the feudal lords in paying homage. The officials, overwhelmed with longing, either took his desk and staff to establish temples for worship or retrieved his clothing and cap to guard his true tomb. Thus, there is a tomb on Mount Qiao, and wherever the Yellow Emperor once traveled, shrines were erected. Five hundred years later, the tomb on Mount Qiao collapsed, leaving only the sword and a red crow, which also vanished one day.

The Yellow Emperor ruled for one hundred and twenty years in total, reigning for one hundred and five years. After ascending as an immortal, he rose to become the Sovereign of the Great One, and his spirit became the constellation Xuanyuan in the Southern Palace. The form of the Yellow Dragon was later honored, and he was ranked among the Five Thearchs of the Center, paired with Heaven. As the Yellow Emperor embodied the virtue of Earth, he occupied the central position, governing the four directions. The Star of Saturn was paired with him as his son, named the Pivot Spirit, serving as his assistant in sacrificial offerings.

The Emperor’s son, Shaohao, named Zhi and styled Qingyang, was titled the Metallic Celestial Lord. He occupied the imperial throne for eighty-one years (the *Annals of Emperors and Kings* records eighty-four years; Liu Shu’s *Outer Records* omits Shaohao). His capital was at Qufu, now Yanzhou, and his descendants succeeded one another for four hundred years.

The Yellow Emperor’s grandson Zhuanxu, titled the High Lord of Yang, was born to the Lady of Mount Shu. Endowed with sagely virtue, he reigned for seventy-eight years (the *Annals* records eighty-four years; the *Outer Records* concurs). He lived to ninety-eight and established his capital at Shangqiu and Puyang, now Pu Prefecture. From Zhuanxu onward, rulers took the names of their domains of origin.

Emperor Ku, the High Lord of Xin, was the Yellow Emperor’s great-grandson (the Yellow Emperor’s son, Xuanyao, begot Jiaoji, who begot Ku). Emperor Ku was divinely inspired from birth and declared his own name. He reigned for seventy years (the *Outer Records* records seventy-five years) and established his capital at Yanshi, now Bo Prefecture in Henan. He lived to one hundred and five years (the *Outer Records* records one hundred years).

Emperor Yao of the Taotang clan, the Yellow Emperor’s great-great-grandson and son of Emperor Ku, bore the surname Yiqi and the style Fangxun.

He rose to prominence in Dingtao, where he enfeoffed the Lord of Tang as Emperor. (Dingtao is also called Dingzhou or Taoxian; his capital was at Pingyang, now Jizhou.) He reigned for seventy years (according to the *Book of Documents*, this should be seventy-three years). Another account states that Yao ascended the throne at the age of ten and reigned for seventy years. When he was about to abdicate, he tested Shun for three years before passing the throne to him. After another twenty-eight years, he passed away, making his age one hundred and seventeen. (The *Outer Records* states he reigned for ninety-eight years and lived to one hundred and ninety-eight.)

Emperor Shun of the Youyu clan, a ninth-generation descendant of the Yellow Emperor, bore the surname Shentu (another account says Yao). He acted as regent for thirty years and ruled in his own right for fifty years, living to one hundred and twelve. (The *Outer Records* states he reigned for fifty years and lived to one hundred and ten. The *Records of the Grand Historian* says Shun was sixty-two when he succeeded Yao, reigned for thirty-nine years, and lived to exactly one hundred. Another account states that Shun was summoned to service at thirty, reigned for thirty years—including three years of mourning—and that one of these years was included in the thirty, while the Son of Heaven served for fifty years, making his total lifespan one hundred and ten. His capital was at Puyan, now Hezhong Prefecture.)

Xia Yu, also a great-great-grandson of the Yellow Emperor, bore the surname Si. He reigned as emperor, establishing his capital at Anyi, now Pu Prefecture, and ruled for nine years. His descendants succeeded one another for a total of four hundred and thirty-two years (the *Outer Records* concurs). According to the *Dunjia Lushan Tu*, Yu was a Daoist immortal. In ancient times, there was Yu and Nüwa, nineteen generations apart, who knew fortune and misfortune, life and death, and could weigh the profound and the subtle. They could still the boiling without fire and draw water without a well; their divination was infallible, and they gave birth to the five flavors. Truly, they were divine beings. The Yellow Emperor refined the Nine Cauldrons and ingested the elixir, eventually perfecting the alchemical method and transmitting it to Xuanzǐ. This Way is most sacred, and its transmission requires a covenant of utmost sincerity. The emperor, following the records of the *Central Classic*, concealed it in Mount Jiuyi. To the east, it was called Weiyu, sealed with patterned jade and covered with a massive stone slab. Below the mountain, by the riverside, stands the Great Yu Temple. The *Centuries* states: Sunao of the Youxin clan conceived Yu through a stone, giving birth to him on the sixth day of the sixth month. The people have long observed this day with fasting and offerings.

Tang of Yin, a twentieth-generation descendant of the Yellow Emperor (the Yellow Emperor’s son, Xuanyao, begot Qiaoxuan, who begot Gaoxin, who begot Xie; after ten more generations came Tianyi, who became King Tang of Yin), bore the surname Zi. He reigned as emperor, establishing his capital at Bo, now Bo Prefecture, and ruled for thirteen years. His descendants succeeded one another for a total of six hundred and thirteen years (the *Outer Records* records six hundred and twenty-eight years).

King Wu of Zhou, a twenty-second-generation descendant of the Yellow Emperor, bore the surname Ji (the Yellow Emperor’s grandson, Zhuanxu, took the surname Ji after residing by the Ji River; thus, Gaoxin’s son, Houji, also bore the surname Ji). After sixteen more generations, Fa became King Wu. He reigned for six years, establishing his capital at Haojing, now Yongxing. Later, King Ping moved the capital to Luoyi. His descendants succeeded one another for a total of eight hundred and seventy-two years (the *Outer Records* and chronicles differ, recording nine hundred and twenty-seven years).

The descendants of the Yellow Emperor each received their surnames based on their deeds. The emperor established twelve surnames by pitch-pipes, as previously recorded. His nine sons were each enfeoffed with a state, giving rise to thirty-three clans descended from the Yellow Emperor. The *Pre-Heaven Records* states that his descendants succeeded one another for a total of one thousand five hundred and twenty years (the *Centuries* records one thousand two hundred and fifty years).

Your servant Daoyi remarks: Though Xuanyuan (the Yellow Emperor) humbled himself, he first led seventy-two armies before governing the world with ease. In his time, rulers were enlightened, ministers virtuous, the people honest, and customs simple. Though he possessed the world, he felt no shame in remaining uninformed, and thus both gods and men willingly submitted to him. The people still praise him today, and from this, we may discern the distinctions between emperors, kings, and hegemons in later ages. As the *Dao De Jing* says: "Therefore the sage manages affairs without action and teaches without words. The myriad things arise, yet he does not refuse them; he gives them life, yet claims no possession; he acts, yet does not rely on anything; his work is accomplished, yet he does not dwell in it. It is precisely because he does not dwell in it that it does not leave him." Could this not describe Xuanyuan?

*True Immortals Through the Ages Who Embodied the Dao* (Volume One) concludes.

**Preface to *The Comprehensive Mirror of True Immortals Through the Ages Who Embodied the Dao***

Master Bai Haiqiong says: In the Jin dynasty, Ge Hong composed the *Biographies of Divine Immortals*, recording over a thousand individuals. Master Liu Gang later compiled *Sequel to the Biographies of Immortals*, adding sixteen hundred more. During the Song dynasty, Wang Taichu gathered nine hundred immortals in *Collected Biographies of Immortals*. In the Xuanhe era, after examining ancient and contemporary records, he chronicled fifty thousand immortals in *The History of Immortals*. How flourishing indeed is the teaching of non-action of the Most High!

Whenever I observe those who transcend the mundane—men of purity and lofty virtue, be they filial sons, loyal ministers, chaste women, or steadfast maidens—they all scorn worldly attachments in the realm of clarity and emptiness, directing their minds toward the mysterious and wondrous. Some seek obscurity to conceal their brilliance, while others aspire to rise above the ordinary and ascend to sagehood. Thus, they chew the primordial chaos, grasp the vast undifferentiated, ingest the essence of the sun and moon, and partake in the transformations of heaven and earth. They purify their minds and bathe their natures, nurturing simplicity to preserve their true selves. They delve into the void to establish the foundation of their crucible and explore the subtle to refine the ingredients of their elixir. Lead ascends, mercury descends, relying on water and fire for refinement; the tiger leaps, the dragon soars, depending on yin and yang for mastery. Hence, they are called the Golden Elder and the Maiden, the Yellow Matron and the Venerable Ding—all secret practices of cultivation and esoteric principles of ascending to the mysterious.

The Most High transmitted the teaching, calling it the Golden Elixir. It is passed down only to the worthy, with vows and covenants governing its transmission. At first, one refines essence into qi, qi into spirit, and spirit into union with the Dao, until yin is entirely stripped away, the body transforms into pure yang, and a body exists beyond the body—a transformed immortal fetus.

When the elixir completes its nine revolutions, the method aligns with great perfection. Through the accumulation of three thousand merits in yin cultivation and the fulfillment of eight hundred virtues in conduct, the talismans of the Great One summon them to dwell among the Penglai Isles; the decrees of the Supreme Emperor bid them ascend to the realms of the Great Luo. Those of lesser attainment achieve one of the four forms of liberation through the corpse, or wander as spirits through a hundred transformations. Yet the paths of master and disciple diverge, and practices vary: some chant sutras and mantras, drink sacred water, or swallow talismans; others cultivate visualization, swallow saliva, or ingest qi; some consume herbal medicines, while others refine elixirs from metals and minerals. Though a thousand gates and ten thousand methods exist, all ultimately return to the One Dao—just as every willow-lined path may lead a rider astray, yet every household has a road to Chang’an.

Yet only the internal refinement of the Golden Elixir encompasses all transformations, like following the true path or rivers flowing to the sea. Thus, all who achieve liberation through the corpse or ascension do so by this means. During their cultivation, they forget worldly glory, embrace tranquility, and wear dust-covered faces and tattered robes. Some sleep exposed to the rain, others dine on pine nuts and drink from mountain streams; some blend with the world, while others shun its dust.
