Scattered in mountains and forests, wandering lakes and seas, resting in grottoes, or traversing the mortal realm—the vulgar and common folk, with their shallow ears and base eyes, whisper to the young and gossip among themselves: *"These are but poor Daoists, beggars and vagabonds."* Those who draw near turn away; those who glance avert their gaze. Few honor them, unlike the high officials who flaunt their jade tablets and the wealthy who cling to their gold. Those who mock and scorn them are legion. Yet when these practitioners, through hidden merit and external cultivation, refine their inner essence, ride clouds and command qi, soar through the void, inscribe their names in the Upper Clarity, and dwell in the Azure Vault—then even the proud bow in reverence, and the gilded and purple-robed gaze in awe.

Alas, what loss or gain does this bring to the Dao? Only our Primordial Heavenly Worthy, in the ancient land of Dafuli, expounded the sutras with the Jeweled Pearl, enlightening all beings and pervading the ten directions. At that time, the Dao permeated the multitudes, its grace suffusing all existence, renewing the kalpas and awakening the true wind. Later, the Most High Lord Lao, the Supreme Dao Lord, continued this profound teaching, perpetuating its transformation. Then our August Heavenly Emperor, through the unfolding of celestial cycles, crystallized the true Dao in emptiness, guiding immortals step by step and nurturing all things. From ancient times to the present, those who ascend in broad daylight or achieve liberation through the corpse have flourished ever more abundantly.

This humble one, though insignificant, has long immersed himself in the study of the mysterious, yearning to transcend the world and wearying of mundane distractions. I have observed that the Confucians have their *Comprehensive Mirror for Aid in Government*, and the Buddhists their *Comprehensive Mirror of the Śākya Clan*, yet our Daoist tradition lacks such a work. The so-called "transmissions" and "histories" of Master Bai Haiqiong are no longer extant. Thus, I have compiled the deeds of immortals and perfected beings from ancient times to the present, examining their practices, discerning right from wrong, and expounding the great Dao to enlighten later generations. With earnest words, I guide them to return to the Most High, adhering to the ultimate truth and eschewing empty rhetoric.

Yet true immortals often conceal themselves, revealing little while hiding much. Of those who leave their names, barely one in a hundred is recorded. Moreover, the records of their comings and goings may vary in sequence, and their transformations defy orderly narration. Thus, this work cannot follow the conventions of secular histories, which arrange events chronologically. For each named immortal who attains the Dao, I have meticulously verified and edited the accounts, refraining from reckless embellishment. My hope is to distinguish between the immortal and the mortal, to honor those who leave their names, and to make my humble intentions known both in the human realm and the heavens—may the perfected beings of ten thousand kalpas bear witness.

I have titled this work *The Comprehensive Mirror of Perfected Immortals Embracing the Dao Through the Ages*. I, Zhao Daoyi, a Daoist of the Everlasting Longevity Palace on Floating Cloud Mountain, respectfully present this preface with incense and bows.

Divergent traditions abound in the transmission of such accounts. Some immortals cunningly conceal their identities, or their names and surnames are lost or altered beyond recognition. For instance, the tradition holds that Zhang Zifang’s master, the Yellow Stone Elder, was in fact Red Pine, who was also the Old Man of the Yi Bridge, who was also the Four Hoary Ones, who were also the Lords of the Eastern Sea, who were also the Valiant Ones. Had people not been deluded, how could a single old man in the wilderness have concealed both himself and a warrior? How could four elders have appeared by the roadside amidst weapons and armor, known to the ruler yet unnoticed by the people? Extending this logic, the Eight Immortals could be old or young, and the Daoist adept could transform in an instant—such manifestations of the will-born body are nothing strange.

Further, as the *True Records* attest, sages, loyal ministers, filial children, scholars, and men of talent across the ages share a single qi, existing through transformation without true death. For heaven and earth are but the body of humanity, just as humanity is the body of heaven and earth. I once sought to emulate Ban Mengjian’s *Tables of Notable Persons*, cataloging those who attained the Dao since the time of the Yellow Emperor. Though some were robust, others frail; some genuine, others false—yet this one became a heavenly immortal, that one an earthly immortal, another dwelt in seclusion, and so on. Some achieved perfection through cultivation, others through elixirs, while others failed or met misfortune. Some are worthy of emulation, others of admiration, caution, or fear. If one cannot find them in their original form, one may find them in their kind. Like Zhao Wenzi, who received instruction upon donning his cap, or the bodhisattvas who simultaneously expounded the Dharma before the Buddha—profound words fill the eyes, and all gates stand open. The benefits are boundless, far beyond merely recording names and deeds.

The venerable Zhao Quanyang, a lofty adept, was able to gather the works of Liu Zixuan, Ge Zhichuan, and others up to recent times. With tireless effort and meticulous care, he inscribed characters as fine as worm-eaten leaves, beyond numbering in the tens of thousands.

Though the accounts transmitted vary in their details, their general purport remains consistent. Through them, I have further come to see that the so-called adepts of the northern lands do not traffic in strange arts or unfathomable techniques, yet remain unattainable in their own right—this is likely the true teaching. There are bookworms who cannot be called wise, yet those who consume the characters of *Immortals* as if feasting on human hair may themselves become immortal by ingesting such hair. Quanyang, in his waking and dreaming, partakes of this immortal feast. Many have done so—not merely in ranks like cicadas—and should one obtain even a single strand, it would suffice to transmit alongside the ancient immortals. With reverence, I inscribe this preface for General Gu’s *Character Illuminations*. Those whose essence has already taken flight need not doubt the words of the man from Wuling; as for me, I have no leisure for such hesitation.

Written by Liu Chenweng of Luling in the fifth month of the jiawu year.

Since ancient times, those who attained immortality were said to have names recorded in celestial and terrestrial registers—charts and histories stored in heavenly realms, earthly mountains, and grotto-palaces, unbound by worldly concerns. The *Scripture of Salvation* states: "At the beginning, the Primordial One preached the Dao amidst the Azure Heavens, and the boundless hosts of perfected great spirits from the ten directions and infinite realms arrived, floating through the void." There are the "Limitless," the "Measureless," and the "Countless Multitudes"—much like the Buddhist sutras’ "three times, ten directions, and sands of the Ganges," or "hundreds of thousands of myriads of nayutas." Inexpressible, inexpressible. If all buddhas and bodhisattvas were to inscribe every name and title on bamboo and silk, it would be impossible to record them all.

Liu Xiang’s *Arrayed Immortals* begins with Red Pine and ends with Xuan Su, yet does not extend to the Yellow Emperor. Ge Hong’s *Immortals* starts with Guangcheng and concludes with Feng Junda, but does not reach the Jin dynasty. Shen Fen’s *Sequel to the Immortals* notes that when people inquire about those who attained immortality, they hear of scarcely one in a thousand. The *True Reports* records Yang Jun’s transcriptions from the underworld’s overseers, who acknowledged only those with official ranks, while the unranked remained largely unknown. Thus, the unrecorded are limitless. In essence, the immortal realm has its registers, just as the human world has its histories. Humans cannot know the immortals, nor do immortals seek renown among men—hence the disparity in their numbers and the variance in their records.

The Daoist of Floating Cloud Mountain, Zhao Quanyang, compiled the *Mirror of Immortals*, meticulously verifying and collating its contents. He may well be called the Dong Hu of the immortal realm. Yet I harbor a doubt: Ge Hong’s account of the Eight Lords of Huainan is grand, and it is understandable that Han histories would conceal it. But Liu Xiang’s father, Liu De, who governed Huainan’s prisons, obtained the *Pillow Book of the Hongbao* and marveled at its wonders. Why, then, did Liu Xiang omit the Eight Lords from his *Arrayed Immortals*? In the Jiang region, traditions about Jingyang are modest, yet dazzling to the eye. Yet when examining the *True Reports*, which records the genealogy and names of the Xu family’s perfected ones—from their eldest to youngest, from the Minister of Education to the Tiger General and Jade Axe—there is not a single mention of Jingyang. The *True Reports* was composed during the Liang dynasty, not long after the Eastern Jin, and should not suffer from historical omissions. This is truly strange.

In Quanyang’s records, the deeds of Liu An and the Grand Scribe Xu stand alongside those in the *Arrayed Immortals* and *True Reports*. Is there not cause for doubt? If the perfected sages of the celestial realms already hold positions in the scriptural canons, then including them in the *Mirror of Immortals* might seem like a mere fraction of the whole. To enumerate each would be impossible. Quanyang, in your editing, I urge you to reconsider this matter. May you meet with good fortune.

Written by Deng Guangjian, the Recluse of Jianzhong Studio, in the third month of the year at Benyi Hermitage.

I once saw that the Confucians had ritual texts for the Master, but the historian of Siming rebuked them, saying: "To exalt him is to diminish him." This is why Master Zhu of Kao-t’ing, at White Deer Grotto, preferred not to sculpt the Master’s image, setting out only a ritual tablet during sacrifices. Yet no one has ever questioned the Master’s lineage—this is why the Elder of Zhizhai, upon reviewing the *Veritable Records*, was moved to lament for the Confucian teaching.

The Daoist of Floating Cloud Mountain, Zhao Quanyang, in compiling the *Mirror of Immortals*, has accomplished what others could not. I venture to ask: Is the Master not the sovereign of the vast mulberry fields beyond the seas? This is recorded in Han Kuang’s biography and listed in the ranks of the Golden Register’s ritual positions. Why, then, have you omitted him? Is it that the immortals you have included are like the three thousand disciples of Confucius’ gate, while the Master’s exalted status remains beyond the reach of your words? Alas! In every mote of dust, in every realm, the Jade Emperor’s body is wholly reflected within the boundless bright mirror. Let these words serve as your eulogy.

**Memorial:**
Your Daoist servant ventures to say: The Great Dao is non-action, existing before the beginning of heaven and earth. The true immortals transmit their teachings, uniting past and present in a single day. From the Three Sovereigns onward, generations stretch into the distant past, governed by knotted cords, without written records to consult. Only with Fuxi did written characters begin, and later ages followed his example. Yet as the years multiplied, bamboo slips decayed, and the affairs of high antiquity became scarcely one-tenth known to later generations. The degeneration of human hearts is deeply lamentable.

Fortunately, the incarnations of the Most High have appeared across the ages to expound the teachings. Thus, even in an era of declining customs, the wind of returning to purity and simplicity endures. Is this not magnificent?

Your Daoist servant, with utmost reverence and trepidation, bows his head and knocks his forehead to the ground, honoring the Most High, the Jade Emperor of the Golden Gates of the Azure Heavens, whose true constancy is profound and still, whose wisdom is wondrous and complete. He is the teacher and lord of the Three Realms, the supreme model of the ten directions, eternally propagating the perfect Dao and boundlessly delivering beings.

Though I am foolish and ignorant, I have gathered from the scriptures and traditions the verifiable deeds of the highest sages and true immortals, compiling them into the *Comprehensive Mirror of True Immortals Through the Ages*. Through it, I seek to publicly evaluate the Dao and virtue, to reveal the models of immortals and sages, to manifest the true lineage, to praise the great transformation, to illuminate the enlightened ancestors, and to admonish future generations.

Yet true immortals dwelling in the world often conceal their radiance and hide their forms, their distant transformations beyond reckoning. Of those who leave their names in records, scarcely one in a hundred is known. Permit me, with my humble and shallow understanding, to present this to Your Majesty.

Consider the realms of the Three Clarities, the heavens of the ten directions, the divine mountains upon the seas, the Five Marchmounts beyond the seas, the Celestial Perfected and Supreme Thearchs, the Perfected Persons and Divine Kings—majestic as thunder, companionable as stars—each with their appointed offices. And as the *Scripture of Salvation* declares, the boundless and immeasurable hosts of the Most Perfect and Great Spirits of the ten directions are beyond enumeration, far exceeding what mortal realms can fully recount. Here, I rely upon the true scriptures as my source.

First, I list the exalted Perfected and Supreme Sages in several ranks to establish the framework. Next, I record the several dozen who attained the name of true immortals in the eras of the Three Sovereigns—Fuxi, Shennong, and the Yellow Emperor—to reveal the origins of communion between heaven and humanity. From the Three Sovereigns onward, though the lineage of true immortals has been transmitted in unbroken succession, most have remained reclusive, eschewing written records, their voices but faintly heard among mortals. From the Five Emperors and the Three Dynasties, nearly a hundred have left their names in the world, yet even these cannot exhaust the details of their appearances and transformations.

By the Yin and Zhou dynasties, the Most High again descended in incarnate form, and the great Dao flourished. Thus, from the Qin and Han through the Three Kingdoms, Jin, Northern and Southern Dynasties, Sui, Tang, Five Dynasties, and Song, the transmission of teachings and establishment of precepts reached their zenith. Yet within grotto-heavens and blessed lands, in courtly halls and rustic retreats, some harmonized their light with the dust of the world, while others concealed their forms and withdrew from the fray. What records cannot fully capture, what eyes and ears cannot universally perceive—of these, only a few thousand true immortals have left their names in the world.

Beyond these, there are the encounters of mortals: some witness flying immortals descending, others divine immortals at play, their names hidden, their traces fleeting and distant—most of which escape the written word. What I have compiled here are only those true immortals whose personal conduct and practices have entered the realm of human perception.

Yet spanning ancient and modern times, how could this compilation be without errors? I, of dull and ordinary endowment, how could my account be without faults? I humbly beseech Your Majesty to discern its subtle points, to consider my earnest devotion, and to deign to peruse it. Thereafter, may it be disseminated among mortals to serve as a mirror and admonition for future seekers of true immortality. This is the deepest wish of my humble self.

Daring to offend Your Celestial Majesty’s awe-inspiring dignity, I tremble with fear. Thus, I have compiled the *Comprehensive Mirror of True Immortals Through the Ages* and now reverently submit this memorial for Your Majesty’s consideration.

With utmost reverence and trepidation, I bow my head and knock my forehead to the ground.

Respectfully submitted by the humble Daoist disciple Zhao Daoyi, of the Lesser Luminaries, from the Abbey of Myriad Years on Floating Cloud Mountain.

*Comprehensive Mirror of True Immortals Through the Ages*, Scroll Two
The Perfected Master of the Dao of Pervasive Mystery

The Perfected Master of the Dao of Pervasive Mystery bore the title Grand Master of the Mystery Within. During the era of Heavenly Sovereign Fuxi, he revealed the *Twelve Scrolls of the Cavern of Perfection*, imparting the Great Dao of the Limitless to inquire among humankind.

The Ancient Grand Master
The Ancient Grand Master, during the era of Earthly Sovereign Shennong, revealed the *Twelve Scrolls of the Cavern of Mystery*, transforming people through the Supreme Dao of Orthodox Perfection.

Master Pangu
Master Pangu, during the era of Human Sovereign Suiren, revealed the *Twelve Scrolls of the Cavern of Divinity*, transforming people through the Dao of Great Peace and Non-Action.

Yu Hua Zi
Yu Hua Zi descended to the fields during the reign of Fuxi, bestowing the *Inner Writ of the Heavenly Sovereign*. He also transmitted the *River Chart* and the *Eight Trigrams*, teaching people the Dao of Following One’s Nature. He was also known as Wan Hua and styled himself the Master of the Fields, composing the *Thirty-Four Scrolls of the Primordial Yang*.

Guang Shou Zi
Guang Shou Zi descended upon Mount Heng during the reign of Zhu Rong, bestowing the *Inner Writ of the Human Sovereign* and teaching the Dao of Calming the Spirit. He instructed people in the craft of molding vessels to refine and transform life. He was also known as Chuan Yu Zi and composed the *Ninety Scrolls of the Comprehensive Classic of Massage and Essence*.

Da Cheng Zi
Da Cheng Zi, also known as Chuan Yu Zi, descended upon Jiyin during the reign of Shennong, bestowing the *Inner Writ of the Earthly Sovereign* and teaching the Dao of Cherishing Life. He instructed people to cultivate grains and fruits to replace the cooking and slaughter of animals, and to harmonize medicinal recipes to heal illnesses and nurture nature. It is also said that he composed the *Thirty-Six Scrolls of the Primordial Essence of the Great One*.

Guang Cheng Zi
Guang Cheng Zi dwelled in a stone chamber on Mount Kongtong. The Yellow Emperor, having heard of him, went to visit and said: "I venture to ask the essentials of the Supreme Dao." Guang Cheng Zi replied: "You govern the world, yet clouds do not wait to gather before raining, and trees do not wait to yellow before falling. How can one speak to you of the Supreme Dao?" The Yellow Emperor withdrew and lived in seclusion. After three months, he returned to see him, advancing on his knees, bowing twice, and inquiring about the Dao of governing the body. Guang Cheng Zi answered: "The essence of the Supreme Dao is profound and obscure. The ultimate of the Supreme Dao is dark and silent. See nothing, hear nothing, embrace the spirit in stillness, and the body will naturally align. Be still, be pure; do not labor your form, do not disturb your essence, and you may attain longevity. Guard within, close without; excessive knowledge leads to ruin. I preserve the One and abide in harmony, thus I have lived for one thousand two hundred years without aging. Those who attain my Dao ascend to become sovereigns; those who lose it descend to become dust. I shall depart from you, entering the boundless, roaming the limitless wilds, sharing radiance with the sun and moon, and enduring with heaven and earth. Mortals will all perish, yet I alone shall endure." Thereupon, he bestowed upon the Emperor the *Classic of Yin and Yang*. The *Annals of the Yellow Emperor* state that he bestowed the *Classic of Spontaneity*. He was also known as Li Mo Zi and composed the *Seventy Scrolls of the Classic of Dao Attainment*.

This humble Daoist, Zhao Daoyi, observes: Guang Cheng Zi said, "I preserve the One and abide in harmony, thus I have lived for one thousand two hundred years without aging." The *Classic of the Dao and Virtue* states: "Of old, those who attained the One: Heaven attained the One and became clear; Earth attained the One and became tranquil; spirits attained the One and became numinous; valleys attained the One and became full; the myriad things attained the One and came to life; lords and kings attained the One and became the standard for all under heaven." This is likely what he meant. Guang Cheng Zi’s intent was for the Yellow Emperor to embrace the One as the model for all under heaven. Later, the Yellow Emperor attained the Dao and ascended to heaven in broad daylight. Subsequent emperors and kings were ultimately unable to match him—how wondrous was Guang Cheng Zi’s achievement!

Sui Ying Zi
Sui Ying Zi, also known as the Master of the Great Ultimate, descended upon Mount Kongtong during the reign of Shaohao and expounded the *Classic of Solemn Respect*, teaching the Dao of following the seasons and enacting decrees.

Chi Jing Zi
Chi Jing Zi, during the reign of Zhuanxu, expounded the *Classic of Subtle Words*, teaching the Dao of loyalty and obedience. The *Comprehensive Collection of the Southern Marchmount* states: "On Lotus Peak, there remains a platform for transmitting scriptures. During the Xianhe era of the Jin dynasty, several youths were seen on the southern slope of the mountain, playing with a flock of white cranes."

Lu Tu Zi
Lu Tu Zi descended upon the banks of the Yangtze during the reign of Emperor Ku and expounded the *Classic of the Yellow Court*, teaching the Dao of purity and harmony. He commanded the Perfected Lords of the Nine Heavens and the Perfected August Ones of the Three Heavens to hold the Eight Radiant Tallies and the Tallies of Auspicious Clouds, descending to the Terrace of Pastoral Virtue to bestow upon Emperor Ku the numinous treasures of the Nine Heavens and the precious talismans of the Three Heavens. Above, these served heaven’s mandate, ensuring the two forces suffered no loss; below, they nurtured the people, ensuring their years and lives suffered no decline. The Emperor then performed a sacrifice to heaven at the altar of the Northern River and concealed the talismans upon the peak of Mount Zhong. Later, he ascended to heaven as a Perfected One of the Mysterious Palace. At that time, Lu Tu Zi transmitted the Dao to Red Pine Master, Clothed-in-Robes Master, Wang Ni, and Nie Que. It is also said that he composed the *Fifty Scrolls of the Classic of the Yellow Court*.

Wu Cheng Zi
Wu Cheng Zi descended upon Mount Gushe during the reign of Emperor Yao and expounded the *Classic of Mysterious Virtue*, teaching the Dao of humility and modesty. It is also said that he composed the *Forty Scrolls of the Classic of Governance and Transformation*.

Yin Shou Zi
Yin Shou Zi descended upon Heyang during the reign of Emperor Shun and expounded the *Classic of the Dao and Virtue*, teaching the Dao of Non-Action. He also transmitted the Dao to Peng Zu. It is also said that he composed the *Seventy Scrolls of the Classic of the Perfected One of Pervasive Mystery* and the *One Thousand Two Hundred Scrolls of the Classic of the Dao and Virtue*.

Zhen Xing Zi
Zhen Xing Zi, also known as Yu Zhen Zi, descended upon Mount Shang during the reign of Yu the Great, teaching the Dao of diligence and frugality. He bestowed the *Nine Categories of Writings* and commanded the divine envoy Xuan Yi of Wanwei to present Yu with the *Five Numinous Talismans of the Jade Writs*, the *True Writs for Governing Floods*, and the methods for pacing the stars, summoning spirits, and exorcising demons. The Grotto-Heaven of Supreme Joy and Lawful Music on Jade Bamboo Mountain was the very place where Yu received the *True Writs of the Numinous Treasure*. Its traces remain to this day. The Grotto-Heaven of the Forest Chamber on Dongting Mountain in Lake Tai is where Yu concealed the true writs. It is also called Baoshan. In the twelfth year of King Helü of Wu, in the first month, he ascended Baoshan and commanded the diver Long Wei to enter the grotto of Baoshan to explore its depths. There, he saw a golden city and jade halls, inscribed with the words: "The Separate Palace of the Queen of Heaven, the Hall of Great Yin."

Upon the jade table within the chamber, he obtained a scroll of the *Plain Book*, comprising one hundred and seventy-four characters, and then returned. King Helü, unable to decipher the script, dispatched an envoy to inquire of Confucius. A red crow then delivered a written text to the king.

Confucius said: "Once, while I traveled by the Western Sea, I heard a children’s rhyme that went: *'The King of Wu sets forth to view the trembling lake, / Long Wei the Elder, by name, in seclusion dwells. / North to Baoshan he ascends, entering the numinous void, / To Dongting’s depths he steals the writs of Yu. / The Heavenly Emperor’s great texts must not be unfurled, / This script shall long transmit the hundred-sixth cycle’s doom. / Now forcibly taken, it shall bring ruin to the royal house.'* I have examined the rhyme and conclude that Long Wei the Elder obtained it within the grotto, and the red crow bore it here—beyond my knowledge."

The King of Wu, struck with fear, returned the book.

Another account states: During the time of Yu the Great, he emerged as a master named Jizi Qing, composing the *Scripture of Primordial Beginning* in forty-six scrolls, the *Scripture of Wondrous Joy* in seventy scrolls, and the *Scripture of Virtue and Admonitions* in thirty scrolls.

**Xi Zezi**
Xi Zezi descended upon Jian Mountain during the Shang era, expounding the *Scripture of Longevity* and teaching the Way of reverence and compassion. The site of the Dragon Hall before the Heavenly Blessing Palace on Mount Qian is the very place where he dwelled. He was also called Xishouzi, or Jiezi Qing, and authored the *Scripture of the Dao’s Origin* in seventy scrolls.

**Xie Yizi**
Xie Yizi, also known as Chijingzi, descended upon the southern slopes of Mount Qi, expounding the *Scripture of the Red Essence* and teaching the Way of benevolence and trustworthiness. When King Wen of the Zhou heard of him, he summoned him to serve as Archivist.

**Yuchengzi**
Yuchengzi, upon King Wu of Zhou’s conquest of Shang and ascension to the throne, was promoted from Archivist to Pillar Historian. He composed the *Scripture of the Wandering Mechanism*.

Another account states: During the reign of King Wu of Zhou, he emerged as a master named Guoshuzi, also called Xuchengzi or Tianlaogong, and was further known as Lao Jun. At times appearing as an ordinary man, at others as Pillar Historian, he composed the *Scripture of Longevity* in thirty scrolls and presented it to the king.

**Jingchengzi**
Jingchengzi, serving as Pillar Historian during the reign of King Cheng of Zhou, expounded the *Scripture of Vast Transformation* and transmitted its teachings on the Dao to the Duke of Zhou. He later retired to a life of leisure and journeyed to the western lands of Da Qin, Jambudvipa, and other realms, where he was known as the Ancient Master.

**Guoshuzi**
Guoshuzi served as Pillar Historian during the reign of King Kang of Zhou.

*Comprehensive Mirror of Perfected Immortals Embodying the Dao, Scroll the Second—concluded*
*Comprehensive Mirror of Perfected Immortals Embodying the Dao, Scroll the Third*

**Chisongzi**
Chisongzi served as the Rain Master during the reign of Shennong. He consumed water jade to instruct Shennong and could enter fire to immolate himself. He journeyed to Mount Kunlun, where he often resided in the stone chamber of the Queen Mother of the West, ascending and descending with the winds and rains. The youngest daughter of the Flame Emperor pursued him and, attaining immortality, departed with him. By the time of Gao Xin, he again served as Rain Master—today’s Rain Master traces his lineage to him.

The *Record of the Cinnabar Terrace* states: He became the Immortal Earl of Kunlin, governing the Southern Marchmount. The *Baopuzi* records: Chisongzi soaked jade in dark wormwood blood to create water, which he consumed, enabling him to ride the mist and ascend or descend at will. Ingesting jade fragments or drinking jade-infused water both confer immortality.

**Nanfengzi**
Nanfengzi lived during the time of the Yellow Emperor and was traditionally regarded as the Yellow Emperor’s Pottery Master. A traveler passing by assisted him in tending the fire and could produce five-colored smoke. Over time, he taught this art to Nanfengzi. Nanfengzi then immolated himself in the accumulated fire, ascending and descending with the smoke. When his ashes were examined, his bones remained intact. The people of that era buried him together in the northern mountains of Yu, hence he was called Nanfengzi.

Master Nanfeng resided in the northern cliffs of Mount Qingcheng in Shu. The Yellow Emperor became his disciple and inquired about the Dao of the Three Ones. The master replied: "I have heard that the Heavenly Perfected Sovereign, having endured the kalpas of the Most High, now dwells near Mount Emei. He has attained the source of the Three Ones—you may seek him as your teacher." Thereupon, he transmitted the *Scripture of the Dragon’s Pace* to the Yellow Emperor. After receiving it, the Yellow Emperor could ride cloud-dragons to traverse the eight directions. He then erected an altar atop the mountain and honored the Treasure Lord as the Perfected of the Five Marchmounts. He commanded the spirits of the rivers and mountains to receive their duties at the Pure Capital. Later, he entered the northern cliffs of Mount Emei to receive the Dao of the Three Ones from the Sovereign. His chariot tracks encircled the seas and mountains, and they remain to this day.

It is also said: "The Yellow Emperor enfeoffed Lord Yu as the master of the Five Marchmounts, overseeing the mountain spirits. Here, he regulated the water clock with flowing water, establishing the Six Seasonal Waters. During yin hours, the water scatters like mist; during yang hours, it ceases."

**Ma Shihuang**
Ma Shihuang was the equine physician of the Yellow Emperor. He understood the diagnosis of horses’ forms, qi, life, and death, and could cure them without fail. Later, a dragon descended before him, drooping its ears and gaping its mouth. Shihuang said: "This dragon is ill and knows I can heal it." He then stitched its lower lip to its mouth and administered a licorice decoction, restoring it to health. Thereafter, whenever ailing dragons emerged from the marsh, they would seek him out for treatment. One day, a dragon bore him away.

**Chijiang Ziyu**
Chijiang Ziyu lived during the time of the Yellow Emperor.

Chijiang Ziyu consumed no grains, subsisting solely on the blossoms of a hundred herbs. In the time of Yao, he served as Minister of Wood, able to ascend and descend with the wind and rain. At times, he traded arrows in the marketplace, earning the name "Father of Arrows."

**Woquan**
Woquan was a gatherer of herbs on Mount Huai. Fond of eating pine seeds, his body grew hair several inches long, and his eyes became square. He could fly and outrun galloping horses. He once presented pine seeds to Yao, who had no leisure to consume them. Those among Yao’s people who did ingest them lived to two or three hundred years.

**Fanghui**
Fanghui was a recluse in Yao’s time. Yao summoned him as a scholar of leisure, whereupon he refined mica powder and stone, administering them to the ailing populace. Later, he concealed himself in the Five Oaks Mountain. In the final years of Xia Qi, he served as an official but was seized by bandits and imprisoned in a chamber, from which he sought the Dao. He transformed and escaped, sealing the door with his seal. People of the time said that applying a single round of his clay to a door rendered it unopenable.

**Qian Keng**
Qian Keng was a great-great-grandson of Emperor Zhuanxu. He presented pheasant broth to Yao, who enfeoffed him at Pengcheng, later known as Pengzu. He had two sons: the elder named Wu, the younger named Yi. The mountain where he concealed himself was later named Wuyi Mountain. One account states that Yin Shouzi transmitted the Dao to Pengzu during the time of Yu Shun, while another identifies Qian Keng as Pengzu himself.

He practiced Daoist breathing exercises and guided qi; when ill, he would hold his breath to attack the affliction, circulating it through his body until it reached his fingertips, restoring him to normal. It was said: "A superior adept sleeps on a separate bed, a middling adept under a separate cover—yet consuming a hundred packets of medicine is not as good as sleeping alone." People compiled his techniques into *The Pengzu Classic*.

*The Arrayed Transmissions of Immortals* states: Pengzu lived from the Xia to the end of the Yin dynasty, over eight hundred years. He regularly ate cassia bark and excelled at guiding qi and circulating breath. In Liyang stood Pengzu’s immortal chamber; prayers offered there were answered without fail by wind and rain. Two tigers always lingered by the shrine, and after rituals, tigers would appear nearby. It was said he later ascended as an immortal and departed.

Another account claims Keng concealed himself in the mountains, weaving bamboo into a door and eating pine seeds as sustenance. He could ride the wind and command qi, leaping into the void. By the end of the Yin dynasty, he had already lived over seven hundred years, and after seven hundred seventy-seven years, he dissolved and transformed.

Zhao Cigong said: The county of Pengcheng in Xuzhou derived its name from Pengzu.

According to *Comprehensive Records of the World*: Pengzu, a worthy minister of the Yin dynasty and great-great-grandson of Zhuanxu, lived to seven hundred sixty-seven years by the end of Yin. His ancient tomb lies north of the former capital, now called Dapeng.

*The Records of Eminent Worthies of Mount Lu* states: Peng Keng once passed by the shores of Pengli, where he visited the renowned mountain—now Mount Lu. He traversed its grottoes to glimpse the sacred traces, then fished upon a terrace. Two carp transformed into twin dragons and soared into the heavens. Some say the Fishing Terrace by the riverbank was Pengzu’s legacy.

**Xiaofu**
Xiaofu was a man of Jizhou who, in his youth, mended shoes in the Western Zhou marketplace for decades without anyone recognizing him.

Later, when people marveled at his agelessness, the curious sought his methods of preservation, but none succeeded—only Liangmu obtained his technique for kindling fire. As he prepared to ascend Sanliang Mountain, he bade farewell to Liangmu, arranging dozens of fires before ascending to heaven. The people of the western village have since revered and worshipped him.

**Shimen**
Shimen was a disciple of Xiaofu. He, too, could command fire and fed upon the blossoms of peach and plum trees. He served as the Dragon Master for Xia Kongjia, but when Kongjia failed to comply with his wishes, he was killed and buried in the wilderness. The next day, wind and rain came to receive him, and when it ceased, the mountain’s trees were all consumed by fire. Kongjia, filled with remorse, offered sacrifices and prayers, yet upon his return, he died upon the road.

According to Liu Shu’s *Supplementary Records to the Comprehensive Mirror*, Kongjia was fond of ghostly and divine matters but neglected the cultivation of virtue, leading many feudal lords to rebel. At that time, heaven sent down a pair of dragons, male and female, which Kongjia could not feed and thus failed to obtain. After the decline of the Dragon-Taming Clan of the Taotang lineage, there emerged Liu Lei, who studied dragon-taming under the clan and served Kongjia, able to feed the dragons. The Xia ruler praised him and granted him the clan name Yulong, replacing the descendants of Shihwei. When one of the female dragons died, Liu Lei secretly stewed it and served it to the Xia ruler. The ruler enjoyed it but later demanded the dragon be returned. Fearing punishment, Liu Lei fled to Luzhou.

From the perspective of Daoist unity, Liu Lei may well have been Shimen, though this remains uncertain. Thus, it is noted here for future scholars to discuss.

Minister Dao Yi remarks: Shimen attained the Dao and served the Xia dynasty, only to encounter the misfortune of its ruler. Kongjia first killed and buried him, then later, moved by remorse, offered sacrifices—yet he still died upon his return. This mirrors Sun Ce’s slaying of Gan Ji, which led to his own fatal wounding, or Yao Chang’s execution of Wang Jia, which preceded his downfall. Yet Wang Jia later appeared in Longyou, and Gan Ji reappeared in a mirror. Shimen, too, was received by wind and rain—what harm did this bring to his Dao? Those who rule must take heed: if they honored the virtuous and delighted in scholars, could such calamities ever occur?

The *Dao De Jing* states: "Why would a ruler of ten thousand chariots treat his person as insignificant before the world? Such frivolity loses ministers, and such impatience loses the throne." This is precisely the case.

Wu Guang—Wu Guang in the *Zhuangzi* is written as *Piè*—was a man of the Xia dynasty. His ears measured seven inches; he loved the zither and subsisted on cattail roots and wild leeks. When Tang of Shang launched his campaign against Jie, he consulted Guang, who replied: "This is not my concern." Tang asked: "Who, then, is suitable?" Guang said: "I do not know." Tang pressed: "What of Yi Yin?" Guang answered: "He is strong and enduring, patient with disgrace—but I know nothing beyond that."

After Tang conquered Jie, he offered the realm to Guang, saying: "The wise devise strategy, the martial execute it, and the benevolent occupy the throne—this is the Way of antiquity. Why do you not take it? I will serve as your minister." Guang declined: "To depose a sovereign is unrighteous; to kill men is inhumane. Others bear the hardship while I reap the reward—this is unprincipled. I have heard that one who acts without righteousness does not accept its emoluments, nor does one tread the path of office in a lawless age. To be exalted above me is something I cannot endure." Thereupon, he carried a stone and drowned himself in the Liao River—the *Zhuangzi* calls it the Lu River, while Sima [Qian] writes it as the Lu River, located on the western border of Liaodong. Another account places it within the bounds of Beiping Prefecture. Thereafter, he concealed himself.

Four years later, during the reign of Wu Ding, he reappeared. Wu Ding wished to appoint him as chief minister, but he refused. Wu Ding had him conveyed by carriage and pressed him to comply, disregarding propriety. Thereupon, he cast himself into the river at Mount Fu, later wandering to Mount Shangfu.

One account of the ministerial Way states: After the Great Simplicity had dispersed, there came Tang’s punitive expedition, the Battle of Mingtiao. Had no Perfected One of the Dao emerged in that interval, the fundamental norms would have dissolved a thousand years hence. By reproving Tang’s transgressions, Wu Guang made clear the distinction between ruler and minister. Even at the threshold of life and death, he did not alter his resolve. Herein lies the very foundation of the enduring standard of loyalty and righteousness for ten thousand generations. Later, at the gathering at Meng Ford, Bo Yi and Shu Qi remonstrated by seizing the bridle, and starved to death on Mount Shouyang—was this not rooted in Guang’s Way?

The *Daodejing* says: “In a state of darkness and disorder, there are loyal ministers.” I would add: Though it is misfortune to have darkness and disorder, it is also fortune to have loyal ministers.

Qiu Sheng
Qiu Sheng, of unknown origin, served as Minister of Wood under Tang for over thirty years, yet grew only more vigorous. All knew him to be a man of longevity and revered him as their teacher. He was said to subsist on pine resin and to have built his own stone chamber on a northern mountain in his homeland, where sacrifices were offered to him.

Master Rongcheng

Master Rongcheng

Master Rongcheng claimed to have been the teacher of the Yellow Emperor and was received by King Mu of Zhou. Skilled in the arts of supplementation and guidance, he refined his essence within the Mysterious Female. His essential teaching was that the Spirit of the Valley never dies—preserving life, nurturing qi, turning white hair black again, and making fallen teeth regrow—practices akin to those of Laozi. Some also say that Laozi took him as his teacher.

There are those who claim that Master Rongcheng attained the art of sexual cultivation, holding firm without emission to return essence and replenish the brain. This account is not accepted here, for it is but a later misguided transmission.

Your servant Dao Yi says: The *Daodejing* states, “The Spirit of the Valley never dies—this is called the Mysterious Female. The gate of the Mysterious Female is called the root of Heaven and Earth. Subtle and seemingly present, its use is never exhausted.” Those who attain this Way ascend to become immortals; those who lose it descend to become ghosts. Master Rongcheng grasped this Way, the gateway to all marvels. Later generations, failing to attain the true Way, strayed onto side paths and crooked trails, clinging to mere branches. Some even pushed to extremes, fabricating the art of sexual cultivation and falsely attributing it to Master Rongcheng—this is a grave error.

Lü Shang

Lü Shang was a native of Jizhou.

Born with innate wisdom, he foresaw survival and ruin. To escape the chaos of King Zhou, he concealed himself in Liaodong for forty years. Later journeying west to Zhou, he hid in the Southern Mountains, fishing at Pan Stream for three years without catching a single fish. Those around him all said, “You should give up.” Shang replied, “This is not something within your understanding.” Soon after, he indeed found a military tally within a fish’s belly. King Wen dreamed of encountering a sage; upon hearing of Shang, he carried him back in his chariot. When King Wu of Zhou launched his campaign against Zhou, Shang composed over a hundred treatises on covert strategy. He consumed *zechi* mushrooms and earth marrow. Though he lived for two hundred years before announcing his death, he faced calamity and was not buried. Later, his son Ji interred him, but no corpse was found—only six scrolls of *The Jade Tally*, totaling ten thousand characters, remained in the coffin.

**Ge You**

Ge You was a Qiang tribesman. During the reign of King Cheng of Zhou, he enjoyed carving wooden sheep to sell. One day, he rode a sheep into Shu, and the kings, marquises, and nobles of Shu pursued him up Sui Mountain. Sui Mountain lies southwest of Mount Emei, its height boundless; those who followed him never returned, all attaining the Dao of immortality. Thus, a local saying goes: “If you obtain a single peach from Sui Mountain, even if you do not become immortal, you will live with pride.”

**Fan Li**

Fan Li, styled Shaobo, was a native of Xu. He served the Zhou court and studied under Grand Duke Wang. Fond of consuming cassia and drinking water, he became a minister of Yue and assisted Goujian in defeating Wu. Later, he boarded a light boat and entered the sea, changing his name and surname before settling in Qi as Yazi Zi. Over a hundred years later, he appeared in Tao, becoming the Lord of Tao Zhu, amassing wealth of hundreds of millions. Known as Tao Zhu Gong, he later abandoned it all to sell medicine in the marketplace. Subsequent generations continued to recognize and encounter him.

Li Yuanying recorded that Fan Li studied the Dao on Mount Liyuan, which belongs to Pengzhou. *The Record of Twenty-Four Transformations* states that Fan Li attained immortality on Mount Beiyu.

**Na Liu**

Na Shu was a scribe enfeoffed by the Zhou court.

Skilled in circulating qi and refining his form, he boiled stone marrow and consumed it, calling it stalactite, for several hundred years. He came and went within Mount Tai Shi, where a reclining stone served as his pillow.

Jiezi Tui
Jiezi Tui, surnamed Wang and named Guang—though he had no given name—delighted in Zhao Xuanzi and accompanied him. A man of Jin, he once saw a yellow sparrow perched at his gate, which Duke Chong’er of Jin found strange. Together they lived abroad for over a decade, enduring hardship without complaint. When they returned to Mount Jie, Bozi Zhen came at dawn and called to Tui, saying, "You may depart now." Tui declined, and with his mother entered the mountains, following Bozi in his wanderings. Later, Duke Wen sent thousands with jade and silk to honor him, but he did not emerge. Thirty years afterward, he appeared on the shores of the Eastern Sea, selling fans as Wang Su. Decades later, none knew his whereabouts.

Juanzǐ
Juanzǐ was a man of Qi. Fond of consuming wood, he absorbed its essence as sustenance, and after three hundred years appeared in Qi. He composed *The Classic of Heaven, Earth, and Humanity* in forty-eight scrolls. Later, while fishing in the rivers and marshes, he found a talisman within a carp’s belly. He concealed himself on Mount Yan, where he could command wind and rain. He received the Nine Immortal Methods from Boyang, though Prince An of Huainan obtained only fragments of his writings and could not grasp their meaning. His *Three Scrolls of the Zither’s Heart* were well-ordered.

Ma Dan
Ma Dan was a Di man of Jin.

At the time of Marquis Wen, he served as a grandee, and by the reign of Duke Xian, he was again appointed as Minister of the Curtain. When Duke Xian annihilated the Di and killed the Reverent Crown Prince, Dan departed. By the era of Zhao Xuanzi, he rode a carriage of peace into the Jin capital and awaited the grandees. Duke Ling wished to employ him, but pressed him without propriety, whereupon a swift wind arose, and Dan entered the whirlwind and vanished. The people of the north revered him and offered sacrifices in his honor.

Ping Changsheng
Ping Changsheng of Gucheng—his origins are unknown. He died and revived many times, which people of the time found unbelievable. Later, when great floods surged forth, wreaking widespread devastation, Ping stood atop the summit of Quemen Mountain and cried out, declaring, “Ping Changsheng is here!” He foretold that the rain and floodwaters would cease in five days. When they did, the people ascended the mountain to seek him and offer sacrifices, but all they found were Ping’s garments, leather belt, and sandals. Decades later, he reappeared as a gatekeeper at Huayin.

Lu Tong
Lu Tong, known as Jieyu the Madman of Chu (alternatively written as *Yu*, pronounced similarly to *remainder*), was fond of nurturing life. He consumed the fruit of the *nanglu* tree and the seeds of turnips. He wandered among famous mountains, and on Mount Emei in Shu, people saw him generation after generation. When Confucius traveled to Chu, Jieyu the Madman of Chu passed by his gate and sang:

“O phoenix, O phoenix,
How the Dao’s virtue has declined!
The age to come cannot be awaited,
The age gone by cannot be pursued.
When the world follows the Way,
The sage achieves;
When the world loses the Way,
The sage survives.
In this present time,
One barely escapes punishment.
Fortune is lighter than a feather,
Yet none know how to bear it;
Disaster is heavier than the earth,
Yet none know how to avoid it.
Enough, enough—
Approach others with virtue!
Perilous, perilous—
Mark the ground and hasten away!
Beware, beware,
Do not harm my path!
My path winds and turns,
Do not harm my feet!
Mountain trees bring ruin upon themselves,
Lamp oil consumes itself in flame.
Cinnamon is edible, so it is felled;
Lacquer is useful, so it is slashed.
All know the use of what is useful,
But none know the use of what is useless.”

Jianwu encountered the Madman Jieyu, who asked, “Zhongshi of the Sun, what would you have me tell you?” Jianwu replied, “He told me that a ruler of men, by issuing his own standards, models, principles, and measures, could make all obey and transform. Who would dare not listen?” The Madman Jieyu said, “This is deceitful virtue. In governing the world, it is like crossing the sea by digging a river or making a mosquito carry a mountain. The governance of the sage attends first to rectifying what is external and only then proceeds, ensuring that each matter is handled by one capable of it. Moreover, the high-flying bird avoids the harm of nets and arrows, while the mole digs deep beneath the sacred mound to escape the calamity of heavy digging. Yet these two creatures are deemed ignorant!”

Jianwu asked Lian Shu, “I heard Jieyu’s words—grand but without foundation, sweeping but unattainable. I was startled and terrified by his speech, which seemed as boundless as the Milky Way, vast and divergent, far from human sentiment.” Lian Shu asked, “What did he say?” Jianwu replied, “On the distant Mount Gushe, a spirit-person dwells. Their skin is like ice and snow, their grace like that of a maiden. They do not eat the five grains but inhale the wind and drink the dew. They ride the clouds and qi, mount flying dragons, and roam beyond the four seas. Their spirit is concentrated, causing things to be free of blight and the yearly harvests to ripen. I consider this mad and do not believe it.”

Lian Shu replied, “Indeed. The blind cannot partake in the spectacle of patterns and colors; the deaf cannot share in the sound of bells and drums. Is this not because their bodily forms are deaf and blind? Yet his words are but the folly of the moment—like yours. That person, that virtue, would regard the myriad things as a single whole, treating the world’s chaos as mere kindling. Who would exhaust themselves by taking the world as their concern?

That person would suffer no harm from things. Though great floods reach the heavens, they would not drown; though severe drought melts metal and stone, scorches mountains and earth, they would not feel the heat. Their dust and chaff, their husks and dregs, could yet mold and cast a Yao or Shun—who would deign to make things their business?”

Huangfu Mi said: “Jieyu tilled the fields himself. The King of Chu sent envoys bearing a hundred *yi* of gold and two teams of four horses to summon him, but he did not go.”

Qin Gao
Qin Gao was a man of Zhao. Skilled at playing the zither, he served as a retainer to King Kang of Song. Practicing the arts of Xuan and Peng, he wandered for over two hundred years in Jizhou and Zhuo Commandery (or *Ma* Commandery). Later, he took leave and entered the Zhuo River to retrieve a dragon’s offspring. He set a date with his disciples, who all purified themselves and waited by the water, preparing sacrificial offerings. As promised, he rode a red carp to the shrine, with tens of thousands observing. After a month, he entered the water and departed. Today, in Xuanzhou, there stands Qin Gao’s Fishing Platform.

Kou Xian
Kou Xian was a man of Song. He made his living by fishing, dwelling by the Sui River for over a hundred years. When he caught fish, he would sometimes release them, sometimes sell them, and sometimes eat them. He wore a cap and sash, delighted in planting lychee trees, and ate their flowers and fruit. Duke Jing of Song asked him about the Dao, but he refused to answer, so the duke had him killed. Decades later, he appeared at the gates of Song, playing the zither for days before leaving. The people of Song honored him in every household.

Prince Wang Qiao
Prince Wang, named Jin, styled Ziqiao, was also called Qiao, styled Zijin. King Ling of Zhou had thirty-eight sons, and Prince Jin was the crown prince. Born with divine marvels, he loved the Dao from childhood. Though he dwelled in the palace, he often went without food. In moments of silent reverie, immortals would descend to him, unbeknownst even to those at his side. He was fond of playing the sheng, producing the sounds of *luan* and phoenix, his music piercing the clouds and filling the palace. White *luan* and vermilion phoenixes would crane their necks and flap their wings, gathering to listen, while rare birds and strange fowl danced in the courtyards and terraces as if it were commonplace.

One day, Master Fuqiu of Mount Tiantai descended and taught him the essentials of the Dao, instructing him in the methods of refining stone essence, concealing golden radiance, and recording spirit-light. In the twenty-second year of King Ling’s reign, when the Luo River threatened to destroy the royal palace, Prince Jin repeatedly admonished the king, who refused to listen. Yielding to his nature, the prince withdrew to a separate palace, fasting and meditating on the Dao. Master Fuqiu secretly descended to his chamber, bestowed upon him divine medicine, and led him to ascend a high mountain.

Years later, his friend Lin Liang encountered Prince Jin on Mount Hou. The prince said to him, “On the seventh day of the seventh month, I shall ascend to heaven. You may gather with old friends to bid farewell.” On that day, Lin Liang and a crowd of officials and commoners climbed the mountain. They saw Prince Jin leave his carriage at the foot of the slope, drinking and feasting as before. Then, mounting a white crane, he waved his hand in farewell to the people of the world and ascended to heaven. Those near and far who witnessed it exclaimed, “Prince Wang has become an immortal!” He then declared, “Wang is my surname.” Thus, they took Wang as their clan name.

At that time, the assembled officials bowed in farewell. The horse he had ridden also bowed, then soared into the sky and departed. Today, the place is called Bowing Horse Gorge. After ascending, Prince Jin became the Right Assistant, overseeing the Five Peaks and serving the Morning Emperor. He was titled the Perfected One of Tongbai, governing the Golden Court Grotto-Heaven.

The *Chu Ci*’s *Li Sao* and *Tian Wen* state:
*“The white snake coiled, why linger in this hall?*
*How could one obtain the good medicine yet fail to guard it well?*
*The heavenly patterns shift and turn; yang departs, and one dies.*
*Why does the great bird cry out? Where has its body gone?”*

The commentary cites the *Immortal Biographies*: “Cui Wenzi studied the Dao under Prince Wang Qiao. Prince Qiao transformed into a white snake, and Wenzi held the medicine for him. Startled, Wenzi struck the snake with a halberd, causing the medicine to fall. Looking down, he saw Prince Qiao’s corpse. In an instant, it transformed into a great bird, which flew away crying.”

The *Record of Geography* states: “The central peak of the Western Mountains is the highest. At its summit lies the altar left by Prince Wang Qiao. It stands beside the ridge and now belongs to Longxing Prefecture.”

You Bozi
You Bozi was a guest of the Su clan of Zhou.

In winter he would wear only unlined garments, and in the height of summer, thickly padded robes. His appearance changed with the years, yet after decades he grew only more robust—none of his contemporaries could fathom it. Generation after generation, he came to offer sincere blessings to the descendants of the Su clan, who received his beneficent power.

**Gui Fu**
Gui Fu was a man of Xianglin. His complexion shifted from black to white, from yellow to red, and the people of Nanhai saw and revered him. He regularly consumed cassia and sunflower seeds, blending them with turtle brains into a thousand pellets, using ten *jin* of cassia. For generations, people witnessed him, and to this day, south of Jingzhou, cassia pellets remain.

**Xiaqiu Zhong**
Xiaqiu Zhong was a man of Yu. For over a hundred years, he sold medicine in Yu, and people considered him long-lived. Then, an earthquake struck, destroying his dwelling; Zhong and several dozen households in his village, their homes bordering the water, all collapsed. Zhong died, and some villagers cast his corpse into the water, taking his medicine to sell. Later, Zhong, clad in furs, appeared and approached them to retrieve his medicine. Those who had discarded him grew fearful and kowtowed, pleading for mercy. Zhong said, “I bear no grudge against you. I only wish to make people aware of who I am.” Later, he returned to Yu from the north, and the northerners called him the Banished Immortal.

**The Wine-Seller**
The Wine-Seller was a tavern keeper in the marketplace of Liang. His wine was always excellent, and he sold it daily for ten thousand coins. When he was driven away for some transgression, the tavern’s wine turned sour, and the owner grew impoverished. Many merchants in the Liang marketplace wished to marry their daughters to him and welcome him back. He came and went unpredictably, and over a hundred years later, he returned as the magistrate of Liang. He urged the people to plant more taro and vegetables, saying that in three years there would be a great famine—and indeed, it came to pass as he foretold, yet the people of Liang did not perish. Five years later, he removed his official seal and departed, and none knew where he went.

**Ren Guang**
Ren Guang was a man of Shangcai who was skilled in preparing cinnabar elixirs. He sold them in the capital’s streets and alleys for eighty-nine years before people realized he was the same Ren Guang of old. He spoke as he always had, and decades later, some elders still recognized him. Zhao Jianzi invited him to return with him. He often stayed on Baiti Mountain, and for three generations, none knew his whereabouts. The people of Jin regularly consumed his elixir.

**Xiao Shi**

The Xiao clan received its surname during the Yin dynasty. By the time of King Xuan of Zhou, there lived a man named Xiao Qin, whose wife was of the Wang clan. Both were wealthy and devoted to the Dao. Lord Lao once descended to their home, and in the seventeenth year of King Xuan’s reign, on the fifth day of the fifth month, a son was born—this was Xiao the Immortal.

From birth, he neglected his family’s affairs, wandering instead to Mount Zhongnan, where he encountered an extraordinary person who taught him the arts of longevity and instructed him in playing the xiao flute. Returning home, he told his parents of his wish to enter the Dao. Though they pressed him to marry, Xiao the Immortal said, “The stranger warned me against marriage, for I am destined to wed an emperor’s daughter.” His parents relented.

In the final years of King Xuan’s reign, the historical records fell into disarray. Xiao the Immortal, skilled in letters, composed accounts to supplement what the histories had missed. People called him “the Historian,” though this was not his true name—he was the third-born. He wandered near and far, eventually entering Qin. When Mengming’s army suffered defeat and retreated to Qin, the nobles gathered to mourn. Xiao stood respectfully beside Mengming. The Lord of Qin asked of the defeat, but Mengming could not answer; Xiao spoke in his stead with great detail. Mengming was spared punishment thanks to Xiao’s intervention.

After returning, Mengming once more let Xiao wander among mountains and rivers. At the time, the Lord of Qin had a daughter named Nongyu, who excelled at playing the sheng. Finding no suitable match, her father sought a sheng player to pair with her. Mengming, remembering Xiao’s eloquence, recommended him, and he was summoned. The Lord of Qin asked Xiao of his skills, and he replied, “I am skilled in the xiao.” The lord said, “My daughter favors the sheng—how can a xiao player suit her?” Xiao withdrew, having failed to meet expectations.

But the girl, listening from behind a screen, called out, “Let him play and see.” At the first note, a pure breeze arose; at the second, colored clouds gathered; at the third, phoenixes descended. The girl declared, “This is my husband—I wish to marry him.” Xiao said, “Let the lady also play the sheng.” She did so three times, and the same wonders occurred. Thus, Mengming acted as matchmaker, and Saisu as master of ceremonies, and a banquet was held in the Western Palace. No other music was performed—only the two played, their xiao and sheng in harmony. Before the piece ended, phoenixes descended, and the two immortals mounted them and departed.

The Lord of Qin was struck with sorrow and blamed Mengming. Mengming sent men in all directions to search for them. At the borders of Chu and Wu, someone saw on a western mountain’s high peak a man and woman playing the sheng and xiao, with phoenixes perched beside the xiao player. The messengers hurried to seek them, but they had already ascended into the heavens. Their whereabouts thereafter remain unknown—this is the broad outline of their tale.

The Red-Bearded Master

The Red-Bearded Master was seen by generations in Dengzhong. It is said he was once the fish warden under Duke Mu of Qin. He repeatedly foretold disasters and calamities—floods and droughts—within the borders of Deng, with scarcely a single error. Zhang Junfang sought him out as his teacher and studied under him. The Master had long favored eating pine nuts, asparagus root, and mineral grease. His teeth fell out and regrew; his white hair turned black again. He consumed morning radiance and ceased taking grain. Later, he dwelled at the foot of Mount Wu for over a decade before vanishing without a trace.

The Cock-Blessing Elder

The Cock-Blessing Elder was a man of Luo who lived at the foot of the northern mountain in Shixiang. He raised chickens for over a hundred years, each with its own name. His flock numbered over a thousand. At dusk, they roosted in the trees; by day, he released them to scatter. When he wished to gather them, he called their names, and they came, each breed returning separately. From selling chickens and their chicks, he amassed over a million coins, which he would then discard. He went to Wu, where he built a fish-rearing pond. Later, he ascended Mount Wu, and white cranes and peacocks often alighted beside him.

Cui Wenzi

Cui Wenzi was a man of Mount Tai from the Qin era. His family had long been devoted to the teachings of the Yellow Emperor and Laozi, and he lived at the foot of Mount Qian. Later, he crafted "Yellow Powder" and "Red Pills" at the shrine of Father Shi and sold medicines in the marketplace, claiming to be three hundred years old. When a pestilence later struck and tens of thousands perished, the magistrate beseeched him for aid. Cui Wenzi held a red brush, tied the Yellow Powder to it, and distributed it among the people. Those who drank the powder or took the pills were cured—tens of thousands in all. Later, he left for Shu to sell his medicines. Thus, the world treasured Cui Wenzi’s Red Pills and Yellow Powder, deeming them near to the divine.

Zhu Zhong

Zhu Zhong was a man of Kuaiji.

At the time of Empress Lü of the Han, an edict was issued offering rewards for three-inch pearls. Zhu Zhong, reading the proclamation, remarked, "Now your true worth is recognized." Taking a three-inch pearl, he journeyed to the palace and presented a memorial. The pearl’s quality surpassed all expectations, and he was immediately granted five hundred gold. Later, Princess Lu Yuan privately offered seven hundred gold to acquire the pearl from him, whereupon Zhu Zhong presented a four-inch pearl. Once delivered to the palace, he departed without delay. The emperor then issued an edict summoning him from Kuaiji, but his whereabouts remained unknown.

During the reign of Emperor Jing, he reappeared, offering dozens of three-inch pearls before vanishing again, leaving no trace of his destination.

Dongfang Shuo

Dongfang Shuo, styled Manqian, was a native of Yanci in Pingyuan. Orphaned three days after his birth, he was later found wandering in the marshes when a yellow-browed immortal pointed at him and said, "This is my elder brother. I abstain from grain to refine my qi, returning to wash my marrow once every three thousand years and shedding my skin and hair once every two thousand. I have already undergone three marrow-washings and three skin-sheddings."

When Emperor Wu of Han first ascended the throne, he summoned men of talent and learning from across the realm, offering them positions without regard to rank. Scholars from all directions submitted memorials on governance, numbering in the thousands from the streets and alleys alone. Those deemed unworthy were promptly dismissed.

Dongfang Shuo, upon his arrival, presented a memorial that read: "Your servant Shuo lost his parents in infancy and was raised by his elder brother and sister-in-law. At thirteen, I studied writing for three winters, and my mastery of literature and history sufficed for all needs. At fifteen, I learned swordsmanship; at sixteen, I studied the *Book of Songs*, reciting two hundred and twenty thousand words. At nineteen, I mastered the military strategies of Sun and Wu, the art of battle formations, and the teachings of war drums—also reciting two hundred and twenty thousand words. In total, your servant has committed four hundred and forty thousand words to memory, and I have long followed the words of Zilu. At twenty, I stand nine feet and three inches tall, my eyes like hanging pearls, my teeth like strung cowries. I am as brave as Meng Ben, as swift as Qing Ji, as upright as Bao Shu, and as trustworthy as Weisheng. With such qualities, I am fit to serve as a great minister to the Son of Heaven." Your servant Shuo, risking death, bows twice to make this known.

Shuo’s memorial was immodest, filled with self-praise, yet the emperor admired his boldness and ordered him to await summons at the Public Carriage Office. His stipend was meager, and he was not granted an audience for some time. Later, Shuo teased the court dwarfs, saying, "The emperor believes you lot are of no use to the state. You cannot till the fields or labor as others do; you cannot govern the people when placed in office; and you are unfit for military service or combat."

"You are of no use to the state’s needs, merely consuming food and clothing—now the emperor intends to execute all of you." The dwarfs were seized with terror and wept bitterly. Shuo instructed them, "When the emperor passes by, kowtow and beg for mercy." After a short while, word came that the emperor was approaching, and the dwarfs wailed, knocking their heads to the ground. The emperor asked what was the matter, and they replied, "Dongfang Shuo says Your Majesty intends to kill us all." The emperor summoned Shuo and demanded, "Why are you frightening the dwarfs?" Shuo replied, "Your servant speaks in life, and I shall speak in death. These dwarfs stand barely over three feet tall, yet each receives a sack of grain and two hundred and forty coins. If the dwarfs are sated to the point of death, your servant starves to the point of death. If my words are of use, I humbly beg for different treatment; if they are of no use, dismiss me—do not let me merely consume the price of grain in Chang’an." The emperor roared with laughter and thereafter ordered Shuo to await summons at the Gate of the Golden Horse, gradually drawing him into closer favor.

The emperor often had several masters of divination play at *shefu*, placing a gecko beneath a bowl and having them guess what it was—none could hit the mark. Shuo volunteered, "Your servant once studied the *Book of Changes*; allow me to try." He then arranged the trigrams in a separate chamber and answered, "I believe it is a dragon, yet it has no horns; I believe it is a snake, yet it has feet—it must be either a gecko or a skink." The emperor said, "Excellent." He then had Shuo guess other objects in succession, and each time Shuo was correct, the emperor rewarded him with silk.

At that time, there was a favored performer named Guo Sheren, whose wit and humor knew no bounds. Whatever Sheren asked, Shuo would answer in an instant, his responses shifting and cunning, leaving none able to outmatch him. The courtiers were astonished, and the emperor appointed Shuo as a Gentleman of the Palace, whereupon he gained the emperor’s favor and affection.

Later, the emperor sought to strengthen ties with the King of Yue and dispatched Shuo to sail across the sea in search of treasures, instructing him to return within a year. Yet Shuo took two years to return. Before his arrival, the emperor asked his attendants, "Shuo has been gone so long—who in the realm is skilled in divination?" They replied, "Only Sun Bin is most proficient in the *Book of Changes*." The emperor then changed into commoner’s clothes and, taking two bolts of silk with his attendants, went to knock at Bin’s door. Bin came out to receive them and offered them seats, not recognizing the emperor. After casting the hexagrams, Bin realized who his visitor was and, trembling with fear, rose to bow. The emperor said, "I have come seeking something—do not speak of it." Bin replied, "Your Majesty has not come to divine about other matters, but about Dongfang Shuo. Shuo will arrive in seven days. Even now, he is at sea, facing west and summoning the waters with a great sigh. When he arrives, I beg you to question him."

On the appointed day, Shuo returned. The emperor asked, "You promised to return in a year—why has it been two?" Shuo replied, "I dared not delay, but the treasure was not yet found." The emperor said, "Seven days ago, you were at sea, facing west and summoning the waters with a great sigh—why?" Shuo answered, "I sighed over no other matter: it was because Sun Bin did not recognize the Son of Heaven and sat facing him as an equal." The emperor was deeply astonished by this.

Later, Shuo wrote to a friend: "Do not let the dusty net of fame and the bonds of reputation ensnare you. Laugh freely, cast off the Ten Continents and Three Isles, and together let us gather jade-like herbs, swallow the radiance of the sun and moon, and ascend lightly into the heavens." The Queen Mother of the West once pointed to Shuo and said to the emperor, "This is the little boy from my neighborhood, ever full of wit and mischief—he has come three times to steal my peaches. Long ago, he was an immortal official under the Supreme Lord of the Dao. The Supreme Lord sent him to Mount Fangzhang, but he did nothing but play, recklessly stirring thunder and lightning, whipping up waves and winds, causing flood dragons to crawl on land and mountains to crumble into the sea. The Supreme Lord banished him to the mortal world, but recently the Two Immortals of Jinhua and the Nine Doubts Lord Chen begged for his pardon."

The emperor then realized Shuo was no ordinary man and came to believe in the existence of immortals throughout the world. Yet he indulged in sensual pleasures without restraint and never ceased his campaigns of conquest. After six years of studying the sacred texts, his understanding deepened, and he believed the divine had truly descended, certain he would transcend the mortal realm. He built towers and palaces, exhausting the people, and disregarded every subtle admonition of the Queen Mother and the profound warnings of the Lady of Supreme Primordial. The two immortals never returned. In the second year of the *Taichu* era, the Pavilion of Cypress Beams burned, and the *True Form Chart*, *Six Jia and Five Thearchs Spirit-Flight Twelve Matters Divine Radiance Scripture* were all lost in the flames.

Yet earlier, the emperor had received the *Chart of the Five Peaks* from the Queen Mother and bestowed it upon Dong Zhongjun, and from the Lady of Supreme Primordial, he had received the *Six Jia* and given it to Li Shaojun. These texts thus circulated in the world. After the books were burned, the emperor realized he had lost the Dao. Later, Shuo one day mounted a dragon and ascended into the heavens.

Liu Xiang’s *Biographies of the Immortals* states: By the time of Emperor Zhao, Dongfang Shuo was sometimes called a divine being, sometimes an ordinary man. He acted with varying degrees of depth and restraint, sometimes speaking earnestly, sometimes in jest—none could fathom his intent. By the beginning of Emperor Xuan’s reign, he abandoned his post as Gentleman of the Palace to escape the chaos of the age, leaving his official cap in his quarters before being carried away by the wind. Later, he was seen in Kuaiji, selling medicine by the Five Lakes. The wise suspected he was the essence of the Year Star.

The *Miscellaneous Records of the Western Capital* records Dongfang Shuo as saying: "No one in the world knows me—only the Grand Historian understands." Emperor Wu summoned the Grand Historian and asked, "All the stars are in their places—why is the Year Star not visible?" **Xiu Yanggong**—Xiu Yanggong was a man of Wei.

Within the stone chamber of Mount Huayin hung a suspended rock, its surface worn hollow where a couch had stood outside it, yet the stone itself remained unmoved. At times, he gathered yellow essence to eat. Later, his mastery of the Dao became known to the throne. Emperor Jing of Han honored him, keeping him in the royal residence for several years, though the Dao could not be obtained from him.

One day, the emperor asked, *"When will you speak, Master?"*
Soon after, the man transformed atop a grove into a white stone ram. Upon its flank, he inscribed: *"Xiu Yanggong bids farewell to the Son of Heaven."* Later, a true stone ram appeared upon the Tower of Spiritual Communication. The ram then vanished, its whereabouts unknown.

Your servant Daoyi says: *The* Daodejing *states: "Between heaven and earth, is it not like a bellows? Still yet unyielding, moving yet ever-producing. Excessive speech hastens exhaustion—better to guard the center."* Xiu Yanggong had attained this. Moreover, transforming into a white stone ram and inscribing his flank—*"Xiu Yanggong bids farewell to the Son of Heaven"*—reveals his unflagging gratitude for the emperor’s recognition, the profundity of his Dao, and the fulfillment of his duty.

**Ji Qiujun**
Ji Qiujun was a Daoist of Mount Tai. During the reign of Emperor Wu of Han, he was rewarded for his mastery of the Dao and Way of Guarding Life, his white hair returning to black and his fallen teeth regrowing. Later, he departed.

When the emperor journeyed to Mount Tai, Ji Qiujun donned a *zhangfu* cap and yellow robes, cradling a zither as he came to greet him. *"Do not ascend, Your Majesty,"* he warned, *"or you will injure your toes."* After several *li*, the emperor’s left foot indeed broke. He concealed the injury, offering sacrifices before returning. A shrine was erected for Ji Qiujun, with a hundred households granted to maintain it in perpetuity.

**Duzi**
Duzi was a man of Ye.

Ji Qiujun spent his early years on Black Mountain, gathering pine nuts and *fuling* mushrooms to consume as elixirs. After several hundred years, he would sometimes appear youthful, sometimes aged, sometimes handsome, sometimes plain—revealing himself as an immortal.

He often visited the Yang family in the capital to purchase wine. The Yangs had a daughter whose brows were joined and whose ears were slender and long; all who saw her marveled, calling her a celestial being. One day, Duzi arrived leading a yellow calf, and the Yang girl took a liking to him. She devoted herself to serving him. When she followed Duzi out to gather peaches and plums, they returned after a single night, bearing fruits of extraordinary sweetness. The townspeople trailed them, but upon leaving the gate, they seized the calf’s ears and fled—none could catch them.

Later, Duzi reappeared in the marketplace, remaining for decades before departing. He was later seen beneath Pan Mountain, selling peaches and plums in winter.

**Qi Longming**
Qi Longming was a man of Huntíng. At twenty, he found over ten dragon hatchlings in a pond, resembling geckos. He raised them, feeding them and building a thatched hut to guard them. As the dragons grew, they gradually departed. Over fifty years later, a flood destroyed his hut and carried them away.

One day, a man riding a dragon arrived at Huntíng and declared, *"I am the grandson of Feng Bochang. If this dragon is not released within five hundred *li*, it will surely die."* Those who heard him dismissed it as a demon’s ramblings. By the eighth month, a flood indeed came, drowning tens of thousands.

**Zhuzhu**
Zhuzhu’s origins were unknown. He ascended Rock Mountain with a Daoist and said, *"Here lies cinnabar—enough to yield tens of thousands of *jin*."* The prefectural magistrate, learning of this, sealed the mountain, but the cinnabar flowed out like flying fire. Thus, they permitted Zhuzhu to retrieve it.

Magistrate Zhang Junming consumed the cinnabar for three years and obtained divine cinnabar as light as drifting snow. After five years of ingestion, he gained the ability to fly and departed with Zhuzhu.

**The Old Man in Deerskin**
The Old Man in Deerskin was a man of Miaochuan. In his youth, he served as a minor clerk in the prefectural office, skilled in carpentry—his hands could craft any implement with precision.

Atop Mount Cen lay a sacred spring, inaccessible to men. The clerk petitioned the prefect, requesting thirty carpenters with axes and adzes. They constructed a revolving wheel and suspended pavilions, their ingenuity unbounded. Within days, a laddered path took shape on all four sides. At the summit, they built a shrine and lodgings, where he remained, severing two of the paths for his own seclusion.

He ate *zhi* herbs and drank from the sacred spring, dwelling thus for nearly seventy years. When the Miaoshui River rose in three surges, he summoned his clansmen and household—over sixty in number—and bade them ascend halfway up the mountain. The flood submerged the entire commandery, drowning tens of thousands.

The clerk then took his leave, sending his kin back down the mountain. Donning a deerskin cap, he departed, returning to the pavilion. Over a hundred years later, he was seen selling medicine in the marketplace.

**The Stream Father**
The Stream Father was a man of Lü in Nan Commandery.

At his mountain dwelling, there lived an immortal who often stayed in his home. Once, when purchasing melons, the immortal taught him to refine the melon seeds, mixing them with cassia, *gui* stalks, and *zhushi* fruit for storage, then sharing them equally to eat. After over twenty years, he gained the ability to run swiftly and ascend mountains or enter water. More than a hundred years later, he took up solitary residence atop the mountain. He would call down to the elders by the stream and speak of matters from the time of his birth.

**Mountain Chart**
Mountain Chart was a man of Longxi. In his youth, he loved riding horses, but one threw him, breaking his leg in the mountains. A Daoist taught him to take realgar, *danggui*, *qianghuo*, *duhuo*, and *kushen*; after a year, he lost his appetite for food, and his illness was cured, his body lightened. The Daoist questioned him, saying, "The Five Peaks have sent me to gather herbs from the famous mountains. If you follow me, I can make you immortal." Mountain Chart followed him for over sixty years. One day, he returned home to observe mourning for his mother. After a year, he departed again, and none knew where he went.

**Valley Spring**
Valley Spring was a man of Liyang. During the reign of Emperor Cheng of Han, he served as a Gentleman. He died of an epidemic, yet his body did not stiffen.
