His family held the funeral and wore mourning clothes but dared not seal the coffin. Three years later, he was seen sitting at the county gate, wearing his cap and sash. The townspeople were astonished, and his family came to fetch him, but he refused to return. When they opened the coffin, they found only clothes, no corpse. He stayed at the gate for three nights, then left for Chang’an, stopping at the Heng Gate. People recognized him and pursued him, but he departed again. He went to Mount Taibai, where he established a shrine on the mountain and would occasionally come to stay the night in his own shrine.

**Yin Sheng**
Yin Sheng often begged in the markets of Chang’an. The townspeople grew weary of him, and some even splashed excrement on his clothes, yet his garments remained unstained as before. The local officials heard of this and tried to arrest and beat him, binding him in stocks, but he reappeared in the market. They attempted to kill him, and only then did he leave. The household of the man who had splashed excrement collapsed on its own, killing over ten people.

Your servant Daoyi says: The Way of Yin Sheng was established for the destitute and helpless of all generations. That the market-dweller’s household collapsed was because their evil had reached its limit, and calamity befell them. Observe how they took pleasure in cruelty, humiliating the lonely and poor—such was the depth of their inhumanity. As for Yin Sheng, he merely used their deeds to reveal his transformation; it was not Yin Sheng who harmed them. Likewise, the hidden sorrow of Duke Cao of Wei or the fallen beggar Wang Dunjia—all share this intent. The *Daodejing* says: "Thus the sage constantly excels in saving people, and so abandons no one." Is this not the Way of Yin Sheng?

**Ziying**

**Ziying**

Ziying was a man of Shu Village. Skilled in diving to catch fish, he once caught a red carp. Admiring its fine color, he took it home and placed it in his pond, feeding it rice and grain for many days. Within a year, it grew over a *zhang* in length, sprouted horns, and grew wings. Ziying, astonished, bowed and paid his respects. The fish spoke: "I have come to fetch you. Mount my back, and I shall carry you to ascend to heaven." Just then, a great rain fell. Ziying climbed onto the fish’s back, and together they soared away. Year after year, he would return to his old home, eating and drinking with his wife and children, before the fish came again to fetch him. This continued for seventy years. Thus, in the gates and households of Wu, images of the divine fish were made, and a shrine to Ziying was established.

**Fujianzi**
Fujianzi—his origins unknown—was a man often seen in Ju, coming and going along the seashore. Among the various shrines, there were three immortals who gambled with melons. Fujianzi saw a magistrate carrying several dozen yellow and white melons. The immortals told him to close his eyes, and when he opened them, he found himself on Fangzhang Mountain, which lies south of Penglai Mountain. Thereafter, he would travel to Ju, bringing back treasures, pearls, and jade from Fangzhang Mountain to sell. After some time, one day he shaved his head and donned ochre robes, his appearance grown old. When asked, he said it was because he had taken things from the temple. Several years later, his appearance became youthful and fine again, his temples as they had been in former days.

**Wen Bin**
Wen Bin was a man of Taiqiu Village.

Wen Bin made his living by selling straw sandals, taking wives many times, only to abandon them after several decades. Later, one of his former wives had grown old in longevity, over ninety years of age, when she saw Bin again—now robust and youthful. At another time, the old woman bowed to Bin, weeping in gratitude. Bin said, "You should not come on the first morning of the new year. Might you meet me at the western shrine of the village pavilion?" The old woman, though aged, traveled over ten *li* at night with her children and grandchildren, sitting in the shrine to await him. After a moment, Bin arrived and exclaimed in surprise, "Do you pursue the Dao? I knew you would come." He continued, "Before, I would not have left you. Now, I will teach you to take chrysanthemum flowers, *difu* (earth skin), mistletoe from mulberry trees, and pine nuts to replenish your *qi*." The old woman, too, grew strong again and was said to have lived another hundred years.

**Shangqiu Zixu**
Shangqiu Zixu was a man of Gaoyi. He enjoyed herding pigs and playing the *yu* reed pipe. At seventy, he had not taken a wife yet showed no signs of aging. The people of his village found him extraordinary and sought to learn the Dao from him. He told them simply to eat the roots of *mu* (wood) and *jupu* (sweet flag), drink water, and they would neither hunger nor age. Thus, he was seen across generations for over three hundred years. When nobles and wealthy families questioned him and took his remedy, they could not persist for even a year, their hearts growing weary and negligent. They claimed he must be hiding some secret technique.

**Zizhu**
Zizhu spoke in the Chu dialect with a delicate voice. His origins were unknown.

He journeyed to the court of the King of Jiangdu of Han, declaring: *"Master Yu hired me as a retainer, yet for three hundred years I have not been released from service."* The king took him for a madman. When asked where the master resided, he replied: *"On the summit of Longmei Mountain."* The king dispatched an official to ascend the peak, where they found Master Yu—his body covered in hair, his ears broad, his hair unbound as he plucked a zither. Upon seeing Zizhu, he bowed his head. The official delivered the king’s message, to which the master said: *"This is Zizhu, the ninth-generation descendant of my former neighbor. Moreover, I foresee that three women in your household will die violently—do not meddle in my affairs."* As his words ended, a great wind arose, and the official fled down the mountain. By the time he returned to the palace, three women had indeed been killed. The king then offered sacrifices of the three livestock and established a shrine there.

**Tao Angong**
Tao Angong was a master smelter of Liu’an. One day, as he repeatedly stoked the furnace, the flames suddenly surged upward, and a purple *qi* pierced the heavens. Angong prostrated himself beneath the furnace, pleading for mercy. In an instant, a vermilion phoenix alighted upon the cooling metal and spoke: *"Angong, Angong, the cold metal now communes with Heaven. On the seventh day of the seventh month, a crimson dragon will come to receive you."* When the appointed day arrived, a crimson dragon descended amid a great rain. Angong mounted it and soared toward a city in the southeast. Tens of thousands from the town gathered to see him off, bidding him a final farewell.

**Chifu**
Chifu was a man of the Ba frontier.

Chifu served as the registrar of the Green Rooster Shrine. Skilled in refining cinnabar and saltpeter through water tempering, he consumed the elixir for thirty years, reverting to a youthful state—his hair and beard all turned crimson. Decades later, he ascended Mount Hua to gather *Yu’s surplus grain* for sustenance, selling it along the Cangwu and Dian Rivers. The legacy passed through generations, and upon his palm remained the mark of a crimson axe.

**Hu Zixian**
Hu Zixian was a diviner beneath the watchtower of Hanzhong. Aged over a hundred, on the eve of his departure, he called to an old tavern woman: *"Hasten your preparations—I shall accompany you to join the Prince of Zhongling."* That night, an immortal arrived bearing two straw dogs. Hu Zixian took one, while the tavern woman mounted the other; both transformed into dragons, ascending Mount Huayin. From the mountain’s heights, he would often cry out: *"Zixian—here stands the tavern keeper’s mother!"*

**The Master of the Mirror-Load**
The Master of the Mirror-Load’s origins were unknown, though his speech resembled that of the Yan and Dai regions. He would carry a mirror-grinding frame through the markets of Wu, polishing mirrors for a single coin. As he worked, he would ask the owner if they suffered any ailments, then offer a purple pill—all who took it recovered. For decades, he did this, and when a great plague struck, he went door to door distributing medicine, saving tens of thousands without accepting payment. The people of Wu then recognized him as a true immortal. Later, he climbed a sheer cliff on Mount Wu, dangling medicine from its edge to give to those below. Before departing, he told them: *"I return to Penglai. For your sake, I shall send down divine water from the cliff’s peak."* Thereafter, a milky stream flowed daily from the stone crevice, and many who drank it were cured of their illnesses. Over ten shrines were erected in his honor.

**Ruan Qiu**

Ruan Qiu was a Daoist of Mount Sui. Clad in furs with unbound hair, his ears measured seven inches, and his mouth bore no teeth. He could walk four hundred *li* in a day. For over a hundred years, he cultivated scallions and leeks in the mountains, unknown to others. At times, he descended to sell medicine. Zhu Huang of Guangyang suffered from a virulent ailment, and Qiu gave him a seven-ingredient remedy, expelling the Three Corpses. Later, he entered Mount Fuyang with Zhu Huang, who then recognized him as a divine immortal.

Zhu Huang was a man of Guangling. From youth, he suffered from a virulent ailment and sought out Ruan Qiu of Mount Sui. Qiu took pity on him, saying: *"You shall expel the Three Corpses from your abdomen—this is the work of a true immortal. You may transcend the world."* Huang replied: *"When my illness is cured, I shall serve you as a disciple for thirty years, never daring to return on my own."* Qiu gave Huang a seven-ingredient remedy, instructing him to take nine pills daily. After a hundred days, his ailment discharged in quantities like liver and spleen—several *dou* in volume. Nurtured for several decades, he grew robust, his mind and spirit daily more luminous. Qiu gave him the *Yellow Court Scripture* of Lord Lao, commanding him to read it thrice daily. Once he mastered it, he could grasp its meaning.

Ruan Qiu then entered Floating Sun Mountain’s Jade Maiden Shrine with Huang, where they remained for eighty years. When they returned to their former dwelling, Huang’s white hair had turned black, and his temples now grew three *chi* longer. He visited his family to take meals, staying for several years before departing again. Thus he remained until the end of Emperor Wu’s reign.

**Lingyang Ziming**
Lingyang Ziming was a native of Quan Village. Fond of fishing, he once hooked a white dragon in Whirling Creek. Terrified, Ziming untied the hook, bowed, and released it. Later, he caught a white fish whose belly contained a text teaching him the method of ingesting and refining elixirs. Ziming then ascended Mount Huang, where he gathered the Five Mineral Resins and boiled them in water. After three years of ingestion, a dragon came to welcome him away, and he dwelled on Mount Lingyang—now part of Xuanzhou—for over a hundred years. The mountain rose more than a thousand *zhang* above the earth. He would call down to people below, bidding them ascend halfway up the slope, saying, *"The one named Zi’an from the creek will come. Ask him if my fishing rod still remains."*

More than twenty years later, Ziming died. People buried him on the mountain, whereupon a yellow crane alighted on the trees above his tomb and cried out, *"Zi’an!"* At Mount Yellow Crane in Wuchang stands the Yellow Crane Tower. The *Qi Records* state: *"The immortal Zi’an rode a yellow crane past this place."*

The man known as Xingzi claimed to be a native of Shu. Fond of hunting with dogs, he was skilled in judging their qualities. One day, his dog ran into a mountain cave, and Xingzi followed. After more than ten nights of travel, they had traversed several hundred *li*. Emerging at the summit, he found terraces, halls, and palaces, their verdant pines towering in dense array, while immortal officials and guards stood in solemn vigil. There, he saw his former wife, who was washing fish. She gave him a sealed talisman and instructed him to return and deliver it to Magistrate Qiao of Chengdu. When the magistrate opened the seal, he found fish roe inside. Placing them in a pond and raising them for a year, they all transformed into dragons. Xingzi then returned the talisman to the mountain, whereupon his dog’s fur turned a deeper red, and it grew long wings. For over a hundred years, the dog accompanied Xingzi as he came and went, eventually remaining on the mountain while occasionally descending to protect his clan. The people of Shu erected a shrine at the cave’s entrance, where the sounds of drums, flutes, and heralding voices were often heard. For dozens of *li* to the southwest, the people jointly worshipped there.

Mu Yu was a native of Nanheping Township in Julu. His mother, poor and of low status, worked as a midwife. Once, while attending a birth, she saw the newborn open its eyes, gaze at its mother, and laugh aloud. Terrified, she dreamed that night of a tall figure in a grand cap and crimson sash standing guard over the child, who said, *"I am the Lord of Life. I shall repay your kindness by allowing your son, Mu Yu, to attain immortality."* The mother secretly took note of this. Later, when she gave birth to a son, she named him Mu Yu. The child she had delivered turned fifteen, when one night a carriage and horses arrived to take him away. Passing by the mother’s home, he called out, *"Mu Yu, come drive for me!"* And so they departed together.

More than twenty years later, crows and sparrows would daily bring two or three fish and place them upon the mother’s doorstep. She concealed this and told no one, selling the fish instead, and only revealed the matter after thirty years had passed. The mother lived to be a hundred years old before she finally passed away.

Xuan Su

Xuan Su claimed to be a native of Hejian. He wore clothing made from bayu fiber and sold medicine in the marketplace, charging one coin for seven pills, which effectively cured all manner of illnesses. The King of Hejian suffered from a carbuncle, so he purchased the medicine and took it, whereupon more than ten snakes emerged from his body. When the king inquired about the medicine’s nature, Su replied, *"Your Majesty’s carbuncle was the accumulated misfortune of six generations descending upon you—it was not something you brought upon yourself. Once, you released a lactating doe, and your benevolence moved Heaven, which is why I was sent to you."* An elderly retainer in the king’s household said his father had known Su in his own time.

Su cast no shadow. The king summoned him and placed him in the sunlight, confirming that he indeed had no shadow. The king then offered his daughter in marriage to Su, but that night, Su vanished. Later, he was seen at the foot of Mount Chang.

*Comprehensive Mirror of Daoist Realization, Attaining the Way* (Volume Three) concludes here.

**Editorial Principles of *The Mirror of Immortals***

1. The first section lists the Three Pure Ones, the Five Venerable Lords, and other lofty perfected beings, comprising five volumes. Each entry is supported by scriptural citations, presenting the essential framework to demonstrate reverence for Heaven and the exalted Sovereign, titled *Outer Annals of the Comprehensive Mirror*.

2. *The Comprehensive Mirror of Daoist Realization* begins with the Three Sovereigns of high antiquity and extends to the end of the Song dynasty. The accounts of immortals and perfected beings who attained the Way were gathered from imperial archives, verified against classical histories and Daoist hagiographies, and compiled after careful collation. Where necessary, redundancies were trimmed and essentials preserved, with no arbitrary additions from the compiler’s own hand, so as to ensure credibility for posterity and modestly emulate the principle of "transmission, not creation."

3. There are five grades of immortal cultivation and three stages of elixir refinement. Once one has verified the truth, the wondrous applications are unfathomable, and thus they are recorded in a unified manner, without attempting to distinguish differences in superiority or inferiority.

4. The biographies of various immortals record terms such as *ascending in flight*, *soaring aloft*, *rising to Heaven*, *lightly ascending*, *stretching upward*, *ascending in flight*, *attaining perfection*, *liberation through transformation*, *transformation through release*, *feathered transformation*, *concealed transformation*, *manifest transformation*, *manifest death*, and *manifest passing*—all of which are transcribed exactly as they appear in the original sources, without alteration.

5. Where the practices of perfected immortals align with the *Five Thousand Words of the Dao and Virtue*, commentary is occasionally provided to extol their excellence, demonstrating the supreme value of venerating the Dao and Virtue. Later scholars should take these as models.

6. The arrangement of this work does not strictly adhere to chronological order, but rather presents a general sequence. If a learned scholar is able to investigate and correct it, such emendations would be most welcome.

1. On the Errors in the *Comprehensive Mirror for Aid in Government*’s Chronological Tables
   – Examining the Zhou dynasty: King Li reigned for thirty-six years, and the Duke of Zhou and Duke of Shao administered the realm jointly for fourteen years, totaling fifty years. Yet the *Comprehensive Mirror*’s chronological tables record King Li’s reign as forty years and the joint regency as fifty, amounting to ninety years—an error that inserts forty extra years. How could ministers assisting a young sovereign possibly hold power for fifty years before returning governance? According to Liu Shu’s *Outer Annals*, King Li did not reign for forty years, and the text states that in the fourteenth year of the joint regency, King Li died in exile at Zhi—there is no record of a fifty-year regency. This is the error of the compiler of the chronological tables. Moreover, the lifespans of the Zhou kings vary, and when their reigns are summed, they total nine hundred twenty-seven years. Upon examination, this is because an entire cycle of the sexagenary calendar—fifty-four years in Zhou and six in Shang—has been erroneously included, causing the sequence of sexagenary years to be misaligned. Liu Shu’s *Outer Annals* also concludes, based on the *Three Sequences Calendar*, that the Western and Eastern Zhou together spanned slightly over eight hundred years, never exceeding nine hundred. This further demonstrates the clear errors in later chronological tables. From the first year of Emperor Yao of Tang upward, though various scholars’ records of imperial reigns differ, none have mistakenly included an entire sexagenary cycle—let this pass without further discussion. From the first year of Qin’s Yuan downward, the records align with those of other scholars.

2. Upon the completion of the *Comprehensive Mirror of Perfected Immortals Who Embodied the Dao*, the chronology follows the chronological tables in Xie Guanfu’s *Veritable Records of the Primordial Origin*, aiming to emulate the structure of the *Comprehensive Mirror for Aid in Government*. In compiling the *Comprehensive Mirror of Perfected Immortals Who Transmitted the Dao*, the first task was to verify the chronology for the benefit of future scholars. Just as the *Comprehensive Mirror for Aid in Government* begins with King Weilie of Zhou and the *Comprehensive Mirror of Buddhism* follows suit by starting with King Zhao of Zhou, the Daoist tradition, adopting the format of these two works, appropriately begins with Tang Yangjia of Yin. This is because Lord Lao descended from the Great Clarity Realm in the seventeenth year of Yangjia’s reign, incarnating in the womb of the Mysterious and Wondrous Jade Maiden. However, upon examining Liu Shu’s *Outer Annals of the Comprehensive Mirror*, Shao Yong’s *Book of the World’s Evolution*, and the chronologies of imperial reigns recorded in Daoist scriptures, discrepancies emerge. These three sources differ because the lengths of reigns they record vary, leading to mismatches in the sequence of years and stems-and-branches. Liu and Shao were both eminent Confucian scholars of antiquity, yet their findings diverge, and even Confucians cannot definitively determine which is correct. Some say Liu’s work focuses on thoroughly investigating order and chaos rather than precise chronology, while Shao’s book, which clarifies mathematical patterns, emphasizes chronological accuracy—perhaps Shao’s is the correct version. If so, does Liu’s work rely on historical records, and are those records false? Others argue that the remote past cannot be verified, and this view is well-founded. In compiling the *Comprehensive Mirror of Embodied Dao*, it is fitting to rely solely on the chronologies recorded in Daoist scriptures, such as the chronological tables in Xie Guanfu’s *Veritable Records of the Primordial Origin*, which have already been meticulously verified. Later compilers should have no doubts on this matter.

---

**Scroll Four of the *Comprehensive Mirror of Perfected Immortals Who Embodied the Dao***

**The Heavenly Perfected Sovereign**
The Heavenly Perfected Sovereign’s origins in the Dao are unknown, yet he was one who cultivated the utmost Dao in a prior kalpa. His body stood nine feet tall, and his entire frame was covered in dark, shaggy hair over a foot long. During the Yellow Emperor’s time, he dwelled beneath the sheer yin cliffs of Mount Emei, residing in a house of azure jade with a throne of gold, draped in patterned silk banners and burning the finest incense. His attendants were immortal youths and jade maidens, and three seated guests, all addressed as *Celestial Immortal Kings of the Great Clarity*. The Yellow Emperor bowed twice and inquired of the Dao, receiving the scripture of the *Five Teeth and Three Ones*. Later, on Mount Emei, he bestowed the *Supreme Purity Numinous Treasure Scripture for the Salvation of Humanity* upon the Yellow Emperor, and on the Terrace of Pastoral Virtue, he transmitted it to Emperor Yu. Another account states that north of the Min River in Shu’s Mount Min lies Mother of Mercy Mountain, where the Heavenly Perfected Sovereign cultivated the Dao. The mountain holds Dragon Pond, in which swim gold, silver, copper, and iron fish, each matching its color. Those who consume them find their taste like dried ginger, and eating them confers longevity—they are called *flesh mushrooms*. One Dragon Pond lies on the mountain, another in the sky, both as clear as mirrors, unstained by the slightest impurity. If a withered leaf or twig falls upon them, a five-colored phoenix swiftly carries it away.

**Bai Shisheng**
Bai Shisheng was a disciple of the Central Yellow Elder and had already lived over two thousand years by the time of Peng Zu. He refused to cultivate the path of ascending as an immortal, content merely with avoiding death. He did not forsake the pleasures of the human world, and his practice centered on the elixir of golden fluid. Initially, troubled by poverty and low status, he could not obtain the elixir. For over a decade, he raised pigs and herded sheep, practicing frugality until he amassed ten thousand gold pieces, with which he purchased and consumed the elixir. He often boiled white stones for sustenance, hence his residence on White Stone Mountain earned him the name *Bai Shisheng*. He occasionally ate dried meat and drank wine, sometimes consuming grains, and could walk three to four hundred *li* in a day. His complexion appeared no older than thirty. By nature, he enjoyed paying homage and meditating on spirits, as well as reading immortal scriptures and the *Great Simplicity Transmission*. Peng Zu asked him, “Why not consume the elixir and ascend to heaven?” He replied, “There is no greater joy than this world. The only concern is avoiding old age and death. Heaven is filled with exalted beings, and serving them is more arduous than life here.” Thus, people called him the *Reclusive Leisurely Immortal*, for he was not eager to ascend to heaven, seek an immortal office, or pursue fame.

**Wang Ni**

The ancient immortal Lord Wang Ni was a disciple of the Old Lord. He attained the Dao during the eras of Fuxi and Shennong. The Yellow Emperor encountered him and received from him the essentials of the Way. Through the reigns of Shaohao and Zhuanxu, he often wandered among mortals. Before the time of Emperor Yao, he served as the teacher of Nie Que, teaching him the art of "flying steps." Even in the eras of Yao and Shun, there were still those who saw him, until one day he ascended to heaven.

**Master Hong Ya**

Master Hong Ya was, according to some, Ling Lun, a minister of the Yellow Emperor, who attained the Dao and departed as an immortal, bearing the surname Zhang. Others say that by the time of Emperor Yao, he had already lived for three thousand years. During the reign of Emperor Wu of Han, a man named Wei Dushi entered Mount Hua in search of his father, Shuqing. He found Shuqing on a sheer cliff, playing a game of *bo* on a stone with several others. When asked who they were, they replied: Master Hong Ya, Xu You, Chao Fu, Grandee Di, Feihuangzi, Prince Jin, and Xue Rong.

In the *Western Capital Rhapsody* by Ban Mengjian of the Eastern Han, it is written: *"Hong Ya stands and gestures, amidst the fluttering of delicate plumes."* Thus, the master had long been a leader among the immortals. Tao Hongjing’s *Declarations of the Perfected* states: *"Master Hong Ya now serves as the Perfected of the Grotto of True Reality on Mount Qingcheng,"* which is why the mountain is also known as Hong Ya today. Guo Jingchun’s *Poems on Roaming Immortals* says: *"To the left, he grasps the sleeve of Fuqiu; to the right, he claps Hong Ya’s shoulder."* Elsewhere, it reads: *"Chang’e lifts her wondrous voice, while Hong Ya strokes his chin."* At that time, the master and his companions—Chang’e, Fuqiu, and others—were still visible to those who sought the immortal path.

Mount Hong Ya lies among the western mountains of Yuzhang, where the master once secluded himself. In the ninth year of the Kaihuang era of Emperor Wen of Sui, the commandery of Yuzhang was renamed Hongzhou, after the mountain where the master resided. Today, Hong Well lies at the northern cliff of Mount Fulong. On either side, sheer stone precipices rise abruptly, and in spring and summer, cascading torrents roar like thunder before plunging into the well, where their force is suddenly quelled. The remaining flow forms a small stream that feeds into Luan Pond.

An ancient altar stands above the well, said to be where the master refined his elixirs. In times of drought, prayers offered there summon a red serpent that appears upon the water’s surface, and rain follows at once. About a *li* north of the well, among the rocky shoals, lie five stone mortars, their color as vivid as cinnabar, each round and over two *chi* deep. These are said to be where the master pounded his medicines. Locals claim that on the morning of the fifth day of the fifth month, before dawn, the sound of pounding can sometimes be heard, and woodcutters occasionally come upon his leftover dregs.

About two *li* south of the well lies Luan Ridge, encircled by water—this is Luan Pond. Legend holds that the ridge was where the master’s simurgh rested, and nearby once stood Luan Mountain Abbey. In *The Five Peaks’ Audience Rites* by Celestial Master Sima, it is written: *"The grotto of Mount Qingcheng spans two thousand *li* in circumference. In ancient times, Master Hong Ya consumed the blossoms of *langgan* and secluded himself there, succeeding as the Perfected of Qingcheng."*

**Zhan Shanggong**

Zhan Shanggong was an immortal of the Gaoxin era.

Zhan Shanggong studied the Dao under Fu Long, whose land happened to be owned by Li Mimian. After attaining the Way, Shanggong now serves as the Right Protector of the Nine Palaces. He often told the other immortals: "Long ago in Huayang, I ate a white plum so delicious that I still recall its taste—yet in the blink of an eye, three thousand years have passed." After Guo Sichao, five fruits were planted there, and the land was also suitable for cultivating crabapples. These were the "crabapples of the blessed land," said to dispel plague and pestilence. *The Jade Casket Record* states: "Xianshan, commonly called Dunu Mountain, is where the immortal Zhan Shanggong ascended to heaven. He once said, 'Long ago in Huayang, I ate a white plum—suddenly, three thousand years had passed.'" There is a Green Plain where Lord Mao oversees the planting; White Plum Creek lies north of Small Mao Mountain.

*The Commentary on the Declarations of the Perfected* notes: "According to various chronologies, from the first year of Yao’s reign (wuxu) to the year jimao of the Qi era, 2,803 years have elapsed. Gaoxin was Yao’s father, so if Shanggong spoke these words during the Jin dynasty, claiming three thousand years had passed, then from Yao’s time to the present would indeed be no less than 2,800 years. External calendars may vary, but even so, the count of dinghai years should not have already been exceeded. Examining *The Bamboo Annals*, the total is precisely 2,643 years—a discrepancy even greater."

**He Hou**

He Hou was a recluse on Mount Cangwu during Yao’s reign. Longing for immortality, he farmed with over three hundred people. When Shun made his southern inspection, he stayed at He Hou’s home. The Five Elders of Heaven then told Shun: "Your time of ascension is near." The next day, the Five Emperors descended to welcome Shun, who ascended to heaven in broad daylight. By the time of Yu of Xia, the Five Emperors gave He Hou a vessel of medicine, instructing him to mix it into wine. His entire household of over three hundred drank without exhausting it, and with the leftover wine, they sprinkled their home, which then rose into the heavens. He Hou was appointed an immortal of the Supreme Ultimate. Today, Mount Yi is said to have a temple dedicated to He Hou, beside Shun’s shrine.

**Wenzi**

Wenzi, surnamed Xin and named Ping, also called Jiran, was a native of Pui in Kuiqiu. His ancestors were princes of Jin. He studied the Dao under Lord Lao. King Ping of Zhou (or Chu, in some versions) asked Wenzi: "I hear you received the Way from Lao Cong. Though a worthy man may possess the Dao, if he lives in an age of chaos and seeks to transform a long-corrupted people with the power of one man, how could that be possible?"

Wenzi replied: "Virtue corrects depravity to restore rectitude, lifts disorder to bring governance, and transforms decadence into simplicity and purity. When virtue revives, the world is at peace—this depends on one man. Thus, accumulating virtue leads to kingship, while accumulating resentment leads to ruin. Yao and Shun flourished by this principle, while Jie and Zhou perished by it." King Ping followed his advice, and the realm was well governed.

Later, Wenzi traveled south to Wu and Yue, where Fan Li became his disciple. When Yue planned to attack Wu, Fan Li admonished: "I have heard from my teacher: 'War is an instrument of ill fortune; battle is contrary to virtue; contention is the least of affairs. To plot in secret is to defy virtue, to favor the use of ill fortune, to test oneself in the least of matters—this must not be done.'" Goujian refused to listen and was defeated at Fuchao. Wenzi later held the rank of grand minister but declined the position. He secluded himself on Mount Yu in Wuxing, where legend says he ascended by riding the clouds.

According to *The Universal Geography* and *The Wuxing Gazetteer*, thirty *li* southeast of Yuying stands Jichou Mountain, where the Yue minister Jiran once climbed to survey the terrain—hence its name. Today, on the White Stone Peak of the southern mountain stands the Tongxuan Abbey, his former retreat. The Purple Cloud Pass and Shengyuan Abbey were originally Changqing Abbey, renamed by Emperor Xiaozong of Song during the Qiandao era. Halfway up the mountain lies the "Sunlit Cloud-Riding Stone." Emperor Ming of Tang posthumously honored him as the Perfected of Tongxuan, and his writings are titled *The Scripture of the Perfected of Tongxuan*.

**Kang Cangzi**

Kang Cangzi, surnamed Gengsang and named Chu, was a native of Chen. He attained the Dao of Lord Lao and could see with his ears and hear with his eyes. When Shusun reported this to the Lord of Lu, the ruler was astonished and sent his highest minister with lavish gifts to summon him. When Kang Cangzi arrived, the Lord of Lu humbly inquired, to which Kang Cangzi replied: "The transmission is false. I can see and hear without using my ears and eyes, but I cannot alter their natural function."

The Lord of Lu said: "This is even more extraordinary—what is the principle behind it?"

Kang Cangzi answered: "The body unites with the mind, the mind unites with *qi*, *qi* unites with the formless. With resolute presence and resonant harmony, whether far beyond the eight wilds or near between the brows, I must know it. Yet I do not know how my seven apertures and four limbs perceive, nor how my heart and six viscera comprehend—I simply know of myself."

The Lord of Lu was greatly pleased.

Another account says he lived on Mount Weilei. Those among his ministers who were rigidly knowledgeable departed, and his concubines who were cloyingly kind also left. He lived with the hunchbacked and employed the restless. After six years, Mount Weilei experienced a great exorcism.

Later, he traveled to Wuxing and concealed himself on Meng Peak in Piling, where he attained immortality and departed as a transcendent. Subsequently, during the Han dynasty, Zhang Daoling, and in the Tang, Zhang Guolao, successively withdrew to cultivate the Dao in seclusion, thereby earning the site the name "Zhang Gong’s Altar, Blessed Land." A Cavern-Spirit Abbey was built, which the Song later renamed the Great Longevity Palace of Tai Jia.

Master Fuqiu—styled Fuqiu Bo in his generation—was known as Master Fuqiu. He dwelt on Mount Song to cultivate the Dao and ascended in broad daylight. He once composed the *Song of the Origin of the Dao*, which reads:

The tiger crouches, the dragon too conceals;
The dragon hides only after the tiger yields.
Complete the River Chariot’s work,
And need no embankments to resist.

Disciples seeking flight as immortals
Wander madly, finding no abode.
Left and right, lord and minister align,
Four agents guard and protect in turn.
When Qian and Kun’s model is complete,
The Perfected One will naturally attend.

He also transmitted the *Classic of the Crane’s Physiognomy* to Prince Jin of Wang. Cui Wenzi studied the Dao under Prince Jin, obtained the text, and concealed it in a stone chamber on Mount Song. The Duke of Huainan, while gathering herbs, discovered it and thus transmitted it to the world. The *Classic of the Crane’s Physiognomy* states:

The crane is a yang bird yet roams in yin.
It draws upon metal’s *qi* and rides fire’s essence to nourish itself.
Metal’s number is nine, fire’s seven;
Thus, after seven years, it undergoes a minor transformation;
After sixteen, a major one;
After one hundred sixty, transformation ceases.
At one thousand six hundred years, its form remains pure,
Hence its color is white, its cry heard in heaven.
Its head is red, for it feeds in water;
Its beak is long, for it soars in the vanguard;
Its hind toes are short, for it treads on land;
Its legs are tall and tail sparse, for it wheels through clouds;
Its feathers are abundant and flesh sparse, its throat vast to expel;
Its neck is long to receive the new;
Thus its celestial longevity is immeasurable.
Its body bears neither green nor yellow,
For wood and earth’s *qi* nurture within, not manifesting without.
Therefore, it walks only by islets and shoals,
Rests only among groves and trees.
It is the patriarch of feathered kind,
The unicorn steed of immortals.

The crane’s superior physiognomy features:
A lean head with a vermilion crown,
Exposed eyes with black pupils,
A high nose and short beak,
Cheeks like dice, ears like the *de* of a *ku* vessel,
A long neck and a torso refined as a simurgh’s breast,
Wings like the phoenix’s and feathers like the sparrow’s,
A tortoise’s back and a sea-turtle’s belly,
Front elevated, rear drooping,
A tall neck with primary joints,
A robust viscera and slender toes—
Such are the marks of perfection.
When it cries, its voice reaches heaven;
When it flies, a single lift carries it a thousand *li*.

At two years, the crane’s fledgling down sheds, replaced by black-spotted plumage;
At three, it begins to brood.
After another seven years, its wing feathers are complete;
After another seven, it soars to the Milky Way;
After another seven, its dance accords with rhythm;
After another seven, its cries at the twelve hours of day and night match the pitch pipes.
After another seven, it no longer eats living things;
Its great feathers fall, downy plumage grows,
And it becomes pure white as snow—or wholly black—
Mud and water cannot stain it.
After one hundred sixty years, male and female gaze at each other and conceive.
At one thousand six hundred years, it drinks but does not eat,
And through embryonic transformation gives birth to simurghs and phoenixes,
All becoming drought spirits.
When a sage occupies the throne,
It soars with the phoenix over the royal domain.

In present-day Lizhou, Hubei, there is Solitary Floating Mountain. The *Illustrated Classic* records: "Of old, Master Fuqiu cultivated the Real here. A stone chamber still remains."

Song Laizi was the market overseer during the reign of Duke Zhuang of Chu.

Song Laizi would often sweep the marketplace. Over time, a beggar would appear, lingering there all day, chanting as he begged:

*"Twin blossoms bloom on Heaven’s court,
The mountain’s source reveals yin’s deceit.
At dawn I rein the celestial steed,
And come to the home of the Great Real."*

He repeated these lines as he begged, yet none in the market understood them—save for Laizi, who suddenly grasped their meaning. He suspected the beggar was an immortal but could not decipher the verse. Resolving to follow him, Laizi abandoned his post and pursued the beggar for thirteen years. The beggar then transmitted to him the Dao of the Middle Immortals. Laizi now dwells on Mount Song.

The beggar was none other than Feng Yanshou, Perfected One of the Western Marchmount, who had served as a scribe during the reign of King Xuan of Zhou.

---

Shen Xi was a native of Wu Commandery. He studied the Dao in Shu, where he could only dispel misfortune and cure illnesses, aiding the common folk. The people’s gratitude for his remedies moved Heaven, and the celestial spirits took note of him.

In the tenth year of King Shen of Zhou (the *bingchen* year), Lord Lao dispatched envoys to summon the hermit Shen Xi. One day, as Xi and his wife, née Jia, rode together to visit their daughter-in-law, Zhuo Kongning, they encountered a procession on the road: a dragon carriage, a tiger carriage, and a white deer carriage, each drawn by a single beast, accompanied by dozens of riders in crimson robes, bearing spears and swords, their radiance filling the path. They asked Xi, *"Are you the Daoist Shen Xi?"*

Startled, Xi replied, *"I am."*

The riders said, *"Xi has served the people with merit, his heart never straying from the Dao. Since birth, his conduct has been flawless. Though his allotted lifespan was brief, his years are now at an end. The Yellow and the Old have sent us, the immortals, to welcome him."*

The attendant Lang Bo rode the white deer carriage; the Transcendent Lord of the Age, Sima Sheng, rode the azure dragon carriage; and the escorting envoy, Xu Fu, rode the white tiger carriage. In an instant, three feather-clad immortals appeared, bearing jade tablets, a green jade scepter, and a vermilion-jade writ, which they presented to Xi through the Attendant of the Azure Vault. Xi could not read the script, and so they bore him away to ascend to Heaven. At that moment, laborers tilling the fields witnessed the scene. Soon, a great mist arose, and when it cleared, Xi and his carriage had vanished—only the ox he had ridden remained, grazing in the field.

Some recognized the ox and informed Xi’s family. His descendants, numbering in the hundreds, feared he had been spirited away by demons into the mountains and valleys. They divided into groups and scoured the land for a hundred *li*, but found no trace of him.

In the first year of Emperor Shang of Later Han (the *bingwu* year), four hundred and twelve years later, he returned to his hometown. His descendants traced the lineage and found his fourth-generation descendant, Huai Xi, who said, *"I have heard our ancestors speak of a celestial forebear. Now that the immortal has returned, he stayed for several days and recounted his first ascent to Heaven. He did not see the Heavenly Thearch but only paid homage to Lord Lao. Lord Lao sat facing east, his palace resplendent, wreathed in clouds of five colors—mystic yellow and dark hues—beyond description. Hundreds of attendants surrounded him, more women than men. In the courtyard stood trees of pearl and jade, clusters of sacred mushrooms, dragons, tigers, and apotropaic beasts. As they wandered among them, only the clamor of bronze and iron could be heard, its meaning unfathomable. The four walls gleamed with talismanic script inscribed upon them. Lord Lao’s form stood nearly ten feet tall, his body radiant, impossible to gaze upon directly."*

Lord Lao commanded a jade maiden to present a golden tray bearing a jade cup filled with elixir, saying, *"This is the divine cinnabar. Whoever drinks it shall not die."* Husband and wife each received a *daogui* measure. After they drank, he gave them two dates, each as large as a chicken’s egg, along with a talisman and a Daoist formula, instructing Xi, *"Return for now to the mortal realm to relieve the suffering of the people. If you wish to ascend to the upper realms, inscribe this talisman and hang it from the tip of a pole, and the immortal officials will come to welcome you."*

With these words, Xi suddenly awoke as if from sleep, finding himself back on earth. When Empress Dowager Dou fell ill, she once sent envoys to summon him. He remained among mortals during the reign of Emperor An, but later ascended to Heaven once more.

---

Wang Fu, styled Gongque, was a man of Zhou.

Wang Fu, styled Gongque, was a native of Zhou. At fifty, he abandoned his home to study the Dao. He ingested *huanglian* for one hundred and forty years, yet his hearing and vision remained sharp, his wisdom and perception broadened, his white hair turned black again, and his fallen teeth regrew.

He had a son named Shenjing. Both father and son attained the Dao and later ascended to Heaven.

---

Liu Fenglin was a man of Zhou. He studied the Dao on Mount Songgao, where over four hundred years he compounded the divine cinnabar thrice, though each time it was ruined by malevolent spirits. He then entered Mount Weiyu, where he could hold his breath for three days without respite. Though he lived for over a thousand years, he had yet to ascend as an immortal, merely achieving deathlessness through the ingestion of *huanglian*.

---

Master Cheng Lian
Boya studied the zither under Master Cheng Lian, who then traveled with him to Mount Penglai. Leaving Boya behind, he said, *"Practice diligently—I shall return shortly."* The master poled his boat away, and Boya gazed after him, seeing only the vast expanse of the sea, the dark and distant forests, and the mournful cries of birds and beasts. Sighing, he said, *"My master seeks to stir my emotions."* He took up his zither and sang. When the song ended, Cheng Lian returned, and Boya’s playing attained celestial perfection. Cheng Lian was, in truth, an immortal.

---

The Lord of Mount Wuyi
On Mount Wuyi dwelt a divine being who called himself the Lord of Wuyi, saying, *"I reside upon this mountain, and thus I am named."*

It is also said that when the primordial chaos first parted, a divine figure known as the Holy Matriarch lived here with her child. In the Qin era, the people called her the Holy Matriarch, and the assembled immortals honored her as the Great Matriarch and Holy Mother. Today, those who pray at her temple invoke her as the Great Primordial Lady.

Another account holds that the Original Numinous Lord of Mount Tiantai and the Perfected Immortal Master Hua dispatched their seventh disciple, named Shuren, who rode the clouds astride a crane to survey this mountain and arrange the dwelling places of earthbound immortals. The people of today call him the Crane-Riding Immortal.

Some say that in ancient times, a prince of Wei named Ziqian established his royal city at Tongzhou, ten *li* east of the Great King’s Stone, where the foundations of the old walls still remain. This man was a fallen earthbound immortal who later attained the Dao upon this mountain.

It is further said that twelve seekers—Zhang Zhan, Sun Chuo, Zhao Yuanqi, Peng Lingzhao, Liu Jing, Gu Siyuan, the Master of White Stone, the Master of Horse Neighing, along with four women of the Hu, Li, Yu, and Wang clans—all came to this mountain in search of the Dao. They paid their respects to the Prince of Wei, who acted as their host. At a time of severe drought, the prince, in a state of drunken reverence, offered sacrifices and prayed to the immortals for rain. Then the Crane-Riding Immortal descended from the heavens upon a white horse, bringing a soaking downpour. Zhang Zhan and the others thus beheld him.

Zhang Zhan presented a quatrain to the immortal:

*Beneath Mount Wuyi dwells the Lord of Wuyi,*
*His white horse’s reins trailing into purple clouds.*
*In the empty air, only the three libations of wine are heard,*
*As rain and mist rise over Dragon Pool’s embankment.*

The immortal was greatly pleased by the poem. Observing that Zhang Zhan and the others possessed uncommon bone structure and a precise devotion to the Dao, he sensed that each had a destined share in immortality. He dispatched He Feng’s elder brother to Mount Tiantai to retrieve a scroll of the immortal registers. Upon examining it, he found that all had been banished to the mortal realm as common folk, fated to dwell upon this mountain for eight hundred years before attaining the Dao, undergoing bone-transformation, and returning as celestial immortals.

Once their names were confirmed in the register, he arranged for the Prince of Wei and the twelve others to reside upon the mountain, bestowing upon each a measure of sesame and half a measure of medicinal decoction. The prince then held a feast, where Zhang Zhan sent Yuanheng to play the *jiegu* drum, Peng Lingzhao to play the transverse flute, Gu Siyuan to perform a dance, and Li Sanniang to play the pipa. The gathering ended in joy, and the assembly of immortals dispersed.

The immortal told them, *"After eight hundred years, you may fell the yellow-hearted trees to make coffins. Within these cliffs, you shall undergo transformation, and your souls shall ascend to Heaven."* When the appointed time came, they indeed underwent transformation. Within the Lesser Hidden Cliff, thirteen long coffins were arranged, their wooden supports driven into the rock to suspend their spiritual remains, where they remain to this day.

It is also said that on the fifteenth day of the eighth month in the second year of the First Emperor of Qin, the Lord of Wuyi prepared food and wine and convened the villagers upon Peak of the Tent Pavilion. Over a thousand men and women, having purified themselves, arrived at the appointed time. They beheld a rainbow bridge spanning the stream, its craftsmanship exquisite, with winding staircases and balustrades set along its sides. Light of body and joyful of heart, they felt no weariness as they ascended.

At the mountain’s summit, within the Tent Pavilion’s resplendent halls—hundreds of chambers shimmering in dappled light—eight multicolored banners stood on either side, their silver dragons clutching jade-hemmed pennants, their golden phoenixes adorned with kingfisher plumes. The pavilion could seat over a thousand, with eastern and western seating mats arranged in long rows, much like the stations of monks and nuns today. Green-oiled and red-flowered screens were set before the tables, which stretched from north to south without interruption beneath the pavilion.

On the northern wall at the center stood a hollowed-out forest, called the Jade Throne of the Supreme Ultimate. To its west was another hollowed form, the seat of the Holy Matriarch and Perfected Wei. To the east was the seat of the Lord of Wuyi. Each was adorned with a crimson cloud-mat and a purple mist-cushion, with bronze basins holding flower-scented water.

When the villagers arrived at the peak, outside the pavilion’s gates they heard the sound of drums. Soon, a voice rang out from the void, addressing them all as *"descendants."* It said, *"Let the male descendants enter first through the eastern sequence, and the female descendants follow through the western sequence."*

Then came an announcement: *"The Jade Emperor of the Supreme Ultimate has descended to this mountain retreat. Let the descendants bow in gratitude."* Another voice declared, *"The Holy Matriarch and Perfected Wei—let the descendants bow."* Then, with a cough, the Lord of Wuyi spoke in a loud voice: *"All you descendants, men and women alike, are well and at peace. Let the men sit in the eastern seats, and the women in the western."*

Within the central pavilion hung a green silk canopy, beneath which stood a forest of musical instruments. Another announcement came: *"Let the drum master Zhang Anling strike the leading drum, Zhao Yuanqi the secondary drum, Liu Xiaoqin the bell-drum, Zeng Shaozhong the cluster drum, Qiao Zhiman the clamor drum, Gao Zichun the short drum. Let the flute master Bao Gongxi play the transverse flute, and the clapper master He Feng’er lead the ensemble."* Thus, in the eastern canopy, they performed *"Left Immortal’s Halted Clouds."*

Then came the command: *"Let the zither master Dong Jiaoniang pluck the konghou, Xie Yingfei stroke the long zither, and Lü Hexiang strum the round pipa. Let the next pipe master Gu Zao trill, Bi Yexiu softly play the dongxiao, Zhu Xiao’e play the sheng, and the bronze-cymbal master Luo Miaorong strike the tongbo."* Thus, in the western canopy, they performed *"Right Immortal’s Welcoming Clouds."*

The instruments, though untouched, resounded with wondrous precision. The order was given to serve wine, and in an instant, the wine arrived—no formal thanks were required. The wine was sweet, fragrant, and rich as nectar, accompanied by a hundred rare delicacies, all surpassing the ordinary.

Another round of wine was called for, and the song master Peng Lingzhao was bidden to sing *"Lament for the Mortal World,"* with these words:
*"In heaven above, in the mortal world below—rare are our meetings,
As the sun sinks west and the evening crows take flight.
A hundred years pass in a fleeting moment—hopes and wishes unfulfilled,
The Heavenly Palace so near, yet grief keeps us apart."*

As the song ended, suddenly colored clouds gathered on all sides, and the sounds of jade pendants and horses filled the air. Another announcement came: *"The Jade Spirit Grand Matriarch and the Great Matriarch bid farewell to their descendants—bow twice."* Then it was said: *"You must swiftly descend this mountain. Linger too long, and you will encounter serpents, centipedes, tigers, and leopards—meet them not."*

They descended the mountain, and soon a violent storm arose. When they turned to look back at the summit, not a single trace remained. The villagers called to one another: *"We, so base and mortal, have feasted with the immortals!"* Later, they established a shrine on the mountain, naming it Tongshan.

Attendant Gentleman Liu Kui’s preface states: *"The mountain lies over two hundred li north of Jianning and thirty li south of Chong’an County."* According to the *Inner Records of Master Mao*, *"Among the thirty-six grotto-heavens of the immortals, Mount Wuyi is the sixteenth, the Heaven of Ascended Perfection and Mystic Transformation."*

**Wang Zhangxuan**
Wang Zhangxuan—his origins are unknown. The *Declarations of the Perfected* states he was an attendant gentleman to King Zhuang of Chu, who received the Dao from Master Wang. Having attained the Way, he dwelled in the grotto-chamber of Mount Linwu. Han Chong of Wu, fond of the Dao, traveled famous mountains in search of esoteric arts. On Mount Linwu, he encountered Zhangxuan and sought the Way of transcending the world. Zhangxuan bestowed upon him the *Flowing Pearl Elixir*, saying: *"Practice this path without hindrance to your life in the world. When your merit is complete, you shall ascend as an immortal."* Han Chong’s practice proved greatly efficacious. He served as Governor of Runan, governing for fourteen years with such virtuous rule that his administration was deemed the finest in the realm. At seventy-four, Zhangxuan descended again to teach him the method of *Concealment and Dissolution of Form*. Entering the Great Mount Huo, he further transmitted the *Mud-Pill and Purple Portal* technique, whereupon Han Chong ascended to heaven.

**Han Zhong**
Han Zhong of Deyang County in Hanzhou studied the Dao in the Qinzhong region. The Heavenly Perfected Sovereign bestowed upon him golden script and jade characters, enabling him to ride purple mist wherever he went and ascend to heaven in broad daylight. The *Li Sao* in the *Songs of Chu* says: *"I marvel at Fu Yue’s lodging among the stars,
Envious of Han Zhong’s attainment of the One Form.
Serene and distant, he withdraws from the world of men,
Leaving the vulgar far behind."*

**Wang Cijun**
Wang Cijun was an immortal of ancient times. During the late Zhou and the Warring States period, amid the alliances and rivalries of the age, he secluded himself on Mount Xiaxia in Fanyang. Observing that the seal script of Cang Jie was too intricate for swift use, and that writing was the foremost tool of governance, he transformed the seal and great-seal styles, creating the clerical script.

After Qin Shihuang unified the realm, recognizing the script’s utility, he thrice summoned Wang Cijun to the capital, but Wang refused. The emperor dispatched envoys with this message: *"I have conquered the Six Directions and unified the world—who dares defy me? You, a mere scholar, defy the Son of Heaven’s command. I shall have you carried here in a light chariot. Refuse, and I will kill you, bearing your head back to rectify customs and curb insolence."* The envoys reached the mountain and delivered the decree, loading Wang into the carriage. Suddenly, Wang transformed into a great crow and soared out of the vehicle. The envoys, prostrating in shock, cried: *"If we return without fulfilling our mission, we shall be executed. Pity us, O divine one!"* The crow circled in the sky and plucked out one or two of its own feathers, which the envoys retrieved and presented to the emperor. Qin Shihuang, ever fond of the Way of immortals, was filled with regret upon hearing of the transformation. He named the place *Mount Fallen Feather*, and the locals have worshipped Wang there without cease.

**Ruoshi**
Ruoshi was an immortal of antiquity, his name unknown. Lu Ao of Yan, traveling during the Qin dynasty to the Northern Sea, passed through the Great Yin, entered the Dark Portal, and came to Mount Menggu, where he encountered Ruoshi. His appearance was striking: deep-set eyes and a dark nose, hawk-like shoulders and a long neck, broad above and tapering below. Joyfully, he danced in the wind. Glancing at Lu Ao, he fled and hid beneath a stele. Lu pursued and saw him crouched like a tortoise, eating crabs and clams.

Lu Ao addressed him: *"I alone have wandered, forsaking kin and companions, seeking all beyond the Six Directions. From youth I loved travel, and in age I have not ceased. I have traversed the Four Poles, save only the Northernmost. Now I behold you here—might I call you friend?"*

Ruoshi smiled faintly and said: *"Ah, you are a man of the Central States—how unfitting that you have come so far! This place is as the sun and moon in radiance, as the constellations in splendor. It is a realm beyond naming, like the innermost chamber of a house. Once I roamed south to the Wilderness of Vast Surge, rested north in the Land of Silence, penetrated west to the Chamber of Profound Darkness, and pierced east to the Light of Sudden Illumination. Below, there was no earth; above, no heaven. Gazing, I saw nothing; listening, I heard nothing. Beyond lies the boundless expanse of surging waters, where a single step spans ten thousand miles—yet even this I have not fully explored. You have only just arrived and speak of exhausting all sights—is this not shallow? Still, remain here. I have an appointment with Hanman at the Ninefold Summit and cannot tarry long."*

Then he raised his arms and refined his form, vanishing into the clouds. Lu Ao gazed upward, but seeing nothing, ceased his search—lost in a daze, as though something had slipped away. He sighed: "Compared to this master, I am but a yellow sparrow beside a clod-bound worm. Though I wander all day without leaving a foot’s span, I deem it far—how pitiful! The *Dao in Unity* states: *Lu Ao roamed the Northern Sea and met a transcendent being. When he spoke of exhausting all sights, how truly shallow he was. Yet even that transcendent wandered beyond the Six Directions, with no fixed limit, and still could not fathom its wonders. Later generations will surely have those who surpass Lu Ao—those who grasp a single method, a single art, and mistake it for the great Dao’s emptiness, believing nothing more exists. How shallow indeed!*

The *Dao De Jing* says:
*Look and it cannot be seen—call it the Subtle.
Listen and it cannot be heard—call it the Rare.
Grasp and it cannot be held—call it the Minute.
These three cannot be further questioned,
for they merge into One.
Above, it is not bright;
below, it is not dark.
Endless, unnameable,
it returns to nothingness.
This is called form without form,
image without image—
this is called the Vague and Elusive.*

That transcendent being nearly approached the Dao. O ancient man of resolve!"

Xu the Great and Master Yin Xu traveled together to Mount Song and Mount Hua. Beneath the pines, they encountered an ancient man and a woman. The two gentlemen asked, "How have immortals come to this place?"

The ancient man replied, "I was a laborer of Qin, and this Lady Mao was a palace woman of Qin. Both of us were conscripted laborers who escaped the disaster of Mount Li. We have hidden here ever since, unaware of how many cycles of sixty years have passed."

The two gentlemen said, "Fortunate to meet great immortals, we humbly seek the elixir of gold and the great medicine."

The ancient man said, "I was originally an ordinary man. At first, I consumed cypress seeds, then ate pine resin. Over the years, I ascended into the void, and my hair turned green as if forged. But I know not what the elixir of gold or the great medicine truly is."

Lady Mao recited a poem:
*Who knows what was ancient is not what is now,
Leisurely treading blue mist around emerald peaks;
The flute pipes of Qin towers must be still,
While floating clouds vainly cling to my vine-woven robe.*

The ancient man said, "There is pine resin of ten thousand years and cypress seeds of a thousand years. You may consume them, and you too shall transcend the world."

Later, the two gentlemen dwelled upon Lotus Flower Peak.

—Yanmenzi

Yanmenzi achieved the Dao through liberation by corpse-transfiguration. His tomb lies in Dili County of Yuyang, while his true self now resides in the Golden Court of the Great Cavern of Mount Meng, where he received scriptures and was appointed as the Middle Prime Immortal Minister. Yanmen is none other than Xianmen.

When Master Purple Yang, Zhou Yishan, heard of the elixir and that the master had attained the Dao on Mount Meng and could recite the *Dragon Hoof Scripture*, he pursued him there. Upon Mount Meng, he encountered Xianmenzi riding a white crane, holding a feathered canopy, and bearing a jade tally adorned with green plumes, attended by over ten jade maidens. Yishan then prostrated himself and kowtowed, entreating the essential secret of longevity. Xianmenzi replied, "Your name is already inscribed in the Cinnabar Terrace and Jade Chamber—what fear is there of not becoming immortal? You have crossed rivers and mountains to ascend here—what more do you seek?"

Shen Wentai
Shen Wentai was a native of Jiuyi. He obtained the method of the Crimson Spring Divine Elixir and the Way of Earth Talismans for prolonging life and enhancing destiny. Having verified its efficacy through ingestion, he journeyed to Kunlun. He remained in Anxi for over two thousand years before transmitting the teachings to Li Wenyuan, saying, "Earth Talismans alone, without ingesting medicines or practicing the Dao, are of no benefit." Wenyuan then received the esoteric essentials and later ascended as an immortal. Thereafter, the methods of decocting elixirs with bamboo-root sap and the Yellow and White Arts for expelling the Three Worms originated from these two men.

Dong Ye
Dong Ye, styled Zhongxuan, was a native of Yuyi in Wudu.

In his youth, he was fond of learning and often roamed mountains and marshes, carrying books on his back. Finding them cumbersome, he gathered tree leaves at home to replace bamboo slips, for they were easier to roll. He once worked as a hired herdsman and at times gathered firewood to sell. He would encounter books in the wild, all transformed by spirits and gods, and would copy them onto scrolls. Unrestrained and refusing office, he wandered among butcher shops. Sometimes he begged for dog or sheep skins to wear, and his dwelling was no larger than what could accommodate his knees. He carved wood into shapes and slept on piles of animal fur. In summer, he slept exposed on grass and rocks. At one hundred and ninety years of age, his hair and beard remained like that of a child. He appeared and vanished unpredictably, sometimes riding an ox or donkey, sometimes wearing straw sandals. His home lay three hundred *li* from Chang’an, yet he could reach it in less than a day. He often rested at people’s homes, writing on his palm, and upon returning home, transcribed it onto slips. Thus, the words on his palm and paper were few, but his diligence wore his tongue black and his palm raw. The world called him "one who studies with his tongue and records with his palm."

He despised the clamor and chaos of the world and wrote tens of thousands of words expounding his doctrines. He blamed the followers of Zhou and Confucius for misleading later generations, twisting and distorting ritual and music, causing many to lose their true nature. He said: "Man, endowed with the five constant *qi*, is the finest of all creatures. Naturally, he understands ritual and music—why must he be taught and have his emotions restrained? Fu Xi, the Yellow Emperor, Tang Yao, Yu of Xia, and Tang of Yin were supreme sages, while Zhou and Confucius were merely men of broad learning. Why do I say this? Fu Xi hunted birds and beasts to fill his kitchen, yet later understood the harm of raw and rank odors. The Yellow Emperor taught people to ride boats, yet later they built houses to dwell in. The three sages—Tang Yao, Yu of Xia, and Tang of Yin—could regulate floods, dispel droughts, and rid people of harm. But Zhou and Confucius forcibly bound people with ritual and confused them with music. When music reaches its extreme, sorrow deepens; when ritual becomes excessive, chaos ensues—neither is the great principle of governing a state."

Emperor Wu of Han, hearing of his unconventional ways, summoned him to the Western Capital. Their conversations were profound and harmonious. Later, none knew where he had gone.

Li Chong

Li Chong was a native of Fenglan. He claimed to be three hundred years old, having followed the First Emperor of Qin to Mount Kuaiji, where he gazed upon the rivers and seas. In his youth, he loved learning and became an erudite, with ten thousand disciples. When Master Fu was ten years old, he studied the *Book of Documents* with Chong in a stone chamber, who transmitted it orally to Fu’s son. The affairs of four generations were preserved without omission. Fu’s son, in turn, recited it, tying a rope of over ten *xun* around his waist—each recitation knotting it once—until the entire rope was filled with knots. He recited it tens of thousands of times. Yet he said that eating grain harmed one’s essence and wisdom, leading to forgetfulness. Of the hundred chapters now transmitted, only one remains; the *Canons of Yao and Shun* are largely lost.

During the Han era, Chong often consumed chrysanthemums and tree sap. When asked why he did not speak, he would remain silent for ten days or more, saying: "In this world, there is nothing worth eating, nor anyone worth speaking to. My spirit roams freely, gathering the essence of clouds and the nectar of dawn. Only my heart remains—how could I speak? I fear it would merely weary my spirit and move my tongue."

The Emperor, hearing of his divine peculiarities, summoned him. Chong arrived wearing a straw cloak and carrying a basket, bearing the *True Forms of the Five Peaks* on his back. The Emperor received him with ritual courtesy and also styled him "Master of the Borne Chart."

Meng Qi
Meng Qi was a reclusive gentleman of Qinghe.

Seeking masters, he shunned no peril or hardship. Having lived seven hundred years, he recalled events from the early Zhou as vividly as if they lay before his eyes. Some say: he once saw the Duke of Zhou holding King Cheng in audience at the ancestral temple of Zhou, while Qi stood by as the Duke ascended the altar. When the Duke mounted the steps, Qi reached out to brush King Cheng’s feet; the Duke then bestowed upon him the royal ornaments. Qi treasured them always, often dusting the bamboo case with his sleeve—its edges now sharp enough to snap.

He once consumed cassia leaves and gathered herbs at the foot of Mount Huayin. Hearing the Emperor favored immortals, he emerged from the wilds. **Guo Qiong**

Guo Qiong was a man of Dongfang Prefecture. Though his appearance was coarse and unremarkable, his bearing surpassed others. Leaning on a staff, he wandered at will. Whenever he lodged in a household, he would beg for firewood to light his way, reading through the night without rest. Once, a host possessed secret apocryphal texts and weft prophecies, sealed tightly in rattan. Yet Qiong had already learned of them and read them all—none failed to marvel at his uncanny ability. When word spread that Qiong sought lodging, households would bolt their doors and block their gates; any forbidden books were burned before they dared admit him, fearing he might uncover their secrets.

Qiong often carried a bamboo tube from which he drew a handful of counting rods, scattering them before his knees to divine a household’s hidden affairs. At times, he would walk abroad by day without closing his eyes, leaving no trace, his chest bared like a madman. Emperor Wu of Han esteemed his singular gifts.

Yellow An was a man of Daijun. He claimed himself lowly and unworthy to dwell among others, wielding a whip to clear brambles while reciting texts and tracing characters upon the earth to tally his words. One night, the ground beneath him turned into a pool; when he moved elsewhere the next day, the same occurred. The people of his time called this "plowing with the tongue." Though over eighty years of age, he appeared as a youth. He constantly ingested cinnabar, his entire body turning crimson, and wore no clothing. He sat upon a divine turtle, three feet wide.

People once asked him, "How many years have you sat upon this turtle?"
He replied, "Long ago, when Fuxi first crafted nets and traps, this turtle emerged from the sea to bestow itself upon me. Its back is seven spans flat. This turtle fears the light of sun and moon, emerging its head but once every two thousand years—I have already witnessed it emerge five times. When I walk, I bear a dragon upon my back, and the world calls me ten thousand years old."

Emperor Wu of Han, hearing of his extraordinary traces, summoned him to discourse on emptiness. Finding no talk of immortals or transcendents, the Emperor grew displeased. Later, during the Feng and Shan sacrifices at Mount Tai, Yellow An rode in the same carriage as Dongye, Li Chong, Meng Qi, and Guo Qiong—together they were called the Five Immortal Ministers. After the Emperor’s passing, he departed, and none knew his whereabouts.

*The Comprehensive Mirror of Perfected Transcendents Embracing the Dao, Scroll Four ends*
*The Comprehensive Mirror of Perfected Transcendents Embracing the Dao, Scroll Five*

Royal Chuiping

Royal Chuiping, also known as Lanxi of Danxi, was a native of that region. At the age of fifteen, while tending his family’s sheep, a Daoist priest, observing his goodness and prudence, took him to a stone chamber in Mount Jinhua. For over forty years, he remained there, utterly untroubled by thoughts of home.

His elder brother, Chuqi, had long searched for him in vain. Later, encountering a Daoist skilled in divination at the marketplace, he inquired, “My younger brother was herding sheep when he vanished over forty years ago. I know not whether he lives or has perished—would you divine his fate for me?” The Daoist replied, “I once saw a Royal Chuiping in Mount Jinhua. Could he be your brother?” Hearing this, Chuqi was overcome with joy and followed the Daoist to seek his brother. There they found him, and the brothers embraced in tearful reunion.

After speaking, Chuqi asked, “Where are your sheep?” Chuiping answered, “Just east of the mountain.” Chuqi went to look but saw nothing—only heaps of white stones. He returned and said, “There are no sheep east of the mountain.” Chuiping replied, “The sheep are there—you simply cannot see them.” The brothers went together, and Chuiping shouted, “Sheep, arise!” At once, the white stones all rose and transformed into tens of thousands of sheep.

Chuqi said, “My brother alone has attained the Dao of divine transcendence—can I learn it as well?” Chuiping replied, “Certainly, if you cultivate the Way earnestly, you may achieve it.” Thereupon, Chuqi abandoned his wife and children, remaining with Chuiping to ingest pine resin and fuling. After fifty thousand days, they could sit or stand at will, vanish or reappear, cast no shadow at noon, and their complexions retained the freshness of youth.

They returned together to their hometown, but by then, all their relatives had long since passed away. They departed once more, and before leaving, Chuiping taught his methods to Nan Bo Feng, changing his name to Red Pine Master. Chuqi altered his courtesy name to Luban, while Chuiping took the name Pine Master. Thereafter, dozens of others who consumed this elixir attained transcendence.

Mount Jinhua now lies within Weizhou. There, stone sheep remain visible to this day. Some say it was Cloudyang Mountain in Chaling, where Yellow Chuiping, known as Red Pine Master, dwelled on the southern slopes of Mount Heng. In that place, pines towered ten thousand feet high.

Shen Jian

Shen Jian was a native of Danyang.

His family had long served as local officials, yet Shen Jian alone loved the Dao and refused to enter public service. He studied the arts of *daoyin* and *fushi*, the methods for restoring youth and reversing aging. He was also skilled in treating illness—no matter how slight or severe, those who saw him were cured. Thousands of households revered him.

Whenever he traveled afar, he would entrust three to five servants, a donkey, and several dozen sheep to a host, giving each a single elixir pill. He would instruct the host, saying, "Simply provide them shelter; do not trouble yourself with food." Then he would take his leave. The host would be greatly perplexed, thinking, *"This gentleman has left over fifteen servants and animals in my care, yet not a single coin—what am I to do?"*

After Shen Jian’s departure, the host would offer food to the servants, but they would recoil at the scent, retching and refusing to look at it. When grass was given to the donkey and sheep, they too would avoid it, even turning aggressive toward people. The host was astonished. Yet after a hundred days, the servants’ bodies grew radiant, their complexions surpassing those of well-fed men, while the donkey and sheep became plump and vigorous.

Three years later, Shen Jian returned. He gave each servant, donkey, and sheep another elixir pill, and they resumed eating as before. Thereafter, he ceased consuming grain entirely, able to lift his body and fly, departing and returning at will. He lived in this manner for over three hundred years before vanishing without a trace.

Hua Ziqī

Hua Ziqī was a native of Huainan.

Master Shi Jiaoli received the esoteric *Lingbao* formulas from a mountain recluse: the first called *Flying Turtle Rite of the Yi and Luo*, the second *White Yu’s Correct Mechanism*, and the third *Balanced Alignment*. When taken together, they reversed aging day by day. He could walk five hundred *li* in a day, lift a thousand *jin*, and shed his skin ten times in a year. Later, he ascended as an immortal, and the mountain where he dwelled was named Mount Ziqī, now part of Jianning Prefecture.

Wang Yuan

Wang Yuan, styled Fangping, was a native of Donghai. He was nominated as a *xiaolian* and appointed Gentleman of the Palace, gradually rising to the rank of Grand Master for Splendid Happiness. Well-versed in the Five Classics, he also mastered astronomy, apocryphal texts, and the essentials of the *He* and *Luo* diagrams, enabling him to foresee the rise and fall of the realm and the fortunes of the Nine Provinces. Emperor Huan of the Han, having heard of him, repeatedly summoned him, but he refused to appear. The court then had local officials compel him to the capital by carriage. He kept his head bowed and mouth shut, declining to respond to the imperial decree. Instead, he inscribed over four hundred characters on the palace gate panels, all foretelling future events. The emperor, displeased, ordered the writing erased. The outer characters vanished, but the inner ones reappeared, the ink having seeped deep into the wood.

Fangping never returned. His descendants and fellow villagers transmitted his deeds for generations. Chen Dan, the Grand Commandant of the same commandery, built a chamber for him, bowing in reverence morning and evening, seeking blessings and wishing to study the Dao. Fangping stayed in Dan’s household for over thirty years. During this time, Dan’s family knew no illness, death, or misfortune; their servants and maids were at peace, their livestock multiplied, their fields and silkworms yielded severalfold, and their official ranks advanced. Later, Fangping told Dan, “My destined time to depart has come. I can no longer stay. Tomorrow at noon, I will leave.” When the hour arrived, Fangping died. Dan, realizing he had transformed and departed, dared not place the body on the ground. He wept and sighed, saying, “Master, you abandon me—what shall I rely on?” He prepared a coffin, burned incense, and dressed the body in its robes. After three days and nights, the body suddenly vanished, its clothing and belt undisturbed, like a cicada’s molted husk.

Over a hundred days after Fangping’s departure, Dan passed away. Some said Dan had attained Fangping’s Dao and transformed as well; others claimed Fangping, knowing Dan’s end was near, had simply left him behind.

Fangping later entered Mount Kuocang, passed through Wu, and visited Cai Jing’s home in Xumen. Having attained the rank of immortal, he became the Perfected One of the Western Citadel in the Western Extremity, commanding fifteen thousand immortals and governing the Nine Immortals’ Treasure Chamber of Mount Qingcheng. The *Tujing of Zhongzhou* states: “The Yu Temple and Jingde Abbey were once called the Immortals’ Palace, the mountain where Wang Fangping of the Former Han attained the Dao. In the first year of Xianping of Emperor Zhenzong of Song, it was bestowed with one hundred twenty volumes of imperial calligraphy; in the first year of Jingde, it received its present name.”

Cai Jing

Cai Jing was a commoner, yet his bones were such that he was destined for immortality. Fangping, recognizing this, visited his home—now the site of Cai Jing’s residence in Pingjiang Prefecture—and said to him, “Your fate is to transcend the world, so I have come to recruit you for the immortal bureaucracy. However, you are young and lack understanding of the Dao. With too little *qi* and too much flesh, you cannot ascend to heaven and must undergo *shijie* (corpse liberation). It will be as if passing through a dog’s burrow.” He imparted essential teachings and then departed.

Later, Cai Jing suddenly felt his body burning like fire, craving water to douse himself as if quenching something scorched. After three days, his bones dissolved entirely. He entered his chamber, covered himself with a blanket, and vanished. When his family looked beneath the blanket, they found only his skin, head, and feet intact, like a cicada’s shed husk.

Over ten years after his departure, he unexpectedly returned home. Though he had left aged, he now appeared youthful and robust, his hair entirely black. He told his family, “On the seventh day of the seventh month, Lord Wang will visit. Prepare several hundred *hu* of wine to serve his retinue.” He then left. His family followed his instructions, borrowing jars and brewing hundreds of *hu* of wine, arranging them in the courtyard to await his arrival.

On the appointed day, Fangping indeed arrived. Before reaching Cai Jing’s home, the sound of drums, flutes, and pipes filled the air. As he drew near, all were astonished, unsure of what approached. Upon arrival, Cai Jing’s entire household saw him. Fangping wore a *yuanyou* cap, a vermilion robe, a tiger-headed satchel, a multicolored sash, and a sword. His complexion was yellowish, his beard sparse, and his height average. He rode a carriage with five canopies, drawn by five dragons, each of a different hue. Preceded and followed by banners, standards, and an entourage befitting a grand general, he was accompanied by twelve companies of five hundred soldiers each. Their mouths were sealed with beeswax, and their musicians rode qilin, descending from the heavens rather than traveling by earthly roads.

Once they arrived, the attendants vanished, leaving only Fangping seated. After a moment, he summoned Cai Jing’s father and brothers. He then sent a messenger to inquire after Lady Ma Gu, though none knew what deity she was. The message read: “Wang Fangping respectfully reports: I have long been absent from the mortal realm. Now that I am here, might the Lady deign to visit briefly?” Shortly after, a reply came, though the messenger remained unseen. It said: “Ma Gu bows. Though we have not met, five hundred years have passed in an instant. With due reverence for hierarchy, I have long been troubled by your absence. Hearing you are here, I should come in person.
