However, I have just received a summons to inspect Penglai. I will go briefly and return, at which time I shall pay my respects. I hope you will not depart immediately.”

After two such exchanges, Ma Gu arrived, her approach also heralded by the sound of men and horses. Upon arrival, her retinue was half the size of Fangping’s. When Ma Gu appeared, Cai Jing’s entire household saw her—a beautiful woman of about eighteen. Her hair was coiled atop her head, the rest cascading to her waist. Her garments bore patterns, yet were not of brocade or silk; their radiance rivaled the sun, and their names were unknown, for they were unlike anything in the world.

She entered and bowed to Fangping, who rose to his feet in return. Once seated, each was served a feast. Gold platters and jade cups held dishes mostly of various flowers, their fragrance filling the inner and outer chambers. As they broke the dried meats to share, one resembled cypress-roasted flesh—it was, they said, the jerky of a qilin. Ma Gu herself remarked: “Since I began attending the immortals, I have witnessed the Eastern Sea transform into mulberry fields three times. Recently, when I visited Penglai, the waters were shallower than before—perhaps half their former depth. Could it soon become dry land?” Fangping smiled and said: “The sages all say that even the seas will one day stir up dust.”

Ma Gu wished to see Cai Jing’s mother and his wife, but his wife had recently given birth mere days before. Ma Gu caught sight of her and knew at once, saying: “Ah, stay back for now.” She asked for a handful of rice, then tossed it to the ground. Where the grains fell, they turned to cinnabar. Fangping laughed: “Ma Gu still plays youthful games. I am old now and no longer delight in such clever transformations.”

Fangping addressed Cai Jing’s family: “I wish to offer you wine, but this wine comes from the celestial kitchens. Its flavor is rich and sweet, unsuited for mortals—it may even corrode your innards. I shall dilute it with water, so do not be alarmed.” He mixed one *dou* of water with one *sheng* of wine and served it to the household. After drinking about one *dou*, they all grew drunk. When the wine ran out after some time, Fangping told his attendants: “It is not enough—fetch more.” He gave a string of cash to an old woman from Yuhang to buy wine. Soon, a messenger returned with an oilskin bag containing about five *dou* of wine. The old woman relayed: “I feared earthly wine would not suit your refined taste.”

Ma Gu’s fingernails did not resemble human hands—they were like a bird’s talons. Cai Jing thought to himself: “If my back itches, these claws would be perfect for scratching.” Fangping, already aware of his thoughts, had someone drag Cai Jing away and flog him, saying: “Ma Gu is a divine being. How could you think her claws suitable for scratching your back?” Though the whip struck Cai Jing’s back, no one holding it was visible. Fangping told Cai Jing: “My whip is not to be taken lightly.”

A neighbor of Cai Jing’s family, surnamed Chen, whose given name is lost, had once served as a magistrate. Hearing that divine beings were at Cai Jing’s home, he came to the door, kowtowed, and begged to meet them. Fangping brought him forward and spoke with him. The man then asked to serve as an attendant, like Cai Jing. Fangping said: “Stand and face the sun.” From behind, Fangping observed him and said: “Ah, your heart’s needle is not true. I cannot teach you the Dao of immortality. Instead, I shall grant you the office of an earthly overseer.” Before leaving, he placed a talisman and a manual in a small box and gave it to Magistrate Chen, saying: “This will not grant you transcendence, but it will extend your life. Your natural lifespan is already a century. You may use it to ward off disasters and cure illnesses. If a patient’s fate is not yet exhausted and they bear no grave transgressions, they will recover when you bring the talisman to their home. If malevolent spirits or blood-consuming ghosts cause harm, command the local earth deities to seize and deliver them. Judge each case with discernment.” Magistrate Chen used the talisman to heal the sick with great success, and hundreds of households sought his aid. He lived to be one hundred and ten before passing. After his death, his descendants used the talisman, but it no longer worked.

After Fangping departed, the several hundred *hu* of wine left in Cai Jing’s courtyard vanished, though no one was seen drinking it. Cai Jing’s parents privately asked him: “Where does Lord Wang usually reside?” Cai Jing replied: “He often governs Kunlun, traveling between Mount Luofu and Mount Kuocang. All three mountains have palaces, and Lord Wang regularly oversees the affairs of the celestial bureaus. In a single day, he journeys to and from the heavens dozens of times. The life and death matters of the Five Peaks on earth are all first reported to him. He travels only by riding a yellow qilin, his procession solemn. Wherever he goes, the spirits of mountains and seas come to pay homage, some even hailing him along the way.”

Decades later, Cai Jing briefly returned home to visit. Fangping sent a letter to Magistrate Chen. The characters were bold and large, though not in standard script. Before this, no one knew Fangping’s name, but word spread from afar, and many came to learn of it. Magistrate Chen’s family still preserves Lord Wang’s handwritten letter and the small box containing the talisman and manual to this day.

**She Zheng**

She Zheng, styled Xuanzhen, was a native of eastern Ba.

During the reign of the First Emperor of Qin, his deeds were as vivid as if one had witnessed them firsthand. By the end of the Han dynasty, She Zheng entered Mount Hao with twenty disciples, yet he kept his eyes closed at all times—even while walking, they remained shut. His disciples followed him for twenty years without ever seeing him open his eyes. One disciple persistently entreated him, so She Zheng finally opened them. When his eyes opened, a sound like thunderclap erupted, and a light like lightning flashed, striking his disciples, who all unconsciously prostrated themselves. Only after a long while could they rise, by which time She Zheng had already closed his eyes again.

After attaining the Dao, no one witnessed what he consumed or practiced, yet he taught his disciples to cultivate qi through breath control, abstain from the bedchamber, and ingest cinnabar and mineral elixirs. It was said that Li Babai called She Zheng a "four-hundred-year-old child."

Your servant Daoyi remarks: The *Daodejing* states, "The five colors blind the eye," and "The sage acts for the belly, not for the eyes." Ancient immortals also said, "The hun resides in the liver, not in the leaking eyes," and "Close your eyes to see your own vision." If one can guard the spirit within and not be swayed by external things, then even Mount Tai before one’s eyes will go unseen. Now, She Zheng kept his eyes closed even while walking—was this not to embody the sage’s principle of acting for the belly, not the eyes, and to spiritually instruct his disciples? Later Dao seekers should awaken to this.

**Sun Bo**

Sun Bo was a native of Hedong. Gifted with literary talent, he composed poetry in a hundred verses and recited tens of thousands of words of scripture. In his later years, he studied the Dao and mastered the arts of Mozi, enabling him to make plants, trees, metal, and stone all burst into flames, illuminating dozens of *li* around. He could also turn his body into fire and exhale flames from his mouth. Pointing at a tree would ignite it, scorching its leaves to withered crispness, but pointing again would restore it. Thus, he could also cause an entire army to form separate clusters of fire.

A man from the region had lost a slave who was hiding among the troops. After days of searching in vain, the slave’s master sought Sun Bo’s help. Sun Bo said, "I will set their camp ablaze, and the slave will surely flee. You need only watch carefully and seize him." Thereupon, Sun Bo hurled a red pellet into the military encampment. In an instant, flames soared to the heavens, and the slave indeed fled, whereupon he was captured. Sun Bo then threw a green pellet into the fire, and it immediately extinguished. All the charred houses and objects within were restored to their original state.

Whenever Sun Bo kindled fire to burn something, even if others doused it with water, it could not be quenched—only when he himself ceased did it stop. When crossing vast waters, not only did his own body remain dry, but he could also keep those with him from getting wet. Moreover, he could spread mats upon the water, sit with others to drink and feast, and have them dance atop the waves without sinking or getting drenched, reveling joyously all day.

Those afflicted with illness sought him out for healing. Without any elaborate methods, he merely pointed at them and declared their recovery, and they were cured. When he entered mountain cliffs or boulders on the ground, his back and ears would remain visible in the stone for a time before he vanished entirely. He could also swallow dozens of swords and pass through walls as if they had openings. He could bend mirrors into blades and straighten blades into mirrors, maintaining their altered forms for extended periods until he pointed at them to restore their original shapes.

Later, he entered the forests of Mount Linlü, where he compounded the divine elixir and ascended as an immortal.

**Ban Meng**

Ban Meng’s origins are unknown.

Some say she was a woman. She could fly and remain aloft all day. She could also sit in empty space and converse with others, or enter the earth—first her feet would vanish, then her waist, then her chest, until only her headdress remained visible, and after a long while, she would disappear entirely. She could pierce the ground with her finger, and a spring or well would form, from which water could be drawn. She could also inhale the tiles from people’s rooftops, causing them to fly into her home. If a household had thousands of mulberry trees or fruit trees, she could gather them all into a mound like a mountain; after ten or so days, she would blow on them, and they would return to their original places as before. She could also spread paper before her, chew ink, and spray it onto the page—whereupon the paper would fill with writing, each character bearing meaning. Later, she consumed wine and elixirs, and at the age of four hundred, her appearance grew youthful again. Finally, she entered the Great Cold Mountain and departed as an immortal.

**Wang Gang**

The Heavenly Gate Master’s surname was Wang, and his given name was Gang. He was particularly versed in the secrets of nourishment and cultivation. Thus, his classic states: *"Yang arises at the hour of yin (3–5 a.m.), the essence of pure Wood; Yin arises at the hour of shen (3–5 p.m.), the essence of pure Metal. When Wood is cast against Metal, it is invariably harmed—thus Yin exhausts Yang. Women adorn themselves with powder, emulating Metal’s whiteness. Therefore, true persons and Daoist adepts must focus their minds and refine their intentions, mastering the subtle and discerning the flourishing and declining. I move as the Azure Dragon, while she moves as the White Tiger; I seize the Vermilion Bird, while the Dark Warrior advances before me—this is the Way of immortality."*

It also states: *"A woman’s nature is more urgent than a man’s in desire, yet outwardly she restrains herself, unwilling to solicit the Yang—this reveals Metal’s refusal to yield to Wood. The Yang nature is fierce and impetuous, its will and conduct careless; yet in social gatherings, its voice softens, its words grow humble—this reveals Wood’s awe of Metal."*

Having mastered this Way, Wang Gang lived to two hundred and eighty years of age, retaining the complexion of a maiden. He then ingested the Pearl Elixir, attained immortality, and departed for the Dark Continent.

**Huang Hua**

The Nine Spirits Master’s surname was Huang, and his given name was Hua. He attained the essentials of rejuvenation, embryonic breathing, and inner vision, as well as the Way of the Five Phases. His classic states: *"This art can repel weapons, deter tigers and wolves, safeguard one’s body, protect one’s household, ensure the prosperity of descendants, and harmonize inner and outer realms. Those who see you will rejoice; those who do not will long for you. It is fitting for soldiers and beneficial for travelers."*

Those who scheme against one are dissolved before their plots take shape; a thousand calamities and ten thousand misfortunes lie dormant, never arising. The paths of treachery and deceit are blocked, the gates of malevolent spirits sealed. Those who curse you find their curses unfulfilled; those who cast hexes see their sorcery undone. All worthy men under heaven come to revere you, winning the favor of divine spirits and the hearts of the common folk. Fields yield abundant harvests, silkworms thrive, the six livestock multiply, servants remain loyal to their households, and illnesses are cured. Officials release their grievances, legal disputes are resolved in your favor, and every endeavor prospers. Those who devote themselves to this Way in their generation attain its profound wonders, living over five hundred years with ever-youthful countenances. Later, refining the elixir, they ascend as immortals and depart.

**Yin Heng**

The North Pole Master’s surname was Yin, and his given name was Heng. His classic states: *"The Way of cultivating the body treasures the love of spirit; the art of nurturing nature is to die into life and emerge anew. By practicing this constantly, one becomes as enduring as heaven. Seeking life through life, one attains true life. Forging iron with iron is called truth; refining man with man is called spirit."* Later, he ingested the Divine Elixir and departed as an immortal.

**Li Xiu**

The Peerless Grotto Master’s surname was Li, and his given name was Xiu. His classic states: *"The weak can overcome the strong; the yin can subdue the yang. Ever as if treading deep abysses or perilous heights, guiding a galloping steed or a speeding chariot—this is the Way of longevity."* He lived over four hundred years with an undiminished complexion.

Yan composed forty scrolls, titled *The Origin of the Dao*. He ingested the Returning Elixir and ascended to heaven.

**Liu Rong**

The Master of the Southern Pole’s surname was Liu, and his given name was Rong. He could hold powder in his mouth and form it into parrot chicks, spitting out dozens at a time. When boiled and eaten, they were indistinguishable from real parrot chicks. The remaining powder in his mouth, no larger than a fingertip, could be placed in a cup and enchanted, transforming into a turtle. When boiled, it became edible, with fully formed organs and entrails, while the cup turned into a turtle shell. Once the meat was removed, the shell reverted to a cup. Water enchanted by him became fine wine, intoxicating those who drank it. With a wave of his hand, he could conjure a great tree; if someone broke off a small branch to use as a roof beam, it would remain intact for days before gradually withering, no different from real wood. He ingested the Cloud-Frost Elixir and departed as an immortal.

**Ge Yue**

The Master of Yellow Reed’s surname was Ge, and his given name was Yue. He was highly skilled in healing illnesses. Even when patients were a thousand *li* away, he could cure them simply by receiving their names—there was no need to see the afflicted in person. He was adept in the arts of qi restraint, able to immobilize tigers, wolves, and all manner of insects, prevent birds from taking flight, and even reverse the flow of water for a *li*. At the age of two hundred and eighty, he could lift a thousand *jun* and run as swiftly as a galloping horse. Above his head, a five-colored qi often rose over a *zhang* high. During times of great drought, he could descend into deep pools, summon dragons to emerge, and urge them to ascend to the heavens to bring rain. He performed this feat repeatedly. One day, he bid farewell to his relatives and friends, mounted a dragon, and departed, never to return.

**Liu An**

Liu An, the Prince of Huainan, was the grandson of Emperor Gao of Han. He was fond of Confucian scholarship and esoteric arts, composing the *Inner Book* in twenty-one scrolls and the *Hongbao Wannian* in three volumes, expounding on the Dao of transformation. Eight elders came to visit him, and the gatekeeper, seeking to test them, said: "Our prince desires three things: first, the Way of extending life and reversing aging; second, a great scholar versed in broad learning, profound wisdom, and subtle principles; and third, a warrior of immense strength, capable of lifting tripods and braving death in battle. Yet you gentlemen are all advanced in years—you lack the art of annotating texts, the vigor of Meng Ben and Xia Yu, and the ability to master the Three Canons, Five Classics, Eight Compilations, and Nine Anthologies, to delve deeply and reach far, to exhaust principles and fulfill nature. Since you fall short in all three, I dare not announce your arrival."

The elders laughed and replied: "We have heard that the prince reveres worthies and cherishes scholars, sparing no effort in seeking even the humblest talent. The ancients valued the learning of the Nine-Nine, nurturing even barking and howling retainers, truly wishing to purchase a horse’s skeleton to attract unicorns, to emulate Master Guo to summon fine scholars. Though we are unworthy, we do not match your prince’s requests, yet we have come from afar to meet him. Even if we offer no benefit, we shall do no harm. Why do you obstruct us with such prejudice? If the prince insists on seeing only the young as those with the Dao and dismisses the gray-haired as mediocrities, this is hardly the way to strike stone to obtain jade or plumb the depths to seek pearls. You slight our age, yet we are still young at heart."

As they finished speaking, the eight elders transformed into youths of fifteen, their hair loose and temples dark, their complexions like peach blossoms. The gatekeeper, startled and trembling, rushed to inform the prince. Upon hearing this, Liu An did not even pause to put on his shoes but hurried out barefoot to greet them. He led them to the Terrace of Thoughtful Immortality, where he arrayed curtains of brocade, set out ivory couches, burned incense of a hundred fragrances, presented tables of gold and jade, and donned his disciples’ slippers. Facing north, he clasped his hands and said: "Though I possess only mediocre talent, I have long cherished the Dao and virtue. Yet shackled by worldly duties and mired in vulgar customs, I have been unable to cast off my burdens and roam free in the mountains and forests. Still, day and night, I hunger and thirst for the divine, cleansing myself of filth and sincerely reforming my frivolity. My pent-up longing remains unfulfilled, as distant as clouds and mud. I never imagined such great fortune—to have the Dao Lords deign to visit. This is my destiny, to be lifted from obscurity. Overwhelmed with joy and fear, I know not what to do. I only beg the Dao Lords to take pity and instruct me, that I may borrow wings like a cicada grub and soar from the earth."

The eight elders then reverted to their aged forms and said to the prince: "Though our knowledge is shallow, we have mastered the teachings of our predecessors. Knowing of your devotion to the Dao, we have come to follow you. We do not yet know what you desire. One of us can summon wind and rain at will, conjure clouds and mist in an instant, draw rivers on the ground, and pile mountains from handfuls of earth. Another can level heights and fill abysses, herd tigers and leopards, summon dragons and serpents, and command spirits and ghosts. Another can split his form and alter his appearance, sit yet vanish, stand yet disappear, conceal entire armies, and plunge daylight into darkness. Another can tread the void and walk the skies, rise from the sea and soar through mist, enter and exit without hindrance, and breathe across a thousand *li*. Another can enter fire without burning, enter water without getting wet, remain unharmed by blades or arrows, feel no cold in winter or sweat in summer. Another can transform endlessly at will, turning birds, beasts, grasses, and trees into being in an instant, and shifting mountains, rivers, and peaks. Another can avert disasters and transcend calamities, ward off evil and repel harm, extend life, and attain longevity. Another can smelt mud into gold, forge lead into silver, refine the Eight Minerals with water, make pearls fly and flow, ride dragons and drive clouds, and roam the Great Clarity. Whatever you desire, my prince, we can provide."

Thereafter, Liu An paid homage to them morning and night, offering fruit and wine. He first begged them to demonstrate their arts, and their transformations of wind, rain, clouds, and mist all proved effective. They then bestowed upon him the *Classic of the Elixir* and thirty-six formulas involving mercury, but before the medicine was completed, Liu An’s son, named Qian, who was fond of swordsmanship and considered himself unmatched, was sparring with the courtier Lei Bei. Bei accidentally struck Qian, who flew into a rage. Bei sought to join the campaign against the Xiongnu to atone for his offense, but Liu An refused. Fearing Qian would kill him, Bei submitted a memorial to the emperor. At that time, Han law decreed that any feudal lord who obstructed the passes or mobilized forces against the Xiongnu would be sentenced to death. Liu An was to be executed, but Emperor Wu, who had always respected him, merely stripped him of two counties.

When Lei Bei and Wu Bei had long been close, Wu Bei had also incurred Liu An’s wrath through illicit dealings, though Liu An had not yet acted on his anger. Fearing execution, Wu Bei falsely accused Liu An of plotting rebellion. The emperor dispatched the Minister of the Imperial Clan bearing the imperial tally to investigate Liu An. The Eight Perfected addressed Liu An, saying: “You may depart now—this is Heaven’s way of sending you forth. Do not hesitate.” Thereupon, Liu An ascended the mountain with them to perform a great sacrifice, burying gold in the earth before ascending to heaven in broad daylight. The stones trodden by the Eight Perfected and Liu An sank beneath their feet, and to this day, traces of their footprints and hoofprints remain. *The Treatise on Geography* states: “Mount Bagong lies north of the Fei River and south of the Huai, where the Prince of Huainan and the Eight Perfected dwelled before ascending to heaven in daylight. It now belongs to Shou Prefecture.” Another account claims this is not so, but rather the place where Fu Jian saw grasses and trees transformed into soldiers. Mount Bagong bears the “Resting Stones of the Eight Perfected of Huainan.” In Han times, it belonged to Jiujiang Commandery; today, it lies southwest of Lai’an County in Di Prefecture. Yet another account says that atop Mount Bagong stands a temple to Prince Liu An of Huainan, now within the boundaries of Chaoxian County in Wuwei Prefecture.

The Eight Perfected told Liu An: “Though the celestial envoy has come, Wu Bei, as a minister, has falsely accused his lord and father. Those whose names are recorded in the registers of immortals—any who conspire against them shall die, and any who offend them shall be destroyed. Wu Bei now faces execution.” When the Minister of the Imperial Clan arrived, Liu An was nowhere to be found. Upon inquiry, they were told: “The Prince has departed as an immortal.” The emperor, hearing this, was filled with regret and subtly instructed the Commandant of Justice, Zhang Tang, to indict Wu Bei for devising the rebellion on Liu An’s behalf. Both Wu Bei and Lei Bei were then executed by extermination of their clans, just as the Eight Perfected had foretold. The Han historians concealed the truth, unwilling to speak of divine transcendence lest later emperors neglect state affairs in pursuit of immortality. Thus, they claimed Liu An had taken his own life. Another version says that Liu An ascended to heaven with the Eight Perfected, leaving behind his alchemical cauldron; his parrot and dog licked the residue and likewise ascended, the parrot crying in the clouds and the dog barking in the heavens. Yet another account states that Liu An obtained the *Hongbao* and *Wannian* arts of immortality, departed as a transcendent, and was enfeoffed as the Perfected of the Supreme Ultimate.

**Liu Tu**
In the third year of *Yongchu* of Emperor An of Han (119 CE), on the *jiyou* day of the second month, the Venerable Lord descended upon Mount Tai. He dispatched the Feathered Messenger of Mount Tai with chariots and cavalry to summon Liu Tu, a virtuous man of Jiangxia, intending to have him collate the registers of all under heaven. When Liu Tu arrived, he saw the Venerable Lord seated facing south upon the throne, the Lord of Mount Tai seated facing east and west, the Nine Celestial Perfected seated facing south and north, and the Lords of the Eight Directions seated facing west and east. Liu Tu was commanded to collate the celestial registers of all under heaven alongside the officials, a task completed in three days. The Venerable Lord, wishing to demonstrate to Liu Tu the karmic retribution of sin and blessing, ordered the Feathered Messenger to escort him to the Heavenly Palace. There, he beheld the Golden Terrace and Jade Hall of the Grand Pure Palace, where music arose spontaneously, and the transcendent beings, clad in azure robes and bearing golden tablets, chanted the scriptures. After the visitation, he was sent back. Through this, Liu Tu attained the Dao, became a Daoist, and later departed as an immortal.

**Jie Jiu**
Jie Jiu’s origins are unknown. He traveled to Mount Fang in Jian’an, where he studied the Dao of the Mysterious Unity under Master White Sheep, Du Bi. He mastered transformation and concealment, often accompanying his master into the Eastern Sea. Passing briefly through Wu, its ruler Sun Quan treated him with reverence and built a quiet hall for him. Jiu visited several times a day, and Sun Quan sent attendants to inquire after his well-being. Jiu would appear now as a youth, now as an old man, ate nothing, and refused all gifts. When Sun Quan sought to learn his arts of protection, Jiu declined, saying that Sun Quan’s inner chambers were not conducive to transmission. Enraged, Sun Quan had Jiu bound in armor, tied to a crossbow, and shot. When the arrows were loosed, only the ropes remained—Jiu had vanished without a trace.

Minister Dao Yi remarked: “The Dao within a person is tranquil, silent, empty, and formless—serene, unadorned, and plain. Sensual pleasures cannot sway their resolve, nor can fame and profit muddy their hearts. How could Sun Quan, of all people, be worthy of discussing the Dao? By this time, Jie Jiu had already attained the Dao, mastering transformation, concealment, and the reversal of aging to youth. Truly, he could ‘enter an army without fearing weapons.’ Yet Sun Quan, in a moment of anger, sought to kill him—how base! As the *Daodejing* says: ‘Blades find no place to pierce—why? Because there is no ground for death.’ Let scholars take heed.”

Dragon Shu

Dragon Shu’s origins are unknown. On Mount Jin, he obtained the divine *lingzhi* fruit, the size of a phoenix tree seed. Refining and consuming it, he took a knife-tip’s measure daily. After two years, he achieved immortality through *shijie* and departed.

The *Zhenji Ying* states: Long Bogao was a man of the Later Han. When General Ma Yuan of the Han’s Fubo Army admonished his brother’s son, he praised this man as exemplary and worthy of emulation—this was he. Later, Bogao studied the method of ingesting *qi* for embryonic transformation under the immortal Diao Daolin. He also regularly consumed the "Green Hammer Elixir," feigning drunkenness to conceal his form, and vanished into Fangtai, where he became a disciple of Master Dinglu.

A note clarifies: Bogao’s given name was Shu, a native of Jingzhao. During the Jianwu era of the Han, he served as magistrate of Shandu, and when Ma Yuan, then governor of Lingling, campaigned in the south, he wrote to his brother’s son Yan, saying: “Long Bogao is sincere, circumspect, and prudent; his words are without fault. Humble and frugal, he is upright, impartial, and commanding. I cherish and esteem him—may you and your peers emulate him. Even if you fail to match Bogao, you will still become a man of disciplined conduct, like one who carves a swan but falls short yet still resembles a wild goose.”

Zhao Bing

Zhao Bing was a native of Dongyang in the Later Han.

Having wandered far and wide, he once chanced upon an old acquaintance. Drawing water, he transformed it into wine; shaving a single oar, he fashioned it into dried meat. Both drank their fill and ate to satiety. On another occasion, arriving at a ferry crossing and finding no boat, he spread his mat upon the water and sat, borne across by the wind. He could also chant incantations over withered trees, causing them to burst into bloom and leaf.

Zhe Xiang

Zhe Xiang, styled Boshi, was a native of Guanghan. From youth he devoted himself to the study of the Yellow Emperor and Laozi. Later, he became a disciple of Master Yushuya of Dongping, who had likewise attained the Dao. Xiang was steadfast in the pursuit of nurturing life, maintaining a profound silence. Though his family was wealthy, he believed that amassing riches brought no benefit. He distributed a thousand gold pieces to relieve the poor and suffering. When some admonished him, Xiang replied: “As Dou Ziwen once said, ‘My bestowal of goods is to flee misfortune, not to shun the times.’” Those who understood him all admired his wisdom. On the day he knew he would depart, his body dissolved like a snake shedding its skin.

Wang Yao

Wang Yao, styled Boliao, was a native of Poyang. He had a wife but no children. He was skilled in healing the sick, and none failed to recover under his care. He performed no sacrifices, used no talismanic water or sealed medicines. When treating illness, he would simply spread an eight-foot cloth upon the ground and sit, neither eating nor drinking. After a short while, the patient would recover, and he would rise and depart. If malevolent spirits caused affliction, Yao would draw a prison on the ground, summon them, and all would appear in their true forms within—foxes, lightning serpents, and the like. He would then behead them, burn the corpses, and the patient would immediately recover.

Yao possessed a bamboo basket several feet long. A boy surnamed Qian carried it on a nine-jointed bamboo staff, and when they set out, even in the rain, neither Yao nor his disciples were touched by the wet. At dusk, two torches would often light their way. After traveling some thirty *li*, they would ascend a small mountain and enter a stone chamber. Inside, two men were already present. Upon arrival, Yao took the basket from his disciple, opened it, and removed five bamboo flutes and three reed pipes. He played one himself, giving another to each of the two men in the chamber, and all three played together. After a long while, Yao took his leave. The three flutes were returned to the basket, which the boy Qian carried. The two men in the chamber saw Yao off, saying: “You should have come sooner. Why linger so long in the world of mortals?” Yao replied: “I have come as I am.” A hundred days after returning home, one night the sky again rained. Yao lit a lamp, prepared his belongings, and donned a hempen robe and headscarf he had not worn in over fifty years. His wife asked: “Are you leaving me?” Yao said: “Only for a short while.” She wept and pleaded: “Stay a little longer.” Yao replied: “If so, I shall return.” Over thirty years later, his disciples saw Yao again in the mountains of Ma’er, his complexion as youthful as before. He had already become an immortal.

Chen Yongbo

Chen Yongbo was a native of Nanyang.

Chen Yongbo obtained the Seven Stars Powder formula from the Prince of Huainan. After preparing and consuming it for twenty-one days, he suddenly vanished without a trace. Yongbo had a nephew named Zengzu, aged seventeen, who also took the powder. His father struck his feet and confined him in a sealed chamber, stationing guards to watch him day and night. After twenty-eight days, he too disappeared, gone without a trace. The original formula stated that one would attain immortality after thirty days of ingestion, yet the two Chen youths vanished before the thirty days were complete, so later generations dared not take it. When immortals depart, immortal officials must come to welcome them—it is only that mortals cannot see them.

Liu Zheng

Liu Zheng was a native of Peiguo. Gifted and erudite, he studied all branches of knowledge. Profoundly reflecting that worldly glory and honor are but fleeting, he deemed the pursuit of the Dao the only path to longevity. Thus, he abandoned all ambition for advancement and sought the arts of nurturing life. Diligently seeking rare knowledge, he traveled a thousand *li* without hesitation, and if he encountered someone superior to himself, even a servant or retainer, he would take them as his teacher. Later, he studied the *Mozi’s Five Elements Record* and also ingested the Vermilion Essence Pill. At over one hundred and eighty years of age, his complexion remained that of a child. He delighted in transformations and concealment, able to multiply one body into a hundred, a hundred into a thousand, and a thousand into ten thousand. He could also conceal an entire army, turning men into a grove of trees, or into birds and beasts. If he took another’s belongings and placed them elsewhere, no one would notice. He could cultivate fruit trees, making their blossoms and fruits edible, and conjure a traveling kitchen to serve hundreds. With a breath, he could summon wind, flinging sand and stones; pointing at houses, mountains, forests, or vessels would make them tremble as if about to collapse, but pointing again would restore them. He could transform into a beautiful woman or a wooden figure, traversing thousands of *li* in a single day. With a sigh, water became clouds; with a wave of his hand, mist arose. He could heap soil into mountains or pierce the earth to create abysses. He could shift between old and young, large and small. He walked through water without getting wet, strode upon its surface, and summoned fish, turtles, jiao-dragons, and giant sea turtles from rivers and seas to come ashore. From his mouth, he exhaled five-colored qi spanning ten *li*, rising to connect with the heavens. He could leap hundreds of *zhang* into the air, and later, his whereabouts became unknown.

Wang Qiao

Wang Qiao was a native of Wuyang in Jianwei. In Wuyang stood Mount Beiping, located 147 *li* south of Yizhou, towering 1,300 *zhang* high. At its summit grew a white toad, called the "flesh zhi," which granted longevity to those who consumed it. Only those with the bone structure of immortals could obtain it. Qiao, devoted to the Dao, faced the mountain in reverence for over a decade. His devotion moved the mountain, and he was able to eat the zhi. His body became light, his strength doubled, and he could run as swiftly as a galloping horse. Later, he served as magistrate of Boren and attained the Dao on Mount Dongguan. Today, Wuyang has a shrine to Immortal Qiao. There were three men named Wang Qiao: Prince Jin of the Crown, Magistrate Qiao of Ye, and the flesh-zhi-eating Wang Qiao of Shu, who was a divine immortal of the region.

Cheng Junping

Cheng Junping was a native of Changsha Commandery.

At the age of fifteen, his elder brother sent him to herd geese and sheep. Suddenly, he encountered an immortal elder who took him into Mount Shuhua. Later, his brother searched and found Junping in the mountains. Asking where the geese and sheep he had been herding were, Junping pointed to white stones and said, "These are they." He then drove them to rise, bidding them follow his brother. After ten days, they returned to the foot of the mountain and transformed back into stone. These stones remain to this day, and the mountain was thus named Mount Eyang. This mountain lies twenty *li* north of Changsha County. Originally called Mount Shuhua, it is also known as Mount Shibao. At its summit stands an immortal’s altar and cinnabar dragon. Bi Tian’s poem reads:

*In what year did the feathered guest refine the elixir here?*
*Still, the empty turtle shell guards the crumbling cliff.*
*In the clouds, the immortal’s parrot and hound must remain;*
*Below the mountain, the geese and sheep turn to stubborn stone.*
*How many times has the Xiang’s islets seen the sea transform?*
*No more does the city of Liaoyang see Lingwei return.*
*In what year will the immortal’s chariot come again?*
*Then all shall be sent soaring through the Nine Passes.*

Ding Yue

The extraordinary Ding Yue concealed himself among the ranks of soldiers.

Vei Ziwei became his disciple. One day, he took his leave. As he departed, he said to Ziwei: "Sir, you have attained the Dao, yet two layers of dust still separate you."

*End of Scroll Five of* A Comprehensive Mirror of Perennial Immortals Who Embodied the Dao

*Scroll Six of* A Comprehensive Mirror of Perennial Immortals Who Embodied the Dao

**Lord of the East**
The Lord of the East is also called the Earl of the East or the King Father of the East. He is the primordial essence of the Azure Yang and the progenitor of the ten thousand spirits. He wears a crown of triple ascent and robes of nine-hued clouds and mist, and is also known as the Jade Sovereign Lord. He dwells within the chambers of clouds, with purple clouds as his canopy and azure clouds as his city. Immortal youths stand in attendance, and jade maidens scatter incense. His true officials, immortal companions, and celestial friends number in the billions, each with their appointed duties, all receiving his command. Thus, those men who attain the Dao have their names recorded in his register. Their merits and deeds are assessed, then reported to the Primordial Beginning, who conveys the decree to the Lord Lao.

Another account states that the Lord of the East is the Azure Lad, governing Mount Fangzhu in the Eastern Sea.

**Ninefold Primordial Master**
The Ninefold Primordial Master refined purple gold and compounded the divine elixir to ascend as an immortal. His scripture is titled *The Scripture of Geng and Xin*.

**Supreme Yellow Master**
The Supreme Yellow Master cultivated the Way of pacing the Dipper and attained the method of concealment. He could render himself invisible.

**Master Everborn**
Master Everborn regularly rinsed his mouth with water mixed with jade fragments and consumed it to ascend.

**Master Everlasting**
Master Everlasting perfected the Dao and became the Immortal Earl of the Dark Continent.

**Master Zhang Mu**
Master Zhang Mu cultivated the Supreme Ultimate and ascended as an immortal in the first year of the *Nianji* era. Later, he transmitted this method to Gong Shujin, Wang Wenqing, and Yin Zifang, all of whom attained the Dao.

**Master Gaoqiu**
Master Gaoqiu was a man of the Yin dynasty.

He was devoted to the Dao and entered the Six Radiant Mountains, where he lived for over five hundred and twenty years, studying only the *Yellow and White Scripture of the Dao*. He consumed wood-based elixirs, later compounded the *Vast Cinnabar*, and thereby attained terrestrial immortality, wandering among the Five Peaks for over two hundred years. Later, he obtained the *Golden Liquid* and ascended to the Great Clarity. Today, he serves as the Perfected One of the Central Peak. The *Declarations of the Perfected* states: "His tomb lies in Wenxi County of Zhongshan." The annotation clarifies: "Zhongshan has a Nüxi County; Wenxi belongs to Hedong."

**Master Pu**
Master Pu often rode a white deer to gather magic mushrooms on Mount Mao.

**Master Everchild**
Master Everchild studied the Dao on Mount Di, where he cultivated the *Scripture of Bathing and the Contracting Bell* and attained immortality.

**Elder of the Nine Springs**
The Elder of the Nine Springs serves as the Lord of the Fangzhang Palace, overseeing all water spirits of the world, as well as the yin-essence water creatures such as dragons and whales.

**Master Wanqiu**
Master Wanqiu ingested the *Regulating Destiny Pill* and attained the Dao. By the end of King Tang of Yin’s reign, he had already lived over a thousand years. He transmitted the method to his disciple Jiang Ruochun, who, after three hundred years of practice, appeared no older than a fifteen-year-old child. Peng Zu’s teacher studied under him and received three of his formulas.

**Master Green Crow**
Master Green Crow was a disciple of Peng Zu. Having received the teachings of an enlightened master and mastered the subtle principles of immortality, he entered Mount Huayin to study the Dao. After 471 years, he underwent twelve trials, failing three. Later, he ingested the *Golden Liquid* and ascended to heaven. The Supreme Ultimate Dao Lord deemed that, having failed three trials, he was but an immortal and not a *Perfected One*.

**Master Longhair**
Master Longhair often went bareheaded and singing:
*"Silken gold, silken gold,
Enter the Gate of Heaven.
Call forth the long essence,
Draw the Dark Spring.
Sound the Celestial Drum,
Nurture the Cinnabar Field."*
The Archivist of the Pillars heard this and said: *"The words Master Longhair sings embody the Way of ingesting the Five Stars and guarding the Grotto Chamber."*

**Cai Qiong**
Cai Qiong, styled Boyao, studied under Laozi and received the *Tai Xuan Yangsheng Fu* and the *Returning Cinnabar Formula*. Through their combined practice, he attained the Dao and ascended to heaven in broad daylight. He often used the *Yangsheng Fu* to revive the dead—so long as their bones remained, casting the talisman upon them would restore them to life.

**Liezi**
Liezi was a native of Zheng, surnamed Lie and named Yukou. He sought the Dao from Master Guan Yin, then studied under Master Huqiu Zilin, and later under Master Lao Shang. He befriended Master Bogao Zijin. After nine years of practicing the Way of these two masters, he could ride the wind and rain. His disciple Yan Hui asked: *"When you speak of seeking the Dao, is it for wealth?"* Liezi replied: *"Jie and Zhou valued profit over the Dao and thus perished."* He once lived in seclusion in the Zheng gardens for forty years, unknown to others. After attaining the Dao, he composed a book titled *Liezi*, which circulated in the world.

During the Tang dynasty, Emperor Xuanzong posthumously bestowed upon him the title *Master of Serene Emptiness*, and his book was titled *The True Classic of Serene Emptiness*. During the Song dynasty, Emperor Huizong honored him as *Perfected Lord of Profound Mystery*.

**Zhuangzi**
Zhuangzi was a native of Song. His surname was Zhuang, given name Zhou, and courtesy name Zixiu. Born in Meng County of Suiyang, he studied the Dao of the Old Master. During the reign of King Hui of Liang, he served as the keeper of the lacquer garden in Meng County but, considering the position too base, refused to take office. King Wei of Chu sent envoys bearing jade and silk to summon him, wishing to appoint him as prime minister. Two grand officers were dispatched ahead, saying: *"We wish to burden you with the cares of our land."* Zhuangzi was fishing on the banks of the Pu River, holding his rod and ignoring them. He replied: *"I have heard that in Chu there is a divine turtle, dead for three thousand years, which the king keeps wrapped in silk and stored in a shrine. Would this turtle rather have died to leave its bones honored, or lived to drag its tail through the mud?"* The two grand officers said: *"It would rather live and drag its tail through the mud."* Zhuangzi said: *"Go your way. I shall drag my tail through the mud."*

Later, the King of Song sent envoys to summon Zhuangzi. Zhuangzi said: *"Have you seen the sacrificial ox? It is clothed in embroidered robes and fed with fine grain. Yet when it is led into the great temple, though it might wish to be a lonely calf, could it ever be so?"* He urged them: *"Leave quickly, lest you defile me. How could I be shackled by those who rule states?"* Thus, he never again took office.

Later, having attained the Dao, he composed a book titled *Zhuangzi*. The *True Records* states: *"Zhuangzi studied under Master Chang Sang, receiving his esoteric teachings, and was thus called Zhuangzi."* He concealed himself in Mount Baodu, consumed the *Northern Nurturing Fire Elixir*, ascended to heaven in broad daylight, and was appointed as an editor in the *Taiwei* Bureau. A note below clarifies: *"Master Chang Sang was the teacher of Bian Que, as recorded in the *Wei Annals* and the *Records of the Grand Historian*."* If the world truly knew Zhuangzi as such, his book would be all the more revered.

During the Tang dynasty, Emperor Xuanzong posthumously bestowed upon him the title *Master of Southern Florescence*, and his book was titled *The True Classic of Southern Florescence*. During the Song dynasty, Emperor Huizong honored him as *Perfected Lord of Subtle Wonder and Primordial Penetration*.

**Liu Yue**
During the Zhou dynasty, there was a Master Kuang named Xu who cultivated the Dao on Mount Nanzhang.

Later, a young man visited him several times, his words and discourse extraordinary and grand. The Master found him remarkable and asked, "I have long heard of your noble conduct—may I inquire as to your hometown and name?" The youth replied, "I am Liu Yue, dwelling to the left of this mountain. Below the peak stands a stone, roughly two feet high; knock upon it, and it shall invite you in." The Master followed his instructions and struck the stone, whereupon it suddenly parted, revealing a cavernous entrance. A young attendant with side-locks greeted him, leading him forward for several dozen paces. Then, two maidservants in azure robes, bearing crimson staffs, guided him onward. Gradually, pavilions and terraces came into view, their jade and gold hues shimmering in contrast, while rare birds and strange beasts roamed amidst exotic grasses and trees. A Perfected One, crowned with a jade diadem and girded with a vermilion sash and sword, came forth to welcome him. The Master wished to remain, but the Perfected One, sensing his intent, said, "Your hidden merits will soon be fulfilled; our reunion is not far off, and there will be time enough to follow me another day." He offered three cups of jade wine and a sip of the *Longevity-Preserving Elixir*, then sent him forth. When the Master turned to look back, the stone he had struck appeared just as it had before. On another day, he knocked again, but there was no response.

At present, outside the three gates of the Tai Ping Xing Jin Palace on Mount Lu stands a pavilion built of stone, named *Immortal Stone*. Upon the stone, the characters "Liu the Immortal" remain inscribed.

**Wang Guo**
Wang Guo was a worthy man of Chu. Disgusted by the filth of the world and the clamor of fame and profit, he retreated into the mountains and forests, cultivating stillness and withdrawal in all his conduct. One day, he rode away upon a cloud.

**Master Guigu**
Master Guigu was a man of the time of Duke Ping of Jin. His surname was Wang and his given name Ling; his place of origin is unknown. He received the Dao from the Old Lord. Entering the Cloud Qi Mountains to gather herbs and concoct elixirs, he attained the Dao through ingestion, his complexion like that of a young boy. He dwelled in Ghost Valley of Green Creek, whence his sobriquet.

Su Qin and Zhang Yi sought the Dao from the Master. The Master said, "Hearing the Dao is easy; cultivating the Dao is difficult. As your minds are still entangled with worldly concerns, you may study the art of persuasion to suit the needs of the present age. You will surely become ministers of state, but you will not escape death as ministers." If they were unafraid, he would transmit the teachings. The two men requested instruction, and after three years, they took their leave. The Master said, "You two have forsaken the eternal longevity of the pine and cedar for the fleeting glory of a single day—what a pity!"

Later, he sent them a letter, saying: "Gentlemen, you have toiled with four-horse chariots, your achievements and fame resplendent, the Nine Provinces bowing in reverence. Yet like spring blossoms that wither by autumn, your glory cannot long endure. Your allotted days draw to a close, and your time nears its end. Have you not seen the trees by the river? Horses and carriages break their branches, waves erode their roots—such is the fate of those who dwell in such places. Have you not seen the pines and cypresses of Mount Song and Mount Tai, or the catalpa and sandalwood of Hua and Huo? Their leaves and trunks reach the azure clouds, their roots penetrate the Three Springs, enduring for a thousand autumns and ten thousand years, untouched by axe or blade.

**The Fox and the Reviving Herb**
Once, a silver fox died of plague. A crow, like a raven, placed a blade of grass over its face, and the fox revived. The matter was reported to the throne, and the First Emperor of Qin dispatched envoys bearing the grass to inquire of the Master. The Master said, "In the vast sea lie the Ten Isles. On Ancestral Isle grows the herb of immortality, sprung from the midst of jasper fields, also called *yangshen zhi* (Spirit-Nourishing Mushroom). Its leaves resemble wild rice but do not grow in clusters; a single stalk can revive one person."

The Master dwelled among men for several hundred years, after which his whereabouts became unknown.

Some say that Ghost Valley lay in Yangcheng, south of Mount Song. **Mao Meng**—styled Chucheng—was a native of the southern gate of Xianyang. He was the great-great-grandfather of Ying, the Minister of Destiny of Shuqing, and a disciple of Master Ghost Valley. He entered Mount Hua to cultivate the Dao, later ascending to heaven in broad daylight, riding clouds and driving dragons. Earlier, a song had circulated in his village:

*"The immortal attained is Mao Chucheng,
Who rides dragons aloft into the Grand Clarity,
At times descending to Dark Continent to sport at Red Citadel.
Those who follow in his line shall be my kin—Ying.
If you would learn, emulate him on the feast of Jiaping."*

When the First Emperor of Qin heard this, he renamed the La festival *Jiaping*, in hopes of attaining immortality.

**Lord Ximen** was a man who from youth cherished the Dao and mastered the apocrypha and weft texts. He presented the *Chart of Mountain Opening* to the First Emperor of Qin, who failed to heed it.

**Xu Fu**, styled Junfang, was of unknown origin. During the reign of the First Emperor of Qin, many in Dayuan perished unjustly by the roadside. Frequently, crows resembling ravens would appear, placing blades of grass over the faces of the dead, who would revive at once. Xu Fu took the grass to inquire of Master Ghost Valley of Beiguo, who said it was the *Spirit-Nourishing Mushroom* from Ancestral Isle. The First Emperor then believed it could be sought and obtained. He sought out the most sincere Daoists and found Xu Fu, dispatching five hundred boys and five hundred girls—some say three thousand each—who set sail in towered ships to search for Ancestral Isle. They never returned, and their fate remains unknown. Later, when Shen Xi attained the Dao, the Yellow Emperor and Laozi sent Xu Fu as an emissary, arriving in a chariot drawn by white tigers. Thus, later generations knew that Xu Fu had attained the Dao.

The *Supplement to Biographies of Immortals* records: During the Kaiyuan era of the Tang, a scholar suffered from half his body withering and blackening. The imperial physician Zhang Shangke and others could not save him. His family gathered and said, "With a body in such a state, how can it long endure? We have heard that in the great sea dwell divine immortals. Only by seeking their arts can this illness be cured." His clan tried to dissuade him, but he would not be stopped. He took provisions and an attendant to the shores of the great sea near Dengzhou. There, they encountered an empty boat, which proved to be what they had brought. They hoisted the sail and followed the wind. After more than ten days, they neared a solitary island where several hundred people stood as if in audience. Soon, they reached the shore, where a woman was washing herbs. They asked who those people were, and she pointed, saying, "The white-haired one seated in the center is Lord Xu." They asked who Lord Xu was, and she replied, "Do you know of Xu Fu from the time of the First Emperor of Qin?" They said, "We do." She said, "This is he."

After a moment, the crowd dispersed. The scholar then disembarked to pay his respects, recounting his circumstances in full and seeking medical treatment. Lord Xu said, "Your illness—encountering me means you shall live." He first fed him a broth and rice, the vessels all strangely small. The scholar found the portions meager, but Lord Xu said, "If you can finish this, it will be a fine measure—though I fear you may not." The scholar ate continuously, consuming several bowls' worth until he was full and could eat no more. Lord Xu then gave him a small vessel of wine, which he drank until drunk.

The next day, Lord Xu gave him several black pellets to eat, after which he passed several *dou* of black fluid, and his illness was cured. The scholar asked to stay and serve him, but Lord Xu said, "You have an official position awaiting you; it is not yet fitting for you to remain. I shall send you back with a gust of wind—do not worry about the distance of your return journey." He then gave the scholar a pouch of yellow medicine, saying, "This medicine is effective for all ailments. If you encounter someone ill upon your return, you may administer it with a *daogui*."

The scholar returned, reaching Dengzhou in a few days. He presented the medicine to the court, and Emperor Xuanzong ordered those who were ill to take it—all were cured.

**Guo Sichao**
Guo Sichao was a man of Yan during the Zhou dynasty.

Guo Sichao and his three brothers studied the Dao together, with Sichao as the eldest. During the Qin dynasty, he attained the Dao and came to reside south of Gouqu Mountain. Where he lived, he built embankments to dam the streams, deepening the waters, and raised walls and dikes—traces of which remain discernible today. As *Zhengao* records: "Before his dwelling lies a pond, which was constructed by Guo Sichao." He heightened the banks, ensuring the water grew deep. Yet over the long passage of ages, the pond’s walls have crumbled.

A note adds: The present dwelling seems to be the residence of Secretary Xu, before which there is indeed a pond. To the west stands a dike, which dams the waters of Liuji—though this lies far from Guo Qian’s location. Guo Qian dwells northwest of the Northern Grotto, where a great reservoir now exists. Sichao likely first resided there, though the meaning of "before his dwelling" remains unclear; perhaps Secretary Xu later established fields by the reservoir. Further explanations follow.

Sichao would often drift upon the pond in a small boat, striking the gunwale as he sang:

*"A limpid pool girds the numinous peaks,
Long forests lush with verdant green.
Dark birds conceal themselves in secluded wilds,
While awakened words flow with ease.
Beating the oars, I ride the divine waves,
Bowing my head in hope of the Dawn Wind—*
*(Here, ‘Dawn Wind’ refers to the jade breeze of the Upper Clarity, not the feathered creature of the *Mao Odes*.)
*Yet the hour of liberation eludes me,
And I wander carefree amid the wooded hills.
The waves surge beyond the Nine Abysses,
As I refine the Dao and preserve my true nature.
I tuck away these spirit-phoenix wings,
Concealing my radiant dragon scales.
The inch within my breast soars high,
While myriad breaths all turn to dust.
I pity the morning-born clam and toad,
For who can exhaust your chariot wheels?*
*(The favor of women knows no bounds, nor the love of men ever tires of their wheels—here, the morning-born clam and toad serve as metaphors for the fleeting nature of mortal life.)
*Roaming the void, I let my spirit soar,
Treading the formless with phantom steps.
The round sun gleams with radiant mist,
As the Nine Phoenixes sing at dawn’s first light."*

I spread my wings to fan the Celestial Ford,
Shrouding the auspicious clouds in flight.
Thus I arrive at the Great Tenuity’s halls,
Embracing this golden pear nectar.
Roaming beyond the Dark Abyss,
Neither existing nor perishing—
*(The Dark Abyss and Nine Abysses denote realms beyond the Eight Extremities, atop the Nine Radiant Mists.)*
I ascend in flight to the Wood Star,
Also called the Dark Luminance, the easternmost of the Yang Abysses,
*(As the transcendent Lu Ao once declared: “I have made tryst with Hanman beyond the Nine Abysses.”)*
I mount the reverent dance of the Divine Empyrean,
Arrayed in radiance, girded with the Nine Suns.
The August Emperor’s dragon carriage aligns,
And I arrive at the Northern Flower Chamber.
The divine tiger stirs the jade grove,
As fragrant winds merge into one.
I unseal the gates of the hidden dark,
Where numinous transformations draw near to the mystery of annihilation.

*(Four served as Jade Terrace Bearer of the Canopy,
Hence the phrase “the August Emperor’s dragon carriage aligns.”)*
*(It is further said: In the true Dharma, those who serve the Three Offices for six hundred years without transgression are elevated in rank. When Four’s term ended, he was promoted to Left Immortal Duke of the Nine Palaces, overseeing the Jade Terrace Bearers of the Canopy—a post long vacant until Sihe succeeded him.)*
The mountain abides among the people,
And to this day a level marsh is called “Guo Thousand,”
For Four’s surname lingers on the lips of the folk.
Year after year, whenever Four journeyed forth,
He would pass through this place to visit Sihe,
Roaming the plains and hills.
*(A note below states: This is the Central Plain of the Mao tradition.)*
*(By this account, Guo Thousand was merely a place of cultivation, not a dwelling. His residence was the Prefect’s estate, which proves correct. Today, the embankments have crumbled, the central waters no longer grand, and all regard it as mere farmland. Yet the land remains broad and slightly dammed, still forming a pool where one might row a boat and sing. But none can trace the footsteps of that distant age—how lamentable! Later it is said: Even after Four’s promotion, he still yearned for his former home, often passing through to feast in the Eternal Constancy and gaze fondly upon his companions.)*

**Zhou Taibin**
Zhou Taibin was a Daoist of the Qin era.
He studied the Dao with Jiang Shumao,
Dwelling on Gouqu Mountain,
Where he cultivated the five fruits and five pungent herbs,
Selling them to purchase cinnabar.
To this day, the mountain is thick with chives—
The legacy of his planting—
Now called Chive Mountain,
West of Great Mao Peak, where great chives abound.
Elsewhere, too, garlic, lotus roots, and water chestnuts grow,
For Chive Mountain and Jiangba are one and the same.
Both attained immortality.
Taibin was gifted in the arts,
Skilled at the zither,
Able to play a single string and harmonize all eight tones,
Teaching Mi Changsheng and Sun Guangtian.
*(Guangtian was none other than Sun Deng.)*
**Jiang Shumao**

**Jiang Shumao**

Jiang Shumao’s origins are unknown. He was often a companion to Zhou Taibin, studying the Dao and cultivating immortality. Today, he serves as Left Minister in Penglai. The Jiang clans of Nanzheng are his descendants. Shumao once wrote to the officials of the Great Ultimate, saying: *"Formerly, I studied the Dao at Guigu; attained it at Shaoshi; nurtured my wings at Huayang; and awaited ascension in the Land of Leisure. At times, I rode the maple-wheel chariot and feasted at Gouqu. In moments of awakening, I sighed deeply at the swiftness of change—things endure while men perish. What labor is mine to bear?"*

*The Declarations of the Perfected* states: *"In the Qin era, the Daoist Zhou Taibin and the Marquis of Baling, Jiang Shumao, came to dwell at the foot of Gouqu Mountain, where they also planted the five fruits and five pungent herbs."* Shumao was enfeoffed as marquis during the reign of King Xiao of Qin. The place is now called Jiangba, named after him. A note below reads: *"The name of the land remains, and a great road still exists, running from behind Lesser Mao Peak to Yanling—now called Jiangba Road."* However, during the reign of Duke Xiao of Qin, the land had not yet been unified, and Chu established commanderies. Baling County was first established in the early Jin dynasty, so there could not have been a marquisate of Baling. It was likely the Ba of Bashu.

**Gong Zhongyang**

Gong Zhongyang received the Six Disciplines of the Stepping Method from the Lesser Lad of Mount Song.

**Gu Xizi**

Gu Xizi studied the Dao and attained immortality, becoming an authentic official of the Supreme Perfected. Dongfang Shuo was his disciple, receiving from him the *Plate of Wind*, the *Maps of Mount Zhong and Penglai*, and the *True Forms of the Divine Continent*.

*The Declarations of the Perfected* states: *"Gu Xizi served as Right Immortal Duke of the Great Ultimate."*

**Wang Zhonggao**

Wang Zhonggao’s origins are unknown.

In the markets of Huainan, he was often seen divining. Elders of successive generations beheld him, his face ever bearing the bloom of youth. Wu Bei spoke of him to Liu An, King of Huainan, who, upon hearing of him, rejoiced and immediately dispatched a summons. Bei said, "Zhonggao often stays at Zhang Meng’s home. I am on good terms with Meng, who always says that Zhonggao is of upright and unyielding character, difficult to invite, and cannot be bent by authority. I shall persuade him through Meng." The king ordered a carriage prepared and sent Bei to Meng’s residence to extend the invitation. Meng said, "Master Wang mentioned yesterday that he would be traveling briefly, though nearby, and we might see him from time to time. He has now gone out to divine and will return by evening." Bei waited, and before long, Zhonggao returned. Seeing Bei, he laughed heartily and said to Meng, "When I spoke of a brief departure yesterday, I was referring to this guest." He then followed Bei to see the king. The king came out to greet him, facing east to receive the Dao, and performed the rites of a disciple. Zhonggao said, "I am but an ordinary man who has merely attained the Way of long life and immortality. I possess no other abilities. Fearing my knowledge is too shallow to offer to Your Highness, I harbor no reluctance in my heart." The king repeatedly entreated him, but Zhonggao said to Bei, "I wish to transmit the Dao to the king, yet his heart and will are shallow. Even if he cannot practice it, he should not hear of it." He added, "The Yellow Emperor was the elder of my father’s generation. Formerly, I studied under Master Zhu Xiang and received the secret of long life. Later, I studied under Master Huang Dong and received the Way of immortality. To this day, I have lived for over six thousand years." He then transmitted the Dao to the king, and afterward, none knew where Zhonggao had gone.

**Gongsun Jing**

Gongsun Qing studied the Dao on Mount Dongliangfu, also said to be Mount Ziye. Within the mountain’s palace, there were ingredients for concocting the elixir of immortality. Those who consumed it would immediately ascend as immortals. The spirits of the sun and moon dwelled within the palace. When compounding the elixir, they chanted:

*The Jade Maiden divides the doses,*
*The Toad and Frog govern the blending;*
*One pill refines the human form,*
*Two pills beautify the countenance.*

During the reign of Emperor Wu of Han, when magicians ventured into the sea in search of Penglai, Gongsun Qing went ahead and encountered an old man leading a dog. The emperor believed him to be an immortal and hoped to obtain his true essence.

**Li Shaojun**

Li Shaojun, styled Yunyi, was fond of the Dao. He entered Mount Tai to gather herbs and practiced the arts of grain avoidance and bodily preservation. He met An Qisheng, and when Shaojun fell gravely ill, he kowtowed, begging for his life. An Qisheng gave him a dose of *Divine Tower Powder*, and he immediately recovered. In the early years of Emperor Wu of Han, he arrived at Yong during the suburban sacrifice and witnessed the Five Sacrificial Altars. Thereafter, the emperor performed the suburban sacrifice once every three years. At that time, Shaojun presented the emperor with the method of *Sacrificial Favor*, grain avoidance, and rejuvenation. He often claimed to be seventy years old yet could make things revert to youth. The emperor showed him an ancient bronze vessel, and Shaojun said, "This vessel was displayed in the Wuqin Terrace during the tenth year of Duke Huan of Qi." Upon examining the inscription, it was indeed a vessel from Duke Huan’s reign. The entire court was astonished, deeming Shaojun a man of several hundred years. Shaojun told the emperor, "Through sacrificial rites, all things may be summoned, and cinnabar can be transmuted into gold. Once gold is formed, it may be fashioned into vessels for food and drink, thereby prolonging life. With prolonged life, the immortals of Penglai may be seen. Through the Feng and Shan sacrifices, one may attain immortality—such was the case with the Yellow Emperor." He added, "I once traveled upon the sea and met An Qisheng, who fed me jujubes as large as melons." Thereupon, the emperor began performing the *Sacrificial Favor* rites and dispatched magicians into the sea to seek Penglai and the likes of An Qisheng.

Another account states that Shaojun, an ancient minister, could congeal mercury into silver and refine cinnabar into gold. Those who consumed it would ascend to heaven in broad daylight, their bodies refined to traverse the void, riding flying dragons to the eight distant realms or mounting white swans to circle the nine heavens. The jujubes of the Dark Sea were as large as melons, and the plums of Mount Zhong were as vast as basins. Having eaten them, he gained wondrous radiance.

The Master An Qisheng transmitted to me oral instructions, enabling the preservation of all things that may be perfected. Thereupon, the emperor held him in the highest esteem and built him a grand residence.

The *Baopuzi* states: According to *The Household Records of Li Shaojun* compiled by Dong Zhongshu, Shaojun possessed the formula for immortality, yet his family was impoverished and lacked the means to procure the necessary ingredients. Thus, he entered official service to secure a path to wealth, and once his Dao was accomplished, he departed.

Further, according to the *Han Dynasty Records of the Chu Palace* with annotations: As Shaojun was about to depart, Emperor Wu dreamed of ascending Mount Song with him. They encountered an emissary in embroidered robes riding a dragon down from the clouds, who declared, "The Great One summons Shaojun." The emperor awoke and said to his attendants, "As in my dream, Shaojun will leave me." Several days later, Shaojun fell ill and died. When placed in his coffin, the emperor ordered it opened—no body was found, only his robes and cap remained.

*Comprehensive Mirror of Perfected Immortals Through the Ages Who Embodied the Dao*, Scroll Six—concluded.
*Comprehensive Mirror of Perfected Immortals Through the Ages Who Embodied the Dao*, Scroll Seven.

Dong Zhongjun

Dong Zhongjun was a native of Linhuai. From his youth, he practiced qi-cultivation and bodily refinement, and though he lived past a hundred years, he did not age. Once, falsely accused and imprisoned, he feigned death—his body rotted and teemed with maggots. The jailers carried him out, and only then did he revive, departing through *shi jie* (corpse liberation).

Che Zihou

Che Zihou was a native of Fufeng. Emperor Wu of Han admired his purity and tranquility, gradually promoting him to the position of *Shizhong* (Attendant Within). One morning, he told his family, "I have now been appointed to an immortal office. This spring I shall depart, but by midsummer I will return briefly before leaving again." His words proved true.

Emperor Wu, missing him, composed a song:
*"Fine the hidden orchid, its beauty unfurled,
Yet lurking within, the seductive and wild.
Bright the sun, resplendent the day,
The breeze lingers, scattering fragrance away.
O Heaven, unwise—
The perfected one departs for the immortal skies.
The celestial path stretches far, no return in sight,
Unbidden, my tears soak my robes in their flight."*

Wang Xing

Wang Xing was a native of Yangcheng. He dwelled in the Wan Valley, an ordinary man unaware of the Dao, with no thought of cultivating it. In the second year of the *Yuanfeng* era of Emperor Wu of Han, on the *jiazi* day of the first month, the emperor ascended Mount Songgao and climbed the *Dayu* stone to establish a Daoist temple. He sent Dong Zhongjun, Dongfang Shuo, and others to purify themselves and meditate upon the spirits. Suddenly, an immortal appeared, towering over two *zhang* in height, his ears extending above his head and hanging down to his shoulders. Emperor Wu bowed and questioned him. The immortal replied, "I am a man of Mount Jiuyi. I heard that on the stone mountain of the Central Peak grows inch-long *changpu* (calamus) with nine nodes, and consuming it grants longevity. Thus, I have come to gather it." With that, he vanished.

Emperor Wu turned to his attendants and said, "He is no mere cultivator of the Dao or consumer of herbs—he must be a spirit of the Central Peak, come to instruct me." Thereupon, he gathered and consumed *changpu* for two years. However, Emperor Wu favored rich, heated foods, and after eating *changpu*, he would invariably feel stifled and unwell, so he ceased. Many of his officials also consumed it, but none could persist. Only Wang Xing, having heard the immortal’s words, gathered and consumed it without pause.

Later, he became the *Zhubu* (Registrar) of Pujiang County. Hearing of divine transformations and immortals within the county’s borders, he would gaze toward the clouds, his heart filled with sincerity and longing. He resigned his post and secluded himself on Mount Qiuchang, where the twenty-two transformations occur. Below lies a cavern, within which dwells a thousand-year-old golden toad. According to ancient lore, those who behold it shall attain the Dao.

Atop the mountain grew a *qiong* flower tree, eight or nine feet in girth, its leaves resembling those of the white sandalwood. Though winter’s chill endured, its foliage remained ever lush. It was said that when this tree bloomed, someone on the mountain would ascend to heaven and attain the Dao. Its blossoms resembled hibiscus, their fragrance carrying for miles.

Wang Xing dwelled on this mountain, preserving his spirit and embracing the One, absorbing the radiance of the sun and moon in inner cultivation. He also practiced the *Way of Riding Dragons and Treading the Constellations*, refining himself for nine years. Suddenly, the *qiong* flowers burst into bloom, and the golden toad leapt forth, leading him into the cavern. There, he encountered the Golden Liquid Elixir, bowed, and consumed it. Later, a cloud chariot arrived to welcome him, and he ascended to heaven in broad daylight. Because Wang Xing attained the Dao, later generations transmitted the tale as the *Transformation of the Registrar*.

**Marquis of Longevity Light**
The Marquis of Longevity Light could subdue a hundred ghosts and myriad specters, compelling them to bind themselves and reveal their forms. A woman in his village fell ill from a specter’s affliction; the marquis subdued it, and a serpent of several dozen feet died outside her door. There was also a divine tree—anyone who rested beneath it would die, and birds that flew over it would fall. The marquis subdued it as well, and in the height of summer, the tree withered and shed its leaves. A serpent, seven or eight *zhang* in length, was found hanging dead among its branches.

Emperor Wu of Han heard of this and summoned him for an audience. The emperor tested him, saying: “After midnight in my palace hall, several figures in crimson robes with unbound hair, carrying torches, often follow me. Can you subdue them?” The marquis replied: “Such minor apparitions are easily dispelled.” The emperor secretly ordered three men to impersonate them. The marquis subdued the three, who immediately collapsed to the ground, lifeless. The emperor, greatly startled, said: “They were no specters—I was merely testing you.” He revived them, and they awoke.

**Wei Shuqing**

Wei Shuqing was one who attained immortality through ingesting mica. In the eighth month of the second year of the Tianhan era of Emperor Wu of Han, on the day *renchen*, the Venerable Lord once more dispatched Wei Shuqing to meet the emperor. At that time, the emperor was at leisure in his palace hall when suddenly he saw a figure clad in feathered robes and a star-crown, arriving in a cloud-chariot drawn by white deer. Startled, the emperor asked who it was, and the figure replied: “I am Wei Shuqing of Zhongshan.” The emperor said: “If you are a subject of Zhongshan, then you are my minister—come forward and speak with me.” Yet in an instant, Shuqing vanished without a trace. The emperor deeply regretted this and immediately sent Liang Bo to Zhongshan to seek him. Though he could not be found, Liang Bo brought Shuqing’s son, Dushi, back to see the emperor. The emperor asked: “Where is your father now?” Dushi replied: “My father has long been devoted to the Dao, shunning worldly affairs. He left our family forty-five years ago, saying he would enter Mount Hua.” The emperor again dispatched Liang Bo and Dushi together to Mount Hua to search for him. At the foot of a sheer cliff, they saw Shuqing playing a game of *bo* with several others atop the crag, enveloped in purple clouds, their pieces fashioned of white jade. Several immortals stood behind them, holding jade tablets. Dushi bowed twice from afar, and Shuqing said: “Why have you come?” Dushi replied: “The emperor deeply regrets that he could not speak with you the other day. He has now sent the emissary Liang Bo and me to seek you, hoping to see you once more.” Shuqing said: “I was previously sent by the Most High to inform the emperor of the time of great calamity and the method to avert peril, that the dynasty’s fate might be prolonged. But the emperor was arrogant and self-important, failing to recognize the true Dao, so I departed. Now I must join the Central Yellow and Grand Unity to stabilize the celestial origin—I shall not return again.” Liang Bo returned and reported this, and the emperor was filled with remorse. Then Dushi asked Shuqing: “May I ask who those seated with you are?” Shuqing replied: “They are Master Hongya, Xu You, Chao Fu, Lord Tai Xuan, Feihuangzi, Prince Wang Zijin, and Xue Rong. The world is soon to descend into great chaos. In several hundred years, earth will perish and metal will fall. Return home and retrieve the jade case beneath the northwestern pillar of my study. Inside is a divine book of plain silk—take it and follow its instructions for a year, and you will be able to ride the clouds. When your cultivation is complete, come join me here.” Dushi bowed and took his leave.

Later, he taught the divine method to Liang Bo’s master. Together, they refined and ingested the elixir, and both attained immortality.

**Dai Meng**
Dai Meng, a Daoist of Mount Wudang, styled Chengzi, was a native of Wuwei. During the reign of Emperor Wu of Han, he served as a general in the palace. Originally surnamed Yan, named Ji, and styled Zhongwei, he changed his name after attaining the Dao. Some say he lived during the reign of Emperor Ming of Han. Orphaned in youth, he cared for his mother with utmost devotion and was fond of studying immortality, traveling throughout the land. After his mother passed, he entered Mount Huayang, where he consumed white wood, Solomon’s seal, mica, realgar, cinnabar, and lingzhi mushrooms. His resolve for the Dao grew ever stronger with time. One day, the Pure Numinous Perfected Lord Pei bestowed upon him a jade pendant, a golden cauldron scripture, and the Stone Essence Golden Light Talisman. Through diligent cultivation, he felt his body grow lighter. He wandered famous mountains and sought transcendent realms, covering seven hundred *li* in a day, and attained the Dao of deathlessness. At his waist hung over ten scrolls of scripture, known as *The Yellow Writ of the Grand Tenuity*. The immortals Guo Zihua, Zhang Jilian, Zhao Shuda, and Shan Shiyuan often kept him company, and Xie Yun made him his teacher. Yun, styled Daotong, was a native of Liyang. In his youth, he was abducted and sold to Dongyang.

After some time, he reported his case to the authorities but was falsely accused in Wuniu. When his execution seemed imminent, an elderly man appeared at night to bestow a talisman upon him, and a yellow-robed youth came and went, thus sparing him from death. During the Xiankang era of Emperor Cheng of Jin, he arrived at Mount Wudang in Xiangyang, where he met Dai Meng. Observing his bearing and physique, he realized that the one who had granted him the talisman in prison was none other than Meng. Thereupon, he took the disciple’s rites and sought the essential teachings of the Dao.

Later, he entered official service, serving as magistrate of Liyang, Xinfeng, and Xidao counties. Wherever he went, his spiritual efficacy was widely attested. Yun remained youthful even at seventy, while Meng would appear and vanish unpredictably, his whereabouts unknown. *The Declarations of the Perfected* states: "The yellow-robed youth was an official of the Jade Pendant and Golden Cauldron."

**Shan Shiyuan**
Shan Shiyuan received the methods of Master Dai Meng. Every evening, before retiring, he would first recite *The Inner Radiance of the Yellow Court Classic* once, allowing his hun and po souls to refine themselves. He practiced this for twenty-one years and attained transcendence. The ideal was to complete ten thousand recitations, though three or four in an evening were considered excellent. Shiyuan achieved the Dao and became the Perfected Lord of Grand Harmony.

**Mao Bodao**
Mao Bodao, Liu Daogong, Xie Zhijian, and Zhang Zhaoqi were all men of the Later Han. Together, they studied the Dao on Mount Wangwu for over forty years and jointly compounded an elixir of transcendence. Bodao consumed it first and immediately died; Daogong followed and likewise perished. Zhijian and Zhaoqi dared not ingest it, so they abandoned the elixir and returned home. Before leaving the mountain, they suddenly saw Bodao and Daogong each riding a white deer, accompanied by immortals bearing ceremonial tablets. The two men were struck with grief and remorse, whereupon Daogong taught them the method of consuming fuling. Later, they too transcended the world.

A note in *The Declarations of the Perfected* states: "Xie Zhijian appears in three different accounts—one where he accompanied Ge Xuan, another where he resided in the Deer Track Grotto.
