This version is the most detailed and likely the correct one. The others may refer to individuals of the same name."

**Su Lin**
The gentleman Su, whose personal name was Lin and courtesy name Zixuan, was a native of Qu Shui in Puyang. From youth, he possessed extraordinary conduct and stood apart from his peers. His resolve to seek the Perfected grew ever more steadfast with each passing day.

Once, he journeyed to Zhao with a carrying pole to study under Master Qin Gao. At the age of twenty-one, he received the teachings of refining qi to nourish life. Qin Gao had initially served as a retainer in the court of King Kang of Zhou, where he mastered the arts of cultivating inner conduct, refining essence, and alchemical methods. Capable of traversing water, he had already lived for nine hundred years—immortal in body yet not a flying transcendent. Later, he would ride a red carp into the waters, sometimes emerging among men.

Yet Su Lin, gazing toward the cinnabar clouds, aspired to greater heights and eventually changed his teacher to Master Qiu of Mount Hua. Master Qiu had been the Minister of Wood during the reign of King Tang. He practiced the method of embryonic nourishment, the arts of returning spirit and guarding the soul, from which Su Lin greatly benefited. The master said, "You are a true person; you should study the true Dao. My path is no longer sufficient for you to tread." Thus, he introduced Su Lin to Master Juan.

Master Juan was a perfected one. Upon meeting Su Lin, he transmitted the true oral instructions, saying: "If you wish to become a terrestrial perfected one, you must first consume medicinal substances to expel the Three Corpses and eradicate the grain worms. The Three Corpses are: first, the Green Ancient, which attacks the eyes—hence dimmed vision, wrinkled face, foul breath, and tooth loss, all caused by the Green Ancient’s qi boring through the Mud Pill Palace. Second, the White Maiden, which assaults the five viscera—hence a muddled heart, depleted qi, forgetfulness, and confusion, as the White Maiden drains the fluids of the six bowels. Third, the Blood Corpse, which ravages the stomach and intestines—hence abdominal distension, withered bones, scorched flesh, a closed mind, unstable thoughts, hunger upon missing a meal, sorrow, sighing, mental dullness, and scattered spirit, all due to the Blood Corpse gnawing at the gates of the soul’s embryo. If one does not expel the Three Corpses before ingesting elixirs, though grain may be forsaken, the worms will not die. Merely abstaining from the five flavors and diligently practicing breath control will be of no benefit, for these worms, once born, seek to prevent man’s immortality. Thus, consuming elixirs without dispelling death and life is due to the Three Ghosts—the Green Ancient, White Maiden, and Blood Corpse—remaining within. Even if one abstains from grain, the body grows heavy and sluggish, listless and dull. Moreover, the dullness is not genuine; it is inverted and disordered, with licentiousness unremoved, because the worms within agitate the five spirits. Those who seek the true must first take the Worm-Restraining Pill. The Worm-Restraining Pill is also called the Primordial Spirit-Expelling Root-Removing Pill. To become a perfected one, one must first take the Transcendent-Restraining Pill. The Transcendent-Restraining Pill is the Supreme Eight-Jade Flying Essence Elixir. All who seek longevity and deathlessness, all who aspire to transcendence, must first take the Worm-Restraining Pill to eliminate the corpse-worms and establish the root of eternal life. How can one attain transcendence with worms in the belly? How can one achieve perfection with ghosts thriving in the body? These worms are malevolent, hastening one’s death—thus, they must be expelled."

Master Juan told Su Lin: "I have been summoned by the Emperor to ascend and fill the post of Grand Master of the Four Central Yellow Offices, assuming the title of Duke of the Northern Sea. My departure from the world is imminent." Later, Su Lin visited Master Juan’s chamber of quiet repose and received a scroll left for him. Its text read: "The secret of the Five Pecks and Three Ones was concealed by the Great Emperor. Through twenty years of concentrated meditation, the Three Ones appeared, and the scripture was transmitted to you. With only the Three Ones, one attains undying life and guards it even in death. If you can preserve the Three Ones, your name will be inscribed on the Jade Tablets. Will the corpse meet the Three Ones? By preserving the Cavern Chamber, one becomes a Duke of Supreme Clarity; by mastering the Three Origins, one becomes a Lord of the Five Emperors. The Golden Portal Emperor of Later Sageliness soars on lightning and traverses the ten heavens precisely through the Dao of the Cavern Chamber, Three Origins, and True One. I have consumed the essence of trees for three hundred years, refined qi for five hundred, meditated for six hundred, guarded the Three Ones for three hundred, preserved the Cavern Chamber for six hundred, and cultivated the Mysterious Elixir for five hundred. In the interim, I have wandered famous mountains, gazed upon the eight seas, circled the five peaks, and rested in grotto chambers. I delighted in the drooping branches of forests, frolicked with birds and beasts, read the rivers’ exhaled essence, and marveled at the lush hills. I witnessed the flourishing of all things, the turning of seasons, fished in long streams, roamed amid ethereal winds, stilled my heart in mountain vales, nurtured my spirit, and cultivated qi. I summoned the Six Dings, and jade maidens appeared as guards; I traversed the six directions without hindrance. For over two thousand eight hundred years, I guarded my form and contemplated the true, finding joy in the midst of transcendence, seeking no fame. Now, suddenly summoned to fill a celestial post, I linger in worldly grace, reluctant to part. I must go; let us take leave here. Strive diligently, and may our paths cross again in the Chamber of Soaring."

Su Lin read the scroll, tears streaming, and bowed in vain toward the empty air—Master Juan’s traces had already vanished. The Mysterious Elixir is the spirit of the Mud Pill Palace. Its method derives from the *Supreme Plain Numinous Instructions*: guarding the Three Ones makes one a terrestrial perfected one; preserving the Cavern Chamber makes one a perfected one; cultivating the Mysterious Elixir makes one a denizen of the Grand Tenuity Palace.

Su Lin reverently upheld the precepts, cultivated the Dao to completion, and surveyed the world. He wandered famous mountains, divided his form and scattered his radiance, rested on cinnabar mounds, sold shoes in market alleys, and tested his authenticity through humble guises. When content, he dwelled; when transformed, he followed no pattern—contemporaries could not recognize him. In the second year of Shenjue during the reign of Emperor Yuan of Han, on the sixth day of the third month, he told his disciple Zhou Jitong: "Yesterday, I was summoned by the Dark Continent to become a perfected one and assume the post of Grand Master of the Central Ultimate. Today, I take leave of you." By dawn the next day, a cloud chariot with feathered canopy, drawn by dragons and tigers, arrived with thousands of attendants to welcome Su Lin. That very day, he ascended to heaven, drifting slowly toward the northwest.

After a long while, clouds and mist enveloped him, and he vanished without trace.

Before Su Lin’s departure, the Supreme Ultimate had first dispatched an envoy to confer upon him the title of Perfected One of the Central Marchmount. Later, the Most High again sent the Jade Youth to bestow the rank of Perfected One of the Earthly Realms of the Five Marchmounts, with his palace located on Cinnabar Mound.

His disciple Zhou Jitong remarked:
"I witnessed my master attain the Dao and become an immortal. Thrice was he honored with appointments before ascending. His vast virtue was lofty and wondrous, his mysterious resonance long predestined. His numinous transformations flowed from the empty source, his spirit illumined the eight directions. Dragons ascended and phoenixes followed as he strode through the gates of reality. Concealed or revealed, he traversed the ford of existence, observing and testing the winds of the mortal world. His Dao was divine, his methods precious—beyond what brush and paper can fully convey. Here, I merely sketch its outline, hoping that future adepts of the Way may cast their gaze upon it."

Yang Sheng
Yang Sheng dwelled on Mount Jinmen in the west of Shaoshi. The mountain held a golden flask of nectar; those who drank it attained the Dao.

Wang Sizhen
Wang Sizhen’s era of attaining the Dao is unknown. He held the position of Immortal Attendant of the Scriptures to the Most High. On the first day of the first month in the second year of Guanghe during the reign of Emperor Ling of Han, the Most High Lord Lao descended upon Mount Tiantai and commanded Sizhen to don the nine-colored robe of retribution. He then presented the thirty-six scrolls of the *Dongxuan* and *Great Cavern* scriptures to the Immortal Duke Ge Xuan of the Left Palace of the Supreme Ultimate.

Wang Zhongdu
Wang Zhongdu was a man of the Han dynasty.

Yang Sheng (alternate account)
It is also said that he was a Daoist who studied the Way on Mount Liang, where he encountered the Perfected One of Venus, who bestowed upon him the Rainbow Elixir. Thereby he mastered cold and heat, and had already lived for over two hundred years. Emperor Yuan of Han summoned him to the capital and tested his arts. Once, in the depths of winter, the emperor took him on an outing. He ordered Zhongdu to ride a four-horse chariot through the Shanglin Park and around the Kunming Pond, clad only in a single layer of clothing. The emperor, wrapped in fox fur, still felt the cold, while Zhongdu’s countenance showed no change, and steam rose from his back in swirling wisps. Again, in the height of summer, he was exposed to the blazing sun and encircled by ten braziers, yet his mouth uttered no complaint of heat, nor did his body break into sweat. Later, he too departed as an immortal. Sun Simiao once dwelled on Mount Emei, cultivating truth and practicing the Dao. Zhongdu, along with three or five companions, disguised themselves as hunters and passed by his dwelling to test him. They discussed the principles of longevity, whereupon Zhongdu transmitted the Way to Simiao before departing.

Shang Chenggong
Shang Chenggong was a native of Xuan County. After setting out on a journey, he remained away from home for a long time. Upon his return, he told his family, “I have attained immortality.” He then bid them farewell and left. People saw him take a step and rise slightly into the empty air, lingering for a long while before vanishing. He lived during the Later Han dynasty.

Tong Jun

In the third year of Jian'an during the reign of Emperor Xian of Han, the kingdom of Ertu presented a wailing stone parrot. Its color was vermilion, and its size resembled that of a swallow. It would cry in the earth in accordance with the seasons, its voice carrying far. Upon hearing its cry, the people of the kingdom would slaughter animals to sacrifice to it, and where the sound emanated, they would dig and retrieve the parrot. If the world was at great peace, it would soar and fly, considered an auspicious omen, and was also called the treasure parrot. People listened to the earth to mark the hours. Daoist masters said: "The immortal Tong Jun gathered stones and entered a cave for several *li*, obtaining cinnabar. The stone parrot ground it into medicine, which, when consumed, gave one a resonant voice but caused death after heaven’s decree."

In the first year of Baoding during the reign of Emperor Hao, the four directions offered rare and marvelous tributes, including an amber swallow. Placed in a quiet chamber, it would cry and flutter within the room. Such was its kind.

Liu Chen and Ruan Zhao
Liu Chen and Ruan Zhao were natives of Ke County. In the fifteenth year of Yong'an during the reign of Emperor Ming of Han, the two went to Mount Tiantai to gather herbs but lost their way, and their provisions ran out. They saw a peach tree atop a mountain and together ate its fruit, feeling slightly invigorated. Descending the mountain, they found a stream and drank from it, bathing as well. Then they saw turnip greens growing from the mountainside, and next, a cup floated out, containing crumbs of sesame rice. The two said to each other, "People cannot be far from here." Crossing the water, which was about four *chi* deep, they traveled a *li* and crossed another mountain, emerging at a great ravine. There, they saw two women of unparalleled beauty, the likes of which the world had never seen. The women called out Liu and Ruan by name, as if they were old acquaintances. Delighted, they said, "Why have you gentlemen come so late?" They invited them to their home, where the halls were adorned with exquisite garments and ornaments, and the east and west chambers each had embroidered curtains and bed canopies, with seven-jeweled garlands—things not of this world. The attendants, all maidservants in azure robes, were uniformly comely, and there were no men or boys. Soon, they served sesame rice and dried mountain goat meat, which were delicious. They also offered sweet wine. Then, several immortals arrived at the women’s home with three or five peaches, saying, "We have come to celebrate the daughters’ husbands." Each brought out musical instruments, and they sang and played music. As dusk approached, the immortals departed.

Liu and Ruan stayed at the home of the women who had invited them, remaining for fifteen days. When they asked to return, the women replied, "Your coming here was summoned by the fortune of past lives, allowing you to reach the immortal abode. Compared to the mortal world, how could there be such joy?" They stayed for half a year. The weather was mild and pleasant, always like the second or third month. The cries of the hundred birds were mournful, and all felt sorrowful longing. Their desire to return grew urgent, and the women said, "The roots of your sins have not yet been eradicated, which is why you gentlemen feel this way." They then summoned all the immortal women to play music and send Liu and Ruan off from the mouth of the mountain cave. Not far from there, they reached the main road. Following the women’s words, they returned to their hometown, but no one recognized them. The villagers found it strange and verified that seven generations of descendants had passed, and their ancestors had entered the mountains and never returned, leaving no one to inquire after them. With no relatives, they had nowhere to stay. They wished to return to the women’s home but could not find the mountain path they had taken years before. By the eighth year of Taikang during the reign of Emperor Wu of Jin, the two gentlemen were ultimately lost, and no one knew where they had gone.

Wu Ding
Wu Ding of Guiyang City possessed the Way of immortals and often dwelled among people. Suddenly, he said to his younger brother, "On the seventh day of the seventh month, the Weaving Maiden crosses the river, and all the immortals return to their palaces. I have been summoned and cannot stay; I must bid you farewell." His brother asked, "Why does the Weaving Maiden cross the river, and when will you return?" He replied, "The Maiden briefly visits the Herdboy. Three thousand years after I depart, I shall return." The next morning, Wu Ding was gone. To this day, people still say that on the seventh day of the seventh month, the Weaving Maiden marries the Herdboy.

Master of the Dark Capital
The Master of the Dark Capital received the *Scripture of the Black Jade Heaven-Earth Bell of the Immortals* and, by practicing it, attained the Dao.

Cai Changru
Cai Changru was a native of Shu Commandery. By ingesting the Ten Essences Pellet, he lived to three hundred years of age, yet his complexion remained that of a young boy.

Yanming Zigao
Yanming Zigao attained immortality by consuming deer antler.

Cui Yezi
Cui Yezi consumed wood to transcend the world.

Ling Zizhen
Ling Zizhen achieved immortality by ingesting peach resin.

Ren Dun
Ren Dun was a native of Bochang. In his youth, he studied the Dao at Mount Luofu, later dwelling in the Southern Grotto of Mount Mao. He practiced the Dipper-Stepping Dao and the *Five Talismans of the Cavernous Mystery*, enabling him to command and summon spirits and gods, conceal his form, and divide his body. While residing in his mountain abode, tigers and wolves dared not violate his presence.

Jing Xuanzhi
Jing Xuanzhi cultivated the Dao of the Central Realm, preserving the Dao and guarding the Three Ones. He often sang:
*"From afar I gaze at Kunlun’s peaks,
Below lie three qing of fields.
I ask, who tends these fields?
The Red Child, named Yuanxian.
Earth births two numinous trees,
Twin gates flank either side.
Sun and moon illuminate each other,
The divine path spans the central heavens.
Gathering herbs on Three Subtleties Ridge,
I drink and rinse at Hua Pond’s spring.
Roaming the Twelve Towers,
I stride leisurely across the central plains.
I wish to behold the Crimson Palace,
But arrive as Zidan sleeps.
A golden tower holds a jade table,
Canopy linked in splendor.
Glancing, I see two envoys,
Clad in robes vast as Mount Taihang.
How towering the Long Valley,
Qi’s walls stand as neighbors.
Loosing my flying dragon’s reins,
I suddenly arrive at the Boundless Abyss.
Yellow essence grows at the spring’s depths,
Mushroom herbs spread along Qi’s streams.
I desire to take the yellow essence,
To refine cinnabar before my eyes.
Pacing, I drink the flowing elixir,
My feathered wings gleam with swift brilliance.
Yet beyond my plans,
Ziqiao lifts my arm.
The journey is truly perilous,
But what is prized is attaining immortality."*

Bo Ju
Bo Ju, styled Zigao, once entered the mountains to gather firewood when he saw two white cranes alight upon a stone and transform into two immortals. They spoke, saying, "We recently compounded the Yin Elixir and sought the Nine-Sword Wine from the Queen Mother of the West in Hebei. It proved most efficacious." Hearing the immortals’ words, Zigao sought out the Queen Mother, obtained the Nine-Sword Wine, and returned to inform the immortals. He begged for the Yin Elixir, consumed it, and instantly ascended into the void. He dwells among the clouds, charged with the task of governing cloud and rain. During the Wei and Jin dynasties, there was a Bo He who studied under the Queen Mother of the West in Hebei—it is uncertain whether this is the same person.

Xu Jidao
In his youth, Xu Jidao resided on Mount Huming. Later, he encountered a perfected one who said to him, "To study the Dao, one must don a sky-blue headscarf, chant the *Great Calendar*, tread the *True Annals* as a path, pair two whites, and circle two reds. These are the Five Spirits of Primordial Simplicity, the Dao’s secret matters—its language is veiled." The *Great Calendar* refers to the *Writings of the Three Sovereigns*. Jidao cultivated and attained the Dao.

Zhao Shuqi
Zhao Shuqi’s origins are unknown.

Zhao Shuqi studied the Dao within the mountains of Wangwu, often emerging to inquire among the people. Hearing of a diviner in the marketplace, he went to see him. The diviner said to Shuqi, "If you wish to enter the Gate of Heaven, harmonize the Three Passes, visualize the Crimson Robe, and align with Kunlun." Shuqi recognized him as a divine being, bowed deeply, and begged for the essential Dao. The diviner then gave him a scroll, the *Records of the Womb*. Having received it with reverence, Shuqi later compounded the divine elixir and ascended to heaven.

Zhuang Bowei
Zhuang Bowei was a man of the Han dynasty who, from youth, cherished the Dao but knew not the method to seek it. He would face the northwest at sunset, close his eyes, clench his fists, and visualize Mount Kunlun. After thirty years of this practice, he beheld a person from Kunlun who bestowed upon him the formula for the Golden Fluid. Having compounded and ingested it, he attained the Dao.

The *True Annals* states: "After visualizing Mount Kunlun for twenty-one years, he ingested medicinal substances and entered Mount Zhong to study the Dao. Still adhering to this method, he continued for another decade or so. Later, closing his eyes, he suddenly beheld Kunlun. Persisting in this visualization without cease, he then saw an immortal who transmitted to him the formula for the Golden Fluid, by which he attained the Dao."

Qu Wu
Qu Wu was a man of the Later Han dynasty.

At the age of seven, he abstained from grains and ingested yellow essence and purple mushrooms. Entering Mount Emei, the Perfected One of Heavenly Bamboo transmitted to him the true instructions, whereupon he departed riding a white dragon. Today, in Shuzhou, there stands a shrine to Master Qu.

Kuang Su
Kuang Su, styled Zixi, was renowned from youth for his filial piety and fraternal devotion. Though summoned and offered office, he declined and devoted himself wholeheartedly to the study of the Dao. Traveling through famous mountains, he came to Mount Fusun, atop which lay a lake spanning several *li*, abundant with numinous herbs and strange creatures beyond recognition. Beside it was a stone wellspring connected to the lake. There were also stone crows that took flight in flocks during spring and autumn. Moreover, small stone bamboo shoots stood there, within which lay jade tablets inscribed with the names of blessed mountains, blessed lands, and those who had attained the Dao. Later, through the ingestion of medicinal substances, he attained the Dao.

Lu Dan
Lu Dan, in his youth, studied the Dao and became an immortal. Later, he served as an administrator in a prefecture. Often, he would travel through the void to return home, only to return by dawn. Once, during a grand prefectural assembly, he arrived late as the officials were lined up in attendance. As he circled the pavilion, preparing to descend, the master of ceremonies hurled a tablet at him, striking one of his shoes to the ground. Thereupon, Lu Dan flew away.

Master Fu
Master Fu studied the Dao within Mount Jiao. After seven years of concentrated meditation, he encountered the Perfected One of the Great Ultimate (the *True Annals* states it was the Venerable Lord of the Great Ultimate), who gave him a wooden drill and instructed him to bore through a stone disc, some five *chi* thick, saying, "When the stone disc is pierced, immortality may be attained." Thereupon, he drilled day and night. After forty-seven years, the stone was finally pierced. The immortal came and said, "With such resolve, how could one fail to attain the Dao?" He then transmitted to him the formula for the Golden Fluid and the Reverted Elixir. Having ingested it, he transcended the world. The *Records of the Elixir Terrace* states that he ascended to the Great Clarity and became the Perfected One of the Southern Marchmount.

Huang Guanzi
Huang Guanzi, from youth, was devoted to the Dao. His family practiced both Buddhism and Daoism, and he paid homage morning and night, praying for longevity. After forty-nine years of such devotion, he began ingesting medicinal substances and entered Mount Jiao. The Perfected One of the Great Ultimate tested him with one hundred and forty trials, all of which he passed. Thereupon, he ingested the Golden Elixir and chanted the *Perfect Scripture of the Great Cavern*. Today, he holds office as the Left Immortal Minister of the Great Ultimate.

Shi Tan
Shi Tan, styled Hongsun, was a native of Bohai. Traveling through the famous mountains of Zhao and Wei, he attained the Dao and gained the ability to divide his body. When invited by more than ten households at once, each household would see a Shi Tan, though their words differed.

Zhang Jujun
Zhang Jujun’s origins are unknown. When Xu Jishan fell gravely ill and could not recover, he purified himself, fasted, and made offerings at Mount Tai, praying for his life day and night. Suddenly, a divine person appeared and asked, "Who are you, and why do you plead so earnestly to the unseen realm?" The Celestial Emperor has sent me to question you; answer truthfully." Jishan replied, "I am Xu Jishan of Pingyu in Runan. I have been afflicted for three years, yet I know not the cause of my transgression. Thus, I have come to this sacred mountain to entreat the powers of life and death." The divine person said, "I am the immortal Zhang Jujun. I possess the arts of the *Book of Changes* and divination, and I can discern the source of your misfortune." Jishan bowed twice and entreated, "By the grace of your descent, divine immortal, I humbly beg for your guidance." Jujun cast a hexagram and obtained *Zhen*, with changes in the first nine, six in the second, and six in the third. He said, "You are a man of no virtue; how could your illness be cured?" Jishan replied, "I beg you to reveal it." Jujun said, "Once, while escorting a guest on a journey, you avenged a wrong done to your father by killing the guest on the road and concealing his body in an empty well, covering it with a great stone. This man has appealed to the Celestial Court, and thus you suffer this affliction." Jishan said, "This crime is indeed mine." Jujun asked, "Why did you do such a thing?" Jishan replied, "My father was struck by another, and I could not bear the shame of this lasting disgrace. When I and a guest sought to avenge him, the guest intended to report the matter to the authorities, so I killed him." Jujun said, "The principles of the unseen realm are not to be deceived. You must earnestly confess your crime. I shall return to the mountain and plead on your behalf." Gradually, Jishan recovered. Jujun transmitted to him the arts of divination and hexagrams, and Jishan delighted in the practice of *Yi* divination, though he never obtained Jujun’s method for transcending the world.

*Comprehensive Mirror of Perfected Immortals Who Embodied the Dao Through the Ages, Scroll Seven* concludes.
*Comprehensive Mirror of Perfected Immortals Who Embodied the Dao Through the Ages, Scroll Eight* begins.

Yin Xi, the Supreme Perfected Yin Xi, styled Gongwen. His mother once napped at midday and dreamed of the crimson heavens swirling around her body. When Xi was born, lotus flowers spontaneously bloomed upon the ground within his home, their radiance and hue resplendent. His eyes held the essence of the sun, his form tall and refined, arms hanging past his knees—his bearing majestic, befitting a celestial being. From youth, he devoted himself to the study of ancient texts and was skilled in celestial patterns and esoteric apocrypha. Gazing upward and peering downward, nothing escaped his penetrating insight; even spirits and gods could not conceal their truths from him. Of magnanimous and heroic disposition, he cared little for worldly etiquette. He diminished himself to aid others, seeking neither fame nor advancement. His renown spread far and wide, and during the reign of King Kang of Zhou, he served as a grandee before being summoned as a guest-friend to the Eastern Palace. He wove grass into a tower to observe the celestial bodies, his mind fixed upon the supreme Dao, and thus it was called the "Tower Observation." At that time, Xi beheld a purple qi advancing westward from the eastern horizon—a celestial omen foretelling the passage of a sage through the pass. He thus petitioned to be appointed magistrate of Hangu Pass, and the king granted his request.

In the distant kalpas, there was a sage named the Most High Lord Lao, who since the dawn of creation had propagated the great Dao, descending through the ages as the teacher of emperors (as detailed in Scroll Two, from the Heavenly Sovereign to Guo Shuzi of Zhou). His subsequent incarnations are recorded in the *Veritable Records of the Primordial Origin*. In the seventeenth year of King Yangjia of Yin, he divided his spirit and transformed his qi to descend, taking form in the womb of the Mysterious and Wondrous Jade Maiden. After eighty-one years, on the fifteenth day of the second month in the ninth year of King Wuding (a gengchen day), he was born. His hair was white from birth, hence he was called "Laozi" (Old Master). Laozi was none other than Lord Lao. In the forty-third year (a jiayin year), he ascended to heaven upon a white deer in Bozhou (as detailed in the later scroll, *Records of the Supreme Primordial Sovereign*).

In the twenty-first year of King Xin of Yin, King Wen descended again upon the southern slopes of Mount Qi. When King Wen of Zhou became the Lord of the West, he appointed Laozi as the Keeper of Archives. During the reign of King Wu, he was promoted to the Archivist Beneath the Pillars, and he retained this position under King Cheng. He then journeyed to the western lands of Da Qin, Jambudvipa, and other nations, where he was known as the Ancient Master, guiding and instructing those realms (Jambudvipa lies west of Kunlun, not the Tianzhu of the "Heavenly Poisonous" lands). During the reign of King Kang, he returned to Zhou and resumed his post as Archivist Beneath the Pillars. In the time of King Zhao, he resigned his office and retired to Bo, living in seclusion.

Lord Lao, wishing to enlighten the Western Regions, set out in the twenty-third year of King Zhao (a guichou year, the first year of the Heavenly Realm of the Infinite in the celestial reckoning), on the sixteenth day of the fifth month. He rode in a carriage drawn by a blue ox, its canopy fashioned from thin planks, with Xu Jia as his charioteer. Crossing westward through Hangu Pass, Xi arrived at the pass and declared: "The yang number reaches its apex at nine; the stellar lodges align with Metal; the year and month converge in sovereign harmony. Within ninety days, a great sage shall pass through the capital." He then instructed the pass officer Sun Jing: "If any appear with unusual features or attire, do not permit them to pass." Xi prepared in advance, purifying himself through fasting and ritual, ordering the roads swept for forty *li* and incense burned along the way to await the arrival of the celestial perfected.

On the twelfth day of the seventh month (a jiazi day), an elder indeed arrived—hoary-haired, keen-eared, riding in a white carriage drawn by a blue ox. The pass officer said, "Your Excellency has given orders; we humbly request you to tarry awhile." He entered to inform Xi, who exclaimed, "The Dao has come at last! I shall behold the sage!" Immediately donning his court robes, he went forth to welcome him, prostrating and kowtowing, entreating, "May the great one deign to pause his divine carriage." Lord Lao declined, saying, "I am but a poor old man dwelling east of the pass, my fields to the west. I am merely fetching firewood—why detain me? Pray, allow me to pass." Xi again bowed deeply, replying, "Surely the great one is not fetching firewood. I have long heard that a great sage would journey westward. Though weary from exposure, I beg you to rest your divine carriage awhile." Lord Lao said, "I have heard that in Jambudvipa there is an Ancient Master who has mastered non-action and abides in eternal continuity. Thus, I ascend the Way and pass through this pass. Why do you persist in detaining me?" Xi replied, "Now that I behold you, your sagely bearing surpasses all; you are the supreme one of heaven. What need have you to visit the borderlands? I beg you not to dissemble but to bestow your compassion." Lord Lao asked, "How do you recognize me?"

Xi answered, "Last winter, in the tenth month, the Celestial Reason stars traversed the Dipper (the Celestial Reason consists of four stars governing the ordering of all things). Since the first day of this month, the harmonizing winds have blown thrice, and a true qi from the east, resembling a dragon-serpent, has advanced westward—this is the sign of a great sage. From youth, I have studied the *Yi* and celestial patterns and esoteric apocrypha. All that I observe above and below has never failed to prove true, so I knew a sage would cross the pass. Day and night, I have meditated without cease. Now, by good fortune, I encounter your immortal carriage. I beg you to bestow your compassionate teaching and deliver those lost in darkness."

Lord Lao, having tested him thrice and found him worthy, smiled and said, "Excellent! You know me. I, too, have known you. You possess a vision that penetrates the divine and shall attain liberation from the world." Overjoyed, Xi leapt up, kowtowed, and bowed twice, asking, "May I dare inquire the great sage’s name and style?" Lord Lao replied, "My name and style are vast, spanning kalpas beyond recounting. Now, my surname is Li, my style Boyang, and I am called Old Cong (the character *cong* shares its pronunciation with *peng* and is also written as *yan*)."

Thereupon, Xi prepared a seat in the official residence and offered provisions, presenting washing implements and performing the rites of a disciple. Lord Lao’s charioteer, Xu Jia, had long been in his service, contracted at a daily wage of one hundred coins. By the time of their departure from the pass, the debt amounted to seven million three hundred thousand coins. Seeing Lord Lao resign his post and journey far, Xu Jia hastened to demand payment. Lord Lao said to him, "I am traveling to the Western Sea, to Da Qin, Jibin, Jambudvipa, Parthia, and other lands. As my charioteer, upon our return, I shall repay you in gold."

Xu Jia honored the agreement. Upon reaching the pass, as they fed the blue ox in the wild, Lord Lao wished to test him. He transformed an auspicious herb into a beautiful woman, who approached the place where the ox was grazing and began to jest with Xu Jia. Enchanted, Xu Jia wished to stay, thus breaking his prior vow. He then went to the Pass Prefect to lodge a complaint against Lord Lao, demanding his wages. Lord Lao said to him, "You have followed me for over two hundred years. You should have died long ago, but I gave you the *Tai Xuan Sheng Fu* to sustain you until today. How could you forget this and sue me?" As he spoke, the talisman flew from Xu Jia’s mouth, its cinnabar script still fresh. Xu Jia instantly became a pile of white bones.

Xi, pitying Xu Jia for dying due to his own betrayal, kowtowed and pleaded for his life, vowing to redeem his debt if granted rebirth. Moved by Xi’s compassion, Lord Lao said, "Very well." He cast the *Tai Xuan Sheng Fu* again, and Xu Jia revived at once. Lord Lao said, "I do not blame you. You broke your original vow, so the Dao abandoned you, and thus you died. Now I shall repay your wages." Xi then gave the money to Xu Jia and sent him off with proper rites. Xu Jia begged to stay, but Lord Lao refused. Prostrating himself, Xu Jia struck his cheeks and said, "I have been graced with your boundless mercy, my crimes pardoned. This withered bone has seen the light again. I shall carve your kindness into my heart and follow your cloud-borne chariot." Yet Lord Lao remained unmoved.

Lord Lao stayed with Xi at the pass for over a hundred days. Xi fasted, kowtowed, and knelt to implore, "This humble one has been blessed to meet a sage. I surrender myself entirely—pray, teach me the Great Dao." Lord Lao said, "How profound is your question! The Great Dao preserves the true. Its three grades serve as its rule, unity as its measure, and rectitude as its virtue."

Xi asked, "The Dao has three grades. Is it possible to ascend as an immortal by practicing them?" Lord Lao replied, "If you can grasp the One, all things are complete. Seal your passions, enter the inner chamber, refine gold, and ingest qi—this is the foremost path. Master it and never lose it."

Overjoyed, Xi prostrated himself and asked, "How does one refine gold?" Lord Lao said, "It is a divine method. Even the Most Perfect Sovereign attains the Dao through the Golden Elixir, traversing the Nine Darks to enter the profound void. Above and below, emptiness prevails, yet through spirit and illumination, all ascend together."

Xi prostrated himself again and said, "I beg to hear its essence." Lord Lao replied:
*"Red lead and black tin, the head of the Great Elixir,
From red to black is true cultivation.
Extract essence from black, marrow from red,
Resolve the red and black—no medicine compares.
Use red in black to preserve long life,
Use black in red to become a celestial immortal."*

Xi said, "The Dao is lofty and wondrous! This unworthy student has not yet fathomed it. Pray, grant further instruction." Lord Lao continued:
*"The first is lead—lead is the lord,
The second is mercury—mercury is the minister.
If lead is not true, mercury will not draw near;
If lead is true, the household minister will not stray.
The Green-Waisted Messenger, the Red-Blood General,
Harmonize the two clans, disparate yet of one root.
White mercury forms the brain, yellow sprouts the root,
Transform lead to powder, refine mercury to dust.
Yin dwells in yang’s place, yang’s number balances yin.
The sun waxes, the moon wanes, cold and heat divide.
The pattern unfolds, resplendent with script.
Only this Dao endures as heaven and earth."*

Xi bowed and said, "I reverently receive your teaching on the ingredients. But what of the furnace and crucible, the timing of water and fire?"

Lord Lao chanted:
*"Round as three-five, a tenth of an inch,
Mouth four-eight, lips two inches,
Two inches long, thickness even.
Belly threefold, warmth descending.
Yin above, yang below rushing.
Head and tail martial, center civil.
Begin with seventy, end at thirty,
Two hundred within, well-tempered.
White yin fire, yellow sprout silver,
Two sevens gather, aiding the adept.
Dwell in the palace, secure and abiding,
Roam and return without leaving the gate.
Gradually grow great, nature pure,
Return to the One, restore the origin.
When one cycle completes, be diligent,
Guard closely, never stray into confusion.
The path is distant, profoundly mysterious.
If you attain this, you will meet heaven and earth.
At midnight and noon, moisten soul and spirit,
Gain long life, enter the immortal village.
Those who delight in the Dao, seek its text,
Ponder deeply, speak no more."*

He chanted again:
*"Sun and moon are the essence of heaven and earth,
The hexagrams revolve, clearly manifest.
Three-five before, three-five after,
Five-six makes thirty, then reborn.
Born and extinguished, twelve cycles,
Twelve divides into twenty-four.
Within the twenty-four qi, all shifts,
All images and hexagrams reside here.
Mercury, one flavor, splits in two,
Transforming yin and yang, becoming ‘already’ and ‘not yet.’
‘Already’ and ‘not yet’ pair as husband and wife,
Then the pot holds heaven and earth."*

And again:
*"The Golden Fluid Returning Elixir flows with immortal splendor,
Soaring high on clouds, ascending celestial mounds.
Red and yellow substances form in an instant,
Obtaining the chaotic pearl of yin and yang.
It can summon transformations and summon the kitchen,
Spiritual beings and jade maidens accompany you.
Entering and exiting, no need to ask—one with heaven’s tally.
Its essence congeals like frost, adept at sinking and floating.
If you reverently await, they will surely come.
The secrets of the Golden Fluid end here."*

"When the elixir is complete, fashion vessels from gold to eat from, and you too may attain long life. First test the gold—only when it is perfected may you ingest it. Thus it is said: *Gold can be made, the world can be delivered.*"

Thereupon, he bestowed upon Xi the *Tai Qing Ba Fu Jing*, the *Tai Qing Guan Tian Jing*, the *Jiu Du Jing*, the *Shen Dan Jing*, the *Jin Ye Jing*, and the *Ba Lian Jiu Zhuan Huan Dan Fu Huo Jue*. Lord Lao further instructed, "If you truly desire to become a divine immortal, you must first ingest the Returning Elixir and Golden Fluid. If you do not, your suffering will be in vain—afflicted by cold, heat, wind, and damp, struck by demonic qi, even the Controller of Destinies cannot save you. Can you not strive?"

Strive diligently in elixir-making, and take early precautions to guard yourself. Do not reveal these teachings to fools, lest they mock and slander the divine Dao, compounding your transgressions.

Alas! Though the walking corpse may possess all things under heaven and hold rank as prince or lord, before a hundred years pass, it becomes but a basket of earth—how pitiable! Yet in the toil of compounding the divine elixir, though the labor lasts but a moment, once perfected, you ascend as an immortal, your years equaling heaven’s, your heart’s desires fulfilled—can such joy ever end?

Xi asked, "In refining gold and ingesting qi, are there two distinct Ways?"

Lord Lao replied, "The essence of heaven and earth, the root of yin and yang—these are the two qi. The yang dragon and yin tiger, the liquid of wood and the essence of metal—when these two qi unite and are refined, it is called the Outer Elixir. Holding harmony within and refining the storehouse, exhaling the old and inhaling the new, ascending to the Mud Pill Palace, descending to the Cinnabar Field, circulating without cease, ascending at dawn to the Crimson Palace, gathering from the Five Treasuries to nourish the hundred spirits—this is the Inner Elixir. Those who cultivate the Dao and attain the Inner Elixir may prolong their years; those who attain the Outer Elixir may ascend to heaven. The Three Ones and Nine Contemplations are the essence of inner cultivation; the Nine Elixirs and Golden Fluid are the pinnacle of outer refinement. Cultivate both together, and the Dao is perfected."

Xi again entreated, "I have received your instruction on the method of refining gold—may I now hear of ingesting qi?"

Lord Lao said, "To ingest qi and secure essence, receive the *Mysterious Classic of Radiance*. The essential subtleties of the generative Dao emerge from darkness into light. Above, secure the Cloud Gate; below, fortify the numinous root. To know this is easy; to practice it is difficult. When the body moves, virtue scatters; when qi strays, the Dao parts. Essence dissipates, the hun-soul wanes, the eyes stir, and the po-soul is thrown into chaos. Thus the sage stills the body and secures qi, hoards essence and cherishes vision—then the Dao and virtue congeal in emptiness, the hun and po are firmly guarded, the body is one, the spirit myriad, and the Dao is accomplished.

"Always after midnight, lie supine with fists clenched, inhale pure qi through the nose, and exhale slowly through the mouth. Then guard the Three Ones, enter the chamber, and practice the Nine Contemplations. When spirit is settled and qi is at peace, the immortal Dao draws near."

Thereupon, he bestowed upon Xi the *Thirty-Five Chapters of the Jade Calendar Classic*. Xi said, "I beg you to instruct me on the meaning of the Three Ones."

Lord Lao replied, "The Way of the Three Ones is revered by divine immortals, yet the world rarely hears of it—guard it well as a secret. Between the brows, one inch inward is the Hall of Light; two inches inward, the Grotto Chamber; three inches inward, the Mud Pill Palace—this is the Upper Cinnabar Field. Within it dwells the Red Child, styled Yuanxian, named Imperial Minister. The heart is the Crimson Palace, the Middle Cinnabar Field. Within it dwells the Perfected One, styled Zidan, named Radiant Firmness. Three inches inward from the navel is the Gate of Destiny, the Lower Cinnabar Field. Within it dwells the Infant, styled Yuanyang, named Mystic Valley. All are three inches in height, clad alike in red robes, red shoes, and red caps—these are the Three Ones. (Another version says: the Upper One wears purple, the Middle One red, the Lower One yellow, each in the form of an infant.) Below stands a golden forest and jade table, where with a golden furnace and jade spoon they stir the essence to nourish the Upper One, Middle One, and Lower One. You must visualize this day and night.

"If you desire long life, the Three Ones must be made clear. If you can guard the One, the One will guard you. Qi transforms into essence, essence into spirit, spirit into the infant, and the infant ascends as the Perfected One. The Perfected One then becomes the Red Child—this is the true One.

"It is also said: The false Dao nurtures the form; the true Dao nurtures the spirit. When spirit is true, the Dao is penetrated—it can vanish or endure. Spirit can make the body fly or move mountains. When the body turns to ash and earth, what awareness remains? The ears and eyes, sounds and sights, are transgressions that bind you; the nose and mouth, fragrances and flavors, are foes. The body is the root of affliction—pain, itching, cold, heat; the mind is the burden of form—sorrow, poison, worry, vexation. If you do not swiftly cast these aside, your will and qi will daily diminish, and your lifespan will not be prolonged. This has been so for ages. You must first diminish all desires and prevent the mind from straying. Dwell in seclusion, still your thoughts, and fast in purity. Though you may have ten thousand scrolls of elixir scriptures, they are not equal to guarding the One. Always take emptiness as your body and nothingness as your mind. The body of no-body, the mind of no-mind—this is called guarding the spirit. When spirit is guarded and the mysterious is penetrated, it is called unity with the Dao. It is like lofty mountains and vast marshes—not seeking insects, fish, birds, or beasts, yet they gather there of their own accord. If one can be empty, desireless, and non-active, though not seeking the Dao, the Dao will naturally come to them." (I have seen this in the *Scripture of Western Ascension*.)

Then he bestowed upon Xi the method of the Nine Refinements of the Golden Perfected of Grand Yang, calling it the Nine Chambers of Contemplation: First, the Contemplation of No Deviant Thoughts; second, the Contemplation of Upright Body; third, the Contemplation of Attaining Rectitude; fourth, the Contemplation of Grand Rectitude; fifth, the Contemplation of Utmost Rectitude; sixth, the Contemplation of Profound Rectitude; seventh, the Contemplation of True Rectitude; eighth, the Contemplation of Penetrating the Mysterious; ninth, the Contemplation of Grand Penetration. Entering these nine chambers and practicing these nine contemplations, you will unite your form with Grand Yang and together attain the Dao.

Xi received all these secrets, bowed twice, and prostrated himself, reverently cherishing the profound grace. Thereupon, he resigned from office on grounds of illness. On the twenty-fifth day of the twelfth month, he respectfully invited Lord Lao to his home. Another day, he asked, "My mind is dull and I know not what to ask—may I request further instruction?"

Lord Lao said, "If you wish to cultivate the body and nurture nature, practice the Dao and discipline the form, congeal qi into spirit, and attain endless continuity, nothing precedes stillness. Thus heaven is still to establish constancy, spirit is still to effect transformation, and man is still to attain life. When about to still yourself, turn your hearing inward and observe within. Let the mind not harbor reckless thoughts, the mouth not utter reckless words, the body not make reckless movements. The color of no-color becomes visible, the sound of no-sound becomes audible, the flavor of no-flavor becomes sweet, the teaching of no-words becomes instruction. The numinous radiance descends, blessings and virtue arrive, and harmonious qi responds. If you wish to still the spirit, first bathe and fast for twenty-five days, then refine your body until the hun and po are at peace—only then may you enter the chamber."

Upon entering the chamber, should a cinnabar serpent appear upon your heart, or the Queen Mother of the West descend, or a Dao-body manifest in response—these are but the spirits within your own body testing you. Remain unalarmed. If questioned, do not answer; if harmed or offended, do not fear. Simply settle the mind and steady the will, and the apparitions will depart of their own accord.

After twenty-five days, forty-five days, sixty days, eighty-five days, one hundred and five days, one hundred and twenty-five days, one hundred and fifty days, or one hundred and eighty days, spirits may come—all to test you. Keep the mind at peace and do not engage, and they cannot harm you. If fear arises and the trial is failed, the Way is lost. Be vigilant and cautious. After one hundred and eighty days, the chamber will brighten of itself, and matters of safety, peril, life, and death will be foreknown without exception. The palaces and chambers within the body will all become visible.

After two hundred and eighty days, all illnesses will vanish. After one year, scars will fade entirely. After a thousand days, both form and spirit will attain perfection, and you will become a Perfected Person. Then shall you be granted the *Wondrous Truth*, *Inner Explication*, *Supreme Methods of the Great Clarity*, *Three Admonitions of the True Scripture*, *Talismans and Diagrams of the Numinous Treasure*, and the *Great Mystery*, among other teachings, to instruct the most refined and benevolent. Thus shall the feathered transformation of divine immortality be perpetuated without end.

Xi bowed his head in reverence and gave thanks. The master then said to Xi: "I tell you again—of old, the Former Master was none other than my own body, once transformed in the land of Jambudvīpa. Now I shall return my spirit to the nameless, abiding endlessly as if present. I depart now, returning to the One Source."

As the Old Lord prepared to journey west, Xi kowtowed and begged to accompany him. The Old Lord replied: "I roam beyond heaven and earth, play within the depths of the Dark and Mysterious, traversing the four directions and eight limits, above and below without bound. How could you follow me?"

Xi said: "To enter fire or abyss, to ascend to heaven or descend to earth, to reduce this body to ashes or forfeit this life—I wish to follow the Great Immortal."

The Old Lord said: "Those who attain the Way can see through all with their eyes, hear through all with their ears, and perform transformations beyond measure, now hidden, now manifest, yet still they cannot follow me on my distant travels. Though your bones and countenance accord with the Dao and you are destined to achieve perfection, you have received the teachings but briefly and cannot yet penetrate the divine. How could you transform and follow my sacred body?"

Xi bowed again and asked: "May I hear of the Way of penetrating the divine and performing transformations?"

The Old Lord said: "The qi of the living and the forms of the shaped are all illusions. That from which creation begins, that which yin and yang transform—this is called life

The following year, in the jia-yin cycle, on the twenty-eighth day of the fourth month, the Old Lord prepared to take leave of Xi at his dwelling on the southern hill and ascend to heaven. The reason the Old Lord had not yet journeyed west but instead ascended was to await Guan Yin’s attainment of the Dao, that they might together transform the Western Regions.

Xi, overcome with sorrow and longing, pleaded for him to stay. The Old Lord once more instructed him in the principles of dispelling defilements, stilling thoughts, and guarding the One with a tranquil mind. He admonished Xi, saying: "After a thousand days, you may seek me at the Green Sheep Market in Shu."

Having spoken, he rose into the air, seated upon a cloud of radiant hues. His face emitted fivefold brilliance, his body shone with golden light, illuminating the ten directions. Slowly he ascended, his glow entwining the dwelling in five colors of dark and yellow. After a long while, he vanished from sight. Xi, his gaze fixed upon the clouds, wept and reached out in longing.

That day, rivers swelled and overflowed, mountains and streams trembled, and a five-colored light pierced the Purple Tenuity (or, as the *Records of the Grand Historian* has it, the Purple Subtlety), suffusing the four quarters. From the ninth year of King Gaozong of Yin to this day, two hundred and seventy-four years had passed.

Xi then took the Old Lord’s essential teachings on governing the state and cultivating the self, his words on abandoning extravagance and extinguishing desire, and compiled them into thirty-six chapters. As these were expounded at the time of his ascent to the Western Ultimate, the text was named the *Scripture of Western Ascension*. The humble cart the Old Lord had ridden was treasured by successive dynasties and remains extant to this day. The platform from which he ascended lies south of the Louguan Temple and is now commonly called the Old Lord’s Mound.

At the moment of his ascent, a five-colored light pierced the Purple Tenuity and suffused the four quarters. King Zhao inquired of his Grand Historian concerning the auspicious or inauspicious omens. The Grand Historian replied: "A sage shall depart to the west; after a thousand years, his teachings shall return here." King Zhao then had this recorded at the suburban altar.

This was the portent of the Western Transformation. From King Zhao’s jia-yin year to the Yongping era of the Han, precisely a thousand years had passed.

Xi then retired to a thatched hut, purified himself in fasting, and severed all worldly affairs. Within three years, his cultivation was complete. His mind congealed, his form dissolved; hunger and thirst no longer afflicted him, nor did cold or heat. He mastered the subtleties of reckoning and transformation, the principles of unifying form and multiplying spirit, attaining their utmost mystery.

Thereafter, he composed nine chapters, which he titled the *Guanzi*. In the ding-si year, he journeyed to western Shu in search of the Green Sheep Market. The Old Lord had ascended in the jia-yin year, and by the yi-mao year, he had divided his body from the Palace of Grand Tenuity to descend and be reborn in the household of the great official Li of Shu. He had previously saved the Azure Dragon of the Green Emperor, transforming it into a sheep—its coat lustrous and pure, its color like green gold. It remained by the infant’s side, eating rice without instruction. One day, the sheep suddenly vanished, and the child, searching for it, found it in the market. When Xi arrived in Shu, he inquired among the locals, but none knew of the Green Sheep Market. Suddenly, he saw a child leading a sheep and thought to himself: "Since there is a green sheep, and it is in the market, the sage’s promise must lie here." He asked: "Whose sheep is this, and where are you taking it?" The child replied: "My lady gave birth to a son, and this sheep eats rice by his side. It went missing two days ago, and the child has wept without cease. Now that I’ve found it, I’m taking it home."

Xi then instructed the child: "Please inform the lady’s son that Yin Xi has arrived." The child did as told and relayed the message. The infant immediately straightened his clothes and rose, saying: "Summon Xi to come forward." When Xi entered the household, the halls and courtyards suddenly expanded, and lotus thrones emerged. The Old Lord transformed into a body of white gold, towering several *zhang* in height, his brilliance like the sun, a halo encircling his neck. He wore a crown adorned with the seven luminaries, robes of morning essence, and a nine-colored mantle of parted silk. Seated upon the lotus throne, the entire household marveled in astonishment.

The Old Lord said: "This dwelling is the Palace of Grand Tenuity; my true body is the One. Supreme Harmony descends as essence, and the luminous soul becomes man. Guest and host are mutually dependent—why be astonished?"

Yin Xi prostrated himself in joy, weeping and leaping with boundless delight. He bowed his head and said: "I never dared hope to again behold your celestial countenance. May I ask how the Venerable One emerged from non-being into being, and how you fare?"

The Old Lord replied calmly: "Since we parted, what have you gained or lost? In preserving the Dao and guarding the One, have you found benefit?"

Xi bowed his head and said: "Since receiving your secret essentials, I have roughly grasped their mystery. My ancestors have all received boundless blessings."

The Old Lord said: "Good. The reason I kept you here is that you have dwelled in the world for a long time, deeply entangled in love and attachment. Though you first received the scriptural instructions, you had not yet achieved success. Thus, I awaited you here. Now, you have preserved your form and refined your *qi*; your three years of effort are complete. You have attained true subtlety, your heart bound with purple threads, your face radiant with divine light. Your golden name is inscribed on the Dark Diagram, your jade tablet tied to the Purple Chamber. Your *qi* merges with Grand Tenuity; you have dissolved your form and united with the Real."

Xi bowed twice, prostrating himself in gratitude, and said: "The sagely teacher’s virtue surpasses heaven and earth; your kindness exceeds that of father and mother. Heaven and earth can cover and bear me, yet they cannot grant me the Dao; my parents gave birth to and raised me, yet they cannot make me endure forever."

The Old Lord said: "This is also due to your own mysterious allotment."

He then commanded the summoning of the hosts of the Three Realms. In an instant, the Lords of the Heavens, the Divine Kings of the Ten Directions, and the multitudes of immortals arrived, floating in the air. Each held incense and flowers, bowing their heads to receive his decree.

The Old Lord instructed the Five Elder Thearchs and the Four Poles’ Overseers of the Real to confer upon Xi a jade tablet and golden script, bestowing the title "Master of the Literary Beginning" and the rank of Supreme Perfected. He granted him a crown of purple hibiscus, a skirt of flying kingfisher feathers, sleeves of cinnabar and green, a rainbow robe of intersecting harmony, a yellow sash of silk patterns, a nine-colored staff, and five thousand jade boys and jade maidens. He was to reside above the Twenty-Four Heavenly Kings and command eighty thousand immortals.

Xi descended in obeisance, prostrating himself, and said: "This dust-born child, having encountered the Great Sage, has been granted flesh upon withered bones. A thousand lifetimes of fortune could not equal this."

Xi was thus appointed to oversee the tasks of wealth and sweeping, with attendants readied for his journeys—this was both his desire and his honor. His rank and title were lofty, his ceremonial grace abundant. Ashamed of his meager virtue, how could he dare refuse? The Old Lord said: "You have long yearned for the Dao, your hidden virtue ascending to be heard. Your cultivation has been diligent, your mysterious merit now fulfilled. This is no favor I bestow upon you alone; press on with resolve." Xi, unable to decline, bowed twice and accepted the mandate.

From then on, he could soar through the empty void, attending the Dragon Chariot and roaming the Eight Directions. The Old Lord then expounded the *Primordial Yang Sutra* to the Great Official and Sacred Mother, and in an instant, her household of over two hundred—young and old—ascended to heaven together. The Old Lord, having accumulated merit and virtue, was fated to ascend, and thus manifested within her family. Today in Chengdu, the Green Ram Palace, the Birth-Descending Terrace, and the Boyang Terrace remain as vestiges. The Hanlin Academician and Drafter-in-Waiting, Yue Penggui, was commissioned by imperial decree to compose the stele.

The Old Lord said to Perfected Lord Yin: "Long ago, you wished to wander far with me. Now that your Dao is complete, you may roam beyond the Eight Cords." Thereupon, he exhaled the hidden script of the Eight Directions and bestowed it upon him. Xi, having received the transmission, summoned the Eight Radiance Cloud Chariot. The Old Lord mounted the chariot, drawn by five-colored divine dragons, bearing the Vermilion Nodes of the Flowing Empyrean and the Nine-Light Crane Canopy. Twelve guardian officials led the way, celestial soldiers wielding banners. Behind followed ninety thousand flying immortals, their pennants fluttering, lions clearing the path, phoenixes flanking the carriage. They traversed the void in formation, with the Perfected Lord and the Four Heavenly Kings in attendance.

They arrived at the Mountain of the Sun’s Cavern and the Eternal Radiance, where they plucked the cinnabar stalks of the Fusang and scattered the crimson blossoms of the Ruomu. They beheld the Azure Sea and embraced the Eastern Well. Passing the Jade Pool Palace, the Divine King of the Sun Valley and the Azure Lads of the Eastern Sea presented cinnabar fruits and golden nectars of jade-green wine. Next, they ascended the Ancestral Mountain, gazed upon the Mushroom Fields, gathered spirit-nourishing herbs, and rested at the Penglai Palace.

They then journeyed south to Phoenix Mountain, climbed Green Mound, crossed the Purple Court, where the Supreme Prime Perfected Lord and the Purple Court Master offered Nine-Light Sweet Dew, White Veined Jade Essence, and Azure Grove White Seeds. This mountain was also called Xiao Mound, yielding the essence of Nine Lights and the cloth of the Fire Court. Next, they ascended Longli Mountain, crossed the Crimson Ford, and entered the Great Cinnabar Palace, where the Lady of the Southern Culmen served jade-blossom wine and crimson-spirit fire dates. Arriving at Crimson Mountain, they observed the Land of Flowing Fire, rested at the Scarlet Mound’s gate, where the Jade Perfected of Supreme Harmony and the Upper Duke of the Florid Canopy presented embers of the Flame Ridge, flying cinnabar purple peaches, and the liquid of cloud waves.

They then traveled west to Tortoise Terrace, entered the Seven Treasures Garden, and beheld the Flying Mystery Purple Script. Passing the Flowing Essence Gate, the Nine Numinous Metal Mother and the Primordial Sovereign of the Great Simplicity offered jade-script dates, their fruit like ingots, and commanded her attendants to present soul-returning incense, dark-light azure peaches, and golden-purple intertwined pears. Next, they sailed the Weak Waters, climbed Phoenix Mountain, entered the Jade Pool, and rested at Kunwu Mountain, where the White Emperor Heavenly Lord gathered Seven Luminous Stone Mushrooms, flowing essence jade cream, and golden-light cinnabar wine to offer them.

They journeyed north to the Hollow Cavern Mountain, passed the Cavern Yin Palace, where the Northern Culmen Perfected Lord presented Ten-Knotted Spirit Herbs, dark-cloud plums, and hollow melons—melons that ripen once every four kalpas. Ascending the Dark Mound, they observed the Eight Refining Pools of the Northern Darkness, rested at the Vast Cold Ruins, where the Supreme Mystery Immortal Earl offered crimson-tree cinnabar fruits and Three Mysteries purple crabapples.

They then ascended the Central Marchmount, Kunlun Mountain—this was not the Five Marchmounts of the mortal world, but the divine mountain beyond the seas. The Eastern Marchmount was called Broad Mulberry, the Southern Marchmount Longli, the Western Marchmount Lovely Agriculture, the Northern Marchmount Vast Wilds, and the Central Marchmount Kunlun. They roamed the Jasper Terrace and Jade Tower, beheld the Seven Treasures’ Jade Grove, listened to the nine-plumed phoenix’s song, and gazed upon the sun, moon, and stars in radiant exchange. Below, the Four Heavens lay as if in the palm of their hand. Atop the mountain stood golden terraces and jade towers, seven-treasured palaces, luminous day and night, where the Heavenly Thearchs and divine kings roamed and dwelled. On one side were two hundred and forty gates, pearl and jade groves, purple blossoms, cinnabar fruits, and azure leaves. The jade music was like zither and lute, harmonizing with the pitch-pipes. The Great Mystery Nine Palaces were the abodes of immortals, all with natural celestial kitchens, their comings and goings as they willed. The heavenly retinues were exquisite, the music beyond compare—truly the Pure Capital of the Inner Realm, the grand spectacle of divine perfected beings.

When Perfected Lord Yin first received the office of Youthful Perfected, he followed the Old Lord in touring these and the world’s Five Marchmounts, grotto-heavens, palaces, and the four seas’ rivers, springs, and water palaces. Their lords were sometimes called Sacred Thearchs, sometimes Perfected Kings, or Dukes or Marquises. In their consultations, they often discussed the Two Modes and Three Radiances, the yin-yang qi and seasons, the length and brevity of kalpas; the lifespans of emperors and kings, their peace and peril, rise and fall; the fortunes and misfortunes of the multitudes; the stages of learning the Dao and ascending as immortals, the matters of demotion and promotion; the harmonizing of qi and seasons, the methods of suppressing and dissolving the Yang Nine and Hundred Six calamitous convergences. Sometimes they sought instruction on the origins of the Dao and virtue, the subtleties of the formless and traceless. The Old Lord answered all as requested, his words profound and obscure, untransmitted to the world.

The Old Lord said to Xi: "I shall now ascend with you to the Jade Dawn Court and wander the Emperor’s Realm." As he spoke, the eightfold numinous sounds arose, cloud steeds gathered from the four directions, and they slowly ascended into the void. They traversed the Nine Heavens, where the Heavenly Thearchs of each realm came to welcome the Old Lord into their palaces, offering jade blossoms and immortal fruits, moon liquid and cloud nectar, spirit mushrooms and celestial fruits. Radiance illuminated the seats, heavenly music filled the air, and the divine songs were wondrous beyond compare. The Heavenly Thearchs and immortal perfected beings all bowed in reverence, entreating the natural, supreme, mysterious, and perfect Dao of the Primordial One. Then the Supreme Perfected of the Upper Prime, the Supreme Immortal of the Middle Prime, and the Supreme Immortal Earl of the Lower Prime arrived in jade-green and yellow cloud chariots, drawn by azure qilin and lions, bearing canopies of intersecting radiance, streaming rosy clouds, simurghs, flying cranes, and phoenixes. They wielded the Sun Essence’s Perfected Banner, the Moon Radiance’s Demon-Quelling Nodes, and the Star Light’s Immortal Flags.

Amidst the procession, one hundred fifty thousand attendant immortals and spirit officials—seventy thousand from the Upper Prime, fifty thousand from the Middle Prime, and thirty thousand from the Lower Prime—followed in ranked array, their cloud chariots, canopies, banners, and ritual staffs likewise graded by station. Each bore incense and flowers, bowing their heads in reverent welcome as the Lord Lao ascended to the Vermilion City of the Sun Gate and the Jeweled Pearl Palace in the Upper Clarity heavens. There, the Lord commanded the Joyous Audience to pay homage to the Highest Sage, the Jade Dawn, the Supreme Lord of the Great Dao. In response, the Dao Lord bestowed upon him twelve treasures: the Joyous Ring, the Unyielding Elixir, the Hidden Dragon Mushroom, the Pearl Blossom, the Jade Nectar, and other sacred offerings.

From there, the Lord descended with his retinue to the numinous mountains of Tianshui, arriving at the present-day Mount Qiling in Qinzhou of the Western Regions, where the Western Ascent Terrace and the Hall of the Sacred Countenance stood beneath the cliffs. Earlier, when the Lord had departed the Zhou court, he had journeyed westward to transform the lands of Da Qin, Anxi, Yuezhi, Wuge, and Jambudvipa, where he was known as the Ancient Master. Their kings and subjects all embraced his teachings and precepts. Later, he returned to China with the Supreme Perfected Yin Xi, traveling to the kingdom of Yanbin to propagate the Dao, then proceeding to the lands of Tiaozhi and Khotan, where he subdued ninety-five schools of heterodox teachings.

In the fourth year of King Mu’s reign, the cyclical year jiashen, the Lord descended to roam the Eastern Sea, meeting the Great Emperor at Fusang to review and rank the merits of the various immortals. He then divided his form to descend upon the Western Sea, journeying to the kingdom of Sulin to spread the teachings before ascending once more to heaven. King Mu, who had long cherished the Way of divine transcendents, climbed Mount Zhong to the Jasper Pool before returning to his capital. He reigned for fifty-four years and lived to the age of one hundred and four.

After Yin Xi had crossed the Flowing Sands, his thatched hermitage stood on the northern slopes of Mount Zhongnan. The king, longing for the numinous presence, ordered his chariot to visit the site, where he had an abbey and shrine constructed. He appointed Du Chong and six others as Daoist priests to oversee the rites. During the reign of King Yi, the Lord, accompanied by the Three Ancient Masters, descended upon Mount Sanxue in Mianzhu of Shu, where he transmitted the Way of Ascension to Li Duoduo, who thereafter governed as Lord Duoduo.

In the twenty-first year of King Li’s reign, the cyclical year jiachen, the Lord descended to Louguan, where he bestowed upon the Daoist Song Lun the *Way of the Middle Effulgence*, the *Scripture of Penetrating the Real*, and the *Six Jia Talismans of the Numinous Flight in Plain Silk*. In the twenty-third year of King Ping’s reign, the cyclical year guimao, in the twelfth month, the Lord once again emerged from the Pass to enlighten the various kingdoms. He then traveled to the Western Sea, visiting the islands of Liulin and others to examine the merits and practices of the assembled immortals before ascending once more to heaven.

During the reign of King Ding, the king inquired of the Lord regarding the divine transcendents of the world. The Lord replied: "On the Eastern Marchmount resides Master Zhan Qin; on the Southern Marchmount, Master Kuang Xu; on the Western Marchmount, Yin Xi; on the Northern Marchmount, the August Person; and on the Central Marchmount, the Ancient Master—that is I."

In the eighth year of King Xian’s reign, the cyclical year gengshen, during the reign of Duke Xiao of Qin, the Lord returned eastward. Accompanied by the Perfected Yin and others, he wandered to the Red City of Shangyu and Mount Meng, revisiting the Fusang abode of the Great Emperor to review the assembled transcendents. Thereafter, he concealed himself in the Scenic Chamber Mountain of Luoyang. At times, five white-haired elders—some riding cranes, others clad in feathered robes, leaning on staffs of green bamboo—would gather to discourse on the reckonings of heaven and earth, though none in the world recognized them.

The Lord composed scriptures totaling one hundred thousand words. Beside him stood two divine attendants, bearing a golden flask filled with ink dark as pure lacquer, with which they inscribed the texts. Wherever the ink touched wood or stone, it formed characters in the ancient seal and great seal scripts.

In the ninth year of King Nan’s reign, the cyclical year yimao, the Lord, accompanied by the Perfected Yin and other immortals, wandered the mountains of Nüji, Difei, and Tianzhu. He then exited the western pass, crossed the Flowing Sands, ascended Kunlun, and returned to the Purple Tenuity’s Upper Palace before journeying back to the homeland of the Supreme Mystery. When King Zhao of Qin learned of this, he lamented not having witnessed the event and ordered the construction of cities and towns along the western frontier where the Lord had passed, marking the sacred sites. To this day, the old post station of Lao Ting and the city of Yin Xi remain, their ruins still extant.

---

**Yin Gui, the Perfected of Great Harmony**
The Perfected of Great Harmony, Yin Gui, styled Gongdu, was a native of Taiyuan and the younger cousin of Master Wen Shi. From youth, he studied astronomy and was well-versed in apocrypha and weft texts. He came to serve the Master, who taught him to ingest the flowers of yellow essence and transmitted to him over a hundred Daoist scriptures, each accompanied by oral instructions. After the Master ascended in perfection, Yin Gui, then twenty-eight, secluded himself with the hermit Du Chong and others in the Master’s former residence to cultivate the teachings. He abstained from grains to nourish his qi and devoted himself to the highest methods.

The Supreme Lord took pity on him and bestowed upon him the title Perfected of Great Harmony, appointing him to oversee the immortal officials at the Du Yang Palace. Yin Gui often traveled abroad, carrying over ten tubes of divine elixirs, traversing the world to aid those in need. Sometimes he refined gold and silver to relieve the poor; at other times, he administered elixirs to rescue those in peril. All who sought his mercy received his blessings.

His comings and goings were unfathomable, his presence and absence inscrutable. Thus, the *Imperial Chapters of the Upper Clarity’s Jeweled Writ* states: "The Perfected of Great Harmony, together with the Perfected of Mount Taihua, the Three Heavens’ Lord of Longevity, the Southern Culmen’s General Overseer, the Northern Emperor’s Central Attendant of the Western Terrace, the Nine Numinous Princes of the Central Perfected, the Jade Maiden of the Supreme Numinous, the Crimson Essence Jade Youth, Master of the Dark Valley, Master Red Pine of the Southern Marchmount, Wang Qiao of Mount Zhong, the Perfected of Purple Yang, the Lord of the Western City, Master Zhonghuang Zhao Boxuan, Shan Zhongzong, and others—all cultivated the *Highest Methods of the Three Perfected Treasure Scriptures*. Their faces radiated golden light, their necks bore halos, and they rode the void to ascend the heavens, roaming and feasting in the Purple Court. Their transformations were boundless, their movements free and unfettered. At a whistle, they summoned all spirits; with a command, they subdued demonic forces and decided matters of life and death. They rode the clouds and mist, entering and departing the imperial courts of heaven."

In the second year of Emperor Hui of Jin’s Yongxing reign, he donned the Heaven-Penetrating Crown, wielded the Spirit-Subduing Staff, wore a crimson ceremonial skirt, and draped himself in a yellow-patterned robe. From the east, he arrived at the abbey of the Perfected Yin. At that time, the Daoist Liang Chen bowed his head and expressed his desire to present his studies. Yin Gui said to him: "I am the younger cousin of the Supreme Perfected Master Wen Shi. When the Master ascended in perfection, I was twenty-eight years old. Already, I had abstained from grains to nourish my qi and devoted myself to the highest Dao."

The Most High took pity on me and thus granted me ascent to the Great Harmony, entrusting me with the governance of the immortal officials at the Abbey of Du Chang. This abbey spans four thousand *li* from east to west and seven hundred *li* from north to south. It is encircled by ninefold golden walls and adorned with ten jade towers. Its palaces, furnishings, divine mushrooms, and sacred herbs defy enumeration. The myriad scrolls of the *Supreme Clarity*, *Primal Yang*, and *Great Cavern* scriptures—numbering in the hundreds of thousands—are all guarded by golden lads and jade maidens. Naturally, there are sun, moon, and stars, clouds and mist, concealed radiance and flowing essence, illuminating all below. The immortals, numbering in the tens of thousands, shimmer with divine light, live eternally, and abide in effortless freedom. Some roam the mortal realm, while others ascend to the Jade Capital to proclaim and assess all deeds—good and evil—and the karmic retribution and predestined cycles of beings. Some discourse on the celestial motions of heaven and earth, the sun, moon, and stars, and the measured or swift passage of time. Others feast among the heavens, deliberating the ranks and administrative methods of immortals as recorded in the divine registers. Some establish the protocols for the demeanor and bearing of youthful perfected ones and nascent immortals. Others oversee the mortal realm, inspecting the merits of those who perform virtuous deeds, erect altars, and hold fasts. Some supervise the ordination of male and female Dao seekers, as well as the arts of medicinal recipes and elixirs. Others traverse the hundreds of mountains and thousands of rivers, reviewing the records of divine overseers and ghostly officials to examine the causes of sin and fortune. Still others deliberate on matters of wind and rain, thunder and lightning, floods and droughts, abundance and scarcity.

My form knows no fixed appearance: at times a Daoist, at others a scholar, a child, or an elder—unconfined to a single path. Sometimes, I ride with the perfected immortals, the dragon-serpents and phoenixes, soaring through the void, racing like clouds and lightning, emerging from existence and vanishing into nothingness, multiplying my form and scattering my shadow, gathering and wandering everywhere. At times, I patrol the grottoes of the Five Marchmounts, or journey to the islands of the Ten Continents, or venture beyond the Eight Wastes, or descend into the Nine Dark Realms. Sometimes, I fish at the azure sea’s ford, or embrace the snow of the Black Hills, or pluck cinnabar blossoms from the Board Garden, or gather crimson fruits from the Jade Orchard. All this has been achieved through the accumulation of merit, the study of sacred texts, and the endurance of toil and hardship.

By now, I have lived over one thousand three hundred years, and the events I have witnessed are too numerous to record in your brief missives. I have merely outlined their general scope.

On the first day of the eighth month, I suddenly refined my body and ascended into the heavens, rising gently aloft. The lingering sound of pipes and flutes could still be heard, while only my robes and implements remained below.

Your servant Dao Yi says: Yin Gui’s Dao was lofty, his virtue wondrous, and his meritorious deeds unparalleled. His radiant form multiplied, and his divine powers were vast. As the *Dao De Jing* states: *"The ancient masters who excelled as scholars were subtly mysterious, profoundly penetrating, so deep as to be unknowable. It is only because they were unknowable that one is compelled to describe their appearance."* Such was Yin Gui—truly one who grasped its essence.

*Comprehensive Mirror of Perfected Immortals Who Embodied the Dao Through the Ages*, Scroll Eight—concluded.
*Comprehensive Mirror of Perfected Immortals Who Embodied the Dao Through the Ages*, Scroll Nine.

Du Chong

The Perfected of the Great Ultimate, Du Chong, styled Xuanyi, was a native of Gaojing. In the twenty-seventh year of King Zhao of Zhou, the ding-si year, upon hearing that Master Wen Shi had attained transcendence, he took residence at this numinous abode to cultivate the Dao in seclusion. At that time, recluses and eremites came from afar—five in number (the *Veritable Records of the Primal Origin* states seven). All were serene and detached, refined and lofty in character, their arts of the Dao mutually forgotten as they together upheld the principle of non-contention.

The master’s original residence, granted a hundred *yi* of gold during the reign of King Kang of Zhou, was extensively renovated and bestowed the name "Tower Abbey." Chong dwelled there, chanting and reciting the *Dao De Jing*, nurturing and guarding his spirit and qi.
