When King Mu learned of this, he had the abbey repaired and a shrine built, appointing Chong as a Daoist master. His qi was as balanced as that of [the sages] Chao and Xu, and his virtue served as a model for all things. Thus, the Son of Heaven honored him without subjecting him to servitude, and the feudal lords revered him without conferring rank.

After Chong had resided at Tower Abbey for over twenty years, the Perfected Zhenren Zhan Xiansheng descended in the quiet of his chamber. Two attendants stood to his left and right, bearing a case of green jade. Chong bowed his head and pleaded humbly, whereupon he was granted two cases of the *Scripture of the Nine Radiant Elixirs*. The master said to him: "Lord Lao and Master Yin summoned the Great Emperor at the Eight Haltings Mountain in the Eastern Sea to assemble the host of Perfected. Daoist immortals from grotto-heavens and mountain caves throughout the world came without exception. At that time, the local earth officials commended your diligence, and Lord Lao bestowed upon you this scripture of transcendence." Chong followed the formula in compounding and ingesting the elixir, whereupon his body took on a jade-like luster, his five viscera became firm and moist, and his countenance and breath were suffused with qi.

Later, the Perfected Li Jun appeared to him and transmitted the *Supreme Scripture of the Primordial Numinous Grotto’s Profound and Vast Wonders*. Chong cultivated it anew and found its effects most efficacious. Thereupon, he dissolved the bonds of the womb and untied the knots of fate, preserving life and congealing his true nature, commanding the host of spirits and penetrating the mysteries of all things.

King Mu personally revered the teachings of the Dao, seeking divine transcendence. Together, they harnessed steeds swift as the wind, covering a thousand *li* in a day. Midway, they reached Kunlun Mountain and ascended the Palace of the Mystic Orchard. To the west, they journeyed to Tortoise Mountain and paid homage to the Queen Mother in the Azure Jade Chamber. To the east, they roamed the Azure Sea, offering reverence to the Venerable Elder and gathering the blossoms of the Fusang Tree. To the north, they traveled to the Dark Mound, and to the south, they crossed the Long Flights, together embracing the marrow of Crimson Mountain. They drove tigers and leopards, commanded the hundred spirits, and traversed the hidden and the obscure—none could fathom their depths.

At the age of one hundred and twenty-odd years, in the twelfth year of King Yi’s reign (the *jihai* year), the Supreme Clarity Princess dispatched immortal officials to descend and welcome him, bestowing upon him scriptures and appointing him as the Perfected of the Great Ultimate, thereafter serving as the Immortal King of Mount Wangwu.

*The Record of the Primal Chaos* states: "At the age of one hundred and □-odd years, in the nineteenth year of King Mu’s reign (the *jihai* year), the Lord Lao sent the Supreme Clarity Princess to descend and welcome him, conferring scriptures." Upon examining the biographical records, it is clear that *The Record*’s account is in error.

Your servant Daoyi remarks: Du Chong delved into the mysteries of the Dao and held wealth and nobility in light esteem. Thus, the Son of Heaven honored him without subjecting him to servitude, and the feudal lords revered him without bestowing rank. As the *Dao De Jing* says: "The Dao is eternally nameless. Though its simplicity be small, none in the world dare claim dominion over it. If lords and kings could but hold to it, the myriad things would of themselves submit." Was not Du Chong one who took this Dao as his own burden, thereby guiding kings and lords to return to the Dao?

Peng Zong, the Perfected of Great Clarity, styled Faxian, was a native of Pengcheng. At the age of twenty, he became a disciple of the Perfected Du Chong, receiving profound favor and instruction. King Mu of Zhou revered the Yellow Emperor and Laozi, yearning for divine transcendence. Upon visiting Chong, he accordingly restored and adorned a hall of treasures, erecting a sacred altar and establishing a temple with statues of Lord Lao and the Perfected Yin. He widely summoned scholars of the Dao from across the land to propagate the immortal teachings. He further instituted offices to oversee the temple, ensuring its seasonal maintenance and adornment. Later, Peng Zong journeyed west to Kunlun Mountain, where he again paid homage to the Queen Mother before departing.

Peng Zong then dwelled in the truth, savoring the Dao, his essence penetrating both man and spirit. Once, while gathering herbs with his master, he suddenly fell into a deep ravine, injuring his hands and feet, leaving him in dire straits. After a long while, he revived, his reverence undiminished. Another time, while gathering firewood in the mountains, he was bitten by a snake, yet showed no sign of anger. Moved by his resolve, Du Chong established an altar and swore oaths over the *Elixir Canon*, the *Five Thousand Character Text*, and the Dao of Mysterious Unity. Peng Zong treasured and cultivated these teachings, daily delving into their profound mysteries.

At times, during the night, several divine lamps would float in the air, illuminating his mat, their radiance lingering and suffusing the darkness with clarity. When he rose at dawn to practice, the atmosphere would grow lofty and luminous, often with five-colored clouds and mist swirling around him. He could merge three days and nights into a single breath. At other times, he would submerge himself in water for an entire day before emerging. If he closed his eyes and lay still, he might remain motionless for over a year, dust accumulating upon him like layers of paper. Observers would suspect him dead, but when he rose, his complexion appeared even more radiant. He could recite the *Five Thousand Character Text* in a single breath, completing it twice, his voice clear and resonant, no different from that of an ordinary man.

In the mountains, venomous snakes and fierce tigers would cower at his qi, lurking in secluded dens. Though people might brush against them, the beasts would not stir until Peng Zong released them. Once, a hunter slandered him from afar, and when the man approached his door intending to humiliate him, Peng Zong restrained him with his qi. The hunter’s limbs involuntarily stiffened, leaving him standing rigid as a corpse. At other times, Peng Zong would send spirits to strike near the man’s door, eliciting only the sound of kowtowing, the cause unseen. Only after the man repented would Peng Zong release him.

At over one hundred and fifty years of age, he retained the vigor of a twenty-year-old. In the thirteenth year of King Li’s reign, the year *bingshen* of the first month, the Supreme Dao Lord dispatched immortals to welcome him, bestowing upon him the title of Perfected of Great Clarity and appointing him to govern the Red City Palace.

---

Song Lun, the Perfected of Great Clarity, styled Dexuan, was a native of Luoyang (also said to be from Luoyuan). In the twenty-first year of King Li’s reign, the year *jiachen*, he entered the Dao and took residence at Louguan. There, he concentrated his mind, stilled his spirit, embraced unity, and harmonized his qi, withdrawing from worldly affairs to wander the emptiness alone. Daily, he recited the *Five Thousand Character Text* several times and consumed yellow essence and white wood. After over twenty years of practice, he secretly beheld Lord Lao, whose neck bore a radiant halo and whose face emitted golden light. Clad in a nine-colored robe of parted mist and crowned with a seven-rayed dawn coronet, he was attended by six immortal youths who assisted and recorded his words.

Prostrating himself in grief, Song Lun pleaded, whereupon Lord Lao declared: *"I possess the Dao of the Radiant Center and the Scripture of Communing with the True, born at the inception of the Three Origins, issuing from the Court of the Nine Mysteries. The Five Virtues converge in celebration, the Six Qi congeal in essence, dispersing the true and scattering the radiant to preserve distant longevity. If you cultivate this, you will swiftly ascend in cloud chariots, moving between being and non-being, penetrating the obscure and illuminating the dark. The Three Luminaries will shine together, the Two Qi will purify the spirit, transformations will follow your will, and you will ascend to the Highest Clarity."*

Song Lun pressed his five limbs to the earth, weeping bitterly. Lord Lao calmed him and revealed a treasure, presenting him with the *Numinous Flight of the Six Jia and the Plain Memorial of the Elixir Talismans*. He further instructed: *"If you diligently cultivate the Supreme Dao, savor the true and contemplate the mysterious, practice without interruption, and persevere in refinement, you will ascend and traverse the void on cloud chariots. Reverence brings blessings; negligence invites calamity. The Dao aligns with those who practice it—guard this well and do not transmit it lightly."*

After receiving the scripture and cultivating it, Song Lun naturally attained spiritual resonance. Six jade lads took turns attending him. He could foresee events before they arose, discerning fortune and misfortune with divine clarity, his words invariably proving true. At times, he would rest among the inner immortals of the Five Emperors, where divine transcendents would invite him to wander and feast in the mountains and forests. Light as a feather, he could traverse three thousand *li* in a day, crossing waves and scaling perilous paths as if treading level ground. Occasionally, he would roam the marshes to test men’s hearts, transforming into birds or beasts to tame those around him.

At times, he became a deer, pursued by hunters who could never close the distance of a hundred or fifty paces, nor could the most skilled archers strike him. At others, he took the form of a wagtail, soaring over plains and hills, eluding the nets of fowlers. Or he might appear as a leper, offering expedient teachings to awaken those deluded by duality, instantly curing the afflicted.

At over ninety years of age, in the thirty-second year of King Xuan’s reign, the year *dingsi* of the seventh month, the Supreme Lord dispatched immortals to welcome him, bestowing the title of Perfected of Great Clarity and appointing him to oversee the divine transcendents’ register of Mount Song, the Central Peak.

---

Feng Chang, the Perfected of the Western Peak, styled Yanshou, was a native of Lishan. At fifteen, he mastered books on yin-yang and divination. King Xuan of Zhou, having heard of him, appointed him as an archivist. Feng Chang inwardly cultivated clarity while outwardly blending with the world, fearing entanglement in the rise and fall of fortunes. Observing the disorder in celestial patterns, he feared calamity would befall him. Thus, he retired on the pretext of illness, concealing his light and withdrawing into seclusion.

He discarded wealth and severed worldly ties, savoring the Dao and nurturing life while refining his spirit and preserving his qi. Daily, he recited the *Five Thousand Character Text* and consumed asparagus root. After five or six years, he gradually perceived its benefits. With unwavering diligence, he vowed to extend his heavenly allotment.

Thus, he was moved by the True Man Deng, who bestowed upon him the *Numinous Writ of Purple Text* and the Dao of Treasuring the Spirit. Chang then harnessed the dawn’s light to ascend, riding qi and roaming the primordial. At the sacred peaks of Zhongnan, he planted cliffs and bridged distances, summoning the radiance of the celestial luminaries. He refined his po-soul and softened his hun-soul, reversing yellow to red until his face gleamed with jade-like luster. After more than a decade, his vital essence flourished in luxuriant abundance. Naturally, azure essence congealed into liquid, purple clouds gathered into springs, all hundred vessels thrived, and the Three Passes flowed with moisture.

Later, he encountered the True Man Peng Zong, who rode a white tiger and descended into his chamber with two attendants. Chang performed the rites of a disciple, standing humbly to the side, restraining his breath and stilling his qi as he sought the essentials of the Dao. The True Man said: "Your virtuous resonance is profound and wondrous, your spirit and qi distant and pure. The Dao must return to the real; you are destined to transcend the world. If you wish to soar like a roc on the cloud-path, your jade-like brilliance resplendent, you must cultivate with unyielding diligence and never retreat. Then, you shall surely be summoned." Thereupon, he produced the *Hidden Writ of the Most High* and conferred it upon Chang.

Chang further annotated the *Eight Numinous Scenes*, savored the *Mysterious Nine Origins*, lodged his radiance in the streaming clouds, and guarded the Great Vastness in profound stillness. Thereafter, he roamed the primordial yang, observing the safety and peril of all things. Whenever he encountered illness, none failed to receive his protection. Once, a madman raged, and he cured him—some recovered in ten days, others in five. A leper pleaded for mercy, and within a month, he was healed. When a fire broke out, rafters and beams ignited in succession, wind and flames raging uncontrollably, none could extinguish it. Chang directed his intention toward it, and the raging fire stilled of its own accord.

At over eighty years of age, in the twentieth year of King Ping’s reign (the *gengyin* year), in the third month of spring, he ascended and transformed. At that time, the Heavenly Thearch dispatched immortals to descend and welcome him, appointing him as the True Man of the Western Peak. He ascended to the Upper Clarity, entering and exiting the realm of non-action.

---

Yao Tan
The True Man of the Dark Continent, Yao Tan, styled Yuantai, was a native of Pingyang. In the first year of King Ping of Zhou, when the court relocated to Luoyang, Duke Xiang of Jin, who had rendered meritorious service in escorting the Zhou, was enfeoffed as a feudal lord. The royal decree commanded the presentation of ritual gifts at the ancestral temple, the restoration of the abbey and shrine, and the allocation of five households and seventeen erudite scholars. At the time, Tan was nineteen years old. Due to his mastery of antiquity, he was singled out for special favor and reception. Duke Xiang knelt, bowed his head to the ground, and faced north to address him as his teacher. He partook of the wind and savored the Dao, and this continued for many years. Tan’s precision was so exacting that he seemed like a divine being, and all beneath the heavens revered and submitted to him.

His son, Duke Wen, also cultivated reverence and admiration for him. Once, during a four-year eastern journey that passed through the Wei River, he personally visited to offer congratulations and provide medicinal supplies. Tan, finding the world’s tumult oppressive, retreated to secluded cliffs. He constantly recited the *Five Thousand Character Text*, his concentrated thought never wavering. Suddenly, a crevice in the rock face split open, snapping trees as if descending from heaven, striking directly above his head. Sand and stones flew in countless numbers, yet Tan remained unmoved, his gaze fixed and unyielding. Soon after, a horde of great serpents emerged, converging upon his dwelling. Their mouths gaped and eyes stared, as if about to devour him. Some coiled around his body, yet Tan remained unafraid.

Then, the mountain spirit led a host of ghosts, bearing a colossal boulder towering like a peak. Driven by wind and lightning, it pressed ever closer, threatening to crush him. Tan slowly opened his eyes and rebuked them: "What petty fiends are you, daring to act so lawlessly? I have long cultivated true fruit, my sincere heart like jade. Your demonic delusions cannot obstruct my true path." Thereupon, he concentrated his mind and advanced single-mindedly. In an instant, the apparitions vanished.

Three figures of imposing stature then appeared and said to Tan: "We are the rightful spirits of this mountain. The Heavenly Thearch commanded us to test you, and now the trial is complete." With these words, they departed. Thereafter, Tan refined pine resin. Over decades, azure-clad youths often played in his bedchamber. Gradually, his room grew luminous, and all objects within became visible.

Later, the transcendent Lord Xu descended in secret and conferred upon him the *Dao of the Mysterious White Returning Form* and the *Scripture of the Three Celestial Passes for Flying Transcendence*. Tan cultivated his mind and mastered himself, attaining wondrous spiritual resonance. Within, his steps left no trace on his robes; treading through mud and mire, his shoes remained unstained. His eyes emitted divine radiance, flashing like lightning. He usually walked with his eyes closed. When disciples entreated him, he would open them slightly, and a swift, dazzling light would stream forth, startling all who saw it, leaving them unable to compose themselves. When he closed his eyes, the light ceased.

At over two hundred and ten years of age, in the eleventh year of King Jian’s reign (the *bingxu* year), in the fifth month of summer, a sudden storm darkened the sky, thunder roaring and crashing. None dared venture outside. As the thunder gradually subsided, disciples emerged to find silver flowers raining from the heavens, scattering in profusion upon the earth. After a long while, they dissolved. That day, the Primordial Lady of the Great Simplicity dispatched immortals to descend and welcome him, appointing him as the True Man of the Dark Continent. He ascended in blossoms at the White Water Palace.

---

Zhou Liang
The Eightfold Simplicity True Man, Zhou Liang, styled Taiyi, was a native of Taiyuan. His mother once dreamed of five-colored streaming clouds veiling her home, and thus conceived. After fifteen months, she gave birth. At nineteen, he stood eight *chi* tall, bearing the dignified air of the ancients. Free-spirited and aloof, he took no delight in glory or emolument. He was especially versed in the *Book of Changes*, the philosophers, and the histories. Though he dwelt amid worldly discourse, his aspirations were fixed upon the true and ultimate.

He became a disciple of Yao Tan, who transmitted to him the *Five Thousand Character Text* and the *Eightfold Simplicity True Scripture*. Liang cultivated these teachings and attained profound resonance. When households were troubled by ghosts and spirits shaking their dwellings, transforming water into blood, or harming people and livestock, Liang would recite the *Five Thousand Character Text* and perform hidden incantations, and the malevolent calamities would naturally dissipate. When foxes, turtles, or serpents bewitched people, defiled their food and drink, or stole their possessions, hurling tiles and pebbles in mischief—none could be expelled—Liang would recite scriptures and hold incantations, and the demonic beings would revert to their true forms, some dying at his side.

Prince Jin of King Ling of Zhou, having heard of him, summoned him for an audience. They played the zither and flute together, traveling through Shang and Luo. Liang then plucked the solitary strings of the *wuxian*, harmonizing the eight sounds until a hundred birds danced in unison. The prince admired him and bestowed upon him the *Nine Radiant Seven Luminous Mushrooms* and the *Dao of the Flying Goblet and Liberating Net*.

Liang cultivated the Dao and ingested the sacred mushrooms, daily perceiving their numinous efficacy. The Emperor secretly roamed the treasure caves with immortals, embracing and sipping jade wine, playing the zither, and playing chess, whistling and singing all day. At times, when he appeared seventy years old, his hair white and teeth fallen, after one or two nights in seclusion, he would transform into a youth, his countenance even more radiant. If seized by malevolent men who mocked him with filth, he would instantly vanish, leaving them unaware that they had bound and tormented themselves. Those who hurled abusive words at him would find their mouths spontaneously bleeding, and only after repenting and seeking forgiveness for a full day would they be released. At the age of over one hundred and ninety, in the twenty-fourth year of King Weilie’s reign, the year *jimao*, the Heavenly Emperor dispatched celestial officials to descend and welcome him, bestowing upon him the scriptures and appointing him as the Perfected One of the Qin-Long Palace. He came and went in the Great Clarity, feasting and wandering through the heavens.

Yin Cheng, the Perfected One of the Grand Tenuity, styled himself Chumo, and hailed from Fenyang. At twenty-eight, in the third year of King An’s reign, the winter of the year *renwu*, the tenth month, he lodged at Louguan to cultivate wisdom and refine his spirit, dwelling in emptiness and vastness. He purified himself with fasting, chanted scriptures, and kept apart from worldly affairs. His garments were like a belt of rope, and his food barely sufficed. He often purchased incense and arranged it upon the altar.

At first, when the incense in his casket was exhausted, suddenly divine fragrances filled the censer and burned—all were rare and precious scents. Once, when his lamp failed to cast light, a radiant glow naturally illuminated the space from the void. These were all manifestations of his refined essence moving the spirits, who aided him with divine favor.

While traveling in the mountains, he encountered a deer with an injured leg, struggling and unable to proceed. Moved by its suffering, Cheng applied medicine to its wound. Later, when he entered the mountains again, he was suddenly caught in a torrential downpour. With no food and only thin garments, he was stranded in the thickets. Just then, a herd of deer approached, gathering around him. When hungry, he drank their milk; when weary, he rested in their embrace. They accompanied him for days without returning.

He once lodged in a small cave atop a sheer cliff. One night, a mountain fire erupted, filling the valley with flames and smoke. With no escape, a troop of apes linked their arms and lowered him down, carrying him to safety beyond the peril. This, too, was the protection of the divine.

When Emperor Qin Shi Huang heard of him, he repeatedly issued edicts to summon him, seeking the arts of nurturing life. In the thirtieth year of his reign, when Mao Meng of Mount Hua ascended to heaven in broad daylight, a ballad spread. Upon hearing this, the emperor’s belief in immortals deepened, and he dispatched envoys bearing gold and silk to express his sincerity.

At the time, Cheng wished to journey to Penglai and Yingzhou, so the emperor ordered the statue of the Old Lord turned eastward. A separate temple was built south of the Perfected One’s shrine to house it, with fourteen Daoist priests appointed and thirty *qing* of incense fields granted, along with a hundred households for support. The edict read: *"The Great Dao flows boundlessly, ever near to left or right. Though the Old Lord wanders west, he turns his gaze eastward. As I seek to build Penglai and Yingzhou, may his influence linger like an echo."*

Emperors Gaozu, Empress Lü, Emperor Hui, Emperor Jing, and Empress Dowager Dou of the Han dynasty all inherited this devotion to the sacred realm. They frequently summoned recluses and transcendent scholars, keeping fourteen or sixteen in attendance at all times, each granted a disciple. The temple’s households were increased to one hundred fifty, with enhanced provisions for its upkeep and protection. Offerings and prayers never ceased, and the people’s reverence grew like gathering clouds.

Cheng, however, found the commotion disruptive. He secretly told his disciples: *"My immortal arts remain unfinished, and my virtue is tied to this fate. I must make the mountains and forests my home, living as a hermit of the wilds."* Thus, he changed his name to *Lin* ("Forest"). Wandering the valleys and peaks, he fled into secluded ravines, eating cypress leaves and sipping from streams. He traversed perilous paths and crumbling cliffs, enduring hardships in the wilderness. His form grew gaunt, yet he sought hidden masters, braving every trial. Though the roads were rugged and endless, he pressed onward without hesitation.

On Mount Taiyi, he encountered a stone bearing *zhi* mushrooms, glowing against the green cliffs. Gazing at it by night, he saw a radiant light and gathered them to consume. After seven days, he could travel six or seven hundred *li* in a day.

Later, in the mountains of Emei, he met the immortal Song Jun, who bestowed upon him the *Inner Writings of the Three Sovereigns* and the secret formulas of the Nine Elixirs. Cheng cultivated these arts with great efficacy, gaining the power to seal mountains and command peaks, to heal the sick and protect the living. Once, he cast a talisman into the water, and the current reversed for several paces before the surging waves abruptly stilled. With his medicines, he revived those who had died suddenly.

For years, malevolent spirits and ghosts plagued the land. When he subdued them, they bound themselves and came forth, some begging for mercy, others slain or released at his command. Once, a violent wind threatened to destroy homes and forests. He restrained it, and while the storm raged elsewhere, his dwelling alone was spared.

Another time, he encountered a landslide with trees crashing into the ravine. He sealed it with a talisman, and the disaster halted at his touch.

At over three hundred forty years of age, in the first year of Emperor Zhao’s reign, the sixth month of the year *yiwei*, the Lord of the Grand Tenuity dispatched celestial officials to descend and welcome him. Bestowing upon him the scriptures, he was appointed the Perfected One of the Grand Tenuity and ascended to wander the Nine Heavens.

---

Wang Tan, the Perfected One of the Yellow Court, styled himself Yangbo and hailed from Taiyuan. His appearance was striking, his bearing radiant as clouds and rosy dawn. He mastered the primordial currents and delved deeply into the roots of the Dao.

During the Han dynasty, he served as a Palace Attendant and Gentleman of the Interior. When Empress Lü usurped power, Tan withdrew to the southern mountains and dwelled at Louguan. There, he devoted himself to refining his essence through the *Morning Audience* and the arts of exhaling the old and inhaling the new.

When Emperor Wen ascended the throne, he revered Tan’s reputation and honored him as a man of leisure, though Tan was only thirty-six at the time. He often recited the *Five Thousand Character Scripture*, understanding that fame was fleeting while virtue was the foundation of the Dao. Thus, he widely practiced charity, ever mindful of the common people.

An immortal named Master Zhao disguised himself as a madman, his appearance disheveled. He begged from Tan without cease, yet Tan gave unstintingly, never doubting or questioning. Zhao secretly told him: *"I was testing you—you are worthy of instruction."* He then transmitted the *Inner Cultivation of the Yellow Court* and the formula for the *Alisma Elixir*. After months of practice, Tan’s spirit underwent a sudden transformation.

He entered the southern mountains to gather herbs and later returned to Louguan. There, he encountered the Jade Maiden of the Grand Primordium, Xiling Zidu, who taught him the *Way of Concealing the Radiance and Recording the Form*. He could then transform his body and alter his appearance in myriad ways—standing amidst groves, sitting by springs and stones, or shifting into water, fire, birds, or beasts. Yet his true form, following the *Fu of Yu*, remained unchanged.

He also studied under Sima Jizhu, mastering the *Boundless Arts of Spiritual Transformation*. Often walking with others, he would suddenly disperse his body into mist or stand upon level ground and become a towering peak. Onlookers trembled in awe, yet his original form remained serene in its place.

At the age of ninety-one, in the sixth year of Emperor Wu of Han’s *Yuanshuo* reign (the year *wuwu*, first month), the Golden Mother of the Western Numinosity dispatched immortal envoys to descend and welcome him. They conferred upon him the scriptures and named him Perfected of the Grand Ultimate, governing the Palace of Great Possession.

Li Yi, Immortal Minister of the Western Marchmount, studied under the Perfected Wang Tan and ascended as an immortal through the Dao.

He transmitted the Dao to the Elder of the River’s Bank, bestowing upon him the *Five Thousand Characters of the Dao and Virtue*, delving deeply into the mysteries of the Valley Spirit and the Dark Female. He also encountered extraordinary figures who imparted to him the *Book of Changes*, granting him penetrating insight into the workings of heaven, earth, yin, yang, and the transformations of creation. Thus, he traced hidden tracks and probed profound depths, aligning his virtue with heaven and earth, and his fortunes with spirits and gods. Through this, he could dwell in stillness like a corpse yet manifest like a dragon, remain as silent as the abyss yet resound like thunder, and stir the numinous to which heaven itself responded. He ascended into the heavens, roamed the mists, and traversed the boundless. Once his merit was complete and his Dao perfected, his dark virtue ascended to be heard, and the Heavenly Emperor conferred upon him the scriptures, appointing him Immortal Minister of the Western Marchmount.

*Comprehensive Mirror of Perfected Immortals Who Embodied the Dao Through the Ages*, Scroll Nine—concluded.
*Comprehensive Mirror of Perfected Immortals Who Embodied the Dao Through the Ages*, Scroll Ten.

Li Eight-Hundred, a native of Shu, whose given name remains unknown. Initially, he came to divine his dwelling at Five Dragons Ridge in Junyang, also called Red Ridge Stronghold—now the seat of Gao’an Prefecture—where the Quenching Sword Pool and Seven Stars Well still stand. Through the Xia, Shang, and Zhou dynasties, he lived eight hundred years, and when he moved, he could travel eight hundred li in a day; thus, the people of his time called him Li Eight-Hundred. At times he concealed himself in mountain forests, at others he dwelt amid the dust of markets.

Later, he cultivated his practice in a stone chamber on Mount Hualin. When his elixir was perfected and his Dao complete, he returned to Shu. By the Qin era, learning that Tang Gongfang possessed aspiration but had not encountered an enlightened master, he wished to instruct him. First, he went to test him, serving Gongfang as a hired laborer. Gongfang, unaware that he was an immortal, drove Eight-Hundred to work harder than the others, yet held him in great affection.

Later, Eight-Hundred feigned illness, growing weak as if near death. Gongfang summoned physicians and compounded medicines, spending tens of thousands of coins without regret, his concern for Eight-Hundred evident in his countenance. Then Eight-Hundred developed malignant sores covering his body, festering and foul, so noxious that none could approach. Gongfang wept and said: "You have toiled diligently for my household for years, only to fall gravely ill. I am most eager for your recovery and would spare nothing—yet now, what can be done?"

Eight-Hundred replied: "My sores may be cured, but they must be licked." Gongfang ordered three maidservants to lick them, but Eight-Hundred said: "The maids’ licking cannot heal me; if you yourself were to lick them, I should recover." Gongfang immediately did so. Eight-Hundred then said: "Even your licking cannot heal me; if your wife were to lick them, I would be cured." Gongfang then had his wife lick them.

Eight-Hundred declared: "My sores are healed. I now require thirty *hu* of fine wine for bathing, and then I shall be fully restored." Gongfang promptly prepared thirty *hu* of wine and filled a vessel with it. After bathing in the wine, Eight-Hundred’s sores vanished, his body smooth as congealed lard, without a trace of scarring. He then revealed to Gongfang: "I am an immortal. Because you possess a sincere heart, I came to test you. You are certainly fit to be taught. Now I shall truly transmit to you the secrets of transcending the world."

He had Gongfang, his wife, and the three maidservants who had licked his sores bathe in the leftover wine, whereupon they all grew youthful, their complexions fair and radiant. He bestowed upon Gongfang a scroll of elixir scriptures and entered Cloud Terrace Mountain to compound the elixir. When the elixir was complete, he consumed it and ascended as an immortal.

One tradition records Gongfang as Gong Fang, also called Tang Gongfang, a native of Xingyuan Prefecture, who drank the immortal wine of Li Eight-Hundred and later ascended with his entire household. Today, Dou Mountain Abbey stands as his legacy. The *Veritable Records of the Primordial Origin* state: Li Tuo studied the Dao of longevity and, during the reign of King Mu of Zhou, came to dwell beneath Dragon Bridge Peak on Mount Jintang in Shu. There he compounded the Nine-Flowered Elixir, and upon its completion, traveled among the Five Marchmounts, the Ten Grotto-Heavens, and over two hundred other sites for more than two hundred years. On the sea, he encountered the Flying Yang Lord, who transmitted to him the Dao of Water and Jade. Returning to this mountain, he refined the elixir to perfection, then departed for several hundred years more. Sometimes hidden, sometimes visible, he wandered through markets and courts.

Later, he returned beneath Dragon Bridge Peak, where he refined the Golden Tripod Returning Elixir. When the elixir was complete, he had already lived eight hundred years. The people of Shu saw him through successive generations, hence the name Li Eight-Hundred. As he studied the Dao thrice upon this mountain, later generations called it Three Studies Mountain—also known as Mount Xixian—now under the jurisdiction of Huaian Prefecture.

The *Illustrated Classic of Immortal Abodes in the Nine Regions* states that Li Eight-Hundred ascended from this place. The *Veritable Records of Mount Hualin* record that Li Eight-Hundred ascended in broad daylight at Three Studies Mountain in Jintang County, Hanzhou. His stone chamber lies a hundred paces west of Floating Cloud Abbey, beneath the central peak, measuring one *zhang* in both width and height, and is called the Eight-Hundred Grotto-Heaven. To the southeast is another grotto entrance, just large enough for a person to enter. After several *zhang*, the passage gradually widens and rises, its depths unfathomable.

During the early Kaiyuan era of Emperor Xuanzong of Tang, Celestial Master Sun received the esoteric formulas of Celestial Master Zhang and concealed them within this grotto, which people thereafter called the Grotto of Celestial Master Sun. In the Huichang era of Emperor Wuzong, a local man named Gong entered the grotto and obtained a scroll of the Six Ding Rain-Praying Formula. Whenever drought struck, his prayers were instantly answered. In the fifth year of the Xiantong era of Emperor Yizong, the Gao’an Daoist Zhu Yuanzheng entered the grotto and retrieved two scrolls of scripture from a stone casket, bearing the inscription: *The True Wind Reveals the Nature of Color*. Yuanzheng pondered: “Nature is surname; the nature of color must refer to the Zhu clan.” He then returned to Gao’an to propagate the teachings, which flourished in his time. Many have entered this grotto before and after, each encountering different circumstances, though those of impure or defiled disposition invariably meet with obstacles. Truly, the abodes of immortals and transcendents do not suffer those without the bone of the Dao to rashly intrude or pry.

Floating Cloud Abbey was later renamed Floating Cloud Mountain Abbey of Saintly Longevity and Myriad Years during the Song, and placed under the jurisdiction of Fengxin County, Longxing Prefecture.

**Master Kuang Fu of Mount Kuang**
Master Kuang Fu, whose given name was Xu and courtesy name Junping—also called Zixiao or Junji—was a native of Southern Chu. Some say he descended from the lineage of Great Yu. Endowed with divine intelligence from birth, he harbored aspirations beyond the mundane even in childhood. During the reign of King Wu of Zhou, he studied under Lao Cong, the Archivist Beneath the Pillars, and attained the Dao of longevity. He then built a thatched hut above Tiger Brook on the southern slope of Mount Nanfu and lived in seclusion.

Within his chamber, there was nothing—only a single couch and a few bundles of bamboo slips. When King Wu heard of his reputation, he repeatedly summoned and invited him, but the Master never rose to answer. After many years had passed, several youths came to visit him. One introduced himself, saying: "My surname is Liu, my given name Yue. My home lies to the left of the mountain ahead. I invite you, Master, to visit." He added: "At the foot of the mountain, there is a stone about two feet high—that is my dwelling." Later, the Master went as promised. When he reached the foot of the mountain, he looked around but saw no dwelling—only the stone. He knocked upon it, and the stone opened like double doors. Two attendants in blue, bearing crimson tally-staffs, led the way before him. Gradually, he beheld towers and terraces rising in tiers, their gold and jade radiance shimmering, birds soaring, and rare flowers and trees. The youth, wearing a crown of dark jade and girded with a vermilion sash and sword, ascended the hall to receive him. The Master realized this was no mortal realm and wished to remain. The youth said to him: "Your hidden merits are not yet complete; a later meeting may be expected." He then offered the Master three cups of jade wine, followed by a sip of the *Elixir of Longevity and Life-Preservation*. The Master took his leave and departed. When he turned to look back, only the great stone remained as before.

After this encounter, the Master’s spirit and countenance grew ever more luminous, and he never ceased his cultivation. King Ding once asked the Archivist Boyang Fu who among the immortals still dwelled in the world. Boyang Fu listed the immortals of the Five Peaks, and the Master was among them. The King then summoned him, but the Master delayed and did not appear. By the time of King Weilie, envoys were again sent with a comfortable carriage to invite him. Before they arrived, the Master said: "The time has come." He then ascended into the sky in broad daylight. When the envoys sought his place of seclusion, only an empty thatched hut remained. Upon their return, they memorialized the throne, requesting that Nanfu Mountain be renamed Jinglu Mountain. The people of the region also called it by the Master’s surname—Kuang Mountain, or Kuangfu, or Kuanglu. Later, to avoid the taboo of the Song founding emperor’s name, *Kuang* was changed to *Kang*. To this day, villages and altars in the area are named after him, and Tiger Brook became one of the Thirty-Six Blessed Lands.

According to the *True Record of the Primordial Origin*, citing the *Erya* and *Explanation of Names*: "A mound of earth is called *fu*." This mountain was originally named Nanfu, meaning "earth bearing the three celestial spears." In ancient times, Mount Qian was worshipped as the Southern Peak, and Nanfu served as its auxiliary, hence it was also called the Southern Peak. After the Master’s ascension, the Celestial Emperor commanded him to oversee the droughts and floods of the Huai and Chu regions and bestowed upon him the Seal of the Lord of Warmth, placing him in charge of the eight divisions of warmth spirits. Thus, he was popularly styled *Master of Harmonious Warmth and Prosperous Mound*.

The Master had two eminent disciples: one was the Perfected of the White Deer, the other the Perfected Hongzi. Today, on Mount Lu, the *Hong Well of Elixir-Refining* and the *White Deer Grotto* remain as their legacy. In the first year of the *Yuanfeng* era of Emperor Wu of Han, during his southern inspection tour, he ascended the Heavenly Pillar and offered sacrifices. Later, he shot a dragon in the Xunyang River. Turning to his attendants, he asked which spirit presided over this mountain. The scholar Liu Gu replied: "Master Kuang Xu attained the Dao here." The Emperor then enfeoffed him as the *Duke of Great Brilliance of the Southern Pole* and ordered a shrine built at his former seclusion by Tiger Brook, including it in the official sacrifices.

By the Eastern Jin, the monk Huiyuan of Yanmen, returning from Mount Luofu, spent the night at the shrine. Enamored of the beauty of the streams and mountains, he petitioned the prefect Huan Yi, saying: "Last night, I dreamed that Master Kuang wished to cede the shrine for a temple." Huan Yi consented, and thus the Eastern and Western Forests Monasteries were established, while the Master’s shrine was relocated to the northwest of the mountain’s entrance. During the *Kaiyuan* era of the Tang, the temple was further expanded. At the beginning of the *Tianbao* era, Emperor Ming commanded envoys to offer sacrifices, honoring it as an immortal sanctuary. When the local people suffered from floods, droughts, or epidemics, their prayers were always answered.

In the *Baoda* era of the Southern Tang, the chancellor Zhou Zong, serving as commissioner to the southern regions, arrived in Jiujiang. Seeing the shrine in disrepair, he ordered its restoration. He then summoned the Daoist Que Yuanyin to oversee it and ensure the continuity of incense offerings. He also memorialized the throne to grant a manor with lands, permanently endowing it for vegetarian feasts.

During the *Zhiping* era of Emperor Yingzong of the Song, the shrine was granted the plaque "Abbey" and bestowed the name *Shousheng*. When imperial sacrifices were conducted at the suburban altars, inscribed tablets were descended, and the prefectural deputy was dispatched to offer libations, establishing this as an enduring ritual. In the first year of the *Jianzhong Jingguo* era, Emperor Huizong issued a decree posthumously enfeoffing the Master as *Jingming Zhenren* ("True Person of Serene Illumination"). In the thirty-second year of the *Shaoxing* era of Emperor Gaozong, to avoid the honorific name of the *Deshou* Palace, the plaque was changed to *Guangfu* ("Vast Fortune").

Bai Yuchan of Qiongshan inscribed an ancient-style poem:
*King Wu laughed as he rode the azure jade steed,*
*Seizing the aged tyrant Zhou to dash him to pieces.*
*The four seas’ people all perished from plague,*
*While recluses in the woods willingly endured hunger.*
*One man wrote books beneath Mount Song,*
*Another gathered fern on Shouyang’s heights.*
*Eight demons spread pestilence to poison the young,*
*Eight-spoked wind-chariots blew fire-horses’ breath.*
*I have heard that Kang Xu hid in his serene hut,*
*Where the Old Man of the Azure Ox bestowed upon him a book.*
*The Purple Emperor granted him the Seal of Pestilence-Quelling,*
*And the world’s withered people gradually revived.*
*Yet when he heard of the ten rebellions in the human realm,*
*He steeled his will, ate asters, and drank from spring streams.*
*Neither King Ding nor King Lie could summon him forth,*
*Nor could the Qin king’s boats reach Xiaohan’s shores.*
*By the time the ruins of Wangyi were overgrown with moss,*
*The Central Plains’ deer had fled to the Han.*
*The Daoist-loving Son of Heaven swore oaths to the river dragon,*
*And thus enfeoffed the Master as Duke of Great Illumination.*
*A Jin monk loved the land and planted white lotuses,*
*Reporting his dream to the herdsman to build a Buddhist temple.*
*I suspect that Lao Cong once transformed into a dragon—*
*Could the Master’s intent not have been the same?*
*The waters of Tiger Creek coil with azure dragons,*
*The mountains of Tiger Creek scrape the azure heavens.*
*Later men mocked Ge Hong for his mistake:*
*Having reached Mount Lu, he still set foot elsewhere.*
*After Ge Hong’s departure, how many have come?*
*The cave is filled with white clouds, cold and desolate.*

Minister Dao Yi remarked: "Kang Xu, though repeatedly summoned by the Zhou king, refused to rise, honing his resolve in the Dao. He regarded the nobility of kings and marquises and the wealth of gold and jade as no more than dirt or grass. Ultimately, he perfected his merit and fulfilled his conduct, ascending in broad daylight. As the *Daodejing* states: *'Though one may offer a large jade ring followed by a team of four horses, it is not equal to sitting and advancing in this Dao.'* This was truly Kang Xu’s path. Among later Daoist adepts who spurned kings and lords, exalted their pursuits, and either ascended in flight or achieved liberation in death, there have been countless thousands—perhaps all tracing their origins to Kang Xu."

**Jade Master**
The Jade Master, surnamed Zhang and named Zhen, was a native of Nanjun. In his youth, he studied the various classics. When King You of Zhou summoned him, he refused to appear, sighing: "In this worldly life, one drifts ever farther from birth and ever nearer to death. Rather than coveting wealth and rank, it is better to nurture one’s nature. When life’s span ends and qi is exhausted, one dies—what use are titles like king or marquis, or mountains of gold and jade, when the body becomes ashes and dust? Only the immortals who transcend the world offer boundless existence." He then became a disciple of Sangzi, receiving all the classics in full. Later, he devised his own school of methods, composing over a hundred scrolls of Daoist texts. His arts centered on *wu kui* (the five astral emanations), and he mastered the subtleties of the Five Phases, expounding their mysteries to nurture life, cure illnesses, and dispel disasters and misfortunes.

He could summon whirlwinds to tear off roofs and snap trees, or conjure thunderstorms, clouds, and mists. He could transform grass, pebbles, and tiles into the six livestock or dragons and tigers, which would immediately come to life and move about. He could divide his form into hundreds or thousands of people. He could stride across rivers and seas; when he held water in his mouth and spat it out, it turned to pearls and jade, never reverting. At times, he would hold his breath until he could not be lifted, pushed, bent, or straightened, remaining thus for tens or even a hundred days before reviving. When traveling with disciples, he would mold clay into horses for each, instructing them to close their eyes. In an instant, the clay became great steeds, carrying them a thousand *li* in a day. He could exhale qi in five colors, rising hundreds of *zhang* high; if a flying bird passed by, he could point to it and it would fall to the ground. By casting talismans into deep pools, he could summon fish and turtles to shore.

He could also enable his disciples to see objects a thousand *li* away with a glance, though they could not sustain this for long. During *wu kui* rituals, he would fill a vessel with water, place two *kui* (astral markers) within, and blow upon it. A radiant red light would rise one or two *zhang* above the water. This water could cure all illnesses: those with internal ailments drank it, while external afflictions were washed with it, and all were instantly healed. Later, he entered Kongtong Mountain to compound the elixir and ascended to heaven in broad daylight.

**Luming**
The Master of Great Yang, surnamed Li and named Ming, was a close friend of the Jade Master from the same era. After the Jade Master had perfected his Daoist arts, Luming became his disciple, observing all the rites of a pupil without the slightest negligence. The Jade Master held him in particular affection; among his three thousand disciples, none could compare. However, Luming was fond of wine and often drunk, for which he was frequently reproached.

Though skilled in the arts of the Five Phases, his hair had turned grizzled with age, yet his flesh remained full, his complexion radiant, and even after three hundred years, his appearance showed no change. The Jade Master said to him: "You ought to cultivate the body and nurture the nature to serve as a model for all worthy disciples, yet you remain sunk in drunken stupor, neglecting your practice, failing to refine the great elixir. Even if you lived a thousand years, it would still not suffice to escape death—how much less so to die after merely a few hundred? Such conduct is beneath even the common and mediocre; how could it befit one who has attained understanding?" He replied: "As a latecomer to the Way, my nature is stubborn, and worldly habits have yet to be purged. Thus, I use wine to curb my own arrogance in this manner."

He composed *The Art of the Seven Jeweled Trees*, mastering the essentials of the Dao. Having ingested the elixir and attained immortality, he often remained in the world, and for five hundred years, his face retained the freshness of youth. His fondness for wine, however, left his temples and hair snowy white.

**Du Yu**
Du Yu was the lord of Shu. Once, when a great flood struck Shu, Yu and the people took refuge from the waters on Changping Mountain, located above the Weijiang River in Qingcheng, eighty *li* from the county seat, where they built ramparts and settled. Later, Bie Ling dredged the gorges and tamed the waters, allowing the people to return to dry land. Yu abdicated his throne to him and retired to the Western Mountains, where he attained the Dao and ascended to heaven. The descendants of Bie Ling ruled the land of Shu for twelve generations until the reign of Kaiming, when it was annexed by Qin and thus connected to the Central Kingdom.

**Li Bing**
Li Bing and Yang Mo were both adepts of the Dao from Shu who commanded ghosts and spirits, drove away clouds and dragons, and could accomplish anything. During the time of the Kaiming rulers, they wandered and rested in Shu, where they once assisted in governing the waters, bringing relief to the people of Shu. In the reign of King Xiaowen of Qin, Bing served as the governor of Shu Commandery and opened the rivers to irrigate ten thousand *qing* of fields. At the time, shamans claimed that each year the River Lord took a young girl as his bride. When Bing arrived at the river shrine to rebuke him, the spirit suddenly vanished. After a long while, two dark oxen appeared wrestling on the bank. Presently, Bing returned, drenched in sweat, and said to his officials: "I am utterly exhausted—can any of you assist me?" He pointed southward: "The one with the white at its waist is my transformed self." Soon after, he was again spent. The magistrate stabbed the ox facing north, and the River Lord perished. The river no longer brought disaster, nor did it demand brides.

Bing carved five stone rhinoceroses to suppress the waters: one at Qingcheng, two at Xipu, one at the bridge in Chengdu, and one at Wangzhong. He also set up three stone figures in the water beneath the White Sand Mound at the Jade Maiden’s Chamber north of the county, swearing an oath with the river spirit: "When the waters recede, they shall not fall below the feet; when they rise, they shall not reach the shoulders." To this day, the oath holds, and the stone figures remain on the left bank of the river. The people of Shu have worshipped Bing for generations. When Emperor Xuanzong of Tang fled to Shu, in recognition of Bing’s contributions to the people, he ordered the shrine to be adorned and posthumously bestowed upon him the titles of Minister of Works and Chancellor. He decreed that wherever floods threatened, villages should erect temples to Bing, and the waters would subside.

Yang Mo also possessed divine guardians and could subdue dragons and tigers. He likewise diverted water to irrigate fields at the side of Great Soapberry Hill, swearing an oath with the dragon.

**Lu Ban**
Lu Ban, a man of Dunhuang, was so skilled in craftsmanship that his works rivaled the creations of heaven and earth.

Lu Ban once resented the people of Wu for killing his father. At the south of Su City, he crafted a wooden immortal whose hand pointed toward the land of Wu, causing a great drought there for three years. Divination revealed: "This is Ban’s doing." The people of Wu offered sacrifices and made amends, whereupon Ban severed the wooden hand. That very month, heavy rains fell across Wu.

**Ma Chengzi**
Between the Zhou and Qin dynasties, the realm was in tumult—strong states encroached upon the weak, the many oppressed the few, and ceaseless campaigns left people no respite for peace. Ma Chengzi of Fufeng, witnessing this, sighed: "A lifespan of a hundred years, a body of six feet—yet none can preserve themselves. Such is the world entire. Since heaven has given me life, there must be a Way to prolong it. Why cast myself into death? I have heard that the Dao is the ancestor of the ten thousand things, the origin of life’s essence, the root of transformation, the foundation of heaven and earth, unchanging through the ages, abiding in stillness. How might I find an enlightened teacher to reveal the gate of cultivating the Dao?"

For years, this thought occupied him. He abandoned his home, sought masters, and pursued the Dao. Hearing that on the southern slopes of Mount Qi, beside the branching Wei River, lay Boyang Valley—a place where the Old Lord (Laozi) and Yin Xi had once traversed—and that there stood a terrace where the Old Lord had transmitted the supreme Dao to King Wen of Zhou, he set out to find it.

Arriving at Boyang Valley, he encountered a youth who asked Chengzi: "What do you seek by climbing this mountain?" Chengzi explained his quest for the Dao. The youth laughed: "I have served the Old Lord for twelve thousand years, yet I have not heard of the profound and subtle Great Cavern Dao. You, who have barely ventured beyond the narrow confines of this world, dare seek the Dao—is this not difficult?" Astonished by his words, Chengzi bowed deeply and pleaded: "The life of a morning mushroom is but a fleeting instant. Without a sage to prolong it, it will rot and crumble into dust. Once this body is lost, when shall I again hear the Dao? I beg you, sage, take pity and instruct me."

The youth replied: "I am but a servant of the Most High, young and ignorant, unversed in the great Dao. I cannot teach you. Yet your苦志 in the mountains and springs, your weariness and spiritual strain, your tireless devotion to the Dao—these are truly pitiable. Still, I have heard the Most High Old Lord once tell King Yudan of the Heaven of Abundant Joy: 'The Dao gives birth to the ten thousand things, and the things do not depart from the Dao. Those who attain the Dao live; those who lose it die. The Dao resides within the self, not in others.' Now you exhaust yourself traversing mountains and rivers, enduring hardships—this is indeed a sign of resolve, yet you remain far from the Dao."

Chengzi bowed again and asked: "If the Dao is within the self, by what gate may one cultivate it?" The youth then taught him the method of refining the primordial qi of the embryo.

Chengzi entered Shu and arrived at Hummingbird Mountain, where he secluded himself in a stone cave. There, a man over ten feet tall, clad in a deerskin robe of coarse hair, leaning on a staff, approached him and discoursed on the arts of reclusion. He said to Chengzi: "This mountain is home to a stone pigeon that cries once every three hundred years. When it cries, someone in this mountain attains the Dao and ascends to heaven. This bird has cried frequently of late—you shall ascend soon." He then transmitted the divine elixir, saying: "The Dao-qi of the Most High is the inner elixir; herbs are the outer elixir. Hidden merit is the inner elixir; minerals and metals are the outer elixir. You have refined the primordial qi of the embryo, taught by the Yellow Canopy Youth. The Yellow Canopy is the son of the Dark Heaven and Grand Yang, and with the Golden Flower Jade Maiden, he attends the Most High. Through countless kalpas, his countenance remains ever youthful. To have encountered such a teacher is no different from personally attending the Most High. Since the inner elixir is already complete, my outer elixir is but a trifle. The Most High taught this to the Lord of the Grand Tenuity, who transmitted it to the Later Sage Lord of Great Peace, who in turn passed the secret to me. On the Central Mystery Mountain, I gathered the essence of the eight winds and the five planets, employed the furnace of the sun and moon, harmonized the qi of heaven and earth, commanded the Three Origins, summoned the myriad spirits, and refined it for eighty-one years before the elixir was complete. Now I bestow it upon you. Consume it before the Nine Heavens, and you shall be appointed the Most High’s Grand Minister of the Supreme Ultimate and Attendant of the Nine Florets, entering to serve the Jade Dawn and ranking among the lofty perfected."

With these words, he departed on a cloud. Chengzi reverently received and consumed the elixir, then told his disciples: "The Dao-qi of this mountain is extraordinary. Those who achieve great merit and rank among the highest perfected in the Three Heavens often attain the Dao here—this is why the stone pigeon cries every three hundred years." Soon after, he ascended to heaven in broad daylight.

Later, Celestial Master Zhang Daoling also dwelled on this mountain. The Most High descended to him, bestowing the title of Great Dharma Master of the Three Heavens and appointing him to oversee the Bureau of the Grand Mystery. Indeed, this occurred over three hundred years later.

**King Kang of Chu**
King Kang of Chu’s given name is unknown; he was a descendant of King Huai.

King Kang was known for his virtuous conduct and won the people’s allegiance, so the nation enthroned him. When the First Emperor of Qin conquered the six states and divided the land into thirty-six commanderies, King Kang, pressed to extremity, fled to Mount Lu and took refuge in a deep valley to the southeast to evade disaster. There, he secretly prayed to the mountain spirit, hoping for unseen aid. At that time, General Wang Jian led his troops to the valley’s mouth, but seeing mists and dust swirling, thunderstorms raging, and ravines flooding—obscuring all paths—he grew fearful and withdrew his forces. Thus, King Kang escaped. From afar, he saw the retreating army hasten away. The place is now called Horse’s Arrival Ridge.

King Kang sighed and said: “In ancient times, Shun’s southern tour never ended; I have found refuge on Mount Lu, to grow old among its forests and springs—this is enough.” He ventured deeper into the valley and never emerged. After a long time, he encountered an extraordinary person and attained the Dao. Later, those who entered the mountain sometimes saw him. When they observed his unusual movements and questioned him, he would give them his hairpin or beard, or reveal his name. In the early Datong era of the Liang dynasty, a temple was built beside the site, which Emperor Wu named the Temple of King Kang.

Dai Shiyu praised him, saying: “Chen Shunyu of Mount Lu recorded that this was King Kang of Chu. According to the *Spring and Autumn Annals*, he died in the twenty-first year of Duke Xiang of Lu, when the lords of Chen, Xu, Zheng, and Lu sent their rulers’ envoys to attend his funeral beyond the western gate, and the ministers of the feudal lords all gathered at his tomb. At that time, Chu was strong, yet three hundred twenty-six years later, Qin rose and destroyed it. How could King Kang still exist? Yet it is not unknown that before the Zhou, there was King Ding Yu, and after, King Ding Jie; before Lu, there was Duke Wen Xing, and after, Duke Wen Jia. Thus, the Zhou had two King Dings, and Lu had two Duke Wens. By this logic, there could indeed have been another King Kang after King Kang Zhao—it is no wonder, merely an omission in the Grand Historian’s records. Many renowned figures of Mount Lu do not appear in the standard histories but emerge only in miscellaneous accounts.”

The Three Generals of Tang and Qin:
One was named Jianwei, of the Tang clan;
Another was named Deshou, of the Li clan.

One was named Yundiao, of the Song clan—none knew their origins. During the reign of the First Emperor, the three were all warriors who had rendered great service to the state and held lofty ranks and titles. Later, seeing the governance of Qin grow increasingly disordered, they conferred among themselves: “The tide of the times has turned; heroes shall rise. Now petty men fill the court, upright words go unheeded, the Kingly Way is in disarray, and governance is perverse. If we do not act soon, we shall be but fish and meat for others.” At that time, ten renowned officials—all upright gentlemen—also departed in succession. Thus, the thirteen men all abandoned their posts to cultivate the Dao, seeking famous mountains and entering mist-laden groves, like deer escaping the hunting grounds, with no thought of return.

They passed along the southern slopes of Mount Lu and came to the foot of Purple Cloud Peak, where they admired the beauty of the mountains and waters. The three warriors wished to settle there, but the ten others said: “Not so. Our original intent was to return to the Cavern of Assembled Jade—how can we abandon our path midway?” Before they could set out, one night a thunderstorm suddenly descended, and torrents surged forth. At daybreak, they saw that their dwellings had transformed on either side into two streams, and upon a boulder in the midst of the waters lay a jade slip inscribed in celestial script: *“By divine transformation, the Spirit Stream arises; the golden tablet marks where true adepts dwell in the hidden Jade Cavern.”* The ten men vanished without a trace, while the three warriors took up residence beside the stream, planting peach trees and gathering lingzhi to sustain their cultivation.

Jianwei said: “We should bestow alms upon the poor.”
Deshou said: “We should heal the sick with medicine.”
Yundiao said: “We should speak to dispel delusion.”
Though their methods differed, their merit was the same, and those near and far reaped their blessings. In time, only auspicious clouds drifted through the sky and a pair of cranes danced in flight—from then on, the three attained the Dao and ascended as immortals.

Later generations named their dwelling the Cave of the Three Generals and established a shrine there. In the reign of Emperor Wu of Han, it was bestowed the name Spirit Stream Abbey.

*Records of Perfected Immortals Through the Ages Who Embodied the Dao, Scroll Ten—concluded*
*Records of Perfected Immortals Through the Ages Who Embodied the Dao, Scroll Eleven*

Kong Qiuming, Luo Fatong, Wu Tianyin, Zhang Fashu, Xie Zhikong, Zhou Xianyong, Zou Wujun, Xie Youcha, Yang Yuanzhong, He Zixiao, and three others—thirteen in all—lived during the reign of Qin Ershi. Distressed by the chaos of the times, they swore fellowship, abandoned their official posts, and journeyed far in search of the Great Dao. Among them were three warriors: Li Deshou, Song Yundiao, and Tang Jianwei, whose lineages, ranks, and native places remain unknown. Upon first arriving at Mount Lu, they wished to rest. One evening, a fierce wind and torrential rain formed a stream, within which they discovered a stone inscription reading: *"Divine transformation at Spirit Stream; golden tablets mark the Perfected’s decree—hidden dwelling in the Jade Grotto."* The three remained by the stream, and this is the site of present-day Spirit Stream Abbey.

The other ten—Kong’s family resided southwest of Jade Bamboo Mountain, and Wu’s family west of Gan River. Kong said: *"The peaks of Qunyu in the south are the Seventeenth Grotto-Heaven, known as the Celestial Realm of Great Elegance and Dharma Joy. The mountains are refined, the grottoes numinous—we may follow our original resolve and dwell here in retreat. How could we abandon our path midway?"* The ten prepared their belongings and hastened to Qunyu. Kong said: *"West of the Grotto-Heaven, extraordinary peaks rise in splendor—there must be a sacred crag where we may rest and pay homage to the Primordial."* Indeed, before a southeastern stone cliff, they encountered a branching cavern. On the wall was ancient seal script, which read: *"Western Gate of the Grotto-Heaven."*

All ten were reclusive gentlemen of lofty virtue, refining their spirits and harmonizing their qi, each practicing distinct arts. One day, an elder in plain robes arrived holding a bronze basin containing ten small carp. He said: *"These fish are extraordinary—tend to them well."* They promptly dug a pond behind the Grotto-Heaven to house them, and later generations called it the Dragon-Rearing Pool.

He Zixiao loved distant travels and was often careless, ignoring the exhortations of his companions. The other nine, recognizing that immortality could be cultivated, redoubled their efforts. During the reign of Emperor Jing of Han, their Daoist practices reached perfection. A spirit descended to their hermitage, identifying itself as the Controller of Destiny of the Grotto-Heaven, and addressed the nine: *"Your sincerity has reached its peak. Today, your names are inscribed in the northern register of Dengluo, and your titles engraved in the Southern Palace."* It then transmitted the secret of returning cinnabar and departed. After refining and consuming the elixir, the spirit returned, saying: *"The August Emperor’s edict is imminent—hasten to the Immortal-Sending Terrace."* They awaited the appointed hour, and when the time came, a host of immortals had already arrived. A grand feast was laid out in farewell, resembling an imperial court assembly. As the wine circulated, a pure breeze arose, clouds gathered in ranks, and a fragrant mist enveloped them. Nine dragons drew the carriage, while phoenixes and luan birds danced before them. The Jade Emperor dispatched envoys in embroidered robes and azure-clad youths, bearing ten jade tablets, ten chests of rosy-cloud robes, a casket of golden elixir, and rainbow banners with feathered staffs—all presented upon the terrace.

Only He Zixiao, still wandering afar, had not returned. From dawn to mid-morning, the nine Perfected consumed the elixir, changed into their celestial robes, and prepared their carriages. As they waited in vain, they left one jade tablet, one chest of rosy-cloud robes, and a plain register upon the Flying Immortal Stone for him. The immortal music grew plaintive, and the assembly of immortals urged their departure. Perfected Kong sighed: *"Immortal Liang, oh Immortal Liang! To what realm do you wander? I now depart—why do you alone remain?"* Soon after, their forms ascended, vanishing into the distance. The nine dragons that drew their carriage were none other than the carp they had once reared.

Before their ascension, the nine Perfected had forged ten treasured swords at the Stone Terrace in the eastern sun. One was given to Immortal Liang to wear, another buried at the Immortal-Sending Terrace, and the rest enshrined to guard the eight gates of the Grotto-Heaven.

**He Zixiao**
He Zixiao, styled Immortal Liang, was also said to bear the surname Deng. After the nine Perfected had ascended, Immortal Liang finally returned, his spirit untrammeled, weeping before the mist and clouds. He climbed the Flying Immortal Stone and received the chest and register. The Perfected Lord Controller of Destiny arrived and said: *"You, Perfected One, have defied the Jade Emperor’s decree and may not attend the Primordial Assembly of the Nine Perfected. Your merit remains incomplete—you may conceal yourself in the Yuan Gui Grotto."* Opening the chest and donning the robe, he examined the plain register, which contained the method for consuming the herbs of Great Clarity, stating that it could confer earthly immortality. It also mentioned a grotto northeast of the mountain, situated in the open plains—this was the abode of earthly immortals, where he might reside.

Immortal Liang overturned the chest atop the peak, and in an instant, it transformed into stone. Later generations named the peak after it, for its shape bore a striking resemblance. He also released a white ape and a dog, both of which fed on the immortal herbs and ascended into the void. Immortal Liang consumed the herbs of Great Clarity and practiced the secret methods of the plain register. Within days, he could traverse the emptiness. Massive boulders from the remnant mountains flew into the stone grotto—such was the way of earthly immortals.

Initially, the spirit had commanded them to rear the fish in the pool, which transformed into nine dragons to carry the nine Perfected aloft. Upon inspection, the pool was gone. Only one fish surfaced intermittently, later transforming into a dragon that concealed itself in the branching grotto.

**Tang Gongfang**
Tang Gongfang, also recorded as Tang Gongfang, was a native of Xingyuan Prefecture.

In Xingyuan stood the Dou Mountain Abbey. From the flat plains rose a solitary mountain, its four faces sheer cliffs, its summit flat as the bottom of a dipper—hence its name. The *Kaishan Jing* states: "Five caverns of Dou Mountain connect to Kunlun. Among the mountains dwell thousand-year-old toads called *rouzhi*, whose flesh, when eaten, grants a thousand years of life." The mountain was wreathed in creeping fig and draped in fir and juniper, its scenery most wondrous. Nearby lay the site where Tang Gongfang had drunk immortal wine with Li Babai, and where his entire household had ascended bodily into the heavens. The foundation of his former residence, some three *mu* in size, had sunken into a pit—this was where the earth itself had risen with them. Another account claims that when Gongfang ascended with his household, his parrot and dog followed, but his rat, despising its own lack of ambition, refused to go. The rat later repented, vomiting thrice in a month to replace its entrails, becoming the famed "Tang rat" of Guang Weimo’s records. A poem left by a former visitor reads:

*Robe of rosy mist, half-drunk, near to soar,*
*Unseen, the whole household dwells now evermore.*
*The homestead recalls but parrot and hound,*
*Who would believe the road to heaven so near and bound?*
*From the Three Clarities’ vastness, the dust-dream cast,*
*To the Eight Radiant Mists, the morning court is passed.*
*Only the old grove, verdant and proud,*
*Where dew and haze veil the startled terrace, enshroud.*

In Yangzhou stood Cold Spring Mountain. The *Hanzhong Ji* records: "Qin-era Tang Gongfang became a disciple of the immortal Li Babai. When Gongfang grew thirsty, Li struck the cliff with his staff, and a spring gushed forth." This was the very mountain. Those who ascend it must do so with utmost reverence.

At times, when disputes arose, sudden storms of wind and thunder would erupt—hence its name.

**Ding Lingwei**
Ding Lingwei was a native of Liaodong. In his youth, he followed a master and attained the Dao of immortality, gaining the power to divide his form at will. Often, he would transform into a white crane and alight upon the ornamental pillar outside the city gate of his hometown, where he spoke:

*"I am Ding Lingwei, gone from home a thousand years. Now I return—
The city walls stand as before, but the people are not the same.
Why not learn the Way and flee the tomb’s shadow?"*

Then he soared high into the heavens and departed. That Zuo Yuanfang became a sheep and Lingwei a crane were but fleeting transformations of their time, not permanent forms. The genealogies of Liaodong’s Ding clan record that Lingwei attained immortality through Daoist practice during the early Han.

**Zhang Liang**
Zhang Liang, styled Zifang, was descended from the people of Han. When Qin destroyed Han, Liang used his family’s wealth to hire assassins to strike at the King of Qin and avenge his homeland. As his ancestors had served five generations as Han’s ministers, Liang once studied rites in Huaiyang. On the shores of Cangzhou, he encountered a strongman who wielded an iron mace weighing one hundred and twenty *jin*. When the First Emperor of Qin toured the east and reached Bolangsha, Liang and his retainer lay in ambush. They struck at the imperial procession but mistakenly hit the escort carriage. Enraged, the First Emperor sought the assailants with great urgency. Liang changed his name and fled into hiding in Xiapi.

Once, while strolling near Xiapi, Liang came upon an old man in coarse hempen robes standing on a bridge (the people of Chu called bridges *yi*). The man deliberately dropped his shoe beneath the bridge and said to Liang, "Boy, go down and fetch it." Liang was startled and wished to strike him, but out of respect for his age, he restrained himself, descended, retrieved the shoe, and knelt to present it. The old man placed his foot out to receive it, much to Liang’s astonishment. The man said, "You are teachable. Meet me here at dawn in five days." Liang, puzzled, knelt and agreed.

At dawn on the fifth day, Liang arrived, but the old man was already there. Angrily, he asked, "Why are you late?" He instructed Liang to return at the crowing of the rooster five days later. When Liang arrived, the old man was again already there and scolded him for his tardiness. After another five days, Liang went at midnight. After a short while, the old man arrived and, pleased, said, "This is how it should be." He produced a scroll and said, "Read this, and you will become the teacher of kings. In ten years, you will rise. Thirteen years from now, you will see me beneath the city walls of Jibei in Gucheng—there, the yellow stone is me." Then he vanished.

At daybreak, Liang examined the scroll and found it to be *The Art of War of the Grand Duke*. Astonished, he studied and recited it often. While in Xiapi, he acted as a knight-errant and frequently advised the Lord of Pei using the strategies of the Grand Duke. The Lord of Pei delighted in his counsel and often followed it, though he paid little heed to others’ advice. Liang remarked, "The Lord of Pei is surely heaven’s chosen." Thus, he remained by his side and never left.

When the Lord of Pei sought to attack Qin’s forces at Hangu Pass, Liang said, "I hear their general is the son of a butcher, a merchant easily swayed by profit. I suggest we hold our position, raise more banners on the mountains to create the illusion of a larger force, and send Li Yiji with precious gifts to win over the Qin general." The Qin general considered making peace, and when his guard was down, they struck. The Qin army was defeated, and they advanced to Xianyang, where the King of Qin, Ziying, surrendered.

When the Lord of Pei entered the Qin palace, he saw its curtains, carriages, hunting dogs, treasures, and women—numbering in the thousands—and wished to remain. Though Fan Kuai remonstrated, he did not listen. Liang said, "Qin ruled without the Way, which is why you have come this far. To rid the world of tyranny, you should conduct yourself with simplicity. Now, upon entering Qin, you indulge in its pleasures—this is to aid Jie in his cruelty. Loyal words may grate upon the ear, but they benefit conduct; bitter medicine may be hard to swallow, but it cures illness. I hope you will heed this advice." The Lord of Pei then withdrew his troops to Bashang. (For the meeting at Hongmen, see *The Annals of the Han Emperor Gao*.)

When the Lord of Pei became the King of Han, Liang advised him to burn and sever the plank roads, signaling to the world that he had no intention of returning, thus reassuring Xiang Yu. After the King of Han pacified the Three Qin, Liang sent a letter to Xiang Yu, saying, "The King of Han lost his rightful position and merely wishes to reclaim Guanzhong. If the covenant is honored, he will stop and dare not advance further." He also sent a letter to Xiang Yu regarding Qi’s rebellion, stating, "Qi and Zhao seek to jointly destroy Chu." As a result, Xiang Yu turned north to attack Qi.

The King of Han enfeoffed Liang as the Marquis of Chengxin and followed him east to strike at Chu. After their forces were defeated and they retreated, the king dismounted, sat upon his saddle, and asked, "I wish to relinquish the lands east of Hangu Pass—who can I entrust with this task to share in the merit of defeating Chu?" Liang replied, "The King of Jiujiang, Ying Bu, was once a fierce general under Xiang Yu and has a rift with him. Peng Yue has rebelled in Liang with the King of Qi. These two men can be urgently dispatched. Among your generals, only Han Xin can be entrusted with great matters and command an entire front. If you wish to relinquish these lands, bestow them upon these three men, and Chu can be destroyed." The King of Han then sent Sui He to persuade Ying Bu to join forces with Peng Yue. Ultimately, it was these three who defeated Chu.

Liang was often ill and served as a strategist, accompanying the king intermittently. In the third year of Han, Xiang Yu besieged the King of Han at Xingyang. The king consulted with Li Yiji on how to undermine Chu’s power. Li Yiji said, "In ancient times, when Tang overthrew Jie, he enfeoffed Jie’s descendants in Qi; when King Wu punished Zhou, he enfeoffed Zhou’s descendants in Song. Now that Qin has destroyed the Six States, if Your Majesty truly restores their descendants, they will all vie to support your virtue and righteousness, willingly becoming your subjects. Once your virtue and righteousness are established, you may face south and proclaim yourself overlord, and Chu will surely fold its robes and pay homage." The King of Han said, "Excellent." He hurriedly had seals carved and instructed Li Yiji to distribute them.

Before Li Yiji could depart, Liang arrived from outside. The King of Han was eating and said, "A guest has devised a plan for me to undermine Chu’s power." He recounted Li Yiji’s proposal in full. Liang said, "Allow me to borrow your chopsticks to calculate this." (See the first scroll of *Western Texts* for the argument against restoring the Six States.) "If this plan is truly adopted, Your Majesty’s cause is lost."

The King of Han spat out his food in fury and cursed, "This pedantic fool nearly ruined my great enterprise!"

When Han Xin conquered Qi and sought to be named its king, the King of Han flew into a rage. Zhang Liang persuaded him—this is recorded in *The Biography of Han Xin*.

In the fifth year, the King of Han fortified his position at Guling, but the feudal lords failed to arrive. Zhang Liang advised him, and the lords all came—this is recorded in *The Annals of Emperor Gao*.

In the sixth year, he enfeoffed his meritorious ministers. Though Zhang Liang had never fought on the battlefield, the Emperor said, "To devise strategies within the command tent and secure victory a thousand *li* away—this is your achievement, Master Zhang." He offered Zhang Liang the choice of any three *wan* households in Qi. Zhang Liang replied, "When I first joined you at Xiapi, we met at Liu, and Heaven bestowed me upon Your Majesty. Though my plans have fortunately met with success, I ask only for Liu as my fief." Thus, he was enfeoffed as the Marquis of Liu, ranked alongside Xiao He and the others. The remaining ministers, still vying for rewards, had yet to receive their enfeoffments.

The Emperor resided in Luoyang—further details are in the first scroll of *Western Texts*—and Zhang Liang petitioned him to establish the western capital in Guanzhong.
