That very day, the Emperor set out for Guanzhong, with Zhang Liang accompanying him. Prone to illness, Zhang Liang practiced *daoyin*, abstained from grains, and secluded himself indoors. Over a year later, the Emperor sought to depose the Crown Prince and install Lady Qi’s son, Prince Ruyi of Zhao, in his place.

Empress Lü dispatched Lü Ze, the Marquis of Jiancheng, to coerce Zhang Liang, saying, "You have long been the Emperor’s chief strategist. Now that he daily contemplates replacing the Crown Prince, how can you rest easy?" Zhang Liang replied, "This cannot be resolved with mere words. However, there are four men the Emperor has been unable to summon. All are advanced in years, and because the Emperor treats scholars with disdain, they fled into hiding in the mountains, refusing to serve Han on principle. Yet the Emperor holds them in high regard. If you earnestly invite them, they may come. Once here, treat them as guests and have them accompany the Crown Prince to court. Their presence alone will be of aid."

Thereupon, Empress Lü instructed Lü Ze to send envoys bearing the Crown Prince’s letter, with humble words and generous gifts, to welcome the four men. By the eleventh year, when Ying Bu rebelled, the Emperor, stricken with illness, wished to send the Crown Prince to suppress the revolt. The four men then advised the Marquis of Jiancheng, "If the Crown Prince leads troops and achieves merit, his position will not be strengthened; if he fails, he will invite disaster. The generals who helped the Emperor conquer the realm are all formidable warriors. To have the Crown Prince command them would be like setting a sheep to lead wolves. We have heard that the mother who is loved will see her son embraced. Now, Lady Qi attends the Emperor day and night, and the Prince of Zhao is always at his side—it is clear he is destined to replace the Crown Prince. Why not urgently petition Empress Lü to seize the moment and weep before the Emperor, saying: ‘Ying Bu is a fierce general, skilled in warfare. The other generals are all Your Majesty’s peers—if you send the Crown Prince to command them, none will obey. Moreover, when Ying Bu hears of this, he will march west with drums beating. Though Your Majesty is ill, you must force yourself into a war chariot and personally oversee the campaign, for none will dare to hold back.’"

Following the four men’s advice, the Emperor said, "This boy is not up to the task—I must go myself." As he prepared to lead the army east, Zhang Liang, though ill, struggled to rise and see him, saying, "The men of Chu are swift and fierce—I urge you not to engage them directly." He then advised the Emperor to appoint the Crown Prince as General and overseer of the troops in Guanzhong. The Emperor replied, "Though you are ill, Master Zhang, force yourself to assist the Crown Prince." At the time, Shusun Tong served as Grand Tutor, while Zhang Liang acted as Junior Tutor. They accompanied the Emperor to crush Ying Bu.

Upon their return, the Emperor’s illness worsened, and his desire to replace the Crown Prince grew stronger. Zhang Liang remonstrated, but the Emperor would not listen, so he withdrew from court due to illness. Shusun Tong cited ancient precedents and risked death to protest, but the Emperor feigned agreement while still intending to make the change.

At a banquet, the Crown Prince attended as cupbearer, accompanied by the four men. All were over eighty, with snowy hair and brows, their robes and caps magnificent. The Emperor, surprised, asked, "Who are these four?" Each gave his name, and the Emperor exclaimed, "I have sought you, yet you fled from me. Why now do you accompany my elder brother?" The four replied, "Your Majesty treats scholars lightly and often berates them. We refused to endure such humiliation. But we have heard the Crown Prince is benevolent and filial, respectful and fond of scholars. All under Heaven stretch their necks, longing to die for him. That is why we have come." The Emperor said, "I trouble you to continue guiding and protecting the Crown Prince."

After the four men offered their toasts and departed, the Emperor watched them go, then summoned Lady Qi and pointed them out, saying, "I wished to replace the Crown Prince, but these four have become his wings. Now that they are fully formed, he cannot be shaken." Lady Qi wept, and the Emperor said, "Dance the Chu dance for me, and I will sing you a Chu song." His song went:

*"The swan goose soars high, with a single flight a thousand* li.
Its wings now fully grown, it cuts across the four seas.
Cutting across the four seas—what can be done?
Though there be nets and arrows, where can they be set?"*

After singing several stanzas, Lady Qi danced with forced cheer, her tears flowing. The banquet ended, and the Crown Prince’s position was never changed—this was due to Zhang Liang’s success in summoning the four men.

Zhang Liang had often discussed matters of state with the Emperor at leisure. He then declared, "My family served as ministers to Han for generations. When Han fell, I did not惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜

Six years later, he passed away, and was posthumously enfeoffed as Marquis Wen of Liu. When Master Zhang first encountered the old man on the Yí Bridge, thirteen years later he followed the High Emperor in passing through Jǐběi, and indeed found the yellow stone beneath Gǔchéng Mountain, which he took and treasured, enshrining it in worship. When Master Zhang passed away, he was buried together with the yellow stone. Each time he visited the tomb, he would prostrate himself and sacrifice to the yellow stone. His son, Bùyí, succeeded him, and the *Book of Han* records this.

Daoist scriptures state: After Master Zhang ascended as an immortal, by the eighth generation his descendant Dàolíng attained the Dao and ascended in flight. The Supreme Lord sent Master Zhang down as an imperial envoy. Your servant Dao Yi says: The perfected man, when hidden, becomes a celestial immortal; when manifest, he brings auspiciousness to the world. Thus, in cultivating himself alone, he rectifies his mind and nurtures his person with sincerity; in benefiting all under heaven, he orders his household, governs the state, and brings peace to the realm. The Way is ever present in both, depending only on whether one’s circumstances are straitened or flourishing, concealed or revealed. Zhang Liang may be called one who embodied the Way in both aspects.

The *Dao De Jing* says:
Cultivated in the person, its virtue becomes true;
Cultivated in the household, its virtue overflows;
Cultivated in the village, its virtue endures;
Cultivated in the state, its virtue abounds;
Cultivated in all under heaven, its virtue is universal.

This precisely describes Zhang Liang’s loyalty to Hán, through which he accomplished the great enterprise of Hàn. Yet though immortals achieve merit and fame in the world, do they seek wealth and honor for self-glorification? No—it is but the fulfillment of their aspiration, and thus in the end they return to the world’s refuge.

The scripture further says: "When merit is accomplished, fame achieved, and the person withdrawn—this is the Way of Heaven." Is this not what it means?

Sū Dān.

Sū Dān was a native of Guìyáng. His mother, née Lǐ, once washed silk in the river when she struck a sunken log and conceived. At Dān’s birth, a pair of cranes flew into the courtyard, their radiance piercing the doors and windows. As a child of but a few years, he seldom spoke and took no part in childish games—some say he had already attained the Dao of immortality. When he played with other children, he often rode a deer, which appeared no different from any other. Yet when they came to perilous or impassable terrain, he could always leap across. The children asked, “How is it that your deer is unlike all others?” He replied, “It is a dragon.”

From youth, he was renowned for his utmost filial piety. At fourteen, his mother, who had been eating meat, said, “I suddenly crave *lǒng* fish from Zīxīng, but it is too far to obtain.” Dān replied, “I shall go to the market for it.” His mother took it as a jest and smiled. Before she had finished eating, Dān placed the fresh fish before her, saying, “Here is *lǒng* fish from Zīxīng.” His mother said, “You are most honest and sincere—Zīxīng is over two hundred *lǐ* away. How could you go and return in an instant? You deceive me.” Dān replied, “When I bought the fish, I saw my uncle. I told him to convey my regards to you, and he will visit in a few days.” His mother ate the fish and found it was indeed *lǒng* fish from Zīxīng. Soon after, his uncle arrived and recounted seeing Dān in the market. His mother marveled greatly at the affair—some say that when his mother desired fish soup, Dān went to the market in Xiāngzhōu to buy it, though it was fourteen hundred *lǐ* from home, and returned in an instant. Dān’s uncle, a clerk in the prefecture, saw the boy in the market and sent a letter home, astonishing the household.

One day, Dān told his mother, “The fruit of the Dao is now perfected, and the day of my ascension draws near. I shall soar through the realm of clouds and waters, freed from the dust and mire of the world. The stem and root of life are now mine to command; the jade terrace and purple palace are but my own abode. Neither yīn nor yáng can mold me, nor heaven and earth claim jurisdiction over me. Though mountains and valleys shift, I shall not; though sun and moon age, I shall not. The primordial qi of the true origin endures for ten thousand ages.”

His mother said, “I rely on you—if you leave, on whom shall I depend? Why speak of going?” Dān replied, “I have often heard my master say: When one ascends as an immortal, nine generations of kin receive protection, and even those who have passed are no longer mere shades. Though I depart, I shall know all your movements and breaths.” He then left a locked chest, sealing it tightly, and instructed her not to open it. If she needed anything, she had but to speak of it, and it would be as she wished—some say he told her thus.

He said to the villagers, “In two years, a great plague will strike the land.” He planted orange trees and dug a well, saying, “Those who fall ill need only eat one orange leaf and drink a cup of this spring water to recover”—some say that when Dān was about to depart, he warned, “This year, a great pestilence will come, and nearly half will perish. Draw water from this well and drink, and you shall suffer no harm.” Later, all came to pass as he had foretold.

As he finished speaking, five-colored clouds descended into the courtyard, and the faint strains of flutes and drums approached.

Dān then ascended into the clouds, weeping as he bid farewell to his mother and the villagers, and slowly drifted away toward the southeast. Hundreds of villagers and local officials witnessed this—it was the third year of Emperor Wen of Han’s reign. Some say that when Dān had attained the Dao, dozens of white cranes descended at his gate, and he mounted them to rise into the clouds and the heavens.

Thereafter, whenever his mother lacked for anything, she would pray before the chest, and all she desired would appear. One day, missing Dān, she thought he might be inside and opened the chest—only to find nothing within, save two cranes soaring into the sky.

Two years after Sū Xiān’s ascension, a great plague indeed struck the region. The people took orange leaves and spring water to cure their illness, and all recovered at once; hundreds, even thousands, were saved. The prefect, his officials, and the townsfolk all bowed in worship beneath the orange trees and by the well, where offerings were made as if at a bustling market.

Before long, Dān’s mother fell ill, and Dān would often come to inquire after her. Soon after, she passed away at over a hundred years of age. The court ordered the prefect to oversee her funeral, and she was buried south of Sū Mountain. At that time, apes wailed in grief and cranes cried in sorrow; the wind grew bleak and the mist dim, clouds of sorrow lingered unbroken, and a mournful rain fell cold. From the mountaintop came the sound of weeping—distant when heard from afar, yet near when listened to closely.

The prefect, leading his officials and the townsfolk, climbed the mountain to console Dān. Though they heard the weeping of the immortal, they could not see his form. Prefect Lú Xiànkě then said, “Without this visit of consolation, we would have no chance to pay homage to the immortal. I wish to behold your countenance, that my worldly hindrances may be dispelled—this would be not only my own fortune, but that of my entire clan.”

Dān replied, “The paths of immortals and mortals differ; our fates rise and fall along separate roads. I do not begrudge letting you see me, but I fear your blessings and karmic retribution may not allow you to behold me fully.” He then said, “I shall let you see half of me.” Dān revealed half his face and one arm to Xiànkě and the others. The officials saw that his face was like true jade, radiant and luminous, while his arm bore fine hair, its glow rivaling the sun’s rays.

The officials bowed again in reverence. The immortal Dān said, “The mountain path is perilous, and you have labored far, my lords. I shall build a bridge so you may return home safely—only, do not look back.” He took a scroll of the *Jade Axis Scripture of the Golden Court* and cast it into the air. In an instant, a great bridge formed, spanning the void like a jade rainbow, its railings and beams adorned with gold and jewels.

Lú Xiànkě and the officials ascended the bridge, soon arriving at the prefecture. Only the magistrate Zhāng Xìnchén glanced back and fell into a deep ravine. Yet he landed upon rotten wood and withered leaves, unharmed, and after three days made his way back to the prefecture.

After Dān’s mother’s passing, the weeping on the mountain ceased only when the mourning garments were put away. Later, the prefect reported these events to the throne. The mountain was named Sū Immortal Mountain, its temple called Sū Immortal Temple, and the prefect conducted seasonal rites there with solemn purity.

Yuán Jié wrote a poem:
*A divine orange, rootless, a well with spring—*
*This world is but a dream, another thousand years.*
*No homeland to return to, only cranes alight again;*
*Now which immortal is this, bearing what name?*
*Wind chimes on the dew-drenched altar, all is still;*
*Desolate paths, overgrown with creeping grass.*
*How might one draw near to Lord Sū,*
*As rainbow banners escort him to the heavens in broad daylight?*

Another poem by Shěn Bīn on Sū Immortal Mountain:
*Eyes strain through the forest altar to see Bāng Prefecture,*
*Where well and spring intertwine in tangled roots.*
*Seeking the Dao, yet sitting idle—*
*When will this toiling life ever cease?*
*Sū’s old dwelling, aged in mist and clouds;*
*Xī’s tomb, overgrown with sorrowful grass and trees.*
*Of right and wrong through the ages, none can ask—*
*As the sun sets in the west, the waters flow east.*

In the early Song dynasty, a crane alighted upon the roof beams of the prefectural hall and remained for some time. The prefect’s subordinates and their sons gathered to watch, and one shot at it with a pellet bow. The crane lifted its foot and traced characters upon the roof, which was tiled with wooden planks. Then it spread its wings and ascended into the clouds. The prefect sent men to climb onto the roof, where they found the inscribed words:
*Returning once more after parting from my homeland,*
*Yet not by the reckoning of sixty-year cycles.*
*Do you not recall the shifting hills and valleys,*
*The white bones blanketing the fields, the green mountains of old?*
*Perched high upon the rooftop,*
*I look down upon the crowd of children below.*
*I am Sū the Immortal—why shoot at me?*
*Turning beyond the clouds, I return to my abode.*

Some say Dān rode a white crane to alight upon the northeastern tower of the prefectural city. When someone shot at it with a pellet bow, the crane inscribed upon the lacquered roof planks:
*Though the city walls remain, the people are not the same;*
*Two hundred and forty years have passed since I last returned.*
*I am Sū the Immortal—why shoot at me?*
The prefect took the plank and stored it in the government office, later returning it to the temple. The immortal never came again.

During the Shaoxing reign of Emperor Gaozong, Sū Xiān was granted the title *True Man of Pure Ascension and Universal Response*.

---

Sīmǎ Jìzhǔ

Sīmǎ Jìzhǔ was a man of Chǔ who practiced divination in the markets of Cháng’ān. During the reign of Emperor Wen of Han, the grand masters Jiǎ Yì and Sòng Zhōng said, “We have heard that sages do not always dwell in court but may wander among the dusty streets. Let us go and observe him.”

They found Jìzhǔ seated in leisure, his disciples reciting the *Records of Yin and Yang* at his side. The two said, “Judging by your appearance, Master, and listening to your words, we have never seen the like. High rank and noble position are bestowed upon the worthy—why do you follow such a roundabout path?”

Jìzhǔ laughed and said, “You gentlemen seem to possess some Daoist arts, yet your words are crude. Now, when barbarians refuse to submit and the four seasons fall out of harmony, you rise in vain to speak, drawing one another by power and extending one another by profit. Even the worthy should be ashamed of this. To be free of hunger and cold within, untroubled by robbery or seizure without, honored when in high position and unharmed when in low—this is the Way of the noble man. Divination as a profession is what is called ‘the highest virtue not acting as virtue.’ The phoenix does not flock with sparrows and swallows—how could you petty men understand the elder?”

The two were suddenly struck with self-doubt. Later, they said to each other, “The Way is honored when one is at peace; power is dangerous when it is high. To divine without careful consideration is to risk losing one’s essence. To plan for one’s life without caution is to have no place to stand.”

Later, Song Zhong met with punishment, and Jia Yi, moved by the roc’s fate, did not flee from Master Ji’s mirror of warning.

Master Ji entered the Great Abundance Palace within Mount Weiyu, where he studied under Master Xiling. Master Xiling was a transcendent maiden of the Supreme Mystery, who had received the Dao of the Stone Essence, Golden Radiance, Hidden Light, and Transformative Form. As he prepared to depart, he left behind a pillow and mat in place of his form, nearly indistinguishable from his true body. His family buried them south of Mount Pan in Shu.

Zhuge Liang inscribed his stele in praise:
*"In the vast silence of the mysterious desert,
Yin and Yang merge in primordial oneness.
Heaven and Earth intermingle in flux,
Myriad beings flourish in manifestation.
The Master’s principles were set forth,
Distinguishing softness and hardness.
Spirits and gods beheld them,
The Six Perfections made luminous."*

After attaining the Dao, Master Ji often recited the Jade Canon, ingested the essence of Bright Cinnabar, and embraced the radiance of Dawn’s Brilliance. His complexion remained like a maiden’s, his beard three feet long, black as ink. He had two children: his son, named Fayu, and his daughter, named Jihua. Both dwelled on Mount Weiyu, together studying the Thirty-Nine Chapters.

*Record of Perfected Transcendents Through the Ages, Embracing the Dao and Penetrating the Mirror, Scroll Eleven—concluded*
*Record of Perfected Transcendents Through the Ages, Embracing the Dao and Penetrating the Mirror, Scroll Twelve*

Liu Feng

Liu Feng, styled Weihui, was a native of Yingchuan. He studied under Master Ji and ingested the essence of the sun and moon. After attaining the Dao, he returned to his hometown, departing with the semblance of a staff and sandals.

*The Declarations of the Perfected* states: "Liu Weihui of Yingchuan was Liu Feng, the Master of the Imperial Carriage under the Han Emperor. He served Sima Jizhu as an inner disciple. After achieving the Dao, he returned to his hometown in his later years, assuming the form of a staff and sandals, his body concealed beneath a mulberry tree. His traces remain in Ancheng County, Runan."

Bao Shuyang

Bao Shuyang was a native of Guangning. During the reign of Emperor Gao of Han, he served as a grandee to King Zhang Er and King Zhang Ao of Zhao. From

Liu Cheng

Liu Cheng had long arms that hung past his knees and a thick beard. He dwelled for many years on Mount Wudang, five hundred *li* from Xiangyang, a journey he could make from dawn to dusk. Though he made no show of cultivation, he often healed the common folk with medicines and arts. He labored tirelessly, gathering most of his own herbs, and his knowledge of plants and minerals was exhaustive. Liu Daochan, the Inspector of Yongzhou, grew envious of his long arms and had him seized in Xiangyang and sent to the capital under Emperor Wen. Each morning, he was taken by caged cart to the mountains to gather herbs and returned by dusk to the prison of the Minister of Justice. Later, he handed two short scrolls to the jailers, who dared not accept them and burned them in disgust. By night, the scrolls vanished entirely, though the locks and bolts remained undisturbed. One evening, the night patrol of the prison gate captured him and sent him to the Minister of Justice. Liu Cheng told the jailers, "The court will soon execute me. After my burial, I beg you not to nail the coffin shut." He was indeed put to death. Days later, Emperor Wen, troubled by his words, ordered the coffin opened. Inside, no corpse was found—only a bamboo staff.

Minister Dao Yi remarked: "Liu Cheng’s long arms spared him from military service, yet his body brought about his death. Had he truly understood that to know the body is not to know the Dao, and to know the Dao is not to know the body, he would have grasped the subtlety of the Dao—an existence beyond the body, not of a single day’s attainment. This is why, after his execution, only a bamboo staff remained in his coffin." The *Daodejing* states: "My greatest affliction is that I have a body. If I had no body, what affliction could I have?" Scholars should ponder this deeply.

---

Yan Qing

Yan Qing was a native of Kuaiji. Though poor, he often made charcoal in the mountains when he encountered a stranger who spoke with him. Unaware the man was a divine being, Yan received a scroll as the stranger departed. "Your bones are fit for immortality," the stranger said. "I grant you this divine formula." Yan replied, "I cannot read. What am I to do?" The divine being answered, "No need to read it. Simply place it in a clean vessel and set it on high." He also taught Yan the method of ingesting stalactite essence. Yan accepted the scroll and lived in the mountains, possessing no fine vessel—only a drinking flask. He used it to hold the scroll, and soon, dozens of attendants appeared at his side. When Yan transported charcoal by boat down the mountain, the spirits would tow his vessel, making it seem to move on its own. He healed the sick by bringing the scroll to their homes, and many revered him. One night, returning from a disciple’s home, Yan was stopped by a night patrol. The captain demanded, "Who goes there?" Yan retorted, "Who are *you* to be out at night?" Enraged by his insolence, the captain ordered his men to seize the offender. Yan then commanded his attendant spirits, "Arrest all these night travelers!" He strode away, leaving the captain and his dozens of men and horses unable to move. The next morning, passersby found the captain and asked why he was stranded. He recounted the events, and they said, "This must be Master Yan." The captain replied, "I cannot move. Send word to my family to kneel before Yan and beg forgiveness, saying I did not know it was you last night. Ask him to release us." Yan then shouted, "Release those arrested last night!" The captain and his men were freed. Thereafter, night travelers would first ask, "Are you Master Yan?" before proceeding. Later, Yan ceased eating grains and, after a year, ascended to Mount Xiaohuo as an immortal. Today, in Wu and Kuaiji, many honor him as the deity of the Yan family, though they no longer seek immortality through herbs and elixirs, content with offerings alone.

---

Wang Gushen

Wang Gushen and Pi Xuanyao were Daoist masters of Mount Qingcheng in Shu during the Western Han. Precocious from youth, they spurned worldly honors and mastered the *Laozi*, *Zhuangzi*, *Wenzi*, and *Liezi*, excelling in astrology and cosmology. They wandered famous mountains, crossed the Panzhou shallows, sailed the Xiao and Xiang rivers, and reached Mount Heng, where they built a hut beside the Golden Mother’s shrine.

Later, they cultivated embryonic breathing to return to the primordial, and after several years, their Dao was accomplished. They roamed the Jade Clusters and sought the Nine Immortals. During Emperor Wu’s southern progress, he encountered them and saw their extraordinary spirit and qi, so he invited them to reside in seclusion on the Western Peak. The emperor bestowed generous gifts and enfeoffed Wang as Master of the Grand Tenuity and Pi as Master of the Primordial Simplicity, honoring them with the rites of a senior minister. Three years later, they rode azure mules and ascended to immortality.

**The Old Man of Mount Tai**
The Old Man of Mount Tai—his name and origins were unknown. During Emperor Wu’s eastern progress and hunt, he saw an old man hoeing by the roadside, his white hair glowing several feet high. Struck by his strangeness, the emperor summoned and questioned him. The old man appeared to be about fifty, yet his face bore the complexion of a youth, his skin and body radiant, unlike ordinary men.

The emperor asked, “What arts of the Dao do you possess?”

The old man replied, “When I was eighty-five, I was decrepit and near death, my hair white and teeth fallen. A Daoist master taught me to abstain from grains, consume wood-infused water, and fashion a spirit pillow. Within the pillow were thirty-two substances: twenty-four to correspond to the twenty-four qi, and eight to align with the eight winds. I practiced this, and my old age reverted to youth—black hair regrew, lost teeth reappeared, and I could walk three hundred li in a day. Now I am one hundred and eighty years old.”

Emperor Wu accepted his formula and bestowed upon him gold and silk. The old man then entered the mountains of Tai, returning to his hometown every five or ten years. After more than three hundred years, he no longer returned.

**Wu Yan**
Wu Yan, styled Zidu, was a native of Beihai. When Emperor Wu of Han encountered Zidu at the Wei Bridge, a dense purple qi, over a *zhang* in height, rose above his head. The emperor summoned and questioned him: “How old are you, and what arts have you attained to bear such an extraordinary qi?”

Zidu replied, “I am now one hundred and thirty-eight years old, yet I possess no special attainment.”

As he prepared to depart, the emperor summoned Dongfang Shuo to assess what Daoist protection this man possessed. Shuo responded, “This gentleman has *yin* protection.”

Emperor Wu dismissed his attendants and questioned Zidu further. Zidu answered, “When I was twenty-five, I suffered from pain in my waist and spine, cold feet I could not warm, a parched and bitter mouth, a dry tongue, and constant nasal discharge. Every joint and limb ached, and my feet were numb—I could not stand for long. Since obtaining this Dao, seventy-three years have passed. I have thirty-six sons, my body remains robust, free from illness, and my strength is as it was in my prime.”

The emperor said, “You are unkind. To possess the Dao and not share it with me is not the conduct of a loyal subject.”

Zidu kowtowed and replied, “I truly know this Dao to be authentic, yet matters of *yin* and *yang* are private affairs within the public sphere—difficult for a subject to speak of. Moreover, its practice runs counter to human nature, and few can endure it. Thus, I dared not make it known.”

The emperor said, “Do not apologize; I was merely jesting with you.” He then received Zidu’s method.

Zidu lived to over two hundred years of age, consuming and refining cinnabar. He ascended to heaven in broad daylight. Emperor Wu later practiced his method but could not fully adhere to it; nevertheless, he attained a lifespan far surpassing that of other emperors.

Li Fengxian was a native of Shu. From childhood, he did not speak. At eighteen, he often sought cold and secluded dwellings to avoid the stench of cooked food and meat. When asked why, he replied, “To know the white and guard the black—Dao values obscurity and silence.”

His master, the Lord of South Mountain, said to him, “I was the flute-playing crown prince of King Ling of Zhou. You have served the Dao for three lifetimes, yet your trials have not been marked by conspicuous merit. Now I transmit to you the method of the Crimson Network, that you may ascend and be delivered to the Southern Palace. My master, Lord Fuqiu, bestowed it upon me, and now I pass it to you. You must apply yourself diligently. If you delay further in this life, you will not be delivered for ten thousand kalpas. I am to become the Attendant of the Morning Audience to the Controller of Destiny of South Mountain, and shall also be appointed as the Perfected One of Tongbai.”

Having spoken, he vanished. Emperor Xuan of Han summoned him, but he did not respond. All was clear, peaceful, and auspicious.

The land was clear, peaceful, and auspicious. Of Pei Commandery was a man who had been Wei Ping in the time of Emperor Gao of Han and whose complexion remained unaged by the reign of Emperor Guangwu. Later, he departed through *shijie* and, over a hundred years later, returned to his hometown. After several days, he again departed through *shijie*.

**Lord of Yellow Mountain**
The Lord of Yellow Mountain cultivated the arts of Pengzu and lived for several hundred years while retaining a youthful appearance. He also pursued the path of earthbound immortality, not seeking ascent to the heavens. After Pengzu’s departure, he compiled Pengzu’s teachings into the *Scripture of Pengzu*. Those who obtain the *Scripture of Pengzu* become like the pine and cypress among trees.

**Lü Gong**
Lü Gong, styled Wenjing, had loved ingesting medicinal substances since youth. Taking one servant and one maidservant, he gathered herbs in the Taihang Mountains when suddenly three figures appeared in the valley. They asked him, “Do you desire long life, yet endure such toil and hardship?” Gong replied, “I truly desire long life but have not encountered a proper method. Thus, I gather and ingest these herbs, hoping for some small benefit.”

One said, “I am surnamed Lü, styled Wenqi.”
Another said, “I am surnamed Sun, styled Wenyang.”
The third said, “I am surnamed Li, styled Wenshang. We are all immortals of the Grand Clarity and Grand Harmony Palace, here to gather herbs and instruct new learners. Since you share our surname and your style contains half of mine, it is your destiny to attain long life. If you follow us to gather herbs, we will teach you the method of immortality.”

Gong bowed and said, “I am fortunate to meet divine beings, but I fear my transgressions are too many to be worthy of instruction. If you deign to save me, it would be as if I were reborn.” He then followed the immortals. After two days, they transmitted a secret formula to Gong and sent him home, saying, “Return to visit your hometown.”

Gong bowed in farewell. The immortals told him, “Though you have been with us for only two days, two hundred years have passed in the human world.” When Gong returned home, he found only empty fields, with no trace of his descendants. He then encountered Zhao Guangfu, a descendant of his hometown several generations later, and asked, “Where is the Lü Gong household?”

The man regarded him with surprise and said, “Where do you come from, to ask about such an ancient figure? I have heard from my ancestors that Lü Gong took one servant and one maidservant into the mountains to gather herbs and never returned, presumed to have been devoured by tigers or wolves. Over two hundred years have passed—why do you ask?” He added, “Your descendant Lü Xi, who lives ten *li* northeast of the city as a Daoist, is often revered by people. You may find him easily.”

Following Guangfu’s words, Gong went to Xi’s home and knocked on the door, calling out. A servant answered, “Where do you come from?” Gong said, “This is my home. Long ago, I went to gather herbs and followed immortals away. Over two hundred years have passed, and now I have returned.”

Xi’s entire household emerged in astonishment and joy, prostrating themselves and saying, “The immortal has returned!” They wept uncontrollably. After staying for some time, Gong transmitted the divine formula to Xi and departed. At the time, Xi was already eighty years old, but after ingesting the formula, he grew increasingly youthful. At two hundred years of age, he entered the mountains. His descendants, generation after generation, took this medicine, never aging or dying, and all attained immortality.

**Chen Anshi**
Chen Anshi was a native of Jingzhao.

Chen Anshi served as a retainer to Guan Shuping. By nature compassionate and kind, whenever he encountered birds or beasts on the road, he would step aside to avoid startling them. He never trod upon living insects nor took any life. At thirty years of age, Shuping, who was devoted to the Dao and longed for transcendence, was suddenly visited by two immortals disguised as scholars. They accompanied Shuping on his travels to observe and test him. Unaware of their true nature, Shuping grew increasingly negligent over time.

One day, as Shuping prepared a fine meal inside, the two immortals returned to the gate and asked Anshi, “Is Shuping at home?” Anshi replied, “He is.” He went inside to inform Shuping, who immediately rose to greet them. His wife stopped him, saying, “Those starving scholars only seek to fill their bellies. Do not feed them.” Shuping then instructed Anshi to go out and say he was not at home. The two men said, “You just said he was here, and now you say he is not. Why?” Anshi replied, “My master told me to say so.” The two men praised him for his honesty and said to one another, “Shuping has cultivated diligently for many years, yet today, upon meeting us, he has grown negligent. Had he not encountered us, he would have nearly succeeded only to fail.”

They then asked Anshi, “Do you enjoy idle amusements?” He answered, “I do not.” They asked further, “Do you seek the Dao and long for immortality?” He replied, “I do seek the Dao, but I have no means to learn it.” The two said, “If you truly seek the Dao, meet us tomorrow morning beneath the great tree north of the road.” Anshi arrived early at the appointed place, but by sunset, the two had not appeared. He rose to leave, saying, “Those scholars must have deceived me.” Just then, the two called out from beside his ear, “Anshi, why are you so late?” He answered, “I came early, but I did not see you.” They said, “We are here to transmit the Dao to you. You have kept our three appointments faithfully.” Anshi always arrived early, and knowing he was teachable, they gave him two pills of medicine, instructing him, “Return home, abstain from all food, and stay in a separate place.” Anshi followed their instructions, and the two often visited him there.

Shuping found this strange, asking, “Anshi stays in an empty room. How can there be voices speaking? I go back and forth but see no one. Why?” Anshi replied, “I am speaking to myself.” Seeing that Anshi no longer ate, drank only water, and rested in a separate place, Shuping suspected he was no ordinary man. Realizing his own folly in failing to recognize a worthy one, he sighed and said, “The Dao is noble, and virtue is precious—they do not depend on age. Though my parents gave me life, without a teacher, I cannot attain longevity. He who first attains the Dao shall be my teacher.” He then humbly assumed the role of a disciple, serving Anshi morning and night, sweeping and cleaning for him. When Anshi’s cultivation was complete, he ascended to heaven in broad daylight. Before departing, he transmitted the essential Dao to Shuping, who later also attained immortality.

**Ling Shouguang**
Ling Shouguang was a native of Fufeng. At over seventy years of age, he obtained the formula for the Vermilion Radiance Pill. After preparing and ingesting it, he experienced its effects, growing increasingly youthful until he appeared no older than twenty. In the first year of *Jian’an* during the reign of Emperor Xian of Han, Shouguang was already two hundred and twenty years old. He often lodged with Hu Tian in Jiangling and died without illness. Tian buried him, but over a hundred days later, someone saw him in Xiaohuang. He sent a letter to Tian, who, upon receiving it, opened the coffin to find it empty. The nails were still intact, and only his sandals remained inside.

**Zhang Lizheng**

Zhang Lizheng and Shi Mingqi were both Daoist practitioners who once studied the Way in the Heng Mountains. During the late Han, Lizheng entered the mountains and consumed *huangjing* (yellow essence), maintaining a robust complexion as though he were still forty years of age. Mingqi entered the mountains at the end of the Wei dynasty, ingesting the *Zexie Baisi* Pill (made of *zexie* and cypress seeds). Together, they dwelled in a cave until both received the *Hongjing* Elixir formula from Lord Wang of Xicheng. They had been taking this elixir for forty years—*Zhen’gao* states forty-three—though they often lamented the scarcity of cinnabar. Both later left for Guangzhou, where they became Buddhist monks during the tenure of Governor Teng Han. There, they achieved inner and outer clarity, their eyes sharp and bodies light, capable of walking five hundred *li* in a day. They then entered the Jiuyi Mountains.

*Zhen’gao* records: "They also practiced *shouyi* (guarding the One) for thirty years." On the first day of the third month, they were summoned by the Eastern Flower Realm and ascended to heaven upon clouds that very day. Their former abodes in Fangzhu remain beneath the earthen mounds.

*Note*: Teng Han served as Governor of Guangzhou in the *jiachen* year of the tenth *Yonghe* reign (354 CE). Their ascension occurred in the *yichou* year, twelve years later, meaning they had already been taking the elixir for thirty years before venturing out.

**Li Gen**

Li Gen, styled Ziyuan, was a native of Xuchang.

There was a man named Zhao Mai who, having heard from his father and grandfather of their transmission through the generations of Li Gen’s teachings, followed Gen from childhood. By the time Mai reached eighty-four, Gen remained youthful and unaged. Formerly, he resided in Shouchun at the home of Wu Dawen, who studied the Dao under him. Gen taught him the method for transmuting gold and silver, which succeeded immediately. Gen possessed transformative abilities: he could sit unharmed in water or fire, and his traveling kitchen could provide for twenty people, serving refined delicacies and rare, exotic foods not native to the region.

One day, he suddenly told Dawen: “Wang Ling is doomed to fail, and Shouchun will soon fall into military chaos. You can no longer stay here—flee at once.” Dawen secretly relayed this to his younger brother, who carelessly let the words slip. When Wang Ling heard of it, he took it as seditious sorcery and sent men to arrest Gen, intending to execute him. At that moment, Gen was about to write a memorial when he suddenly heard that over a thousand soldiers had surrounded Wu’s home in search of him. Gen said to Dawen’s father: “Do not panic. Simply tell them I am not here, and let the officials search themselves. I left yesterday.” Dawen stepped outside, then turned back to glance at Gen—only to find him gone. All his writing implements and belongings had vanished as well.

The soldiers entered and searched every container for food and clothing, leaving no corner unturned, yet they found no trace of Gen. After a long while, Dawen emerged to meet them, and there was Gen, seated as before, composed and unchanged. Gen said to Dawen: “Minister Wang will be executed with his entire clan. Your brother leaked the words, and within ten days, he will die.” All came to pass as he foretold.

Among Dawen’s disciples, there was one who offered his daughter to Gen. This girl was literate, and when Gen was away, she secretly took a scroll of his *Plain Book*. Upon reading it, she found Gen’s own records of his Daoist studies, which stated that he had begun his training under a certain master during the *Yuanfeng* era of the Han (110–105 BCE). Calculating from that time, Gen was already over seven hundred years old. Dawen also described Gen’s eyes as having square pupils, and the *Scriptures of the Immortals* state: “At eight hundred years, a person’s pupils become square.” Gen told his disciples: “I have not attained the great elixir or the ultimate Daoist formulas, only the methods of an earthbound immortal. My lifespan will endure as long as heaven and earth, yet I shall not be counted among the immortals of the lower realms.”

**Huang Jing**

Huang Jing, styled Boyan, was a native of Wuling.

In his youth, Huang Jing studied the classics and served in his prefecture as a subordinate official. Later, he abandoned worldly life to study the Dao on Mount Huo for over eighty years, after which he entered the Central Marchmount. He specialized in qi-absorption and grain avoidance, practicing breath-swallowing and exhalation, embryonic respiration and inner visualization, summoning the Six Jia Jade Maidens, and ingesting the yin-yang talismans. He also visualized the Red Star before the Grotto Chamber, expanding it until it filled his body like fire. By two hundred years of age, he had reverted to youthful vigor. The Daoist Wang Ziyang visited him several times, seeking essential teachings. Huang Jing told Ziyang: “I do not cultivate the Way of ingesting medicinal elixirs, but merely abide by nature—this is but the path of an earthbound immortal. What is there to ask of me?” When asked about the method of the Yin Lord of Xinye for ascending to heaven through divine elixirs, he replied: “That is the ultimate attainment of the great Dao. You may follow him.” He added: “One who can cast aside desires as I have cannot learn what I practice.” Ziyang persisted in his request, so Huang Jing instructed him: “Within the Great Pass lies the Auxiliary Star. Visualize and perceive it, and through repeated practice, the Red Youth will appear there, pointing to the Vermilion Court. Direct your attention and sway it to refine your form. Dispel the Three Corpses, erase the name of death, and if you can guard this steadfastly, you may attain longevity. Lose it, and you will soon sink into darkness.” Ziyang received these teachings and obtained the Dao of long life.

**Gan Shi**

Gan Shi was a native of Taiyuan. He was skilled in qi-absorption and abstained from food and drink. He also ingested *asparagus cochinchinensis* and practiced the arts of the bedchamber, following the methods of Rong Cheng’s *Profound* and *Plain* texts, which he expanded and refined into a single scroll. His practices yielded immediate results, and he cured illnesses without acupuncture, moxibustion, or herbal decoctions. After living over a hundred years, he entered Mount Wangwu and departed as an immortal.

**Huang Ziyang**

Huang Ziyang was a man of the Later Wei who understood the subtleties of long life. He studied the Dao in Mount Boluo for over ninety years, subsisting solely on peach bark and drinking the yellow water from stones. Sima Jizhu transmitted to him the *Eight Directions of Daoist Guidance*, enabling him to transcend the world.

**The Riverside Master**

The Riverside Master’s personal name is unknown; he was also called the Riverside Elder. During the reign of Emperor Wen of the Han, he built a hut of thatch by the river and constantly recited the *Daodejing* of Laozi. Emperor Wen, who admired Laozi’s teachings, issued an edict commanding all princes, nobles, ministers, and prefectural governors with salaries of two thousand *shi* to recite the text. Several passages remained obscure, and none in the realm could elucidate them. Upon hearing the attendant gentleman Pei Kai speak of the Riverside Master’s study of the *Laozi*, the emperor dispatched envoys bearing the unresolved passages to inquire of him. The Master replied: “The Dao is revered, and virtue is noble; they cannot be pressed with questions.” Emperor Wen then personally traveled to see him and said: “Under the vast heavens, there is no land that is not the king’s domain; within the bounds of the earth, there are no subjects who are not the king’s servants. Among the Four Greats of the cosmos, the king occupies one. Though you possess the Dao, you are still my subject. Why do you not humble yourself? I can make men rich or poor, noble or base.” In an instant, the Riverside Master clapped his hands, rose into the air, and floated gently upward like ascending clouds, stopping over a hundred *zhang* above the earth in the void. After a long while, he looked down and replied: “Above, I do not reach heaven; in the middle, I do not burden men; below, I do not dwell on earth. What subject am I to you? How can Your Majesty make me rich or poor, noble or base?” The emperor then understood he was a divine being. He alighted from his carriage, bowed deeply, and apologized: “I, unworthy as I am, have inherited the legacy of my ancestors and bear a talent unequal to my duties, burdened by my inadequacies. Though I govern the affairs of the world, my heart reveres the Dao and virtue. It is only due to my ignorance that much remains unclear. If the Daoist Master would show mercy and aid me, it would be like seeing the light of the sun in the dark of night.” The Riverside Master then presented him with two scrolls of the *Laozi’s Chapter and Verse in Plain Script*, saying: “Study this thoroughly, and your doubts will resolve themselves. Since I annotated this scripture, over seven thousand years have passed, and it has been transmitted to only three people—you make the fourth. Do not pass it to the unworthy.” Emperor Wen knelt to receive the text, and when he finished speaking, the Master vanished. Some say he departed in a rising mist.

Here now stands the Riverside Master’s Temple north of Shan Prefecture, alongside the remnants of Emperor Wen’s Terrace for Gazing at Immortals.

Your servant Daoyi observes: The Riverside Master built his hut by the river, serene and uncalculating, drifting in effortless non-action. His going forth and returning, his concealment and revelation between sacred and mundane, have not been the work of a single day. As the *Daodejing* says: “The Dao is honored, virtue is prized—no one bestows rank upon them, yet they are ever spontaneous.” Truly, this describes the Riverside Master.

One day, Emperor Wen of Han, hearing of his attainment, personally journeyed to him. The Riverside Master then presented him with two scrolls of the *Laozi’s Chapter and Verse in Plain Script*. Thereafter, Emperor Wen governed the realm with reverence and frugality, and later generations praised him as possessing the spirit of the Three Dynasties—was this not the transformative influence of the Riverside Master’s Dao and virtue?

*Comprehensive Mirror of Perfected Immortals Embracing the Dao, Scroll Twelve* ends here.

---

*Comprehensive Mirror of Perfected Immortals Embracing the Dao, Scroll Thirteen*

An Qisheng

An Qisheng was a native of Fuxiang in Langye. He sold medicines by the Eastern Sea, and the people of his time called him the “Thousand-Year Elder.” When the First Emperor of Qin made his eastern progress, he requested an audience and spoke with him for three days and nights. The First Emperor, struck with wonder, bestowed upon him gold and jade worth tens of millions. An Qisheng left them all at the pavilion of Fuxiang, offering only a single red jade crow in return. He left a letter saying: “Seek me at Penglai a thousand years hence.” The First Emperor then dispatched envoys—Xu Fu, Lu Sheng, and several hundred others—to enter the sea, but before they reached Mount Penglai, they repeatedly encountered winds and waves and returned. Shrines were erected along the shores of Fuxiang Pavilion, numbering in the dozens.

The *Han Records of Sacrifices* states: “An Qisheng, the immortal, traverses Penglai. When conditions align, he appears to men; when they do not, he remains hidden.” Yan Shigu’s commentary explains: “Alignment refers to harmony with the Dao.”

The *Veritable Records of the Primal Origin* states: “Later, An Qisheng transmitted the Dao to Ma Mingsheng, Ma to Yin Changsheng, and Yin to Master Erzhu.”

Furthermore, according to the *Records of the Grand Historian*: “Among the descendants of Yue Yi was Yue Chengong, who excelled in cultivating the teachings of the Yellow Emperor and Laozi. His original master was the Riverside Elder, though his origins are unknown. The Riverside Elder taught An Qisheng, An Qisheng taught Mao Xigong, Mao Xigong taught Yue Xiagong, Yue Xiagong taught Yue Chengong, Yue Chengong taught Gai Gong, and Gai Gong taught in Gaomi and Jiaoxi, becoming the master of Chancellor Cao.” It is also said: “In the first year of Emperor Hui’s reign, when Cao Shen was Chancellor of Qi, he summoned all the elders and scholars to inquire how to gather and govern the people. The scholars numbered in the hundreds, each offering different advice, and Cao was unsure whom to follow. Hearing that Gai Gong was skilled in the teachings of the Yellow Emperor and Laozi, he sent a messenger with generous gifts to invite him. Gai Gong expounded: ‘In governing, value clarity and stillness, and the people will naturally settle.’ He elaborated on this principle in detail. Cao adopted his methods, and thus served as Chancellor of Qi for nine years, bringing peace to the state.”

The *Collected Biographies of Immortals* records: There was a certain Wang Lao, whose name is unknown. He befriended Feng Junda and the Woman of Lu, wandering in search of the Dao among the famous mountains. On the southern slopes of Mount Tai, they encountered divine immortals riding white deer, accompanied by ten or so attendants, descending from the mountains. Knowing them to be transcendent beings, they bowed twice and begged for the Way of prolonging life. The immortals said: “Do you know of An Qisheng? It is I. Your sincerity has moved Heaven, and the Most High has sent me to transmit to you the secrets of transcending the world.” They then instructed him: “The Dao of immortality is not distant—seek it within yourself. Without thought, without action, neither expelling nor absorbing, the true unity fills your being, and you will attain long life and ascend in flight. Do not let your thoughts churn restlessly, exhausting your vitality.” The Most High says: “Subtle yet ever-present, its use is inexhaustible.” This is the true Dao. With these words, they ascended into the heavens and departed.

The *Baopuzi* further states: An Qisheng had dragon-like brows and a broad forehead, cultivating himself through refinement and ingesting golden elixir to attain long life. He would dwell among the world for a thousand years or more before departing.

Minister Dao Yi remarked: Qin Shihuang, a ruler of boundless extravagance and cruel tyranny—how could one speak to him of the Dao? An Qisheng left behind his gold and jade to show him the virtue of frugality. "Seek me on Penglai a thousand years hence"—this was to show him that immortality could not be learned. Yet he sought to force his way with a single moment’s effort, sailing into the sea to find Penglai—how could he succeed? An Qisheng did not conceal the Dao; Qin Shihuang was simply unworthy of attaining it.

The *Daodejing* says: "Heaven and Earth are not humane; they regard the myriad things as straw dogs. The sage is not humane; he regards the hundred clans as straw dogs." Qin Shihuang indulged his desires of ear and eye, exhausting the world with ceaseless labor, utterly at odds with the hearts of Heaven, Earth, and the sage. Abandoning the Dao to seek long life—could there be immortality outside the Dao? This is why An Qisheng could not remain within the seas and departed for Penglai.

Ma Mingsheng (also written as Ma Wusheng) was a native of Linzi in the state of Qi. His original surname was He, and his courtesy name was Junshi (also written as Xian or Bao). In his youth, he served as a county clerk hunting bandits and was wounded by them. The Perfected Lady of Great Truth, passing by Mount Tai on her way east, saw him and took pity on him.

At that moment, he was near death. After a long while, he suddenly saw a maiden of sixteen or seventeen, her attire strangely magnificent, her beauty unmatched in the world. She walked beside him and asked Junshi, "Why are you bleeding so?" Junshi answered truthfully. The lady said, "Your wound is grave—the blade pierced your lung, your five viscera are ruptured, blood congeals in the Crimson Palace, and qi surges beyond your intestines. This is a mortal crisis. What can be done?" Junshi, realizing she was a divine being, kowtowed and pleaded for mercy, begging for salvation. The lady took a pill from a case at her elbow, no larger than a small bean, and immediately had him swallow it. In an instant, he was cured: the bleeding ceased, the wound closed, and all pain vanished.

Junshi bowed again and knelt, saying, "My family’s wealth is insufficient to repay you. I do not know how to requite your kindness, but I shall devote my humble strength to repay what I have received." The lady replied, "If you truly wish to thank me, your intent is commendable. Would you follow me?" Junshi then changed his name and styled himself Ma Mingsheng, serving the lady as an attendant.

The lady entered the sheer cliffs of Mount Tai in the Eastern Marchmount, where stone chambers clung to precipitous walls, suspended between towering crags and hidden depths, over a thousand *zhang* above the earth. Within the stone chamber stood golden forests and jade tables, rare treasures of wondrous splendor—places no mortal could reach. At first, Mingsheng only wished to learn the art of treating sword wounds, but upon witnessing the comings and goings of immortals, he came to know of the Way of Undying.

From dawn to dusk, he attended to her needs, sweeping and serving without the slightest negligence. The lady tested him with illusions of ghosts, monsters, wolves, and tigers, but Mingsheng remained clear-minded and unshaken, utterly unafraid. She also sent him on errands to lodge elsewhere, where beautiful women would tempt him with flirtation, yet his heart remained steadfast, his resolve untainted by impure thoughts.

At times, the lady would depart for ten or five days, or even a month or twenty, and upon her return, he would see immortals and guests arriving on dragons and phoenixes. Some came to pay their respects, filling the chamber with true immortals for days on end. When guests arrived, she would send Mingsheng to another room. At times, exquisite delicacies, rare fruits, fragrant wines, and strange nectars would appear unbidden, their names beyond mortal ken. Occasionally, she would call Mingsheng to sit and share the feast.

He also heard the ethereal strains of zithers and lutes, their songs exquisitely sweet. The lady herself would sometimes play, her instrument having but one string, yet producing all five notes in harmony—its lofty, mysterious resonance carrying for miles. Flocks of birds would gather at the mouth of the cave, circling and soaring, undeterred even when driven away. Such was the celestial music, the wondrous sound of nature itself.

The lady dwelled with Mingsheng in the same stone chamber, though on separate couches. In that secluded place, only the two of them resided. When she departed, she never revealed her destination, but he would always see a white dragon arrive to welcome her. She would don a cloud-patterned embroidered robe, mount the white dragon, and depart. The robe was adorned with luminous moon pearls stitched along its seams, jade pendants at her waist, and a golden crown of Supreme Mystery. No attendants accompanied her; upon her return, the dragon would vanish, its whereabouts unknown.

Upon a jade-like platform in the stone chamber lay purple brocade quilts and sheer silk curtains. Among the treasures were objects of adornment and playthings—golden caskets, radiant gems, and arrays of black and yellow silks—none of which existed in the mortal world, their names beyond his knowledge. Two scrolls of plain silk bore the title *The Supreme Daoist Scripture of the Nine Heavens*. Mingsheng dared not unroll them to read their contents, attending only to sweeping and guarding the stone chamber. Even the treasures he did not dare to gaze upon, nor did he presume to ask about them.

For five years, he served with ever-increasing diligence, never slackening.

The lady sighed and said to him, "You are truly teachable—surely one who will attain the Dao. Though you are a mortal, you are neither licentious nor negligent, reverently honoring the numinous qi without fail. Even if you sought only longevity and immortality, how could you not succeed?

She then revealed her origins to him: "My surname is Wang, my given name Wanluo, and my courtesy name Bosui. I serve in the Supreme Mystery of the Great Perfection. My son holds the post of Chief Inspector of the Three Heavens’ Supreme Bureau, overseeing the ranks of celestial officials. In his youth, he was repeatedly entrusted with duties but wandered in idleness, neglecting his responsibilities. The authorities memorialized his misconduct, and he was demoted to the register of Mount Tai’s Retired Perfected King, where he now oversees the teachers of ghosts and spirits, with his term renewed every five hundred years. I came to observe him and urge him to mend his ways, governing his duties to atone for his past faults.

I have long dwelled among mortals, but now, by the command of our sovereign and the summons of the Supreme One, I may no longer remain. Yet I think fondly of your devotion and thus confide in you. I wished to teach you the methods of longevity and the arts of extending life, but what I have received—nourishment through the Great Harmony, a body naturally formed of dragon’s essence—can only be transmitted to the Perfected of the Three Heavens, not to one at the beginning of their studies. It is not something you may yet hear. Even if you were to hear it, you would surely be unable to apply it to preserve yourself.

There is Anqisheng, who understands the method of the Golden Elixir and the Reverted Cinnabar. His formula is secret and essential, the Dao of the Nine Lords and the Great Unity, by which one ascends to heaven in broad daylight. Anqisheng will come tomorrow, and I shall entrust you to his care. Follow him for a time, and his arts will surely be passed on to you."

The next day, Anqisheng arrived, riding a piebald qilin. He wore a robe of sheer silk, a *yuanyou* cap upon his head, and a jade girdle with a tiger-headed pouch. He appeared to be no more than twenty, radiant and dignified. Six or seven immortals accompanied him, each bearing a staff and attending in reverence.

Upon meeting the Lady, he bowed with utmost reverence and addressed himself as "your humble servant." Soon after, wine, fruit, and a feast were laid out, and they drank and feasted for half a day. The Lady then spoke to Mingsheng: "I can no longer stay. You must follow this gentleman and set your worries aside, for I shall visit you from time to time." With that, she presented him with two five-character poems to sustain their bond.

Mingsheng wept as he took his leave, preparing to follow Anqisheng and receive the Way of the Nine Elixirs. The Lady’s first poem read:

*For now, I leave the city’s walls,*
*To ride my chariot to Mount Tai’s folds.*
*Gazing up at the Great Clarity’s gates,*
*Cloud-palaces rise, towering and cold.*

*Within the void dwells the True One,*
*Coming and going in splendor bright.*
*Refine your form, preserve the natural state,*
*And feast on the Great Harmony’s light.*

*Each dawn, the Nine Heavenly Kings attend,*
*At dusk, I lodge in Western Hua’s embrace.*
*Essence refined may take flight,*
*Breathing in qi to nurture jade’s grace.*

*The supreme medicine is no gold or stone,*
*Yet the wind sings its song untold.*
*Ascending and descending through radiant skies,*
*In feathered robes, how free and bold!*

*The Five Peaks are not my abode,*
*The Dark Capital is my true home.*
*Below, men vie in vain pursuit,*
*Like snails and toads in muck they roam.*

*Gazing back at the dust-choked world,*
*Where woes entangle all they see.*
*If you’ve not grasped the Mystery’s core,*
*Why strive for carving jade needlessly?*

*Misfortune comes when the Dao is revealed,*
*Guard its secrets—blessings will then unfold.*

The second poem read:

*Once I dwelt in Kunlun’s halls,*
*Discoursing on how to extend heaven’s span.*
*Though Golden Elixir grants long years,*
*It cannot match the Great Harmony’s plan.*

*I ascended the Tower of Dark Spirit,*
*In empty reverie, chanting to the divine.*
*Suddenly, I met the King of Mulberry Trees,*
*And the Nine Elders, immortals divine.*

*His chariot was drawn by purple rainbows,*
*His visage radiant, fresh, and bright.*
*He urged me to seek the endless path,*
*And invited me to the Ford of Spontaneity’s light.*

*He taught me the art of soaring flight,*
*And bestowed the Jade Embryo’s scroll.*
*Jade nectar congealed with primal qi,*
*While the White Maiden expounded its role.*

*Embracing the lush jade phoenix’s breast,*
*I soared upward through the Three Heavens’ height.*
*The Cloud Net set my steps in place,*
*And the Five Peaks I could visit in flight.*

*The Dark Capital is not so far,*
*Nor Penglai’s mountain beyond reach.*
*Transmission and reception bind us in love,*
*As friends, we become heaven’s kin.*

*Reveal it, and you’ll face judgment’s decree,*
*For calamity spares neither fool nor sage.*
*Guard it well, and eternity is yours,*
*But leak it, and your body will age.*

After receiving the poems, Mingsheng followed Anqisheng, carrying his staff. They journeyed west to Nüji, north to Yuánqiū, south to Qínlú, and secretly to Qīngchéng and Jiǔyí, traversing the world entire. For twenty years, he endured every hardship. At last, Anqisheng declared: "You truly possess the bones of an immortal, and your devotion surpasses even mine." Thereupon, he transmitted the formula for the Great Clarity’s Golden Elixir Divine Cinnabar and instructed: "If you do not yet wish to ascend to heaven, simply consume half a dose to attain longevity."

Mingsheng then parted ways with Anqisheng and entered Huàyīn Mountain. There, he compounded the Golden Elixir according to the formula and consumed half a dose, attaining immortality while appearing no different from ordinary men—none recognized his extraordinary nature. During the reign of Emperor Ling of Han, only Grand Tutor Hú Guǎng discerned his attainment of the Dao. He once sought Mingsheng’s counsel regarding the dynasty’s fate. At first, Mingsheng remained silent, but later, he revealed all, and every prediction came to pass.

Later, people marveled at his agelessness. He then consumed the remaining half-dose of the Golden Elixir and ascended to heaven in broad daylight. Before departing, he left behind three poems for posterity, written in the third year of *Guānghé*. The first read:

*How enduring is the Great Harmony,*
*Yet man’s life is fleeting as dew at dawn.*
*Gathering like morning’s mist,*
*Vanishing in the blink of an eye upon waking.*

*Life’s cycles are the world’s delusion,*
*For suffering arises from restlessness.*
*I sought the True One,*
*Calming my spirit to embrace the luminous.*

*I lingered in Kunlun’s halls,*
*And roamed the Dark Capital’s expanse.*
*Juānzǐ guided my wanderings,*
*While the Supreme Perfected came to call.*

*Each dawn, I stood before the Queen Mother,*
*At dusk, I returned to Zhōngyuè’s peak.*
*Gazing up, I plucked jade blossoms,*
*Below, I sipped from the gemstone well’s deep.*

*A thousand years pass like a moment,*
*Ten thousand ages like lightning’s flash.*

The second poem read:

*Heaven and earth have their constancy,*
*Yet man’s life is most perilous.*
*Years fly swifter than an arrow loosed,*
*Or a fleeting moment’s light.*

*Though one may possess a radiant form,*
*Jade too gathers dust and grime.*
*Forests and grasses gleam not in autumn,*
*Nor do green leaves endure the year’s time.*

*Pity the lush and thriving, cut down,*
*By a single morning’s frost so dire.*
*Where there is preservation, there is loss,*
*Where there is rise, there is decay’s mire.*

*The True Lord plays at the Mystic Ford,*
*Unfettered by the world’s embrace.*
*His spirit roams the purple clouds,*
*His form dwells by mountain streams’ grace.*

*Facing the void, he forgets all cares,*
*His gaze wanders to the horizon’s rim.*
*What can the world’s dust bring?*
*For the true Dao is vast and prim.*

The third poem read:

*Truly, the turbid world is cause for sighs,*
*Its pleasures unworthy of pursuit.*
*Shaking off my robes, I sweep the dust away,*
*And soar alone, remote and absolute.*

*Amidst the desolate peaks and cliffs,*
*My myriad thoughts scatter like the wind.*
*The numinous Perfected wander with me,*
*As I ride the sun’s descent, a swan’s kin.*

*At dawn, I arrive on cloud-wheels,*
*At dusk, I depart on the whirlwind’s flight.*
*Amidst the clamor of heaven and earth,*
*How can the clamorous find a foothold in light?*

**Yin Changsheng**
Yin Changsheng was a native of Xinye.

In the eighth year of *Yongyuan* during the reign of Emperor He of Han, on the *jichou* day of the third month, Lady Yin was established as empress—she was the great-granddaughter of Yin Changsheng.

Though born into wealth and nobility, she disdained honor and rank. Concealing herself in seclusion, she devoted herself entirely to the arts of the Dao. Later, she heard of Ma Mingsheng, who had attained the method of transcending the world, and so she entered the famous mountains in search of him. Arriving at Taihe Mountain in Nanyang, she finally met him and served as his menial, personally performing the most laborious tasks. Yet Ma Mingsheng did not teach her the Way of transcendence; instead, from dawn to dusk, he spoke only of the fleeting glory of the world and the management of gardens and estates. For over a decade, Changsheng never wavered in her diligence. Twelve others had also sought Ma Mingsheng’s instruction, but all grew resentful and departed—only Changsheng’s reverence deepened. Whenever she erred in speech, Ma Mingsheng would scold and berate her, yet she remained composed, offering apologies without hesitation. After twenty years of such devotion, one day in leisure, Ma Mingsheng asked what she desired. Changsheng knelt and replied: *"I seek only life itself. With this body of dust and straw, I have entrusted myself to the Heavenly Craftsman. I dare not be impatient, nor fear delay."*

Moved by her words, Ma Mingsheng said: *"You are truly one who can attain the Dao."* He then took her to Mount Qingcheng, where he transmuted yellow earth into gold to demonstrate its truth. They erected an altar, made a blood oath, and on that very day, he bestowed upon her the Divine Elixir of Golden Liquor from the Great Clarity. As he prepared to depart, Changsheng kowtowed, entreating him to linger a while longer. She bowed in farewell, saying: *"From youth, I was raised in luxury, yet I shunned arrogance and embraced humility, disciplining myself as if standing at the edge of an abyss. I could not propagate the Dao nor glorify its virtue, nor spread its wondrous essence—merely stood idle like a hollow vessel, and now old age has come upon me. Thus, I set my heart on life’s covenant and abandoned the world to seek the true. Heaven granted this blessed encounter, and I was fortunate to meet you. For twenty-two years, I have served you, yet my strength has faltered, ever fearful of failure. My sinews grow weak, my efforts meager, and I have repaid none of your kindness. Day and night, my gratitude overflows. Now, reborn by your grace, I receive this sacred formula—this ashen form is granted extended years, like parched grass revived by sweet rain. You have restored breath to the lifeless and opened the eyes and ears of the blind. My debt is beyond words.*

*In the year *gengchen*, I heard that you, Master, along with the Perfected of South Mountain, Lord Hongya, Lord Yuncheng, and the Immortal Maidens of Yingzhou, sat in council to transmit the teachings. There were oaths of silk and pledges of shared sashes, and offerings were made to the Nine Elders of the Immortal Capital and the Nine Black Venerables. Prayers were answered, and the great elixir was to be bestowed. Yet when the rites were performed, it did not succeed. I, your disciple, was present in the hall, weary yet attentive, and heard the immortals recount the origins of their attainment, as well as the former instructions on the alchemical process. Today, you enlighten me anew—should I not mention this? Or is it that your teaching was incomplete, or perhaps you feared I was not yet ready?"*

Ma Mingsheng consoled her, saying: *"It was not incomplete. Your nature delights in the profound and abides in harmony. The numinous officials have observed and approved—there is no need for the oaths of common men."*

Thereupon, Changsheng entered a stone chamber in Mount Wudang to compound the elixir. She first consumed half a dose and did not immediately ascend to heaven. Instead, she transmuted tens of thousands of catties of gold and distributed it to the poor and needy, whether she knew them or not. She traveled throughout the world without her family, yet all her household enjoyed long life. Later, she entrusted her affairs to others and entered Mount Pingdu in Zhongzhou to refine and consume the elixir. On a bright day, she ascended to heaven. Before departing, she composed nine scrolls, recording that immortals of ancient times were too numerous to recount in full. She noted that since the rise of the Han, forty-five lofty scholars had attained transcendence, though only six had reached the thousand-year mark. Twenty-eight had departed through *shijie* (corpse-liberation), while the rest ascended in broad daylight. She also wrote a preface, stating: *"In the first year of *Yanguang* of the Han, I received the essential secrets of the divine elixir north of Xinye Mountain and achieved the Dao, departing the world. Copies are hidden in famous mountains—whoever obtains them shall be ranked among the Perfected, free to come and go. This is the way for the worldly to attain deathlessness. The key lies in the divine elixir. Practices such as circulating *qi*, guiding and stretching, and consuming herbs and plants may yield minor attainments, but they cannot grant eternal transcendence to become a Heavenly Immortal. If you wish to hear the Dao, this is the essential teaching—it comes from accumulated study, not divine intervention. The superior person pursues it with diligence; the foolish laugh and dismiss it as false. Yet those who know the divine elixir shall enjoy enduring vision and eternal life."*

She then inscribed three copies of the elixir scripture on yellow silk and golden tablets, depositing them in Mount Song, Mount Hua, and Mount Huan. One copy on silk was entrusted to her disciples, to be passed down through generations. She left behind three *four-character* poems for the world, which read:

---

*Of my ancestors,*
*They aided the reigns of Tang and Yu.*
*Through the Han, purple seals entwined.*
*Yet I alone loved the Dao,*
*And lived as a common man.*
*My lofty, pure resolve*
*Shunned lords and kings.*
*To live having gained life—*
*What more could I seek?*
*Beyond the azure vault,*
*I ride the floating chariot.*
*The Blue Consort mounts wings,*
*Yet stands as my foe.*
*Fire cannot burn me,*
*Water cannot drench.*
*Roaming the Great Ultimate,*
*What care or sorrow remains?*
*Sporting in the Immortal Capital,*
*I pity the foolish and dull.*
*Life’s passing years*
*Flow like a river.*
*In an instant, all is gone—*
*Dust and earth their due.*
*Racing toward death,*
*Never pausing to rest.*

*My sagely teacher,*
*Embodied the true Dao.*
*Ascending, transforming,*
*With Red Pine and Wang Qiao as kin.*
*Of my fellow students,*
*Twelve in all,*
*We sought the Dao through cold and heat,*
*For twenty years.*
*Many grew weary,*
*Their resolve unsteady.*
*Alas, my companions—*
*Fate lies with Heaven.*
*Heaven does not bestow in vain;*
*The Dao must return to the worthy.*
*Buried in dark earth,*
*When shall they return?*
*O you who come after,*
*Strive with diligence and devotion."*

Do not be swayed by the vulgar currents, nor ensnared by wealth and rank.
Once the divine elixir is perfected,
You shall ascend to the Nine Heavens.
Your lifespan shall equal the Three Luminaries—
How could it be a mere hundred million years?

From the time my hair was bound in youth,
I loved the Dao and its virtue.
Leaving home to follow my teacher,
I wandered east and west, south and north.
I cast aside the Five Classics,
Withdrawing from the world to seek my own path.
For over twenty years,
I dwelled beside sacred mountains.
Cold, I had no time for clothing;
Hungry, I had no leisure to eat.
I dared not think of returning,
Nor dared to rest from my toil.
I served my sagely teacher,
Attending him with joyful countenance.
Though my face was grimed and my feet calloused,
He saw my devotion and took pity.
He transmitted the essential secrets to me—
His grace was profound and unfathomable.
My wife and children gained long life,
All enjoying boundless years.
The yellow and white elixirs were perfected,
Bringing wealth beyond measure.
I commanded spirits and gods,
With jade maidens attending at my side.
I attained deliverance from the world—
All through the power of the divine elixir.

This stele is inscribed at Jingde Abbey on Pingdu Mountain for posterity.

The Jin dynasty’s Ge Hong of Danyang said:
I once heard a proverb: *"If you do not walk at night, you will not know there are night-walkers on the road."*
Those who have not attained immortality—how can they know that in the secluded mountains and forests of the world, there are those who study the Dao and achieve transcendence?
Lord Yin has already consumed the divine medicine. Though he has not yet ascended to heaven, his presence is stern and majestic. When like minds resonate, he naturally seeks out and encounters immortals. Thus, I know that in recent times, the number of such transcendents is not few.
Yet the common folk dismiss this as false. What they themselves have not heard, they declare nonexistent—is this not lamentable?
Even reclusive scholars, who find fulfillment in seclusion, delight in the classics, and shun ostentation, do not flaunt their literary brilliance, nor seek fame, nor cultivate friendships, nor pursue worldly success—even they cannot recognize such truths.
How much less, then, would immortals hasten to make known their deeds to those as ephemeral as morning mushrooms?

Minister Dao Yi said:
Yin Changsheng’s devotion to his teacher was arduous. Though he did not obtain the Dao at first, he never wearied—his sincerity was perfect, beyond the reach of ordinary men.
Of the twelve who studied under Ma Mingsheng at the same time, all grew resentful and left. Only Changsheng’s reverence deepened, and in the end, he alone attained the Dao.
As the *Daodejing* says: *"To learn what others do not learn is to redress the errors of the multitude, aiding the self-so of the myriad things without presuming to act."*
This describes Changsheng.

Wei Boyang,
Wei Boyang was a man of Wu. Born into a noble family, he was by nature drawn to the Daoist arts and refused to enter official service. Living in seclusion to cultivate his nature, none knew his origins—people assumed he merely tended to the people and nurtured himself.
He entered the mountains to concoct the divine elixir, taking three disciples with him. Knowing that two of them were not entirely sincere, once the elixir was complete, he tested it, saying:
*"Though the golden elixir is made, we must first try it. Feed it to a white dog—if the dog can fly, then humans may consume it. If the dog dies, it must not be taken."*
When Boyang had entered the mountains, he had brought a white dog with him. The elixir’s cycles were not yet complete, its fusion imperfect, and the toxic elixir, if consumed, would cause temporary death.
Boyang thus fed the toxic elixir to the white dog, and the dog immediately died. He then asked his disciples:
*"I feared the elixir might not succeed. Now that it is made and the dog has died after consuming it, I worry it may not have the approval of the divine spirits. If we take it, we may suffer the dog’s fate—what should we do?"*
The disciples asked: *"Will you take it, Master?"*
Boyang replied: *"I have turned my back on the world’s paths, left my family, and entered the mountains. If I do not attain the Dao of immortality, I would be ashamed to return. Whether death or life, I shall consume it."*
He then took the elixir, and as soon as it entered his mouth, he died.
The disciples looked at one another and said: *"The purpose of making the elixir was to seek long life. Yet consuming it brings death—what are we to do?"*
One disciple said: *"Our teacher is no ordinary man. If he died after taking the elixir, could there be a deeper meaning?"*
Boyang took the elixir again, and once more, he died. The remaining two disciples said to each other:
*"We made the elixir to seek long life. Now that consuming it brings death, what use is it? If we do not take it, we can still live for decades in the world."*
They refused to consume it and left the mountain together, intending to seek coffins and burial goods for Boyang and the deceased disciple.
After the two had gone, Boyang revived. He placed the elixir he had consumed into the mouths of the disciple and the white dog, and in an instant, both arose. Taking the disciple surnamed Yu and the white dog, he departed. He encountered a woodcutter in the mountains and wrote a letter to his fellow villagers, entrusting it to the two disciples.
When the disciples saw the letter, they were filled with remorse.

Boyang wrote the *Cantong Qi* and its five related texts, totaling two volumes. Though it appears to explain the *Zhouyi*, it actually borrows the hexagrams and images to discuss the intent behind elixir-making.
Another account states: Wei Boyang of the Eastern Han was a native of Shangyu in Kuaiji. Born into a family of officials, he alone refused office, cultivating truth in seclusion and nurturing his will in emptiness. He regarded courtly robes as mere husks, indifferent to worldly glory.
It is unknown from whom he received instruction, but he obtained the *Dragon and Tiger Classic* of the ancients and mastered its profound secrets. He then drew upon the *Zhouyi* to compose the *Cantong Qi* in three chapters.
