Feeling it had not exhausted the subtleties, he wrote an additional chapter, *Supplementing Omissions*, to further elucidate the mysteries of the elixir texts.
His writings often employ allegory and metaphor, concealing and revealing meaning through varied expressions.
Boyang composed the *Cantong Qi* to show that elixir-making follows the same path as creation itself, and thus he used the images of the *Yi* to discuss it. The work has circulated in the world, and later commentators number several, but only Peng Xiao of the True Unity School provided the most accurate exegesis. After achieving the elixir and ascending as an immortal, his book fortunately survived.

Minister Dao Yi said:
The *Daodejing* states: *"The Dao is the mystery of the myriad things, the treasure of the good."*
Wei Boyang was a good man. He did not keep this treasure for himself but shared it with the world—this is the height of goodness.
Since Guangchengzi revealed the secrets of the Three Elixirs and Nine Tripods to illuminate the supreme Dao, through the eras of the Five Emperors and the Xia dynasty, though immortals consumed the elixir and transmitted its teachings, the profound resonance of the elixir’s Way nearly faded into silence.

By the Yin and Zhou dynasties, the Supreme One once more manifested in the world, and the Way was revived. During the Former Han, various immortals subtly embedded its teachings in songs and poems, yet the Way remained not fully expounded. Then came Boyang, who borrowed the principles of the *Yijing* to compose the *Cantong qi*, exhaustively revealing the subtleties of the supreme Way. He established a model for the world, one that could be transmitted endlessly—thus did the treasure of the good man become known. From this, its teachings flourished in the Han and Jin, thrived in the Sui and Tang, and have endured to this day. Is this not the merit of Boyang?

*Comprehensive Mirror of Perfected Immortals Who Embodied the Dao, Scroll Thirteen* (conclusion)
*Comprehensive Mirror of Perfected Immortals Who Embodied the Dao, Scroll Fourteen*

Zhou Yishan
The Purple Yang Perfected, surnamed Zhou, named Yishan, styled Jitong, was a native of Ruyin. A seventh-generation descendant of the Han Chancellor Bo, his family, renowned for its noble lineage, had long held high office. His grandfather Xuan served as Inspector of Qingzhou in the first year of Emperor Zhaodi’s Yuanfeng reign. His father, Mi, was Magistrate of Fanyang, and it was then that the young master was born. Later, his father accumulated ranks and promotions, rising to become Inspector of Chenliu. At sixteen, the young master followed his father to the prefecture, where he first studied the *Classic of Filial Piety*, the *Analects*, and the *Yijing*. Grave and composed, he spoke little, his joy or anger never showing on his face. He favored solitude, sitting in quiet places, and formed no attachments to fame or favor. Yet his mind was keen and meticulous, and whatever he contemplated, he brought to fruition.

Each day, after the first light of dawn but before sunrise, he would stand facing east, rinse his mouth, swallow his saliva, and circulate his *qi* a hundred times, then bow twice toward the sun. He maintained this practice for years, until his father, finding it strange, asked what he was doing. The young master knelt and replied: *"Yishan delights in the radiance of the sun’s long light, and so I bow to it."*

On the first day of each lunar month, he would wander through markets, alleys, and humble lanes, where upon seeing the destitute and starving, he would remove his clothes to clothe them and provide food. Often he climbed famous mountains, sighing with sorrow.

At times, he would enter a stone chamber, where he would laugh joyfully in solitude. Renowned scholars of Chenliu, hearing of his profound virtue and serene, refined nature, all came to visit him, but he would always claim illness and refuse to meet with guests. Cai Xian, the Han Attendant Gentleman and a distinguished scholar of Chenliu who had some understanding of the Dao, also heard of his virtuous conduct and repeatedly sought him out. Each time, he feigned illness to avoid seeing him, until his father grew deeply perplexed and angrily rebuked him, pressing him to go out and meet the visitor. With no choice, he finally emerged to greet Cai Xian. Cai launched into an expansive discourse on pure conversation, discussing the Dao of immortals and the arts of transformation. Yet the young master remained silent, inwardly withdrawn, his spirit empty and still, merely nodding in response—never uttering a word.

That year, a severe drought struck, and a *dou* of rice cost a thousand coins. Starving people filled the roads, reduced to eating wild grasses. He then exhausted his wealth and emptied his household to relieve their suffering, performing these acts of kindness in secret so that no one knew it was his compassion at work. He treated all beings as if they were newborn infants—such was the depth of his accumulated virtue and benevolence.

Later, Huang Tai of Chenliu came to him and said: *"I have heard of your devotion to the Dao, your hidden virtues flowing like a current, and your subtle, wondrous thoughts that have truly moved me. That is why I have come to see you. I am Xu Lin, styled Zixuan, an immortal of Mount Song. Originally from Wei, I was born in the final years of Duke Ling. From youth, I loved the Dao and studied under Master Cen, who taught me arts for refining the body and dispelling calamities. Later, I met Master Qiu, who instructed me in the methods of circulating *qi*, returning the spirit, and guarding the soul. I practiced these diligently, and the benefits were profound. You, in your youth, already know how to return the yang, preserve your essence and marrow, and practice guiding and gathering *qi*, swallowing sunlight and drinking dew—so you no longer require the inner arts of yin elixirs or embryonic nourishment. However, the Three Worms remain unharmed, and the Three Corpses are not yet dead, which is why your practice of guiding *qi* and circulating breath has not yet attained its principle. You should first take refined pills to kill the grain worms. These worms have three names: the first is Green Ancient, the second is White Maiden, and the third is Blood Corpse—they are called the Three Worms. When they reside within, they cause restlessness, fullness in the heart, a clouded will, and unstable thoughts. When you miss a meal, you feel hunger; sorrow and melancholy arise, and your essence and spirit fail to settle—all due to the disruption caused by irregular eating. Even if you abstain from grains, your body will feel heavy and sluggish, your mind dull and oppressed, your dreams unreal, your thoughts confused and inverted, and worldly impurities will not be purged—all because these worms stir within and agitate the five viscera. The formula uses five *liang* of aconite, seven *sheng* of hemp seeds, six *liang* of rehmannia, seven *liang* of *mu* (cinnamon or another wood), a seven-inch segment of large evodia root, four *liang* of cassia, and five *liang* of cloud fungus—seven ingredients in total. First, boil calamus root to make a thick broth, then strain it to clarity. Heat one and a half *dou* of thick broth, and steep the seven herbs in it—you may either chop them coarsely or leave them whole. After three days, remove and dry them in the sun. Then steep them again in the same broth for another three days, dry them once more, and repeat until the broth is exhausted. Grind the dried herbs in an iron mortar until they become a fine powder. Mix with white honey to form pills. At dawn, facing east, begin by taking two pills the size of small beans, gradually increasing by one pill until you reach ten or more. This will relieve abdominal tension, upward counterflow of *qi*, and blockages in the chest, while nourishing the skin, lightening the body, and imparting a radiant glow. After finishing one course, the worms will die, and once the worms are dead, the Three Corpses will wither and naturally fall away. You may prepare this remedy multiple times without limit. Afterward, combine the Four Guardian Pills, adding one *liang* each of azurite and Solomon’s seal to complete the grain-abstention process. If your practice of guiding *qi* and circulating breath still does not attain its principle, you may first consume various herbs such as *ju sheng*, *fu ling*, *mu* (wood), cassia, asparagus, coptis, rehmannia, rhubarb, peach kernels, and their skins—choose as you see fit. Though these medicines may grant you strength, without the Dao of the Nine-Turned Divine Elixir and Golden Liquid, you cannot become a flying immortal—you may only extend your years and prolong your life. Follow these steps in order, and after five years of consuming the wood medicine, your body will emanate a luminous glow, and you will be able to see clearly within, perceiving your five viscera. Then, seek out an immortal to request the essential techniques of flying transcendence. The immortal said: 'There are many kinds of medicines and many ranks of immortals. Some ride clouds and drive dragons, ascending to heaven in broad daylight, befriending the Perfected of the Great Ultimate and becoming lords of the immortal palaces—equal in rank to the True Duke, the Fixed Prime Duke, the Great Life Duke, the Central Yellow Grand Master, the Nine Qi Elder, and the Duke of the Immortal Capital. These are the highest immortals. Others become immortal ministers or great masters, ranking just below the highest immortals. They wander the Five Peaks or ascend to the Great Clarity, commanding ghosts and spirits—these are the middle immortals. Some are enfeoffed with a mountain and govern ghosts and spirits; others roam the lesser realms, gathering in the palaces of Pure Emptiness—these are the next rank of middle immortals. Those who eat grains yet do not die, casting no shadow at noon, are the lower immortals. Others undergo corpse liberation in daylight, passing through the Great Yin before attaining immortality—these are the next rank of lower immortals. I received the secret essentials of Master Juan, and I am but a middle immortal. Your name is recorded in the Golden Register, and you are destined to become a Perfected One. My Dao is not what a Perfected One like you should study. Today, I transmit to you the method of guarding the Three Ones, two hundred texts from the Mysterious Lesser Realm, stone fungi, red stalks, and several divine mushrooms for you to consume. My teachings are now complete, and you may seek a master farther afield.'*

The young master bowed twice to receive the instructions. Afterward, he consumed divine mushrooms for five years, gaining the ability to see a thousand *li* away and travel five hundred *li* in a day. He then wandered through famous mountains in search of immortals. Hearing that Master Le of Mount Meng could recite the *Dragon’s Pride Scripture*, he went to seek him out. There, he met Master Yanmen, who transmitted to him the *Dragon’s Pride Scripture* and the *Inner Writings of the Three Sovereigns*. Ascending Mount Wangwu, he encountered Master Zhao Tuo, who bestowed upon him sixteen charts of divine mushrooms and the secret talismans of the Five Phases.

Then he encountered Master Huang, who transmitted to him the *Divine Prescriptions of the Yellow Simplicity*, along with forty-four formulas of the *Five Emperors and Six Jia Spirit-Flight Writings of the Left and Right*. Ascending Mount Panzhong, he met Lord Shangwei, who bestowed upon him the *Transmission of the Great Simplicity*, the *Record of Left Yi and the Chaotic East*, and the *Statutes of Right Yu and the Subduing Killings*. Climbing Mount Songgao, he came upon the Central Yellow Venerable Lord, who was convening with immortals within the Cavern Gate of the Great Chamber. The young master prostrated himself and bowed, entreating for the Way of long life and deliverance from the world.

The Yellow Venerable Lord asked, “Have you beheld the White Prime Lord within your Chamber of the Grotto?”

The young master replied, “Indeed, I have beheld the White Prime Lord within the Chamber of the Grotto.”

The Yellow Venerable Lord said, “Your Dao is not yet sufficient, for you have not seen the Peerless Lord. Continue your wanderings and receive the essential formulas; then I shall transmit to you the scriptures of the Supreme Perfection.”

“To behold the White Prime Lord is the affair of a lesser immortal, granting a lifespan of three thousand years. To behold the Peerless Lord is to become a true one, granting a lifespan of ten thousand years.”

The young master bowed twice to receive the teachings and withdrew. He then roamed through the renowned mountains and great marshes of the world. Westward, he ascended White Void Mountain, where he met Master Bo of Shayeh and received the *Supreme Scripture of the Great Clarity*. Climbing Mount Emei, he entered the Golden Treasury of the Empty Grotto and encountered Master Ning, who transmitted to him the *Hidden Writings of the Great Elixir* and the *Ten Formulas of the Eight Endowments*. Ascending Mount Min, he met Master Yin and received the *Nine Crimson Mottled Talismans*. Climbing Mount Qi, he encountered Zang Yanfu and was given the *Essential Formulas of the Melancholy and Joyful Plain Songs*. Ascending Mount Liang, he met Lord Cheng of Huainan and received the *Three Charts of the Celestial Pass*. Climbing Oxhead Mountain, he encountered Zhang Zifang and was bestowed the *Authentic Scripture of the Great Clarity*. Ascending Mount Jiuyi, he met Li Boyang and received the *Mysterious Scripture of the Li Clan*. Climbing Mount Zhong, he encountered Master Gaoqiu and was given twenty-seven *Divine Elixir Prescriptions*. Ascending Mount Heming, he met Lord Yang’an and received the *Scripture of the Golden Liquid Elixir* and the *Divine Elixir of the Nine Tripods*. Climbing Mount Meng, he encountered Master Azure Essence and was transmitted the *Transmission of the Yellow Simplicity*. Descending into the grotto chamber of the Yi River at Mount Luhun, he met Li Zi’er and received the *Eight Arts of the Hidden Earth*. Ascending Mount Rong, he encountered Zhao Boxuan and was given the *Art of the Twenty-Seven Plain Women*. Climbing Mount Yangluo, he met the Young Yang Lord and received the *Purple Writings of the Azure Essentials*. Ascending Mount Huo, he encountered the Lord of Destiny and was bestowed the *Blue Charts of Life*, the *Registers of the Supreme Sovereign’s People*. Climbing Mount Wushu, he met Master Mo Di and received the *Inner Vision Charts of the Purple Radiance and Blazing Light*. Ascending Mount Yaoming, he encountered the Divine Youth Who Awaits the Night on Behalf of the Great Emperor and was given the *Scripture of the Golden Root*. Climbing Mount Weiyu, he met Sima Jizhu and received the *Stone Essence and Golden Light Concealing Radiance Transforming Form*. Ascending Mount Dadu, he encountered Liu Zixian and was transmitted the *Sevenfold Divine Arts of Transformation*. Climbing the Towering Tree of Duguan, he met Gu Xizi and received the *Art of the Yellow Qi*, the *Techniques of the Great Void*, and the *Essentials of the Three Paths of Solar Essence*. Ascending Mount Tongbai, he met Wang Qiao and was given the *Plain Memorials of the Cinnabar Talismans*. Climbing Mount Taihua, he encountered Master Red Pine of the Southern Marchmount and received the *Authentic Writings of the Upper Prime*. Ascending Mount Taiming, he met the Nine Elder Immortals of the Divine Metropolis and was bestowed the *Four Authentic Arts of the Yellow Water and Moonlight*. Climbing Mount Heli, he met the August Personage and received the *Eight Simplicities Authentic Scripture* and the *Hidden Writings of the Supreme*. Ascending Mount Jing, he encountered Master Wanbi of the Yellow Terrace and was given the *Central Scripture of the Nine Perfections*. Climbing Mount Xuanlongyu, he met ten Jade Lads and the Nine Qi Venerable, who transmitted to him the *Art of the White Feather and Purple Canopy, Clad in the Yellow Water and Moonlight*.

Arriving at the Mulberry Grove, he ascended Mount Fuguang and encountered the Young Lord of Azure Perfection, who bestowed upon him the *Secret Characters of the Golden Writ*. Journeying south to the Vermilion Fire, he climbed Mount Danling and met Gong Zhongyang, who transmitted the *Authentic Records of the Immortal Taboos*. Traveling west, he ascended the Hollow Mountain and beheld the Peerless Lord. Gazing westward into the Chamber of the Grotto, he saw the Peerless Lord seated to the left, the White Prime Lord to the right, and the Yellow Venerable Lord in their midst.

The Peerless Lord wore a robe of golden essence and vermilion-jade-green silk, its radiance like the dawn’s rosy clouds, its brilliance illuminating the heavens. He bore the *Luminous Chapters of the Supreme Numinous Qi*, wielded the *Nine Emperors’ Exorcising Wands*, and wore the *Azure-Topped Purple-Spirit Crown*—he was the Ancestral Father of the Supreme Elixir, the Numinous Upper Prime, and the Crimson Child. To his left, the qi of the Azure Palace connected, crowning the myriad spirits. He had existed before heaven and earth, born from the empty void.

The White Prime Lord wore a layered robe of cinnabar-jade brocade and cloud gauze, its white light inwardly vermilion, its radiance piercing the heavens, its splendor reflecting the spirits, its dark and yellow hues penetrating the void. He bore the *Luminous Chapters of the Supreme Numinous Essence*, wielded the *Mysterious Prime’s Demon-Subduing Wands*, and wore the *Black Dragon-Summoning Crown*—he was the Father of the Upper Prime Crimson Child of the Jade Chamber and Cloud Court, the Lord of the Luminous Azure Chamber who governs life at dawn.

The Central Yellow Venerable Lord was the aged master of the Four Perfected Kings of the Supreme Ultimate. Above, he oversaw the Nine Heavens; in the middle, he roamed Kunlun. The Yellow Gate stood without, the Purple Portal within. Below, he entered the Chamber of the Grotto with the two lords, its circumference three inches, all majesty therein complete.

“Only through profound contemplation of the spirits may one become a perfected person. To behold the White Prime Lord is to become a lesser perfected one, with a lifespan of three thousand years. To behold the Peerless Lord is to become a middle perfected one, with a lifespan of ten thousand years. To behold the Yellow Venerable Lord is to rival heaven, ascending as a perfected person and inscribing one’s name upon the Golden Terrace.”

Having arrived, the young master prostrated himself and bowed, entreating for the supreme essential formulas. The Yellow Venerable Lord said, “Turn your gaze back to your Chamber of the Grotto.”

The young master then closed his eyes and inwardly beheld. After a long while, he indeed saw within the Chamber of the Grotto two divine persons—the Peerless Lord and the White Prime Lord—clad as they had been on the Hollow Mountain.

The Yellow Venerable Lord smiled and said, “How subtle and profound! The precision of your intent and thought is the Way of ascending to heaven in broad daylight. Return to Mount Chang and I shall transmit to you the Way of the Supreme Perfection.”

The young master then returned to the stone chamber of Mount Chang, where he fasted and meditated upon the Dao. After accumulating over ninety years more, the White Prime Lord, the Peerless Lord, and the Yellow Venerable Lord dispatched their attendants to transmit to him the *Thirty-Nine Chapters of the Great Grotto Authentic Scripture*. Twenty-one Jade Lads and twenty-one Jade Maidens, all serving the perfected, burned incense and practiced day and night.

After eleven more years, he ascended to heaven in broad daylight, riding clouds and driving dragons, to reach the Grand Tenuity Palace, where he received the scriptures and was named the Perfected One of Purple Yang. He bore the Yellow Pennant’s staff, the Eight Might’s scepter, a belt hung with flowing-gold bells, and wore robes of spontaneity. He consumed the sweet dew of jade nectar and drank the golden liquid’s broth. He governed the Bronze City of Golden Court on Mount Geyan—this was the Purple Yang Palace. Among the eight Perfected Ones of Purple Yang, he stood at their right. Thrice daily he ascended Kunlun, and each dawn he attended the Lord Emperor of Grand Tenuity. Mount Panzhong became his Purple Yang detached palace, known as the Hidden Palace of Dongting. Within Mount Panzhong’s caverns, a hidden passage led to the Clear Void Lesser Heaven of Wangwu, which also secretly connected to the Gate Wind.

Minister Dao Yi said: Zhou Yishan feigned illness to nurture obscurity, accumulating virtue and piling up benevolence. From beginning to end, his sincerity remained unbroken. He broadly studied the myriad wonders and became a true erudite of divine transcendence. Witnessing the Han Attendant-in-Ordinary Cai Xian and the eminent scholar of Chenliu visit him, Xian expounded at length on pure discourse, discussing the Dao of divine transcendents and the affairs of transformation. Yet Yishan remained inwardly still, gathering his spirit in emptiness and tranquility. He nodded in harmony but did not reply.

The *Scripture of Dao and Virtue* states: “Trustworthy words are not embellished; embellished words are not trustworthy. The good do not dispute; the disputatious are not good. The knowing are not broadly learned; the broadly learned do not know.” Such was Yishan’s intent.

The Perfected One of Clear Void, Lord Wang, named Bao, styled Zideng, was a native of Xiangping in Fanyang and a seventh-generation descendant of the Marquis of Anguo. He was born on the twenty-seventh day of the ninth month in the third year of Jianzhao during the reign of Emperor Yuan of Han. His family’s great foundation and enterprise had long been recorded among the eminent and prosperous.

His father, whose personal name was Kai, was renowned for his virtuous conduct and noble character, celebrated throughout the province. He was nominated as a *maocai* (Exemplary Talent), appointed *Yilang* (Discussion Gentleman), and successively promoted to *Zhonglei Dafu* (Grandee of the Central Rampart), *Tai Shou* (Grand Administrator) of Shangdang, *Huangmen Shilang* (Gentleman of the Yellow Gate), *Shizhong* (Palace Attendant), *Zuo Jiangjun* (General of the Left), and *Tai Shou* of Yamen. Kai maintained an upright demeanor, offering forthright counsel and forthright remonstrance. His governance was marked by sincerity and directness, fulfilling his duties with diligence, ruling through ritual, and lightening punishments and taxes—commanding respect without sternness. The Son of Heaven esteemed him, promoting him to *Dian Shang San Lao* (One of the Three Elders of the Palace), where he served as an honored guest to the Crown Prince, lecturing on the *Spring and Autumn Annals*, the *Book of Documents*, the *Analects*, the *Rites*, and the *Book of Changes*. His magnanimity and benevolence, his patient and skillful instruction, brought him renown that resounded beyond the imperial gardens, his fame spreading throughout the capital and the land. One quiet night, the Lord was moved by profound reflection and sighed in sorrow: “The world is enveloped in the dust of mundane strife, where men rush after gain and loss, where profit and harm assail one another—this is like the fledgling crane gazing upon the aging swallow.” Resolving to leave his family, he entered Mount Hua, where he remained for nine years.

One night at midnight, he suddenly heard the sounds of pipes, drums, and the clamor of men and horses rising from the forest marshes. Gradually, the noise drew nearer. Looking up, he beheld a thousand chariots and ten thousand riders descending through the empty sky. Divine beings rode upon three clouds of pure white, bearing tiger tallies in hand, their crimson seals opening the way. They grasped standards and banners, their brocade flags veiling the void as the procession cast shifting shadows in the pale dawn. One of the divine beings halted his carriage and spoke: “I am the True Man of the Supreme Ultimate, Xi Liang Ziwen of the Western Beam. Hearing of your devotion to the Dao and your arduous toil in the mountains and forests, though you have yet to grasp the essential truths, I pity your sincerity. Your earnest pursuit of immortality is indeed most commendable.”

The Lord hastened to the wheels of the divine carriage, prostrating himself and striking his head upon the ground as he spoke: “I, Bao, am but a mortal, dull-witted and base, yet from youth I have cherished the Way of life, though I know nothing of its hidden secrets.” The True Man replied: “To study the Dao without a master is to lack the thread that unravels the knot. I, the True Man of the Supreme Ultimate, preside over the affairs of divine transcendents, overseeing the examination and selection of scholars, and recommending the upright. Your name has been recorded in the Golden Writ of the Upper Clarity of the Eastern Flower, enrolled among the ranks of the Pure Void. You shall ascend to the Lesser Existence and inevitably take charge of the treasuries of sacred texts, assuming the office of Heavenly King. Simply focus your mind on the Four Effulgences, diligently cultivate the supreme practice, and the Dao will naturally be achieved.”

Later, while secluded in the Yangluo Mountains, he was visited by the Lady of the Southern Culmen and the True Man of the Western City, who bestowed upon him the *Precious Writ of the Most High*, the *Hidden Writ of the Eight Simplicities*, the *Perfect Scripture of the Great Cavern*, the *Numinous Writ*, the *Eightfold Dao of the Purple Crossing*, the *Flame-Light Stone Essence*, the *Jade Steed of the Divine Tiger*, and the *Feathered Mystery of the Lofty Transcendent*—thirty-one scrolls in all. Following the prescribed rites, he swore an oath and received them. The True Man then escorted him to the Dark Continent, arriving in an instant.

The four sides were bound by vast seas, their towering waves suspended a thousand *zhang* high. Upon the continent stood palaces and towers, jasper chambers and jade halls—beyond all reckoning. The True Man of the Western City said, “This is the capital of the immortals’ realm, where the Most High Elder dwells.”

He then led the disciple into the Palace of Purple Cassia, where he beheld the Elder clad in a feathered robe of flowing rosy clouds, crowned with a lotus coronet, a belt of divine radiance at his waist, and a fire-bell in hand. Hundreds of maidens attended him, while dragons and tigers guarded the steps. The Most High Elder and the True Man of the Western City exchanged courtesies, then clasped hands and sat together, the disciple standing at their side.

The Most High Elder said, “Is this not the one called Wang Zideng? He has met with a worthy teacher in his pursuit of the Dao and is on the verge of attaining it.” The True Man of the Western City smiled and ordered the disciple to bow. After the obeisance, the Most High Elder had him sit facing north. The Elder then prepared a feast, and in an instant, the meal was set. A thousand kinds of numinous delicacies were arrayed, the cinnabar wine brimming, sandalwood smoke curling in fragrant coils, and incense of dark mystery wafting through the air. The grand music of the *Jun Tian* resounded as golden chimes struck the seven luminaries, the melodies of Mount Kongtong rising to pierce the luminous heavens.

Then dragons soared upon cloud-capped cliffs, and phoenixes cried out in flight. Mountains trembled as leviathans surged through the waves, and billows crashed in towering swells. Flowers of light bloomed in the void, and winds stirred across the boundless expanse. The Nine Perfected sang sacred hymns, their refined chants echoing through the emptiness; jade maidens joined in harmony as the Western Consorts swayed in dance.

Thereupon, the immortals swept their sleeves in unison, and the myriad spirits advanced in procession. Feathered youths bore the ritual staffs, and auspicious clouds wove brocade patterns in the sky. The Most High Elder then convened twenty-nine Perfected Ones, all Great Perfected Lords of the Dark Continent. The first among them, who styled himself the Lord of the Dao of Immortals, pointed to the disciple and said to the True Man of the Western City, “Behold this one—his eyes are limpid and distant, his spirit serene, his form composed. The radiance of the Six Effulgences shines forth from him. He is among the finest of the Perfected, a worthy prince of the Lesser Existence.”

The True Man of the Western City replied, “It is said that nature arises from Heaven, while destiny is shaped by man.”

Then the Lord of the Dao of Immortals commanded the attendants Fan Yunhua, Zhao Junzhu, and Wang Baotai to open the jasper coffer, unfurl the green scrolls, and present the *Hidden Writ of the Supreme Clarity* and the *Two Scrolls of the Dragon-Script Eightfold Numinous Canon*. They also bestowed upon him two *sheng* of *Cloud Azure Yang Water* and *Morning-Flying Cinnabar Elixir*. The disciple bowed and consumed them.

The Perfected Ones then escorted him back to the Western City. After nine years, his Dao was perfected, and he was granted a chariot of flying terraces. He journeyed east, crossing the *Starry Dawn* and the *Azure Sea*, ascending Mount Guang Sang to enter the *Court of First Light*, where he paid homage to the Great Emperor Lord. Kneeling twice in reverence, he received from the Emperor the *Nine-Script Dragon Radiance of the Purple Phoenix and Vermilion Writ* and the *Eightfold Dao Jade Record of the Supreme Clarity*.

Next, he traveled south, crossing the *Bo Sea* and the *Cinnabar Sea*, ascending Mount Chang Li to pay homage to the Lady of the Southern Culmen, the *Purple Prime*, and the *Lord of the Canopy of Flowers*. They bestowed upon him the *Five-Cloud Night-Glowing Jade Frost*.

Then he journeyed west, crossing the *Yuqiu* and the vast *Sea of Sunken Feathers* at the *Ford of the Gourd*, ascending Mount Li Nong to pay homage to the Lady of the Purple Canopy of Dawn and the *Three August Lords of the Radiant Perfection*. They granted him the *Jade Dao of Green Script* and the *Hidden Writ of the Refulgent Supreme Perfected*.

Next, he traveled north, crossing the *Xuan Sea of Carved Gentleness* and fording the *Upper River of the Gourd* at the *Ford of the Bottle Gourd*, ascending Mount Guang Ye to pay homage to the *Supreme Jade Lord of the Great Dao of the Void*. There, he encountered the Lord as he set forth on his journey, driving the chariot of the sun and moon’s dawn, riding the radiance of the *Purple Origin*, enveloped in clouds of yellow essence, resplendent with the effulgence of the Eight Effulgences. Countless flying immortals accompanied him, beyond all numbering.

The disciple bowed twice by the roadside, then proceeded to pay homage to the *Jade Dawn Emperor of the Supreme Clarity* and the *Six Subtle Lords of the Mysterious Clarity*. The two Lords bestowed upon him the *Precious Writ of the Soaring Empyrean and the Absolute Mystery*, the *Gold Chapters*, the *Hidden Writ of the Great Ultimate*, the *Dragon-Luminous Precious Pearl*, and the *Crimson Harmony Cloud Mushroom*. He bowed and consumed them, whereupon his body turned golden, a halo of radiance encircling his neck, the Seven Luminaries scattering blossoms that shimmered upon his form.

He then withdrew to wander the wilds of *Yue Feng* and the palaces of *Xuan Pu*, where he paid homage to the *Jade Emperor of the Central Augustness* and received the *Jade Canon of Dissolving Form, Vanishing, and Flowing Radiance*.

Next, he crossed the *Yu* and *Jue* rivers, fording the *Weak River* to the west, arriving at *Turtle Terrace* to pay homage to the *Nine Numinous Supreme Perfected Lady of the Supreme Clarity*. Afterward, he purified himself in retreat for three months and received the *Three-Flowered Precious Radiance of the Jasper Writ*, the *Jade Record of Numinous Splendor*, and the *Seven Dawns of the Plain Scripture*.

He then purified himself in retreat for another three years, floated upon the *Vast Sweat River*, and ascended Mount Bai Kong Yu. The mountain spanned thirty thousand *li* in circumference, and he wandered its expanse. The following day, he hastened to the *Jasper Tower of the Purple Clarity and Grand Simplicity*, the domain of the *Three Primordials of the Grand Simplicity, the Supreme Lord of the Dao*. There, within the *Palace of Cinnabar Spirit and White Jade*, resplendent with flying radiance and absolute brilliance, purple auroras cascaded in luminous streams, and the seven lights intertwined, weaving above the clouded eaves. The wondrous hues of dark and yellow defied all description.

Countless jade lads and maidens, along with Perfected attendants, stood in service. The disciple knelt twice in reverence before the jasper tower. After some time, the *Three Primordials of the Grand Simplicity, the Supreme Lord of the Dao*, sent forth the embroidered-robed messenger Xi Linzao to bestow upon him the *Golden Perfection and Jade Radiance of Flowing Gold Fire-Bells* and the *Seven Primordials of the Vast and Eight Effulgences of Soaring Auroras*.

The Lord also dispatched the *Left Lady of Pure Perfection*, Guo Linggai, and the *Right Jade Maiden of the Yang*, Zhong Feiji, to present him with the *Divine Talisman and Jade Seal*, appointing him as the *Perfected of the Grand Simplicity and Pure Void*, the *Heavenly King of the Lesser Existence*, the *Right Protector and Supreme Duke of the Three Primordials and Four Offices*, charged with governing the *Grotto-Heaven of Mount Wangwu*.

He was granted three hundred jade lads and maidens each, tasked with overseeing the *Jade Chapters of the Supreme Clarity*, the *Precious Mysteries of the Grand Simplicity and the Great Ultimate*, the *Nine Heavens’ Numinous Writ of the Supreme Grade*, the *Secret Records of the Six Harmonies*, and the *Wondrous Canons of Mountains and Seas*. He was also entrusted with the oversight of the *Three Treasures of Luminous Clarity* within the grotto, permitted to ride the chariot of tigers and the carriage of dragons, with a golden canopy and jasper wheels, and the *Flying Chariot of the Eight Effulgences*, to travel in and out of the *Supreme Clarity*, attend to affairs in the *Grand Simplicity*, and repose in the *Great Ultimate*.

**Mei Fu**
Mei Fu, styled Zizhen, was a native of Shouchun in Jiujiang.

In his youth, Mei Fu studied in Chang’an, mastering the *Book of Documents*, *Guliang Commentary*, and *Spring and Autumn Annals*. He served as a scholar in his commandery and was later appointed as the magistrate of Nanchang. During the reign of Emperor Cheng of Han, the emperor entrusted power to the Grand General Wang Feng, who monopolized authority. The Metropolitan Prefect of the Capital, San Zhang, had long been loyal and forthright, openly criticizing Wang Feng and was executed by him. The Wang clan grew increasingly powerful, and omens of disaster frequently appeared, yet none among the officials dared to speak truthfully. Mei Fu again submitted a memorial sharply criticizing the Wang clan, but the emperor did not heed it. Moreover, as Emperor Cheng had long been without an heir, Mei Fu proposed establishing the Three Sequences and enfeoffing Confucius’ descendants as the successors of Yin, submitting another memorial—yet it, too, went unheeded.

At that time, Mei Fu lived at home, devoting himself to reading and cultivating his nature. By the *Yuanshi* era of Emperor Ping, Wang Mang had seized power. One morning, Mei Fu abandoned his wife and children, left Jiujiang, and became a gatekeeper in the market of Wu, as recorded in the *Former Han History*. Daoist texts state that Mei Fu attained the Dao and ascended as an immortal.

The *Yuzhang Provincial Gazetteer* records: Mei Ridge lies in the Western Mountains, towering and precipitous. A winding path like a sheep’s intestines ascends five *li* to its summit. At the mountain’s base stands the Plum Immortal Temple, now called the Yangling Temple. Above the temple is the Plum Immortal Altar, where, according to tradition, Mei Zizhen resigned his post as Nanchang magistrate to study the Dao. Below Mei Ridge, the White Stone Spring emerges.

It is also said that the Ink Pool lies within the administrative precinct of Nanchang County. The site was once the former residence of Mei Fu, the Han-era magistrate of Nanchang, and was later established as a temple. The waters and bamboo there are secluded and lush. When the Jin-dynasty calligrapher Wang Xizhi governed Linchuan Commandery, he would pass by daily, lingering long and unable to depart, hence its name, the Ink Pool. The Song poet Xie Lingyun also resided there for a year, composing his *Hidden Explanations on the Classic of the Dao and Its Virtue* along with a commentary. During the *Zhenguan* era of Emperor Taizong of Tang, it was renamed the Taiyi Temple, where the Celestial Master Wan was ceremonially received to reside. In the second year of the *Longshuo* era of Emperor Gaozong, an offering ritual was held, and at night, clouds descended upon the hall, dispersing by dawn. On the altar appeared the auspicious sign of immortal lamps. During the *Kaiyuan* era of Emperor Xuanzong, it was renamed the Kaiyuan Temple, with the emperor himself inscribing the plaque. In the second year of the *Chongning* era of Emperor Huizong of Song, it was renamed the Chongning Wanshou Temple, and later the Tianning Temple.

The *Records of the Ten Circuits and Four Barbarians* state: Mei Fu’s Pool was where Mei Fu planted lotuses. He sighed, “Life is my torment, the body my shackles, form my humiliation, and wife my poison.” He then abandoned his wife and entered Hongya Mountain. Could this Ink Pool be the same? Elsewhere, such as the Plum Immortal Temple on Plum Mountain in Fuzhou, the Plum Immortal Temple in Fengcheng County of Longxing Prefecture—where an immortal altar and cinnabar well remain—the Jade Bamboo Mountain’s Chengtian Palace in Xingan County of Linjiang Prefecture, the Plum Mound Immortal Residence and Plum Immortal Temple in Xinchang County of Ruizhou, all mark places where Mei Fu traveled to cultivate the Dao.

The *Veritable Records of Plum Immortal Affairs* recount: Seeking a master and yearning for the Dao, Mei Fu visited the Ya Dang Mountains, journeyed through southern Min, and entered Zhiti Mountain. He then entered Xianxia Mountain, which lies east of Mount Wuyi. There, he built a hut on the cliffs and dwelled for years until he encountered the Immortal Lord of Kongtong, who transmitted to him the methods of inner and outer alchemy. He then proceeded to Yinglong Mountain but failed to achieve refinement. Next, he entered Maozhu Cave and Yanxian Mountain, then traveled to Yuhua Mountain, followed by Wushi Mountain. Upon reaching the western ridge of Jian River, he again met the Immortal Lord of Kongtong, who descended and said, “Your destined path lies on Flying Swan Mountain.” Mei Fu then went to Flying Swan Mountain, built a hut, and cultivated for a thousand days. His work complete, his spirit roamed beyond his body, and the radiance of his elixir illuminated the heavens. After consuming the cinnabar, Mei Fu prepared to depart and returned to Jiujiang. There, he beheld auspicious light piercing the sun and purple mist floating in the sky, while celestial music resounded from the clouds. Golden lads bore the imperial tally, jade maidens held banners, warriors controlled the phoenix chariot, and immortal attendants carried the *Shao* music. Mei Fu bowed to the decree, expressed his gratitude, and ascended on a green *luan* bird. Thereafter, Flying Swan Mountain was called Plum Immortal Mountain.

In the fifth year of the *Yuanfeng* era of Emperor Shenzong of Song, an imperial edict proclaimed: “In the time of the Han, Mei Fu, though isolated and distant, boldly spoke on the empire’s affairs—how noble was his ambition! In his later years, he lived at home, reading and cultivating his nature, ultimately transcending the world and ascending as an immortal, as tradition holds. Today, west of the Great River, his temple and image remain, and prayers there are always answered, bringing blessings to our people.”

The authorities reported this to the throne, and thus bestowed upon him this illustrious title, that his luminous spirit might not fade. In gratitude for Our grace, he is hereby specially enfeoffed as Perfected One of Shouchun.

In the second year of the *Shaoxing* era of Emperor Gaozong, in the intercalary fourth month, an imperial edict proclaimed: “When We formerly journeyed through the southern lands, We took Yuzhang as the eastern court of the Empress Dowager. Leading the palace ladies, We traveled by boat, braving the perils of wind and wave. Wherever We passed, protection was surely granted. Now We bestow this grace in recompense for the divine favor received. At the Immortal Ascension Altar of Mei Fu on the north bank of the Great River in Fengcheng County, Hongzhou, the Perfected One of Shouchun, though his forthright remonstrance went unheeded, left behind a lofty name unblemished. Moved by the Han court’s lack of discipline, he departed for the marketplace of Wu and never returned. Having already honored his temple with a title, We now further adorn it with a noble designation, that the fresh grace bestowed may be but slightly extended. Let this extraordinary favor console his lifelong aspirations. He is hereby specially enfeoffed as Perfected One of Reclusive Service in Shouchun.”

Minister Dao Yi states: “The *Daodejing* says: ‘Those who would take the world and act upon it, I see they will not succeed.’ This is like Tang and Wu, who revolutionized the mandate, aligning with Heaven and responding to the people. It also says: ‘The world is a sacred vessel; it cannot be acted upon. Those who act upon it ruin it.’ This is like Wang Mang of the Xin dynasty, who overstepped his bounds and usurped the throne. Even with the benevolence of Tang and Wu, they could not escape later criticism. How much more so for rebellious ministers and treacherous sons who monopolize power and plot usurpation and regicide? How excellent was Mei Fu’s memorial, which cautiously admonished against the gradual encroachments of the Wang clan! His foresight was profound, his concern for the moral order meticulous. Alas, the ruler of his time could not heed his words, and disaster ultimately unfolded, giving rise to treachery. Thus, later generations saw the likes of Huan Xuan and Hou Jing, who followed in his wake. The *Daodejing* says: ‘Act before things exist; govern before disorder arises.’ Was this not Mei Fu’s intent—to reinforce the weight of the Three Bonds and Five Constants with this Dao? Alas, his warning went unheeded. The *Daodejing* further says: ‘When the great Dao declines, benevolence and righteousness arise; when cunning and wisdom emerge, great falsehood follows.’ These words say it all.”

*Records of Perfected Immortals Through the Ages Who Embodied the Dao*, Scroll Fourteen concludes.
*Comprehensive Mirror of Perfected Immortals Through the Ages Who Embodied the Dao*, Scroll Fifteen begins.

Master Pei, the Perfected One of Pure Tranquility—styled Xuanren—hailed from Xiayang in Youfufeng. He was born in the second year of the reign of Emperor Ming of Han. Of clear and luminous bearing, his countenance and demeanor were refined and unadorned; he excelled in speech and laughter. His eyes shone with keen light, his arms hung past his knees, and his voice carried with resonant clarity, ringing like a struck bell.

His family revered both the Buddhist and Daoist Ways. From the age of ten, he remained awake day and night, immersing himself in the study of scriptures with single-minded devotion. On the eighth day of the fourth month, he once traveled by carriage with Feng Lan, Zhao Kangzi, and Hao Jicheng of Shangdang to a Buddhist stupa. The sky was overcast and rain fell when suddenly a lowly man, clad in a worn hempen robe and a yellow headscarf, approached the rear of their carriage and begged for a ride. Master Pei greeted him with courtesy and inquired after him, but the man did not reply. Pei alighted and invited him aboard. Kangzi and Jicheng grew furious and rebuked him: “What manner of man is this, that he should ride in our carriage?” Pei reasoned with them, and they relented, allowing the man to join them. Pei himself walked behind the carriage, his expression unchanged, while the stranger rode in ease, showing no sign of shame.

As they neared the stupa, the man said, “My home lies nearby.” He stepped down from the carriage and vanished abruptly within the stupa. A Daoist adept named Zhi Ziyuan, who possessed some knowledge of the Way and was said by elders to be one hundred seventy years old, saw Pei and sighed: “From youth to old age, I have seen many people, yet never one like you.” He invited Pei into a secluded chamber, a quiet and serene room, where a lavish feast was laid out. After they had eaten and drunk, the adept led Pei to a more secluded retreat and bade him sit. He then said, “I am skilled in reading faces, but none compare to yours. The pupils of your eyes resemble the moon’s pearl, and your forehead mirrors the radiant Yaoguang star of the Northern Dipper. From your back downward, your form is like that of the celestial stalwart. You are destined for noble rank and shall become a divine immortal—your aspirations in this world shall be fulfilled. Yet the bridge to the Way has not yet opened, and the seven qi remain unrefined. Without witnessing wondrous phenomena, you cannot achieve success without cause.”

He then revealed to Pei the secret methods of cultivation he had practiced, saying, “These are the inner arts of longevity, unknown to the world. Long ago, I wandered to Mount Jiao and the slopes of Ao Zu, where I encountered the immortal Master Jiang—none other than Chi Jiang Ziyu. He bestowed upon me five divine formulas. I have followed them for one hundred seventy years, and my vitality remains youthful; I do not feel the onset of age. Yet because I have not practiced diligently, my true resolve has faltered, and I have not transcended the world. Though my years have been prolonged, I have not attained divine immortality. This is the fault of lax practice and insufficient focus. Now I shall teach them to you.”

Thus he instructed Pei in the various stages of meditative visualization, the methods of circulation and breath-holding, and bestowed upon him sacred scriptures and talismanic writings from the loftiest perfected ones. He also transmitted the two formulas for consuming *fuling* and sesame, as taught by Master Jiang of Mount Jiao to Ziyuan. The method for preparing *fuling* is as follows:

Take five *jin* of *fuling*, thoroughly clean and remove the outer skin, then pound it finely and soak it in three *dou* of white honey. Place this in a copper vessel—or a heat-resistant white ceramic vessel—and set this vessel inside a large cauldron, filling the cauldron with water halfway up the sides of the drug container. Simmer with a gentle fire, allowing the water to boil and the vessel to heat. Frequently turn and stir the mixture to ensure thorough blending. When the honey has fully dissolved and the liquid has reduced, remove it and place it in an iron mortar. Pound it thirty thousand times until it can be formed into pills. Take thirty pills daily, each the size of a *wutong* seed. After one hundred days, all ailments will vanish; after two hundred days, one may read by night; after two years, one may command ghosts and spirits; after four years, jade maidens will attend you; after ten years, your night vision will gleam with light, and you will be able to conceal or reveal yourself at will, achieving longevity and enduring sight.

After one year of taking this, no harm can befall you, no illness can afflict you; your complexion will revert to that of an infant, your skin will be plump and radiant, white hair will turn black again, and your eyes will gleam with flowing light. When compounding the medicine, fast for three days and prepare it in a secluded chamber. Ensure no women, birds, dogs, or impure persons witness the process. For five *jin* of *fuling* and one or two *dou* of white honey, use a wooden lid to cover the vessel during cooking, keeping it sealed. Stir frequently while cooking, and only open the lid once the medicine is fully prepared. Use only fine firewood and charcoal, not rough kindling. Pay close attention to the process, constantly monitoring and adjusting as needed. The quantity for compounding may be adjusted as desired.

Once the medicine is prepared, form it into pills in advance and store them in a honey vessel, where they will keep for a thousand years without spoiling.

The method for consuming sesame, as taught by Master Jiang to Ziyuan in the Golden Ao Zu Mountains, is as follows:

Take three *dou* of sesame, selecting plump, clean seeds regardless of whether they are yellow or black. Roast them over a gentle fire until fragrant and thoroughly dry, then grind them finely into a powder, ensuring it is fine and even. Do not sift it. Mix three *dou* of white honey with the sesame powder, stirring until fully blended and smooth. Place the mixture in a vessel and set it in a cauldron of water, then cook it following the same method as for *fuling*. Once the mixture has reduced, remove it and pound it thirty thousand times until it can be formed into pills the size of *wutong* seeds. Take thirty pills daily. After consuming one full dose, your intestines will transform into sinew, you will be unaffected by cold or heat, your face will regain a youthful glow, and you will command a host of spirits.

Master Jiang relied solely on these two formulas, ascending through the mist in transformation, his breath summoning instant arrival, moving without hindrance, riding a retinue of dragons, ascending to pay homage to the imperial perfected ones, and attaining the rank of immortal patriarch.

**Le Ba**
Le Ba, styled Shuyuan, was a transcendent from Neihuang. The *Immortals’ Biographies* states he was from Shu Commandery.

Le Ba served the Han Emperor Huan, rising through four promotions to become Grand Administrator of Guiyang, where his governance earned great renown. Later, he was transferred to Yuzhang as Grand Administrator. The commandery’s lands abounded with mountains and rivers teeming with malevolent spirits, and the common folk often ruined their fortunes in offerings and prayers. Le Ba, who had long cultivated the Dao and could command ghosts and gods, systematically destroyed the illicit shrines, suppressed the deceitful shamans, and thus caused all uncanny phenomena to vanish. Though the people initially feared his measures, they ultimately found peace.

After Emperor Huan’s death, when Emperor Ling ascended the throne and Chen Fan was executed, Le Ba was implicated in the partisan affair and demoted to Grand Administrator of Yongchang. He submitted a memorial citing his merits to request dismissal, pleading illness and refusing to assume office. He submitted another memorial in vehement remonstrance, arguing the injustice of the Dou clan’s case. Enraged, the emperor issued an edict of severe rebuke, ordering his arrest and delivery to the廷尉. Le Ba took his own life.

The *Record of the Ocean of Compiled Accounts* states: The following day, a great wind arose, and the sky darkened into gloom, and Le Ba vanished. When inquiries were made, it was learned that on that very day, he had returned to Chengdu to bid farewell to his relatives before ascending to heaven.

The *Immortals’ Biographies* records: Le Ba was a native of Chengdu in Shu. From youth, he loved the Dao and neglected worldly affairs. When the Grand Administrator visited him, he requested that Le Ba serve as his Merit Officer, treating him with the courtesy due a teacher or friend. Upon Le Ba’s arrival, the Grand Administrator said, “I have heard that you possess the Dao. Might you demonstrate some marvel?” Le Ba assented. Seated calmly, he entered the wall and vanished, drifting like a wisp of cloudy qi, until his whereabouts were no longer known. Outside the wall, witnesses saw him transform into a tiger—indeed, the tiger was Le Ba.

Later, he was nominated as Filial and Incorrupt and appointed Gentleman Cadet, then promoted to Grand Administrator of Yuzhang. The temple on Mount Lu housed a spirit that could converse with outsiders from within its curtains, tossing wine cups into the air. Those who sought its blessings could command the winds on rivers and lakes, raising sails to meet passing ships. When Le Ba arrived in the commandery, he went to the temple and the spirit vanished. Le Ba declared, “This temple spirit has falsely posed as a celestial official, harming the people for too long. Its crimes warrant punishment.” He entrusted the matter to his Merit Officer while personally pursuing the spirit. “If we do not swiftly subdue it,” he warned, “it may roam the realm, accepting sacrifices everywhere and wrongfully harming good people. We must press it with severe interrogation.” He dispatched orders throughout the region, investigating mountain groves and earth-altars to track the spirit’s traces. The spirit fled to Qi Commandery, where it transformed into a scholar well-versed in the Five Classics. The Grand Administrator of Qi took the scholar as his son-in-law. Le Ba, learning of its whereabouts, submitted a memorial requesting leave from his post to capture the spirit.

Upon arrival, Le Ba visited the Grand Administrator and said, “I have heard you have a worthy son-in-law. Might I meet him?” The spirit, aware of Le Ba’s coming, feigned illness and refused to emerge. Le Ba told the Grand Administrator, “Your son-in-law is no man—he is the old spirit who impersonated a temple god. He has fled here, and I have come to seize him.” When the Grand Administrator summoned the scholar to no avail, Le Ba said, “Bringing him out will be easy.” He requested the Grand Administrator’s brush, ink, and memorial case, then inscribed a talisman. As he finished, he let out a long whistle into the air. Suddenly, an unseen figure took the talisman, and the entire assembly was startled. The talisman reached the scholar, who wept to his wife, “I must die if I go.” Moments later, the scholar clutched the talisman and appeared in the courtyard. Upon seeing Le Ba, he dared not approach. Le Ba rebuked him, “Old spirit, why not resume your true form?” At once, the scholar transformed into a raccoon dog, kowtowing and begging for mercy. Le Ba executed it, and all saw the blade descend from the air, the raccoon dog’s head rolling to the ground. The Grand Administrator’s daughter had borne a child, which also transformed into a raccoon dog and was killed.

Le Ba returned to Yuzhang. The commandery had many ghosts, including numerous one-legged spirits that harmed the people. After his arrival, such afflictions ceased, and all malevolent and uncanny forces vanished at once. Later, he was summoned to serve as Gentleman of the Palace. On New Year’s Day, during the grand court assembly, Le Ba arrived with the scent of wine about him. When the emperor bestowed wine upon the officials, Le Ba did not drink but instead spat three times toward the west and southwest. The censors reported his disrespect. Summoned to explain, Le Ba said, “In my hometown, the people built a temple for me in my lifetime, believing I could subdue ghosts and protect the sick. Now, elders from my village have come to my temple to make offerings. I could not bear to turn them away, which is why I carry the scent of wine. Just now, I saw a fire in the marketplace of Chengdu, so I spat wine to summon rain and extinguish it. I dared not show disrespect.” He requested that an imperial edict be sent to verify the matter, offering to accept punishment if his claim proved false.

A courier was dispatched to Chengdu, which reported: “On New Year’s Day, after the morning meal, a fire broke out. Suddenly, three great rains came from the northeast, and the fire was quenched. The rain that fell upon people carried the scent of wine.”

One day, a sudden storm arose, and the sky darkened until those seated opposite could not see one another. Le Ba vanished. When inquiries were made, it was learned that he had returned to Chengdu to bid farewell to his relatives, declaring he would not return. Young and old gathered at his temple to see him off. As they did, the wind and rain darkened the sky, and none knew where he had gone.

The *Declarations of the Perfected* states: “Formerly, Le Ba departed through a martial liberation and entered the forests of Lü Mountain, where he remained for thirteen years before returning home. He now dwells in the Red Rock Mountains of Heming.”

**Zuo Ci**
Zuo Ci, styled Yuanfang, was a native of Lujiang. From youth, he was well-versed in the Five Classics and also mastered astral prognostication. Seeing that the Han dynasty’s mandate was nearing its end and the realm was descending into chaos, he lamented, “In this declining era, high office invites peril, and great wealth courts death. The glory of this world is not worth coveting.” He thus devoted himself to the Dao, becoming particularly adept in the Six Jia techniques and able to command ghosts and gods, conjuring banquets at will. He meditated deeply in the Tianzhu Mountains and obtained the *Nine Elixirs of the Golden Liquid* from a stone chamber. His transformations were myriad and beyond count.

Cao Cao heard of his fame and summoned him, confining him in a chamber under guard and cutting off his grain, providing only two *sheng* of water daily. After a year, Zuo Ci emerged, his complexion unchanged. Cao Cao wished to learn the Dao, but Zuo Ci said, “To cultivate the Dao, one must be pure and inactive.” Enraged, Cao Cao plotted to kill him. Zuo Ci, sensing this, requested to resign and return home. Cao Cao asked, “Why so suddenly?”

Zuo Ci replied, “I knew you intended to kill me, so I sought to leave.” Cao Cao said, “I had no such intention. If you wish to pursue lofty aspirations, you should not stay long.” He then prepared a feast for him. Zuo Ci said, “Now that we part ways, I wish to share this cup of wine with you.” Cao Cao agreed. Zuo Ci drew his hairpin and traced the wine in the cup, which instantly split in two, leaving a gap of about a *fen* between them. Zuo Ci then drank half and offered the rest to Cao Cao, who was displeased and did not drink at once. Zuo Ci urged him to finish it, then tossed the cup toward the roof beam. The cup hung suspended from the beam, swaying as if a bird in flight—seeming about to fall yet never falling. All present fixed their gaze upon it. After a long while, the cup finally fell to the ground. When they looked, Zuo Ci had vanished.

Later, during one of Cao Cao’s banquets, Zuo Ci was also in attendance. Cao Cao turned to his guests and said, “Today’s gathering is grand, with delicacies nearly complete—all that is missing is a *Wu* River perch from Songjiang.” Zuo Ci then asked for a bronze tray filled with water, into which he cast a bamboo rod with bait. In an instant, he pulled out a perch. Cao Cao said, “One fish is not enough for all our guests.” Zuo Ci cast his line again and pulled out another perch, each over three *chi* long. Cao Cao then remarked, “Now that we have the fish, it is a pity we lack fresh ginger from Shu.” Zuo Ci said, “That is easily obtained.” Fearing he might fetch it from nearby, Cao Cao said, “I previously sent men to Shu to buy brocade—tell them to add two more bolts.” In moments, the ginger arrived, along with the messenger’s report. When the messenger returned and was questioned about the additional brocade, his account matched perfectly.

Later, Cao Cao went to the outskirts of the city, accompanied by over a hundred officials. Zuo Ci produced a *sheng* of wine and a *jin* of dried meat, pouring and serving it himself. All the officials drank and ate their fill. Cao Cao, harboring ill intent, ordered his men to seize Zuo Ci and kill him. Zuo Ci stepped back into the wall and vanished without a trace. Later, someone reported seeing Zuo Ci at his dwelling, and Cao Cao sent men to capture him. They seized Zuo Ci, who did not resist—he wished the world to witness his divine powers. He was then imprisoned. The jailers prepared to torture him, but when they opened the cell door, there stood one Zuo Ci inside and another outside. Unsure which to interrogate, they reported to Cao Cao, who, enraged, ordered a general to take him out and execute him in the marketplace.

In an instant, seven Zuo Cis appeared. The officer managed to seize six, but one escaped. Soon after, the six vanished as well. Cao Cao then ordered the four city gates closed and a search conducted. Some, unfamiliar with Zuo Ci, asked what he looked like. They were told, “He has one blind eye, wears a hempen headscarf, and a plain blue robe.” Yet every man they saw resembled Zuo Ci, and none could be captured. Cao Cao commanded that whoever was caught should be beheaded on the spot. Days later, Zuo Ci appeared and had his head cut off, presenting it to Cao Cao. Overjoyed, Cao Cao declared it was indeed Zuo Ci’s head. But upon closer inspection, it was merely a bundle of thatch. When they turned to look at the body, it too had vanished.

Later, a traveler from Kuaiji arrived and reported seeing Zuo Ci there. Another encounter occurred at the summit of Yangcheng Mountain, where pursuers chased him until he fled into a flock of sheep. Knowing he could not be caught, Cao Cao ordered his men to call out from among the sheep, “We will not kill you—we only wished to test your arts.” Suddenly, an old ram knelt on its forelegs, stood upright, and spoke, “Why so hasty?” As they rushed toward it, the entire flock of several hundred sheep transformed into old rams, all kneeling on their forelegs and repeating, “Why so hasty?” Thus, they could not tell which to seize.

The above accounts largely align with those in the *Book of the Later Han*. Governor Liu Biao also deemed Zuo Ci a corrupting influence and planned to arrest and execute him. Liu Biao led his troops in a display of force. Zuo Ci, sensing his intent to test his arts, approached him and said, “I have some humble wine—I wish to offer it to your army.” Liu Biao replied, “You are but a solitary Daoist—how can your meager provisions suffice for my many soldiers?” Zuo Ci insisted. Liu Biao sent men to inspect the offerings: a *dou* of wine in a vessel and a bundle of dried meat, which ten men together could not lift. Zuo Ci then stepped forward, took the meat, sliced it with a knife, and scattered the pieces on the ground. He invited a hundred men to distribute the wine and meat to the soldiers. Each received three cups of wine and one slice of meat, which tasted like ordinary fare. Though over ten thousand men were fully sated, the vessel’s wine remained as before, and the meat was not exhausted. Even the thousand guests at the banquet grew thoroughly drunk. Liu Biao was astonished and abandoned any thought of harming Zuo Ci.

Zuo Ci then took his leave of Liu Biao and entered Dongwu. Xu Duo of Dantu was a practitioner of the Dao, and Zuo Ci visited him. Xu Duo’s retainers had six or seven ox-drawn carts parked at his gate. They deceived Zuo Ci, saying, “Master Xu is not at home.” Zuo Ci, knowing they lied, ordered them to leave. Immediately, the oxen were seen walking along the treetops. When the men climbed the trees, the oxen vanished; when they descended, the oxen reappeared, still walking above. The carts’ hubs sprouted thorns a *chi* long, which could not be cut or moved. Terrified, the retainers reported to Xu Duo: “An old man with one blind eye—we thought him an unimportant person and lied, saying you were not at home. After he left, the oxen began behaving strangely. We do not know what this means.” Xu Duo exclaimed, “Ah! That must have been Master Zuo passing by. How could you deceive him? Hurry and pursue him—you may still catch up!” The retainers scattered to search, and upon finding Zuo Ci, they surrounded him and kowtowed in apology. Zuo Ci’s anger subsided, and he let them return. When they arrived, the carts and oxen had returned to normal.

Zuo Ci later visited Sun Ce, who also wished to kill him. Once, while out on an excursion, Sun Ce invited Zuo Ci to accompany him and had him walk ahead of his horse, intending to stab him from behind. Zuo Ci wore wooden clogs and leaned on a bamboo staff, walking slowly. Sun Ce whipped his horse in pursuit but could not catch up and eventually gave up. Later, Zuo Ci entered Mount Huo, where he compounded the *Nine-Flower Elixir*. Upon its completion, he ascended as an immortal.

The *True Records* states: “Zuo Ci now resides on Mount Xiao Kuo, often traveling here and there. He will soon receive another appointment.”

Zuo Ci’s complexion remained youthful, having benefited from the refining fire of the *Nine-Flower Elixir*. The annotation below states: Zuo Ci, styled Yuanfang, was the younger brother of Li Zhongfu and the master of Ge Xuan. The Wei ruler and his son summoned various masters of esoteric arts, and Zuo Ci was among them. At the end of Emperor Xian of Han’s *Jian’an* era, he crossed the Yangtze in search of mountains and entered a grotto. There, he begged for cinnabar and compounded the *Nine-Flower Elixir*. The *Nine-Flower Elixir* is a method from the *Taiqing* canon; *Xiao Kuo* refers to Mount Xiao Kuocang, located north of Yongjia’s Xi Bridge.

Kong Yuanfang was a native of Xuchang. He regularly consumed pine resin and fuling fruit. When he first obtained this medicine, he was already advanced in years. Thereafter, he grew younger with each passing year, maintaining the appearance of a man in his forties. You Yuanjie and Zuo Yuanfang were close friends, both well-versed in the Five Classics and worldly affairs, yet devoted to the cultivation of Daoist arts. Yuanfang was benevolent and kind, wearing coarse clothing and eating simple fare. He drank no more than one *sheng* of wine a day. He lived to be over one hundred and seventy years old. Daoists would occasionally invite Yuanfang to gatherings where guests took turns proposing drinking games. When his turn came, Yuanfang said nothing but propped his staff against the ground, then grasped it and stood upside down, head below and feet above, holding a wine cup in one hand to drink. No one else could perform such a feat.

Yuanfang had one wife and one son. He accumulated no surplus wealth and grew a modest amount of grain. Once, when a fire broke out, neighbors rushed to help salvage his belongings—clothing, provisions, and household items—but Yuanfang paid no heed, sitting exposed beneath a fence to watch the flames. His wife urged him to assist, but Yuanfang laughed and said, “Why fret over such things?” Elsewhere, by the water’s edge, he carved a cave into the bank, over a *zhang* in width and breadth. Yuanfang entered it to abstain from grain for months before returning home. Even his family was not permitted to visit. Before the cave stood a mulberry tree, and he would come and go through brambles and undergrowth, his path winding and concealed. When disciples had urgent matters and sought his dwelling, none could find it.

Later, a young man from the east, surnamed Feng and named Yu, was fond of the Dao. He observed Yuanfang entering the cave and followed him inside. Yuanfang said, “No one has ever found me before. Today you have seen me—you seem teachable.” He then presented two scrolls of plain script and said, “These contain the essential teachings of the Dao. Every forty years, I may transmit them to one person. If the world lacks a worthy recipient, I will not recklessly pass them on merely to fulfill the time limit. If after forty years no one is found, but after eighty years two suitable candidates appear, I will transmit the teachings to both at once. To withhold transmission from one who is fit is to obstruct the Dao of Heaven; to transmit to one who is unfit is to leak Heaven’s treasure. Obstructing the Dao or leaking its treasure brings misfortune upon one’s descendants. Now that I have found my successor, I shall depart.” He then abandoned his wife and child and entered the western cliffs.

Fifty years later, he briefly returned to his hometown, where some recognized him.

Jiao Xian, styled Xiaoran, was a native of Dayang in Hedong.

In his hometown, he lived for many years, reaching the age of one hundred and seventy. He subsisted on white stones, resembling the large taro of today. Daily, Jiao Xian would enter the mountains to gather firewood, which he distributed to others, beginning with the first household at the village head and proceeding in order, cycling through them again and again. He would first place the firewood outside a person’s door, and if they saw him, they would spread a mat for him to sit and prepare a meal. Jiao Xian would then sit and eat but never spoke to anyone. If no one noticed him, he would quietly leave the firewood at the door and depart. He continued this for years.

When the Wei dynasty received the Mandate of Heaven, he dwelled by the banks of the river, weaving grass into a hut where he lived alone. He did not arrange mats or cushions, using only grass as his seat. His body was filthy, caked with grime like mud or lacquer. Sometimes he ate only once every few days. He never walked along paths and avoided all association with women. When his clothes wore out, he would sell firewood at the market to buy new ones, yet he always wore only a single layer, even in winter.

Governor Dong Jing visited him, but Jiao Xian refused to speak. Nevertheless, Jing regarded him as a worthy. Later, a wildfire broke out and burned down his grass hut.

When people came to see him, they found Jiao Xian seated solemnly beneath his hut, unmoving. After the fire had passed and the hut was entirely consumed, he slowly rose—his clothes unscorched by the flames. He then built another hut. One day, a great snow fell, and many houses collapsed. Jiao Xian’s hut also toppled, and when people came, they could not find him, fearing he had frozen to death. They dismantled the hut to search for him and discovered him soundly asleep beneath the snow, his complexion flushed, his breath steady and deep, as if he were a drunkard napping in the heat of summer. Though none understood his strangeness, many wished to study the Way under him. Jiao Xian said, "I possess no Way." Whether old or young, he remained thus for over three hundred years before taking leave of others, vanishing without a trace. Those who sought his teachings never received a single word from him.

*The Book of Wei* states: "Since the time of Fuxi, there has been only one such man."

**Yang Wengbo**
Yang Wengbo served his parents with filial devotion. When he buried his father and mother, the spirits were so moved that a spring welled forth beside their grave. One day, a man who had come to water his horse gave Yang a pint of white stones, telling him to plant them, for they would grow into fine jade. Later, a youth in blue led him to a mountain by the sea, where an immortal said, "Your filial piety toward your parents has earned you and your wife immortality." Soon after, a woman of the Xu clan was betrothed to him with a white jade as the bride-price. Several years later, the couple ascended together to heaven.

*The Records of Anomalies* also states: Yang Wengbo often offered travelers broth. One day, after a man had drunk his fill, he took a pint of white seeds from his sleeve and gave them to Yang, saying, "Plant these, and they will grow into fine jade, and you will also gain a good wife." Yang did as instructed. A woman of the Xu clan, surpassingly beautiful, sought his hand in marriage. Lord Xu said, "Only if you present a pair of fine jade." Yang gave him the jade disks he had grown, and so took her as his wife.

**Li Yiqí**
Li Yiqí was a man of Shu Commandery. He lived from the time of Emperor Wen of Han until the reign of Liu Bei of Shu. When someone spoke of the palaces, temples, markets, and streets of the commanderies and kingdoms, Li Yiqí would mold soil into miniature replicas—every detail of the lands and their people perfectly rendered, though in minute scale. In an instant, they would crumble away, vanishing without a trace.

When Liu Bei prepared to launch a campaign against Wu to avenge Guan Yu, he summoned Li Yiqí. When Li arrived, Liu Bei asked him about the campaign’s fortunes. Li Yiqí did not answer but instead took up brush and paper, drawing a dozen or so soldiers, horses, and weapons before tearing the paper to shreds. He then drew a great man digging a pit and burying something before departing without a word. Liu Bei was displeased. He indeed set out with his army, only to be defeated by Lu Xun. His forces—over a hundred thousand strong—were slaughtered, and only a few hundred men returned. Their armor, weapons, and provisions were utterly lost. Overcome with shame and distress, Liu Bei fell ill and died at Yong’an.

The assembled company then reflected on the figure Li Yiqí had drawn—of the great man digging a pit and burying something—and realized it had been an omen of Liu Bei’s death.

Another account states: Li Yiqí hollowed out a clay cave at the corner of the city wall and lived within it. Winter and summer alike, he wore only a single robe, drinking wine and eating dried meat and dates. Sometimes he would not emerge for a hundred days, sometimes two hundred.

Du Qi
Du Qi, styled Guangping, was a native of Duling in Jingzhao. In the early Jian’an era of Emperor Ling of Han, he crossed the Yangtze to join Sun Ce. Later, under Sun Quan (in *True and Unadorned Pavilion*, mistakenly written as Sun Hao), he served as □□ Commandant. In the second year of Huangwu, Du Qi studied the Dao, taking Jie Ying as his teacher. He received the arts of the Mysterious and the White and dwelled on the eastern slopes of Mount Mao. After a long time, he gained the ability to conceal his form and vanish from sight. Often, he would gather firewood with his disciples and trade it for clothing and provisions, yet no one could detect him. Several times, he entered grottoes and attained immortality.

*The True Records* states: He had two disciples, one named Sun Gui, a woman called Cold Blossom, and the other Chen Shijing. During the reign of Sun Xiu, Shijing served as Gentleman Attendant.

Li A
Li A was a man of Shu during the Three Kingdoms period. Those who passed down his story saw him unchanged by age. He often begged for food in the markets of Chengdu, distributing whatever he received to the poor. He would depart at night and return by dawn, yet no one in the market knew where he lodged. An old man named Gu Qiang suspected Li A was an extraordinary person and frequently attended to him. Once, he followed Li A to his dwelling and discovered it was in the Qingcheng Mountains. Later, Gu Qiang trailed him again but, fearing tigers and wolves, secretly carried his father’s great sword. Li A saw this and grew angry, saying, “You follow me, yet fear tigers?” He took the sword and struck a rock, shattering it. Gu Qiang was deeply distressed over the broken blade. The next morning, Li A asked him, “Are you worried about the ruined sword?” Gu Qiang replied, “I truly fear my father’s anger.” Li A then gathered the fragments, struck the ground with them, and restored the sword to its original state before returning it.

Gu Qiang followed Li A back to Chengdu. Before they arrived, they encountered a man driving an ox-cart. Li A placed his foot beneath the wheel, crushing his bones to pieces, and died instantly. Gu Qiang watched over him, but after a moment, Li A revived, pressing his foot back into place as if nothing had happened. At the time, Gu Qiang was eighteen, while Li A appeared to be around fifty. When Gu Qiang was over eighty, Li A remained unchanged. Li A told others that he had been summoned by the Kunlun Mountains and would not return.

*The Nine Regions Record* states: On Jiaotan Mountain in Zizhou, the Perfected One Li A once cultivated the Dao. Later, he ascended to immortality at Xinjin in Shuzhou.

Your servant Daoyi remarks: Li A had long since attained the Dao, and many years had passed. Observing his eagerness to aid the orphaned and poor, even humbling himself to beg for food to fulfill his teachings, his intent was profound. Note his words to Gu Qiang: “You follow me, yet fear tigers?” This aligns precisely with the *Daodejing*’s meaning of “traveling by land without encountering rhinoceros or tiger.” That Gu Qiang, though sharp-eyed enough to recognize Li A as an extraordinary person, could not comprehend that rhinoceroses would have nowhere to thrust their horns nor tigers to place their claws!

Jie Xiang
Jie Xiang, styled Yuanze, was a native of Kuaiji. Well-versed in the Five Classics and widely read in the works of the Hundred Schools, he was also skilled in composition. Secretly, he practiced Daoist arts and entered the Eastern Marchmount to receive esoteric techniques of restraint. He could kindle fire atop reeds to boil a goose, leaving the reeds unscorched. He could ensure that within a mile, no one cooked or steamed food, and dogs and chickens would remain silent for three days. He could make an entire marketplace sit motionless, conceal his form, and transform into grasses, trees, birds, or beasts.

Having heard of the *Scripture of the Nine Elixirs*, he traveled thousands of miles in search of it. Failing to find a enlightened teacher, he entered the mountains to meditate in solitude, hoping to encounter immortals. Exhausted, he lay down upon a rock, where a tiger approached to devour him. Awakening, he saw the tiger and said, “If Heaven sent you to attend and protect me, stay. If the mountain spirit sent you to test me, leave at once.” Entering the mountains, he found in a valley countless purple-hued stones, radiant and as large as goose eggs. He took two and wandered deeper into the valley, but the depths were impassable, so he returned to the mountains.

There, he saw a beautiful girl of fifteen or sixteen, her appearance extraordinary, clad in five-colored garments—clearly an immortal. Jie Xiang bowed and begged for the method of longevity. The girl said, “Hurry and return what you hold to its original place, then come back. I will wait for you here.” Jie Xiang returned the stones to the valley and came back to find the girl still in the same spot. He bowed again, and she said, “The qi of your blood and food has not yet dissipated. Abstain from grains for three years, then return. I will remain here.” Jie Xiang went home, fasted for three years, and returned. The girl was still in the same place. She gave him a single elixir formula and instructed, “Attain this and you will become immortal. Do nothing else.”

Before he could compound the medicine, Jie Xiang often stayed at the home of his disciple Le Yanya. Beneath the curtains, several scholars debated unresolved matters from books and records. Unable to restrain himself, Jie Xiang intervened to resolve their disputes. The scholars, realizing he was no ordinary man, secretly memorialized him to the lord of Wu. Jie Xiang learned of this and wished to leave, saying, “I fear official duties will constrain me.” Le Yanya firmly detained him.

The lord of Wu issued an edict to summon him.
