When Jie Xiang arrived at Wuchang, he was treated with great respect and addressed as “Master Jie.” A residence was built for him, furnished with imperial curtains, and he was bestowed gifts worth thousands of gold. He taught the lord of Wu the art of concealment. After testing it in the rear palace and passing through palace gates unseen, the lord was astonished. He also commanded Jie Xiang to transform and cultivate melons, vegetables, and a hundred fruits, all of which sprouted instantly. When the lord discussed with him which fish dish was finest, Jie Xiang replied, “Steamed fish is the best.”

The lord said, “This fish dwells in the sea—how can it be obtained?”

Jie Xiang replied, “It can be obtained.” He instructed that a square pond be prepared in the palace courtyard and filled with water. Then he cast a line with hook and bait, lowering the line into the flames. In less than the time it takes to eat a meal, he caught a small fish. The lord was astonished and delighted, asking, “Is this edible?”

Jie Xiang said, “I retrieved it precisely to prepare a steamed dish for Your Majesty—how could it not be edible?” He then had the royal chefs cut the fish. The lord remarked, “When the envoys from Shu do not come, the finest steamed fish is made with ginger. Yet even that cannot compare to this—how can ginger be obtained?”

Jie Xiang replied, “It is easily done. Send someone with fifty coins, and I will inscribe a talisman on a bamboo staff. Have the person close their eyes and mount the staff, and when the staff stops, let them buy ginger. Once purchased, they must close their eyes again.” The person followed his instructions and mounted the staff. In an instant, they arrived in Chengdu, unaware of where they were until they asked and were told they were in Shu. There, they bought ginger. At that time, the lord of Wu’s envoy, Zhang Wen, was in Shu, and his attendants happened to meet the ginger-buyer. Startled, they wrote a letter to send home. The buyer returned with the ginger to the palace kitchens, and the steamed fish was prepared.

Jie Xiang could also read all talismanic scripts as if reading a book, without error. When some doubted him, they took various talismans, removed their annotations, and showed them to him. Jie Xiang distinguished each one without fail.

Another man planted millet in the mountains and was constantly troubled by macaques eating it. Hearing of Jie Xiang’s mastery of the Dao, he sought a method to repel the monkeys. Jie Xiang told him there was no other way but this: “Tomorrow, go to your millet field. When you see a troop of monkeys, do not shout loudly but say to them, ‘I have already informed Master Jie, and he has instructed you not to eat the millet.’” The man, taken aback, thought Jie Xiang was deceiving him. The next day, when he saw the monkeys about to descend from the trees, he tried speaking as instructed. The monkeys immediately retreated to the farthest branches.

Jie Xiang repeatedly requested to leave Wu, but the lord would not permit it. He then declared that he would fall ill on a certain day. The lord sent attendants to bestow upon him a box of pears. Jie Xiang ate them and died in an instant. The lord had him buried. Though he died at midday, by dusk that same day, he had already arrived in Jianye. There, he gave the pears he had been bestowed to the palace gardeners to plant. Later, the gardeners reported this to the lord, who opened the coffin to find only a wooden tablet with a talisman.

The lord, missing Jie Xiang, converted his residence into a temple and frequently went in person to offer sacrifices. Often, a white crane would alight upon the seat and remain for a long while before departing. Later, his disciples saw Jie Xiang in the Gai Zhu Mountains, his complexion even more youthful than before.

*Record of Perfected Immortals Through the Ages Who Embodied the Dao, Scroll Fifteen Concludes*
*Record of Perfected Immortals Through the Ages Who Embodied the Dao, Scroll Sixteen*

Dong Feng, styled Junyi, was a native of Houguan County in Fuzhou. During the reign of the former lord of Wu, a young man once served as magistrate of his home county. At the time, Junyi was over thirty, though the magistrate did not know he possessed the Dao. More than fifty years later, the magistrate returned to another post and passed through Houguan. All the former officials and clerks went to see their old superior, and Junyi also went. His complexion remained as before, entirely unchanged. The former magistrate, who had known him long ago, asked, "Do you cultivate the Dao? When you were in the county all those years ago, those of your age are now white-haired, yet you remain youthful." Junyi replied, "It is merely happenstance."

Du Xie, serving as Inspector of Jiaozhou, contracted a poisonous illness and died. Three days had passed when Junyi, who was then in the south, went to him. He placed three medicinal pellets into the dead man’s mouth and had others lift Xie’s head to help him swallow them. After the time it takes to eat a meal, Xie opened his eyes and moved his limbs. His complexion gradually returned, and within half a day, he could sit up. He revived completely. Four days later, he was able to speak and recounted, "At the moment of death, it was as if I had fallen into a dream. I saw dozens of black-clad men come to take me away. They placed me on a dew cart and entered through a great vermilion gate, then delivered me directly to a prison. Each cell had but a single door, just wide enough for one person. They put me into one and sealed it from the outside with earth, so I could no longer see beyond. In a daze, I heard someone say, ‘The Great One has sent an envoy to summon Du Xie. Quickly, open the door and let him out.’ I heard people digging at the cell with shovels, and after a long while, they pulled me out. Outside, I saw carriages and horses with vermilion canopies. Three men sat together in one carriage. One held a tally and called for Du Xie to board. They were about to return to the gate when I awoke."

After Xie revived, he had a tall tower built for Junyi in his central courtyard. Junyi did not consume ordinary food, eating only dried meat and jujubes, though he greatly enjoyed drinking wine. Three times a day, Xie would prepare a feast for him, and Junyi would come to his residence to eat and drink. When descending the tower, he would suddenly seem like a flying bird, instantly arriving at his seat without any sense of moving downward. Ascending was the same. This continued for three years, until Junyi sought to leave. Xie wept and begged him to stay, but Junyi did not consent.

Xie asked, "Where do you wish to go? I shall prepare a great ship for you." Junyi replied, "No ship is needed—only a coffin will suffice." Xie then had one prepared. By midday the next day, Junyi had died. Xie ordered his burial. Seven days later, a traveler from Yanchang arrived and saw Junyi, who thanked Duke Du, urging him to take good care of himself. Xie then opened Junyi’s coffin and found only a piece of silk bearing a talisman inscribed in cinnabar.

Later, Junyi returned to live beneath Mount Lu. A young man afflicted with leprosy, near death, carried himself to Junyi, kowtowed, and begged for mercy. Junyi had the man sit in a room, covering his eyes with five layers of cloth and warning him not to move. He instructed his household to keep away. The man said, "I felt something come and lick me—so painful I could not endure it. Its tongue seemed about a foot long, its breath as heavy as an ox’s. I do not know what it was, but after a long while, it left." Junyi then returned, removed the blindfold, gave the man water to drink, and sent him away, saying, "You will soon recover. Only avoid the wind." After ten days, the man’s body turned entirely red, skinless and in agony, but bathing in water eased the pain. After twenty days, new skin grew, and his sores healed, leaving his body smooth as congealed fat.

Once, during a great drought when all grains withered, the county magistrate Ding Shiyan said to his clerks, "Master Dong possesses the Dao and must be able to summon rain." He personally brought wine and dried meat to Junyi and explained the suffering caused by the drought. Junyi replied, "Rain is easily obtained." Looking up at his roof, he said, "A poor man’s house lets in the sky—how can rain be summoned here?" The magistrate understood and said, "Master, only pray for rain, and I shall have a proper roof built for you." The next day, Shiyan led his officials and laborers to gather bamboo and timber to construct a house. When it was finished, they prepared to plaster the walls, digging earth to mix with water for mortar. Junyi said, "No need to fetch water—by dusk, rain will come of its own." That night, a great rain fell, filling both high and low places.

Junyi dwelled in the mountains, healing the sick with incantations and water, never accepting money or goods. Instead, he instructed those cured of serious illnesses to plant five apricot trees, and those with minor ailments to plant one. Over several years, he amassed over seventy thousand trees, which grew into a dense forest. Beneath the apricots, beasts and insects of the mountain roamed freely, yet no weeds grew, as if the ground had been meticulously tended. When the apricots ripened, Junyi built a granary beneath the trees and told the villagers, "Those who wish to buy apricots need not announce themselves—simply take them. Place a measure of grain in the granary, and take an equal measure of apricots." If someone took more apricots than the grain they offered, three or four tigers would glare and chase them. Terrified, the person would flee, the apricots spilling, and the tigers would depart. Upon returning home, they would find the apricots matched the grain they had given. Others who stole apricots without leaving grain would find their families dead upon returning home. Only after returning the apricots and kowtowing in apology would the dead revive. From then on, those buying apricots measured them fairly in the grove, daring no deceit.

Junyi used the grain he received to relieve the poor and aid travelers, distributing three thousand *hu* each year, yet still having much left over. The magistrate’s relative had a daughter possessed by a malevolent spirit, and no one could cure her. He told Junyi, "If you heal her, I shall give her to you as a wife." Junyi summoned the spirits, and a great white dragon, sixteen feet long, slithered overland to the girl’s door. Junyi ordered it slain, and the girl recovered. The magistrate then gave his daughter to Junyi in marriage. For a long time, they had no children, and as Junyi often traveled, his wife could not live alone. He adopted a ten-year-old girl to keep her company. One day, Junyi received a mandate from the Supreme Emperor, appointing him Overseer of the Azure Void and Perfected Man of the Great One. He ascended in broad daylight. His wife and adopted daughter continued to live in his house, selling apricots. If anyone cheated them, tigers chased them as before. The adopted daughter grew up and married, but her husband was a violent man who often stole sacred robes and objects from temples. The temple deity spoke through a shaman, saying, "So-and-so relies on being the immortal’s son-in-law to steal my clothes. I am not here, so I can only shame him. For the immortal’s sake, I shall not pursue the matter."

Junyi lived among the people for a hundred years, his complexion ever like that of a man in his thirties. After his ascension, people built a shrine on the site of the apricot grove, calling it the Palace of the Great One. Emperor Zhenzong of the Song bestowed the name *Da Zhongxiangfu Guan*, and Emperor Huizong of the Song, during the Xuanhe era, posthumously enfeoffed him as Perfected Man of Ascending Primordiality. Some say that south of Zhongli County in Haozhou lies Apricot Mountain, where Dong Feng planted his trees.

Yao Guang—Yao Guang was a man of unknown origin.

Having mastered the Dao of divine elixirs, he could divide his form and scatter his shadow, sit or stand at will and vanish, remain unscorched by fire, and unharmed by blades. The King of Wu personally tested him: stacking thousands of bundles of reeds, he had Yao Guang sit within them and set fire to the pile on all sides. The smoke and flames blotted out the sun, and the onlookers filling the capital all believed Yao Guang would be reduced to ashes. Yet when the fire died down, Yao Guang emerged from the ashes, shaking out his robes, his countenance as composed as ever. In his hand he held a scroll, which the King of Wu read but could not comprehend. Later, his whereabouts became unknown.

Xu Wan—Xu Wan was a native of Haiguan in Wu Commandery. From a young age, he possessed Daoist arts and could subdue malevolent spirits. A girl of the Du family in Qiantang suffered from a demonic affliction. Xu Wan performed a ritual to summon the specter, and suddenly a man clad in a white linen robe entered the door. With a single shout from Xu Wan, the man transformed into a white tortoise. One day, Xu Wan went with several of his cousins to Stone Ridge Mountain to gather spring firewood. As dusk fell, he did not return. The next morning, they searched but found no trace of him—until they suddenly saw him on the mountain, his sickle tucked under his arm, leaning against a tree, motionless. They embraced him, only to find an empty husk.

Master Mao—The Perfected One’s surname was Mao, his given name Ying, and his courtesy name Shushen. He was a native of Nanguan in Xianyang. His ancestral line descended from the Ji clan, and his family took the name Mao, accumulating virtue and benevolence over generations, their blessings flowing through a hundred ages. Their descendants were born with luminous wisdom, succeeding one another in an unbroken line.

His great-great-grandfather, whose given name was Meng and courtesy name Chucheng, possessed profound insight into the mysteries and surveyed the rise and fall of states. Foreseeing the decline of Zhou, he refused to serve any of the feudal lords and instead became a disciple of Master Guigu of Beiguo Bei’e. He then retreated into seclusion on Mount Hua, dwelling on the western peak Lingfeng, roaming the secluded valleys, contemplating the immortals, and maintaining a lofty detachment from the world of mortals.

His great-grandfather, whose given name was Yan and courtesy name Taineng, was the fourth son of Meng. He served during the reign of King Zhaoxiang of Qin, beginning as a Gentleman of the Palace and later rising to the rank of Cavalry Colonel and Marquis of Changping, known for his loyalty and integrity. He rendered meritorious service to his time.

His grandfather, whose given name was Jia and courtesy name Zhenglun, served King Zhuangxiang of Qin as Marquis of Guangxin. At that time, Qin had already annexed Ba, Shu, Hanzhong, and the regions of Wan and Ying, establishing Nanjun. To the north, it had seized Shangjun and the lands eastward, establishing Hedong, Taiyuan, and Shangdang, extending east to Xingyang, annihilating the Two Zhous, and establishing Sanchuan Commandery. Lü Buwei was appointed Chancellor and enfeoffed as Marquis Wenxin, tasked with attracting wandering scholars and strategists to unify the realm. When the First Emperor ascended the throne, Jia assisted the imperial house and was enfeoffed as Marquis Dexin. In the sixth year of his reign, Han, Wei, Zhao, Wei, and Chu jointly attacked Qin (the *Zizhi Tongjian* records that Qin was attacked by the five states of Chu, Zhao, Wei, Han, and Yan, who seized Shouling). The First Emperor dispatched Jia to lead troops against them, achieving great merit. When Wei was pressed toward its eastern capital, Jia again subdued it, pacifying the region. The First Emperor, admiring Jia’s resolve and integrity, bestowed upon him five thousand catties of gold. In the twenty-fifth year, Qin launched a massive military campaign, sending Jia to attack Liaodong in Yan. He captured the King of Yan and returned. He was then dispatched to pacify the Jiang region of Jing, and the southern lands all submitted. That same year, Kuaiji Commandery was established, and Jia was sent to lead troops there but vanished. The First Emperor, mourning his loyalty, buried him with the rites of a Chancellor on the southwestern slope of Longshou Mountain in Chang’an.

Jia had six sons, all renowned in their time. The First Emperor granted them official ranks and titles to honor their father, each receiving a surname. His sixth son, whose given name was Zuo and courtesy name Yanying, neither sought office nor pursued scholarship, content to live as a farmer. He was Mao Ying’s father.

Zuo had three sons: the eldest, whose given name was Ying and courtesy name Shushen; the second, whose given name was Gu and courtesy name Jiwei; and the youngest, whose given name was Zhong and courtesy name Sihe. Mao Ying was born in the fifth year of Emperor Jing of Han’s Zhongyuan era (the bingshen year). From childhood, he possessed extraordinary conduct, his natural talent shining brightly. He harbored lofty aspirations and distant ambitions, neither seeking fame nor associating with the unworthy. He delighted in purity and emptiness, his heart tranquil and his spirit attuned to the mysteries. At the age of eighteen, he abandoned his home and left his family, entering Mount Heng, where he studied the *Laozi’s Dao and Virtue Classic* and the *Zhouyi Commentaries*, gathering mountain herbs to consume as food. Dwelling in secluded cliffs and pristine valleys, he aspired to the sublime, forever estranged from the world.

In the thirtieth year of the First Emperor’s reign, on the gengzi day of the ninth month, Mao Ying’s great-great-grandfather Meng, who had studied under Master Guigu on Mount Hua, ascended to heaven in broad daylight, riding clouds and dragons. Earlier, a folk song in his hometown had foretold:

*"The immortal attained is Mao Chucheng,*
*Riding dragons to ascend into the Great Clarity,*
*Now descending to the Dark Continent to sport in Red City.*
*In generations to come, it shall be our Ying,*
*If the Emperor learns this, let the twelfth month be renamed Jiaping."*

When the First Emperor heard the song, he inquired about its meaning. The village elders explained, "This is an immortal’s song, exhorting the Emperor to seek longevity." Thereupon, the First Emperor joyfully conceived the desire to seek immortals and renamed the twelfth month Jiaping.

After six years on Mount Heng, Mao Ying’s devotion to the supreme Dao evoked a profound response. In his dreams, he communed with divine discourse, and one day, a transcendent jade maiden of the Great Mystery appeared before him, holding a jade tablet. She said, "In the Western City resides Lord Wang, who has attained the Dao. He can be your teacher. Why do you not seek him out and receive his teachings?" Mao Ying was awakened and inspired. He climbed perilous peaks and traversed rugged paths to reach the Western City. After three months of fasting and purification, he bathed and faced the sacred realm. Pushing through brambles and braving dangers, he prostrated himself before the divine precinct and finally beheld Lord Wang.

Twenty years later, he followed Lord Wang west to Mount Gui, where he met the Queen Mother of the West. Mao Ying kowtowed and bowed twice, addressing the Queen Mother: "I, Mao Ying, am a humble and lowly being, a remnant of withered bones. How dare I, with my unworthy frame, aspire to the lifespan of dragons and phoenixes? How can one of ephemeral existence seek the duration of endless ages? Though I gaze upon the distant current, I know not how to cross the ford, for the path is blocked and impassable, and my desires find no refuge. I constantly fear that one day I shall perish in the calamity of the mundane world, becoming a laughingstock to the vulgar."

Thus, in days past, he bore his pack into the secluded groves, craving the life his master bestowed. There he encountered Lord Wang, who took pity on Mao Ying’s earnest suffering and imparted to him the essentials of bodily cultivation and the method of absorbing qi. Thereafter, he retired to a quiet chamber in profound seclusion to practice these arts. His master further instructed him, saying: “Your body is not of jade or stone, nor does it possess an enduring master within; your qi does not arise from the four seasons as an unceasing inner spring. You must properly guide its ingress and egress, regulate your breath to achieve harmony, refine your fluids through cultivation, and align form and spirit without error. When resonance and reflection accumulate, the hun and po will not stagnate; when principle accords with its proper measure and qi is tempered to its rightful state, then the essence of form will not wither, and the dwelling of the spirit will not decay.

“If, however, the spirit is wearied by constant to-and-fro, and the fluids are taxed by ceaseless outflow and inflow, then the form will daily wither, the spirit will likewise fade, the years will diminish from their beginning, and the months will wane from their former fullness. You must seek with subtle discernment the benefits of enduring transformation.”

The Queen Mother of the West said: “Your heart has reached true sincerity. In former times, my own masters—the Primordial Celestial King of the Origin and the Great Emperor Lord of the Fusang Tree—entrusted me with essential teachings. Do you wish to hear them?”

Thereupon, she orally transmitted to Mao Ying the Dao of the Jade Pendant and Golden Wheel, along with the *Canon of the Supreme Ultimate and Mysterious Perfection*. Mao Ying bowed to receive her words and stood with head reverently lowered.

She further instructed him: “The Golden Wheel is the radiant canopy of the Upper Clarity, the inner perfection of the yin luminants. The Jade Pendant is the hidden mystery of the Supreme Lord, the treasured script of the Cavernous Flight. Those who attain this Dao ascend through the rosy clouds, roam the eight poles, repose in the high void, and wander the Purple Emptiness.”

The words spoken earlier by the Primordial Celestial King and the Great Emperor Lord were the esoteric writings of the Two Luminants of the Grand Empyrean, the texts of the Jade Pendant and Golden Wheel. There are also the inner true writings of the yin and yang luminants, which accompany the original texts. By the law of the Supreme Lord, these are to be transmitted only to the Directors of Destinies. You, Mao Ying, are divinely chosen and inscribed in jade; your name is carved in gold, your inner radiance shines with yellow brilliance, and your pure script belongs to the Upper Clarity. It seems you are destined to become a Lord of the Upper Ministers, entrusted with the office of Director of Destinies. This Dao shall later be bestowed upon you in full.

“Yet without first mastering the Dao of the Mysterious Perfection of the Hall of Light, you cannot obtain the esoteric writings of the Grand Empyrean.”

Thereupon, Mao Ying took leave of his master and returned home. Though he dwelt among the common folk, he did not conform to worldly ways. He later recounted that he entered the northern valley of Mount Heng to study the teachings of the Confucians, at which time he was forty-nine years of age.

His parents were still living. When his father saw him, he flew into a rage, reproaching his son for unfilial conduct, for failing to attend to their care. He accused him of pursuing delusions and drove him away, declaring, “I shall disown you as if you had never been born!” He sought to beat him with a staff. Mao Ying knelt in obeisance and pleaded: “I have received a mandate to attain the Dao. The laws of the Dao and the affairs of the world cannot both be served. Though I am far from your daily care, I bring no momentary benefit, yet I can ensure the peace of our household and the long life of my parents.

“I have already received the talismans and registers of my sagely master. Those who assist me are the soldiers of the Celestial Ding, and those who attend me are the jade maidens and immortal youths. Now that my Dao is accomplished, I cannot be struck, for even a minor official’s investigation would not be a trivial matter.”

His father, outwardly bound by ritual propriety, had not yet grasped the inner subtleties. The mysterious realm of the Dao remained beyond his understanding. Thus, Mao Ying demonstrated his true condition to dispel the doubts of the multitude.

Then, as his father raised the staff toward Mao Ying, poised to strike, the staff suddenly shattered into dozens of fragments, each flying like loosed arrows—those that struck the wall pierced it through, and those that struck the pillar sank deep into the wood. His father, awakened to the extraordinary, abandoned his anger and desisted.

Mao Ying said, “What I warned of earlier was precisely this: had the blow fallen upon another, injury would have been unavoidable.”

By the time of Emperor Xuan of Han, both of Mao Ying’s younger brothers had risen to prominence. Mao Zhong served as Grand Master of the Five Officials and Governor of Xihe, while Mao Gu became Commandant of the Capital. As they prepared to assume their posts, hundreds from their hometown gathered to see them off. Mao Ying, also present, addressed the guests: “Though I do not hold a two-thousand-bushel office, I too have a celestial appointment. Next year, on the third day of the fourth month, you shall know. Could you gather again as we do today?” The assembly agreed, for it was the fourth year of Emperor Yuan’s *Chuyuan* reign.

The following year, the guests assembled as before. On the appointed day, several *qing* of land before Mao Ying’s gate suddenly leveled itself, not a blade of grass or speck of dust remaining, all covered in azure silk that draped over the eaves. Beneath the roof, layers of white felt were spread, enough to seat hundreds. Word spread far and wide, and the road was choked with those who came—far more than had gathered to send off his brothers. As the guests assembled, Mao Ying played the gracious host, yet no servants were seen. Instead, golden platters and jade cups appeared of their own accord before each guest, bearing rare delicacies and fruits beyond naming, and wine of surpassing excellence. There were also musicians—strings, winds, bells, and chimes—whose music shook heaven and earth, while the fragrance of musk and orchid drifted for miles. Over six hundred dined and drank, all sated and intoxicated.

The next day, when the officials arrived to welcome them, hundreds of civil officers in crimson robes and white sashes appeared, while the military escort bore armor, weapons, and banners that blazed like the sun. Mao Ying took leave of his family and kin, then addressed his clansmen: “The true Dao of immortals is hidden, its glory veiled at the edges, not meant to dazzle the eyes or deafen the ears. That I cannot silently withdraw into obscurity or ascend the empty peaks of Mount Kongtong is only to inspire my younger brothers to follow this path. How could it be only Gu and Zhong who turn from delusion? All under heaven with hearts inclined should aspire to the hope of attaining transcendence.”

Having spoken, he returned to Mount Juyu, which the people thereafter called the Mountain of Lord Mao. Meanwhile, his brothers, still in office, heard of Mao Ying’s divine feats—how he walked upon the void, crossed waves as if treading land, and was attended by spirit officials, his fame on every tongue, his banners and standards illuminating the world. Only then did they believe that immortality could be cultivated and the divine attained, that Wang Qiao and Chisongzi were no mere legends, and that the tripod of Mount Dinghu was real.

Thereupon, they both resigned their posts and returned home. In the year corresponding to their birth signs, they began to practice the remnants of Mao Ying’s teachings. Yet without the oral instructions, they gained no benefit. Sighing together, they said, “Our elder brother has attained the Dao—who else could it be? If we do not go to him and ask for the secret instructions, but remain here studying these common methods, how can we hope to grasp the Way?” Resolved, they abandoned their homes, carrying their own provisions, and set out in search of him.

In the second year of Emperor Yuan’s *Yongguang* reign, on the sixth day of the third month, they crossed the Yangtze to seek their brother on the Eastern Mountain. At last, they met, tears of sorrow and joy mingling. Mao Ying said, “Why have you awakened so late?”

His brothers knelt and replied, “Gu and Zhong were dull and ignorant, blind to the Dao. We beg you to grant us long life and salvation.”

Mao Ying said, “You are already old—it will be difficult to restore you. Even with the true instructions, you may only become earthbound immortals. Ascending to the great heights of the heavens is beyond what I have studied. For now, I will teach you gradual steps, easier practices to sustain yourselves.”

Thereupon, he instructed them in the Way of swallowing the first sprouts of green teeth and circulating saliva, a method to stanch the flow of blood, replenish desiccation, and strengthen sinews and bones—a practice to prolong life without death. After three years of strict fasting, he transmitted the higher Dao, teaching them to visualize the *qi* of the Mysterious True within the Hall of Light, to refine and circulate generative essence, and to harmonize the spirit and soul. Within three years, through sincere and concentrated effort, their divine radiance manifested. Then the Six Ding spirits attended them, and celestial soldiers guarded them.

Mao Ying also bestowed upon each a dose of Nine-Turn Returning Elixir and a divine formula. They bowed, consumed them, and attained the immortal Dao. Later, he gave each a scroll of Purple Silk Script, a hundred characters long, which Gu and Zhong received with reverence.

Some still harbored doubts, so Mao Ying revealed the Purple Silk Text, which read:

*“By the command of the Supreme, the Heaven-Bearing True Scripture declares: Mao Gu of Xianyang, dwelling at the Southern Pass, styled Jiwei, is destined for transcendence. His rank is Fixed Record, and he oversees the earthly immortals. He is to recommend the worthy and the Dao-endowed, whose lifespans are intertwined. Through diligence and reverence, he upholds the laws of the Four Poles. His palaces and towers are established on Mount Juyu in Danyang. Gu, be vigilant—your every movement is observed.”*

And further:

*“Mao Ying and his brother Zhong, of pure and accomplished virtue, though versed in returning to the correct path, have probed the subtle and perfected sincerity. They have severed ties with the Six Heavens and displayed keen discernment. Now they are humbled to the Three Offices, preserving life and establishing their names. They govern Mount Tai, record life and death, and hold the rank of Earth Immortal. As luminaries of the Nine Palaces, they instruct the young, open the path to power, and teach the women’s quarters. They are entrusted with wondrous numina, govern the hundred ghosts, oversee the spirits, and examine the sources of rivers. They regulate the flow of the Yangtze and seas, seal the Golden Valley, and store the Jade Liquor. They oversee the cultivation of dragon mushrooms and luminous herbs of the caves. They govern Mount Liangchang, stand at the mouth of the Northern Grotto, and guard the gate of the Dark Palace.”*

The messenger delivered the scripture and departed.

In the second year of *Yuanshou* of Emperor Ai of Han, on the *jiyou* day of the eighth month, the Five Themes each rode their directional chariots, accompanied by their retinues of officials, descending to receive the mandate of the Great Emperor. They bestowed upon Ying the title of *Supreme Minister of the Eastern Marchmount and Lord Controller of Destiny*. The decree was inscribed on purple jade tablets in golden characters. Its text read:

“Whereas Ying, born of emptiness and clarity, has long been steeped in the subtle mysteries of the profound; from childhood, he let his hair loose upon the Northern Mountains, stilled his heart amidst forests and marshes, and with concentrated spirit sought the divine. He scaled perilous peaks and traversed deep valleys, enduring hardship in his quest for a master’s gate. Casting off his form in utter abandon, he flung himself across ten thousand fords; with cinnabar sincerity and untrammeled nature, he followed the promptings of Heaven. Thus he attained the radiant craftsman and received the numinous scriptures ninefold. He sheared his hair in solemn vow, severed his head and body in sacrifice, girded himself with ropes in joy, and scorned hunger and cold. His path was the Dao alone; his safeguard, authenticity. His heart shone before the Supreme Emperor, and his fervor moved the Great Mystery.

Now, with reverence, We appoint Ying as *Great Perfected of the Primordial Origin* and *Supreme Minister of the Eastern Marchmount and Lord Controller of Destiny*. You have aligned your heart with uprightness, held fast to integrity firm as metal and stone, and with a cinnabar heart outshone the multitude, your spirit soaring in lofty radiance. Therefore, We bestow upon you the *Jade-Iron Green Banner and the Eight Might-Wielding Staff*, that you may subdue the sources of streams and marshes and vanquish the myriad spirits.

You have endured cold in forest valleys, savored the mysterious and gazed upon the real, your thoughts stirred by secluded peaks, your heart opened in pure sincerity. Therefore, We grant you the *Purple Tassel Staff and the Lotus-Blossom Crown*, that you may summon and command the myriad numina, seal mountains, and call forth clouds.

You have forsaken home and journeyed alone, parted from kin to delight in immortality, embraced hardship in your duties, and bared your breast to the mountains and rivers in winter. Therefore, We bestow upon you the *Embroidered Feather Purple Robe and the Vermilion-and-Indigo Flying Skirt*, that you may ascend the celestial steps with ease and bear the mandate of the Jade Perfected.

You have traversed marshes and trodden perilous cliffs, your heart devoted and your aspirations lofty, undaunted by fear. Therefore, We grant you the *Spotted Dragon Chariot and the White Tiger Plow*, that you may float upon the luminous void and soar to the imperial court.

You have pushed through brambles to merge with the light, endured cold and braved frost and snow, your heart seeking the radiant and true, unwavering and unafraid. Therefore, We bestow upon you the *Curved Dawn Jeweled Canopy and the Jasper Curtain Green Chamber*, that you may roam and gaze upon the Nine Palaces, your spirit serene in tranquil seclusion.

You have shunned worldly glory and withdrawn in reclusion, your heart untroubled, your form hidden in secluded peaks, your thoughts stilled amidst the myriad forests. Therefore, We grant you the *Flowing Gold Fire Bells and the Twin Pearl Moonlight*, that you may ascend to the Supreme Ultimate and communicate your voice to the *Upper Clarity*.

Your true heart is lofty and still, untouched by excess or entanglement, naturally resplendent, inwardly and outwardly at peace. Therefore, We bestow upon you the *Brocade Banner and Embroidered Pennant, the White Feather Black Staff*, that you may summon the Six Yin and command the Jade Maidens to attend your chariot.

Your kindness extends to all things, your hidden virtue nurtures the myriad beings, and even the tiniest creatures are tended with care. Therefore, We grant you the *Phoenix and Luan Flutes, the Golden Bell and Jade Chime*, that you may harmonize the spirits in the empty halls and delight the Perfected with dances of the numina.

You have nourished your spirit through hunger and thirst, sought the true through hardship, undeluded by the myriad things, your purity uncorrupted by a thousand evils. Therefore, We bestow upon you the *Purple Essence of the Lin Tree and the Jade Liquor in Golden Vessels*, that your life may equal the Three Luminaries and your name be inscribed upon the cinnabar jade tablets.

Ying, you preside over the pure and mysterious, your purple jade gleams with eightfold radiance, your heart shines with the brilliance of the double sun, and your spirit blazes with the great rosy clouds. Truly, you are foremost among the Perfected, and thus We honor you with the title *Great Primordial*. Your nine virtues are now complete, fully accumulated in the *Grand Tenuity*; Heaven and humanity dwell in empty whiteness, and without seeking, they converge as one. Now We requite your nine deeds to repay your past aspirations.

Ying, your heart and spirit are now radiant, the Four Numinous Ones abide within you, your cinnabar spirit shines forth, and you hold fast to uprightness without wavering. Your integrity is whole and steadfast, and your oversight leaves nothing unseen. Now We appoint you as *Minister of the Supreme Office* to govern the Eastern Marchmount. We further entrust you with the duty of *Controller of Destiny* to oversee the recording of registers and charts. We assign forty Jade Boys and forty Jade Maidens to attend you, that you may enter and exit the *Grand Tenuity* and serve in the *Supreme Ultimate*.

Your administrative palace is the *Red City Jade Grotto Residence*; govern it with care, and report all activities without fail.”

Thereupon, Ying took leave of his two younger brothers, Yu and Zhong, and departed with the Perfected Lord Wang for the *Red City Jade Grotto Residence*. As they passed through the mountains and rivers, the spirits and officials in charge came forth to welcome, guide, and follow them—numbering in the thousands and tens of thousands. Before departing, Ying addressed his two brothers: “I now leave and assume my duties, and we shall no longer be able to visit each other frequently. Though we may see each other morning and evening, it will be a thousand years before I return to this mountain. Mark these dates: on the eighteenth day of the third month and the first day of the twelfth month, my master, the *Great Void Red City Perfected of the Southern Marchmount*, will visit you here. Remember this well. If any aspirants to the Dao await me here, I shall personally attend to them, instructing and guiding those who have not yet awakened.”

Thereupon, Jiwei and Sihe remained to govern this mountain grotto, establishing palaces and structures outside. They spread the Dao to nurture the myriad things, bestowing moisture upon the mortal world, their virtue extending to birds and beasts, each attaining its true nature. Their spiritual efficacy revealed fortune and misfortune, and all sins and transgressions were made manifest. With inner teachings harmonized and outer teachings at peace, wind and rain came in due season, the five grains ripened, pestilence did not arise, and calamities were averted.

The *True Records* state: Yu held the position of *Perfected of Juqu* and *Recorder of the Right Prohibitions*; Zhong held the office of *Controller of Destiny in the Three Offices, Preserver of Life*.

The village elders sang:
“Maoshan joins Jinling,
Lakes and rivers lie downstream.
Three divinities ride white wagtails,
Each presiding o’er a mountain’s crown.
Sweet rains drench the parched rice,
Dry fields’ seedlings grow supple too.
Wives and children keep their homes secure,
Freeing me from every care.
White cranes soar in azure clouds—
When shall they return to roam?”

Minister Daoyi said: Mao Ying, scion of true immortals, fulfilled the immortals’ prophecy, spurned the glory of tripods and cauldrons, and yearned for the teachings of the Mysterious Origin. Thus he fixed his resolve on the Dao, his purity moved the numinous, and through profound merit he attained success. Though wealth and nobility abounded, and his two younger brothers held lofty ranks and illustrious positions, Ying remained unmoved. To him, his brothers’ splendor was but a fleeting dream, a bubble, a shadow. Yet they had not yet awakened, so he manifested divine transformations to enlighten them, ultimately guiding both brothers to return to the □ Dao.

The *Daodejing* says:
“Music and fine food—
passing travelers pause.
The Dao, when spoken,
is bland, without flavor.
Look—it cannot be seen;
listen—it cannot be heard.
Yet its use is inexhaustible.”

Such was Mao Ying’s intent.

Han Chong
Han Chong, styled Changji, was a native of Piling in Wu Commandery.

In his youth, Han Chong was devoted to the Dao. The immortal Wang Zhangxuan of Linwu Cave once transmitted to him the method of the Flowing Pearl Elixir, which he reverently practiced with great efficacy. Zhangxuan told him, “By following this Way, you may still enter officialdom without hindering your ascent to immortality.” Chong thus served as Magistrate of Wanling, governing with benevolence and pacifying the people through the Dao. Tigers and wolves kept their distance, and locusts never alighted within his borders. Later promoted to Governor of Runan, he recognized the talent of his clerk, Yuan An, and recommended him for advancement. An would later rise to the position of Minister over the Masses, and contemporaries universally acknowledged Chong’s discernment in judging men.

Chong lived in simplicity, and the emperor, marveling at this, increased his salary to the rank of *zhong erqian shi*. When Emperor Xiaoming of the Later Han toured Runan, he visited Chong’s residence, where Chong had sent his wife to stay with a solitary elderly woman. Upon hearing of this, the emperor sighed, “Han Chong is truly tempered steel that does not melt.” He bestowed upon him fifty bolts of fine silk.

Chong governed the commandery for fourteen years, his transformative governance renowned as the finest in the realm. At the age of seventy-four, Zhangxuan transmitted to him the method of Hidden Liberation. He departed to enter Great Huo Mountain, where he received Zhangxuan’s technique of the Mud-Pill Cinnabar Gate for transcending the world. Today, he serves as Left Supervisor of the Central Bureau within the grotto.

The *Book of Han* records similar events, though its phrasing differs slightly.

Yuan An, styled Shaoping, began as a county clerk and, through successive promotions, rose to the Three Excellencies, passing away during the reign of Emperor He. He was the great-grandfather of Yuan Shao. During the Jin dynasty, there was also Feng Xi, who likewise served as Grand Master, their fame and rank being comparable.

After Han Chong achieved Hidden Liberation, he must have left behind an empty corpse. In Shangjin of Jin Commandery stands a towering tomb, long known as Han’s Mound. Some suspect it resembles the tomb of Lord Peach, and that this is merely an empty barrow, though later generations mistakenly call it the tomb of Sun Ce’s general, Han Dang.

*Comprehensive Mirror of Perfected Immortals Embracing the Dao Through the Ages*, Scroll Sixteen (concluded)
*Comprehensive Mirror of Perfected Immortals Embracing the Dao Through the Ages*, Scroll Seventeen

Feng Liang

Feng Liang was a native of Guanjun in Nanyanɡ. In his youth, he served as a county clerk. At the age of twenty, he was appointed as an attendant to welcome the Inspector. Ashamed of his lack of ambition, he smashed the linchpins of his carriage, tore his tattered robes, and fled. He studied the *Book of Songs*, the *Book of Rites*, and the *Book of Changes* under a teacher, and later learned Daoist arts and divination. His family believed him dead, but after fifteen years, he returned. He cultivated his resolve and integrity, maintaining strict discipline. Though the province and commandery summoned him with honors, he refused. The imperial court specially summoned him as a Filial and Incorrupt candidate of the highest rank, but halfway there, he abandoned the journey and returned home. At the time, the Three Excellencies vied to yield their positions to him, yet he declined to descend and accept. At the age of sixty-seven, he abandoned the world, crossed eastward into the mountains, and now resides in the Deer’s Approach Grotto. He was a man of Emperor An of the Later Han’s reign. The *Book of Han* records a similar account.

Lang Zong

Lang Zong, styled Zhongsui, was a native of Anqiu in Beihai. In his youth, he served as an official and became the magistrate of Wu County. He studied Daoist arts with precision and divined the winds and qi. One day, a violent wind passed through his window. He divined that a great fire would burn the Great Xia Gate in the capital and sent someone to verify it—indeed, it was so. When the various nobles heard of this, they summoned Zong as a Court Academician. Zong, ashamed to be appointed for his divination skills, removed his official seal and sash by night, shouldered his books, and fled.

Dwelling at the foot of Mount Hua, he consumed sesame pills, attained the Dao, and now resides in the Deer’s Approach Grotto on Mount Mao.

The *Book of Later Han* records Lang Zong’s affairs as follows: He mastered the *Changes* of Jing Fang, excelling in astrology, wind divination, the six-day and seven-part cycles, and the observation of qi to prognosticate fortune and misfortune. He often earned his livelihood through divination. Emperor An summoned him to respond to a policy discussion, and the various scholars endorsed him. Later, he was appointed magistrate of Wu County. One day, a sudden violent wind arose, and Zong divined that the capital would suffer a great fire. He noted the year and month, sent someone to verify it, and the event unfolded exactly as he had foretold. The nobles, upon hearing of this, memorialized the throne, and he was summoned as a Court Academician. Zong, ashamed to be recognized for his divinations, received the summons, hung his official seal and sash in the county courtyard, and fled, never again to serve in office.

His son, Chan, styled Zhiyuan, inherited his father’s arts and studied them with precision, gathering several hundred disciples. In the second year of Emperor Shun’s *Yangjia* reign (133 CE), he was summoned to the palace and presented eleven memorials, after which he was appointed Gentleman of the Palace. Upon returning home, he was later murdered by a fellow townsman, Sun Li.

Chunyu Shen

Chunyu Shen, styled Shuxian, was a native of Shangyu in Kuaiji. During the reign of Emperor Huan of the Han, he served as magistrate of a county in Xuzhou. In Emperor Ling’s time, he was summoned by the Grand General. From youth, he was devoted to the Dao, mastered arts of calculation, and consumed sesame and Solomon’s seal as elixirs. Later, he retired to Mount Wuwumu in Wu to live in seclusion, where he encountered the immortal Huichezi, who transmitted to him the *Scripture of the Rainbow Radiance Elixir*. Through cultivation, he attained the Dao and now resides in the Grotto’s Registry of Attainment as the Law-Enforcing Gentleman of the Standard-Bearing Bureau.

The *Triplex Unity of the Book of Changes* states: "During Emperor Huan’s reign, Chunyu Shutong of Shangyu received instruction from Xu, an Attendant in Xuzhou. Gazing upon the celestial patterns to discern disasters and anomalies, his predictions often proved accurate. For this discernment, the commandery recommended him as a fangshi, and he was promoted to Market Director of Luoyang." This account differs slightly, for there is no Mount Wuwumu in Wu. Both Jiaxing and Wuxing have Mount Tianmu; perhaps it is one of these.

Tao Jun

Tao Jun, styled Wengzhong, was a native of Qiantang. In his youth, he served as an assistant in the commandery, but later abandoned his post to study at the Imperial Academy, where he mastered classical arts and the interpretation of disasters and anomalies. In his later years, he became Governor of Jiaozhi. At the end of the Han, he renounced the world and entered Mount Zengcheng to study the Dao, where he encountered Dongguo Youping. Youping, a man of the Qin era who had long dwelled in seclusion in Mount Zengcheng and attained the Dao, taught Jun the method of refining qi with the Nine Essences to align the heart with the auxiliary stars. Jun cultivated this practice to perfection and now resides in the grotto, concurrently serving as the Controller of the Northern River and Director of Punishments for the Water Bureau. Though this position falls under the Registry of Attainment, in truth, he receives his duties from the Central Palace’s Discipline Office. The *Book of Han* makes no mention of these events.

The tomb now lies in Linping of Qiantang, its mound and altar still distinct, with descendants yet remaining. Locals have at times heard the sound of drums and horns nearby, so none dare encroach or damage it, all addressing it as the Tomb of Controller Tao. The Qiantang recluse Du Jing, who served Jing Chan, and the former worthy Xian Yinju, together composed poems in praise of his virtue, which are collected separately.

As for Youping, nothing further is recorded of note.

Liu Lan

Liu Lan, styled Zixiang, was a native of Yingchuan. From youth, he cherished the Dao and virtue, though his family was exceedingly wealthy. He often aided the poor and distressed, delighting in bestowing hidden kindnesses and secret favors. When Zhang Jizha of Chenliu was returning to mourn his teacher, his funeral carriage broke down and his ox faltered, leaving him stranded on the road in Runan. Lan encountered him and spoke with him without revealing his name, then immediately offered his own carriage and ox for Zhang’s use. He aided the bereaved and rescued the destitute on more than one occasion.

Later, when Lan was in Chang’an, he was recommended for office. Upon arriving in the capital, the Emperor praised his heart and appointed him Gentleman of the Palace, then promoted him to Governor of Chenliu. For five hundred *li* beyond Chang’an, he gathered the dead and succored the poor, diminishing himself to share with others. While traveling through Yangping, he encountered Master Ma Huang, who told him: “Your benevolent heart has moved Heaven, and your hidden virtues have touched gods and spirits. The Supreme One will commend your sincerity and has sent me to impart to you the Dao of longevity. I am an immortal official—would you be willing to follow me?”

Lan then knocked his head upon the ground and struck his breast, saying: “From youth I have loved longevity. Now, by good fortune, I have met a divine immortal—pray, allow me to attend and serve you.” Master Ma Huang then led Lan into Mount Tongbai, where he transmitted the Eight Arts of Concealing the Earth and the method of ingesting the essence of the Five Stars. He now bears the name Donghua and resides in the grotto, serving as Right Supervisor of the Registry of Attainment.

The *Book of Han* states: “Lan, styled Zixiang, was a native of Yin. His family was wealthy, and he was ever able to bestow aid without considering it a favor. Once, while traveling through Runan, he encountered Zhang Jizha of Chenliu, who was hastening to a teacher’s funeral. Struck by cold and ice, Zhang’s carriage had broken down, leaving him stranded upon the road.”

Lan, seeing this, said to him: “You hasten to fulfill your duty with such reverence—your journey must not be delayed.” He then dismounted, gave Zhang his own carriage, and departed without revealing his name, urging his horse onward. Zhang Jizha suspected it was Lan Zixiang.

Later, when Zhang returned to Lingyin, he sought to return the borrowed carriage, but Lan shut his gate and refused to receive him. He remained steadfast in his resolve, lying ill in bed, declining all official summons. The prefect of Henan’s Shen□kou Commandery appointed him as a Merit Officer. When the Yellow Turban rebels arose, Lan aided those in dire distress, providing sustenance to several hundred. When villagers or clansmen perished, he ensured their burial; when widows or widowers lacked means, he assisted in their remarriage.

When Emperor Xian relocated the capital to the Western Metropolis, Lan was recommended as an Exemplary Filial and Incorrupt Candidate. At the time, bandits blocked the roads, so he traveled by night and hid by day, eventually reaching Chang’an. The emperor, admiring his loyalty and diligence, appointed him Gentleman-Consultant and later promoted him to Grand Administrator of Chenliu. Lan then distributed his treasures, keeping only his carriage and horses, and set out eastward on his own. Several hundred *li* beyond the pass, he came upon a scholar-official who had died by the roadside; he exchanged his horse for a coffin and removed his own robes to clothe the deceased.

Later, he encountered an old acquaintance starving by the road. Unable to bear leaving him, he slaughtered the ox pulling his carriage to feed the man. Others urged him to stop, but Lan said: “To see someone perish and not save them is no act of a man of resolve.” In the end, they both starved to death.

These accounts differ in minor details, so both are recorded here for consideration. Lan’s courtesy name, Zixiang, aligns with the naming conventions of the time, and the character *shuo* (朔) also carries fitting connotations—though it remains unclear which is correct.

**Lü Zihua**
Lü Zihua (or Lü Zi□hua) was a native of Shanyang.

The disciple of the Yin Lord had already consumed the liquid of rainbow elixir but had not yet studied the *Inner Canon*. He came to follow Shu Qing to receive the *Hidden Writ of the Grand Empyrean* and recited it twice daily, delighting in the secluded retreat of the Square Terrace. He had no desire to ascend to the rank of immortal.

**Cai Tiansheng**
Cai Tiansheng was a native of Shanggu. In his youth, he sold miscellaneous incense for the Whistling Master in the wilds to sustain himself. His nature was kind and sincere, and he never spoke ill of others. Once, while traveling, he encountered a young girl from Hebei who was purchasing incense from him. Tiansheng recognized her as an extraordinary being and, bowing twice, offered her a full load of incense. Moved by his gesture, the girl taught him the method of paying homage to the Heavenly Emperor and the Jade Sovereign. Thereupon, he attained immortality, assuming the form of a crow perched upon a staff, and secluded himself on the Square Terrace. The girl still visits him from time to time. Tiansheng became her disciple.

**Liu Ping’a**
Liu Ping’a had no given name and never revealed it to others. During the late Han, he served as the magistrate of Ping’a in Jiujiang, hence his sobriquet. He practiced medicine with great virtue, healing others’ illnesses as if they were his own. While traveling, he encountered the immortal Zhou Zhengshi, who transmitted to him the Dao of concealed existence. Assuming the form of straw sandals and a hat, he came to dwell on the Square Terrace of Mount Mao. To the southwest of Greater Mount Mao lies the Four-Year Mountain, commonly known as Square Mountain. At its base is a grotto named the Square Terrace. He regularly absorbed the morning qi of the sun and moon, his complexion like jade, appearing as a man of thirty or so.

**Zhang Jizi**
Zhang Jizi was a native of Henan, originally named Zhang Feng, courtesy name Gongxian. In his youth, he was called Jizi. This man also seldom disclosed his name. The Grand Tutor Yuan Chen admired his lofty conduct and married his daughter to him. The daughter’s attire was extravagant and ornate, but Feng paid it no heed, treating her no differently than a stranger. Only after she changed her garments did they become a proper household. Later, he abandoned the world and entered Mount Ke, where he encountered the Mountain Chart Noble. The Mountain Chart Noble had been a grandee during the reign of King Ai of Zhou and was an immortal. He transmitted to Jizi the *Nine Clouds’ Robust Jade Method*. Through cultivation, Jizi attained the Dao and now resides in the Eastern Florescence Palace, serving as an appointee of the Supreme Ultimate. At times, he oversees the Nine Palaces as Minister, working alongside the Northern River Marquis to govern waterways and examine the Northern River’s Controller of Destinies. At other times, he serves as the Marquis of Prohibitions and Protections, sharing duties with others for this purpose. The Northern River’s Controller of Destinies also governs within the grotto-heavens, working in tandem with Zhang Jizi.

The *Book of Wei* records: Zhang Fan, courtesy name Gongyi, was a native of Xiuwu in Henan. His grandfather Yin served as Minister over the Masses in the Han, and his father Yan was Grand Commandant. Yuan Yi of Taiwei wished to marry his daughter to Fan, but Fan declined. His nature was tranquil, and he delighted in the Dao, refusing all official summons. Later, he became a Gentleman Consultant and served as an aide in the arsenal of the Chancellor and Martial Lord, who held him in great esteem. He was fond of aiding the poor and destitute, leaving no surplus wealth in his household. He died in the seventeenth year of the Jian’an era. His younger brother, Cheng, courtesy name Gongxian, was also renowned. He was appointed Gentleman of Rectitude, Remonstrating Gentleman, Grand Master for Remonstrance, and Grand Administrator of Zhao Commandery. Later, he followed the Martial Lord on a western campaign and died of illness in Chang’an. The names and details here differ significantly: Cheng and Feng are similar but not Yuan’s sons-in-law. If this refers to Fan, their courtesy names do not match. Upon careful examination of the circumstances, it is likely that they were brothers. The *Book of Wei*’s *Biography of Wang Xiu* further states: Xiu frequently traveled to Nanyang and often lodged at Zhang Feng’s residence. When Feng’s entire household fell ill, Xiu nursed them back to health. However, Zhang Fan and his brother had once taken refuge in Yangzhou, seeking shelter with Yuan Wei—not Liu Biao—and should not have been in Nanyang. These inconsistencies raise doubts.

**Zhao Guangxin**
In the Minor White Mountains of Ke, there was a Daoist practitioner named Zhao Guangxin, a native of Yangcheng.

At the end of the Wei dynasty, he crossed the Yangtze and entered these mountains, where he received from Li Facheng the method of *fuqi* (absorbing qi) and from his master Zuo Jun the Way of Guarding the Mysterious Center and the technique of internal visualization to see clearly through the five viscera. For seventy or eighty years, he wandered among the commanderies and states. Sometimes he sold medicines among the people, yet none recognized him. He often came to the capital, where he refined cinnabar into Nine-Flowered Elixir. Upon completing the elixir, with a single dose, the Supreme One Dao Lord dispatched an envoy on the seventeenth day of the sixth month in the first year of Emperor Mu’s *Yonghe* reign (345 CE). After three days, he bid farewell to his fellow practitioners in the mountains, then rode clouds and mounted a dragon to ascend to heaven in broad daylight. He now resides in the Eastern Florescence Sea.

**Zhang Zuchang**
Zhang Zuchang was a native of Pengcheng. During the Wu dynasty, he came from the north and entered the Fang Terrace Grotto of Mount Mao. Zuchang feigned death in a carriage accident, concealing his form in a secluded abode while cultivating the practice of Guarding the One. His master was Bao Cha of Shangdang, a fifth-generation descendant of Bao Xuan, the Han dynasty Minister over the Masses. Cha received the Dao from Master Wang. Bao Xuan, a Han dynasty Colonel-Director of Retainers, was killed by Wang Mang. Xuan’s son was Yong, Yong’s son was Yu, and Yu’s son was [unnamed].

**Yu Wengsheng**
In the Langwu Mountains lived a Daoist practitioner named Yu Wengsheng, a native of Kuaiji. Formerly, he received from the immortal Jie Jun the method of consuming solar essence, and during the Wu era, he came to seclude himself in these mountains. He also practiced the Way of Cloud Qi and Returning the Form. Through prolonged and concentrated meditation, his body reverted to the youthfulness of a child. On the twenty-third day of the seventh month in the first year of Emperor Mu’s *Yonghe* reign (345 CE), the Eastern Great Emperor dispatched an envoy to welcome him. That very day, he ascended to heaven on clouds and now resides in the Yang Valley Mountains. The Langwu Mountains contain a sea, directly facing the White Chapter Shore and Valley, commonly called Wolf Mountain.

**Zhu Ruzi**
In the Red Waters Mountains lived a Daoist practitioner named Zhu Ruzi. At the end of the Wu dynasty, he entered the mountains and consumed chrysanthemum flowers and tree fungi. Later, he encountered the Master of Western Return, who transmitted to him essential instructions and the method of internal visualization of the *niwan* (mud-pill). After thirty years, he could summon clouds and rain within his grotto chamber. On the fifth day of the eighth month in the first year of Emperor Mu’s *Yonghe* reign (345 CE), the Queen Mother of the West sent an envoy to welcome him. That same day, he ascended to heaven in a five-colored cloud chariot and now resides on the Terrace of Accumulated Stones. The Red Waters Mountain is said to lie a thousand *li* south of Yin County, three hundred *li* inward from the mouth of the Xi Creek. The mountain itself is entirely red, spanning fifty *li* in circumference and rising over a thousand *zhang* in height. This likely corresponds to the so-called Red Rock in the northeast of Yongjia in Linhai. The Red Mountain where Master Xu resided, also called Burning Mountain, is this same place.

**Yin Qianzi**
In the Huayin Mountains lived Daoist practitioners Yin Qianzi, Zhang Shisheng, and Li Fangbai, all contemporaries of Emperor Wu of the Jin. They received from the immortal Guan Chengzi the method of steaming elixirs and consuming tree fungi, and all partook of them to prolong life and strengthen their movements. They further received from Zhou Shouling of Sumen the Way of Consuming Rosy Clouds. After fifty years of practice, their concentrated minds turned inward, and they no longer required food or drink. Their bodies became light and robust, their complexions like those of children. On the twelfth day of the second month in the first year of Emperor Mu’s *Yonghe* reign (345 CE), the Supreme One dispatched an envoy to welcome them. That day, they ascended to heaven on clouds. Now on the Dark Continent, they received scriptures and were appointed as Perfected Ones of the Lofty Mountain, with Zhang Shisheng as the Earl of Eastern Source.

**Zheng Jingshi**
In the Qian Mountains of Lujiang lived Daoist practitioners Zheng Jingshi and Zhang Chonghua. Both received oral instructions from the immortal Meng Deran at the beginning of the Jin dynasty and entered the mountains to practice the method of Guarding the Five Viscera and Containing the Sun, along with consuming sesame and the Dark Elixir. Over time, they no longer required food or drink, their bodies became light and strong, and they transformed their former forms. On the nineteenth day of the fourth month in the first year of Emperor Mu’s *Yonghe* reign (345 CE), the Northern Dark Elder Supreme One welcomed them with a cloud palanquin, and they ascended to heaven in broad daylight. They now reside on the Dark Continent.

**Ping Zhongjie**
In the Kuocang Mountains lived a Daoist practitioner named Ping Zhongjie, a native of Hezhong.

During the Great Hu’s chaos in the Central Plains, Ping fled across the Yangtze and entered the Kuocang Mountains, where he received from Master Song the Way of the Mind-Mirror and the practice of the Hundred Spirits traversing the Grotto-Chambers. After forty-five years of such concentrated cultivation, his body grew younger and was filled with true qi. On the first day of the fifth month in the first year of Emperor Mu’s *Yonghe* reign (345 CE), the Central Yellow Elder dispatched an envoy to welcome him. That very day, he rode clouds and drove dragons, ascending to heaven in broad daylight. He now resides in the Cloud Terrace of the Canglang. The "Great Hu’s chaos" refers to the time of Liu Yuan and Liu Cong, while Shi Le was the "Lesser Hu."

**Wu Mu**
Wu Mu was a native of Chang’an. In his youth, he served as a county clerk, abusing his office to extort the people. When one of his victims brought suit against him, the law demanded his execution. Mu abandoned his post and fled deep into the mountains. After days without food, he came upon a stone chamber where Master Sun was secluded in study. The chamber was surrounded by fields of millet and sesame, and its stores were ever full. Mu begged for food and stayed for a month without leaving. Though Master Sun knew he was a fugitive, he did not question him, instead providing meals, tending to his needs, and reciting scriptures while expounding the Dao, speaking of fortune and misfortune. Upon hearing this, Mu’s heart opened and his mind awakened. He knocked his head to the ground, striking his chest in remorse, recounting the origins of his crimes, the deeds of his former life, and confessing his wrongs, pleading for a chance to reform. He remained in the stone chamber, sweeping and serving the master. After forty years, the master transmitted the Dao to him, and together they gathered herbs and consumed sesame. Through diligent cultivation of the scriptural teachings, he attained three hundred and twenty years of life before ingesting the elixir and ascending to heaven in broad daylight.

**Guo Jing**
Guo Jing was a native of Yingchuan.

Guo Jing lost his parents in childhood, with neither siblings nor kin, and lived in destitution, drifting without refuge. At sixteen, the county summoned him to serve as a minor official. Later, he committed an offense and fled into hiding, remaining concealed for two months without venturing out by day. He encountered Master Zheng, who saved and instructed him in the Dharma, exhorting him with teachings of transformation. Jing then followed Zheng, carrying his burdens and serving him for seven years without敢懈怠. He received the essential methods of Daoist guidance and ingestion, consuming mountain herbs and fuling, and lived for three hundred years. Later, on Tianwei Mountain, Master Chisong descended, and the two attained the true Dao. Today, they dwell as Perfected Ones in the Dayou Grotto.

**Fan Bocien**
Fan Bocien was a native of Guiyang. His family was originally of the scholar-gentry, but he suddenly fell into madness and demonic possession, developing a chronic ailment that confined him to his bed for over a year. He sought out physicians and exorcists, depleting his family’s wealth, yet his illness remained uncured. Hearing that the Great Dao was pure and required no expenditure, his resolve shifted. Learning that Shen Jing, a diligent Daoist, had effectively treated many illnesses, he abandoned his secular physicians and followed him. After fifty days, his ailments were entirely healed. Later, he met Lu Wanzhi and received the true inner Dao. Wanzhi could not enter the mountains, but Bocien, discontent with the world, bid farewell and retreated into Tianmu Mountain. Consuming sesame and cultivating with deep concentration for seventeen years, the Perfected Lord of the Great Grotto and Controller of Destiny descended, bestowing upon him the thirty-six-scroll scripture. Having ingested the returning elixir, he ascended to heaven in broad daylight and now serves as the Perfected One of Primordial Unity.

**Han Weiyuan**
The Perfected One of Jiuyi, Han Weiyuan, once received teachings from Song Dexuan of Mount Song. Dexuan lived during the reign of King Xuan of Zhou, attained the Dao through ingesting the *Lingfei Liujia*, and could traverse three thousand *li* in a single day. He could transform his shape into birds and beasts, mastering the Way of Mystic Numinosity, and now resides on Mount Song. Weiyuan followed him for many years before receiving the method. Having perfected the Dao in practice, he now dwells on Mount Jiuyi.

**Liu Shaoweng**
Long ago, there was Liu Shaoweng, who repeatedly entered Mount Taihua to pay homage and bow toward the mountain. After twenty years of this, one day he suddenly beheld the Venerable Elder of the Western Peak, who bestowed upon him the Dao of immortality.

*End of Scroll Seventeen of the Comprehensive Mirror of Perfected Immortals Who Embodied the Dao*

*Scroll Eighteen of the Comprehensive Mirror of Perfected Immortals Who Embodied the Dao*

**Celestial Master Zhang**
The Perfected Celestial Master bore the surname Zhang, with the personal name Daoling and the courtesy name Fuhan. A native of Pei’s Fengyi County, he was the eighth-generation descendant of Zhang Liang, the Marquis of Liu. When Liang first traveled to Xiapi, he encountered the Yellow Stone Elder, who transmitted to him the *Unadorned Writ*. Later, he followed Emperor Gao of Han and rendered meritorious service, for which he was enfeoffed as a marquis. Cultivating his true nature and abstaining from grains, he took Red Pine as his teacher and friend, receiving the esoteric method of "flying steps" from the Eastern Garden Elder. He was posthumously titled the Marquis of Literary Achievement. His hidden virtues and concealed deeds left a fragrant legacy for later generations.

He had a son named Buyi. Buyi’s second son was Gao; Gao’s son was Tong; Tong’s son was Wuwang; Wuwang’s son was Liren; Liren’s son was Jue; Jue’s son was Qi; Qi’s son was Dashun. The Perfected One was Dashun’s eldest son.

His mother once dreamed of a celestial being descending from the Dipper’s *Kui* star, over a *zhang* in height, clad in embroidered robes, who bestowed upon her a fragrant rose. Upon waking, her clothing and chamber were suffused with an extraordinary fragrance that lingered for months. Moved by this, she conceived and gave birth on the fifteenth day of the first month in the *jiawu* year of Jianwu 10 (34 CE), during the reign of Emperor Guangwu of the Eastern Han, in the Wudi region of Mount Tianmu. At the time, yellow clouds shrouded the house, purple *qi* filled the courtyard, and the chamber glowed with light like the sun and moon. The fragrance from the dream lingered for days before dissipating.

By the time he came of age, he stood nine *chi* and two *cun* tall, with towering brows, a broad forehead, green eyes, a vermilion crown, a high nose, a square jaw, and eyes bearing three pupils. His brow ridge extended into his skull, his jade-like occipital bone rose like a peak, his arms hung past his knees, and his beard was magnificent. He carried himself with the poise of a dragon and the stride of a tiger, broad below and tapering above, his presence commanding reverence. Even family and friends regarded him with solemn awe.

At seven, he read the *Two Chapters on the Dao and Virtue* over ten times and grasped their essence. He mastered the subtleties of astronomy, geography, and the *River Chart* and *Luo Writ* apocrypha, delving deeply into their mysteries. Well-versed in the Three Canons, nothing he perused escaped his comprehension. Over a thousand disciples studied under him. Thirty *li* south of Mount Tianmu and eighty *li* northwest, halls for lecturing and recitation stood—present-day Lin’an Immortal’s Abbey and Yuantong Immortal’s Abbey occupy those sites.

Later, he was recommended for the *Xianliang Fangzheng* examination, which tested upright speech and forthright remonstrance. One of the commendations read: "The Celestial Master is stern and upright by nature, profound in classical learning and refined in conduct, and has mastered the methods of Daoist cultivation." In the second year of Yongping (59 CE) during Emperor Ming’s reign, an imperial edict appointed him Magistrate of Jiangzhou in Bazhou, at the age of twenty-six. Though he held office, his heart remained set on refining his form and achieving lightness of body. After a time, he retired to seclusion in the northern mountains of Beimiu, where he cultivated his practice in Luoyang.

In the third year, a white tiger appeared, holding a talismanic text in its mouth and placing it beside his seat. The court summoned him to serve as *Erudite*, but he claimed illness and declined. When Emperor He ascended the throne, hearing of his mastery of the Dao, the emperor dispatched an envoy with a third-rank seal and cord, a four-horse carriage, and an appointment as Grand Mentor, later offering the title of Marquis of Jixian—yet he refused all three summons. To the messenger, he said: "Convey my gratitude to the Son of Heaven. A human life spans a hundred years, yet time slips by in an instant. Parents, wife, and children—how deep the bonds of love, yet how fleeting their constancy! Above the Nine Heavens lies the Realm of Nothingness, where the Golden Portal’s Celestial Lord has issued a decree to enlist me as his subject. If one but embraces purity and stillness, restraining desire, the world will govern itself—what need have I for office?" This occurred in the fourth year of *Yongyuan* (92 CE), the *renchen* year.

Thereafter, he departed from the Central Plains, drawn to the deep and verdant valleys of Shu. Concealing himself in those mountains, he practiced austerity, cultivated the Dao, conserved his *qi*, and nurtured his spirit. To his disciples, he declared: "From youth, I was devoted to study, delving deeply into the Six Classics—yet all are but tools for ordering the world. What weight do high rank and golden chariots hold compared to a single hair of this body? And even this body of flesh and bone—is it truly mine? It is but a transient aggregation of drifting dust. To refine the heart and temper the form, merging with the true Dao, then riding clouds and mounting dragons to ascend in broad daylight—is this not bliss? Human life is marked by partings and meetings, by birth and death. In death, the spirit fades into obscurity, never to return. Yet recall how the Yellow Emperor savored the Dao, or how Master Red Pine and Wang Qiao consumed the morning mist—both ascended in daylight, enduring for eternity. Is this not sublime? The ancients renounced the splendor of ten thousand chariots and the wealth of a thousand teams—surely they had good reason. Since I cannot both master the Dao and serve the world, let me follow my learning while time permits. Is this not fitting?

"Human emotions know no bounds: when gatherings reach their peak, they scatter; when joy reaches its height, sorrow follows. How can one escape this? I shall now wander mountains and seas, far from the dust of the world, dwelling in seclusion to pursue my studies. As I part from you, how do you feel?" Among his disciples, one named Wang Chang had studied astronomy and mastered the teachings of the Yellow Emperor and Laozi, remaining at his side. The Master then dispersed his followers, devoting himself to purity, emptiness, and detachment, severing all worldly ties. Wang Chang carried books and sang as they journeyed together to Yun Jin Mountain, where they took residence.

There, the Perfected One cultivated the profoundest Dao. Later, he followed the method to refine the Great Elixir of Dragon and Tiger. In the first year, a crimson glow illuminated his chamber. In the second, five-colored clouds enveloped the crucible; by night, no lamp was needed, for a coiled green dragon and white tiger constantly circled the alchemical vessel. In the third year, the elixir was complete. Though the Perfected One was over sixty, after consuming it, his appearance grew ever younger, resembling a man of thirty, his stride outpacing a galloping horse.

He also obtained esoteric texts and secret writs, enabling him to command mountains and summon the myriad spirits. One day, he said to Wang Chang: "The Five Peaks teem with immortals, and the Three Shu abound in famed mountains—shall we journey together?" They then traveled north to the cliffs and ridges of Mount Song, dwelling in a stone abode for several years. His concentrated meditation pierced the heavens, and a messenger in embroidered robes appeared, declaring: "Within the stone chamber of the Central Peak lies the *Inner Writings of the Three Sovereigns*, the *Nine Cauldrons of the Yellow Emperor*, and the *Great Clarity Scripture of the Golden Elixir*—whoever obtains and cultivates these shall ascend to heaven." Moved by these words, the Perfected One fasted for seven days, then entered the chamber. Wherever his feet trod, the ground resounded hollowly. He dug at the spot and indeed retrieved the alchemical texts, which he then received.

Then he once more sought the renowned mountains of the Western Limits—alternately called the Western Sea, for as the *Annals of Chengdu* records, when the gorges of the Yangzi were blocked, Shu became a western sea. The land abounded in marvels and rare treasures, so he entered Mount Yangping, where the Yangping Oratory stood in Jiulong County of Pengzhou. Through concentrated meditation and alchemical refinement, he gained the ability to soar in flight and hear at vast distances, mastering the arts of multiplying his form and dispersing his shadow, communicating with spirits, and transforming at will—sitting yet gone, standing yet vanished. Often he would drift in a boat upon the pond, recite scriptures in the hall, recline unseen before guests, or wander with a flowering staff, chanting verses. All these acts occurred simultaneously, yet none could fathom his divine marvels.

The Perfected One devoted himself solely to reciting the *Five Thousand Characters*, day and night without weariness. Later, he journeyed to Mount Xicheng, where he built an altar to invoke the Perfected Ones and summon the Five Thearchs. Suddenly, a villager reported: "Between Fangling and Xicheng in the west, there dwells a White Tiger Spirit who craves human blood, and each year the people sacrifice a life to it." The Perfected One summoned the spirit and admonished it, and it was destroyed. Another warned: "In Zizhou, a great serpent lurks in a mountain cavern; when it roars, the rocks tremble, and it spews poisonous mists. Travelers rarely survive three or five *li* before succumbing." The Perfected One restrained it with his arts, and it no longer wrought harm. As the *Annals of Mount Qingcheng* notes: "The Terrace of the Oath-Bound Dragon lies on the Peak of the Venerable One. In ancient times, a dragon’s lair there would flood fields each summer and autumn. The Heavenly Master erected a stone terrace to subdue the poisonous dragon and suppress the water demon."

On Mount Gezuo—where the Gezuo Oratory stood in Jiulong County of Pengzhou—he concealed himself in a cliffside abode, refining his *qi* and harmonizing his spirit. On Mount Qinzhong—where the Qinzhong Oratory stood in Deyang County of Hanzhou—he cultivated the *Nine Perfected Esoteric Methods*. On Mount Changli—where the Changli Oratory stood in Jintang County of Hanzhou—he gathered and ingested the Five Fungi and myriad herbs. On Mount Lishang—where the Lishang Oratory stood in Deyang County of Hanzhou—he first transmitted to his disciples the methods of nurturing the body and lightening its form. On Mount Yongquan—alternately called Mount Pinggang, where the Yongquan Oratory stood in Deyang County of Hanzhou and the Pinggang Oratory in Xinjin County of Shuzhou—he attained the arts of entering water and fire unscathed. Thus, he saved beings and aided creatures, accumulating hidden merit.

On Mount Zhenduo—where the Zhenduo Oratory stood in Deyang County of Hanzhou—he contemplated spirits and meditated upon the Perfected Ones.
