On Mount Beiping—also called Mount Dou, where the Dou Oratory stood in Xinjin County of Shuzhou—hundreds of fierce beasts roamed, yet they were tamed and lingered outside his door. On Mount Chougeng—where the Chougeng Oratory stood in Pengshan County of Meizhou—a withered old man transformed into a ferocious ghost to terrify him, but the Perfected One recited scriptures without heed, and the apparition retreated of its own accord. On Mount Heming—where the Heming Oratory stood in Dayi County of Yazhou—he ingested the *qi* of the Five Clouds. There, when the stone cranes cried, some ascended to heaven. Earlier, during the *Zhanghe* era, Emperor Zhang had inquired about the cranes’ cries. As the *Annals of Mount Qingcheng* records: "The Terrace of Sheep and Horses lies upon the cliffs of Redstone City. It is said that the Heavenly Master and ghosts carried stones like sheep and horses, or that when sheep and horses cried there, some ascended to heaven. When the Heavenly Master dwelt on Mount Heming, these sheep and horses cried frequently."

Later, he resided on Mount Quting. As the *Annals of Chengdu* notes: "At the Heavenly Master’s Abbey in Guangdu County, beneath the altar lay a well called the Ghost-Subduing Well, where malevolent spirits hid. During the decline of the Han, the boundary between humans and ghosts blurred, and in the region between Hanzhong and Shu, people suffered grievously. Just as the Heavenly Master received the Han court’s decree to dwell in the stone chamber of Quting in Shu, he commanded divine beings to transport the dark stones of Mount Qingcheng to seal the well. The demonic spirits were thus eradicated."

There, he refined the divine elixir of the Nine Cauldrons. After three years, the work neared completion, yet he dared not ingest it. He said to Wang Chang: "Those who would ascend to heaven must first extend their merit to living beings, aid the state and establish their lineage, promote benefit and eliminate harm—only then may they rise lightly, serving the Three Realms without shame. To seek profit for oneself alone, without merit reaching the people, is not the great Dao’s principle of vast salvation. I see that in Shu, serpent poisons and ghostly *qi* coil through the mountains and valleys, and the people, unaware, suffer in secret. I pity them deeply. Now I shall cultivate the transformation of purity and stillness, assist and exalt the great Dao, and nurture the common folk."

Thus, with concentrated thought, his spirit ascended to the Golden Gates of the Latter Sage. In the first year of Han’an of Emperor Shun’s reign, the *renwu* year, on the fifteenth day of the first month, beneath the bright moon of midnight, the Perfected One lay in deep slumber upon Mount Heming. The Lord Lao—also called the Lord of the Dao, for the Latter Sage of the Golden Gates, the Mysterious Primordial Lord of the Dao, is none other than Lord Lao—rode a chariot of flying clouds and green plough-oxen, halting at the southeast of the mountain. Turning to the assembled immortals, he said: "Daoling’s cultivation is arduous and bitter; I am moved by his resolve and shall bestow upon him the secret writings of bodily governance and the Dao of soaring immortality. Yet he has now fallen into rest, his spirit wandering beyond the world of things. You must not startle him; he will awaken of himself."

In his dream, the Perfected One saw a figure clad in armor of night-glowing luminance, crowned with a cap of celestial achievement, bearing the banner of the Three *Qi* of Life and Demons. The figure addressed him: "Ho, Daoling! Why does your heart grow weary? The Sage’s chariot has long awaited you." The dream dissolved, and the Perfected One suddenly started awake, pulling his sleeves and straightening his robes, suspecting some external evil had disturbed him. After a long moment, the jade pendants chimed softly, celestial music murmured faintly, fragrant blossoms blanketed the earth, and purple clouds filled the sky. Gazing eastward, he beheld above the purple clouds a plain chariot drawn by five white dragons. Twenty-four attendants in crimson robes and golden armor, wielding halberds, stood in ranks on either side, facing forward before the chariot. Jade maidens in flowered garments, their cloud-like hair cascading over their shoulders, each held a banner inscribed in gold with the words *Banner of Life and Demons*. Behind them stood two youths, their heads bound in blue cloth, jade rings dangling, trailing skirts, each bearing a tablet—one with a green dragon on the left, the other a white tiger on the right—golden plaques with vermilion script reading *Millstone for Summoning Immortals*. Further back, two more figures in crimson sleeves and golden armor each held a standard of the Three *Qi* and Ten Absolute Principles, its cinnabar plaque and plain script proclaiming *Standard of the Inverted Scene*. Before the chariot stood one in embroidered robes and jade crown, bearing the twin divine swords of *Three-Five Slaying Evil*, each inscribed with the patterns of stars, the sun, and the moon. To the chariot’s right stood another in rosy robes and golden crown, holding a jade seal inscribed *Seal of Merit for Governing the Yang-Ping District*. Countless other attendants and guards flanked them.

Above the plain chariot, nine-colored mist swirled gently. In an instant, the radiance cleared, revealing within the chariot a divine being whose countenance was like ice and jade, holding a five-fold luminous treasure fan, his neck bearing the eightfold halo of the Round Light, his body over six *zhang* in height. His divine radiance dazzled the eyes, making direct gaze impossible. One before the chariot called to the Perfected One: "Do not fear; this is the Most High Lord Lao." The Perfected One gathered his robes and bowed deeply, not daring to raise his eyes.

Lord Lao spoke: "Long ago, I descended upon the mountains of Shu and established the Twenty-Four Districts—*The Record of Chengdu* states: 'The Daoist scriptures speak of twenty-four districts corresponding to the twenty-four *qi*, with the sixty *jiazi* cycles distributed among them.' To avoid the taboo of Emperor Gaozong of Tang, they were later renamed 'transformations,' yet they remain the prisons beneath the Twenty-Eight Constellations, the offices of the Dark Registers of Yin Shadows, governing the life and death, sin and fortune of the human world. I pitied the souls of the lower realm, bound in suffering, their ancestors burdened by karmic transgressions, accumulating hidden grievances that cut short their lives and prevent them from attaining the Dao, all confined within these very prisons. I have since established courts of blessing, yet for countless kalpas, the celestial bureaucracy has been understaffed, its duties neglected. Recently, the blood-consuming spirits of the Six Heavens have seized and occupied them, blurring the boundaries of day and night, confounding humans and ghosts, wantonly harming the living, and inflicting unjust calamities—deeply lamentable. Why do you not rectify the perverse and restore the upright, distinguish between humans and ghosts, restore the proper order of day and night, and resume governance of these districts to bless the people? Your merit would then be boundless. I have seen your name inscribed upon the Cinnabar Terrace; you shall be a Perfected One, and thus I entrust this to you."

The Perfected One kowtowed and replied: "Daoling’s nature and understanding are dull and slow. Through ten thousand kalpas, I have been fortunate to encounter the great Dao, my dead soul reborn, my withered bones reclothed in flesh. I revere and embrace the Dao’s decree and shall diligently carry it out without slackening."

Lord Lao then summoned the Three-Five Merit Officers. In an instant, from the west arose a vigorous surge of five-colored *qi*, within which two immortals rode mounts of dragon and tiger, each several *zhang* in length, clad in black caps and crimson robes, bearing swords and jade tablets. One hundred twenty attendants, all in black-capped embroidered robes, wielding swords and halberds, advanced and bowed in attendance. Lord Lao said: "Are you the Three-Five Merit Officers? Swiftly open the Jade Palace of the Southern Purple Yang and the inner halls of the Jade Dawn, and retrieve the *Secret Writings of the Orthodox Unity Alliance and Might*. I wish to transmit them." In a brief moment, from the south arose the twenty-four *qi* of life, auspicious lights and propitious hues filling the sky. Within them, jade lads each bore a jade case containing one volume—all inscribed with jade tablets and golden script, along with the registers of merit and deeds—and presented them to the Perfected One.

Lord Lao said: "I grant you a term of a thousand days; our next meeting shall be in the Garden of Wen." He further bestowed upon the Perfected One the *Three Clarities’ Collected Scriptures* in nine hundred thirty volumes, the *Seventy-Two Scrolls of Talismans and Cinnabar Turtle Secret Methods*, the *One Thousand Two Hundred Official Petitions*, the twin swords—*The Record of Mount Qingcheng* states: "At the Altar of the Descended Swords, where the Lord of the Dao once conferred the Yin-Yang Swords upon the Heavenly Master, there remains a hidden sword cave"—the *Seal of Merit for Governing the Yang-Ping District*, the *Crown of the Intermingling of the Two Modes*, the *Robes for Driving Away Evil*, the *Fish-Scale Garment*, the *Square Skirt*, and *Vermilion Shoes*. He commanded him to establish regulations and assist the state in enacting transformation. "After a thousand days of practice, even evil spirits shall not dare to meet your gaze directly."

Upon completing the transmission of teachings, he retreated to Mount Heming to study and savor the secret texts, following their methods in practice. After a thousand days of cultivation, he could inwardly perceive his five viscera and outwardly gather the thirty-six thousand spirits. Moreover, he was visited by the Jade Maiden of Pure Harmony, who instructed him in the art of exhaling and inhaling the qi of pure harmony, subduing wayward essences and malevolent forces. He mastered the Way of the Three Steps and Nine Paces from the scriptures, as well as the path of treading the Dipper and intersecting the Qian hexagram. Thus, the Seven Origins of the Northern Dipper manifested before him, and wherever his troops pointed, he could conceal or reveal himself at will, all occurring naturally.

Thereupon, in accordance with the divine mandate, he waged war against the ghosts in Shu. At that time, eight ghostly marshals, each leading ghostly legions numbering in the tens of millions, roamed among humanity. Liu Yuanda commanded ghosts that caused miscellaneous illnesses; Zhang Yuanbo, those that spread pestilence; Zhao Gongming, those that induced dysentery; Zhong Ziji, those that caused ulcers and swellings; Shi Wenye, those that brought sudden sweats and malarial chills; Fan Juqing, those that inflicted aches and pains; Yao Gongbo, those that wielded the Five Poisons; and Li Gongzhong, those that provoked madness, demonic possession, and red eyes. All were perverse qi of the Five Phases, harbingers of calamity and misfortune. They changed their names with the seasons: in the east, they were called Demon Kings; in the south, Ghost Marshals; in the west, Heterodox Ways; in the north, Ghost Lords; and in the center, Spirit-Ghosts.

During the three months of spring, when the hundred birds cried out, they became the ghosts of the Five Graves, offering curses and invocations. By autumn, they transformed into the ghosts of ancestral earth, household earth lords, dwelling dragons, and lingering corpses. In winter, they became the ghosts of tombs and graves, attacking and devouring the living. Following the monthly cyclical signs, they took form in the womb, sometimes appearing as beasts, exhaling poison and howling calamity, violently slaughtering countless people and cutting short innumerable lives.

These eight ghostly marshals led their ghostly hosts to dwell atop Mount Qingcheng in western Shu, where they had a ghostly city and ghostly market. There, they assumed various forms, mingling among humanity, spreading pestilential sands, unbeknownst to mortals. Humans and ghosts intermingled, trading goods and profits. On the first day of the seventh month in the second year of the Han’an era, the Perfected One, bearing the secret registers of the Covenant of Might, journeyed to Mount Qingcheng—*The Record of Mount Qingcheng* states: "There is a Dragon Palace stone chamber, where the Heavenly Master cultivated the Dao." *The Old唐书* notes: "In Qingcheng County of Shuzhou, there is Mount Qingcheng." He set up a throne of glassy azure, with the Great Dao’s Primordial Heavenly Worthy of the Origin on the left and the Thirty-Six Divisions of Perfected Scriptures on the right. He erected the Ten Absolute Spirit Talismans around the ritual mat, sounded the bells and struck the chime stones, burned incense, performed the Dao, and recited the scriptures of the *Dao* and *Virtue*. He deployed the divine troops of the Dragon and Tiger in the city.

The ghostly hosts then brandished weapons, arrows, and stones, advancing to harm the Perfected One. With a single gesture of his hand, he transformed his finger into a great lotus flower to repel them. The ghostly legions bore over a thousand torches of fire, but when the Perfected One raised his hand and pointed, the ghosts set themselves ablaze, unable to advance. From afar, they cried out to the Perfected One: "Master, you dwell on Mount Emei—*Tang Jia Prefecture has Emei County*—why have you come to seize our dwelling? Descend the mountain swiftly, or we shall surely kill you."

The Perfected One replied: "You are cruel and venomous, harming all living beings. Therefore, I shall not allow you to remain here. You shall be banished to the barren lands of the west." Upon hearing this, Yuanda and the others summoned the ghostly marshals and their troops, each amassing millions, clad in fine armor and rhinoceros-blade weapons, surrounding the mountain. Wang Chang, alarmed, entreated the Perfected One: "The Demon Kings and their legions have come. What strategy shall we employ?"

The Perfected One smiled and said: "Why fear such petty ghosts? Bring me the cinnabar brush." Wang Chang presented it, and the Perfected One, wielding the brush, drew in the air toward the ghostly ranks. Instantly, all perished; the lesser marshals and officers collapsed in unison, while the eight great ghost kings lay prostrate, knocking their heads and slapping their cheeks, begging for their lives. The Perfected One remained silent for a long while, then reversed the brushstroke, and the ghostly hosts revived.

He then summoned the ghost kings, saying: "Come forward. I have instructions for you." The ghost kings approached and stood before him. The Perfected One declared: "You must swiftly retreat and henceforth cease spreading illness and wantonly harming lives. The common people are all my disciples and kin. If you disobey, I shall exterminate you without mercy." The ghost kings replied: "The people of the world originally belonged to us. Why do you seek to take them all? At least grant us half." The Perfected One refused and rebuked them.

The ghost kings then assembled the six great demon kings, leading a million ghostly troops to attack once more, encircling the mountain. Wang Chang said: "The ghostly hosts are overwhelming. What shall we do?" The Perfected One laughed and said: "Do not fear. I shall command them myself." Again, he drew with the cinnabar brush, and all the ghosts perished. Only the Six Heavenly Demon Kings lay prone, unable to rise, knocking their heads and slapping their cheeks, begging for their lives before departing. The Perfected One paid them no heed. With another stroke of the cinnabar brush, the mountain split in two, cleaving the sky and piercing the springs—*The Record of Mount Qingcheng* states: "The mountain has an Oath Stone, where the Heavenly Master swore an oath with the ghosts. With a cinnabar brush, he drew a line across the mountain’s sheer cliffs, a crimson mark two *cun* wide and a *zhang* deep, six or seven *zhang* in length." It also notes: "The Ghost-Restraining Brush’s edge lies beside the Great Dragon Bridge, where the Heavenly Master subdued ghosts and spirits with the Orthodox Unity’s methods, swearing: 'Humans live by day; ghosts move by night. Yin and Yang are distinct, each governed by its own office. Those who violate this shall be punished by the Orthodox Unity’s laws without mercy.'"

The ghostly troops, unable to cross, wailed piteously. From then on, they vowed never to return, begging to dwell in the western land of Bāluka. The Perfected One relented and granted permission. With another stroke of the brush, the eight marshals and six demon kings revived. He summoned them forward, but they could not advance. The Perfected One then ordered Wang Chang to shoulder a great stone to form a bridge, allowing the ghost kings to cross. Only then did they approach, standing in attendance with hands clasped.

The Perfected One addressed them: "If you can split this stone with your brush, I shall grant you a share of the people. If you cannot, flee ten thousand *li* at once." Yuanda and the others took the brush and drew upon the stone, but it remained unbroken—*The Record of Mount Qingcheng* states: "Behind the Yinxuan Abbey lies the Trial Brush’s Edge, where the Demon-Subduing Stone of Ritual Law stands."

Though the ghostly hosts had been subdued, the Perfected One sought to fully subdue their hearts as well. He addressed them: "Since you wish to share the people with me, let each of us exhaust our powers to determine victory."

Yuanda and the others replied, "We shall obey your command."

The Perfected One cast himself into a great fire, emerging with his feet treading upon a blue lotus; when the ghostly marshals leapt in, they were consumed by the flames. The Perfected One entered a tree, his body passing beyond its bounds as the wood closed behind him; when the ghostly marshals threw themselves in, they fell to the ground. The Perfected One entered water, riding forth upon a yellow dragon; when the ghostly marshals plunged in, they were drowned by the waves. The Perfected One entered stone, emerging through its other side; when the ghostly marshals cast themselves in, they penetrated but an inch. The Perfected One entered an iron mountain, passing through its depths; when the ghostly marshals attempted the same, they barely breached half an inch.

The Perfected One intoned a divine talisman, and with a gesture of his left hand, the ghosts perished; with a gesture of his right, they revived. When the ghostly marshals raised their hands to do the same, the dead did not return to life. Yuanda and the others then transformed into eight great tigers, roaring and lunging forward. The Perfected One became two lions, pursuing them until they fled in terror. The ghostly marshals next transformed into eight great dragons, seeking to seize the master, but the Perfected One became a golden-winged roc, pecking out the dragons’ eyes, and they scattered in flight. They then took the form of a colossal deity, Nie Zui, who let out a thunderous roar, wielding a massive mace to strike the Perfected One. The Perfected One transformed into a vajra, his body towering seventy-two *wan* in height and fifty-two *wan* in girth, crowned with a great diadem and bearing a halo of radiance. He stood upon a lotus throne, adorned with twelve boundless marks. With a single staff, fist, or gesture, the great deity retreated in defeat.

When the ghostly marshals leapt twelve *zhang* into the air, they fell back down; the Perfected One soared over a hundred *zhang* high, with nothing above to grasp and nothing below to bear him. The ghostly marshals conjured five-colored clouds, darkening heaven and earth so that no light could be seen. The Perfected One transformed into a five-hued auspicious sun, its blazing radiance scattering the clouds. The ghostly marshals exhausted every transformation, yet could do no more.

The Perfected One then manifested a great stone, weighing over a thousand *jin*, suspended by a lotus-fiber thread above the ghostly marshals’ encampment. He commanded two rats to gnaw at the thread, threatening to crush the host below. With no escape, the ghostly marshals cried out in unison, begging for their lives and vowing to flee far away, never again to harm the living.

Thereupon, the Perfected One summoned the gods of the five directions, the eight divisions, and the six heavens to convene an oath at the Yellow Emperor’s altar on Mount Qingcheng. He decreed that humans would dwell in the realm of brightness while ghosts would wander in darkness, commanding the six heavenly ghost kings to return to Beideng and the eight divisions of ghostly marshals to scatter into the Western Regions. The poisons of the five phases were also restrained and released.

Taking up his cinnabar brush, he declared: "Wherever my brush points, the ghostly hosts shall be annihilated." Yet in essence, he sought not to exterminate their kind entirely, but to separate the governance of humans and ghosts, dividing the realms of light and shadow. He swore a covenant with them, breaking a stone to serve as a contract, carving upon it the forms of heaven and earth, sun and moon. Upon the sheer cliff above the Yellow Emperor’s altar—*The Record of Mount Qingcheng* states: "On Mount Qingcheng stands the Stone Heaven and Earth, round above and square below, twelve *chi* in breadth, with twelve corners. There are also the Stone Sun and Moon, each five *zhang* wide and one *zhang* two *cun* thick, standing opposite one another upon pillars, their forms of crow and hare resplendent, their roundness and squareness, thickness and thinness plainly visible." *The Record of Mount Qingcheng* further notes: "The Master of Heaven’s oath with the ghosts upon the Stone Heaven and Earth, Stone Sun and Moon, decreed that only when the sun, moon, heaven, and earth shone anew would they regain human form." *The Record of Chengdu* adds: "Before the Zhaoqing Abbey on Mount Qingcheng stand the Five Talisman Steles, carved by the Heavenly Master to bind ghostly spirits. Today, a separate stone stele stands before the Yuju Abbey."

Another version states: Upon the Plain of Gang in the mountains, the Perfected One eradicated the residual *qi* of the Six Heavens, inscribing an oath upon stone: "When heaven and earth unite and the sun and moon conjoin, if you dare act again, you shall be utterly exterminated, leaving no trace." He then sealed the ghostly encampments with a divine seal, cutting off all communication between them.

After the oath, the ghostly hosts lingered, unwilling to depart. The Perfected One uttered a divine talisman, which flew into the highest heavens. At once, wind and rain, celestial immortals, heavenly soldiers, and wind blades descended. The ghosts vanished without a trace, fleeing in terror. Thus, the fourteen battles against the ghosts were won, their lairs swept clean, and their dark prisons seized. Twenty-four blessed courts were established, along with twenty-four officials of the netherworld, and the upright *qi* of the twenty-eight constellations was summoned to connect with the earth—another version states: "He also established twenty-four *zhi* in the Gongmu Mountains, further refining the twenty-four *qi* of the mountains to harmonize with the Great Dao, restoring the halls of tranquility." The Gongmu *zhi* was located in Shiyu County of Hanzhou, while the Further Refining *zhi* was in Mianzhu County of Hanzhou.

For each *zhi*, one netherworld official and one immortal official were appointed to oversee the merits and transgressions of the living. Those who performed good deeds, cultivated conduct, held fasts, set up offerings, submitted memorials, offered prayers, or sought blessings for their ancestors would have their merits recorded by the immortal officials and reported to the celestial palaces, thereby increasing their fortune and longevity. Conversely, those who were unfilial, disloyal, deceitful, or cruel, persisting in evil without repentance, would have their sins recorded by the netherworld officials and reported to the earthly courts, diminishing their fortune and longevity, or even severing their lineage. Thus, the retribution for good and evil followed as swiftly as shadow and echo.

Having propagated the teachings of the Orthodox Unity, the Perfected One subdued thirty-six thousand kinds of heretical demons and evil spirits, eradicating falsehood and deceit. The people unanimously accepted him as their master, with tens of thousands of households becoming his disciples. He appointed various *jijiu* to oversee the populace, much like government officials. Regulations were established, requiring the people to contribute grain, silk, utensils, paper, mats, firewood, and other supplies as needed, storing them for rituals, offerings, and the aid of travelers. The people followed his teachings without daring to deceive or steal.

He instructed them to build bridges, repair roads, and dig public wells, calling these acts of merit.

Should any prefectural or county officials or common folk fall ill, they would present a written petition to the Perfected One. He would examine the petitioner’s transgressions, listing two offenses, and command them to hold purification rites and offerings, to make amends through almsgiving, and thus their illness would be cured. He further instructed officials to govern with integrity and diligence, sparing the use of punishments. The people of Shu, in awe of retribution, turned from wrongdoing, and banditry ceased. No blight or pestilence afflicted the land—all was the transformative power of the Heavenly Master.

The Perfected One then arrived at Cloud Terrace Mountain in Cangxi County (the Cloud Terrace Abbey lay in Xixian of Liangzhou). According to the *Tang Book*, Junxi County of Minzhou had a Cloud Terrace Mountain, where he beheld its extraordinary landscape, its peaks arrayed in homage, its earth free of malevolent forces. He said to Wang Chang, “This mountain shall be the place of my ascension and transcendence.” There he chose his dwelling to cultivate the arts of the Ninefold Return and Sevenfold Reversion, focusing his mind solely on the Great Dao.

After forty-nine days, he once more heard the celestial music of jade chimes and carriages from days past. The Perfected One straightened his robes and prostrated himself, whereupon he saw the Lord Lao as before, attended by a thousand chariots and ten thousand riders, descending from the void. For a long while, they hovered without alighting. The Perfected One bowed again, weeping and leaping in grief, saying, “Your servant once reflected that, having long basked in your sacred grace and received your secret texts, I followed heaven’s decree, battled demons, and spread the teachings. My work complete, I retired to seclusion. Now, as your august carriage returns, you do not descend to me—does this mean the Great Dao has forsaken your servant, and I am but a hollow husk?”

He raised his hands and cast himself to the ground. The Lord Lao then commanded his messenger to declare: “Your merits have earned you the rank of a Ninefold Perfected Upper Immortal. I sent you to Shu to wrest the ghostly nether-prisons, to distinguish between humans and spirits, and to spread the teachings of purity and tranquility. Yet you have slain ghosts excessively, summoned wind and rain at will, commanded spirits and gods, driven the stars in their courses, shaken mountains and rivers, darkened the sunlit sky, and polluted the air with killing intent—this is not the Great Dao’s love of life. The Celestial Emperor has rebuked you for these transgressions, and thus I cannot draw near you. I am unable to assess your merits; you must withdraw into the world of men and await the Sovereign of the Lower Prime. Then I shall plead your case to absolve your grave faults.”

The Perfected One wept bitterly, begging to die that very day. The Lord Lao spoke again: “Close your eyes and bind your gaze.” Thereupon he saw a figure in yellow robes with black sashes, bearing a jade casket containing three plain silk scrolls, titled *The Three Eights: Atonement, Erasure of the Black Ledger, and the Chapters of Transcending the Mysterious Ancestors*. The Perfected One bowed twice and received them. The Lord Lao instructed: “Diligently perform rites of atonement to the twenty-eight lunar lodges, the twenty-four solar terms, and the lords of yin, yang, and destiny. When your sins are erased from the Black Ledger, your name will ascend to the Purple Clarity, and your seven ancestors and nine forebears shall together become Upper Immortals. After atoning, you must further cultivate for three thousand six hundred days, and I shall await you in the Land of Nothing-Whatever, within the Eightfold Radiance Palace of the Upper Clarity.”

With these words, the sacred carriage departed. The Perfected One followed the instructions, leading his disciples to Crane Cry Mountain, where he built an altar to perform rites for the sun and moon. On the Three Primes, the eight festivals, his own destiny days, the beding and jiazi cycles, the three assemblies, and the five seasonal fasts, he held purification rites, set up offerings, recited scriptures, lit lamps, and repented before the sun, moon, and stars, heaven and earth, yin and yang, and the sins of his nine forebears and seven ancestors. After three years, his mysterious ancestors ascended to heaven.

His disciples gathered once more for several days, then together they went to the Registrar’s Mountain (the Registrar’s Abbey lay in Pujiang County of Nazhou). There, his hidden merits became renowned, and myriad auspicious signs manifested. One night, a divine being presented him with a jade disk, saying, “The host of immortals sends me to illuminate your dwelling at Original Bamboo Mountain (the Original Bamboo Abbey lay in Xinjin County of Shuzhou). The Perfected Ones have bestowed upon you the *Upper Scripture of the Numinous Treasure* at Mount Mengqin (the Mengqin Abbey lay in Taideng County of Kuizhou).”

A divine messenger summoned the Perfected One by night to accompany him, and after three days, he returned. He then led his disciples to Queting Mountain. At that time, dozens followed him. One day, he addressed his disciples: “My disciples, I thank you for your diligent service. Yet your worldly attachments remain unsevered, and you cannot yet renounce the mortal realm. You may learn my arts of circulating qi and guiding the body, or perhaps the methods of consuming herbs and plants in their hundreds. Your karmic burden is heavy, and your blessings thin—you cannot yet swiftly attain the Dao. After three more lifetimes, you may meet me again. Now, depart.”

Then he pointed to Wang Chang and said: “Only you, having cultivated goodness over many lifetimes, may now achieve perfection.”

He added: “In the east, there is a man named Xiao Yue who shall likewise ascend in flight. Though he comes from a thousand *li* away, he will arrive on the seventh day of the first month next year.” He described in full his height, build, and complexion.

When the appointed day came, the Perfected One said: “The sun nears noon—surely Master Zhao has arrived.” No sooner had he spoken than the man appeared, matching every detail as foretold. The disciples reported this, and the Perfected One said: “Ah, this man has come—but he may not yet be admitted at once.” He subjected him to seven trials.

First, he refused to receive him, sending servants to spit and revile him, yet Xiao Yue did not leave. He endured forty days of open-air lodging, his resolve only growing firmer, until at last the Perfected One granted him an audience. Next, he was sent into the mountains to guard millet and drive off beasts. That evening, a beautiful woman appeared, claiming to be a traveler caught by nightfall and seeking shelter. Xiao Yue shared her mat but sat upright until dawn. The following day, she feigned a lame foot to linger, then adorned herself and attempted to seduce him, yet he never strayed from rectitude.

Later, while walking along the path, he came upon dozens of gold cakes left behind, but passed them by without taking any. He was then ordered to gather firewood, whereupon three tigers roared and charged before him. Unperturbed, Xiao Yue said: “I have journeyed far to seek the deathless Dao from a sage—are you mountain spirits testing me?” The tigers then departed. Finally, he was sent to a shop to purchase silk. Though he paid in full, the merchant falsely accused him of failing to settle the debt.

Xiao Yue made no dispute, instead selling his clothes to repay the debt. He was then ordered to guard the rice fields, where a man in tattered robes, emaciated and covered in sores, his skin ulcerated and his breath foul, knelt to beg for food. Xiao Yue’s heart was moved, and he removed his own garments to clothe the man, giving him rice and leaving him the rest of his provisions. After six trials—each designed to stir the heart or provoke emotion—Xiao Yue remained steadfast in his resolve, his mind unwavering.

The Perfected One then led them to the summit of Cloud Terrace, a sheer cliff where he wandered freely, chanting and tasting the wind, gazing down into an abyss of ten thousand fathoms. A peach tree grew from the precipice, its fruit most extraordinary. The Perfected One addressed his disciples: “Whoever can retrieve this fruit shall be taught the Dao.” Over two hundred disciples leaned forward to peer down, but all trembled in fear, their bodies drenched in cold sweat, and they pleaded, “This peach cannot be obtained.” Only Xiao Yue stepped forward and said, “With the sagely master’s protection, what peril could there be? As long as the master lives, he will not let me fall into this ravine. If my destiny permits instruction, then this peach can be plucked.” With that, he cast himself downward, landing precisely upon the peach tree without stumbling, and gathered an armful of fruit. Clinging to the green stone wall, he found no way to ascend, so he tossed the peaches upward—over two hundred in all. The Perfected One divided the fruit among the disciples, keeping one for Xiao Yue, then reached down over the ravine to pull him up. The others saw that his arm did not lengthen, yet the Perfected One, with a gentle tug, drew him up and said, “Xiao Yue obtained the peaches through the steadfastness of his heart, avoiding a fatal fall. Now, I shall test myself by leaping down—I should surely gather even more peaches.” The disciples all protested, but only Xiao Yue and Chang remained silent. The Perfected One then cast himself down and vanished. After a long while, with no sign of his return, the disciples were struck with dread. Xiao Yue and Chang remained silent for a time before saying, “The master is like a father to us. Now that he has departed, where shall we go?” With that, they both leapt into the ravine, landing before the master. There they saw the Perfected One seated in a jeweled forest beneath a canopy of precious silk, upon a seven-jeweled terrace, his eyes closed in meditation. He smiled and said, “I knew you two would come.” He then bestowed upon them divine elixirs and secret scriptures of profound wisdom. The other disciples waited atop the cliff for two days before scattering.

The Perfected One returned with Wang and Zhao to the central realm three days later. One day, while leading his disciples afar, he saw a white vapor rising from Yang Mountain, stretching to the heavens. He said to Chang and Xiao Yue, “There must be a demonic presence there. We shall go and eliminate it.” Upon arriving, they encountered twelve divine maidens before the mountain, their forms enchanting and alluring. The Perfected One questioned them, and the maidens replied, “We are the yin spirits of this land.” The Perfected One then asked where the salt spring was, and the maidens answered, “Ahead lies a great pool where a poisonous dragon dwells. Though you summon it with your arts, it will not emerge.” The Perfected One inscribed a talisman, which transformed into a golden-winged phoenix. It circled above, crying out, and the dragon, seized with terror, abandoned the pool and fled. The waters receded, revealing the salt spring, which they boiled into salt. The golden-winged phoenix alighted upon the southern mountain, and later generations called it Phoenix Terrace, where to this day no birds or beasts dare perch.

The twelve divine maidens each presented a jade bracelet, saying, “We wish to serve you as your humble attendants.” The Perfected One accepted the bracelets, and with a gesture of his hand, the twelve merged into one. He said, “I shall cast this bracelet into the well. Whoever retrieves it shall be my destined companion.” Hearing this, the maidens stripped off their garments and plunged into the well, scrambling to seize the jade bracelet. The Perfected One then sealed the well, swearing an oath: “Henceforth, you shall be well spirits. You may not emerge again, lest you bring harm to the living.” As the Perfected One refined the salt spring, a hunter arrived. The Perfected One admonished him for his fondness for killing and taught him the method of boiling salt. The well was five hundred and forty feet deep and ten feet wide, yielding over forty measures of brine daily, bringing great profit.

The Perfected One then pointed to the northwest mountain and said, “This place is fit for building a city.” He then indicated the land south of the city: “Here, where the rivers and mountains pay homage, a blessed sanctuary may be established.” Later generations, moved by the Perfected One’s words, built a shrine there, and to this day, offerings and prayers continue without end.

The Perfected One took Xiao Yue and Chang to reside in Ban Valley. One day, lost in thought, he said to them, “When I took the divine maidens’ garments, I feared they might reclaim them and bring harm to the people.” He then returned to the place, hiding the clothes in a stone chamber atop a high peak, commanding the earth spirits to guard them. This is the Flame Sun Grotto, and to this day, the people of that region remain free from the maidens’ harm while enjoying the benefits of the salt well. Later, the place was named in honor of the Perfected One’s deeds, and it is now Lingzhou. In the salt marshes of Shu, shrines to the Lord of Qinghe were established nearby—Qinghe being a prefecture of the Zhang clan.

At the foot of the mountain, there were no rivers or wells, and the people suffered from a lack of water. The Perfected One plunged his divine sword into the earth, and a well sprang forth. He set spirits to guard it, ensuring its waters would never fail. The Perfected One then said to Xiao Yue and Chang, “This mountain is full of cliffs, and people dwell here. I fear the rocks may fall and harm them.” He summoned the mountain spirits and bound them by oath to spare the people.

The Perfected One and his disciples crossed the Song River, where many strange creatures harmed the people. He placed a stone casket in the river, recording the names of the malevolent spirits and summoning them with his arts, sealing them within. He then inscribed a great talisman of mountain script to suppress them, and the monstrosities ceased. Later generations called it the *Bingui Talisman*, and when the waters receded, people often saw it. They would copy it and keep it in their homes to ward off evil.

The Perfected One then led Xiao Yue and Chang to Crane Cry Mountain. At midday, they suddenly saw a man in vermilion robes with a blue sash, wearing slippers and holding a tablet. Beside him was another man in black silk, girded with a sword, bearing a jade casket. The vermilion-clad messenger approached and said, “By command of the Supreme Clarity, a true talisman summons the Perfected One to wander the Ban Gardens.” In an instant, from the northeast appeared fourteen attendants, riding dragons, tigers, simurghs, cranes, tortoises, scaled creatures, fish, and crows. They bore standards and banners, with a procession of thousands of chariots and ten thousand riders—lions, apotropaic beasts, celestial soldiers, and countless mounted officials—all come to welcome the Perfected One.

Next, a black dragon drew a purple chariot, and two jade maidens escorted the Perfected One to mount it. In an instant, they arrived at the palace gates, where a placard above read: *Gate of the Supreme Mystery Capital’s Orthodox Unity Perfected One*. Upon the Perfected One’s arrival, the assembled immortals bowed in reverence.

After some time, two black-robed officials bearing celestial talismans, girded with swords, and holding registers of destinies approached. The documents stated that the records of the Perfected One’s ancestors had been elevated, and all were now enrolled in the Vermilion Mound Prefecture. Having concluded his duties, the Perfected One led his disciples to reside in a stone chamber on Queting Mountain, where they cultivated the qi of the Grand Perfection.

One day, two azure lads led a host of immortals, all clad in vermilion robes and bearing crimson standards, who announced: “The Venerable Lord has arrived.” Among them stood a figure over ten feet tall, with silver hair and a ruddy complexion, a halo of radiance crowning his head. Two attendants, appearing no older than twenty, accompanied him. Some pointed and said, “This is Master Zhang Liang, and this is Master Yan Hui.”

After a moment, a jade-green chariot was brought forth, and two others assisted the Perfected One into it. They soared into the heavens and arrived at a place where towering terraces and palaces rose, their steps of gold and jade. Someone told the Perfected One, “You are to pay homage to the Most High Primordial Heavenly Worthy.” The Perfected One adjusted his robes and hastened forward, but the radiant halo above the hall was too dazzling to gaze upon directly. A voice explained: “To the left stands the Most Supreme Lord of the Great Dao; to the right, the Perfected One of the Supreme Ultimate; before him, the Lady of the Void and Subtle; and behind, the Most High Perfected One.” Golden lads and jade maidens attended with incense and scattered blossoms, while the Wondrous Conduct Perfected Ones held scriptures and bowed, stepping forward to form ranks.

The assembly of immortals declared: “Today, you have all attained perfection. By your single thought, the karmic entanglements of ten thousand kalpas have been extinguished in this moment.” After some time, a green lad from the hall conveyed to the Perfected One the methods of the Orthodox Unity Alliance of Might, charging him to transmit them through the ages, to serve as a teacher of humans and gods. He was then invested as the Great Master of the Supreme Mystery Capital’s Orthodox Unity, Pacifier of the Three Black Heavens, Supporter of the Dao, and Assistant to the Primordial, and exhorted to return to the mortal realm to awaken the unawakened. The time of his ascension was also secretly revealed to him.

Having received his mandate, the Perfected One returned to the Red Stone Cliff abode on Queting Mountain. There, he transmitted the Three Heavens’ Orthodox Unity esoteric methods to Chang and Sheng, instructing them to present themselves for testing in the mountains behind the city. At Jade Bureau Mountain, he imparted secret instructions to Sheng and Chang. (The rear-city retreat was located in Shiyu County of Hanzhou.) He later expounded the teachings in the Li Yuan Mountains (Li Yuan retreat in Jiulong County of Pengzhou), then returned to Yangping Mountain, where he entrusted his successor with the methods of light-ascent for immortals.

He next entered Lutang Mountain (Lutang retreat in Mianzhu County of Hanzhou), where he refined the Nine-Cauldron divine elixir, then moved to Pinggai Mountain (Pinggai retreat in Xinjin County of Shuzhou) to compound the Great Nine-Splendor Medicine.

At that time, two masters of restraint and qi-binding, Yao and Xu, who could summon the spirits of local shrines, reverse funeral processions, and revive the dead, roamed the Nine Provinces with legions of spectral soldiers and tens of thousands of ghostly cavalry. Hearing of the Master’s presence in Shu, they sought an audience, declaring: “The Great Dao is but a single qi. Among spirits and numina, is there truly high or low? We command the eight directions and a hundred million yin soldiers. Even if you possess the Dao, what can you do to us?” They ordered their followers to assemble outside the gate, but the Perfected One refused them entry. Turning to Chang and Sheng, he said: “These are the heterodox deities of the Six Heavens; they should not meet with the orthodox qi.” He commanded them to stand by the roadside for three days and nights without moving.

His disciples, puzzled, questioned him, and the Perfected One replied: “They have come with a host of malevolent spirits to test me. Having them stand outside the gate causes them no real harm.” Yao and Xu cried out: “We heard the Master possessed the Dao, so we came seeking an audience. Not only were we denied entry, but we have been made to stand here for so long—what crime have we committed?” The Perfected One then instructed his disciples to tell them: “Today, I pardon you and will not inquire into your past offenses.” Only then were they permitted to depart.

The Perfected One led his disciples back to Mount Heming. On the seventh day of the first month in the first year of Yongshou of Emperor Huan’s reign (the year *yiwei*), at the fifth watch of the night, Chang and Sheng saw a celestial immortal official riding through the sky, driving a cloud chariot. He lingered in the southeast of the mountain and cried aloud: “Zhang Daoling’s merits and conduct are now complete; he shall be conferred with the secret registers.” As his words faded, Lord Lao arrived in a dragon-drawn carriage, while the Perfected One rode a white crane, meeting at the foot of Chengdu beneath Mount Quting.

When Lord Lao arrived together with him, the myriad spirits came forth in grand welcome. A jade platform, over a *zhang* in height, emerged from the earth. The platform was established in Yizhou’s Chengdu County—what is now the Jade Platform Abbey. Lord Lao ascended the seat and once more transmitted the essentials of the Dao to the Perfected One, reiterating the principles of the Orthodox Unity and Alliance of Powers. He expounded the *Scripture of the Northern Dipper for Prolonging Life*. On the fifteenth day, the Shangyuan Festival, they met again in Chengdu, where he taught the *Scripture of the Southern Dipper* and expounded various other scriptures.

After the Perfected One had heard all, Lord Lao departed, and the jade platform dissolved, leaving an empty cavern. The *Records of Chengdu* states: “After Lord Lao’s departure, the seat sank into the earth, forming a deep cave that connected with the fifth cavern of Mount Qingcheng.” Daoling, however, deemed the jade platform’s alignment with the Ghost Star inauspicious, fearing it would disrupt the *fenye* (territorial correspondences) if the cave were left open to the qi. Thus, he sealed it with stone and blade.

The Perfected One then proceeded to Lutang Abbey, where he summoned the Four Guardian Deities of the Year, the Five Peaks and Four Seas, the deities of soil and grain, and all the immortals, who assembled in full. Before the mountain stood a stone spire, over a *zhang* tall. The Perfected One lifted it and swore an oath before the gathered spirits: “The Supreme Lord has commanded me to bind you by this vow: uphold the true Dao, cherish life and abhor killing, aid the state and pacify the people. Those who disobey shall be punished by the myriad spirits.” He then cast the stone spire down the cliff, where it stood erect beside the abbey.

Thereafter, he established the ranks of the thirty-six *jinglu* (serene hermitages), seventy-two *fudi* (blessed lands), and three hundred sixty sacred mountains, each assigned a presiding deity, mirroring the governance of commanderies and counties in the mortal realm. He then led Sheng and Chang to Yuntai Abbey, where in the northwest corner they built an altar and installed a furnace to refine the Great Elixir. Upon its completion, he consumed it, bathed in water, and a divine radiance spanned the heavens.

In the second year of Yongshou (*bingshen*), the Perfected One, deeming his work accomplished and his Dao manifest, leapt from the mid-cliff of the abbey into the stone wall, emerging from the summit, thus forming two caverns. The one halfway up the cliff is called the Steep Immortal Grotto; the one atop is called the Level Immortal Grotto. On the ninth day of the ninth month that year, in the Red City Grotto of Mount Quting in Baxi, the Supreme Lord dispatched envoys accompanied by the retinues of the Five Emperors, bearing a jade tablet to confer upon him the title of Perfected One of Orthodox Unity.

The Perfected One then transmitted to his eldest son, Heng, the secret registers of the Alliance of Powers and Merit, the Two Swords for Slaying Demons, the jade tablet, and the jade seal, admonishing him: “These texts govern the Three and Five Steps of Manifestation and the essentials of Orthodox Unity. They shall pass to one son in each generation, succeeding my position. They must not be transmitted to those outside our clan or lineage.” The *Records of Mount Qingcheng* state: “On Red City Mountain lies the repository of the Heavenly Master’s scriptures,” while another account places the sealed scriptures and decrees in the mountains of Jinkou. (Note: The Jinkou Abbey is located in Cangxi County of Hezhou.)

To Chang and Sheng, he said: “I have remaining elixir in the golden basin atop the Elixir-Refining Pavilion. You two may divide and consume it, for today you shall follow me.” At noon that day, they saw a man in vermilion robes with a cyan sash, wearing sandals and holding a tablet, and another in black silk with a sword at his waist, both bearing jade caskets. They followed the vermilion-robed messenger forward, prostrated themselves, and said: “By command of the Supreme Clarity, we present the true talismans to welcome the Perfected One to the Gardens of Paradise.”

Presently, from the northeast appeared twenty-four riders mounted on dragons, tigers, simurghs, and cranes, each bearing green banners and crimson staffs. Lion-like and *pixie*-warding creatures, along with armored celestial soldiers, arrived, announcing themselves as the officials of Jingyang. Then a black dragon drew a purple carriage, and two jade maidens escorted the Perfected One and his wife, Lady Yong (or Lady Sun, according to some accounts), into the vehicle. Preceded by a celestial procession and followed by heavenly music, they ascended to the heavens in broad daylight from the summit of Yuntai Peak. At that time, the Perfected One was one hundred and twenty-three years old.

Emperor Xuanzong of Tang composed this eulogy:
*In that distant age of fiery Han,*
*The celestial chart was flawed, the cosmos rent;*
*All things withered, the Three Powers in disarray.*
*Yet our Master arose to meet the mandate,*
*His divine might swiftly unleashed.*
*He served the true origin in person,*
*Receiving the secret transmissions.*
*Demonic toxins scattered like clouds,*
*Haunted mountains split by his sword.*
*He widely proclaimed the teachings,*
*Thoroughly purging the plague of corruption.*
*With a single flourish of non-action,*
*He brought eternal radiance to the bounded realm.*
*Soaring on simurghs and cranes,*
*His image was captured in cinnabar and ink.*
*His jade countenance and true form*
*Transmit an undying fragrance.*

He composed another eulogy:
*Remote is the true immortal,*
*Lofty and unyielding his integrity.*
*His qi pierced the vault of heaven,*
*As the Mysterious Origin revealed its secrets.*
*His divine bearing was resplendent,*
*Like the moon in its purity.*
*He executed demons and severed spirits,*
*Driving away ghosts and banishing malevolence.*
*In the Han, he established the Alliance of Powers,*
*Its transmission unbroken to this day.*

Emperor Suzong of Tang composed this eulogy:
*Virtue arises from purity and emptiness,*
*The essence of the sagely teachings.*
*Now hidden, now revealed,*
*He embodied simplicity and substance.*
*Abiding in a jade hall,*
*He begged for incense in a chamber of jade.*
*His Dao-heart was undivided—*
*Such is Orthodox Unity.*

The jade tablet for the posthumous investiture of the Perfected Lord, bestowed by Emperor Huizong of Song, reads:
*In the second year of Daguan, the cyclical year* wuzi*, on the sixteenth day of the tenth month, the first day of which was* dingchou*, We, the Emperor, reverently bow and declare:*
*The Dao is without fixed form,*
*Yet is perfected through humanity.*
*Of old, the utmost perfected ones*
*Used the Dao to flourish the age.*
*Their merit embraced the myriad things,*
*Thus they became enlightened sovereigns...*

The task is deemed worthy of such honor—how dare We not revere it? With reverence, We recall the Orthodox Unity Perfected Lord, the Three Heavens’ Upholder of the Dao, Auxiliary of Primordial Qi, Great Dharma Master of the Han Celestial Master: his embodiment of the subtle revealed the profound, bringing great benefit to the world. In the twilight of the Liu dynasty, his achievements flourished abundantly. Thus, he harnessed radiance and light, transcending the common multitude, concealing the true charts and secret ordinances, entrusting them to posterity. He eradicated demonic afflictions, warded off inauspicious omens, and in the unseen realm, startled the people—his fame enduring and ever more resplendent. Without such illustrious titles, how could We fully repay him? By bestowing honor and extolling his gracious favor, We now dispatch the Court-Bestowed Grand Master and Prefect of Xinzhou, Liu Yan, to confer the exalted title: *Perfected Lord of Orthodox Unity, Serene Response*.

The Great Dao is concealed in obscurity yet manifests in clarity; its merit extends afar yet is evident near at hand. Not that We alone can achieve this—only through unceasing constancy may one ascend to observe and reflect upon these deeds, thereby perpetuating their legacy, aiding and assisting Our state and household, and extending blessings to Our people. May boundless prosperity be proclaimed, enduring through eternal ages.

In the third year of Jiaxi under Emperor Lizong, he was further enfeoffed as *Perfected Lord of Orthodox Unity, Serene Response, Manifest Assistance*.

Minister Dao Yi states: The transformations of ghosts and spirits have existed since antiquity. When humans and ghosts intermingle in slaughter, the Dao is forsaken. The Celestial Master Zhang discerned the teachings of talismans and registers, comprehending the sentiments of Heaven and Earth, distinguishing yin and yang, and separating humans from ghosts. As for seizing ghosts in their hidden prisons and establishing the Twenty-Four Dioceses, this differs not from the Most High’s descent to subdue the ninety-five kinds of heterodox ways. The transmission of the Orthodox Unity teachings to later generations has been no small contribution.

Moreover, his virtue has descended to his descendants, who have inherited the true wind generation after generation, enduring to this day—could this not be Heaven’s reward for his merit?

The *Daodejing* states: *"When the Dao is used to govern the world, its ghosts lose their numinosity."* It is not that the ghosts lose their numinosity, but that their numinosity does no harm to people. And since their numinosity does no harm, the sage likewise does no harm. The Celestial Master Zhang must have profoundly grasped this principle.

*Comprehensive Mirror of Perfected Immortals Embracing the Dao Through the Ages*, Scroll 18 (conclusion)
*Comprehensive Mirror of Perfected Immortals Embracing the Dao Through the Ages*, Scroll 19

Wang Chang

Perfected Immortal Wang Chang—his native place is unknown—studied under Perfected Zhang of the Orthodox Unity. When the Perfected departed for Yunjin Mountain and dispersed his many disciples, only Wang Chang, versed in celestial patterns and master of the Huang-Lao teachings, remained to attend him. Chang then carried books and sang as he walked, accompanying the Perfected to Yunjin Mountain, where he served him daily. Ingesting elixirs and battling demons, he accumulated deeds and amassed merit. Later, on Quting Mountain, the Perfected one day pointed to Chang and said: “Only you, having planted goodness over many lives, bear the bone of an immortal from former times—you may now be brought to completion.” Thereupon he transmitted to him the essentials of the Nine Cauldrons, and Chang ascended in broad daylight.

Zhao Sheng

Perfected Immortal Zhao Sheng, styled Master Deer Hall—his native place is unknown. At first, when Perfected Zhang of the Orthodox Unity was in Shu, Sheng came from a thousand *li* away, wishing to take the disciple’s rites. The Perfected tested him with seven difficult tasks, yet Sheng remained steadfast from beginning to end. For the seventh trial, he and Wang Chang were sent to fetch peaches and cast into a valley, where they beheld the Perfected seated in a jeweled grove beneath a canopy of treasures. There they bowed and received the divine elixir and sacred scriptures. Later, having served the Perfected until his merit and conduct were complete, Sheng ascended to Heaven in broad daylight.

Your servant Daoyi observes: Zhao Sheng sought a master from a thousand *li* away, maintained unwavering sincerity, and was devoted to the Dao, forgetting his own body. He endured humiliation and bore disgrace, his resolve firm and his integrity unyielding. In the end, he grasped the Perfected’s teachings, received the profound mysteries of the Dao and virtue, accumulated deeds and amassed merit, refined his form, and ascended lightly. In his resolve, he differed not from the transmitted accounts of the Master who pierced the stone. Later seekers of immortality may truly take him as their model.

The *Daodejing* states: *“Those who strive resolutely possess the will.”* This is what it means.

Zhang Heng

Successor Master Zhang Heng, styled Lingzhen—also recorded as Ziping—was the eldest son of Zhang Zhengyi the Perfected. Skilled in celestial portents and the study of the Dao, he later emerged to serve the Han as Governor of Longxi, then rose to Attendant-in-Ordinary. From youth, he was broadly learned, yet lived in reclusion, refusing office, and gained great renown throughout the realm. When the Emperor heard of his mastery of the Dao, he summoned him to serve as Gentleman of the Yellow Gate, but Zhang declined. He withdrew from worldly affairs, practicing breath control and abstaining from grain. In the second year of Guanghe of Emperor Ling’s reign (159 C.E.), on the twenty-third day of the first lunar month, he transmitted the Perfected’s teachings to his son.

The Master and his wife, Lady Lu, attained the Dao on Mount Yangping and ascended to Heaven in broad daylight.

Zhang Lu
Zhang Lu, styled Gongqi—recorded in the *Book of Han* as Gongqi—was the eldest son of Successor Master Zhang. Devoted to the Dao, he upheld the Perfected’s teachings. He served the Han as Chief of Agriculture, General of Pacification, and Governor of Hanzhong and Nanzheng. Later, he withdrew to study the Dao, healing illnesses with talismans and methods, accepting a single *dou* of rice as payment, whereupon the afflicted would recover at once. Over time, his store of rice grew to tens of thousands. When the King of Wei learned of this, he dispatched envoys with troops to subdue him. His disciples warned him, but the Master said, “Take care not to fear.” He then ascended a ridge with his disciples and gazed out, seeing troops encircling them on all sides. The Master drew a river upon the earth with his tablet, its raging waves surging forth, plunging into unfathomable depths, blocking the soldiers’ advance. When the envoys returned with a naval force to the riverbank, the Master again drew upon the earth with his tablet, and a peak rose from the river’s midst, towering over a thousand *zhang*, halting their progress. The envoys returned and reported all that had transpired.

(Alternatively recorded: During the Jian’an era, Cao Cao usurped power, threatening the Han house. Though Zhang Lu resented this, he lacked the strength to oppose Cao, so he raised troops and fortified his position. Later, when King Liu Bei established Shu, he enfeoffed Zhang Lu as Duke of Fuyi, recognizing his loyalty. The King of Wei sent envoys to apologize, offering seals and ribbons to appoint him Governor of Liang and Yi Provinces, General Who Pacifies the South, and Marquis of Wen, with a fief of thirty thousand households. The Master firmly declined, telling the envoys, “I am a cultivator of the Dao, and the world admires those who ascend lightly. This division of land and titles is not my desire. Return the seals and ribbons, and do not come again.”)

Later, he refined his practice and ascended to Heaven riding a dragon.

(Alternatively recorded: Zhang Lu transcended on the southern peak of Mount Taibai, and his burial was in the southern district of Baocheng. Later, when Jiang Wei stationed troops in the western mountains of Shu, he encountered Zhang Lu amidst the celestial mists, but after a long while, he vanished.)

The Master had two younger brothers: the elder named Wei, the younger named Kui. Wei served as General Who Summons Righteousness, devoted himself to the Dao, and ascended to Heaven from Jialing. Kui served as Governor of Nanjun, then abandoned office to study the Dao. After a long time, he too ascended to Heaven in broad daylight.

Zhang Zi
Zhang Zi—recorded in the *Book of Han* as Fu, styled Yuanwei—was the eldest son of Successor Master Zhang. He was summoned to serve as an aide to the Chancellor, then as Gentleman of the Yellow Gate, later becoming Governor of Hanzhong and enfeoffed as Marquis of Changting. After a long time, he attained the Dao and departed through *shijie*.

He had four younger brothers: Yong, Sheng, Yi, and Ju.

Yong, styled Lingzong, served as Commandant of the Imperial Carriage, Gentleman-Consultant, and was enfeoffed as Marquis of Louting. He attained the Dao and departed through *shijie*.

Sheng, styled Yuanzong, served as Commandant of the Imperial Carriage and Gentleman Cavalier Attendant, enfeoffed as Marquis of Duting. Once, he sighed deeply and said, “The teachings of our ancestors have always been transmitted to the eldest son, yet my elder brothers all remained unmarried. Can it be that this line will end here?” During the Yongjia era of the Western Jin, one night he gazed eastward over the great river and saw auspicious vapors piercing the heavens. He said to his wife, “This can complete my elixir.” He then abandoned office and journeyed south. Upon reaching Poyang Commandery, he observed the vapors and said, “It is near.” After five days of traveling through the mountains, he arrived at a range of peaks, their beauty unmatched. Rejoicing, he declared, “I have found it!” At the summit stood a well and a cave where Perfected Ones had once refined elixirs and cultivated the Dao. He built a hut beside the well and cave. After a year, Lady Lu came searching for him, and they dwelled together on the mountain. They had one son.

(Alternatively recorded: Lady Lu carried a son from Shu and settled at the mountain’s base. After nine years, the elixir was complete. One day, he departed through *shijie*, and people called him the Dragon-Tiger. His descendants mostly lived to the northeast of the mountain.)

Yi, styled Lizong, served as General of the Van, Commandant of the Empress’s Carriage, General Who Quells Bandits, Governor of Hanzhong and Nanzheng, and Marquis of Wen. After a long time, he attained the Dao and departed through *shijie*.

Ju, styled Ruzong, served as Palace Attendant, Pacification Commissioner of the South, and Governor of Yiyang. After a long time, he too attained the Dao and departed through *shijie*.

(Alternatively recorded: The fourth brother was Sheng, the fifth Yi, the sixth Ju, and the seventh Mengde, styled Wenzong, who served as Grand Master for Admonition and Director of the Clan Court. He attained the Dao and departed through *shijie*.)

Today, at White Mist Abbey in Linlü, stands Great Auspicious Mountain. It is said to be the place where the fourth-generation descendant of the Celestial Master refined elixirs and attained the Dao. Tao Bi of the Song dynasty wrote a poem:

*Here the feathered guests ascend to the origin,*
*Ancient altars stand amid old trees.*
*The elixir’s auspicious glow remains,*
*Where the crane’s nest emptied as he rode away.*
*Seals were bestowed from Heaven,*
*Talismans linked to the Dao’s flow.*
*That true qi of the time—*
*In pines and cassia, the night wind blows.*

Zhang Zhaocheng
Zhang Zhaocheng, styled Daorong, was the eldest son of Sheng. He cultivated the Dao tirelessly, often sitting upright in his chamber while his spirit wandered hundreds of *li* away. He could tame tigers and leopards. At the age of one hundred and nineteen, he passed away, yet his body remained warm as if alive. After burial, thousands of mushrooms sprouted upon his tomb.

One day, villagers witnessed a crane emerge from his tomb, borne aloft by a radiant cloud. When the tomb was later opened, only his cap and shoes remained. Another account states that he attained the Dao during the early Jin dynasty and ascended as an immortal in the Xiankang era of Emperor Cheng.

Zhang Jiao
Zhang Jiao, styled Dexin, was the eldest son of Daorong. Having mastered the true method of governing spirits, he transmitted the secret registers bestowed by the perfected ones to ordain disciples in the world. The Jin emperor repeatedly summoned him, but he never answered the call. After attaining the Dao at over a hundred years of age, he bade farewell to his disciples and passed away in serene transformation.

Zhang Zhonghui
Zhang Zhonghui, styled Dechang, was the eldest son of Dexin. Inheriting his father’s teachings, he could abstain from grain and travel hundreds of *li* in a day. Later, he entered the Shu Mountains and never returned; his fate remains unknown.

Zhang Jiong
Zhang Jiong, styled Yanchao, was the eldest son of Dechang. He attained the Dao in his youth, possessed a graceful bearing, and excelled in discernment. Daily, he arranged the registers of the perfected ones by rank, reverently enshrining them in his oratory, where incense and offerings burned without cease throughout his life. In healing illnesses and expelling evil, none failed to recover, and the world held him in high esteem.

At ninety years of age, he passed away—alternatively, it is said that Emperor Tai of Qi summoned him to court.

Zhang Fu
Zhang Fu, styled Dexin, was the eldest son of Yanchao. Devoted to the Dao, he inherited and upheld the teachings of the Perfected Ones. He died at the age of ninety-two.

Zhang Zixiang
Zhang Zixiang, styled Linbo, was the eldest son of Dexin. Well-versed in the classics, he explored the wisdom of past and present. Assuming the robes of a scholar, he served the Sui dynasty as a magistrate in Luoyang. Before long, he resigned his post, retiring with his wife and children to Mount Longhu—alternatively, it is said that he once sighed: "Though the Sui have unified the realm, chaos will not be long in coming." Thus, he withdrew and never again took office. Hundreds of disciples gathered around him, their aspirations fixed on self-cultivation. His complexion grew ever more youthful, perpetually resembling that of a man of twenty. He could expel the cinnabar elixir from his abdomen, place it in his palm, and play with it; or cast it into a vessel at night, where its radiance pierced the roof, before swallowing it again. After long years, he attained the Dao and died at the age of one hundred and two—alternatively, one hundred and twenty. His coffin was remarkably light. On the night of his burial, a hole suddenly appeared in his tomb. When the mound was opened, only his clothing remained.

Zhang Tong
Zhang Tong—alternatively, his given name was Zhongda, as the character *tong* conflicted with a taboo name of the Song dynasty—was the eldest son of Linbo. He inherited and upheld the teachings of the Perfected Ones. For forty years, he kept his door closed and never ventured out, and his wife and children saw him only at appointed times. After many years, he attained the Dao and died at the age of ninety-seven.

After several months in the coffin, his corpse remained entirely undecayed. Both Tong and Gaoshun shared names that violated ancestral naming taboos—though the reason for this remains unclear.

Zhang Zhongchang
Zhang Zhongchang, styled Derun, was the eldest son of Zhongda. Well-versed in Confucian texts, he too possessed numinous abilities. Emperor Gaozong of Tang summoned him to court, but he secretly returned home, sighing, *"I nearly fell into the snare of the world."* He studied the Dao at home, inheriting and upholding the teachings of the Perfected Ones. Skilled in bilocation and transformation, he once pushed a vat into his chamber, where he ate meat and drank wine with his wife. That night, drunk beside the vat, he vomited into it—yet the contents remained unspoiled for days. He died at the age of ninety-eight. Another account states that he buried the vat in his chamber, eating meat and drinking wine before his wife and children. That night, when the vat was opened, all were found inside, yet none had decayed after days.

Zhang Guang
Zhang Guang, styled Dezhao, was the eldest son of Derun. From youth, he received the teachings of the Perfected Ones. After many years, he abandoned his wife and, with his second son Wu, entered the mountains to cultivate for over two decades. He later emerged to reunite with his wife, living together for another five years. He passed away at home at the age of one hundred and two, while Wu also mastered the art of grain avoidance.

Zhang Cizheng
Zhang Cizheng, styled Ziming, was the eldest son of Dezhao. Well-versed in the classics, he excelled in the *Book of Changes*, with over a hundred disciples studying under him. After many years, he withdrew to the mountains to cultivate the Dao, living apart from his wife and children. He transmitted the teachings of the Perfected Ones, bestowing the secret registers of the Three Primes upon initiates each year, drawing seekers from all directions. With the alms he accumulated, he aided impoverished scholars during famine years. He also mastered the arts of refining cinnabar and transmuting base metals. He died in the mountains at over a hundred years of age, and faint strains of celestial music were heard in the air. Another account states that he could transmute tiles into gold and silver with an elixir, forging them into vessels; when cast into water or passed through fire, they reverted to tiles.

Zhang Gao
Zhang Gao, styled Shilong (later changed from Shilong to Shilong to avoid the taboo of Emperor Xuanzong of Tang), was the eldest son of Ziming. He studied the Dao and upheld the teachings of the Perfected Ones, drinking up to a *dan* of wine without intoxication. Emperor Minghuang of Tang summoned him to the capital, where he officiated at an altar to receive the registers. The emperor bestowed gold and silk upon him, exempted him from taxes, and enfeoffed him with the title "Celestial Master of the Han Ancestor." Emperor Suzong burned incense and performed rituals, personally inscribing a eulogy in imperial calligraphy to honor the Celestial Master. During the Zhenyuan era, imperial offerings were sent, including a gold-gilded silver censer, incense box, a brocade-trimmed golden scarf, and yellow-covered vessels. He died at home at the age of ninety-one.

Zhang Yingshao
Zhang Yingshao, styled Zhifeng, was the eldest son of Shilong. Well-versed in the classics, he later retreated to the mountains to practice grain avoidance, capable of fasting for a hundred days. He farmed alongside his wife and children and could play an iron flute, its notes carrying for miles.

One day, he said to his son: "Our family has transmitted the teachings of the Perfected for generations, and our merits have extended to many. Now, as my years draw to a close, you must carry on and preserve them." Having spoken, he sat upright in stillness, closed his eyes, and passed away at the age of ninety-nine.

Zhang Shun
Zhang Shun, styled Zhongfu (also recorded as Zhongfu), was the eldest son of Zhifeng. From youth, he served his mother with filial piety, saying: "To seek the Dao and pursue immortality while being unfilial and disloyal is like abandoning a boat to ford a great river." He served as the Guishui Magistrate of his home county but later relinquished his post along with his wife and children, dwelling in a thatched hut. At the age of eighty-seven, his complexion remained youthful and his teeth white; he passed away without illness.

Zhang Shiyuan
Zhang Shiyuan, styled Zhongliang, was the eldest son of Zhongfu. In his youth, he studied broadly across many books and only began cultivating the Dao after the age of forty. He practiced night meditation, and after a long time, he could move his arms freely up and down, entering and exiting as if flying. He transmitted talismanic methods to others and treated illnesses, and he could make peach and plum trees bear fruit in an instant. When the local lord heard of his attainment, he repeatedly summoned him with offers of prestigious offices, but Shiyuan firmly declined. He passed away at home at the age of ninety-two.

Zhang Xiu
Zhang Xiu, styled Dezhen, was the eldest son of Zhongliang. He was simple and unadorned, always wearing plain cloth and disliking ostentation. He farmed with his wife in the fields and did not associate with the villagers.

Each year, he transmitted talismanic methods to others and treated illnesses, with effects manifesting immediately. All the alms he received from his teachings he distributed to impoverished scholars, content in solitude and free from desire. Two years prior, he personally arranged his tomb and said, "I shall depart in two years." When the time came, he bathed, changed his clothes, sat upright, and passed away, aged eighty-five.

*The Record of Divine Verifications* states: Liu Qian, a wealthy merchant from Jiangxi, sought the transmission of the *Dugong* talismanic cord from the Nineteenth-Generation Celestial Master. The following year, he died in Jinling but revived after two nights. He recounted: "I was seized by officials of the underworld when suddenly a golden light descended from the heavens. A yellow-robed messenger arrived through the air, holding a white tablet and reading aloud: 'Liu Qian bears the *Zhengyi* cord; his name is recorded in the celestial registers, not under the jurisdiction of the earthly authorities. Though his allotted time has come, he may be granted thirty more years.'" Thereafter, he donned coarse robes and cultivated the Dao, entering Dragon-Tiger Mountain to serve as a disciple to the Celestial Master.

Zhang Chen
Zhang Chen, styled Zijian, was the eldest son of Dezhen. A learned scholar of his time, he mastered both cursive and clerical scripts. In his later years, he embraced the Dao and was capable of *bigu*. Some say Emperor Wenzong of Tang summoned him and offered an official post, which he declined before returning home. During the *Xiantong* era of Emperor Yizong, he was invited to preside over a grand *Jian* ritual. One day, after three rounds of drinking, he became thoroughly intoxicated and passed away, aged over a hundred.

Zhang Bingyi
Zhang Bingyi, also known as Yankang, styled Wenfu, was the eldest son of Zijian. His mother initially dreamed of a golden—or in some versions, enormous—tortoise entering her womb, and upon waking, conceived. In his youth, he studied the Dao and could see clearly through walls.

Zhang Bingyi once amassed a fortune of a thousand gold pieces, which he used during years of famine to purchase grain and distribute it to the poor and destitute. At the age of ninety-two, he said to his wife one day, "When I die, if there is an earthquake, then encoffin and bury me." Having spoken these words, he sat upright, holding a ritual tablet, and passed away. Seven days later, an earthquake indeed occurred, and they encoffined and buried him; his body remained warm and uncorrupted.

Zhang Shan
Zhang Shan, styled Yuanchang, was the eldest son of Wenfu. From childhood, he abstained from meat, and in adulthood, he embraced the Dao. He traveled through famous mountains and great rivers for twenty years before returning home. Thereafter, he never left his dwelling, deeply cultivating inner refinement. He died at the age of eighty-seven—or, in some accounts, eighty-one.

Zhang Jiwen
Zhang Jiwen, styled Zhonggui, was the son of Yuanchang. Each year, he transmitted the secret methods of the various ranks to disciples capable of cultivation, using talismanic water to cure illnesses with immediate effect. He died at the age of eighty-seven.

Zhang Zhengsui
Zhang Zhengsui, styled Baoshen, was the eldest son of Zhonggui. His nature was honest and unadorned; he did not associate with worldly people and, when encountering them on the road, would hasten to avoid them. Each year, he transmitted the dharma of initiation and alms to relieve the poor and destitute, disregarding his own poverty.

Zhang passed away at the age of eighty-seven and was posthumously enfeoffed as Master Zhenjing.

Zhang Qianyao
Zhang Qianyao was the eldest son of Baoshen. Fond of the Dao, he upheld the teachings and statutes of the Perfected Master. The *Huiyao* states: In the eighth year of the Dazhong Xiangfu era, the Daoist Zhang Qianyao of Xinzhou was summoned to the capital, where an altar was established at the Upper Clarity Palace to transmit the register and ordain disciples. When Emperor Renzong of Song heard of his attainment in the Dao, he summoned him to court in the fifth month of the eighth year of the Tiansheng era and bestowed upon him the title Master Chengsu. The emperor inquired about the matter of ascending in flight, and after a long pause, he replied, "This cannot serve to assist governance and instruction." The emperor praised his response. When asked about his sons, he answered that his eldest had inherited the Dao while the second pursued Confucian studies. Thereupon, his second son, Jiansu, was appointed as a general and served as a supervisor of the registry. Though Jiansu held office, his heart remained devoted to the Dao. After retiring as a Gentleman of the Court of the Imperial Stud, he withdrew to seclusion at Shuhu in Poyang, where his descendants reside to this day.

Zhang Sizong
Zhang Sizong was the eldest son of Master Chengsu. He inherited the teachings of the Perfected Master and transmitted the secret registers. Having mastered the method of exhaling and inhaling qi, he appeared as a child at seventy. He died at the age of eighty-one and was posthumously enfeoffed as Master Xubai. The *Huiyao* states: In the eighth month of the third year of the Zhihe era, he was bestowed the title Master Chongjing.

Zhang Xiangzhong
Zhang Xiangzhong, styled Gongchen, was the eldest son of Master Xubai. At the age of seven, he was granted the purple robe and succeeded to the lineage.
