Another account states that at thirteen, he was exceptionally intelligent, widely versed in the classics and histories, and particularly skilled in the arts of the Dao.

Emperor Renzong of the Song summoned him for an audience, granted him a seat, and consulted him on the subtleties of Daoist methods. The emperor specially bestowed upon him a purple robe and personally brushed an imperial inscription to bless the ancestral temple, further presenting him with silk and gold vessels. Thereafter, the court’s favor and honors continued unabated, and he succeeded to the teachings of the Perfected Master without negligence throughout his life.

Zhang Dunfu
Zhang Dunfu, styled Yanzhi, was the eldest son of Gongchen. In his youth, he wore the scholar’s robe and gained renown in the examination halls. Later, as the eldest son, he succeeded to the twenty-eighth generation of the Orthodox Unity lineage, greatly promoting his ancestral traditions, which were revered by all quarters. He died at the age of fifty-three and was posthumously enfeoffed as Master Baoguang.

Zhang Jingduan
Zhang Jingduan, styled Ziren, was a descendant of the twenty-fourth generation, named Di, the fifth son. Devoted to the Dao, he succeeded to the teachings of the Perfected Master. He died at the age of thirty-one—another account states fifty-two—and was posthumously enfeoffed as Master Baozhen.

Zhang Jixian
Zhang Jixian, styled Zunzheng, was a descendant of the twenty-sixth generation. His father, named Churen and styled Dexuan, was a Gentleman for Announcing Teachings and magistrate of Linchuan, and he was the second son. At the age of nine, he succeeded to the teachings of the Perfected Master. From the Chongning era of Emperor Huizong onward, he was summoned to court four times, granted the title Master Xujing, and ranked as a Grand Master for Thorough Service. Initially, Emperor Shenzong had the six-character seal of the Perfected Master—"Yangping Zhi Du Gong Yin"—carved from kun jade and stored in the Repository of the Processional Regalia at the Sanqing Chuxiang Palace, intending to bestow it upon one of virtuous attainment. At this time, it was granted to Jixian. Subsequently, he was further enfeoffed as Perfected Lord of Orthodox Unity, Serene Response, and Manifest Protection, and an edict was issued to the relevant authorities to establish a subordinate abbey in the eastern part of his fief for his residence, bestowing upon it the name Chongdao. Additional funds were granted to renovate the Shangqing Palace on Longhu Mountain, and the Bukou Estate, valued at fifty thousand, was allocated to provide meals for his followers. The name of the palace was changed to the Shangqing Orthodox Unity Palace. His ancestors and father were posthumously enfeoffed with honorific titles, and his grandmothers, née Chen and Feng, as well as his sister Baozhen, were ordained as Daoist priestesses and provided with a Daoist abbey for their residence. Following the precedent of Master Chengsu, his elder brother Shaoxian was appointed Acting Gentleman of the Interior, and the imperial favors were exceedingly generous. The Master’s aspirations lay in serenity and simplicity, and he declined further honors to return home. He once constructed the Jingtong Hermitage behind the Shangqing Palace as a place for heart-fasting and sitting in forgetfulness, and he also practiced refinement following the legacy of his ancestral master’s Cloud Brocade Mountain, Dragon-Tiger Elixir Cauldron. Auspicious radiance and propitious light illuminated the valleys, and sites such as the Hall of Descending Auspiciousness and the Cauldron-Washing Pool remain to this day. Later, he composed *Heart Discourse* and *Song of the Great Dao* to bequeath to the world.

In the dingwei year, at the age of thirty-six, Emperor Qinzong summoned him to court. He reached Sizhou, where he attained transformation. In the winter of the jiyou year, he attended the birthday feast of Master Bi at the Ximen in Hangzhou. That year, bandits invaded the region, and the Master forewarned the assembly before departing. To this day, those who chant the Dao and travel often encounter him at Luofu or in western Shu, his presence elusive and uncertain.

Another account states: In the sixth month of the wushen year, the Master, together with Zhang Tongzhi of Hedong, returned from the capital. Upon reaching Sizhou, they rested at the Weaving Boat Tax Pavilion. Feeling slightly unwell, he drank a cup of broth and immediately departed this life, his body taking on the hue of wax. Daoist priests from Yanchang Abbey requested his remains for burial, but the tax official refused. He was temporarily interred on official land, with Magistrate Zhang overseeing the matter. Later, Zhang received an edict to retrieve Liu Wenkou, and he recounted the events to Zhang Jiuzhong of Xinzhou, who served as Military Attaché. Jiuzhong said, "At that time, the Heavenly Master came to die by this river, and a tomb of the immortal remains there." Shortly afterward, someone arrived from Guizhou bearing a letter from the Heavenly Master thanking Magistrate Zhang, revealing that he had not died. Others claimed to have seen him at Luofu in Huizhou.

Zhang Shixiu
Zhang Shixiu, styled Chaoying, was a descendant of Master Xubai. He was well-versed in Confucian scholarship and sat for the examinations multiple times without success. Thereafter, he retired in tranquility, his aspirations turning toward cultivation and refinement. As Master Xujing remained unmarried and had no heir, the community urged Shixiu to succeed to the lineage.

At the age of sixty-one, he shed his mortal form at the ancestral residence of Longhu. **Zhang Shouzhen**

Zhang Shouzhen, styled Zunyi, was the eldest son of Chaoying. His mother, née Wu, once dreamed that she was given a divine fruit, and was told, "If you eat this, the son you bear will preside over the seal of merit for the Yangping governance." Born with a pure and serene disposition, he grew to be sparing of desires.

In the tenth year of the Shaoxing reign of the Song (gengshen, 1140), he succeeded to the hereditary teachings. Each year during the Three Primes, he transmitted the precepts, and from all directions, people gathered like spokes to a hub. He dispelled evil and purified toxins, and the Dao flourished under his guidance.

On the seventh day of the second month in the twenty-ninth year (1159), Emperor Gaozong bestowed upon him the title *Master of Right Response*. On the thirteenth day of the tenth month in the sixth year of the Qiandao reign (1170), Emperor Gaozong summoned him. On the thirteenth day of the eleventh month, he was ordered to proceed to the Deshou Palace and was lodged at the Yangyu Villa. Three days later, he was granted an audience, offered a seat, and consulted on the methods of the Dao, with great warmth. On the nineteenth day, Emperor Xiaozong summoned him, granted him a seat, bestowed upon him a golden-tin fast, and upon his return to his lodgings, presented him with frequent gifts.

On the nineteenth day of the twelfth month, Emperor Gaozong commanded a jiao ritual at the Yuetai Terrace, where his prayers met with extraordinary responses. The following year, he was summoned again.

Having long preserved the various treasures of the Three Caverns, he was granted gold by the Directorate of Daoist Rites to cast movable type and compile the texts. At the Yanxiang Abbey, he transmitted the precepts and was commanded to take the printing blocks back with him. He was also bestowed an ivory tablet, a *jingzhen* sword, and a handwritten copy of the *Yinfu Jing*.

After Master Shouzhen returned to his retreat, he remained carefree and content, untroubled by worldly concerns. He often said, "I have collected the writings of my elder brother, Master Xujing, who made an appointment to travel to Shu. I shall go there to wander." On the thirtieth day of the tenth month in the third year of the Chunxi reign (1176), he shed his mortal form without illness.

**Zhang Bojing**

Zhang Bojing, styled Deying, was the eldest son of Master of Right Response. Tall and dignified, with a jade-like complexion, a fine beard, and a majestic presence, people said he bore the manner of the Orthodox Unity lineage.

During the Qiandao reign of Emperor Xiaozong of the Song, he accompanied Master of Right Response to the imperial summons. Emperor Gaozong granted him a seat and bestowed a fast upon him, and with his own brush, changed his name to Jingyuan. Later, he was received in the Southern Palace, where he expounded on the methods of the Dao and was greatly praised and accepted.

A month later, Emperor Gaozong commanded Master of Right Response to perform a grand jiao ritual at the Yuetai Terrace. Master of Right Response entrusted Jingyuan with the proceedings, and each time, extraordinary responses were obtained. The emperor bestowed frequent gifts and presented him with an ivory tablet before his return.

Thereafter, he oversaw the teachings of the Three Primes and the transmission of talismans and registers, which flourished under his guidance. Initially, the Prince of Wei, who was stationed in Mingzhou, summoned the master to his jade altar, and their bond grew especially deep. One day, after sending someone to present gifts and extend an invitation, he suddenly said to his disciples, "Though the favor of men may reach its height, I have my own celestial appointment, which I cannot miss." He then leaned against his desk and shed his mortal form.

**Zhang Qingxian**

Zhang Qingxian, styled Shaozu, was the legitimate son of Deying. Before Qingxian’s birth, Deying had raised his younger brother Sixian as his heir and subsequently instructed him in the ancestral teachings. When Qingxian descended into the world, his celestial bearing was refined and elegant, his nature simple and reticent—much like Liezi dwelling in the gardens of Zheng, unknown to his contemporaries. In time, his reputation grew fragrant, his numinous marvels shone forth, and Daoists and layfolk alike revered and turned toward him, unanimously declaring: “Truly the heir of the Master of Right Response.” Thereupon, he was officially recognized, and in the first month of the fifth year of Jiatai of Song Ningzong’s reign (the xinyou year), he inherited the thirty-fourth generation’s position. The transmission of the Three Primes and registers drew clouds of devotees bearing incense and offerings.

The master ever maintained his true purity, lived frugally at home, and treated all beings with kindness and compassion. Upon encountering scholars in poverty or wandering in cold solitude, he felt particular pity and relieved their distress. He had no other indulgences, save for a fondness for wine, though he never succumbed to drunkenness. In the second year of Jiading, during the Lower Prime’s altar-opening, seven days later, a scholar in a crimson robe and headscarf appeared—his spirit majestic and towering, resembling one of the Dao. The crowd did not inquire whence he came, but the master, upon seeing him, opened the wine vessel and offered his seat, as if they were lifelong friends. After parting, they still whispered to each other, lingering for some time before he departed. From then on, the master burned incense and abstained from grain, disengaging from worldly affairs. His family, sensing his imminent transformation, entreated him for final teachings, but he remained silent. On the twenty-ninth day of that month, he rose at dawn, washed and groomed as usual, then sat serenely in repose and shed his mortal form.

**Zhang Keda**
Zhang Keda, styled Zixian, was the second son of Master of Right Response, grandson of Boli, and second son of Master of Benevolent Stillness, Tianlin. Earlier, when Jingyuan ascended, Boli had temporarily assumed the thirty-fourth generation’s duties. When Qingxian ascended, his legitimate son Chengda was still young, so Tianlin again acted as the thirty-fifth generation’s master, transmitting its teachings. He was summoned by Song Ningzong and bestowed the title *Master of Benevolent Stillness*. Soon after, Chengda passed early, and Keda was designated Qingxian’s successor. In the third year of Shaoding of Lizong’s reign, when Master of Benevolent Stillness ascended, Keda was only thirteen, yet he rightfully inherited the thirty-fifth generation’s teachings. His spirit was striking and extraordinary, his nature and wisdom uncommon. Disciples from all directions seeking registers and transmissions numbered in the tens of thousands, and the Dao’s transformation flourished.

In the third year of Duanping, he received an imperial decree granting funds to reprint the registers bestowed by previous emperors. In the second year of Jiaxi, he was enfeoffed as *True Lord of Right Response, Stillness, Manifest Aid*. The deities of Zhufa, Wushan, Yuquan, and Longjing were all granted titles. In the third year’s fourth month, he was summoned by imperial decree to the temporary capital, where his prayers for receding tides, rain, locust eradication, and frontier protection all met with divine response. In the seventh month, he was received in audience, granted a seat and vegetarian meal, and bestowed the title *Master of Observing the Mysterious*. The emperor’s praise was profound, his gifts abundant, and he further granted funds to restore the *True and August Abbey* of former reigns, designating it as a residence for mother and son, endowing it with land and exempting it from taxes. The emperor personally inscribed the abbey’s plaque, as well as those of the *Hall of True Wind* and the *Purple Tenuity Pavilion*, and bestowed a fan inscribed with his own calligraphy:

*"When spirit and Dao become one,
Heaven and man are linked as kin.
If with precision and devotion you guard,
You shall ride the clouds and soar the mists."*

The master also petitioned the court on behalf of the deities of Zhufa, Wushan, Yuquan, and Longjing, all of whom were granted noble ranks. Thereafter, imperial favor deepened, and there was no year without imperial summons, incense offerings, or altar rites—each prayer met with response. In the second year of Baoyou, he was again summoned by imperial decree to the temporary capital to preside over Longxiang Abbey. Pleading old age among his kin, he declined, and the emperor assented, appointing him *Supervisor of the Three Mountains’ Registers, Overseer of the Imperial Abbeys’ Teachings, and Director of Longxiang Abbey*—a position he held in absentia to this day.

Having secured his request, he harbored the intent to wander beyond the world. In the third year of Jingding, he transmitted the teachings to his second son, Zongyan, and submitted a memorial to inform the throne. On the tenth day of the fourth month, he shed his mortal form. The emperor and crown prince each bestowed funeral gifts, and upon his interment, imperial bestowals were especially generous. Chancellor Jiang Wanli composed his stele inscription.

*Comprehensive Mirror of Perfected Immortals Who Embodied the Dao, Scroll Nineteen (concluded)*
*Comprehensive Mirror of Perfected Immortals Who Embodied the Dao, Scroll Twenty*

Gan Ji

Gan Ji was a native of Langye—some say of Beihai. Originally named Shi, he later changed his name to Ji. His ancestors for generations had possessed Daoist arts and refrained from taking life; Ji’s devotion and austerity surpassed even theirs. He often wandered by the flowing waters of Quyang, where he obtained over a hundred scrolls of divine scripture, written on red silk with white silk borders, their headings in blue and their characters in vermilion. These were called the *Tai Ping Qing Ling Shu* (The Green-Headed Scripture of Great Peace), received in the second year of Heping, the jiawu year, during the reign of Emperor Cheng of Han. It is said that Ji personally received this teaching from Lord Lao, and it is now known as the *Daoist Scripture of Great Peace*. The text is divided into ten sections according to the ten celestial stems—jia, yi, bing, ding, wu, ji, geng, xin, ren, and gui—each section comprising seventeen scrolls.

Another account states that Ji suddenly fell gravely ill, suffering for over a decade without remedy. One morning, he burned incense and piteously entreated Heaven, vowing to seek deliverance. Lord Lao, moved by his sincerity, sent the immortal Bo He to appear as an old medicine-seller in the marketplace. There, Bo He bestowed the scripture upon Ji, saying, “By obtaining this book, you will not only be cured of your illness but will attain longevity and transform the world.” Ji bowed in gratitude and received it; his illness vanished at once. Lord Lao descended again to personally instruct him in its essentials. Ji then compiled the earlier scriptures into a total of one hundred and seventy scrolls.

Having grasped its teachings, he cultivated himself and nurtured his nature, dispelling misfortune and curing illnesses—all with unfailing efficacy. Its core principles declare: “When a person is born, Heaven bestows spirit upon them, Earth bestows essence, and the harmonious void bestows qi. If one can preserve essence, cherish spirit, and safeguard qi, then inwardly one attains longevity, and outwardly one brings great peace to the realm.”

It further states: “A minister’s conduct should begin with love for their lord, desiring his long life. As a child, one should remember their parents, fearing their advancing age, and guide their hearts toward the Dao. One should constantly seek rare formulas and extraordinary arts to serve one’s lord and parents. As a disciple, one should remember the kindness of one’s teacher. For a person is born of parents, their virtue and power are perfected by their teacher, and their honor and glory come from their lord. When one reflects that one’s lord, parents, and teacher are aging and there is nothing to repay them, one should study diligently, serve the worthy and enlightened, and seek rare formulas and wondrous methods to benefit them. Such is the most excellent loyal minister, filial child, and obedient disciple of the Highest Antiquity and the August Sovereigns. If all people act thus, the world will be at great peace.”

“Those with sincerity in their hearts perform only good deeds. Their words and actions are pure and steadfast, their minds self-disciplined. They purify their hearts and reform their conduct, moving even the heavens above. When they receive Heaven’s grace, they express gratitude and repay it. Through unwavering devotion, they attain the realm of immortals.”

One of its formulas states: “My character ‘shi’ with eleven strokes is called ‘scholar.’ Bingwu and dingsi are the ancestral beginnings. Four mouths govern affairs and the principles of all things. The child’s cap uses the corner to govern the right. The hidden dragon must not act—Kan corresponds to si. If people see it, their lives will be long. Dwelling between Heaven and Earth, one merely lives, yet by governing a hundred thousand people, immortality may be awaited. Those who skillfully cure illness must not dispense lightly. There is no joy like that of the marketplace in Chang’an. May people’s lives be as long as the Queen Mother of the West, returning to the beginning like the four seasons in their cycle.” Ninety characters in all, this strategy was transmitted to the fangshi.

For these were the divine elixirs and rare medicines with which one could serve one’s lord, parents, and teacher. Lord Lao also bestowed upon Ji the methods of the *Kejie Jijiu* (Precepts and Admonitions for Libationers) to transmit to him.

Later, Ji revered the scripture and practiced the Dao, disseminating its teachings among his disciples. He established male and female officials, widely transforming the people, and from all directions they turned toward him. In the second year of Yuanhe during the reign of Emperor Xiaozhang, Lord Lao descended again and reproached Ji, saying, “I previously entrusted you with the Dao to aid the state and sustain life, worrying for the myriad people. Yet in recent times, your male and female disciples, invoking my name and position, have grown greedy for wealth, indulged in desire, become arrogant and haughty, envied the worthy, and suppressed talent, all the while engaging in mutual slander. This is not how it should be, and so I have come to speak with you.”

Ji prostrated himself, touching his head to the ground a hundred times, and said, “Yes, yes! I beg the Most High to pardon past transgressions and allow me to cultivate future goodness. From this day forward, how may I save my male and female disciples from reproach?”

Lord Lao replied, “Listen well to my teaching. Even if a person lives ten thousand years, without upholding the precepts, how do they differ from an ancient tree or a long-standing stone? Better to die upholding the precepts for the sake of virtue and power than to live in violation of them. Those who uphold the precepts mend the heavenly offices and ascend as immortals through liberation in the corpse. Though one may be a king or a duke, or even an emperor, if they commit grave sins, it will be of no benefit to their soul and spirit. Can they not grieve over this? Clearly uphold my precepts and teach them to others.”

Thereupon, he expounded one hundred and eighty precepts. When he finished, he said to Ji, “The ancient sages of old all attained the Dao through these. The Dao has no form; it is perfected through a teacher. The Dao must not be abandoned, nor the teacher slighted.”

Ji bowed deeply, received the command, and expressed his gratitude with repeated bows.

Later, Ji took up residence in Kuaiji. When Sun Ce pacified the Jiangdong region and advanced to attack Kuaiji, he saw that the people all called Ji “Gan Lang” and revered him as a deity. Sun Ce summoned Ji to be a guest in his army. Many of his officers and soldiers fell ill, and when Ji prayed over water for them, they were immediately cured. Sun Ce, leading tens of thousands of troops, intended to welcome Emperor Xian and campaign against Cao Cao. He had Ji divine the winds and omens, and each time the results were divinely accurate. The officers and soldiers all venerated Ji, bowing to him before paying respects to Sun Ce.

Sun Ce, seeing that many of his officers were with Ji, grew enraged and said, “Am I not the equal of Lord Gan?” He arrested Ji and reproached him, saying, “The heavens have long been dry, and the waterways are blocked. You do not share in the people’s worries but sit idly in your boat, playing the part of a ghost, misleading my officers and soldiers, and disrupting my ranks. Today I shall do away with you.” He bound Ji and exposed him to the scorching sun, ordering him to pray for rain. “If you can move Heaven and bring a great downpour by midday, I will pardon you. If not, you will be executed.”

Suddenly, clouds gathered and rain poured down in torrents, causing the river to overflow. The officers and soldiers all congratulated Ji, but Sun Ce proceeded to kill him. The officers and soldiers wept as they collected his remains for burial. The next day, when they went to visit the grave, his body had vanished.

Sun Ce was deeply remorseful, and from then on, Ji often appeared before and behind him. Later, Sun Ce was soon wounded by an assassin sent by Xu Gong. Gazing into a mirror, he saw Ji within it; greatly startled, he struck the mirror and cried out, whereupon the wound in his chest split open and he died.

The *Hunyuan Shilu* states: Ji lingered among people for over a hundred years before ascending as an immortal.

Your servant Daoyi says: The *Daodejing* states, “Fine weapons are inauspicious tools—things may detest them, and thus those who possess the Dao do not dwell with them.” Ji’s ancestors revered the Dao, and he himself diligently cultivated the practices of those who came before him. Yet he ended up in the midst of military affairs and was killed by Sun Ce. Though this may be called a “martial liberation,” had Ji instead withdrawn into seclusion, accumulating merit through hidden deeds, who is to say he would not have attained the rank of ascension? Those who study the immortal arts hereafter should take the presence of fine weapons as a profound warning.

Guan Song
Guan Song was a native of Langye. Gifted in literature, he composed over a hundred scrolls of writings. He became a disciple of the adept Gan Shi. During the reign of Emperor Yuan of Han, Song followed Ji to Quyang Spring, where they encountered celestial immortals who bestowed upon Ji the *Tai Ping Jing* in ten fascicles, written in cinnabar on green silk. Ji practiced its teachings and attained the Dao, then transmitted the text to Song. Later, Song presented this work to the court. Its contents extensively discuss the waxing and waning of yin and yang, calamities and blessings, and expound the Dao of Heaven, the Dao of Earth, and the Dao of Man. It declares that rulers who employ its principles may attain longevity—such is its essence. Song ingested mica and lived for several centuries, retaining the complexion of a youth. Later, he entered and exited Fenlyu Mountain and ascended as an immortal.

Wang Daozhen
Wang Daozhen was a man of the Han dynasty.

Wang Daozhen attained the Dao at the Ancient Cypress Terrace east of Ghost Valley Mountain, where white clouds perpetually emerged from within the terrace, appearing from afar like a towering pavilion of a hundred feet. Daozhen often rode these clouds, frolicking atop the mountain peaks, and at dusk returned to the terrace, where the white clouds would likewise gather and withdraw into it. This place is Ghost Valley Mountain north of Qingxi in Jingzhou. Some claim this to be a terrace, but this is incorrect.

The Perfected Immortal Wang Xuanfu
The Perfected Immortal, surnamed Wang and named Xuanfu, was a man of Donghai from the Han dynasty. He studied the Dao under the Perfected One of White Clouds and was also known as the Perfected One of Huayang. He descended to the world on the fifteenth day of the sixth month and ascended on the sixteenth day of the tenth month, though the dynasty of his time is unrecorded. Later, he transmitted the Dao to Zhongli Quan, also known as Zhongli Jue, the Master of Rectifying the Intestines. His written works, though profound, were not widely transmitted. One of his poems, recorded in the *Hun Cheng Ji*, reads:

Within Huayang Mountain lie fields of magic mushrooms,
The old man of Huayang ever extends his years.
Beneath the towering boughs by the verdant pine crags,
He drinks from flying springs amid the billowing white clouds.
Neither cold nor hot, his spirit drifts free,
From east to west his qi flows unbroken.
With three thousand meritorious deeds complete, he returns—
No need to ask others of the grotto-heavens.

In the sixth year of the Zhiyuan reign of the Great Yuan, he was posthumously enfeoffed as the Lesser Yang Emperor of the Purple Palace of Donghua.

Ji Zixun
Ji Zixun’s countenance remained youthful even after two hundred years.

Once, while holding a neighbor’s infant at a gathering, he accidentally dropped the child, who died upon hitting the ground. The child’s family immediately buried it. Ji Zixun arrived from outside, retrieved the child, and returned it alive. Fearing he might be a ghost, the family dug up the burial site, only to find nothing but earth. During the Han dynasty, no noble in the capital failed to earnestly seek an audience with him. Upon his arrival in the capital, officials from the ranks of ministers and below thronged his residence, often numbering in the hundreds, all offering him wine and dried meats, which never ran out throughout the day. One day, students from the Imperial Academy came to invite Ji Zixun. He set out at mealtime and arrived by midday, having traveled over a thousand *li* in less than half a day. He visited twenty-three households, and the nobles, delighted, each believed he had come to them first. The next day, when they inquired among themselves, they found that Ji Zixun’s attire and complexion had remained unchanged, astonishing all near and far. Later, he departed belatedly, and his whereabouts became unknown. On the day he left, only white clouds were seen rising in dozens of places. Travelers in Bacheng, east of Chang’an, witnessed him rubbing a bronze statue with an old man, remarking to each other, “We just saw this cast, yet nearly five hundred years have passed.” Those who saw him called out, “Master Ji, stay a while!” Though he walked at a leisurely pace, even galloping horses could not overtake him.

According to the *Accounts of Immortals*, Ji Zixun was a native of Qi. He was recommended as a filial and incorrupt candidate, appointed Gentleman of the Palace, and later served as a Commandant. None knew he possessed the Dao. Other records of his deeds are largely the same.

Wang Qiao
Wang Qiao was a native of Hedong. During the reign of Emperor Ming of the Han, he served as a Gentleman of the Imperial Secretariat before being appointed Magistrate of Ye County. By Han law, officials within the capital region were required to return to court on the first day of each month. Wang Qiao, however, would arrive at the imperial court from his county every first day of the month. The emperor marveled at his frequent appearances yet absence of carriage or escort, so he secretly ordered the court astronomers to observe him. They reported that each time he neared, a pair of birds would fly in from the southeast. The emperor then ordered nets to be set, and upon capture, one of the birds was found to be a single shoe. When sent to the Imperial Workshop for examination, it was identified as one of the shoes issued to Gentlemen of the Imperial Secretariat four years prior. Whenever court was in session, the drum at the gate of Ye County would sound of its own accord, audible even in the capital.

Later, a jade coffin appeared before the hall. Though officials and commoners pushed and pulled, it would not budge. Wang Qiao said, “Does the Heavenly Emperor summon me alone?” He bathed, donned his robes, lay within the coffin, and the lid sealed itself at once. By the next morning, he was buried east of the city, his tomb forming naturally. That night, all the cattle in the county sweated and panted in exhaustion, though no one knew why. The people built a temple in his honor, calling it the Shrine of Lord Ye. Officials and commoners who prayed there found their requests invariably answered. If any violated their vows, misfortune would swiftly follow.

Some say he was the ancient immortal Wang Ziqiao, as recorded in the *Book of the Later Han*. Later, the shrine was converted into the Shuangliang Abbey, which fell under the jurisdiction of Ruzhou.

**Hugong**

Hugong’s origins are unknown. He often sold medicine, hanging a gourd at the front of his stall. When the market closed, he would leap into the gourd. No one in the marketplace saw him enter, save for Fei Zhangfang of Runan, who observed from an upper floor. Marveling at the sight, Zhangfang approached and bowed twice, offering wine and dried meat. Hugong, perceiving Zhangfang’s divine potential, said, “Come again tomorrow.” The next day, Zhangfang returned, and Hugong took him into the gourd. Inside, they beheld halls of jade, resplendent with fine wine and delicacies in abundance. After drinking, Hugong emerged and said, “I am an immortal, demoted for a transgression. Now I must depart—can you follow?” Below the building stood a small jar of wine, which Hugong offered as a parting gift. Zhangfang ordered ten men to lift it, but they could not budge it. Hugong laughed, hoisted it with a single finger, and when they looked, the vessel held no more than a liter, yet two men could drink from it all day without exhausting it.

Zhangfang wished to seek the Dao but worried for his family. Hugong cut a green bamboo stalk, measuring it to Zhangfang’s height, and told him to hang it in his house. Later, his family saw it and mistook it for Zhangfang’s corpse, believing he had hanged himself. They wailed in grief and buried it. Zhangfang stood beside them, unseen.

Thereafter, he followed Hugong into the mountains, treading through thorns and brambles. Left alone among a pack of tigers, Zhangfang felt no fear. He was made to lie in an empty chamber with a rotten rope suspending a thousand-catty stone over his heart, while serpents gnawed at the rope, nearly severing it—yet he did not flinch. Hugong returned, stroked his head, and said, “You are teachable.” He then ordered Zhangfang to eat excrement, which contained three worms, foul and putrid beyond measure. Zhangfang recoiled in disgust, but Hugong said, “You were nearly enlightened—what a pity this flaw remains.”

Zhangfang asked to return home. Hugong gave him a bamboo staff, saying, “Ride this wherever you wish, and you will arrive. Cast it into Ge Marsh when done.” (The marsh lies in present-day Xinjian County, Yuzhou.) He also gave Zhangfang a talisman, instructing, “Use this to command earthly spirits.” Zhangfang hung the staff, and in an instant, he was home. Though he believed only ten days had passed, over a decade had elapsed. He cast the staff into Ge Marsh, and it transformed into a dragon. His family, assuming him long dead, refused to believe him. Zhangfang said, “The bamboo stalk you buried was the staff.” They exhumed the coffin and found the staff still inside.

Thereafter, Zhangfang could heal all manner of illnesses, flog and command ghosts, and even compel the local earth god. Sometimes, he would sit alone in anger, and when asked why, he would say, “I am punishing lawbreaking spirits.” Once, while seated with guests, he sent someone to fetch fresh fish from Wan Market, and the man returned in an instant with a meal. On a single day, people saw him in several places a thousand *li* apart.

Later, he lost the talisman and was killed by ghosts, as recorded in the *Book of the Later Han*.

Another tradition states: In Runan, a demon annually impersonated the prefect, donning official robes and beating the drum at the government gate, much to the distress of the populace. One day, as the demon arrived, it encountered Zhangfang, who was paying respects to the prefect. Terrified, the demon could not retreat. It removed its robes, kowtowed, and begged for mercy. Zhangfang rebuked it, saying, “Reveal your true form in the courtyard.” It transformed into an ancient turtle, as large as a cartwheel, with a neck a *zhang* long. Zhangfang gave it a writ to deliver to the Lord of Ge Marsh. The demon kowtowed, weeping, and planted the writ by the marsh, coiling its neck around it before dying.

Later, the Lord of the Eastern Sea visited the Lord of Ge Marsh and seduced his wife. Zhangfang bound him for three years, during which the Eastern Sea suffered a great drought. When Zhangfang arrived at the shore, the people begged for rain. He said, “The Lord of the Eastern Sea has sinned; I once bound him at Ge Marsh. Now I release him to bring rain.” Immediately, the rains poured.

Once, while traveling with others, Zhangfang saw a scholar in a yellow turban and fur robe riding a saddless horse. The scholar dismounted and kowtowed. Zhangfang said, “Return the horse and I will pardon you.” When asked why, he replied, “This is a fox spirit—it stole the earth god’s horse.”

Zhangfang could also contract the earth’s veins, drawing distant places before him as if they were fully present.

Wu Jun’s *Continuation of the Qi Xie Record* states: Huan Jing of Runan studied under Fei Zhangfang. Zhangfang told him, “On the ninth day of the ninth month, your family will face disaster. Have them sew crimson pouches, fill them with cornel, and tie them to their arms. Ascend a height and drink chrysanthemum wine—this will avert the calamity.” Jing followed his advice, and when his family returned that evening, they found all their chickens and dogs dead. This is the origin of the custom of ascending heights on the ninth day of the ninth month. Today, Denggao Mountain in Jianning Prefecture preserves this tradition.

The *Record of the Cinnabar Terrace* states: Hugong’s surname was Xie, his given name Yuanyi. In Xinghua Prefecture, there is a Mount Hugong, where a man once met Hugong and was led to the summit. There, he saw palaces and towers, which Hugong said were “the sun and moon within the gourd.” A shrine to Hugong still stands there. Another account claims that the Xuanhu Abbey in Caizhou was Fei Zhangfang’s former retreat, where a “hanging gourd tree” grows. The Lingyang Abbey in Xinzhou is also said to be where Zhangfang’s bamboo staff transformed into a dragon, though the details are unclear.

**Hua Tuo**

Hua Tuo, styled Yuanhua, was a native of Qiao in Peiguo during the Han. Well-versed in the classics and skilled in the arts of nurturing life, he lived past a hundred yet retained the vigor of youth. His contemporaries regarded him as an immortal. The prefect of Pei, Chen Gui, recommended him as a filial and incorruptible scholar, and the Grand Commandant Huang Wan summoned him, but he declined both appointments.

Proficient in medicine and prescriptions, he used no more than a few ingredients, intuiting their precise weights without measurement. His acupuncture and moxibustion required but a few points.

If an illness was lodged deep within, beyond the reach of acupuncture or medicine, he would have the patient take *mafei powder* with wine. Once intoxicated and insensate, he would incise the abdomen or back to excise the affliction. If accumulations lay in the intestines or stomach, he would sever, rinse, and remove the diseased filth before suturing, then apply a divine salve. The wound would heal in four or five days, and full recovery would follow within a month.

Wu Pu of Guangling and Fan A of Pengcheng both studied under him, and by following his methods, saved many lives.

*From the* **Book of the Later Han**.

**Master of the Azure Vale**

The Master of the Azure Vale’s origins are unknown. He constantly practiced the Dao of the Nine Breaths and *qi*-ingestion. Later, he compounded the furnace fire and the Great Elixir, and by ingesting it, attained the Way.

**Liu Wenrao**

Liu Wenrao was Liu Kuan of Hongnong. From youth, he was devoted to the Way. Once recommended as a *fangzheng* of the Han, he gradually rose to become Prefect of Nanyang. He treated the people as his children, never letting anger show on his face or harsh words escape his lips. He practiced hidden virtue, aiding the cold and destitute, so that the people cherished him as a parent. Later, he became Minister over the Masses and Grand Commandant.

The emperor bestowed wine upon him, but he prostrated himself and fell asleep. When summoned by imperial decree, he answered: "Your servant bears heavy responsibilities, and my heart is ever anxious as though drunk." Once, he sent a servant to the market to buy vegetables, but the servant stole the money to drink and returned late, then lay down in the courtyard without bringing the vegetables. When he awoke, he cursed the servant as a "worthless cur." After scolding him, he fastened his sash and entered the hall. Fearing the servant might take his own life afterward, he was so preoccupied with concern that he unknowingly fell asleep. He begged for the emperor’s mercy and forgiveness.

His benevolence and compassion extended to all things in this manner. At the age of seventy-three, the Master of the Azure Vale descended into his bedchamber one day and taught him the method of the Staff of Liberation. He then entered Mount Taihua, practicing the Dao of the Nine Breaths and *qi*-ingestion. Later, he was given the formula for the furnace fire and the Great Elixir, and through cultivation, attained the Way. Now, he resides in the grotto as the Youthful Prime Marshal and Supreme Marquis, overseeing those who first embark on the Dao.

A note in *True Reports* states: Liu Kuan, styled Wenrao, was a native of Huayin in Hongnong. His father, Liu Qi, served as Minister over the Masses during the reign of Emperor Shun. Kuan was a man of prudence and integrity. Once, a man who had lost his ox came to Kuan’s carriage to claim it. Kuan said nothing, untethered the ox, and gave it to him, then walked home. Soon after, the man who had found the ox returned it, ashamed and fearful. Kuan merely thanked him and sent him away.

In the eighth year of Emperor Huan’s *Yanxi* reign, he became Prefect of Nanyang, where he always used whips made of rushes. In the fifth year of Emperor Ling’s *Jianning* reign, he was appointed Grand Commandant. Once, in the emperor’s presence, he fell asleep after drinking. The emperor asked, "Is the Grand Commandant drunk?" Kuan looked up and replied, "Your servant does not dare to be drunk, but my heavy responsibilities weigh upon my heart like intoxication."

On another occasion, a guest arrived at Kuan’s home, and he sent a servant to buy wine. The servant returned late, thoroughly drunk. The guest cursed him as a "beast." Kuan said, "What greater humiliation could there be? That is why I feared he might take his own life." Later, he was enfeoffed as Marquis of Daixiang with six hundred households. He passed away in the second year of *Zhongping*, aged sixty-six, and was posthumously honored as General of Chariots and Cavalry. His posthumous title was Marquis Zhaodao. His son, Liu Song, succeeded him.

As these accounts differ, they are recorded here in detail.

Minister Dao’s First Account states: Liu Wenrao served in the Han court, regarding the people as his own children—such was the outward manifestation of his virtue and power. Observing his governance, his anger never showed on his face, nor did harsh words escape his lips. He delighted in performing hidden acts of virtue, aiding the cold and destitute. Truly, he could serve as a model for those who withdraw from court and marketplace to cultivate immortality. In general, the accumulation of merit and the refinement of conduct lie in such deeds. The *Daodejing* says: "The sage has no constant heart, taking the people’s heart as his own. Those who are good, I treat with goodness; those who are not good, I also treat with goodness—thus virtue becomes goodness." Could this not describe Liu Wenrao?

Zhao Weipa and Zhao Weibo, natives of Dongjun, were brothers. From youth, they loved the Dao and studied under Master Deng Zhang of Na. In later years, on Mount Zhongyue, they received the Jade Pendant and Golden Cauldron Scripture from Fan Qiulin, the wife of Wei Xingdao, the Han dynasty’s General of Tower Ships. Having attained immortality through Daoist cultivation, she transmitted to them the Way of Embracing the Sun and Moon and the practice of ingesting the essence of the Nine Luminous Mirrors. After achieving the Dao, they entered Huayang within, where Weibo served as Minister of Life Preservation.

The *Hetu* states: "...In Wu and Chu, many have witnessed the Great Peace." When told of this, they said, "These words are not empty; the verification will come soon." The mirrors they preserved were not of the common methods of this world. Weibo was also skilled in the art of whistling—its sound like the rushing wind striking a vast forest or a flock of birds crying in unison. Once, while whistling atop the Celestial Market Altar to summon the wind, clouds soon gathered above, and in an instant, dark mist closed in from all sides, bringing a light rain. The Ministry of Life Preservation had four ministers, with Weibo overseeing the registers of immortals and recording those who studied the Dao. They also summoned sudden rains and the numinous zhi herbs.

Le Changzhi, a native of the village of the Lord of Life in Dongqing, served during the reign of Emperor Huan of Han, rising to the position of Gentleman of the Palace. Later, he studied under Master Li of Mount Zhongyue and received the method of pacing the Seven Primes.

Having cultivated the Dao to fruition, he entered Hua Yang to serve as a Minister of Life Preservation.

Liu Gen
Liu Gen was a native of Yingchuan. He could summon ghosts and concealed himself on Mount Song. When Du Xin, the Prefect of Yingchuan, heard of him, he suspected sorcery and summoned him to the prefectural seat. Xin addressed Gen, saying, "What powers do you possess that you so delude the people?" Gen replied, "I can make men see ghosts." Xin retorted, "Prove it now. If no ghost appears, you shall be executed." Thereupon, Gen glanced left and laughed. In an instant, Xin’s deceased parents appeared before him, bound and reversed. The ghosts reproached him, saying, "You, as a son, have failed to honor us—why trouble the dead?" They then urged Xin, "Hasten to apologize to Master Liu." Xin wept and kowtowed in repentance. Soon after, both Gen and the ghosts vanished, their whereabouts unknown. Within days, Xin also died.

Some say Liu Gen regularly consumed the kernels of jujube pits, rendering him immune to all malevolent influences. A man of the Later Han, Pi Rixiu wrote in a poem to Mao Gongquan:

*Long ago, Liu Gen attained the Dao,
This vale has known him four hundred years.
Matted fur cloaks his form—
They call him the Green-Furred Immortal.*

*I think of the pure spring he drew,
Bored through the narrow ridge’s crest.
Five hues refined to perfection,
A single ladle rings clear.*

*Now with civil and martial fire,
Swiftly he mastered the Yin-Yang Canon.
Crimson basins splash scarlet mist,
Sunlight scatters pale smoke.*

*Consuming it, wings sprouted,
In a flash, he soared to the Dark Heavens.
Though his true reclusion lingers near,
His rites approach a thousand years.*

*I come seeking numinous wonders,
Here to end my days at last.
Drops race like water from a broken spout,
Moss deepens where the incense coils.*

*Clear as jade marrow’s purity,
Bright as gold’s essence, fresh.
Its hue half-mingled with milk,
Its savor wholly lead’s harmony.*

*Drink it, and obstructions melt,
Bathe in it, and the spirit leaps.
At times, those who dine here are struck—
In a trice, wind and thunder rage.*

*White rice threads remain uncut,
Viet jars hold the belly’s ease.
When drawn, moonlight stirs the liquid,
Where borne, water swirls in its wake.*

*Great offerings to the Grand Censor,
Placed before the bell-pavilion’s gate.
Pure as one of unblemished integrity,
It cleanses even the sweeping might of power.*

*Sun-basking rustics feel their spirits rise,
And I, too, pity the lords and marquises.
I know the bitterness of drinking mere water—
Would that I might receive but a single spring’s gourd.*

*The *Nanyue Zongsheng Ji* states: Master Liu Gen cultivated the Great Cavern’s Emperor Yi’s Dao, traveling as an official in all directions, governing with virtue. In his later years, he returned to the eastern peak of Mount Heng, refining his essence to greet the Dipper, ingesting qi and offering sacrifices to the gods, until he transcended in mystery.*

Liu Weidao
Liu Weidao of Zhongshan was a man of the Han. He studied immortality on Mount Pan Zhong for twelve years. An immortal tested him by suspending a stone weighing a hundred thousand *jin* with a single white hair, ordering Weidao to lie beneath it. Weidao’s heart remained at ease, his body joyful, utterly free of fear or dread. After twelve years, the immortal tested him repeatedly in every conceivable way, and at last bestowed upon him a divine elixir. He ascended to heaven in broad daylight.

Xia Fu
Xia Fu, styled Zileng, was a native of Chenliu.

In his youth, he was fond of the Dao and regularly ingested *muhe* and mica. Later, he entered Mount Wu, where he received the *Lianhun* method from the Red-Bearded Master. He also encountered the Perfected One of Mount Tongbai, who transmitted to him the *Huangshui Yunjiang* method, and by practicing it, he attained the Dao.

In his early years, Xia Fu was summoned by the public office, yet he hung the summons on a mulberry tree and departed—such was his lofty and unyielding nature. After achieving the Dao, he became Attendant Gentleman of the Dawn.

The *Later Han Records* and *Biographies of Eminent Recluses* both state: He was a native of Yu in Chenliu, a scholar in his youth. During Emperor Huan’s reign, he was recommended for his forthright speech but declined the appointment. By nature upright and uncompromising, he refused to join the cliques of his time. The powerful despised him, and he was ensnared in the proscription of the party factions. To evade disaster, he cut his beard and hair, altered his appearance, and fled into the forests and mountains, where he worked as a laborer. Later, he returned home but shut his door and refused to see anyone. He died before the party prohibitions were lifted.

Fan Youchong
Fan Youchong was a native of Liaoxi. He once served as Gentleman of the Palace of the Han and was skilled in geomancy. He mastered the Dao of embryonic transformation and altering form, daily visualizing three qi—blue, white, and red—each like a boat, entering his mouth directly from beneath the eastern sun. He embraced them ninety times, stopping only when sated. After ten years of practice, the three-colored qi naturally resided within him, and he attained immortality. This is the *Neijing* method of High Lord Tai Su.

The *True Records* states: Fan the Overseer was this very man, who in former times became a youthful immortal. He now resides in Central Huayang.

Zhongli Jian
Zhongli Jian was a man of the Later Han. He served as Gentleman of the Palace, and together with his younger brother Quan, entered the Three Peaks of Mount Hua and attained the Dao. After his practice was complete, he ascended to heaven in broad daylight.

*Comprehensive Mirror of Perfected Immortals Who Embody the Dao Through the Ages, Volume Twenty, Concludes*
*Comprehensive Mirror of Perfected Immortals Who Embody the Dao Through the Ages, Volume Twenty-One*

Feng Heng
Feng Heng, styled Junda, was a native of Longxi. From youth, he studied the Dao and mastered the teachings of Laozi and Zhuangzi, diligently seeking true formulas. Initially, he ingested *huanglian* for fifty years, then entered Wu Shou Mountain to gather herbs. Later, he consumed wood for over a hundred years, yet upon returning to his hometown, he appeared as a man of scarcely twenty. Whenever he heard of someone ill or dying—whether acquaintance or stranger—he would offer medicine from the bamboo tube at his waist or apply needles, curing them instantly with a touch. He cherished and conserved his essence and qi, never gazing excessively or speaking boastfully. Of all charts, records, and transmitted texts, there was none he did not study and recite from memory. Later, he encountered Lu Nüsheng, who transmitted to him the formula for *huandan* and the *True Forms of the Five Peaks*, whereupon he traveled throughout the world. Thus, mountain officials and water spirits secretly welcomed and attended him, while malevolent ghosts and strange creatures invariably fled. Some doubted him and sought to harm him with arrows and blades, yet none could injure him. He often rode a black ox, the name of which no one knew, and so he was called the Black Ox Daoist. When Emperor Wu of Wei inquired about the essentials of nurturing life, the Master replied: "Let the body be constantly active, but not to excess; let food be constantly moderate, but not to the point of depletion. Avoid rich and heavy flavors, temper sour and salty tastes, restrain thoughts, curb joy and anger, abandon reckless pursuits, and be cautious in the bedchamber—then you will approach the Dao. Thus, the sage nourishes yang in spring and summer, and yin in autumn and winter, aligning with their root to harmonize with the subtleties of creation." He had two attendants: one carried a stack of books, the other a medicine basket. Among his works were the *Twelve Scrolls of Rongcheng’s Qi-Nurturing Arts*, *Mozi’s Method of Concealing Form*, and the *Scripture of Numinous Treasure Life Preservation*. In his basket were refined *shuang* of mercury, *huanglian* powder, and the like. He lived among people for over two hundred years before vanishing into Yuanqiu Mountain.

Wang Lao
Wang Lao, whose given name is unknown, was a friend of Lu Nüsheng and Feng Junda.

Wang Lao sought the Dao amidst famous mountains and, on the southern slopes of Mount Tai, encountered immortals riding white deer, accompanied by some ten attendants descending from the mountains. Recognizing them as divine beings, he bowed twice and begged for the Way of longevity. The immortal said: "Do you know of Lord Anqi? I am he. Your sincerity has moved Heaven, and the Supreme Lord has sent me to bestow upon you the secret of transcending the world." The *Scripture* states: "Subtle yet ever-present, its use is never exhausted—this is the true Dao." With these words, he ascended into the heavens and departed. Wang Lao practiced all the more diligently; after three years, he could outrun a galloping horse, his skin became lustrous, and his appearance resembled that of a maiden. He could divide his form and transform at will, sitting or standing yet vanishing without trace. He wandered throughout the world, and from time to time, people would catch sight of him.

Zhang Hao
Zhang Hao, styled Wenming, was a native of Runan. During the Yongchu era of Emperor An of the Eastern Han, he was once summoned by imperial decree among the recluses to become a Daoist adept. At the age of twenty, he was selected. One day, Feng Heng summoned him. Zhang Hao, upon seeing him, was filled with reverence and sought enlightenment. Heng, observing his heart, sent him to cross a deep abyss, where he encountered coiled serpents pressing in, yet his countenance remained unchanged. Tempted with beauty and tested with wealth, his heart did not waver. Heng said: "He is teachable." Thereupon, he entrusted him with the *Green Essentials and Purple Writ of the Golden Root Scripture* and half a tael of divine elixir, admonishing him: "Diligence will attain it; negligence will lose it." Zhang Hao prostrated himself and accepted the charge, then entered Mount Chicheng to ingest the elixir and practice the Dao. After a long time, his ears could hear with perfect clarity, and his eyes could see through all things. Whenever seekers of the Dao came to visit, he would sometimes transform into a white crane, sometimes into drifting clouds, soaring through the void and vanishing without a trace. By the Taihe era of Emperor Ming of Wei, he ascended as a perfected immortal.

Wang Shaodao
Wang Shaodao and his like-minded companion Li Boshan often practiced hidden virtues and secret kindnesses to rescue others. Both had cultivated the Dao for generations, their conduct so refined that merit and virtue accumulated until they attained immortality. Shaodao often said to people: "When merit fills three thousand, one ascends to Heaven in broad daylight. With surplus goodness, a cloud chariot descends to receive you. Ceaselessly propagating the Dao, one naturally attains deathlessness." These words are true indeed. Of old, the Perfected One of the Great Ultimate achieved the Dao by manifesting eight bodies in a single day, while Ge Xuan required seven lifetimes to assume the office of Immortal Duke. Yet the merit of accumulated goodness aids the mysterious ancestors above and flows to posterity below—how could it be merely for one’s own longevity? Strive on, exert yourselves; my words are not empty. Both attained the status of divine immortals.

*The Declarations of the Perfected* states: In the Youthful Prime Bureau were Wang Shaodao, Fan Shusheng, and Li Boshan—all paragons of that bureau. Shaodao was Wang Zhu’er of the Han dynasty. Fan Shusheng, Prefect of Shanyang during the Han, hailed from Beidi. Li Boshan, Yellow Gate Gentleman under Emperor Wen of Wei, was the son of Li Zhongfu. His father, Zhongfu, served as Magistrate of Baima during the Han, practicing hidden virtue and accumulating the Dao over generations, his conduct refined and his merit profound. These immortals of the two bureaus all advanced step by step to enter this realm.

The Perfected One Lu Da’an, surnamed Lu and named Guang (also called Da’an), was a native of Neihuang County in Daning Commandery, Xishu. Later, he relocated to Bozhou, being a ninth-generation descendant of Lu Wenshu of the Han. Born at the hour of *zi* on the fifteenth day of the ninth month in the first year of *Han’an* under Emperor Shun, he possessed a spirit of clarity and bones of elegance, with sparse hair and blue eyes. Inheriting his family’s legacy, he mastered the classics and histories. Through the tripartite division of the Three Kingdoms and the founding of the Jin dynasty, as the examination system remained unjust and official advancement grew arduous, he sighed: "From youth, I have been hindered by fate, my fortunes rising and falling with the times. Though I possess the talent to aid the world, how can I contend with the discord between timing and destiny? My schemes come to naught, and my aspirations for merit and fame have now ceased." Thus, he abandoned his home to cultivate the Dao.

Traveling to Heyang, he sought lodging at the home of Mo Yu. The clerk warned: "You cannot stay at the post station—there are malevolent spirits. If you doubt this, misfortune will surely befall you." The Perfected One replied: "I wield a divine sword capable of slaying evil specters. Say no more." He took up residence there. At midnight, a chill wind howled. As he gazed into the darkness, a woman’s sorrowful voice emerged from the courtyard’s miasma: "Noble official, I beg your deliverance. This was once the Zhang family estate, where bandits slaughtered and buried me here. If you would rebury my remains, I may at last attain rebirth." The next day, he excavated the site and indeed unearthed linked white bones, which he interred on a high mound. From that moment, his resolve to pursue the Dao deepened, and he sought widely the arts of delivering the living and transcending death, visiting renowned mountains.

In the fifth year of *Taikang* of Emperor Wu of Jin (the *jiachen* year), on the fifth day of the fifth month, he wandered to Mount Gushe. Beneath an ancient juniper, he suddenly beheld an old man clad in yellow fur, seated upon a stone. Bowing in greeting, he asked: "Why does the master sit alone here?" The elder looked up, sighed deeply, and remained silent for a long while.

The Perfected One’s courtesy was most reverent. After a long while, the old man addressed him: "You have stood by my side for so long—what is it you truly seek?" He observed, "Your official destiny is meager, but your Dao-nature is weighty. In time to come, your name and years shall endure together." Hearing these words, the Perfected One felt as though awakened from a dream. He bowed again and declared, "What your disciple seeks is the Dao."

The elder replied, "The Dao is formless and imageless—how can one seek it?" The Perfected One bowed once more and entreated, "Though the Dao is ineffable, might I obtain the arts of delivering the living and transcending death to save the world?" The old man said, "The Dao, in its wondrousness, gives rise to all things. It is ever-responsive, ever-still, not to be sought by sound nor grasped by effort. Only in preserving serenity, gathering the spirit in stillness, and abiding in the primordial qi, undisturbed by external things, may one then practice the circulation of qi, refine the essence, and temper the spirit—thus transcending the mundane to enter sagehood."

The Perfected One said, "Today, I have heard your instruction, and my heart is as dead ashes. I beseech you, Master, to bestow upon me a single art for saving others and cultivating myself." The elder replied, "You are teachable." Thereupon, he transmitted the *Scripture of the Six Heavens’ As-You-Will Great Method*, saying, "Follow this in practice, and you shall deliver the living and transcend death—its wondrous efficacy is beyond thought. Guard it well." With that, he brushed his sleeves and departed; pursuit was in vain. Turning back, he called to the Perfected One, "After thirty years, we shall meet again."

From then on, the Perfected One retreated to the Immortal’s Palm Peak of Mount Hua to cultivate. On the fifteenth night of the tenth month in the second year of *Yongxi* under Emperor Hui, he dreamed that the Most High Lord Lao commanded his right attendant jade youth to bestow ten jade keys, which he combined with the elder’s earlier scripture. Upon waking, his spirit was enlightened, and his mind unsealed. From that time, his written talismans, qi-circulation practices, and healing arts—whether curing illness or expelling evil—were all efficacious without fail.

By the first year of *Yongkang*, blood rain fell upon the Qin region, baleful stars appeared at noon, and pestilential toxins spread, causing the people to perish unjustly. The Perfected One reverently distributed talismanic water and lit Primordial Lamps; after thirty days, the calamity subsided. In the first month of the second year of *Yongkang*, tigers and rhinoceroses entered the city, stirring unrest among the people, yet none could stop them. At the time, Wang Rong held the position of chief minister. Emperor Hui rebuked him: "You bear the weight of the realm’s governance—how have such creatures come to harass my people? I now issue an edict to summon men to exterminate them."

The Perfected One was Wang Rong’s nephew by marriage. He approached the posted notice and said to Rong, "I possess an art to restrain these beasts." Rong, hearing his nephew’s words, memorialized the emperor, who summoned him to court. The Perfected One petitioned to be allowed to remove the harm from the people, and the emperor granted him full authority. Invoking the Primordial Method, he summoned the tigers and rhinoceroses, which flew through the air to him. The emperor was astonished. The Perfected One spat water and intoned over them, transforming them into toads, which he then absorbed with his qi. The city was at once pacified.

Delighted, the emperor praised and questioned him: "You are a true Heavenly Master of our dynasty, sharing the same title as the Heavenly Master of Han, though in a different age, yet with the same merit." He bestowed upon him a green robe with vermilion trim, a black silk sash, jade rings, gold, and silk. The Perfected One smiled but declined, memorializing: "To aid the state and save the people—how could I defile myself with material rewards?" He then returned to Mount Hua, transmitting the *Primordial Record* to Ding Yi, the *Primordial Scripture* to Guo Pu, the *Primordial Method* to Xu Jingyang, and the *Primordial Acupuncture* to the wondrous adept Zhu Xian.

On the twelfth day of the eighth month in the first year of *Da’an*, he dreamed that the Most High Lord Lao said to him: "Your name and years are now one—you may ascend to the heavens, to assist the Purple Tenuity and the Northern Pole Great Emperor, assuming the office of Controller of Destinies Perfected Lord. Furthermore, you shall descend to the mortal realm every third and ninth day of each month to examine men’s merits and transgressions. Those facing disasters, calamities, or urgent perils shall be delivered at the sound of your call." Upon waking, his body felt light; in an instant, he soared into the heavens and departed. His Primordial Method endures in the world to this day.

**Wang Zhen**
Wang Zhen was a native of Shangdang.

At seventy-nine, he took up the Dao, practicing the art of embryonic respiration and abstaining from grains for over thirty years. His complexion remained youthful and fair, his gait swift enough to outpace a galloping horse, and his strength equal to that of several men. When Emperor Wu of Wei heard of him, he summoned the man for an audience, estimating his age at no more than thirty. Suspecting deception, the emperor investigated his hometown, where all witnesses—many of whom had known him since their own childhood—spoke with one voice: Wang Zhen was already four hundred years old. Convinced of his mastery of the Way, the emperor held him in the highest reverence.

**Chen Chang**
Chen Chang dwelled on Mount Fenyu for over six hundred years. The people of Fenyu Mountain built him a dwelling and, with each season, prepared sacrificial offerings of meat and wine. Though Chen never partook of food or drink, his appearance remained that of a man in his sixties. Whenever his devotees fell ill, they would bring vessels to him, begging for consecrated water to drink, and all were cured. For generations, the people of Fenyu Mountain served him in succession, yet none knew his origins or the details of his diet and practices. Fenyu lies in the Eastern Sea; those from Wu who accidentally landed there remained for three years before returning, recounting all they had witnessed. The mountain spans a thousand *li* in circumference, home to over a thousand households. Its five grains ripen in abundance, though none know the era of its founding. Its customs mirror those of Wu.

**Wang Hui**
The Daoist Wang Hui was a man of the Wei era and a disciple of the White Ram Master. He resided in the Cavern of the Bear’s Den on Mount Hua, within the *Zhen* Abbey. He often cultivated Solomon’s seal by the streamside, where tigers plowed the earth for him and leopards weeded the fields. He rode tigers and leopards as mounts, outfitting them with saddles and bridles, guiding them with a whip as one would a horse—no different in practice. He subsisted on Solomon’s seal and *cangmu*, having done so for many years.

Wang Hui later transmitted the Daoist arts to Wang Fachong, then departed through *shijie* corpse-liberation. His disciples buried his cap and sandals to the left of the cliff, where a yellow cloud settled above them. He once composed over a hundred words of esoteric instructions to teach others, yet none could comprehend them. The verses read:

The Yellow Emperor ascended to Dinghu Lake,
Riding the plain into purple mist.
Bright essence and yin do not endure long—
As fate turns, dragons wheel in flight.
Withered forests soon shall fade,
Gleaming scales sink in the deep abyss.
Wandering immortals soar through clouded heights,
Delighting in the endless flow of years.
By day, cast no tortoise-shell divination;
At dusk, sing where verdant hues arise.
The Central Peak anchors harmonious qi,
The *banshu* completes the scroll as one.
Should you grasp its meaning,
A measure of gold shall be your reward.

**Chang Ji**
Chang Ji’s origins are unknown. While gathering firewood in the mountains, he was crushed by a collapsing cliff and fell to his death, though a faint breath remained. His wife arrived to find him, weeping in grief. The immortal Yin Yi, moved by her sorrow, said to her, “I am an immortal and can heal your husband.” He gave her medicine along with the formula, instructing, “If the first dose does not fully restore him, prepare more as needed. With prolonged use, it will make one an immortal.” The wife administered the medicine, and Ji recovered. After compounding and consuming the remedy for a thousand days, he suddenly ascended in flight. His wife, weeping, pursued him, whereupon he turned and said, “The Dao differs from the world—take care to honor yourself.” Filled with resolve, she too prepared the medicine and took it for three years, then likewise flew away. She reached Mount Penglai, where Ji greeted her, saying, “I knew you would come.”

**Zhang Xuanbin**
Zhang Xuanbin was a native of Dingxiang.

During the reign of Emperor Wu of Wei, Zhang Xuanbin was nominated as a *maocai* (esteemed talent). Returning to his hometown, he became a disciple of Ji Gong of Xihe, receiving the arts of ingesting wood, practicing the *Dongfang Baiyuan* (White Prime of the Cavern Chamber). Later, he encountered Fan Ziming on Mount Shaoshi, who taught him the Dao of concealment, transformation, and hidden radiance. Formerly dwelling on Mount Tianzhu, he now serves as the *Lijin Bo* (Master of Water and Rain) in Huayang. The *Zhen Gao* states: The *Lijin Bo* is an official who also oversees the guardianship of life as a steward of the realm.

Xuanbin was skilled in discoursing on *wu* (non-being). He said: "The *yuan* (primordial) is the dwelling of *dayou* (great being), while *xiaoyou* (small being) arises from it. By accumulating *xiaoyou* to nurture *xiaoyuan* (small primordial), one perceives *dayou* as the root of *dayuan* (great primordial). Being arises from *yuan*, and *yuan* arises from being. Thus, my eyes see no things, nor do things see *yuan*. By lodging in being to perfect *yuan*, and lodging in *yuan* to attain *yuan*—there, *yuan* is the dwelling of *yuan*, and the great void is also the dwelling of *yuan*. Before my birth, all under heaven was *yuanyuan* (primordial primordiality)."

His arguments were so well-founded that even the immortals of Mount Tongbai could not refute them. He claimed to have once visited Song Chensheng on Mount Penglai. Song Chensheng was the Left Immortal Elder of Penglai, and in their discussion of *yuan*, Xuanbin roughly grasped the essential meaning.

Minister Dao Yi said: "To discuss the Dao through the single word *yuan* is truly to grasp the subtlety of the Dao." The *Daode Jing* states: "*Wu* (non-being) is named the beginning of heaven and earth; *you* (being) is named the mother of the myriad things. Thus, by constantly abiding in *wu*, one observes its mystery; by constantly abiding in *you*, one observes its manifestations. These two emerge together yet bear different names, both called *xuan* (profound)." It also says: "The myriad things under heaven are born of *you*; *you* is born of *wu*." Zhang Xuanbin must have deeply grasped this principle, though he expressed it only obliquely.

**Wang Zhonglun**
On Mount Wushi in Gaotang County stood a cliff over a hundred *ren* high. When struck with objects, the rock emitted a clear, resonant sound. During the *Taikang* era of Emperor Wu of Jin, the reclusive scholar Tian Xuan dwelled beneath the cliff, delighting in the wind, frost, and moon amid the village stones. Often, he saw a man in a plain white robe pacing the cliff’s edge, departing only at dawn. Later, Tian Xuan had someone strike the rock while lying in wait within the cliff. When the man appeared, they swiftly seized his sleeve and entreated him. He revealed: "I am Wang Zhonglun, a native of Wei. During the reign of King Xuan of Zhou, I entered Mount Shaoshi to study the Dao. Passing through this place on my frequent journeys to Mount Fang, I grew fond of the stone’s resonance and lingered to listen."

Tian Xuan earnestly begged for the secret of longevity. Wang left him a stone the size of a sparrow’s egg, saying, "This will allow you to abstain from grain." At their parting, he ascended over a hundred paces into the air, still visible, until gradually obscured by mist. Tian Xuan held the stone in his mouth and went a hundred days without hunger.

**Peng Qiu**
Peng Qiu, styled Bojian, was a native of Beihai.

During the *Taishi* era of Emperor Wu of Jin, Peng Qiu entered the western Jade Maiden Mountain of Juqiu to fell timber. Suddenly, he detected a strange fragrance. Following the scent with the wind, he saw the mountain open of its own accord, revealing palaces dense with verdure and towers vast and bright. Peng Qiu entered the gate and peered within, where he beheld five jade trees. Advancing further, he saw four immortal maidens playing *weiqi* in a hall. Upon seeing him, they all rose in surprise and asked, "Master Peng, how have you come here?" Peng Qiu replied, "I followed the fragrance and arrived." With that, they resumed their game as before. A younger maiden ascended a tower to play the zither, jesting, "Why has Yuanhui alone gone up to the tower?" Peng Qiu stood beneath the trees, sating his hunger by licking the dew that dripped from their leaves.

Presently, a woman arrived riding a crane and said, "Jade Flower Cloud, why do you entertain this mortal here? The Queen Mother has ordered Wang Fangping to inspect the immortal chambers—he must depart at once." Terrified, Peng Qiu exited the gate, and when he turned back, all had vanished. Upon returning home, he found it was already the *Jianzhong* era; his former dwelling and estate had become graves and ruins.

Having thus roamed through renowned mountains in search of the Dao, he never returned.

**Bao Shuo**
Bao Shuo, styled Taixuan, was a native of Chenliu. From youth, he possessed keen insight and profound understanding of the mysterious and subtle, his mind deeply absorbed in the arcane—none could fathom him. Some accounts state he served as Governor of Nanhai, where he attained secret methods and awakened to the truth of the Dao, receiving the essential precepts of true immortality from Chen Mu. According to the *Records of Grotto Heavens*, Shuo and his sister were reborn from former lives. Their seven-times-great-grandfathers, Li Zhan and Zhang Lü, both natives of Beixiang in Duling, had once lodged together at an inn by the Wei Bridge. There, they accumulated hidden virtues, cherished the Dao, and longed for transcendence, and so their blessings extended to Shuo and his kin. Though their lineages changed across generations and their surnames altered, they were reunited as kin by heaven’s design. Though their ancestral roots differed, the shade of their virtue remained the same.

Shuo studied the classics and mastered astrological prognostication. He became a disciple of Zuo Yuanfang, receiving the Central Scripture’s methods and the essential techniques for summoning the Three Sovereigns and Five Peaks, which he practiced with divine efficacy. He could command ghosts and spirits, seal mountains, and subdue demons. In the first year of *Daxing* under Emperor Yuan of Jin, Shuo briefly traveled east of the Yangtze. On the northern road of Jiang Mountain, he encountered a youth of sixteen or seventeen, radiant in countenance. They walked together for several *li*, but the youth’s steps grew gradually swifter, and Shuo, though riding a galloping horse, could not keep pace, falling ever farther behind. He asked, “Judging by your gait, you must be one who has attained the Dao.” The youth replied, “I am the immortal Yin Changsheng. The Most High has sent me to Red City. You have long yearned for the Dao, and thus you were permitted to see me.” Shuo dismounted and bowed, inquiring after his well-being, but before he could speak further, Yin said, “This land will see war and bloodshed in ten years.” Later, during Su Jun’s rebellion, the prophecy was fulfilled to the decade.

Yin continued, “You have long aspired to the Dao, and I shall deliver you.” The immortal arts teach that for those who attain transcendence, *shijie*—corpse liberation—is the most wondrous method. The higher form of *shijie* employs a blade, the lower a bamboo or wooden implement. Both require a brush dipped in divine elixir to inscribe the *Tai Shang Tai Xuan Yin Sheng Fu* upon the blade’s edges, whereupon the characters vanish in an instant. The inscribed face and body then perish upon the forest floor, while the true self escapes, never to return home. The family, believing the blade to be the deceased, mourns accordingly. The method with bamboo or wood follows the same principle. Yin then transmitted this Way to Shuo.

He further discussed the rise and fall of the Jin dynasty with Shuo, expounding one as ten and ten as a hundred to convey the reign’s duration to Emperor Yuan. Shuo claimed these were calculations from his astrological studies, never revealing they came from Yin’s teachings—a silence Yin had enjoined. The *Illustrated Records of Mount Luofu* state that when Ge Zhichuan resided on Luofu, Shuo, then Governor of Nanhai, was renowned for his mastery of the Dao. Once, while inspecting his domain by sea, he was caught in a storm and, ravenous, boiled white stones to eat. He was close to Zhichuan and often visited the mountain, sometimes debating until dawn before departing. When people saw him arrive, there were no carriages or horses—only a pair of swallows flying to and fro. When questioned, he revealed they were but a pair of slippers.

The *Collected Immortal Biographies of Pengcheng* records that Shuo married his daughter to Ge Hong. Later, Shuo returned to Danyang and was buried at Shizigang. When Su Jun’s rebellion erupted, his coffin was opened, but no corpse was found—only a great blade. As the rebels sought to take it, thunderous sounds of soldiers and horses arose from the tomb’s surroundings. Startled, they turned to see the blade humming with a roar like thunder, and the rebels fled in terror. After the rebellion was quelled, the blade was recovered and buried anew.

The *True Reports* states that Shuo became a subterranean overseer, bearing the title *True Man of Qian Mountain*. After five hundred years, he would serve as *Keeper of the Kunlun Chambers*. The *Book of Jin* records: Bao Shuo, styled Taixuan, was a native of Donghai. At five, he told his parents, “I was once a child of the Li family in Quyang. At nine, I fell into a well and died.” His parents sought out the Li household, and all details matched. Shuo’s learning spanned both exoteric and esoteric traditions; he mastered astronomy and the *River Chart* and *Luo Scripture*. Later, he became Governor of Nanhai. Once, while inspecting his domain by sea, he was caught in a storm and, starving, boiled white stones to sustain himself. He once met the immortal Yin Jun, who transmitted the Dao’s essential precepts to him. He lived over a hundred years before passing.

**Xu Mai**
Xu Mai, styled Shu Xuan and nicknamed Ying, was a native of Juqu in Danyang. His family had long been of noble lineage, their eminence passed down through generations.

Xu Ying, from childhood, was drawn to the Dao. As the *True Records* states: "With a pure and empty heart, he embraced the Dao, dwelling far beyond the worldly realm," and so he changed his name to Yuanyou. He associated with the Wang family, father and sons, and Wang Youcheng treated him with repeated reverence. According to a handwritten transmission of the Six Jia Yin-Yang Talismans: "In the first year of Yongchang, at twenty-three years of age," this places his birth in the first year of Yongkang, the gengshen year. Yet genealogical records state that in the autumn of the fourth year of Yonghe, he severed all ties with the world at West Mountain in Lin’an, aged forty-eight. This would make the first year xinyou, one year short of his age; here, his own account is taken as correct, making him forty-nine at the time of his departure. He married the daughter of Sun Chong, styled Yanda, of Wu Commandery—granddaughter of General-in-Chief Sun Xiu.

Once, he consulted Guo Pu for a divination, drawing the hexagram *Great Strength* transforming into *Great Possession*, with the top line activated. Guo Pu told Ying: "Your primordial fortune descends from Heaven; you should study the Dao of light ascent." Earlier, Bao Shuo had transmitted to him the Central Scripture’s methods and the *Inner Writings of the Three Sovereigns*. One day, he bid farewell to his family and departed, never to return. He entered the Suspended Torrent Mountain in Lin’an, unbound his hair, shed his burdens, and took the name Yuanyou. He consumed the wood essence and yellow essence, gradually reaping their benefits, focusing his mind on the subtle and imperceptible, day and night without ceasing. Over several years, he secretly perceived the mysteries of the Void, and the Supreme One True Person, the Record-Keeper Lord Mao, descended to transmit the supreme methods.
