Thereupon, he mastered embryonic breathing and inner vision, pacing the Dipper in reclusion. With each communion, he neared transcendence beyond the Milky Way.

Later, he moved to Red City in Lin’an, where he encountered Wang Shilong, Zhao Daoxuan, and Fu Taichu. Yuanyou then took Shilong as his teacher, receiving the Dao of Unbinding and Reverse Circulation, and ingested the Jade Fluid and Morning Brain Essence. Within three years, his face bore the glow of youth. As Yuanyou attained the Dao, the Three Offices issued a general prohibition, dispatching the Custodian of the Registers, Zhou Fang, and the Enforcer of Transgressions, Yan Baihu, each bearing a cinnabar tablet of his transgressions to interrogate him. Had his answers been inadequate, they would have seized him. Fortunately, Gong Youjie and Li Kailin came to his aid.

Yuanyou, greatly alarmed, forced a long laugh, rebuked them sternly, and replied: "The Great Dao is impartial, bestowing only upon the good; Heaven and Earth are without favor, sparing only those of virtue. Thus, when the Ban Spring flowed with blood, did the dragon’s beard spare the Three Miao? When the Crimson Wilderness saw the battle of Zhuolu, did the crimson grasses hinder the divine transformations of the Great Sage, his lofty communion and ascent? My seventh-generation ancestor, Xu Zia, accumulated benevolence and amassed virtue, secretly aiding birds and beasts. In years of famine and pestilence, when a hundred were left with but one survivor, Zia dispersed his wealth to save them, personally preparing remedies. Lives on the brink of death hung in his hands, and those he delivered numbered four hundred and eight. The virtue he bequeathed to us should yield five immortals, all recorded in the Azure Palace—how could the likes of you presume to interfere?"

As the *True Records* states: "The Prefect’s seventh-generation ancestor, Ziao, styled Zia, performed deeds of relief and kindness." Yet upon consulting the genealogy, his seventh-generation ancestor was named Jing, styled Wuqing, who served as Minister of Ceremonies under Emperor An and was appointed Grand Commandant in the first year of Yongjian under Emperor Shun. The names and styles differ from the *True Records*, and the reason for this discrepancy remains unclear. In the second year of Yongchu under Emperor An, a great famine struck: a *dou* of grain cost two thousand coins, and people resorted to cannibalism. If he saved four hundred and eight lives, it must have been during this time. The *Discussions on Han Offices* by Ying Zhu records a memorial by Cui Yuan, which states: "Xu Jing, nearly a hundred years old, still holds the position of Grand Commandant." Thus, not only did his hidden virtue flow to his descendants, but Jing’s manifest merit was renowned in his own time, ensuring his longevity, safety, and ascent to the highest offices. His son Xun and grandson Xiang both became the Three Excellencies. Since their migration south of the Yangtze, their lineage has flourished, ultimately attaining divine transcendence.

When he finished speaking, the Lord of Life’s Destiny dispatched the Listener-in-Waiting, Li Zun, who arrived grasping a bell. Zhou Fang and his companions laughed and fled, whereupon Yuanyou was delivered to the Eastern Palace and ranked among the middle-grade earthbound immortals. Yuanyou’s fifth younger brother, Mu, also attained the Dao at the same time.

The *Book of Jin*’s biographies state: "Xu Mai, styled Shuxuan, was a native of Jurong in Danyang. His family had long been an official clan, yet Mai, from youth, was serene and indifferent, showing no ambition for official advancement. At the time, his father was still living, and he could not bear to leave his parents. He noted that Suspended Torrent Mountain in Yuhang was near Maoshan in Yanling, the western gate of Dongting, which grinds through the Five Peaks. There, he established a meditation hut. On the first and fifteenth of each month, he returned home solely to pay his respects. After his parents passed away, he sent his wife, née Sun, back to her family and roamed the famous mountains, gathering herbs on Changshan in Tonglu County. He consumed the wood essence for three years, intending to cease grain consumption. Finding this mountain too near human habitation to focus, he enclosed it on all sides. Those who wished to meet this devotee of the Dao could not do so. He regularly practiced qi absorption, sustaining a single breath for over a thousand cycles."

Later, he moved to the Western Mountains of Lin’an and changed his name to Xuan, styled Yuanyou. He wrote a letter to bid farewell to his wife. When Wang Xizhi visited him, they would often spend entire days together, forgetting to return, forming a bond beyond the mundane world. Xuan wrote to Xizhi: "From Shanyin south to Lin’an, there are many golden halls and jade chambers, as well as immortal herbs and mushrooms. Zuo Yuanfang and his followers, along with all those who attained the Dao in the late Han, reside there." Thereafter, Xuan’s fate became unknown, and those devoted to the Dao all claimed he had ascended as a feathered immortal.

Xu Mu, styled Sixuan, also named Mi, had an ancestor named Shang and a father named Fu. From a young age, Mu was renowned. When Emperor Jianwen of Jin was still a prince, Mu became his close companion. He began his career as a scholar at the Imperial Academy and was gradually promoted to Gentleman Attendant at the Yellow Gates and Chief Clerk of the Protector-General. Though he wore the robes of office, his heart yearned for the Dao and virtue. When his fourth elder brother, Yuanyou, pursued the distant and never returned, Mu submitted a memorial to resign his honors. Emperor Taizong respected his resolve and did not oppose it. Mu then settled on Maoshan, where, alongside Yang Xi, he delved into the profound mysteries of the numinous. Heaven bestowed upon him jade tablets, appointing him as a Perfected One of Highest Clarity. At the age of seventy-two, he shed his mortal coil. The *True Reports* states: "Mu was refined and pure in disposition, erudite and gifted in literary composition. Emperor Jianwen long regarded him as a paragon above worldly concerns, and he associated with many of the era’s worthies. In his youth, he served as a clerk in the commandery and as a secretary in the office of merit."

Wang Dao and Cai Mo both summoned him as an Attendant Gentleman of Linchuan, but he declined. Later selected to fill a vacancy as Erudite of the National University, he was then appointed Magistrate of Yuyao. Returning to the capital, he served as Gentleman of the Secretariat, Rectifier of the Capital District, Attendant Gentleman of the Protectorate, Palace Attendant, and Cavalier Attendant-in-Ordinary. Outwardly, he blended with worldly affairs, yet inwardly he cultivated the study of the true. Secretly receiving teachings and records, he followed the supreme Dao. By the measure of his innate portion, he became a Perfected One of Highest Clarity, his rank elevated to that of a marquis or earl, his position among the secondary ministers and directors. He aided in the governance of immortals and assisted the sagely in shepherding the people. He passed away in the first year of Taikang during the reign of Emperor Xiaowu, at the age of seventy-one. His wife, a daughter of Tao Wei of the same commandery named Kedou, died during the Xingning era and likewise entered the teachings of the School of Easy Transformation. Emperor Wu of Liang later established a shrine, the Hall of the Perfected, on the mountain in his honor. The former residence of the Attendant Gentleman was, in the thirteenth year of Tianjian, converted into Zongyang Abbey, which is today’s Ziyang Abbey. A well south of the residence was dug by the Attendant Gentleman himself. To the south lies a pond, constructed by the four courts of Guo to dam Liugu Valley, known as Gong Spring. The *Records of Maoshan* states: "North of Minor Maoshan lies a mountain called Leiping. To its northwest stands the former residence of the Perfected One of Highest Clarity, Attendant Gentleman Xu, now an abbey. Before the abbey is the sacred altar of the Perfected One."

Hu Qian, a native of Wei Commandery...

Hu Qian was by nature unrestrained and unconventional, unashamed of coarse clothing or simple fare. Fond of wine, he cared nothing for its quality or refinement. He would often chant:

*"The wind enters through the window’s chink,
Wine sways within the cup’s embrace.
Forty-nine in hand, I grip,
While numinous light shines from above.
Beneath the towering catalpa’s shade,
Alone I laugh at mysteries profound."*

And again:

*"Advance—I’ll not scale the Dragon Gate,
Retreat—I’ll not seek rank or fame.
To while away the endless day,
Ever drunk, ever towering high."*

Skilled in *Yi* divination, he often practiced his craft before the shop of a woman named Xu in the back alleys of Jiankang. For each reading, he charged one hundred coins, stopping once he had earned five hundred a day—never accepting a second reading for a thousand. His mother lived west of Shangfang Gate, and each day he gave her three hundred coins for her support. The remaining two hundred he spent on wine, either drinking himself or sharing with the poor and destitute.

Once, Emperor Hai Xi of Jin went out at dawn and saw a crimson serpent coiled upon the imperial carriage, only for it to vanish moments later. He summoned Hu Qian to divine the omen using the *Forest of Changes*. Qian said, "The Jin house stands firm as bedrock, but Your Majesty bears the sign of one who must depart the palace." The emperor asked, "Can this be averted?" Qian replied, "In two years, a great general will suffer defeat in a northern campaign. If you dispatch thirty thousand men to intercept him north of Shouchun, this disaster may be dispelled."

The following autumn, Huan Wen’s northern expedition ended in failure. Blaming Yu Province Inspector Yuan Zhen for failing to provide reinforcements, he executed him. Returning to Stone Citadel, Huan deposed Hai Xi and enthroned Emperor Jianwen. When Huan’s concubine later gave birth with great difficulty, Qian divined, "In the sixth stable west of your residence, a wall will collapse—once this happens, the crisis will pass. The child will be a son, his voice and spirit fierce and mighty, destined to shake the four seas." Huan rewarded Qian with three hundred thousand coins. Qian said, "I always struggle to spend my divination earnings, and besides, I have no place to store money. Please return it to the treasury." Huan refused.

The Xu family lent Qian an empty chest to hold the coins, but soon after, Huan’s wife sent another three hundred thousand. After receiving Huan’s money, Qian divined three times daily to support his mother, while spending the rest on wine, inviting all who could hold their drink—whether acquaintances or strangers—to join him in revelry. His following grew large, and the Xu family always treated him with the courtesy due a worthy, never questioning how much he drank.

Later, Qian severed ties and no longer visited the Xu household. After searching for him for over a year, they suddenly encountered him by the Qiao Ditch. "We need the chest back," they said. "Please return home to retrieve the money you left with us." Qian laughed and replied, "In three years, I’ve drunk several thousand *dou* of wine—only forty days’ worth would cover the debt. There’s barely a hundred and fifty coins left. You needn’t trouble yourself further. I’ve scratched a tally on the wall with my nail; check it yourself, and you’ll find not a single coin missing." The Xu family tested his words and found the account exact.

Later, when Qian’s mother passed away in the night, Qian returned at dawn and said, “The green is exhausted.” He buried her and departed, and none knew where he went. Several days later, members of the Xu household saw Qian on the roadside near Luoxing. At first, they thought him drunk and grasped his hand to lead him, only to find an empty robe with no body inside.

Minister Dao Yi remarked: Hu Qian nurtured his mother with filial devotion, never seeking fame or profit. Within, he cultivated the utmost Dao; without, he blended with the dust and light. Each divination he cast earned him a hundred coins, but he limited himself to five hundred coins a day. Most he offered to his mother, a little he kept for himself, and if a second divination was needed, he required a thousand coins—yet he was not avaricious. Had he not been so restrained, how could he have reached such a state?

The *Dao De Jing* says: Which is dearer, name or self? Which is greater, self or wealth? Which is more harmful, gain or loss? Thus, excessive attachment brings great expense, and hoarding invites heavy loss. Knowing contentment averts disgrace; knowing when to stop prevents peril—this is how one endures.

Hu Qian truly mastered this Dao.

*Comprehensive Mirror of Perfected Immortals Embodying the Dao Throughout the Ages, Scroll Twenty-One* (conclusion)
*Comprehensive Mirror of Perfected Immortals Embodying the Dao Throughout the Ages, Scroll Twenty-Two*

Du Bing, styled Shugong, was a native of Qiantang in the state of Wu. At eighteen, while playing with his peers outside the northern walls of the city, an elderly man called out to Yu, saying: "This youth bears an extraordinary countenance. Alas, I am too old to witness what he will become."

Yu had been orphaned young and served his stepmother with utmost filial piety, his reputation spreading throughout the village and commandery. Thrice summoned to office, he declined. Sighing, he said: "Now is a time when the realms of men and spirits are in chaos—only the primordial qi of the Orthodox Unity can bring order."

Thereupon, he became a disciple of Chen Wenzi of Yuhang, receiving the methods of the Orthodox Unity. His cures proved effective, and the people flocked to him. One night, a divine being descended, declaring: "I am Zhang Zhennan. You are destined to transmit my Daoist arts, so I have come to bestow upon you their secret essentials and the canonical rites of the Yangping governance."

Whenever Yu entered meditation and burned incense, he could perceive the fortunes and misfortunes of the people for three to five generations, foretelling them with perfect clarity. His written talismans and consecrated water worked instantaneously, and Daoists and layfolk from near and far gathered like clouds to follow his teachings. Within a decade, the households pledging their rice offerings numbered in the tens of thousands.

During the tenure of the Jin Grand Tutor Xie An as Governor of Wuxing, he once observed a radiance of yellow and white and inquired of Yu about it. Yu replied: "Your ancestors accumulated hidden virtue among the people, and their blessings flow to their descendants—you shall rise to the highest rank among ministers."

The Director of the Imperial Secretariat, Lu Na, had seen his forebears afflicted by creeping paralysis at the end of their lives. When Na was just over thirty, he suddenly received a memorial stating: "The eldest scion of the Lu family shall pass through this trial." Yu then transmitted to him the *Lingfei San* formula. After taking it, Na declared that he would live to seventy-nine.

When Sima Huan Wen launched his northern expedition, he asked Yu whether he would achieve victory. Yu replied: "Next year, in the third month, you shall undertake a campaign alone and blunt the enemy’s edge." When Huan Wen reached Fangtou, the Stone Gate remained sealed, the waters dried up, and provisions ran out. He was captured by the Xianbei and said to his disciple Taoye: "I regret not heeding Master Du’s words, and thus have met with this defeat."

Before Fu Jian reached Shouchun, the General of Chariots and Cavalry, Xie Xuan, led troops to campaign against him. Xie asked Yu about the outcome. Yu said: "We must not advance—if we do, we shall fail. They must not come—if they do, they shall be utterly routed. This is the season for you to render your service." Fu Jian was indeed defeated and scattered.

Lu Lian styled himself "Master" and was always accompanied by over three hundred disciples. Yu reported to Huan Wen: "Lian is but a demonic essence of withered wood, deceiving the common folk. Soon he shall storm the palace gates, and only then will he perish." During the Xian’an era of Emperor Jianwen of Jin, in the dead of night, Lian led several hundred men and women straight into the palace, proclaiming the restoration of the deposed Emperor Hai Xi. The imperial guards swiftly suppressed them, and only then did Huan Wen sigh in admiration.

Later, Huan Chong sought to appoint Yu’s descendant Yu Xigai as an attendant official, but Yu declined, saying: "My children and grandchildren are all short-lived; I do not wish them to enter officialdom. Only in my fifth-generation descendant shall my blessings manifest." Yu also stated: "After my passing, there will be those who usurp my methods to disrupt the Great Dao—this is but a minor purge, akin to the Yellow Turbans, and shall soon vanish." He wrote these words on plain silk, sealed them in a box, and entrusted them to his wife, Lady Feng, instructing: "Should calamity or omen arise, open this and show it to our nephews and sons, that they may diligently cultivate virtue and guard themselves."

During the Long’an era of Emperor An, Sun Tai of Langye was executed for sorcery and deception, bringing ruin and misfortune to many. Yu suddenly gathered disciples for days on end, indulging in revelry without restraint. He ordered his scribe, Chong Tao, to purchase funeral implements in the market and had his family sew mourning garments, declaring: "On the twenty-sixth day of the third month, at noon, I shall depart." Shortly after, he fell mildly ill, and on the appointed day, he lay down in his chamber, his body softening as his qi dissipated. His Daoist followers and disciples erected a stele for him, posthumously honoring him as the "Illustrious Master."

Zhu Ku
Zhu Ku was a man of unknown origin.

Zhu Ku had long ingested mineral elixirs, practiced spring breath-holding, abstained from grains, and consumed talismanic water, never feeling hunger or thirst, growing robust and ageless. Suddenly, he declared: "I am destined for transcendence and shall depart on an appointed day." Taking leave of his kin and old friends, he said: "There will be those who come to welcome me." Clad in a single robe and white boots, in an instant, two yellow cranes descended into the central courtyard. Zhu Ku then ascended beyond the world. Three yellow cranes followed in the courtyard, flying toward the outskirts east of the city, while three Daoist adepts in yellow robes walked hand in hand toward the east. He entrusted a letter to a villager to deliver to his family. When his family examined his body, only an empty husk remained.

Jiang Bozhen
Jiang Bozhen was a man of unknown origin. From youth, he was fond of the Dao. While gathering herbs on Mount Meng, he suddenly encountered the immortal Shi Bozhen. Standing upright in the midday sun, he turned to observe his shadow behind him, only to find his heart misaligned. The immortal said: "You have studied diligently to the utmost, yet remain unaware that the misalignment of your heart is a flaw." Thereupon, he taught him to ingest *shinao*. *Shinao* is mottled in color, soft in texture, and shaped like small stones, found everywhere. After prolonged ingestion, the body grows warm yet does not thirst, and one may eventually attain transcendence. Fan Yangzi, who also consumed it, likewise achieved the Dao.

Wang Ba
Wang Ba was a man of the Liang dynasty.

He ascended at Yishan in Sanshan, Fuzhou—now the site of Zhongxu Palace—where the soapberry tree still stands. Wang Ba once inscribed the elixir formula on gold tablets and buried them behind the mountain; those who later unearthed them also attained the Dao.

The formula states:
Gold is the essence of cinnabar,
Teeth are the foundation of lead.
Grasp but the root and branch,
And in practice you shall not err.
After one full cycle of refinement,
Open the furnace to succeed—
Crimson and violet rays will strike the eye,
Dazzling in radiant splendor.
Ground fine as powdered fat,
Grains like sesame seeds.
Take one each day,
Never recklessly increase.
Bones transform to golden substance,
Countenance regains youthful bloom.
Should you wish to transmute,
A single grain’s power
Turns ten ounces of dry mercury
Instantly to horse-tooth silver.

Later, Cai Junmo left this inscription:
The perfected one’s jade bones are light,
Riding the qi to ascend Jasper Terrace.
Bowing his head to gaze below,
Ten thousand hamlets lie in foul dust.
Incense and flame long extinguished,
Mountains and rivers stand desolate.
The old tree entwined with green vines,
The empty grave overgrown with purple moss.
In serene meditation, the white day lingers,
A long chant summons the clear breeze.
Falling blossoms scatter like chess pieces,
Wandering bees alight on wine cups.
In the fair moon, much drinking,
Noble guests truly rare talents.
How could immortality be hoped for?
When will the golden crucible open?
*Yuanzang ji*

The Sui dynasty recluse Yuan Zangji served as an adjudicator for a maritime envoy. Caught in a storm, his ship broke apart, and he drifted on wreckage to an island. The locals said: "This is Cangzhou, tens of thousands of li from the Middle Kingdom. The island spans a thousand li, its flowers and trees ever in the bloom of the second or third month, and its people rarely die. Here grow split-stem melons two feet long, green dates and red chestnuts, all as large as pears. In the pools swim four-legged fish, and women gather golden lotus blossoms for their hair—without wearing them, one may not dwell among the immortals."

Zangji suddenly longed for China, so the islanders fashioned for him a wind-skimming boat that shot across the water like an arrow. In ten days, he reached Donglai. When he inquired about the dynasty, he learned it was now Tang. From the Daye era to Zhenyuan, two hundred years had passed.

Wang Yin
The *jinshi* Wang Jie was a scholar of the *Yujing* and *Lashi*, diligent and unyielding. He plumbed depths untouched by ancients, grasped truths unattained by former Confucians, and composed the *Zhiguzi* in thirty scrolls. No error in the Six Classics or flaw in the historical records escaped his needle piercing their fat and his medicine curing their marrow. In his two kinds of essays and exegetical explanations, even the most penetrating insights of ancient sages fell short.

He delighted in wine and lived for his own pleasure, unbound by convention. Beyond the joy of intoxication, he invariably probed the treasuries of meaning, refining the pivots of rhetoric—much like Liu Lan, who reviled the ancients. Yet his habit of inhaling wind and dew, chewing mist and clouds, led to chronic illness, years of suffering from a cold malady that no remedy could cure.

While traveling in Yan, he met on the road a man leaning on a cherry staff and wearing a palm-bark hat. With the bearing of a crane and an air of lofty antiquity, he stood apart from his peers. His name was Xidao. Smiling, he said: "Young man, are you burdened by the three delusions? Why else would you be so emaciated?" Jie explained his condition, and Xidao replied: "I possess the art of the crucible and furnace—what illness could withstand it?"

Jie submitted himself as a disciple. After purifying himself for three days by the Zhang River, he received the secret formula: "The essence of wood is the celestial soul; the liquid of metal, the terrestrial spirit. Kan and Li circulate—neither laxity nor force achieves success. Metal and wood have their measures; Qin and Jin must harmonize." The near effect would come in sixty days, the distant in three years. He taught this song:

*"When the spirit enters the soul and the female and male unite,
Yang refines, yin nourishes, gods and ghosts perish.
A thousand hymns, ten thousand praises—none compare;
From ancient times to now, they cast aside sun and moon."*

Jie followed the instructions, ingested the elixir, and within a year his illness vanished. Thereafter, he lived in seclusion, feigning madness to blend with the times. At eighty, he died on the road to Pengshan, and those who recognized him mourned him. Soon after, he reappeared in Chengdu, often lodging in Lewen County. At the time, a beast with a knotted tail was wreaking havoc. Jie, drunk, slept in the wild grass, his body exposed in the forest, fearing nothing—such was his transformation, like the cicada shedding its husk.

Li Jian
Li Quan, styled Daguanzi, dwelled on Shaoshi Mountain and was devoted to the Dao of immortals.

Li Quan frequently traversed famous mountains, broadly gathering esoteric arts. At Tiger’s Maw Crag on Mount Song, he obtained the *Yellow Emperor’s Original Scripture of the Yin Talisman*—a plain silk scroll sealed in a lacquered jade casket, inscribed: *"Seventh day of the seventh month, second year of Tai Ping Zhen Jun of the Great Wei. Hidden among the famous mountains by the Highest Clarity Daoist Kou Qianzhi, to be transmitted to those of like aspiration."* The text was moth-eaten and decayed; Quan copied and read it thousands of times, yet still failed to grasp its principles.

Thereupon he entered Qin, and at the foot of Mount Li encountered an old woman—her topknot coiled atop her head, the rest of her hair hanging loose, clad in tattered robes, leaning on a staff, her appearance most singular. By the roadside, she saw embers left burning a tree and remarked to herself: *"Fire is born of wood; calamity inevitably consumes its source."* Quan, startled, asked her: *"This is the* Yellow Emperor’s Yin Talisman—*how does an old woman know of it?"* The woman replied: *"I have received this scripture for three kalpas and six cycles of sixty years. How did a youth like you come by it?"* Quan bowed deeply, prostrating himself, and recounted how he had obtained it. The woman said: *"Your facial bones align with the Gate of Life, your Mandate Gate levels with the Sun’s Angle; your blood and marrow are not yet exhausted, your heart’s reflection remains unbiased. You are virtuous and fond of the Dao, spirited and delighted by wisdom—truly my disciple. Yet at forty-five, you shall face a great sigh."*

She then produced a cinnabar talisman, threading it onto the tip of her staff, and bade Quan kneel to receive it. The woman thereupon sat upon a rock and expounded the meaning of the *Yin Talisman* to him: *"The* Yin Talisman *comprises three hundred words: one hundred expound the Dao, one hundred expound the Law, one hundred expound the Arts. Above lies the Dao of immortals embracing the One; in the middle, the methods for enriching the state and pacifying the people; below, the techniques for strengthening armies and securing victory. All arise from the inner workings of the heart’s mechanism, outwardly harmonizing with human affairs."*

Gazing into its subtleties, the *Eight Scenes of the Yellow Court* are not profound enough to be called mysterious; examining its essentials, the classics, commentaries, philosophers, and histories are not refined enough to be called literature. Applying its ingenuity, even Sun Wu, Wu Qi, Han Xin, and Bai Qi would not be extraordinary enough to be called marvelous. Those without the Dao must not be allowed to hear of it.

Thus, the perfected person who employs it attains the Dao; the worthy person who employs it attains the Law; the upright person who employs it attains the Arts—each according to their capacity. If transmitting it to a like-minded companion, one must first purify oneself with fasting before imparting it. Those with the root become teachers; those without, disciples. One must not value the rich and noble nor slight the poor and humble. Those who violate this shall have twenty years deducted from their lifespan.

Recite it seven times on one’s natal day to sharpen the heart’s mechanism and extend one’s years. On the seventh day of the seventh month each year, copy one text and conceal it within a famous mountain’s stone cavern to gain additional years. After some time, the woman said, "The sun has already set. I have barley porridge—let us eat together." From her sleeve she produced a gourd ladle and bade Quan fetch water from the valley. Once filled, the ladle suddenly grew heavy by over a hundred *jin*, and Quan could not control it, causing it to sink into the spring. Upon returning, the woman had vanished, leaving only several *sheng* of barley porridge. Quan ate it and thereafter abstained from grain.

During Emperor Xuanzong of Tang’s *Kaiyuan* era, he served as Vice Military Commissioner of Jiangling and Imperial Censor. Quan possessed military strategy and composed the *Tai Bai Yin Jing* in ten scrolls, as well as the *Zhong Tai Zhi* in ten scrolls. At the time, he was sidelined by Li Linfu and never rose to prominence. He eventually entered the famous mountains in search of the Dao, and his later whereabouts remain unknown.

Wang Kejiao was a native of Kunshan in Suzhou. Originally a farmer, he had no prior knowledge of the Dao. At several years of age, his eyes began to emit a five-colored radiance, which intensified at night, allowing him to discern objects even in pitch darkness. Someone told his kin, "This is an ailment—once the light fades, he will lose his sight." His ignorant parents summoned a quack physician to cauterize his eyes, and the light vanished.

In the eleventh month of the tenth year of Emperor Yizong of Tang’s *Xiantong* era, Kejiao was returning home from the market when he saw a grand barge by the riverbank, its hull adorned with gold and brocade, embellished with pearls and kingfisher feathers, sailing to the accompaniment of music. Kejiao stood watching as the barge docked by the shore. A youth in azure robes beckoned him aboard, where he saw over ten men in towering caps and feathered robes, their garments patterned with clouds, mist, mountains, and rivers. Each held a musical instrument. One sang, "The Third Uncle wishes to meet you," though none knew whence he hailed. Another remarked, "He has the bones of an immortal, but they were damaged by fire. He must not drink wine yet—only after abstaining from grain for ten years may he attain the Dao." They gave him a chestnut, instructing him to eat it. Kejiao consumed half, keeping the other half in his hand, as the company played music and drank. The youth then led him back to shore, and all seemed like a dream. No sooner had his feet touched the ground than he found himself beneath the waterfall cliffs of Mount Tiantai. In an instant, he had traversed a thousand *li* by land and water.

The prefect of Taizhou, Yuan Cong, suspected deception and sent an official dispatch to verify his origins. From the day Kejiao vanished to his arrival at Mount Tiantai, thirty days had passed. Thereafter, Kejiao abstained from food, his complexion glowing with vitality. Yuan granted him a feathered robe and allowed him to reside in the Purple Ultimate Temple. Wang Feng, the Surveillance Commissioner of Yuezhou, memorialized: "He seemed to have wandered to the celestial realm, hearing but a single strain of the *Xiao Shao* melody. Awakening as from a dream, he was asked the date—thirty days had passed. Though he spoke of a decade-long trial, one fears he may yet take flight one day."

The imperial edict read: "The annals of immortals abound with such marvels, their divine wonders worthy of record. Having ascended from mortal flesh, he now dwells in a famed mountain—an age-old tale, no different from ancient times. How distant, then, are Penglai and Yingzhou? Let the local authorities ensure he finds refuge like Master Anqi." Thus left to roam freely, he remained in the Jiangbiao region for several years.

---

Chen Jian was a minor clerk of Jinhua County in Wuzhou. Arriving early at the county office before the gates opened, he lingered in hesitation. Suddenly, he encountered a Daoist traveler hurrying on his way.

Chen Jian unconsciously followed him. After three or five *li*, they suddenly arrived at a Daoist abbey, its halls and pavilions towering in solemn grandeur, flanked by a great mountain. The Daoist traveler led him into a chamber, where a desk, brushes, ink, and other writing implements were laid out. He handed Chen a scroll of yellow silk and over ten sheets of paper, saying, "As you have an affinity for calligraphy, transcribe this for me." Unfurling the scroll, Chen saw it was all in ancient seal script. Though he had never studied such characters nor devoted himself to learning, his heart sank at the difficulty. The Daoist had already departed, leaving no room for refusal. Tentatively, he followed the text and copied it—surprisingly, with ease. By midday, he had finished.

The Daoist gave him a cup of broth, saying, "This is the divine nectar of Jinhua, not to be lightly obtained. Whoever drinks it shall enjoy boundless longevity, and its taste is sweet and exquisite." Then, with words of encouragement and gratitude, he sent Chen off, adding, "When worldly troubles arise, return here—this is the Golden Flower Grotto-Heaven." Stepping outside, Chen felt as if waking from a dream—three days had already passed.

Upon returning home, he practiced seal script, his strokes bold and vigorous beyond compare, yet he no longer partook of food or drink.

The Prefect Xian Zifang, upon receiving the record, found the matter extraordinary and deemed it a propitious sign from the immortals. He issued a county verdict stating: *"Having obtained the secret record, this auspicious omen has appeared. It clearly marks the threshold of enlightenment and truly accords with the portent of attaining the true Dao."* Soon after, Chen returned to Golden Flower Mountain and was never heard from again.

**Lu Jun**
The Chancellor Lu Jun, having passed the imperial examinations and served as a Gentleman of the Ministry, sought leave due to illness and was appointed Prefect of Junzhou. Upon arriving in his jurisdiction, his condition worsened—he grew emaciated and could no longer bear the sight of others. He often secluded himself in a mountain studio behind the prefectural residence to cultivate his nature, sending even his attendants far away; none dared approach unless summoned.

One day, a man in tattered clothing scaled the wall and entered. Lu invited him in, and the man said his surname was Wang. Asked where he came from, he replied, *"From the mountains."* Lu smiled and said, *"Then you must be Master Wang of the mountains."* Lu asked, *"What guidance do you bring this time?"* The man replied, *"Your Excellency holds the highest rank among men, yet your years are not long. Disaster now befalls you, manifesting as this lingering illness—thus I have come to save you."*

Noting there was no water in the studio, Lu intended to call for servants to fetch tea or the like, but Wang stopped him. Dipping his sash into the well, he dissolved a grain of cinnabar, wrung the water from the sash, and gave it to Lu. Then he made an appointment: *"In five days, your illness will be cured, and your health will surpass your former state. Three years hence, you will face a great calamity. I urge you to accumulate hidden merit—be mindful of saving lives and showing compassion to all beings. At that time, I will meet you again at the beginning of summer."*

From then on, Lu’s illness improved, and within ten days, he fully recovered. The following year, he resigned his post and returned to the capital, where he was appointed Salt and Iron Revenue Officer. In the fourth month of summer, as he passed by the eastern gate of the Wuben Bureau, he suddenly saw the mountain man arrive at his residence. The man said, *"This year marks the end of your second life limit, and the disaster would have been severe. However, last year in your prefecture, you exonerated the wrongly accused and saved three lives—thus the calamity has been averted. Within this month, on the third or fifth day, you will suffer a minor ailment, but it will pass without harm."*

The next day, the mountain man instructed two servants to take ten thousand coins to Gouji Slope and distribute them among the poor and sick before departing. He added, *"On the fifth day of the fifth month, twenty-three years from now, at noon, have a Daoist await me atop Wanshan Peak. By then, you will govern Hanzhong, and I will bestow upon you the Elixir of Golden Flower—do not miss the appointed time."*

Thereafter, Lu advanced through illustrious offices, growing ever more prosperous. The following year, he was posted to Hanzhong—twenty-three years had indeed passed. At the appointed time, he sent the Daoist Niu Zhiwei to ascend Wanshan Peak at noon on the fifth day of the fifth month. The mountain man was there and gave Niu two grains of golden elixir to swallow, saying, *"You possess the qi of the Dao but lack hidden merit, so you have not yet attained the rank of immortality. You must cultivate diligently."* He then presented Lu with ten grains of the elixir, saying, *"You will enjoy a long life. Do not cease your practice. When your worldly allotment is complete, I await your return to the Peng Palace."*

After parting with Niu with a bow, the mountain man vanished. Later, Niu lived to over eighty, yet his appearance remained as that of a man in his thirties. Lu, at ninety, retained sharp senses and unflagging vigor. After his passing, his chamber was filled with an extraordinary fragrance.

**Wang Zizhi**
Wang Zizhi, styled Xianmiao, claimed to be from Weishan in Henan. He often traveled between the capital and Luoyang, and elders said they had seen him for fifty years—his appearance always that of a man in his forties, his age unknown. He was devoted to cultivating qi and fond of wine.

When the Prince of Langye, Pu Chongying, first took up his post as military governor of Puzhou, Zizhi resided at the Purple Ultimate Palace. The prince treated him with great courtesy and, hearing of his love for wine, sent him two large jars daily. One day, Zizhi went out and encountered a woodcutter at the palace gate carrying firewood. The man’s appearance was extraordinary, and Zizhi found him remarkable. He bought the wood, paying generously, and the woodcutter accepted the money without protest before leaving.

Zizhi had someone follow him to observe. The woodcutter went straight to a tavern, drank all the wine, and returned home. The next day, he reappeared and said to Zizhi, *"This wine is fine, but it cannot compare to the brew of the Shi family in Jie County. I just came from there and regret not having a companion to share it fully."* Zizhi descended the steps, took his hand, and sat with him by the brazier, entreating, *"Could you obtain some of the Shi family’s wine?"*

The woodcutter agreed and wrote a talisman in cinnabar, placing it over the fire. Before the smoke faded, a young servant appeared. The woodcutter commanded, *"Take this gentleman’s servant with these two jars and go directly to the Shi family to fetch wine. I will await you here to share a drink with the master."* Though it was already night and the gates were barred, the young servant told Zizhi’s servant, *"Close your eyes."* He then lifted the servant’s head, and both man and jars slipped through the gate’s crack. They reached Jie County, bought the wine, and returned.

Zizhi shared the wine with the woodcutter—its sweetness, richness, and purity were unmatched in the world. At midnight, the woodcutter said, *"You are drunk. Shall I summon a guest to sit beside you?"* Zizhi agreed. The woodcutter wrote another vermilion talisman and burned it. In an instant, a rare fragrance filled the room, and a man of imposing bearing, with fine beard and brows, clad in purple robes and holding a tablet, entered and bowed before sitting down. They drank together for a long while. Then the woodcutter heated an iron poker and warmed the purple-robed man’s garments, saying, *"You may go."* By then, dawn was breaking, and they rose to part.

The woodcutter asked Zizhi, *"Do you recognize the man who just left?"* After a moment, he added, *"Go to the riverbank temple to see him."* Zizhi escorted the woodcutter away, then visited the temple, where he saw the man from the previous night—it was the deity. The mark from the iron poker remained clearly visible.

Later, Zizhi encountered the woodcutter-immortal again, who imparted to him the secrets of cultivation and refinement, whereupon he became an earthbound immortal.

Wang Kuo
Wang Kuo, a commoner of the Tang dynasty during Emperor Yizong’s Xiantong era, was sailing from Kezhu when a fierce wind forced his boat to anchor beneath Jun Mountain. With several companions, he followed a mountain path along the shore and ascended the slopes. Suddenly, he caught the scent of wine, but when he asked his companions, none detected it. The fragrance grew stronger, and upon the cliffside beside the path, he noticed a cave. Suspecting something unusual, he entered. After walking about ten paces, he found a depression in a flat stone holding wine. He scooped some and drank; its flavor was rich and exquisite. After consuming half a *dou* or more, he became pleasantly intoxicated. Resting beside the depression, he gradually sobered and returned to the boat, where he recounted the experience to his companions. They rushed to search but found nothing. From then on, Wang Kuo felt invigorated and free of illness, gradually losing his taste for grains. He entered the famous mountains to study the Dao.

Later, he read in an immortal’s book: *"On Jun Mountain there is celestial wine; drinking it, one ascends as an immortal."* What Wang Kuo had encountered was this very wine.

*History of Perfected Immortals Embracing the Dao Through the Ages, Scroll Twenty-Two (concluded)*
*History of Perfected Immortals Embracing the Dao Through the Ages, Scroll Twenty-Three*

The Perfected Immortal Lord Ge

The Perfected Immortal Lord was surnamed Ge, named Xuan, and styled Xiaoxian. His family originally hailed from Langye. Their ancestral line of officials and scholars traced back to their great-great-grandfather Lu, who served as the Han dynasty’s General of Agile Cavalry and was enfeoffed as the Marquis of Xiana. Later, he relinquished his state and, together with his younger brother Wentuo, journeyed south to the lands east of the Yangtze, wandering freely among the hills and valleys. Arriving in Jurong of Danyang, they found its mountains and waters elegant and its customs simple and honest, which perfectly suited their refined sensibilities. By chance, their second cousin Sun had come to serve as Administrator, and one day, while attending upon him, they remarked: “Our ancestor was Taibo, yet this unworthy descendant may be considered a successor to Zhongyong.” Thus, they settled there together.

The Perfected Immortal’s grandfather, Ju, served the Han as Gentleman of the Yellow Gate. His father, Xiaoru, successively held the offices of Grand Herald and rose to become a Minister of the Imperial Secretariat. Their lineage descended from the Ge Tian clan, who had been enfeoffed at Ge and thus adopted the state as their surname. The family had long borne the virtue of loyalty, serving as feudal lords through the ages.

The Perfected Immortal was originally a Perfected One of the Great Canopy Heaven, who descended to the world in the seventh year of the *Yanxi* era of Emperor Huan of the Later Han, on the eighth day of the fourth month of the *jiachen* year. His father had long practiced the Daoist arts and, upon his birth, dispatched messengers bearing incense, flowers, and coins to the local Xuanjing Abbey to procure fragrant water for the child’s bath. At that time, there appeared a transcendent Daoist named Zhi Daoji, whose origins were unknown. Hearing that the Minister had been blessed with a son, he joyfully addressed the messenger: “Last night, I dreamed that the Master of Penetrating the Mysteries descended from the Great Canopy Heaven and said to me: ‘It has been kalpas since we last parted—have you forgotten me?’ I bowed and replied: ‘This disciple wishes to attain the eye of the supreme, orthodox, and true Dao.’ He instructed: ‘Return and inform the Minister that I shall come tomorrow to congratulate him on the birth of this extraordinary boy.’”

The messenger returned and reported this in full. The following day, Daoji indeed arrived to offer his congratulations. The Minister said: “This child is my firstborn, and I had hoped to secure him as heir to our lineage, fulfilling my aspirations.” Daoji requested to see the infant, but the mother hesitated. The father ordered the child brought out, and upon seeing him, Daoji unconsciously rose in reverence. The Minister, astonished, inquired further, to which Daoji replied: “I had foreseen this auspicious sign and now dare to offer my congratulations. This child is enveloped in purple qi, like a precious canopy, with divine radiance flowing and shimmering—he is destined to become a divine immortal, unlike ordinary mortals.” The Minister said: “The sages and immortals are distant and elusive, their transformations obscure and unfathomable. I would be content if he could live a long life as heir to our lineage.” Daoji replied: “His wisdom and intelligence, though briefly passing through this world, will bring celebration in the Nine Heavens and joy to his seven generations of ancestors. The living will be blessed, and the dead will ascend to heaven.”

Thereupon, Daoji recalled the Perfected One’s merits from past lives and performed obeisance to the immortals and sages of the ten directions, praying for eternal and supreme fortune. After the rites, he composed a eulogy for the Perfected Immortal, which read:

Though the body cycles through sacred transformations,
The soul and spirit never perish for a moment.
Virtues accumulated through kalpas of past merit,
Vows of old are fulfilled not in this day alone.
A Perfected One of the Great Canopy descends,
Immortals and sages emerge bearing true essence.
Heavenly dragons sprinkle fragrant blossoms,
Fearing lest I refine this mortal frame.
Who would believe such subtle words?
Yet the divine appointment is fulfilled by mysterious blessing.
The mind of the Dao transcends duality,
Its primordial unity manifest in perfect completion.
Alone, he awakens to the original thought,
Radiant and free in the Great Vehicle’s ease.

After reciting the eulogy, Daoji bowed deeply and departed, vanishing in an instant.

At the age of eight, the Perfected Immortal lost his parents but was already able to devote himself to learning and stand on his own. From birth, he was exceptionally bright, his heroic bearing vibrant, his natural talent surpassing others, and his nature and intellect keen and flourishing. By thirteen, he had mastered the classics of past and present, and there was no work among the Confucian canons, histories, philosophers, or masters that he had not thoroughly perused. Whenever he encountered his father’s handwritten manuscripts, he would gaze heavenward, weep aloud, and birds would circle above, their cries mournful. Sighing, he would say: “The mountains and rivers do not change their hues, yet my stern father has returned to emptiness. If there exists a Way to long life and immortality, why should I not cultivate it?” Thus, he wandered near sacred peaks and distant mountains, seeking extraordinary masters.

He was fond of playing the zither, reciting the works of Zhuangzi and Laozi, and lived in tranquil detachment, inwardly content and without desires. By fifteen or sixteen, his name resounded throughout the lands east of the Yangtze. Eminent men sought to recruit him for office, but the Perfected Immortal said: “To eat simple fare, wear coarse cloth, rest my head on stone, and rinse my mouth with flowing water—this is my joy. How could I exchange it for that?” Thereupon, he donned Daoist robes and entered the Tiantai, Chicheng, and Shangyu mountains, where he concentrated his thoughts on the Dao. As his aspirations bore fruit, he encountered the Perfected One Zuo Yuanfang, who transmitted to him the *Scripture of Nine Elixirs and Golden Liquor*, methods for refining cinnabar to preserve the body, secret techniques for healing illnesses and subduing spirits, and the *Wondrous Scripture of the Three Primes and True Unity*. Practicing these for three years, he amassed vast merit and efficacy.

On the first day of the first month of the second year of the *Guanghe* era of Emperor Ling, the Most High Lord Lao, together with the Perfected One of the Great Ultimate, Xu Laile, and others, descended upon Mount Tiantai. Lord Lao rode in an eightfold-jewel jade chariot, accompanied by a retinue of ten thousand attendants, with the Perfected One of the Orthodox Unity in attendance. Lord Lao styled himself the Perfected One of the Supreme Mystery and Unity, and the Perfected One of True Stability and Radiance as the High Master of the Mysterious Canon. He commanded the Immortal Attendant of the Scriptures, Wang Sizhen, to unfurl the ninefold-luminous jade cords and present the *Cavernous Mystery Great Cavern Numinous Treasure Scripture* in thirty-six sections, which he bestowed upon the immortal Ge Xuan, along with the two grades of Upper Clarity purification rites and the seven ranks of the Three Registers purification methods.

The Three Registers were: the Golden Register purification, for safeguarding the nation’s destiny; the Jade Register purification, for protecting empresses, consorts, dukes, and noble clans; and the Yellow Register purification, for delivering the nine generations of ancestors and seven generations of forebears, freeing them from the eternal night of suffering.

The seven ranks were: the Illumination of the Perfected purification, for transcending the departed and resolving all karmic entanglements; the Spontaneous purification, for universally seeking blessings and atoning for transgressions on behalf of all beings, and for the methods of cultivating immortality; the Three Primes purification, for repenting transgressions of precepts and absolving oneself before the Three Officials; the Eight Nodes purification, for repenting the sins of one’s primal ancestors and oneself, and for the method of erasing the Black Register; the Cavernous Spirit purification, which valued purity and simplicity, for the methods of seeking immortality and protecting the nation; and the Upholding the Teachings purification, which prized clarity and frugality, for the methods of healing illnesses and averting disasters.

The Mortification purification, which valued suffering and austerity as merit, for the methods of repenting transgressions and seeking blessings.

He also expounded the *Dharma Wheel Sutra* in forty-five fascicles, along with the *Sutra of Infinite Penetration*, the *Sutra of the Mysterious Turning of the Spirit*, and the *Sutra of Entering Samādhi*, bestowing them upon the Perfected Lord to propagate in the world. He declared: "You should constantly contemplate the Highest Great Daoist King of the Vastly Empty Primordial Perfected One, whose title in the great thousandfold world is Laozi, the Great Dharma Master of the Mysterious Realm."

He further revealed the celestial registers of human transgressions and blessings, titled *The Ledger of Karmic Responses*. And he said: "When merit fills three thousand, one ascends to the heavens in broad daylight. With surplus goodness, one descends seated upon a cloud chariot. Unceasingly propagating the Dao, one naturally attains immortality."

The Perfected Lord bowed in reverence and gratitude. Today, on Mount Tiantai at Tongbo Abbey, there stands the Dharma Wheel Cloister, where the Three Perfected Ones descended with the scriptures. The altar where the Perfected Lord commanded spirits to construct the platform for receiving celestial decrees still remains.

At eighteen or nineteen, the Perfected Lord’s immortal arts gradually matured. He roamed mountains and seas, appearing and vanishing in an instant, then journeyed to Kuocang, where he visited his uncle. His uncle, named Mi, styled Xiaogong, was then lecturing on the classics, surrounded by scholars from all directions, their shoulders and sleeves brushing together. A lecture hall stood beside his residence. The Perfected Lord returned to pay his respects, and Mi inquired about his wanderings, saying: "I have often thought of you, dwelling in seclusion, distant from worldly affairs, gazing up at the azure clouds and down upon the vast sea, enduring hardships and dangers—what others dread, you have accomplished. Now the realm enjoys cultural brilliance, and the Three States seek talent. With your vast and extraordinary learning, you are surely destined for greatness."

The Perfected Lord replied: "I am dull by nature, unfit for worldly affairs, and have failed my ancestors’ legacy. I decline the company of those who seek office and renounce the path of those who bear the tripod’s weight. I have long resolved to dwell in mountain caves, my heart nestled in mist and clouds, wandering rivers and peaks for my delight. I hope to befriend Master Juan and take Red Pine as my companion. My uncle, you widely propagate the Dao and the arts, expounding the Five Classics, reviving the legacy of the Lu and Si rivers, and restoring the flourishing of poetry and refinement. With the Three States at peace, the teachings of non-action must prevail. My aspirations are vast and distant; I forsake worldly glory. May you, my uncle, achieve renown and dedicate yourself to the realm, bringing prosperity to future generations."

Mi answered: "You transcend the common and enter the sacred—something I cannot match. You should diligently study the canons of preserving life and heed the admonitions of prudence. Then, ascending to the tripod lake will be no difficulty."

The Perfected Lord took his leave and once more traversed the mountains of Kuocang, Nanyue, and Luofu, seeking a site for refining the golden elixir. Wending his way through Yunsun, he arrived at Hezao, then ascended the lofty peaks of Shoulou to survey the land. He declared: "The form is harmonious, the colors deep; the soil is fertile, the waters clear—this is truly a dwelling for immortals, the very ground for my golden elixir. Yet after the elixir is complete, I must broadly accumulate hidden merit, delivering all beings, so that my name may be inscribed in the registers of the Three Heavens and my rank established among the Nine Empyreans, leaving no cause for remorse."

Then, lamenting the fall of the Han, the wars of the Three States, the ravages of drought and flood, famine, and the countless dead from warfare and captivity—lost souls and stagnant spirits, sunk in evil destinies, unable to escape the wheel of rebirth—he compiled the *Lingbao Scriptures and Decrees*, composing the *Great Rites of Sacrificial Refinement*, the *Precious Register for Ascending to Heaven*, and the *Secret Talismans of the Numinous Treasure*, presenting them to the Heavenly Emperor. He established a Dharma altar and, on the auspicious days of the Three Primes and Eight Nodes, summoned the destitute souls and stagnant spirits from the ten directions’ great hells to gather before the altar, where they all received sacrificial refinement, talismanic registers, and liberation to be reborn.

After practicing these rites, responses were frequently witnessed. On the evening of the Lower Prime Festival in the year of Jiawu, during the sacrificial refinement, a ghost king, five *zhang* in height and clad in a brown robe, bowed twice, stepped forward, and said: "I am a lowly ghost, governing destitute spirits. For countless kalpas, I have sunk in evil destinies with no hope of escape. Yet through the true immortals’ universal Dharma assemblies, sacrificial deliverance of lost souls, bestowal of talismanic registers, and salvation of the netherworld, hundreds of thousands have attained rebirth. We all share in this blessing and hear the Dharma’s sound. Overwhelmed with gratitude, I have come to pay homage. Moreover, I have heard the Dark Heaven North Emperor proclaim to the hells’ ghosts and spirits: ‘The Perfected Lord Ge has long practiced sacrificial refinement, his merit recorded in jade tablets, his name inscribed on golden slips. In five years, the Three Heavens will descend a decree, bestowing a commission to ascend and join the celestial bureaus.’" With that, he took his leave.

Thereupon, the Perfected Lord entrusted the *Scriptures of Sacrificial Refinement*, the Dharma methods, precious threads, talismanic texts, and secret instructions to the Zong Altar of Hezao and the Chongxu Altar, transmitting them to later disciples to broadly deliver the lost.

The Perfected Lord further reflected that beings, having attained human form and birth in a land of bliss, indulge their desires and neglect the true Dao. As transgressions accumulate, karmic retribution becomes inescapable. Only the *Three Vehicles’ Secret Scriptures of Lingbao* can enlighten beings, repent their sins, deliver the suffering, and awaken them to the true and real. Thus, he synthesized the essentials of the *Shangqing* and *Lingbao* scriptural corpora, compiling the *Nine Dark Hells Great Repentance Rites of the Merciful Dharma Altar* in ten fascicles, which spread throughout the world among devout men and women. Those afflicted by disasters in their homes or mourning deceased kin may establish grand Dharma altars, array the true images, and recite the *Nine Dark Hells Great Repentance*. Thereby, the living may receive blessings, the departed may attain rebirth, and both old and new karmic debts may be extinguished. The cold courts of hell will adjourn their trials, and suffering spirits will receive grace. This repentance rite has spread across the four seas, bestowing boundless beneficence.

The Perfected Lord, having received the *Shangqing* and *Lingbao* scriptural corpora, studied and recited them with utmost devotion. Within the *Dongshen* and *Taiqing* corpora, he expanded the *Dao and Its Virtue*, composing commentaries and prefaces, which he placed at the beginning of the texts.

Still, in his commentary on the present scripture, he declared: "I attained the true Dao and once recited this scripture ten thousand times. I received it from the Lord of Eastern Splendor, who received it from the Lord of the Golden Portals, who received it from the Queen Mother of the West—each transmitting it orally, without committing it to writing. Now, in this world, I have inscribed and recorded it. Thus, the transmission of this scripture truly begins with me.

In former times, when the Perfected Lord encountered his true master, he was taught the arts of multiplying his form ten thousandfold and the methods of numinous responsiveness and transformation. He could sit upon kindling and set it aflame without his robes or cap being singed, or drink deeply and lie upon a spring without his body becoming wet. While traveling, if he encountered kin or friends, he would invite them to stay, plucking grass or piercing a tree to draw forth sap, which he collected in a cup—flowing like a spring until the cup was full. When he urged his guests to drink, it was always fine wine. Taking shards of tile, pebbles, or the fruits of plants and trees, he would offer them to his guests, saying, 'These are delicacies,' and upon eating, they became dried meats and jujubes.

Once, while boating with a guest, the guest noticed a box containing a dozen or so talismans and asked, 'Might I witness the efficacy of these talismans?' The Perfected Lord immediately took one and cast it into the water, where it drifted downstream. He asked, 'What do you think?' The guest replied, 'Even an ordinary person could do the same.' The Perfected Lord took another talisman and cast it into the water, where it traveled upstream. He asked, 'What do you think?' The guest said, 'That is extraordinary.' The Perfected Lord cast yet another talisman into the water, where it neither sank nor floated but remained suspended. After a moment, the upstream talisman descended, the downstream talisman ascended, and they met in the current, the three talismans gathering together before he retrieved them.

On another occasion, by the water’s edge, he saw a man fishing for large fish and said to the fisherman, 'I wish to borrow this fish to take to the River Earl.' The fisherman replied, 'This one is already dead.' The Perfected Lord said, 'Even so, place this cinnabar-inscribed paper in its mouth and cast it into the water, and it will leap away.' Later, a guest arrived for an audience. As they sat, another visitor arrived, and the Perfected Lord rose to greet and escort him in, yet the Perfected Lord on the seat continued conversing and laughing with the guest, unmoved.

During a bitter cold spell, he said to his guests, 'Living in poverty, I cannot afford a brazier to warm you. Let me conjure a fire to await you all.' Thereupon, he exhaled, and flames burst forth, filling the room in an instant. On another sweltering day, as he lay resting, he had someone apply powder to his abdomen and said to his guests, 'It is too hot for other amusements.' He then slowly rubbed his abdomen upward, and the powder adhered to the roof beam.

Once, while dining with guests, he spoke of divine transformations. A guest said, 'After we finish eating, you must perform a marvel.' Before the meal was done, the Perfected Lord asked, 'Do you wish to see it sooner?' He then spat out the rice from his mouth, which transformed into flying bees filling the room. Some alighted on the guests, who were all astonished, though the bees did not sting. After a while, he opened his mouth, and the bees flew back in, returning to rice, which they ate again.

He pointed to a forest, commanding it to walk; to toads and other creatures, commanding them to fly; and to swallows, sparrows, and turtles, commanding them to dance—all moving in rhythm like humans. In winter, he served his guests fresh melons and jujubes, and in summer, he provided ice and snow. He once had someone scatter dozens of coins into a well, then held a vessel over the well and called for the coins to emerge. One by one, the coins flew out of the well, each returning to where it had been cast.

When he served wine to guests, no one passed the cups, for they came of their own accord. If a guest did not finish drinking, the cup would not depart. Once, while traveling, the Perfected Lord passed a spirit shrine where all who passed were required to dismount a hundred paces away, or else misfortune would befall them. Beside the shrine stood dozens of large trees, upon which perched several birds that none dared disturb. The Perfected Lord drove his carriage straight toward it. Suddenly, a great wind arose, and dust obscured the sky. His attendants were terrified, but the Perfected Lord grew angry and said, 'How dare a petty demon act thus!' He raised his hand and pointed at the wind, which immediately ceased. He then had someone cast a talisman into the shrine, and the birds all fell dead while the shrine itself burst into flames.

Passing through Wukang, he saw a household where illness had taken hold, and a shaman was summoned to sacrifice to the malevolent spirits. The spirit possessing the shaman demanded that the Perfected Lord drink. He refused, and the pernicious spirit spoke insolently. The Perfected Lord rebuked it sternly, saying, 'How dare you, wicked ghost!' He commanded the Earth Lord to drag the possessed man’s head and lash his back against a pillar. The sound of whipping was heard, and blood flowed to the ground. The possessed man, terrified, begged for mercy, saying, 'I have offended the Perfected One. I beg for forgiveness.' The Perfected Lord asked, 'What kind of malevolent spirit are you? Confess at once.' It replied, 'I am a ghost from the rear mountain.' The Perfected Lord said, 'I pardon your offense, but the sick one must recover within three days, or I will punish you severely without mercy.'

Once, while passing through Huayin, he saw a scholar entrapped in the household of a serpent spirit. The Perfected Lord transformed into a peasant driving a yellow calf to plow. He said to the scholar, 'You have fallen into a perilous place. This woman is a serpent spirit who has devoured countless people.' He led the scholar to an ancient well filled with white bones. Then he instructed the scholar to secretly observe, saying, 'Flee eastward, and I will protect you.' The scholar did as told and saw the serpent spirit—fangs bared, eyes glaring—lying in a netted canopy with a small serpent brother beside her. The Perfected Lord slew and beheaded her. Innumerable small serpents came to her aid, but he slaughtered them all. He gave the scholar a talisman to ingest, and the scholar vomited up earthworms, toads, and the like, thus preserving his life.

In former times, the Perfected Lord received from the Most High Lord Lao the *Thunder Rites of the Lightning Fire Palace*, enabling him to command thunder deities and punish the unrighteous. In the second year of the Chiwu reign, on the first day of the first month, the Perfected Lord ascended Laoshan Mountain to meditate upon the Dao. At noon, the Most High bestowed upon him the *Thousand Perfected Precepts and Admonitions*, which he expounded to the assembled immortals, exhorting and admonishing those yet unenlightened. These teachings have since spread throughout the world."

The Perfected Lord once resided on Purple Canopy Mountain in Jingmen Commandery to cultivate and refine his practice. There, he encountered a bitter cold that froze his feet, and his garments were tattered and threadbare. Two daughters of the Qu family, observing from afar, pitied his endurance of the cold. Under the cover of night, they hastily crafted a pair of shoes and, the following day, sought to present them to him. Arriving at his alchemical furnace, they found the Perfected Lord already departed, though the ashes in the hearth remained warm. The sisters raked through the ashes and discovered a single elixir pellet, which they divided and ingested. Thereafter, their *qi* surged with vitality; they neither hungered nor thirsted, and yearned only for purity and stillness. Later, they vanished into seclusion, and people of the time declared them to have attained immortality, as recorded in Sima Ziwei’s *Record of the Ma Immortal’s Abode*.

The Perfected Lord and the Celestial Master shared a bond like that of outer and inner garments, their traces and wanderings often found in the lands of Shu. Across the ages, their deeds have grown distant, and few among the people could fully comprehend them—thus, they cannot be exhaustively recounted.

The Perfected Lord once cultivated on Xiaoyou Grotto-Heaven of Mount Magu in Xujiang, where he carved five wells corresponding to the Five Phases, aligning them with the Five Stars above. To this day, the ebb and flow of their waters follow a cyclical pattern from one to five, endlessly repeating, as if governed by a fixed measure. These wells lie before the foothills of Mount Magu.

At that time, the Lord of Wu received the Perfected Lord with the courtesy due a guest. One day, as they sat upon a high tower, they observed from afar a petitioner offering prayers to the earth deity for rain. The Lord of Wu asked, “The people long for rain—can it be granted?” The Perfected Lord replied, “It can.” He inscribed a talisman and ordered it burned at the altar. In an instant, the heavens darkened, wind and thunder arose in tumult, and a timely rain fell, reviving the withered crops.

Once, the Perfected Lord accompanied the Lord of Wu on a voyage to the confluence of the Three Rivers. A storm arose, and many boats were lost to the waves; the Perfected Lord’s vessel, too, vanished without trace. The Lord of Wu sighed, “The Perfected Lord of Ge is a man of the Dao—how could he not escape this?” He dispatched messengers in search, and by nightfall, they suddenly beheld the Perfected Lord striding across the water toward them. Upon arrival, he still bore the flush of wine. He apologized, saying, “Yesterday, Wu Zixu insisted I stay for drinks, delaying me and causing Your Majesty this distress.” The Lord of Wu smiled and replied, “Masters are often detained by spirits and deities—such is the reach of your virtue and power.”

One day, the Perfected Lord wandered at leisure in Kuaiji. A merchant from the region, returning from the sea, passed by a spirit’s shrine and saw an attendant summon him, saying, “I wish to entrust a letter to the Perfected Lord of Ge on Mount Kuaiji.” With that, the attendant tossed a sealed missive onto the merchant’s boat. The seal was as if nailed fast, immovable. Upon returning to Kuaiji, the merchant reported this to the Perfected Lord, who received the letter and opened it with ease. It was a missive from the Lord of the Lesser Hua Flowers, addressed to “The Perfected Lord of the Left Palace of the Great Ultimate.” The characters were written in tadpole script, an ancient form. Upon seeing this, people knew the Perfected Lord’s name had long been recorded in the celestial registers.

One day, the Lord of Wu invited the Perfected Lord to ascend the palace hall, where incense was burned and a fast observed. His disciples Zhang Tai, Kong Long, Zheng Siyuan, and others stood in attendance. The Lord of Wu said, “In my ignorance, I have yet to grasp the profound mysteries. I delight in tales of immortals and spirits and wish for you, Master, to instruct me in the secret canons, the principles of fasting and purification, and the swiftest path to cultivating truth. Among the ranks of Daoist scriptures, which should take precedence? Among talismans and secret diagrams, which are most wondrous? Enlighten my ignorance and fulfill my hopes.”

The Perfected Lord rose from his seat and replied, “Since Your Majesty deigns to inquire, how dare I conceal anything? Yet this is not a matter for rulers to pursue with single-minded devotion. If, amidst the myriad affairs of state, you can still the heart and hold to the One, the Way is not far off. The Dao of immortals is subtle and wondrous, as recorded in the alchemical classics. To study the Dao and cultivate immortality, one must first refine conduct and uphold precepts—only then can gradual progress be made. Once the Dao is established in practice, one may ingest numinous medicines, guide and refine the primordial *qi*, swallow and absorb the Great Harmony, regulate the breath of yin and yang, and forge the inner elixir. Thus may one become an earthbound immortal: unscathed by fire, undrowned by water, transcending calamities, averting misfortune, and summoning good fortune. Yet this requires the completion of fasting and purification.

“The scripture containing these teachings emerges from the *Wondrous Canon of the Numinous Treasure, the Cavernous Mystery of the Great Dao, the Primordial Ultimate, the Spontaneous and True One, the Five Invocations*, found within the *Inner Writings of the Three Sovereigns*. The ancient texts on immortality therein declare that all wondrous arts culminate in the Great Law of the Numinous Treasure. In former times, Celestial Master Zhang attained immortality after personally receiving from the Most High Lord Lao the secret methods of the Orthodox Unity Alliance of Might for cultivating truth, as well as the *Five Invocations of the Numinous Treasure*, with fasting as their foundation. The Great Law of the Numinous Treasure is concise in text yet profound in meaning—its depths cannot be fully expounded.

“Earthbound immortals first ascend the numinous mountains to become their divine overseers. Their great term spans six hundred years, or three hundred for some, after which they all ascend to become celestial immortals. Only through the ninefold cyclical refinement of the golden elixir, the golden liquid and jade nectar, can one ride clouds and mount dragons to ascend to heaven in broad daylight. As for the *True Scripture of the Great Cavern*, its recitation alone enables ascension, allowing one to sit and behold the ten directions without need for elixirs or potions. Those with the bone of immortals may encounter this text. Those who steal its numinous words, though they grow wings, cannot fly. One must receive oral transmission from a master, swear oaths before the heavens and true immortals—only then may it be passed on.

“The *Inner Writings of the Three Sovereigns*, the *Seven Transformations and Seven Treasures of the Ten Lands of the Five Marchmounts*, and the *Inner Chapters of the Numinous Diagrams* are all treasured by the highest immortals. Those who study the Dao progress from the subtle to the manifest, from the near to the distant, without skipping steps. The talismans and diagrams of the Numinous Treasure are most exalted and weighty, capable of delivering one from the nine hundred and six calamities of the Great Yang. Those who transcend the Three Realms and become Perfected Ones all follow this path.”

The Lord of Wu said, “By the accumulated blessings of past lives, I have become a ruler. Now, by good fortune, I have met a sage and heard these wondrous teachings. Though I am mired in frivolity, my heart holds reverence. I shall inscribe them upon golden tablets, seal them in a jade casket, and never dare show them to the unworthy. I shall venerate them all my life.” The Perfected Lord replied, “If Your Majesty can do so, it is most excellent.”

At that time, a Buddhist monk named Daowei, having heard from afar of the Perfected Lord’s attainment of the Dao, came seeking him as a teacher. He bowed and inquired, “I have heard that the Dao knows no before or after, no past or present. May I ask whether its principles are the same or different?”

The Perfected Lord said, “In its essence, there is no distinction of high or low, noble or base, form or name—hence it is called the Dao. Laozi existed before Heaven and Earth, and in the age of the Shang dynasty, he manifested to broadly proclaim the teachings of the Dao, guiding both Hua and Rong. Responding to things naturally, he is forever without birth or extinction.”

The Perfected Lord said, “The left is yang, and yang governs generation. The right is yin, and yin governs extinction. In utmost yin there is no birth; in utmost yang there is no extinction—such is the principle of nature. Yet the Great Dao is profoundly esoteric and not transmitted to the vulgar. None but the utmost persons of the world may hear of it.”

Daowei bowed again and exclaimed in admiration, “Excellent! I wish to hear of this Dao.”

The Perfected Lord said, “Those whose merit and virtue are not yet complete do not seek immortality. You, however, have fulfilled your merit and completed your virtue in past lives. My predecessors have already been your teachers. By karmic affinity, we meet again, and you shall soon transcend the world.”

Thereupon, he established an altar on Mount Tiantai and bestowed upon Daowei the *True Forms of the Five Peaks*, saying, “This is the token of transmission from the Most High. Carry it as you travel to the famous mountains of the eight directions, and the Three Realms shall receive you with reverence.” He also transmitted the *Scripture of the Golden Elixir of the Most High*, the *Five Sacred Treasures of the Numinous Treasure’s Natural Radiance*, the *Inner Writings of the Three Sovereigns*, the *Golden Writ of the Wondrous Scripture of Great Possession*, the *Jade-Light Numinous Writ*, the *Thirty-Nine Chapters of the Purple Writ of the Great Cavern*, the *Hidden Writ of the Grand Empyrean*, the *Illuminated Mirror Register*, and a single stalk of *Taiyi’s Dragon-Soaring Mushroom*. He summoned the covenant spirits and commanded each to be worn upon the body. He then instructed his disciple Zheng Siyuan to orally transmit the essential instructions.

He further addressed Siyuan and the others, saying, “Long ago, I received the *True Forms of the Five Peaks* and the *Scripture of the Golden Elixir* from Master Zuo Yuanfang on Mount Chicheng. Today, I entrust them to you. As for the various talismans and registers, the *True Scriptures of the Cavern of Perfection*, the *Cavern of Mystery*, and the *Cavern of Divinity*, these were transmitted to me by the Perfected One of the Great Ultimate, Xu Laile, at Kuaiji. I have already disseminated them in the Hezao Grotto-Heaven west of the Great River. These are forbidden texts of the Upper Realm, guarded by flying immortals. Today, I entrust them to you to uphold the Great Dharma. Yet the prohibitions of the Nine Heavens are weighty—do not show them to the unworthy. If there are those of utmost sincerity, transmit them in accordance with the *Bright Statutes of the Four Poles* over the span of kalpas.”

Siyuan and the others bowed again, receiving the precepts and commands.

He also gave Daowei a grain of immortal medicine, enabling him to abstain from grains and forsake the five flavors and worldly cravings, so that he might wander far among the famous mountains and sever worldly affairs. After Daowei ingested it, along with the *Flowing Brilliance’s Seven Luminaries Purple Pellet Elixir*, he immediately felt his body lighten, his mind and spirit at ease, free from all desires. When the hundred-day retreat was complete, the Perfected Lord further instructed Daowei, “You should return to Mount Song and fast for three years. Thereafter, go to Wangwu Mountain, purify your fast, and meditate deeply upon the Great Dharma.”

Having received the essential instructions, sacred scriptures, and immortal medicines, Daowei was neither hungry nor thirsty. He wished to remain and attend the Perfected Lord, but the Perfected Lord said, “If your heart holds me, I shall be visible to you—there is no need for attachment. Now, your mortal form has only just begun to learn and has not yet attained penetrating vision. You should ascend Mount Song. When you arrive, you will see the various Perfected Ones, who will further instruct you. After five years, I shall transmit to you the secret instructions, perfecting your Dao, so that you may attain penetrating vision of the formless and perceive the ten directions as clearly as objects in your palm or reflections in a mirror. You and your companions shall dwell on the Terrace of Gentle Winds for three hundred years before ascending to Heaven.”

“Some attain the Dao of immortality and ascend to Heaven in broad daylight within their lifetime. Others take ten, dozens, or hundreds of years, or even three thousand, five thousand, or ten thousand years before ascending. Before attaining ascension, they temporarily reside in the Five Peaks, the famous mountains, the grotto-heavens and blessed lands, or among the Ten Continents and Three Islands in the Eight Seas. There, palaces of the seven treasures and chambers of jade and jasper abound, along with natural gold, silver, pearls, and jade, immortal medicines, and countless rare and wondrous treasures beyond description. Natural music resounds through the Great Void, phoenixes and qilin intermingle in dance. Amid jade trees and forests of coral, pure winds arise, their sounds like the *Nine Shao* melodies. Those immortals who have not yet ascended dwell in these palaces within and beyond the mountains, at leisure in joyous feasting. To wander together with your companions—is this not bliss? Yet you must broadly accumulate good deeds and travel to the Five Peaks to pay homage to the various Perfected Lords. I may not tarry in these mountains to wander and rest with the host of immortals.
