Fast for seven days, then ingest the mushroom I gave you earlier. You will need no food or drink, and your harmonious qi will be at ease, sparing you from old age. How much more so if you cultivate the Great Scriptures!”

Then, on the famous mountain of Tiantai, he addressed Zheng Siyuan, saying, “The various scriptures of the Three Caverns and Numinous Treasure, the covenants of the Upper Clarity, which I have transmitted—on the day of my ascension, one copy shall be entrusted to Hezao Mountain, and another to the disciples of my lineage, to be transmitted through the generations to those of worth. Do not lightly bestow them, nor show them to the unworthy. If you find the right person, transmit them without secrecy.”

He further instructed his disciples, “I shall traverse the Five Peaks and rest my carriage on Penglai.”

At that time, he briefly returned to the capital to pay his respects to Lord Xie Hao. During a gathering with his younger cousin, the Director of the Bureau of Scrutiny Xi, he remarked, “Among my disciples, there are those of broad talent and erudition, whose reputations resound at court and whose families flourish. Yet I fear none have pursued the Way of immortality. They are steadfast in refining literary arts

When the Immortal Lord refined his elixir, he often ground herbs in a stone mortar embedded in the cliff face of West Peak. Once, a grain no larger than a millet seed fell from his pestle. A bird happened upon it, ate it, and thereby attained immortality. To this day, on nights of still moonlight and gentle breeze, the bird can be heard making the *ding-dang* sound of pestle and mortar—hence its name, the Elixir-Pounding Crow.

The Immortal Qin Gao, having heard of the Immortal Lord’s attainment of the Dao, rode a pair of carp from the Eastern Sea to visit him at Reclining Cloud Hermitage. The two drank deeply together. Once intoxicated, Qin Gao stepped outside to relieve himself, and upon sobering, found the carp transformed into stone. The Immortal Lord then gifted him a pair of cranes, upon which he departed. Those stones remain to this day in the rear mountains.

In the first year of the Red Crow era, the year *wuwu* of the sexagenary cycle, on the first day of the eleventh month, the Most High successively bestowed three decrees, dispatching celestial officials to announce them in the Court of Blessings.

The first decree read: *"The Jade Writ of the Most High proclaims: The disciple of the Supreme Learning of Immortality, Ge Xuan, has cultivated苦行 through past kalpas, accumulating merit, sacrificing his body in almsgiving, and delivering those in peril. His devotion has moved the Most High, and his name is now inscribed in the Mystic Capital, his rank fixed among the Upper Immortals. Thus, wisdom and brilliance have descended upon his virtuous lineage. His nature is jade-pure, his fragrance like orchid in bloom; his celestial gifts surpass all, standing tall and unmatched. His Dao is profound and majestic, unrivaled in his generation. Forsaking worldly glory, he embraces simplicity and truth, devoting himself to the scriptures of immortality, preserving the One in hidden radiance. Roaming forests and peaks, he spurns the bustle of courts. With a compassionate heart, he ceaselessly delivers others. Now that his virtue and power are full, he is worthy of this decree. We hereby bestow upon him the Heavenly Treasure Feathered Robe, a skirt of cinnabar clouds to shatter the nets of the flying snare, a lotus-flowered crown of precious jade, the Golden True Divine Tiger Staff, the Banner of Commanding Demons, and the power to summon seas and mountains at will."*

The second decree read: *"We exhort the disciple of the Supreme Learning of Immortality, Ge Xuan: You have delved into hidden scriptures, translated sutras, observed long fasts, and cultivated stillness in thought. Your concentration is unwavering, your diligence tireless. We now grant you the Eight-Scenery Jade Chariot, drawn by dragons and borne on clouds, with a halo of radiant light crowning your head, golden seals and jade inscriptions to reward your past virtues, and authority to uphold the discipline of the Daoist gate. May later worthies look up to you as you uphold the Dharma Wheel. This decree of the Most High is weighed by the Three Heavens."*

The third decree read: *"The disciple of the Supreme Learning of Immortality, Ge Xuan, embodies virtue and magnifies the Dao, enlightening the unenlightened, universally delivering all beings to transcendence and awakening. His merits are accomplished, his name resounds, and even the loftiest immortals submit in faith. The hosts of the Three Realms and all spirits revere him with solemnity; his grace fills the ten directions, his might fulfills all desires. We now bestow upon him the title of Immortal Lord of the Supreme Jade Capital’s Great Ultimate Left Palace, with authority over the Six Heavens of the Three Realms and the Great Demon Kings. He shall preside over the registers of the Three Caverns and Four Supplements, attended by five hundred jade lads and maidens. In his left hand, he shall hold the Nine Radiance Flower Pestle; in his right, the True Scripture of the Mystic Cavern. With dragon banners and tiger tallies, he shall traverse the Nine Palaces of the Upper Clarity, thrice yearly paying homage at the Jade Capital and Golden Portals of the Mystic Capital in the Supreme Heaven. This decree of the Most High, borne by the Celestial Emperor, shall be executed in accordance with the ancient statutes of the Three Heavens."*

On the *jiazi* day of the first day of the eleventh month of the first year of the Red Crow era, the Celestial Emperor, whose taboo name is Yuan, proclaimed the decree at Huo Tong Mountain—also called Huo Mountain: *"The Immortal Lord’s golden elixir has ripened, and he has received three decrees from the Jade Emperor. He may no longer tarry in the mortal world. He must erect an altar, offer libations to heaven and earth, mountains and rivers, and all spirits before consuming the elixir."* Thereupon, within the Court of Blessings, he constructed an altar named the Eight Sceneries. On an auspicious day, he ascended the altar to offer thanks to heaven and earth. After three days of grand libations, he knelt and consumed the golden elixir. At that moment, celestial blossoms drifted to the earth, and divine light illuminated the heavens.

The Immortal Lord then addressed his disciples: *"Now that I have consumed the golden elixir, a celestial decree shall descend from heaven. The day of my ascension draws near."* He then concealed the secret registers of the Three Caverns and Four Supplements upon the sacred altar, saying, *"In time, a disciple of my lineage, devoted in heart and practice, shall inherit these. The transmission of these arcane scriptures and numinous texts shall bring blessings to the four seas."*

On the fifteenth day of the eighth month in the seventh year of the Red Crow era, at midday, suddenly celestial music resounded, banners and canopies veiled the sky, and a phoenix-drawn jade chariot descended from the void. Jade lads and maidens, divine officials in resplendent array, alighted before and behind the altar. A Flying Celestial Deva bore a jade edict; the Immortal Lord straightened his tablet, knelt, and faced the Heavenly Gate to receive the proclamation:

*"The disciple of the Supreme Learning of Immortality, Grand Master of the Mystic Treasure Scriptures and Registers, Ge Xuan, has long devoted himself to the supreme Dao, skillfully nurturing the essence of the embryo. He has expounded true scriptures, refining and offering them for the deliverance of sunken souls; he has compiled immortal classics, illuminating the path for later learners. His hidden deeds have saved the world, his secret practices align with the true. His name is inscribed in the Jade Capital, his body belongs to the celestial realms. We hereby specially bestow upon him the title of Immortal Lord of the Supreme Jade Capital’s Great Ultimate Left Palace, with authority over the Six Heavens of the Three Realms and the Great Demon Kings, and charge him with presiding over the affairs of the Three Caverns and Four Supplements. He shall ascend at the hour of noon on the fifteenth day of the eighth month of the *jiazi* year, proceeding directly to the celestial court. We further grant him a jade casket of golden elixir and immortal robes."*

This decree of the Most High, borne by the Celestial Emperor, shall be executed in accordance with the ancient statutes of the Three Heavens. The Celestial Emperor, whose taboo name is Yuan, proclaimed the edict at the Court of Blessings on Mount Hezao.

The Immortal Lord gazed toward the Heavenly Gate, bowed twice, and received the decree. Then, beside East Peak, he bid farewell to his disciples and friends. Ascending the Robing Terrace, he donned a gown of parted mist, a lotus-flowered crown of precious jade, a halo of radiant light crowning his head, and held a jade tablet. Clad in crimson skirts and vermilion shoes, jade pendants chiming at his waist, he seated himself in the Eight-Scenery Jade Chariot, preceded and followed by jade lads and maidens, flanked by divine escorts. Auspicious clouds and white cranes swirled in the azure sky as he rose slowly aloft.

The disciples and friends clung to him, reluctant to part. Thereupon, the Immortal Lord briefly halted his celestial chariot and composed three five-character poems, which he bestowed upon his companions, bidding them chant and recite them widely to enlighten those yet to come. In the year of his ascension, he was eighty-one. The three poems are recorded below.

**The First:**
The Perfected One once left his teachings,
Moved by pity for the benighted and foolish.
Those who reject the Dao and trust in wickedness—
From this do calamity and chaos arise.
The body fades swift as morning dew,
Regret and remorse know no end.
Sins too great to cast away
Poison the streams—who shall govern them?
In darkness, the hour of deliverance unseen,
Only when the kalpa ends will it cease.
Passed down to the poor and lowly,
Again they are made to serve.
Their limbs may be broken,
Begging in the marketplace with shattered jade.
Unknowing of the retribution for accumulated sins,
They rail against Heaven, spurning the gods.
The Great Dao is ever non-action,
Its vastness begins with goodness.
Now I attain lightness and ascent,
Through cultivation and merit achieved.
The Three Realms all bow their heads,
As I recline in the Purple Palace’s ease.
Halting my chariot in the Void,
Life flows like water.
At parting, I inscribe these plain words,
Roughly marking the wondrous and subtle.

**The Second:**
Now I ascend to Heaven,
My thoughts turn to all you learned ones.
The Dao’s essence is emptiness and nothingness,
In stillness, its essence abides.
Though it seems obscure and dim,
Within its depths, all is bright and clear.
Do not call the Dao false and vain—
The fault lies in lack of sincerity.
Why not climb the sacred mountains,
And chant the *Dongzhen Jing*?
With each recitation and song,
The mystic sound pierces the Great Clarity.
The Most High radiates a golden countenance,
All immortals join in unison.
From the ten directions, fragrant flowers scatter,
Incense smoke of plum and sandalwood perfumes the air.
The Royal Consort plays the *Nine Shao*,
Phoenixes and simurghs harmonize in song.
Dragon-drawn chariots veil the sky in welcome,
Canopies of light illumine the distant dark.
Leisurely, I ascend the Terrace of Kalpas,
Indra suddenly descends to the courtyard.
The Eight Kings offer elixir,
Which I drink—my body grows light.
Carefree, I wander the realms of being and non-being,
Luminous, beyond form and name.
Divine youths attend at my side,
Naturally paying homage to the myriad spirits.
Swaying in the Eight-Scenery Chariot,
I feast and wander in the White Jade Capital.
My seven ancestors ascend to the Hall of Blessings,
All the departed are liberated and reborn.
If kings and lords hold steadfast faith,
They shall surely become the world’s pillars.
The great embrace the supreme virtue,
All things partake of its completion.

**The Third:**
Roaming freely through mountains and waters,
I exhaled and inhaled the numinous springs.
Refining qi, I awaited the subtle and still,
Silently chanting the *Daode Pian*.
With utmost sincerity, I revered the Mystic One,
And now, at last, my hidden resonance is revealed.
A flying chariot drawn by nine dragons,
I soar on swirling purple mist.
Radiant splendor lights the celestial thoroughfare,
Crimson clouds gather before the Emperor.
Briefly I tarry at Penglai Palace,
In an instant, I am a guest of Heaven.
Majestic, the assembly of all Perfected,
Vast, I ascend through the layered mysteries.
My form is eternal, beyond kalpas,
My golden visage shines fresh as the sun.
In joy, I forget the upper realms,
Yet grieve for all living beings.
Who can escape decay and death,
Bound by unseen karmic threads?
Vast and boundless, the perfect Dao,
No gap exists where it does not enter.
Subtle and wondrous, hard to fathom—
The wise call me worthy.
If one can magnify its myriad wonders,
Lightly they shall rise as immortals.

When the songs were finished, clouds and birds slowly ascended to Heaven and departed. The Immortal Lord left behind for the world the *Preface to Laozi’s Daode Jing*, three scrolls of *Methods for Fasting and Ingesting Qi*, nineteen scrolls of the *Scripture on Meditation in the Mountains*, along with his divine immortal songs and poems.

According to the *Annals of Yu and Earth*, Emperor Wu of the Han dynasty favored the Daoist arts and often consorted with the immortal Ge Xuan, whom he deeply respected. For him, he specially established the Dongxuan Abbey on Mount Fang. Later, the Immortal Lord ascended to Heaven in broad daylight at Mount Hezao, and to this day, the cauldron for decocting medicine and the mortar for grinding elixirs remain on Mount Fang.

In the third year of Chongning of the Song dynasty, on the twenty-eighth day of the second month, the imperial carriage visited the Altar of Immortal Lord Ge in Hezao Mountain, Qingren County, Linjiang Prefecture. A land of sublime mountains and rivers, a dwelling of immortals and sages—his illustrious virtue and mighty deeds, renowned throughout the world, compelled Us to honor him with rites. The Perfected One’s parting words and established teachings all lead to the ultimate principle, transcending the mundane to soar with the Dao. His altar within the jade palace has stood for years, where prayers for blessings and relief have brought great benefit to the people.

Bestowing splendid honors in commendation, We specially establish a lofty title, that his beneficent influence may be sought, and this realm eternally blessed. Let him be specially enfeoffed as Perfected One of Penetrating Response.

In the sixth year of Chunyou of the reign of Emperor Lizong, on the seventeenth day of the third month, an imperial decree was issued concerning the Perfected One of Penetrating Response, Lord Ge of Mount Hezao under the jurisdiction of Qingjiang County, Linjiang Prefecture. Zhuang Zhou said: "The spirit-man employs things without harm, and the grain ripens in season—is this not what is meant by an immortal?" You cultivated the sublime Dao upon the renowned mountain, and the age has transmitted the tale of your ascension—this is long established. During the Chongning era, you were already granted enfeoffment. Recently, the regional commissioner, responding to the entreaties of the local officials, again memorialized the efficacy of prayers and the repeated abundance of the harvests. Though We hold no predilection for the discourse of Daoist adepts, We commend your merit among the people and thus command the ritual officials to expand your honorific title. As for riding clouds and driving the wind, roaming beyond the eight directions—what need is there for a name? Yet this is but to manifest Our heartfelt admiration and esteem.

Let him be specially enfeoffed as Perfected Lord of Penetrating Response and Blessed Protection.

*Record of Perfected Immortals Through the Ages Who Embodied the Dao and Penetrated the Mysteries, Scroll Twenty-Three* (concluded)
*Record of Perfected Immortals Through the Ages Who Embodied the Dao and Penetrated the Mysteries, Scroll Twenty-Four*

Zheng Siyuan

In his youth, Zheng Siyuan was a scholar well-versed in the laws of calendrical astronomy and apocryphal texts. In later years, he became a disciple of Ge Xiaoxian, receiving the Orthodox Unity scriptures, the Three Sovereigns’ esoteric texts, the True Forms of the Five Peaks, the *Taiqing Scripture of Golden Liquor*, and the *Five Talismans of the Cavernous Mystery*. He took residence in Ma’er Mountain of Lujiang, where his benevolence extended even to birds and beasts. On the mountain where he dwelled, a tiger gave birth to two cubs. The villagers below captured the mother tiger, causing the father to flee in alarm, leaving the cubs unable to fend for themselves. Upon witnessing this, Siyuan took them back to his mountain abode and raised them. The father tiger later returned and remained by Siyuan’s side. Thereafter, whenever Siyuan traveled, he would ride the father tiger, while the two cubs carried his scriptures, clothing, and medicines in tow.

Once, at Yongkang’s Hengjiang Bridge, he encountered an acquaintance, Xu Yin, who prepared warm medicinal wine. The tigers immediately gathered firewood and kindled a fire. Xu Yin suffered from a toothache and asked Siyuan for a tiger’s whisker, intending to heat it and insert it into the aching tooth for relief. Siyuan plucked the whisker for him, and the tiger remained still, submitting without resistance.

Minister Daoyi remarks: The *Daodejing* states, “The highest virtue is like water; water benefits all things and does not contend.” Siyuan may indeed be called one of the highest virtue. In nurturing the Dao amidst forests and springs, his benevolence extended even to birds and beasts. Tigers are creatures that harm humans, universally feared and reviled. Yet Siyuan pitied the cubs for losing their mother, taking them in and raising them. The ancients warned that “raising a tiger invites calamity,” a principle that would seem inevitable. Yet Siyuan saw no peril in this, and the tigers even carried his scriptures, clothing, and medicines, gathering firewood to kindle flames. Truly, this may be called the loftiness of the Dao, the depth of virtue, and the resonance of the highest goodness.

—Ge Hong

Ge Hong, styled Zhichuan, was a native of Jurong in Danyang. From youth, he loved learning, but his family was poor. He personally chopped firewood to trade for paper and ink, and at night, he would transcribe books and recite them, thereby gaining renown as a Confucian scholar. By nature, he was free from desires, possessing no fondness for playthings, unaware even of the number of lines on a chessboard or the names of dice games. He was simple and inarticulate, disdaining fame and profit. He shut his door and swept away worldly dust, never engaging in social visits. Occasionally, he would seek out books or inquire about their meanings, traveling thousands of miles over rugged paths, enduring hardships to obtain them. Thus, he thoroughly studied the classics and canons, with a particular fondness for the methods of divine transcendents and Daoist nourishment. His great-uncle, Ge Xuan, had learned the Dao and attained immortality during the Wu dynasty, earning the title "Divine Lord Ge." Xuan transmitted his secret arts of elixir refinement to his disciple Zheng Yin, and Hong studied under Yin, mastering all his techniques.

In the early years of Emperor Cheng of Jin’s reign during the Xianhe era, the Minister over the Masses, Wang Dao, summoned him to serve as a clerk in the provincial administration, later selecting him as a Gentleman Cavalier Attendant and concurrently Director of the Palace Library. Hong firmly declined and did not accept the posts. As he grew older, he wished to refine elixirs to prolong his life. Hearing that cinnabar was produced in Jiaozhi, he requested to be appointed Magistrate of Julou. The emperor, considering Hong’s high reputation, refused. Hong said, “I do not seek honor; it is for the cinnabar.” The emperor relented. Hong then set out with his sons and nephews. Upon reaching Guangzhou, the provincial governor Deng Yue detained him, but Hong refused to stay and departed. He eventually settled on Mount Luofu to refine elixirs, residing there for many years, living in leisurely seclusion and writing without cease.

In his preface, he wrote: “Hong lacks the talent for advancement, yet by chance favors the pursuit of non-action. If I were to spread my wings, I could soar through the ethereal skies; if I were to spur my feet, I could chase the wind and tread upon shadows. Yet I still wish to restrain my strong pinions among the flock of sparrows and conceal my swiftness among the ranks of lame donkeys. How much more so when the great cosmos has endowed me with but ordinary, short wings, and creation has lent me the most sluggish and halting of steps? Having carefully assessed my limitations, how dare I strive like a fly aspiring to soar to the heavens or urge on a lame turtle to pursue the path of a flying hare? Thus, I have turned away from the path of glory and honor, contenting my aspirations in the realm of poverty and ruin. The petals of the lotus possess the sweetness of the eight delicacies, while the thatched hut offers the joy of floating duckweed.”

The Confucians of the world know only to revere the teachings of Zhou and Confucius, disbelieving in the books of divine transcendents. Not only do they ridicule them, but they also slander and defame the true and correct. Therefore, I have written on the matters of alchemical gold and silver in what I call the *Inner Chapters*. The remaining refutations and explanations are titled the *Outer Chapters*. Together, the inner and outer chapters number one hundred and sixteen. Though they may not be worthy of concealment in the famous mountains, I intend to seal them in a golden casket to show to those who understand. I style myself the *Master Embracing Simplicity*, and thus name the book accordingly.

Hong was erudite and deeply versed in learning, unmatched in the lands south of the Yangtze. His writings were more abundant than those of Ban [Gu] and Sima [Qian]. He was also skilled in discerning the traces of the mysterious and analyzing principles with profound subtlety. Later, he suddenly sent a letter to Yue, saying, “I shall travel to seek a teacher and will depart on the appointed day.” When Yue received the letter, he hurried to bid farewell, but by the time he arrived, Hong had sat motionless until midday, appearing as if asleep, and had passed away. Yue thus did not get to see him again. Hong was eighty-one years old. His complexion appeared as if alive, and his body remained supple. When his body was lifted into the coffin, it was as light as an empty garment, and the world believed he had attained immortality through *shijie* (release from the corpse).

The historian remarks: From the time Zhichuan first tied his hair to study, he remained tireless in old age. He gathered rare texts from the archives, compiling the lost writings of a hundred generations; he recorded the transformations of the immortal realms, exhausting the secret arts of the nine elixirs. He rejected fleeting honors and abandoned miscellaneous arts, disdaining worldly treasures and cherishing every moment. Roaming in virtue and dwelling in truth, he transcended the mundane world. Among the ways of preserving life, his was the most excellent.

Tang Geng of Meishan in the Zixi year of the Xianchun era of Emperor Duzong of the Song wrote a eulogy: “The lands south of the Yangtze had grown coarse, devoid of moral splendor. Soaring yet not alighting, he flew gracefully south. Deng Yue was but a petty child, a remnant of the faction of [Sima] Zhong. What understanding could he possess? Yet even he looked up in admiration. I refine the inner elixir and thus dwell on Mount Luofu. Was it because of Yue that I debated staying or leaving? What I sought was great; why should I care for the small? My association with Yue was like befriending gulls.”

Daoyi remarks: The *Daodejing* states, “Favor and disgrace are like startling alarms; regard great trouble as you would your own body.” Ge Hong, with his outstanding talent and learning, abandoned the esteemed path of official rank—how could this be without reason? After the Jin court moved east, treacherous ministers wrought disaster, and the royal way declined. Extraordinary scholars and remarkable individuals rarely appeared. The lands south of the Yangtze were in turmoil—when would they find stability? Ge Hong’s vision may be called rising above the common herd. Thus, he was untroubled by the world’s neglect and delighted in the Dao, preserving his true nature. He left favor behind, and disgrace did not touch him; he forgot himself, and trouble did not reach him. In the end, he remained steadfast in his studies, and the immortal Dao was accomplished. Later Daoists should take him as their model.

Huang Yeren—Huang Yeren was a disciple of the Divine Lord Ge, or some say he was Ge’s servant. When Zhichuan retired to the mountains to refine elixirs, Yeren followed him. After Ge attained immortality and departed, he left an elixir between the pillar and the stone. Yeren, returning from outside, found a single pill and consumed it, becoming an earth-traveling immortal. His physical body remains in the world to this day, and those who are fortunate may encounter him.

Later, someone traveling on Mount Luofu stayed overnight in a rocky valley. In the middle of the night, they saw a man whose body was unclothed but covered in green fur, and they surmised he must be an immortal. They bowed and inquired of the Dao, but the man paid no heed, merely laughing loudly several times, his voice shaking the forest trees. He sang a poem:
*“Clouds come, and ten thousand peaks stir;*
*Clouds depart, and the sky is one hue.*
*Laughing long two or three times,*
*The empty mountains beneath the autumn moon turn white.”*
This was clearly Yeren.

During the Xianchun era of Emperor Duzong of the Song, a traveler wearing a black square hat and a Han-style robe wandered about Mount Luofu. Upon seeing people, he would laugh loudly and run away. For three years, he did not reveal his name. One day, returning drunk, he suddenly took coal and wrote on the wall:
*“The clouds’ intent is unknown,*
*As the blue sea’s spring light.”*

Seeking to ascend the verdant heights, one stumbles at a single misstep.
Though a thousand kalpas pass in longing, the plum blossoms have not returned.
Having written this, he crossed the sea and departed—was he not one of the wild immortals’ company?

**Perfected Yang Xi**
The Perfected Yang, styled Junxi, was born in the ninth month of the gengyin year of the fifth Xianhe era of Emperor Cheng of Jin. A native of Wu, he came to reside in Jurong and studied the Dao on Mount Mao. Of fair complexion and handsome bearing, he was eloquent and fond of laughter. Diligent in calligraphy and devoted to learning, he was well-versed in the classics and histories. Profound and solemn by nature, he possessed from childhood the discernment of spiritual communion. Early on, he formed a divine bond with the two Xus: Xu Mai, the Far-Wanderer, and Xu Mu, the Prefect. The Prefect recommended him to the Prince-Regent, who appointed him Attendant of the Ducal Residence. In the early Yonghe era of Emperor Mu, he received the *Zhonghuang Method for Taming Tigers and Leopards*. In the sixth year, he studied the *Five Lingbao Talismans* under Liu Pu, the eldest son of Lady Wei. The Master was deep and serene in his responses, embracing emptiness with self-possession, like the natural affinity of dryness and moisture for fire and water. In profound stillness, he revered the unseen, and the transmission flowed without trace.

At thirty-six, in the third year of the Xingning era of Emperor Ai (yichou), a host of Perfected descended to bestow upon him the essentials of the Dao. Among them were the Supreme Minister Green Lad, the Perfected of Great Emptiness, the Crimson Lord High Steward, the Lord of Western Citadel, the Perfected Mao of Taiyuan, the Perfected Pei of Pure Numinosity, the Perfected King of Tongbai, the Perfected Zhou of Purple Yang, the Middle Mao Lord, the Lesser Mao Lord, the Marquis Fan, the Marquis Xun, the Lady of Purple Radiance, the Lady of Southern Marchmount, the Lady of Right Florescence, the Lady of Purple Tenuity, the Ninth Hua Consort An, the Lady of Illustrious Numinosity, and the Lady of the Marquisate—none failed to trail rainbow banners in the hidden dusk, refine their spirit steeds in secret, or gather like drifting clouds in the ethereal void, their traces vanishing from mortal paths. Their golden voices resounded like chimes in the Master’s presence. Not a day passed without their visitation, nor a year without fulfillment.

Yang studied under Lady Wei, befriending the Nine Hua and the assembly of Perfected. Thus the Ninth Hua Consort An declared: “The Radiant Master’s spirit is empty and at ease, his secret structure jade-bright. A lofty current from the orchid spring, his pure resonance fills the golden palace. He is destined to serve as a high minister among the Four Assistants, receiving the mandate of the Sage Lord, governing life and severing death, rewarding and punishing spirits, commanding the thousand numina, sealing mountains and summoning clouds. He shall oversee the harmonious qi of yin and yang and become the Lord of Spirits and Gods over Wu and Yue.” Twenty-two years later, he would ride the dragon and mount the clouds in broad daylight to ascend to heaven. If he could not endure the smoke of wind and fire, he might seek release by the sword as a final defense.

The Perfected of Mystic Purity further instructed Xi: “To study the Dao is like shooting an arrow: one must aim straight and unwavering to strike the target. Enter the mountains with resolve, advance without doubt, and you shall attain the utmost truth.” Xi reverently received the teaching, practiced diligently, and achieved immortality. Later, Emperor Jianwen of Jin’s empress became his disciple and attained the Dao. Xi eventually departed through the sword-release and vanished in concealment. The *True Reports* record that he passed away in the twelfth year of the Taiyuan era of Emperor Xiaowu (bingxu).

His disciple Xu Liu—whose father, Xu Mu, had also encountered the Perfected through Yang—continued the lineage. Thus the nine members of the Xu clan, though blessed with prior karmic connections, saw their spiritual awakening unfold like dust settling on a mirror, their brilliance polished by Yang’s guidance. In the thirteenth year of the Taiyuan era, Yang rode the clouds and drove the dragon westward to pay homage at the Great Simplicity, northward to the Jade Purity. He assisted the Eastern Florescence and oversaw the affairs of spirits and gods in Wu and Yue. The *Records of the Cinnabar Terrace* state that he became the Eastern Florescence’s chief assistant.

**Xu Liu, the Perfected of Leiping Mountain**
The Perfected Xu Liu, styled Daoxiang and nicknamed Jade Axe, was the son of Xu Mu, the Jin Prefect and Defender-in-Chief, who held the true rank of Left Minister of Supreme Clarity. His mother, née Tao and named Tadpole, had earlier entered the grotto-heavens before Xu Mu and was appointed Lady of the Transmuted Office. From childhood, the Perfected stood out with exceptional purity, his inner truth profound and inscrutable. Xu Mu recognized his extraordinary qualities. Though recommended for the posts of Provincial Accounts Officer and Registrar, he declined all appointments. Radiant and refined, he shed worldly concerns like a spring clearing its turbidity, advancing naturally as his vessel filled.

Residing at the foot of Leiping Mountain, he studied under Master Yang and transmitted the *Orthodox Script of the Three Heavens* and the *Phoenix Texts of Plain Silk*. Later, the Perfected of the Definitive Register bestowed upon him the Supreme Dao, admonishing him: “Studying the Dao is like digging a well: the deeper you go, the harder it is to remove the earth. Without unwavering resolve and upright conduct, how can you reach the spring’s source?” The Perfected longed to wander the grotto-chambers early and did not wish to linger in the mortal realm. He journeyed north to announce his departure and dwelled in the Fangyuan Hall of the Fang’ou Grotto on Square Mountain. He often traveled to the Four-Square Terrace, hence the *True Reports* state: “Though the secluded one lived in the world, his heart always delighted in dwelling there.” A letter from Master Yang to Xu Mu also mentions: “I wonder if the Perfected of the Directions has established his seat in the Transmuted Gate. Sixteen years later, he shall ascend to the Eastern Florescence, receive the scriptures, and be appointed Perfected Lord of Supreme Clarity and Prime Minister.”

The *Genealogy of the Celestial Dawn* records his age as thirty but does not note the year of his departure. According to the two registers, in the second year of the Taihe era of Emperor Fei of Jin (dingmao), he was twenty-seven. Thus he was born in the seventh year of the Xiankang era of Emperor Cheng (xinchou). The *Annotations to the True Reports* state he was born in the sixth year of the Xianhe era, and the records of his appointment by the Minister of Education are incorrect. After the third year of the Taihe era, no further traces of him appeared. According to the genealogy, he was thirty at his departure, which would place his passing in the gengwu year. The *Traditions of the Elders* recount: “On the northern stone altar of the northern grotto, he burned incense and prostrated himself, then lay down and did not rise. The next morning, his form appeared as if alive. The altar remains to this day.”

It is further said that he received the method of ritual disrobing from Zhang Zhennan, which he performed at night upon the altar, then departed. He married the daughter of Huang Yan, Prefect of Jiankang, and fathered a son, Huang Min, before returning home.

Xu Huangmin, Magistrate of Linju and Perfected Immortal of the Xu clan—styled Xuanwen, son of Li of the Upper Clarity Immortal Lords and grandson of Mu, Left Minister of Upper Clarity—was born in the fifth year of the Shengping era of Emperor Mu of Jin (xinyou). At the age of twenty-one, he married the daughter of Ge Wan’an, Prefect of Xiyang (Wan’an being the second grandson of the *Baopuzi*), and served successively as Registrar of the Commandery, Filial and Incorrupt Candidate, Aide to the Minister of Agriculture, Adjunct to the Protector of the Southern Man, and Magistrate of Linju. In the third year of the Yongxing era of Emperor Hui, when the capital was in turmoil, he carried the scriptures to Kuaiji, where he was revered by Ma Lang. Lang’s younger cousin, Han, also provided him with generous support. At the time, all knew that Master Xu had attained the Dao, and as both his father and grandfather were renowned, they accorded him even greater veneration.

In the sixth year of the Yuanjia era of Emperor Wen of Liu Song, wishing to relocate to Qiantang, he sealed a cabinet of his true scriptures in Lang’s quiet quarters, instructing, “This is the abode of immortals and spirits—even if there are books, do not share them with others.” Later, when he stayed briefly at the home of Du Daoju, he passed away at the age of sixty-nine. The *True Reports* state that Huang Min, his great-uncle Mai, his grandaunt Ehuang, his elder cousin Lian, Huang Min’s son Rong, and his grandniece Qionghui all achieved transcendence.

Ma Lang revered the scriptures as he would his lord and father. Whenever numinous radiance and sacred qi manifested in his halls, Lang’s wife repeatedly saw jade maidens in azure robes moving through the air. His household thus enjoyed prosperity and longevity. Later, Lang, enraged that He Dao of Shanyin had stolen the books and divulged their contents, cast molten bronze to seal the cabinet’s lock, forbidding his family from ever opening it again. After Lang’s death, his son Hong, who had received the teachings from Ji Zhen, continued to uphold the tradition.

In the first year of the Jinghe era of the Deposed Emperor, the lay scholar Lou Huiming persuaded Ji Zhen to petition for the cabinet’s forced opening. Ji Zhen, well-versed in the Daoist arts, was esteemed in his time. Upon its opening, the scriptures were presented at the Hualin Gardens.

Upon beholding the true scriptures at last, their vermilion and yellow hues blazed with such radiance that none dared to peruse them fully. When Emperor Ming ascended the throne, Ji Zhen petitioned to reclaim the texts for his private collection. Later, Lu Jianji journeyed south to establish the Chongxu Cloister, and the scriptures were thus returned to the imperial repository.

How wondrous was the divine workings—first concealed within Ma’s lineage, then revealed through Ji, and finally entrusted to Master Lu. Though Ma and Ji revered the tradition of wrapping texts in silk and storing them in cabinets, they never penetrated its profound mysteries.

Lu Xiujing, the Master of Mount Lu, was a scion of the illustrious Lu clan of Wuxing, styled Xiujing. From the moment primordial qi descended and gave him life, he stood apart from the common world. His countenance was ever serene, his virtue ever radiant. Clarity illumined his writings, and emptiness bridged the unseen. In his youth, he devoted himself to Confucian scholarship, mastering the classics, apocrypha, and weft texts without exception. Yet he believed that those who aided the primordial transformation, uniting the essence of qi with the True Sovereign, were recorded in golden registers and jade scripts. Thus, he gathered the sacred texts scattered across the world, delving into hidden realms and obscure paths.

From Xiongxiang and Jiuyi to Luofu, westward to Wu Gorge and Mount Emei, his journey was like clouds mirrored in pine winds, resplendent upon mountains and reflected in waters. After his labors bore fruit and he knocked upon the gates of mystery, spirits bestowed upon him divine secrets. In that moment of serendipity, he attained communion with the questions of immortals and perfected beings.

At the end of the Yuanjia era of the Song, while selling medicine in the capital, Emperor Wen, who had long admired his Daoist bearing, dispatched a jeweled carriage drawn by rosy clouds, with the Left Chief Minister Xu Zhan conveying the imperial decree to detain him. The Master firmly declined, turning away without a glance, and departed with a sweep of his robes. Later, when the Emperor faced the disaster of the Taichu era, all marveled at the Master’s foresight.

At the time, the Master was sailing south along the Yangtze, particularly enamored with the sublime scenery of Mount Kuang. In the fifth year of the Daming era of Emperor Xiaowu, he built a hermitage at the foot of White Cloud Peak. In the third year of the Taishi era, Emperor Ming again issued an edict, dispatching Governor Wang Jingwen to earnestly persuade him. Reluctantly, the Master acquiesced. On the day of his departure, bears, tigers, apes, and crows filled the road with mournful cries, ceasing only when he left the mountain.

Upon his arrival at the capital, the Emperor established the Chongxu Cloister and Tongxian Terrace to receive him. There, the Master expounded the Dao with the wind at his back, his teachings profoundly nourishing the Emperor’s heart. Scholars of the court and commoners who recognized the truth flocked to him like water rushing into a ravine or wind responding to a tiger—who could resist? The Master dispelled the mists and unveiled the sun, sifted the sand to reveal gold, and pointed the way to overturn falsehoods. Those of middling capacity and above all fulfilled their destined measure, as did figures like Minister Yuan Ji.

After establishing the Chongxu Cloister, the treasured scriptures and esoteric teachings of Ji’s lineage were all entrusted to it. From then on, the degenerate customs of the age were transformed in an instant, and the Master became the revered teacher of both court and commonwealth.

The following year, when the Emperor fell ill, he summoned the Master to perform the Xu Tan ritual. That night, auspicious clouds swirled around the altar, and by dawn, the Emperor’s illness had abated. When Prince Guiyang waged war, leaving bleached bones strewn across the fields, the Master provided coffins and burial shrouds to inter them. His hidden virtues and subtle acts of kindness were too numerous to recount.

The Master repeatedly sought to return to his mountain, but the Emperor would not permit it. In the fifth year of the Yuanyong era of Emperor Cangwu, on the first day of spring, he suddenly addressed his disciples: “Bound by imperial favor, I have long deferred my deepest aspirations. Now I shall return to my old mountain—prepare the carriage.” His disciples drew near. On the second day of the third month, he lay down and peacefully departed, his body glowing with radiance, an extraordinary fragrance suffusing the air.

Three days later, disciples on Mount Lu witnessed the Master, his cloud banner shimmering, returning to his former retreat. In an instant, he vanished, leaving them astonished and awestruck. He had left instructions to be wrapped in a cloth sack and cast into a mountain ravine, but his disciples could not bear it. Thus, they returned his remains to Mount Lu. He was seventy-two years old—one who refined his form in the hidden earth and ascended in splendor to the Great Subtlety.

An edict posthumously bestowed upon him the title Master of Simplicity and Seclusion, and his former residence was designated the Jianji Abbey, honoring his Daoist legacy. Previously, the authenticity of texts in the Dongzhen canon had been muddled, but the Master edited and corrected them, drawing a clear line between the pure and the turbid. Thus, his liturgical and ritual standards became the model for future generations. He authored over a hundred works—records, treatises, and discourses—all of which circulated in the world. Among his disciples who attained the Dao, Sun Youyue and Li Guozhi were the most renowned.

Later, in a letter to Guozhi, Kong Dezhang wrote of the Master: “The Master’s Dao crowned the central capital, and his transformative influence flowed to the eastern lands. Emperors received his guidance, and the people revered his teachings. Now that his subtle words have ceased, the great Dharma is fading. As a preceptor endowed with divine stability and occupying the highest rank, your learning and enlightenment are the refuge of disciples. It is fitting that you restore his legacy, uphold the essentials, illuminate the Master’s remaining influence, and compile the transmission of his profound teachings. In doing so, you may guide the degenerate customs of later ages and enlighten those who follow.”

When the Master first answered the imperial summons, he had carried a cloth sack. After his passing and return to the mountain, a cloth sack was found hanging from a tree on the cliff. Today, the western ravine of his residence is named the Cloth Sack Peak. There stands a stone for offerings, six or seven feet tall, over a zhang in width and breadth, oriented toward the northwest—also called the Dipper-Worshipping Stone. Outside the stone gate lies the Alchemical Well, and a twin-trunked tree with intertwined roots. There is also a stone chime, its sound clear and resonant, and medicinal herbs and bitter bamboo that once grew in the mountain valleys—all remnants of his presence.

In the first year of the Taiji era of Empress Wu Zetian of the Tang, a grand offering was held at the abbey, where black dragons and flocks of cranes appeared as omens. An imperial decree praised and honored him, and the records were entrusted to the official archives.

On the first day of the seventh month of the first year of the Xuanhe era of Emperor Huizong of the Song, he was posthumously enfeoffed as the Perfected One of Cinnabar Primordial. The edict read: “We consider the lofty recluses of antiquity—those whose names endure but whose titles remain unbestowed—and deliberate how to posthumously honor them. The Master of Simplicity and Seclusion, Lu Xiujing, attained perfection within, corrected the lost scriptures, and established standards for his age, transcending the world in an instant. His former retreat on Mount Lu has long had a shrine, and now, after verifying the facts, We bestow upon him the title of Perfected One. This is not merely to honor his past footsteps but also to inspire those who hear of him to recognize where the Dao resides and to strive accordingly.”

Let him be specially enfeoffed as the Perfected One of Cinnabar Primordial.

Lu Xiujing passed away during the Yuanhui era of the Song, yet *The Comprehensive Mirror of Buddhist History* records: “In the first year of Shaotai of Emperor Jing of Liang, the Daoist Lu Xiujing and others, having been cast aside by Emperor Wu of Liang, fled to Wei. By then, their followers had grown numerous. When Emperor of Qi embraced Buddhism, Xiujing and his disciples, resenting this, petitioned the court to debate the Dharma with the Buddhist monks.” However, when one examines the chronology, the Yuanhui era lies more than sixty years after Shaotai—how could such an account not be erroneous?

Master Sun Youyue, whose surname was Sun and given name Youyue, styled Yingda, was a descendant of the House of Wu of Dongyang. From childhood, he was reverent; in maturity, he was harmonious. His stillness was like an abyss; his qi was like spring. He sifted the common and refined the divine, plumbing the subtle and obscure. Once, he wandered to the Crimson Pine Gorge and the Cloud-Wrapped Hall of Mount Jinyun, where he divined a site for his final repose.

During the Taichu era of Emperor Wen of Song, when Master of Simplicity and Seclusion [Lu Xiujing] arrived at Mount Lu, Youyue presented himself as a disciple and received the scriptures and methods of the Three Caverns, along with the ink traces of the Two Perfected Ones, Yang and Xu. Thereafter, he subsisted on fungi and abstained from grains, later devoting himself solely to the Elixir of Grain Transcendence. At sixty-seven, his complexion remained radiant, and with time, he grew ever younger.

After Master of Simplicity and Seclusion ascended as a feathered transcendent, Youyue returned to his former retreat to delve into the true essence of the Dao. In the second year of Yongming of Emperor Wu of Qi, he was summoned to preside over the Xingshi Abbey. Thereupon, extraordinary and reclusive scholars vied to gather around him, including Kong Dezhang and Liu Xiaobiao, who formed bonds beyond the mundane world. Though he often petitioned to return home on grounds of illness, the imperial decree never permitted it. In the fifth month of the seventh year, he suddenly bathed, sat in repose, and passed away. His disciples numbered in the hundreds, but only Tao Hongjing was deemed an inner-chamber successor. To him, Youyue entrusted the Three Caverns scriptures and the ink traces of Yang and Xu, emptying his baskets in full.

Later, Hongjing compiled *Declarations of the Perfected*, which circulated in the world.

Tao Hongjing, the Recluse Master, whose surname was Tao and given name Hongjing, styled Tongming, was a native of Danyang. His residence lay east of the southern ridge of White Poplar Lane. When the Song dynasty first implemented the *tuduan* land registration, his household was assigned to Tongxia Ward in the western precinct of Moling County, where his descendants have resided ever since.

The Tao clan originally hailed from Pingyang in Jizhou, descendants of the sage-king Yao of the House of Tao Tang. As Yao governed Pingyang in Jizhou, his lineage settled there. When the Han arose, Tao She served as Marshal to Emperor Gaozu, and his son Qing rose to the rank of Chancellor. Their thirteenth-generation ancestor, Tao Chao, crossed the Yangtze at the end of the Han and first settled in Danyang.

Their seventh-generation ancestor, Tao Jun, was the younger brother of Tao Huang, Inspector of Jiaozhou. He served the state of Wu as General Who Pacifies the South, was enfeoffed as Marquis of Jurong with a fief of two thousand households, and, along with Sun Hao, surrendered to Jin. He was appointed Gentleman Consultant, Cavalier Attendant-in-Ordinary, and Master of Writing.

Their sixth-generation ancestor, Tao Mo, was the third son of Jun. During the Yongjia era of Emperor Huai, he served as Marshal to the Prince of Donghai, Sima Yue, commanding garrison troops and following the prince to Xuchang. After their defeat, he returned south of the Yangtze and became a military advisor to the Grand General Wang Dun. When Dun was appointed Chancellor, Mo was transferred to Military Consultant and Libationer. Later, he accompanied Dun on his southern campaign but, fearing the disaster to come, petitioned to sever his clan registry and was confined for many years. In his later years, he was appointed Military Advisor to the General of Chariots and Cavalry but declined the post. He died in the fourth year of the Shengping era of Emperor Mu and was buried separately on the northern slope of Mount Baishi, overlooking the lake.

Their great-grandfather, Tao Pi, was discerning in judgment and possessed a lofty and extraordinary bearing. Though demoted for his literary pursuits, he refused to seek office, declining all summons from the prefecture and commandery. Later, he was selected as an aide to the Governor of Nan’an but never assumed the post. He died in the third year of the Yuanxing era of Emperor An.

Their grandfather, Tao Long, stood seven *chi* and five *cun* tall, with a handsome appearance, great strength, and skill in riding and archery. He loved learning, was adept at calligraphy, and also understood the properties of medicines, often dedicating himself to healing and rescue. He served as a military advisor to the General of the South.

Accompanying Emperor Xiaowu of Song on his campaign against the rebels, he rendered meritorious service and was enfeoffed as Marquis of Jin’an, appointed as a principal aide, but firmly declined. Yan Jun, relying on imperial favor, sought to exchange his residence for a Buddhist temple, but he refused. Consequently, he resigned from office, was secretly stripped of his title, and exiled to Guangzhou. Later, by imperial grace, he was appointed Magistrate of Xiping County in Nanhai and subsequently served as Supervisor of Xinhui Commandery, where he died in the fifth year of the Daming era of Emperor Xiaowu of Song.

His father, named Zhenbao, styled Guozhong, was summoned by Liu Tiren, Prince Jian’an and Minister of Education, to serve as Gentleman Attendant, then promoted to Gentleman Attendant of the Southern Bureau, and appointed Chancellor of Xiaochang in Jiangxia. He was also skilled in riding and archery, and excelled in clerical and official script. Though his family was poor, he made a living by copying sutras, earning forty coins per sheet. His calligraphy followed the styles of Yang Xin and Xiao Sihua. Deeply versed in medical arts and widely read in the classics and histories, he was fond of literature and possessed a dignified bearing. In his social circles, he associated with Xiao Sihua, Wang Zhao, and Liu Bing, and was highly esteemed by the nobility. In the winter of the fourth year of the Yuanyuan era of Emperor Cangwu, he was dispatched as an envoy to the northern court to foster amicable relations with neighboring states, earning widespread acclaim. In the first year of the Shengming era of Emperor Shundi, he returned to the capital and compiled an account of his travels, along with several thousand characters of poetry and other writings. Liu Bing requested to read them, but they were lost during the Stone Fortress affair, with no other copies surviving, and thus did not circulate in later generations.

Previously, Zhenbao had relocated his family to Yingzhou with Xiao, and in the second year of the Xiaojian era of Emperor Wu of Song, Xiao perished. That September, his mother realized she was with child and dreamed of a small azure dragon emerging from her body, ascending straight toward the east. Upon waking, she looked but could not see its tail. (*The History of the Southern Dynasties* states: His mother, née Hao, dreamed of two celestial beings holding incense burners approaching her, after which she conceived. Tang scholar Li Bo’s account records: His mother, early in her pregnancy, dreamed of the essence of the sun within her womb, and two celestial beings descending with golden censers. Upon waking, she confided to her attendants: "I shall bear a son, no ordinary man, though I fear he may have no posterity." At the time, she was twenty-five.) That winter, she returned to the capital with Xiao’s troops, residing in the eastern quarters near the archery hall among the left encampments.

On the thirtieth day of the fourth month of the *bingshen* year of the Xiaojian era—with that year having an intercalary third month, and the following dawn marking the Summer Solstice—the Master was born at midnight. At birth, his countenance was luminous and refined, his eyes bright and brows well-spaced, his frame slender, his forehead broad, and his ears prominent. On his right knee were several dozen dark moles arranged in the pattern of the Seven Stars. From childhood, he was perceptive and quick-witted, and as he matured, his learning became vast and profound. At four or five, he took to books, and even now, examples of his writing from the age of six survive, already composed with proper structure. By nine, he began reciting the Six Classics and delved into composition. At ten, upon obtaining *The Biographies of Divine Immortals* by Ge Hong, he studied it day and night, nurturing aspirations for cultivating longevity. He remarked to others: "Gazing at the azure clouds and beholding the white sun, I feel no distance is beyond reach." He read over ten thousand volumes, and any subject he did not know he deemed a deep shame. Skilled in the qin and chess, he also mastered cursive and clerical scripts.

At eleven, he became a tutor to Liu Hao, son of Wang Zhao, Left Chief of the Minister of Education. At thirteen, his father relocated the household, following Liu Bing, Minister of Personnel, to Huainan Commandery. At fifteen, he returned to the capital, lodging temporarily in the outer barracks behind the armory, then established a separate residence, never again returning to his former home. At seventeen, he underwent the capping ceremony. He often accompanied Liu Bing, who governed Danyang Commandery, receiving provisions from the household guard and riding a subordinate’s horse when traveling. Liu Bing’s second son, Si, was renowned from a young age and served as Sacrificial Wine Officer of the Minister of Education. Si had a refined appreciation for literature and spent days and nights searching for texts with the Master, often sharing meals and traveling together in the same carriage. Si, along with Jiang Shu, Chu Xuan, and Liu Si, were known as the Four Companions of Emperor Shundi, and Si was particularly celebrated for his talent and learning. He composed *Eulogies on the Virtues of Song*, a series of seven *lianju* poems, which were hailed as unparalleled in his time. After Si’s death, his writings scattered, and though the Master wished to compile them, he was ultimately unable to do so.

In the winter of the first year of the Shengming era, at the age of twenty-two, the Master followed Liu Bing into Stone Fortress to join Yuan Ji’s cause. The Master, along with Han Bin and Mi Tan, was responsible for drafting official documents. When the affair failed and the fortress fell, he managed to escape. Si and his younger brother Gai fled disguised as Buddhist monks but were captured and died in the prison of Jiankang. None dared approach their bodies, but the Master personally gathered and buried them, interring them in an old family grave. After arranging everything, he renounced the world and retreated into the mountains. Amid the transition from Song to Qi, the realm remained unsettled. Having been allied with the Liu clan, he harbored deep apprehensions. His father, through Ji Sengzhen, sought service under Emperor Gao of Qi at Xinting and was accepted as a retainer. In the second month, after Shen Youzhi’s rebellion was quelled, he returned to the eastern quarters with the emperor. The emperor then dispatched envoys to instruct his younger brothers, the fifth son Hua and the sixth son Gui, in their studies, while also assisting the emperor with official correspondence.

The Master, then twenty-three, was appointed Gentleman Attendant to the Prince of Baling. He remarked: "In times of dynastic change, even modest contributions merit a rank or two. Why should there be no place for me?" Thus, he declined the appointment. The following year, he accompanied the Prince of Ancheng to garrison Stone Fortress. The next summer, he observed the mourning rites for his father, Chancellor of Xiaochang. (*The History of the Southern Dynasties* states: Before reaching adulthood, Emperor Gao of Qi, then serving as regent, summoned him as a tutor to the imperial princes and appointed him Gentleman for Court Audiences. Though within the imperial gates, he kept to himself, avoiding external affairs and devoting himself solely to reading. His opinions on court precedents were often adopted as standards.)

Upon Emperor Wu’s ascension, he was appointed General of Vibrant Might and assigned as tutor to the Prince of Yidu. During the Qi dynasty, the role of imperial tutor entailed overseeing all matters of the secretariat, requiring individuals of exceptional talent. The Master excelled in all ceremonial and administrative documents, from auspicious and inauspicious rites to internal and external protocols, as well as memorials, memorialized reports, and official correspondence, surpassing all others.

Several princes’ document clerks took his writings as models for drafting, and many imperial tutors grew envious and resentful. The Master paid no heed, remaining untroubled. At twenty-eight, upon completing his mourning period, he was appointed General of the Left Guard and Palace Attendant, much to the satisfaction of contemporary expectations. The Master, however, was taken aback, unable to fathom the reason. He confided in Yu Daomin, discussing those who had been overlooked. Yu then petitioned Emperor Wu in person, to which the emperor replied, “This office was personally bestowed by the late emperor—did you not know? How can it be declined?” Yu relayed this to the Master, who sighed deeply and said, “Five years ago, I declined the position of Gentleman Attendant to the Prince of Yuzhang, yet now I am given this post. A post horse is no steed of swift flight.” He wished to firmly decline, but Yu pressed him, saying, “Since the founding of the dynasty, this office has always been held by men of renown, such as Pei Songzhi, who advanced from it to Gentleman Attendant. If the man fits the office, what wrong is done to you? I fear you may hinder my affairs.” At the time, he was entrusted with overseeing all matters of the princes’ households, and thus, with no alternative, he accepted the appointment.

At twenty-nine, when the new Clear Stream Palace was completed, the emperor celebrated with feasting. The Master submitted a memorial and presented an ode, while Fu Manrong also offered a rhapsody. Thereupon, the emperor instructed the Palace Secretary Liu Xi to issue an edict, praising both works and urging the preservation of the old palace’s bronze and stone inscriptions. The emperor intended to have the Master’s ode engraved on a stele, but Wang Jian opposed the idea, and it was abandoned. Among the five who presented rhapsodies, the Master’s was deemed the finest. Promotion was imminent when he was bereaved by his mother’s death and left office. Soon after, he was reappointed General of Vibrant Might. Upon his return to service, he was specially granted wine and food, and his salary was adjusted to accompany the Prince of Yidu to the capital. When the emperor planned to visit the Wujin Palace, the Master composed another ode. Though the ode was completed, the imperial procession was canceled, and it was never presented. It was said, “This ode’s style is surpassingly fresh, far exceeding the old forms.”

After three years, he returned to the capital and was appointed Gentleman for Court Audiences. Displeased with the appointment, he wrote to his cousin, “In official service, one should decide based on one’s health. I had hoped to become a Gentleman Attendant around forty, then serve as magistrate of a reputable eastern Zhe county, where I might enjoy the mountains and waters before retiring to lofty reclusion. These long-held aspirations now seem as clear as the palm of my hand. Yet at thirty-six, I am only appointed Gentleman for Court Audiences—what does this portend for my future? Better to leave early than to endure such humiliation.” The following May, he submitted a memorial to resign, seeking refuge in the mountains and forests. Thus began his aspirations for the azure clouds.

That year was the eleventh of Emperor Wu’s Yongming reign, the *ren-shen* year. When the Master first withdrew, he did not wish to formally resign from the court. Instead, he removed his official robes and hung them at the Divine Tiger Gate. Donning a deer-fur cap, he departed directly from the Eastern Pavilion, instructing his attendants, “Let no one know of this.” He then bid farewell to Wang Yan, who cautioned, “His Majesty is most severe in governance and does not permit eccentric conduct. If you act contrary to his wishes, you may incur blame. How then can your aspirations be fulfilled?” The Master pondered in silence for a long while before replying, “I follow my own resolve, not for fame. If such concerns arise, what is there to be done?” Thereupon, he did not return to the court but submitted a memorial expressing his sincerity. (*The History of the Southern Dynasties* states: In the tenth year of Yongming, he removed his official robes at the Divine Martial Gate and submitted a memorial to resign his salary.) An edict granted him ten bolts of silk, twenty torches of wax, and a monthly allotment of five *jin* of *fuling* and two *sheng* of white honey for his medicinal regimen.

Having fulfilled his wish, he ordered a small boat prepared and descended the river. The court officials and nobles saw him off at the Zhenlu Pavilion with lavish provisions, carriages, and horses crowding the roads. All remarked, “Nothing like this has been seen east of the Yangtze in recent times—until today.” He then settled on Mount Gouqu in Jurong. The Master said, “This mountain is the Grotto Palace of Jintan, encircling a hundred and fifty *li*, known as the Heaven of Huayang. It houses the offices of the Three Mao Lords of Destiny, hence its name, Maoshan.” There, he established a retreat, styling himself the Recluse of Huayang, much like Shi’an of Xuanyan or Zichuan of Baopu. In all his letters and documents, he used this name in place of his own.

The Master was well-versed in antiquity, expounding the Seven Classics with comprehensive understanding of their great principles, yet he disliked establishing doctrines at odds with earlier scholars’ discussions. He preferred writing to oral debate. He was particularly fond of the Five Phases and yin-yang, divination by wind and celestial omens, the *Taiyi* and *Dunjia* systems, astrology, calendrical calculations, geography, the products of various regions, medical prescriptions, the blending of incense and herbs, and the classification of insects, birds, plants, and trees—mastering all these subjects without omission. His clerical script was unlike conventional styles, forming a distinct school with vigorous and elegant strokes. He was also skilled in the qin, chess, archery, and horsemanship.

By nature, he was adaptable and modest, his mind a mirror that comprehended all it encountered, perceiving things with clarity. His speech was free of confusion, and if errors arose, he corrected them at once. He was seldom sorrowful or envious, indifferent to joy and anger, and untroubled by grief or delight.

In the *jia-zi*, *yi-chou*, and *bing-yin* years, he studied Daoist talismans and scriptures under Sun Youyue, master of the Xingshi Lodge in the Eastern Yang. Though the transmitted texts were authentic, repeated copying had introduced discrepancies. He thus sought widely to correct them. In the *wu-chen* year, he first journeyed to Maoshan, where he obtained the authentic handwritten texts of Yang and Xu, filling him with joy and inspiration. By the *geng-wu* year, he requested leave to travel through Zhe and Yue, seeking spiritual wonders in every place. He visited the recluse Lou Huiming at Great Flood Mountain in Kuaiji, the recluse Du Jingchan at Taiping Mountain in Yuyao, and the master Zhong Yishan at Chaoshan in Shining. He also traveled to Mount Tiantai in Shifeng, meeting the monk Zhu Sengbiao and various senior Daoists, acquiring over ten volumes of the Perfected Ones’ posthumous writings.

Having traveled through mountains and rivers for over two hundred days, he then returned. From there, he journeyed to Changshan in Dongyang, Tianmu Mountain in Wuxing, and all the renowned peaks of Yuqian, Linhai, and Angu, leaving none unvisited. His body was naturally lithe and agile, making ascents effortless—*The History of the Southern Dynasties* records: "He traversed famous mountains in search of immortal herbs. Light and nimble in body, he was by nature drawn to landscapes." Whenever he passed through ravines or valleys, he would sit or lie among them, chanting verses and lingering, unable to tear himself away.

To his disciples he remarked: "I see vermilion gates and vast halls, and though I recognize their splendor and joy, I feel no desire to enter them. Gazing upon towering cliffs or vast marshes, I know such places are hard to dwell in, yet I cannot help but yearn to approach them." He took pity on those who lived in cold and solitude, aiding those in peril or distress, healing the sick and ailing, tireless from dawn to dusk. Beyond these acts, he bestowed hidden kindnesses and secret favors, known to none.

Even when borrowing others’ books, he would correct errors as he read. In the early years of Emperor Yongyuan of the Qi dynasty’s reign, he had a three-story tower constructed. He resided at the top, his disciples in the middle, and guests below, thus cutting himself off from the world. Only a single servant was permitted to attend him. Though once skilled in horsemanship and archery, he abandoned both in later years, content only to listen to the sound of the *sheng*. He had a particular fondness for the wind in the pines, planting them throughout his courtyard; whenever he heard their rustling, he would rejoice in delight. At times, wandering alone among springs and rocks, those who glimpsed him took him for an immortal.

By nature, he loved writing and cherished the strange and wondrous. He treasured every moment of light and scenery, a devotion that only deepened with age.

He was particularly versed in yin-yang and the Five Phases, divination by wind and stars, astrological calculations, the geography of mountains and rivers, the products of various regions, medical arts and pharmacology, and the chronology of imperial dynasties. Through calculation, he determined that in the second year of the Han dynasty’s Xiping reign (173 CE), the winter solstice occurred at noon on the *dingchou* day, whereas the true *xiantian* calendar placed it at midnight on the *yihai* day—thirty-eight *ke* earlier—meaning the Han calendar lagged two days and twelve *ke* behind. He also constructed a *huntian* celestial model, roughly three *chi* in height, with the earth at its center and the heavens revolving around it while the earth remained still. The twenty-eight lunar mansions, their degrees, and the paths of the seven luminaries were all clearly marked, as were the rising and setting of the central stars. When turned by mechanism at dawn or dusk, it aligned perfectly with the heavens. He remarked, "This is essential for cultivating the Dao, not merely a tool for court astronomers." He further sought to create a natural water clock, using flowing water to drive a twelve-hour wheel in perpetual motion without need for supervision. However, he worried that mountain streams would accumulate moss and sediment, causing irregularities, and so the project remained unrealized.

In his movements and bearing, he was light and agile, his countenance gentle and radiant, never stern or severe. Young and old alike took joy in his presence and were drawn to him, yet all held him in awe and reverence. His disciples gathered around him, attending with reverence as if in a palace hall. From childhood, he kept a distance from others, and after a few years, he no longer shared bowls or chopsticks when eating. As he grew older, whether traveling, lodging, or resting, he remained composed, never engaging in jest or idle talk. He eschewed all worldly frivolity. His spirit was strong and unyielding; he walked alone at night and slept in solitude without fear. He deeply admired Zhang Liang, declaring no ancient worthy could compare. Unburdened by worldly concerns, he moved with the lightness of clouds and mist. All his practices arose from his own insight, beyond the reach of ordinary understanding.

In the second year of Yongyuan (500 CE), he withdrew into seclusion as dusk approached. When Emperor Wu of Liang rose to power and deliberated on the new dynasty’s name, the Master cited various prophecies and omens, showing that "Liang" was the destined sign. He also selected an auspicious day for the suburban sacrifice, and its efficacy was manifest. The emperor urged him to enter the mountains and sent envoys with gifts in gratitude. Having long been acquainted with the Master, the emperor, after ascending the throne, treated him with even greater favor, sending letters and inquiries without cease, so that carriages and officials were constantly seen at his door. After receiving his esoteric teachings, the emperor believed the elixir of immortality could be achieved but lamented the lack of ingredients, which the emperor then provided. Whenever the emperor received his writings, he burned incense and reverently accepted them.

The emperor commissioned him to create a new calendar, marking the *jisi* year (549 CE) with a red dot—this was the third year of Taiqing. The emperor personally summoned him with a handwritten decree and bestowed upon him a deerskin cap. Despite repeated summons and honors, the Master responded by drawing two oxen: one roaming freely among water and grass, the other adorned with a golden bridle, led by a man holding a rope and driven by a staff. The emperor laughed and said, "This man seeks nothing; he wishes to be like the tortoise dragging its tail in the mud. How could he be compelled to come?" Yet on matters of state, the emperor consulted him without fail, and contemporaries called him the "Prime Minister of the Mountains."

In the fourth year of Tianjian (505 CE), he moved to Jijin Ravine. Practicing breath abstention and guiding *qi* through *daoyin* exercises, he lived in seclusion for over forty years, yet at eighty, his appearance remained robust. In the early Datong era (527 CE), he presented two blades, one named *Shansheng* ("Excellent Victory") and the other *Chengsheng* ("Perfect Victory"), both prized treasures. In the second year of Datong (536 CE), he announced the day of his passing. At eighty-five, his complexion remained unchanged, his limbs supple as ever, and the fragrance in his chamber lingered for days.

A decree was issued posthumously appointing him Gentleman Cavalier Attendant and conferring the posthumous title *Master Zhenbai* ("Pure and White"). An emissary was dispatched to oversee his funeral rites. Among his dozens of disciples, only Wang Yuanzhi was deemed his foremost successor.

Master Hongjing possessed profound mastery of numerology and divination, foreseeing the fall of the Liang dynasty. He composed a poem in advance, which read:
*"Yifu indulged in idle abandon,
Pingshu sat discoursing on emptiness.
Who would have thought the Hall of Zhaoyang
Would transform into the Khan’s palace?"*
The poem remained hidden in a basket until after his passing, when his disciples gradually revealed it.

By the late Datong era, scholars vied to expound on metaphysical principles, neglecting martial affairs. Later, when Hou Jing usurped the throne, it indeed occurred in the Hall of Zhaoyang. His writings included *Academy of Learning* in one hundred fascicles, *Collected Annotations on the Classic of Filial Piety and the Analects*, *Imperial Chronology*, *Collected Annotations on the Materia Medica*, *Proven Remedies*, *One Hundred and One Emergency Prescriptions from Behind the Elbow*, *Records of Ancient and Modern Prefectures and Commanderies*, *Essential Illustrated Compendium*, *Jade Casket Records*, *New and Old Seven Luminaries*, *Commentaries on Numerology and Astrology*, and *Formulae for Alchemical Elixirs*. The esoteric portions of these works were not transmitted, and ten additional unfinished treatises were accessible only to his disciples.

In *The Golden Tower Master*, Emperor Liang remarked: *"Among recluses, I esteem Tao Hongjing; among scholar-officials, I esteem Zhou Hongzheng."* His grasp of principle and meaning was inexhaustibly profound—truly a paragon of his age.

Ma Shu, in *Transmission of the Dao*, recorded: *"Tao Hongjing was invested as the Celestial Overseer of Penglai."* Much of the foregoing account aligns with *The History of the Southern Dynasties*.

Minister Dao Yi observed: *"The* Dao De Jing *states: ‘Govern the state with uprightness, deploy troops with cunning, and win the world through non-interference.’ It further declares: ‘Weapons are inauspicious tools, not instruments for the noble. When their use is unavoidable, restraint is paramount. To triumph and then glorify it is to delight in slaughter. Those who delight in slaughter shall never prevail under heaven.’*

*Laozi’s intent was to restore the customs of high antiquity—of Fuxi, the Yellow Emperor, Tang, and Yu—emphasizing substance over ostentation, ensuring rulers and ministers alike shunned sensual indulgence and extravagance to cultivate a transformation of tranquility. Thus, they would avoid the exhaustion of warfare and preserve the governance of non-action. Yet later generations, failing to grasp his essence, mistook idle discourse and reckless abandon for profundity. Some administrations erred toward leniency, obscuring rewards and punishments; others succumbed to indolence, neglecting diligence and reverence; still others faltered in carelessness, ignoring precision and subtlety; or relied on talent while growing arrogant and negligent. These corruptions were manifold, culminating in the catastrophic failures of the Jin dynasty’s rulers and ministers.*

*In later times, some even lectured on the* Dao De Jing *while preparing for battle. By then, Laozi’s Way had been defiled. Had those who truly understood his teachings acted thus?*

*Tao Hongjing lived through turbulent times, dwelling in reclusion among the mountains. Observing the flaws of court governance, he wrote:*
*‘Yifu indulged in idle abandon,
Pingshu sat discoursing on emptiness.
Who would have thought the Hall of Zhaoyang
Would transform into the Khan’s palace?’*

*Emperor Wu of Liang governed the realm through Buddhist teachings, and his ministers likewise competed in metaphysical discourse, leading to misguided policies and neglected defenses, gradually culminating in the dynasty’s ruin. Thus, Hongjing’s poem alluded to this. As a scholar of Laozi’s Way, those who later studied it and entered officialdom should deeply ponder its meaning."*

Here ends *Volume Twenty-Four of the Comprehensive Mirror of Perfected Immortals Who Embodied the Dao Through the Ages*.
*Volume Twenty-Five of the Comprehensive Mirror of Perfected Immortals Who Embodied the Dao Through the Ages* begins.

**Wang Yuanzhi**

The Daoist Wang Yuanzhi of Langye was the son of Tan Shou, Regional Inspector of Yangzhou under the Chen. His maternal grandfather, Ding Chao, served as Gentleman of the Palace Carriages under the Liang. His mother conceived him after dreaming of a divine phoenix. The monk Baoji declared, “The child she bears shall become a patriarch of divine transcendents.”

At seven, he could recite ten thousand words a day, mastering all books with profound comprehension of the supreme Dao. At fifteen, he entered Huayang to study under Master Tao Zhenbai, receiving the Three Caverns’ teachings. He also followed Master Zang Jin of the Zong Dao lineage, inheriting esoteric oral instructions.

The Chen sovereign summoned him to Chongyang Hall, honoring him with exceptional courtesy, bestowing gifts and provisions before sending him back to Mount Mao. There, on the northwest ridge, he built a quiet chamber to dwell in, delving into the mysteries of the arcane.

In the final years of Emperor Xuan of Chen’s reign, a divine being suddenly appeared in his chamber, drunk and vomiting. Yuanzhi lit incense and paid homage. The spirit said, “I am bound for Mount Tiantai—can you accompany me?” Yuanzhi followed him out and ascended the ridge. Midway up the mountain, he recalled that he had not entrusted his scriptures to two or three disciples. After retreating a dozen paces to look back, he saw the spirit transform into a crane and fly away.

When Prince Guang of Jin, later the Duke of Yang, governed Yangzhou, his ministers Liu and Gu successively invited Yuanzhi. Upon arrival, his hair and beard suddenly turned white in an instant. Alarmed, the prince sent him back, and shortly after, his appearance returned to normal.

After ascending the throne, the prince dispatched Cui Feng to summon him. The emperor personally received him as a disciple. In Jiangdu, a Jade Clarity Abbey was built to house him, and he was appointed to succeed Master Yue as preceptor.

During the time when the future Tang Gaozu was still in obscurity, Yuanzhi secretly revealed to him the celestial mandate. Prince Qin (later Taizong) and Fang Xuanling visited him in plain clothes. Yuanzhi greeted them, saying, “A sage is among you.” When Prince Qin pressed him to reveal the truth, he replied, “You shall become the Emperor of Great Peace—cherish yourself.” Prince Qin then received the Three Caverns’ teachings from him.

Upon ascending the throne, Gaozu sought to bestow high office upon him, but Yuanzhi firmly declined and returned to the mountains. In the ninth year of Zhenguan, Taizong established the Taiping Abbey in Runzhou on Mount Mao and ordained seven disciples. He sent an imperial edict, saying:

*“When I was still a prince, I early had the fortune to seek your teachings. Your noble bearing remains ever present in my waking and dreaming thoughts. Recently, upon reading your memorial requesting to return to your former mountain retreat, I have issued a separate decree to honor your lofty aspirations.
