The abbey I have ordered built shall serve as a testament to my enduring devotion.”*

Yuanzhi’s vital essence was vast and his mind empty; his speech and silence were as one. His illumination was like a mirror, responding to all things without partiality.

There was a man named Dou Deglun who, having previously passed through Yangzhou, encountered an emissary of the Controller of Destiny. The emissary told him he was destined for high office but would die at the age of eighty-one. Deglun pleaded for mercy, and the emissary said, “The Perfected One, Wang, the Dharma Master, is the Immortal Elder of Shaoshi. He oversees the records of humans and spirits and submits memorials to the celestial bureaus, which are always promptly answered.” Deglun then earnestly entreated Yuanzhi, who, though reluctant, interceded on his behalf. The emissary reported back, “His life shall be extended by thirteen years.” During the reign of Gaozong, Deglun served as Left Chancellor and died at the appointed time—all as foretold. Thus, the world came to call Yuanzhi the “Dharma Master.”

He later learned that he had been appointed to an immortal office. He told Pan Shizheng, “Yesterday, I saw the celestial register. Due to a childhood mistake—injuring a boy’s lip—I was denied ascension to heaven in broad daylight. Instead, I was appointed Immortal Elder of Shaoshi, with a near-term assignment.” The next day, he bathed, donned his cap and robes, burned incense, and lay down to pass away in meditation at the age of one hundred and twenty-one.

Pan Shizheng and Xu Daomiao both received his esoteric instructions and became his foremost disciples. Chen Yu and Wang Gui followed next, while others dwelled in grotto-heavens, never wavering in their practice for the rest of their lives.

In the second year of Tiaolu, Gaozong posthumously granted him the title of Grand Master for Thorough Counsel and the posthumous name Master Shengxuan. He also ordered the establishment of the Taiping Abbey and the ordination of forty-nine Daoists. At the beginning of Empress Wu’s reign, he was further posthumously honored as Grand Master of the Palace with Gold and Purple and his posthumous name was changed to Master Shengzhen.

During the Tianbao era of Emperor Ming, he urged Li Hanguang to build a portrait hall at the Taiping Abbey, where his likeness was painted to commemorate his immortal legacy.

Another account states that Yuanzhi was skilled in the *Book of Changes* and could foretell life, death, fortune, and misfortune. He authored the *Comprehensive Commentary on the Changes* in fifteen scrolls. One day, amid thunder, rain, and mist, an elder rebuked him, saying, “Where are the books you have divulged? The Celestial Emperor has commanded me to dispatch the Six Ding spirits and thunderbolts to retrieve them.” Terrified, Yuanzhi prostrated himself upon the ground. Beside him stood six attendants in black, already holding the books. The elder scolded him, “The celestial realm forbids such texts. They are guarded by flying immortals, and their golden precepts are hidden in the Mystic Capital. How dare you secretly keep such records?” Yuanzhi replied, “The Elder of Qingxi transmitted them to me.” The elder said, “The Celestial Emperor has shown mercy. Your immortal rank is now assured, and your ordination is deferred by four years—a span of two cycles.” After Yuanzhi’s passing, a traveler crossing the sea was blown off course by the wind. Suddenly, a leaf-like boat appeared from the horizon—it was Yuanzhi. He said, “Why have you endured such peril? This is the eastern edge of the vast ocean, a hundred thousand *li* away. With a swift wind, you may reach Dengzhou in a single night.” After he departed, the boat flew like a feather, the wind howling behind. By the next day, the traveler indeed arrived at Dengzhou.

**Wang Gui**

The Daoist Wang Gui, styled Hongfan, was a native of Linyi. His great-grandfather, Jun, served as Cavalier Attendant-in-Ordinary, Minister of the Palace Treasury, and Minister of Revenue under the Liang. His grandfather, Ku, was Gentleman of the Palace Washbasin and General Who Summons the Distant for Emperor Jianwen’s Crown Prince.

His father, Yu, served as Editorial Director and Regular Attendant to the Prince of Poyang under the Chen. At twenty, Gui became a disciple of his master Wang Yuanzhi, observing the rites of the towel and water vessel for sixteen years. Whenever he sat beneath his master to hear the *Dao De Jing*, *Scripture of Western Ascension*, *Lingbao* scriptures, and *Nanhua* sutras, he would later expound their meanings in detail to others. He also transcribed the revered methods of *Shangqing*, the talismans and secret treasures of *Dongxuan* and *Dongshen*, sealing them in a stone chamber to guard the mountains and peaks. He consumed the resin of the *zhun* pine and *song* pine, a practice he maintained for many years. In his teachings and transmissions, he prioritized the creation of sacred images and aiding those in urgent need.

Emperor Taizong of Tang, knowing his reputation, frequently consulted him on the essentials of the Dao. On the first day of the eleventh month in the second year of Qianfeng under Emperor Gaozong, he said to his disciples: “Last night, I dreamed of three figures in feathered robes, each holding a tablet. The first said: ‘The Celestial Official of Huayang has been appointed by the Divine Immortals as their master, and will also oversee the review and administration of celestial offices.’ Long ago, on Mount Tongbai, I had this same dream, but declined the summons. Now it has returned—my departure must be near.” He instructed his disciples on the essentials of cultivating the Dao, entrusting each with scriptures and secret teachings. On the eighth day, he bathed and dressed in ceremonial robes. The following day, he sat in a bamboo chair and transformed. When they prepared to enshroud him, only his empty garments and tied sash remained. He was eighty-eight years old. Yu Xinzhi of Henan later inscribed a stele at Huayang Cave.

**Pan Shizheng**

The Daoist Pan Shizheng, styled Zizhen, was a native of Zongcheng in Beizhou. His grandfather, Chang, served as Prefect of Chuzhou under the Zhou, and his father, Kuan, as Prefect of Tongzhou under the Sui. His mother, née Lu, was skilled in discourse on names and principles. At Shizheng’s birth, a radiant light filled the room.

The neighbor’s mother, skilled in physiognomy, declared, “This child will either become an immortal or attain high rank.” When he could speak, he was taught the Six Classics and mastered them all. One day, he asked, “Beyond these books, is there anything greater?” His mother replied, “Only the *Five Thousand Characters of the Dao and Its Virtue*.” He then recited it.

When his mother fell gravely ill, she said to Shizheng, “Death is the great appointed end for all; when the time comes, one must go. What regret could I have? Yet you are still young, and I cannot help but worry for you.” Shizheng, weeping blood, clasped her hand and said, “If heaven takes your kind face from me, I will not live on.” His mother replied, “If you destroy yourself, that would not be true filial piety from beginning to end.” After a long collapse, Shizheng revived and said, “Though I endure life against my will, I shall fast and follow the Dao, hoping to rely on the true teaching as my bridge.” His mother stroked his head and encouraged him.

After the burial, he built a hut by her grave and became renowned for his filial devotion. During the *Daye* era of Emperor Yang of Sui, the Daoist Liu Aidao saw him and esteemed him, saying, “The steed of the Three Clarities—who but you could ride it?” At the time, Wang Yuanzhi of Mount Mao was favored by Emperor Yang, who often summoned him to the palace to offer pine and spring water for blessings. Aidao said to Shizheng, “It is not that I do not wish to keep you with me, but to accomplish the work of the Dao, none but Yuanzhi will do.” When Yuanzhi met him, he exclaimed to Aidao, “Today, another immortal Pan has appeared—how fortunate for my teaching!” Thus, Shizheng was registered among the Daoist clergy and received the hidden scriptures and true texts of the Three Caverns.

Soon after, Yuanzhi requested to return to Mount Mao, and Shizheng accompanied him. While crossing the Yangzi River, he drank foul water and suffered dysentery so severe his stool resembled congealed fat. Then he dreamed of a man in dazzling white robes descending from the sky, who gave him a white pill. Upon waking, he was cured.

Upon arrival, Yuanzhi said, “Though I wish to keep you here, Mount Songyang is your destined place for cultivating the true Dao. You must return at once.” There, he lived with Liu Aidao on the summit of Double Springs for over twenty years, later building a hut in Xiaoyao Valley. His sustenance was only the water of green pines and mountain streams. He purified his heart and forgot his form, becoming one with the grasses and trees. The scriptures and methods he practiced included three of the Great Clarity, six of the Middle Perfection, and eight of the Lower Perfection.

Emperor Gaozong of Tang, visiting the eastern capital, summoned him and requested talismanic writing, but Shizheng declined, saying he did not know it. The emperor then asked what he needed in the mountains. Shizheng replied, “Lush pines and clear springs are all I require, and this mountain has them in abundance.” The emperor, struck by his words, did not detain him but instead built Chongtang Abbey and Fengtian Palace at his dwelling. He also ordered a gate built at Xiaoyao Valley, naming the southern side “Weary of Wandering” and the northern “Seeking the True.” When the Court of Imperial Sacrifices presented new music, the emperor renamed the pieces *Praying for Immortals*, *Gazing for Immortals*, and *Longing for Immortals*.

In the early *Tiaolu* era, Emperor Gaozong hunted at Mount Song and had his carriage bring Shizheng to Songyang Abbey to inquire about the Dao, then escorted him back to Xiaoyao Valley. There, he saw a rattan couch on the verge of decay, with no cooking utensils—only two large gourds. When asked their purpose, Shizheng replied, “I have *qingzhui* rice, which Lord Wang of the Western City made from *nan zhu*. Eating it leads to the Dao.” Upon returning to the capital, the emperor ordered envoys to Jiangdong to prepare *qingqu* rice as a gift.

Frequently, the emperor sent handwritten edicts to comfort and inquire after him, always addressing him with the names of his disciples. Robes, incense, candles, gold, and silk were sent without cease. Such was the depth of his imperial favor. Shizheng told his disciples, “I truly have no use for these things, yet the emperor’s grace overflows. As a Daoist, my robes are all imperial gifts, and grand structures have been built for me, disturbing the earth, slaughtering plants and trees, and startling birds and beasts. I am a sinner and will surely incur dark retribution. You young disciples should seek the deepest mountains and most remote valleys, far from the world’s entanglements, to avoid such burdens.”

When the emperor was in Luoyang, he issued another summons. Unable to refuse, Shizheng stayed at the Celestial Garden. Upon returning to the mountain, the emperor sent him off with a poem.

On the first day of the first month of *Shuishen* year, from the eastern cliff of the valley, sounds of flutes and ethereal singing suddenly arose. His disciples came to report it. The master said, “I hear nothing. Do not seek fame to dazzle the world.”

Suddenly, he said to his disciple Han Wenli, “Build me a stone chamber beneath the northern cliff. By late summer, I shall move there.” Wenli could not bear to do it, but Shizheng urged him relentlessly. Wenli asked, “Would the northern cliff, connected to the sacred mountain, be suitable?” Shizheng replied, “I have lived here for over fifty years. Three times have perfected beings descended, and seven times have they spoken of essentials. Each of you has mastered one thing—you will understand in time.”

On the fourteenth day of the sixth month, he asked for a bath and wrote a green talisman, placing it in the water. He said, “This is my lifelong struggle.” The next day, just before dawn, the cries of gibbons and cranes echoed mournfully, lingering without departure. By evening, hearing the stone chamber was unfinished, he said, “It seems it will not serve my purpose after all.” Then he abruptly declared, “I am leaving.” Wenli asked, “Where are you going?”

He replied, “To inspect merits and virtues at Mount Tai.”

On the sixteenth day, he said again, “Since the stone chamber is not yet complete, temporarily build a tiled house to preserve my true self. Do not alter my garments. After a hundred days, move me into the stone chamber.” That day, clouds enveloped the courtyard, and a strange fragrance filled the room. In an instant, he dissolved into transformation at the age of ninety-eight. An imperial edict posthumously conferred upon him the title of *Grand Master for Palace Counsel*, with the posthumous name *Master of Embodied Mystery*.

The Master’s divine bearing and immortal bones were refined, much like a reclusive sage. Those who conceal their truth to refine their truth, who temper their radiance and wander in transformation—are they not of this kind?

His disciples numbered eight in all, each exceptionally gifted. Yet those whose phoenix-like grace and crane-like poise shimmered among the cloud-pine were Wei Fazhao, Sima Ziwei, and Guo Chongzhen. All had received instruction in the Jade Court, secretly inherited the teachings of the Jasper Chamber, devoted themselves to the arts of the Jade Clarity, and left behind the company of mortal immortals.

At the time, Chen Zi’ang composed an ode.

Sima Chengzhen was a descendant of Sima Yixuan, Duke of Langye in the Later Zhou. His given name was Chengzhen, and his courtesy name was Ziwei. A native of Wen in Luozhou, he studied under Master Pan, transmitting the arts of grain avoidance and guiding-and-pulling, mastering them all without exception. Master Pan marveled at him, saying, “I have received the Orthodox Unity teachings of Tao Hongjing. Now, through four generations, it has reached you.” After a long time, he took leave of his teacher’s mat and traveled extensively among the famous mountains.

He built a retreat on Mount Tiantai, constructing a tiered pavilion atop the altar, which he named the Terrace of Myriad Wonders. Empress Wu of the Tang once summoned him, but he soon departed. With Chen Zi’ang, Lu Zangyong, Song Zhiwen, Wang Shi, Bi Gou, Li Bai, Meng Haoran, Wang Wei, and He Zhizhang, he formed the Ten Daoist Friends.

Emperor Ruizong later dispatched his elder brother Chengwei to visit him, with an edict that read: “The Perfected Master’s virtue transcends the banks of the Yellow River, his ease like that of Fuqiu. He soars high in the azure courts of heaven, strides alone through the pure springs of the Dao. As We have newly ascended the throne, We have long relied upon his illustrious guidance. Though Emperor Yao yearned for the great plans of Nie Que, and the Yellow Emperor gazed afar toward Mount Kongtong, We cherish those distant aspirations yet do not neglect this present regard. Morning and evening, Our thoughts linger, Our heart soars near though We remain distant. We wished to send envoys to welcome him specially, but feared the Perfected Master might find the occasion inopportune. Thus, We have sent Chengwei to convey Our wish that he come with him. Should he decline, let there be no concern beforehand. Once arrived, he shall be received within the inner palace.”

When questioned about his arts, he replied: "In pursuing the Dao, one reduces daily—reducing and reducing again—until reaching non-action. The knowledge and perceptions of the heart and eyes, even when diminished, cannot be entirely stilled; how much more so when one assails heterodoxies and increases cunning thoughts?"

The Emperor asked: "For cultivating the self, this may suffice—but how does one govern a state?"

He answered: "A state is like the self. Thus, let the mind wander in simplicity, unite the qi in stillness, and move with things naturally without harboring private desires—then the world will be well-ordered."

The Emperor sighed in admiration: "What words of Guangcheng could surpass these?" He bestowed upon him a treasure zither and a rosy cloud-woven robe before sending him away. The court ministers composed poems to see him off, later compiled by Chang Heng and Xu Yantan into a preface titled *Record of White Clouds*.

Later, the Emperor again dispatched envoys to summon him to the capital, personally conferring talismans and registers upon him, with lavish rewards. Yet he repeatedly declined, requesting to return home. Lu Zangyong, who had once secluded himself on Mount Zhongnan before rising to high office, saw Chengzhen preparing to depart for Mount Tiantai. Pointing to Zhongnan, he remarked: "This mountain holds many fine places—why must you go to Tiantai?"

Chengzhen replied: "From my perspective, it is merely a shortcut for official advancement." Lu Zangyong flushed with shame.

Emperor Minghuang ordered the construction of an altar chamber on Mount Wangwu to house him. Chengzhen excelled in seal and clerical scripts, and his "golden scissors calligraphy" formed a style uniquely his own. The Emperor commanded him to transcribe the *Laozi* in three scripts, correcting its text and punctuation. He once forged a *Containing-Image Mirror* and a *Quaking-Light Sword* as tribute. The Emperor sent the Minister of Works, Wei Tao, to his residence to establish a ritual altar according to the *Golden Register*, bestowing generous gifts.

Upon returning from the Feng and Shan sacrifices, the Emperor asked Chengzhen which spirits presided over the Five Peaks. He answered: "The peaks are the great mountains of the realm, capable of summoning clouds and rain, and serve as the nation’s beacons. Yet the immortals who dwell there are governed by separate celestial officials." Thereupon, the Emperor decreed that separate temples for the immortal officials be established at each of the Five Peaks.

At that time, the female immortal Jiao Jingzhen crossed the sea to Penglai in search of a master. On an island, she encountered a Daoist who pointed and said: "Sima Chengzhen of Mount Tiantai—his name is inscribed on the Cinnabar Terrace, his body dwells in the Red City—he is a true and worthy teacher." Jingzhen returned and sought initiation from Chengzhen, and before long, ascended to heaven.

Once, he descended to address Xue Jichang, saying: "Master, your attainment surpasses that of Ren of Taodu Waters—you shall become the Perfected Lord of the Upper Clarity of Eastern Florescence."

During the Kaiyuan era, the Celestial Master Wenjing and Chengzhen attended the *Changsheng* Palace for the *Qianqiu* Festival’s dawn vigil. After the midnight rites, they retired behind cloud-patterned screens to rest. Suddenly, the sound of a child reciting scripture arose, clear and resonant as jade and gold. The Celestial Master lifted his robe and crept forward to peer, seeing a coin-sized sun upon Chengzhen’s forehead, its radiance illuminating the entire chamber. Drawing nearer to listen, he realized the voice emanated from within Chengzhen’s skull. The Celestial Master withdrew and told his disciples: "The *Yellow Court Scripture* says, ‘The Nine Perfected of the Mud-Pill Palace each have their chambers, a square inch within this place.’ It also says, ‘The Divine Lord of the Left, Gongzi, speaks the divine language.’ This describes our Master." He had over seventy disciples.

Suddenly he declared: "From Jade Cloud Peak, gazing east toward Penglai, I see a numinous perfected one descending in a chariot—now the Lesser Green Lad of the Eastern Sea. The Lord of Eastern Radiance has summoned me; I must depart." In an instant, he transformed and departed like a cicada shedding its husk. His disciples buried his robes and cap. He was eighty-nine years of age. By imperial edict, he was posthumously appointed Grand Master for Splendid Happiness with Silver and Cyan, and granted the posthumous title *Master of Orthodox Unity*. The emperor personally composed the inscription for his stele, and Wei Qumou wrote his biography. His works—*Arcane Essentials of Cultivating Perfection*, *Chart of the Palaces of Heaven and Earth*, *On Sitting in Forgetfulness*, and *Lineage of Ascending Perfection*—circulated in the world.

Minister Dao Yi remarked: "Sima Chengzhen scorned the trappings of rank, dwelling in grotto-heavens. His lofty heart-mind and profound learning are not easily matched. In reply to Emperor Ruizong of Tang, he said: ‘The state is like the body. Thus, to wander the heart in tranquility, to merge intent with the vast, and to follow things as they are without private bias—this is how the realm is governed.’ Truly, he grasped the profound purport of the Supreme. As the *Dao De Jing* states: ‘When I practice non-action, the people transform themselves; when I cherish stillness, the people rectify themselves; when I am without affairs, the people enrich themselves; when I am without desire, the people return to simplicity.’ This is the very meaning." —Li Hanguang.

The subject was a native of Jinling. His family, originally of pure Confucian stock, was known in the region as the "Master of Integrity and Reclusion." Later, to avoid the personal name of Emperor Jingzong of Tang, the family changed its surname to Li. His son, Han’guang, at the age of thirteen, was deeply devoted to Daoist learning. Even in seclusion, he conducted himself as though in the presence of a sovereign or father. When others beheld him, his demeanor was always composed. Skilled in seal and clerical scripts, some even claimed he surpassed his father. Upon hearing such praise, he never wrote again in those styles for the rest of his life.

Later, he became a disciple of the Master of Orthodox Unity, who entrusted him with the sacred texts of cloud-seal scriptures, bestowing them without reservation. The master declared: "You are a guest of the Pure Jade Clarity. Embrace emptiness and practice cultivation, and your Dao shall never be exhausted. Yet if you seclude yourself in remote mountains and conceal your traces, your virtue will remain shallow." Though the teachings were profound, he urged Han’guang to prioritize saving others.

Having received this true instruction, Han’guang forgot his own concerns and aided those in distress. Whenever he composed memorials or petitions, he purified his heart and body, never once growing negligent. Emperor Ming of Tang summoned him and inquired about governance and transformation. Han’guang replied: "The *Dao De Jing* is the teacher of rulers. Formerly, Emperor Wen of Han practiced its principles and guided the people into the realm of benevolence and longevity."

When asked about the golden elixir, he said: "The Dao and virtue are impartial. Lightness and transcendence are but private inclinations within impartiality. Though such inclinations appear self-serving, they remain part of the sagely teachings—like seeking life. Yet to pursue desires is like grasping at the wind. Is that not difficult?" The emperor praised him and treated him with great courtesy.

Before long, Han’guang pleaded illness and returned to Juqu, where an imperial edict established the Ziyang Abbey as his residence. When the emperor received the *True Scripture of Yang and Xu*, he requested Han’guang as his teacher, but Han’guang again declined due to illness. Thereupon, in the Hall of Great Unity, the emperor composed a formal address, bestowing upon him the posthumous title "Master Wenjing" from afar. Imperial decrees were repeatedly issued, and provisions were continuously supplied.

Han’guang once compiled the *Biographies of Immortals’ Learning*, a treatise on the differences and similarities among the Three Mysteries, and the *Phonetic Glosses of the Materia Medica*. He was also ordered to complete several pages of calligraphy left unfinished by Yang the Perfected. In the eleventh month of the fourth year of the Dali era of Emperor Daizong, he told his disciples Wei Jingzhao and Meng Zhanran: "I shall follow the transformation of nature." Shortly after, his countenance remained serene as he departed. Auspicious clouds descended, and lingzhi mushrooms sprouted. He lived to the age of eighty-seven.

*Comprehensive Mirror of Perfected Immortals Who Embodied the Dao*, Scroll Twenty-Five—concluded.
*Comprehensive Mirror of Perfected Immortals Who Embodied the Dao*, Scroll Twenty-Six.

Master Historian Xu, the Perfected Lord of the Grand Scribe, bore the surname Xu and the given name Xun, styled Jingzhi. His great-grandfather was Xu Mei, his grandfather Xu Wang, and his father Xu Su. The family had long resided in Xuchang, maintaining lofty integrity and declining public office. They were descendants of the Yingyang You lineage. During the Han dynasty’s decline, his father relocated to Nanchang in Yuzhang, where they settled. In the second year of Chiwu of the Wu kingdom (the year *jiwei*), his mother, the Lady of the House, dreamed of a golden phoenix bearing a pearl that alighted in her palm. She admired and swallowed it, and upon waking, felt movement in her womb. Thus she conceived and gave birth to the Perfected Lord.

Master Yuanyou of Mount Juqu and Mu, the Chief Clerk of the Protector-General of the Jin, were the Perfected Lord’s second cousins. From birth, the Perfected Lord displayed exceptional intelligence and a striking, majestic appearance. As a child, he was open and guileless, never acting against others. Once, while hunting, he shot a pregnant doe, and its fawn fell to the ground. The mother doe turned back to lick it, dying before she could finish. Moved by this, he immediately cast aside his bow and arrows, resolving to devote himself to learning.

He mastered the classics and histories, attaining profound knowledge of astronomy, geography, music, the Five Phases, and apocryphal texts. Yet he was especially drawn to the arts of divine transcendence and self-cultivation, achieving remarkable mastery. Hearing that Wu Meng of Xi’an had received esoteric methods from the perfected adept Ding Yi, he journeyed to study under him, receiving the full transmission of his secrets. Thereafter, he and Guo Pu explored famous mountains in search of auspicious sites for dwelling in truth. They found the southern slope of Mount Xiaoyao in Xishan, the residence of the Jin family, and moved there—now known as the Xiaoyao Blessed Land and the Jade Prosperity Palace of Ten Thousand Longevities.

He devoted himself daily to cultivation, and to this day, the Elixir Well and Mortar remain. Though he sought no fame or prominence, his village was transformed by his filial piety and brotherly love, and his associates admired his virtue and righteousness. Once, a merchant sold him an iron lampstand. That night, as he lit the lamp, he noticed peeling lacquer, revealing gold beneath. The next day, he sought out the owner and returned it. If someone offered him a gift, he would accept nothing unless it accorded with propriety. Though recommended as a Filial and Incorrupt candidate by the prefecture, he declined the appointment.

The court repeatedly extended offers of official appointment, and he could no longer decline. Thus, in the first year of Emperor Wu of Jin’s Taikang era (280 CE), at the age of forty-two, he assumed the post of magistrate of Jingyang County in Shu Commandery. Upon taking office, he earnestly exhorted the clerks and subordinates to abandon greed and vulgarity, eliminate trivial regulations, and release prisoners from their fetters. He instructed them all in the Dao, and both officials and commoners were pleased and submitted willingly, all wishing to reform themselves. His administrative decisions were as if divinely inspired, and the clerks dared not deceive him. When hearing lawsuits, he would first teach the litigants about loyalty, filial piety, kindness, benevolence, patience, prudence, diligence, and frugality—drawing near to the worthy, distancing the treacherous, and putting an end to greed and violence. These teachings were recorded in detail in his *Wencheng* texts.

Yet he lamented that the county’s vast expanse made it difficult to ensure every household understood his governance. Thus, he selected virtuous and respected commoners, along with elders of wisdom, and entrusted them with the task of exhortation and leadership. As a result, the spirit of contention gradually faded, and over time, lawsuits ceased entirely.

Previously, during a year of famine, the people had no means to pay their taxes, and the commandery and county enforced the law strictly, driving many to flee. The Perfected Lord then transmuted tiles and pebbles into gold using an elixir and had them secretly buried in the county garden. One day, he summoned all those who had yet to pay their taxes to the courtyard and set them to work in the rear garden. As they dug, they unearthed gold, which they used to pay their taxes, and thus all were able to remain in their homes. Hearing of his virtue and benevolence, refugees from neighboring regions flocked to him in great numbers, and the population flourished.

When a great epidemic later struck, killing seven or eight out of every ten people, the Perfected Lord employed the divine formulas he had been taught to heal them. Wherever his talismans and incantations reached, the afflicted recovered instantly. Even those suffering from chronic or severe illnesses were cured without exception. Word spread to other commanderies, and the sick arrived in an unbroken stream, numbering in the thousands daily. He then planted bamboo outside the city walls along a ten-*li* stretch of the river, placing talismanic water within it, and instructed the people to drink beneath the bamboo—all were healed. For the elderly, the frail, and those too ill to come themselves, he allowed them to draw the water and drink it at home, and they too recovered. The people of Shu composed a song about him:

*No theft or robbery,*
*No deceit from officials.*
*Our lord revives the people,*
*No illness can withstand him.*

Later, people from the region east of the Yangtze also came to draw water from Jingyang. The Perfected Lord then consecrated a vessel of water with a talisman and instructed them to take it back and place it by the riverbank, planting bamboo to mark the spot. The sick who drank from it were likewise cured. This river is now called the Shu River, also known as the Brocade Waters, and lies within present-day Gao’an County in Ruizhou.

After serving as magistrate of Jingyang for many years, the Perfected Lord foresaw the coming chaos of the Jin dynasty and resigned his post to return east. Jingyang County belonged to Hanzhou; after the Perfected Lord’s ascension, the imperial court renamed it Deyang in honor of his virtue and its people. Later, the county seat was moved west, and the former site was converted into a Daoist temple, now known as Jingyang Abbey.

The people of Shu, moved by his transformative virtue, could find no way to detain him. Everywhere he had been, they erected shrines to him in life, and households enshrined his portrait, revering him as a divine being. On the day of his departure, those carrying provisions to see him off filled the fields. Some followed him for a thousand *li* before turning back, while others accompanied him to his home, wishing to serve him and never return. They settled on vacant land east of his residence, building huts like a military encampment. Many even changed their surnames to match his, and thus the place became known as the Xu Family Encampment. Such was the depth of his enduring love among the people.

Once, the Perfected Lord traveled to Xinyu and rested beneath a bridge grove. Suddenly, five maidens appeared, each bearing a precious sword, which they offered to him. Marveling, he accepted them. The site is now known as Bridge Grove Abbey. Thereafter, the maidens accompanied him to his residence, where they amused themselves daily by striking the swords together, their purpose unfathomable to others. The Perfected Lord, recognizing their exhaustion from the swords, treated them with courtesy, and in time, they proved their worth as divine blades. After his ascension, they concealed themselves beneath the wutong tree he had planted, and thus became known as the Wutong Immortal Maidens.

Later, he and Lord Wu journeyed to Songyang, where they heard of a female master named Chen Mu in Huangtang, Danyang County, near Jinling, who possessed many Daoist arts. Together, they went to pay their respects and inquired about the subtleties of the Dao. The mistress said: “You both were born with sacred bones, and your names are recorded in the celestial registers as immortals. Yet in the past, the Filial and Fraternal King descended from the Upper Clarity to transform and deliver the mortal world, demonstrating the practice of filial piety. He first descended to the home of Master Lan in Qufu, Yanzhou, and said to him: ‘In a later age of the Jin dynasty, a divine immortal named Xu Sun will appear, to whom you shall transmit this Dao, for he shall be the leader of all the Perfected.’ He left behind the Golden Elixir and Precious Scriptures, along with bronze talismans and iron charters, instructing Master Lan to safeguard them until Xu Sun’s arrival. This has been many years. I, too, have received the teachings of the Filial Dao Bright King, which also take filial piety as their foundation. Have you now come?’ I shall transmit them to you.”

She then selected an auspicious day and ascended the altar. Following the ritual protocols, she administered the oaths and instructions, expounding on the Way of Filial Piety with solemn admonitions. She produced the bronze talismans, iron charters, Golden Elixir and Precious Scriptures, along with the Orthodox Unity methods for slaying demons, the arts of the Three and Five Flying Steps, and all the secret techniques of the various ranks, transmitting them all to Lord Xu. Turning to Lord Wu, she said: “In the past, you served as Lord Xu’s teacher in divine formulas, but now only he has received the teachings of the Filial Dao Bright King. You should now defer to him as your master. Moreover, the Jade Emperor’s celestial register ranks you as the Inspector of the Mystic Capital, while Lord Xu holds the position of High and Illustrious Grand Master, overseeing the celestial registers and outranking all others. You are each assigned to govern one of the twelve earthly branches corresponding to the twelve states: Lord Xu presides over the Xuan Yang region, corresponding to the *zi* branch, and oversees the twelve terrestrial divisions. You govern the Star Chronicle state, corresponding to the *chou* branch. From now on, you should acknowledge Lord Xu as your superior.”

The two lords bowed in gratitude and took their leave. The Perfected Lord then resolved to visit the mistress every year. Sensing his intention, she said: “Do not come again, for I shall soon return to the imperial realm.” She then took a stalk of fragrant cogon grass, faced south, and cast it, saying: “When you return, build my shrine where the grass falls. A visit each autumn will suffice.” The two lords returned and first sought the place where the grass had landed. They found it over forty *li* south of their residence, where it had already grown into a thicket.

Thereupon they built a shrine hall, likewise with a yellow chamber, naming it the Venerable Dao Abbey. Each year on the third day of mid-autumn, they would invariably go to pay homage. Earlier, when the Perfected Lord had gone to seek the fallen cogon grass, he saw by the roadside a clear pond and rested there briefly, saying: “This is where I rested in true tranquility—now known as the Qingbei Village Tranquility Abbey.” He also saw villagers preparing lavish feasts of slaughtered animals to sacrifice to the gods, remarking to one another in surprise: “If the offerings are not abundant, the gods will grow angry and send down calamity.” The Perfected Lord said: “How dare such malevolent spirits act thus?” That night, lodging at an inn, he summoned wind and thunder to strike them, uprooting their grove. The next day, he told the villagers: “The demonic shrine has been driven away; there is no need for sacrifices.” To this day, the site lies abandoned, and no one makes offerings there.

He also saw travelers burdened with water jars along the road, so he thrust his staff into the dried marsh before the shrine, causing a spring to gush forth to aid them. Even in drought, it never runs dry—now known as the Purple Yang Tranquility Stone Well of Daze Village. The next day, ascending a mountain peak, he pointed to a spring altar halfway up the slope and said: “There is a strange creature hidden here, which will later bring harm.” Thereupon he established an altar to pacify and suppress it. Each year when he came to pay homage to the mistress, he would rest here, and it is now called Dragon City Abbey.

He then crossed the Xiao Shu River—now called Huanghu Port—and reached a tavern by the riverbank. The proprietor, a man surnamed Zhu, though poor, received him with great reverence. The Perfected Lord playfully drew a pine tree on the wall before departing. From that day on, the family’s profits doubled. Later, when the river flooded and breached the dike, all the market stalls were swept away—only the wall with the pine remained intact. Now called Pine Lake Market, the Zhu family built a temple there and still draws sustenance from the land.

The Perfected Lord once refined divine elixir on Yellow Dragon Mountain in Aicheng. The mountain stream harbored a flood dragon, which made its lair in the deep pools and frequently unleashed floods to sweep away the elixir chamber. The Perfected Lord dispatched divine soldiers to capture it and nail it to a stone cliff—where the Dragon-Nailing Stone remains to this day. After the elixir was completed, he offered it in sacrifice at the stone chamber of Immortal Ge on Mofu Mountain.

He then came to Xiuchuan, admiring its swift currents and firm waters, and took his divine sword to whet it on a stone by the stream. The site remains in Meishan of Xiuchuan, and later generations built an abbey there to mark the sacred proximity—now called Jingyang Abbey. Soon after, he crossed the river and ascended秀峰—now called Jingyang Mountain—where he built an altar on the peak to offer thanks to the Supreme Emperor before consuming the immortal elixir.

Lord Hao resided nearby—south of the stream lies Hao Immortal Village and Hao Immortal Abbey, the former dwelling of Perfected Lord Hao. The Perfected Lord then visited Lord Hao’s residence. Passing through Xi’an County—now known as Fennin—he was met by the local earth god, who inquired about malevolent creatures harming the people, only for the god to conceal them. As the Perfected Lord passed a small shrine, the deity within—a man surnamed Mao with four brothers, now known as the Temple of Harmonious Protection, located four hundred paces east of the county—came forth to greet him, saying: “Here dwells a flood dragon that harms the people. Knowing of your arrival, it has fled to Ezhu. It will return later, so I beg you to rid this land of it for the people’s sake.”

The Perfected Lord followed his words, tracking its trail to Ezhu. By the roadside, he encountered three elders—now the Three Kings Temple—who, when asked about the dragon’s whereabouts, all pointed and said: “We saw it lurking beneath the bridge ahead”—now called Hidden Dragon Bridge. The Perfected Lord reached the bridge, brandished his sword, and rebuked it. The dragon, startled, fled into the great river and concealed itself in the depths—now called Lower Dragon Hollow. He then compelled the local officials and soldiers to drive it out. The dragon burst forth from the upper reaches, and he slew it—now called Upper Dragon Mouth.

Enraged at the dereliction of the Xi’an earth god, the Perfected Lord sealed the temple gates and forbade the people from making offerings. To this day, the main gate of the City God Temple in Fennin County remains closed, and it is said that when it opens, the town will suffer fire. The priests now enter and exit only through the side door, and few villagers make offerings. Instead, they now worship at the small shrine—now the Temple of the Marquis of Harmonious Protection—which receives abundant sacrifices and is renowned for its divine efficacy.

Finally, he returned to the prefectural city. The Perfected Lord said: “This place is a vital hub of water and land routes, teeming with people—how could there not be those weary of the world’s divisions and seeking repose?”

Having tested the waters by mixing several grains of his elixir with other medicines for sale, he let the credulous purchase them. Though many later sought to redeem their purchases, not a single one succeeded. The Perfected Lord sighed, lamenting the rarity of those in the world fit for transcendence.

Hearing that a flood dragon was wreaking havoc in Xinho, he took up his sword and gave chase. The path he traversed is now called Dragon Spring Abbey—later renamed Immortal’s Journey. The dragon, terrified, fled into a mountain stream, which to this day is called Hiding Creek. The Perfected Lord then inscribed talismans upon a massive boulder and composed the *Text for Suppressing the Dragon* to bind it. The stone stele bearing the *Text for Suppressing the Dragon* still stands, now within a monastery called Prolonging the True. Nearby is an abbey, also named Prolonging the True, ten *li* west of Fengxin County.

At that time, in the upper reaches of Haihun, a colossal serpent had claimed a mountain cave as its lair, exhaling clouds of qi that, once spread, would swallow any man or beast within forty *li* of its miasma—none escaped. Boats on the rivers and lakes were likewise capsized and drowned, bringing great suffering to the people. The Perfected Lord, upon hearing of this, ascended the summit of the northern ridge to investigate. The peak east of Red Crow Abbey—now called Immortals’ Gathering Peak—was the very place. There, he saw the venomous qi darkening the sky.

Moved by the plight of the people, he gathered his disciples, intending to slay the beast. As they first entered its domain, over three hundred residents from near and far, knowing of the Perfected Lord’s mastery of the Dao, came pleading for help, their entreaties earnest. The Perfected Lord said: “The turning of the world’s fortunes brings calamity in its wake, and the people must endure its trials. I have come precisely for this purpose. I shall rid you of this scourge—I swear I shall not live in the same age as this serpent.” Soon after, his disciples arrived, all urging him to act. The Perfected Lord replied: “The time must be ripe.”

Thus, he planted his sword into the earth and silently prayed to Heaven. After a long while, a spring gushed forth, and soon a red crow flew past. The Perfected Lord said: “The time is ripe.” That place was named the Time-Watching Terrace, later renamed Red Crow Abbey, and now called Longevity Sage Abbey, also known as Broad Blessings.

A Daoist of the Song dynasty, Wan Zhongxing, wrote a poem:
*Of old a giant serpent wrought its venomous might,
Jingyang here awaited the hour to smite.
Cave-dwelling immortals gathered in the know,
While in the heavens a sacred crow marked the time’s flow.
Talismans flew in wrath o’er the valley’s mouth,
Sword-stars clashed down—ghosts and gods grieved in drouth.
A thousand years hence, rise and fall swift unfold,
Yet boundless remains the hidden merit untold.*

Zhang Tianjue also composed a poem on the Sword-Planting Spring:
*The sword planted became a well beneath the stone,
Waiting for the crow at noon to stir alone.
The sea’s dark fiends now purged, their taint undone,
Yet blessings linger still in the Seven Tranquil Charts shown.*

Proceeding to the serpent’s lair, he brandished his sword and deployed his qi. The serpent, terrified, retreated into its cave. He then sent a flying talisman to summon the Lord of Haihun’s Earth Altar to drive it out, but it could not emerge. He next summoned the Lord of Nanchang’s Earth Altar to assist, and the talisman fell two *li* east of the county, where an abbey was later built, named Talisman-Fall Abbey, now called Supreme Harmony.

The serpent emerged from its cave, rearing its head over ten *zhang* high, its eyes like torches of fire, spewing venom that blotted out the sky. The villagers all clamored and drummed to aid him. At that moment, the Perfected Lord whistled, commanding wind and thunder, and summoned divine soldiers with a gesture to subdue it, rendering it immobile. Then, Lord Wu strode forward and trampled its head, cleaving its skull with his sword. The serpent at last cowered low, and his disciples Shi Cen, Gan Zhan, and others led the troops to strike. The serpent’s belly split open, and a smaller serpent, several *zhang* long, slithered out from within. Lord Gan sought to slay it, but the Perfected Lord said: “It has done no harm—we must not kill without cause.” The young serpent, frightened, fled six or seven *li*, the clamor of the drums still audible as it turned to glance back at its mother. The place is now called Serpent’s Offspring Harbor and Seven-*Li* Ford.

His disciples urged him to pursue and slay it, but the Perfected Lord said: “If this serpent brings harm to the people in a hundred and fifty years, I shall return to slay it. The banyan I plant before my altar shall serve as proof—when its branches sweep the ground, that will be the time.” He also foretold: “One thousand two hundred and forty years after my departure as an immortal, within the borders of Yuzhang and the Five Mounds, in the eastern lands of Jiangzhou and Fengshui’s celestial divisions, the eastern gate’s stronghold shall be Wanling. In the southern lands of Yangzhou’s celestial divisions, the southern gate’s stronghold shall be Haoling. In the western lands of Yongzhou and Weitai’s celestial divisions, the western gate’s stronghold shall be Queling. In the northern lands of Youzhou and Taiyuan’s celestial divisions, the northern gate’s stronghold shall be Fuling. In the central lands of Chang’an and Changpu’s celestial divisions, the central gate’s stronghold shall be Tailing. Then shall emerge eight hundred earthbound immortals, whose master shall arise in Yuzhang to greatly propagate my teachings. When a sandbar suddenly rises in the heart of the prefectural river, covering the mouth of Shajing, that will be the time.” (This event is recorded in *Longsha’s Rise* in *Yuzhang’s Gazetteer of Administrative Geography*. Longsha lies atop the rocks on the western bank of Zhang River, facing the prefectural city.)

Pan Qingyi wrote a poem, *Gazing at Longsha*:
*Countless souls dwell in the Five Mounds’ keep,
Their eyes fixed on Longsha’s record deep.
Though Longsha has not yet fully grown,
Its aura already stirs with mystic tone.
Once dragons writhed here in ancient days,
Now mulberry and hemp claim their maze.
The land curves with the river’s bend,
Isles float in chains without end.*

“If at that time the young serpent brings harm, those eight hundred shall surely slay it. But if it harms no living thing, it must not be killed.” The serpent’s offspring thus entered the river at Jianchang County’s Serpent’s Offspring Harbor, where a temple stands on Xinjian County’s Wucheng Mountain, renowned for its efficacy. In the Song dynasty, it was enfeoffed as the Spirit-Compliant, Manifest-Response, Peace-Bringing, Blessing-Bestowing King, commonly called the Little Dragon Temple.

After the great serpent’s death, its bones piled into an islet, now called Serpent-Bone Isle. Wherever the Perfected Lord passed through Haihun, he left behind altars and wells—six in all, including the Time-Watching Terrace, making seven. Their arrangement mirrored the Dipper’s form, serving to suppress future calamities. The Seven Tranquilities refer to Advancing Transformation Tranquility, Imperial Memorial Tranquility, Cinnabar Talisman Tranquility, Flowery Tablet Tranquility, Purple Yang Tranquility, Huo Yang Tranquility, and Liu the Perfected’s Tranquility. Today, all have become official abbeys, some now temples or government residences.

He then traveled to the northwest of the county, where he found a mountain spring clear and pure. He cast a talisman into it, enabling the people to cure illnesses with its waters, its efficacy rivaling that of the Shu River. The place is now called Jade Water Terrace.

After the giant python was slain, its monstrous blood stained his sword. He thus sharpened and washed it, testing its edge on a stone. Today, in Jianchang County, the Sword-Sharpening Pool and Sword-Testing Stone remain. He addressed his disciples: “Though the great serpent is destroyed, the dragon-spirit remains unvanquished. That creature is cunning—it must know of my intent to eradicate harm. I fear it may seize an opportunity to breach the prefectural city. Let us return to the prefecture.” Shi and Cen followed him.

This occurred in the sixth year of Emperor Huai’s Yongjia reign. The Perfected Lord’s Daoist arts were wondrous and widely renowned. Hundreds sought to become his disciples, but he could not accept them all.

Then he transformed charcoal into a beautiful woman and dispersed her among his disciples at night to test them. At dawn, he reviewed them, and only ten remained unstained by her allure—these were the very disciples who would later ascend to immortality. Thereafter, whenever he roamed rivers and lakes to slay dragons and serpents, they never failed to accompany him. The rest, ashamed, departed. Today, at West Ford in Jianchang County, the market is called Charcoal Woman Market, and a temple named Miaoming stands there.

The Perfected Lord then returned to the prefecture with Lords Gan and Shi, surveying the city. There, a youth of refined bearing and splendid attire presented himself, announcing his surname as Shen. His manners were earnest, his responses quick, and he soon took his leave. The Perfected Lord said to his disciples: “That was no man, but the spirit of the old dragon, come to test me. Though his form was human, a rank wind clung to him. I feigned ignorance to expose his kind fully.” Tracking his path, they found him by the river, transformed into a yellow ox, lying upon the sands outside the prefectural city—now called Yellow Ox Shoal. The Perfected Lord cut paper into a black ox and sent it to engage the creature, ordering Shi Cen to conceal himself with a sword and strike when the beast was off guard. With a single swing, Shi Cen severed its left thigh, and the ox fled into a well south of the city. The well, named Horizontal Spring, still lies at the southeast corner of Upper Blue Temple, its mouth sealed by a wall—hence its other name, Dragon Well. The Perfected Lord dispatched a talismanic officer to trace its tracks, discovering it had fled straight to Changsha, emerging from the well of Jia Yi. There, it took human form and entered the household of Prefect Jia Yu.

Earlier, the dragon spirit had admired Jia’s daughter for her beauty and, transforming into a handsome youth, sought an audience. Jia, impressed by his talent, promised him his daughter’s hand and, through lavish gifts to Jia’s confidants, secured their praise. The marriage was thus arranged. After several years, they had two sons. Each spring and summer, the husband would depart alone, roaming rivers and lakes as if a merchant. By autumn, he returned in a great ship laden with treasures—plunder from vessels capsized in the floods. That autumn, he returned to Jia, claiming: “Bandits seized our goods and wounded my left thigh.” The entire household lamented, and Jia sought physicians to treat him.

The Perfected Lord then disguised himself as a physician and called upon Jia, who welcomed him and summoned his son-in-law for treatment. Sensing danger, the dragon spirit dared not appear. Jia rose to fetch him, and the Perfected Lord followed into the hall, crying in a stern voice: “Dragon spirit of rivers and lakes, you have wrought harm beyond count! I have tracked you here—how dare you flee! Come forth at once!” Cornered, the creature revealed its true form, coiling beneath the hall, and was slain by the officers. The Perfected Lord sprinkled its two sons with ritual water, and they too transformed into small dragons, promptly executed. Jia’s daughter nearly changed form as well, but her parents pleaded for mercy, and the Perfected Lord gave them a divine talisman, sparing her.

He warned Jia: “Beneath the dragon spirit’s dwelling lies water. Dig but a few feet beneath your home, and you will find vast waves. Move at once, lest you court disaster.” The entire household, terrified, relocated to high ground. Soon after, the site sank into an abyss, its depths unfathomable—now known as Bright Pool in Changsha.

The Perfected Lord returned to Yuzhang, but the dragon’s remaining followers thrived, uneasy at the prospect of his wrath. They took human form and wandered the city, seeking his disciples. Feigning innocence, one said: “I hail from Chang’an, where my family has long practiced virtue. I have heard of your master, Lord Xu, and his divine sword—might I learn of its power?” A disciple replied: “Our master’s sword is divine: point it at the heavens, and they split; at the earth, and it cracks; at the stars, and they lose their course; at rivers, and they reverse their flow. No evil dares stand before it—it is a treasure of gods and sages.” Another added: “Yet is there aught it cannot harm?”

The disciple jested, “It can harm all but winter melons and gourds.” Taking this as truth, the dragons transformed themselves and their kin into gourds and winter melons, vines and all, floating in dense clusters upon the river, intending to drift beyond the borders.

At dawn, the Perfected Lord sensed a surge of malevolent qi. Gazing upon the river, he saw the shapes of the dragon spirits and handed his sword to Shi Cen, commanding him to tread the waters and slay them. Their followers, entwined like vines, were annihilated without exception, turning the river’s flow murky. The Perfected Lord declared, “This place is a den of dragons and serpents. Without a means to suppress them, they will resurface to wreak havoc, beyond human control.” Thus, he summoned spirits and gods to forge an iron pillar at the well south of the yamen, its shaft rising several feet above the ground, its base secured by eight chains to anchor the earth’s veins—now the site of Yan Zhen Abbey. He intoned, “If the iron pillar bends, the demons shall rise again, and I will return. If the pillar stands true, the demons are vanquished forever.” From then on, water spirits withdrew, and the city knew peace.

Yet he feared that future generations might breed treachery, so he inscribed upon the iron pillar a cryptic verse: *“Where the land prevails and hearts are virtuous, no villainy shall arise. Even if schemes take root, they will never reach fruition.”* Such was the depth of the Perfected Lord’s foresight for posterity.

The following year, learning that remnants of the dragons and serpents had scattered into Poyang and Deyang, he feared their return. He traversed rivers and lakes, eradicating them utterly. Atop Mount Caoxiao, three dragon lakes pierced the cliffs, their caverns connecting to the great river and the lands of Rao and Xin. The Perfected Lord slew their dragon spirits and established Yuyang Prefecture’s Jing to suppress them. At the bay beneath the northwestern stone cliffs, he founded Kaihua Jing for the same purpose. He further established Taicheng Prefecture’s Jing, beside which lay a bottomless abyss teeming with dragons and serpents—these he exterminated entirely, save for one young dragon that fled. Thus, he erected this Jing to sever its path. He also cast an iron talisman to seal the mouth of Poyang Lake, blocking their entry—now embedded in the river at Shangzhong Stone in Hukou County. He forged an iron lid to cover Yuan Pond in Luling, restraining their hidden lair, and set an iron talisman upon it—now called Feifu Ridge, home to Chongzhen Abbey. A sword was left there, a foot and a handspan in length, resembling jade or stone, yet neither—its nature unrecognizable to men.

The next year, the seventh of Yongjia, he journeyed again to Changsha, then to Shaoyang. The following year, he visited the prefectures of Tan and Heng, purging poisons and eliminating harm wherever he went, before returning to Yuzhang. In all, he established over seventy prefectures and Jings to suppress malevolence and avert calamities across commanderies and towns.

In the second year of Emperor Ming’s Taining era, the Grand General Wang Dun, styled Chuzhong, raised arms against the court and encamped by the lake. The Perfected Lord and Lord Wu went to pay their respects, hoping to dissuade him. At the time, Master Guo Pu served in the general’s staff, and they entered together. Chuzhong, pleased, invited them to drink and asked, “I dreamed of a tree splitting the sky—what does this portend?” The Perfected Lord replied, “It is no auspicious sign.” Lord Wu said, “A tree splitting the sky forms the character *wei* (未, ‘not yet’). You should not act rashly.” Chuzhong’s expression darkened, and he ordered Guo Pu to divine the outcome. Guo Pu said, “It will not succeed.” Chuzhong grew displeased. “How long do I have to live?” he demanded. Guo Pu answered, “If you proceed, disaster will strike soon. If you return to Wuchang, your lifespan cannot be measured.” Enraged, Chuzhong asked, “And how long do *you* have to live?” Guo Pu replied, “My life ends at midday today.” Chuzhong flew into a fury and ordered his guards to seize and behead Guo Pu. (The *Biographies of Immortals* records that Guo Pu had forewarned his family, preparing funeral arrangements at his encampment. His fate was sealed by the river’s western pines. Three days later, merchants in Nanzhou market saw Guo Pu selling his garments, conversing with acquaintances. When Chuzhong heard this, he refused to believe it. Opening the coffin, he found no corpse—Guo Pu had attained liberation through death and now serves as an immortal lord of the water realm.)

The Perfected Lord then raised his cup and cast it into the air, where it transformed into a white wagtail, circling the beams. When Chuzhong looked up, the two Lords had vanished. Chuzhong ultimately met defeat, dying in bitter regret, his corpse subjected to posthumous punishment.

The two Lords returned to Jinling and sought to hire a boat to Yuzhang. The boatman claimed no hands were available to row. The Perfected Lord said, “Close your eyes and sit calmly—do not peek. I will steer for you.” He summoned two dragons to flank the vessel, and with his seal, he imprinted the western cliff to ward off water spirits. The seal’s mark remains to this day. The boat glided through the air, swiftly passing over the summit of Mount Lu, arriving at the Golden Palace Grotto on Purple Cloud Peak. The two Lords wished to explore the cave, so the boat descended slightly, scraping the treetops with a grating sound. The boatman could not resist peeking; the dragons abandoned the vessel upon a towering peak, snapping the mast into a deep ravine—both later turned to iron and stone, now called Iron Boat Peak. The mast lies broken in the gorge.

The Perfected Lord admonished the boatman, “You disobeyed my command—where will you go now?” The boatman knelt, begging for salvation. The Perfected Lord taught him to ingest sacred herbs, enabling him to fast and achieve immortality. He vanished into these mountains. Later, when Huan Yi governed Jiangzhou, he sent men to investigate the wonders of Mount Lu. At Purple Cloud Peak, they saw a boat in the lake, accompanied by cranes, red-scaled fish, and a youth on a white horse, his long whistle audible for hundreds of paces—suspecting him to be one of the boatmen. The two Lords, each riding a dragon, traveled by land and water to reunite at Heavenly Treasure Grotto on the northern ridge. They returned to their former retreat, spending their days expounding the true Dao with their disciples. For decades, they paid no heed to worldly affairs, devoted solely to cultivating the supreme Way.

He composed the *"Drunken Thoughts of an Immortal"* song and inscribed the *"Eight Treasures of Sagely Instruction"*, which read:

**Loyalty and filial piety, integrity and prudence—**
Loyalty precludes deceit; filial piety averts rebellion.
Integrity shuns greed; prudence prevents loss.
Cultivate the self thus, and virtue may be perfected.

**Magnanimity and tolerance, forbearance and composure—**
Magnanimity wins the multitude; abundance leaves no lack.
Tolerance embraces all; forbearance brings ease.
Conduct yourself thus with others, and grievances shall vanish.

**All my disciples of the Dao, in motion or stillness, be diligent and sincere.**
Keep these precepts ever in mind, ever guarding your solitude.
Should your heart stray, the Three Officials shall examine and punish.
When the village and community emulate this, all turn toward goodness and distance themselves from transgression, and filial piety flourishes in practice.

In daily life, his comings and goings, his responses to circumstances, differed not from ordinary men. Only in his dwelling did cranes circle in flight, and auspicious clouds swirl about.

Since the chaos of the Eastern Jin’s collapse and the frequent disturbances along the Jiangnan region, within a hundred *li* of the Perfected Lord’s abode, bandits dared not intrude. The villages knew peace, harvests were bountiful year after year, and the people suffered no calamities. Such blessings showered upon the living, yet none knew their source.

In the second year of Ningkang of Emperor Xiaowu (the *jiaxu* year), the Perfected Lord was one hundred and thirty-six years old. On the first day of the eighth month, a cloud-borne procession descended from heaven. Two immortals, accompanied by a grand retinue, alighted in the Perfected Lord’s courtyard. The Perfected Lord descended the steps to receive them with bows. The two immortals said, "By the Jade Emperor’s decree, we present you with an edict." The Perfected Lord prostrated himself to listen as the edict was proclaimed:

*"The Supreme Edict to the Immortal Student Xu Sun: In countless kalpas past, you have assiduously cultivated the supreme Dao, enduring hardships and mastering its profound intricacies. Of the myriad methods and thousand gates, none have you not studied. You have rescued the distressed, delivered the imperiled, eradicated harm, and vanquished demons—your merits have succored the living, and your name is exalted in the Jade Register. The host of immortals reveres you; it is fitting you be elevated. You are hereby appointed the Celestial Historian of the Nine Provinces and Grand Illuminator, bestowed with a purple feathered robe, a jade banner, a sacred staff, an elixir of jade nectar, and a pill of golden cinnabar. Receive and execute this decree."*

The Perfected Lord bowed twice, ascended the steps, and accepted the edict. One immortal said, "I am Cui Ziwen, the Jade True Lord." The other said, "I am Xiaqiu Zhong, the Primordial True Minister." Having spoken, they invited the Perfected Lord to sit and informed him of the day of his ascension. Then they departed in a cloud chariot.

The Perfected Lord summoned his disciples and the village elders to announce his departure. Thereafter, he gathered with them day and night at his residence, hosting feasts and cherishing their parting moments. He instructed them in the principles of performing good deeds and accumulating merit to attain the Dao of immortality. He composed works such as the *Book of the Spirit Sword* and, for each of his eleven disciples, wrote ten five-line poems of admonition in couplets to bequeath to the world. He also transmitted the formula for the *"Great Merit Wish-Fulfilling Elixir"* to those disciples who would not ascend with him—a formula also found among Ding Yi’s divine prescriptions. The method required first selecting an auspicious day, observing purification rites, and setting up an altar to invoke the spirits of the eighteen medicinal ingredients. Only then were talismans inscribed, incantations recited for each ingredient, and the elixir compounded. It cured all manner of ailments as desired.

On the fifteenth of the month, he held a grand feast, inviting all the villagers, young and old, to gather. At midday, music was heard from afar, and auspicious clouds filled the sky, gradually approaching the assembly. A dragon-drawn chariot with a feathered canopy arrived, flanked by attendants, celestial youths, and maidens in colorful attire, with red auroras and purple vapors spreading all around. The two envoys arrived again, and the Perfected Lord descended the steps to receive them. The two immortals once more proclaimed an edict:

*"The Supreme Edict to the Immortal Student Xu Sun: Your past-life sins of greed, killing, and neglecting ancestral rites are absolved. Your present-life merits in chanting spells, wielding talismans, healing the sick, and punishing evil with potent toxins are recorded. The Controller of Life of Mount Qian has been commanded to transmit the golden elixir to the mortal realm. Your debts are sealed, your form concealed; your body, household, and all possessions are to return to the Three Heavens. Hasten to purify yourself. Ascend through the earth, soaring aloft. The Celestial Ding of Great Power on your left, with the Flowing Gold Fire Bell, shall illuminate and protect the Central Yellow. Let none be negligent. Upon your departure, your remote ancestor You is appointed Attendant of the Jade Void; your great-grandfather Ying, Grand Guardian of the Grand Tenuity; your grandfather Yu, Registrar of the Supreme Ultimate; your father Su, Immortal Official of the Central Marchmount. Your residence is named the Left Mansion of the Immortal Court."*

The Jade True Lord said, "Though your disciples are many, only six may accompany you. The rest shall each have their own day of ascension and may not join you." He then bowed to the Perfected Lord.

The Perfected Lord mounted the dragon chariot, with Chen Xun and Shi He bearing the registers in the lead, Zhou Guang and Zeng Heng driving, Huang Renlan and his clan following, and Xu Lie with his mother and a retinue of forty-two immortal kin ascending together. Even their parrot and dog soared after them. The villagers, clinging in sorrow, threw themselves to the ground in lamentation, unable to bear the parting. The Perfected Lord said, "Our paths diverge, and grief is natural. Uphold filial piety and benevolence, revere Heaven and Earth—what cause is there to fear no reward?" He left behind a meditation bell and a stone casket, saying, "As the world changes and times shift, this shall serve as a sign for future ages."

A servant named Xu Da, who had gone with his wife to buy rice at West Ridge, heard that the Perfected Lord was about to ascend. He rushed back in haste.

In their haste, the cart overturned, scattering rice upon the ground—where it took root and sprouted, giving the place its present names: Overturned Cart Ridge and Sprouted Rice Town. By the time Xu Da arrived, he wept and begged to follow. The Perfected Lord, seeing that his destiny did not yet align with immortality, taught him the arts of an earthbound immortal, and he and his wife both withdrew into seclusion on West Mountain (for details, see *The Biography of Xu Da*).

Once the immortal procession had ascended, a mortar and pestle soon fell from the sky, along with a wheel hub, while a parrot’s cage plummeted ten *li* southeast of the residence—now called Parrot Perch Ridge, today the site of Chongyuan Abbey. Several mice also fell to the ground, their entrails dragging yet still alive, for they had once stolen and eaten the immortal elixir. Later, those who glimpsed them took it as an auspicious omen.

As the immortal chariot soared into the heavens, it vanished from sight, leaving only auspicious clouds and rosy mists filling the mountains and valleys. For a hundred *li* around, an extraordinary fragrance lingered, unwaning for a month.

Earlier, when the Perfected Lord had returned from Jingyang, he presented a bolt of Shu brocade as a token of sincerity to Mistress Chen. She fashioned it into a temple curtain. On the day of his ascension, it suddenly flew back, circling above his former residence for an entire day before vanishing into the clouds. Later, when the abbey was built, it was named *Wandering Curtain* in commemoration.

Long before, the Perfected Lord and Guo Pu had sought the Dao and chosen scenic sites, arriving at Bingwu Mountain in Yichun, where Wang Shu, son of the Prefectural Governor, welcomed them to stay in the West Pavilion. After some time, the Perfected Lord told Shu, "I see that you are fit to inherit my arts." He secretly imparted the immortal formulas, then added, "This place boasts elegant mountains and rivers, with a sacred spring flowing south of the path, a grotto-heaven before it, and the Yuan River below—it is well-suited for a Daoist sanctuary." Shu followed his advice. The Perfected Lord inscribed a celestial seal—the character *jing*—upon the wall before departing.

On the day of his ascension, a cloud-drawn plow passed overhead. Two azure-clad attendants descended to inform Shu: "We have been summoned by the Jade Emperor’s decree and come now to bid you farewell." Shu and his entire household gazed upward in reverence, praying for deliverance. The Perfected Lord leaned down and said, "Your immortal bones are not yet fully tempered, but you may prolong your years." He then bestowed a single stalk of celestial thatch, saying, "This thatch has a rare flavor. Planted here and consumed over time, it grants longevity. Its sweetness nourishes the flesh, its pungency the joints, its bitterness the *qi*, its saltiness the bones, its slipperiness the skin, and its sourness the sinews. Blend it with bitter wine and drink—it will surely prove effective." With these words, he took his leave.

Following their counsel, the Wang clan consumed the elixir as prescribed, each attaining a lifespan of a century. Today, the Jade Void Abbey in Linjiang Prefecture stands upon this very site, where the immortal thatch still endures.

Of the more than three hundred who accompanied the Perfected Lord in his wanderings, eleven—including Master Tonghao—distinguished themselves through merit and conduct. After the Perfected Lord’s ascension, the villagers and Jian, a descendant of his clan, established a shrine upon the spot. There, they inscribed the one hundred and twenty poems he had left behind onto bamboo slips, which they placed within a great calabash. Visitors would draw these slips to divine fortune or misfortune, calling them the "Sacred Lots." His bell, carriage, mortar, and pestle—all treasures—were enshrined within. Later, the shrine was expanded into an abbey and named *Youwei* ("Wandering Canopy") after the embroidered curtains that adorned it.

The people of Shu’s Jianyang Prefecture, eager to repay his virtue, competed to donate gold and silk, carrying bricks and tiles to rebuild the well in his honor. Each inscribed their names upon the bricks—though later, when the abbey was renovated, these were removed. A few remnants remain to this day.

During the reign of Emperor Yang of Sui, the rites fell into neglect, and the abbey soon fell into ruin. In the *Yongchun* era of Emperor Gaozong of Tang, Celestial Master Hu Huichao revived its construction. Emperor Minghuang of Tang later bestowed particular reverence upon it. Emperors Taizong, Zhenzong, and Renzong of Song each presented calligraphic gifts, while Zhenzong further dispatched envoys bearing incense, candles, floral offerings, ritual banners, and dancing effigies. He renamed the abbey *Yulong* ("Jade Exaltation"), drawing from the *Scripture of Salvation*: *"The Great Release, the Jade Exaltation, Soars Victorious to Heaven."* He also forbade logging in the sacred mountains and exempted the land from taxes and corvée labor. An official was appointed to oversee the abbey, designating it a place of honor for venerable ministers.

Emperor Huizong later conferred a jade tablet and an exalted title, with the prayer text for the offering rite reading:

*"In the second year of Zhenghe, the cyclical year *renchen*, the fifth month, the *dingsi* day of the new moon, the seventeenth day, *guiyou*, the Emperor, in his sacred name, respectfully dispatches Cheng Qi of the Inner Court’s Palace Domestic Service to invite twenty-one Daoist priests to conduct a seven-day ritual at Hongzhou’s Jade Exaltation Abbey. Upon its conclusion, a grand offering of one altar and three hundred sixty divine stations shall be established. We humbly invoke the Perfected Lord of Wondrous Aid and Divine Merit: Though the utmost spirit defies form and eludes naming, its accomplished virtue resides in humanity. Thus, we follow the signs you have shown, honoring and exalting your traces. We now offer this first tribute of reverent praise, praying that you deign to accept our devotion and forever bless this sacred land."*

The undersigned, with utmost reverence and trepidation, prostrates in earnest supplication. Humbly submitting these words:

The sacred scripture and proclamation bestowed by Your Imperial Majesty for the Perfected Lord have been reverently received. We, your servant, now invoke the exalted Perfected Ones, inaugurating the display of their manifest traces. Gazing toward the celestial vault above, we present our devotion within this numinous sanctuary. As the blessings of bounty descend, the people’s fortune shines resplendent. May these graces extend further, prolonging the splendor of this reign. Your servant, with unwavering sincerity and fervent devotion, prostrates in utmost reverence.

We respectfully present this memorial to make known our plea.

Your servant, with profound awe and trepidation, bows his head and speaks with utmost sincerity.

The text of the jade scripture reads:

In the second year of Zhenghe, the year *renchen*, the fifth month, the *dingsi* day of the new moon, the seventeenth day, *guiyou*, the Emperor again bows and declares:

Heaven’s favor is abundant, bestowing grace upon the four directions. There exists a Perfected One, who assists the Supreme Emperor, wielding awe-inspiring virtue and power, granting prosperity and peace. Yet without a proclaimed name and title, how can the rites of reverence be fully manifested? Thus, We command the relevant offices to examine the secret registers, to expound upon the hidden virtues, and to transmit them for endless generations.

We reflect upon the Perfected Lord, who personally grasps the primordial chart, secretly aligning with the wondrous Dao. From the Wei to the Jin dynasties, his illustrious spirit has shone brilliantly. He relieves the destitute and heals the afflicted, upon whom an entire region relies. He vanquishes malevolent forces and poisons, harmonizing the three qi. Thus, he received the celestial mandate, his name inscribed in the registers of the capital’s immortals. Ascending beyond the highest realms, his legacy endures through the ages. His temple image stands majestic, his virtuous influence as if still present. Like the radiant sun, his glory shines, aligning with the flourishing of the imperial destiny. Auspicious omens descend, revealing his hidden assistance. Through prayers and exorcisms, his responses echo, bringing abundance and peace to the people.

It is fitting to bestow upon him the most exalted title, to manifest our solemn reverence.

We respectfully dispatch Wang Jian, Gentleman for Court Service, Compiler of the Jixian Hall, Administrator of Hongzhou’s Military and Civil Affairs, Concurrent Commissioner of Agriculture for the Region, Concurrent Military Commissioner of the Jiangnan West Circuit, Defender-in-Chief, and recipient of the Purple Gold Fish Bag, to confer the honorific title: *Perfected Lord of Wondrous Aid and Divine Merit*.

May the Perfected Lord deign to witness this, graciously accepting this grand decree, granting us boundless protection and preserving this glorious mandate. May he bring radiant harmony to the realm and bestow blessings upon all people.

Respectfully submitted.

In the sixth year of the Zhenghe reign, the temple was elevated to the status of a palace.

The Perfected Lord’s numinous efficacy and manifest proofs have been manifold. Having repeatedly received imperial favor, the details of these events are recorded in the *Records of the Xiaoyao Mountain Yulong Wanshou Palace*. Your servant Daoyi states:

The Grand Scribe Xu renounced official glory to devote himself to the Daoist arts. To succor the people, he employed talismanic water and incantations; to eliminate harm, he slew dragons and serpents. His merits complete and his practice perfected, he ascended to the ranks of immortality. Yet among his village and kin, he was known for his filial piety and fraternal love, while his companions admired his virtue and righteousness. Adapting to circumstances and responding to all things, he differed not from ordinary men—save that where he dwelled, cranes would cry and soar, and auspicious clouds would spiral about.

In his official career, his governance was worthy of note; in his reclusion, he cultivated the elixir within while blending with the world without. Truly, he was a hero among divine immortals.

The *Daodejing* says: "The Dao is empty, yet its use is inexhaustible. Profound! It seems the ancestor of the myriad things. Blunting its sharpness, unraveling its tangles, harmonizing its brilliance, uniting with the dust. Submerged, it seems to endure. I know not whose child it is—it appears before the Lord on High."

The Grand Scribe Xu attained this.

*Comprehensive Mirror of Perfected Immortals Who Embodied the Dao Through the Ages*, Scroll Twenty-Six (conclusion)
*Comprehensive Mirror of Perfected Immortals Who Embodied the Dao Through the Ages*, Scroll Twenty-Seven

Wu Meng, styled Shiyun, was a native of Puyang. He served as Magistrate of Xi’an in Wu, and later settled there—this is present-day Fennin County. His nature was supremely filial: in his youth, during summer months, he would not drive away mosquitoes, fearing they might leave him only to bite his parents. At forty, he received esoteric formulas from the perfected one Ding Yi, and later studied under Bao Shuo, Prefect of Nanhai, from whom he obtained secret methods. During the Huanglong era of Wu, heaven descended a white-cloud talisman to him, and he thereafter widely propagated his arts of the Dao throughout Wu and Jin.

During the reign of Emperor Wu of Jin, the Perfected Lord Xu received transmission of the teachings from Shiyun, who imparted all his secret essentials to him. At the end of the Yongjia era, Du Qiang rebelled in Shu, overrunning its prefectures and counties. After the Perfected Lord had slain the great serpent, Shiyun said, “The serpent was the spirit of Shu; with its death, Du Qiang will perish.” And so it came to pass.

Once, as a violent gale arose, he inscribed a talisman and cast it onto the roof. A green bird carried it away, and the wind immediately ceased.
