When asked the reason, he replied, “On South Lake, a boat was caught in this storm, and two Daoist priests cried out to heaven for deliverance. Thus I halted it.” Investigation confirmed his words.

When Magistrate Yu Qing of Xi’an died and had lain three days, Shiyun said, “The magistrate’s allotted years are not yet spent; I shall plead his case before heaven.” He then performed rites beside the corpse, and after several days, both he and Qing arose together. Yu Qing’s younger brother, the Gentleman of Writing Bao, moved by this marvel, composed the *Soushen Ji*, which circulated in the world.

Once, while crossing the Yuzhang River, he encountered wind and waves that left no boat serviceable. Shiyun drew upon the water with his white feather fan and crossed over, to the astonishment of onlookers.

The *Book of Jin* states: Wu Meng was a native of Yuzhang. From youth, he was filial, never driving away mosquitoes in summer, lest they leave him to bite his parents. At forty, the villager Ding Yi first transmitted to him esoteric formulas. Returning to Yuzhang, where the river’s currents ran swift and deep, Meng crossed without boat or oar, drawing upon the water with a white feather fan, to the wonder of all who saw.

In the second year of Ningkang of Emperor Xiaowu of Jin, the Perfected Lord ascended. Shiyun then returned to Xi’an. On the fifteenth day of the tenth month that year, the Celestial Thearch commanded the Perfected Zhou Guang to bear an edict summoning Shiyun. He then mounted a white-deer carriage and, with four disciples, ascended in broad daylight. His abode was named the Purple Cloud Palace—now the Wu Immortal Temple of Peaceful Repose in Wu Immortal Village, Fennin County.

In the second year of Zhenghe of Emperor Huizong of Song, by imperial decree he was enfeoffed as Perfected Immortal. The edict read: “In the blessed land of Hongdu, among the perfected of the Purple Palace, your numinous wonders are renowned—how could honors be withheld? You early pursued the supreme Dao, awakened to secret words, and spread transformative teachings, earning the world’s name of ‘Compassionate Father.’ With merits complete, you ascended to the celestial realm.”

To the west of the Great River, his former abode still stands, where every prayer meets response, and our people find refuge. Bestowing this new enfeoffment serves to manifest his illustrious virtue. Our decree is just, and may it be witnessed herewith. Let him be specially enfeoffed as Perfected Immortal of Divine Might.

Chen Xun
Chen Xun, styled Xiaoju, was a native of Shu. Learned and widely informed, he lived when Wei dispatched Zhong Hui and Deng Ai to conquer Shu, and Liu Shan surrendered. Though still young, Xiaoju already harbored aspirations beyond the dusty world. He entered Mount Qingcheng and sought the method of transcending the world from Master Gu Yuanzǐ. Later, hearing of Perfected Xu’s benevolent governance in Jingyang, he hastened to the public court, wishing to serve as a scribe. Perfected Xu commended him and entrusted him with clerical duties. In leading his peers, transforming local customs, and practicing the art of nurturing the people, he contributed greatly. Thus, he was drawn into the master’s inner circle as a disciple and confidant. He oversaw the scriptures and guarded the alchemical furnace. When Perfected Xu ascended, he was commanded to hold the reins and lead the way. Formerly, to the west of Yulong Palace in Xima stood Xiaoju’s hermitage, named the Mansion of Inheriting Immortality, where he planted a great cypress. The hermitage faced north. In the second year of Zhenghe of Emperor Huizong of Song, he was enfeoffed as Perfected Immortal of Upright Distinction. The edict read in part: “For you early devoted yourself with sincerity, serving the Dao Lord as your master. Among his disciples, you alone were entrusted with the arcane mysteries. With merits complete, you ascended bearing the banner. To the west of the Great River, your legacy endures, akin to the edict of Perfected Wu.”

Zhou Guang
Zhou Guang, styled Huichang, was a native of Luling and a descendant of the great general Zhou Yu. From youth, he delighted in the study of astronomy and music; in maturity, he mastered the teachings of primordial purity and stillness. Once, while traveling with like-minded companions in Mount Yuntai of Bashu, he obtained the Han Celestial Master’s method for expelling noxious qi and malevolent spirits, thereby relieving the people’s suffering. Hearing of Perfected Xu’s presence in Jingyang, he journeyed directly to the public court, wishing to serve in a humble capacity. Perfected Xu accepted him and assigned him to attend to his staff and sandals. Diligent day and night, he practiced the Daoist methods without cease. Upon returning to his private residence, he remained ever obedient. Then, a hundred paces west of his home, he built a chamber to dwell in.

When Perfected Xu ascended in flight, Hui-chang and Zeng Xingguo together harnessed the dragon carriage. His residence was named the Xuan Zhao Palace. During the Tai-zhong reign of the Tang, the prefectural governor Zhou, styled Lord Shaozhen, honored him as an ancestor and renovated his dwelling, renaming it the Xuan Zhao Palace. The stele inscription remains extant; today it is called the Tai Xu Abbey. In the second year of Zhenghe of Emperor Huizong of the Song, he was enfeoffed as Perfected Yuan Tong. The decree read in part: "For you early aligned with the mountain’s embrace, serving the immortal lord as master. Your primordial transformation communicated with the divine, enabling you to attain the Dao. With meritorious practice now complete, you ascend together to the imperial realm. West of the great river, your former precincts stand solemn, their beginning and end echoing the decree of Lord Hao."

Zeng Heng
Zeng Heng, styled Xingguo, was a native of Sishui and a descendant of Zeng Can. From youth he was a Daoist, endowed with keen intelligence and broad learning. He cultivated the teachings of the Three Celestial Masters and could foresee future events. Every path through the famed mountains and sacred peaks lay open to him. His wondrous formulas and efficacious talismans cured all ailments without fail. The divine man Sun Deng, upon seeing him, declared: "Your bones are refined, your spirit astute; through diligent tempering of your essence, you shall surely become a being beyond the heavens. Strive onward." Later, he withdrew to reside in Fengcheng of Yuzhang. Hearing of Perfected Xu’s renown, he presented himself at his gate, wishing to attend to his towels and desk. Perfected Xu esteemed him greatly, transmitting to him without reserve all esoteric methods and secret formulas. Later, he too ascended to heaven in a dragon carriage. Today, the Zhen Yang Abbey in Fengcheng County marks his former abode. In the second year of Zhenghe of Emperor Huizong of the Song, he was enfeoffed as Perfected Shen Hui. The decree read in part: "For your refined bones and divine intelligence, your heaven-endowed exceptional bearing, serving the immortal lord as master, you harmonized elegantly with the Dao. With meritorious practice now complete, you journey together to the imperial realm. West of the great river, your altars and wells remain, their beginning and end echoing the decree of Lord Hao."

Shi He
Shi He, styled Daoyang, was a native of Julu.

In his youth, he became a Daoist and entered the Four Bright Mountains, where he encountered a divine being who taught him the arts of embryonic breathing and myriad wondrous techniques. Through these, he could dispel sleep and abstain from grain, command ghosts and spirits, expel malevolent specters, transmute gold and jade, and relieve the impoverished. The people received his beneficence, and his fame spread far and near.

During the reigns of Emperors Hui and Huai, hearing of Perfected Xu’s filial piety and the flourishing of his teachings east of the Yangtze, Shi He journeyed on foot to his door, wishing to become his disciple. Perfected Xu accepted him and transmitted secret formulas. Later, he sent Shi He back to the mountains to instruct his followers. Emperor Ming of the Jin summoned him to court, but when the master questioned him, Shi He steadfastly refused to remain. He ultimately returned to attend by Perfected Xu’s side.

In the second year of Emperor Xiaowu’s Ningkang era, he ascended to heaven in the company of Chen Xiaoju, bearing the imperial册 and leading the procession. His former abode in Yuzhang City was named the Purple Canopy Palace, now the county hall of Nanchang. The Fengxian Abbey in Muyang County of Donghai marks his earlier retreat.

In the second year of the Song’s Zhenghe era, he was enfeoffed as Perfected Hong Shi. The decree read in part: "For your lineage from Donghai, long esteemed as a family of immortals, you found your own master and attained the grand model. Preceding the dragon standards, you ascended together. West of the great river, your former residence remains, its beginning and end echoing the decree of Lord Hao."

Gan Zhan
Gan Zhan, styled Bowu, was a native of Fengcheng.

For his filial piety, he was esteemed among his village and kin. Amidst the chaos of the age, he concealed himself in the wilds and marshes, drawn to the arts of divine transcendence and long life. Hearing of Perfected Xu’s practice of filial virtue and the Daoist arts—eradicating harm and benefiting all beings—he journeyed to his gate and earnestly entreated, wishing to serve as his attendant. Perfected Xu, recognizing his exceptional talent and bearing, granted his request. When Perfected Xu ascended, he further entrusted him with the secret formulas of the Golden Elixir.

Later, Bowu returned to Fengcheng, where he spread virtue and bestowed kindness. In the first year of Emperor Xuān’s Dajian era, on the seventh day of the first month at noon, a celestial decree descended, and he mounted a qilin-drawn carriage, riding the clouds away. The present Qingdu Abbey in the county marks the site where he once concealed his elixir. His former residence, named Huayang Pavilion, has the Feihuang Abbey dedicated to his veneration.

In the second year of Emperor Huizong’s Zhenghe era, he was enfeoffed as Perfected Jingxing. The decree read in part: "From your youth, you devoted yourself to the Daoist teachings; in maturity, you served the Immortal Lord. Driving out demons and dispelling evil, your merits were abundant. With consummate conduct, you ascended to wander in the imperial realm. West of the great river, your former residence remains, its beginning and end echoing the decree of Lord Hao."

Shi Cen
Shi Cen, styled Taiyu, was a native of Pei Commandery. His grandfather, Shi Shuo, had served in Wu and thus relocated to Chiyu County in Jiujiang. Taiyu possessed a commanding and heroic appearance, unmatched strength and valor, and excelled in archery and swordsmanship. When Perfected Xu first led his disciples to slay the great serpent of Haihun, over three hundred stalwarts from the village arrived to assist, and Taiyu was among them. He presented himself with reverence and sincerity, offering to serve. Perfected Xu accepted him, and he, along with Gan Bowu, often stood wielding swords at his side.

On the morning of the twenty-eighth day of the tenth month in the second year of Ningkang of Emperor Xiaowu of Jin, a youth was seen in the eastern sunrise, riding upon multicolored clouds, holding a white staff, and driving a green ox, descending to his dwelling. He proclaimed the Jade Emperor’s decree, then ascended upon a green rainbow and rode the clouds away. Two *li* southeast of Perfected Xu’s residence stood an altar called the Purple Jade Palace—this was the place where he had dwelled. On the western ridge, by the riverbank, a stone bore an inscription reading "Utmost Virtue," which served as Taiyu’s watchtower. A similar site existed in Nanchang, both used to observe water demons. Later, the Tang immortal Shi Jianwu retreated here to fish, and the place thus became known as the Fishing Terrace. In the second year of Zhenghe of Emperor Huizong of Song, Taiyu was enfeoffed as the Perfected of Courageous Awakening. The edict read in part: "By your nature brave and awakened, you received the master’s transmission of the profound teaching, enabling you to enter the inner chamber. A divine youth revealed the wondrous, and you ascended to the imperial realm. West of the great river, your former residence remains, its beginning and end echoing the decree of Lord Hao."

Peng Kang
Peng Kang, styled Wuyang, was a native of Lanling.

Peng Kang was nominated as Filial and Incorrupt and served the Jin, rising through the ranks to become Left Assistant Director of the Imperial Secretariat. He diligently cultivated the Daoist arts and resigned from court due to illness. He became a disciple of the Perfected Lord Xu, and his beloved daughter was betrothed to the Perfected Lord’s son—though the old claim that Peng’s daughter became the Perfected Lord’s consort is mistaken. The elders referred to her as the Perfected Lord’s daughter-in-law, which is correct. When the Perfected Lord, during the final years of Emperor Huai’s Yongjia era, transformed a charcoal-seller’s wife and executed the serpent, Peng Kang was already in office, seventy-six years of age—how could he have taken a wife at that time? It is often said that the Perfected Lord’s consort was Lady Zhou. Upon examining the *Eulogy on Filial Piety*, one finds a brilliant piece titled "Lady Historian Zhou’s Reply to Her Mother-in-Law of Xuyi," which may well be the consort’s humble self-designation as "Lady Historian." The *New Canon of Scriptures* mistakenly calls her the "Holy Mother." Moved by Peng Kang’s reverent sincerity, the Perfected Lord entrusted him with all the essential secrets in their finest detail and promptly sent him back to court.

In the second year of Emperor Mu’s Yonghe era, Peng Kang retired from office and journeyed south, bringing his family to reside in Yuzhang’s city. He returned to the Perfected Lord’s gate, inquiring morning and evening, and his mastery of the Dao grew ever more refined.

In the second year of Emperor Gaozu’s Yongchu era of the Liu Song dynasty, the *Record of Administrative Geography* dated the event to the twenty-fourth day of the eighth month in the second year of the Yixi era, when Peng Kang and his entire household of twenty-six ascended to heaven in broad daylight. The present Zonghua Abbey in the capital is the site of this ascension.

In the second year of Emperor Huizong’s Zhenghe era of the Song dynasty, Peng Kang was enfeoffed as Perfected Person of Latent Benevolence. The imperial edict read in part: "For you renounced fame and forsake profit, cultivating in seclusion and refining within. You exhausted your sincerity in serving your master and were entrusted with the essential secrets. As your merit and practice neared completion, you ascended to the celestial realm. West of the Great River, your former residence still stands, where the immortal’s chamber and sacred altar remain in solemn array, as recorded in the imperial edict for Master Hao of Junzhuo."

Xu Lie
Xu Lie, styled Daowei, was a native of Nanchang. Orphaned in youth, he served his mother with such filial devotion that it became widely known. His mother was in fact the elder sister of the Perfected Lord. The Perfected Lord had two sisters, and Xu’s mother was the eldest. As the *Record of Enduring Love* states: "Xu Junlie and Zhongli Junjia of Nanchang were nephews of Lord Xu." Thus, it is certain that Xu’s mother was the Perfected Lord’s sister. Seeing her widowed state, the Perfected Lord built a chamber for her several dozen paces west of his residence, where she and her son could daily hear the wondrous Dao. Whenever the Perfected Lord went out, Xu’s mother would manage his household affairs, and all immortal guests and reclusive visitors were received by her. As Celestial Master Hu Shi’s eulogy says: "I once came here," indicating he was a guest of Xu’s mother. Both mother and son received a decree from the Jade Emperor, and with their celestial retinue, they ascended to heaven. The Daoist abbey west of the wall is their former residence, now called the Mansion of Harmonious Rites.

In the second year of Emperor Huizong’s Zhenghe era, Xu Lie was enfeoffed as Perfected Person of Harmonious Tranquility. The imperial edict read in part: "For you studied the Perfected Lord’s Dao and awakened to the source of the Five Refinements. Your nature was serene and harmonious, moving in accord with the great transformation. In the end, you ascended to the celestial realm with your mother. West of the Great River, your former residence still stands, as recorded in the imperial edict for Master Hao of Junzhuo."

Zhongli Jia
Zhongli Jia, styled Gongyang and also Chaomu, was a native of Nanchang and the son of the Perfected Lord’s second sister. Orphaned in youth, his nature was simple and indifferent. The Perfected Lord once sighed that he possessed the capacity to receive the Dao, and so entrusted him with divine formulas to save and succor, and wondrous instructions to command and expel. When the Perfected Lord ascended to heaven, he first bestowed upon Zhongli Jia the gift of golden elixir. On the fifteenth day of the tenth month of that year, a jade carriage of azure radiance descended from heaven to welcome him. Gongyang bowed to the celestial music, mounted the carriage, and departed.

His former residence was at Xiyuan in Xiangyashan of Xinjian. There stands an abbey called Danling, where a stone mortar for alchemical drugs remains, now known as the Jade Mansion of Zhong. In the second year of Emperor Huizong’s Zhenghe era, Zhongli Jia was enfeoffed as Perfected Person of Universal Benevolence. The imperial edict read in part: "For you upheld the arts of refinement and cultivation, and excelled in the skills of talismans and prohibitions. Your universal benevolence extended near and far, and your merit and practice shone brightly. The Perfected Lord entrusted you with his instructions, and you ascended to wander in the celestial realm. West of the Great River, your former residence still stands, as recorded in the imperial edict for Master Hao of Junzhuo."

Huang Renlan
Huang Renlan, styled Ziting, was a native of Gao’an. His father, Huang Fu, styled Wanshi, was recommended as a Filial and Incorruptible Scholar and served as a censor. Ziting was of striking and elegant appearance, with a bearing both composed and far-reaching. The Perfected Lord gave his daughter to him in marriage, and Huang Renlan fully attained the Perfected Lord’s Dao. When he took office as an attendant in Qingzhou, he left his wife to serve his parents. Yet every night, he would return home, unbeknownst to others.

One evening, a servant reported that voices and laughter had been heard in the Lady Xu’s courtyard at night. His mother-in-law questioned her, and Lady Xu replied, "It was Huang Lang." His mother-in-law said, "My son is serving in office thousands of *li* away. How could he be here?" Lady Xu said, "He has already attained the immortal Dao and can traverse a thousand *li* in an instant. He warned me not to speak of it, so I dared not let you know." His mother-in-law said, "If that is so, let me see him."

That night, when Ziting returned, Lady Xu told him what had transpired. By dawn, Ziting had no choice but to present himself to his parents, saying, "Though Renlan serves in a distant office, he returns secretly every night to attend you. The immortal Dao is secret and must not be spoken of, lest it bring calamity and trouble." Having spoken, he took a bamboo staff and transformed it into a green dragon, mounting it to depart.

Thereafter, Wanshi also came to know and admire the immortal Dao, and he served the Perfected Lord with the rites of a disciple. However, Ziting’s two younger brothers were bold and unrestrained, spending their days hunting. Though their father and brother received the imperial decree and ascended in flight, the two remained at their hunting grounds. They declared that their natures were too unruly for immortality, and begged to be allowed to continue hunting deer while their elder brother’s entire clan soared away. Ziting sighed at their allotted fate and transformed a blade of grass into a deer to curb their reckless hearts.

Then, with his parents and a household of thirty-two, he rode the clouds eastward, following the Perfected Lord’s immortal procession to ascend to heaven. The two younger brothers later concealed themselves on West Mountain—now the Fangang Temple, where they are popularly called the Fourth and Fifth Lords of the Huang Clan.

After the immortal procession departed, a stone ball and a mortar for alchemical drugs fell from the clouds at Xiangfu Abbey in Gao’an County of Ruizhou. This was once the Abbey of Prayers to the Immortals, and Huang Renlan’s former residence. Nearby lies the Isle of Lady Xu’s Fallen Hairpin.

In the second year of Emperor Huizong’s Zhenghe era, Huang Renlan was enfeoffed as Perfected Person of Penetrating the Dao. The imperial edict read in part: "For you held to the arts of refinement and cultivation, and your virtue and power extended universally. Your merit and practice were illustrious. The Perfected Lord entrusted you with his instructions, and you ascended to wander in the celestial realm. West of the Great River, your former residence still stands."

The edict continued in part: "As you inherited the blessings of Chuping, you were endowed with extraordinary gifts. You served the Dao Lord as your master, mastering the most profound mysteries. No sooner had your merit and practice reached fulfillment than you ascended to wander in the imperial realm. West of the Great River, your former residence still stands, its beginning and end alike recorded in the imperial decrees of the House of Hao.

Renlan’s father, Fu, also sought to become a disciple of the Perfected Lord. The Perfected Lord, considering him a kinsman of honor, treated him with the courtesy due a guest, and thus he was not counted among the eleven disciples. All the disciples who received the teachings were permitted to transmit them to their clans. Altars and oratories were established, each bearing the names of *fu* and *ting*. The great ritual of the teaching states: the *fu* is the lesser ritual, the *ting* the greater. In practicing the Dao and its methods, they are named according to the number of participants.

Long ago, there was an extraordinary person named Lan Qi, whose given name none dared speak, and so he was called Master Lan. He first resided in Jiuyuan Village of Gaoping Township, Qufu County in Yanzhou. His family of over a hundred members cultivated filial piety with utmost devotion, prompting a Perfected One from the Dipper to descend into their home. He called himself the Filial and Fraternal King, with the taboo name Hongkang and the style Bozhong. He said to Master Lan: 'The primordial *qi* is the Great Dao. In the sun, it becomes the Dao of Filial Piety; the primordial *qi* of the Immortal Kings is the Supreme Dao. In the moon, it becomes the Filial Dao Radiant King; the mysterious *qi* is the Dao of Filial Piety. In the Dipper, it becomes the Filial and Fraternal King. When filial piety reaches heaven, the sun and moon shine brightly. When it reaches earth, the myriad things are born. When it reaches the people, the kingly Way is accomplished. From the Upper Clarity downward, I have manifested in the human realm to expound the teaching of filial piety. In later generations of the Jin dynasty, there will be a true immortal, Xu Xun, who will transmit the lineage of my filial Dao and become the leader of all immortals.'

Thereupon, he bestowed upon Master Lan secret instructions, the *Precious Canon of the Golden Elixir*, and bronze talismans and iron charters, commanding him to transmit them to the female Perfected Chen Mu of Huangtang Oratory in Danyang. He further admonished him: 'In the future, when the aspiring immortal Xu Xun appears, you must transmit these to him.'

The Filial and Fraternal King then led Master Lan to wander in the outskirts. By the roadside, three ancient tombs suddenly appeared. Pointing to them, he said to Master Lan: 'These are the traces of your three past lives’ transformations. The first tomb holds the immortal remains you left behind after liberation in the corpse. The second tomb is where you refined your form in the Great Yin; your body is now complete and will soon rise. The third tomb contains only your discarded bones. You should move it away from the roadside to prevent people and animals from treading upon it.' Having spoken, the Filial and Fraternal King ascended to heaven.

Master Lan then posted a notice to travelers, blocking the old path. People called him deluded and reckless for altering the road, and they seized him to bring before the authorities. The officials detained him and demanded proof of his claims. Master Lan recounted the previous events in full. The officials said: 'If your words are false, you will be executed.' Master Lan replied: 'My words come from the Filial and Fraternal King—how could they be false?'

The officials then led Master Lan to the site to open the tombs in their presence. The first tomb indeed contained a yellow robe. The second revealed a person with the complexion of a child and a delicate frame, as if just awakened from sleep. The third held a set of interconnected bones. The crowd was astonished, and the officials took the robe to present to the prefect. The prefect tried to wear it, but it was too large for him, so he returned it to Master Lan. When Master Lan donned it, he merged with the person from the tomb, his body refined and light, ready to ascend.

The officials, filled with remorse, prostrated themselves and earnestly asked when he would descend to the human realm again. Master Lan leaned down and said: 'From now on, I may descend every ten days or every hundred days to propagate the Dao of Filial Piety and aid those lost on the path.' Thereafter, in the capital of Wu, a fifteen-year-old youth appeared, and in Danyang, a three-year-old divine child—both were incarnations of true immortals, come to propagate the teaching of filial piety and transmit it to those destined for transcendence.

Your servant Daoyi says: Lan Qi cultivated the truth across lifetimes, his mind never straying from the Dao. His devotion moved a Perfected One from the Dipper to descend and expound the Dao of Filial Piety, opening the way for future generations. Among those who attained the status of true immortals, none exemplified sincerity more than Lan Qi. Beholding the traces of his three lives’ transformations, one is vividly moved. As for the wondrous union of form and spirit, the refinement of the body, and the lightness of ascension—these were achieved through a single sincerity spanning four lifetimes. The Dao of immortality was ultimately perfected, how could this be the work of a single day’s merit and practice?

The *Daode Jing* says: 'One who does not lose their place endures. One who dies yet does not perish is long-lived.' Does this not speak of Lan Qi?

Xu [Xun] the Great..."

Xu Da was a servant in the retinue of the Perfected Lord. On the day the Perfected Lord ascended, Xu Da and his wife happened to be transporting rice to the market—now called West Ridge Market—when they heard of their master’s ascent. They overturned their rice cart and rushed home. By the time they arrived, the immortal procession had already departed. The couple beat their breasts and wailed, begging to follow. The Perfected Lord told them their merit was not yet complete and they were unfit for ascension, but he bestowed upon them the arts of earthbound immortality. The two then concealed themselves in the Western Mountains. The rice spilled from their overturned cart took root in the earth, and the place is now called Overturned Cart Ridge and Sprouted Rice Market. After going into seclusion, they wished to remain unknown and changed their surname to Wu. When this was discovered, they altered it again to Gan.

Both left poems for the world. Gan Jun’s poem reads:
*Since the Bright Prefect ascended to the heavens,*
*I have wandered the mortal realm to this day.*
*Not to hide my name and blend with the vulgar,*
*But selling firewood and buying wine, I forget worldly cares.*

His wife’s poem says:
*Drunk, I dance and sing amidst fallen blossoms,*
*My green silk skirt bears traces of cinnabar.*
*Coming and going through the city, I sell herbs—*
*Only these Western Mountains are my home.*

Another of her poems:
*Entering and leaving the immortal realm, I forget the seasons,*
*How could I know the world’s cold and warmth?*
*My home lies only within the Western Mountains—*
*None but white clouds ever reach my door.*

When Gan Jun traveled and did not return for some time, she walked alone to the altar platform and, moved by emotion, composed this verse:
*Yesterday I wandered to the emerald peaks,*
*Where altar bells chimed amid sparse apricot blossoms.*
*The green peach tree bore my message—*
*Why does no one return from the mortal world?*

When Xu and his wife heard the Perfected Lord was about to ascend, they desperately begged to accompany him. The Perfected Lord, bound by celestial decree, explained that the number of those permitted to ascend was already fixed and their request could not be granted. Thus, he had arranged for them to be away beforehand. Though they overturned their cart and hurried back, it was already too late. Even now, some claim to have seen them.

The *Records of Divine Investigations* states: In the Western Mountains of Hongzhou, there was a woodcutter who called himself Gan Da. None knew his true name. He would occasionally appear in the villages, greeting people with clasped hands but never speaking a word. If anyone tried to question him, he would bow and depart.

A young man once awaited his appearance and bowed to him, saying, "I wish to serve you, Master." Gan Da was startled and tried to leave, but the youth hastily grasped his coarse robe and followed him. Gan Da asked, "What do you want?" The youth replied, "I wish to serve you, Master," bowing repeatedly as they walked. They traversed perilous and desolate paths without pause. After some time, Gan Da sat by a mountain stream and asked, "Would you like some tea?" The youth assented. Gan Da then loosened his robe, took out tea powder, placed it in the youth’s palm, and instructed him to scoop water and swallow it. When the youth finished and looked up, Gan Da had vanished. He searched for the woodcutter’s path and emerged, finding himself in the territory of Fennin County. Several days later, he returned home. From then on, the youth felt light and vigorous, free from illness.

Master Celestial Hu Huichao, styled Basu, was of unknown origin. No one knew his age. During the *Shangyuan* era of Emperor Gaozong of Tang, he came from Mount Lu and settled at Hongjing in the Western Mountains of Yuzhang. Clad in a simple cloth headscarf and hempen robe, he walked barefoot, staff in hand.

Upon arriving at Youwei Abbey, he met his fellow Daoists, yet his hands held no ritual tablet—only a raised fist in greeting. His beard and brows were fine, his bearing majestic, resembling a man of some forty years. Though not exceptionally tall, whenever he stood among crowds, his head alone rose above the rest; even the tallest men reached only to his shoulders. Thus, the people of the time called him "Tall Immortal Hu." When asked his age, he would say, "Fifty-two years." Decades later, the same answer was given. Yet when he spoke of the rise and fall of dynasties since the Jin and Song, not a single detail was amiss. He delighted in discussing the writings of Jin Minister Zhang Hua, whose encyclopedic knowledge he matched as a friend might. Some said that Masters Xu and Wu had once taught him the arts of longevity, refinement, and transformation—the Way of the Three Primes and Nine Cycles—enabling him to summon spirits, command thunder, and summon rain.

When Tao Hongjing collated the *Seventy Scrolls of the Supreme Clarity Scripture* at Huayang Cave on Mount Mao, the Celestial Master likewise participated. His name was inscribed in vermilion on the seams of the scrolls, visible to all who beheld them. He once remarked, "When I first came here, I lodged with an old woman named Xu Mu—yet I know not from what age she hailed." Whenever he encountered exposed bones or abandoned remains by the roadside, he would bury them. Where ancient treasures or sacred vessels lay buried, excavation would yield them just as he had foretold. He despised malevolent spirits and monstrous beings as one would a bandit or hawk, and was swift to eradicate them.

At the time, a camphorwood spirit near the western gate of Yuzhang had become a one-legged deity, wreaking havoc with its sorcery and luring people into lewd sacrifices. The Celestial Master, upon seeing it, rebuked and cursed it, then inscribed a talisman to bind it. He ordered the tree felled, stacked with firewood, drenched in oil, and set ablaze. The demonic haunting ceased, and the site became the abbey formerly known as Xinguo; its plaque now reads Tianqing.

Once, while visiting Youwei Abbey, he found it in ruins from the early Tang. When he asked the abbot why it had not been restored, the reply was a lack of resources. The Celestial Master strode forth resolutely and, within a month, had timber bundles delivered. At the mouth of Zhangmu River in Gao’an—ninety *li* from the abbey—he commanded raftsmen to lash the logs tightly and moor them by the riverbank. As dusk fell, he cast a black talisman, and by midnight, a fierce storm of wind and thunder raged. By dawn, the bundles lay at the abbey’s foundation. Along the route through the ridges and valleys, the forest trees were swept aside, broken and felled.

He also unearthed a vault at the foot of the mountain, yielding three hundred thousand coins to fund labor and supplies. For structures unfit for human habitation, he employed ghosts and spirits to work through the night. Outside the gates, three wells were dug to avert fire disasters—commonly called "Fire-Prohibiting Wells"—and indeed, Yongyuan County has since been free of fires.

In time, his extraordinary deeds became widely known. During the reign of Emperor Gaozong of Tang, he happened to visit the capital and was summoned to exorcise fox demons from Shouchun Palace, for which he was granted the title *Master of Cavernous Truth*. Later, Empress Wu dispatched envoys with a rush-wheeled carriage to summon him. The Celestial Master had long concealed himself in the mountains and valleys, but when local officials pressed their search, he had no choice but to emerge. Arriving in the capital, he was received at Wucheng Hall. The Empress inquired about immortal arts, yet the Celestial Master spoke only of the Dao, virtue, and the foundations of imperial governance. Delighted, she sought to retain him in the capital to oversee alchemical work, but he declined, requesting to return to his mountain retreat for cultivation. She then sent envoys bearing gold and jade to escort him home.

As he passed through Shanfu, she bestowed a letter upon him, which read: *"Master, your Dao and rank are lofty, having long transcended the mundane world—like Guangchengzi of ancient times or the River Earl of Han. Thus, you journeyed a thousand *li* to answer our summons in the Three Rivers. Now, as the sun rises first in the east, your cloud-borne robes fade into the distance; as the Heavenly Ford lies behind, your crane-borne canopy grows ever more remote."*

The winds and clouds of the empty terrace left her endlessly forlorn. Should the Master’s ninefold elixir yield a remnant, she longed for but a single pill. Thereupon, the Celestial Master refined his cinnabar at the ancient altar of Master Hongya, a labor spanning three years. An imperial edict hastened his summons to court, and upon arrival, he was lodged within the palace precincts. When he sought leave to return, the sovereign firmly denied his request. Yet one morning, the Master vanished without trace. The emperor, upon hearing the news, sighed in deep regret. He dispatched envoys bearing lavish gifts and a poem, which read:

*"The lofty man aligns with lofty aims,
In mountain garb he seeks his mountain home.
Far, far the wind and moon now drift apart,
Beyond the mists where rosy clouds are blown.
The azure peaks reveal the mystic grotto,
The jade cauldron refines the cinnabar’s glow.
Today, by Starry Ford, I lift my gaze,
Yearning for the sacred raft’s swift flow."*

The Celestial Master returned to West Mountain, dwelling at Xumu Jing. There stood the Three Clarities’ Central Gate, and the Hall of the Perfected Lords, which remains atop the old pavilion of the Immortal’s Well—all wrought by spirits’ craft. The beams and rafters, stacked to the ridge, bore cuts so precise that human hands might emulate, yet their upright stance, unwavering and enduring, surpassed mortal skill. The imperial plaque bore the reign title in vigorous calligraphy. He also painted his true likeness upon the rear hall’s wall.

During his residence on West Mountain, all deferred to him as master. For a thousand *li* around, no pestilence, drought, or flood brought suffering; no fierce beasts nor untimely deaths afflicted the land, and all near and far depended on his grace.

On the sixteenth day of the second month in the third year of the Chang’an era, he commanded his disciples to construct a brick tomb on Hidden Dragon Ridge northwest of the Wandering Canopy Abbey. Within were interred two *Tai Xuan* True Talismans, one Seven Stars Divine Sword, and one Numinous Treasure Staff. The work was completed in three days. The Celestial Master, clad in full regalia, sat upon a rope-strung couch as rare fragrance filled the chamber. From the void came the cries of cranes and clouds; beyond the walls, the clamor of men and horses swelled without cease. When they looked again, he had already shed his mortal form.

The prefecture reported the event, and the court bestowed funds for a grand offering rite, posthumously honoring him as Master of the Grotto’s Truth. Sima Zhen of Gusuzhen composed the stele, recording the details in full.

During the Kaiyuan era, the Celestial Master reappeared, earning the esteem of Emperor Minghuang, who sent him back to the mountains with a poem:

*"The immortal wearies of the mortal realm,
As lone clouds match his tranquil soul.
Unfinished, our parting words remain,
While mist and water stretch o’er myriad hills."*

It is also told that three of Minghuang’s princesses studied the Dao under him: the Eldest Princess Yuzhen, the Second Princess Yuzhen, and Princess Zhenyi. After attaining the Way, they all vanished into the Cavern of Soaring Simurghs. Their master, too, withdrew into seclusion.

The present Fulong Mountain’s Lingyun Abbey was where the Master resided upon his return to the mountains. The site where the princesses studied the Dao under him lies over ten *li* south of Lingyun, where three mounds rise from level ground. The place where the Master later concealed his sword, seal, and talismans is commonly called the Three Coffers and remains under the registry of Lingyun Abbey. His disciples and foremost students were many, the most eminent being Master Wan and Master Lan.

Linchuan’s Jing Mountain’s Huanghua Gu relates: At Weiguan Abbey, there was a mural of Master Hu’s true likeness. One day, as the wall threatened to collapse, a wandering *yunshui* Daoist suddenly arrived, traced the image onto wooden boards, and restored it to its former appearance. The next evening, the wall crumbled, and the Daoist vanished without a trace. The temple hall was rebuilt by imperial decree in the sixth year of Song Huizong’s Zhenghe reign, and the original mural was removed. Only the wooden replica remains today.

*Comprehensive Mirror of Perfected Immortals Through the Ages, Scroll Twenty-Seven (concluded)*

---

*Comprehensive Mirror of Perfected Immortals Through the Ages, Scroll Twenty-Eight*

**Wang Zuan**
Daoist Wang Zuan was a native of Jintan. He dwelled on Maji Mountain, ever practicing hidden merits to aid all beings. During the late Western Jin, as the Central Plains descended into chaos—famine, pestilence, and plague raging—many perished without succor. Moved by their plight, Zuan retired to his oratory, weeping as he submitted a flying memorial to Heaven.

Three days later, his chamber blazed with daylight brilliance. Soon, auspicious winds and rosy clouds swirled in the sky, while rare fragrances and celestial music descended into the courtyard. First came over thirty armored warriors, wielding golden weapons. Then, in swift succession, pearl-encrusted canopies, jeweled banners, rainbow streamers, and feathered standards appeared, borne by an entourage before and behind. Four azure youths held flowers and incense, while two attendants unfurled a cloud-brocade mat upon the ground. A towering screen stood at the fore, flanked by Dragon and Tiger Generals and their retinues—over twenty on each side—arrayed as if in solemn guard. Beyond them stood twenty-six armored generals and ten divine kings, their ranks as orderly as the Dragon and Tiger Lords’.

Suddenly, reed pipes and flutes sounded from the northwest, and five-colored auspicious radiance blazed forth. A figure bearing a sword and tablet stepped forward and announced to Zuan: “The Supreme Dao Lord has arrived.” At once, a throne of myriad treasures descended from the void. The Dao Lord sat upon it, attended by two Perfected Ones and two Heavenly Emperors. Zuan prostrated himself, kowtowing in reverence. The Dao Lord spoke: “You have pitied the living, expressing your plea in memorials, carving your heart and wiping your blood—moving both the seen and unseen realms. The Earth Bureau has reported your merit, and I have taken note of you.”

After Zuan offered his thanks, the Dao Lord continued: “The interplay of yin and yang nurtures the myriad things, with the Five Phases as their sovereign. The Five Phases vie in dominance, each waxing and waning in turn, their transformations ceaseless. Qi and life perpetuate one another without pause, unbroken since time immemorial. Those who attain life align with supreme yang, ascending to Heaven as immortals; those who meet death sink into supreme yin, becoming ghosts upon the earth. Among ghostly beings, there are gradations of strength and weakness, hardness and softness, goodness and evil—no different from the mortal world. The Jade Emperor, fearing the wanton harm wrought by ghosts and spirits, has charged the Five Emperors and the Three Officials with their regulation, ensuring that laws, commands, punishments, and statutes are clear and complete.

Yet in this degenerate age, the wellspring of purity has dispersed, and deceit and falsity arise daily. People disloyal to their lords, unfilial to their parents, violate the teachings of the Three Bonds and Five Constants, casting themselves into the realm of death. Thus, the followers of the Six Heavens’ Black Demons, along with the defeated generals and slain warriors of ages past—who once slaughtered the living—now ride the winds and rains, seizing upon weakness and opportunity to spread manifold diseases. Countless are those afflicted, even those who do not meet their allotted years, like Wang Jian and Bai Qi. Generals in life become commanders of troops in death; those who served well are promoted to yin officials, while the cruel and destructive remain among the demonic. They exploit the qi of the Five Phases’ decline, bringing plagues and pestilence. Yet I restrain them with the might of yang and subdue them with divine incantations, so they must ever be curbed.

Today, I bestow upon you the *True Tang Scripture of Pacifying Spirits and Transforming Demons* and the *Divine Incantation Scripture*, which I once conferred at the Duyang Palace. Practice them, and you may deliver the multitudes.” He then commanded an attendant to unroll the Nine Radiance Scroll, presenting the two scriptures along with the secrets of the Three and Five Grand Fasts. “Strive in your practice,” he said, “and hidden merit may be fulfilled, and the rank of Perfection attained.” With these words, the thousand chariots and ten thousand riders ascended to the northwest.

Zuan followed the scriptures’ teachings and disseminated the fasts’ rituals. From that time forth, no pestilence or plague arose south of the Yangtze.

**Shan Daokai**
Shan Daokai was a native of Dunhuang.

Shan Daokai customarily wore coarse robes, and though others often gifted him fine silks, he never donned them. He feared neither cold nor heat and remained awake day and night. He regularly ingested fine pebbles, swallowing several at a time, once daily—sometimes more, sometimes less. Fond of dwelling in mountains, he encountered spirits of all strange forms among the trees, yet his countenance never betrayed fear. During the reign of Shi Jilong, he traveled from Xiping, covering seven hundred *li* in a single day to reach Qinzhou. A memorial was sent to Ye, recorded in the *Records of Buddhist Teachings*: In the third year of Yonghe under Emperor Mu of Jin, the imperial astronomer reported to Jilong, “A star of immortals has appeared; a lofty adept is about to enter the realm.” Jilong pressured the prefectures to seek out extraordinary persons and report them. In the eleventh month, the Inspector of Qinzhou memorialized the arrival of Shan Daokai in Ye. Jilong ordered Fotucheng to converse with him, but could not humble him. Fotucheng remarked, “This Daoist observes the rise and fall of states. If he departs, great chaos will befall the land.” True to his words, as Jilong’s reign neared its end, Daokai crossed south to Xuchang, and soon after, Ye descended into turmoil.

In the third year of Shengping under Emperor Mu of Jin, he arrived in the capital, later journeying to Luofu Mountain in Nanhai. There, he dwelt alone in a thatched hut, detached from worldly concerns. Having lived over a hundred years, he passed away in his mountain abode. His disciples placed his body in a stone cavern, then later moved it to a stone chamber.

When Yuan Hong of Chen Commandery served as Prefect of Nanhai, he ascended Luofu Mountain and arrived at the mouth of the stone chamber. There, he beheld Shan Daokai’s remains, appearing as though still alive, with incense and earthenware vessels still present. Hong remarked, “The Master’s deeds and conduct stand apart from the multitude—this is truly the molting of a cicada.” He then composed a eulogy, as recorded in *The Book of Jin*.

Tang Zixi of Meishan in the Song Dynasty wrote in his preface: “Over thirty years after Ge Zhichuan’s transformation, Shan Daokai first came to Luofu. Today, those in the mountains know of Zhichuan but not of Daokai. For Zhichuan, having been detained by Deng Yue, resided on the mountain for years, refining elixirs and writing books, his alchemical furnace and cauldron still preserved. Daokai, however, consumed only a few small stones daily, remaining indifferent to worldly affairs. Thus, later generations could find no records of him.”

Though Yuan Hong of Chen Commandery composed a eulogy for Daokai, he had once written the *Nine Bestowments* for Huan Wen—how could such hands again engage in matters beyond the world? Moreover, his eulogy no longer survives. Therefore, two eulogies were inscribed in the mountain valleys, their locations left unmarked, to bequeath them to later seekers of the extraordinary.

The eulogy for Daokai reads:
Ordinary men chew the soft,
Yet spit out what is hard.
Scooping mushy rice,
Their mouths bellow like oxen.
The perfected forget things,
Hard and soft as one.
To them, eating stones
Is like consuming cakes.
The Northern Plain’s pearl-drinkers,
Acting without intent—
The principle of stone-eating
May be sought therein.
Though I cannot do the same,
I grasp its truth,
And may rinse with it
To whet my teeth.

From *Luofu Illustrated Records*.

Wang Jia
Wang Jia, styled Zinian, was a native of Anyang in Longxi.

Light of bearing yet coarse in appearance, he was witty and fond of jest. He ate no grains, wore no fine garments. Clad in black, serene and empty, he shunned the company of worldly men. He concealed himself in Shuyang Valley, carving a cave into the cliff to dwell within. His disciples numbered in the hundreds, all living in caverns. He claimed to ride six black dragons, guarding the Three Ones, and neither winter nor summer altered his robes—his complexion grew ever more youthful.

At the end of Shi Hu’s reign, he abandoned his followers and hid on Mount Zhongnan, building a thatched hut to stay. His disciples followed once more, so he moved to Daoshou Mountain. Scholars and admirers flocked to him, inquiring about worldly affairs, and he answered each question as it came. Fond of parables, he spoke as if in jest. His words foretold events yet to pass, his phrases like prophecies. None of his contemporaries understood, yet all came to pass. Those who sought him with sincerity saw him; those without sincerity found him invisible, his form concealed. His robes hung on the rack, his sandals and staff remained in place. Should one attempt to take his clothes, they could never reach them—the rack would rise higher, the room no larger. The same held for his sandals and staff.

Fu Jian of Qin repeatedly summoned him, but he refused. When Jian later launched a great southern campaign, appointing Mao Rong as grand general, he sent envoys to question Jia. Jia replied: *"Metal is firm, fire is strong."* Then, mounting the envoy’s horse, he straightened his robes and cap, slowly riding eastward for several hundred paces before whipping the horse into a gallop and returning. He stripped off his clothes, cast aside his cap and sandals, and went back inside. Dismounting, he sat upon his bed in silence. Jian, still perplexed, sent another envoy to ask about the fate of his reign. Jia said: *"Not yet ended."* Jian rejoiced, taking it as an auspicious omen. The following year, in the *guiwei* cycle, Jian suffered a crushing defeat at Shouchun and lost the state of Qin. *"Not yet ended"* referred to that year. Qin, ruling in the west, was metal; Jin, seated in the south, was fire—fire could melt metal.

Jia later moved to Mount Songgao. When Yao Chang and Fu Deng clashed, Chang asked Jia: *"If I kill Deng, will I secure the realm?"* Jia replied: *"You will roughly gain it."* Enraged, Chang snapped: *"If I gain it, I will say I have gained it—what is this ‘roughly’?"* He then executed Jia along with two disciples. Earlier, Chang had sent men to meet Jia and his two disciples on the Longyou road, over a thousand *li* away—it was the very day Jia was slain. Jia had sent a letter to Chang, who ordered the opening of Jia’s coffin and those of his two disciples. No corpses were found, only a bamboo staff in each.

Jia authored the *Records of Gleanings* in ten scrolls, filled with strange accounts, which circulated in the world.

Meng Qin
Meng Qin was a native of Luoyang.

Left Ci and Liu Gen possessed arts that drew the admiration and devotion of the common folk. Fu Jian summoned Meng Qin to Chang’an, and, displeased by his ability to delude the masses, ordered Fu Rong to execute him. Soon after, Qin arrived, and Rong detained him, hosting a grand feast for the officials. As the wine flowed freely, Rong signaled his attendants to seize Qin. Qin transformed into a whirlwind and flew beyond the hall. Shortly after, word came that he had been spotted east of the city, and Rong dispatched cavalry to pursue him. Though they nearly closed the distance, he was already far ahead. At times, armed forces barred their path, or streams and ravines blocked their way, and Qin vanished without a trace. In the final years of Jian’s reign, he reappeared in Qingzhou, where Fu Lang pursued him to a sea island.

Guo Zhisheng
Guo Zhisheng, styled Tongming, was a native of Zhuti Prefecture. During the reign of Emperor Yuan of Jin, he claimed to be four hundred years old, though he appeared no older than fifty. He carried two baskets filled with short scrolls of writings, which he bore on his back at all times. He often stayed at the home of Zhang Ji of Wuchang, where he would sigh: *"War and famine will soon spread their poison, and the living will find their coffins in ditches, their mourners in flies. This inevitable fate is heartbreaking to behold."* Two years later, Sun En’s rebellion erupted, and winter and summer alike saw slaughter and starvation—barely one in ten survived. Suddenly, he told Ji: *"My time has come. Prepare the coffin and funeral implements, but do not bury me. Instead, carry me to a mountain crag and weigh the coffin down with stones."* Shortly after, he died, and Ji followed his instructions precisely. Days later, a kinsman of Ji’s returned from Fuyang and saw Zhisheng riding a white deer through the mountains. Zhisheng sent a letter to Ji.

Guo Pu
Guo Pu, styled Jingchun, was a native of Hedong.

Guo Pu was deeply devoted to the classical arts, erudite and gifted, yet reticent in speech and discourse. His *fu* rhapsodies stood as the finest of the Jin restoration, and he was fond of ancient scripts and rare characters, excelling in the mysteries of yin-yang, divination, and calendrical astronomy. There was a certain Master Guo who dwelled as a guest in Hedong, mastering the arts of divination. Pu studied under him, and the master bestowed upon him nine scrolls from his green satchel. From then on, Pu penetrated the secrets of the Five Phases, celestial patterns, and the arts of divination—warding off disasters, averting misfortunes, and summoning blessings without limit. Even Jing Fang and Guan Lu could not surpass him.

Once, his disciple Zhao Zai stole the green satchel’s texts but had not yet read them when they were consumed by fire. During the reigns of Emperors Hui and Huai, Hedong was first to descend into chaos. Pu divined the coming calamity and fled southeast, seeking refuge with General Zhao Gu. At that time, the general’s prized steed had just died, and in his grief, he refused to receive guests. When Pu arrived, the gatekeeper did not announce him. Pu declared, *"I can revive the horse."* The gatekeeper, astonished, relayed this to Gu. The general rushed out and asked, *"Can you truly save my horse?"* Pu replied, *"Gather two or three dozen strong men, each with a long pole. Proceed thirty *li* east until you reach a wooded mound with a shrine. Strike the area with the poles, and you will find a creature—seize it at once and bring it back. With this, the horse will live."* Gu followed his instructions and indeed captured a creature resembling a monkey. As they returned, the beast approached the dead horse and exhaled into its nostrils. Moments later, the horse rose, shook itself, neighed, and began eating as before. The creature then vanished. Gu marveled and rewarded Pu generously.

After crossing the Yangtze, Wang Dao held Pu in high esteem and enlisted him as an advisor in his military affairs. When Emperor Yuan first established his court in Jianye, Dao had Pu divine the omens, and all his predictions proved accurate. Pu was promoted to Gentleman of Writing. At the time, the balance of yin and yang was disrupted, and punishments and trials proliferated. Pu submitted a memorial, stating: *"Those who revere the Way will enjoy fortune; those who grow arrogant will invite disaster. We must purge transgressions and promote yang while bestowing benevolence."* In the fourth year of Jianwu, on the *guihai* day of the third month, a dark spot appeared in the sun. Pu attributed this to the emperor’s excessive use of punishment, which had thrown yin and yang into disorder. Pardons, he argued, should not be granted too frequently. Yet, as Zichan’s casting of penal statutes—though not an ideal policy—was necessary to remedy abuses, so too was a pardon now warranted. Soon after, he was promoted to Gentleman of the Masters of Writing.

In the first month of the first year of Yongchang, Pu again submitted a memorial, urging a general amnesty to celebrate the birth of the imperial grandson. The emperor consented, and a great amnesty was declared, along with a change of era. Wang Dun appointed Pu as his Recorder and Military Advisor. Pu, skilled in divination, foresaw Dun’s inevitable rebellion and the calamity it would bring, and he grieved deeply. When the general Yuan Shu died, Pu wept with profound sorrow, saying, *"Who knows if this is not a blessing in disguise?"*

After Emperor Yuan’s passing, Pu resigned due to his mother’s mourning. He divined a burial site in Jiyang, about a hundred paces from water. Others warned of its proximity to the river, but Pu replied, *"It will soon become dry land."* Later, silt accumulated, covering the tomb, and for miles around, the land turned to mulberry fields.

Pu once arranged a burial for a client. Emperor Ming, in disguise, observed the proceedings and asked the host, *"Why bury at Dragon’s Horn? This method will bring annihilation to your clan."* The host replied, *"Master Guo said this is the burial of a dragon. Within three years, it will summon the Son of Heaven."* The emperor asked, *"Summon the Son of Heaven?"* The host answered, *"It will at least summon the Son of Heaven’s inquiry."*

The emperor found this most extraordinary.

In the third month of the first year of *Daning* during Emperor Ming’s reign, Wang Dun plotted to usurp the throne and subtly pressured the court to summon him. The emperor personally issued an edict to recall him, and Wang Dun relocated his garrison to Gushu. By the fifth month of the second year, he prepared to march his troops toward the capital and ordered Guo Pu to interpret his dreams. Pu divined and said, *"It will not succeed."* Wang Dun asked, *"How long do I have to live?"* Pu replied, *"If you proceed with this, disaster will come swiftly. But if you return to Wuchang, your lifespan cannot yet be measured."* Enraged, Wang Dun demanded, *"How long do you have to live?"* Pu answered, *"My life ends at midday today."*

Wang Dun flew into a rage and ordered his guards to bind Pu. Pu said to the guard, *"When I was thirteen, I took off my robe at Zhatang and gave it to you, telling you that my life would one day be in your hands. You may use my blade."* The guard, moved by this past kindness, wept as he carried out the execution. Even before divining Wang Dun’s dreams, Pu had already informed his family to prepare funeral arrangements at the execution site. His life ended between two pines by the riverbank. Three days later, people in the southern market saw Pu selling his lifelong garments and conversing with acquaintances. When Wang Dun heard this, he refused to believe it; upon opening the coffin, he found no body—Pu had achieved *bingjie* (transcendence through violent death). Later, he became the Immortal Lord of the Water Palace.

Pu had long been close friends with Huan Yi. Whenever Yi visited, he would enter directly, even if Pu was inside or outside. Pu once told him, *"When you come, you may go straight to any other place, but never seek me in the privy—it will bring misfortune to both host and guest."* Later, Yi, drunk, visited Pu and found him in the privy. Peering in, he saw Pu naked, hair unbound, holding a blade and arranging ritual objects. Seeing Yi, Pu clutched his chest in shock and exclaimed, *"I warned you not to come, yet you do this! Not only will it bring disaster upon me, but you will not escape it either."* In the end, Pu met his doom at Wang Dun’s hands, and Yi perished in Su Jun’s rebellion.

Pu compiled over sixty cases of divination and verification, titling the work *Donglin*. He also excerpted the essentials from the *Jing* and *Fei* schools, composing *Xinlin* in ten chapters, along with *Bu Yun* in one chapter. He annotated the *Erya*, as well as the *San Cang*, *Fangyan*, *Mu Tianzi Zhuan*, *Shanhai Jing*, and *Chu Ci*, all of which circulated in the world. His poems and *fu* (rhapsodies) amounted to tens of thousands of words. Much of the above aligns with the *Book of Jin*.

Your servant Daoyi remarks: Guo Pu’s response to Wang Dun was meant to deter the heart of a treacherous minister. Wang Dun, holding the esteemed rank of Grand General and perceiving the weakness of the Jin court, sought to betray and devour it—truly a man who desired what he should not and knew no contentment. Pu hoped to dissuade him, as seen in his words: *"If you proceed with this, disaster will come swiftly; but if you return to Wuchang, your lifespan cannot yet be measured."* Was not Guo Pu taking the Dao upon himself, hoping to turn the heart of a treacherous minister? The *Daodejing* states: *"No crime is greater than yielding to desire; no disaster is greater than discontent; no fault is greater than covetousness. Thus, contentment alone brings lasting satisfaction."* This was indeed Guo Pu’s intent in stopping Wang Dun.

—Guo Wenju

Guo Wenju was a native of Chaohun in Henei. From his youth, he loved mountains and rivers, often wandering among famous peaks and visiting the stone chambers of Huayin. When Luoyang fell, he entered the Wu region and dwelled on Mount Dapi. He lodged in the hollows of trees, covering himself with thatch for shelter. Though fierce beasts ran rampant at the time, Wenju lived there for over a decade without harm. The Chancellor, Wang Dao, sent for him to come to the capital, and all the court officials gathered to see him. Wenju sat slouched with legs sprawled, as if no one were present. Zhou Ji asked, *"Fierce beasts harm men—why do you alone fear them not?"* Wenju replied, *"I harbor no intent to harm beasts, so beasts do not harm men."* Zhou Ji, Yu Liang, Huan Wen, and Liu Hui all sighed in admiration: *"Though Wenju lacks the talents of a worthy man, he possesses the virtue of one."*

In the first year of the Xianhe era under Emperor Cheng of Jin, he earnestly petitioned to return to the mountains, but Wang Dao refused. Soon after, he fled to Mount Baitu in Lin’an. The following year, Su Jun rebelled, and people remarked that Wenju had foreseen this, hence his departure. He possessed two scrolls of the *Laozi*, which he reverently hung in his dwelling, though he was never seen reading them. A man from beyond the mountains, Xu Kai, became his disciple and received his records. The generals, officers, and soldiers from the records appeared to Kai in form, serving him. Wenju also allowed Kai to see the spirit of the local altar, warning him: *"You must not take a wife, or I shall no longer send them to you."* Later, Kai married a woman of the Ji clan, and the spirits vanished at once. Only two record-keeping officers remained, no longer obeying his commands. They told Kai: *"You have violated your master’s covenant. The celestial bureau has already seized the officers and soldiers. We remain only to guard the Supreme Records and can no longer be sent."* When Wenju died, his body vanished like a cicada shedding its husk. The people below the mountain erected a stele in his memory.

Xu Wenju inscribed on lotus leaves, composing the *Golden Male Poems* and *Golden Female Records*. Later generations discovered them beneath his bedding, and upon examining them in order, found them to resemble prophecies and apocrypha, whereupon they were transmitted to the world.

Your servant Daoyi remarks: Guo Wenju dwelled in reclusion among the mountains and forests, unafraid of fierce beasts. Consider his reply to Zhou Ji’s question: *"I harbor no intent to harm beasts, so beasts do no harm to man."* From this, his cultivation and learning may be discerned—no wonder he inspired such admiration. The *Daodejing* states: *"One whose virtue is profoundly deep resembles an infant: no venomous creature stings them, no fierce beast seizes them, no bird of prey snatches them."* Could this not describe Guo Wenju?

Wang Zhi
Wang Zhi was a native of Dongyang during the Jin dynasty. While felling trees in the mountains, he came to the Stone Chamber Mountain in Xin’an Commandery, where he saw several boys gathered in a stone chamber, playing go and laughing—one version says he encountered Red Pine Master and Anqi Sheng playing go. Zhi set down his axe and watched. The boys gave him an object like a jujube pit, instructing him to hold it in his mouth and swallow its juice, whereupon he felt neither hunger nor thirst. The boys said: *"You have stayed long enough; you may return."* Zhi took up his axe, only to find its handle had rotted away entirely. When he returned home, he calculated that centuries had passed; all his kin and acquaintances had perished, none remaining. He reentered the mountains, attained the Dao, and for over a hundred years, people occasionally saw him. Later, he too ascended to heaven. In eastern Zhejiang’s Xin’an, there is a Rotten Axe Handle Mountain, the very place—also called Axe Handle Mountain, now under Xi’an County in Quzhou. Another Rotten Axe Handle Mountain exists in Xin’an, Guangdong, now under Zhaoqing Prefecture.

Dong You
Dong You was a native of Hailing.

The three brothers were born of the same parents, with You being the youngest. Having lost their father early, their mother doted on You, who was often ill, and thus unable to manage the household. At eighteen, he said to his mother: *"My illness is severe and will not soon be cured. I only burden my two elder brothers and will never live a full life. I wish to enter the Daoist gate, sweeping and cleaning to pass my days."* His mother consented.

In his master’s household, You was reverent, diligent, and devoted to cultivation. He observed long fasts, studied earnestly, and never rested for a moment. Thus, he thoroughly mastered the arts of Daoist practice. At forty-one, one night, a perfected being descended to teach him the Way of walking on water without drowning. The immortal gave him a horsewhip and instructed him to strike the water with it, allowing him to walk upon its surface as if on level ground.

During the *Yixi* era of Emperor An of Jin, You returned home to bid farewell to his mother: *"I have attained the Dao and will no longer remain in the human realm. I have come now only to take leave of my family."* His mother asked: *"Where will you go, and when may you return?"* You replied: *"I must go to Mount Emei to receive further instruction; there is no set time for my return."*

Relatives and neighbors all came to see him off. When they reached the West River at Quyang, they saw You strike the water with his whip and walk away, gradually receding into the distance. Turning to his two brothers, he said: *"Pass down our family’s Daoist tradition through the generations."*

Fan Bao
Fan Bao was a native of Weizhong in Baxi. For a long time, he dwelled on Baili Isle in the Zhi River, cultivating the Way of Supreme Peace and Non-Action. When he exhaled and rinsed his mouth at the end of the day, a five-colored light arose from the back of his neck.

In winter and summer, he wore only a single layer of cloth. By the time of Huan Wen, his hair had already turned gray. Yet by the *yuanjia* era of Emperor Wen of the Song, his appearance remained unchanged. His divinations of fortune and misfortune—even matters thousands of miles away—were as clear as if he held them in his palm. All who met him asked: *"Are you a banished immortal?"* He replied: *"Dongfang Shuo once mocked me. In my youth, I often played tricks with him."* He also said: *"I saw King Wu of Zhou conquer King Zhou at the head of Luoyang’s city walls—singing before battle, dancing after victory."*

Emperor Wen of the Song summoned him for an audience. Fan Bao replied to the imperial edict, saying: *"I may call myself ‘I,’ but the Crown Prince is a great villain."* As he passed by the Eastern Palace, he pointed to its gates and said: *"Within lies a shrike-crow—why nurture a traitor unknowingly?"* The emperor, enraged, ordered Fan Bao to take his own life. Prince Jiangxia had him buried at Chiling Ridge by the Red Shore of Xinting. When the emperor later commanded his coffin be opened, it was found empty. He then regretted his actions.

The following year, Chen Zhong, a disciple of Fan Bao, rose in the night and suddenly saw the room illuminated as if by daylight. Fan Bao entered, walked to the bed, and sat down. An old man arrived shortly after, and Fan Bao stood to greet him. When Chen Zhong asked who the visitor was, Fan Bao only smiled and did not answer. After a moment, both departed. Fan Bao then said to Chen Zhong: *"I shall return to the eastern countryside soon. Guard my home well."* This was none other than Baili Isle.

Feng Boda
Feng Boda was a native of Jianchang in Yuzhang. His family had long practiced filial piety, and he himself was diligent in aiding others. Among the Daoist followers, Chen Ci received the imperial decree, much like Dai Jin—both were his contemporaries.

During the *yuanjia* era of Emperor Wen of the Song, Feng Boda traveled to the capital. Later, he hitched a ride home with a fellow townsman. When their boat reached Meigen, they were delayed for days by contrary winds. Feng Boda said to the boatmaster: *"If you wish to reach home swiftly, simply rest and do not open your eyes."* That night, those aboard heard the sound of branches scraping beneath the boat, yet it remained steady. Those who secretly peered out saw two dragons bearing the vessel on their wings, swift as lightning. Before dawn, they arrived at his home. Soon after, Feng Boda entered Mount Lu and did not return.

Ma Rong

Ma Rong resided in Gucheng of Liangguo. Though his eyes were inflamed and ulcerated, his pupils blind to the world, he possessed a penetrating vision that saw through all things. The north suffered from a prevalence of leprosy, and those shunned by their villages would invariably seek him out. Ma Rong treated them, and all were cured. He claimed affliction in his legs and often rode a white deer-drawn carriage, traveling near and far without any visible hand to guide it—yet the carriage arrived of its own accord. At times, he would answer dozens of summons in a single day, and at each place, a Ma Rong would appear. In conversation, he referred to himself as "the Wretched One." He composed three poems about pulling the carriage, akin to prophetic verse.

In the second year of the *xiaojian* era of Emperor Wu of the Song, on the third day of the third month, he wrote letters bidding farewell to the people of two kingdoms. On the sixteenth day at midday, he indeed departed this world.

---

Han Yue

Han Yue was a native of Guanjun in Nanling. His heart yearned for immortality, though his appearance resembled that of a mad fool. He followed his master in long periods of fasting and chanting, his voice never ceasing. He always wore wooden clogs and walked without regard for distance. When he entered the mountains, he might stay for a hundred days or fifty, then return home. If questioned, Han Yue never gave a straightforward answer.

Later, a villager hewed a bow from withered wood and, in a stone chamber on a sheer cliff in Mount Dayang, saw Han Yue reading scriptures with six or seven immortals. Afterward, Han Yue returned from the mountains and suddenly died in Luancun. His family prepared to receive his coffin, but it felt unusually light, raising doubts that it contained his true body. When they opened it, they found only a bamboo staff.

During the *daming* era of Emperor Xiaowu of the Song, a villager of Han Yue’s became a general in the imperial court. While on a northern mission to Qingzhou, he encountered Han Yue at the southern gate—his countenance now youthful. They spoke for some time, inquiring after the lives and deaths of relatives, their emotions mingling sorrow and joy. Han Yue said, *"My wife suffers from a persistent cough that has not yet healed. Today, I will give you a packet of medicine to steep in warm wine and have her drink it all at once."* The general returned to the capital and relayed Han Yue’s words. His wife took the medicine, and her cough was cured.

---

Daoist Yan Dong

Daoist Yan Dong’s origins were unknown.

Daoist Yan Dong was over forty years of age. During the *jianyuan* era of Emperor Gao of the Qi, he traveled to Jinling and became a disciple of Daoist Li Jing. He often reproached himself for his foolishness, wearing tattered clothes and worn-out shoes, carrying only a gourd, and possessing no scriptures. Yet when he engaged in discussion, his insights were profound and subtle, his voice clear and resonant, astonishing all who heard him. In his laughter, songs, and verses, he blended light and shadow, mingling with the common world. Though all knew him to be no ordinary man, they revered and admired him. After five or six years in Jinling, one day he announced his departure. Taking up his brush, he began annotating the *Scripture of the Numinous Treasure for Salvation*. His writing flowed without pause, continuing until the day’s end. Then he entered the Fan Mountains of Liyang, and his whereabouts thereafter were unknown.

Wang Lingyu

Wang Lingyu was a Daoist from Jiujiang. His nature was gentle and patient, and he was diligent in the Dao. He first resided on the Five Elders Peak, where one night a divine being spoke to him: *"Those who attain the Dao each have their proper place. Just as planting the five grains in sand and stone will yield no harvest, so too if one possesses the bone of ascension but lacks a blessed land or numinous abode, transformation cannot be achieved. Though one may accumulate virtue as earth and amass conduct as wings, if the place is not fitting, demons will corrupt one’s merit, and the Dao will never be attained."* Lingyu asked where he might dwell, and the being replied: *"The highest peak of Zhu Ling and the neighboring summit of Zi Gai—there you may ascend to heaven."* He then moved to the Central Temple of Mount Heng, where he remained for twelve years. On the thirteenth day of the seventh month in the eleventh year of the *tianjian* era of Emperor Wu of the Liang, a host of immortals descended to welcome him at the altar, and he ascended to heaven. Emperor Huizong of the Song later bestowed upon him the title *Master of Penetrating the Subtle and Gathering the Void*.

Daoist Shuang Xizu

Daoist Shuang Xizu, styled Zhongyuan, was a native of Wu during the Liang dynasty. He first dwelled on Mount Heng, later moving to the Nine Doubts Mountain. He devoted himself to the Dao in pursuit of transcendence.

Daoist Shuang once declared that where sincerity and purity reach, the loftiest immortals must respond. Thus, he resolved to recite the *Huangting Jade Chapters* with unwavering devotion. He built the Hall of the Yellow Court and had his disciples reside there, while he himself dwelled in White Horse Crag. One day, he returned to the hall to bathe and meditate, shutting himself in his chamber. For seven days he did not emerge. His disciples, alarmed, opened the door to find him suddenly ascending in lightness, leaving behind his immortal robe upon the treetops. This occurred in the fourth month of the first year of the *zhen'guan* era of Emperor Taizong of the Tang. The sleeping mat in the crag remained intact for over a hundred years thereafter, as recorded in *The Collected Wonders of Mount Heng*.

Huan He

Huan He, whose origins are unknown, served Master Tao the Recluse at the Huayang Lodge on Mount Mao for over a decade. His nature was upright and meticulous; beyond his duties, he remained still and seemingly idle. One day, two azure lads and a white crane descended from the sky and alighted in the courtyard. The Recluse, overjoyed, received them, believing the summons was for him. The lads said, "The Most High has called for Master Huan." The Recluse silently reviewed his disciples but found none surnamed Huan. Upon inquiry, he discovered only the attendant Huan He. When asked how he had attained this, Huan replied, "I have long practiced the Dao of silent audience, paying homage to the Great Emperor for nine years—hence today’s summons." As he prepared to ascend, the Recluse sought to become his disciple, but Huan firmly declined out of humility. Unable to persuade him, the Recluse lamented, "I have propagated the teachings and cultivated the Dao with utmost diligence, yet remain mired in the mundane. Must there be some fault in me?" He entreated Huan to investigate and inform him later. Thereupon, Huan donned celestial robes, mounted the white crane, and ascended into the void.

Three days later, he descended in secret and said, "Your hidden merits are indeed manifest, yet in compiling the *Materia Medica*, you employed creatures like horseflies and leeches as medicine. Though your work benefits humanity, it harms living beings. For this, you must undergo another twelve-year cycle before shedding your form and departing, whereupon you shall be appointed Supervisor of the Waters of Penglai." The Recluse then composed a separate *Materia Medica* in three volumes, substituting mineral, plant, and other remedies for those that took life, to atone for his transgression. Later, he indeed shed his form and departed.

*Comprehensive Mirror of Immortals Through the Ages Who Embodied the Dao*, Scroll Twenty-Eight (concluded)
*Comprehensive Mirror of Immortals Through the Ages Who Embodied the Dao*, Scroll Twenty-Nine

Master Celestial Master Kou Qianzhi, styled Fuzhen, was a native of Pingchang in Shanggu. He was the younger brother of Kou Zan, the Prefect of the Wei dynasty. His distant ancestor, Kou Ren, had concealed himself on Mount Wangwu during the reign of Emperor Cheng of Han, ascending in broad daylight to become an immortal, whereupon he was styled Master Illuminated Perfection. Ren’s grandson, Kou Jun, likewise departed riding a dragon. His father, Kou Fenlan, served as Governor of Hedong. The Celestial Master was born in the seventh month of the *yichou* year of the Jianyuan era of Fu Jian of Qin (365 CE), on the seventh day of the seventh month. At sixteen, he stood over eight *chi* tall. By eighteen, he had turned his heart wholly toward the Dao, his hidden yearnings reaching the heavens.

There was an immortal named Cheng Gongxing who had hired himself out to the household of the Celestial Master’s maternal aunt. One day, while clearing fields, Kou Qianzhi sat beneath a grove calculating the cycles of the viscera, but his reckoning did not align. Gongxing thereupon instructed him, and the calculations fell into place at his touch. Kou Qianzhi marveled and, after a moment, suddenly said to him, “If the Master is inclined to study the Dao, might we withdraw together into seclusion?” They then traveled to Mount Hua, where they gathered herbs for sustenance, and Kou Qianzhi never again knew hunger.

Later, they concealed themselves on Mount Song for several years. One day, Gongxing said to Kou Qianzhi, “When I depart, someone will bring you medicine—simply consume it.” As foretold, someone arrived bearing medicine, but upon inspection, it was composed of venomous insects and foul, noxious substances. Kou Qianzhi, seized by fear, went out to meet him. When Gongxing returned, Kou Qianzhi recounted what had occurred. Gongxing sighed and said, “The Master is not yet ready to attain immortality, but he may serve as a teacher to kings.” He added, “I shall not remain long.
