Tomorrow at noon, I will depart.” After Gongxing’s death, he instructed Kou Qianzhi, “If you bathe yourself, someone will come to receive you.” Gongxing then entered the third chamber of a stone grotto and expired. Kou Qianzhi personally performed the ablutions.

At noon the following day, someone knocked at the stone chamber. Kou Qianzhi emerged to find two youths—one bearing ritual vestments, the other a bowl and staff. He led them inside to Gongxing’s corpse. Suddenly, Gongxing rose, donned the garments, took up the bowl and staff, and departed. Kou Qianzhi thereafter remained steadfast in his resolve on Mount Songyang, never again venturing forth.

In the summer of the second year of the Shenrui era of Emperor Mingyuan of Wei (415 CE), on the first day of the fourth month, two figures clad in kingfisher-feathered robes and cloud-woven crowns, riding dragons and bearing banners, suddenly appeared, announcing, “The Venerable Lord has arrived.” Soon after, celestial music resounded, and the Most High descended in a white jade chariot, drawn by nine dragons, his majesty resplendent, accompanied by a procession of immortals and divine attendants, alighting upon the mountain’s summit. Kou Qianzhi reverently prostrated himself and beheld the five palace gates swing open, revealing towering terraces and halls.

The Most High sat beneath a silver-flowered forest and commanded the Immortal Duke Wang Fangping to bring Kou Qianzhi before him. He declared, “I have received a memorial from the Master of the Assembly of Immortals at Mount Song, stating that since Zhang Daoling attained perfection, those who cultivate the Dao have lacked proper instruction. Now, the Daoist Kou Qianzhi of Mount Song conducts himself in accord with the natural order and is fit to occupy the position of master. Therefore, I confer upon you the office of Celestial Master, along with the *Yunzhong Chants* and the new scriptures and precepts of the Dao. Since the beginning of time, these have never been transmitted to the world.”

Now the turning of the celestial cycles has come to fruition, and you must cultivate these teachings to assist the state and uphold the Mandate, transforming the living beings. Thereupon, he produced nine scrolls of the new scriptures and precepts. Once Kou Qianzhi had received them, the five-cloud terrace and halls vanished from sight.

On the fifteenth day of the first month in the second year of the Tai Chang era, the Most High descended once more, bestowing over ten scrolls of new talismans and registers. He admonished Kou, saying, “The talismans and registers given before and after may only be transmitted to those who are worthy. If you confer them upon the unworthy, the fault shall be yours.” Kou Qianzhi bowed deeply and accepted the instruction, and thereafter his resolve and conduct daily renewed.

During the Shi Guang reign of Emperor Taiwu, the court dispatched the Governor of Luozhou, Duke Liang, along with over a thousand officials to the mountain to welcome the Master to the capital. Yet the court and common folk did not yet fully believe or revere him, save for the Minister of Education, Cui Hao, who became his disciple. Cui memorialized the throne, saying, “I have heard that when a sagely ruler receives the Mandate, Heaven responds with auspicious signs. The *River Chart* and *Luo Writing* conveyed their messages through creatures and beasts, yet none compare to the divine and mortal communion of today. Though Emperor Gao of Han was most sagely, the Four Hoary Ones still refused to bend to him.” The Emperor grasped his meaning and ordered envoys to present jade and silk in sacrifice to Mount Song, and to bestow upon the Master palaces and lodgings. He drew near to inquire of the Dao, and his reverence grew ever more profound. Again, he sought to appoint the Master to the position of chief minister, but the Master firmly declined, saying, “I am now the Sagely Master, for the Most High has descended four times, and immortals have descended six times, all bestowing upon me the celestial scriptures and precepts. Judging by these manifestations, he is truly a sage.”

Thereupon, the Emperor established a capital altar, constructed the Palace of Serene Wheels, and instituted rituals and regalia, all in accordance with the scriptures and precepts. Thus, the realm turned in reverence toward him.

In the year *gengchen*, the Master requested to pray for blessings on the Emperor’s behalf at Mount Song. Through his utmost sincerity, he moved the unseen, and the Most High secretly bestowed upon the Emperor the title *Tai Ping Zhen Jun* (“True Lord of Great Peace”), along with ceremonial caps, robes, talismans, and registers. Upon his return, the Master memorialized the throne in full, and that year was changed to the first year of the *Tai Ping Zhen Jun* era.

In the second year, Kou Qianzhi memorialized, saying, “Now that Your Majesty rules as the *True Lord*, having established the Palace of Serene Wheels—an achievement unparalleled since antiquity—you should receive the talismans and registers to manifest your sagely virtue.” The Emperor assented and ascended the altar to receive them.

On the seventh day of the first month in the ninth year, he said to his disciples, “Last night, I dreamed that Cheng Gongxing summoned me to the Immortal Palace of Mount Song.” On the twenty-fifth day of the fifth month, he indeed ascended as an immortal. A mist of blue-black qi issued from his mouth, rising halfway to the heavens before dissipating.

His form gradually shrank, which those with insight called a "corpse-deliverance." He lived to the age of eighty-four. On the fifteenth day of the seventh month, Shen You of Dongjun, while gathering herbs atop Mount Song’s summit, saw Qianzhi’s body gleam like silver, radiant as the sun. Thus it was known he had become an immortal.

Li Jiao, a disciple of Kou Qianzhi, practiced qi-absorption and grain avoidance, secluding himself in Changshan for decades. At over ninety years of age, his complexion remained that of a youth. Each day, he bathed and donned his cap and sash, to the astonishment of his household. Soon after, he sat in transformation, and Daoist priests all declared he had attained immortal corpse-deliverance.

Master Wei Jie, styled Chuyuan, was a native of Duling in Jingzhao. His family was eminent, possessing over ten thousand scrolls. From childhood, Jie loved antiquity, mastering the classics, histories, and various arts, including divination and astrology. At fourteen, Emperor Wu of the Later Wei appointed him as a calligrapher in the Eastern Palace. When Emperor Xiaoming first ascended the throne and the Empress Dowager held court, he was sent to govern Lu Commandery. After Emperor Zhuang’s enthronement, he was reassigned to Yangxia, drawn by its proximity to Mount Song and the true Daoist priest Zhao Jingtong. Upon arrival, he returned his official regalia to the court and sought out the master. He received the sacred texts of the Three Caverns, divine formulas, and esoteric instructions.

Jingtong said, “Mount Song is a blessed land for immortals, yet lately Buddhists have dwelled here. Lacking transcendent conduct, they merely seek to lend their names to the mountain to enhance their reputation. Thus, corpses accumulate and souls stagnate, defiling this sacred peak. Recently, celestial signs and climatic patterns have grown violent and unbalanced. I fear calamity may flow from this—how can one remain at ease? You should journey to Shangluo, Min, and Yi to inquire further. I shall wander to Mount Tai or perhaps sail the seas on a raft.”

Jie then settled on the southern slopes of Mount Hua, where people called him the Master of Huayang. He consumed yellow essence, white wood, sesame, fuling, cinnabar, and realgar, practicing the Three Ones, the Feminine One, the Eight Ways, and the Nine Perfected. He also performed the *Huangting Neijing* and the *Dharani of Wisdom-Dispelling Demons*. He compiled the *Preface to the Three Caverns Rituals*, annotated the *Miaozhen*, *Xisheng*, *Zhuangzi*, *Liezi*, *Doctrine of the Mean*, *Classic of Filial Piety*, and *Analects*, while the *Laozi* and *Book of Changes* received separate treatises totaling over eighty scrolls. After reading the *Inner Biography of Master Louguan of the Taihe Era*, he composed an additional volume.

Emperor Wu of the Northern Zhou once invited him to receive the *Five Talismans of the Numinous Treasure* and the *Red Writ of the True Script*. A white crane descended upon the altar, circling before departing. The Emperor praised him and bestowed frequent gifts. He was further ordered to compose a hymn for cultivating the Dao, and thus he wrote the *Method of Refined Contemplation*. The Emperor repeatedly expressed his admiration and granted him the title Master of Refined Contemplation.

At the time, Zhou Hongzheng, an envoy from Chen, heard of the master’s renown and wished to seek his teachings. The Emperor summoned them for discourse, where Jie expounded profound mysteries, weighing and comparing the Three Teachings. Hongzheng marveled, saying, “This is a paragon of the three realms, not merely one to be revered by two nations.” The Emperor specially renamed him the Great Master of the Mystic Center.

Later, he dwelled on the eastern ridge of the mountain, shielding himself from noise to dwell in purity and vastness. The Emperor, upon hearing this, bestowed upon him the Taiyuan Refined Abode. In the fourth year of Emperor Wu’s Taihe era (recorded as Tiankang in the *Outer Annals*), a canopy of colored clouds suddenly appeared, covering his hut. He declared, “I shall depart upon this.” Thereafter, he did not leave his chamber. Twelve days later, he peacefully transformed, having lived seventy-three years.

Field Master Wen, whose personal name was Shiwen, hailed from You’e. In the seventh year of Emperor Wen of Sui’s Kaihuang era, he tested his studies and entered the Dao, serving Master Wei Jie to receive transmission of the Three Caverns’ scriptures and methods, along with talismanic incantations. He also recited the *Scripture of the Numinous Treasure* and the *Chapters on Generating the Spirit*. In his daily life, he consumed white wood and narrow-leaved hoelen, and over time, it proved beneficial. He would refine his qi in a quiet chamber, sometimes emerging only after ten or fifteen days, his complexion growing ever more radiant. On all eight seasonal nodes, ten auspicious days, and Gengshen days, he observed fasts and rites without fail. When petitioned to pray for blessings, none failed to evoke a response. When called to heal the sick, none did not recover fully.

Master Chen Gang once invited him to perform a jiao offering; suddenly, he produced from his sleeve several dates that appeared upon the altar—when eaten, they were unlike anything found in the human realm. Another time, the Daoist Yin Qi had him wear a talisman and register; in an instant, it fell into water with a splash, yet Qi was already standing on the shore. Such were the wonders of his true registers and divine talismans.

He often told others, “If people suffer, one must aid them.” Yet few believed him. There was a villager named Helan Kai who had received the precepts from the Master. One night, Kai suddenly died and was seized by ghostly officers, taken to a yamen-like court in the unseen realm. The record-keeper examined his ledger and said to Kai, “You bear the name of one who has received the precepts—you may return.” Thus, he revived. Such were the effects of his communion with the hidden and penetration into the netherworld. Far and wide, many came to believe and revere him, and the blessings he bestowed were too numerous to record.

In the seventeenth year of the Zhenguan era of the Tang Emperor Taizong, on the nineteenth day of the sixth month, the Master ascended in transcendence. All witnessed divine maidens bearing flowered banners and feathered regalia come to escort him away, and he declared, “Now I ascend to the Hall of Blessings in the Southern Palace.” He had lived seventy-five years. Among his disciples, only Yin Wencao had entered the inner chamber.

As for the Daoist Xu Ze—Xu Ze was a man of the Eastern Sea region. Serene and sparing of desire, he had long harbored the aspiration to dwell in reclusion. He thus entered Mount Jinyun to cultivate the Dao. After a long time, the Perfected One Xu of the Great Ultimate descended and told him, “When you reach eighty, you shall become the teacher of a king, and only then will you attain the Dao.” Thereupon, he built a hut on Mount Tiantai, fasting to nourish his vastness, subsisting on nothing but pine and water.

When Emperor Yang of the Sui was Prince of Jin and garrisoned Yangzhou, he summoned Xu Ze with a letter. Xu Ze said to his disciples, “This year I turn eighty-one; the prince summons me—thus the words of Perfected One Xu are proven true.” Upon arrival, the Prince of Jin requested instruction in the Daoist arts, but Xu Ze declined, citing an inauspicious day. That night, though incense and lamps remained as usual, at dawn after the fifth watch, he silently returned to the True.

The prince ordered envoys to escort him back to Mount Tiantai. Along the route from Jiangdu, some saw the Master walking on foot, saying he had returned home. When he reached his former hermitage, he bequeathed his scriptures and Daoist arts to his disciples. Then he swept a chamber clean and said, “If a guest arrives, receive them here.” After a while, he mounted the stone bridge and departed, vanishing without a trace. The next day, the envoys indeed arrived.

At the age of eighty-two, the Prince of Jin, filled with remorse, thrice dispatched envoys to capture his likeness and commanded Liu Shi to compose a eulogy, which read:

*"The Dao that can be spoken is not the eternal Dao;
The name that can be named is not the eternal name.
Supreme virtue does not feign virtue—
Perfect power seeks no adornment.
The true wind now stirs.*

*In the land of Yue, he tempered his golden bones of old,
Delighting his spirit in the Jade Clarity.
Washing with stone marrow, refining the elixir near completion,
His thoughts turned to Ge Zhi, soon to follow Mao Ying.
Our prince, from afar, was moved by his empty sincerity.
For a moment, he descended from the pillar’s height,
Immersing his essence by the river’s flow.
He left behind a talisman as token,
Transforming his staff into a light-footed dragon.
Seeking the numinous beyond, how could mere sentiment suffice?"*

Master Qihui, styled Pingding, was a native of Jingzhao. In the fifth year of Emperor Wu of Zhou’s Taihe reign, he entered the Dao. Soon after, when the emperor purged the followers of Buddhism and Daoism, he reverted to lay life. By the time Daoist arts flourished again under the Sui, he was twenty-six, his resolve for the virtuous path ever firmer. He then studied under Master Su at the Tongdao Abbey. Over time, he transmitted the teachings of the Three Caverns, practicing and expounding without rest. Within, he embraced stillness to preserve his true nature; without, he roamed freely to suit his inclinations. Through the passing years, he attained profound self-mastery.

In the seventh year of the Sui Dynasty’s Daye era, Emperor Yang personally led an expedition against Liaodong. Qihui addressed his disciples, saying: "The Dao of Heaven is about to change; I shall yet live to see it, and it will come to pass in no more than a few years." Someone asked: "What will the future hold?" He replied: "A descendant of the Old Lord shall rule the world, and thereafter our teachings shall flourish greatly." Several years later, the Sui Dynasty indeed fell into chaos.

When Emperor Gaozu of Tang revered his virtue, he dispatched envoys bearing treasures, silks, and a jade dragon to seek his blessings. On the night of the ritual, white clouds enveloped the altar, and a pair of deer docilely approached the steps—such was the depth of his spiritual resonance. The emperor, greatly pleased, issued an edict to renovate the Louguan Abbey, restoring its altars, halls, and sacred images to pristine splendor. He further granted the lands of Lantian to fund its rituals and appointed Qihui as its master.

One day, the emperor personally visited the temple and said to his attendants: "The Old Lord is our sagely ancestor. Now that he presides over the state, how can we fail to honor him with grand constructions?" Thus, he renamed the abbey *Zongsheng* ("Ancestral Sage") and bestowed grain and silk to support its observances.

Beyond his prayers for the nation, Qihui practiced the Three Guardians of Unity and the methods of the Outer Constellations. As the *Scriptures of the Immortals* state that those who seek to become immortal must enter Mount Taibai, he selected his most devoted disciples and journeyed there together. Upon their return, his chamber was often filled with the laughter and conversation of divine immortals.

In the fourth year of Emperor Taizong’s Zhenguan reign, on the eighteenth day of the seventh month, Qihui suddenly told his disciples: "At the Si hour tomorrow, I shall depart this world." At the appointed time, he indeed ascended in transcendence, having lived seventy-three years.

---

Sun Simiao was a native of Huayuan in Jingzhao. At seven, he began his studies, reciting a thousand words daily. When the Governor of Luozhou, Dugu Xin, saw the young boy, he marveled: "A sagely child indeed, though his talents may prove too vast for the world to employ." As he grew, he delighted in the teachings of Zhuangzi, Laozi, and the Hundred Schools.

During the reign of Emperor Xuan of Zhou, amid the turmoil of the imperial house, he withdrew to Mount Taibai to study the Dao, refining his qi and nurturing his form in pursuit of transcendence. Proficient in astronomy and calendrical calculations, he mastered medicine and pharmacology, scrutinizing the subtleties of pulse and complexion. His heart ever brimmed with benevolence; in all his actions, he strove to accumulate hidden virtues and aid all beings.

Once, while traveling, he encountered a cowherd boy killing a small snake, its blood already spilled. Simiao sought out the boy, bartered his own clothes to ransom the creature, and tended its wounds with medicine before releasing it into the grass. Over a month later, while traveling again, he saw a young man in white, his horse and retinue impeccably arrayed, dismount and bow before him. The youth expressed his gratitude: "My younger brother was saved by your kindness." Simiao paid little heed.

The youth bowed again and urged him to mount a spare horse, and together they sped away as if flying. They arrived at a city where flowers bloomed in springtime splendor, the scenery radiant and gentle. The gates and halls gleamed resplendently, teeming with people, resembling the abode of a king. The youth led Simiao inside to meet a man of dignified and handsome bearing, clad in a crimson robe and a black cap. Surrounded by a vast retinue, the man welcomed him warmly.

He thanked Simiao, saying: "I deeply admire your virtue, so I sent my son to welcome you. Earlier, my youngest child ventured out alone and was grievously wounded by a fool. Thanks to your ransom and rescue, his life was spared. Here, none of our kin are few, and we are all indebted to you for this second life. To meet you today is our greatest honor."

Moments later, they entered an inner chamber where a young woman, accompanied by a maidservant and a small boy in green, emerged to bow repeatedly in gratitude. "This child was reckless," she said, "and was harmed by others. We owe his survival to your kindness." Simiao recalled having saved a green snake and wondered at this strange turn.

He noticed that those around him were palace attendants and courtesans, addressing the robed man as "Lord" and the woman as "Queen." Perplexed, he discreetly inquired and was told: "This is the Water Palace of Jingyang." The king then ordered his ministers to prepare a feast with music and entertainment, but Simiao declined, explaining that he subsisted on breath and qi, drinking only wine.

After three days of hospitality, the king asked what he desired. Simiao replied: "I delight in dwelling in the mountains, cultivating the Dao, refining my spirit. Though my eyes may see, my heart harbors no desires." The king then offered him fine silk, pearls, and gold, but Simiao firmly refused. "Does the Daoist truly disdain such things?" the king asked. "How then may I repay you?" He commanded his son to present Simiao with thirty prescriptions from the Dragon Palace, saying: "These are true methods for a Daoist, capable of saving lives and aiding the world."

Soon after, the king ordered his attendants to escort Simiao back to the mountains. Upon his return, he marveled at the encounter. Testing the prescriptions, he found them miraculously effective. Later, he compiled the *Essential Prescriptions Worth a Thousand Gold Pieces* in thirty volumes, including the Dragon Palace formulas. He also authored the *Pulse Classic*, which circulated widely.

When Emperor Wen of Sui served as regent, he summoned Simiao to the post of Erudite of the Imperial Academy, but he declined. He once told others: "Fifty years hence, a sage shall arise, and I shall aid him in saving the people." By the time of Emperor Taizong of Tang, he was summoned to the capital. The emperor, astonished by his youthful appearance, remarked: "Now I understand that those of the Dao are truly worthy of reverence. The tales of immortals like Xianmen are no empty words." When offered a noble rank, Simiao steadfastly refused.

At the beginning of Emperor Gaozong’s reign, he was appointed Remonstrance Grandee but again declined. Though he was ninety-nine years old, his hearing and sight remained sharp. Lu Zhaolin of Fanyang, a man of renown, suffered from a grievous illness. Lamenting the disparities of fate and the mysteries of longevity, he asked Simiao: "What is the Way of a great physician in curing illness?"

Simiao replied: "I have heard that one who speaks well of Heaven must ground it in man, and one who speaks well of man must root it in Heaven. Heaven has its four seasons and five phases, with cold and heat alternating in succession. Its movements bring harmony as rain, fury as wind, condensation as frost and snow, and expansion as rainbows—such are the constant patterns of Heaven and Earth."

Man has four limbs and five viscera, waking and sleeping, exhalation and inhalation. In motion, they become going and coming; in flow, they become *ying* and *wei*. Manifest, they become complexion; expressed, they become voice and sound—such are the constant patterns of man.

Yang employs its essence, while Yin employs its form—this is what Heaven and Earth share. When these patterns fail, steaming gives rise to heat, stagnation to cold. Coagulation forms warts and tumors; collapse forms ulcers and abscesses. Rushing brings panting; exhaustion brings withering and desiccation. Diagnosis appears in the face, and changes move through the body.

Extending this to Heaven and Earth, it is likewise so. Thus, the five planets wax and wane, stars and constellations lose their courses, the sun and moon err in their paths, comets and shooting stars streak across the sky—these are the illnesses and sores of Heaven and Earth. Untimely cold and heat are their steaming and stagnation. Rocks standing and earth surging are their warts and tumors. Mountains collapsing and land caving in are their ulcers and abscesses. Rushing winds and violent rains are their panting and exhaustion. Untimely droughts and dried-up rivers are their withering and desiccation.

The skilled physician follows these principles with medicinal stones, rescues with acupuncture, harmonizes with virtue and the Dao, and assists with human affairs. Thus, man has curable illnesses, and Heaven and Earth have avertable disasters.

Zhaolin asked: "What of human affairs?"

Simiao replied: "The heart is the ruler; a ruler must be reverent, thus desires should be small. As the *Book of Songs* says: *As if treading over a deep abyss, as if walking on thin ice*—this speaks of smallness. The gallbladder is the general, charged with decisiveness and resolve, thus desires should be great. As the *Book of Songs* says: *Valiant warriors, the shields and walls of lords and marquises*—this speaks of greatness. Benevolence is the image of Earth’s stillness, thus it should be square. As the tradition says: *Not swayed by profit, not pained by righteousness*—this speaks of squareness. Wisdom is the image of Heaven’s movement, thus it should be round. As the *Book of Changes* says: *Seeing the moment and acting, not waiting the whole day*—this speaks of roundness."

Thus, his literary works stand out brilliantly, and his arts of the Dao are beyond enumeration.

Zhaolin again asked about the essentials of nurturing life.

Simiao answered: "Heaven has fullness and emptiness; man has hardship and peril. Without self-caution, one cannot overcome them. Thus, nurturing life must begin with knowing self-caution. Caution is rooted in awe.

A scholar without awe neglects benevolence and righteousness; a farmer without awe slacks in sowing and reaping; a craftsman without awe disregards rules and measures; a merchant without awe fails to grow his goods; a child without awe forgets filial piety; a father without awe abandons kindness; a minister without awe achieves no merit; a ruler without awe leaves chaos ungoverned.

Therefore, the highest awe the Dao; next, awe Heaven; next, awe things; next, awe others; next, awe oneself. He who worries for himself is not constrained by others. Caution in small matters brings no fear of great ones. Vigilance in near things brings no regret for distant ones. Thus are human affairs complete."

In the latter years of Emperor Gaozong’s reign, an imperial decree appointed him Gentleman for Rendering Service, assigning him to the Imperial Pharmacy Bureau, but he declined the post. On the fifteenth day of the second month in the third year of Yonghui (652 CE), at over a hundred years of age, he bathed at dawn, donned his robes and cap with solemn dignity, and sat upright with hands clasped. Addressing his descendants, he said: “Pressed by the world, I secluded myself in mountain grottoes to cultivate and refine my nature, soon to ascend to the realm of Nothingness, to serve in the Golden Towers. I cannot answer the summons to come and go.” Soon after, his qi ceased.

He left instructions for a simple burial, forbidding the use of funerary objects, sacrificial vessels, or animal offerings. Over a month later, his complexion remained unchanged. When his body was lifted into the coffin, it was as light as an empty garment—he had already achieved *shijie* (liberation through apparent death). The dates of his transformation recorded in the hagiographies of immortals align with those in *The Old Book of Tang*. *The Old Book of Tang* states he lived over a hundred years, while *The Comprehensive Mirror of Buddhism* records that the recluse Sun Simiao died in the first year of Yongchun (682 CE). Proficient in the teachings of Lao-Zhuang, yin-yang, and medicine, he held Buddhist scriptures in particular esteem, and the world honored him as Sun the Perfected One.

Reconciling the recorded dates of his transformation, however, reveals he lived over thirty years longer—thus exceeding one hundred and twenty years. Comparing this with reliable historical records, the account in *The Comprehensive Mirror of Buddhism* is incorrect.

When Emperor Xuanzong of Tang fled to Shu, he dreamed of Sun Simiao requesting realgar. The emperor then ordered an imperial envoy to deliver ten catties of it to the summit of Mount Emei. As the envoy ascended the mountain, he saw an old man in a headscarf and coarse robe, flanked by two young attendants in blue. The old man said, “I have a memorial to present to the emperor.” The envoy looked upon a stone where over a hundred characters were inscribed in vermilion. As he copied them, the writing vanished as soon as it was transcribed. Suddenly, a white mist arose, and the figures disappeared.

Later, in Chengdu, there was a monk who recited the *Lotus Sutra* with great devotion. Though wars raged, he remained unharmed. One day, a mountain servant arrived and said, “The Master requests the monk to recite the sutra.” He was led through several streams and ridges, entering a mountain dwelling amid mist and clouds. The servant said, “The Master is elderly and ill, rising late. Please recite the ‘Treasure Tower’ chapter so he may hear it.” At that moment, the Master emerged—clad in rustic garb, leaning on a flowering staff, his ears hanging to his shoulders. After burning incense and listening to the recitation, he returned inside and did not reappear. The monk was served a meal of wild rice in a bamboo bowl, with dishes of wolfberry and chrysanthemum. Though lacking salt or dairy, the food tasted as sweet as ambrosia. He was also given a ring of bronze coins. The servant escorted him to the path’s end, where the monk asked, “What is the Master’s surname?” “Sun,” came the reply. “And his given name?” The servant wrote two characters in the monk’s palm: *Simiao*. The monk was startled; when he turned back, the servant had vanished. Searching the mountains, he could not find the old path. Upon returning, he examined the coins—now a hundred pieces of gold.

From that single meal, his body became light and free of illness. By the Tianxi era of Emperor Zhenzong of Song (1017–1021 CE), the monk was already over a hundred years old. Later, he vanished into seclusion, and none knew his whereabouts.

Minister Dao Yi remarked: Sun Simiao refined his qi and nurtured his spirit, delving deeply into medicine and tirelessly practicing hidden virtue. His compassion was boundless, and he devoted himself to goodness. Even for the bite of a small snake or the tiniest insect, he would apply medicine, seal the wound, and release them. His virtue extended even to insects—beyond what ordinary people could achieve. Thus, he received the dragon palace’s repayment, and such wondrous responses followed. As the *Daodejing* says: “Constantly good at saving all things, there is nothing discarded.” Sun Simiao embodied this principle.

Hu Yin Yao

Hu Yin Yao was a Daoist from Mount Dongting, who claimed to be a descendant of Master Jiaoli. On that mountain stood Jiaoli Village and Jiaoli Temple, where generations had attained the Dao. Yin Yao resided on Mount Jiao, where he studied the method of refining the form through the Great Yin. He died within a cave, instructing his disciples: "Observe my body constantly, and allow no thing to violate it. After six years, if I revive, clothe me again in robes and cap." His disciples watched over him—his flesh had decayed, yet his five viscera remained unchanged. They sealed and guarded him, and at the appointed time, he indeed revived. They prepared hot water for his bath and dressed him in new garments. His hair was loose and black, his beard thick and straight. Sixteen years later, he died again as before, reviving after another seven years. This occurred thrice in all, and though he lived some eighty years, his appearance remained that of a man in his thirties. Emperor Yang of Sui heard of him and summoned him, bestowing extraordinary favor and courtesy. During the *Zhenguan* era of Tang, Emperor Taizong summoned him to the inner palace and inquired about the Way of nurturing life.

He replied, "What I cultivate is but the resolve of a common man, my merits too slight to benefit the world. When an emperor cultivates the Dao, a single word of his brings fortune to ten thousand lands, and the efficacy of attaining the Way is all the swifter. My humble learning is not what one of Your Majesty’s exalted station should pursue." He then begged leave to return to the mountains, and his whereabouts thereafter were unknown.

**Liu Daohé**
Liu Daohé, also named Ai Dao, was a native of Wanqiu in Chen. From childhood he harbored reclusive aspirations and dwelt on Anyang Mountain in Shouchun. At the end of the Sui, he moved to Su Mountain and received the Dao from the Daoist Meng Shuo of Xiantang Abbey. Later he entered Huo Mountain. On the Spring Equinox, he opened his vow-text in a valley and, after walking several *li* back, was met with thunder, lightning, and rain, whereupon he took shelter in a cave. That night, he dreamed of being summoned; upon waking, a radiant light filled the air, and he saw a divine figure over ten feet tall, clad in robes, cap, sword, and sash, holding a talisman and accompanied by six or seven armored guards. The figure said to Daohé, "I am the Yellow Spirit, Great Mightful Envoy. Now the Six Heavens’ vile fiends harm the people and all things. Hearing of your devotion to the Dao and your unyielding integrity, you may subdue these demonic hordes. I bestow upon you the talismans and contracts of the Three Heavens’ Orthodox Unity and Alliance Might." Daohé received and swallowed them, and from then on, wherever he applied his Daoist arts, none failed to prove efficacious.

During the *Wude* era of Tang Gaozu, he entered Song Mountain and dwelt alongside Pan Shizheng. Gaozong, learning of this, issued an edict establishing Taiyi Abbey at his place of seclusion and bade him reside there. When the emperor was about to perform the Feng sacrifice at Mount Tai, unceasing rain fell. He dispatched Daohé to perform exorcisms, and the skies soon cleared. Favored by the court, Daohé would distribute any gifts he received to the poor and needy. When Luoyi suffered a plague of locusts, Daohé presented a talisman to the officials, instructing them to distribute copies throughout the region, whereupon the locusts vanished at once.

In the *Xianheng* era of Tang Gaozong, the emperor summoned him to create talismans. Having completed them but before he could present them, Daohé suddenly sorted through his writings with restless urgency, as if preparing to depart. When his disciples asked him about it, he replied, "The Lord of Life of Mount Lu has summoned me." Shortly after, he bathed, donned his cap and hempen robe, and transformed. During the *Diaolu* era, when the Fengtian Palace was being constructed, Daohé’s tomb was relocated. Upon opening the coffin, his bones were found disjointed, like a cicada’s molted husk—some say only an empty skin remained, split open along the back like a cicada’s cast-off shell. The emperor, hearing of this, remarked, "He prepared elixirs for me, yet consumed them himself and departed!" Thus concludes *Volume Twenty-Nine of A Comprehensive Mirror of Perfected Immortals Through the Ages Who Embodied the Dao*, and begins *Volume Thirty*.

Master Liang Chen

Daoist Liang Chen, styled Kaocheng, was a native of Fufeng in Jingzhao. He was broadly versed in the classics and histories, and though he delved into the arts of yin-yang divination and astrological observation, there was nothing he did not thoroughly master. He spurned fame and profit, disdained rich flavors, and found contentment only in tranquility and ease.

One day, a physiognomist saw him and remarked, "This youth’s eyes radiate a white light, and his countenance gathers true *qi*—he is no ordinary man." Later, he indeed took delight in the Dao of divine transcendents.

In the early *Xianxi* era of Emperor Yuan of the Great Wei, at the age of seventeen, he studied under Master Zheng at Louguan. His benevolence overcame his attachment to life, and his harmony precluded any desire to compete; all who knew him found joy in his presence. He often dreamed of wandering with immortals—now ascending famous mountains, now drinking stone marrow—and thus found his own amusement.

In the second year of the *Yongxing* era of Emperor Hui of Jin, the fifth day of the fifth month of the *yichou* year, Lord Lao commanded the Perfected One Yin Gui to descend at Louguan. Liang Chen then served him with the utmost reverence as a disciple. The following month, he was first taught the method of refining *qi* to conceal his form, then the arts of the cinnabar elixir of water and stone, and finally the talismans of the Six *Jia* spirits and the technique of gathering and ingesting the yellow essence of the sun and moon.

Later, he secluded himself on Mount Zhongnan, consuming black millet and swallowing talismans, fully realizing their wonders. He also extensively sought cinnabar, which he refined into an elixir. Whenever he spoke, his voice carried a clear and resonant tone. As his admirers grew in number, he withdrew deeper into the cliffs and valleys.

Once, trapped by a great snowstorm in which birds and beasts perished, Liang Chen alone remained in serene solitude, his resolve steadfast and sincere—thus, numinous immortals naturally gathered to him. His eyes could see things beneath the earth, and his ears could hear sounds from miles away.

One day, he suddenly told his disciples, "A friend awaits me on the southern peak; I must go now." He then donned his cap and robes and departed. Clouds and mist obscured his form, and only the faint strains of ceremonial music lingered in the air.

This occurred in the first year of the *Daxing* era of Emperor Yuan. The *Annals of the Primordial Origin* states: "He could fly and transform at will. After three years, his elixir was complete, and he ascended to heaven in broad daylight." —Sun Che

The Daoist Sun Che, styled Zhongxuan, was of unknown origin and served as the master of registers to Yin Tong. His nature was upright and forthright, sparing of speech. Outwardly, he seemed simple, yet within, he cultivated purity—no one could fathom him. In the early years of the *Chuguang* era of the Former Zhao, at the age of eighteen, he became a disciple of Master Wang. The master guided him in matters of withdrawal and engagement; people called the master the Great Refiner and Che the Lesser Refiner. As the master was held in high esteem by his age, those seeking his counsel grew numerous, and he soon withdrew into seclusion. Only Che remained at Louguan, sometimes lodging in the treetops or in places seldom frequented by others. He habitually wove kudzu into mats, sat upright with eyes closed, as if lost in thought. When others mocked him, he responded with humility, so that they would feel ashamed and withdraw. He could discern a person’s fortune or misfortune merely by observing their countenance, without waiting for them to speak.

At over seventy years of age, in the spring of the eighth year of the *Jianyuan* era of the Qin, he suddenly told his attendant, "I must depart for a time." He then brushed his robes and left, and no one ever knew his destination. His friend Ma Jian, missing him, took his kudzu mat and enshrined it in a quiet chamber. For several days, voices were heard speaking from the mat. Such were his numinous wonders.

Minister Dao Yi said: "Sun Che kept himself aloof from the dust of the world, delighting in the Dao and nurturing his true nature. When others treated him with disdain, he responded with humility, so that all felt ashamed of themselves. As the *Daodejing* says: *Only because he does not contend does the world not contend with him.* And again: *The Dao of the sage is to act without contending.* This describes Sun Che." —Ma Jian

Master of the Dao Ma Jian, styled Yuanyue, was a native of Youfufeng in Jingzhao and the tonsure-master of Yin Tong. At sixteen, he stood eight *chi* tall, with large, thick ears, arms that hung past his knees, a ridge of hidden rhinoceros bone upon his brow, and vertical lines upon his palms. He diminished his indulgence in music and beauty, and set aside fame and profit. Widely versed in the classics and histories, he excelled especially in the *Songs of Chu* and the *Airs of the States*. The commanderies and counties marveled at him and offered official appointments, but he declined. During the *Ganling* era of the Qin, he entered the register of Daoist adepts at Louguan and studied the Dao under Sun Che, at the time aged seventeen. Sun Che then transmitted to him the essentials of the Dao.

In scriptural abundance, these included the *Five Talismans of the True Writ*, the *Inner Writ of the Three Sovereigns*, the *Daodejing*, the *Scriptures of Numinous Treasure*, and the arts of *dunjia* divination and astrological prognostication. In the subtleties of medicinal arts, these encompassed grain avoidance and water ingestion, the consumption of jujube paste, *tianmen* elixirs, wood decoctions, *jianshang* preparations, *lu* wine, the *Cloud Teeth of the Five Directions*, the *Six Jia Talismans*, the *Inner Sounds of the Myriad Heavens*, and methods of *xingqi* and *daoyin*. In commanding the myriad spirits and subduing the host of demons, he mastered the ordinances of the *Eight Officials and Six Ding*, the *Twenty-Four Spirits*, and the *Essentials of the Three Sovereigns*—none of which failed to prove efficacious.

Yao Chang, hearing of him, found him extraordinary and dispatched envoys to summon him, but he declined on grounds of illness. Yao Chang, admiring his integrity, provided him with incense and candles, his reverence and esteem deepening. Jian’s resolve in the Dao grew ever firmer; his benevolence and kindness extended to all things, and those who flocked to him for aid increased daily.

One day, a celestial spirit descended and declared: "Master of the Dao, you have long accumulated merit and virtue, and now you diligently cultivate the Daoist arts. Your cinnabar name is inscribed in the Jade Register, your white tally recorded in the Dark Terrace—this has been so for some time. But preserve your heavenly years... you shall surely attain transcendence."

Why should one trifle with prayers and petitions, toil over summons and exorcisms? One may instead roam freely through the Three Primes, merge with the Five Spirits, sever all sensory perceptions, and preserve solitude in purity and vastness. Thus, nurturing the spirit and cultivating simplicity, he no longer ventured forth, while immortals and perfected beings descended at times.

At ninety-eight years of age, in the winter of the tenth month on the first day of the fifth year of Emperor Taiwu of the Later Wei’s *Dayan* reign, he said to his disciple Yin Tong: "All that I have cultivated and attained in this life must be kept secret and not revealed." Soon after, a white cloud came from the northwest, covering his bedchamber. In an instant, he returned to the True, leaving only an unceasing fragrance, as the white cloud ascended to the south.

The Daoist Yin Tong, styled Lingjian, was a descendant of the Perfected One’s lineage. From childhood, he studied the Confucian classics, mastering all the group of classics, histories, and philosophers without exception. He often lamented the impermanence of worldly transformations, gazing at the heavens in sighs. His parents, unaware of his aspirations, pressed him to marry and pursue an official career. Tong knelt and said: "I have heard that when Zhang the Perfected ascended to heaven, Zhen Nan succeeded his glory; when the Mao Lords attained the Dao, the Grand Guardian pledged his faith. How much more, as the descendant of the Supreme Pole Perfected One’s legacy, should I not honor and continue it? I wish to follow my own resolve." His parents consented, and he departed in a gust of wind.

At the time, banditry and calamity ravaged the land. Tong endured hardships and dangers, braving perils to reach Louguan. At twenty-six, in the first year of Emperor Taiwu’s *Shiguang* reign, he served Master Ma Jian. After years of diligent service, he was finally bestowed the Perfected One’s secret transmissions: jade scripts and golden writings. When his parents passed away, he observed the rites of filial piety to their fullest, yet his resolve to seek the True and guard the One grew daily. Morning and evening, he tended the incense and paid homage without the slightest slackening. For decades, he consumed yellow essence, realgar, and asparagus root, his body growing ever lighter and his nature more keen. He was especially devoted to healing the sick—those who could be cured, he treated; those beyond hope, he declared incurable.

Emperor Taiwu, fond of the Dao, revered his reputation and often sent envoys with incense and candles, commissioning him to perform purification rites and conduct Daoist ceremonies. From then on, visitors from all directions sought his audience without cease, yet Tong’s heart dwelled only on merit and virtue, giving without seeking, dispersing without hoarding. At the time, his nephew Fa Xing, along with Niu Wenhou, Wang Daoyi, and seven other disciples, followed in his footsteps, all aspiring to the numinous path. Thus, the teachings of the immortal winds and true way flourished anew.

At one hundred and one years of age, his hearing and vision remained sharp, and he could still write by night. In the fourth month of summer, on the eighth day of the twenty-third year of Emperor Xiaowen’s *Taihe* reign (later revised to *Chengming* in the second year), he suddenly bid his disciples a final farewell. After a moment, he passed away in an instant, his complexion unchanged. After his burial, on the western slope of Laozi’s Ascension Mound, several divine lamps appeared, their light illuminating the site before gradually dispersing.

The Daoist Niu Wenhou, a native of Longxi, was of exceptional intelligence and learning, deeply versed in the ancient and modern, particularly in the teachings of Zhuangzi and Laozi. He mastered astronomy and geography, leaving no detail unexamined.

He was also skilled in instructing others, guiding them in loyalty and filial piety according to their nature. In exhortation and admonition, he revealed the principles of sin and blessing; in enforcing prohibitions, he employed talismans and registers. Thus, the Daoist teachings flourished anew, and many turned from evil to goodness. When lecturing to others, he never concerned himself with profit or wealth; if compelled to accept, he took little and declined much. When he learned of someone in poverty, he would secretly send goods to their home, wishing to conceal the source. Each winter’s cold, he scattered grain upon the ground so that birds and insects might have food. His hidden merits and quiet kindness extended greatly to people and slightly to creatures. Cultivating himself and accumulating virtue, his dedication deepened with time.

In the fifth year of Emperor Wen of Western Wei’s *Datong* reign, on the twenty-eighth day of the eighth month, he dreamed of a young Daoist in blue robes who announced: "The Emperor Above has issued a decree—you should prepare at once, for you shall depart at dawn tomorrow." Upon waking, he bid farewell to his disciples. The next day, after bathing, he indeed passed away, having lived eighty-two years.

**Wang Daoyi**
The Daoist Wang Daoyi was a man of the Wei dynasty. Well-read in all classics, he also mastered apocryphal texts and prognostication. Knowing that Mount Zhongnan held the site of Yin Xi’s transcendence, during Emperor Xiaowen of Northern Wei’s *Taihe* reign, he led six or seven disciples from Mount Guye to reside there. Earlier, Daoists Niu Wenhou, Yin Lingjian, and over forty others had propagated the Dao and its teachings, earning reverence from court and commoner alike. In times of famine, when the monastery’s resources were nearly exhausted, Daoyi undertook grand renovations, mobilizing laborers and craftsmen. Though hundreds worked daily, supplies never ran short. Those who marveled and observed found storehouses fully stocked, their contents inexhaustible. All knew the master’s divine transformation was secretly aided by spirits. Thus, halls, altars, and pavilions were all renewed. Only the Laozi Hall built by the First Emperor of Qin, for its grandeur, remained untouched. He instructed his disciples to collect over ten thousand volumes of sacred scriptures, all funded by his own means, never soliciting others. His nature was vast and unburdened.

Within his chamber, voices were often heard. When disciples stealthily investigated, they discovered gatherings of true immortals. During Emperor Xuanwu of Northern Wei’s *Yongping* reign, as he neared his return to the Dao, white clouds filled the room and rare fragrances perfumed the courtyard, lingering until sunset. Locals later saw Daoyi riding a deer as he departed.

**Chen Baochi**
Master Zhengyi Chen Baochi was a native of Yingchuan. At twenty-one, he took no pleasure in marriage or office. In the eighteenth year of Emperor Xiaowen’s *Taihe* reign, he entered the register of Louguan Monastery and served the Dharma Master Wang Daoyi. Soon after attaining transcendence, he journeyed to Huayin.

Once more, he encountered the Perfected Immortal Lu Jing, who transmitted secret methods to him before he returned. From then on, he cultivated with utmost sincerity and emptied himself, adhering faithfully to the practices and reciting the *Great Cavern Scripture*. Over time, his communion deepened, and rare birds and strange beasts would often come to attend and guard him. Whenever he paid homage at the Laozi shrine or presented dragon tablets at the eight solar nodes, white tigers would docilely follow at a distance, escorting him to and fro. If travelers harbored ill intent, the tigers would roar and surge forward, once even striking the locust tree to the left of the temple, causing the malevolent to flee in terror. The people thus named it the "Tiger Tree." His virtue manifested so profoundly that he communed with the unseen and reached the hidden realms, leaving nothing beyond his influence. Before events came to pass, he would know of them in advance. When malevolent spirits or demons harmed people, his prohibitions would halt them at once.

Emperor Wen of Western Wei, struck by his extraordinary abilities, summoned him to the Yan Ying Palace to inquire about the Dao. At the time, the Grand Preceptor, the Duke of Anding, and the court’s scholar-officials all followed and took him as their master. At seventy-six, on the seventeenth day of the third month in the fifteenth year of the *Datong* era, he addressed his disciples: "Last night, I dreamed that immortals summoned me, and I shall not tarry long. Why rejoice at coming? Why grieve at going? Life and death are one in the Dao; dream and waking share the same principle. You must embody this—let no sorrow arise." With these words, he suddenly departed.

An imperial edict posthumously bestowed upon him the title "Master of Upright Virtue."

**Wang Yan**
Daoist Wang Yan, styled Ziyuan, was a native of Fufeng. At just nine years old, he was drawn to the Dao. In the third year of Emperor Xiaowen of Western Wei’s *Datong* era, the *ding-si* year, he entered the Dao under Master of Upright Virtue Chen Baochi. By eighteen, he was studying at Louguan Monastery and befriended the Perfected Immortal Li Shun. Later, he visited the Yuntai Temple on Mount Hua and took Jiao Kuang, the Perfected Immortal, as his master, receiving the secret oral instructions and true scriptures of the Three Caverns. He subsisted on pine needles and drank from mountain streams, seeking the profound truths of the Dao.

Emperor Wu of Northern Zhou, having heard of his reputation, dispatched envoys to summon him. The Perfected Immortal Jiao said to him: "The Daoist teachings have declined, long bereft of support. You should answer the summons and propagate the great Daoist teachings. From this moment, I shall depart." Upon arriving at the capital, after some time, he obtained permission to return to the Yuntai Temple on Mount Hua’s western peak. The emperor then ordered its expansion to accommodate him. However, the mountain’s rocky terrain lacked soil, making its transport exceedingly laborious. In silent prayer to Heaven, soil suddenly welled forth beside the temple, inexhaustible no matter how much was taken.

Once, troubled by a shortage of oil, he placed a vessel there, and by morning it was full, remaining abundant even after prolonged use. Whenever guests were about to arrive, two azure crows—shaped like ravens—would fly and cry out in advance. Climbing the Immortals’ Palm or the Lotus Peak, he moved as if treading level ground. Wherever he dwelled, fierce tigers would appear, tame and distant, as if guarding him.

At that time, the world was submerged in the teachings of the Buddha. Yet his followers failed to uphold the discipline of meditation, instead wielding notions of sin and fortune to alarm the common folk. The corruption grew rampant, prompting a purge. Daoist teachings teetered on the brink of extinction. Only the Master’s name was held in reverence by the emperor, who summoned him to the palace to consult on the essentials of the Dao. The emperor also wished to establish a Tongdao Temple and commanded him to collate and compile the Three Caverns’ scriptures, rituals, precepts, talismans, and registers—over eighty scrolls in total. He further composed the *Three Caverns Pearl Satchel* in seven scrolls, which the emperor ordered disseminated at the Tongdao Temple. Thus, Daoist teachings revived, and the court adopted the era name *Daxiang* in recognition.

When Emperor Wen of Sui abdicated, he established the Xuandu Temple and decreed that Yan oversee it. In the sixth year of the *Kaihuang* era, the *bing-wu* year, he was specially summoned to the Daxing Palace. The emperor, in sincere devotion, received the Great Precepts of Wisdom. Auspicious winds and propitious clouds then enveloped the altar. From this, the rituals and decorum of the Daoist gate were established—the term "decorum" originated here. At the time, the court’s ministers and scholar-officials all revered and followed him.

In the fourth year of the *Renshou* era, on an auspicious day in the third month, he addressed his disciples: "I wish to return to the western peak, but I fear the emperor may not permit it." On the ninth day, he ascended at the Xiandu Temple, where white cranes flew and cried, circling the courtyard. The emperor, struck by the marvel, sent envoys to escort his burial at the western peak. When the tomb was opened, only an empty coffin remained.

Minister Dao Yi remarked: "Wang Yan, from his youth, studied the Dao and found enlightened masters. He upheld the teachings and established their lineage, communing with spirits and moving all things. When Emperor Wu ordered the expansion of the Yuntai Temple, the labor of transporting soil was a concern. In silent prayer to Heaven and Earth, soil suddenly surged forth, inexhaustible no matter how much was taken. This was the power of accumulated sincerity moving Heaven—how could such a feat be easily achieved? As the *Dao De Jing* states: 'The Dao of Heaven shows no partiality; it always aligns with the good.'"

Li Shunxing

Daoist Li Shunxing was a native of Jingzhao. His mother conceived after dreaming of a bright star descending from the heavens. At his birth, a Daoist arrived and said: "This child was once an attained adept of the Dao, temporarily lodged in the womb." At just nine years old, he loved purity and emptiness, often sitting in perfect stillness. His parents, discerning his inclination, sent him to study under Master Zheng Yi. At eleven, he took the Daoist register.

He constantly recited the *Great Cavern Sutra*, never tiring. Zheng Yi then established an altar for him, transmitting the *Five Thousand Character Text* and the *Yellow Court Scripture*, saying: "Though you are still young, your heart already aligns with the Real. According to the hidden instructions, if you recite these for three years, you will ascend to heaven in broad daylight. You must strive diligently." Thereupon, he devoted himself to recitation in his dwelling. Before three years had passed, on an autumn equinox evening, thousands of flying immortals gathered in the sky, their divine radiance illuminating his chamber. Stepping outside to gaze, he saw two figures who said: "The Supreme Emperor has commanded us to await you in the Purple Pavilion Grotto. We are the gods of the Direct Day and have come to summon you." He then mounted a wind-borne chariot and arrived in an instant.

There, he saw three immortals, each seated upon a couch, with five-colored clouds and mist swirling above them. Their attendants bore banners and plumes beyond description. He bowed and inquired about the Way of ascending in flight. They said: "You possess accumulated virtue from past lives, and your rank is that of a Perfected. To ascend in both form and spirit would not be difficult. However, the Most High has sent you to be reborn to accumulate merit through diligent practice. Though you have fasted and recited scriptures for some time, your merit has not yet extended to others—how could you attain this so soon?" He then earnestly pleaded, hoping to inspire the common and mediocre, and asked: "If I accumulate merit and deeds to atone for past transgressions, would that be possible?" The immortals replied: "Excellent! Such a heart is truly pitiable. Though your bones and qi align with the Real, your fetal form has not yet been shed."

The attendant scripture immortal then opened the *Nine-Colored Flowing Radiance Record* and presented three scrolls before the three immortals. The eldest immortal unfurled the *Jade Perfection Golden Radiance Scripture of the Most High*, saying: "I am Perfected Zhao Boyuan of the Supreme Clarity. I once received this scripture from the Eastern Flower Youth and cultivated it to attain perfection. I now transmit it to you—you must cultivate it." The next immortal produced the *Divine Continent’s Seven Transformations and Seven Changes, with the Heavenly Scripture*, saying: "I am Perfected Zhang Zhongyi of the Supreme Clarity. I once received this scripture from the Heavenly King of Lesser Existence and cultivated it to become a Perfected. I now bestow it upon you—you must strive diligently." The third immortal then took the true scriptures from the hands of the other two and exhorted: "I am Perfected Li Shaojun of the Supreme Clarity. I once received this scripture and thereby attained ascension. I share a karmic connection with you, so I have come to oversee your transcendence. If you follow the rites of the Four Poles and practice for seven years, your body will gain the power of flight. After seven hundred years, you may transmit these teachings to three others; if no suitable person is found, you must seal them in a famous mountain. The true arts of immortality now bestowed upon you—if you cultivate them without cease, you will transform the mundane and succeed, ascending to immortality in due time. Without this Way, your spirit will not achieve penetrating clarity, your body will not attain purity and emptiness, and you will be recorded by the Eight Emperors and overthrown by the Six Heavens—how then could you transform the mundane?"

They then composed a verse:
The supreme Dao is originally formless,
Yet takes names from things.
If one diligently studies the highest,
The Way of immortality naturally succeeds.
The Jade Emperor summons the Crimson Child,
The Golden Perfection unites the Yellow Court.
The six senses achieve profound union,
The eight difficulties thus vanish.
The radiant spirit revolves sevenfold,
The empty breast illumines the Four Clarities.
Breath and transformation can shift ten thousand ways,
Revering and gazing upon the hundred spirits.
In harmonious transformation, roam the dusty paths,
Swiftly rein the cloud-banners.
I pledge to my many friends,
To meet you in Penglai’s isles.

Thereafter, the three immortals mounted their chariots and departed, and he returned to his dwelling. Upon his return, he recited the scriptures and practiced their arts. At seventeen, his Dao was accomplished: his transformations were boundless, and he responded to circumstances and engaged with others without obstruction. Zheng Yi, recognizing this, treated him with even greater esteem. Skeptics secretly tested him by pouring boiling water and exposing him to fire, yet he never complained of heat. When made to tread fire or enter water, he could not be burned or drowned.

Emperor Wen of the Western Wei, hearing of his fame, summoned him to the capital, where he attended over a hundred vegetarian feasts held in the city’s wards, all of which he could attend. Though the emperor knew of his ability to divide his form and transform his shadow, he still doubted whether he could be near and far at once. He then ordered simultaneous vegetarian feasts in the four prefectures of Qi, Ning, Tong, and Hua, all of which he attended in full. From then on, both court and common folk revered and believed in him.

Initially, people did not know of his abilities and simply called him "Master Li the Cultivator." After his spiritual transformations became widely known, he was styled "Master Li the Sage." At thirty-eight, in the eighth year of the Datong era, he feigned illness and passed away. On the day of his burial, a nephew encountered him on the road to Mount Li and was told: "If the Son of Heaven has not forgotten me, erect my image here, facing north, and I will ward off the perverse customs of the northern lands for the state." The nephew returned home only to learn of his passing. He reported the matter in full, and envoys were sent to open the tomb, finding only an empty coffin. A shrine was then established in Shayuan.

Hou Kai

Daoist Hou Kai, styled Faxian, was also a native of Jingzhao. At fourteen, he devoted himself to the study of scriptures, particularly excelling in the teachings of Laozi and Zhuangzi. Drawn to solitude and loftiness, he neither married nor pursued office, instead studying under Master Zheng Yi. At nineteen, during the Zhengshi era of Emperor Xuanwu of the Later Wei, he became a Daoist and was transmitted the secret instructions of the *Mysterious Text*. His morning and evening devotions grew ever more fervent over time.

Zheng Yi said: "Though you are steadfast in heart and resolute in conduct, unwavering in the Dao, without retiring to the mountains and forests, attainment will not come easily." Hou Kai replied: "The Dao resides in the square inch of the heart—why must one seek the mountains and forests?" Zheng Yi said: "I too know the Dao is everywhere, yet when cultivated among people, there are times when attainment is possible."

Yet since ancient times, those who attained transcendence often first took refuge in the wilds and marshes. Only after achieving perfection did they emerge to mingle with the world of dust. The Perfected of the Highest Realms have also said: *"The* Great Cavern Perfection Scripture *must not be chanted among men—if chanted, great demons will corrupt it."* Moreover, when the Venerable Master Ge was about to ascend to perfection, he parted from his disciple Zheng Siyuan, saying: *"Why not ascend a famous mountain to recite the* Great Cavern Perfection Scripture*, intoning each verse with resonant harmony, so that the mystic sound pierces the Great Clarity?"* From this, we know that entering the mountains is not merely a matter of preference—it naturally accords with the scriptures and the Dao. You now yearn for the profound and the subtle; thus, retiring to the mountains is most fitting.

Hou Kai replied: *"Though dwelling in the mountains may preserve perfection, does it not distance one from the master’s teachings and the discipline of precepts?"* His master praised his words and added: *"The Dao is not difficult to know—it is difficult to practice. If you can remain steadfast from beginning to end, the Dao will reside within you."*

When Zheng Yi ascended as an immortal, Hou Kai chose to dwell in Cold Valley, where he practiced the *Three Rushing Arts*—a method attributed to the Yellow Emperor’s *Three Rushing Arts of Governing Women*. Later generations, misled by its transmission, have come to mistake it for what the immortals strictly forbid. Yet Hou Kai, having studied under Chen Baochi, traced his lineage to the authentic traditions of divine transcendence; it was unlikely he practiced the *Three Rushing Arts*. Rather, it was likely the *High Rushing* method of the immortals, a practice aligned with the Great Dao—perhaps a scribal error in later transmissions.

He recited the *Great Cavern Scripture*, the *Inner Texts of the Three Sovereigns*, and the arts of summoning and exorcism. His dwelling was encircled by clear springs, and three pines arched overhead, creating a secluded and tranquil retreat—his abode of true attainment. Thus, he named it Three Pines Abbey. Whenever people suffered from the harm of mountain spirits or demons, regardless of distance, they sought his aid. Some he cured with incantations, others with talismans and arts, and all afflictions were instantly dispelled.

When his end drew near, he was free of illness. He addressed his disciples, saying: *"Long ago, Fei Zhangfang lost his talisman and was slain by ghosts. I have not lost my talisman—I am returning to the perfection of the Dao. If the world fails to understand, they may mistake me for Zhangfang."*

In his eighty-sixth spring and autumn, he transcended form in the winter of the tenth month of the second year of Jiande under Emperor Wu of Zhou.

Master Yán Dá, styled Dàotōng, was a native of Fúfēng. From his earliest years, he harbored aspirations beyond the mundane world. Whenever he obtained a flower or a fruit, he would reverently offer it before the sacred image. Master Hóu of Lóuguàn observed this and esteemed him highly. In the *Yǒngxīng* era of Emperor Míngyuán of the Later Wèi, he entered the Dao at the age of twenty. During his intervals of fasting and cultivation, he would often seek instruction in the great scriptures. Thus, he mastered the *Qióngchuò* and attained broad comprehension of the subtle and profound.

During the *Jiàndé* era of Emperor Wu of Zhou, the emperor summoned Master Yán and Wáng Yán to the private palace hall. At that time, the emperor had already purged the Buddhist clergy and had further consulted his ministers, intending to abolish the Daoist tradition as well. The emperor asked the master which was superior, the Dao or the teachings of Śākyamuni. The master replied: *"The host is superior, the guest inferior."* The emperor asked: *"How does one distinguish host from guest?"* The master said: *"Śākyamuni came from the West—is he not the guest? The Dao arose in the Central Lands—is it not the host?"* The emperor said: *"If the guest returns to the West, does the host not see him off?"* The master replied: *"If the guest returns, it benefits the lands of the Hu; if the host remains, it does no harm to the Middle Kingdom. What need is there to pursue the departed or send them off? Let those who remain be officially preserved."* The emperor praised his response, yet could not avoid some suppression. Apart from the temples of the Five Marchmounts, all others were abolished. He specially built the Tōngdào Abbey for the master to the left of Tiángǔ, and selected ten disciples from Lóuguàn to jointly propagate the true teaching.

At the time, Wáng Yán sought to acquire more disciples, but the master said: *"The enlightened of antiquity first established it within themselves before establishing it in others. Now, though the emperor does not wish to abolish the Daoist teaching, his intent is to reduce its excesses. Yet the Dao values those who embody it; the subtle net of the Way will naturally uphold itself. Why must there be many? For many bring many burdens, and this would instead become a blemish upon our Way. The Dao does not favor mixture; mixture leads to excess, excess to confusion, confusion to disorder, and disorder to the loss of true principle. What benefit could there be?"* Thus, together with Wáng Yán, Sū Dàobiāo, Chéng Fǎmíng, Zhōu Huàshēng, Wáng Zhēnwēi, Shǐ Dàolè, Yú Chángwén, Zhāng Fǎchéng, and Fú Dàochóng—ten in all—they forgot worldly concerns through the arts of the Dao, harmonizing their comings and goings. The age called them the *Ten Elders of Tiángǔ*.

When the Dàoist teaching revived under the Suí dynasty, Emperor Wén in the *Kāihuáng* era issued an edict to restore the two temples, meticulously selecting Daoist clergy and repeatedly presenting written prayers to invoke blessings. Thus, both court and common folk revered and followed them. In the fifth year of *Dàyè* under Emperor Yáng, on the seventeenth day of the third month, the emperor listened as Master Zhōu played the zither. He remarked: *"The zither’s sound moves the spirits; a deity shall descend."* He asked for another piece to be played. Before the melody concluded, the master suddenly returned to the true, having lived ninety-one springs and autumns.

Master Yú Zhāng, styled Chángwén, was a native of Yòu Fúfēng.

At the age of seven, his parents taught him the *Classic of Filial Piety*. After several days, he said: *"I have heard of the* Dàodé Jīng*; my heart wishes to study and recite it."* His parents, struck by his words, allowed him to follow his inclination and study under Master Hóu. In the ninth year of *Dàtǒng* under the Western Wèi, he took the tonsure, enduring the toils of the monastic life for fourteen years. The master, moved by his dedication, revealed to him the essential methods of the *Three Caverns* and the host of perfected beings, bestowing them as if overturning a basket. He once said to himself: *"The talismans and mandates of the perfected are not for common transmission. Now that I have obtained them, they are truly my treasures."* Thereupon, in a quiet chamber, he transcribed cloud scripts and dragon charts, conducting the rites with utmost reverence. When he applied these to others, none failed to manifest divine efficacy.

It so happened that an imperial edict selected ten clerics of pure precepts to reside at the *Tōngdào* Abbey, and he was among them. Yet he always harbored a longing for the true, aspiring to dwell in seclusion. In the second year of *Dàxiàng* under Emperor Jìng of Zhōu, he chose a site beneath the western ridge below the abbey. There, he felled thatch, piled stones, and roamed the forests and springs, savoring their flavors. He consumed yellow essence, fuling, and mountain rehmannia, practiced *qi*-absorption, swallowed talismans, and conducted *fēizhāng* rites. Through such unceasing diligence over the years, in the seventeenth year of *Kāihuáng* under Emperor Wén of Suí, he again received the *Sixty Jiazi* and the talismanic seals of the *Five Emperors* and *Five Marchmounts* from the *Royal Elder of Transformation* and the *Perfected Lord of the Supreme Ultimate*, totaling one hundred and thirty-six items. He also expounded the origins of heaven and earth, the roots and branches of talismans, and the ritual forms for altar arrangements. Recording the days and months for talisman transmission and the instructions of perfected immortals, he compiled them in order, titling it *Origins and Sequence*. Thus, his aspiration to commune with the true advanced daily. His divine transformations in dispelling demonic dreams and malevolent spirits were immeasurable, and the benefits bestowed upon the common folk grew ever more abundant.

On the fourteenth day of the sixth month in the tenth year of *Dàyè* under Emperor Yáng, he ascended in feathered transformation, having lived eighty-two springs and autumns. On the day of his passing, a white crow departed from his coffin, and people said he had attained the Dao of shedding his mortal form.

**Master Zhāng Fǎlè**
The Daoist Master Zhāng Fǎlè was a native of Nányáng.

In his youth, he studied the Dao and took delight in springs and rocks. Upon reaching the age of adolescence, he took refuge at the Edge Tower Abbey, serving Master Yǐn Qǐ. With wholehearted devotion, he attended to his master’s side for many years. Moved by his diligence and toil, Master Yǐn eventually entrusted him with the essentials of the Dao. On the night of his initiation under the open sky, divine lamps radiated brilliance, and auspicious clouds shimmered with color. Thereafter, he fulfilled his duties with utmost reverence—tending to the master’s headscarf and water vessel, bearing the labors of desk and mat—observing every ritual from beginning to end. Later, he sought seclusion and explored wonders, choosing to dwell west of Gěng Valley. Wearing tattered robes and subsisting on vegetables, he severed all worldly ties. Daily, he recited the *Five Thousand Character Text* and cultivated the Dao of *Cíyī*. Refining his form and nurturing his *qi*, he embraced oneness and guarded the true, enduring thus for thirty years. Clouds gathered upon the beams, and rosy hues settled upon his window—people called his abode Cloud Abode Abbey. In time, his Daoist practice flourished, and spiritual resonance came naturally. Once, a tiger’s roar shook the earth, yet he regarded it without fear. Later, the beast came and went, docile as if offering protection. When visitors approached with disrespect or insincerity, they were invariably repelled and could not draw near. Morning and evening, the faint sound of divine bells lingered in his ears, though none could discern their source. On fast days, twenty-odd figures clad in grass garments would deliver frankincense and a few dried jujubes; when he stepped outside to look, they vanished.

In the third year of Emperor Fèi of the Western Wèi, in the third month, he said to his disciple Zhāng Tōng: “Though I have received subtle signs, my merits and virtues remain incomplete. Recently, a spirit foretold that I shall not linger long and must entrust my form to the deep earth for over two hundred years. The affairs of the unseen realm value secrecy—you may know but a little.” On the fifteenth day of the fourth month, at dawn, he leaned upon his desk and transformed. At that moment, a white *qi*, cloud-like, pierced through the window, stretching over a *zhàng* in length, and dispersed only after the time it takes to eat a meal.

**Jù Guózhēn**
The Master Jù, named Guózhēn, was a native of Wǔgōng. Of sincere and honest nature, he was fond of the study of immortals and transcendents. At thirty, he severed worldly ties and served Master Yóu at the Abbey of the Tower. This was in the fourth year of *Rénshòu* under Emperor Wén of the Suí. Beyond his devotions, he recited scriptures without cease, his heart ever fixed on the One. He forgot both fame and profit, relinquishing joy and anger. Subsisting on vegetables and wearing tattered robes, his resolve only deepened. If anyone offered him goods, he would accept and distribute them at once.

Should anyone treat him with disdain or contempt, he never once grew resentful or angry. Pleased with his conduct, the Dharma Master bestowed upon him the *Sīwēi Precepts Record*, along with sealed talismans and summons. Following these texts in his practice, his diligence knew no bounds. Whenever he approached the altar to recite scriptures, though he might not yet have completed even a few rounds, neither winter’s winds nor summer’s heat ever caused him to falter. One day, struck by illness, others urged him to take medicine. He replied, “When the Dao prevails, illness vanishes—what cause for concern is there?” Such was his unshakable faith.

From near and far, the common folk, drawn by his virtue, came in numbers beyond counting. At the age of sixty, on the thirteenth day of the fifth month in the summer of the eighth year of *Zhēnguàn* under Emperor Tàizōng of the Táng, as he napped in the daytime, his disciples suddenly heard the sound of carriages and horses. Moments later, the tiled roof trembled, and the Dharma Master thus departed. *Lìshì Zhēnxiān Tǐdào Tōngjiàn*, Scroll Thirty, ends here.

---

**Zhōnglí Quán**
The Perfected One, surnamed Zhōnglí, named Quán, later changed his name to Jué. His courtesy name was Jìdào, and his sobriquets included Hé Gǔzǐ, Zhèng Yángzǐ, and Yúnfáng Xiānshēng. A native of Yàntái—some say of Xiányáng in Jīngzhào—his great-grandfather’s name was Pǔ, his grandfather’s name was Shǒudào, and his father’s name was Yuán, all renowned figures of the Hàn dynasty. His father held the rank of marquis and served in the Yúnzhōng Prefecture.

At the time of the Perfected One’s miraculous birth, a radiance spanning several *zhàng*, resembling a raging fire, illuminated the surroundings, startling all who stood guard. The Perfected One’s appearance was striking: his head was round, his forehead broad, his ears thick, his shoulders long, his eyes deep-set, his nose prominent, his mouth square, his cheeks full, and his lips and face as rosy as cinnabar or milk. His arms hung long, like those of a three-year-old child. For seven days and nights, he neither cried nor fed, until on the seventh day, he leapt up with a resonant voice, declaring, “My body roams the Purple Palace; my name is inscribed in the Jade Capital.” His voice rang like a bell, and his gait was swift as a galloping horse—no child of his age could match him. (Some accounts say that in his youth, he studied literature and served the Hàn dynasty as a Remonstrating Grandee. Having submitted a memorial on Lǐ Jiān’s frontier affairs, he was exiled to the south of the Jiāng. After the Hàn dynasty fell, he served the Wèi and later the Jìn.) *Lìshì Zhēnxiān Tǐdào Tōngjiàn*, Scroll Thirty-One.

In his prime, he served the Jìn as a great general, leading troops to battle the Tǔfān in the northwest. As the two armies clashed, suddenly heaven shook with thunder and lightning, wind and rain plunged the world into darkness, and men could not see one another—both armies scattered without a fight. (Another account says that during the reign of Emperor Wǔ of Jìn, he was ordered to join the Vice General Zhōu Chǔ in a campaign that ended in defeat. The Perfected One fled alone into the mountains, losing his way. That night, he pressed deep into a secluded forest ravine, hoping to preserve his life. There he encountered a foreign monk, his forehead shaded by a bamboo hat, his body clad in a robe of woven grass. The monk led him for several *lǐ* to a village, saying, “This is where Master Dōnghuá attained the Dao. You may rest here.” With a bow, the monk departed.)

(Another version says he met a monk who, without speaking, pointed southeast toward a temple. Before its gates stood two Daoists in blue robes. When he asked where he was, they replied, “This is the abode of the Lesser Yáng Emperor of the Purple Palace.” The Perfected One dared not disturb the village. After a long while, he suddenly heard voices saying, “That green-eyed foreign monk is meddlesome.” Then an old man in a white deer-fur cloak, leaning on a staff of green jade, called out, “Are you not the great general Zhōnglí Quán?” The Perfected One answered, “I am.” The old man continued, “Why did you not lodge with the mountain monk?” Startled, the Perfected One thought, *This must be no ordinary man.* His tiger-like ferocity vanished, and his heart turned toward the Dao like a phoenix or crane. Unaware, he had already resolved to seek the path to transcendence.

Thereupon, the old man bestowed upon him the True Oral Formula for Longevity, the Vermilion Talisman and Jade Script, the Golden Regulations and Sacred Texts, the Fire Phases of the Golden Elixir, and the Sword Techniques of the Azure Dragon, urging him to practice diligently. When the Perfected One took his leave and turned back, the village had vanished. From then on, he grasped the profound mysteries.

(Another account says that, knowing he possessed the bones of an immortal, he cast off worldly entanglements to inherit the fruits of transcendence.
