First, he met the Supreme Immortal Wáng Xuánfǔ, from whom he received the Oral Formula for Longevity. Later, he encountered the Perfected One of Huáyáng, who transmitted the Great Unity’s Knife and Spoon, the Fire Talismans of Internal Alchemy, and the profound mysteries of the Mysterious Dao.)

(Another version says that long ago, the Yellow Emperor obtained the secret formula of the Golden Elixir and concealed it in a jade casket within the Suspended Bell Cavern on Purple Gold Mountain east of Shòuchūn County. After receiving transmission from his master, the Perfected One wandered as a cloud or flowing water. Arriving in Lǔ, he dwelled in Zōuchéng, entered Kōngtóng, and resided on the Four Elders’ Peak of Purple Gold Mountain. There, an immortal led him into a cavern, where he retrieved the jade casket and its secret formula. His inner virtue perfected, he ultimately attained the wondrous Dao.)

*The Complete Transmission of the Perfect Realization* states: The Perfected One was born on the fifteenth day of the fourth month in the Hàn dynasty and ascended on the twentieth day of the fifth month during the Jìn, though the year is unrecorded.

Later, Lǚ Shàoxiān, a Táng dynasty *jìnshì*, failed the imperial examinations repeatedly and roamed the world. First, on Mount Lú, he met the Perfected One of the Fire Dragon, who transmitted sword techniques. Later, on the road to Cháng’ān, he encountered the Perfected One’s inscription on a wall:

*Sitting or lying, always with a jug of wine,*
*Never letting both eyes gaze toward the Eastern Capital.*
*In heaven and earth, nameless and unknown,*
*A carefree man of the world, a true gentleman.*

Shàoxiān bowed deeply. The Perfected One bade him compose a poem expressing his aspirations. Shàoxiān wrote:

*Born into a Confucian family in peaceful times,*
*With scholar’s cap and sash, clad in humble cloth.*
*Who in this world would vie for fame and profit?*
*I serve the Jade Emperor, returning to the Supreme Clarity.*

The Perfected One rejoiced, saying, “My dwelling is on Crane Peak in the Zhōngnán Mountains, where there is a cavern. You may follow me.” Then, through divine transformation, they arrived in an instant at a peak. The cavern’s gate shimmered with rosy clouds, and three tigers crouched before it. The Perfected One rebuked them, and they leapt into a bottomless ravine. He offered Shàoxiān the Wine of Primordial Harmony and sat upon a stone to discourse on the mysteries. Soon, a youth in blue arrived bearing a letter from Mount Pénglái, inviting the master to the Heavenly Pond to discuss the Five Primes.

As the Perfected One prepared to depart, he said to Shàoxiān, “Since you have come here to follow me in the Dao, I now name you Chà, with the courtesy name Dòngbīn. I must go now, but you should dispel worldly cares and purify your immortal bones. I shall return before long.” With three tigers guarding the gate, he mounted a white crane and slowly vanished into the southeastern clouds.

Chà then studied day and night the texts the Perfected One had left in the cavern. The next day, the Perfected One returned and asked, “Do you not long for home?” Chà replied, “I have severed worldly ties and purified my mortal bones. Having followed you to explore the wondrous Dao, how could I dare to be burdened by worldly dust again?” The Perfected One said, “Excellent! Those who guard the yīn know only the pò; those with yáng are merely wandering hún. Mortals do not understand the difference between yīn and yáng. If one can preserve the yáng and gather the wandering hún, uniting them with the yīn pò, so that yīn and yáng merge and hún and pò become true, this is called a Perfected One.”

Chà asked, “The principle is profound—how can one preserve the form?” The Perfected One replied, “When wisdom arises from obscurity and the spirit is firmly settled in serenity, the spirit merges completely—how could it not unite with the true? The golden form and jade substance arise from utmost sincerity. Once the Great Medicine is complete, the body becomes as light as flight.”

That evening, he bestowed upon him the Supreme Perfected’s Mysterious Oral Formula. Soon, someone knocked at the door—it was Zhèng Sīyuǎn of Qīngxī and the Perfected One Shī of Tàihuá, arriving from the southeast, walking leisurely through the void, their forms radiant as gold and jade. They bowed, sat together, and after a while, proceeded to the alchemical chamber of Yǐn Sīyì. There, they entered the immortal’s gate.

The Perfected One Shī asked, “Who is this attendant?” The Perfected One replied, “This is the son of Lǚ Hǎizhōu Ràng of today, originally versed in Confucianism and Mohism. Disheartened in the capital, he chanced upon me in a Cháng’ān wineshop and followed me in the Dao, mastering the subtleties of yīn-yáng refinement and the merging of form and spirit into the wondrous.”

Chà then bowed to the two immortals. The Perfected One Zhèng said, “His form is pure, his spirit present; his eyes are bright, his essence concealed. If you wish to escape the net of the world, let him compose a poem.”

They bestowed upon Chà a golden brush and rosy-cloud stationery, along with divine glue and a rhinoceros-inkstone. Standing, Chà presented a poem:

Through ten thousand kalpas and a thousand lives I’ve come to this,
At last this body, life after life, attains the lightness of flight.
I cast aside home and kingdom for the joy of cloud-wrapped peaks,
Refining soul and spirit with the essence of sun and moon.
I’ve seen worldly men debate the Nine Tripods,
Seeking the Great Elixir and visiting the Three Pure Ones.
Now, having met the faces of immortals,
My name is recorded at the gates of the Purple Palace.

The three immortals exchanged glances, sighing at his pure talent and elegant lines. Just then, spring birds chirped melodiously. The Perfected One said to Chà, “You may inscribe at the cave’s entrance: ‘Spring’s qi fills the sky, flower-dew drips; dawn’s sun strikes the sea as mountain clouds withdraw.’” Then, turning to Chà, he said, “Our audience at the Primordial Court draws near. The feathered adepts of the Ten Isles will journey to the Jade Capital to report their merits and ascend the immortal ranks. I fear you cannot long remain in this cave. We shall meet again at Dongting Lake in ten years.”

Taking up his brush, he swiftly wrote sixteen characters on the cave’s stone wall in cursive script:
*By day, lofty and bright;
By night, the moon full and clear.
Yin and yang, soul and spirit,
Merge and ascend together.*

Tossing the brush aside, he told Chà, “As you wander the world, practice the Way of beneficence. When your deeds are complete and your merit fulfilled, we shall meet again.” Suddenly, several immortals appeared, their gossamer robes shimmering, bearing golden tablets and divine talismans. They announced, “The Celestial Emperor summons Zhongli Quan.” At once, phoenixes and simurghs soared, golden banners and jade regalia trailing, their celestial music fading into the dawn as they drifted away. Chà could not bear to part. After some time, he traveled as a guest through the Jiang-Huai region and Dongting, carving inscriptions at Hubei’s Yue, the two capitals of Bian and Luo. When his Dao was perfected, he departed elsewhere.

Their profound exchanges were compiled by the immortal Shi Jianwu into *The Anthology of Zhong and Lü Transmitting the Dao*, which circulates in the world. In the first year of Jingkang during the reign of Emperor Qinzong of Song, the Perfected One was enfeoffed as the Perfected Lord of True Yang. In the sixth year of the Zhiyuan era of the Yuan dynasty, he was further honored as the Perfected Lord of True Yang, the Enlightened Transmitter of the Dao.

Liu Gang
Liu Gang was a native of Xia’na during the Jin dynasty. Initially dwelling on Siming Mountain, he later served as magistrate of Shangyu. He studied the Dao under Master Bo and administered affairs in the central region. After years of cultivation, his Dao was perfected, and he composed *Sequel to the Biographies of Immortals*, which circulated in the world. One day, he invited his relatives and old friends to a farewell gathering. After the feast, he ascended a large honey locust tree beside the county hall, over ten yards above the ground. Raising his hand in farewell, he suddenly flew into the clouds and vanished. His wife, too, attained the Dao and ascended at the same time.

Wang Lie, styled Changxiu, was a native of Na’e. He entered the eastern seas and dwelt in Baodu Mountain, where he once traveled in company with Ji Shuye. Lie obtained a stone marrow resembling maltose; he consumed half himself and gave the other half to Shuye. By the time Shuye arrived, it had all congealed into stone. Later, he entered a stone chamber, within which lay two scrolls of plain silk. Lie read them but did not recognize the characters and dared not take them, though he memorized the forms of a dozen or so. Upon returning, he transcribed them to show Shuye, who recognized all the characters. Delighted, Lie then led Shuye back to the place, clearly recalling the path. When they arrived, the stone chamber was nowhere to be found. Lie thus said to his disciples: “Shuye is not yet destined to attain immortality.”

Liu Daocheng
Liu Daocheng was a native of Xinhao in Yuzhang. He studied the arts of the Yellow Emperor and Laozi. During the Yongjia reign of Emperor Huai of Jin, he entered officialdom through his mastery of the classics and was repeatedly promoted, eventually becoming governor of Chenzhou. Later, he returned to his hometown, where he diligently maintained incense offerings and revered the True Talisman of the Great Luo. Decades later, his entire family ascended to heaven in broad daylight. Xu Xuan’s *Stele Inscription of Kaiye Abbey* records: “On the fifteenth day of the eighth month in the second year of Yongjia, the whole clan ascended; several thousand villagers gazed at the clouds as they bid farewell.” During the Datong reign of Emperor Wu of Liang, his former residence was established as Kaiye Abbey, now named Zhaode Abbey, over a hundred paces from the county seat. When Bai Yuchan visited Zhaode, Chen Lingbao composed a poem:

*I’ve seen the immortals of my homeland—no idle boast,*
*Their faces gleam like jade, radiant as cinnabar clouds.*
*Newly opened, the celestial library of scriptures,*
*Once the home of cloud-dwelling phoenixes and hounds.*
*Thirty-seven years, a heart stronger than iron,*
*Countless affairs, yet eyes unblurred by flowers.*
*Now I sense my greetings grow ever more unrefined,*
*Twice daily, bees report to the court like officials.*

Xiang Mandu
Xiang Mandu was a native of Puji in Hedong.

Xiang Mandu entered the mountains in search of immortality and returned after ten years. When his family asked the reason, Mandu said: “After three years of concentrated meditation in the mountains, an immortal came to welcome me, and together we rode a dragon to ascend to heaven. After a long while, I lowered my head to gaze at the earth—all was dark and indistinct, with no visible boundary above, and the distance from the earth was immeasurable. The dragon flew swiftly, its head and tail rising and falling. As I sat upon its back, my face turned ashen with terror. Upon reaching heaven, I first beheld the Purple Palace with its golden couches and jade tables, gleaming and resplendent—a place of true nobility. The immortal offered me but a single cup of flowing rosy clouds; after drinking it, I suddenly forgot my home. Before the heavenly beings, I lost my composure and was reprimanded, then sent back to the mortal realm. Only after further self-reflection and correction may I be permitted to return. In former times, King Liu An of Huainan, upon meeting the Great Pure Immortal Elder, was punished with three years of guarding the celestial privy for his lack of reverence in rising and sitting. Those who study the Dao thereafter—can they not be cautious?” For this reason, the people of Hedong called Mandu the “Reprimanded Immortal.”

Xu Changxuan
The Daoist Xu Qixuan resided on Mount Zhongnan during the Yuanjia reign of Emperor Wen of Song. His virtue and power were held in high esteem, and all who knew him revered him. Skilled in the arts of the Dao, he could discern good and ill fortune.

Past affairs were vividly discernible. There was once a certain Grand Master Wang, who had but one daughter, named Jin Ying in her childhood. She was a beauty of the highest order, and he cherished her deeply. One day, as Xu Qixuan wandered at leisure, he passed by the Wang residence. Observing that the house was enveloped in the lingering resentment of a past-life grievance, its rancorous qi stretching to the heavens, Qixuan asked the gatekeeper, “Is the Grand Master at home?” The gatekeeper replied, “He is.” Qixuan said, “Go and announce to him that the Daoist Xu Qixuan of Mount Zhongnan wishes to see him on a small matter.” The gatekeeper entered and relayed the message, whereupon the Grand Master immediately came out to receive him.

Qixuan said, “Do not rise hastily. I have something to consult with you—may I speak?” The Grand Master replied, “I await your instruction.” Qixuan said, “Just now, I observed that your residence is burdened by a deep grievance from a past life, and the aggrieved party seeks an opportunity for vengeance. Are you aware of this?” The Grand Master answered, “Without your sagely insight, how could I, with my mundane eyes, perceive such a thing?” Qixuan asked the household servants, both male and female, to observe, but none could see anything amiss. He then inquired, “Is there anyone else in the residence?” The Grand Master replied, “I have a daughter, Jin Ying by her childhood name. I dote on her so much that I am almost ashamed of it.” Qixuan said, “This young lady is none other than your past-life adversary. Summon her at once.”

Hearing this, the Grand Master thought it absurd, but he instructed his wife to call her. When the lady went to fetch her, they found the girl leaning against her chamber door, facing the wall, and sighing, “My past-life enmity remains unresolved, and I was about to seize the chance for vengeance—how vexing that this Daoist has revealed my past affairs!” The lady, alarmed, reported this to the Grand Master. Overwhelmed with dread, he bowed to Qixuan and pleaded, “This is a past-life feud—how may we escape it?” Qixuan replied, “It is but a small matter.” The Grand Master said, “If you, Venerable Master, would show mercy and deliver us, I would be indebted to you for life and death.” He bowed again, and Qixuan said, “No more words—let me dispel it at once.”

Qixuan then took up a sword and a bowl of water. Brandishing the sword, he spat the water and followed the Grand Master into the residence, ordering the door to be opened. Jin Ying said, “This is my grudge—what concern is it of yours?” Qixuan replied, “The Daoist gate takes salvation as its merit and aiding others as its highest duty. You must swiftly reveal your true form and no longer dwell here.” He glanced at her, then ordered a coffin and lining to be prepared, which arrived shortly after. Qixuan opened the door and beheld her transformed into white bones. He commanded the attendants to gather them and place them in a spirit carriage, instructing, “Take it beyond the city gate, travel over ten *li*, and cast it into a great grove of trees. Flee swiftly and do not look back.” The attendants followed his words, carrying it beyond the city gate for over ten *li* until they reached a vast forest, where they placed it beneath the trees and hurried back. Only after returning to the city gate did they turn to look—there, the great forest was engulfed in crimson flames that stretched to the heavens, reducing all to ashes.

The Grand Master and his wife, weeping in gratitude, bowed in thanks and offered precious treasures, silks, and coins in recompense, but Qixuan paid them no heed and departed.

---

Master Wan Zhen, styled Changsheng, was a native of Nanchang in Hongzhou. He attained the Dao of long life and enduring vision, and his fame flourished between the Qi and Liang dynasties, though none knew his true age. Skilled in talismans and incantations, he healed the suffering of others with immediate efficacy, and his contemporaries regarded him as a peer of Jingyang and Le Ba. Emperor Wen of Sui, having heard of his renown, held him in high esteem and decreed the construction of a meditation hall for him on Mount Hongya—this is the present-day Bingzhen Abbey. In the fifteenth year of the Zhenguan reign of Emperor Taizong of Tang, Governor Zhou Xun requested the establishment of Taiyi Abbey on the former residence of Mei Fu, and respectfully invited the Master to reside there—this is the present-day Tianning Wanshou Abbey.

Earlier, a fisherman had recovered a blue-green stone, seven feet in length, which emitted musical tones when struck. The prefecture presented it to the imperial court, and Emperor Gaozong ordered it broken open, revealing two swords. On their hilts were inscribed the Master’s name. The Emperor marveled at this.

In the second year of the Xianqing reign, Emperor Gaozong summoned the Master to the Guangyao Hall of the palace. The Emperor inquired about the Dao of governing the state and nurturing life. The Master replied: *"Without thought, without action—embrace clarity and stillness as the rectification of all under Heaven. Governing the state is like governing the body."* The Emperor honored him as both teacher and friend, bestowing gifts upon him, though the Master accepted none.

In the first year of the Longshuo reign, the Master underwent *shijie* in the capital. When the coffin was opened several days later, only a sword and a staff remained. By imperial decree, the sword and staff were encased in a bronze casket and interred beside the Heavenly Treasure Grotto on Western Mountain—this is the present-day Dongyang Abbey. The Master’s stele of virtue and achievement, composed by Prince Teng Yuan Ying of the Tang, stands within Kaiyuan Abbey.

Cao Dexiu
Cao Dexiu claimed to have journeyed from Green Islet Mountain in the Eastern Sea to travel through Jiangxi. For over thirty years, those who saw him found his countenance unchanged. He often walked among the people, healing the sick with talismans and medicines—none failed to recover. There was a man with a daughter, over twenty years of age, who was betrothed to another.

Suddenly, a malevolent spirit possessed her, and despite every treatment attempted, her condition only worsened. Her father sought out Dexiu and recounted her symptoms in full. Dexiu asked, “Does your home lie near a mountain stream with a deep pool?” The father replied that it did. Dexiu continued, “In spring, as your daughter strolled by the stream, a flood dragon spied her and has since seized and confined her essence and soul within its lair. Take this talisman of mine and cast it into the pool.” Soon after the talisman was thrown, the pool’s waters surged violently, accompanied by thunderous roars. In an instant, a creature over twenty feet long surfaced—its form resembled a black serpent, its head like a great ladle—already split open, its brains spilling forth as it perished in a pool of blood. The father returned home to find his daughter’s spirit clear and bright, her illness entirely vanished. He brought gifts of silk and wealth to express his gratitude, but Dexiu said, “I acted only to heal the sick—why offer such things?” He steadfastly refused to accept them.

Dexiu often told others, “If your household suffers illness or hardship, there is no need for wealth or silk. Come to me for talismans and medicines. Offer a platter of river fish and a flask of fine wine, feast me, and make your plea—your ailment will naturally be cured.” The villagers followed his instructions, and none failed to see results; all revered him as a divine being. Later, he suddenly announced to the people, “I shall now depart this place for the Heavenly Treasure Grotto on Western Mountain. Yet come spring, a severe cattle plague will strike. I leave you a name to transcribe and pass on: when the plague comes, feast me with offerings, inscribe this name, and affix it to the horns of your cattle—they shall suffer no harm.” That spring, a great cattle plague indeed swept through the land. In every household where the name was affixed, the cattle were spared; where it was not, they perished. The people longed for him, but he was never seen again.

The *Biography of Wang Yuanzhi* states: Cao Dexiu was a Grand Scribe of the Jin, later serving as Minister of the Board of Rites under the Later Liang. He attained the Dao of immortality.

Du Tanyong
Du Tanyong, styled Yuanlao, was also known by his Daoist name, Yuanlao. A native of Jingzhao in the Three Metropolitan Districts, his family’s official rank spanned generations until the imperial decree of the Southern Migration, when they settled in Qiantang County of Wujun. He began his career as Left Gentleman of the Household of the Grand Marshal, Prince of Yuzhang, and later served as Gentleman Attendant to Xiao Ziyun, a former official of the Southern Qi. Outwardly, he devoted himself to Confucian scholarship; inwardly, he cultivated the true Dao. When the Qi and Liang dynasties underwent revolution, he sighed deeply with emotion. Comparing his brush to the reins of a carriage and his arrogance to the bonds of the world, he cast off the trappings of prosperity, shook out his robes, and departed. He journeyed far to the Min and Long regions, sojourned in Lin Tao and Emei, then returned to his old mountains—more than two years had passed.

Later, he passed through Juqu, seeking the Dao and searching for the true. He devoted himself wholly to the gates of the teachings, humble and serene in silence, so that none knew what he practiced. In the twelfth year of the Tianjian era of Emperor Wu of Liang (the year *jiazi*), he set down his staff and emerged from the valley. From Qiantang, he lightly loaded his family onto a boat and sailed south to Yushun Mountain in Luling Commandery, where he rebuilt the Pavilion of Pure Emptiness as his dwelling. At the time, the forest

From this point onward, disciples seeking the Dao followed in his footsteps. The next year, he entered the Great Emptiness Grotto-Heaven of Fa Le, and with the resources he had brought, constructed several dozen rafters for living quarters. He rebuilt the palace halls, personally inscribed a grand stele, and recorded the wonders of the grotto-heaven. He established fields in the Oriole Valley west of the grotto, as well as in the western mountains beside the grotto—Great Dragon’s South Gully, Great Boulder, and Melon Source—so that those who cultivated truth and nurtured the Dao might have sustenance, and he inscribed the name "Grotto-Heaven Stone Terrace" upon them.

That same year he entered the grotto, Emperor Wu, having heard of his reputation, bestowed upon him the title Master of the Golden Watchtower. Xiao Zhen, too, came from the lands south of the Yangtze with his kin, sailing to join him, and took him as his teacher. He received the secret Dao and personally inscribed a stele to commemorate Du’s virtue. This was the seventh year of the Putong era.

Later, while the Master remained in the grotto, he and his disciple, the Gentleman of Outer Affairs Qian, refined the secret of the Nine Cauldrons’ Returned Elixir. Spirit immortals descended frequently, foretelling that his ascension was near. When the elixir was complete, he and Qian consumed it atop the summit of Mount Taibai, and in broad daylight, they ascended to the heavens in a most manifest manner. His family became earthbound immortals, concealing themselves in the rear grotto.

---

Xiao Ziyun, styled Jingmu, was a grandson of Emperor Gao of the Southern Qi and the son of Yu Jing, the Prince of Wenxian. He was a descendant of He, the Chancellor of Han. Among his sixteen brothers, all were enfeoffed as commandery dukes. When Emperor Wu of Liang received the abdication, in the early years of the Tianjian era, Xiao Ziyun, then twelve, had his rank reduced to viscount. In his youth, he was drawn to the Dao, aspiring to uprightness and tranquility, and took no pleasure in official advancement. Though he held eminent office, he often conversed and laughed in secret with extraordinary persons. He was repeatedly promoted, serving as Aide of Danyang Commandery, then soon after as Gentleman of the Yellow Gate and Left Director of the Department of the Grand Master of Ceremonies.

Xiao Ziyun often journeyed with his family to the famous mountains of Jiangbiao. One day, he set sail to visit the Jade Bamboo of Luling. Upon first arriving at the Pavilion of Clarity and Emptiness, he found that Du Yuanlao had already attained the Dao at Jade Bamboo. A former colleague from the Southern Qi court, they met again with the same warmth as before, and Xiao treated him as his master. Traveling to the grotto heavens, he gained much of Du’s esoteric teachings. He personally carved an inscription in stone to extol Du’s virtue.

Later, passing through the southeastern range of Jade Bamboo’s interconnected mountains and layered cliffs—now called Xiaoshan—he left behind altars, furnaces, and mortar pits, the traces of which remain to this day. Just then, an imperial edict from Emperor Wu of Liang arrived, summoning him to court along with his son, Xiao Te, and entrusting his family to the capital. Upon arrival, he was appointed Gentleman of the Palace. His mastery of cursive and clerical scripts further enhanced his reputation. Xiao Te was also skilled in calligraphy and held the post of Attendant Gentleman of the Palace, but he predeceased his father.

In the first year of the Taiqing era, during Hou Jing’s rebellion, Xiao Ziyun was among the captured court officials. Though over sixty, his bearing was extraordinary, and his spirit remained transcendent. Fearing he would not escape disaster, he hastily returned to Xiaoshan, later relocating again to the Pavilion of Clarity and Emptiness. In the fifth year, a divine being suddenly descended and declared: “To the northeast lies a dense grove, where a ravine’s waters flow eastward—there you may dwell long.” Xiao moved his family and settled there.

After two twelve-year cycles, the Celestial Emperor bestowed upon him a jade tablet, appointing him as Chief Administrator of Wuzhou and Keeper of the Registers of the Blessed Grove’s Felicitous Court—a divine immortal’s office. Together with eighty-two fellow immortals of the prefecture, he vanished from the world, never to be seen again. The matter was kept secret, known to few. Later, those who entered the grotto would occasionally glimpse his dwelling.

Should one seek him with single-minded devotion, he would remain forever unattainable.

Ding Xuanzhen—Master Ding’s religious name—styled Zhongcheng, was a native of Deyang. By nature diligent and keen, he observed the precepts with utmost rigor, earning the reverence of his village. Once, he encountered a master of esoteric arts and received transmission of a teaching both subtle and wondrous. Thereby, he gained command over spirits and demons, bending them to his will without fail.

He often remarked that the land of Kangwang Valley was most numinous and refined. At its mouth stood the Temple of the Bronze Horse, said to house a bronze steed cast by Wang Mang of Han. Over time, a spirit had possessed it, wreaking havoc as a malevolent entity—devouring livestock, crops, and even the people’s belongings—until the villagers built a shrine to appease it. Xuanzhen, disdaining such practices, demolished the temple and erected a sanctuary of true teaching upon the site. He then cast the bronze horse into the Southern River, yet before the men returned, the steed had already reappeared in its former place. Xuanzhen severed its left foreleg, whereupon the horse transformed into a human figure, weeping and pleading, “Grant me but a place to feed.” Xuanzhen then relocated its shrine to the west of the ravine, permitting it to remain so long as it ceased its depredations.

Further ahead lay the Poison Dragon Pool. One storm-wracked, murky day, two dragons emerged to sport with a pearl, its radiance dazzling the gloom. Xuanzhen rebuked them and seized the pearl, placing it within his sanctuary. The dragons followed, snatching back the pearl, and when they failed to retrieve it, they spewed saliva across the floor. Then, upon the sanctuary’s pillars—where the painter Zhang Sengyao had depicted two dragons—they took flight, summoning wind and thunder to shatter the eaves and beams. Xuanzhen inscribed an iron talisman, cast an iron bell, and subdued the pool’s dragon, which fled westward through the mountain. He then drove an iron nail into the pillar, piercing the painted dragons’ eyes, and the calamity ceased. Thus, all manner of spirits and anomalies fled the land, and the site became a court of blessing.

This occurred in the tenth year of Emperor Wen of Sui’s *Kaihuang* era. The Prefect of Jiangzhou memorialized the events to the throne, and the emperor, struck by their marvel, issued an edict of praise and honor, commanding the prefecture to accord Xuanzhen due reverence. In the third year of Emperor Yang’s *Daye* era, he departed this world, and that very night, a white light stretched across the southeastern sky. Only after Xuanzhen’s passing did it fade. He was seventy-eight.

Master Liu, whose personal name is unknown, dwelt at Yuntai Abbey in Huayin during the *Zhenguan* era of Emperor Taizong of Tang. For twenty years, he refined his *qi* and abstained from grain. Each year, on the Three Yuan fasts, a man clad in a patched robe of coarse cloth, his appearance plain and swarthy, would arrive and take the lowest seat. When the fast concluded, he would depart in silence. This continued for over a decade, yet his garments and complexion never altered. Finding him strange, Master Liu questioned him, to which the man replied: “I am surnamed Zhang, named Gongbi, and dwell in the northeast corner of Lianhua Peak.” Master Liu, supposing the place uninhabited, asked to accompany him. Gongbi assented, saying, “It is most pleasant there. If you wish to stay, there will be no hindrance.” After journeying over twenty *li*, grasping vines and creepers, they came upon a path barely wide enough for crows. The cliffs and ravines were perilously sheer, impassable even to apes and monkeys. Yet to Gongbi, it was as level as a thoroughfare, and Master Liu followed without difficulty.

They arrived at a stone wall towering over a thousand *ren*, its base overlooking a bottomless gorge. A path, mere inches wide, allowed only the edge of one’s foot. Gongbi tapped the wall with his finger, and a voice from within asked who it was. “It is I,” he replied. Suddenly, a door opened, revealing a world of boundless expanse, teeming with all things under heaven. As Gongbi led Master Liu to enter, the man within grew angry: “Why have you brought an outsider?” He shut the door, and the wall became solid stone once more. Gongbi said, “This is no stranger—he is Master Liu of Yuntai Abbey, an old acquaintance. Let us enter together.” The door opened again to admit them. Gongbi said, “Master, since you have come, he may prepare a meal.” The man asked if Master Liu would stay, to which the latter replied he would return another day. The man then took a bowl of water, mixed it with a powder from the blade in his green pouch at his elbow, and offered it to Master Liu to drink. Its taste was sweet and fragrant.

Gongbi said, “I have often spoken of the joys of this mountain. Why not perform for the master’s amusement?” The man sprinkled water into the valley, and soon a black dragon and a white elephant appeared, dancing in perfect harmony. A vermilion phoenix and a green *luan* bird sang in antiphonal clarity. Gongbi and Master Liu bade farewell and stepped outside. After walking several dozen paces and turning back, they saw only towering cliffs and deep ravines. As they neared the abbey, Gongbi took his leave. Master Liu returned, settled his affairs, and sought Gongbi again, but each step was fraught with peril, and he could not proceed. Thereafter, Gongbi never returned.

Li Yuanji
Li Yuanji was a man of the early *Wude* era of Emperor Gaozu of Tang.

Deep in the Hidden Vine Mountain, he possessed Daoist arts and could vanish while sitting or standing, leaving others baffled. Often traveling, he healed people with talismans and medicines. He extracted tiger bones, needled the shadow of magpies, and revived countless fish and turtles. By day he wandered forth, but at nightfall he halted, sleeping exposed in the wild grasses. In the final years of Emperor Daizong’s reign, while in Jianchang County, he covered his body with pine and cypress branches and flew away. Later, someone gathering herbs on Hidden Vine Mountain saw Yuanji riding a green deer, moving as if in flight; when questioned, he gave no answer, and none knew where he had gone.

Master Chen Daozhong
The Dharma Master bore the surname Chen and the given name Daochong. He was a native of Deyang. While his mother was pregnant, she dreamed of heavenly immortals entering her chamber. At birth, he bore extraordinary marks. As a child, he neither drank wine nor ate meat, and whenever he heard others expounding sutras or discoursing on the Dao, he would incline his ear to listen intently. As he grew, his precepts and conduct were lofty and pure, and he transmitted the Dharma records to extraordinary men. He then built a hermitage on a separate peak of Purple Empyrean, a place of surpassing beauty. He had eight or nine disciples, all of whom observed strict precepts and were learned; the standards of his gate were most exacting, and he did not casually receive others. Those of his time who were favored with his company were said to have ascended the Dragon Gate, a comparison to Li Ying of the Han. Daochong was deeply devoted to Laozi and Zhuangzi, and not merely did he recite their words—he thoroughly grasped their principles. He once declared, “Our teaching fundamentally follows Laozi and Zhuangzi, and the intent of Laozi and Zhuangzi is originally to awaken and illuminate the nature-ground. Thus their words often say, ‘Nothing is better than clarity’—this is their essential point. Later people merely practice techniques and cling to the superficial, missing the mark by far.” Morning and evening, he invariably lectured to his assembled disciples. He composed a treatise that circulated in the world. In the spring of the twenty-first year of the Zhenguan era of Emperor Taizong of Tang, he suddenly told his disciples, “I wish to travel to the famous mountains.” The assembly, considering his age, urged him to desist. Daochong replied, “I must go.”

At midday, he dissolved into transformation—he was one hundred fourteen years old. His complexion remained as in life, and his body was still supple. When the coffin was lifted, it felt as though it held nothing; people believed he had ascended as an immortal.

**Wang Shouyi**
Wang Shouyi, in the early Zhenguan era of Emperor Taizong of Tang, styled himself "Wang the Commoner of Mount Zhongnan" in Luoyang. He sold medicine in the Luoyang marketplace. A wealthy man named Liu Xinwei had an only son with a fleshy growth above his brow. The commoner drew a pill from his gourd and gave it to him; in an instant, the growth burst open, and a small serpent, resplendent in five colors, leapt forth, growing to over a *zhang* in length. Wang shouted at it, and the serpent soared upward, clouds and mist darkening the sky. Wang mounted the serpent and flew away.

*Volume Thirty-One of* Comprehensive Mirror of Immortals Who Embodied the Dao *concludes here.*
*Volume Thirty-Two of* Comprehensive Mirror of Immortals Who Embodied the Dao

**Master He the Venerable**
Master He the Venerable—no one knew his origins—dwelt on Mount Heng during the Longshuo era of Emperor Gaozong of Tang, concealing his name and lineage. His countenance resembled that of a man of forty, and he moved as swiftly as the wind. He often traveled between Cangwu and the Five Ridges, coming without desire and departing without instruction. For over a hundred years, people frequently saw him, his appearance unchanged. When asked about his clan, he would only say, "He, he." When questioned about his homeland or cultivation, he likewise replied, "He, he." Thus, people called him Master He the Venerable. Though his robes were tattered and his sandals worn, his heart was vast as the void.

Daoists Tian Xuying and Deng Zhongxu once asked him, "Master, you never speak—how can you enlighten disciples?" He replied, "To know and yet not know is supreme; to not know and yet know is inferior. Who can chisel the apertures of chaos or awaken to the principle of spontaneity?" Then, leaning on a flowering staff, he entered the forest and vanished. Soon after, a pack of tigers followed him, and he was seen no more.

During the Kaiyuan era of Emperor Xuanzong of Tang, Sima Chengzhen traveled to Mount Heng. Gazing at Zhurong Peak, he remarked, "A lofty immortal must dwell here—how else could the qi and color be so extraordinary?" Presently, he saw the Venerable Master in the forest. Chengzhen paid his respects and posed questions, but the Master sat upon a rock as if seeing nothing. Receiving no answer, Chengzhen withdrew, sighing, "This is one who may be called whole, whose virtue is unexpressed in words." He then built a hut on Zhurong Peak to invite the Master, who came and never again emerged. The regional inspector, Lü Wei, visited the hut to receive talismans and mantras. Though Zhang Taikong, Tian Xuying, and Deng Zhongxu served as his disciples, none grasped his essential teaching.

On the Lower Prime Day of the second year of the Tianbao era, clouds and cranes soared in the sky, and a rare fragrance filled the air. He told his disciples, "After I depart, you shall find me on the coiled stone of the southern peak of Purple Canopy." Then he transformed, his complexion unchanged.

The disciples then encircled him and performed the rites for transmuting the spirit. At midnight, a thunderous roar shook the heavens, and he vanished from their sight. The Prefect of Hengyang, Su Wulian, composed the inscription for his stele.

The Daoist Liu Zhigu, styled Guangxuan, hailed from Pengcheng in Pei. His lineage traced back twelve generations to Prince Jing of Zhongshan, all of whom had attained prominence. His great-grandfather, Ying, passed the imperial examination for filial piety and incorruptibility during the Sui dynasty and served as Magistrate of Linna; thus, his grandfather and father settled in Linna. His mother, the Lady Wu, conceived him after an auspicious dream. Born with wisdom, he displayed intelligence in childhood, elegance in youth, and uprightness in maturity. He regarded fame and profit as foes and devoted himself solely to the Dao. During the Longshuo era of Emperor Gaozong of Tang, he left home to become a Daoist of the Three Caverns at Taiqing Abbey. He mastered the esoteric teachings of the Eight Lords and the Elegant Chapters, the secret registers of the Three Simplicities, the principles of alchemical classics and pulse diagnosis, and the arts of transcending death and returning to life.

Emperor Ruizong summoned him to court to inquire about Daoist affairs. Pleased with his responses, the emperor bestowed special honors upon him and sent him back to the mountains. During the Kaiyuan era of Emperor Xuanzong, when natural disasters and epidemics afflicted the land, with eight or nine out of ten people falling ill, the emperor called upon Zhigu to treat them. Sighing, he declared: "Even the Sage of the Fire Virtue and the Star Lord suffer from pestilence. Lowering oneself to refine medicines and examining voices as a physician—how far is this from moxibustion and acupuncture?" Thereupon, he diagnosed illness by observing complexion and cured it by regulating qi. Thus, he could dissolve obstructions deep as the Gaohuang and disperse stagnation like melting snow, so exquisite was his skill. The emperor favored him with gifts, all of which he declined.

In the nineteenth year of the Tianbao era, Zhigu was ordered to assist the Minister of the Interior, Tian Sichong, in conducting a grand jiao ritual for the Twenty-Four Lords. After some time, he requested to return to Shu and offered his residence to be converted into Daqianqiu Abbey. The emperor personally inscribed the plaque and bestowed it upon him, while Li Yong composed the stele inscription.

As his elder brother followed Confucianism and his younger brother embraced Buddhism, Zhigu installed images of the Three Teachings to honor them. Duke Zhang Yue of Yi, having heard of his reputation, was delighted and composed the *Inscription on the Three Teachings*, which read:

*"The upright qi generates spirits,
Weaving emptiness into reality.
The Supreme Clarity venerates the Emperor,
The Central Yellow guards the emergence.
Robed in radiant hues,
They dwell in palaces of vacuity.
Riding the purple aurora, they mount the Dipper;
From the red furnace, they drink the sun.
The Ten Heavens and the Twenty Thousand Spirits
Receive their commands from this.
The Lotus of the Buddha’s gate,
The Unicorn’s horn of Confucian arts—
Their dharma is not two,
Their minds attain the One.
The mind of Dao is subtle;
Guard it and never lose it."*

Later, on the emperor’s birthday, the abbey was renamed Tianchang Abbey. Once, a guest taught him the arts of alchemical transmutation. Though the abbey’s halls and pavilions were grand and magnificent, costing tens of thousands, he never sought funds from others. When the construction was complete, the guest returned and arranged to meet him at Funiushan in Shuyang, where an ancient abbey stood. There, he restored it and took up residence.

The guest then transmitted to him the *Divine Tiger’s Treasure Scripture*, the *Hidden Writings of Supreme Clarity*, and the essentials of the *High Ascent to the Dao*. After practicing these for ten years, a light suddenly appeared in his chamber, and a stalk of cinnabar lingzhi mushroom grew, emitting a metallic resonance when struck. In a dream, a divine being told him: "Behind the mountain, within a stone cliff, lies a golden fish. Mount it, and you may ascend to the heavens. Without this mushroom to strike the stone, it cannot be obtained." At dawn, he searched for the golden fish but found no trace. That night, he dreamed again: "It lies beneath the dripping spring." Arriving there, he struck the stone with the mushroom, and with a roar like thunder, the massive boulder split open. He found a golden fish, over three feet long. Mounting it, he soared into the sky, enveloped in swirling clouds and mist, and departed.

Wang Yu.

Wang Yu resided on Green Gauze Mountain in Luoyang. The villagers had known him for several hundred years, yet he retained the appearance of youth. Dwelling in seclusion amid serene landscapes, he cultivated lingzhi mushrooms, medicinal herbs, and flowering trees, all with meticulous method. He authored three scrolls titled *Miscellaneous Records of Mountain Dwelling*. Daily sustenance came from powdered lingzhi blossoms, which he exchanged for green-skiff rice. His arts spread throughout the world. At times, he wandered renowned mountains; at others, he sojourned in Jingzhou.

During the reign of Emperor Gaozong of Tang, when the Wu clan wielded power and their might overshadowed the realm, only Wu Youxu, the Crown Prince’s Attendant and nephew to the Heavenly Empress, withdrew to avoid disaster. He settled in Songyang, where he took Wang Yu as his teacher and master, receiving from him the secrets of guiding, nurturing, and refining qi. Wang Yu told him: "To forsake noble rank for the immortal’s path is a difficult endeavor. It demands unwavering resolve in the forests and valleys, fulfilling its principles in full. Do not let the summons of imperial edicts sway your resolve."

In the Kaiyuan era of Emperor Xuanzong, Wang Yu was summoned to the capital and received with great favor and courtesy. Earlier, the emperor had obtained on Mount Mao the original manuscripts of the Seven Perfected of Yang and Xu, along with the calligraphy of Tao the Recluse for the various Shangqing scriptures. After receiving the *Three Caverns’ Precious Records* from Sima Baiyun, he later sought the *True Scripture of the Original Traces* from Li Yuanjing. For the dozen or so missing pages in Yang Jun’s hand, he dispatched Wang Yu with imperial letters and gifts to Purple Yang Abbey, entreating Master Yuanjing to complete them, saying: "I do not wish to send lesser officials to trouble you. Entrusting this mission to you alone, I hope the immortal’s brush may bridge past and present." On the day of his arrival, sacred cranes soared and cried. As the scriptures were being supplemented, an extraordinary fragrance filled the air, and divine beings descended into Yuanjing’s chamber—all responses to his profound sincerity.

After returning to the capital, Wang Yu requested, a year later, to return to his old mountain. He never again wandered the imperial city.

Wang Yu frequently corresponded with Minister Daxi. After Wang’s death, Daxi visited his abode with staff and sandals, only then learning that he had undergone *shijie*—transcendence through simulated death.

Wu Daoyuan, originally named Wu Daozi, had mastered the arts of the immortals. After traveling widely among the people, he changed his name to Daoyuan. His painting was divinely inspired, surpassing all others in skill. When Emperor Xuanzong of Tang heard of him, he summoned him to the palace. There, a freshly plastered wall several *xun* in length awaited his brush. The emperor asked what Daoyuan required, to which he replied: "Have the wall draped with curtains and bring me a vat of ink." The emperor complied. In an instant, Daoyuan drew back the curtains, scooped the ink onto the wall, and with a single vigorous sweep, covered it again. After a brief moment, the emperor inquired about the progress of the landscape. Daoyuan replied: "It is finished. Pray, Your Majesty, behold it." The emperor approached and saw mountains, waters, forests, and trees, along with human dwellings, birds, and beasts—all rendered in exquisite detail. The craftsmanship was so extraordinary that even the finest court painters could not rival it. The emperor gazed in admiration for a long while, then Daoyuan slowly stepped forward and pointed, saying: "Beneath this cliff lies a small grotto, home to many immortals. If one knocks, they will surely respond." He tapped the spot with his finger, and suddenly a door opened, revealing a young attendant. Daoyuan addressed the emperor: "This grotto may be entered, and its wonders are many. I shall go first; may Your Majesty follow." With that, he leapt inside. From within, he beckoned to the emperor, who could not pass through. The door then closed. Moments later, guards outside the palace reported: "Wu Daozi has leapt over the imperial walls and vanished—his whereabouts are unknown." The emperor returned to inspect the wall, only to find it smooth and white as before, the painted landscape gone.

Yan Zhenqing, styled Qingchen, was a descendant of Yan Shigu in the fifth generation. A man of broad learning and literary skill, he served his parents with filial devotion. During the Kaiyuan era of Emperor Xuanzong, he passed the imperial examinations and was later promoted to the post of Investigating Censor. His later virtues and deeds are recorded in detail in the *Old唐书*. Ouyang Xiu’s *Catalogue of Ancient Inscriptions* notes: "Yan Zhenqing authored and inscribed the *Stele of the Altar of Lady Ma Gu*. Though his loyalty and righteousness shone as brightly as the sun and moon, he was not immune to the allure of tales of immortals. How deeply have the old ways of Daoists and Buddhists troubled this people!"

The *Qingsuo Gaoyi* records: "Ouyang Yongshu and Mei Shengyu once traveled to Mount Song in a drunken state. Gazing at the towering cliffs of the western peak, they saw four large cinnabar characters inscribed there: *Grotto of Divine Clarity*. Yongshu pointed them out to Shengyu, who saw nothing. Yongshu said no more. Later, when he retired from office, he composed a poem:

*Four cinnabar words on a cliff ten thousand feet high,*
*The Grotto of Divine Clarity locks its towers away.*
*Gazing to the ends of the rosy clouds, none come near—*
*Only phoenix and crane await my arrival today.*

A few days later, he passed away. Throughout his life, he never spoke of immortals or transcendents, yet his convictions in the Way were thus."

In the fourth year of the Jianzhong era, Emperor Dezong dispatched Yan Zhenqing to punish Li Xilie. All within and without knew he would not return, and his kin bid him farewell at the Slope of Everlasting Joy. Intoxicated, Zhenqing leapt and danced before the front pillar, saying: "Long ago, a Daoist told me: 'Tao Baba bestowed upon me the Elixir of Azure Radiance, and to this day I have not declined.' He also said: 'At seventy, misfortune shall turn to fortune, and one day, await me on Mount Luofu.' Could this be the misfortune of today?" Upon reaching Daliang, Xilie ordered him strangled, and his body was placed south of the city. When Xilie was defeated, his family opened the coffin and found his countenance as if alive, his entire body golden, his nails grown beyond his hands, and his beard and hair several feet long. He was reburied in the northern mountains of Yanshi, an event recorded in the seventeenth year of Emperor Minghuang’s reign.

Yan Zhenqing had once obtained and consumed a divine elixir. Later, when killed by Li Xilie, his coffin was reopened after Xilie’s defeat, and his face appeared as in life. The recluse Cao Yong remarked: "Thirty years hence, he shall burst forth, soaring aloft, clad in feathered robes, wandering the mountains and marshes. This is what is called an *earthly immortal*." Later, a merchant traveling to Mount Luofu encountered two Daoists playing go beneath a tree. One asked: "Who comes here?" The merchant replied: "A humble traveler from Luoyang." The Daoist smiled and said: "Then kindly deliver a letter to my family." He sent a boy to fetch paper and brush

Initially, he secluded himself in the northwest of Magu Altar. Later, while returning home to visit his parents, he chanced upon a divine sword along the way and wore it at his side. His nature was resolute and unyielding, and he carried himself with the confidence of one destined to save the world. Whenever he rested among the streams and valleys, he would recite the *Tianpeng Incantation* without cease, until at last he moved the Northern Emperor to dispatch a divine messenger to instruct him in the sword’s art. He journeyed far to seek out Zhu Ling of Mount Nanyue, paid homage at the Green Jade and Radiant Heaven Altars, and offered rites to the Perfected One Deng. There, he dreamed of a revelation.

During the Kaiyuan era of Emperor Minghuang of Tang, he was summoned to the Datong Hall, where he performed rites for the protection of the northern frontier and was enfeoffed as *Heavenly Master*. For twenty-seven years, he cultivated merit and virtue, until one day he saw a tiger-drawn chariot and a dragon carriage appear, with two attendants bearing tallies standing in the courtyard. Turning to his friend Zhu Wuyou, he said: "This comes to welcome me. Petition on my behalf that I be permitted to return for burial on my native mountain, and that a temple be established beside the altar." Emperor Minghuang granted his request, and afterward, he underwent *shijie*—transformation through the corpse.

**Yiqi Xuanjie**
Yiqi Xuanjie had the complexion of a child and the fragrant purity of his breath. He often rode a yellow mare, which neither ate fodder nor wore bridle or reins, its back cushioned only by a green felt mat. He wandered between Qingzhou and Yanzhou, speaking of events a thousand years past as though he had witnessed them with his own eyes. When Emperor Xianzong of Tang heard of his extraordinary gifts, he summoned him to court. There, Xuanjie was lodged in a chamber on Mount Jiuhua, seated upon a purple *jiá* mat, and served wine infused with dragon’s essence. Each day, the emperor visited him personally, treating him with profound reverence. Yet Xuanjie remained simple and unrefined, never once observing the etiquette of a subject.

The emperor then asked, *"Master, your years are many, yet your countenance remains unaged—how is this so?"*
Xuanjie replied, *"I cultivate and consume enchanted herbs from the shores of the Eastern Sea."* Thereupon, he planted three varieties before the palace hall: the first, *Twin-Unicorn Fungus*; the second, *Six-Harmonies Sunflower*; the third, *Ten-Thousand-Root Vine*. The emperor partook of them and felt their numinous efficacy.

At that time, the Western Regions presented two exquisite jades, one round and one square. Xuanjie declared, *"These are the Dragon-and-Tiger Jades. The round was born in water—treasured by dragons. The square was born in mountains—treasured by tigers."* When envoys were dispatched to inquire, they indeed learned the jades had been obtained from hunters and fishermen.

Xuanjie wished to return to the Eastern Sea and petitioned the emperor, who did not grant leave. One day, the palace artisans carved a replica of the Three Isles of the Eastern Sea, adorning it lavishly with pigments and inlaying it with pearls and jades. On New Year’s Day, the emperor and Xuanjie beheld it together. The emperor pointed to Penglai and sighed, *"Were one not an immortal transcendent, none could ever reach such a realm."*
Xuanjie smiled and said, *"The Three Isles lie but a foot’s measure away—who says they are hard to attain? Though I am unworthy, I shall attempt a journey for Your Majesty, to gather its wonders and judge their beauty or baseness."* With that, his form rose into the void, gradually diminishing in size. In an instant, he vanished into the golden and silver towers. Though attendants called out repeatedly, he was seen no more.

The emperor, lost in longing and regret, nearly fell gravely ill. He named the isle *Hidden Perfection Isle*. Ten days later, a report arrived from Qingzhou: Xuanjie had been seen riding his mare across the sea.

**Xu Bingyan**
The scholar Xu Bingyan dwelled at the foot of Mount Qi.

During the *Zhenyuan* era of Emperor Dezong of Tang, Xu Bingyan sat for the imperial examinations but failed to pass. While studying at the Haotian Temple in Chang’an for over a month, he lost three horses in succession, leaving him unable to travel. Seeking another fine steed, a foreigner led a horse to him, claiming it was of unmatched speed. Bingyan wished to purchase it but remained doubtful. At the temple was a Daoist skilled in divination, so Bingyan asked him to cast a hexagram. The reading was *Qian*: *"The flying dragon soars in the heavens—auspicious to meet a great person."* The Daoist said, *"This horse is of dragon lineage. Through it, you shall meet a great person, and all affairs will be harmonious."* Others scoffed at the absurdity, but Bingyan alone believed and bought the horse. Though he tended to it with care, its coat and hide remained lackluster.

Later, when Lord Wei was stationed as military governor in western Shu, Bingyan—once a retainer under him—traveled to the region to pay his respects. Passing through Jian’ge, the horse startled and lost its footing, plunging both rider and mount into a ravine tens of thousands of feet deep. They landed upon a bed of withered leaves, unharmed. Gazing upward at the sheer cliffs, Bingyan saw no way to climb out.

After a long while, Bingyan prayed aloud: *"I am not Liu Bei, nor are you the steed of Lu. There is no way to leap free."* Sighing, he said, *"Ah, how mistaken was the Daoist’s divination!"* Thereupon, he removed the horse’s bit and bridle, stripped off its saddle and pad, and let it roam as it pleased.

After what seemed a full day, Bingyan groped among the stone crevices and gradually found footing. Stepping upon fist-sized chestnuts, he gathered and ate them, which greatly eased his hunger and thirst. Thus he traveled some tens of *li* more, until the crevices grew brighter. Suddenly, as if emerging from a cave’s mouth, he beheld a level expanse of several *li*, resplendent with spring’s glory. Over ten thousand peach trees flourished in emerald verdure, and among the blossoms lay a pool of blue-green stone. Beside it stood a stone hut, within which a Daoist—white-haired and ruddy-faced—reclined upon a stone couch, attended by two jade maidens.

Bingyan prostrated himself and bowed twice. The maidens cried out in alarm: *"Who are you, to suddenly appear in the chamber of the Great One, Primordial Lord?"* Bingyan recounted the whole affair, and the maidens reported it to the Primordial Lord. The Lord summoned Bingyan, who knelt and touched his forehead to the ground in reverence.

*"What do you favor in the human realm?"* the Primordial Lord asked.
*"I favor the Dao,"* Bingyan replied, *"and have read much of *Zhuangzi*, *Laozi*, and the *Huangting Jing*."*
*"What lines have you grasped from each of the Three Daoist texts? Recite them one by one."*
Bingyan answered: *"Zhuangzi says, ‘The perfected person breathes through their heels.’ Laozi says, ‘Their essence is most true.’ The *Huangting Jing* says, ‘Simply contemplate this one scripture for boundless longevity.’"*
The Primordial Lord nodded: *"You have drawn near the Dao."* Then he commanded Bingyan to sit, and the jade maidens poured stone marrow for him to drink. *"Even Xi Kang could not obtain this,"* they said. *"That you do is your destined fortune."* Bingyan knelt in thanks and drank.

One of the maidens then announced: *"The Daoist of Ying has arrived."* The Primordial Lord ordered a couch prepared, and a Daoist entered—long-browed, thick-lipped, with an imposing, ancient countenance. He held a divining rod and knelt in greeting. The Primordial Lord welcomed him: *"Why have you come from afar?"*
*"I came to pay my respects,"* the Daoist replied.
*"Then let us test your calculations on two matters,"* said the Primordial Lord. *"First, what spirit cleaved Mount Hua? Second, what ghost erected the bridge over the sea? I have not been able to discern these."*
The Daoist spread his divining rods with a rustling sound, perusing the Three Realms and deliberating the Six Directions, ranging from the highest heavens to the deepest springs. After a long while, he declared: *"Though it is said the Giant Spirit cleft Mount Hua, in truth it was the spirit of Kuafu. Though the sea-bridge’s builder is called a hideous monster, it was the ghost of the Five Ding."* The Primordial Lord nodded: *"Just so."*

*"Now calculate what I shall do this very night,"* he said.
The Daoist cast his rods again: *"Tonight, the Primordial Lord will journey eastward thirty thousand *li*."*
*"Why so far?"* the Lord asked.
Bingyan, gazing intently at the Daoist, recognized him as the one who had divined about the horse. Astonished, he marveled at the turn of events. The Daoist said: *"The *Qian* hexagram of that day is fulfilled today."* Bingyan bowed his head in gratitude.

Presently, a transcendent youth arrived, riding a deer-dragon, and announced: *"The Lord of the Eastern Marchmount has sent me to welcome the Primordial Lord. Tonight, you are to admire the moon at Qulong Mountain."* The Primordial Lord clapped his hands and laughed: *"The Daoist’s divination was correct!"* The Daoist respectfully took his leave, and the Primordial Lord said: *"Tell Xing Hepu for me."*
*"As you command,"* the Daoist replied.

To Bingyan, the Primordial Lord said: *"You may accompany me to Qulong Mountain."* They bathed in the pool and together mounted the deer-dragon, arriving in an instant. There, they beheld a perilous bridge a thousand paces long, its towering pillars stretching ten thousand *xun*, like a rainbow spanning the azure sky or a silken sash trailing across the heavens. Its form linked the Milky Way, its reflection plunged into the deep blue sea. Gleaming jade bore no dust, and clouds congealed without dispersing.

The Primordial Lord bade Bingyan bow to the Lord of the Eastern Marchmount, who said: *"You are the grandson of Prefect Xu."* Bingyan replied: *"I was orphaned young and do not know what office my ancestor held."* The Lord of the Eastern Marchmount said: *"Last night, I drank with your grandfather and knew you would come."*

He then commanded a transcendent youth to pour sweet wine, and the three drank together. The Primordial Lord asked: *"How fares the sea of late?"*
*"Compared to our last gathering, it has receded by half,"* the Lord of the Eastern Marchmount replied. *"Alas, the mulberry fields will not be long in coming."*

He ordered the jade maidens to sing the *"Song of the Master of Qingcheng"* to toast the Primordial Lord:
*"Moonlit jade steps where spring water drips like milk,
Jade flutes urge the phoenix to dance amid the mist.
Where does the Master of Qingcheng wander?
A crane’s cry pierces the sky, a wisp of cloud remains."*

The transcendent youths struck jade chimes and joined in harmony. When the feast reached its height, the Lord of the Eastern Marchmount took up a jade tablet and inscribed a poem:
*"The Bridge of Creation spans the eastern sea,
The jade wheel rolls past, crushing the rainbow bright.
A rainbow sash seems to brush the peak of Yingzhou,
The luminous breath stealthily dissolves the lock of decay."*

The Primordial Lord continued:
*"A perilous bridge arches on stone above the clouds,
Riding a deer, the view is vast and boundless.
The luminous soul washes the mist, the azure sky clears,
Osmanthus blooms brush the cold jade hairpin."*

He then asked Bingyan to compose a verse. Bingyan said:
*"Atop Qulong Bridge, I feast on Yingzhou’s fare,
A mortal bone, I join the boundless wanderer’s flight.
No need for a cinnabar ladder to tread the empyrean—
A crystal platter gleams in osmanthus autumn’s light."*

Then red luan birds sang, and colorful phoenixes danced. Pipes and flutes resounded beyond the heavens, while zither and lute melodies drifted down to the mortal realm. The transcendent revelers, their joy complete, prepared their chariots and palanquins. They ordered Bingyan to mount a deer-dragon and return with them. Looking down upon a great city below, Bingyan asked: *"What place is this?"*

The Perfected Lord said: *"This is Silla."*
They then arrived at a small town by the sea. Again, Bingyan asked: *"What place is this?"*
*"This is Dengzhou in the Tang realm,"* came the reply.

In an instant, they reached his old grotto abode. Bingyan bowed twice and took his leave. The Perfected Lord said: *"You have drunk the marrow of stones and already gained a thousand years among mortals. Do not leak secrets, do not indulge in dissipation. If you can do this, you may yet see me again."*

She commanded a jade maiden to bring Bingyan’s horse, saying: *"Though this is your steed, it is in truth the dragon-child of my grotto. Once, for no reason, it raged and harmed the crops, and so was banished to bear burdens among men. By chance, it departed to join you."*

When the horse reached the place where its saddle had once been removed, its coat was as before—its spirit soared, its frame lean, like the Eight Steeds in form.

The Perfected Lord said: *"When you return to the mortal world, you will have no use for this horse. Simply release it in the Wei Stream, and it shall transform into a dragon, no different from Fei Zhangfang casting his green bamboo staff into Ge Marsh."*

Bingyan leapt in astonishment, bowed his head, and took his leave.

The jade maiden said to Bingyan: *"When the dragon-child returns, have the woman called Tiánpó seal a small gift and send it to me."*

Then, mounting his horse, he flew like the wind. In the time it takes to eat a meal, he had already reached his old estate in Haoxian. The fields lay overgrown, the wells and towns in ruin.

Upon inquiry, he learned that sixty years had passed—it was now the fifth year of Emperor Xuānzōng’s Dàzhōng era. Bingyan’s body had grown pure and empty, his nature both serene and indifferent. With no desires left, what use had he for worldly things? Thus, he made no claim to his former properties, seeking only to fulfill the task of delivering Tiánpó’s sealed gift.

One day, he found Tiánpó and asked after her. She replied, *"The sisters of the Tàiyī household in Zǐxiāo often send letters asking me to buy seals for them."* When pressed further, she fell silent, her lips sealed, refusing to speak.

Bingyan then took the seal, struck it against his horse’s mane, and released the steed by the banks of the Wei. True to the Perfected Lord’s word, it turned north, transformed into a dragon, and vanished into the waters. Later, Bingyan secluded himself in the mountains of Kuānglú, where many claimed to have seen him.

**Mō the Healer**
Mō the Healer—no one knew his origins. He wandered the capital, carrying a small bamboo basket to peddle medicines. When someone fell ill, he would touch them with his hand, and they would invariably recover; thus, people called him *Mō the Healer*. His true name remained unknown. If offered money, he accepted it; if not, he never asked. His hair was tied in twin knots atop his head, his appearance wild. Yet his eyes were clear, his gaze arresting.

One day, caught in the rain, he sought shelter at the home of a tea merchant named Lǐ. The merchant welcomed him, and from then on, Mō would return each night to stay, departing only at dawn. Later, he arrived with another guest, and though the merchant hesitated, he did not refuse them.

In the dead of night, Lǐ rose to check on them through the window and saw a radiant glow. Startled, he peered closer and beheld Mō sitting amidst flames, while the other guest strained against the bed, his shoulder pressed hard against it. Lǐ cried out in alarm, and the fire vanished at once. The room plunged into darkness, leaving only the sound of snoring. The next morning, Lǐ questioned Mō: *"What were you doing last night?"* Both men merely laughed, offering no answer.

After that, Mō departed and was never seen again.

**Lord Wáng the Perfected**
Lord Wáng the Perfected had loved the Daoist arts since youth. He and his wife entered the mountains together, cultivating their practice with single-minded devotion, cutting themselves off from worldly affairs. On the eight seasonal festivals, they would pay homage according to the four directions.

Later, they encountered the Perfected of Tàixū, and both husband and wife bowed before him, entreating him to impart the Way. The Perfected presented Wáng with twenty-five scrolls of plain script—*The Way of the Nine Heavens’ August Immortals and the Supreme Numinous Elixir*—and said: *"You possess the highest affinity and are destined for transcendence. Your immortal name is already fixed; simply reverently guard this Way and never show it to others."* He then bestowed the scriptures upon him.

After seven more years, the Central Yellow of Tàiyī granted him the *Elixir of Numinous Blossoms*. Soon after, a dragon-drawn chariot with a feathered escort descended from the heavens. In broad daylight, he ascended as an immortal, becoming the Perfected of Tàihé. Only after his ascension did he learn, upon paying homage to his teacher, that the one who had bestowed the scriptures was none other than the Perfected of Tàixū—Chìsōngzǐ of Mount Nányuè.

**Liáng Xū the Daoist**
Liáng Xū the Daoist—no one knew his origins. As a Daoist, he had heard that consuming the seeds of the *dìngláng* tree could reverse aging and restore youth, granting the ability to see ghosts clearly at night. Though Xū was already seventy, he took the remedy and grew even younger and stronger. By the time he reached one hundred and forty, he could read by night and run as swiftly as a galloping horse. He later departed for the Green Cloud Mountains.

**Wáng Yuánzhī**
Wáng Yuánzhī was a native of Zhōnglíng.

At the age of ten or so, he went out one night and encountered a Daoist. After conversing with him, Yuánzhī followed the Daoist as they walked beneath the water of the river, bathed in moonlight. No mud or sand was visible, and the water parted with each step. Along the path, he saw a creature like a dragon, or perhaps a serpent, some ten *zhàng* in length, radiating five-colored light. When he asked the Daoist what it was, the reply came: "This is the Water Mother. Those who see her attain longevity."

By dawn, he had returned home. From then on, he delighted in roaming the mountains and seeking out mysteries. He drank wine often but consumed no medicinal elixirs. He would speak of having traversed the immortal sites of the Xiāoshǐ Altar on Mount Hóngyá in the western mountains, the Jade Bamboo of Mount Lú, and the grottoes of Mágū—none were left unexplored.

During his travels, he once met the immortal Cáo Déxiū in Jiāngyòu. Déxiū had been a Grand Scribe of the Western Jìn and later a Minister of the Liáng. He had attained the Dao of deathlessness and sailed the western rivers, coming and going with Yuánzhī. Yuánzhī had once served as a county clerk but was imprisoned. When Déxiū learned of this, he visited Yuánzhī’s family and instructed them to fetch a small amount of water. He then performed an incantation over it and had someone deliver it to Yuánzhī. After drinking it, Yuánzhī’s shackles fell away. He returned home and departed with Déxiū.

For over forty years, they traveled between Jiǔjiāng, Jīnlíng, and Jiāngdū before finally returning. Yuánzhī grew ever younger. Previously, Zhōnglíng had been plagued by mountain demons, but when Yuánzhī approached, they fled, saying to one another, "The Master Wáng is coming." Some saw a thousand soldiers with banners and flags on the road, only to realize it was Yuánzhī passing by. Sometimes he sailed against the wind with his sail hoisted, or drifted upon the water in perfect repose.

In the final years of the Xiàntōng era under Emperor Yìzōng of the Táng, Yuánzhī visited Jade Bamboo Mountain. Pí Yuánxiū, a Daoist of the Cloud and Water, had long been his close friend. One day, at Yùmù Hollow, he suddenly saw Yuánzhī strolling with several Daoist companions. He asked where they were headed.

Yuánzhī replied, "It is Xiāo Zǐyún, Wú Shìyún, Méi Fú, and Dàxiū—several immortals have invited me to ascend Jade Beam Mountain and await Immortal Fàn of Pénglái." No sooner had he spoken than he vanished, clouds and mist swirling thickly as wind shook the forest valleys. Yuánxiū gazed after him in dismay before returning home. (One version writes Yuánzhī’s name with the character *zhī* instead of *zhī*; it is unclear which is correct.)

**The Medicine-Selling Elder**
The Medicine-Selling Elder’s name was unknown; when asked, he would say that was his name. Some who had seen him as children still found his appearance unchanged in their old age. He always carried a large gourd to sell medicines. When people sought remedies for their illnesses, he gave them freely, whether they paid or not, and his medicines were miraculously effective. But if someone without illness asked for medicine in jest, they would inevitably lose it. Thus, people dared not request medicine lightly and revered him as a divine being.

Often drunk in the marketplace, he would give any money he received to the poor. Once, someone teased him, asking, "Do you sell the Great Return Elixir?" He replied, "I have one pill, but it costs a thousand strings of cash." People laughed, thinking him mad. He would often shout in the streets, "You have money but won’t buy medicine—you’ll all end up as dirt dumplings!" No one understood his meaning, and they only laughed.

Later, in Cháng’ān, he shook his gourd, which was now empty, and a single pill emerged, radiating brilliant light. Placing it in his palm, he said to the crowd, "For a hundred years, I’ve sold medicine among you, passing by countless millions, yet not one person was willing to spend money on medicine. How lamentable! Now I must take it myself." He placed the pill in his mouth, and five-colored clouds rose beneath his feet. A wind arose, and he ascended, drifting away.

**Master Yuán Kàng**
Master Yuán Kàng’s origins were unknown. Clad in hempen robes and straw sandals, he wandered the world, always deeply drunk. While traveling through the market of Chángqīng County in Qízhōu, he encountered a wealthy young man named Lǐ, who was oppressed by a local magnate. The Master visited Lǐ’s home daily, extending his hand to say, "Give me a hundred gold pieces for wine." Lǐ never refused, and the Master came every day for a full year without tiring.

One day, the Master took his leave, saying, "I have long imposed upon you. Now I must journey far. If you would host a farewell feast, you will have fulfilled your duty as host—and I will have something to teach you." Lǐ replied, "I was just about to prepare a parting banquet." They went beyond the city outskirts, and as the wine flowed freely, the Master said, "You bear a great grievance. If you are cautious, you may avoid it; otherwise, calamity will strike unpredictably."

Lǐ replied, "If you would instruct me, how dare I not obey?" The Master took up a brush and wrote the character *shèn* (caution) on Lǐ’s palm, saying, "Beware of striking anyone. If you do, the person will die by your hand, and you will only be safe after a month." Lǐ returned home, brooding day and night, too afraid to go out.

Ten days later, he suddenly heard a commotion outside his gate. Forgetting the Master’s warning, he rushed out to see. A lame beggar stood before his granary, hurling foul insults. Enraged, Lǐ struck him, and the beggar fell, his head striking the doorstep. He lay motionless, without breath. Lǐ wept in remorse, saying to his mother, "I did not heed the Master’s teaching, and now disaster has struck! To flee would be unfilial, but to stay means certain execution."

A man of utmost filial piety, he wailed in despair. His mother said, "You must flee to survive—do not wait to be bound." He slipped out through the back door, but as he emerged, he suddenly saw the Master. Weeping, Lǐ bowed and said, "It has barely been a month since we parted, and I have already disregarded your warning. Now, as you foretold, what is to be done?"

The Master replied, "Return home. I will devise a solution for you." He entered a quiet chamber and said to Lǐ, "Go out and submit to arrest. I have a plan." The Master then shut the door, closed his eyes, and sat in meditation. Lǐ stepped outside, where a crowd had gathered like a wall. The officers seized him.

Soon after, the lame man sat up, and after a moment, he walked away swiftly. The officers released Lǐ, allowing him to return home. Entering the chamber, he found the Master still sitting with eyes closed in deep meditation. The next day, the Master opened his eyes and said, "The lame man was indeed dead. I projected my spirit into his body to make him walk. Now I have placed his corpse by a dry ravine on Língyán Mountain, where no one goes."

The Master added, "You are a filial son and deserve a good reward. Your destined lifespan was seventy-four years, but striking the lame man has shortened it by four." The Master then prepared to leave. Lǐ said, "You have given me life anew—all my family’s wealth is insufficient to repay your kindness. What do you desire?"

The Master smiled and said, "I roam with the stars and endure with heaven and earth. What use have I for worldly goods?" And with that, he departed.

*Comprehensive Mirror of Perfected Immortals Who Embodied the Dao, Scroll Thirty-Two (concluded)*
*Comprehensive Mirror of Perfected Immortals Who Embodied the Dao, Scroll Thirty-Three*

Chen Xingming
Perfected Immortal Chen Xingming cultivated his practice at Yuanyang Palace on Mount Nanyue. The palace stood northeast of the temple, five *li* up the mountain, forming a tripod-like formation with the Upper Clarity Central Palace. This was during the Taishi era of Emperor Wu of the Jin dynasty.

In his youth, the Perfected One wandered through famous mountains, seeking to visit the abodes of immortals. On the summit of Heavenly Pillar Peak, he encountered two divine beings, both appearing eighteen or nineteen years old. They declared, "We traverse the four seas, guiding those of resolute aspiration. Worldly practitioners of the Dao may briefly attain single-minded devotion, yet halfway abandon their efforts, failing to persevere with diligence. How then could they ascend in bodily form to the heavens, soaring through the celestial thoroughfares? Your accumulated merit is commendable, but you must not retreat. Why fear your name will not be inscribed in the Golden Gates and Jade Halls? The bitterness of the path precedes its joy—for suffering has its limit, while bliss knows no end.

Why is this so? Dwelling in secluded forests and valleys, with birds and beasts as your companions, hunger and thirst inevitably arise. Enduring cold and heat, toiling in hardship, you sever worldly ties, forsake glory, bid farewell to kin, and relinquish love—this is true suffering. Yet to live as long as heaven and earth, to transform without end, to ride the void and mount the empty air, to grow wings at will—this is true joy. How could one not strive with unwavering effort?"

Xingming bowed deeply and replied, "I shall forever bear your sacred words in mind. I will attain the Dao without the slightest negligence."

The divine beings then bestowed upon him the Way of the Luminous Mirror. After eighteen years of cultivation, the two immortals descended once more and declared, "We once imparted to you the supreme Dao, and you have indeed practiced with diligence. Now you ascend to the Nine Heavens, roaming and feasting across the Eight Extremities—a reward for your accumulated merit. The bitterness of the path precedes its joy, and now you have attained it."

On the first day of the third month in the first year of the Taikang era of Emperor Wu of the Jin, mist and rosy clouds enveloped his chamber, while celestial music floated in the air. The villagers below rushed to witness the spectacle, but found only an empty room—even the chickens and dogs had ascended with him.

In the first year of the Chonghe era, Emperor Huizong bestowed upon him the title *Zhixu Shoujing* ("Void-Guarding and Stillness-Abiding") Perfected Immortal.

---

Yin Daoquan
Perfected Immortal Yin Daoquan, surnamed Yin and named Daoquan, was a native of Tianshui. He cultivated the Way of Returning to Spirit through Cavernous Perfection, wearing the talismans of the Five Thearchs and Six Jia, as well as the Left and Right Numinous Flight.

A celestial immortal descended and addressed him, saying, "Those who ascend in flight must possess the requisite capacity before achieving the Dao. In former times, Emperor Wu of Han personally received from the Queen Mother of the West the Twelve Arts of Numinous Flight and the True Forms of the Five Peaks, yet he only attained liberation through the deathless body, unable to make his form and bones ascend together. You have obtained but one of these arts, yet harbor the hope of ascending to heaven—is this not due to the merit accumulated in past lives and the seeds planted by your destiny?"

Daoquan replied, "My learning is shallow and my knowledge limited. I humbly request you reveal the titles of the Twelve Arts."

The celestial immortal recited:
1. The talismans of the Five Thearchs and Six Jia, and the Left and Right Numinous Flight.
