2. The scripture of the Great One’s Primal Chaos and Eastern Meng.
3. The Nine Vermilion Spotted Talismans of Bing and Ding Entering Fire.
4. The Register of the Six Ding of Grand Yin, the Way of Permeating Perfection and Concealing the Numinous, and the Jade Maidens.
5. The Book of the Six Wu of Grand Yang, Summoning Perfection and the Celestial Light’s Essence-Strategy.
6. The Oral Instructions of the Six Ji, the Golden Light of Stone Essence, and the Method of Concealing the Radiant Form.
7. The Statutes of the Six Geng for Summoning and Commanding Servitors.
8. The Method of the Six Xin for Attracting the Yellow Water and Moonlight Essence.
9. The Eight Techniques of the Six Ren and Gui for Concealing and Hiding in Earth.
10. The Six Void Dignities of the Eight Endowments of Zi, Wu, Mao, and You, and the Ten Oral Instructions.
11. The Three-Five Sequential Practices of the Earthly Perfection and Plain Oral Instructions of Chou, Chen, Xu, and Wei.
12. The Central Internal Vision of the Purple Degree and Blazing Light of Yin, Si, Shen, and Hai.

The celestial immortal continued:
1. The Mountain Talismans of the Five Peaks, which pacify and guard the sacred mountains, summon the myriad spirits, and are the true scriptures of the Most High.
2. The Mountain Traces of the Five Peaks, where immortals observe the inverted reflections, gazing down upon the mountains and rivers, transcribing their winding contours and the coiled, layered terrain.
3. The Mountain Forms of the Five Peaks, detailing the locations of their peaks and grotto chambers, the habitats of divine mushrooms and numinous herbs, their heights and measurements, and the distances of their eastern, western, southern, and northern boundaries.
4. The Mountain Bones of the Five Peaks, depicting their skeletal structures and branching divisions, modeled above on the stellar patterns and governing below the origins of human affairs.
5. The Charts of the Water Caves and Passages of the Five Peaks, mapping the sources of their springs, the locations of their hidden gold and treasures, and the networks of their earthly veins.

Each talisman and chart commands tens of thousands of officials, soldiers, and subordinates. The Five Peaks alone govern three great mountains and one hundred sixty lesser ones, along with one thousand two hundred minor mountains. Together with the bureaus and offices of the immortals, their numbers are vast indeed.

Though Emperor Wu of Han obtained these methods, he failed to uphold their precepts, exhausting his military might and indulging in warfare, thereby destroying his own fortune. Thus, he could not achieve the same merit as the Yellow Thearch. Now that you have encountered them, it is clear you descend from the lineage of Wen Shi and belong to the clan of Great Harmony—a family that has produced such individuals across generations. I shall await you above the Nine Purities, within the Great Void."

With these words, the celestial immortal departed.

The Perfected One, on the ninth day of the third month in the first year of Emperor Huaidi of Jin’s Yuankang reign, saw a white cloud arise within his chamber, lingering for three days without dissipating. When it finally dispersed, the Perfected One had vanished, leaving only a lingering fragrance that filled the room. In the first year of Emperor Huizong of Song’s Chonghe reign, he was bestowed the title *Tongzhen Guan Miaozhen Ren* (Perfected One of Wondrous Reality at the Abbey of Communion with the Real).

Prefect of Tanzhou Zhang Maozong inscribed a poem at the Hengyue Abbey, which reads:
*Before the sacred peaks of the numinous mountain, I wander the ancient abbey—*
*How does this place differ from the jeweled palaces of alchemy?*
*Five-cloud immortals, each with forms most strange,*
*Ten-grotto mists and blossoms, their scenes unlike the heart’s design.*
*By the elixir furnace, golden and mineral qi rises in fragrant coils;*
*At the star-summoning altar, the wind sighs through creeping fig and pine.*
*Having heard the great Dao’s secrets of perfected cultivation,*
*Are the Three Clarities’ realms truly so near, yet so far?*

The Abbey of the Grotto Gate at Hengyue, where Shi Cun dwelled, lies west of Stone Mill Peak and south of Pomegranate Peak, twenty *li* from the temple below. The Perfected One Shi, whose given name was Cun and who styled himself Master Hufu (or "Wanpenzi"), studied under Huang Luzi and mastered the *Inner Writings of the Three Sovereigns*. He commanded the guardianship of tigers and leopards, mastered the arts of concealment and transformation, and the methods of shifting through light and shadow. For centuries, he appeared and vanished at will. Admiring the austere purity of the Grotto Gate, he deemed it a place of vital resonance with the Real and took up residence there. On the western peak, he constructed a pavilion within a stone chamber, which one day stood empty for over ten *zhang*. He would ride a white leopard or return to the mountain on foot, the leopard always coming to greet him. Immortals of the seas and mountains would gather there from time to time. Though the villagers revered and longed for him, few were granted an audience. On the seventh day of the fourth month in the first year of Emperor Huidi of Jin’s Yongkang reign, he ascended to heaven riding his leopard. In the first year of Emperor Huizong of Song’s Chonghe reign, he was bestowed the title *Chonghe Jiansu Zhenren* (Perfected One of Harmonious Simplicity and Unadorned Reality).

There was also Li Changli of Shu, who dwelled in seclusion for years before wandering to the Heavenly Treasure Grotto. Today, only the remnants of the Leopard-Taming Crag remain. The *Zhen’gao* states: "Shi Cun was a man of Qi who styled himself Wanpenzi. Having attained the Dao of transformation and shifting through light, he now resides on Central Peak or at Shaoshi." It is said that the famed Master Hu of old was none other than he.

Yet he had not received the scriptures of the Most High, and thus had not attained perfection as a Perfected One. He wielded the jade axe and military fire talismans—these were but branches of what he had received.

Shi Cun was counted among the three thousand disciples of Confucius.

**Master Liaoran**
Master Liaoran was a man of Liaodong whose given name and surname remain unknown. After wandering through the twenty-four sacred sites of western Shu, he later dwelled on Mount Taibai. Tigers and leopards, tamed, would circle him as he came and went, though none knew what arts he cultivated. Later, he journeyed through the Three Chu regions, living for over a hundred years. Those with whom he shared close bonds included Wu Meng, Lu Xiujing, Guo Pu, Xie Lingyun, and the monk Huiyuan, who followed one after another. Yu Liang once took him as his teacher and asked: "Master, in your view, can these worthies escape this turbid world?" He replied: "Their merits vary in depth, but the Dao is of one essence. Though each has found their own path, none have attained perfect clarity." Yu Liang then asked: "And what of the Master?" He answered: "Leave this month, and I shall speak further to you." Before the month had passed, Yu Liang died.

Later, the Master traveled from the Western Mountains to visit South Peak, where he paid homage at the Green Jade and White Jade altars. Seeking the cave entrance ahead, he visited Master Li Changli, and they drank deeply for several days. When Li then departed for the mountains of Shu, the Master returned to seclude himself in the front cave. The Song monk Zong Bing once sought him there but did not encounter him.

**Deng Yuzhi**
Deng Yuzhi, styled Yanda, lived in reclusion at the Terrace of Flowers on South Peak. By night he recited the *Great Cavern Scripture*, and in response, the Lady Wei descended to address him, saying: "You possess the destiny of an immortal; I have come especially to visit you." One day, he suddenly saw three azure crows, large as cranes, dancing and calling as they flew—only after some time did they depart. Yuzhi then said to his disciples: "The azure crows have come; the appointed time has arrived." Soon after, he shed his mortal form.

Xu Lingqi

**Xu the Perfected One**
Xu the Perfected One, named Lingqi, was a native of Wu. He dwelt in reclusion at the Upper Clarity Palace on Mount Heng, cultivating the Dao. The palace lay seven *li* northeast of the temple. In his youth, a divine being imparted to him the essentials of the Mysterious Elixir, the method of absorbing the sun’s radiance, and the Way of guarding the Mud-Pill Palace. He subsisted on sesame rice, and thus was able to wander the seas and mountains, journeying to and from the Southern Mountains for many years. He explored the mountain’s grottoes and valleys, composing the *Record of Mount Heng*, which recounts the numinous wonders of its grotto-palaces.

He wrote that the Purple Canopy and Cloudy Screen Peaks each rose over five thousand *zhang* in height, and that on Cloudy Screen stood a stele from Yu the Great’s flood-control efforts, inscribed in tadpole script. Below the stele lay a stone altar, encircled by flowing water, a most sublime site. On Purple Canopy, cranes often gathered at its summit, where divine mushrooms and numinous herbs grew. Below stood a stone chamber, within which were a censer, pestle, mortar, and cinnabar tortoise.

Atop the Peak of Zhurong stood a jade altar, five *chi* square. To its east grew a purple pear tree, three hundred *chi* tall, planted by Yu of Xia. Its fruit was as large as a *dou*, red as the sun; those who ate it would attain immortality and never die. During the Yixi era of Emperor An of Jin, the mountain-dweller Pan Jue reached the western side of the peak. A rock split open, and a substance emerged, like purple clay, fragrant and soft, edible. Jue, not recognizing it as stone marrow, ultimately did not eat it and cast it aside. When he suddenly realized and returned, it was already gone. These were the sacred marvels he recorded.

He could also command spirits and gods, subdue dragons and tigers. On the ninth day of the ninth month in the first year of Yuanwei of King Cangwu of Song, he ascended as a perfected being. In the seventh year of Dali during the reign of Emperor Daizong of Tang, the Master of Mystic Harmony, Zhang Dakong—teacher of Li Bi—resided there and attained the Dao, later achieving liberation through the corpse at Yuanyang Palace. In the first year of Dazhong, Han Weiyi, admiring his example, dwelt there in cultivation and likewise attained the Dao. In the first year of Chonghe, Emperor Huizong of Song bestowed upon him the title *Mingzhen Dongwei Perfected One*. The foundations of the palace remain today.

A stone stele records that in former times, an immortal parrot announced the dawn, having eaten the immortal herb and become deathless. Occasionally, woodcutters glimpsed it but could not capture it.

**Deng Yuzhi of the Nine Immortals Palace on Purple Canopy Peak**
Deng Yuzhi, styled Yuanda, was a native of Xinye in Nanyang. In his youth, he dreamed of a flying crow bearing an official seal. Later, he obtained a talisman for expelling evil and dispelling poisons, and all whom he treated were cured. He formed a bond of transcendents’ friendship with Xu Lingqi, wandering famous mountains and seeking out perfected beings.

Having encountered a perfected being, he was transmitted the arts of the golden crucible and fire talismans. In the second year of Yuanhui under Song Emperor Cangwu, after Xu had ascended, Deng Yuzhi concealed himself in the cavern gate. After a long while, he wandered beyond the lakes, traversing every grotto-heaven and blessed land. Unable to procure the ingredients for his elixir, he gathered herbs and lodged for the night in a stone grotto. In a dream, a divine personage said to him: "You have merit and shall soon be summoned. You ought to emerge at the appointed time, for the host of immortals awaits you." Awakening, he was startled and overjoyed.

In the early years of Tianjian under the Liang, the imperial court memorialized that the Lesser Yang star had appeared in the Changsha region of southern Chu. Emperor Wu dispatched an inspector to seek him out. When asked of his practices, he replied: "This poor Daoist refines the golden liquor but lacks the ingredients for the elixir." The emperor bestowed gold and silk and permitted him to select a secluded and propitious site in the Grotto of Perfection and Blessed Land of Mount Nanyue, establishing upper, middle, and lower abbeys to cultivate both inner and outer elixirs.

One evening, a divine personage addressed him, saying: "The neighbor of the Great Grotto is the land that summons blessings, the hamlet that extends life. Mark this well and do not forget." Later, when his elixir was complete, he again moved to the eastern slopes of Purple Canopy Peak. On the thirtieth day of the twelfth month in the final year of Tianjian, eight perfected ones descended into his chamber in feathered canopies and cloud chariots—the same eight perfected beings who had previously attained the Dao. Thereupon, he ascended to heaven from the natural stone altar.

In the first year of Chonghe, Emperor Huizong of Song bestowed upon him the title *Chaozhen Jimiao Perfected One*. Zhang Guan, prefect of Hengzhou, submitted a memorial to establish an abbey plaque.

**Chen Xidu**
Chen the Perfected One, whose personal name was Huidu, was a native of Yingchuan.

Initially, he resided on Mount Mao, where he gathered rare and wondrous herbs to sell, drinking wine without taking food. After but a few years, he journeyed south. The two peaks he carried were filled with minerals and stones. Upon reaching Mount Heng, he chose a secluded and scenic spot to dwell at Jade Purity Abbey. South of Stone Gruel Peak, twenty-five *li* from the temple up the mountain, he made a covenant with Heaven and swore to refine the elixir. Deep in the night, he was harassed by ghosts, who thrice pounded his alchemical furnace and hurled stones to crush him. Yet he sat cross-legged upon a rock in deep meditation, reciting the *Huangting Jing*, wearing the *Yuelan Wuyue Zhenxing Tu*. His resolve grew ever more steadfast; in secret, resonance was achieved, and the power of the Dao lent its support. He captured the mountain spirits and demons, and the malevolent qi gradually dispersed. The ghosts, trembling and wailing in terror, were made by the Perfected One to shoulder stones and swear oaths to spare their lives, whereupon they were banished far beyond the borders. Later, when his elixir was complete, radiant qi filled the mountain, illuminating all near and far. After consuming it, on the thirteenth day of the fifth month in the third year of Yongming under Emperor Wu of Qi, he ascended to heaven.

The Tang poet Zhang Jiuling’s *Poem on the Elixir Terrace* reads:
*"West of Parrot’s Head, the side gate opens wide—*
*Chen’s elixir soars to the Terrace of Kalpas past.*
*Do the oaths sworn to demons in years gone by still hold?*
*Even now, they speak of the ghosts made to bear the stones."*

In the first year of Chonghe, Emperor Huizong of Song bestowed upon him the title *Chongxu Yuanmiao Perfected One*. Today, atop the abbey’s foundation, one may still find the Elixir Terrace, the Ghost-Bearing Stones, the Thunder Pool and Wind Cavern, the Scripture-Recitation Altar, and the Elixir-Bathing Spring. In later times, a monk established a temple called Brightness upon the abbey’s foundation, though it was soon abandoned. During the Qiandao era of Emperor Xiaozong, the Daoist Deng Shiyong and the lay practitioner Huang Shouzhen opened the mountain, felled trees, and cleared the undergrowth. They appealed to the worthy and virtuous, newly constructing halls and pavilions.

Rain prayers and disaster averting rites alike proved responsive, their efficacy manifest. Rustic dwellers in mountain huts deeply embraced the Dao’s transforming influence.

**Zhang Tanyao**
The Zhaoxian Abbey of Hengyang lies eight *li* east of the temple. Old records state its foundation was laid by Liu Zong, its site divined during the Xiao Qi dynasty. Another account dates its establishment to the reign of Emperor Wu of Jin, during the Xianning era. Formerly, the Perfected Zhang, whose name was Tanyao, dwelt here. Moved by his devotion, the Heavenly Perfected secretly descended, transmitting the Way of Internal Nourishment of Primordial Harmony and the Silent Audience before the Great Emperor. After twelve years of practice, his spirit ascended the Great Void, where he was received in audience by the August Emperor of the Supreme Ultimate. Bestowed with jade treasures, langgan elixir, and the fluid of merged spirit and radiance, he consumed them, undergoing transformations beyond measure, his divine powers boundless. On the third day of the seventh month in the first year of Yanxing under Emperor Fei of Qi, a sudden thunderous roar shook heaven and earth. In an instant, phoenixes and cranes bore a vermilion edict, bearing him aloft to ascend as an immortal. In the first year of Chonghe, Emperor Huizong of Song granted him the title *Baoguang Ximing Perfected One*.

**Zhang Ruzhen**
The Jiuzhen Abbey of Mount Heng lies ten *li* east of the temple. Old records state it was built by the Master of Xinye during the Taikang era of Jin. In the early years of the Tianjian era under Emperor Wu of Liang, the Perfected Zhang Ruzhen resided there. Zhang was a fellow villager and neighbor of the Master. From childhood, he spoke little, his temperament aloof and untouched by worldly concerns. In his prime, he dwelt in seclusion, his innate spiritual bone drawing the descent of a divine being to his thatched chamber, who transmitted the Way of the Luminous Mirror and Penetrating Insight. The divine being said: "That which illumines the principles of things is Heaven; that which reflects their forms is the Dao. Heaven’s Way is pure; the mirror’s Way is bright. Scrutinized without error, form is fixed here, while things respond there. Thus, the shapes of rivers and mountains, the dispositions of ghosts and spirits—none can escape or conceal themselves. Heaven, in its clarity, embraces the myriad things; the mirror, in its brightness, reflects all forms. If one cultivates the clarity of Heaven and the brightness of the mirror, calming the heart and settling the spirit to achieve inner and outer transparency, then the supreme Dao is attained. But if one is externally enslaved by things and internally wearied by the spirit, the spirit and heart grow turbid and cannot be stilled—then one strays far from the Dao. This method I once received from Master Changsang, who received it from the Heavenly Emperor of the Great Tenuity. Those who obtain it gain penetrating insight and far-reaching vision, illuminating the eight directions. Within the methods of the *Dongzhen*, there is the Way of the Four Regulations, practiced in accord with the four seasons, which is of the same essence as this. The ancients spoke truly: 'Empty the chamber, and whiteness arises of itself; settle the heart, and the Dao comes of itself.'"

Ruzhen practiced this for nine years, his vision penetrating a thousand *li*, nothing able to remain hidden. On the eighteenth day of the eleventh month in the thirteenth year of Tianjian under Emperor Wu of Liang, he wandered alone into the mountains and did not return for three days. His disciples searched for him and saw Ruzhen then clad in immortal robes, riding a cloud chariot, accompanied by flutes and drums, ascending into the heavens in ethereal splendor. In the first year of Chonghe, Emperor Huizong of Song granted him the title *Quanzhen Dadao Perfected One*.

**Liao Zhong**
Liao Chong, styled Qingxu, resided in Lianshan Prefecture during the third year of Datong under Emperor Wu of Liang. Renowned for his talent and virtue, he served as the chief clerk of his home prefecture. Later, he resigned his seals and ribbons, roaming in search of the essentials of the Dao. He dwelt on Mount Songgao for a time, then passed through Jingzhou and Gong’an, where two spirits stirred up mischief, conjuring winds and waves to obstruct his boat.

Having subdued and expelled them, he commanded the two spirits to guard the boat and ferry him across. Upon reaching Mount Nanyue, he encountered the Supreme Peace Perfected Lord atop Zhurong Peak, who transmitted to him the essentials of the Dao. He then addressed the two spirits: "I shall dwell in Bangyang to refine the elixir. You may guard my furnace, and when the elixir is complete, you too shall have a share." The elixir was duly perfected, and he returned to his hometown. He would often ride a tiger, wielding a serpent as his whip. Having lived over a hundred years, in the second year of *Xiantian* under Emperor Ruizong of Tang, he ascended amid darkening winds and clouds.

**You Daorong**
You Daorong of the Northern Qi was taciturn from childhood, disinclined toward literature, and fond of solitude. While roaming Mount Nanyue, he met the Red Lord, who taught him the arts of talismanic water, prohibitive incantations, and the reckoning of celestial portents—all of which he mastered in full. Another account states that in his youth, he became a Daoist and, hearing of a man in Jinyang renowned for his mastery of esoteric arts, sought him out. That man, well-versed in Daoist talismans, prohibitive incantations, yin-yang calculations, celestial patterns, and the properties of medicinal herbs, transmitted all his knowledge to Daorong. After more than a year, he said: "I am originally an immortal of Mount Heng, but for a minor transgression, I was demoted by the celestial bureaucracy. Now my term is complete, and I shall return home. Escort me to the Fen River." Upon arrival, the river had surged violently, and the bridge was destroyed. The man then performed the *Yu step* by the water’s edge, casting a talisman into the current, which instantly parted. Moments later, the waters rose, yet the two crossed unhurriedly over the sand. Daorong was later summoned by Emperor Wenxuan to the Liaoyang Mountains of Jinyang. In the dead of night, his horse startled, and a fierce beast appeared mere paces away. Daorong calmly drew his staff across the ground, forming a fiery pit, and the beast fled in haste.

**Jia Ziran**
Jia Ziran cultivated himself through fasting and meditation at the Supreme Peace Abbey on Mount Heng, where he encountered the Nanyue Perfected Lord Chen Shaowei, who had descended from Ziming. The Perfected Lord said: "I am aware of your cultivation. When a lofty immortal is destined to appear, the mysteries must be transmitted." Later, the Venerable Master of Qingcheng descended to his chamber and bestowed upon him the secret of the *Nine-One Flying Immortal*, enabling his ascension in broad daylight.

**Xiao Linghu**
Xiao Linghu, styled Tianyou, was a native of Luling. At seven, he could compose poetry, all his verses imbued with otherworldly intent. At fifteen, he developed a passion for the Dao, and in his prime, he met a perfected being who transmitted to him the arts of the *Golden Liquor Elixir* and *Embryonic Breathing*. He traversed renowned mountains, carrying over a hundred scrolls of Daoist scriptures. He often said: "To ascend to the Southern Palace, one must first cross the Vermilion Mound." While visiting Dongyang, he passed by Mount Lu and gazed upon the image of Perfected Lord Deng, remarking: "This mountain is one of the blessed lands of the Vermilion Mound." That night, the Perfected Lord appeared to him and transmitted the art of the *Fire Cauldron*. In the second year of *Zhenguan* under Emperor Taizong of Tang, he sailed the Xiang and Xiao Rivers, personally performing rituals to invoke life and expel evil, bringing immeasurable relief to the local populace. Later, he resided at Zhao Xian Abbey, refining the *Fire Cauldron* technique, transmuting base metals into gold and silver for alms, and renovating the abbey’s halls, restoring them to pristine condition. A certain marquis or prince revered him, inviting him to serve as the master of rites, and all deferred to him. In the fifth year, he established the Pavilion for Seeking the Perfected. In the sixth year, the year *Renchen*, he cast a bronze bell weighing five hundred *jin* in Guizhou. Upon returning to the abbey, he refrained from striking it for five watches, lest he disturb the earth spirits. Later, he selected a secluded and scenic site to the north of the mountain to refine the divine elixir. After three altars, the elixir was finally perfected. Having consumed it, in the second year of *Hongdao* under Emperor Gaozong, on the Mid-Autumn Festival, he addressed his disciples: "My time of departure has come; I must go and cannot tarry. You must diligently cultivate, for there will be those who succeed me." Thereupon, he underwent *shi jie*, his chamber filled with fragrant vapors, and faint celestial strains seemed to linger beyond the door for some time before fading. In the final years of *Duan’gong* under Emperor Taizong of Song, at the fifth watch one day, the abbey’s bell suddenly tolled. The assembly was astonished and rose to investigate, only to find the bell cracked. Within ten days, a Daoist appeared, melting copper in his palm and mending the fissure, the crimson glow dimming of its own accord. The onlookers were filled with awe. The Daoist then entered the stream to wash his hands and vanished without a trace. To this day, the bell bears the marks of those who touch it, a testament to its numinous wonder.

**Zhang Huiming**
Zhang Huiming was a native of Zhaojun.

Zhang Huiming built his hut upon Mount Zhongtiao and received the teachings at Yuanzhen Abbey. He regularly practiced incantations and exorcisms, driving away malevolent spirits. Later, he journeyed to Chang’an, where he encountered Master Hunyuan and was initiated into the Dao of *Gaoben*. Through its practice, his merits flourished and his virtue perfected, his Daoist learning surpassing all others. Those who gathered at his seat were all disciples of the highest order. Emperor Taizong of Tang summoned him to the inner palace, where he conducted a grand offering that moved the spirits. Later, he petitioned to return to the mountains and forests, and the emperor permitted him to reside at Mount Nanyue, bestowing upon him the title *Master of Wondrous Salvation*. One evening, he unexpectedly encountered the Lady Youying of the Southern Peak, who transmitted to him the essentials of *embracing oneness and guarding the true*, and the *unity of the Three and Five*. After practicing these for twelve years, he was again summoned to the western capital to attend to imperial inquiries. Once more, he underwent *shi jie*.

**Li Simu**
Li Simu was a native of Chengji. He formed bonds of mist and clouds with Dong the Alchemist and Master Bai. Together, they wandered the famous mountains of the Three Xiang regions before visiting the Five Peaks of Mount Nanyue. Though their masters and teachings differed, each had his own path to enlightenment. After Master Bai ascended from Stone Drum Peak, Li Simu entered the capital, where Gao Lishi, resentful of Wu Yun, recommended him to Emperor Xuanzong. His answers to the emperor’s questions were well-received, and later, he petitioned to return to the mountains. The emperor bestowed upon him generous gifts for his journey. He annotated the *Classic of Purity and Stillness*, which circulated in the world. Later, he achieved profound transformation upon Purple Canopy Peak. Only Dong remained at the rear cavern of Mount Heng in Hengyang, where he often used incantations to heal the sick. Those who offered him recompense found that only wine—enough to intoxicate—sufficed. Thus, he was never sober; his drunken traces marked roads and streams, yet when rain fell, his robes remained dry, and in the biting frost, his hair gleamed white. After several years, he went door to door, telling people, "Take good care of yourselves." The people were astonished, and soon after, he underwent *shi jie* behind the cavern, as if shedding an old husk. The Tang poet Du Fu, in his poem *Recalling the Past*, wrote in its closing lines: *"Then I sought Dong the Alchemist of Hengyang— / Southward journey, early drums trailing along the Xiao and Xiang."*

**Shen Taizhi**
Shen Taizhi, styled Guangxiang, was originally from Luoyang. His ancestors, having served as officials in the southern lakes, settled in Changsha for generations before dispersing and wandering the four directions. Admired near and far, Taizhi chose to reside by Willow Pond in Renfeng Village of Shaozhou. For generations, his family cultivated kindness and benevolence. From childhood, he kept to himself, avoiding even relatives and friends. Fond of reading, he lived with constant frugality and purity.

He wandered and rested upon Mount Nanyue, inquiring into the affairs of divine transcendents. One evening atop Zhurong Peak, he encountered a Perfected One, who transmitted to him the defense of the Golden Elixir and Fire Dragon. Returning, he refined the elixir upon the northern summit of Yunshan, where the clouds gather, for many years. When the Great Medicine was complete and his merit and practice both perfected, he could ride the void and spirit-travel, appearing and vanishing at will, endowed with numinous marvels beyond mortal comprehension.

In the twenty-sixth year of the Kaiyuan era of the Tang, the year *wuyin* (738), on the sixteenth day of the eighth month, Emperor Minghuang addressed his close ministers: "Last night, on the Mid-Autumn, I dreamed that a divine personage told me: 'In Yunshan of Shaozhou in Hunan, there is a Daoist refining the elixir who has attained transcendence. If you honor and receive him, he may serve as the state preceptor.'"

**Master Zhang Taikong**
Master Zhang, whose surname was Zhang and given name Taikong, secluded himself in the Upper Clarity Palace on Mount Heng, cultivating practice to attain the Dao. In the seventh year of the Dali era of Emperor Daizong of the Tang (772), he became the teacher of the Tang minister Li Bi. Later, he secluded himself in the Yuanyang Palace, and on the thirteenth day of the sixth month of the fourth year of the Zhenyuan era of Emperor Dezong (788), he underwent *shi jie* upon Lingyin Peak. The imperial composition read:

*"The supreme Dao is nameless; we provisionally bestow a name to honor the Dao. The supreme Perfected is without designation; we must seek a title to clarify the Perfected. Only that which may be named resides in the perfection of virtue. Thus, the Daoist Zhang Taikong of the Yuanyang Palace on Mount Nanyue, nurtured by the Primordial Chaos, delved into the profound mystery beyond mystery. He refined his bones in the Three Clarities and preserved his spirit in the Eight Effulgences. Cultivating virtue upon the peaks of Heng, he neared a century in years. Relying on the formless to seek the hidden, he wielded the primordial chaos with effortless mastery. His vital force was vast as the ancient void, his true form that of primordial antiquity. Recently, under the former emperor, he expounded the wondrous subtleties of the Dao. Gazing upon the chariot of the dark crane, he was bestowed with robes of purple mist. I have a minister of aid, whose lofty words and footsteps I revere; ever do I cherish this transcendent, regretting that we did not live in the same age. To express my admiration, I now confer this illustrious command. Let his name be recorded and his virtue proclaimed, that it may endure without end. He is to be posthumously honored as Master Xuanhe."*

The palace underwent renovations during the Chunhua, Tiansheng, and Zhenghe eras of the Song. In the first year of the Xuanhe era (1119), Emperor Huizong renamed it Chongming Abbey. Three *li* beyond it lies Fuhu (Crouching Tiger) Crag.

**Liu Shi**
During the Yuanhe era of Emperor Xianzong of the Tang, there were two men, Liu Shi and Yuan Che, who resided upon Mount Heng. Both had uncles who served as officials in the eastern regions of Zhe, but due to the entanglements of commoners in legal troubles, each was exiled to the remote prefectures of Guan and Ai. The two gentlemen, bound by filial duty, journeyed to visit them. Arriving at Baipu County in Lianzhou, they boarded a boat to cross the sea. As they neared Jiaozhi, their vessel moored at Hepu’s shore.

That night, villagers were offering a feast to the gods, with flutes and drums clamoring. The boatmen and the two gentlemen’s servants all went to watch. As the night deepened toward midnight, a sudden gale arose, snapping the mooring ropes. The boat drifted into the vast sea, directionless. Soon, it reached a solitary island where the wind stilled. The two gentlemen, disheartened, disembarked. They saw an image of the Jade Heavenly Worthy, resplendent upon an altar, with a golden incense burner but nothing else.

As they surveyed the surroundings, they suddenly beheld a colossal beast emerging from the eastern sea. It turned its head in all directions, as if listening intently, then after a long while, departed. Hesitantly, a purple cloud surged from the sea, spreading for several hundred paces. A five-colored lotus leaf, over a hundred *chi* tall, unfolded petal by petal. Within, a canopy shimmered, woven of brocade and embroidery, dazzling the eyes. A rainbow bridge suddenly extended, reaching directly to the island.

Presently, two maidens with twin buns appeared, as if bearing a jade casket and holding a golden censer shaped like a lotus, approaching the Heavenly Worthy’s altar. They replaced the spent incense with exotic fragrances. Seeing the maidens, the two gentlemen kowtowed repeatedly, their pleas mournful and bitter, beseeching a return to the mortal world. The maidens did not respond. After the two men entreated for a long while, one of them asked: "Who are you, and how have you come here?" The two men recounted their circumstances.

The maiden said, "Shortly, the Venerable Master of Jade Void will descend upon this island to meet with the Lady of Southern Qi. If you persist in your entreaties, your wishes may yet be fulfilled." As her words ended, a Daoist riding a white deer and wielding colored clouds descended straight onto the island. The two men bowed and wept as they recounted their plight. The Venerable Master, moved by their pleas, said, "Follow this maiden to pay homage to the Lady of Southern Qi, and your return shall be granted. Have no fear." Turning to the maiden, the Master instructed, "Attend briefly to your cultivation, then guide these two men to receive her teachings."

Before the canopy, they performed the rites of obeisance. There they beheld a woman of unmatched beauty, clad in robes of five-colored patterns. The two men announced their names, and the Lady smiled, saying, "Long ago on Tiantai Mountain there was Liu Chen, and now there is Liu Shi; once there was Ruan Zhao, and now there is Yuan Che—surely this is fate." She prepared two couches for them to sit.

Presently, the Venerable Master arrived, and the Lady rose to greet him before resuming her seat. Several fairy maidens played flutes, pipes, and sheng, while phoenixes and simurghs danced beside them, their movements in perfect harmony. The two men felt as though lost in a dream, for such sights were rare even in the mortal world. Then, the Lady ordered wine to be served.

Suddenly, a black crane descended from the sky, bearing a brocade scroll in its beak. It announced, "Master Anqi, knowing the Venerable Master attends the Southern Assembly, humbly requests your presence." The Venerable Master read the message and said to the crane, "I shall go there shortly." Turning to the Lady, he remarked, "Master Anqi and I have not met in a thousand years. Though he has not journeyed south, there is no chance to converse." The Lady then urged her maidens to serve refreshments. The vessels were of luminous jade, and she dined with the Venerable Master, while the two men were not permitted to partake.

The Venerable Master said, "These two guests are not yet fit to share this repast, but let them be given food for mortals." The Lady assented and had common fare served to them. After the Master finished eating, he drew from his robe a scroll of cinnabar talismans and presented it to the Lady, who received it with reverence. Then he took his leave, saying to the two men, "You possess the bones of Dao. Your return will not be difficult. Yet this chance encounter means you are destined to receive an elixir. However, your destined master is another—I am not fit to be your teacher." The two men bowed, and the Venerable Master departed.

The Lady commanded her maidens, "Escort these two guests away." She asked, "By what means shall they travel?" A maiden replied, "The Hundred-Flower Bridge will serve." The two men expressed their gratitude and took their leave. The Lady gifted them a jade flask, over a *chi* in height, and inscribed upon it a poem with her brush:

*You came by a single-leaf skiff,*
*You depart upon the Hundred-Flower Bridge.*
*Should you knock the jade flask in the mortal world,*
*The mandarin ducks will speak plainly to you.*

Soon, a bridge spanning several hundred paces appeared, its railings adorned with rare blossoms. The two men peered between the flowers and saw thousands of dragons and rainbows intertwined as pillars and stones. A messenger addressed them, "I ought not to be your guide, but I bear a weighty request and am compelled to this task." From his sash, he produced a small box, within which something stirred faintly, resembling a spider. He said, "We are water immortals, beings of yin, and thus have no men among us. Long ago, I encountered a youth from Panyu, and our deep affection bore a child. Before he turned three, we were forced to abandon him. The Lady commanded that he be given to the God of Southern Marchmount as a son, and he has been there for some time. Recently, the God of Southern Marchmount returned to Crow Peak, and as I had business in the water palace, I entrusted my son to a messenger upon his return. The messenger took the jade ring my son was playing with and vanished—I hold this a great grievance. I ask you, noble sirs, to carry this box to the foot of Crow Peak, seek out the messenger’s shrine, and cast it there. There will be a wondrous transformation. If you recover the jade ring, deliver it to my son, and he will surely reward you. Do not open the box." The two men accepted it, and one asked, "The Lady’s poem says, *Should you knock the jade flask in the mortal world, the mandarin ducks will speak plainly to you.* What does this mean?" The messenger replied, "When you return, should you have need, knock the flask, and a bird will answer. Your wishes will be granted." The other asked, "The Venerable Master said we each have our own master. Who might that be?" The messenger answered, "The Supreme Master of Southern Marchmount. You will meet him in time." Then they parted from the messenger.

As the bridge ended, they reached the place where they had moored their boat in Hepu. Looking back, the bridge was gone. When they inquired about the era, they found that ten years had passed. They hastened to their home provinces, only to find their kin long deceased. Overcome with sorrow, they resolved to return to Mount Heng. Along the way, they knocked the jade flask, and a pair of mandarin ducks spoke, "Eat and drink, and you will encounter what you seek ahead." Soon, by the roadside, platters of food and wine appeared, and the two men ate their fill. After several days’ journey, they reached home, where the children of their youth had grown to adulthood. Yet they learned that each had died three days prior, and their families were torn between grief and joy. People said, "The young masters perished at sea, and their mourning periods have long since ended." The two men seemed weary of the world, their bodies light and ethereal. Seeing their wives’ funerals, they felt little sorrow.

Together, they traveled to the foot of Crow Peak and sought the messenger’s shrine, casting the box into it. Suddenly, a black dragon dozens of *zhang* long stirred the winds and spat hail, snapping trees and uprooting houses. With a thunderous crack, the shrine shattered. Trembling, the two men dared not look closely. From the air, a jade ring was tossed down, which they retrieved and delivered to the shrine of Southern Marchmount.

Upon their return, a youth in yellow robes arrived at each of their homes, bearing two golden boxes. He said, "The masters’ elixir is *Returning Soul Ointment*. Should any in your families have died, even if a full cycle of sixty years has passed, anoint their crowns, and they will revive." Then the youth vanished. The two men used the ointment to revive their wives. Later, they wandered together in search of the Supreme Master, but no trace of him was found.

Amidst the snow, they saw an old woodcutter selling firewood. Moved by his age and the cold, the two men gave him wine to drink. Noticing the characters "Tai Ji" carved on the eaves above his firewood, they found it strange and bowed to him as their teacher. They presented the jade flask to him, and the old man said, "This flask is where I store my jade liquid." Overjoyed, he then led the two men up Mount Zhurong, and they never emerged again.

*Records of True Immortals Through the Ages Who Embodied the Dao and Attained Profound Understanding*, Scroll 33—End
*Comprehensive Mirror of True Immortals Through the Ages Who Embodied the Dao*, Scroll 34

**Chen Faming**
The Dongyang Palace of Mount Heng stands northwest of Shileng Peak, where the True Man Shi subdued demons in assembly. When Chen Faming returned in response to the imperial summons during the Tang, he opened a cave and built an altar at the foot of this peak, aided in secret by mountain dwellers. Gazing south toward Yunyang, he paid homage to the Dao each morning and evening, reciting the *Great Cavern Scripture*. Later, he ingested the elixir and transcended through the mysterious. Today, the old foundations remain, along with a few monastic halls.

**Wang the Eighteenth**

When the Tang dynasty’s Grand Councilor, Lord Liu Yan, was young, he was fond of Daoist arts and practiced them diligently without wearying, yet he never encountered a master. He had heard that extraordinary persons often frequented market stalls, for the bustle and commotion allowed them to blend in unnoticed. While traveling in Chang’an, he came to an apothecary shop where he overheard someone say: “There are usually three or four old men—wearing gauze hats and leaning on staffs—who come to drink wine. Once they finish, they leave. They also ask to see the herbs but never buy much. I suspect they are no ordinary folk.” Lord Liu asked, “Do they come at a fixed time?” The man replied, “They should arrive tomorrow.” At dawn the next day, Liu went to wait for them. Soon enough, three Daoist adepts arrived. They drank their fill, conversing and jesting with great delight, as if no one else were present. After a long while, one asked, “Are there any in the world like us?” Another answered, “Wang the Eighteenth.” Then they departed. From that day on, Liu remembered the name but could never find him.

Later, when Liu served as prefect, he passed through Hengshan County in the southern regions. It was early spring, the weather mild and warm. He was served a plate of chilled noodles with fragrant herbs—artemisia and the like—remarkably fresh and pure. Struck by this, Liu asked the postal clerk, “Is there anyone of refined bearing nearby? Where did these vegetables come from?” The clerk replied, “The county has an official garden. Wang the Eighteenth tends it, so the kitchen always has fine greens.” Liu suddenly recalled the Daoists’ words. He asked, “Is the garden far?” The clerk said, “It’s right behind the guesthouse.” Liu went to inquire and saw Wang the Eighteenth, wearing a loincloth and tending the beds, his appearance rough and rustic. At the sight of Liu, he hurried forward to bow, trembling. Liu gradually asked about his hometown and family, and Wang replied, “I drift like tumbleweed, with no memory of such things, nor any kin.” Liu found this even more extraordinary. He invited Wang to sit, offered him wine, and pressed him to accept, but Wang firmly refused.

Upon returning, Liu went to the county office and requested that Wang accompany him beyond the mountain range. The magistrate, not understanding his intent, immediately sent Wang off—still in tattered clothes and straw sandals—boarding the boat with Liu. As they traveled, Liu grew familiar with Wang and had his wife and children pay their respects, sharing tea and meals with him. Yet Wang’s appearance and clothing grew increasingly filthy, and the household secretly despised him. Liu’s wife asked, “Is there something special about him? Why do you treat him so?” Liu remained unwavering. After traveling several hundred *li* toward their destination, Wang fell ill with dysentery, growing weaker by the day.

The boat’s cabin was cramped, and Wang never left Liu’s side. Those around him pinched their noses and refused to eat, unable to bear the stench. Yet Liu showed no sign of disgust—only deep sorrow. He urged Wang to take broth and porridge, but after several days, Wang passed away. Liu sighed in grief, weeping as he performed every funeral rite without omission, then buried him by the roadside.

The following year, Liu’s term ended, and he returned to the capital. On his way back, he stopped at Hengshan, where the county magistrate greeted him outside the city. Once seated, the magistrate said, “The servant you brought with you left not long ago to search for something and has just returned. He must have been unfit for service.” Liu asked in shock, “When did he return?” The magistrate replied, “A little over a month ago. He said you had given him leave to go back.” Horrified, Liu rushed on foot to the garden estate. The thatched hut still stood, but all within was empty. A neighbor told him, “Wang the Eighteenth left last night.” Overcome with remorse, Liu bowed twice toward the hut, weeping as he turned away. Upon checking the date, he realized it was the very day Wang had died of illness on the road. He sent men to open the grave, but only Wang’s clothes remained.

Months later, Liu arrived in the capital and took his place among the court officials. One day, he fell gravely ill, his condition worsening until his family gathered around him, wailing in distress. Suddenly, a frantic knocking came at the door. The doorman rushed in, announcing, “A man calling himself Wang the Eighteenth asks to be announced.” The household, trembling, hurried to greet him. Wang entered with a faint smile and went straight to Liu’s bedside. He ordered all screens and medicines removed, then drew three pills the size of small beans from a gourd at his waist. Using a reed tube, he poured half a bowl of water, fed the pills to Liu, and shook him gently. Soon, Liu’s belly rumbled like thunder. In moments, he opened his eyes, sprang up, and stood—no trace of illness remained.

Lady Liu exclaimed, "Wang the Eighteenth!" Tears and mucus streamed down her face as she bowed again and again, overcome with emotion. His wife, daughters, and servants all wept as well. Wang the Eighteenth, unmoved, said, "I am ashamed to have repaid an old debt so belatedly—thus I came to save him. This pill grants ten more years of life; when the time comes, I shall return." With that, he drank a bowl of tea and departed. Minister Liu entreated him to stay a while, but Wang refused. When Liu offered gold and silk, Wang only laughed aloud.

Later, Minister Liu was appointed Chancellor and concurrently oversaw the Salt and Iron Commission. Due to a misstep, he was demoted to Prefect of Zhongzhou. Thirty years passed. One day, stricken with illness, he was visited again by Wang the Eighteenth, who said, "I must see the Minister." Liu sighed deeply with emotion and welcomed him into his chamber. Once more, he pleaded earnestly. Wang the Eighteenth replied, "Your illness will soon pass—return the pills to me." He then dropped a tael of *ling* into water, and after Liu drank it, he vomited up three pills, their color unchanged from those he had taken thirty years before. Wang the Eighteenth asked for scented water to wash them. Liu’s nephew, who had been attending his uncle’s illness, seized two of the pills and swallowed them. Wang the Eighteenth gazed at him intently and smiled, saying, "You possess the qi of the Dao—I knew these were meant for you." He strode out and left without another word of farewell.

Minister Liu soon recovered. Months later, an imperial edict arrived, and he passed away.

Sun Deng

Sun Deng, styled Gonghe, was a native of Jiyin Commandery. He had no family and dwelt in an earthen cave in the northern mountains of the commandery. Skilled in the art of long whistling and fond of studying the *Book of Changes*, he would pluck a single-stringed zither. His nature was free of anger or ambition.

Once, he traveled to Mount Yiyang, where a charcoal-burner saw him and, recognizing him as no ordinary man, spoke to him. Sun Deng made no reply. When Emperor Wen of Jin heard of him, he dispatched Ruan Ji to observe him. After meeting, Ruan Ji spoke to him, but Sun Deng again remained silent.

Ji Kang later accompanied him for three years, asking about his aspirations, yet Sun Deng never answered. As Ji Kang prepared to take leave, he said, "Master, will you truly say nothing?" Sun Deng replied, "Do you understand fire? Fire is born with light, yet it does not use its light—does its purpose lie in using light? A man is born with talent, yet he does not use his talent—does his purpose lie in using talent? Thus, using light depends on obtaining fuel to preserve its brilliance; using talent depends on recognizing truth to preserve one’s years."

Ji Kang then asked to learn the zither, but Sun Deng refused to teach him, saying, "Your talent is vast, but your understanding is shallow—how will you escape the perils of this age?" Ji Kang departed, and Sun Deng ascended to heaven in broad daylight.

The *Book of Jin*’s biography of Ruan Ji states: Ruan Ji once encountered Sun Deng on Mount Sumen, where they discussed ancient matters and the arts of nurturing spirit and guiding *qi*. Sun Deng remained silent. Ruan Ji then let out a long whistle and withdrew. Halfway down the ridge, he heard a sound like the cry of phoenixes, echoing through the cliffs and valleys—it was Sun Deng’s whistle.

The *Comprehensive Records of Mount Nanyue* states: Sun Deng abandoned honor and rank, secluding himself to seek immortality. He endured sleeping in the open and bearing the cold, eating grasses to stave off hunger, and earnestly pursued the supreme Dao. Moved by the Red Lord, he obtained the Jade Elixir Paste and later entered Kuaiji. Thus, records say Sun Deng dwelt there, leaving his memorial tablets on Tiger Mountain.

Ji Kang

Ji Kang, styled Shuye, once followed the Daoist Sun Deng in the northern mountains to learn the zither. Sun Deng refused to teach him, saying, "You possess the talent of a fugitive—you will surely be executed in the marketplace." Ji Kang then took his leave, and Sun Deng ascended in a sudden ascent. Ji Kang traveled south and sought lodging at the home of Wang Botong of Kuaiji.

Wang Botong had built a lodge, but before three years had passed, every guest who spent the night there would die before dawn. Witnessing this ominous sign, he had long since sealed it shut. Now, as Ji Kang stayed the night within, he took up his zither after the first watch. By the second watch, he saw eight ghosts emerge from the rear of the lodge. Fearing them, he quietly recited the hexagram *Qian*—"Originating, Penetrating, Beneficial, Steadfast"—three times, then asked the ghosts: "Wang Botong built this lodge three years ago, and every guest who has stayed here has died. Was it you eight ghosts who killed them?"

The ghosts replied: "We are not murderous spirits. We were the eight brothers who served as music officials in the time of Emperor Shun, known as the *Ling Lun*. Shun, swayed by slanderous ministers, wrongfully executed us, and we were buried here. When Master Wang built this lodge, he unknowingly raised walls over our remains, crushing us beneath. Whenever someone stayed here, we would appear to warn them, but they would die of fright upon seeing us—not by our hands. Now, we beg you to tell our master to exhume our bones and rebury them elsewhere. Within half a year, he will be appointed governor of this commandery. In gratitude, we will teach you a *Guangling* melody, unmatched in all the world."

Delighted by this, Ji Kang offered his zither to the ghosts. After they played it once, he could replicate the tune perfectly. As he played deep into the night, Wang Botong, hearing the exquisite music from his residence, rose in his robe to listen. Perplexed, he questioned Ji Kang, who answered: "The ghosts who kill in this lodge—I have just seen them."

"How so?" asked Botong.

Ji Kang recounted the entire affair. The next day, Botong sent men to dig at the site, and indeed, they unearthed eight skeletons. He had coffins made and reburied them in a pure, elevated place. Later, during the reign of Emperor Wen of Jin, Botong was appointed governor as foretold, while Ji Kang became *Zhongsan Dafu*. The emperor ordered Ji Kang to face north and receive his decree, instructing palace women in music, but Ji refused. Later, swayed by slanderous ministers, the emperor had Ji executed in the marketplace. Ji embraced his zither as he died. When his coffin was opened after burial, it was empty—his body had vanished.

The *Book of Jin* states: Ji Kang, styled Shuye, was a native of *Quan* in Qiaoguo. His ancestors, originally surnamed Xi, were from Shangyu in Kuaiji but relocated to avoid enmity. Nearby stood Mount Ji, and his family settled beside it, adopting the mountain’s name as their surname. Orphaned young, Ji possessed extraordinary talent, surpassing his peers without arrogance. Standing seven *chi* and eight *cun* tall, he spoke with eloquence and carried himself with grace. Yet he cared little for his appearance, and others saw in him the bearing of a dragon or phoenix—his nature was divinely innate. Well-read and broadly learned, he married into the imperial clan of Wei and was appointed *Zhongsan Dafu*. He devoted himself to cultivating his nature, practicing dietary regimens, playing the zither, and composing poetry, finding contentment in these pursuits. He believed that the Dao of immortals was endowed by nature, not acquired through study, though through proper nourishment and guidance, one might attain the longevity of Peng Zu or Anqi Sheng. Thus, he wrote *On Nurturing Life*. He often mused that only Ruan Ji of Chenliu, Shan Tao of Henei, and their circle—Xiang Xiu, Liu Ling, Ruan Xian (Ruan Ji’s nephew), and Wang Rong—shared his aspirations. Together, they roamed the bamboo groves, becoming known to the world as the Seven Sages of the Bamboo Grove. Wang Rong once remarked that in twenty years of living with Ji in Shanyang, he had never seen him display joy or anger.

Ji often gathered herbs in the mountains and marshes, losing track of time when absorbed in his pursuits. Woodcutters and gatherers who encountered him took him for a divine being. Once, in the mountains of Jijun, he met Sun Deng and traveled with him. Sun remained silent and self-contained, offering no teachings. As Ji prepared to leave, Sun said: "Your nature is fiery, your talent sharp—how will you escape calamity?" Later, Ji encountered Wang Lie, and together they entered the mountains. Wang had once found stone marrow resembling malt sugar; he consumed half and gave the rest to Ji, but it hardened into stone. They also entered a stone chamber where Ji saw a scroll of plain silk. When he called out to Wang, the scroll vanished. Wang sighed: "Shuye’s aspirations are extraordinary, yet he meets with such misfortune—it is fate."

When Shan Tao was about to depart for an official post, he recommended Ji as his replacement. Ji wrote to sever ties with him, declaring: "I have heard that Daoist adepts say consuming the yellow essence of *huangjing* grants long life, and I believe it. Roaming mountains and marshes, observing fish and birds, brings me great joy. To take office would mean abandoning what I love for what I fear—how could I do so?"

Now I wish only to dwell in my humble lane, teaching and raising my children and grandchildren, and from time to time reuniting with old friends and kin to reminisce about our lives. A cup of unstrained wine, a tune upon the zither—my aspirations are fulfilled. This letter having been sent, you will know that I cannot be fettered or bent to another’s will.

Ji was exceptionally skilled yet fond of forging. In his courtyard stood a flourishing willow, whose trunk he hollowed with rushing water to power his bellows. Each summer, he would sit beneath it to work the hammer. Lu An of Ping束, admiring Ji’s lofty spirit, would travel a thousand *li* at the slightest longing to visit him. Ji befriended and cherished him.

Later, Lu An was wronged by his elder brother’s false accusation and dragged into litigation. When called to testify, he implicated Ji, who was then arrested as well. Though Ji was cautious in speech and conduct, once bound in prison, he composed the *"Poem of Hidden Grief"*:

*"Though the day’s cause be just,
The spirit is shamed, loyalty thwarted.
Washing oneself in the Canglang’s waters—
How can this ever make amends?"*

Earlier, when Ji lived in poverty, he and Xiang Xiu would forge together beneath a great tree to sustain themselves. Zhong Hui of Yingchuan, a nobleman’s son, was sharp-witted and eloquent, yet he deigned to visit Ji uninvited. Ji neither paid him courtesy nor ceased his hammering. After a long while, Zhong left. Ji asked: *"What did you hear to come? What did you see to go?"* Zhong replied: *"I came for what I heard, and left for what I saw."* From then on, he bore resentment toward Ji.

On this occasion, Zhong told Emperor Wen: *"Ji Kang is a sleeping dragon—best not to rouse him. Your Highness need not fear the realm, but you should be wary of Ji."* He then fabricated a claim that Ji had conspired with Gongsun Qian. The emperor thus had Ji executed.

As Ji was led to the execution ground, three thousand students of the Imperial Academy petitioned to take him as their teacher, but their plea was denied. Ji glanced at the sun’s shadow, called for a zither, and played, saying: *"Yuan Xiaohong once sought to learn the *Guangling San* from me, but I always refused him outright. Now the *Guangling San* is lost forever."* He was forty years old. Scholars across the land mourned him deeply.

The emperor soon came to his senses and regretted his decision.

Earlier, Ji had once traveled to the west of Luoyang and lodged for the night at Huayang Pavilion. He took up his zither and played, and at midnight, a visitor suddenly arrived, claiming to be an ancient man. He spoke with Ji about music and rhythm, his words refined and eloquent. Then he asked for the zither, played *Guangling San*, and its melody was unparalleled. He taught it to Ji, making him swear never to pass it on to others, nor to reveal his name.

Ji was skilled in discourse and adept at composition. He compiled biographies and eulogies of lofty recluses from antiquity onward and wrote the *Admonitions of the Grand Preceptor*. The *Jizuan Yuanhai* records: Bao Shuo, Governor of Nanhai, was a man of spiritual insight. Xu Ning of Donghai studied under him, and one night, Xu heard the sound of a zither in a quiet chamber. Marveling at its mastery, he asked about it, and Bao replied, "Ji Shuye." Xu said, "Ji was bound and executed in the marketplace—how could he be here?" Bao answered, "Though Shuye appeared to die, he truly achieved *shijie*."

Dongguo Yan
Dongguo Yan was a native of Shanyang. He consumed *Lingfei San* and could write in the dark. In a dim chamber, his body emitted light, illuminating the entire room. He could also discern small objects dozens of *li* away on level ground, perceiving their true forms and colors. Moreover, regardless of whether he knew someone or not, he could foretell their life or death with perfect accuracy. In his village, he lived for four hundred years without aging. One day, dozens of people arrived in carriages to welcome him. His neighbors all witnessed this, and he bid farewell to his kin and acquaintances before departing, saying he was bound for Kunlun Mountain.

Yue Zichang
The Perfected Lord of Qianshan was a distant ancestor of Yue Shi. According to the *Zongxian Ji*, the Perfected Lord’s name was Zichang, a native of Qi. From youth, he was devoted to the Dao. At Huolin, he encountered the immortal Han Zhong, who bestowed upon him the *Lingbao Fu* and transmitted the *Jusheng* and *Chisong San*. After consuming the elixir, Zichang lived to one hundred and eighty, his complexion like that of a young girl. His nine wives and children all took the same elixir. He ascended to immortality at Laoshan, dwelling in a chamber on Fangzhang. In the divine realm, he received the *Tai Xuan Sheng Lu* and subsisted on the Five Sacred Fungi. The Supreme Lord appointed him as Gentleman of the Gate of Cultivation, ranking just below the divine hierarchy. Emperor Xuanzong of Tang dreamed of the Twenty-Eight Immortals, who corresponded to the Twenty-Eight Constellations. Among them was the Perfected Lord, who had attained the Dao at Qianshan and was titled the Perfected Lord of Qianshan.

Feng Gang
Feng Gang was a native of Yuyang.

Feng Gang often gathered the blossoms of a hundred herbs, steeping them in water and sealing them with clay. Beginning in the first month and continuing until the end of the ninth, he buried them for a hundred days, then decocted and formed them into pills. When administered to those who had suddenly died, the medicine, placed in their mouths, revived them all instantly. Gang consumed this elixir for long years, living to several hundred without aging. Later, he entered the Mountain of Earth’s Lung and ascended as an immortal.

Zhao Zhai
Zhao Zhai, styled Zirong, was a native of Shangdang. Afflicted with leprosy and near death, someone warned Zhai’s family: "Abandon him while he yet lives, for if he dies at home, this disease will plague your descendants for generations." Thus, his kin prepared a year’s provisions and carried him deep into the mountains, placing him in a stone chamber. Fearing beasts might devour him, they barred the entrance with wooden stakes. Zirong, grieving and full of self-reproach, wept day and night. After more than a hundred days, two figures suddenly appeared before the stone chamber at night. They asked, "Who are you?" Zirong, realizing he was in a remote mountain forest where mortals seldom ventured, surmised they must be divine beings. He prostrated himself, recounting his plight and begging for mercy. The figures moved through the stakes as though through mist, unimpeded. They then asked, "If you truly wish to be cured, you must take medicine. Are you willing?" Zirong replied, "Burdened by past sins, I suffer this vile affliction and have been cast out, my death imminent. If severing my feet or slicing my nose could restore me, I would gladly endure it—how much more so for medicine? I beg you, divine ones, grant me these remaining years." The immortals bestowed upon him five *sheng* of pine resin and said, "Consume this, and not only will your illness vanish, but you shall transcend the world and attain longevity." Before Zirong finished the dose, his leprous sores healed entirely, and his body grew light and strong. Returning home, his family mistook him for a ghost until he recounted what had transpired, whereupon they rejoiced. He continued taking the medicine, and after two years, his complexion grew youthful, his skin lustrous. He could outrun birds and beasts, and though over seventy, he ate pheasants and hares, crunching their bones, and carried heavy burdens all day without fatigue. At one hundred and seventy, he suddenly saw a light outside his house at night, as large as a mirror. When he asked those around him, they saw nothing. The following nights, the light grew brighter, until after several dozen days, an entire room was illuminated, allowing him to write at night. Later, he saw two figures, about three *cun* tall, on his face—exquisite maidens who played about his nose and mouth. After another year, the maidens grew to human size, no longer appearing on his face but standing beside him. He often heard the sounds of zithers and lutes, delighting in solitary joy. Living among the people for over three hundred years, his appearance like that of a child, he finally entered Baodu Mountain and ascended as an immortal.

Wang Xuanfu
Wang Xuanfu was a native of Pei.

The people of Tonghao, Deng Boyuan, studied the Dao at Chicheng and Huo Mountains. He received the methods of consuming azure essence stone rice and swallowing the elixir of solar essence, inwardly contemplating the Grotto Chamber. After thirty-four years, he could inwardly perceive his five viscera and write in the dark of night. On the fifteenth day of the first lunar month in the first year of the Yonghe reign of Emperor Mu of Jin, the Great Emperor dispatched a feathered carriage to welcome him. Xuanfu and Deng Boyuan rode clouds and mounted dragons, ascending to heaven in broad daylight. Today, he resides in the Northern Dark Garden Terrace, where he received scriptures and was appointed as the Perfected One of the Central Marchmount.

Yin Si
Yin Si was a man of Jin. On the night of the fifteenth day of the first lunar month, he sat in his chamber and sent his son to observe whether there was anything unusual in the moon. His son said, "This year will bring floods, for I see a man in the moon wearing a straw raincoat and carrying a sword." Si went out to look and said, "It is not floods but impending military chaos, for the man in the moon wears armor and bears a spear."

Zhang Li
The Minister of Works was surnamed Zhang, named Tian, and styled Ba, a native of Fengchuan County in Guangnan, Yuqi. From youth, he studied Confucian scholarship and was esteemed by all. For his talent and ability, Emperor Ming valued him, and he rose to the position of Minister of Works.

When Emperor Donghun ascended the throne, Zhang Li sighed and said, "Glory must give way to disgrace—this will harm my spirit." He then submitted a memorial to resign and retired to the south. He vowed to seek the methods of long life and enduring vision, wishing to choose a place to cultivate truth and nurture his nature. The emperor refused his resignation, but after repeated petitions, he was permitted to leave. The civil and military officials saw the Minister of Works off at the eastern gate. After several weeks, he arrived at Wenqing Post in You County, where he encountered continuous rain for over a month. Suddenly, the sky cleared, and as he stepped into the post courtyard and looked around, he caught sight of a mountain to the east of the town—its peak towering above the rest, uniquely elegant and rare, the likes of which he had seldom seen. Filled with admiration, he summoned the post official and asked about it, but the man replied, "This humble one does not know." He then called for Mao Guohua, an elder of the market, who said, "According to ancient tradition, it is called Wenshui Mountain, also known as Zilin Mountain." The Minister of Works, hearing this, found it extraordinary.

The next day, he arrived at the foot of the mountain and said to the villagers, "From the town, I saw auspicious clouds veiling its summit and purple qi congealing in the sky. There must be immortals hidden within this mountain—this is precisely what I have longed for in my life." He then entered the Wenshui source beneath the Fangguang Peak, where he built over thirty thatched huts and settled there. His entire family observed abstinence, reciting the *Thirty-Nine Chapters of the Great Cavern Scripture*. By day, he worked with the villagers to channel water and irrigate fields, upholding the Three Hundred Great Precepts. After nearly twenty years, one day, he saw a divine person holding a flowered staff emerge from the mountain and say to him, "I am the disciple of Ge Hong. By the command of the Supreme Emperor, I am to transmit to you the secrets of the golden elixir and the fire cauldron. You must keep them hidden and practice them in secret, using them to relieve the poor and suffering. When your merit is complete, we shall meet again without delay." As he left, the divine person spoke again: "I often gather with the nine immortal companions—Fuqiu, Hongya, Chisongzi, Wang Qiao, Su Dan, Ding Lingwei, Su Yin, and Yan Zhen—on the Immortals’ Summit (now called Huixian Peak), where we play the qin, chess, and enjoy wine and fruit, delighting in perfect harmony. Our comings and goings are not fixed, beyond the knowledge of the mundane world. The great medicine of the golden elixir can transcend the world and become a divine immortal. You have received it—do not lightly disclose it." The Minister of Works, having received the teaching, bowed in gratitude. Suddenly, the divine person vanished, and no one knew where he had gone.

From then on, the Minister of Works diligently practiced abstinence. Later, he perfected the work of the fire cauldron, transmuting tiles and stones into gold, which he secretly used to aid the poor, elderly, and sick. In the second year of the Tianjian era of Emperor Wu of Liang, on the fourteenth night of the eighth month, he suddenly heard a divine voice calling his name from the sky: "At dawn, lead your family into the mountain, but leave your daughter Lu Qiong at home." Between the hours of *chen* and *si*, a maidservant saw a Daoist descend from the sky, his body covered in scabs and sores. He asked, "Is the Minister of Works here?" She replied, "The Minister of Works entered the mountain early this morning and has not yet returned." The Daoist then asked, "Where is the wine cellar?" The maidservant pointed it out, and the Daoist removed his robe, entered a vat in the cellar, and bathed his afflicted body in the wine. When he emerged, he dressed properly and left. At the gate, he said to the maidservant, "When the Minister of Works returns, tell him that Daoist Ge came especially to visit him." The Minister of Works, upon hearing this, rejoiced. Detecting an extraordinary fragrance in the cellar’s wine, he ordered his servants to set up mats in the hall, and all in the household, high and low, drank the fragrant wine from the cellar until it was exhausted. Only the maidservant who had seen the Daoist bathing his sores feigned illness and did not drink.

After the feast, the Minister of Works ordered his servants to prepare hot water so he could bathe and change his clothes before sitting down. He then summoned the village elders and his disciples. He entered the mountain again, lit incense, and ascended the altar, saying to the elders and disciples, "Heaven is summoning me—I do not despise the world." As he finished speaking, phoenixes and cranes danced in the sky, and auspicious clouds gathered above the altar. His entire household of over eighty people ascended lightly into the daylight, leaving only the maidservant, who fell from the clouds midair. The Minister of Works sighed and said, "You lack the destiny for immortality—stay in the mortal world for now. When I see the Supreme Emperor, I will petition on your behalf." On the eighteenth day, the emperor ordered the Dark Warrior deity to descend and guard the mountain’s borders, appointing the maidservant as the local earth deity to protect the mountain altar.

On that day, the village elders and disciples, including Chen Ang, submitted a report to the county, which forwarded it to the prefecture. The facts were recorded in detail and memorialized to the throne, and the edict was issued to the relevant offices. From then on, the mountain was called Sikong Mountain. In the early years of the Yongjia era of Emperor Wen of Chen, two masters, Zhang and Ma of Danyang, whose full names were unknown, arrived at the mountain and said to the villagers, "We are disciples of Minister Zhang Sikong and have come especially to find his dwelling." The villagers replied, "The Minister ascended to heaven with his household on the fifteenth day of the eighth month in the second year of the Tianjian era of Emperor Wu of Liang. Only his abandoned residence remains, and no one dares to live there." The two masters, overjoyed upon hearing this, entered the mountain to fast and cultivate the Dao. One day, their work complete, an extraordinary fragrance filled the mountain.

Woodcutters who heard this perceived no omen, yet they heard the clear resonance of strings and flutes echoing through the distant sky. Raising their eyes, they saw the two masters each riding a propitious cloud and a white crane, ascending into the heavens. Today, the two peaks are named White Cloud and White Crane.

On the night of the twelfth day of the fifth month in the seventh year of the Tianbao era of the Tang, the August Emperor dreamed of the immortal altar on Sikong Mountain and ordered a shrine hall to be established there. Daoist practitioners of virtuous conduct were selected to reside and maintain the rites of incense and cultivation, and the temple was bestowed the name Zhuyang Abbey. In the seventh month of the third year of the Zhenghe era of the Song, the name was changed to Yangsheng, and Master Zhang was canonized as the Perfected One of Grand Simplicity. In the eighth month of the same year, he was further canonized as the Perfected One of Ascension.

Wang Zhongfu
Wang Zhongfu’s origins are unknown. From a young age, he was inclined toward spiritual matters and practiced the method of absorbing the dual luminaries and ingesting the rosy clouds. After more than forty years, he perceived no benefit. His son, who also practiced this method, ascended to heaven in broad daylight after eighteen years. Later, the Perfected One of Southern Marchmount suddenly descended before Zhongfu and instructed him, saying, "The reason you have not attained transcendence is that your body suffers from a grave affliction: your cranial palace is deficient, your sinews and fluids fail to flow, and your numinous essence is red and overflowing. Though you have absorbed the luminaries and ingested the rosy clouds, it has not benefited your body." Zhongfu then followed the instruction, taking medicine to treat his illness while continuing his practice. After another eighteen years, he ascended to heaven in broad daylight and now resides in the Dark Realm, where he has received scriptures and been appointed the Perfected One of the Central Marchmount.

Master Wang
Master Wang’s origins are unknown.

There was one Yang Huizhi, who had long traveled from An in the east through Wu and Chu, and upon reaching Wujiang, heard that Master Wang possessed profound mastery of the Dao. He thus presented himself at the master’s gate. The master, clad in a dark cap and hempen robe, sat leaning against a low table, his bearing refined and elegant. Huizhi bowed twice with full courtesy, and the master returned his greeting with folded hands at his side. Their discourse soared and flowed freely, and unnoticed, the day drew to evening—it was the twelfth day of the eighth month.

The master summoned his daughter, saying, “Sev’nth Maiden.” There appeared an old woman, over seventy years of age, her teeth and hair entirely withered, who shuffled forward leaning on a staff. The master said to Huizhi, “This is my daughter. Lazy and disinclined toward the Dao, she has now grown old.” Then, turning to Sev’nth Maiden, he instructed, “For me, cut paper to fashion the moon of this evening, and place it upon the eastern wall of the chamber.” Soon after, Sev’nth Maiden did as she was told. Presently, a wondrous radiance blazed forth, illuminating every fine detail within the room.

Master and guest conversed within, the cold so piercing it seemed they stood halfway to heaven. As dawn approached and they prepared to part, the master traced a line upon the courtyard with his staff. Dust swirled, obscuring all sight, and when they looked again at their surroundings, they beheld towering cliffs and ravines ten thousand *ren* deep, forests soaring to the sky, and before them, a vast expanse of water stretching beyond the horizon. Huizhi and the master stood at the water’s edge, trembling in awe and astonishment. Huizhi exclaimed, “What we have witnessed this night—is this not a single evening in the realm of immortals, a thousand years in the world of men?”

The master smiled and said, “I meant it only as amusement.” With a shake of his robe and a wave of his hand, in an instant, the courtyard returned to its former state. Huizhi fled in haste, not daring to glance back.

Lord Zhao.

Lord Zhao, Zuo Ci, and others could command water through qi, causing it to flow backward for one or two *zhang*. They once kindled a fire beneath a thatched hut to cook, yet the food was done while the hut remained unburnt. Taking a large nail, they drove it seven or eight *cun* into a pillar, then blew upon it with qi—the nail leapt forth as if shot. They boiled water to a hundred bubbling ferocities, cast in a hundred-odd coins, and bade men pluck them one by one from the scalding broth, their hands unscathed and unblistered. They could restrain water in the central courtyard, leaving it exposed to the open air, yet even in bitter cold it would not freeze. They could also bind the qi of an entire *li*, rendering the scorched impervious to heat.

*Comprehensive Mirror of Perfected Immortals Who Embodied the Dao, Scroll Thirty-Four (conclusion)*
*Comprehensive Mirror of Perfected Immortals Who Embodied the Dao, Scroll Thirty-Five*

Wang Lübing.
Wang Lübing had not originally grasped the great Dao, nor did he know the method of refining the great elixir. He chanced upon the *Precious Scriptures of Supreme Purity* and the *Billion-Morning Ritual Vows of the Perfected One of Grand Simplicity*, and thereafter, on the appointed evenings of each month, would enter a quiet chamber to burn incense, face north, and practice his devotions. After thirty years of secret cultivation, he attained the power to ride clouds and mount cranes, ascending to the Dark Continent. His disciples—Li Zhongzi, Zhao Shuangcheng, Fan Shu, Guan Ping’a, Li Shunxian, and Yan Ansheng—all mastered this Dao, diligently persevering without falter, and likewise became perfected immortals. Some dwelt on the Dark Continent, others ascended the slopes of Kunlun, or mounted the palaces of the Three Primes.

Cen Daoyuan.
Cen Daoyuan was a native of Jiangling. The region around Wanzhou abounded in great mountains. South of the Hong River, the forests and ravines were especially deep and secluded, where a cavern yawned, vast and resonant. At the end of the Sui dynasty, the master fled turmoil, journeying through the Three Gorges until he arrived here. Enamored of the place, he took refuge beneath the cavern. He subsisted on Solomon’s seal, and though he lived over a hundred years, his skin remained like ice and snow, his bearing serene, never betraying joy or anger. After twenty years, he departed, leaving no trace. In the tenth year of the Zhenguan era, a Jiang merchant traveling to Guangling was returning home when he spied an old man of majestic and sagely mien, his appearance most extraordinary.
