The merchant prostrated himself and offered fragrant tea. The merchant departed, and the master vanished from the cavern. Upon the merchant’s return, his wife was aboard the boat when they reached the lake shoals—suddenly, waves roared like thunder, unstoppable.

The merchant, startled and awakened, hastened back to the cavern, where the lingering fragrance remained—but the master had already set sail upon the calm waters, leaving no trace behind.

During the Zhenyuan era of Emperor Dezong, the Investigating Censor Duan Wenchang remarked: "The master was a transcendent of the boundless kalpa—why then did he trouble himself to dazzle the eyes and ears of mortals with wonders? Upon examining his deeds, one must conclude that the floating world is deaf and blind, oblivious to the supreme Dao, and thus he sought to stir their awakening through marvels."

In the tenth year of the Xining era of Emperor Shenzong of the Song, the prefecture’s prayers for rain were immediately answered. The prefect reported this to the court, and an imperial edict was issued, bestowing upon the master the title *True Person of Empty Mirror*.

Wang Yuan and Wang Shun gathered herbs on Mount Zhongnan when they encountered a Daoist. Today, Mount Zhongnan bears the name *Wang Shun Peak*, its numinous efficacy resplendent and unceasing to this day.

Ji Liuxin
In Jiaodong, there lived an extraordinary figure whose name is unknown. He would sing and dance in the marketplace, calling himself *Ji Liuxin*. Later, in broad daylight amidst the market crowd, he ascended upon clouds and departed.

Wang Jia
Wang Jia dwelled in the mountains of the Eastern Sea, where he sought out the immortal Huwu Qiu Lijun. From him, he received the *Defense of the Supreme Ultimate’s First Kalpa*, and by ingesting *crimson herbs* and *divine mushrooms*, he attained transcendence. The mountain lies in the sea—though it appears close, none can reach it. Upon its slopes grow *tree mushrooms*, *numinous woods*, and *divine herbs*; azure *spirit dragons* and *tortoises* dwell there, along with the rare treasures of heaven and earth, whose names cannot be spoken. Within its caverns lie texts such as the *He Luo* and the *Yuanming Calendar*.

Wang Shuming
Wang Shuming’s origins are unknown.

In his youth, he was fond of the Dao and dwelled north of Huayang Mountain, where he cultivated the Way alongside Bao Yuanzhi, sharing the same aspiration. It is unknown which immortal they encountered or what method of defense they practiced, but both attained transcendence and departed.

Tang Ruoshan
Tang Ruoshan was a native of Lu Commandery. During the *Xiantian* era of Emperor Ruizong of Tang, he served as a gentleman in the Ministry of Works and successively governed several demanding prefectures. In the *Kaiyuan* era of Emperor Xuanzong, he was appointed governor of Runzhou, where his benevolent governance earned him widespread praise near and far.

Ruoshan had long been devoted to the Dao of longevity. His younger brother, Ruoshui, was a Daoist priest at Mount Heng, having mastered the essentials of the *Womb-Origin* and *Valley Spirit*. Ruoshui was often summoned to the inner palace, where he earnestly requested to return to the mountains; the emperor granted his plea.

Ruoshan had always been fond of esoteric arts. Wherever he went, he would gather alchemists and their crucibles. Even those whose techniques were of little use were treated with courtesy and respect. His family wealth was nearly exhausted, and though his official salary never left surplus, the expenses on minerals and elixirs knew no bounds. In his later years, his resolve grew even firmer. Using the treasury funds of Runzhou to purchase ingredients, his subordinates, kin, and advisors repeatedly admonished him, but Ruoshan paid no heed.

One day, an elderly man—frail, emaciated, and with a withered countenance—arrived at his gate and requested an audience, claiming to possess the Dao of longevity. Those who saw him laughed at his decrepitude, but Ruoshan received him with utmost reverence and hospitality, keeping him for over a month. Yet all the old man discussed strayed from the principles of alchemy.

Ruoshan had extensively studied myriad formulas, songs, chants, diagrams, and records, examining them all with care. When he inquired about the old man’s strengths, he found them utterly insignificant. Moreover, the old man relished rich foods and fine wine, consuming as much as three or four men despite his frail appearance. Ruoshan served him with unwavering devotion, never showing weariness.

One day, the old man spoke leisurely to Ruoshan: "Your household of a hundred mouths is perpetually in want. Though you hold high office, your resources remain insufficient. Should you one day retire, how will you provide for them? You have misappropriated treasury funds and silks—this is truly a cause for concern."

Ruoshan replied in alarm: "I, too, have long worried about this impending transfer of office, yet I see no solution. If I am punished for this, I shall accept it willingly—my only fear is that my family will suffer hunger and cold."

The old man said: "Do not worry excessively." He urged more wine, and they drank for days. Ruoshan was not a heavy drinker, yet that day he consumed three or four cups without feeling intoxicated, which struck him as strange.

As night fell and the moon shone brightly, they set aside their cups and strolled in the courtyard. After a long while, the old man said to Ruoshan: "Have a servant bring a dozen or so iron pots, cauldrons, and utensils to the alchemical chamber. Let him arrange charcoal, build a furnace, and prepare the mortar, crucible, and tongs into a single pile. Ignite the charcoal until it blazes like a kiln, too fierce to approach."

The old man then untied a small gourd from his belt, took out two cinnabar pills, and cast them into the fire. He closed the door and stepped out, saying to Ruoshan: "You possess the bones of a Daoist and are destined for transcendence. Moreover, your conduct is upright and sincere, free from anger or resentment—such virtues are especially prized by immortals. I am a Perfected One of the Supreme Clarity, roaming the mortal realm to deliver those of earnest heart. Moved by your diligence, I have come to deliver you.

The gold and silver I transmute shall serve two purposes: one, to bequeath to your descendants and aid the poor; the other, to repay the treasury, sparing you future troubles. You should now prepare a boat to travel the river and plan your departure. Tomorrow, await me in midstream."

With that, he vanished.

At dawn, Ruoshan opened the chamber to find the transmuted treasures gleaming brilliantly, illuminating the room. He sealed them again and, with three or five of his officials and guests, set sail upon the river. As they neared Gold Mountain Temple and reached midstream, a dense fog obscured the waters, rendering even nearby objects indistinct. Ruoshan alone saw the old man rowing a fishing boat, which drew alongside their vessel. He beckoned, and Ruoshan stepped into the fishing boat, ascending beyond the mortal realm.

After some time, the wind and waves calmed, and the fog lifted. Ruoshan was gone.

Among the documents left in his office, a letter of farewell was found, instructing his family affairs. Another was a memorial to the throne, its main points as follows:

"Worldly emoluments are fleeting, and floating life is precarious. Only by ascending to the realm of the Perfected and shedding the mortal coil can one set a course for the hereafter. Of old, Minister Fan sailed away to the Five Lakes, knowing his lord could not share his joy; Zhang, Marquis of Liu, followed Master Red Pine, fearing his life could not long endure. Though their aspirations differed from mine, I, favored by an enlightened age and repeatedly honored with rank, early grasped the principle of rise and fall and deeply understood the rule of knowing when to stop.

My heart has long dwelled at the Mystic Pass, and by chance, I obtained the alchemical formula. That gold can be made confirms the ancient words of Huainan; that the white sun can be prolonged reveals the wondrous workings of the true scriptures. Having attained this, what more could I seek? Thus, I wave farewell to the red dust and soar my spirit over the azure sea. Penglai is not far, and Fusang lies in sight. Gazing afar at the imperial court, I am overwhelmed by the depth of my devotion, like a dog or horse to its master."

When Emperor Xuanzong read the memorial, he was astonished and promptly ordered that Ruoshan’s family be generously provided for. He also summoned Tang Ruoshui and dispatched him with an imperial envoy to search the rivers and coasts, but no trace was found.

Twenty years later, an old acquaintance of Ruoshan, serving as an emissary from Zhexi to Huainan, encountered him at a fish market in the city, where he was purchasing fish like an ordinary man. Ruoshan glanced at the emissary and invited him into a humble alley. After winding through several hundred paces, they arrived at a magnificent residence. The emissary was served a meal, and when Ruoshan learned of his long-standing poverty, he purchased twenty ingots of iron for him. The next day, they met again, and the iron had turned to gold, which Ruoshan gave to him entirely. The emissary, surnamed Liu, later settled in Jinling, and his descendants have included those who cultivate the Dao.

*The Comprehensive Record of the Perfected of Mount Heng* states that his brother Ruoshui achieved *corpse liberation* at Mount Heng.

Wang Xiang
The gentleman Wang, whose given name was Xiang, was a native of Duling. From birth, he possessed extraordinary integrity. Gazing for long at the lofty peaks of Mount Zhongnan, he said to his parents: "When I grow up, I shall dwell upon this mountain to seek liberation from the world."

The villagers marveled at him. He broadly studied the ancient classics and could recite whatever he read at a glance. Having come of age, he and his fellow villager Zheng Shuang pursued literary studies and sat for the imperial examinations, yet failed to pass after two years. Retiring to Stone Gate Valley in the Southern Mountains, he devoted himself to sitting in forgetfulness and returning illumination. Over the years, the transcendent Master Meng descended to transmit to him the Dao of the Three Ones and Five Thousands, enabling him to transform, take flight, and divide his form to scatter his shadow.

At the end of the *Kaiyuan* era of Tang Emperor Minghuang, his friend Zheng Shuang, then serving as a censor, was dispatched on a mission to Yangzhou. Upon arrival, he saw Wang Xiang lying in a tower in tattered clothes, standing to one side of the road. Zheng, moved with pity, sent someone to summon him to the postal station and inquired about his travels and rest. Wang replied that his sojourn had left him destitute and emaciated. The next day, he returned and said to Zheng: "You cherish the affection of an old friend—could you change into plain clothes and condescend to visit my humble abode?" Zheng agreed. Changing his attire, he followed Wang in secret, passing through gates and entering a narrow lane as if by an overgrown path, where scarcely a human footprint could be seen. After several *li* through thickets of brambles and dense undergrowth, they reached his dwelling. At the gate, Wang asked to enter first to prepare the seating. After some time, he sent an attendant to lead Zheng inside. As Zheng advanced, he beheld golden towers and jeweled terraces, vermilion eaves and jade-green halls—sights not of the mortal world. Wang wore a rosy cloud crown and cloud-embroidered robes, his feathered guards arrayed in solemn grandeur, his bearing that of a king. Zheng trembled with awe and dared not lift his gaze. Wang detained him for a feast lasting the night, with rare delicacies and immortal music beyond description.

At dawn, Wang saw him to the gate and said: "Though you have achieved fame and success, your strength remains meager and your circumstances straitened." He ordered his woodcutter attendants to carry a tattered canopy and escort Zheng back to the postal station, then instructed him to pawn the canopy at the market for a million coins as a gift. After this, Wang vanished without a trace. Zheng returned to search, but no vestige of the former place remained.

Upon returning to the capital, Zheng submitted a confidential memorial detailing all that had transpired. At the time, Emperor Minghuang was deeply devoted to the pursuit of immortals and the Dao, and had also commanded the military governor of Huaihai to seek out and inquire after Wang—but to no avail. During their conversation, Wang had told Zheng that he had already become an immortal of the Great One.

Lu Zifang
Master Void-Unbound, whose surname was Lu and given name Zifang, practiced cultivation with his father during the Kaiyuan era of Emperor Xuanzong of Tang at the Jade Bamboo Abbey of Primordial Purity. His father achieved liberation through the corpse, leaving behind an empty coffin buried beside the abbey. In time, Master Void-Unbound also perfected his practice, ascending in an airborne vessel from the tip of a cedar outside the abbey gates, vanishing into the heavens.

Wang Yu
The Perfected of Lesser Cavern, Wang Jun, whose personal name was Xia, had once committed an offense and was banished to the mortal realm for five years, during which he was to serve as a chamber attendant. Zhang Maoshi of Nanyang, whose family resided at the foot of Mount Hua, happened to travel to Luoyang during the Dali era of Emperor Daizong of Tang. There, he hired a servant in the southern market and thus obtained Xia. Though Xia appeared to be over forty, he was diligent, capable, and selfless, acting always with utmost sincerity. Whatever task could be done, he performed without needing to be instructed.

Tea Master admired him greatly and changed his name to Dabao. When he sought to reward him generously, Dabao declined. His household only cherished him all the more. After five years, one day Dabao took leave of Maoshi, saying: "Originally, my home was in the mountains, and our family estate was not meager. Yet fate cast me into misfortune, requiring me to serve as an attendant to dispel it. Now my term is complete, and I must take my leave." Maoshi, unable to fathom his words, did not detain him, allowing him to depart that very evening. As dusk fell, Dabao entered to address Maoshi: "I am deeply grateful for your kindness and wish to repay it in some way. My home lies not far from here, and its scenery is worth seeing. Might you accompany me for a visit?" Maoshi replied, "Very well."

Thereupon, Dabao cut a bamboo stalk several feet long, inscribed a talisman upon it, and handed it to Maoshi, saying: "Take this staff and enter the chamber, feigning stomach pain. Send all attendants away to fetch medicine. Once they are gone, secretly place the staff in the quilt, then slip out." Maoshi followed his instructions. Dabao then said: "You may now visit my dwelling." Together they traveled south for over a mile, where a yellow-capped attendant wielding a whip herded a green unicorn and two vermilion-striped tigers, awaiting them by the roadside. Maoshi hesitated, but Dabao said: "Have no fear, proceed forward." Upon arrival, Dabao mounted the unicorn, instructing Maoshi and the yellow-capped attendant each to ride a tiger. Maoshi, trembling with fear, dared not advance. Dabao said: "Since you trust me, why fear now? These creatures are the swiftest in the mortal realm—simply try riding one." Maoshi then mounted, finding it remarkably steady.

Thus, the servant led Maoshi, ascending and traversing peaks and valleys as if by mere thought, the perilous heights unnoticed. By the third watch, they had traveled several hundred *li*. Descending a mountain, they beheld a realm of radiant beauty, where pines and rocks were lovely beyond compare, and towers, palaces, and abbeys appeared unlike anything seen in the mortal world. As they approached the gate, Dabao flicked his whip and called: "The young master arrives." Hundreds of purple-robed officials lined the path, and gradually, dozens of maidservants in azure attire—each of extraordinary beauty and clad in resplendent, indescribable garments—approached, bearing musical instruments to lead the way. They entered the central hall, where a feast was laid. Dabao bade Maoshi sit, then withdrew, changing into ceremonial robes before returning to his seat. His attire, crown, and bearing were majestic, truly befitting an immortal.

The windows, steps, railings, screens, couches, and cushions—all were of a splendor unknown in the mortal realm. Music of phoenixes and luan birds, along with melodies of every kind, filled the air, unheard of before. Maoshi’s spirit soared, his thoughts no longer dwelling on worldly affairs. At the height of their joy, Dabao said: "This is an immortal’s abode, not a place mortals may reach. Your past karma destined you to witness this, granting you this fleeting respite. The path of immortals diverges from the mortal dust; worldly and pure cannot mingle. You should return and cultivate your mind for three or five kalpas, and we shall meet again. My mortal term is nearly complete, and my name is recorded in the upper realms. I have been summoned by the Perfected of Grand Clarity to the Grotto of Lesser Cavern, where I beheld the joys of the Nine Heavens. I was also shown the Sea of Birth and Death, and told: 'Joy is not hard to seek, nor is suffering hard to cast off—like one who builds a mountain, adding earth handful by handful.' Since then, I have cultivated through five or six kalpas, attaining this form. Looking back upon my discarded remains, they have piled like mountains. With each thought, I refined my mind, and in an instant, an age passed. Though my form has changed, this heart remains unchanged. By diligently cultivating its power, the goal is not far off. Some, when their minds are enlightened and their *qi* purified, awaken with a single word—strive on."

Dabao presented a hundred *yi* of gold to aid Maoshi’s cultivation. He then ordered the yellow-capped attendant to accompany Maoshi back to the place where they had mounted the unicorn. Again, the attendant guided him, and Dabao walked Maoshi to his home, where his family was gathered in tears. Maoshi cast the gold into a well. Dabao withdrew the bamboo staff, instructing Maoshi to secretly lie within the quilt. Dabao said: "I must now ascend to Penglai to pay respects to the Great Immortal Elder. Tomorrow morning, atop Lotus Peak, a cloud of radiant hues will gather—I shall ride it." With that, he bowed and departed.

Maoshi suddenly groaned, startling those around him. When asked, he deceived them, saying: "At first my stomach ached, then it seemed someone summoned me—suddenly, it was like this. I know not how much time has passed." His family said: "When we fetched medicine, we called to you but received no answer. Seven days have already passed. Only because your heart remained warm did we not yet prepare you for burial."

The next morning, atop Lotus Peak, a cloud of radiant hues indeed gathered and departed. Thereafter, Maoshi traveled among the famous mountains. Later, none knew where Dabao had gone, and so they named him the Unicorn Guest.

Wang the Fourth

Wang the Fourth, styled as a recluse, was the fourth son of Wang Shān, a magistrate of Luoyang. In his youth, he followed his mother to another household, and afterward, whenever he returned, the Shān family no longer acknowledged him. During the *Yuanhe* era of Emperor Xianzong of Tang, Shān was often transferred from Zheng Prefecture to the capital. Passing through the great ferry at Dongdu’s Jin Bridge, the Fourth knelt before his horse. Clad in coarse cloth and straw sandals, his appearance was that of a rustic. Shān did not recognize him. When he gave his name, Shān took pity on him.

The Fourth then said: "Uncle, now that you are bound for the imperial selection, your nephew has a small gift to offer." From within his robe, he produced five *liang* of gold, its hue like a parrot’s crest, and said: "This cannot be compared to ordinary gold. In the capital, seek out Zhang Pengzi at the gold market and give it to him—he will provide two hundred thousand *qian* in return." Shān was astonished and immediately asked: "Where have you been all this time, and where are you going now?"

He replied: "Lately, I have dwelt in the lesser grotto-heaven of Wangwu. Now I am returning to my home on Mount Emei. Knowing you would pass here, I came to pay my respects." Shān asked: "Where are you staying?" He answered: "At the Xi family’s inn by the central bridge." Shān said: "I will come to see you." The Fourth replied: "My journey has its appointed time; I fear I cannot await your visit."

Shān returned home, changed his clothes, and hurried to the inn, but the Fourth had already departed. Inquiring of the Xi family, they said: "He had four or five wives, all of exceptional beauty. When he stayed here, his saddles and horses were extraordinarily lavish. The recluse Wang carried his own sedan chair and left ahead, bound for Jiannan." Shān privately marveled but did not yet place great trust in him.

Upon reaching the capital, he instructed his servant Jier: "Take the gold left by the Fourth and seek out Zhang Pengzi in the market." Sure enough, they found him. When Jier showed him the gold, Pengzi exclaimed in surprise and delight: "Where did you obtain this? How much do you require?" Jier said: "Two hundred thousand *qian*." Pengzi then gave him the sum as before, saying: "If you need more, you may return again." Jier took the money and returned. Shān was greatly astonished.

The next day, he personally visited Pengzi, who said: "This is alchemical gold sold by the Daoist Wang the Fourth. Western merchants from the Hu lands specialize in purchasing it, and there is no fixed price. It depends only on how much the Fourth originally agreed upon—beyond that, it cannot be sold." Shān then took no more. Thereafter, though he made inquiries, he never saw the Fourth again.

Ye Qianxiao

Ye Qianxiao, styled Lucong, was a native of Jianchang in Hongzhou.

In his youth, Qianxiao served under a Daoist master on West Mountain, studying the arts of the Twelve Perfected Lords—abstaining from grains and absorbing *qi*. Once, while dwelling alone, a sudden storm arose with fierce wind, rain, thunder, and lightning. A man in white robes appeared, bowing to Qianxiao and saying: "Your virtue and power have reached perfection, and the celestial registers have honored you with promotion. You are destined to command ghosts and spirits among men, achieving even greater merits. Now, divine beings shall descend to you—you may meet them without fear." Thereupon, Qianxiao burned incense, clasped his hands in silence, and sat in meditation. Soon, from the clouds descended a vermilion-robed Perfected Official on a distant journey, accompanied by over ten divine generals, all bearing swords and tiger-and-dragon talismans. Their retinue of ghosts and spirits was vast, with yellow-robed and green-robed clerks each holding a scroll. The generals arrayed themselves and bowed to Qianxiao. The Perfected Official addressed him: "Heaven commands that these scrolls of divine generals, clerks, and soldiers be entrusted to you. May you employ them diligently to save the people of the world." Qianxiao bowed, received the celestial writ, and reverently unrolled the scrolls—like mortal military registers. The clerks managed the records, and when summoned, the spirits answered without delay.

Thereafter, when Qianxiao let out a long whistle, winds stirred through the valleys; when he sighed at the waters, rains flowed across the plains; when he scraped his foot against the earth, thunder rumbled in deep tones; when he traced his hand through the air, lightning flashed brilliantly. He wandered the world, often feigning madness, drunk and arrogant in the streets. Yet when he suddenly roared and brandished his power, those who asked would learn: "I saw a fire in such-and-such a place, or a drought in another—I summoned rain to save them." When verified, it proved true. Passing through prefectures and counties during droughts, people would beg Qianxiao to pray for rain. He would prepare an incense table, offer prayers, and in an instant, rain would fall. When asked to summon thunder, he would scrape his foot, and a crackling sound would erupt from the earth. If excessive rain caused suffering and his prayers went unanswered, he would stand and halt the rain. In winter droughts, when snow was sought, Qianxiao would don a single robe, bare his feet, and stand in the sun, whistling and chanting. Soon, winds and clouds would gather, and snow would fall through the night.

He also used talismans to relieve people’s suffering, not waiting for their pleas. Seeing the afflicted, he pitied and healed them without exception. Those with malevolent illnesses would recover merely upon hearing his name, and those who received his talismans would never suffer the same ailment again. In the eleventh year of Xiantong during the reign of Emperor Yizong of Tang, Qianxiao traveled to Haozhou, where he learned that the prefect, Liu Fang, had suddenly been struck by wind-stroke and lay at death’s door, beyond the help of renowned physicians. Qianxiao entered the prefecture with his staff and declared: "By my arrival, the governor shall be revived." He inscribed three talismans and affixed them to Fang’s shoulder, flank, and leg, saying: "Drive the wind out through the feet—you will recover in three days." The wind then whistled from the soles of Fang’s feet, and after three days, he was restored to health.

Fang, a man of broad learning and long devoted to the Dao, had governed with benevolence throughout his career. He said to his guests and officials: "I have always followed the Way, yet was suddenly stricken by this violent wind. Now, an extraordinary man has come to save me. Like Dong Feng restoring Du Xie’s soul, I have found my companion—truly, this is the reward of Daoist power." The people of the prefecture revered Qianxiao, and Fang welcomed him to the prefectural hall, treating him as a master and offering rich gifts of gold and silk in gratitude. Yet Qianxiao abruptly left Fang and departed, vanishing without a trace. Later, someone encountered him in the region of Jing and Xiang, where he spoke of the Haozhou affair and laughed. Over a decade afterward, he secluded himself on West Mountain, though some still claimed to have seen him.

Wang Can

Wang Can (some texts record the surname as Xu) served as magistrate of Wangwu during the thirteenth year of Xiantong in the renchen year of Emperor Yizong’s reign. He once recited the *Huangting Jing* six thousand times, desiring to annotate it himself but finding its profound meanings elusive. After resigning his post, he dwelled at the foot of the mountain, abstaining from grains and swallowing *qi*. He entered a cave and traveled twenty or thirty *li* until suddenly the path opened into a vast expanse. Towering cliffs rose ten thousand *ren* high, and within a grotto stood stone tables and chairs, arranged as if inhabited. On the table lay an ancient scroll of scripture. Not daring to take it, he bowed twice and said: "Your servant, aspiring to longevity, has trespassed into this grotto heaven—what a rare encounter across ten thousand kalpas! Now, beholding this jade table and mysterious scripture, I humbly beg the Perfected Immortal to permit this mortal’s eyes a glimpse."

After a long while, a figure suddenly appeared beside the table and said: "You have come with great diligence. I am Wang Taixu, the Perfected Lord of the Boundless Void, sharing your surname. I have completed my annotations on the *Huangting Jing* and shall now bestow them upon you." He also gave Can a peach pit, large as a vessel holding several *dou*. "This peach grows in the Fusang Grove of the Radiant Emperor. Those who eat it ascend in broad daylight. Grind and consume this pit—it will not only cure illness but also prolong life. You may not remain here; our next meeting shall be in twenty years." With these words, he vanished. Can carried the pit and the scripture back, consumed the pit, and recited the text. His appearance grew ever more youthful.

The *Huangting Jing* annotated by the Perfected Lord of the Eastern Extremity exists in the world.

Li Jue

Li Jue was a native of Jiangyang in Guangling.

Li Jue was born into a family that had long resided in the city, trading in salt as their livelihood. Yet his nature was singularly upright and cautious, setting him apart from his peers. At fifteen, he followed his father in the salt trade. When his father grew old, Li Jue took over the business. Whenever someone came to purchase salt, he would hand them a measuring scoop and let them measure it themselves, charging only two *wen* of profit per *sheng*, regardless of whether the price was high or low, all to support his parents. As the years passed, his clothing and possessions grew abundant. His father, finding this strange, questioned him, and Li Jue truthfully explained. His father said, "Among those who share our trade, none do not manipulate their measures—giving less when selling and taking more when buying—to seek greater profit. Though officials conduct biannual inspections, they cannot eradicate this practice. I realized this long ago, yet even I use the same measure for both buying and selling, believing it to be impartial. But you now leave the measuring entirely to the customers—something I cannot match. That our family enjoys such abundance must surely be the aid of divine spirits."

After his parents passed away, Li Jue, even at over eighty years of age, did not alter his trade. During the Tang Dynasty, when another Li Jue became Chancellor and took command of Huainan, the elder Li Jue, sharing the same name as the new governor, avoided him by changing his name to Kuan.

After the Chancellor Li Jue assumed office, he began cultivating the Dao several months later. One night during his fast, he dreamed he entered a grotto palace, where the scenery was that of spring—mist and blossoms in riotous bloom, phoenixes soaring and cranes dancing amid clouds of auspicious hues, with pavilions stretching endlessly. Li Jue wandered alone beneath them when he saw a gleaming stone wall inscribed with golden characters listing people’s names. Among them was "Li Jue," the characters over two *chi* in length. Overjoyed, he thought to himself, "Born in an enlightened age, I have long held high office and risen to the rank of Chancellor—could I lack merit and virtue that extend to the world? To have my name inscribed in this grotto palace means I am an immortal!" He rejoiced repeatedly.

As he did so, two immortal youths emerged from either side of the stone wall. Li Jue asked, "What place is this?" They replied, "The Hua Yang Grotto-Heaven. But this name is not yours, Chancellor." Startled, he asked again, "If not mine, then whose is it?" The youths said, "This belongs to a commoner from Jiangyang District." At dawn, Li Jue recalled the dream in vivid detail and was filled with astonishment. He inquired among Daoist priests, but none could explain it. He then summoned the officials of Jiangyang to question them, but they too knew nothing. Thus, he ordered a search within the prefectural city for someone sharing his name. After several days, through the recommendations of military camps and neighborhoods, they found Li Kuan, formerly named Jue.

Li Jue had him brought to the prefectural residence by carriage, provided him with a chamber for fasting and bathing, and bowed to him as his Daoist elder brother. His entire household revered and served him, paying their respects morning and evening. Li Kuan’s temperament was naturally serene, his Daoist bearing refined and striking, with a beard over a *chi* long, white and admirable. At sixty, he had once been taught embryonic breathing by a Daoist and had long since ceased eating. The Chancellor Li Jue grew even more reverent toward him. After more than a month, he asked, "Elder brother, what Daoist arts have you mastered in your life? What elixirs have you refined and consumed?" He explained that he had dreamed of the grotto palace and seen the name on the stone wall, and that the immortal youths had pointed to Li Kuan—thus, he had invited him to be his teacher and wished to be instructed.

Li Kuan declined, saying he knew nothing of Daoist arts or elixir refinement. When Li Jue pressed him earnestly about his cultivation, Li Kuan, as a humble commoner unaware of such practices, simply described his salt-trading business. After repeated questioning, Li Jue sighed in admiration, "This is a task most men find difficult—your hidden merit is beyond compare." He added, "Now I understand that even the wealthy and noble may suffer loss, while the poor and lowly, through such deeds, gain divine protection. To have one’s name inscribed in the immortal registry serves as a warning to the worldly. As for embryonic breathing and abstaining from food, I have answered truthfully."

Thereafter, Li Jue daily practiced embryonic breathing under Li Kuan’s guidance. Later, Li Kuan lived to over a hundred years of age, his vigor and health extraordinary. One day, he told his descendants, "I have lingered in this world for many years. Though I have nurtured my *qi*, it brings you no benefit." That night, he passed away. Three days later, a sound came from his coffin. When opened, his clothes and belt remained untied, as if he had shed them like a cicada—he had achieved liberation in the flesh.

Xu Zhongyuan

One day in a Tang Dynasty winehouse in Shu, a Daoist priest passed by to drink. His complexion was youthful, his hair black as lacquer, and his brows and eyes sparse yet refined. As the wine took effect, he leaned on Xu’s shoulder and sang:

*"The tail stream cannot hold back the draining of the vast river,
The nine-cycled divine elixir is all but idle talk.
Only the pearl atop the dragon’s head
Can mend the cave beneath the Jade Hall’s gate."*

Among the neighboring patrons was a man named Xu Zhongyuan who, observing him, said to his companions, "This is no ordinary mortal." He rose to show respect and asked to understand the meaning of the song. The Daoist replied, "Today is not the time to explain. If you truly wish to know, come seek me at the Zhangren Temple on the Double Ninth Festival." Xu then moved his seat to drink with him, but the Daoist left before finishing.

On the appointed day, Xu arrived at the temple at dawn, only to find the Daoist already there. The Daoist reached into his robe and produced a short scroll, handing it to Xu. "This is Lord Lao’s art of returning to youth. I have consumed this elixir and now live to four hundred and twenty-three years. As your innate destiny aligns with this, and your sincerity is profound, I bestow it upon you. If you cultivate hidden merit to perfect it, you shall become an immortal." With these words, he transformed into a white crane and flew away. Xu bowed twice and accepted the scroll. Returning home, he refined and consumed the elixir without cease. Within a few years, his appearance grew youthful, his movements swift as a galloping horse, and his strength equal to that of several men. Later, he entered Mount Qingcheng and was never seen again. Some of his disciples who obtained his arts passed them on to others.

The song speaks of the "Weilü" that cannot withstand the exhaustion of the vast and dark: this refers to the Weilü as the water-draining cave of the Eastern Sea, the place where the qi of the human body is discharged—also called the Weilü. If this is not restrained, even the boundless ocean will run dry.

As for the "Nine-Turn Divine Elixir" being entirely deceptive: it means that dragon-tiger lead and mercury, yin and yang, sun and moon, yellow sprouts and white snow, infant boy and crone girl—none of these return to unity. Only the pearl atop the striped dragon’s crown can mend the cavity beneath the Jade Hall Pass.

This refers to taking a pair of deer antlers, cutting them into three-inch sections, and soaking them in east-flowing river water to wash away the earth. For each catty, use one tael of paper mulberry fruit, two taels each of yellow wax and white mulberry bark, place them in a vessel of metal or stone, and simmer over a slow fire for three days and nights, replenishing with hot water as needed. Once done, pare away the blackened skin and consume it.

Shi Wuji
Master Shi’s given name was Wuji, and his place of origin is unknown. He often traveled to the capital, eating little—sometimes going months without food, drinking only a small amount of wine each day. When pressed to eat, he could consume a whole *dou* of rice in one meal. His body bore blue-green fur, and when people saw him, their qi would circulate; his hair stood straight on end.

He treated illness with water instead of medicine and taught others to practice propriety and righteousness. A mad scholar named Ma Cun followed him for several days, to which the master said, "What do you seek from me?" Cun replied, "I have devoted myself to the furnace and fire for some time, yet have achieved nothing. I wish you would briefly outline the essentials."

At first, the master looked up and sighed deeply, then lowered his head and reproached Cun, saying: "Your family’s wealth exceeds tens of millions—gold and jade piled high, their cords rotting in the treasury, grain moldering in the granary. Yet you eat no more than a few bowls a day and wear no more than a bolt of cloth. Still, you are not content; your insatiable heart is plain to see. A swindler might deceive you, saying, 'Obtain the great elixir, burn strange substances into gold, use it to make drinking vessels, and you may learn to become an immortal.' These are the private words of a fraud, not the ultimate discourse of a true adept.

Long ago, Han Yu and Lü Dongbin first studied the Dao. Someone told them, 'You must obtain an auxiliary art. I possess a guard, which, when used with medicine to boil copper, turns it into silver.' They asked, 'Will it change?' The man replied, 'After five hundred years, it will revert to its original state.'"

Vang replied, "I would not wish to learn it, lest I lead others astray five hundred years hence." With these words, his profound sincerity moved the heavens, and his name was concealed in the true register. To this day, he remains among the immortals.

Cun bowed twice and departed. The Master often resided on Mount Hua.

*End of Scroll Thirty-Five of the Comprehensive Mirror of True Immortals Through the Ages Who Embodied the Dao*

**Scroll Thirty-Six of the Comprehensive Mirror of True Immortals Through the Ages Who Embodied the Dao**

Wei Yu
Wei Yu was a native of the capital. His father, Xian, was a traveling merchant who frequently journeyed to the regions of Hunan and Hubei. After three years without returning, his mother said to Yu, "Your father has been gone so long—if all were well, he would have come back. I worry day and night. You should go and seek him."

Yu then traveled south into Chu and reached Tanzhou, where he encountered a lame man with whom he shared a drink. The lame man took a large jar and filled their cups. After drinking, he left half the wine and handed it to Yu, saying, "You may drink this." Yu did so and immediately detected an extraordinary fragrance. He drained the cup in one gulp, and the lame man rejoiced, saying to him, "You have come seeking your father. Do you know who I am?" Yu bowed and replied that he did not. The lame man said, "I know where he is."

Yu bowed again and asked what he knew. The lame man said, "Tomorrow, go several *li* beyond the Qingtai Gate. You will see several newly built thatched huts—those are my dwelling. I will show you where your father is." Then they parted.

Yu sat and waited for dawn, then set out beyond the Qingtai Gate. After traveling more than ten *li*, he saw on the left side of the road several new huts, neat and elegant. Two young attendants in blue stood at the gate and asked, "Are you not Master Song?" He replied, "I am."

They led him inside. Upon ascending the hall, he saw the lame man, now wearing a tall hat and purple robe, his bearing fierce as a wolf or tiger. He bowed to Yu and invited him to sit. Soon, wine and dice were brought forth, along with rare delicacies and exotic treasures—even the households of princes and dukes could not compare.

After some time, the lame man said, "Let us have some amusement. Bring the Great Flyer and the Lesser Flyer." A servant took two pellets from a vessel, their luster like silver, placing one before the lame man and one before Yu. The lame man commanded, "Let the two of you display your skills to entertain our guest."

The two pellets flew up and struck each other, transforming into long swords that clashed without cease, multiplying into over a thousand blades. Their edges were as sharp as autumn waters; they scattered like stars in formation, gathered like bundled silk, flashed like startled lightning, moved slowly like a drawn rope, spun like a wheel of fire, or flowed like waves. After some time, the lame man asked, "Would you like to master this art? Simply swallow one pellet, and its transformations will be yours."

Yu replied, "I came only to seek my father and do not wish to learn this."

The lame man said, "You have traveled long and must be weary, lacking even daily necessities. I have a method for transmuting silver with an elixir—I could teach it to you."

Yu said, "My fate is meager, and my capacity is limited to mere pecks and bushels. I fear I am unworthy, nor do I wish to learn."

The lame man exclaimed in surprise, "Your Dao surpasses even mine!" He ordered the attendants to clear away the cups and dishes, then said, "Your father died as a traveler in Xiangzhou. Go and seek him, and you will find what you seek. You may return here another day."

Yu returned home. The next day, he went back, but the hut was already empty. He journeyed to Xiang and indeed recovered his father’s bones.

Later, Yu passed the imperial examinations and wandered as a cloud-water monk. His complexion remained rosy and lustrous, and he lives to this day—likely due to the lingering power of that half-cup of wine.

Wei Shanjun
Wei Shanjun was descended from a family of the capital, Jingzhao.

Great-Grandfather roamed freely and never entered official service. Grandfather Xuanmin once served as magistrate of Gong County, and so the family settled in Gong. Father Ang was fond of mountains and rivers.

His mother, née Wang, during her early pregnancy, would suffer abdominal pain for nights on end whenever she glimpsed sacrificial meats, and so she ate only vegetables. After Wei Shanjun was born, at the age of thirteen he maintained a strict vegetarian diet and recited the *Scripture of Dao and Virtue*, the *Scripture of Salvation for Humanity*, the *Western Ascension*, and the *Ascension to the Mystery*, among other texts. Whatever others bestowed upon him, he used entirely for relief and charity.

In his prime, he journeyed to Songyang Abbey to study the Daoist arts under Huang Yuanji, then followed Han Yuanzui of Dongyuan Abbey in Linru, receiving further esoteric teachings. Two blue youths often attended him at his side.

In the early *Tiaolu* reign of Emperor Gaozong of Tang, a man named Liu Wener passed west of the mountain and saw a divine being over ten feet tall, clad in armor and seated. Upon seeing Shanjun approach, the figure rose and drew near. Wener asked those familiar with such matters, who said, "This is a follower of the Precept Dao." His elder brother Qin, struck by wonder, then followed Shanjun back to Songyang.

During Empress Wu’s *Tisheng* era, he took residence at Ascension Abbey. One day, he again saw the divine being, who cried harshly, "Who are you, daring to come here? Leave at once, or you will be harmed!" Shanjun replied, "Are you testing me, divine one? Why press so severely?" The divine being then yielded and departed.

Another time, passing through Tanxu Village to the east, he encountered a black-and-grey dog that circled him without leaving. He took it in and named it Black Dragon. During the *Ruyi* era, intending to visit Shaolin Temple, he fed it his vegetarian meal. A monk said, "Is it right to feed a dog before people eat?" Shanjun apologized, "I was wrong." Soon after, he left the temple, and as he looked back from a distance, the dog grew larger, stretching several *zhang* in length, transforming into a dragon. Shanjun mounted it and returned to Songyang, never venturing beyond its borders again.

In the *Changshou* era, he suddenly told his disciples, "I have studied the Dao for ninety-nine years, and now it is a hundred. The Most High summons me; I must go." Then he rode the dragon away.

Zhang Huigan, styled Zhiyuan, was a native of Gao'an and the fourteenth-generation descendant of the Orthodox Unity Perfected One. He relocated from Chongyuan Abbey to seclude himself at Fuyun, dedicating himself to the cultivation of the Dao of divine transcendents during the reign of Empress Wu of the Tang. A wandering Daoist of Weiguan Abbey, Hu Huichao, who had lived for several centuries, once traveled to the Wu Field Waterfall in Gao'an and paid homage to the Fuyun Master Huigan at the Wu Immortal Altar.

In the fifth year of the *Chang'an* era, Empress Wu summoned Huigan to serve as State Preceptor, holding a ritual fast in the Hall of Light. There, he beheld auspicious clouds, divine dragons, and yellow cranes soaring and alighting. She then dispatched him to Taiqing Palace in Bozhou to perform the Golden Register Fast and offer libations at the Nine Wells. The wells had long been dry, and at the time, ice and snow congealed thickly. Suddenly, a sound like thunder arose, and water surged violently forth as two dragons emerged to frolic. The Empress, astonished, bestowed upon him five hundred bolts of silk.

Returning to Fuyun, he wandered to the Wu Field Waterfall, the Two Worthies Temple of Shulin, and the Three Primordials Abbey, where he made offerings to the Six Ding spirits, expressed gratitude to the Seven Primes, and refined elixirs at Fuyun. During the *Tianbao* era of Emperor Ming, a divine being descended upon the altar and declared, "Your cultivation has been diligent and arduous; the various transcendents have recommended you. Tomorrow at cockcrow, you shall ascend in broad daylight." As foretold, clouds and strange phenomena descended, and he ascended in a blaze of daylight.

A bell cast in the first year of the *Jiushi* era of Empress Wu (the *Gengzi* year) bears an inscription recording Huigan’s name, which may still be examined. In the *Diaolu* Township of Gao'an, the ancestral lane of the Zhang family, where Huigan once lived, remains to this day.

Zhang Zhihe, the Master of Profound Reality, was surnamed Zhang, named Zhihe, and styled Zitong. A native of Shanyin in Kuaiji, some say he was originally from Jinhua in Muzhou, and his original name was Guiling. At sixteen, he passed the *Mingjing* examinations and presented a memorial to Emperor Suzong of Tang, who esteemed and favored him, appointing him as an Academician-in-Attendance in the Hanlin Academy and bestowing upon him his new name. After the passing of his parents, he no longer served in office.

Dwelling upon rivers and lakes, he called himself the "Fisherman of Mist and Waves." He wrote the *Master of Profound Reality*, adopting it as his sobriquet. A certain Wei Yi composed an inner commentary for it. Zhihe also wrote the *Great Simplicity* in fifteen chapters, comprising three hundred and sixty-five hexagrams. His elder brother, Heling, fearing he would linger in the world and never return, built him a hut east of Yuezhou. Its thatch was of living grass, its beams and rafters untouched by axe or adze, its mats of leopard skin, its sandals woven of rushes. Whenever he fished, he used no bait, for his aim was not the catch.

Governor Chen Shaoyou visited him and was detained for the whole day. He memorialized the dwelling as "Profound Reality Lane." Finding the gate too narrow, he expanded it, naming it "Turning Pavilion Alley." Previously, the gate had been blocked by a flowing stream with no bridge; Shaoyou built one, and the people called it "The Grand Master’s Bridge."

The emperor once bestowed upon him a male and female slave, whom Zhihe paired as husband and wife, naming them "Fisher Boy" and "Woodcutter Green." When Lu Yu asked who his companions were, he replied: "The Great Void is my chamber, the bright moon my candle; I dwell with all gentlemen under heaven—who is there to come or go?"

Zhihe was skilled in painting. He could drink three *dou* of wine without becoming drunk. Preserving his true nature and nurturing his *qi*, he felt no cold in snow nor wetness in water. He traveled through all the mountains and rivers under heaven.

The Duke of Lu, Yan Zhenqing, was a close friend. When Zhenqing served as prefect of Huzhou, he gathered his retainers for a drinking feast and composed *Fisherman’s Songs* in turn. The first verse was Zhihe’s own:

*By West Fortress Mountain, white gulls take flight,*
*Peach blossoms drift on waters where mandarin fish grow plump.*
*In bamboo hat and green straw cloak,*
*Through slanting wind and fine rain, there’s no need to return.*

Zhenqing, along with Lu Hongjian, Xu Shiheng, and Li Chengju, composed twenty-five verses in response, each praising the others. Zhihe then took up brush and silk, painting scenes to accompany the lyrics. In an instant, five scrolls were complete—trees and flowers, birds and fish, mountains and waters—so wondrous in their traces that none before or since could match them. Zhenqing and his guests passed them around, marveling without end.

Later, when Zhenqing traveled east to Pingwang Post, Zhihe, flushed with wine, played upon the water. He spread a mat upon its surface and sat alone, drinking and chanting. The mat moved to and fro with the speed of a punted boat. Clouds and cranes followed, hovering above. Zhenqing, his attendants, and guests watched in astonishment. Soon after, Zhihe waved farewell to Zhenqing from the water’s surface and ascended, vanishing into the sky. His treasures are still said to be preserved among the people.

**Zhu Ruzi**
Zhu Ruzi was a native of Angu in Yongjia. From childhood, he studied under the Daoist Wang Xuanzhen, dwelling in the cliffs of Great Bamboo Rock. His master, Tao Liju, had once cultivated the *True Instructions* there, so the place was also called *True Instructions Rock*. To the west of the rock lay Mount Tao. Ruzi served Xuanzhen with diligence and reverence, deeply admiring the Dao of immortality. He often climbed mountains to gather Solomon’s seal, which he consumed as sustenance, continuing thus for over a decade.

One day, as he washed vegetables by the stream, he noticed two small flower-like dogs by the bank. Finding them strange, he chased them to the base of a wolfberry bush. Xuanzhen and Ruzi searched together and dug up two wolfberry roots, their shapes resembling the flower-dogs, hard as stone. They washed them clean, took them home, and boiled them. Ruzi tended the fire, adding fuel for three days and nights without leaving the hearth. He tasted the broth and drank it endlessly. When the roots softened, he told Xuanzhen, and together they ate them. Suddenly, Ruzi ascended in flight to the peak before them. Xuanzhen watched in astonishment for a long while. Ruzi bid farewell to Xuanzhen and rose into the clouds, departing. To this day, the peak is called *Tongzi Peak* ("Boy’s Peak"). Later, Xuanzhen consumed all the remaining roots but lived on without anyone knowing his age or lifespan, eventually vanishing into the western cliffs. On Mount Tao, hunters sometimes claim to see him.

**Wang Lao**
Wang Lao was a native of Yijun County in Fangzhou. He lived in the countryside, deeply devoted to the Dao and fond of guests, diligently performing hidden acts of virtue. His wife shared his aspirations without weariness. One day, a Daoist in tattered robes arrived at his door. Wang Lao and his wife welcomed him, treating him with reverence for over a month. Daily, they engaged in profound discussions and drank together in great harmony. Soon after, the Daoist developed severe sores all over his body. Wang Lao sought medicine and tended to him with even greater care. The sores worsened, persisting for nearly a year, until the Daoist said, "There is no need for ordinary medicine. Simply soak me in several *dou* of wine, and I will heal." Wang Lao prepared the wine with meticulous care. When it was ready, the Daoist instructed, "Fill a large jar with the wine, and I will add medicine to it myself." He then stripped, climbed into the jar, and emerged three days later—his hair and beard turned black, his face youthful, his skin smooth as congealed lard. Wang Lao’s entire household marveled at the sight. The Daoist told him, "This wine can be drunk and will enable one to ascend to heaven." Wang Lao believed him.

Initially, the jar held over five *hu* of wine. When they checked later, only two or three *dou* remained—clear, fragrant, and far superior to ordinary wine. At the time, Wang Lao was threshing wheat with two others. They drank together and became thoroughly drunk. The Daoist also drank and asked, "Shall we ascend to heaven?" Wang Lao replied, "I will follow wherever you lead." Suddenly, an auspicious wind arose, and colorful clouds swirled like steam. The house, thatched roof, trees, the entire household—people, parrots, and dogs—all ascended at once, the sound of threshing still audible in the air. Villagers gathered to watch in awe. Only the cats and mice were left behind. When the wind settled, the two hired threshers were found beneath a tree in a neighboring village. Later, they ate nothing yet lived long lives. Today, thirty *li* west of Yijun County, the *Shengxian Township* ("Ascension Village") still stands.

**Hou Daohua**

Hou Daohua claimed to have come from Mount Emei, and he stayed at Daojing Monastery in Yongle County of Hezhong. He behaved like a madman, and all the Daoist priests looked down upon him. He also said he was from Yincheng in Shanzhou and had traveled to Daojing Abbey on Mount Zhongtiao to serve Master Zhou, whose religious name was Wu Xian. He often acted like a madman, and whenever any part of the monastery was damaged, he would take up an axe to repair it. He climbed perilous heights and stood on precarious ledges where others dared not go. Yet he also performed menial tasks: when guests arrived, regardless of whether they were Daoists, laypeople, or commoners, he would carry water, draw hot water, and wash their feet and clothes. He also dredged ditches, watered gardens, and endured every hardship to serve the community. The others despised him even more, driving him with harsher commands than they would a servant, yet Hou Daohua remained ever compliant. He was also fond of histories and philosophical texts, never letting a book leave his hands, reciting whatever he read aloud. When others asked why he bothered, he replied, "There are no foolish immortals in heaven." They all laughed at him.

After more than ten years, a divine light sometimes appeared on the beams of the main hall, and people often saw it. According to legend, during the Kaiyuan era of the Tang, Master Liu once refined an elixir. He tested it on a dog, which died, so no one dared consume it, and he hid it in the hall’s beams. Most dismissed this as nonsense. *The Precious Jade Record of the Primordial* states: According to *The Xuan Shi Records*, during the reign of Emperor Wenzong of the Tang, the Daoist Deng Taixuan refined an elixir and left a small box of it in the monastery. When the hall later fell into disrepair, Hou Daohua repaired it. Climbing onto the beam, he found a small golden box containing the elixir, which he swallowed before tossing the box aside. After consuming the elixir, he showed no immediate change.

One day, he went to the market and returned drunk. The monastery had a pine tree with sprawling branches, a fine sight. Hou Daohua put on wooden clogs, climbed the tree, and began chopping off all the branches. The other Daoists repeatedly tried to stop him, but he refused. As he chopped, he said, "This will be where I ascend one day." The others, thinking him mad, grew even angrier. Just then, the magistrate of Yongle County arrived, and his attendants, seeing Hou Daohua cutting the pine, were deeply astonished. The Daoists reported the matter to the magistrate, who reprimanded and humiliated him, but Hou Daohua remained unperturbed.

Seven days later, Hou Daohua rose at dawn, bathed, dressed, and burned incense, saying, "The immortals’ envoys will come to welcome me." He bowed repeatedly toward the sky, though no one believed him. Soon, people said they saw clouds and cranes swirling above the pine, accompanied by the clear sounds of flutes and reed pipes. Suddenly, Hou Daohua flew to the top of the pine and sat there. The crowd, greatly alarmed, rushed to watch, along with the magistrate of Yongle County and both Daoists and laypeople. The magistrate who had once humiliated him kowtowed until his forehead bled, but Hou Daohua waved his hand in farewell. He said, "I have received a decree from the Jade Emperor, appointing me as Immortal Terrace Gentleman and Keeper of the Shangqing Palace’s Hall of Good Faith. I depart now." He left behind a poem:

*Within the wrapper, the Great Return Elixir,*
*Its color unchanged for many years.*
*Last night, I carelessly consumed it all—*
*Today, I soar into the azure sky.*
*With shame and gratitude, I bid you farewell,*
*Farewell, Master Deng.*
*Years ago, you refined this medicine,*
*Leaving it for the inner zhi.*
*My master, knowing this art,*
*Refine it swiftly, do not delay.*
*Standing in attendance before the Three Pure Ones,*
*My appointment in the Great Luo is assured.*

In an instant, celestial music filled the air, and banners and canopies appeared faintly in the distance. He ascended into the sky.

In the fifth year of the Dazhong era of Emperor Xuanzong of Tang—alternatively recorded as his farewell address—he declared: "On the first day of the seventh month last year, I was graced by the descent of the Perfected One Han Zhong, sent by the Supreme Lord Lao, who bestowed upon me the surname Li and the name Neizhi, appointing me to reside in the Shangqing Palace’s Hall of Good Faith." Thereupon, he removed his sandals beneath the pine, ascended beyond the ancient pine’s crown, and hung his robes upon its branches before ascending.

Zheng Yunsu of Zhongtiao composed a poem at the Daojing Abbey:

*Upon the pine’s peak, robes left to soar to jade skies,*
*An eternal legacy of the sacred near, transforming Zhongtiao.*
*Do the immortals in their finery bow in greeting?*
*How could it be that now, but two nights part us?*

Governor Zheng Guang inspected the site and reported the matter to the throne. By imperial decree, five hundred bolts of silk were granted, along with imperial robes to adorn the halls and corridors. The abbey was named Ascension Abbey.

Your servant Daoyi remarks: Hou Daohua cultivated the Dao through diligence and humility, subordinating himself to serve others. Witness how he personally wielded the axe and adze to repair the halls and chambers, and performed tasks such as drawing water, boiling broth, and tending the gardens—laboring like a servant among the assembly. Had he not ultimately attained transcendence, would anyone have regarded him as an immortal? For true immortals, in their manifestation of transformation, must carry profound intent.

The *Daodejing* states: "Heaven is eternal, earth enduring. The reason heaven and earth can be eternal and enduring is that they do not live for themselves—thus they attain long life. Therefore the sage places himself last yet finds himself first; disregards his form yet preserves it. Is it not because he is selfless that he fulfills himself?" Hou Daohua embodied this principle.

Ma Xiang
Ma Xiang, styled Ziran, was a native of Guano County in Hangzhou. His family had long served as minor clerks in the county, but Xiang alone delighted in the classics and history, devoting himself to literature. One day, the county magistrate ordered him to travel to Xichuan. Xiang fretted over the journey, but after covering twelve *li* north of the county, he suddenly encountered a Daoist, who led him into a stone well. In an instant, they arrived in Xichuan. After retrieving the documents, he emerged unknowingly from the same well and returned to the county to deliver them. All who witnessed this were astonished, and the well came to be called the "Stone Well of the Immortal," which remains to this day. Thereafter, he followed a Daoist master, wandering throughout the land.

Later, he returned to Jiangnan and often became drunk in Huzhou. Once, he fell into the Shu Brook and emerged after a full day, his robes dry. Sitting upon the water, he declared: "Just now, I was summoned by King Xiang Yu for wine. I grew tipsy and have only now returned to the brook’s edge." A throng gathered to watch, and the scent of alcohol still assailed them. His manner was wild, like one possessed, and many followed to observe. At times, he would thrust his fist into his nose, and upon withdrawing it, his nose remained unchanged. He could also point at the brook’s waters and make them flow backward; after a meal’s time, he pointed at a willow tree, causing it to drift with the current, then return. He pointed at a bridge, breaking it, then mending it again.

Later, while traveling in Changzhou, he met Ma Zhi, who was appointed prefect of the region. Zhi, having long heard of Xiang’s reputation, invited him for an audience and received him with extraordinary courtesy. Zhi asked: "Reverend brother, since we share the same surname, might we become sworn brothers, that I may learn from your Way?" Xiang replied: "What is your ancestral seat?" Zhi answered: "Fufeng." Xiang jested: "Your Excellency is a Fufeng horse, while I am but a wind-driven ox—let us simply know one another, without pressing our shared surname." His meaning was that he and Zhi were as unrelated as wind and horse or ox. Nevertheless, Zhi detained him in the prefectural residence, treating him with even greater respect.

During a drinking gathering, Zhi requested to witness a minor display of his powers. Xiang then took a porcelain vessel, filled it with soil, and planted a melon. In moments, the vine grew, blossomed, and bore fruit. He plucked and shared it, and all the guests marveled at its fragrance and sweetness, unlike any ordinary melon. He also reached into his robe and socks, drawing forth an uncountable number of coins, all of which were cast as bronze cash. Tossing a handful into a well, he called to them, and each coin flew out one by one.

Those who took the coins soon lost them again.

Zhi also remarked that rats infested the city. Xiang inscribed a talisman and had it affixed beneath the southern wall. Striking a plate with a chopstick, he let out a long whistle, and rats came in swarms, scurrying to the talisman and prostrating themselves. Xiang then called to the rats, and a large one approached the steps. He admonished it: "You, a mere creature of fur, are granted grain by Heaven—how dare you gnaw through walls and disturb the prefect day and night? Though I pity you and do not wish to kill you, you must lead your kind away from here at once." The large rat turned to the others, and all kowtowed in apology before forming ranks—numberless as they were—and departing through the city gate. From that day forth, rats vanished from the city.

Later, Xiang journeyed south to Yuezhou. Passing the Dongyan Monastery, he encountered three or four hundred monks at their midday meal. When the monks saw Xiang and the Daoist Wang Zhiwei of Muma Rock in Weizhou’s Yongkang County, along with Zhiwei’s disciple Wang Yansou, they merely gestured for them to sit and eat, offering no bows—only sending someone with rice. Xiang refused to eat, urging Zhiwei and Yansou to finish quickly and rise. The monks had not yet concluded their meal when they left the monastery, and Xiang again hastened their departure. By the time they reached an inn seventy *li* south of Zhuji County, it was deep night when they heard voices calling for the Daoist. The innkeeper hurried to answer, and two monks begged to see the Daoist. When brought before Xiang, they prostrated themselves, weeping and wailing: "The monks failed to recognize a Daoist adept yesterday. We neglected to welcome you properly, incurring your anger. Three hundred monks remain unable to descend from the forest even now. We two, as the monastery’s stewards, could not sit still, so we came to beg your forgiveness." Xiang merely lay sleeping, ignoring them, while Zhiwei and Yansou laughed. The monks pleaded all the more desperately. Finally, Xiang rose and said: "Hereafter, do not treat others with such disdain. Return to the monastery, and the monks will be able to descend from the forest." The monks returned, and it proved as he had said.

The next day, Xiang continued south. It was spring, and he saw a household with fine *song* greens. When he asked for some but was refused—and even met with harsh words—he told Yansou to fetch paper and brush. Zhiwei said: "To be denied greens is no matter for litigation. Besides, those in the Daoist path should not resort to curses." Xiang smiled: "I do not mean to litigate. I merely play a small trick." Yansou presented the paper and brush, and Xiang drew a white egret. Sprinkling it with water, he sent it flying into the vegetable patch, where it pecked at the greens. The owner rushed to shoo it away, but the egret would fly up only to land again, repeating this several times. Xiang then drew a badger, which chased the egret, trampling the greens until they were utterly destroyed. Seeing the Daoist’s mischief, the owner—fearing further sorcery—came to plead for mercy. Xiang said: "I did not truly want the greens. It was only a jest." He then called the egret and badger, which flew and scurried into his sleeve. The greens remained unharmed, as if nothing had happened.

Later, Xiang traveled south to Huotong Mountain and entered Changxi County. That night, he sought lodging at an inn, but the rooms were few and travelers many. The innkeeper jested: "If you Daoists can sleep on the wall, I’ll make room for you." As dusk fell, Zhiwei and Yansou said: "We’ll take any lodging—even if we must sleep on the wall." Xiang replied: "You may sleep among the common travelers. I will sit until dawn." The others slept, but Xiang leapt onto a beam, dangling upside down by one foot. The innkeeper, rising in the night, saw him by candlelight and was astonished. Xiang said: "If I can sleep on a beam, what difficulty is a wall?" He then entered the wall and did not emerge for some time. The innkeeper prayed and apologized for a while before inviting Zhiwei and Yansou inside to sleep in a proper room. At dawn, he lingered, sighing with regret. Zhiwei and Yansou took their leave, and after traveling a few *li*, they found Xiang waiting by the roadside.

Returning from Huotong to the Tianbao Abbey east of Yongkang County, Xiang pointed to a great withered pine before the abbey and said: "This pine is over three thousand years old and will soon turn to stone." Later, it did indeed petrify. Suddenly, a great wind and thunder shook the mountain, and the stone pine toppled, breaking into several sections. Yang Fa, demoted from his post as military governor of Guangzhou to prefect of Weizhou, had a taste for the strange. Learning of this, he had two sections moved to the prefectural residence, then to the Nine Pines Courtyard of Longxing Temple. Each stood six or seven *chi* tall, over three *chi* in girth. The stone bore the pine’s bark and scales, and it remains there to this day.

When someone came to report an illness, Xiang used no medicine but struck the afflicted area—whether on the abdomen or elsewhere—with his bamboo staff. For all ailments, he would apply the staff, then blow upon its tip, producing a sound like rolling thunder, and the patient would recover. One man, bent at the waist and crooked in the legs, arrived leaning on a cane; Xiang struck him with his staff, bidding him cast aside his cane, and at once the man’s limbs straightened. Though some offered him wealth and silk, he would refuse, yet if pressed, he would accept and later distribute it among the poor.

Wherever he traveled—whether to temples, abbeys, or mountain caves—he often left poems inscribed. One, composed upon ascending Hangzhou’s Mount Qinwang, reads:

*Where to seek the first division of the Great One?*
*Only the reckoning of time alters the human heart.*
*Sun and moon of the nine heavens shift dawn and dusk;*
*Rivers and mountains of ten thousand li exchange old and new.*
*The wind stirs the water’s light, swallowing distant peaks;*
*Rain swells the mist, drowning towering forests.*
*Qin’s emperor vainly schemed to drive the mountains—*
*The boundless sea grows only deeper with the turning years.*

Later, he returned to his hometown to visit his elder brother, but the brother was away. His sister-in-law and nephews rejoiced at his return. Xiang told them, “I share this house with my brother. Now that I’ve come back, I claim my portion—only the eastern garden for myself.” His kin found this strange, saying, “Uncle, you’ve been gone so long, and your brother hasn’t even seen you. How can you speak of dividing the land? Surely no one of flesh and blood would be so unfeeling.” He stayed three days, to their growing unease. He ate nothing, drinking only wine, and waited for his brother’s return. When night fell, he suddenly passed away.

The next day, his brother returned and questioned his wife and children, who told him all that had occurred. Grief-stricken, his brother said, “My brother studied the Dao for many years. He did not return to claim a share of the house, but to entrust his transformation to me, cutting off all longing.” They prepared his coffin. That night, a sound arose from within it, startling the household. He was buried in the eastern garden, nine *li* north of the county—a place now called Horse’s Tomb. This took place in the tenth year of Dazhong during the reign of Emperor Xuanzong of Tang.

The following year, a report came from Dongchuan: in Zitong County of Jianzhou, the Daoist Ma Ziran had ascended to heaven in broad daylight.

Xiang of Dongchuan said to others: “I am a native of Yanzhou County. Recently, I underwent transformation in the west of Zhejiang, and now I have been summoned by the Jade Emperor to ascend from here.” When this was reported, an imperial edict ordered the Zhexi Circuit to investigate. They opened his tomb and found in the coffin only a bamboo staff.

Wu Tongwei
Wu Tongwei’s origins are unknown. He was a Daoist whose spirit was pure and bearing serene, ever tranquil and unassuming. Sometimes he would chant verses, sometimes drink to intoxication, often wandering among the famous mountains of Hongzhou. Though people had seen him for many years, if he vanished for a decade or more, upon his return his appearance would be even younger than before. None could fathom what elixirs he refined, where he roamed, or when he rested. Later, atop a wineshop, he ascended in flight while drunk.

Xu Cuo
Xu Cuo claimed to be from Gaoyang. In his youth, he sat for the imperial examinations but repeatedly failed. In later years, he studied the Dao on Mount Wangwu, traveling among the Five Peaks and the renowned grotto-heavens. Later, he journeyed from Mount Emei, passing through the two capitals, then from Kefu, Bian, Song, and on to Jianghuai—visiting Maoshan, Tiantai, Siming, Xiandu, Weiyu, Wuyi, Huotong, and Luofu, leaving no place unvisited. Wherever he went, he inscribed upon sheer cliffs and precipices—places no man could reach—these words: “Xu Cuo, seeking Master Crescent Moon, has come here from Mount Emei.” Those who saw his brushstrokes marveled at their uncanniness, though none could identify Master Crescent Moon.

Later, he often wandered on Mount Lu, and once, drunk, he sang:
*Before the gardens of the Jasper Court lies the land of drunkenness,*
*Where the Queen Mother toasts with nine rosy goblets.*
*The immortals point and scorn my frivolity,*
*Exiling me to the mortal world as a wine-mad fool.*

When curious onlookers questioned him, he replied: “I am a celestial immortal, just now feasting on Kunlun. I was banished for a lapse in decorum.” People laughed, dismissing him as a madman. Later, on a spring day, he adorned his head with flowers and danced with blossoms in hand. He climbed a wineshop, sang while drunk, and ascended upon the clouds.

Jin Keji

Jin Keji was a man of Silla who, during the reign of Emperor Xuānzong of Tang, was honored in the court for his literary talents. By nature serene and devoted to the Dao, he disdained extravagance and ostentation. At times, he practiced qi refinement and bodily cultivation, finding joy in such pursuits. Broad in learning and retentive of memory, his compositions were elegant and refined. His bearing was graceful, and his speech and conduct bore the unmistakable air of a scholar of the Central Kingdom. Shortly after passing the imperial examinations, he declined official appointment and withdrew to Zǐwǔ Valley in the Zhongnan Mountains, where he built a humble dwelling and embraced a life of reclusion. He planted a great many rare flowers and exotic fruits with his own hands. Often, he would burn incense and sit in quiet meditation; whenever thoughts arose, he would recite without cease the *Dao and Virtue* and various scriptures of the immortals.

After three years, he longed to return to his homeland and departed by sea. Later, he came again, clad in Daoist robes, and reentered the Zhongnan Mountains, where he devoted himself to performing hidden acts of virtue. Whatever people sought of him, he never refused, and his diligence in all matters was unmatched. In the twelfth month of the eleventh year of Dazhong, he submitted a memorial stating: “Your servant has received a decree from the Jade Emperor, appointing him as Attendant Gentleman of the English Terrace. On the fifteenth day of the second month of next year, he shall ascend to the heavens.” At the time, Emperor Xuānzong found this extraordinary and dispatched an imperial envoy to summon him to court, but he firmly declined. When asked to produce the Jade Emperor’s decree, he demurred, saying it was held by another immortal and not left in the mortal realm.

The emperor then bestowed upon him four palace ladies, fragrant medicines, gold, and silks. He also dispatched two imperial envoys to attend him exclusively, yet he insisted on residing alone in a quiet chamber, allowing neither the palace ladies nor the envoys to approach. Each night, voices of conversation and laughter could be heard from within his room. The envoys, peering secretly, saw only immortal officials and maidens seated upon dragon and phoenix thrones, facing one another with solemn dignity. Attendants and guards stood in great number, yet the palace ladies and envoys dared not disturb them. On the fifteenth day of the second month, as spring blossomed in radiant beauty and flowers shone in full splendor, five-colored clouds, crying cranes, soaring simurghs, and white swans appeared, accompanied by the music of reed pipes, stone chimes, feathered canopies, and jade carriages. Banners and pennants filled the sky as they bore him away to ascend to heaven. The court officials and common folk who gathered to witness the spectacle filled the mountains and valleys, all gazing in reverence and marveling in awe.

**Song Xuanbai**
Song Xuanbai’s origins are unknown. A Daoist adept, he stood over seven feet tall, with brows and eyes like a painting, his bearing refined, handsome, plump, and fair. His speech was elegant, and all who saw him cherished him. Possessing profound arts of the Dao, he wore cotton in summer and a single layer in winter, yet when standing in snow, steam-like qi would emanate in a circle more than a *zhang* around him, preventing the snow from settling. With a point of his finger, lamps would extinguish, and people would feel as though swept by a draft, rustling faintly. When he gestured toward flowers and grasses in the courtyard, they would sway as if stirred by wind.

He wandered among famous mountains, emerging from Mao Mountain to reside at the Xixuan Abbey in Runzhou, then entering the Kuocang Grotto, where he practiced grain avoidance and qi absorption. At times, he would consume five *jin* of fatty meat, devour a whole basin of garlic, then drink two *dou* of wine with a single white plum. Those who obtained and ate a piece of his garlic claimed it left no garlicky odor but instead an exotic fragrance lingering on their teeth and tongue all day, never fading. Many who ate it lived long, healthy lives, reaching eighty or ninety years of age.

Wherever Xuanbai stayed, he would use gold and silk to acquire two or three beautiful concubines, only to abandon them when he departed. People speculated that he had mastered the arts of "supplementing the brain and restoring primordial qi" through the "Three Peaks" method of bedroom cultivation—practices unworthy of a true immortal. Yet if Xuanbai had indeed ascended as an immortal, why did he keep concubines? This only deepened their doubts. However, it was clear he did not practice the "bedroom arts." Perhaps his intent was to blend with the world and conceal his true nature, leaving others uncertain of his immortality.

Later, he traveled to Yuezhou during a severe drought. The local authorities were performing music and dragon dances to pray for rain, but after ten days, the scorching heat only worsened. Xuanbai, observing this, remarked that rain could only be summoned by aligning with the Mandate of Heaven, not through mere petitions. He then burned incense at his abode and offered prayers, and by nightfall, a great thunderstorm brought ample rain, astonishing the people of Yue.

Later still, he arrived in Xinzhou, where another drought had prompted prayers for rain. A Daoist adept, knowing of Xuanbai’s ability to summon rain, was invited by the locals. He swiftly performed his arts, driving a flying nail into the eyes of the city god. The prefect, Wei Delin, falsely accused him of harboring women and drove another nail into the city god. Declaring Xuanbai a demonic trickster, Wei ordered his subordinates to seize and punish him. Yet as they approached, their limbs stiffened, and they collapsed to the ground, their willow-wood shackles snapping apart. Xuanbai laughed and said to Wei, “Sir, are you acting like Liu Gen, seeking to punish the ancestral *mi*?” Terrified, Wei begged forgiveness and soon after sent him off with courtesy. His numinous wonders were tested time and again, too numerous to record in full.

Later, in Nancheng County of Fuzhou—now under the jurisdiction of Jianchang Prefecture—he ascended to the heavens in broad daylight.

He Zizhen
He Zizhen’s origins were unknown. A Daoist adept, he dwelled on Mount Song. Cultured and refined, he conducted himself with lofty antiquity, ever diligent in his austerities and meditations.
