Though young in appearance, none could determine his age; yet among both Daoists and layfolk, it was widely said that he had been seen for many years, though none knew the nature of his practice. One day, clouds of cranes filled the sky, their cries and music clear and resonant, as Zizhen suddenly ascended in flight. At the time, the scholar-recluse Chen Tao was in the eastern capital and witnessed the people of Luoyang gazing in awe and reverence. Overcome with wonder, he composed a poem:

"Like Zǐjìn’s phoenix-flight o’er ancient Luò’s streams,
Golden peaches ripen anew for Lord Hè’s ascent.
Triple Clarity’s music swells beneath Sōng’s peaks,
Five-hued clouds gather before the imperial gardens.
Crimson-crested dancers whirl to greet the scarlet staff,
Blue-maned singers pause beside the perfumed carriage.
Who now weeps in daylight’s sorrow?
How many myriad years stretch through the Supreme Pole’s light?"

*Comprehensive Mirror of Perfected Immortals Through the Ages Who Embodied the Dao*, Scroll 36 (conclusion)
*Comprehensive Mirror of Perfected Immortals Through the Ages Who Embodied the Dao*, Scroll 37

Deng Qushe

Deng Qushe was a native of Longqiu in Quzhou, dwelling at the foot of Nine Peaks Mountain. From youth he entered the Dao, traveling to study its arts, his concentrated thought never flagging in weariness. At over thirty years of age, he took residence at Anhe Abbey in Songyang County of Chuzhou, the very place where Ye Jingneng had once studied the Dao in his native village. Five *li* north of the abbey rose Mao Mountain, towering over fifty *zhang* in height. Tradition held that Celestial Master Zhang and Ye Jingneng had both dwelt upon this mountain to cultivate the Dao. Inspired by their precedent, Qushe ascended the peak and built a thatched hut to live in.

Later, the abbey’s Daoists followed him to dwell at the mountain’s base, where people constructed houses, halls, and temples. There they enshrined images of Lord Lao, Celestial Master Zhang, and the true portrait of Ye Jingneng, burning incense and performing rites morning and evening. To the mountain’s southeast lay a square stone, over two *zhang* in width, flat as a whetstone—formed by nature itself. Qushe often sat upon it, hands clasped in silent meditation.

One day, a spirit appeared to him, saying: “Celestial Master Zhang’s two demon-slaying swords and a jar of elixir lie buried beneath this stone. You may retrieve them.” Qushe bowed to the spirit and replied: “This stone is of heaven; no human effort could alter it. I am but a humble, deluded man who guards the truth—content to dwell here in peace, long sheltered by sacred protection. How could I presume to take the elixir and swords?”

The spirit said: “Simply cultivate diligently without slackening, and the swords and elixir will come to you of their own accord.” Three years later, the spirit delivered the swords and elixir to Qushe. The swords were Celestial Master Zhang’s Seven-Star Swords, while the elixir was stored in a stone casket, sealed in a jar. When poured, the medicine filled over a *dou*, resembling sesame seeds in size, crimson in color, and radiant with light. Qushe consumed some himself and distributed the rest to others, and all were cured.

At that time, Hua Zao of Lishui County, in the wake of the famine and chaos of the Zhonghe era, gathered local people to fortify a crag and defend it.

The military governor of eastern Zhejiang reported the matter to the court, where it was debated that the troops should be withdrawn. Hua Zao was thus appointed prefect. Yet Zao, treacherous and ruthless, had heard of Qushe’s divine swords and elixir. He surrounded the mountain with soldiers, seized Qushe along with the swords and elixir, and brought them to the prefectural seat. There, he confiscated the swords and elixir and imprisoned Qushe in an airless cell. It was the height of summer, and for a full month, no water was given to him. Zao assumed Qushe must have perished, but when the cell was opened, his countenance remained solemn, his complexion rosy and fair—even more radiant than before. Astonished, Zao sent Qushe back to the mountain but kept the swords and elixir. That very night, a storm of wind and thunder roared through the sky, and they vanished without a trace. Qushe later said the swords had returned to their place beneath the stone.

For over fifteen years thereafter, Qushe dwelled on the mountain. He often spoke of seeing dragons, tigers, and strange birds moving through his courtyard. Daoist priests from Anhe Temple who lodged on the summit to perform rituals would witness these creatures nearby and marvel at the sight. Qushe had not eaten for many years; if anyone defiled the mountain, fierce beasts would appear in spring and winter to startle them, while in summer and autumn, venomous snakes would strike. Qushe also recounted that during thunderstorms, the clouds, dragons, thunder gods, lightning matrons, and countless spirits would gather halfway up the mountain, sometimes appearing before him with great courtesy.

Daoist priests who stayed overnight would hear voices as if Qushe were conversing with others in his quiet chamber. Peering in, they detected only a room suffused with strange fragrance and the sound of jade pendants. At times, they saw four figures seated facing one another—men and women wearing distant-travel caps, crimson robes, coiled topknots, and flowing green silk garments—while jade boys and jade maidens stood in attendance, their bodies aglow. Other divine beings stood at a distance. The priests dared not disturb them, offering only reverence.

One day, Qushe told the priests: “I fear I must soon leave this mountain and may not see you for long.” Several days later, a procession of colored clouds and phoenixes filled the sky with music, hovering above the summit. A palanquin adorned with banners and canopies arrived, borne by spirit officials riding dragons and five-colored deer, some mounted on phoenixes. They came to escort Qushe as he ascended to heaven, witnessed by a great crowd of Daoists and laypeople below.

**Lan Caihe**
Lan Caihe’s origins are unknown.

Lan Caihe was ever clad in a tattered indigo robe, wooden clogs bound with six black straps, and a belt over three inches wide. One foot shod, the other bare, they walked with a halting gait. In summer, they lined their robe with padding; in winter, they lay in the snow, their breath rising like steam. Wherever they went, they sang through the streets, begging for alms. In hand they carried a large clapper, over three feet long. Often drunk, they danced and sang, drawing crowds of old and young alike. Quick-witted and full of jest, they would banter with passersby, their replies so apt that all who heard would collapse in laughter. Though seeming mad, they were not mad. As they walked, they would shake their shoes and sing:

*Dance, dance the song—*
*Lan Caihe!*
*How long can this world last?*
*Youth is a tree in spring bloom,*
*Light a shuttle cast.*
*The ancients, lost in the great flow, never return;*
*Today’s multitudes press on, ever more.*
*At dawn, riding simurghs and phoenixes to the azure vault;*
*At dusk, watching mulberry fields turn to white waves.*
*Bright radiance lingers in the empty sky,*
*Where golden and silver palaces rise, towering and steep.*

Their songs, though often improvised, were imbued with the spirit of immortals—none could fathom their meaning. When given coins, they would string them together and drag them along, or let them scatter, never glancing back. If they saw the poor, they would give freely; if they met a tavern, they would share their alms with the wine-seller.

Wandering the world, there were those who had seen them as children, and upon meeting them again with hair turned gray, found their appearance unchanged. Later, they danced and sang between the beams of the Huai River, and while drunk in a tavern’s upper story, a sound of cloud-cranes, reed pipes, and flutes arose. Suddenly, they rose lightly into the air, casting down their hanfu robe, sash, and clappers into the clouds before drifting away. The robe and other items soon vanished as well.

Zhang Guo
Zhang Guo concealed himself on Mount Tiao in Hengzhou, traveling between Fen and Jin. People of the time spoke of his secret to longevity, and elders who had seen him as children claimed he was already several hundred years old. He often rode a white donkey, covering tens of thousands of li in a day. When resting, he would fold it up—its thickness like paper—and store it in his headscarf box. When he wished to ride again, he would sprinkle water on it, and it would once more become a donkey.

Emperor Taizong and Emperor Gaozong of Tang summoned him, but he did not rise. Empress Wu Zetian called him forth from the mountains, and he feigned death before the shrine of Tuo Nu. It was midsummer, and soon his corpse rotted and teemed with maggots, so the empress believed he was truly dead. (Another account says he later concealed himself in Fengzhou, dwelling on Mount Douji in summer and Mount Jingnu in winter.) Emperor Minghuang invited him, but he did not come. Later, someone saw him again in the mountains of Hengzhou.

In the twenty-third year of the Kaiyuan era, Emperor Minghuang dispatched the Court Messenger Pei Wu to Hengzhou by post-horse to welcome him. Upon meeting Wu, Guo indeed appeared before him—then ceased breathing and died. Wu thereupon burned incense and proclaimed the Son of Heaven’s desire to invite him on a journey. After a brief moment, Guo gradually revived. Fearing to press further, Wu hastened back to report.

The emperor then commanded the Drafter of Imperial Decrees Xu Jiao and Court Messenger Lu Chongxuan to present Guo with an invitation bearing the imperial seal. Guo accompanied Jiao to the Eastern Capital. As Emperor Minghuang was traveling to the hot springs and had arrived at Luoyang, Guo was lodged in the Jixian Institute. Carried into the palace by sedan chair, he was treated with utmost reverence, and all the high ministers came to pay their respects. When the emperor inquired about the arts of immortality, Guo did not answer. He was skilled in breath-holding and could go for days without food, though he drank wine several times a day. When the emperor offered him wine, Guo declined, saying, “This humble servant cannot drink more than two *sheng*. I have a disciple, however, who can drink one *dou*.”

Delighted by this, the emperor ordered the disciple summoned. In an instant, a young Daoist descended from the palace eaves, appearing sixteen or seventeen years old, with a handsome countenance and refined, elegant demeanor. He paid his respects to the emperor with clear, crisp speech and impeccable manners. When the emperor commanded him to sit, Guo said, “My disciple should stand in attendance at my side; he cannot be granted a seat.” The emperor was even more pleased. He offered the disciple wine, who drank a full *dou* without becoming drunk. Guo then entreated, “Do not offer him more. Excess will lead to some mishap, if only to amuse Your Majesty.” The emperor pressed him further, and suddenly wine gushed from the disciple’s crown, his cap falling to the ground and transforming into a comb-cover. The emperor and his consorts all gasped and laughed in astonishment. When they looked again, the young Daoist had vanished—only a golden comb remained on the ground. When they lifted the cover, it held exactly one *dou* of wine. Upon verification, it proved to be a comb from the Jixian Institute. Guo’s immortal arts were tested repeatedly, yet their depths could not be fathomed.

Guo once remarked, “I was born in the *bingzi* year of Emperor Yao and held the position of *Shizhong*.” His appearance suggested a man of sixty or seventy. There was Xing Hepu, who could discern a person’s lifespan, and Shuai Yeguang, who could see ghosts. The emperor ordered Hepu to divine Guo’s longevity, but Hepu was utterly baffled. Secretly, he sent Yeguang to observe him, yet Yeguang could not perceive Guo’s whereabouts.

The emperor said to Gao Lishi, “I have heard that one who drinks wormwood wine without bitterness is an extraordinary man.” As the weather was cold, he took some and offered it to Guo, who drank three cups and then frowned, saying, “This is not fine wine.” He then lay down, and upon closer inspection, one of his teeth appeared scorched and shrunken. Turning to his attendants, he took an iron *ruyi* and struck the tooth, knocking it out and tucking it into his sash. He then produced a medicine and applied it to the gap. After a while, the tooth regrew, straight and gleaming white.

When the emperor hunted in Xianyang, he captured a large deer and ordered the royal chefs to prepare it. Guo said, “This is a celestial deer, already a thousand years old. In the fifth year of *Yuanshou* during the reign of Emperor Wu of Han, I once accompanied him on a hunt in the Shanglin Park, where we caught this deer—and released it.” The emperor said, “There are many deer. Over the long passage of time, how could it not have been taken by hunters?” Guo replied, “When Emperor Wu released it, he marked it with a bronze plaque beneath its left antler.” The emperor ordered it checked, and indeed, a bronze plaque about two *cun* long was found, though the inscription was worn and faint.

The emperor asked, “What was the *jiazi* year of *Yuanshou*? How many years have passed since then?” Guo answered, “That year was *guihai*. Emperor Wu had just begun excavating the Kunming Pool. Now, in the *jiaxu* year, eight hundred and fifty-two years have passed.” The emperor commanded the Grand Historian to verify the calendar, and it proved nearly without discrepancy.

The emperor then asked Ye Fashan, “What manner of man is Guo?”

Guo answered, “I know, yet if I speak, I shall die. Now I dare not speak. If Your Majesty would remove your crown and bare your feet to save me, then I may live.” The emperor consented.

Ye Fashan said, “At the primal division of *hun-tun*, he was the essence of the white bat.” As the words left his mouth, blood flowed from his seven orifices, and he collapsed to the ground. The emperor hastened to Guo’s side, removed his crown, bared his feet, and confessed his fault.

Guo slowly said, “This child speaks too freely. If I do not chastise him, the secrets of Heaven and Earth may be revealed.” The emperor grieved and pondered for a long while. Guo then sprinkled water on Ye’s face, and he revived at once. The emperor marveled at him all the more and issued an edict to have his portrait painted and displayed in the Jixian Institute.

The edict read: “The Master Zhang Guo of Hengzhou wanders beyond the bounds of the world. His spirit soars to lofty heights, his heart enters the distant and obscure. He merges with the radiance of dust, answering the summons to court. None know the count of his years; some say he is a man of the age of Fuxi. Question him on the pivot of the Dao, and he exhausts the ultimate principles. Now, as he prepares to observe court ritual, We elevate him with honor and appointment. Let him be granted the title of *Yinqing Guanglu Daifu* and styled Master of Penetrating the Mysterious.”

Guo repeatedly pleaded old age and illness, begging to return to Hengzhou. The emperor bestowed three hundred bolts of silk upon him, along with two disciples to accompany him, and provided post horses for their journey to Huan Prefecture. One disciple was sent back, while the other followed him into the mountains.

At the beginning of the *Tianbao* era, Emperor Minghuang sent envoys to summon Guo again. They found he had already died, and his disciples buried him. Later, when the tomb was opened, only an empty coffin remained. The emperor had the Qixia Abbey built in his honor.

Minister Dao Yi said: “Zhang Guo transcended the mortal to attain the sagely. He could sit and vanish at will, his transformations boundless, his virtue and power pure. Observing how he left his form in the world, he was no different from Guangchengzi or Qian Keng. Those who attain the immortals are not easily matched.”

The *Daode Jing* says: “In governing people and serving Heaven, nothing surpasses frugality. Only through frugality can one be said to serve early. To serve early is to accumulate virtue heavily. With heavy accumulation of virtue, there is nothing one cannot overcome. With nothing one cannot overcome, none can fathom one’s limits. With none able to fathom one’s limits, one may possess the state. Possessing the state’s mother, one may endure long. This is called having deep roots and a firm stem—the Dao of long life and enduring vision.” Such was Zhang Guo.

Xu Xuanping.

Xu Xuanping was a native of She in Xin’an. During the Jingyun era of Emperor Ruizong’s reign in the Tang, he secluded himself in the southern valley of Chengyang Mountain, where he built a thatched hut to dwell in. Though no one knew what he consumed, he was seen to eat nothing. His complexion resembled that of a man in his forties, and he moved with such lightness and agility that he could outrun a galloping horse. At times, he would carry firewood to sell, his load always bearing a gourd and a crooked bamboo staff. When drunk, he would stagger homeward, chanting:

*With firewood at dawn I set out to sell,*
*To buy wine and return as the sun dips low.*
*None ask of me—*
*Through clouds I vanish into emerald peaks.*

For over thirty years, he aided those in peril or distress. Many in the city sought him, but he was never seen; they found only poems inscribed on the walls of his hut:

*For thirty years I’ve dwelt in seclusion,*
*My hut built high on the southern mountain’s crest.*
*At still night I dine beneath the bright moon,*
*At leisure morn I drink from the jade spring.*
*Woodcutters sing on the slopes,*
*Valley birds play before the cliffs.*
*Joyful, I forget age,*
*And all reckoning of years.*

Those fond of such matters often recited his verses. Some who traveled to Chang’an left them inscribed at post stations along the road to Luoyang and Tonghua. During the Tianbao era of Emperor Minghuang’s reign, Li Bai, having left the Hanlin Academy, journeyed through these stations. Upon reading the poem, he sighed, “This is the work of an immortal.” Inquiring among the locals, he learned of Xuanping’s story. Li Bai then traveled to Xin’an, crossing streams and climbing mountains in search of him, but never found him. He left a poem on the hut’s wall:

*I chanted the poem from the post station,*
*And came to seek the immortal’s abode.*
*Misty ridges obscure the heights,*
*Clouded forests veil the vast void.*
*Peering in, I find only desolation;*
*Leaning on my staff, I stand in vain.*
*He must have transformed into a crane soaring beyond the skies,*
*And will return only after a thousand years.*

When Xuanping returned to his hut and saw the poem on the wall, he chanted in reply:

*A pond of lotus leaves—endless robes,*
*Two acres of yellow essence—abundant fare.*
*Again, men come seeking me,*
*So I must move my hut deeper into the wilds.*

Later, his hut was burned by a wildfire, and no trace of Xuanping was ever found. Over a hundred years later, in the twelfth year of Emperor Yizong’s Xiantong era, a servant of the local man Xu Mingru accompanied others into the mountains to gather firewood. One day, she came upon a man sitting on a rock, eating an exceptionally large peach. He asked her, “Are you from Xu Mingru’s household?” She replied, “Yes.” The man said, “I am Xu Mingru’s ancestor, Xuanping.” The servant said, “I have often heard my family speak of my ancestor’s attainment of immortality, but we had no way to seek him.” Xuanping told her, “Return and tell Mingru that I dwell in these mountains. Give him this peach to eat, but do not take it out of the mountains—tigers and wolves abound here, and the mountain spirit cherishes this peach.” The servant ate it, finding it delicious, and soon finished it. She was sent back with the woodcutters to relay the encounter. Upon returning, she felt her load of firewood light and nimble. At home, she recounted meeting her ancestor Xuanping in the mountains. Mingru, enraged that she had presumptuously invoked his ancestor’s name, took up a staff to strike her. As the staff fell, the servant’s body rose and vanished. Later, someone entering the mountains encountered her—her face youthful, her body light, clad in tree bark, moving swiftly as the wind. She then ascended into the treetops and disappeared.

---

The Daoist Xue Chang was a native of You and Ji. During the Tianbao era of the Tang, he resided at the Cavern Heaven Abbey on Mount Qingcheng in Shu. One day, he obtained wine made from *shanglu* (pokeweed) and drank it, causing blood to flow from his ears and nose until he died. After three days, he suddenly revived, his skin fair, his appearance instantly youthful, his body light, his eyes bright, as if he might take flight. Within days, he could perceive distant and near objects with clarity, seeing and hearing through mountains, forests, and cliffs as if nothing obstructed him. At the time, Emperor Xuanzong revered the supreme Dao, and the regional military governor invited Xue Chang to the guest quarters, intending to send him to the capital with a four-horse carriage. Suddenly, the master vanished. Some later claimed to have seen him on Mount Damian.

---

Wu Yun, styled Zhengjie, was a native of Huayin. Well-versed in the classics and skilled in literary composition, he sat for the imperial examinations but did not pass. Proud and unyielding, he could not conform to the times, so he left to dwell on Mount Yichang in Nanyang. At the beginning of Emperor Minghuang’s Tianbao era, he was summoned to the capital and registered as a Daoist. He entered Mount Song to study under Master Pan Zheng, then journeyed south to Mount Tiantai and observed the Eastern Sea. He delighted in the company of renowned scholars, and his writings circulated in the capital. Emperor Minghuang dispatched an envoy to summon him to the Datong Hall. Pleased with their conversation, the emperor ordered him to await imperial summons at the Hanlin Academy and presented *Three Treatises on the Mystical Framework*. When asked about the Dao, Wu Yun replied, “In seeking the Dao, nothing surpasses the *Five Thousand Words* of Laozi.” When asked about the methods of immortality and alchemy, he answered, “These are the pursuits of rustics, requiring years of effort—hardly matters for a sovereign to attend to.” In his discourses, Wu Yun often addressed the teachings of the age and subtly admonished the emperor, who held him in high regard. The Buddhist clergy, jealous of his favor, and Gao Lishi, who had long served the monks, together slandered him before the emperor. Wu Yun, sensing the realm’s impending disorder, requested to return to Mount Song, where the emperor ordered a residence built for him. Soon after, the An Lushan Rebellion erupted, and he traveled to Mount Mao, then eastward to Kuaiji and the Ke region.

Wu Yun composed treatises on the wonders of the Valley Spirit, such as *On the Mystical Framework*; on the remoteness of the Dao from worldly concerns, such as *On the Pursuit of Immortality*; on cleansing the heart and shedding worldly dust, such as *Rinsing the Heart* and *Dwelling in the Cliffs*; on cultivating sincerity within and resting in the lord of heaven, such as *On the Heart and Eyes* and *In Harmony with the Spirit*. His works also included *Roaming Immortals* and *Pacing the Void*, as well as poems on royal governance and miscellaneous reflections, totaling over four hundred and fifty pieces. The Vice Minister of Rites, Quan Deyu, compiled and prefaced them. Initially, Wu Yun was despised by Gao Lishi and banished, which led his writings to sharply criticize Buddhism. He admired the songs and poems of Kong Chaofu, ranking them among the finest. In the thirteenth year of Emperor Daizong’s Dali era, Wu Yun suddenly burned incense and departed this world at a Daoist abbey in Xuancheng. His disciple Shao Jiyuan and his followers buried him at the western foot of Mount Tianzhu, privately bestowing upon him the posthumous title *Master Zongyuan*.

Li Bai, styled Taibai, was a ninth-generation descendant of the Tang’s Sacred Emperor. His mother dreamed of the Longgeng star before conceiving him, and thus he was named. Born in the second year of Empress Wu Zetian’s Shengli era (699, *jihai*), he recited the *Six Jia* at five and mastered the *Book of Poetry* and *Book of Documents* by ten, studying the works of a hundred schools. Su Ting marveled at him, saying, “This child is a prodigy of heaven; with a little more learning, he may rival Sima Xiangru.”

At fifteen, he took up swordsmanship and roamed in search of immortals, often dwelling in the Min Mountains. He wandered amid rivers and mountains, composing verses as he went. Later, he ascended Mount Emei and journeyed through Jianghuai, visiting the Yunmeng Marsh. There, he married the granddaughter of Xu Yuan, a minister of the Tang court, and stayed in Yunmeng for three years. Fond of the arts of persuasion and knight-errantry, he wielded his sword, valued generosity, and scorned wealth.

Leaving for Qi and Lu, he sojourned in Rencheng, where he joined Kong Chaofu, Han Zhun, Pei Zheng, Zhang Shuming, and Tao Mian in dwelling on Mount Zulai, drinking deeply. They were known as the Six Idlers of Bamboo Creek. In the sixteenth year of Emperor Xuanzong’s Kaiyuan era (728), the emperor wrote in a letter to Pei Yaoqing: “His literary labors have been tireless for thirty springs now.”

In the third year of the Tianbao era (744, *jiashen*), Bai befriended Wu Yun, who was then serving as a drafter in the Hanlin Academy. Bai also traveled to Chang’an, where he met the Grand Tutor of the Heir Apparent, He Zhizhang, at the Purple Ultimate Palace. There, he removed his golden marten cap to exchange for wine in revelry. Zhizhang, upon reading his writings, exclaimed, “You are a banished immortal!” He recommended Bai to the emperor, who summoned him to the Golden Bells Hall. There, Bai discoursed on current affairs and presented an ode. The emperor, moved, personally ladled soup for him. Though appointed as a Hanlin Academician, Bai continued to drink with his boon companions in the marketplace.

One day, the emperor sat in the Agarwood Pavilion, inspired to compose music, and desired Bai to write lyrics. Summoned, Bai arrived drunk. His attendants splashed water on his face to rouse him, and he took up his brush, composing verses of exquisite beauty and precision without hesitation. The emperor cherished his talent. Once, while attending the emperor in his cups, Bai ordered Gao Lishi to remove his boots. Lishi, humiliated, seized upon his poems to incite Yang Guifei. Whenever the emperor sought to appoint Bai to office, the consort would obstruct it. Bai grew ever more unrestrained, joining He Zhizhang, Li Shizhi, Prince Rui of Suyang, Cui Zongzhi, Su Jin, Zhang Xu, and Jiao Sui as the Eight Immortals of Wine. He pleaded to return to the mountains, and the emperor granted him gold and dismissed him.

As he left the Golden Gate, he sought an audience with an imperial censor but failed to find him. Thereupon, he composed a poem on the parrot: *“Shedding feathers, it departs the golden hall, / Crying out, it scolds the brocade-robed one. / Though it could speak, it was cast aside, / And now flies back to the mountains of Long.”* He then visited his distant cousin, Li Yenyun, the Investigating Censor of Chenliu, and requested the High Master of Beihai to initiate him into the registers of Daoist ordination. After receiving the transmission, he returned to Beihai.

From there, he traveled through Zhao, Wei, Yan, Jin, Qi, and Shang, lingering longest in Luoyang and Liang. He revisited Qi and Lu, the Huai and Si rivers, entered Wu again, and wandered to Jinling, ascending Qiupu and Xunyang, leaving poems and prose wherever he went, though the dates are unrecorded.

Bai roamed the four directions. Once, he boarded a boat with Cui Zongzhi from Caishi to Jinling, wearing a brocade robe of the imperial court. Seated in the boat, he appeared as if no one else were present. Another time, he traveled to Mount Hua and passed through a county seat. The magistrate was just opening the gate to attend to official business when Bai, drunk, rode his donkey through the gate. The magistrate, enraged and unaware of his identity, dragged him to the courtyard and demanded, “Who are you, to dare such rudeness?” Bai requested paper to write a statement, declaring: *“I have wiped spittle with the dragon’s kerchief, had soup stirred by the imperial hand, held the inkstone for the noble consort, and had my boots removed by Gao Lishi. Before the gates of the Son of Heaven, I was still permitted to gallop my horse—how can the precincts of Huayin County forbid me to ride my donkey?”* The magistrate, startled, rose to bow in apology, saying, “I did not realize the Hanlin Academician had come here.” Bai mounted his donkey and departed.

In the fourteenth year of the Tianbao era (755), An Lushan rebelled. Prince Yong of Lin marched east, and Bai, taking refuge on Mount Lu, was coerced into joining him. When Prince Yong’s forces were defeated and he was executed, Bai was implicated. Guo Ziyi pleaded to resign his office to atone for Bai’s crime, and thus Bai was exiled to Yelang. This occurred in the first year of Emperor Suzong’s Qianyuan era (758). Earlier, Bai had written in a poem: *“At midnight, the naval forces arrived, / Yuzhang filled with banners. / An empty name led me astray, / Forced aboard the towering ship. / Granted five hundred gold, / I cast it away like floating smoke. / Refusing office and reward, / I was instead exiled to the heavens of Yelang.”* Midway through his journey, he received a pardon and was allowed to return. He ascended Mount Wu and descended the Qutang Gorge. Later, he passed through Jiangxia, Xunyang, Jinling, Liyang, and Xuancheng, leaving poems in both commanderies, though the details are no longer traceable.

Bai’s lifelong aspiration was to become an immortal, and his studies followed the teachings of Laozi. He once wrote in an ancient-style poem on Daoist learning: *“How vast and blue is Mount Tai, / Where stars array in lofty ranks. / Three hundred leagues from heaven, / Remote and severed from the world. / Within, a green-haired elder, / Clad in clouds and pine-snow. / Neither laughing nor speaking, / Truly dwelling in a rocky cave. / I came to ask the perfected one, / Kneeling long to seek the precious formula. / Suddenly, he laughed to himself, / And taught me the art of refining elixirs. / I engraved his words upon my bones, / Refining my body until it vanished like lightning. / Gazing up, I could not reach him, / My five emotions burning with sorrow. / I shall cultivate cinnabar, / And forever part from the world of men.”*

In another poem, he wrote: *“Five cranes came from the northwest, / Soaring and soaring into the Great Clarity. / An immortal upon green clouds, / Claiming to be Anqi Sheng. / Two jade lads in pairs, / Blowing purple phoenix flutes. / Floating down in inverted reflection, / Swiftly leaving no trace. / They left me golden radiance herbs, / Which, when consumed, made my limbs light. / I shall follow Red Pine, / Playing chess upon Penglai.”*

In the eleventh month of the first year of the Baoying era, he departed from Jinling to Caishi to visit his clansman Li Yangbing. There, he seized the moon and plunged into the waters, ending his life—people called it a "water liberation." He was sixty-four years old.

When Emperor Daizong ascended the throne, he summoned Li Bai to the post of *Shiyi*, but the poet had already dissolved into transformation. The *Collected Works of Li Taibai of the Tang* circulates in the world. Its preface states:

Li Bai, styled Taibai, was a native of Chengji in Longxi and a ninth-generation descendant of Emperor Wu of Liang’s clan. His family, long distinguished by official seals and girdle ornaments, had been illustrious for generations. In middle antiquity, however, they were unjustly exiled to Tiaozhi, where they changed their surname and given name. From the impoverished cicada to Shun, five generations remained commoners, their luster dimmed for ages—a lamentable fate.

At the dawn of the Shenlong era, he fled back to Shu. There, pointing to a plum tree, his mother gave birth to Boyang. On the night of his conception, the Star of Venus entered her dream, so he was named *Bai* ("White") and styled *Taibai* ("Great White"). His essence was indeed that of the planet.

He scorned books not of the sages and disdained the compositions of Zheng and Wei. Thus, his words often resembled the speech of celestial immortals. All his writings brimmed with admonition and inspiration. Since the Three Dynasties, after the *Feng* and *Sao*, he galloped past Qu and Song, lashed Yang and Ma, and stood alone for a thousand years—none but he.

Thus, princes and lords hastened to follow his wind; mountains and rivers aligned their paths. Scholars gathered like birds flocking to the phoenix. Lu, the Minister of the Yellow Gate, said: “Chen Shiyi stemmed the tide of decay, and the literary world transformed as one. Even now, court poetry retains the style of the Liang and Chen palace chambers. But with Li Bai’s great transformation, all was swept away. Ancient and modern anthologies fell silent, while his works spread across the Six Directions—truly, his power rivaled creation itself.”

During the Tianbao era, the imperial ancestor issued an edict summoning him to the Golden Horse Gate. The emperor alighted from his carriage to welcome him on foot, as if meeting Qi and Hao. He bestowed a seven-jeweled tray for his meal, personally ladled broth to feed him, and said: “You are a commoner, yet your name is known to me. Without long-cultivated Dao and virtue, how could you have reached this?”

He was installed in the Golden Bells Hall, moving in and out of the Hanlin Academy. The emperor consulted him on state affairs, and he secretly drafted edicts. Yet petty officials, envious of his talent, slandered him. His enlightened counsel went unheeded, and the emperor grew distant.

Thus, Li Bai roamed near and far, drowning himself in wine to cloud his senses. In his songs, he often invoked Mount Shu. With He Zhizhang, Cui Zongzhi, and others, he formed the "Eight Immortals of the Wine Cup." They called him the "Banished Immortal," and court officials composed hundreds of *Songs of the Banished Immortal*, most lamenting his unfulfilled aspirations.

The emperor, knowing he could not be retained, bestowed gold and sent him away. He then sought his distant cousin, Chenliu’s Investigating Censor Yan Yun, and requested the High Celestial Master Gao of Beihai to confer the Daoist registers at the Purple Ultimate Palace in Qizhou. He prepared to return to Penglai, become a feathered immortal, ride to Red Pine, and test his zither and songs. Yet in Dangtu, his heart found no joy.

“Though I am unworthy,” he said, “the Master has not abandoned me.” They shared a small boat in delight. As he neared retirement, Li Bai hastily compiled a hundred scrolls on herbs, leaving his work unfinished. On his deathbed, he entrusted the manuscripts to me, bidding me write a preface.

Discussing the *Book of Changes*, I am shamed before Bu Shang; expounding the *Spring and Autumn Annals*, I pale beside Du Yu. Since the Central Plains fell into turmoil, I have taken refuge for eight years. Of my writings from that time, nine-tenths are lost. What remains has been gathered from others.

This was written on the *jiyou* day of the eleventh month, the first year of the Baoying era.

In the early years of Emperor Xianzong’s Yuanhe era, a man at sea witnessed Li Taibai conversing and laughing with a Daoist atop a high mountain. After some time, the Daoist rode a crimson rainbow through the emerald mist and departed. Taibai leapt up, strode vigorously, and caught up with him, mounting the rainbow together and vanishing.

Later, Li Guinian arrived at Mount Song. From afar, he saw the eastern cliffs draped in ancient trees, their canopies like curtains stretching to the ground. As he approached, tables laden with vessels and offerings came into view. A man stepped forward and said, “Li Hanlin summons you.” Guinian hastened forward, whereupon the man—robed in flowing garments, his complexion radiant and hair lustrous—declared, “I am Li Bai. Your ancestor was Bai Juyi. Though we lived in different eras, we were men of the same age. Our Dao being the same, we now commune across time. Since my release from the waters, I have wandered freely among mountains and rivers, but longing for my homeland drew me back to the peaks of Song. The Celestial Emperor submitted a memorial on my behalf, and I was summoned here to oversee memorials and petitions—a century has passed. Recently, I passed through Tong Pass and composed a lyric:

*Once in the peach-blossom caves so deep,*
*A phoenix danced to a song divine.*
*Still I recall the parting hour,*
*Moonlight and fallen blooms, the mist so fine—*
*Like a dream, like a dream.*

With tears, I saw you off at the gate.”

Guinian asked, “Where is my ancestor now?”
“He resides on Mount Wutai, overseeing merit and virtue—fulfilling his long-held aspiration.”

The man then presented Guinian with a scroll, saying, “Read this, and you may discern the speech of the nine heavens’ birds and the earth’s beasts. Cultivate further merits, and you too may attain immortality.”

Later, Guinian traveled to Youzhou. The prefect, learning of his extraordinary arts, summoned him for inquiry. As two sparrows chirped past the courtyard, the prefect asked, “What do they say?”
Guinian replied, “They speak of grain left uncovered west of the city—they feast upon it.”
The prefect sent men to verify, and it was so.

Then, a tethered horse raised its head and neighed. The prefect asked, “And what does this one say?”
“It complains the trough’s feed is too hot to eat.”
Again, they checked, and it was true.

As the Qingming Festival neared, officials herded over twenty sheep. One lagged behind, refusing to move, and cried out when struck. The prefect asked, “Why does the sheep resist?”
Guinian answered, “It says it carries a lamb and begs to give birth before facing slaughter.”
The prefect kept the sheep for over a month, and indeed, it bore a lamb.

Afterward, Guinian wandered beyond the frontier, and his whereabouts became unknown.

White Haiqiong said: "Li Bai now serves as the Overseer of Pure Transcendence in the Upper Clarity of the Eastern Florescence, while Bai Letian has become the Perpetual Immortal Governor of Penglai."

*Compendium of Perfected Immortals Through the Ages Who Embodied the Dao, Scroll Thirty-Seven Concluded*
*Compendium of Perfected Immortals Through the Ages Who Embodied the Dao, Scroll Thirty-Eight*

**Master Liu Xuanhe**

The Master’s surname was Liu, his given name Xuanhe, and his style Hunchenzi. His ancestors hailed from Pengcheng, but with the Jin dynasty’s southward migration, they settled in Duchang of Jiujiang—now under the jurisdiction of Nankang Prefecture. His father and forebears were scholars who delighted in the Dao and the rustic life of gardens and fields.

In the second year of Emperor Ming of Tang’s Kaiyuan reign, the Master was born. From childhood, he was keenly perceptive, and as he grew, he stood apart from the crowd. After fulfilling the rites of filial piety upon his parents’ passing, he was nearly forty when he resolved to transcend the mundane and withdraw from the world. He entered the Longxing Abbey on Mount Lu—now known as the White Crane Abbey—and paid homage to the abbot, the Three Caverns Master He Ziyu, as his teacher. In the second year of the Tianbao reign, he was ordained as a Daoist priest.

Thereafter, he had a remarkable encounter and dwelled for fifty-two years in a stone chamber on the Five Old Peaks. His resolve was unyielding through frost and dew; he consumed the fruits of pines and cypresses, swallowed the streaming rosy clouds of the two luminaries, and nurtured the jadelike elixir of the three fields. His true essence remained uncarved, and his great vessel was late in its completion. Fierce beasts guarded his hut, and spirit cranes were as tame as domesticated fowl. Such was the purity of his Dao and qi, where self and other were undisturbed, emotions and perceptions both forgotten—harmony perfected.

To the north of the mountain lay a crag, precipitous and towering. The Master planted papaya trees beneath it, and to this day, it is called Papaya Crag. The terrain is perilous, and few people reach it. One day, the Master descended to the west of the abbey, where he planted pines and cypresses, dug an elixir well, and drew water to heal the sick—many were cured. In the courtyard stood an ancient cedar, a hundred feet tall, also planted by the Master’s own hand.

During the Zhenyuan era of Emperor Dezong, Wu Yuanji rebelled, and disorderly troops ravaged the Huai region. The military governor of Hongzhou dispatched his aide, Wang Gou, to present a memorial to the capital, but he was seized by bandits from the Huai.

Wang Gou’s family came to the mountain in grief and knelt before the Master, who said: “Within the abbey dwell the Two Perfected Lords, Controller of Destinies and Recorder of Deeds—attendants of the Jade Emperor. You must pray with utmost sincerity, and I shall present a memorial on your behalf.” Soon after, two divine beings escorted Wang Gou away, their chariots and steeds racing a thousand *li* in an instant, and thus he escaped peril and returned home. This was the proof of the Master’s memorial.

From then on, court and commoner alike revered him, and eminent figures of the age bowed in homage. Yet the Master remained serene and silent, emptying himself to aid others, seeking nothing from the world. At the age of eighty-six, on the eighteenth day of the tenth month in the tenth year of the Zhenyuan era, he suddenly turned to his disciple Fan Xianzhou and said: “I have long dwelled on the Five Elders Peak, but now I shall journey to Golden Florescence. My name is recorded in the Mystic Register, and I must depart. You and the others must devote yourselves to the Dao with diligence, lest you sink into ruin.” With these words, he passed away. Following his instructions, his disciples concealed his sword beneath the Wutong Altar. On the day of his departure, white cranes circled and cried, thunder rumbled in a cloudless sky, and a rare fragrance filled the air. When they examined the coffin, they found it empty—only his shoes remained, which they buried at Crow’s Crag.

Later, Fan Xianzhou and the others erected a grand hall to honor him. Fan Xianzhou himself later attained the Dao, and none knew his end.

**Yang Taiming**
Yang Taiming, styled the Filial Son, was of unknown origin. A scholar by training, he served his parents with utmost devotion and was thus called Yang the Filial. He once served as a retainer to Prince Guo Ziyi of Fenyang, living with indifference to rank and wealth. He often advised Guo: “Though military governance demands strictness, human life is of utmost weight—one must not kill lightly.” For over twenty years, Guo Ziyi commanded troops without arbitrary executions, and his soldiers loved him as a father or elder brother—all due to Yang’s influence.

Yet Yang felt that endless warfare wounded the heart of compassion. He resigned to become Prefect of Chang’an. In the first year of the Yongtai era of Emperor Daizong, he donned Daoist robes, abandoned his post, and vanished into seclusion. First, he hid on Mount Mao, but finding it too shallow, he came to the summit of Mount Lu, where he built a hut, prepared azure-essence rice, and practiced grain avoidance. He crafted pine and wutong incense and prayed to the Perfected King, Envoy of the Nine Heavens, seeking the Dao of immortality. After fourteen years, on a clear autumn night when the moon was full, the sky vast and serene, he suddenly beheld a divine being at his place of worship—clad in a golden crown and crimson robe, adorned with strands of white pearls. Beside him stood one bearing a jade axe and another holding a jade casket.

The divine being said: “I am the Envoy of the Nine Heavens, sent to survey the good and evil of the world. For your lifelong service to the people, your pure and ascetic heart, and your unwavering devotion to the Dao, your sincerity has reached the Nine Heavens. The Three Primordial Lords of Jade Purity and Great Simplicity have commanded me to bestow upon you the *Scripture of the Supreme Great Cavern*, also called the *Nine Heavens Perfected Dao Scripture*.” Yang Taiming prostrated himself in gratitude. The divine being slowly opened the jade casket and presented him with the sacred text, then warned: “Remain steadfast in your practice to the end. When the Dao is perfected, I shall summon you.” With these words, wind and clouds surged, and the being vanished. Opening the scripture, Yang found it to be the *Thirty-Nine Chapters of the Supreme Great Cavern Scripture*, also titled the *Nine Heavens Perfected Dao Scripture*.

From then on, Yang followed the scripture’s teachings, shunning the dust of the world. Thirty-six years later, on the first day of the first month in the eighth year of the Yuanhe era of Emperor Xianzong, auspicious clouds gathered before his hut at noon. Yang ascended upon the clouds and departed.

**Li He**
Li He, styled Changji, was a descendant of the Prince of Zheng and a scion of the Later Tang royal house.

At seven, he could compose literary works. Han Yu and Huangfu Ti, upon first hearing of this, did not believe it. They visited his home and asked him to compose a poem. He took up his brush and finished it at once, entitling it *"A Lofty Chariot Passes By."* The two were astounded, and from then on, his name was known. He was slender and frail, with connected eyebrows, long fingernails, and could write with great speed. Whenever he went out, he rode a weak horse, followed by a young servant carrying an antique brocade satchel. Whenever inspiration struck, he would write it down and toss it into the satchel. Upon returning home at dusk, his mother would search the satchel, and seeing the abundance of writings, would exclaim in anger: "This child will vomit out his very heart before he is done!" Because his father’s name was Jin Su, he refused to take the imperial examinations. Han Yu wrote *"On Taboo Names"* on his behalf, yet in the end, he still did not sit for the exams.

His diction favored the strange and uncanny. What he produced was so startling and transcendent that it left the well-trodden paths of brush and ink far behind—no one of his time could imitate him. He composed several dozen *yuefu* poems, which the musicians of the *Yunshao* orchestra set to strings and pipes, and he was appointed Assistant Director of Music. He died at twenty-seven—some say at twenty-four—having never risen above the rank of Assistant in the Court of Imperial Sacrifices.

As Li He lay dying, he suddenly saw in broad daylight a man in dark robes riding a red steed, holding a tablet inscribed with characters resembling ancient seal script or the markings of thunder-struck stone. The man said: "I have come by the Emperor’s command to summon Li Changji." Li He, unable to read the script, knelt by his bed and kowtowed, saying: "My mother is old and ill. I do not wish to go." The dark-robed man laughed and said: "The Emperor has completed a white jade tower and summons you to compose its record. There is music in heaven—it is no hardship." Li He wept alone, though all around him saw it. Soon after, he breathed his last. From the window of his room, a billowing smoke arose, and the sounds of rumbling chariots and piping flutes filled the air. His mother hastily ordered the mourners to stop weeping and waited as if cooking five *dou* of millet.

*The Xuan Shi Zhi* records: After Li He’s death, his mother dreamed of him saying: "The Supreme Emperor has recently established a capital in the Cinnabar Garden and built a White Jade Palace. He has summoned me to compose the record of the new palace. He has also constructed the Hall of Congealed Emptiness and commands me to compile its musical chapters." Xuanyuan Mi Ming...

The Daoist of Mount Heng, Xuanyuan Miming, was a man of unknown origin who dwelled in the region between Heng and Xiang for over ninety years. *The Comprehensive Gazetteer of Southern Sacred Peak* states: "Linglu Peak is none other than the peak of the mountain, situated west of the Xiang River, a blessed land of the Twenty Caves and the abode of immortals. During the Song Dynasty, it was bestowed the name Jingde, and in the reign of Emperor Huizong, it was renamed the Longevity Palace of Mount Lu. Xuanyuan Miming once secluded himself here."

Skilled in capturing spectral beings, he imprisoned jiao dragons, glass tigers, and leopards. None knew his true age. The scholar Liu Shifu once encountered him south of the Xiang. On the fourth day of the twelfth month in the seventh year of the Yuanhe era of Emperor Xianzong’s reign, Miming traveled from Mount Heng past Mount Taibai, knowing Shifu was in a certain town. That night, he arrived at Shifu’s dwelling to lodge.

The editorial scholar Hou Xi had recently taken in a poetic guest. As Shifu and Xi gathered around the stove to discuss poetry, Miming sat among them. His appearance was exceedingly coarse, and he spoke in the Chu dialect, so Xi regarded him with disdain. Miming suddenly straightened his robes, fixed his gaze, and pointed to the stone tripod in the stove, saying to Xi: "Since you are a poet, can you compose a verse with me on this?"

Shifu, having known Miming from Heng and Xiang, saw only his age and treated him with superficial respect, unaware of his literary talent. Xi, pleased by the proposal, began with the first line: *"A skillful craftsman severs the mountain’s bone, / Carving its core for boiling and searing."* He then passed it to Xi, who eagerly continued: *"The straight handle holds no power, / Its mouth sealed, it swallows its own sound."*

Miming laughed soundlessly and said: "Is this all your poetry amounts to?" He then tucked his hands into his sleeves, hunched his shoulders, and leaned against the northern wall, saying to Shifu: "I do not understand the books of the worldly. Write for me." Thereupon, he intoned loudly: *"The dragon’s head shrinks like a slug, / The pig’s belly swells like Peng Xian."* Though seemingly careless, his words carried a veiled mockery of Xi. The two men exchanged glances, ashamed and startled, and pressed him further.

Shifu then said: *"Its outer layer bears the pattern of dry moss, / Within, dark waves stir in alarm."* Xi followed: *"Though its feet are delicate, it stands firm, / Even when scorched, its resolve remains unshaken."* Miming instructed Shifu to write: *"Mistakenly placed among tripods, / It recklessly pits water against fire."* Shifu replied: *"Its courage is like that of a stalwart warrior, / Round as the tassel of an iron-clad steed."* Xi added: *"Above, it rivals the peak of an incense burner, / Below, it mirrors the flatness of a mirror’s face."*

Miming said: *"Like an autumn melon clinging to its stem, / Or a frozen taro forcing its sprouts."* Shifu continued: *"A lump of primordial qi sealed within, / A slender spring pouring from a hidden crevice."* Xi said: *"Unworthy of the place where offerings are poured, / How could it know the purity of one’s heart?"* Miming replied: *"Just as a great furnace blazes, / So too does a petty vessel brim."* Shifu said: *"Its edges are bladeless, / Its form, like heaven’s own crafting."* Xi added: *"From afar, it seems a tortoise bearing a diagram, / Emerging to bask in the morning’s clear light."*

Miming said: *"Beside it, a single ear is pierced, / Above, a lone topknot juts."* Shifu said: *"Some marvel at its short tail’s leap, / Others liken it to a footless cauldron."* Xi said: *"What a pity, like a cold-food ball, / Cast aside by the roadside ditch."* Miming replied: *"When will it emerge from the ash pit? / No way to escape the jar’s confinement."* Shifu said: *"Its crude form bears the weight of pouring, / Its narrow midst shames the act of lifting."* Xi said: *"How could it boil the elixir of immortals? / Yet it has not sullied the lamb’s broth."*

Miming said: *"Its shape invites women’s laughter, / Its capacity is as light as a child’s."* Shifu said: *"In vain its unyielding nature, / It holds no more than a sheng or a ge."* Xi said: *"From the side, it resembles an upturned broken wheel, / From another, a snapped axle lies crosswise."* Miming said: *"At times, through the holes of an earthworm, / It faintly hums like a fly."* Shifu said: *"Though it spills over with excess, / It truly fails in its appointed task."* Xi said: *"Ever dwelling in the corner of the path, / How dare it harbor thoughts of leakage?"*

Miming said: *"Better to cling to warmth and decay, / Than to share the fate of the frozen."* Shifu said: *"In vain it strives to serve, / Too trifling to be presented."* Xi said: *"It turns and turns, ever motionless, / Opening and closing with a clank."* Xi’s thoughts grew increasingly strained, desperate to surpass Miming. Each time he searched for words, his voice grew more pained; each time he lifted his brush, he hesitated, and in the end, nothing remarkable emerged.

The two men composed over ten couplets, while Miming responded instantaneously, each line sharp and laced with mockery. As the night deepened, the two exhausted their thoughts and could no longer continue. They rose and bowed, saying: "Master, you are no ordinary man—we yield. We wish to join your disciples and dare not discuss poetry further."

Miming, roused, declared: "This poem must be completed." Turning to Shifu, he said: "Take up your brush. I will finish it with you." Then he recited: *"Far surpassing the precious coral, / Yet only a name passed by word of mouth. / Though it graces ancient sacrificial vessels, / It is not held in the hand as a root. / Polished to remove its edges, / Steeped until it gleams with light. / I hope you will not mock it— / This vessel is now in use."*

Shifu wrote it down and had them read it. He asked the two: "Is the poem not yet complete?" Both replied in unison: "It is complete." Miming said: "Neither of you is worthy of my words. Is this truly literature? I have composed within the limits of your abilities, not what I have learned from my masters. What I have heard, you are not fit to hear. Is it only in writing? Even my speech is not commonly heard. I shall close my mouth now."

The two men, greatly alarmed, rose and bowed, saying: "We dare not ask further questions. We only wish to hear a single word." They asked: "Master, you claim not to understand the books of men. Then what books do you understand?" He gave no answer. Discomfited, they withdrew to their seats.

Miming leaned against the wall and fell asleep, his snores rumbling like thunder. The two men turned pale with dread and dared not even breathe. Soon after, the two also succumbed to exhaustion and dozed off. When they awoke, Miming was gone. They heard a servant boy say: "Dawn is near. The Daoist has left the house—he is nowhere to be found." The two, astonished, took the poem and sought out Han Yu to inquire about the man. Han Yu said: "I have heard of a reclusive gentleman named Miming—could this be him?" Thereupon, he composed the *Preface to Linked Verses on the Stone Tripod*.

Miming once passed by the Eight Cassia Yao Temple, where his calligraphy remained. Later generations carved it into stone, recording: "During the reign of Emperor Lizong of the Song, the state historian of Xiaoshan, Ze, wrote *Record of Miming’s Newly Established Hermitage on Mount Heng*, which states: *The Water Curtain Grotto is the most secluded spot of the Southern Marchmount. On the last day of the seventh month in the second year of the Duanping era, Ze of Xiaoshan in Jiangxi visited at dawn and, captivated by its purity, lingered past noon without leaving. Three fellow Daoists grew weary, their servants hungry and seeking food—all departed. I sat alone in the Tianni Pavilion, chanting verses: ‘The old tree’s shade, a weary traveler’s rest / The cold spring, a wanderer’s hunger-quenching rinse.’*"

A recluse with a topknot, leaning on a staff, emerged from the ravine and inquired about the verses I had chanted. Taking the first line I had recited, he immediately responded with a matching couplet: *"This mountain’s vastness holds boundless space— / Lightly chant no verse in haste."* His features were delicate yet ancient. I asked his origin, and he replied: *"The Western White Tortoise dwells in the Land of White Waters."* When I pressed for his name, he gave none. Instead, he plucked a fallen pine needle and inscribed upon the cliff: *"Heaven sent me in the Tang, / Sun and moon illuminate me, / Han Yu knows me."* Suddenly, he drew from his sleeve a stalk of grass, coral-like in form, and said: *"Are you hungry? Eat this."* Then he strode away. Suspecting him to be no ordinary man, I hurried after him and asked: *"What elixir did you just leave me?"* He did not turn back. Upon consulting the *Classic of Materia Medica*, I found that red lingzhi grows on Mount Heng—this must have been a kind of lingzhi.

Later, the Daoist Luo Zhizhen invited me to the White Tortoise Spring, and I realized it was the very White Water Spring! *"Yu"* (愈) combined with *"mi"* (弥) forms *"Ming"* (明), and *"sun and moon"* (日月) also make *"Ming"*—surely this was Miming. I asked Zhizhen: *"Has this old man appeared by the spring?"* He replied: *"No, but who can say he does not dwell unseen beneath this roof?"* So we fashioned an image of him by the spring and established a shrine.

Some say Miming was none other than Han Yu himself. Alas, the old man had already told me as much. Others claim his legacy rests in the *Stone Cauldron Linked Verses* and Han Yu’s preface, not in a shrine. Alas, though the old man has passed through countless kalpas, the karmic habit of speech lingers untransformed, and his lofty, disdainful air toward Magistrate Liu remains unsoftened. From the Yuanhe era of the Tang to this day, the mountain has forgotten him entirely. I was fortunate to encounter him, and Zhizhen fortunate to heed me. To soothe the spirit is one purpose; to fill the mountain’s missing records is another. Was this fated? I commissioned the hermitage of Miming’s companion to inscribe a plaque, and composed a Chu song to summon him:

*"The simurgh leads the way, the swan-drawn chariot soars—
To the Great White Peak, what path shall we meet?
The stone cauldron’s words are small, yet their fame towers high,
Above the peaks of Heng, his name ascends the sky.
O immortal, when shall you return?
Your song defies age beneath the southern heavens’ turn.
How many scrolls lie hidden in the mountain’s keep?
The wooden wings’ secrets lost, no trace to reap.
Within the cauldron’s depths, immortal traces gleam,
Mortal bones shed, his form like a dream.
We offer jade blossoms, the cinnabar’s flow,
Awakening the numinous, stirring the soul’s glow."*

In the second year of the Chunyou era, I further inscribed the *Illustration of the Stone Cauldron Linked Verses*, noting: *"A Tang scholar, reading Jia Dao’s stele, remarked: ‘The Miming of the *Stone Cauldron Linked Verses* is none other than Jia Dao himself.’ But Jia Dao was a Buddhist monk from Fanyang, while Miming was a Daoist from Mount Heng—they do not align. The stele’s claim is baseless; how can it be trusted?"*

Liu Shang, a native of Pengcheng, settled in Chang’an. Diligent in study, he excelled in memorization and literary composition. His *Eighteen Stanzas of the Barbarian Reed-Pipe* circulated widely, recited even by women and children. Passing the imperial examinations, he served in the central bureaucracy, rising to the rank of Gentleman.

His nature was deeply drawn to Daoist arts; whenever he encountered a Daoist, he would take them as his master, diligently practicing alchemy and qi-absorption without exception. Often he lamented how fleeting time was, how his sinews and bones gradually weakened, how he rushed about from dawn to dusk, only to exhaust himself—what benefit did the floating glory of worldly office bring to him? The ancient worthies all abandoned their posts to seek the Dao, many attaining transcendence. Now that his children’s marriages were settled and he was no longer burdened by worldly ties, how was he inferior to Xu of the Far Wanderings? Thus, feigning illness, he resigned his post and entered the Daoist path.

Traveling to Guangling, he encountered a Daoist selling medicine on a city street, drawing crowds with meals, and many spoke of its miraculous efficacy. Among the throng, the Daoist fixed his gaze on Liu Shang with unusual intensity, then set aside his medicines, took his hand, and ascended to a tavern’s upper floor, where they drank in celebration. The Daoist’s discourse spanned events from the Qin and Han dynasties, as if he had witnessed them firsthand. Liu Shang was astonished; he immediately took him as his master and paid him reverence. The Daoist then said: "The Way of divine transcendence cannot be attained so easily." As dusk fell, Liu Shang returned to his lodging, while the Daoist descended the stairs—vanishing without a trace. Liu Shang was even more bewildered. The next day, he searched the marketplace again, where the Daoist was still selling medicine. Seeing Liu Shang, he grew even more delighted, once more leading him to the wine tavern, where they drank deeply and talked animatedly. Producing a small medicine pouch, he presented it to Liu Shang with a playful chant:

*"Should you find yourself in Yangzhou with naught to do,
Come, let us climb the tavern’s stair anew.
This pouch I gift you as we part—
What more could one desire through endless years apart?"*

Liu Shang memorized the words and received the pouch. That evening, they parted. Later, when Liu Shang sought him again, the Daoist was nowhere to be found. Opening the pouch, he found layer upon layer of paper wrapping a gourd, inside which were nine pills resembling sesame seeds. Following the Daoist’s oral instructions, he swallowed them and suddenly felt his spirit invigorated, hunger dispelled, his body light and buoyant. Crossing the river, he traveled to Mount Mao, then later to Zhanggong Cave in Yixing. In springtime, enamored of the scenery by the Hu Stream near his thatched hut, he entered Hufu Islet, secluding himself in the mountains. Nearby woodcutters still glimpsed him, saying: "That is Gentleman Liu." No one knew where he ultimately went—he had already become an earthbound immortal.

---

Liu Shi
Liu Shi, whose childhood name was Yige, was the elder brother of Liu Zhan. Born into poverty yet devoted to the Dao, he often encountered Daoists passing by his home. One Daoist, seeing something extraordinary in him, asked if he understood the Dao. "I do," he replied. Yet the Daoist observed: "Your nature still carries too much worldly qi, and your karmic obstacles have not been smoothed—how can you force yourself to study?" Liu Shi asked: "Could I take you as my master?" The Daoist replied: "Would you dare?" Thereupon, he became his disciple and followed him into Luofu Mountain.

Liu Shi and Liu Zhan both studied books, but while Liu Shi dwelled in the mountains seeking the Dao—eschewing headscarves, wearing hempen clothes, and serving the Daoist as a scribe—Liu Zhan aspired to glory and officialdom. Liu Shi told him: "If he fails the examinations, he will wander the mountains and wilds; if he passes, he will toil in the dust of the world. Yet beware of wealth and rank—within forty years, this will be proven." Liu Zhan said: "The immortals are distant and hard to seek. Even Qin Shihuang and Han Wudi spared no effort, yet the halls of power are within reach. It is easier to become a Ma Zhou or Zhang Jiuling." Thereafter, Liu Shi devoted himself even more intensely to the Dao, eventually secluding himself on Luofu Mountain.

Liu Zhan passed the imperial examinations and held a series of prestigious posts, rising to the rank of chief minister, where he earned a reputation for harmonizing governance. Later, he was demoted and sent south. While mooring his boat by the riverside at Chaotai in Guangzhou, a youth with hempen clothes and unbound hair suddenly appeared through a torrential downpour—his robes and shoes untouched by rain—and sought to see him. The attendants were astonished and announced: "Yige has come." Reporting this to Liu Zhan and describing the visitor’s appearance, Liu Zhan was struck with wonder and rushed to greet him. Liu Shi appeared no older than twenty, while Liu Zhan, now a disgraced official, had grown frail and aged. Overcome with grief and joy, Liu Shi consoled him: "We are brothers, bound as flesh and bone. I grieve that my words of old have come to pass—forty years have now elapsed." Liu Zhan, sighing deeply, asked: "Can I still cultivate the Dao?" Liu Shi replied: "You have long basked in honor and glory, charged with harmonizing yin and yang. How could your thoughts and actions not have taken their toll? Unless I intervene, what can be done? Even if I had ascended as a celestial immortal, how could I save you? I have come only to bid you farewell, not to rescue you." They boarded the same boat, reminiscing about their long separation, and by the next morning, Liu Shi had vanished. To this day, he is occasionally seen on Luofu Mountain. Liu Zhan continued his journey south and died in exile.

---

Luo Wanxiang
Luo Wanxiang’s origins are unknown. A man of letters, well-versed in astronomy and profoundly skilled in the *Book of Changes*, he was of extraordinary integrity, wandering the world as a commoner. He dwelled on Wangwu Mountain for many years, then later traveled to Luofu Mountain, where he sighed: "This is the Cave Heaven of Vermilion Brightness, where Ge Zhichuan once refined his elixir. Though Deng Yue is no longer here to detain me, I shall linger awhile." Enamored of the scenery at Stone Tower, he built a thatched hut at the mountain’s foot and took up residence. For decades, he consumed yellow essence, practiced qi-absorption in his hut, and occasionally ventured to Zengcheng, Quanshan, or the waters below Bushui to gather herbs. He also traveled to the cities of Fujian and Guangdong, selling medicine and drinking wine, coming and going without fixed routine. Sometimes he ate enough for ten men; other times, he fasted for months or years. Light and agile, he could cover three or four hundred *li* in a day, outpacing galloping horses even at a leisurely pace. Later, he returned to his hut by Stone Tower and never emerged again, secluding himself in the mountains.

---

Yin Wenxiang
Yin Wenxiang, also named Daoquan, commonly called Qiqi, was known to many by this name, though his origins are unknown. He wandered the world, and though people saw him for many years, none could fathom his age. His face was fair and bright, as if he were a man of forty. Wherever he went, he often changed his name, never settling in one place.

Once, he sold medicine in Jingzhou. At the time, both the Tibetan and Han populations in Lingtai suffered severely from epidemics, but those who took his remedies recovered instantly, and all called him divine. He would distribute any money he earned to others, yet often remained drunk in the city streets. Zhou Bao met him in Chang’an and later, upon becoming the Jingyuan military governor, invited him with great reverence, admiring his arts of Daoist cultivation and return to the primordial. When Zhou Bao was transferred to govern Zhexi, after several years, Qiqi suddenly reappeared, again selling medicine. Hearing this, Bao was overjoyed and hastily summoned him, treating him with even greater veneration. Whenever Qiqi was drunk, he would sing:

*"In a moment, wine is brewed,
In an instant, flowers bloom.
The zither plays the tune of ‘Green Jade,’
The furnace refines cinnabar bright."*

Bao tested these claims, and all proved true. Qiqi’s other arts—planting melons, angling for fish—resembled those of the immortal Ge Xianweng.

At Hulín Temple, a azalea tree stood over a *zhang* tall. Each late spring, its blossoms would burst into riotous color. Monks said that during the Zhenyuan era of Emperor Dezong of Tang, a foreign monk had brought its roots in his alms bowl, nourished with some elixir, and planted them. Thereafter, the temple adorned the flower courtyard and kept it locked. Some who peered inside claimed to see women in crimson robes, radiant and lovely, wandering beneath the tree. Anyone who plucked a flower or broke a branch would invariably come to harm. The locals called them the flower spirits, and thus all protected the tree, which bloomed more luxuriantly than ordinary flowers. When the blossoms were about to open, scouts would report their progress, and the military governor, his guests, and officials would gather daily to admire them. Later, the entire city—men and women, people from all directions—would follow with wine and music, reveling from spring into summer, from dawn till dusk, until the streets and alleys nearly abandoned their livelihoods.

One day, Bao said to Qiqi: *"The flowers of Hulín Temple are the most wondrous in the world. I’ve heard you can make flowers bloom out of season—could you do so with these?"*
Qiqi replied: *"I can."*
Bao said: *"The Double Ninth Festival is near. Could you make them bloom by then?"*
Qiqi agreed. Three days before the festival, he went to Hulín Temple to spend the night. At midnight, a woman appeared and said: *"Daoist, do you wish to make these flowers bloom?"*
Qiqi asked: *"Who comes here in the dead of night?"*
The woman replied: *"I was sent by the Supreme Mystery to tend these flowers in the mortal realm. I have been here over a hundred years, and soon I must return to the gardens of heaven. Today, I will bloom them with you—none but you could move me to do so."* With that, she vanished.

The next morning, the temple monks were astonished to see the flowers gradually unfurling their buds. By the ninth day, they burst into full, riotous bloom, as splendid as in spring or summer. After several days, the flowers suddenly vanished—no petals littered the ground.

Later, Qiqi happened to visit the home of an official, arriving just as a banquet was underway. The host and guests hurried to greet him, but some entertainers and courtesans present mocked him. Qiqi said: *"The host wishes to use two chestnuts as a drinking game—will that do?"* All agreed, expecting some amusing trick to enliven the feast. He passed the chestnuts around, and those who sniffed them detected a strange, wondrous fragrance and gasped in awe. Only two who had laughed at Qiqi smelled them and turned to stone, their noses stuck fast. They cried out that the stench was unbearable. The two leapt up, dancing wildly, their hairpins scattering, tears mingling with their powder and rouge. The other performers began dancing in chaos, music playing of its own accord, perfectly in time. The song would end, but the dance never ceased. The entire gathering collapsed in laughter.

After some time, the host pleaded with Qiqi for mercy. Soon after, the stone fell from their noses, and the chestnuts reappeared. When passed around again, they still bore the same strange fragrance, and the hairpins and cosmetics were restored, unharmed. Some thereafter treated Qiqi with reverence.

Qiqi could also turn water into wine, carve wood into dried meat, make people walk backward until he told them to stop, or halt a boat with a command. He called birds to follow him, spat on fish to revive them, and by pinching earth and drawing on the ground, could shape mountains and rivers. He would break reeds to gather ants, transforming them into cities and people. Those who had traveled the places he depicted said they matched perfectly—only smaller. His wonders were too numerous to record.

Two years later, Xue Xuan and Liu Hao rebelled, and Bao Nan fled to Hangzhou. Bao Zongrong, who commanded the troops, governed with harsh justice, and his punishments often fell upon the innocent. Former Prefect of Shangrao, Chen Quanyu, passed through his territory and was framed for disaster—his entire clan was executed in a bloodbath. Bao, at eighty-three, remained vigorous in sinew and strength, with a hundred female entertainers in his service, having acquired Qiqi’s arts. Later, as retribution for the innocent and for Quanyu’s wrongful death, he suddenly perished in a single day.

During the mutiny of Liu Hao’s army, Qiqi was pushed off the northern cliff of Ganlu Temple by the mob and presumed drowned in the river. Yet years later, he was seen in Jiangxi, selling medicines and traveling into Shu, his whereabouts ultimately unknown. The flowers of Hulun Temple, their roots lost when the temple burned in the war, had truly returned to the gardens of the immortals.

---

Tan Qiaoyan was a Daoist of Mount Mao. During the Baoli era of Emperor Jingzong of Tang, he traveled through Tiantai, Jiang, and Zhe, his appearance that of a man barely twenty. None knew he possessed the Way; he devoted himself to hidden acts of kindness, often leaving gold on the roads to aid the poor. If thanked, he would not acknowledge it. Asked why, he replied: “The Perfected Lord of the Hidden transforms earth into gold to relieve want—I regret I cannot do the same. To seek gratitude with useless things is no wonder.” Over time, people learned of his arts: he transmuted roof tiles into elixirs with divine cinnabar and commanded ghosts and spirits with talismans.

Once, discussing Emperor Yang of Sui’s eastern progress, Qiaoyan inadvertently remarked: “When the Dan River was dug in the Daye era, three ridges were severed, and blood flowed beneath—I once went to see it.” From this, it became clear that Qiaoyan had lived for several centuries.

His disciple Deng Jia served him for many years and was taught the secrets of alchemy and talismanic arts, though he could not master their full subtlety. He could only subdue tigers on land and bind jiao and li in water. Qiaoyan told him: “A person’s allotment is fixed by fate. Water and stone may be made hot, but fire cannot make them cold. Though you exhaust my Way, this is all you will achieve.” In the Kaicheng era of Emperor Wenzong, he ascended lightly to Mount Nanyue.

---

*Comprehensive Mirror of Perfected Immortals Who Embodied the Dao, Volume 38 (concluded)*

*Comprehensive Mirror of Perfected Immortals Who Embodied the Dao, Volume 39*

Ye Fashan, styled Daoyuan, was a native of Kuocang in Chuzhou and came from a family of Daoists. His mother, née Liu, napped one day and dreamed of a shooting star entering her mouth; she swallowed it and conceived. After fifteen months, she gave birth. At seven, he drowned in the great river for three years before returning. His parents asked why, and he said: “The Azure Lad led me to drink cloud-essence and pay court to the Most High—thus my brief delay.” When he came of age, he stood nine feet tall, his nature simple and sincere, and he abstained from meat.

He received the arts of concealment from Zhao Yuanyang of Qingcheng and the *Eight Histories* from Wei Shanjun of Songyang, thereafter mastering the suppression of ghosts and spirits. He chose to dwell on the Mao-You Mountain, where a massive boulder blocked the road, forcing travelers to take a detour. He cast a talisman, and the stone rose of its own accord.

Once, while traveling on White Horse Mountain, he encountered three divine beings in a stone chamber, all clad in brocade and jeweled crowns. They told Fashan: “We bear the Most High’s secret decree: you are the Left Immortal Minister of the Purple Tenuity of the Great Ultimate, demoted to the mortal realm for negligence in recording merits. Hasten to perform deeds, aid the people, and assist the state—you shall regain your original post. We now transmit to you the methods of the Orthodox Unity of the Three and Five. Strive to practice them.” With that, they departed. Thereafter, his sincerity dispelled all manner of malevolent forces, and his arts proved unfailingly efficacious.

Emperor Gaozong of the Tang, having heard of his reputation, favored him with an official post, but Fashan declined and requested instead to be ordained as a Daoist priest. He was retained in the palace’s inner chambers for rituals, and the emperor bestowed upon him lavish gifts. At the time, the emperor had summoned all alchemists to transmute cinnabar into gold and refine elixirs. Fashan advised, “Elixirs cannot be swiftly concocted; they only waste wealth and time. I beg to distinguish the true from the false.” The emperor agreed, and over a hundred alchemists were dismissed.

Once, while performing a ritual at the Lingkong Shrine in the eastern capital, he erected an altar for sacrifice, drawing crowds of onlookers. Several dozen people rushed into the fire, causing great alarm; they were rescued just in time. Fashan smiled and said, “These were possessed by demons—my method has subdued them.” Upon inquiry, it proved true, and their illnesses were all cured.

For fifty years, spanning the reigns of Gaozong and Zhongzong, he wandered among the mountains yet was frequently summoned to court. He held no fondness for Buddhist teachings, often vehemently criticizing them, which led some to dismiss him as biased against monks. Yet none could fathom the depth of his arts.

On the ninth day of the third month in the fourth year of Jinglong under Emperor Zhongzong, the three divine beings descended again, conveying the Most High’s decree: “You shall assist Our Lord Ruizong and the Emperor of Kaiyuan.” They added, “You must not seclude yourself in remote mountains and crags, neglecting your appointed duty.” At the time, neither emperor had yet ascended the throne, yet Fashan already knew their temple names and reign titles. Thus, he secretly aided Ruizong and Minghuang.

When Tubo presented tribute, the sealed casket bore the inscription: *“Let the Emperor open this himself, lest others know.”* Fashan memorialized, “This is inauspicious—let the Tubo envoy open it.” When opened, a crossbow bolt sprang from the casket, striking the envoy dead.

In the *Xiantian* era of Ruizong, Fashan was appointed *Honglu Qing* in an honorary capacity and enfeoffed as Duke of Yue, with Jinglong Abbey as his residence. His grandfather, Chongmi, was posthumously honored as *“Master of the Dao, of Profound Virtue,”* while his father, Huiming, was posthumously appointed Governor of Shezhou, their renown shining brightly in their time. The number of officials and commoners who received his teachings was beyond count.

His granduncle, Jingneng, was a master of the Dao and skilled in composition. During the reign of Emperor Gaozu, he served in the Hanlin Academy and as Libationer of the Directorate of Education. Once, the Prince of Ruyang hosted a feast for Jingneng, who remarked, “I have a disciple who can drink—let me summon him to meet you.” The next day, a visitor announced himself: *“Daoist Chang Chiman, at your service.”* He appeared as a dwarf. They discoursed on the Dao of the primordial chaos, and when offered wine, he drank some five *dou* before suddenly collapsing—only to reveal himself as a jar.

At Qiantang, a monstrous clam drowned boats, tormenting travelers. Fashan cast a talisman into the water, and the clam perished.
