In the early *Kaiyuan* era, Emperor Minghuang, observing the Lantern Festival at the Shangyuan Palace, declared no spectacle could surpass it. Fashan replied, “Tonight’s lanterns in the Western Freezing Prefecture are nearly its equal.” The emperor, astonished, demanded to see them. Fashan bade him close his eyes, and in an instant, they arrived.

The emperor then presented him with an iron ruyi scepter as a reward for his wine, and the next day sent an envoy to retrieve it—sure enough, it was still there.

On another Mid-Autumn night, Fashan accompanied the emperor to the Lunar Palace, where they heard celestial music. When asked its name, they were told it was *"Purple Cloud Melody."* The emperor, well-versed in music, memorized it and later composed a *yuefu* piece, renaming it *"The Rainbow Skirt and Feathered Robe Dance."*

As they returned from the Moon Palace, passing over Youzhou, they looked down to see the city eerily still, bathed in moonlight as bright as day. Fashan took up a jade flute and asked the emperor to play a tune, then tossed a handful of gold coins into the city below. Within ten days, Youzhou reported that on Mid-Autumn night, celestial music had descended over the city, and gold coins were recovered and presented to the court.

For several years, Fashan resided beneath Siming Mountain and east of Tiantai. One day, on the first of the fifth month, an old man arrived at his gate, wailing and begging for help. His disciples, thinking him ill, informed their master. Fashan summoned the man and asked his trouble. The man replied, *"I am a dragon of the Eastern Sea. The Celestial Emperor commanded me to guard the treasures of the Eight Seas, with each term lasting a thousand years. Those who complete their duty without fault are enrolled among the immortals. I have served nine hundred and seventy years—my merit nearly complete. But recently, a Brahmin sorcerer, practicing illusions on the seashore, has spent thirty years chanting spells day and night. His magic is nearly perfected, and on the fifth day of the fifth month, the sea will dry up. The treasures that govern the tides and secure the seas—divine artifacts ordained by the Celestial Emperor—will surely be seized by the Brahmin. I beg you to save me with your talismanic power."* Fashan immediately dispatched a flying talisman, and the sea returned to its former state. The Brahmin, ashamed and sighing, plunged into the sea and drowned. The next day, the dragon and his kin presented treasures in gratitude, but Fashan said, *"This mountain wild is a dwelling for spirits—pearls and jewels are of no use to me."* He refused the gifts, then told the dragon, *"If you could bring a clear spring to the rocky heights, some distance from the water, it would be a fine favor."* That night, the sound of wind and rain filled the air, and by dawn, a stone channel of flowing spring water encircled the mountain hermitage. To this day, it is called *"The Celestial Master’s Channel."*

The Duke of Yan, Zhang Shuo, once drank with Fashan, who remarked, *"There is a recluse here named Gou—prudent and reticent, but deeply fond of wine. He can drink a *zhong* or a *shi* without issue."* When summoned, Gou appeared as a dwarf, his waist several spans thick, his bows and salutations clumsy. Yet whenever wine was served, he drained it without change in expression. Suddenly, Fashan rebuked him: *"You offer no lofty discourse or refined conversation—only an obsession with wine. What use are you?"* He seized Gou and lifted him—only to reveal him as a massive wine jar.

In the eighth year of *Kaiyuan*, Fashan underwent *shijie* at Jinglong Abbey. Some say he was born in the *bingzi* year of the *Daye* era of the Sui and died in the *rentu* year, living to the age of one hundred and seven. After his transformation, Emperor Minghuang, missing him, issued an edict:

*"The late Daoist Ye [Fashan], whose name and rank are known, possessed celestial purity and profound subtlety, mastering the arcane and expounding the mysteries of talismans. Though his wisdom was ineffable and his nature elusive, he dwelled in the humble abode of the Dao yet mingled with the court. He wore the yellow cap without pride and accepted the purple sash without vanity—peerless in his solitary grace, serene in his singular path."*

His vital qi transcended the mundane, his steadfast wind left no dust; his golden bones jutted outward, his pearlescent radiance shone within. Such was his embodiment of the celestial immortals, his name ascending to the highest virtue.

In moments of respite from governance, We would summon him to inquire of the supreme Dao. He, with the methods of ordering the state, repeatedly offered sagacious counsel—his plans subtle as hidden admonitions, his affairs yielding great benefit. We sigh that his noble voice has not yet faded, yet grieve that his transformation came so soon. Why must such sorrow strike, why must such goodness be cut short? In remembrance of our past sorrow, it is fitting to bestow posthumous honors, to grace his resting earth with dignity. Let him be posthumously appointed Prefect of Yuezhou. By edict, he shall be interred in Songyang, with all officials in white mourning robes weeping as they escort him beyond the city gates. His nephew, the Vice Governor of Runzhou, shall be ordained as a Daoist master.

Among his hundred-odd disciples, only Ji Qiwu and Yin Xi were deemed his true heirs.

---

**Xing Hepu**

Xing Hepu’s origins are unknown. He dwelled in seclusion near the Ying Sea, skilled in mental calculation and divination—whatever a person’s mind conceived, he could discern by casting his calculations. He settled in the region between Mount Song and the Ying River, composing the *Three Treatises of Yingyang*, which included the method of "revolving the mind through empty space." He could also revive the dead through his arts.

In the twelfth year of *Kaiyuan*, Emperor Minghuang summoned him to the capital, where the nobility and high officials flocked to his door like a marketplace. A friend of his lived at the foot of Baima Slope; when Hepu arrived, the man had already been dead for several days. As his mother mourned, Hepu laid the corpse on a bed, then lay down beside it. After sealing the room for a long while, he rose, prepared a bath, and though the man had not yet revived, Hepu lay down with him again. In a moment, the man came back to life.

There was also a certain Marshal Cui, a close friend of Hepu’s, who fell gravely ill. He lamented, *"Master, why have you abandoned me?"* Soon after, they heard a sound like a hole being bored through the wall of his bedchamber. Peering through, they saw a tiny crack, which gradually widened. A procession of several hundred attendants appeared, with one figure in purple robes and a tall hat seated in a carriage. He addressed Cui: *"Master Xing is destined to be saved by the Great Unity."* With these words, they departed, and Cui’s illness immediately improved; the hole in the wall vanished as well.

Fang Guan, serving as Magistrate of Tonglu, treated Hepu with great kindness. One day, they strolled hand in hand beyond the city gates, unknowingly walking ten *li* or more. They arrived at Xiagu Village, where an abandoned Buddhist hall stood, its pines and bamboos dense and shimmering. They sat beneath them. Hepu struck the ground with his staff and ordered his attendant to dig. After several feet, they unearthed a clay jar containing a letter from Lou Shide to Yong the Elder. Hepu laughed and asked Guan, *"Do you recall this?"* Guan’s topknot had once been a monk’s topknot in a past life—his name had been Yong. Hepu said, *"You will rise to the rank of chief minister. Take good care of yourself. Yet in the end, you will be buried in a painted coffin, with a Kuchean pall, neither in your private residence, nor at public expense, nor in a temple, nor at your in-laws’ home."* Later, Guan indeed became a chief minister, but was demoted and exiled to Guizhou, where he died of illness at the Purple Ultimate Palace.

After his condition slightly improved, the prefect summoned him to the prefectural hall, where he was served painted delicacies. Once he finished eating, his illness flared up again. That night, he dreamed of a divine being who said, *"This is the ancient truth of Master Xing."* The omen proved true. The next day, he indeed passed away. Earlier, a merchant had been dragging Kuchean planks to fashion a canopy for the Lord Lao; these were borrowed to make his coffin.

Hepu dwelled on Mount Zhongnan, and many Dao seekers gathered around him. At the time, Cui Wu and his friend served him with reverence. One day, Hepu said to his disciples, *"This evening, an unusual guest will arrive. Prepare a feast for me."* He also warned, *"Be careful not to spy on us."* The next day, a man indeed arrived—five feet tall, three feet wide, with a head occupying half his frame. Clad in coarse robes and holding a tablet, he stroked his thick beard and roared with laughter, his lips nearly touching his ears. His boisterous speech was mostly unintelligible to mortals. Cui Wu, unable to restrain his curiosity, hurried past without facing him directly. The guest fixed his gaze and asked Hepu, *"Is this not the Teacher of Mount Tai?"* Hepu replied, *"Indeed."* After eating, the guest departed.

Hepu said to Wu, *"This was the Celestial Emperor’s playful envoy. When he spoke of the Teacher of Mount Tai, did you understand?"* Wu, tears streaming, replied, *"In my youth, I heard my elders say I was the reincarnation of Master Bao, though my past life remains unclear."* Later, Hepu also vanished without a trace.

**Shen Yuanzhi**
Shen Yuanzhi was a man of unknown origins.

Shen Yuanzhi wandered among famous mountains, broadly gathering esoteric arts, and attained the Dao of inner cultivation and transcendence. During the Kaiyuan era of Emperor Xuanzong of Tang, he was summoned to the capital and installed at the Kaiyuan Abbey. At the time, Zhang Guo, Xing Hepu, Luo Gongyuan, Ye Fashan, Yin Xi, He Siyuan, Shi Chong, and Mi □ Xiyan together upheld the true wind of the Left Assistant, supporting and safeguarding the sovereign. When the emperor traveled to the hot springs or visited the eastern capital, Yuanzhi always accompanied him. Skilled in discoursing on purity and stillness, the emperor frequently summoned him for counsel, their conversations often lasting hours. Only the Noble Consort and the palace lady Zhao Yunrong, who attended the imperial morning audience, were privy to his teachings. Once, as Yunrong served tea, she repeatedly begged for an elixir to prolong her life. Yuanzhi replied, *"What I regret is only that you will not long remain in this world."* Yunrong persisted in her entreaties, and moved by her earnestness, Yuanzhi relented, giving her a single pellet of Crimson Cloud Elixir. *"If you take this,"* he said, *"your body will not decay in death. Only ensure your coffin is large, your tomb spacious, and that you are interred with pearls and jade. Leave gaps for air to circulate, so that your hun-soul does not drift into emptiness nor your po-soul sink into the depths. After a hundred years, you may be reborn. This is the Way of Refining the Form in the Great Yin—you will become an Earth Immortal, and after another century, ascend to a Grotto-Heaven."* When Yunrong fell ill at Lanchang Palace while accompanying the emperor to the eastern capital, she specifically recalled Yuanzhi’s words and consulted the Noble Consort. The emperor ordered the eunuch Chen Yuanzao to fulfill her requests and bury her accordingly. By the final years of Emperor Xianzong’s Yuanhe era, a century later, Yunrong indeed revived.

Yuanzhi, too, appeared and vanished unpredictably, styling himself Master Tian. Those who knew him claimed he was a man of the Wei dynasty, having already lived for several centuries. *The Dragon City Record* states: *"On the fifteenth day of the eighth month, Emperor Xuanzong of Tang, accompanied by Master Shen, journeyed to the Lunar Palace. The cold was piercing, and pure dew dampened their robes. Passing through a great gate, they saw within a radiance of jade a vast palace hall, its plaque reading ‘Palace of Vast Cold and Pure Emptiness.’ Soon after, they beheld over ten moon maidens in white, riding white simurghs, laughing and dancing beneath a great osmanthus tree in the broad courtyard, their music clear and exquisite. Upon his return, the emperor composed the ‘Rainbow Skirt and Feathered Robe Dance.’"* This account closely resembles one involving Ye Fashan, and both are preserved here. Another unofficial history records a similar tale in the biography of Luo Gongyuan.

**Luo Gongyuan**
The Daoist Luo Gongyuan, also named Siyuan, was a native of Ezhou. Some say he was from Jiulong County in Pengzhou. He cultivated the Dao in a hermitage at Liyuan, often traveling to Qingcheng and Luochuan to seek instruction. Having lived through the Zhou, Sui, and Tang dynasties, he reached an age of several centuries, sometimes appearing old, sometimes young, concealing his fame while remaining known far and wide.

During the Kaiyuan era of Emperor Xuanzong of Tang, in the third month of spring, the prefect of Ezhou hosted a banquet for his subordinates in the gardens of the prefectural residence. All the local gentry and commoners came to enjoy the outing. Among them appeared a man in white robes, eight or nine feet tall, his bearing majestic and dignified. The gatekeeper initially grew suspicious, but soon a young boy spotted him and rebuked him sharply: "Why have you left your proper place and come here? You should depart at once." The white-robed man immediately gathered his robes and fled. The gatekeeper seized the boy and reported the matter to the prefect, who questioned him about his family. The boy replied, "My surname is Luo, my given name Gongyuan. From childhood I have studied the Daoist arts. Just now I saw the river-dragon guardian come here, so I drove it away for Your Excellency."

The prefect remained unconvinced. "I must see its form," he insisted.

"Then I ask you to wait until the day after tomorrow," the boy replied.

When the appointed time arrived, he dug a small channel at the riverbank, barely over a foot wide, to draw in the waters of the Yangtze. The prefect and the people of the prefecture all gathered to watch. Presently, a white fish, five or six inches long, swam in with the current. As it leapt, it grew larger, its trail of mist rising like a thread. Moments later, black vapor filled the sky, obscuring everything within arm’s reach. Gongyuan addressed the prefect: "Quickly, take the people of the prefecture up to the ferry pavilion." Before they could reach it, thunder crashed, lightning flashed, and rain poured down. When the storm briefly cleared, a white dragon appeared in the river’s center, its head merging with the clouds. After the space of a meal, it vanished.

At the time, Emperor Xuanzong favored those beyond the mundane world. The prefect reported all this in full, and the emperor summoned Gongyuan. Whatever he was asked, his answers always met the emperor’s expectations.

In Jiannan, there grew a fruit called the *ri shu zi* ("sun-ripened fruit"). Zhang Guo and Ye Fashan once told the emperor that through their arts they could obtain it, saying, "It will arrive by afternoon." That day, as they sat by the brazier, Gongyuan joined them. Evening fell, yet the fruit did not come. Zhang and Ye exchanged glances. "Could it be Master Luo?" they wondered. Gongyuan smiled, reached into the brazier, and pulled out a fire iron. In an instant, a messenger arrived bearing the sun-ripened fruit. Ye questioned the messenger, who replied, "When I reached the capital, flames stretched across the sky, blocking every path. I had to rest awhile before I could get here." The assembled company turned pale.

The emperor often summoned Gongyuan, Fashan, Jingang, and the Tripiṭaka Master to test their arts, and Gongyuan always prevailed. Whenever he entered or left the palace, he would sometimes offer subtle admonitions, sometimes speak plainly to advise or correct. He excelled at dispelling demons, summoning dragons, and bringing rain, while Ye Fashan concealed his own abilities.

The emperor wished to learn Gongyuan’s arts of protection. Gongyuan said, "Your Majesty’s jade tablets and golden slips have already reached the Nine Heavens. You should emulate the effortless governance of Yao and Shun, follow the frugality of Wen and Jing. How can one of Your Majesty’s stature—the lord of all under heaven, the possessor of ten thousand chariots, the guardian of the ancestral temples, the pillar of the altars of soil and grain—lightly pursue such minor arts? If I were to teach you all my skills, you would surely end up carrying the imperial seal among the common folk, trapped in the guise of a fish."

The emperor did not heed his words and instead berated Gongyuan. Gongyuan fled into a palace pillar, leaping through it several times. The emperor grew angrier and split the pillar in pursuit. When Gongyuan reappeared, he entered a stone block, which the emperor then shattered into dozens of pieces—each bearing Gongyuan’s form. The emperor apologized, and Gongyuan returned to normal.

Though the emperor pressed him relentlessly, Gongyuan only taught a little, refusing to reveal all his arts. When others attempted to conceal themselves, they could manage no more than hiding their clothing or belt, or at best their shadow. But when Gongyuan tested his own arts, they proved effective. The emperor bestowed lavish gifts of gold and silk, yet in the end, he could not grasp their subtleties. Enraged, he ordered Gongyuan beheaded.

A eunuch attendant, Fu Xianyu, returned from Shu and hastened Gongyuan westward by carriage. To Xianyu, he said: "I entered Shu during the Xianhe era of Emperor Cheng of Jin, dwelling among forests and springs to cultivate the true Dao. Hearing the Son of Heaven favored the Way, I abandoned the joys of mist and clouds to brave the dust of the mortal world. I wished to teach the supreme Dao to the imperial lord, but when he summoned me to a separate palace to refine elixirs, I told him: 'The human body’s organs are clogged with meat and blood; the Three Fields remain unemptied, the Six Qi uncleansed. Allow me ten years to prepare before receiving the elixir.' Yet he could not endure the wait and, enraged, executed me with a blade to the neck—how cruel! Still, one who has attained the Dao unites form and qi; how could worldly weapons, water, or fire harm me? Yet I recall His Majesty’s name inscribed in the registers of cinnabar splendor, bound by an old jade bond, and my lingering affection for him cannot fade. Take this letter," he said, drawing it from his sleeve, "and deliver it to the emperor. Tell him I am Luo Gongda, disciple of Master Jingzhen. He will surely understand."

He added: "When I secluded myself in the mountains, I ate fruit and drank water, passing the years in quietude. When I came to court to expound the Dao, I subsisted on three jujubes." The emperor sighed deeply and sent him to the Suming Abbey, dispatching the eunuch attendant Guo Daozan with two trays of jujubes. In the sixth month, he was summoned again. The emperor led him into the inner palace, granted him a seat, and together they admired the lotus pond in the sleeping quarters.

The emperor asked: "The land suffers from drought and scorching heat; autumn’s harvest is lost. What can be done?"
Gongyuan replied: "If Your Majesty’s sincerity can move Heaven, I humbly request a nocturnal jiao ritual. It will surely bring sweet rain."
The emperor approved. When the ritual concluded, thunder and rain followed immediately. Overjoyed, the emperor inquired about the essentials of governing the state.
Gongyuan answered: "The sage’s Dao resides in the heart, not in external pursuits."
The emperor bestowed upon him a purple robe and ordained him as a Daoist priest. Thereafter, Gongyuan begged leave of the court and, by imperial decree, returned to his old retreat to refine elixirs, receiving five hundred bolts of silk. In the twenty-seventh year, his elixir was completed. The emperor summoned him to court and lavished him with rewards. When Emperor Suzong issued a summons in the second year of the Zhide era, Gongyuan did not go. In the early Qianyuan era, he reached the age of one hundred and forty before ascending in broad daylight at the Fuyun Abbey.

---

Xue Youqi
Xue Youqi was a native of Baoding in Pu Prefecture. Of a serene and composed nature, he possessed keen insight and remarkable foresight. In his leisure from scholarly pursuits, he delighted in hearing of matters beyond the mundane. During the Kaiyuan era of Emperor Xuanzong of Tang, he passed the imperial examinations at the tender age of twenty and was appointed magistrate of Ling Prefecture. Before his term ended, he felt a longing for forests and springs, so he cast off his official robes, donned a hempen cap and coarse cloth, and wandered between Qingcheng and Emei. After some time, he traveled to Mount Heming, seeking the former abode of the Han Celestial Master. After twelve years of cultivation, his Daoist qi flourished.

In the early Tianbao era, he journeyed to Mount Heng, where he chose a secluded dwelling. Concealing his name, he settled beneath the Five Elders Peak, roaming freely in a realm of self-attainment, unbound and at ease. Though he harmonized with the world and adapted to its ways, his true nature remained uncompromised. He was well-versed in the *Three Caverns’ True Teachings*, and recluses and wanderers flocked to him daily, drawn by his reputation. With vast and profound eloquence, he illuminated the Way according to each disciple’s capacity.

He presented the *Treatise on the Mysterious Subtle* in three volumes, which the emperor praised for its profound insight. Soon after, he achieved liberation from the corpse at Mount Mo. He had once annotated the *Scripture of the Numinous Treasure’s Salvation of Humankind*, which circulated widely. The *Compendium of Mount Heng’s Marvels* records: "Today, the Lingxu Palace’s Celestial Fragrance Terrace is where he annotated the scripture. At dawn and dusk, clouds and mist swirl like incense."

---

Wang Ke
Wang Ke, styled Xianke, was a native of Hengyuan in Qingcheng—some say he hailed from beneath Cuishan in Yongkang County, Shuzhou. His mother, Lady Ding, dreamed of a great star illuminating her body. Upon waking, her chamber was filled with light, and she conceived. At birth, his afterbirth was purple, his veins green, and his appearance extraordinary. As a child, his intelligence surpassed the common. Though his family was immensely wealthy, he paid it no mind. As he grew, he was kind and benevolent, moved to pity by the old, weak, and destitute, his compassion evident in his expression. He aided those in need and bestowed charity. During heavy snowfalls, he scattered grain to feed the birds.

Later, he encountered an immortal who transmitted the alchemical formula. He retreated to a side cave to cultivate, but after years of effort, he achieved nothing. Suddenly, his crucible cracked, and the elixir transformed into golden-threaded stone. Later, while tending his mountain garden, he came one day to the Dragon Pool of the Wei River and ascended the Western Peak, where he met a Daoist refining elixirs. Ke assisted with firewood and charcoal, serving him for three years through cold and heat without faltering. The Daoist, admiring his dedication, imparted secret teachings, instructing him to cultivate the supreme Dao internally while accumulating hidden merits externally. When the elixir was complete, the Daoist shared a portion with him. After consuming it, Ke gradually felt his spirit invigorated, his qi unburdened, his body light, and his mind at ease.

Beside his dwelling stood several large parasol trees. With a leap, he ascended to their crowns and from there rose into the heavens. The trees remain to this day. He attained the Dao in the third year of the Yifeng era of Emperor Gaozong of Tang. The site is now called Luojia Mountain, and the Daoist was none other than Luo Gongyuan.

---

Li Yu
Li Yu was a member of the Tang imperial clan. When Luo Gongyuan discoursed on the wonders of the Dao during Emperor Xuanzong’s leisure, he frequented the Han Yuan Hall and was once tested there. Later, he was appointed prefect of She Prefecture and set out with his family for his post. As they crossed the Yangtze, a turtle spirit seized Yu’s soul and possessed his body, continuing the journey to the prefecture in his stead. One day, Gongyuan, inspecting the records of the water府, discovered this and dispatched a talisman to slay the turtle, restoring Yu’s soul. Yu then abandoned his office and entered the Taiyi Cave on Mount Qingcheng, beseeching Gongyuan for talismans to save his family. He became Gongyuan’s disciple and later attained immortality, now serving at his side.

---

Du Sheng
Du Sheng, styled Keyun, claimed to be a native of Duling in Jingzhao, though his age was unknown. He ate nothing but drank three *dou* of wine without becoming drunk. His complexion was radiant, as if he were a man of thirty.

Du Sheng wore a large square kerchief, a tattered hat, and a green cloth robe in both winter and summer. His discourse was lofty, and he possessed considerable literary talent. If someone offered him a new kerchief or robe, he would accept it but never remove the old one. Upon receiving the new, he would go out and give it to the first person he met. He often wandered the streets in a drunken stagger, skilled in writing with sand. He favored inscribing the character for "dragon" in water bowls or basins, letting it float and turn left and right. If he shouted at it, the character would rise over a *zhang* high, faint as mist, taking the form of a small dragon, and upon being called, descend back into the water. He never asked people for money, but when they gave it to him of their own accord and summoned him to perform under the eaves, he would earn a great deal in a short while—then scatter it among the poor or taverns. He did this daily wherever he went, and people never grew weary of giving him money, though some suspected him of bewitching the crowd with his arts. In winter, he would lie in the snow for two or three days, and people thought him frozen to death. But when they prodded him, he would rise slowly, shake off the snow, and walk away as if still drunk, his breath steaming as though he had just awoken from a summer nap.

Du Ruxiu, son of the Duke of Heguo, served as governor of Suzhou. Hearing that Keyun was in the city, he rejoiced and invited him in, bowing to him and addressing him as "Daoist Master." His guests and subordinates were astonished, but Ruxiu said, "When my late father governed Xichuan, he held this Daoist elder in the highest esteem, and they often exchanged visits in his study. At the time, I was only ten years old. Now, over fifty, I have not seen him for forty years—yet his appearance and bearing remain unchanged." He kept Keyun in the prefectural residence and consulted him on Daoist arts. Keyun replied, "Simply govern with virtue and care for the people. Given the troubled times, you must especially protect yourself. You cannot yet cast off worldly dust and retreat to the mountains and forests with your family. Keep far from the wounds of war—Daoist arts are not yet for you."

When the people of the prefecture offered him money and silk, he declined at first but then, upon leaving the city, distributed it all to others. Ruxiu’s reverence for him grew even deeper. Sometimes Keyun joined Ruxiu and his guests for drinking gatherings. When others composed poems in response to one another, Keyun would speak verses offhand, profound in meaning and rich with the themes of immortals and transcendents—none could match him.

Later, during military chaos, Ruxiu was indeed killed by soldiers, and people saw Keyun wounded and slain as well. Soon after, only his old robe remained, torn into three or four pieces with slashed marks on the ground. Yet days later, many saw Keyun crossing the Song River and Zhe River, passing through Hangzhou, Yue, Qu, and Xin into Jiangxi, still drunk and writing in sand as before. A year later, he was spotted in Hunan. When asked about Suzhou, he recounted the events clearly and laughed. He also mentioned having lived on Mount Nanyue and that he would soon depart. Upon closer inquiry, it became clear he had mastered the Dao of invisibility and transformation—none could fathom it.

Your servant Daoyi remarks: Du Sheng’s attainment of the Dao ran deep. He blended with the world, carefree in poetry and wine, fasting yet clad in rags. His square kerchief and cloth robe, though old, he never discarded; when given new ones, he passed them to others. In winter, he slept in the snow, and daily wandered the streets—yet none could guess his age. Had one judged him by his attire alone, they would never have known he had attained the Dao. True immortals conceal and reveal themselves in the world—how easily can they be perceived? Thus the *Daodejing* says: "The sage wears coarse cloth yet holds jade within."

Yang Xi
Yang Xi was a native of Mount Tai.

Yang Xi held hereditary office and resided in Jinyun. Having passed the imperial examination in classics, he was appointed as the assistant magistrate of Jiajing County in Xizhou. Upon resigning, he returned to Jinyun. His elder brother, Yang Ting, served as the magistrate of Le’an in Taizhou.

Yang Xi dwelled in seclusion on Mount Kuocang, his nature serene and withdrawn, indifferent to worldly honors. He aspired to a life of freedom and long cherished the arts of the Dao. One day, his wife suddenly died. He remarked, "Zhuangzi drummed on a basin to express his enlightenment—now I, too, am joyful. Is it not fitting to bury her?" His son had his own calling, and his daughter was already wed; thus, he was forever unencumbered.

Later, he visited Ruanlang Pavilion. On a cliff over ten *zhang* above the ground, there was an inscription in seal script, its characters immense. The world believed it to be the hand of Ruan Zhao. Later, when Sheng Cheng sent craftsmen to chisel the stone for a rubbing, they discovered that it was in fact a poem left by Li Yangbing, who had once served as magistrate of Jinyun and visited the pavilion:

*"Where has the wanderer Ruan gone?*
*Immortal clouds stretch o’er the cave’s mouth.*
*Where none have trodden for ages past,*
*Today I walk this very ground."*

Beside the pavilion, Yang Xi drank wine with several Daoist priests from Jinyun Observatory during the blossoming season. At midday, he suddenly collapsed as if dead, though his breath remained warm. Carried home, he revived after seven days. The villagers and Daoists came to inquire, and Yang Xi recounted:

"At first, a person in a green turban and crimson robes, who called themselves Lingying, invited me into a grotto palace. There, I saw towering pavilions, phoenixes and cranes circling, the sky clear and the air warm—unlike the mortal world. Soon, from a stone crevice, something flew out, shaped like a pair of objects with long green stems. Lingying pointed and said, ‘This is the Azure Spirit Mushroom. Eat it, and you may attain immortality.’ I was ravenous and, sitting upon a rock, consumed it entirely. The taste was sweet and delicious.

Lingying said, ‘You have long borne the destiny of an immortal; today, you shall at last meet the celestial officials.’ They led me before three immortals: one wore a *yuanyou* cap, the other two, iridescent feathered robes. Their attendants, both civil and martial, were innumerable. Lingying told me, ‘The first is the Lesser Heavenly King, the second the Great Master of Huayang, and the third the Hidden Mystery Celestial Aide.’ I bowed to each in turn, and they all said, ‘You possess the bones of an immortal but cannot yet ascend. You must still cultivate upon the earth.’

Presently, Lingying escorted me out—through the western gate of the Kuocang Grotto. Only then did I awaken to my true self."

Thereafter, Yang Xi no longer favored the scent of grains. He drank three *sheng* of water daily and ate a single bowl of lilies. His body grew light, his joints all moved, rustling like bamboo slats or the sound of clappers. He spoke and chanted incessantly, as if conversing with unseen others, day and night. At times, he would take two or three hundred sheets of paper and fill them with writing in an instant—characters no one could decipher. When Yang Xi read them aloud, they proved to be refined compositions. Daoist priests and curious scholars transcribed them from his dictation; indeed, they were elegant verses, rich with allusions to immortals, Penglai, and the Isles of the Blessed.

For over a year, he remained lean yet vigorous. By the second year, he grew plump and fair, abstaining entirely from grains and drinking only water. In his third year, his hair turned black as lacquer, his complexion like a child’s. He walked as if flying, could drink three *dou* of wine without intoxication, and usually wore coarse cloth. Later, he visited his brother in Le’an, arriving in a single day. He then traveled to Tiantai, again arriving in a day, covering two to four hundred *li* daily. He returned to Mount Xiandu, where he ingested elixirs and cultivated *qi* for over twenty years. Finally, he journeyed south into Mount Weiyu, and none saw him again.

Tan Qiao
Tan Qiao, styled Jingsheng, was the son of Tan Hui, a scholar of the Directorate of Education during the Tang. Precocious in childhood, he grew to be well-versed in the classics and histories, with an exceptional memory—no question stumped him. His prose was pure and elegant. Though his father urged him to pursue the imperial examinations, Tan Qiao had no interest. Instead, he was drawn to the works of the Yellow Emperor and Laozi, as well as the *Inner Biography of the Perfected Lords* from the reigns of King Mu of Zhou and Emperor Wu of Han. He studied them all with meticulous care.

One day, he informed his father of his intent to travel to Mount Zhongnan. His father, considering the mountain’s proximity to the capital, permitted him. From there, he traversed Mount Zhongnan, Mount Taibai, the Taihang range, Mount Wangwu, Mount Song, Mount Hua, and Mount Tai, wandering through renowned mountains in succession, never returning home. His father sent letters in reproach, to which Tan Qiao replied: "In ancient times, Lord Mao was once a son who left his father to study the Dao. Now I emulate him, hoping it may benefit my parents." His parents, seeing his unwavering resolve in seeking the Way, no longer constrained him with worldly affairs and allowed him to follow his path.

For over a decade, Tan Qiao studied under a Daoist master on Mount Song, mastering the arts of *bigu* (abstaining from grains) and cultivating *qi*. He took delight only in wine, often wandering in a drunken haze, going wherever he pleased. In summer, he wore a black fur robe; in winter, a green cloth garment. At times, he would lie in wind, snow, or frost for days on end. People assumed he had perished, but upon inspection, his *qi* remained steady and serene. His father, ever mindful of him, frequently sent servants to seek him out, and without fail, each spring and winter, he would send clothes, money, and silk. Tan Qiao would receive them with joy, then promptly dispatch the servants with a reply, lavishing them with gifts. No sooner had they departed than he would take the clothes his father had sent into the streets, giving them to the poor and destitute, or leaving them at taverns, keeping nothing for himself. When asked why he did this, he replied: "How can I bear to keep them? If they were stolen, it would implicate others. Unburdened by clothes or food, I have no worries." He was always cheerful, though some called him mad. As he wandered, he would chant:

*A thread spun into the Yangtze, a fan spread as the sky,
My straw sandals cast to the eastern sea’s side.
Penglai’s Way is not so far—
Just before this wanderer’s staff, it lies.*

Later, he resided on Mount Heng, where he refined an elixir and consumed it. Thereafter, he could enter water without getting wet, walk through fire without being scorched, and conceal or transform his form at will. He then departed for Mount Qingcheng.

Tan Qiao once composed the *Book of Transformation*. Song Qiqiu of the Southern Tang plagiarized it, claiming authorship, and it circulated under his name. In the summer of the fifth year of Emperor Renzong of Song’s Jiayou era (1060), the fourth month, Bixuzi wrote a postscript to the *Book of Transformation*, stating:

The Lord of Primal Chaos said: "I once asked Master Layman Chen Tuan to recite this book. Upon reaching the *Chapter of the Child*, he closed the volume and told me: 'My friend Tan Jingsheng first composed the *Book of Transformation* on Mount Zhongnan. Later, he traveled to the Three Maos and passed through Jiankang. There, he met Song Qiqiu, who possessed the bearing of an immortal, though mired in cunning. Yet he stood apart from the dust-bound masses. Tan Qiao thus shared this passage with him: *The child plays with his shadow, unaware he is played by it; the madman mocks the image, unaware he is mocked by it. The transformer of the household does not know he is transformed by it; the transformer of the state does not know he is transformed by it. The drunkard clings to his drunkenness, the scabbed treats his scabs—the more they persist, the more their afflictions deepen, and none turn back.* Qiqiu remained unmoved. Tan Jingsheng then presented the *Book of Transformation* to him, saying: *This book’s transformations are boundless. I hope you will write a preface and transmit it to later generations.*' With that, he took up his staff and departed. Qiqiu seized the work as his own and wrote the preface."

Alas! In ancient times, Xiang Xiu expounded on the *Zhuangzi*, but before his commentary could be transmitted, he died. Guo Xiang surreptitiously altered and published it as his own—a true culprit. Now, Tan Qiao’s name is inscribed in the annals of immortals, his body untouched by age, yet Song Qiqiu dared to indulge his thieving heart, obscuring the immortal’s legacy. His crime was grave indeed. It is no wonder he met an unworthy end.

*Comprehensive Mirror of Perfected Immortals Who Embodied the Dao Through the Ages*, Scroll 39 (conclusion)
*Comprehensive Mirror of Perfected Immortals Who Embodied the Dao Through the Ages*, Scroll 40

She Xichang

She Xichang, a native of Hedong—*The Comprehensive Gazetteer of Mount Nanyue* records him as a man of Mianzhu in Hanzhou. His family had long held official rank. From childhood, Xichang scorned worldly glory, abstained from meat, and dressed only in plain cloth. He was deeply fond of mountains and rivers. One day, while wandering Mount Qingcheng, he journeyed south to Taoyuan. Later, he encountered Master Zhengyi, Sima Chengzhen, on Mount Nanyue, who transmitted to him the *Three Caverns Scriptural Canon*. He delved into the profound mysteries of the Dao, practicing diligently without respite. Thus, exalted perfected beings descended frequently, and wondrous fragrances and celestial music were often heard in his quiet chamber.

Emperor Ming of Tang summoned him to the palace, where he was asked about the Dao and virtue. His discourse was supremely subtle. The emperor, delighted, bestowed upon him exceptional favor and honor, though Xichang soon returned to the mountains. The emperor commanded him to compose a poem and presented him with a preface, which read:

*"The Master of Refinement aspires to the Mystic Gate, his heart anchored on Mount Nanyue. Having ascended to the register of Daoist adepts, he suddenly came to take his leave, wishing to return to his old mountain and preserve the purity of emptiness. We do not oppose his noble resolve, for we esteem his devoted cultivation. Should he encounter perfected beings or divine elixirs, he may yet visit the imperial palace."*

The poem said:
*A cultivator of the grotto-palace,
He longs for his old dwelling on Mount Heng.
Having attained the essentials of the Golden Tower,
He offers the sacred texts of Jade Clarity.
The cloud-path to the Three Heavens draws near,
The pine-stream holds ten thousand silences.
Still, he should transmit the secret formulas,
Coming and going to await the immortal’s chariot.*

Xichang once composed the *Mystic Pivot of Dao and Virtue*, a work that encompassed the subtleties of nurturing the true, and annotated the *Nine Perfected’s Descent of the Sage*. He returned to his former hermitage beneath the Flower-Canopy Peak, where he refined the elixir to completion. One day, he suddenly told his disciples: *"This evening, the Celestial Perfected will gather on Zhurong Peak. I have been summoned and must depart."* Thereupon, he ascended into the void and did not return. Later, the Ascending Void Palace was built in his honor.

Tian Xuying

The Daoist Tian Xuying, styled Liangyi, was a native of the State of Qi. By nature, he was simple and unrefined, speaking without reservation. During the Kaihuang era of Emperor Wen of Sui, while serving his parents in You County, he was exiled to Mount Nanyue due to a clamor. There, he tilled the soil on Purple Canopy Peak, fulfilling his filial duty for over fifty years.

After his mother’s passing, he wandered among the Five Peaks, roaming freely to his heart’s content. During the *Longshuo* era of Emperor Gaozong of Tang, the prefect of the state, Lord Tian, built the Hall of Descending Perfection at the Yue Temple to house him, while Tian Qiancheng adorned its walls with white plaster. The esoteric methods of the *Shangqing* Great Cavern he received had been transmitted from Master Zhengyi to Xue Jichang, and from Jichang to Xuying. Having inherited the essentials of the Dao, he traversed rivers and clouds, befriending only Jiang Hanhong. At the time, Lü Wei and Yang Feng, envoys to Hunan, once sought him out for lofty discourse.

When Changsha suffered drought and prayers went unanswered for a long time, Xuying was summoned. Wearing tattered robes, he arrived at the prefecture—without a word, rain fell of its own accord. Another time, when incessant rains persisted, the prefect built an altar at the Yue Temple. Xuying sat in silent composure by the shore; as soon as he ascended the altar, the skies cleared. During the *Yuanhe* era of Emperor Xianzong, he entered Mount Tiantai and never emerged again. When Emperor Xianzong issued an edict, he did not respond.

There was a certain Ouyang Ping, also a master of Daoist learning, who treated him as an elder brother. One evening, he dreamed of three divine beings descending from heaven, each holding a golden censer, as if to summon someone. He secretly told others: *"The two masters will soon depart, and I shall follow."* Before long, Xuying indeed ascended as an immortal, and Jiang followed soon after.

Among his disciples, three achieved prominence: Bingyao Feng Weiliang, Xianglin Chen Guayan, and Fangying Xu Lingfu.

**Feng Weiliang**

The Daoist Feng Weiliang, styled Yunyi, was a native of Xiangzhou. He cultivated the Dao at the Central Palace of Mount Heng, forming a bond of "mist-and-vine" friendship with Xu Lingfu and Chen Guayan. Beyond tending to incense and flame, he found joy in zither and wine. After some time, he came to the Hall of Descending Perfection and became a disciple of Tian Xuying, receiving the secret formulas of the Three Caverns.

During the *Yuanhe* era of Emperor Xianzong of Tang, he entered Mount Tiantai and Guiji. Yuan Ji, the surveillance commissioner, heard of his reputation and admired him, often visiting to inquire about matters beyond the mundane. The Tongwu Temple, since its restoration by Master Zhengyi, had long fallen into disrepair. Weiliang rebuilt it, constructing the Upper Clarity Pavilion, the Hall of Descending Perfection, the White Cloud Pavilion, and the Leisurely Retreat, thus reviving the legacy of Master Zhengyi. He propagated the Dao of the Three Caverns throughout the Jiangnan region.

When Emperor Xianzong summoned him, he did not go, instead establishing the Bingyao Hermitage in the Valley of Flourishing Forests to reside there. He often wandered alone to the Peach Blossom Spring and Golden Mound, returning only once every few months. One day, he suddenly ordered a bath, donned his cap and robe, and descended to the courtyard, as if responding to a summons.

In an instant, he ascended the steps and passed away, aged ninety. Of the hundred-odd disciples he transmitted his teachings to, only Ying Yijie, Ye Cangzhi, and Shen Guanwai grasped their essence; none others attained his profundities.

**Daoist Chen Guayan**
Daoist Chen Guayan, styled Dachu, was a native of Jiyang in Yuezhou. He dwelt in seclusion upon Jade Radiance Peak, calling his abode the Forest of Flourishing Hua. Where the ritual codes of Tiantai had fallen into neglect, he gathered and restored them. In daily life, he made the zither and wine his companions, composing verses with untrammeled abandon, never embellishing his words. One of his mountain-dwelling poems reads:

*Beyond drunkenness, the thatched hall’s gate stands ajar,*
*Awakening, I open my eyes to green mountains afar.*
*Where pine blossoms fall, gibbons still roost at night,*
*Deer in herds return through the forest’s fading light.*

Another verse declares:

*Ice mirrors the water like a polished glass,*
*Snow swept, jade turns to dust as it must pass.*
*Why ask of past or present’s fleeting span?*
*Here stands a man of the primordial clan.*

Though Guayan restored the missing ritual codes, he did not practice them himself. Among his transmitted disciples, only Liu Jie—styled Chujing—abandoned his studies in the classics, left his home in Lanxi of Wuzhou, and became a Daoist under Wu Shousu, master of the Lingrui Abbey. Hearing of Guayan’s renown, he journeyed to the Forest of Flourishing Hua to seek instruction, serving with incense and staff for twenty years until he mastered Guayan’s Way. As Guayan prepared for his *shijie* (liberation by means of a simulated corpse), he instructed Chujing: *"Encase me in a cloth sack and place me in a stone chamber—take care not to use wood."* He lived to sixty-four. Chujing, along with Ye Cangzhi and Ying Yijie, became friends in the realm beyond form. After a long time, as he prepared to sit in transformation, he revealed a poem to his disciples before returning to the True:

*I, formless in origin, briefly took form,*
*By chance came to the mortal world, chasing its swarm.*
*The debts of rebirth now repaid in full,*
*I scratch my head, indifferent, and ascend to the Upper Clarity.*

Ten other poems of his remain in the Daoyuan Abbey of Tiantai.

**Daoist Xu Lingfu**
Daoist Xu Lingfu, styled Moxi Zi, was a native of Tianmu Mountain in Qiantang. Well-versed in Confucian learning, he harbored no ambition for fame or profit. He dwelt in a stone chamber on Tigerhead Rock of Cloud-Covered Peak in Tiantai for over a decade. His disciples built a thatched hut and entreated him to reside there, but he refused. Instead, he constructed his own hut atop a rocky ledge, where towering pines and verdant bamboo stood in solemn array. Nearby lay a square pond over a hundred paces wide, filled with strange rocks resembling islets—thus he named it Square Ying. Daily, he delighted in self-cultivation, and in his leisure, he composed verses such as:

*Silent and still, spirit congeals at the Great Ultimate’s dawn,*
*Responding to things without intent, riding clouds as my throne.*
*Cultivating one’s nature is no quest for attainment—*
*To know the True Person, look no further than this one.*

Another poem reads:

*To learn the Dao and perfect the True lies in this life alone,*
*Deluded fools await death, then seek life anew.*
*If this life fails to grasp the principle of non-birth,*
*Even if reborn, where shall rebirth ensue?*

In the early years of Emperor Wuzong’s Huichang era, the emperor dispatched the eastern Zhejiang inspector to summon him. Unable to decline, Lingfu emerged to meet the inspector and presented a poem expressing his resolve:

*My rustic nature sings of the Three Joys,*
*Imperial grace descends from the Ninefold Throne.*
*I seek to transmit the Purple Chamber’s decree,*
*To avoid descending from White Cloud Peak’s zone.*
*Much shamed by the crane in the books I’ve known,*
*Deeply humbled by dragons drawn on scrolls alone.*
*How might I assist the enlightened lord?*
*I’d rather grow old among pines and stone.*

The inspector memorialized Lingfu’s frailty and infirmity, and the summons was rescinded. Thereafter, he ceased eating, and after a long time, he entered quiescence and passed away, aged eighty-two. His works include *Five Essays on Mystic Insight*, a commentary on the *Tongxuan Zhenjing* in twelve chapters, as well as the *Record of Tiantai Mountain* and *Essentials of the Three Caverns*. Of his disciples, only Zuo Yuanze attained his Way.

**Daoist Liu Yuanqing**
Daoist Liu Yuanqing was a native of Wuchang. He studied under Wang Daozong and received the *Zhengyi Lu*. Before long, as Daozong prepared for his final repose, he bequeathed all his possessions to his disciples, but Yuanqing took only his books. After Daozong was buried on Eastern Mountain, on a clear night, a column of *qi* several *zhang* high arose from the tomb. Yuanqing found this strange and had the grave reopened. When the coffin was opened, only his master’s clothes and cap remained—thus he knew Daozong had attained the Dao. Moved by this realization, Yuanqing sailed across Dongting Lake, traveled to Wuling, and later entered Nanyue, where he studied under Tian Liangyi. Ascending the Immortal Altar of Lady Wei, he conceived the idea of settling there. From the altar, he climbed sixty-five *li* up a precipitous peak (*The Comprehensive Record of Nanyue’s Perfected* states: *ten-odd li*), where he found a south-facing stone cave and made it his dwelling. He channeled a spring to encircle his home, felled trees and cleared brambles, and built a small pavilion in front. A chessboard and tea set were carved from stone. When the prefectural governor Han Yue visited, he named the pavilion the Gathering of Immortals. Yuanqing often brewed wine from the sprouts of a hundred herbs. Though he ceased eating and refined his *qi*, he could still drink over a *dou* at a time.

In the early years of Emperor Jingzong’s Baoli era, he was summoned to the Hall of State Affairs. When asked about longevity, he replied: *"To be free of profit-seeking and scheming, to reduce selfishness and desire—this is the essence of cultivating the self across lifetimes."* The emperor was displeased and posed further challenges, then dismissed him to return to the mountains. When the wife of Tang Shen, prefect of Mingzhou, fell ill, she sought a talisman from Yuanqing. He warned the messenger: *"Present this talisman to the prefect first—do not show it to the lady beforehand."* When the messenger returned, Shen had already recovered, and his wife’s illness had resolved on its own.

During Emperor Wuzong’s Huichang era, Yuanqing was again summoned to the palace. The emperor requested the transmission of the Dharma register and inquired about the Three Pacts of blood sacrifice. He replied: *"What the world values most is the body’s hair and skin. For one of the Son of Heaven’s stature, it suffices to drink elixirs as a substitute."* After purifying himself, Yuanqing ascended the altar to transmit the register. He was bestowed the title of Grand Master for Splendid Happiness, Grand Academician of the Chongxuan Abbey, and styled Master of Broad Perfection. A separate Chongxuan Abbey was constructed for his residence. When he petitioned to return to the mountains, the emperor granted his request.

In the winter of the tenth month of the fifth year of Dazhong during Emperor Xuanzong’s reign, clouds and cranes descended repeatedly, and soon after, he passed away. Heavenly music was heard floating in the air, and on the day his spirit departed, only his staff and sandals remained. His disciple Lü Zhizhen attained his Dao. The Minister of War, Wan Ye, composed a stele inscription; the Vice Minister of Personnel, Zhao Lu, wrote his biography; Lu Fan authored the stone chamber inscription; and the Daoist Zhang Jianbai composed his esoteric biography.

Ye Cangzhi, a Daoist whose courtesy name was Hanxiang, was a native of Songyang in Chuzhou and a descendant of Fa Shan. Initially, he entered Anhe Abbey as a Daoist and traveled to Tiantai to receive the Three Caverns scriptures and registers from Feng Weiliang. He selected a scenic site on Yuxiao Peak to establish a Daoist retreat, naming it the Stone Gate Mountain Abode. Before it stood two peaks, towering and facing each other, hence the name Stone Gate. Daily, he recited the *Dao De Jing* and the *Scripture of Salvation*. In his later years, he became particularly skilled in talismanic arts, and those who sought his aid came in great numbers.

The prefect of Zizhou was afflicted by a malevolent entity and journeyed to request a talisman. Midway, he violated taboos of impurity and lost it. The prefect personally visited again and saw a bamboo tube on the table, sealed tightly—it was the talisman he had previously lost. He burned incense, took the case, and reverently carried it back, whereupon the malevolent entity vanished. Thereafter, households that received his proven talismans offered donations, and if not for his own use, he set them aside entirely for the repair of altars and the expenses of meritorious works. The prefect memorialized his virtue, and Emperor Yizong of Tang issued an imperial decree renaming the Stone Gate Mountain Abode as Yuxiao Abbey.

One day, he suddenly ordered wine and summoned his friend Ying Yijie to drink together. He spoke of his life’s affairs, then announced the day of his departure. When the time came, he inscribed on his door: *"Departing at the hour of the cock’s crow."* His disciples soon heard the sounds of pearl ornaments and mixed drum music in the air, and in an instant, as the cock crowed, they looked and found he had already transformed. He was seventy-four years old. Ying Yijie...

Ying Yijie, styled Shizhong, was a native of Runan. He was the great-grandson of the eminent recluse Ying Ning from the Kaiyuan era of the illustrious Emperor Xuanzong. For generations, his family had declined official service, dedicating themselves instead to the Dao and the cultivation of their nature.

His mother, née He, once dreamed of a shooting star entering her window. Startled awake, she found the room suffused with light and soon conceived. From birth, he showed no taste for meat or fish. At the age of seven, his nature was already keen and perceptive. He journeyed to Lingrui Abbey at Lan Brook, where Master Wu instructed him in the *Wenlie* of Laozi and Zhuangzi, as well as the *Book of Changes*. At thirteen, he took the tonsure as a Daoist, observing the Ten Precepts with diligence, his devotion evident in his constant burning of incense and recitation of scriptures. His masters and peers regarded him with reverence.

In time, he traveled to Mount Tiantai and Mount Longhu, where he received the registers of the Orthodox Unity, Purple Void, and Capital Merit, among others. Later, he was initiated into the *Ascending Mystery* and *Highest Clarity* traditions—the *Returning Chariot* and *Graded Dao*—along with the *Purple Texts*, *Plain Sashes*, *Earth-Traversing*, and *Heaven-Soaring Talismans*.

The great teachings of Highest Clarity had been transmitted from Tao Hongjing to Wang Yuanzhi, then to Master Pan, then to Alchemist Sima, then to Xue Jichang, then to Tian Liangyi, then to Feng Weiliang, and finally to Yijie. His mastery of these practices was meticulous, and thus his every action was subtly aided by numinous forces.

He formed bonds of friendship with the recluses Ye Cangzhi and Liu Chujing in the forests and springs.

During the Huichang era of Emperor Wuzong of the Tang, he established a separate Cold Altar southwest of the Tongqiao Abbey on Mount Tiantai to reside in. The Surveillance Commissioner Li Bao visited to inquire about the Dao, and subsequently memorialized the throne to request a name for the abbey, which was then bestowed as "Dao Origin." Remembrancer Zhang Ying composed the record.

Master Bingzhen dwelled in this place for over fifty years. People from Wu and Yue, gazing upon his virtuous influence, bowed in reverence, and the number of those who wished to attend him as disciples was beyond count. Whenever he entered stillness to perform the Dao, ascended the altar to inspect the registers, or bestowed blessings upon others, his actions were frequently met with numinous responses. In his daily practice, he recited the *Huangting* and *Dadong* scriptures, and was especially diligent in performing the arts of the *Eight Daoist Observances of Clouds*, the *Triple Prime Receptions*, the *Returning Wind Concealing Earth*, and the *Grasping the Dipper Hiding Heaven*.

At times, high officials memorialized the throne on his behalf, and an imperial edict was issued granting him a robe and honorific title, which he firmly declined. He once said to his disciples: "I have upheld the teachings and the Dharma, yet I cannot conceal my traces or hide my beginnings. Though the Dao does not shun humanity, one must practice diligently to attain it. Yet the Jade Capital and Golden Towers, the Yellow Springs and the Deng Metropolis—how far apart are they? They are but summoned by the mind. Strive earnestly, all of you."

During the Qianning era of Emperor Zhaozong, one day, after bathing and entering stillness, he composed his spirit as if awaiting something. At dawn the following day, he peacefully passed away at the age of eighty-five. That night, a clear fragrance filled the air, and apes and crows cried in sorrow. When his spirit was transferred to its resting place, only an empty coffin remained. Luo Yin of Dongyang composed a eulogy. Zuo Yuanze.

The Daoist Zuo Yuanze was a native of Yongjia. By nature, he was upright and unyielding, refusing to bend to the times. He served the master Fang Ying of Lingying, residing in a stone chamber on Fragrant Grove Peak after divining its auspiciousness, roughly a li from Fang Ying’s abode. Morning and evening, he paid his respects, never failing to visit, even in bitter cold or sweltering heat. Moved by his diligence and reverence, Fang Ying transmitted to him the secret essentials.

Later, on Jade Cloud Peak, someone held a Yellow Register Retreat, and Yuanze was listed among the compilers. He ascended the altar in straw sandals. When asked to do so, he replied: “The Three Realms are but a passing vision—what are these mounds of earth?”

Afterward, he returned to his pine chamber, abstained from grain, and ceased speaking. Suddenly, he shouldered a cloth sack containing wooden sandals and an ancient mirror, then entered the mountains, his destination unknown. Occasionally, he would emerge after a month or two to visit his friend Ying Yijie. Beyond discussing the purity of emptiness, he once spoke of his dwelling: a grotto with several dozen great bamboos to the left and right, a pond before it, and amid the winding islets, dozens of emerald lotuses. There were also several dozen patterned birds, resembling swans or roc, swimming among them. Charmed by the scene, he spent the night in the grotto. As night fell, something encircled his body. Awakening, he merely closed his eyes and sat in oblivion, and it departed only at dawn.

His coarse hempen robe reeked only of drool and fishy stench.

That night, he sat again in the grotto, pacing with a net laid out to await it. Sure enough, a creature emerged from the pond—several *zhang* in length, its eyes casting beams like those of a flood-dragon or oyster. He leaned over the cliff and scolded it; slowly, it shrank back into the water. Thereupon he warned: "Those who come after me are defenseless—take care not to dwell in these rocky caverns."

At the Green Barrier Abbey in Wenzhou stood a local earth deity, to whom villagers regularly offered blood sacrifices. Should the rites lapse, it would bring misfortune. Yuze struck the spirit’s back three times with his staff. The next day, a large wildcat lay dead in the courtyard, its back bearing three staff marks. The villagers later dreamed the deity saying: "The one who relied on me was beaten to death by an immortal officer—henceforth, do not offer me blood sacrifices."

One day, Yuze suddenly told the abbey’s keeper: "I shall depart elsewhere; prepare a bath for me." He then instructed: "When covering me, simply follow the scent of incense until it fades, and there you shall stop." That night, wind and rain clashed with thunder and lightning; within the radiance, armored guards appeared. As dawn approached, a voice called out, "Take care." They went to look—he had already transformed.

They followed the fading scent of incense as instructed and, upon reaching its end, found precisely as he had said: a natural stone vault, its age unknown.

He once composed a *Hymn to the True One*, inscribing it upon the cliff face of Fangying:

The Great Dao is profound and obscure, beyond all explication.
It embraces the vast void as its boundless abode,
and unites the ten thousand realms within the True One.
Guard the True with the Dao, yet the True is not singular.
Expressed in spontaneity,
entrusted to the myriad things.
Once the root of the womb is severed,
one transcends the Three Realms,
nine generations attain deliverance,
and the Three Bureaus lay down their brushes.
This truly relies on the merit of non-merit—
a merit so wondrous it defies comparison.

**Lü Zhi Zhen**
Lü Zhi Zhen, of unknown origin, was a disciple of Master Liu Yuanqing of the Broad Accomplishment. Inwardly pure and outwardly harmonious, he seemed incapable of speech. He dwelled in a stone chamber for over a decade, later visiting the capital each year, wandering the Xiao and Xiang rivers, and calling upon the homes of various disciples. He always carried two large gourds, in which he stored medicinal herbs, clothing, scriptures, and Daoist implements. Fond of healing others with minerals and stones, when he entered forests and valleys, tigers and leopards would follow him. When asked about the Dao, he would remain silent, offering no response.

Once, on the road through Shang Mountain, he suddenly paled and halted. Others were astonished, but soon after, bandits appeared ahead, brandishing blades. Zhi Zhen addressed them: "These travelers are all my disciples—do not disturb them." The bandits bowed and stepped aside, no longer daring to advance.

On another occasion, at the mouth of a valley, he declared, "Something harmful to people is traveling with us." He then entered the forest, emerging with two tigers bound by rope. From this, it was known that Zhi Zhen had deeply mastered the Way of Broad Accomplishment.

He once remarked: "In the early days of my stone chamber dwelling, the space was exceedingly cramped. One evening, while performing a jiao ritual, the mountain suddenly opened to reveal a level expanse dozens of paces wide, within which a black leopard tamedly circled my side."

**Du Guangting**
The Daoist Du Guangting, styled Binsheng and known as the Master of Bound Seas, was originally from Chuzhou. *The Record of Mount Qingcheng* states he was from Duling in Jingzhao. Well-versed in all books, his aspirations soared beyond the ordinary. During the reign of Emperor Yizong of Tang, he and Zheng Yunshou composed a ten-thousand-character rhapsody but failed to pass the examination. Resolutely, he embraced the Dao and became a disciple of the Tiantai Daoist Ying Yijie.

He often remarked that the Daoist laws, rituals, and teachings—since their compilation by Celestial Master Zhang of the Han and Lu Xiujing—had spanned vast ages and nearly fallen into ruin. Thus, he examined their authenticity, arranged them in order from beginning to end, so that all Daoist followers might forever benefit from his work. Zheng Tian recommended his writings to the court, and Emperor Xizong summoned him for an audience, bestowing upon him a purple robe and ivory tablet. He was appointed as a scholar of the Linde Hall and, by imperial decree, became the leader of the Daoist clergy. At the time, all deferred to him, saying: "A thousand fathoms deep is his sea of learning, ten thousand leaves thick his forest of words—he alone upholds the ancestral teachings and establishes the Daoist school throughout the realm."

At the beginning of the Zhonghe era, he followed the imperial carriage to Xingyuan, traveling through Xixian. There, he encountered the diviner Chen Qizi, known as Xiufu, whose unconventional manner struck him as extraordinary. Pushing through brambles, he dug into the earth, gathered gourds of wine, and poured a cup, saying: "With this, I exchange your five viscera." Knowing the nation’s troubles were not yet settled, the Master submitted a memorial requesting leave to wander to Chengdu. Delighted by the rugged grandeur of White Cloud Stream on Mount Qingcheng, he built a thatched hut and took up residence there. The stream was, in fact, the site where the Perfected One Xue Chang had ascended to immortality. Soon after, as the imperial court prepared to return to the capital, an edict commanded Guangting to perform a jiao ritual for the Twenty-Four Deities. When Wang Jian established his rule over Shu, he summoned Guangting to serve as tutor to the imperial prince.

King Jian remarked to him, "In former times, the Han had its Four Hoary Ones, yet none compare to my single Master here." Guangting, however, found no joy in palace life and recommended Xu Ji and Xu Jianfu to take his place. Thus, he retired to spend his later years in Chengdu. When Chancellor Xu Guangpu was still a youth devoted to learning, he paid homage to Guangting as a disciple. Guangting once told him, "When I first studied at the Imperial Academy, the National University’s collection was already complete. I began with books on astronomy and the immortals, then turned to the classics, histories, philosophers, and literary anthologies. Within a month, I arranged a fixed schedule for my studies: the first day for reciting the classics, the second for reading philosophers and histories, the third for composition, the fourth for memorizing historical anecdotes, and the fifth for leisure. Each of these five tasks occupied six days of the month. Following this regimen for no more than five or seven years, I mastered the classics and histories thoroughly."

Scholar Wei Ao requested a preface for the collected works of his elder brother, Chancellor Zhuang. Guangting replied, "The Chancellor’s writings are abundant, yet if the collection retains poems of petty sorrow or frivolous elegance, I dare not comply." King Jian appointed Zhang Ge, son of the late Tang Chancellor Zhang Jun, whose literary talent surpassed his contemporaries, though he lacked mastery of historical precedents. In the early years of his rule over Shu, Zhang Ge consulted Guangting on all matters, great and small—for Guangting’s talents extended beyond eloquence to encompass the grand arts of statecraft.

At that time, a Daoist, moved by autumn’s melancholy, sought an audience with Guangting but failed to meet him. One day, Guangting suddenly told his disciples, "The True Palace on Mount Qingcheng is newly founded, and its construction is not yet complete. Last night, I dreamed of attending the Celestial Emperor, who appointed me overseer of the Min and Emei mountains. I fear my time in this world is short." His disciples wept, their sleeves damp with tears. When the True Palace was finished, in the eleventh month of the fourth year of Changxing of the Later Tang (the *guisi* year), Guangting, at the age of eighty-four, donned his ritual robes one last time, bowed in farewell to heaven, ascended the hall, and passed away in lotus posture. His complexion remained warm, his eyes bright, as if still alive. A rare fragrance filled the chamber, lingering long before dissipating.

Guangting had a white dog named Feiyun. He ordered its paws to be coated with sesame oil and wrapped in cloth, saying, "I have heard that a dog with oil on its paws can travel a thousand *li* in a day." Soon after, Feiyun howled several times and died.

Guangting once composed the *Illustration of the Primordial Origin*, *Rhapsody on the Sage’s Chronicle*, *Expansions on the Sage’s Teachings*, *Records of Successive Emperors*, as well as odes, poems, and miscellaneous writings—altogether over a hundred *juan*, all circulating in the world. In all his works, he never failed to take statecraft as his intent. The *Shu Tao Wu* states: "He produced over a thousand *juan* of writings, all grounded in the principle of non-action. Works such as the *Hundred-Verse Poem on Mountain Dwelling* and the two *Rhapsodies on the Dao and Virtue, Reflecting on Past and Present*—ranging from one to fifteen characters per line—proved greatly beneficial to moral instruction."

The Shu ruler Wang Jian initially bestowed upon him the title "Master of Vast Virtue." Later, wishing to elevate his rank and title, Wang inquired into precedent. Mao Wenxi offered this counsel: "In the early years of Wude during the Tang, Qi Pinding was appointed Grand Master for Splendid Happiness. During the Kaiyuan era, Yin Xiju served in the remonstrance office. Thus, he was made Grand Master for Court Consultation, enfeoffed as Duke of Cai, and advanced to the title 'Master of Vast Accomplishment.'" Guangting was subsequently appointed to the Jade Bureau for Transformation. In the first year of Tongzheng, he was promoted to Vice Minister of Revenue. When Wang Yan ascended the throne, he honored Guangting as "Celestial Master of Transmitted Truth," specially advancing him to the ranks of Grand Preceptor, Palace Attendant to the Crown Prince, and concurrently Grand Academician of the Institute for the Veneration of Literature.

Gu Qiu Fangyuan, styled Dafang, was a native of Susong in Shuzhou. From childhood, he was quick-witted and discerning. At sixteen, he mastered the classics and histories, and studied the *Book of Changes* under Chen Yuanwu of Mount Lu. At twenty-nine, he sought the Great Elixir from Zuo Yuanze of Fragrant Grove. Yuanze marveled at him and said to Fangyuan: "Have you not heard Laozi’s words: *My greatest trouble is that I have a body*? For the body arises from non-action and gives rise to action; now, returning to the root is called non-action. As for non-action, to speak of ‘non-being’ is to cling to emptiness, while to speak of ‘being’ is to create obstruction. Clinging to either being or non-being creates stagnation. Only when being and non-being are unified, and the mind is utterly serene, does one approach the Dao. Moreover, the Buddhists take this as the essence of Chan, and Yanzi [Yan Hui] called it ‘sitting in forgetfulness.’ The *Book of Changes* says: *Without thought, without action, utterly still, yet responsive and penetrating.* The principles of all under heaven ultimately converge as one. The scripture also says: *Pursue it, and you do not see its head; follow it, and you do not see its tail.* What is this thing? If you silently comprehend and spiritually realize it, what more is there to seek?" He added: "What a pity—your talent and capacity are so lofty that you could stand as a beacon for the gate of truth." Fangyuan bowed deeply in gratitude and departed. Later, he journeyed to Hidden Truth Cliff in Mount Xiandu, where he served Liu Chujing and studied the arts of cultivating truth and transcending the world.

At thirty-four, he received the esoteric teachings of the *Method of the Celestial Girdle* from Ye Cangzhi at Jade Cloud Palace on Mount Tiantai, and all the secret formulas and arcane instructions were transmitted to him in full. In his spare time from guarding the One and circulating qi, Fangyuan devoted himself to the various works of philosophers and historians. Whenever he opened a book, he would read it through without letting a single word slip from his mind. He often said: "Ge Zhichuan [Ge Hong] and Tao Zhenbai [Tao Hongjing] are my teachers and friends." He edited the *Scripture of Great Peace* into thirty chapters, exhaustively covering its essential principles. His reputation spread ever more widely throughout the Jiang-Huai region.

In the second year of Jingfu during the reign of Emperor Zhaozong of Tang, Qian Liu, Prince of Pengcheng of Qiantang, deeply admired Fangyuan’s virtue and Dao. He sought him out at Great Cleansing Grotto in Yuhang and built a residence to house him. Emperor Zhaozong repeatedly summoned Fangyuan to court, but he declined. Through astronomical divination, Fangyuan had deduced that the lands of Qin would soon be overgrown with brambles and that the Tang mandate was destined for change. Thus, like the recluses Yuan and Qi of old, he refused to emerge from the mountains and never answered the imperial summons. The emperor then issued an edict in praise of his exceptional qualities, bestowing upon him official robes where he dwelt, that he might illuminate the mystic Dao. He was granted the titles *Master of Wondrous Being* and *Master of Mystic Unity*. Spreading the sagely transformation and awakening the benighted, his numinous deeds became widely known throughout Wu and Chu.

From then on, disciples flocked to him from near and far, numbering over two hundred. Among them were Xia Yinyan of Kuaiji, Dai Yinyu of Qiao, Zheng Yinyao of Rongyang, Ling Yinzhou of Wu Commandery, Sheng Yinlin of Guangling, and Zhang Yinzhi of Wudu—all of whom mastered the essentials of the Dao and ascended to its inner sanctum. Guangping’s Cheng Zixiao answered the summons to the Qin palace, while Xin’an’s Nie Shidao propagated the teachings in the land of Wu. Anding’s Hu Qianguang and Lu’s Kong Zonglu, along with ten others, all received the wondrous instructions on refining the spirit through contemplation of the true. Others drew near to the sagely presence or concealed themselves in famous mountains, their names no longer recorded.

On the fourteenth day of the second month in the second year of Tianfu, after bathing and burning incense, Fangyuan sat upright in perfect composure. He awaited the hour of noon and passed away. His complexion remained serene and joyful, his limbs supple and at ease. A rare fragrance filled the air, lingering for three days without dissipating.

The disciples, following worldly custom, prepared the funeral and placed him in the coffin—yet only his empty garments remained, for his body had attained liberation. He was interred beside White Deer Mountain near the Great Cleansing Grotto. Later, both Daoists and laypeople repeatedly encountered him on Immortal Capital Mountain and Mount Lu, where he declared: *"I have left the Great Cleansing Grotto to conceal myself in the Heavenly Pillar Source of Mount Shan."*

Minister Daoyi remarked: Zuo Yuanze’s response to Qiu Fangyuan’s inquiry was excellent, yet his concluding words—*"merely aligning being and non-being, dissolving all distinctions in a state of no-mind"*—still left students unaware of the subtleties between existence and void. Only by recognizing that *"non-being is not entirely void"* and *"being is not entirely substantial"* can one truly harmonize with the Dao. Fangyuan’s attainment, I surmise, went far beyond this.

The *Daodejing* states:
*"Thirty spokes converge at a single hub—
it is the emptiness within that grants the wheel its use.
Clay is shaped into a vessel—
it is the hollowness within that grants the vessel its use.
Doors and windows are carved into a chamber—
it is the void within that grants the chamber its use.
Thus, being provides the advantage,
but non-being enables the function."*
This speaks of non-being.

It further says:
*"The bearing of great virtue follows only the Dao.
The Dao as a thing is elusive and indistinct.
Indistinct yet elusive, within it lies an image;
elusive yet indistinct, within it lies a thing.
Profound and obscure, within it lies an essence—
an essence most true, within it lies certainty."*
And:
*"There is a thing, formless yet complete,
born before heaven and earth.
Silent and boundless, it stands alone and unchanging,
circulating without cease—it may be called the Mother of all under heaven.
I know not its name; I style it the Dao."*
This speaks of being.

Grasping this, one would surely hear Zuo Yuanze declare: *"These words exhaust the truth."*

*Comprehensive Mirror of Perfected Immortals Embodying the Dao, Scroll Forty—concluded*
*Comprehensive Mirror of Perfected Immortals Embodying the Dao, Scroll Forty-One*

Nié Shīdào

Nié Shīdào, styled Tōngwēi, was a native of Shè in Xīn’ān. By nature he was keen, pure, and forthright, his words and deeds marked by humility and prudence. He cared for his parents with such filial devotion that he became widely respected in his village. In his youth he took a master beyond the world—this was the elder cousin of Déhuì. When Déhuì left his post as a provincial vice-director to govern Xīn’ān, he chose a scenic spot on the eastern mountain of the prefecture, built a retreat there, and named it the Wènzhèng Mountain Lodge. Shīdào served him with diligence: at thirteen he donned cap and robe, and at fifteen he received the essentials of the Dharma lineage and the cultivation of the True.

Later he traveled to the mountains of Jìxī. He once read in an esoteric transmission about the method of ingesting pine resin, so he and his Daoist companion ascended Bǎizhàng Mountain to gather it. The cliffs there rose sheer for a hundred fathoms, hence the name. From its summit, the four directions stretched upward for over a thousand yards. One night they lodged beneath a pine on the cliff-top. The sky was clear, the moon bright, when suddenly they heard immortal music arising from the southeast, borne on purple clouds. It drifted slowly past, even more leisurely than the music of Shíjīn Mountain. Shíjīn and Bǎizhàng were of equal height, and though thirty li of flat land lay between them, their summits stood within a hand’s breadth of each other. When the immortal music reached Shíjīn, it paused briefly, then three rolls of a small drum were sounded, followed by a full ensemble of metal, stone, sheng, xiao, silk, and gourd. The drumbeats set the rhythm, but the melody remained unknown—its sound soaring and clear, utterly unlike the music of the human realm. It began at the third watch and ceased only at cockcrow. Later, when they asked people at the foot of the mountain, all confirmed they had heard it that night. His companion sighed and said, “Just as we were gathering numinous herbs, we suddenly heard immortal music. Could this not be a response? Truly, this is an auspicious omen of your attaining the Dao.”

Thereafter, he journeyed to Nányuè, where he paid homage at the Jade Clarity Altar and the Azure Jade Altar of the Radiant Heaven. Later he stayed at the Summoning Immortals Abbey and entered the Cavern of Numinous Source. It was spring, and he heard that not far from the former hermitage of the Perfected Master Cài grew extraordinary flowers and trees, and that woodcutters sometimes saw the Perfected Master there. Delighted, Shīdào fasted for seven days. At dawn he set out alone into the mountains. As he walked, he caught the scent of rare blossoms and lost track of time until dusk.
