Suddenly he found himself beside a great stream. There, a woodcutter sat by the water on the sand. Just as Shīdào hurried to approach, the man shouldered his load of firewood and prepared to cross the stream. Turning, he saw Shīdào and paused, leaning on his carrying-pole. “Where are you going alone?” he asked. Shīdào replied, “I seek the Dao and search for immortals. I have long heard that the Perfected Master Cài dwells in these mountains, and I wish to pay my respects.” The woodcutter said, “The abode of Master Cài lies deep within; no one can reach it.” Shīdào said, “I have climbed vines and scaled cliffs to come this far. If there is a path through the mountains, why should I fear the distance?” The woodcutter said, “Night is falling. Go past this mountain to the east, where you will find homes where you may lodge.” Shīdào wished to follow him, but the woodcutter suddenly stepped into the stream, where the water was shallow. When Shīdào entered, the water became deep and swift, and he dared not wade across. The woodcutter said, “You will not cross this stream for another fifty years.” He watched as the woodcutter walked across the surface of the water and vanished.

Shīdào turned back toward the mountain’s east side and walked over ten li. In the distance he saw three thatched huts surrounded by a fence, with chickens and dogs. As he drew near, he saw a man of thirty, with a complexion of bluish-white, who appeared to be a farmer and lived alone. Seeing Shīdào arrive, the man was surprised that he had come alone through the deep mountains. “My family is all away,” he said. “Why is the master here?” He then asked Shīdào the purpose of his journey. Shīdào replied, “I seek the hermitage of the Perfected Master Cài.” The master of the house said, “Did you meet a woodcutter on the way?” “Yes,” Shīdào said. The master said, “That was the Daoist Cài who just passed by.” Upon hearing this, Shīdào bowed and prayed, saying, “A foolish mortal like myself failed to recognize a sage or immortal. Such is my fate.” Night was falling, and the mountain forest grew dark. With nowhere to stay, he asked, “Where have you come from?” Shīdào recounted his origins in Xīn’ān and his quest for the True. The man then allowed him into his hut. He pointed to a seat by the fire and said, “I happened to run out of food in the mountains and have not yet returned with more.” Shīdào said, “I have abstained from grain for some time and no longer think of food.” Beside the fire stood a cauldron of hot water and several yellow porcelain jars. The master said, “The contents of the jars are edible. Help yourself.” Shīdào lifted one lid—it was tea. The master said, “Pour hot water over it to drink.” When he drank, the flavor was far superior to ordinary tea. After a while, he wished for more tea and tried to open another jar, but it would not budge. He tried all the jars, but none would open. Shīdào was astonished—this did not seem like the home of a villager—but he dared not speak of it. The master slept in another room and did not rise even when the sun was high. There was no lamp or candle. In his sleep, the master said, “This is a lonely place, and I have suddenly fallen ill. I have nothing to offer you. There are many homes in the village ahead; you may go there.” Shīdào set out, but after several li he saw no houses, only perilous cliffs. He turned back, but the place where he had lodged was now lost to him. He walked another thirty li or so until he suddenly encountered an old man. Overjoyed, he invited him to sit on a rock and asked the purpose of his journey into the mountains. Shīdào recounted all that had happened. The old man said, “The father and son of the Cài family both dwell in seclusion in these mountains. The place where you lodged last night was the home of the son.” He added, “Your Dao-qi is strong, but your immortal bones are not yet fully formed. How can you endure hunger and thirst in these mountains for long?”

Suddenly, the old man plucked a blade of grass and handed it to Shīdào—its form resembled ginger sprouts, yet it stretched over a foot long. When chewed, its flavor was sweet and fragrant. The old man then bade him drink from a spring. As Shīdào raised his head, the old man had vanished without a trace. Overcome with sorrow, Shīdào sighed deeply, yet after eating the herb, he felt his qi and strength grow light and vigorous, surpassing even his condition before entering the mountains.

Turning back to follow the mountain path in search of his lodging, he found the way now choked with brambles and vines, impassable. He returned instead to Zhāoxiān Abbey, where the assembled Daoists greeted him with astonishment: “Though this abbey lies near sacred peaks, the mountains teem with beasts and serpents, and few dare travel alone. Why have you been gone for over a month? We have long feared for you.” Shīdào replied, “I left only yesterday and spent but a single night away.” He recounted his encounter with the woodcutter, his lodging, and his meeting with the old man. The Daoists all sighed in wonder, saying, “Though we dwell here together in study of the Dao, we have only heard of the True Man Cài—never once have we been granted a glimpse. Yet you, by virtue of your destined affinity with immortality, have already met both father and son. As for the old man, we have heard that True Man Péng also dwells in seclusion on this mountain. Could he not have been Péng himself? In a single day and night, you have encountered three immortals—yet in the human world, a month has passed. Truly, this is the work of accumulated merit from past lives.”

Shīdào marveled deeply at this and remained at Zhāoxiān Abbey to cultivate and refine his practice for over a year. Later, longing to return home to care for his aging parents, he made his way back to Wènzhèng Mountain. Whenever he ventured into the mountains to gather firewood or medicinal herbs, even tigers and leopards would lower their ears, wag their tails, and prostrate themselves before him. Shīdào would reach out to stroke them, calling them gently, and they would rise and follow at his heels. Sometimes he would place firewood or herbs upon their backs, and they would carry his burdens homeward before vanishing into the wilds. Long ago, Guō Wénjǔ of Dàdí Cave had tamed tigers in much the same way. Since Shīdào’s influence, the mountains near Shè had abounded with fierce beasts, yet they harmed no one.

When his parents asked what he had gained from his travels in search of learning, Shīdào recounted all that had transpired. Upon hearing his tale, they rejoiced, saying, “You tend to us with filial devotion, and we are sustained by your Dao. How fortunate this is for your mother as well! This must be the blessing of good karma from past lives.”

Later, Shīdào set out once more, this time longing to visit Nányuè and Jiǔyí Mountain. He had long heard that True Man Méi and Attendant Gentleman Xiāo both dwelled in seclusion on Yùsǔn Mountain, and many had claimed to see them. Méi was none other than Méi Fú, once magistrate of Nánchāng, while Xiāo was the noble son of the Liáng dynasty, Xiāo Zǐyún. After fleeing the chaos of Hóu Jǐng’s rebellion as governor of Shùyáng, Xiāo had brought his entire family into these mountains, and both men had attained the Dao here.

Shīdào lingered at Qīngxū Abbey on Yùsǔn Mountain, his heart filled with longing for Méi and Xiāo. He ventured into Yùmù Hollow, hoping for even a single glimpse of them, and pressed onward with unwavering resolve, journeying ever deeper into the mountains. Suddenly, he encountered a man dressed in plain cloth and a black gauze hat, his face bearing the appearance of a man in his fifties. Shīdào bowed in respect and asked his name. At first, the man called himself a traveler, then inquired where Shīdào was bound. When Shīdào replied that he sought Méi and Xiāo, the traveler said, “I have heard of your diligent pursuit of the Dao and your pilgrimage to renowned mountains—this is no easy feat. If you wish to meet those two gentlemen, I can guide you.” He added, “Your past karma is strong, and your name is already inscribed in the Jade Register. Though you may not yet ascend in flight, you shall surely transcend this world.”

The traveler continued, “I am Xiè Tōngxiū. I feared you might not recognize me, so I have revealed myself. I once dwelled on Nányuè Mountain alongside Péng and Cài, and three hundred years have passed since then. I know you have traveled to Dònglíngyuán. By chance, the Eastern Flower Lord has commanded me to serve as the Earth Immortal of Yùsǔn Mountain’s forests, overseeing the lands of Qīngxū Abbey as its local deity. You and I share a karmic bond with the Dao, which is why we have met. However, Méi and Xiāo are often summoned by the King of the Lesser Heaven during the day, and I fear they may not return soon—you cannot wait for them.”

Shīdào bowed reverently and said, “A mortal of this fleeting world, I have presumptuously sought the Great Dao, focusing my spirit and thoughts day and night, yet I know nothing of its essential mysteries. Adrift like a man upon the sea, I cannot even discern its shores. Never did I dare hope to meet a Daoist lord such as yourself today—this is the good fortune of eons.”

Tōngxiū replied, “Your sincerity and devotion are deeply moving. Yet your worldly affairs remain unfinished. For now, let me guide you out of the mountains to my dwelling.” They walked several *li* together until suddenly, two thatched huts appeared, neat and pristine. Inside were a bed, a mat, and a small cauldron simmering over a fire, as though a scholar lived there—yet no one was present. Tōngxiū bade Shīdào enter and sit upon a wooden horse, while he himself sat upon a white stone deer. Presently, a youth with flowing hair brought a basin of broth to Shīdào. After sipping it, his spirit and qi felt refreshed and clear.

Tōngxiū then pointed to a shelf and instructed him to take down a scroll. “This is the *Plain Book*,” he said. “Study it without ceasing, and you shall grasp its true essence.” Shīdào wished to remain and study under him, but before he could speak, Tōngxiū already knew his thoughts. “Your parents are advanced in years,” he said. “Though you have an elder brother who can care for them, if you wish to travel further south, you cannot yet stay here. I have a disciple named Zǐzhī, who resides on Jiǔyí Mountain. Seek him out and convey my message. Show him this *Plain Book*, and he will teach you its full meaning. If you do not find him, simply leave the book by Máorú Stream and inscribe a record upon the stone wall of the cave. My words will reach him, and Zǐzhī will impart the essential Dao to you.”

With that, he sent Shīdào on his way. In an instant, Tōngxiū vanished, and Shīdào found himself outside Yùmù Hollow. He returned to Qīngxū Abbey, where the Daoists greeted him in astonishment: “You have been gone for seven days—where have you been?” Shīdào recounted all that had occurred. Two of the Daoists, overjoyed, begged to accompany him back to Yùmù Hollow. When they arrived at the familiar place, the rocks, grasses, and trees remained unchanged, yet the thatched huts were nowhere to be found. They lingered in disappointment for the rest of the day before returning.

Shīdào had obtained the *Plain Book*, its characters legible and clear—all expounding the secret essentials of the Queen Mother of Mount Guī’s governance of the host of immortals.

Those who practice this among the immortals shall ascend to heaven. When passed to mortals, their traces may mingle with the grotto-heavens. Should doubts arise that cannot be resolved, proceed later to Xiāngzhēn Abbey on Mount Jiǔyí of the Southern Marchmount. After more than a month of inquiries along the paths where Zǐzhī’s traces were said to linger, all spoke of a recluse by a certain Máorú Stream—no one knew his name, though some had glimpsed him. Shīdào repeatedly entered the mountains in search, but found no one. Then, following Tōngxiū’s instruction, he left a letter inscribed upon the stone wall.

Later, in a dream, a divine being who called himself Zǐzhī taught him how to dissolve his lingering doubts, and he awoke. Yet after more than a year, he returned to govern, remaining for over twenty. With every act of devotion, he venerated the true-form portraits of the Two Càis, Péng, and Xiè, and on his own silk scrolls, he compiled *Strange Tales* for Daoists and laity alike.

Later, when Emperor Tàizǔ of Wú was consolidating his rule over the Jiāng-Huái region, he heard of Shīdào’s name and deeds and, hoping to benefit from his virtue, seized Guǎnglíng to build the Xuányuán Palace as his residence. Whenever Shīdào ascended the altar to pray for blessings or beseech the heavens, whether for rain or drought, his prayers were never unanswered. So moved were heaven and earth that auspicious clouds appeared in celebration, and he was honored with the titles *Xiāoyáo Dàshī* and *Master of Governance*.

Shīdào’s Dao was rooted in filial devotion, never straying far from his parents. When his mother, who had lived to ninety-five, passed away, he rushed to her side in mourning, crawling on hands and knees to carry the soil and raise her grave. He refused all sustenance beyond what ritual prescribed, then planned to withdraw into seclusion to fulfill his original resolve. Soon after, however, imperial messengers arrived in swift succession, their edicts impossible to refuse. Tàizǔ’s regard for him only deepened, and the entire realm turned to him in reverence.

The disciples Zōu Dékuāng, Wáng Chǔnè, Yáng Kuāngyì, Wāng Yòngzhēn, Chéng Shǒupǔ, Zēng Jǐngxiāo, Wáng Kěrú, Cuī Chánrán, Dù Chóngzhēn, Dèng Qǐxiá, Wú Zhīgǔ, Fàn Kěbǎo, Liú Rìxiáng, Kāng Kějiǔ, Wáng Bǐngxiá, and others were all inner-chamber disciples who transmitted the Shangqing methods. They dispersed across the various prefectures and commanderies, inheriting the true wind to propagate the teachings, and the court bestowed upon them purple robes to honor their Daoist lineage.

Scholars from Qín, Wú, Jīng, Qí, Yàn, Liáng, Mǐn, and Shǔ came in droves, serving with diligence and devotion for over a decade. Shīdào often said to them, *"I possess no Daoist arts—why have you come from such great distances?"* The disciples all replied, *"Just as when Master Zhāng dwelled in Shǔ and the world flocked to him, so too have we followed you."* He guided each according to their practice, imparting the essentials of the Dao.

The disciples performed menial tasks like servants, and only those who remained unwavering for years attained transcendence. Now, they are but descendants of withered bones, their days hastening toward decay. They sought to escape the brevity of life and aspire to longevity, their pleas earnest and unrelenting. Yet Shīdào met all with benevolence, never rebuffing their words. He adapted to their natures and understanding, pointing them toward the Dao’s essentials—like one who walks long through mist and dew, whose garments become damp with lingering moisture, or who draws near to silk and sandalwood, whose body is subtly imbued with fragrance.

Thus, he resided in Guǎnglíng for over thirty years, with more than five hundred disciples. By then, his embryonic breathing had long been perfected, and his elixir refinement had borne fruit. He often wished to return to his native mountains, but the emperor’s favor compelled him, thwarting his long-held resolve.

In the autumn of the year *xīnwèi*, he dreamed of a figure clad in black, girded with crimson, who said, *"Master, your Dao has long been accomplished. Heaven now summons you."* Awakening in a daze, he told his disciples, *"I have been called by the immortals. My time in this world will not be long."*

On the twenty-third day of the tenth month that year, rare fragrance filled the chamber, and cranes stood in the courtyard as if divine spirits had gathered. He took leave and transformed in the Purple Ultimate Palace of the capital, at the age of sixty-eight. A sacred tomb was established outside the Tàipíng Gate, and when his disciples prepared his coffin, a sound arose from within. Upon inspection, it was as if he had shed his mortal form like a cicada’s husk.

Days later, a man from Yùzhāng saw him, accompanied by a youth with hair tied in side knots. Many Daoists and laypeople recognized him and asked, *"Why have you traveled so far?"* He replied, *"I have been away from the Southern Marchmount for many years. I am but making a brief visit."* He stayed in the temples and abbeys of his former travels.

Half a year later, a man from Chángshā reported the same sighting. He added that on the road to Héngyáng, he had seen Shīdào returning to the Cavern of Numinous Source. A woodcutter remarked, *"Fifty years hence, he will pass this stream again."* Truly, the prophecy was fulfilled.

In the third month of the *dīnghǎi* year of Shùnyì, the Grand Preceptor and Duke of Dōnghǎi, Wáng Gōng, in accordance with ritual, escorted his remains back to Xīn’ān. A sacred altar was erected, lands were granted, and his former residence was converted into the Returning to the True Abbey. A memorial was submitted to posthumously appoint him Minister of Ceremonies, bestowing upon him a cap, sword, and ritual vestments—his honors abundant.

Zhāng Yūn, a native of Shénshān County in Jìnzhōu...

Zhang Yun, also named Yun and styled Cangzhen.

His father, Zhang Juqin, and his mother, née Yang, conceived him after she was touched by a black light. After eighteen months, he was born on the sixteenth day of the fourth month in the fourth year of Yonghui during the reign of Emperor Gaozong of Tang. Standing seven *chi* and five *cun* tall, he possessed an elegant and refined bearing, a leisurely disposition, and features as finely drawn as a painting. His speech resonated like a bell. Skilled in the qin and calligraphy, adept at the long whistle, he favored the teachings of the Yellow Emperor, Laozi, and the fangshi.

After his father’s death, when others sought to wed him to their daughters, he fled, declaring, *"I admire the ancient immortal Hongya; henceforth, I shall style myself Hongyazi."* Wandering to Mount Qinggai, he encountered an old man in coarse brown robes who said, *"This is Jingchengzi, your master."* Following his advice, Zhang sought him out and found a man with unbound hair and grass-cloth garments seated upon a flat rock. Zhang bowed twice, and Jingchengzi asked, *"Who sent you?"* Zhang recounted the old man’s words, and Jingchengzi transmitted all his methods to him. He then said, *"South of Gushe lies an ancient cavern where you should dwell. If you obtain the Five Medicines and have the five youths serve you, you will ascend as an immortal."* Zhang journeyed to Gushe, where a divine being pointed out the cavern. There, he indeed found five youths—Ju, Li, Mu, Ge, and Zhuo—who attended him on either side.

For fifteen years, he secluded himself in the cavern, mastering immortal scriptures, secret classics, the Nine Classics, and the works of a hundred schools. A woodcutter once sighed in admiration, so Zhang poured a cup of water onto a stone, which turned to coins when the woodcutter looked—whenever he returned, he found them there. A scholar named Liu Hui marveled at this and followed him, but Zhang vanished without a trace.

Zhang often rode a blue donkey, accompanied by the five youths, traveling to Lingxia, visiting Kunlun, wandering Mounts Zhongnan, Taihua, Qingcheng, Wangwu, and Taihang. He and the two Heavenly Masters, Ye and Luo, explored the arts of the golden elixir and the Flowery Pond, as well as the techniques of transformation and refinement, though none could fathom their mysteries.

During the Shengli era, Empress Wu summoned him, but he did not go. Once, while drunk outside the cavern’s entrance, he awoke to see a divine being over ten *chi* tall, imposing in stature and dignified in attire. The being pointed at him and asked, *"Why do you not study the Great Reclusion?"* Zhang asked, *"What is the Great Reclusion?"* The divine being replied, *"Amid the nine thoroughfares and three markets, where crowds clamor before you."* Zhang asked again, *"Then what is the Lesser Reclusion?"* The divine being said, *"Dwelling alone in forests and springs, at ease in solitude. This was Bo Yi and Shu Qi on Mount Shouyang—such is the Lesser Reclusion. To immerse oneself in the mundane world is the Great Reclusion."* Zhang bowed in assent, and the divine being vanished.

Later, he lodged in Luoyang with Li Jiao, a Gentleman of the Palace, for thirteen years, where scholars and recluses vied to meet him. In the seventh year of Kaiyuan during Emperor Xuanzong’s reign, he was repeatedly summoned but could not refuse. He finally appeared at the Zhanlu Hall. The emperor asked, *"Master, you are skilled in the long whistle—may I hear it?"* Zhang responded with a sound, its ethereal tones stirring the heart and ear. The emperor said, *"How do I compare to Emperor Yao? How do you compare to Xu You?"* Zhang replied, *"Your Majesty’s Dao surpasses that of Emperor Yao, but my virtue falls short of Xu You’s. When Emperor Yao summoned Xu You, he did not come; now, when Your Majesty summons me, I come."* The emperor praised him and appointed him Minister of Ceremonies, later promoting him to Minister of Works, but Zhang declined all offices, saying, *"Why does Your Majesty begrudge me a mountain or a stream, preventing me from following the path of Xu You and Chao Fu?"* That year, in the eighth month, he was permitted to return to the mountains.

While in the palace, Zhang pointed to a white donkey and said, *"This is a thousand-year-old snow spirit."* The emperor thus bestowed it upon him. An edict ordered his home prefecture to renovate his residence in Xiaoyi Village, naming the village Hongya and the neighborhood Zhengjun. Pastureland for his donkey was granted by the Fen River.

Deng Wang Shouli once asked, *"In Huainan, did the chickens and dogs all ascend as immortals?"* Zhang replied, *"Pursuing the Dao and seeking immortality is like waking from a strange dream—father and son, husband and wife cannot share it."* Shouli asked, *"Can one consume the divine elixir and transmute gold?"* Zhang said, *"Wealth, honor, fame, and sensuality are axes that hew the nature; alchemical refinement and transmutation are blades that cut short life. Herbs, trees, metals, and stones are medicines that rot the intestines—these arts are not to be learned."* Shouli asked, *"Are we not fit to be immortals?"* Zhang replied, *"Do not exhaust your form, do not disturb your essence. Be tranquil, desire little, and you may live long, fulfilling your years."* Shouli said, *"I shall heed your teaching."*

Zhang had a refined taste for antiquities, and many renowned figures of the time gifted him treasures. Li Taiyi, Duke of Kaiguo, sent a letter: *"I have heard of your fondness for antiquities and have long admired you. Recently, a man named Zhang, a ninth-generation descendant of Sima Hua of Jin, traveled a thousand *li* to present me with a wooden sandal once worn by Confucius, saying it had been treasured for two hundred years. Gazing upon an object trodden by the Sage, I dared not keep it and hasten to offer it to you."* Tian Youyan, Gentleman Attendant to the Crown Prince, gifted a tortoise once owned by Yin Xi and a ruyi staff once held by Wang Rong. Guo Han, Imperial Censor, presented Wang Lie’s stone marrow and a pair of Confucius’ sandals. Yang Jiong gave a stone inkstone used by Confucius and an iron inkstone used by Yang Xiong. Monk Weigong offered a bamboo staff with joints. Yang Qizhe bestowed Ji Kang’s forging hammer and Chen Ping’s harmonizing steps. Yuan Ting presented several strands of Xie Lingyun’s beard. Monk Zhiyuan gave Cai Yong’s *jiaowei* qin and Ge Hong’s scraping comb. Monk Touran offered the alms bowl of Kasyapa’s skull. Qin Xiuzhuang presented a draft of the *Daodejing* annotated by the Old Master of the River. Liu Shouzhang gifted a deer-antler pillow once used by the Four Hoary Ones. Sima Ziwei gave the mortar and pestle of the Prince of Huainan. Zhou Zigong presented a scroll of ancient imperial portraits. Military Commissioner Zhang Shougui gifted a giant tooth of a sea toad, measuring one *chi* and eight *cun*. Wei Su gave Tao Yuanming’s *Wuming* qin and a lotus crown. Liu Changxin presented Wang Qiao’s sheng.

Zhang ultimately entered the mountains, abstaining from grain and practicing qi absorption. He secluded himself on Mount Gushe and never emerged again. After some time, Li Sizhen, the Inspector of Hedong, and Guo Zhengyi, the Governor of Jin, went to Gushe in search of him. After several days, they found him beneath a pine tree, wearing a horned cap and a deerskin robe, lying in repose.

Then he said, "Why do court visitors press upon this rustic?" The two sighed and said, "Truly a lofty scholar of the rank of Chaofu and Xu You."

He had once annotated the *Laozi*, the *Book of Changes*, the *Three Ritual Classics*, and the *Guliang Commentary*. He also composed the *Records of Lofty Scholars* in ten fascicles, the *Records of Divine Transcendents* in twenty fascicles, the *Records of Hedong* in thirty fascicles, and the *Great Zhou Treatise* in ten fascicles—none of which were circulated in the world.

In the sixteenth year, a great plague struck Hongzhou. A mad Daoist riding a donkey, followed by five youths, dispensed medicine in the marketplace, and the afflicted were cured on the spot. The prefecture, having heard of this, suspected it was Yun and summoned him by post-horse. Indeed, it was Yun. Yet though summoned thrice, he ultimately did not go. Instead, he took refuge at the ancient altar of Master Hongya, coming and going astride a snow-white steed. He commonly wore a black square cap, a red plantain-fiber robe, a black rhinoceros-hide belt, and short boots. The five youths each carried a six-angled fan, an iron *ruyi*, a bamboo staff, a long brimming flask, a perpetually full cup, a carved pomegranate-wood wine comb, and a natural pomegranate-wood ladle—though some say he habitually wore a tangled-hazelwood cap, a six-angled fan, a cloud-drooping hat, a square wooden stool, the *Two Mysteries* book, a mulberry-wood *ruyi*, a Wei Hu flask, and a cypress-wood ladle, with the five youths attending him in all his comings and goings.

He wandered through the cities, drinking and laughing as he pleased, and none could fathom his words. In the twenty-fifth year, a man from Fanyang obtained two great teeth, each one *chi* and eight *cun* in length, and presented them to the throne.

The throne dispatched an envoy to inquire of Yun, who replied: "Recently beneath Kunlun, I saw toads—some as large as a hundred *chi*—likely inauspicious omens."

In the fourth year of the Tianbao era, at the age of ninety-three, on the eighth day of the fourth month at dawn amid a great mist, he underwent *shijie* upon his couch. The townspeople witnessed him ascend slowly with the five youths. That same year, in the eighth month, he again drank heavily with the villagers of Jinzhou, leaving his robes and shoes behind in farewell. On the sixth day, he underwent *shijie* and ascended in the same manner; the people of Jin preserved his sloughed form at Beiyuan.

During the An Lushan rebellion, his numinous resonance aided Emperor Suzong. In the Qianyuan era, upon Shen Taizhi’s report of strange *qi* at Fulong Mountain in Yuzhang, an edict was issued to establish the Yingsheng Palace, where a statue of Suzong was sculpted, and the Master was enshrined alongside him. This is the present-day Ziqing Palace.

In the reign of Dezong, a temple was erected at his former residence in Jinzhou, and another was built at the site of his *shijie* on Hongya Mountain—both now known as Qizhen Observatories.

Three of Yun’s poems survive in the world. The first reads:
*Last year I had no fields to sow,*
*This spring I lack the wine to brew.*
*Let the crows and blossoms mock my plight—*
*Feigning drunk, I lie upon the tower.*

The second:
*Lowly men are scorned, unfit for use,*
*Yet lofty hearts are met with caution.*
*Unversed in the ways of the vulgar age,*
*How am I to conduct myself as a man?*

The third:
*I enter the market not for gain,*
*Nor pass the court to seek renown.*
*At times I mingle with the common throng,*
*And drift along with their ceaseless round.*

From the western springs of Yuzhang’s Bishui Grotto, several *li* onward to the former site of Xichang County in the Sui and Tang, a stretch of several hundred paces of low-lying stone is known as Little Stonehead. There stands a stone jetty called Hongya Fishing Terrace, and a stone pool called Hongya Inkstone Pond, both traditionally held to mark Yun’s study. Yun resided in Yuzhang for eighteen years, and these are the only traces still verifiable.

*The Taiping Guangji* records that during the reign of Emperor Xianzong of Tang, Han Yu was demoted to Chaozhou. Passing through Shang Mountain, he encountered a nephew who had long followed the cloud-and-water path to Dao, and whose whereabouts had been unknown for years. Suddenly, the nephew appeared before Han Yu’s horse, escorting him as far as Dengzhou. There, he said: “My master dwells on this mountain’s Xuanyu Peak, beneath the Emperor’s Canopy, where he serves as Master of the Eastern Garden. He refines the Nine Radiant Elixir from malleable gold and jade-like water, its firing so subtle that he cannot bear to leave it even briefly. I must take my leave here.” Asked who his master was, the nephew replied: “Master Hongya.” The Master of Crimson Clouds remarked: “Master Hongya is known from antiquity, while Hongya Zi lived in the Tang—clearly two distinct figures.” Yet Hongya Zi was also once addressed as “Master” by Emperor Xuanzong. Was the figure Han Yu’s nephew met truly Hongya Zi, or the ancient Hongya? This remains uncertain, though the world must surely hold those who know.

Minister Dao Yi said: Zhang Yun lived among the common folk to nurture his true nature, yet his name resounded throughout court and countryside. Observe his reply to Emperor Minghuang’s question: “Your Majesty’s Dao surpasses that of Emperor Yao, while my own virtue falls short of Xu You’s.” Such was the height of his humility. Since the Five Emperors ruled the world as an office and the Three Kings as a patrimony, the ranks of emperors and kings have differed. How could Minghuang’s Dao truly surpass Yao’s, or Zhang Yun’s virtue truly fall short of Xu You’s? As the *Daodejing* states: “The reason the rivers and seas can be kings of the hundred valleys is that they excel at lying low—thus they become kings of the hundred valleys. Therefore, the sage who wishes to stand above the people must speak as though beneath them.”

Zhang Yun’s words proved prophetic.

The Recluse Fu Xianzong
Master Fu Xianzong of the Immortal Lineage was a native of Chang’an. His father, Lun, served as magistrate of Ziyang. From childhood, Xianzong was bright and drawn to Daoist learning. At twelve, he withdrew to Mount Ziyang. Soon after, a divine being informed him that Jade Table Mountain was a land of fortune, where he might cultivate his practice. Upon arrival, he built the Abbey of Mystic Tranquility as his dwelling. Within a mere twelve-year cycle, armored warriors appeared one day, announcing: “We are the mountain’s guardian spirits. Since your arrival, we have known no peace. Moreover, this is no place for true cultivation. West of the prefecture lies Flat Ridge Mountain, where you should reside.” Xianzong accepted their counsel, mounted a blue mule, and journeyed to Flat Ridge, where he was attended by spirits and gods. There he built a star altar and a quiet chamber, and between them erected a hall to Lord Lao. Emperor Minghuang summoned him to court. At the Jujube Ford of Lizhou, where boats were annually wrecked by the river’s fury, Xianzong arrived at the crossing. Hearing of the people’s suffering, he inscribed talismans on two stone slabs and cast them into the water. The next day, two great fish were found beached on the shoals, their bellies bearing vermilion characters: “Red carp, red carp, born in river waters, refusing to yield to the immortal master—meet your death.” The prefect reported the event, and an imperial edict established a shrine to Xianzong at the ford. Upon reaching the capital, his responses pleased the emperor, who bestowed generous gifts and commanded him to perform a jiao ritual at the Upper Clarity Palace, which the emperor himself attended. Xianzong invoked the Azure Emperor of the East, the Azure Lads, their divine retinue, and the ranked stellar deities, all of whom descended in solemn procession. The emperor, awestruck, asked: “What Dao have you cultivated to achieve this?” Xianzong replied: “I cultivate the Dao by striving to bring peace to people and benefit to all things. I eat sparingly, dress plainly, abide in tranquility, and act with simplicity. Though stirred, I remain clear; though disturbed, I remain pure. By mastering myself thus, all spirits and gods answer my call.” When asked about the golden elixir, he said: “The elixir of liquid gold cannot be consumed at once. Only when merit is complete, conduct perfected, and kindness extended to all beings may one ingest it to attain longevity.” The emperor was greatly pleased. After some time, Xianzong requested leave to return to the mountains. An edict ordered the restoration of his former abbey, which was granted the name “Abbey of the Perfected,” inscribed by the emperor’s own hand. Thereafter, envoys bearing incense and candles were sent without cease to perform rituals at his altar. On the fourteenth day of the tenth month in the third year of Qianyuan of Emperor Suzong’s reign, a voice was suddenly heard in the sky: “The Supreme Lord faces tribulation.” Xianzong asked for water to bathe, then ascended his couch and departed. A townsman, Wang Nian, returning from Chengdu, saw Xianzong riding his blue mule toward Jianzhou, but thereafter none knew his whereabouts. The memorial stele was composed by Song Hun, Vice Censor-in-Chief.

The Daoist Cheng
Of Master Cheng the Daoist, neither his origins nor his name are known; he concealed himself in obscurity. In the late Kaiyuan era of Emperor Minghuang’s reign, an imperial messenger visited the Temple of the Golden Heaven and heard of the Perfected Cheng. Eager to meet him, the messenger awaited his arrival. A Daoist in tattered robes, bearing a cloth sack, approached. When asked his surname, he replied: “Cheng.” The messenger invited him to the post station and inquired about his studies, but received no answer. He provided a horse to take him to Chengdu, where the matter was reported in secret. Minghuang, intrigued by the account, summoned him to court and lodged him in the Penglai Courtyard. When asked about his arts and practices, Cheng remained silent. Soon after, he requested leave to return to the mountains. The emperor consented, and Cheng departed with his cloth sack, drawing laughter from onlookers. Later, it was discovered that the walls of his chamber bore an inscription, which had been scraped and washed but grew ever clearer: “Westward the road to Shu, northward the Yan army advances. Once meant to ascend in broad daylight, now watch the Black Dragon drink from the Wei.” The emperor heard of it but could not fathom its meaning. Within months, he indeed fled to Shu. The events unfolded as foretold.

Daoist Zhao Huizong
Daoist Zhao Huizong was a native of Yidu in Kuizhou. After long years of registration in the Daoist registers, he mastered the *Nine Heavens’ Immortal Record* and the secret methods of the Three Caverns. Later, he dwelled on Mount Guodao. At the end of the Tianbao era, as Emperor Minghuang returned to the gorges, Huizong suddenly piled firewood in the northeast of the prefecture and set himself ablaze. Officials and commoners rushed to witness the spectacle. Seated serenely amidst the flames, Huizong recited the *Scripture of Salvation*. In an instant, he transformed into auspicious clouds and a crane, vanishing into the sky. When the fire subsided, the grass beneath remained green. A bamboo slip was found, bearing two poems. The first read:
Born of emptiness, placed in nothingness,
Essence becomes spirit, primordial qi the body.
Scattered yang brings light, conjoined yin forms the tally.
The form turns to ash and dust, the spirit dwells among the vulgar.

When all defilements are soon to end, all affairs shall be eternally dissolved.

The second poem read:
I ride the steed of time, the sun and moon my guards,
Illuminating the nine heavens, I ascend to meet the Heavenly Emperor.
O my radiant assembly, and my disciples,
False Dao nurtures the form, true Dao nurtures the spirit.
Diligently, diligently—no more need I say.

Zhai Fayan
Zhai Fayan, styled Qianyu, was a native of Yun’an in Kuizhou. Standing six *chi* tall, he took delight in the teachings of Laozi from a young age, cultivating purity and rejecting the five pungent foods. He dwelled in a hermitage in the Jade Stone Village. In the fourteenth year of the Tianbao era of Emperor Xuanzong of Tang, Qianyu was forty-one when he suddenly dreamed of a youth who said, “Two Perfected Ones bid me tell you: tomorrow, go to the stream.” Qianyu awoke with sudden clarity and, at dawn, arrived at the stream, where he saw two figures seated upon a boulder, their bearing transcendent—they were the two Perfected Ones. Qianyu hastened to pay his respects with utmost reverence. Soon, clouds and mist darkened the sky, and the Perfected Ones mounted them to depart, turning to Qianyu to say, “We have recently perused the *Scripture of Numinous Marvels* and learned of your name, so we came bearing a thread. Hasten to the Cloud Ascension Palace, where we shall transmit to you.” Qianyu immediately went, and the Perfected Ones bestowed upon him the three divisions of the sacred writ of the *Lingji*: first, the secret guardianship of the Three Generals; second, the esoteric arts of the Purple Void; and third, the secret methods of the Supreme Alliance of Orthodox Unity. They also granted him one hundred and twenty divine pills, instructing him to consume one at dawn on the first day of the new year, whereby his lifespan would match their number. They further admonished him, “To the west lies the Reservoir Pool, where five dragons reside. You may summon and employ them to benefit all living beings.” Qianyu bowed and received their words. Thereafter, he built a secluded abode and devotedly practiced the three divisions. Thus, the Perfected Ones, along with the lords of the sun, moon, and stars, descended to his chamber night after night.

The villagers drew water from the Jiangxia River, but it was bitter and turbid. Qianyu dug a well beside his hut and summoned a dragon to preside over it. Even in the height of summer, the water remained sweet and cool. Qianyu became renowned for his mastery of summoning. Reflecting on the perilous rapids of the Yangtze in Yun’an—fifteen in all—he performed a ritual to summon the rapids’ spirits and command them to be stilled. That night, fourteen rapids answered his call, but one failed to appear. Enraged, Qianyu insisted on summoning it. When it finally arrived, it took the form of a woman in a towering headdress and voluminous sleeves, who advanced and addressed him with resolve: “Heavenly Master, you act by the mandate of heaven to transform the world. I am but a water spirit—how dare I resist? Yet there is an unsettled matter I must report. Your intent, I perceive, is merely to ease the passage of boats, but you fail to consider that those who labor in boating already profit doubly each day. Though there may be minor costs, they are no great loss. Along this river live three or four hundred humble folk with no fields to till, no mulberry to weave, who rely entirely on hauling goods for their livelihood. If you flatten all the rapids, while it may benefit boats, what will become of these people’s sustenance? The Supreme’s will surely does not intend this. I fear you may incur blame in the future and bring trouble upon yourself. You ought to reconsider.” Qianyu sighed and said, “Your concerns are beyond my reckoning.” He then commanded the spirits of the fourteen rapids to restore their former dangers. That night, wind and rain roared, thunder crashed, and by morning, the fifteen rapids surged with furious waves, just as before.

The military governor of Jingnan, Wang Ji, heard of Qianyu’s fame and personally sought to receive his teachings. That very night, Emperor Daizong dreamed that Ji was wandering with three divine beings. He dispatched the eunuch emissary Ma Chengjing to inquire, and Ji replied with Qianyu’s account. Daizong then said, “I have a Hall of the Six Jia, fashioned of seven treasures, wherein lies a golden casket with jade slips. I have repeatedly sent masters to open it, but the lock remains immovable. Qianyu is a man of the Dao—he should be able to open it.” He issued an edict for Ji to hasten Qianyu’s preparations. Upon arriving in Chang’an, Qianyu spat wine upon the Hall of the Six Jia, and its doors swung open. Daizong was pleased and bestowed upon him the title *Master of Penetrating the Numinous*. Soon after, Qianyu took his leave, and Daizong gathered his court to bid him farewell. Qianyu took a *yue* and placed it upon a jade table. The other Daoists did not know its purpose. Qianyu said, “In my art, the most skilled goes first. Whoever can lift this *yue* shall be my teacher.” None of the Daoists could lift it. Qianyu slowly took it and placed it before them, yet none could raise it. Daizong asked, “What now?” Qianyu replied, “Lifting it is no difficulty—I merely wished to humble these gentlemen.” He then shouted, and the *yue* rose. Daizong marveled greatly. Qianyu then departed, reaching Jiangling in three days.

Upon returning to his dwelling, he found his mother had been killed by a tiger. Qianyu summoned the tiger, and the earth spirit followed, saying, “The Heavenly Master’s mother suffered the Nine Perils and Eight Calamities—it was by heavenly decree that she was slain.” Qianyu flogged the tiger dozens of times before releasing it. Thereafter, he redoubled his efforts to relieve human suffering, refining cinnabar and gold to aid the destitute. In the twelfth month of the tenth year of the Taihe era of Emperor Wenzong, on the first day, he told his disciples, “Five days hence, I shall ascend to the heavens.” At the appointed time, he passed away, and his disciples buried him. At dusk, they heard the sound of bells and chimes in the clouds, which shone in five resplendent hues. Qianyu appeared above them, leaning down to address his disciples: “Strive diligently—do not forget my Dao.” Then, he slowly ascended and vanished. When they opened his coffin, only his clothes and shoes remained.

Fifteen years later, a man named Li Wensheng encountered Qianyu in Yidu, who said to him, “I have briefly journeyed to Qingcheng; upon my return, I shall ascend in the clouds.” In Xinjin County of Yizhou, the Jilong River bears a tree called the Tethered Dragon Tree. The *Fangyu Ji* records: “The immortal Di Shi came from Mount Emei and tethered a dragon here.” This may well have been Qianyu; let those who later peruse widely determine its veracity.

---
**Volume Forty-One of *Comprehensive Mirror of Realized Immortals Through the Ages Who Embodied the Dao* concludes here**
**Volume Forty-Two of *Comprehensive Mirror of Realized Immortals Through the Ages Who Embodied the Dao***

**Shu Xujī**
Shu Xujī, styled Dezhen, was a native of Kaizhou. His family had long tilled the soil, but Xujī alone delighted in forests and springs, favoring the arts of the Yellow Emperor and Laozi. He served the Heavenly Master Di Qianyu.

Once, the Heavenly Master traveled down the river to the Immortals’ Grotto Abbey, where he discovered the *Divine Writ of the Radiant Staff* in a cave—a text bestowed upon Ge Zhichuan by immortals on Mount Luofu. Qianyu said to Xujī, “This was once secretly obtained by my late master, Song Chongyuan, and its name is recorded in the immortal registers. Though you have now acquired it, you do not yet grasp its essence.” Thereupon, he instructed him, adding, “Before the dual qi, the Dao is the Ancestor. From the Dao, the One Qi generates the Three Powers. Thus, heaven possesses the Nine Yangs, humanity the Nine Origins, and earth the Nine Yins. If one, in receiving life, can return to the Ancestor and guard the Origin, then in resonance and transformation, there is nothing to which one cannot adapt.”

“This text was once bestowed upon Emperor Wu of Han by the Queen Mother of the West. The emperor transmitted it to Li Shaojun, and later the Left Immortal Duke of the Supreme Ultimate obtained it. Ge Zhichuan again received it on Mount Luofu, and my master recovered it from Ge the Immortal Duke on Mount Jun in Dongting. Now I charge you: the Dao of the Radiant Staff rides the Great Culmen, treads the North Pole, gazes upon the Jade Light, follows the Cinnabar Origin, leans upon the Numinous Field, steps upon the Gate of Yang, moves the Primal Net, and grasps the Pivot of Heaven. By wielding the Six Qi and commanding the myriad spirits, one may externally summon gods and internally prolong life.”

Xujī cultivated this as instructed, and all proved divinely efficacious. One day, he told others, “Shu abounds with famous mountains, where gods and immortals gather. I shall journey there.” Upon arrival, he always carried several spoonfuls of ashes in a paper pouch. When asked, he replied, “This can cure a hundred ailments.” To those who sought his aid, he mixed the ashes with his saliva and administered it; no illness failed to be healed.

Once, suffering from mouth sores, he said to others, “Look into my mouth.” He opened it wide as a winnowing basket, revealing all five viscera. Those who saw it were astonished. Later, he entered the Bronze Horse Abbey in Xinfan, where he remained for a long time. He often told people, “Long ago, the Yellow Emperor met with Master Yu and the Heavenly Perfected Sovereign here, gathering the host of immortals. The place was named the Three Assemblies Terrace. A bronze horse lay hidden among the trees, and the Dragon Bridge nearby marks its former site. Later generations built a terrace where the bronze horse was concealed to commemorate it. On clear autumn evenings, the bronze horse would suddenly leap and neigh, and those who witnessed it attained the Dao. I have come and gone from this place for thirty years and have been fortunate enough to see it once.”

After residing there for over a year, he suddenly said to an elderly neighbor woman, “Tonight I shall depart for another place. I wish to entrust my final affairs to you.” Pointing to the ground, he instructed, “Bury me here, digging more than three *chi* deep, and I shall surely repay you generously.” That very night, he passed away. The neighbor woman followed his words and interred him, whereupon she indeed found a *yi* of gold. She reported this to the authorities, who examined the burial site and found only a staff and sandals. Thus, they knew he was a divine immortal who had transformed and departed. In gratitude, the gold was returned to the neighbor woman.

Her son, returning from Linna, saw the empty dwelling. On the bank of the Xinjin River, he placed two sweet melons, inviting her to sit, and they shared one between them. The other he sent to his mother with a message: “After years of troubling you, I now depart far away. We shall never meet again—how could I not feel sorrow?” Only when her son returned home did she learn of his transformation.

The *jinshi* Feng Xiao wrote an account of his life.

**Daoist Xiang Daorong**
Daoist Xiang Daorong, whose origins are unknown, was a man of simple and unrefined manner. He served Xu Jie, receiving from him the *Zhenyuan Celestial Writs*, and his name became widely known in Shu. Once, he wished to cast a white horse and a statue of Lord Lao from thirty *liang* of gold. Two-thirds of the gold had already been prepared, yet he remained unsatisfied, lamenting his incomplete work.

One day, while burning incense and reciting scriptures, an object suddenly fell to the ground. Upon opening it, he found ten *liang* of gold, allowing him to fulfill his vow.

He was close friends with Lü Yi, the vice-magistrate of Huayang. Once, he set out several *dou* of wine and urged Lü Yi to drink, who remained sober until dawn. Daorong then declared the date of his departure from the world, saying, “When the time comes, I ask that you send me off beneath the great pine in the eastern outskirts. Kindly cremate my coffin with firewood as a favor.”

Lü Yi found his precise prediction strange and informed his friends Zhang Sheng and Chang Ji. Together with dozens of others, they marked the appointed day to observe him. The evening before, Daorong visited the homes of all his acquaintances, drinking and laughing until nightfall, when he lodged at an inn. Lü Yi secretly sent someone to watch him, who saw him sleeping as usual. Yet by dawn, he had already transformed, his complexion unchanged.

Lü Yi, Zhang Sheng, and Chang Ji prepared a coffin and lined it with silk at the base of the great pine west of the sandy hollow. They piled firewood and set it alight. As the flames rose, the coffin became too fierce to approach. Then, they saw Daorong emerge above the smoke and fire, slowly ascending into the void.

**Daoist Ren Keju**
Daoist Ren Keju, whose origins are unknown...

At forty, Keju was simple and earnest, carrying his satchel to serve Daorong with utmost devotion. Moved by his dedication, Daorong entrusted him with the *Zhenyuan* talismanic script and esoteric instructions, cautioning: "Only after eighteen years may you reveal its efficacy in averting misfortune or foretelling fortune. Do not seek profit or fame, nor recklessly transmit it. Those who attain this Dao become immortals; those who leak it meet premature death. Formerly, Song Chongyuan transmitted it to Zhai Qianyu, Qianyu to Shu Xūjì, Xūjì to me, and now I transmit it to you—this is the fifth generation. When passing it on, you must scrutinize the recipient’s resolve and conduct; do not bring calamity upon yourself." Keju guarded it in secrecy, sustaining himself with other arts, so none could discern his true attainment.

After twenty years, he gradually began to speak of others’ fortunes and misfortunes, sometimes performing rituals of exorcism or offering. For each divination, he first required the querent to purify themselves through fasting, then arranged lamps against a wall to form the image of the Dipper’s handle. Seated before it, he would perceive the weal or woe, fortune or misfortune, as vividly as if witnessing it firsthand.

During the *Dashun* era of Emperor Zhaozong of Tang, he suddenly told Gao Lusī, magistrate of Huayang: "In ten days, I shall depart this life. I ask you to instruct my disciples to refrain from vulgar rites, for such are forbidden by the Dao." When the appointed day arrived, he passed without illness, and Lusī heeded his words, admonishing the disciples accordingly. The *Zhenyuan* talismanic script and esoteric instructions were never transmitted again.

Program Taixu was a native of Xidui in Guozhou. From childhood, he was devoted to the Dao, his moral integrity unlike that of ordinary men. At fifteen, he ascended the eastern mountain near his home, his spirit soaring as if to transcend the void. Soon, clouds of five colors enveloped him, and celestial music with feathered canopies descended in obscurity. Taixu silently reflected that he had not yet bid farewell to kin and friends when suddenly a thunderclap resounded, and all vanished from sight. Returning home, he redoubled his resolve, his cultivation and recitations growing ever more diligent.

At eighteen, having lost both parents, he abandoned his inheritance and dwelled on Mount Nanmin, fasting until he forgot both body and mind. Months and years passed thus, and two tigers attended him on either side, as if awaiting his commands. He named them Good Word and Good Deed, then imparted to them the Three Refuges. They knelt and obeyed, and from then on, they came whenever he called their names. One night, a great wind uprooted trees amid thunder, lightning, and rain. The courtyard’s foundation collapsed, revealing a pit from which boiling water surged. Stirring it with his staff, he retrieved a double-handled jade seal of deep green. Each year, when farmers sought talismans and registers for bountiful harvests, he would imprint them with the seal, and those who received them enjoyed ever greater abundance. Whatever remained after his acts of charity, he used to build shrines and commission images, keeping nothing for himself.

A Daoist nun named Xie Ziran received his teachings and talismans. After imprinting them, he would conceal the seal, but one day it vanished without a trace. In the tenth year of the *Zhenyuan* era of Emperor Dezong of Tang, Ziran ascended to heaven in broad daylight. In the fourth year of the *Yuanhe* era of Emperor Xianzong, Taixu dissolved his mortal form.

In the fifth year, during the second month, he was interred in the divine abode of Zixuan. His countenance remained unchanged, and his body was as light as an empty robe. Where he had transformed, a single *zaojia* tree suddenly sprouted, its branches and leaves drooping—commonly called the "hanging-head *zaojia*."

In the tenth year of the *Dazhong* era of Emperor Xuanzong of Tang, an imperial envoy traveling from the gorges into Shu passed through southern Min to visit Taixu’s shrine. To his disciples, he recounted: "Last winter, as I passed through Shangshan and lodged at an inn, I stepped outside and saw flowers and trees flourishing upon the ridge. Impulsively, I climbed the rocks and scaled the perilous path, ascending some fifty or sixty steps. Below, rare blossoms lined the way for over a *li*. There stood a residence like an official guest hall, where a youth in blue led me inside. I met a Daoist who called himself Cheng Taixu, saying his ancestors hailed from the Western Dui and that he now rested there. He lingered with great warmth and earnestly urged, ‘Next year, when you return from Shu to Min, do not forget to visit me.’ Now, gazing closely at his image, it is indeed no different from the man I saw."

**Yu Lingzuo**
Yu Lingzuo was a native of Hejian. He resided at the Jiuzhen Abbey on Mount Heng, studying the Dao for over a decade. The Red Lord of the Southern Marchmount took notice of him and transmitted the Way of Returning Wind and the method of Guarding the Bright Beam. After practicing for twenty years, he could sit and perceive the affairs of heaven as if viewing his own palm. Yet he concealed his abilities, refusing to astonish the common folk with marvels, and thus none knew of his spiritual attainment. When conversing with others, he often spoke of his travels across the Four Seas and the Nine Provinces. His appearance remained that of a man in his thirties.

During the *Yuanhe* era of Emperor Xianzong of Tang, officials in Bangzhou heard Lingzuo recount the names, appearances, preferences, temperaments, posts, and lifespans of their ancestors—all accurate. The crowd marveled and paid him reverence, but he merely said, "This was mere happenstance, not something I comprehend." He then withdrew, sealing his gate and refusing to emerge, even when earnestly entreated. Only then did they realize he was an extraordinary man. He frequently recited the *Scripture of the Great Cavern*, sometimes fasting, sometimes drinking wine.

An elder immortal named Pan traveled to the Marchmount and befriended Lingzuo closely. He kept an primordial tortoise, four or five *chi* in breadth, whose strength rivaled that of ten men—those who saw it feared it. Lingzuo later rode it into the Jiuyi Mountains, where woodcutters occasionally glimpsed him.

**Zhao Zhiwei**
The Daoist Zhao Zhiwei’s origins were unknown. He built a hut on Phoenix Ridge of Mount Jiuhua, reciting Daoist scriptures daily. For decades, he wore clothing of grass and ate only wild plants, thereby attaining the Dao. Many followed him, and Huangfu Yuanzhen became his disciple for fifteen years.

During the *Xiantong* era of Emperor Yizong of Tang, Zhiwei refined elixirs and sent Yuanzhen to the capital to purchase ingredients. Yuanzhen lodged at the Upper Clarity Courtyard of the Jade Purity Abbey. At the time, Huangfu Mei visited him daily, inquiring about Zhiwei’s affairs. Yuanzhen said: "Since becoming his disciple, I have never seen him display laziness. He once said that he had mastered the arts of dividing cups to form mist and transforming bamboo to angle for bream—though these are but minor parlor tricks.

Last year, on Mid-Autumn, heavy rains fell, and the disciples lamented that the fine evening would pass without moon-viewing. Suddenly, our master ordered a servant to prepare wine and hastily summoned the students. He asked, ‘Who among you dares ascend Heavenly Pillar Peak to admire the moon?’ Though the students assented, they were inwardly astonished. Soon after, our master emerged with his staff, and we followed. When the gate was opened, the sky had cleared, and the bright moon shone as if day. Grasping vines and bamboo, we stood atop the peak. Our master sat solemnly, while we disciples arrayed ourselves beside him. We raised our cups and chanted several poems by Guo Jingchun on roaming immortals. Some disciples whistled clearly, some paced the void, and one played the zither. We did not return until the moon had set. Yet upon lying down, the wind and rain resumed as before."

Yuanzhen was unmatched in chess and skilled in the arts of transformation. After a long time, he returned to Mount Jiuhua and never emerged again.

**Liu Daoping**

Master Liu the Immortal, styled Daoping, resided at Chongxian Abbey of Jade Bamboo, which is today’s Qianyuan Abbey. As early as the reign of Emperor Wu of Han, Dongfang Shuo memorialized: *"Among those destined for celestial office, only Liu Daoping of Pengcheng shall be chosen."* Thus it is known that Master Liu’s immortality was no mere accident.

From childhood, the Master’s inclinations and conduct set him apart from ordinary men. Whenever households were afflicted by pestilence, he would fashion a bamboo horn, inscribe talismans on palm-leaf paper, and with raised arm cry out commands—whereupon all would instantly recover. In times of drought or locust plagues, his invocations were always answered.

When Huang Chao rose in rebellion and swept southward with relentless force, every city he reached fell. Fearing his savagery, the people fortified the ridges and hills. Yet still they fretted over their weak defenses and scant weaponry, so they hastened to Chongxian Abbey to plead for the Master’s aid. Taking pity, he emerged from the northern slopes of the peaks and dispatched spirit soldiers to repel the rebels. Without brandishing a single blade or loosing a single arrow, they routed Huang Chao’s forces—clear proof of the Immortal’s power.

Thereafter, his numinous manifestations multiplied, until at last he ascended lightly into the heavens.

At the summit where he ascended, a yellow stone remains, traditionally called the "Flying Immortal’s Stone," bearing only the imprint of two sandals in white, marking its singularity.

Master Lian Nie Shao-yuan, styled Bozu, was a Daoist adept. His mother, née Cheng, during her pregnancy, abstained from meat and fish. She once dreamed of a celestial being pointing to her belly and saying, "This child shall attain the fruit of the Dao." Born with exceptional intelligence, he kept apart from other children. As he grew, he developed a refined love for books and history, particularly excelling in the works of Laozi, Zhuangzi, Wenzi, and Liezi.

One day, he traveled to Jinling and became a disciple of the Daoist master Gao Lang-zhao, receiving the precepts and registers. That night, he dreamed of entering a city with solemn and imposing offices. Within, a figure in crimson robes, leaning on a desk, addressed Shao-yuan: "This is the Bureau of Longevity. You may examine your own record." The register read: "Nie Shao-yuan enters the Dao at eighteen. At twenty, he receives the Shangqing Perfect Methods. At twenty-six, he journeys to Mount Nanyue." He closed the scroll and awoke.

Later, returning from Jinling to Mount Wen-zheng, he built a hut to reside in. Disdaining worldly conventions, he styled himself the "Nameless One" and wrote the *Record of the Nameless One’s Thatched Hall*. The world often addressed him as Master Lian.

At that time, the Later Lord of Southern Tang was devoted to Buddhism, honoring monks and nuns with reverence, while showing disdain for those in Daoist crowns and coarse robes. Many, lured by fame and profit, shaved their heads and beards to join the Buddhist ranks. Master Lian submitted a memorial in earnest admonition.

Later, due to his mother’s advanced age, he attended to her with utmost devotion, exhausting himself in care. One morning, after bathing, he declared, "My ancestor Bozu once said: ‘Our family, generation after generation, should cultivate the Dao. Each of you must strive earnestly and never forget the teachings of the Most High.’" Suddenly, four cranes alighted on the roof, and a divine radiance descended from the sky, blazing brightly in all four directions. Those in the city who saw it mistook it for a fire and rushed to the scene, only to find nothing amiss—yet Shao-yuan had already departed. The four cranes and the divine radiance ascended slowly into the distance.

The evening before, he had told his mother, "General Hu is arriving. Prepare wine and fruit for fourteen guests." Soon after, sounds and shadows suggested the presence of seated guests. At dawn, the estate servants arrived, reporting: "Master Lian, accompanied by three Daoists in green robes, rode horses southward, followed by dozens of attendants in resplendent attire." Shao-yuan turned his head and said, "I am going to Mount Nanyue."

He authored the *Treatise on the Nature of the Dao* and *Secret Methods of Cultivating Perfection*. Scholars Xu Xuan and Xu Cuo both praised his works, declaring, "Wu Jun and Shi Jian-wu cannot surpass him."

Xu Zuo-qing was a man of unknown origins.

In the thirteenth year of the Tianbao era of the Tang, on the Double Ninth Festival, Emperor Minghuang was hunting at Shayuan when a lone crane was seen circling in the clouds. The emperor personally shot it, and the crane fell with the arrow still lodged in its body. When it was about ten feet from the ground, it suddenly spread its wings and soared toward the southwest. The crowd gazed after it for a long time, but it vanished from sight.

Fifteen *li* west of Chengdu stood a Daoist abbey, whose halls were inhabited only by those devoted to cultivation. The first courtyard of the eastern cloister was especially secluded. Zuo-qing often called himself a Daoist of Mount Qingcheng, his bearing refined and ancient. Three or four times a year, he would visit the abbey, lodging in the Hall of Empty Virtue to await his arrival. When he came, he would stay for three to five days—or even a full month—before declaring his return to Mount Qingcheng. He was deeply revered by all.

One day, he arrived unexpectedly from outside, his countenance troubled. Carrying an arrow, he said to those present, "I was accidentally struck by this in the mountains, but I have recovered. However, this arrow does not belong to any mortal. The owner will come here next year, and I shall return it then." He left it behind the wall and inscribed the date: "The ninth day of the ninth month in the thirteenth year." When Emperor Minghuang fled to Shu and visited the abbey, he saw the arrow and ordered it brought to him. Upon inspection, he recognized it as his own. Startled, he questioned the Daoist, who answered truthfully. Thus, the crane shot at Shayuan the previous year was none other than Xu Zuo-qing. Upon reading the inscription, the emperor realized that in a single instant, the crane had flown from Shayuan to this place. Thereafter, no one in Shu ever encountered Zuo-qing again.

Thirty *li* east of Wuxing, a lovely stretch of streams and mountains lay between two towering peaks to the north and south, known as Feixian Ridge. Elders of the region passed down that this was where Zuo-qing, wounded by the arrow, had alighted. Below the ridge, the ruins of Feixian Abbey still stood. During the Huangyou era of Emperor Renzong of the Song, the northern envoy Guo Zi inscribed a poem there:

*"The emerald ridge marks the immortal’s path near,
Where azure trees part in the mist.
Often when a crane cries over the crags,
One wonders if a feathered robe descends.
At times, a stone flies from the sheer cliff,
Or a cold pool suddenly thunders—
Surely the arrow from the imperial hunt
Still lingers in the cinnabar terrace."*

Li Xia-zhou was a man of unknown origins, possessed of Daoist arts, his appearances and disappearances unfathomable. During the Kaiyuan era of Emperor Minghuang of the Tang, he was once summoned into the imperial palace. After some time, he requested leave to reside at Xuandu Abbey. The chancellor Li Linfu visited him, and Xia-zhou said, "While you live, your family will prosper; when you die, your family will perish." Linfu bowed, weeping, and begged for salvation. Xia-zhou merely smiled and did not answer, then said, "I was only jesting."

In the final years of the Tianbao era, An Lushan grew arrogant and overbearing, causing widespread concern, though the emperor remained oblivious. One day, Xia-zhou vanished without a trace. All that remained were several poems inscribed on the walls of his dwelling, foretelling Lushan’s usurpation and the emperor’s flight to Shu. No one could decipher them at the time, but later, all came to pass. The last lines read:

*"In the Yan market, all the people depart;
At Hangu Pass, the horses do not return.
If you meet the ghost beneath the mountain,
Bind a silk sash upon the jade ring."*

"The Yan market, all the people depart" referred to Lushan’s rebellion, raised with the forces of You and Ji. "At Hangu Pass, the horses do not return" foretold the defeat of Geshu Han at Tong Pass, where not a single horse escaped. "If you meet the ghost beneath the mountain" alluded to *gui* (ghost), the name of a post station. "Bind a silk sash upon the jade ring" referred to Precious Consort Yang, whose childhood name was Jade Ring, and who was strangled with a silk sash by Gao Lishi at Mawei. All his prophecies were of this nature.

Xie Tong-xiu.

Xie Tong-xiu was originally a native of Yichun Prefecture. By nature gentle and refined, he disliked adornment; hearing of goodness brought him joy, while encountering evil was like plunging his hand into boiling water. He served his mother with utmost filial devotion, always wearing a cheerful countenance. In the early years of the Dazong Emperor’s *Dali* reign, one night he suddenly dreamed of a man in a hempen cap who approached and said to him, "Your bones are not those of an ordinary man—why not study the Dao?" Upon waking, he recounted the words to his mother. She approved of his intent and permitted him to seek the Way.

He then journeyed to Mount Heng, where he requested ordination as a Daoist priest. After a long absence, he returned home to visit his mother, only to find five years of famine and scarcity. His kin had scattered, and his acquaintances had fled. One night, he dreamed again of the same man in the hempen cap, who said to him, "In the celestial division of Luling, there is a Jade Bamboo Mountain—a grotto-heaven and blessed land. Within it lies the Pavilion of Pure Emptiness, a detached palace of the Bureau of Destiny, a realm where perfected beings gather and feast. You should go there to cultivate the Dao."

The next day, his mother again consented. Carried in a litter, he entered Jade Bamboo Mountain, where he built no hermitage but dwelled beneath cliffs and among trees. His sustenance consisted of hazelnuts, chestnuts, peaches, apricots, and lingzhi mushrooms. Thus he lived for nearly half a *ji*. When his mother grew old, he buried her in the family tomb. After sealing the burial mound, he donned straw sandals and took up a pilgrim’s staff, wandering among the peaks to seek the numinous. He never left the mountain caves, wearing only grass and eating only wild plants. If anyone encountered him, he would remove his own robe to clothe them.

For over thirty years, he slept in forests and dwelled in caves, cutting himself off from the world of men. One day, deep in a mountain stream’s source, he came upon a stone stele, some three *chi* in length, its surface overgrown with moss and eroded by rain. Brushing it aside, he saw that the inscription remained legible—it was the text of the Pavilion of Pure Emptiness, composed by Minister Xiao. A hundred paces farther, he found an old site where broken tiles and shattered bricks lay scattered upon the ground. The springs and forests were pristine, the flowers fragrant. There he built a hut, choosing it as his place to ascend to perfection.

Before long, the villagers learned of him and, one after another, helped construct an abbey, which they named *Qingju* ("Pure Dwelling"). Some say that from this place, he delved into the mysteries of the Dao, transmitting its teachings, and disciples from all directions flocked to him in numbers beyond counting. When Tong-xiu entered the mountain caves, he would return after five days or ten, speaking of strange and wondrous things.

In the early years of Emperor Muzong’s *Changqing* reign, he entered Yu Wood Hollow and suddenly beheld a mansion with layered eaves and spacious halls, its whitewashed walls and long corridors flanked by rare trees and divine birds—nothing of this world. His spirit instantly felt refreshed, and he lingered in admiration. Soon, a youth in green robes emerged and asked, "Are you Xie Tong-xiu?" "Yes," he replied. The youth said, "The two perfected ones, Xiao and Mei, have awaited you for a long time." He led Tong-xiu inside, where he saw one figure wearing a purple sash and girded with a sword, seated to the left of the hall, and another in a green sash and holding a bamboo slip, seated to the right.

Tong-xiu bowed twice and addressed them: "I am but an ant in the dust of the mortal world, yet I yearn for the Way of immortality. For thirty-six years, I have toiled in devotion. Today, by some fate, I have reached this sacred realm and stand before perfected immortals. My withered bones are reborn, and I have attained this meeting of the mysterious." Xiao said, "Though your heart longs for the Dao and you dwell at the edge of mountains and forests, the *qi* of pungent and acrid foods has not yet dissipated—how could you remain here?" (Tong-xiu had eaten garlic in his youth.) Overcome with sorrow, he prostrated himself and pleaded unceasingly. The two perfected ones, moved by his sincerity, bestowed upon him five ears of auspicious grain and half a *jin* of pine needles, instructing him to consume them at once. Tong-xiu knelt to receive them and ate half, but could not finish the rest.

The two said, "You should return to your dwelling and await further instructions." Upon his return, in the eighth year of Emperor Xuanzong’s *Dazhong* reign, he suffered from bloody dysentery, which only abated the following spring—this was the sign of his purification from the impurities of pungent foods. On the seventh day of the fourth month that year, he suddenly told his disciples, "Last night, I dreamed that the grotto-palace had summoned me to the ranks of immortals. I shall depart soon." The next day, he passed away. His disciples laid him in a coffin.

That night, he dreamed of his master, who said, "I possess a treasured sword—why do you not follow me?" At dawn, he placed the sword in the coffin, but when he looked, his master’s mortal remains had vanished. Thus, he buried the empty coffin at the northeast corner of the abbey. Tong-xiu was then ninety-eight years old.

In the early years of Emperor Yizong’s *Xiantong* reign, a Daoist from Wen-zheng Mountain named Nie Shi-dao, traveling through Yu-mu Hollow, encountered him. Only then was it known that Tong-xiu had indeed become a perfected one.

**Han Xiang**

Han Xiang, styled Qing-fu, was the nephew of Han Yu, Duke Wen-gong. Wild and unrestrained, he paid little heed to his uncle’s exhortations to study. When Wen-gong urged him, Xiang replied, "What I pursue is beyond your understanding." Wen-gong bade him compose a poem to reveal his aspirations. Xiang wrote:

*"Green mountains, cloud-wreathed caves—
this place is my home.
At midnight, I drink the flowing nectar;
at dawn, I chew the crimson mist.
My zither plays the ‘Jade Melody’;
my furnace refines cinnabar.
The golden tiger guards the cauldron;
white crows feed in the primal field.
A gourd holds the world entire;
a blade of three feet slays demons.
I brew wine for border patrols;
I make flowers bloom in an instant.
Whoever can learn from me
shall witness the immortal blossoms with me."*

Wen-gong read it and teased, "Can you truly seize the workings of creation?" Xiang replied, "This is a trifling matter." Wen-gong opened a wine vessel, and Xiang took up soil, covering it with a basin. After a long while, two blossoms emerged—jade-green, resembling peonies but larger, their hues radiant. Between the petals appeared a couplet in golden script:

*"Clouds veil the Qin Ridge—where is my home?
Snow chokes Blue Pass—my horse will not advance."*

Wen-gong did not grasp its meaning, but Xiang said, "Time will prove its truth." Then he took his leave.

Before long, Wen-gong was demoted to Chaozhou for his memorial on the Buddha’s relic. One day on the road, amid falling snow, a man suddenly appeared through the storm—it was Xiang. He said, "Do you recall the lines on the flowers? They foretell today’s events." Wen-gong asked where they were, and Xiang replied, "This is Blue Pass." Sighing deeply, Wen-gong composed a poem:

*"A single memorial submitted at dawn to the ninefold heavens,
by dusk, I am exiled eight thousand leagues to Chaoyang.
I sought to purge corruption for a sagely reign—
how could I, feeble and worn, cling to these fading years?
Clouds veil the Qin Ridge—where is my home?
Snow chokes Blue Pass—my horse will not advance.
Knowing you have come from afar with purpose,
tend well to my bones by the miasmic river’s edge."*

They lodged that night at Blue Pass’s posting house, and only then did Wen-gong believe the Dao was no deception. When Xiang prepared to depart, Wen-gong tried to detain him, but in the end, he wrote a farewell poem:

*"Since ancient times, many have been called to serve the world—
yet who among them rivals your prodigious talent?
Wait until your name and deeds are fulfilled,
then withdraw to the misty wilds beyond."*

Xiang’s parting poem read:

*"The world is drunk on fame and gain,
while I alone awaken to the Dao.
One day, I shall ascend in flight,
piercing the autumn sky—a speck of blue."*

Xiang said to Wen-gong, "You journey to a land of miasmic poison—it will be difficult to preserve your health." He took out a gourd of medicine and said, "Take one pill, and it will shield you from the noxious vapors." Wen-gong replied, "I truly fear I may not escape death, my soul wandering beyond the seas. The thought brings tears to my eyes. I dare not hope for wealth or rank again—if only I might live to pass through Ghost Gate Pass, it would suffice." Xiang said, "You will not remain there long. Not only will your family be safe, but you shall be restored to office." Wen-gong asked, "Will we meet again?" Xiang replied, "Our prior agreement remains uncertain." Later, all came to pass as he had foretold.

**Xuan-yuan Ji**

Master Xuan-yuan Ji of Mount Luo-fu was a man of unknown origins. He dwelled on Mount Luo-fu, and it was said he had lived for centuries, yet his complexion remained youthful, his hair so long it trailed upon the ground. When he sat in a dark room, his eyes emitted beams of light several *zhang* in length. Whenever he gathered herbs in the cliffs and valleys, venomous dragons and fierce beasts followed him as if to guard and protect. Though he was often invited to over a hundred households for vegetarian feasts, he would arrive at each without fail, as if dividing his form. When drinking with others, he would produce a single pot no larger than one or two *sheng*, yet no matter how many guests filled the hall, the wine flowed endlessly for days. If he commanded someone to drink, they could consume a hundred *sheng* without intoxication. At night, he would hang his hair over a basin, and wine would drip forth in a steady stream, its fragrance of yeast and malt undiminished. If he wrote talismans in vermilion, they could summon things from a thousand *li* away. When he brushed the sick with a cloth, they would recover at once.

Emperor Xuan-zong summoned him and asked, "Can long life be attained?" He replied, "Abandon sensual pleasures, temper rich flavors, find joy in simplicity, and practice virtue without partiality. Then you will naturally align your power with Heaven and Earth, your brightness with the sun and moon. Even the Dao of Yao, Shun, Yu, and Tang can be achieved—how much more so long life and enduring vision?" The emperor asked, "How do you compare to Zhang Guo?" He answered, "I know nothing of others, only that I am younger than Guo."

As he withdrew, the emperor tested him by covering a white magpie with a golden basin. Ji was resting outside when he said to the eunuch, "How can the emperor make this old man divine what is hidden?" The eunuch did not understand, and the emperor summoned him again, urging haste. As Ji reached the jade steps, he said to the emperor, "The white magpie beneath the basin should be released." The emperor laughed and said, "You knew it all along." He ordered Ji to sit before the imperial dais and had palace attendants serve him tea.

Ji’s appearance was ancient yet unadorned. Those who laughed at him would suddenly find themselves with crimson lips and the visage of a maiden of sixteen, only to transform in an instant into withered crones—skin sagging, hair ashen—weeping uncontrollably. The emperor ordered Ji to undo the spell, and they reverted to their former selves.

The capital had never seen *dou-lu* or lychee blossoms. When the emperor mentioned this, in moments both flowers arrived—hundreds of blooms each, branches lush and leaves as if freshly trimmed.

Once, when examining lychees, Ji said, “Beneath my mountain grows a finer variety.” The emperor replied, “I have never tasted them.” Ji then took a jade bowl from before the imperial seat, covered it with a jeweled tray, and in an instant lifted the tray to reveal lychees beneath. The emperor ate them and marveled at their unmatched sweetness.

The emperor asked, “How many years will I reign?” Ji took up a brush and wrote forty characters. Each set of ten formed a line, and the emperor laughed, “How could I hope for forty years?” Yet when he passed, it was indeed fourteen years later.

After some time, Ji requested to return to his mountain. The emperor sent an attendant to escort him. Along the way, Ji was seen drawing coins from a cloth sack to give to the poor; by the time they reached Jiangling, he had dispensed tens of thousands, yet the sack never emptied. Before reaching the mountain, he vanished without a trace. The attendant, alarmed, soon received word from Nanhai that the master had returned to Mount Luofu.

**Xiong Derong**
