The Perfected Master Xiong, named Derong and styled Daguang, was a native of Jingzhou. From childhood, he was indifferent to worldly desires, abstaining from meat and strong flavors, his resolve sharp with a longing to transcend the mundane. At thirteen, he left home to seek the Dao, enduring hardship and toil across a thousand *li*. All who saw him marveled.

Later, when he reached Mount Jiuyi, he suddenly encountered a man by the roadside—his hair green, his complexion crimson, his eyes luminous and bright. Suspecting this was no ordinary person, Derong approached and questioned him, but the man only murmured in assent without speaking. Then, taking Derong by the hand, he led him deep into the mountains until they reached a stone chamber. There, he seated Derong and said: *"The Dao abhors杂乱;杂乱 brings disturbance, disturbance brings sorrow, and sorrow cannot be remedied. Thus the sage first cultivates it within himself before extending it to others."* He added: *"It endures like an unbroken thread, yet its use is never exhausted."* Then he declared: *"Your bone structure foretells your eventual attainment of immortality, though not yet."* With that, he reached into his waistband, drew out a gourd, and poured wine for them to drink, saying: *"We shall meet again one day—strive on, strive on!"* Then he entered the chamber. Derong waited for days, but the man never reemerged. For months afterward, he wandered in melancholy, lost in thought.

In the early years of Emperor Xuānzōng’s *Taizhong* era, Derong traveled to Mount Lu, where he took up residence at the Abbey of Simplicity and Stillness. There, he would sit in meditation in a solitary chamber, motionless all day, leaving others to wonder at his practices. In the second year of Emperor Yìzōng’s *Xiantong* era, he departed this world.

Several days after the burial, a Daoist priest returning south encountered Derong on the road, walking alone with a silk headscarf and a flowering staff. The priest asked where he was going, and Derong replied, *"I am bound for Mount Jiuyi to seek my master."* The priest returned home and recounted the meeting. When they opened the coffin, they found nothing inside but a single hairpin.

Earlier, those who had followed Derong—such as Chancellor Li Jue, Chancellor Cui Zhi, and Prefect Yu Dehui—all revered his Way and called themselves his disciples.

---

**Liu Deben**
Liu Deben, styled Xiaoshu, was a native of Ezhou. Skilled in many arts and fond of antiquity, he once inscribed the Six Classics and the histories of the philosophers in seal script. Though his family was wealthy and noble, he sought no official position, instead traveling the great rivers as a merchant.

In the second year of Emperor Xizong’s *Qianfu* era, Huang Chao sacked Ezhou, and the Yangtze region was thrown into turmoil. Judging that he could not return home, Deben abandoned his house and boat, taking to the roads by land. That year, famine was severe, and many starved. Deben distributed the tens of thousands of *shi* of rice he had been transporting, saving over ten thousand households. He buried the dead, and his virtue was admired far and wide.

Later, he took refuge at the foot of the Five Old Peaks, on the southern slope of Mount Lu. One day, a Daoist with unbound hair and a deer-fur robe came to visit, refusing to give his name. Deben welcomed him with poetry and wine, and they enjoyed each other’s company. After some time, the Daoist took Deben by the arm and led him into a deep ravine. Suddenly, they saw an old man leaning on a staff among the rocks. Deben bowed twice, but the old man did not respond. Slowly, he asked, *"What brings you here?"* Deben recounted his journey. The old man seemed about to speak, then said, *"Go to the rear courtyard."* They walked together for four or five *li* until they saw another gate, its vermilion and azure hues radiant, inscribed in gold with the words *"Gate of Purple Radiance of the Primordial Essence."* Beyond it rose tiered pavilions and connected halls, guarded by stern sentinels who barred Deben from advancing. Overawed, he dared not lift his gaze. As he hesitated, the old man said, *"This is the Grotto-Heaven of Chanting Perfection. The Celestial Envoy, the True King, surveys the mortal realm. Because of your good deeds, you are permitted to come here. Your name shall be recorded in the Celestial Register of Immortals, and you will transcend the world without dying."*

Deben bowed again and asked, *"Where does the Celestial Envoy, the True King, reside?"* The old man replied, *"You have lived through four lifetimes, and your karmic burdens remain heavy. Your bone structure is not yet purified—it is not yet time to ask. You must strictly uphold the precepts, clarify your mind and spirit, aid others, and benefit all beings. The True King perceives even the subtlest deeds. One day, he will surely lift you to transcendence."*

Deben bowed in gratitude. Before he could blink, the old man vanished. Returning to his former lodging, Deben asked the Daoist, *"Who was that immortal elder?"* The Daoist answered, *"He is the spirit-official of the Grotto of Chanting Perfection, a guardian of the Celestial Envoy, the True King. Since you have once entered the divine precincts and received solemn instruction, I must now take my leave of you."*

Thereafter, Deben wandered among the Five Sacred Peaks and other blessed mountains. One day, auspicious clouds and auspicious cranes encircled his dwelling. Deben then ascended in flight, and from that time on, he was called *"Immortal Elder Liu."*

---

**Li Guizhen**
The Daoist Li Guizhen’s origins are unknown. In the late Tang, he traveled to Hongzhou’s Xinguo Abbey, where he saw an imperial edict of Emperor Minghuang displayed in the Hall of the Three Officials. The edict praised the exquisite craftsmanship of the clay statues, but the caretakers had not guarded them well, and sparrows had soiled them with droppings. Guizhen then painted an osprey on the wall, and from that time on, no sparrows perched there again.

Later, someone saw Guizhen ascending to immortality on Mount Luofu.

**Zhu Taochui**

Zhu Taochui, styled as *Taochui* in the alchemical retreats of Lingquan’s Fenglian Mountain, attained the Dao and realized the fruit of immortality. Yet he took no delight in ascending in flight, instead mingling among woodcutters and herdsmen, moving between cities and mountains, ever mindful of saving the world and delivering others. The marvels witnessed by those who encountered him defy easy recounting.

Another account holds that he achieved the Dao on Yuzhen Mountain in Shu, leaving behind works such as *Inscription on Nurturing Life*, *Rhapsody on the Thatched Cottage*, *Water Melody Song*, and *Autumn Stirring the Courtyard*, among others. In essence, these writings describe the joys of reclusion and the secrets of inner alchemy.

*The Chronicles of Shu* states: The Daoist Zhu Taochui once visited Wang Chuhui. At the steps before the hall, he drew his sword to turn the earth and planted three flower seeds. In an instant, three blossoms bloomed. Taochui said to Chuhui, "These are the *Banner Flowers of the Immortals*—an omen of your wealth and nobility." Chuhui later governed Shu’s three commanderies, retiring as Grand Tutor to the Crown Prince, just as Taochui had foretold.

Many in Shu revered him. Later, someone commissioned a painter surnamed Xu to capture his likeness. Xu, who had never known what Taochui looked like, struggled to begin. Then, one day, an old man in tattered robes, his face gaunt, arrived with two young attendants. "I am the Perfected Zhu," he said. He then took from the attendants’ satchel a yellow Daoist robe, a deerskin cap, and a white jade hairpin. Donning the cap and changing into the robe, he sat upright, stroking his face until his complexion became youthful. He tugged at his beard, and it turned black at his touch, revealing a handsome, imposing figure—his bearing ethereal, his spirit transcendent. One attendant appeared most peculiar, the other strikingly refined. In an instant, their forms transformed.

The painter, astonished, exclaimed, "I did not know a divine immortal would descend!" The Daoist said, "Render my spirit in your shop. If anyone seeks to purchase it, ask only for a thousand coins." Later, someone recognized him, saying, "This is Zhu Taochui from *The Traditions of Divine Immortals of the Tang*."

Afterward, those seeking the painting came in droves. Xu raised the price to two thousand coins, whereupon he dreamed of the Daoist saying, "Your blessings are limited—how can you demand more?" He then struck Xu’s left cheek. When Xu awoke, his head was permanently tilted. He bowed before the painted image, repenting his greed and refusing to raise the price again. Thereafter, in Shu, Xu’s lopsided depiction of the Perfected Zhu became renowned as a masterpiece, and it was said that the Perfected had been enfeoffed as *Marvelously Responsive and Efficacious Perfected Lord*.

**Autumn Stirring the Courtyard**

In the late Tang, there was a mad Daoist of unknown origin, who concealed even his name.

In Chengdu, the mad Daoist suddenly visited the Purple Ultimate Palace to call upon Master Du Guangting, seeking a place to lodge. The master assented but did not provide one. The Daoist was seen daily selling medicines in the market, using whatever coins he earned to buy wine and drink, singing only the lyrics of *Autumn Stirring the Courtyard*. His intent was to lament the impending fall of Shu, as autumn withers the garden. Yet none understood him, and people simply called him the *Autumn Stirring the Courtyard* Daoist. For half a year, no one suspected he was extraordinary.

One evening, returning deeply drunk as night drew late, his singing grew ever louder. Those who found it strange peered through the door and saw a dazzling scene: lamps and candles ablaze, tables and vessels arrayed in splendor. The mad Daoist was attended by two blue-clad youths standing at his side, pouring wine as he sang. The onlookers reported this to Master Du, who then knocked at the door, saying, "Guangting’s capacity and knowledge are shallow. I never imagined an immortal would deign to visit—this is a grave transgression. Yet, unworthy as I am, I prostrate myself at your gate, hoping for a glimpse of your radiant presence to dispel the dust of my hindrances."

The Daoist replied, "Why such earnest humility? I shall come forth to receive you." He then instructed the two youths to gather the tables, vessels, and all the furnishings before them. As they did so, the objects shrank in their hands to the size of talismans and were placed inside his cap. Next, he pressed the two youths down like wooden puppets, reducing them to the length of a thumb, and tucked them into his cap as well. When the door opened, Master Du entered with reverence, but the room was empty.

Du bowed and sought instruction. The Daoist said, "Your cultivation has not yet reached fruition; you must further refine your true heart. I now leave you with three wine cups and two jade candles. These cups are the pits of peaches from the Southern Sea, sized like goblets. When struck, they emit a clear, golden chime. Their surfaces are carved with patterns resembling a hundred flowers, their radiance translucent, their interiors and exteriors gleaming white. Keep them as tokens, and await your destined meeting in three years." With these words, he transformed into a streak of fiery light and soared into the sky.

**Bian Dongyuan**

Bian Dongyuan was a native of Luoyang. From youth, he admired the learning of Laozi and Zhuangzi and thus entered the Daoist register. He traveled the four directions, selling medicines to sustain himself.

One day, Bian Dongyuan ascended the E’ Ridge of Mount Song, where he encountered a scholar carrying several scrolls on a wooden tablet and a large gourd flask. Together, they rested beneath an ancient pine. Dongyuan asked, "Where are you bound?" The scholar replied, "To Songyang to pursue my studies. If you have acquaintances there, I would be grateful if you could introduce me to your esteemed teacher with a letter of recommendation." Dongyuan agreed.

The scholar then said, "The wine in my flask—might I offer you a drink?" Dongyuan answered, "I have long been fond of wine; your invitation honors me." Thereupon, he drank over ten cups in succession and became intoxicated. The scholar said, "I have a method to sober you, though you must not be alarmed." He took the wooden tablet, polished it, and in an instant, it transformed into a sword. Then he said, "May I borrow your liver to inscribe upon it?" Terrified, Dongyuan sobered at once and prostrated himself, begging for mercy. The scholar observed, "You possess the bearing of an immortal and the bones of a Daoist, yet you have not yet met your destined master." With that, he brandished his sword and soared into the sky, tossing down a scroll. He said to Dongyuan, "Keep this, and come visit me at Five Clouds Stream."

When Dongyuan unfurled the scroll, he found several sheets of five-colored paper and twenty tea-grinding pestles, though their meaning eluded him. At the end of the paper was a quatrain:

*By chance we met on E’ Ridge’s side,*
*Shared wine and spoke of mysteries profound.*
*I meant to teach you swordplay’s art,*
*But you, lost soul, lacked fate’s green ground.*

Dongyuan sighed over his missed encounter, feeling as though he had lost something precious. Wherever he went, he asked people, "Do you know the way to Five Clouds?" Most took him for a madman and ignored him. After some time, he returned to Luoyang, entered the water while drunk, and did not emerge.

Later, a traveler from Heng and Xiang arrived, and Dongyuan entrusted him with a letter at the Southern Marchmount Temple to deliver to his friends and kin in Luoyang. The script bore the distinctive brushwork of his own hand. Those fond of such matters all remarked that he had dissolved into water.

**Li Zhen**

The Daoist Li Zhen was of unknown origin, dwelling in reclusion west of Mount Hua in Qizhou. Wang You, whose family wealth numbered in the tens of thousands, often maintained a guesthouse to welcome scholars from all directions, providing fine delicacies and wine without stint. Zhen arrived bearing a zither and a medicine gourd to call upon You, who then welcomed him into his residence.

Zhen asked, "Your wealth affords you the pleasures of a marquis or earl—yet what if you are not a worthy man?" You smiled and assented. Zhen continued, "Do you keep this empty hall and set out food in hunger for worthy men—or in hunger for the hungry? If for the hungry, then fortunately the world today suffers no shortage of the starving. If for the worthy, then I have yet to hear of your finding one. Thus I know you are not a worthy man myself—do not be surprised by my words. I only fear you pursue an empty reputation while lacking the substance of one who truly awaits the worthy. If you can awaken to this, my words will not have been in vain."

You’s expression shifted, and he bowed twice, saying, "I have heard that all human joys have their purpose. Those who study the arts of persuasion must harbor ambitions of roaming as advisors; those who read military strategy must hold the heart of a warrior. Yet I carry only a zither and a gourd of medicine—could there be no intent in this?" He continued, "The zither: I know it bears the ancient spirit, and I wish to return men to simplicity, to curb their frivolous excess. The medicine gourd: I know men suffer many illnesses, and I wish to ease their pain and grant them enduring peace. Moreover, my zither does not transform me—it transforms others; my medicine does not preserve me—it preserves others. Though you use your abundance to aid people, this differs from those who amass wealth through plunder and injustice. Yet even so, this is how the noble and powerful of old treated scholars—you have not yet done so. The key lies in distinguishing the worthy from the unworthy, and thus your person may remain free of entanglements."

You bowed again, and Zhen then called for wine, pouring for himself. By dusk, he was drunk and departed. Wang Qian, watching in secret, saw Zhen transform into a great stag and bound westward, vanishing without a trace.

---

Zheng Ao (styled Yun sou) was a native of Baima in Huazhou. To avoid the taboo of Emperor Mingzong of Later Tang’s personal name, the world knew him by his courtesy name. In his youth, he studied diligently and excelled in literary composition. At the end of the Tang, he sat for the imperial examinations but did not pass. As the realm descended into chaos, he resolved to cast off worldly ties and depart. He wished to take his wife and children into reclusion with him, but his wife refused, so Ao entered Mount Shaoshi and became a Daoist. His wife sent him letters urging him to return, but he never once glanced at them, casting them into the fire instead. Such was his renunciation of worldly burdens. When his wife and children died one after another, he wept once upon hearing each news and then ceased.

Two azure youths, a crane, and a zither followed him. Ao was close friends with Li Zhen, a powerful minister of the Liang court. Zhen wished to secure him an official post, but Ao refused. Later, when Zhen was exiled to the south after falling from favor, Ao walked a thousand *li* to visit him. From then on, those who heard of this held his conduct in even higher esteem.

Ao heard that on Mount Hua, resin from the five-needle pine had seeped into the earth, transforming over a thousand years into a medicine that could expel the Three Corpses. Thus he moved to the northern slopes of Mount Hua to seek it. He befriended the Daoists Li Daosheng and Luo Yinzhi, forming a bond of "mist and vine" friendship. The world regarded them as the Three Eminent Recluses. Ao tilled the fields, Yinzhi sold medicine to support himself, and Daosheng possessed the art of fishing without bait and could transmute stone into gold. Ao tested this once and believed it, though he did not seek it for himself.

All three loved wine and poetry, excelled at *weiqi*, and were skilled in the long whistle. Ao had a large gourd, said to ward off cold and heat. When wine was placed inside, its flavor remained unchanged over time. Each day, he wandered among flowers, trees, waters, and rocks, sipping and reciting verses. Once, in the midst of revelry, they composed linked verses. Zheng said:
*A gourd holds a treasure named in heaven above,*
*Two men in the world without cares to move.*
Luo replied:
*Drunk beyond Cloud Elder and Yinzhi’s sway,*
*Who knows where true nature may hold its way?*

When Emperor Gaozu of Later Jin ascended the throne, he dispatched envoys to appoint Ao as Remonstrance Grandee. Ao claimed illness and declined, submitting a memorial in refusal. The emperor, admiring him all the more, bestowed the title "Master of Carefree Wandering" and granted him the rank of Remonstrance Grandee in retirement, along with a monthly stipend. Ao once composed a thousand-three-hundred-word poem on wine, which scholars of renown across the land transcribed onto silk scrolls to present to him. Others sent artists from a thousand *li* away to secretly paint his likeness on screens and partitions. Such was the esteem in which the world held him.

In the final years of the Tianfu era, at the age of seventy-four, he passed away in peace.

The poems he composed were collected by the dynastic historian Xue Juzheng, who compiled and prefaced them under the title *Imitating the Peaks Collection*, which circulated in the world.

Daoist Li Shouwei
Daoist Li Shouwei’s origins are unknown. He often wandered in Shu, skilled in nurturing *qi* without eating, and moved swiftly as the wind. Fond of wine, his conversations were full of wit, and he paid no heed to minor conventions, so people often slighted him. One day, he suddenly told others: “I wish to roam the Five Sacred Mountains—now I depart.” When asked about methods for seeking profit, he replied: “This floating life passes in an instant; one should seek truth and visit the Dao, casting off the dusty net. As for absorbing *qi*, refining elixirs, eating magic mushrooms, or fasting—all are beneficial. Why fixate on profit-seeking arts?” Then he vanished.

Some regretted his departure and reported it to the ruler of the false Shu, who ordered a search, but he was never found. Long after, someone saw him in the Liang-Song region, or in Wu and Chu, his appearance entirely unchanged. He told people: “I have just come from the Eastern Sea and now wish to go to the Southern Sacred Mountain.” Later, he was seen no more.

He was on good terms with Han Yu of the Bureau of Sacrifices, who presented him with a poem:
*Ever youthful though the years grow old,*
*Poor and cold, you wander noble halls.*
*Refined, your upright* qi *grows mighty,*
*Nurtured, your primordial spirit strays not from the Dao.*
*Feathers of crane and crow drag your dry mat,*
*Your staff, gnarled as twisted teeth, bears your steps.*
*Why cling to reclusion and not return?*
*Where have all the peaches of immortality bloomed?*

Peng Xiao of Feihe Mountain in Changli, originally surnamed Cheng, was a native of Yongkang in Western Shu. From youth, he devoted himself to self-cultivation, styling himself Master Zhenyi. He was on good terms with He Wuyun, the Bamboo-Striker. During the Later Shu dynasty, he passed the imperial examination in the classics and was repeatedly promoted, eventually becoming magistrate of Jintang. He encountered an extraordinary person from whom he received the alchemical formula, and went on to annotate the *Classic of the Hidden Correspondence*, the *Triple Concordance*, the *Golden Key*, and the *True Unity Formula*. He inscribed talismans to heal the sick, which became known as the "Iron Fan Talismans." He could let out a long whistle that sounded like the cry of a phoenix, and when birds in flight heard it, they would all come to him. King Meng Shou of Shu repeatedly summoned him to inquire about longevity and enduring vision. Peng Xiao replied: "To govern the state with benevolence and righteousness, to make one’s name like that of Yao and Shun—this is the Way of eternal life, never to die." He was repeatedly promoted to Vice Director of the Bureau of Sacrifices, judicial officer of Shuzhou, and acting military governor. He died in the twelfth month of the seventeenth year of Guangzheng, but even after ten days, his complexion remained as if alive. Later, someone saw him on Qingcheng Mountain, standing atop a pine tree and flying away. *(From the* Shu Tao Wu.)*

Tan Zixiao, the Feathered Guest of the Golden Gate, surnamed Tan and named Zixiao (also called Zilei), was originally from Beihai. His great-grandfather was a Daoist adept in the Tang dynasty. Zixiao was born in Jinling. His physique was imposing, his spirit keen and elegant; he walked with the gait of a tortoise and the stride of a crane, with round eyes and a square beak. His forehead bore the character for "auspicious," and his palms showed the pattern of a well—all marked him as extraordinary. He was well-versed in the Six Classics, the hundred schools, and the secret and numinous scriptures. He traveled south to Yunsun Mountain to become a Daoist, and later encountered an extraordinary person who taught him the arts of observing the Dipper, flying talismans, and the "Lantern-Watching" method of defense—all of which proved efficacious. From then on, his name resounded across the rivers and lakes, and people flocked to him like water.

He then entered Min, where Wang Shenzhi, the ruler of Min, treated him with great reverence. He was first appointed Master of the Mysterious Cavern (some texts say "Master of the Mysterious Chapter"), then Master of Ceremonies of the Left Daoist Registry, with an imperial edict stating: "Your compassion nurtures all things, your insight penetrates the divine. Though you have not yet returned to the Ten Caves and Three Heavens, for now, assist us in our dawn audiences and hasty meals." When Min fell, he returned to Jinling. Emperor Liezu of Southern Tang heard of him and sent envoys to greet and inquire after him. Messengers crisscrossed the roads to summon him, and when he arrived, his responses were sharp and eloquent. The emperor was pleased and convinced, appointing him Master of Ceremonies of the Left Daoist Registry and bestowing upon him the robes of office, further honoring him as Master of True Radiance (some texts say "Master of Observation"). The edict read: "You cultivate virtue in the forest of the Dao, your spirit abides beyond form. You have cast off the world’s net, severed ties to profit and the fertile Way." During the Baoda era, he was again granted the title Feathered Guest of the Golden Gate.

Zixiao had long admired the scenic beauty of Mount Lu. There, he chose to dwell in the Hidden Abode Grotto on White Cloud Peak—the former study of Prince Zhaoming of Liang, now the Hidden Abode Abbey. He also built a separate lodge by the Starry Islet at the south gate of the city for his comings and goings, which is now the Longevity Sage Abbey. The Later Lord of Southern Tang long admired his lofty character and again summoned him to Jinling, but before long, he returned to the mountain. In the summer of the sixth year of the Kaibao era of the Song dynasty, on the first day of the fourth month, he bathed, ascended the hall, and passed away in perfect seated posture at the age of one hundred and fifty. At that time, people near the grotto saw a cloud like a dragon rising into the sky. When he was buried, colorful clouds and white cranes circled above. The Later Lord sent envoys to offer lavish posthumous gifts.

Early on, Zixiao had mastered the most refined arts. He could perform rituals to the stars, serve the Dark Marshal, pace the Yu Step, and make hand seals to bind and curse ghosts and demons. For others, he burned memorials and performed rites to avert misfortune and summon blessings, and he had a keen sense of life and death. When summoned, he would bathe at dusk and, by nightfall, ascend a chamber alone to light the incense burner, lock the door, and perform the ritual. Only then would he light the lamp as proof. At dawn, he could accurately recount the length of a person’s life, and none of his predictions failed. He Jingshu, military governor of Wuchang, once became enraged with his favorite maid and threw her into a well, where she died—no one knew of it. In the early Jianlong era, He fell ill and summoned Zixiao. In the middle of the night, Zixiao loosened his hair, lit a lamp in a quiet room, and saw the female ghost recount how she had become a demonic haunting. Zixiao relayed her words, and He said, "It is true." He then wrote a talisman in cinnabar and sent her off, and his illness immediately improved.

Zixiao also possessed extraordinary arts. A neighboring monk was building a pavilion by the stream, but a stubborn boulder obstructed the work, making progress a hundred times more difficult. Zixiao happened to see this and said, "This is easily done." He traced a talisman with his finger, held water in his mouth, and spat it out, then ordered the stone to be struck—it crumbled to dust. Though Zixiao was repeatedly favored by successive courts and received honors comparable to Du Guangting of Shu, he often declined them. All the funds he received from rituals and offerings were used to support worthy scholars, relieve the poor, and entertain guests from the four directions. His room held no coffers or chests.

When Zixiao resided in the grotto, over a hundred Daoist followers, drawn by his reputation, would gather. He often lectured to his disciples on the *Zhuangzi* and *Liezi*, saying: "The teachings of Zhuang and Lie are familiar to our school. Their books fundamentally aim to awaken the true nature, to see that originally there is nothing. Their meaning aligns perfectly with the Buddhist teachings. If one can study the Buddhist scriptures alongside them, the intent of Zhuang and Lie becomes clear and easy to understand. In my youth, I read all the *Vajracchedikā* and *Yuanjue* sutras without exception, and thus I have fully awakened to the original true nature. Today, those who call themselves Daoists merely oppose Buddhism, not realizing that those who truly seek the Dao do not act this way. They merely pick up scraps and fragments, engaging in trivial matters, mistaking these for the Dao. Not only do they fail to awaken to the true nature, but they also stray infinitely far from the original intent of Laozi and Zhuangzi." For this reason, Zixiao’s room contained books from the Daoist, Buddhist, and Confucian traditions.

*(The* Southern Tang Biographies *records: Tan Zixiao was a native of Quanzhou. As a youth, he became a Daoist. There was another Daoist named Chen Shouyuan who, while hoeing the ground, unearthed several dozen wooden tablets stored in a bronze basin. They bore the talismans of Zhang Daoling, their red and black ink as fresh as if newly written. He could not use them and gave them to Zixiao. Zixiao mastered them all and claimed to have received the Celestial Heart Orthodox Method of Zhang Daoling. He was highly effective in subduing ghosts and demons and curing illnesses.)*

King Meng of Min held him in great esteem, bestowing upon him the titles "Feathered Guest of the Golden Gate" and "Master of Orthodox Unity." When Min fell, he lingered in retreat at the Stem-Concealing Grotto on Mount Lu, where over a hundred disciples gathered around him. The Later Lord, having heard of his reputation, summoned him for an audience and offered official positions, all of which he declined. Soon after, he fell ill and died at over a hundred years of age. Those who now speak of the Celestial Heart Orthodox Method all trace their lineage to Zixiao.

Huang Sun of Lianzhou
During the Five Dynasties, there was a Grand Preceptor Huang Sun of Lianzhou. The Grand Preceptor had served the Southern Han until his old age, when he retired and returned home. One day, he suddenly vanished without a trace, and no one knew whether he was alive or dead. His descendants kept his portrait and made offerings to it. After thirty-two years, he returned, sitting upon the steps of the previous day. He called out to his family, but his son happened to be away. His grandson came out to see him and asked for a brush to write on the wall:

*So many years have passed since we parted,*
*Returning, I find all mortal affairs worn away;*
*Only the mirror-pool before the gate remains,*
*Its spring waves unchanged by the wind of old.*

Having written this, he cast aside the brush and departed, impossible to detain. When his son returned and asked about his appearance, the grandson said, "He greatly resembled the old man in the portrait hall." To this day, the people of Lianzhou pass down this tale, and his descendants have since attained high office.

Wang the Elder
Wang the Elder—no one knows from which dynasty he hailed.

During the Tianbao era of Emperor Xuanzong of the Tang, there was a scholar surnamed Cui who served as a magistrate in Ba-Shu. He had just arrived in Chengdu when he died. The regional commander, Zhangqiu Jianqiong, pitying his young widow with nowhere to turn, had a villa built for her in the Qingcheng Mountains. Struck by her beauty, he harbored intentions to take her as his concubine. Finding no opportunity, he said to his wife, "As the wife of a high-ranking lord, why not host a grand banquet and invite all the ladies within five hundred *li*?" His wife was delighted. Jianqiong then ordered his officials to dispatch invitations to all young women within five hundred *li*, setting a date for them to gather in Chengdu. His plan was to detain the widow during the gathering, but unbeknownst to him, she had already been taken in by her uncle Lu.

Lu, having secretly learned of Jianqiong’s intentions, instructed the widow to feign illness and decline the invitation. Enraged, Jianqiong ordered a hundred riders to arrest her. At the time, Lu was dining when the soldiers surrounded his residence. Unperturbed, he continued eating as if nothing were amiss. After finishing his meal, he said to the widow, "Jianqiong’s intentions are clear—you cannot refuse to go. Soon, plain-colored garments will be sent to you; wear them when you depart." With that, he mounted a mule and rode out. The soldiers tried to block his path, but he moved slowly away, and they could not overtake him.

Shortly after, a young servant arrived bearing a box containing an old cyan skirt, a white blouse, a green quilt, and silk gauze—all fabrics unseen in the world. The widow donned them and traveled to Chengdu. The other young women had already arrived, and Jianqiong observed from behind a curtain. When the widow entered, her radiance enveloped her, her beauty dazzling all who beheld her. Those seated were so awestruck that they unconsciously rose to bow. After the gathering, she returned home and died three days later. Greatly alarmed, Jianqiong reported the matter in full to the emperor.

Emperor Xuanzong questioned Zhang Guo about the matter, but Guo merely transcribed it without daring to speak, requesting instead to consult Wang Lao of Qingcheng. The emperor immediately issued an edict to Jianqiong, ordering him to seek out Wang Lao and present him at court. Jianqiong scoured the front and back of Mount Qingcheng but found no such person—only an apothecary in the grass-market who said: "Two men come daily to sell mountain yams, calling themselves Wang Lao." Jianqiong dispatched two attendants, who were followed by his officials. After entering the mountains for several *li*, they arrived at a thatched hut where an old man sat with his feet tucked beneath him. The officials entered to proclaim the edict and convey Jianqiong’s intent. Wang Lao said: "This must be that garrulous little immortal, Zhang Guo." He then agreed with Jianqiong on a date to reach the capital, insisting on first taking medicine to induce perspiration and refusing official transport. Jianqiong complied.

No sooner had the messengers arrived at the Silver Terrace than Wang Lao appeared as well. The emperor summoned him for questioning. At that moment, Zhang Guo stood in attendance beside Xuanzong. Upon seeing Wang Lao, Guo prostrated himself in terror and bowed twice. Wang Lao rebuked him: "Why are you not like this? And why did you send for me from afar?" Guo replied: "This humble immortal dared not act on my own; I awaited only the words of the Immortal Elder." Wang Lao then declared: "Uncle Lu the Second is the storeroom keeper of the Grand Primordial Lady. While traveling below, he noticed that the late commandant’s wife possessed a trace of immortal bone, so he took her as a concubine. Before long, she stole the Grand Primordial Lady’s robes and wore them, for which she was punished in the netherworld. The late commandant’s wife, having donned the Grand Primordial Lady’s garments, has been cast into the Prison of Unanswered Questions." When the memorial was concluded, Wang Lao vehemently refused to remain in service. Guo ordered his release, and afterward, his whereabouts became unknown. The herb-gathering folk...

The herb-gathering folk—during the *Xianqing* era of Emperor Gaozong of Tang, there was an unnamed villager from Qingcheng in Shu Commandery who gathered herbs. Once, at the foot of Mount Qingcheng, he came upon a medicinal plant. He dug into the earth, descending several *zhang* deep, where the root grew as large as a jar. Undeterred, he continued digging until he reached five or six *zhang*, and the ground kept caving in, eventually plunging him over ten *zhang* deep. He fell into the pit with no way out. Looking up, the opening appeared no larger than a star. Certain of his death, he suddenly noticed a side passage. Crawling inside, the space gradually widened, allowing him to proceed on hands and knees for several dozen paces. Ahead, a faint light appeared, and following it for over a *li*, the passage grew taller until he could stand upright. After another two *li* or so, he emerged from a cave mouth to find a river dozens of paces wide. On the opposite bank stood several dozen households, their village shaded by mulberry and catalpa trees, with blossoming flowers, willows, and lush vegetation—all as if it were the second or third month. The men and women wore clothing unlike that of present-day people, and he encountered plowmen and young anglers along the way. One person, startled, asked how he had come there, and he explained what had happened. They ferried him across in a small boat. The villager told them he had not eaten for three days, so they fed him sesame rice and *wuzi* soup. After staying several days, he felt his body growing lighter. He asked his host, "What place is this?"

He also sought the way back to Shu. The villagers laughed together and said, "People of your world know nothing of this realm. That you have come here suggests you possess a share of immortal destiny. You should remain here, and I shall lead you to pay homage to the Jade Emperor." Among them, someone called out, "Tomorrow is the Shangsi Festival—we must go to pay our respects." They then took him along. Some rode upon clouds of *qi*, others mounted dragons or cranes, while he walked on foot amid the mist. In an instant, they arrived at a city adorned with gold and jade, its palaces and towers all wrought of precious metals. The others entered in turn to pay their respects, but he was left alone outside the palace gates. Beside the gate stood a great ox, crimson in color and of most unusual form, its eyes closed as it drooled foam. The villager instructed him to bow to the ox and beseech the immortal Dao, saying that if the ox spat forth any treasure, he should take and consume it. He did as told, bowing and pleading. After a moment, the ox spat out a crimson pearl, a handspan in circumference. Just as he rose to take it, a red-robed youth snatched it away. He begged again and received a blue pearl, only for a blue-robed youth to seize it. Soon after came yellow and white pearls, each taken by their respective youths. Frantic, he reached toward his mouth—just in time to catch a black pearl, which he swallowed at once. The black-robed youth arrived to find nothing, leaving him the sole one remaining. He was then led to pay homage to the Jade Emperor.

The Jade Emperor sat enthroned in the hall, his appearance like that of an earthly king. Seven attendants stood arrayed to his left and right, while hundreds of jade maidens guarded the palace courtyard. Rare and wondrous flowers and fruits filled the air with fragrances unknown in the mortal world. The Jade Emperor questioned him, and he answered truthfully. He then petitioned the Jade Emperor to return home, and the Jade Emperor bestowed upon him a golden ingot. "There is medicine within this gold," he said. "Take and consume it." Suddenly, a flock of swans and cranes appeared soaring in the sky. The others told him, "Do you see them? Simply follow their flight." They lifted him up, and he too rose into the air, arriving without startling the birds, who flew together through the heavens. Looking back, he still saw the villagers on the shore, cupping their hands in farewell. After traveling some hundred *li* or so, he found himself in a bustling city. When he asked where he was, he was told, "This is Linhai County—you are now very far from Shu." It took him a year to return to Shu, by which time it was the end of Emperor Xuanzong’s *Kaiyuan* era. When he reached his home, no one recognized him. Only one man, over ninety years old, said, "My grandfather went gathering herbs years ago and never returned. It has been ninety years since then." This man was his grandson. They embraced and wept, saying, "Your aunts and uncles have all passed away." His own daughter, born before he left, had already married and died, and her son was now over fifty.

He then sought his former dwelling, only to find it reduced to rubble and overgrown thickets—nothing remained but the old mulberry tree. Breaking open his gold to purchase medicine, he swallowed it, but the elixir suddenly vanished. Lifting the mulberry stone, he discovered a jade box containing golden cinnabar, which he consumed at once. His mind grew lucid, and he recalled the path he had taken.

This was how the man attained the Dao in the immortal cavern, though common folk could not fathom the details. When questioned, Master Luo the Celestial Master, then in Shu, heard his account and declared: "This is the Fifth Grotto, the Heaven of Nine Chambers of Precious Immortals. The Jade Emperor is the Heavenly Sovereign. The great ox was a black dragon, and the pearl it spat—red if swallowed grants life coeval with heaven and earth, green bestows fifty thousand years, white ten thousand, and black five thousand. This man received the black pearl, so though he did not cultivate the Dao, he would still live five thousand years in the mortal realm. As for the seven figures who stood before him, they were the Seven Stars of the Northern Dipper."

After consuming the elixir, the man returned to the mountains, and his whereabouts were never known again.

**Yang Tongyou**
Yang Tongyou, originally named Shiwu, was a native of Shiyu in Guanghan. In his youth, he encountered a Daoist who taught him the art of summons and petitions, transmitting to him the celestial texts of the Three Sovereigns. He could command ghosts and spirits, and none failed to answer instantly. He expelled venomous plagues, severed baleful influences, averted floods and droughts, and summoned wind and rain—all arts he mastered. Yet he was simple and aloof, unbound by worldly conventions. His techniques were wondrous and strange, renowned far and near.

Emperor Xuanzong of Tang bestowed upon him the name Tongyou and inquired about the Dao he had received. Tongyou replied, "My master was the True Man of Qingcheng, the South Pole Lord Wang. Long ago in the mountains of Houcheng, he taught me the art of summons and commands, saying that by aiding a sovereign of great peace, one might then attain the Dao of ascension. He warned me to guard my qi and speak sparingly, to avert my gaze from all that was improper, to renounce fame and profit, and to distance myself from the clamor of the world—only then could I transcend the Three Realms and ascend to the Great Clarity."

The emperor further asked what one did upon ascending to heaven or descending into the earth. Tongyou answered, "Those who attain the Dao are unscorched by fire, undrenched by water, tread the void as though it were solid, and touch the solid as though it were void. Though the Nine Earths be deep, the vast seas broad, the Eight Poles distant, or the Ten Thousand Heavens vast, all responds to thought and arrives at will—what bounds could constrain them? This is so because form and Dao have merged as one." The emperor praised his response.

After residing for several years, Tongyou ascended Houcheng Mountain and built a quiet chamber at its summit, occasionally returning home. His disciples reported that celestial perfected beings frequently descended to his chamber, and one day he departed with a host of immortals.

**Cui Wei**
The scholar Cui Wei once traveled to Mount Qingcheng. Dismounting his donkey to rest, he let it graze without a servant. The donkey bolted, and though he pursued it for over thirty li, he reached the mouth of a cave as dusk fell. The donkey ran inside, and Cui, weary and afraid, lay down to sleep. At dawn, he awoke to a faint light in the cave and ventured deeper. After another ten li, he emerged from the cave to behold towering trees and sheer cliffs—none of it familiar. Only golden walls and crimson towers stood before him, guarded by hundreds in armor. Seeing Cui, they shouted and questioned him. He replied, "I am but a humble man of the dust, who wishes to pay homage to the immortal elder." The guards hurried to report, and after a long while, he was summoned.

A figure sat in the hall, clad in feathered robes, his stature over a *zhang* tall, his beard and hair snowy white. Attendants filled his sides, each bearing something in hand. He bade Cui ascend the hall and spoke with him, greatly pleased. Cui was kept overnight, and the feast laid before him was of the rarest and richest delicacies. The next day, the immortal elder said, "This is no mortal realm, but the abode of immortals." Cui replied, "I am bound by the ties of flesh and blood. Though I seek no attachment, I beg to return." The immortal elder said, "To linger is forbidden; the punishment is severe." He gave Cui a talisman, saying, "Should you encounter misfortune, it may conceal your form—but beware, do not wander into the imperial palace." At parting, he gave another talisman, saying, "Open this only in dire need."

He then returned Cui’s donkey. Upon reaching the capital, Cui tested the talisman in people’s homes—none could see him. He entered the imperial gardens and inner palace, where, during the birthday celebration of the Consort of Jiannan, he stole the finest silks and brocades. The emperor, investigating the theft all day, could find no trace of the thief. He summoned Luo Gongyuan, who performed a ritual and held up a vermilion inscription to illuminate the hall. Behind the palace doors, Cui was discovered. When questioned, he recounted the whole affair, but the emperor refused to believe him and ordered him beaten to death.

Suddenly recalling the immortal’s parting talisman, Cui hastily opened it. Gongyuan and his captors all collapsed, stiff as corpses. After a long while, they revived and reported to Emperor Xuanzong, "This man now dwells in the upper realms. To kill him is impossible, and even if we could, we would bring calamity upon ourselves—this would not bode well for the realm." The emperor released Cui and summoned him for a private audience, asking, "Are you deceiving me?" He then ordered a hundred armed men to escort Cui back to the mountains and observe what became of him.

Returning to the cave’s mouth, Cui again saw the golden walls and crimson towers. The immortal elder emerged with a solemn retinue and called out, "Master Cui, you did not heed my words and nearly met with disaster." After bowing, Cui stepped forward. The escorting soldiers wished to follow, but the immortal elder drew his staff and traced a ravine, several *zhang* wide. He tossed a kerchief, which transformed into a rainbow bridge of five colors. Bidding Cui cross, the bridge vanished with each step. Once across, Cui turned and said, "You may return from here." In an instant, clouds and mist arose, obscuring all within a *chi* or *cun*. Only the sounds of phoenixes, cranes, and celestial music lingered, fading after half a day. Gazing into the distance, they saw only empty mountains—nothing else remained.

**Wei Gu**
Wei Gu, styled Laoshi, was a native of Shule.

Wei Gu wore a robe of righteousness, with hundreds of gourds hanging from his waist. His head was wrapped in a gauze kerchief, and he carried a flowering staff, always accompanied by a black dog. During the reign of Emperor Xuanzong of Tang, he entered China, dispensing medicines to cure the sick, and none failed to recover. The emperor held him in high esteem, respectfully calling him the "Medicine King." Later, his dog transformed into a black dragon, and he mounted it to ascend into the heavens—this occurred in the twenty-fifth year of the Kaiyuan era.

**The Mad Daoist**
In Shu there was a Daoist known as the Mad One, commonly called the "Ash-Bag Gentleman," a late disciple of Zhai Qianyu. Qianyu often warned his followers, saying, "Do not deceive this man; he surpasses me." Once, during a heavy snowfall, the Daoist, clad in coarse hempen cloth, entered Mount Qingcheng. At dusk, he sought shelter at a monastery, asking the monk for lodging. The monk replied, "This poor monk has but one sleeve to offer. With such cold, I fear I cannot sustain you." The Daoist merely said, "A grove of trees will suffice." By midnight, the snow deepened and the wind howled. Fearing the Daoist had frozen to death, the monk went to check on him and found him several feet away from the wall, his breath steaming like a boiling pot. Sweating profusely, he lay bare-chested in sleep. Only then did the monk realize he was an extraordinary man. Before dawn, the Daoist departed without a word.

He often stayed in villages, and wherever he lodged, the people grew ever more devoted to him. Once, he fell ill with mouth sores and went months without eating, appearing on the verge of death. The villagers, who had long revered him as a divine figure, prepared a Daoist feast in his honor. After the feast, he suddenly rose and addressed the crowd, saying, "Look into my mouth and see what lies within." He opened his mouth wide as a winnowing basket, revealing all five viscera. The onlookers were astonished and bowed in reverence, questioning him. He only replied, "This is quite foul. Quite foul indeed." Thereafter, his fate remained unknown.

**Elder Wei**
During the reign of Emperor Daizong of Tang, the imperial censor Wei was dispatched to Mount Hua to pay respects at the Yellow Emperor’s altar. At the foot of the mountain, he encountered an old man at an inn and inquired about the altar’s location. The elder knew the way and mentioned, "My surname is Wei, and my family has also served in office." He recounted his lineage, revealing himself to be Wei’s distant ancestor. Together, they entered the mountain. The old man, leaning on his staff, walked ahead, while Wei urged his horse forward but could not catch up. They arrived at a stone chamber where an old woman appeared, saying, "She is your grandmother, and these are your ancestral aunts." Both had hair as white as frost and wore garments of woven leaves. Overjoyed, they exclaimed, "After ages of change, we meet our descendants in a single day!" After paying respects at the altar, Wei returned to the chamber, but they had vanished. The locals at the mountain’s base said the elder appeared every two or three years, though none knew his dwelling.

*Comprehensive Mirror of Perfected Immortals Who Embodied the Dao, Volume 43 (concluded)*
*Comprehensive Mirror of Perfected Immortals Who Embodied the Dao, Volume 44*

Lu Sheng was a man of the Baoli era during the reign of Emperor Jingzong of Tang. He often peddled lime and firewood, traveling between Baiqiu and the southern grass market. Occasionally, he subtly revealed his extraordinary nature, yet no one could fathom him. The merchant Zhao Yuanqing, an inquisitive man, sought to befriend him. He frequently purchased Lu’s goods and offered tea and medicine, feigning interest in his profit-sharing methods. Lu, perceiving this, eventually said, "Your intentions seem not to lie in trade—what is it you truly seek?" Zhao replied, "I know you, elder, conceal your brilliance and hide your virtue, penetrating the mysteries of divination. I humbly beg a word of guidance." Lu smiled and said, "This very day, at noon, your host’s household will face an extraordinary calamity. If my words prove true, you may warn them. Near noon, a pastry vendor will arrive, carrying a sack with over two thousand coins, though his intent is not benign. Tell them to bolt the door and caution the women and children against responding lightly. By midday, he will curse vehemently—then the entire household must flee to the water’s edge. If they do, they will only suffer a loss of three thousand one hundred coins."

At the time, Zhao was staying at the home of a commoner named Zhang. He hurried back to relay the warning, and Zhang, who had long revered Lu as a divine figure, promptly barred the door. As noon approached, a man indeed arrived, knocking and demanding to be let in. Enraged by the lack of response, he kicked the door. Zhang reinforced it with baskets to hold it shut, and soon hundreds gathered. Zhang then led his wife and children out the back to evade the commotion. By midday, after retreating several hundred paces, the man suddenly collapsed and died. His wife arrived, and the crowd recounted the events. She accused Zhang of causing her husband’s death through slander, and the local officials could not resolve the dispute. The crowd explained Zhang’s reason for bolting the door, and the onlookers told Zhang, "You are blameless—defend yourself." Zhang gladly accepted the verdict. The wife then demanded compensation for the market stall and funeral expenses, totaling three thousand four hundred coins. As a result, people flocked to Zhang’s home like a marketplace.

Lu Sheng, growing impatient, secretly traveled to Fuzhou and Huaizhou, stopping at the estate of the scholar Lu. Someone told Lu, "The mountain man Lu is no ordinary man." Lu then paid him a visit. At the time, Lu was preparing to journey to the capital to seek patronage from acquaintances. He asked Lu Sheng to resolve his doubts, who replied, "You must not travel this year—calamity will strike at any moment. Behind the hall of your residence lies a cache of coins, covered by a plank, but it is not yours. It has been there for only three years. Do not spend a single coin, or disaster will follow. Can you heed this warning?" Lu gratefully thanked him. After Lu Sheng departed, before the ripples of his words had settled, Lu laughed and said to his wife and children, "If we follow Lu Sheng’s advice, what more could we desire?" He ordered his servants to dig behind the hall. After a few feet, they indeed found a plank. Removing it, they uncovered scattered coins. Overjoyed, Lu’s wife used her skirt to gather them, threading them with grass until they neared ten thousand. Suddenly, their children began wailing in unbearable pain. Lu exclaimed, "Could this be the fulfillment of Lu Sheng’s warning?" He mounted his horse and pursued Lu Sheng, offering thanks and seeking further counsel. Lu, furious, said, "If you use those coins, disaster will befall your flesh and blood. Weigh the value of your kin against profit—decide for yourself." He then poled his boat away without looking back. Lu rushed home, performed a ritual, and his brother’s daughter recovered.

Lu Sheng often strolled leisurely with several companions. On one occasion, they encountered six or seven finely dressed men reeking of alcohol. Lu suddenly rebuked them, "Your conduct is base—your lives will not last long." The men prostrated themselves in the dust, pleading, "We dare not... we will repent." His companions were astonished, but Lu said, "These are all river bandits." Zhao Yuanqing remarked that Lu Sheng’s appearance shifted between youth and age, and he was rarely seen eating or drinking. Lu once told Zhao, "Those who follow the Dao attain the art of concealment. If one refrains from testing it, after twenty years, one’s form may be altered—a stage called 'shedding.' After another twenty years, one’s name is recorded among the earthbound immortals." His deeds were often extraordinary, for he was a divine immortal.

Liu Wuming was a native of Chengdu. A descendant of Liu Bei, the founding emperor of Shu, he lived in Shu from birth. Gifted and perceptive, at eight or nine years old, a Daoist passing his home saw him and sighed, "If this child studies the Dao, he will become a long-lived divine immortal." From then on, he devoted himself to the Dao, exploring its mysteries and disdaining fame and profit. In his youth, he studied the *Dao De Jing* and practiced breath control, prostration, visualization, and inner alchemy. He regularly observed the Gengshen day to guard against the Three Corpses, cultivated spirit through silent meditation, and consumed yellow essence and white wood to prolong life. He once read an ancient formula stating that herbal medicines merely cured illnesses with modest effects, and fire reduced them to ashes, rendering them incapable of preserving life—how could they grant longevity? Thus, he traversed mountains and rivers, seeking masters and the Dao.

After several years, he entered Wuzhong Mountain, where he encountered an extraordinary figure who taught him to ingest and refine realgar. For over thirty years, he entered a cave beneath the northern cliff of Mount Qingcheng. After walking several miles, he suddenly found himself in a vast, level expanse, far from the mortal world. There, he met divine immortals dwelling within, who called themselves the Perfected of Qingcheng. Liu entreated them ceaselessly, begging to be shown the essentials of the Dao to deliver himself from the depths of suffering and transcend the bitterness of life and death. The Perfected pointed to a rock chamber, where he took up residence. After purifying his mind for seven days, the Perfected revealed to him the methods of the yang crucible and yin tripod, the softening of metal and refinement of flowing jade, and the secrets of subduing water to refine lead into mercury marrow. He said, "Hu Gangzi and Yin Changsheng both mastered this Dao—it is also known as the *Scripture of the Nine Transformations of Divine Elixir of Golden Liquor*. The elixir has nine grades: lead serves as the sovereign, mercury as the minister, the eight minerals as envoys, and yellow sprouts as the agent. When sovereign and minister harmonize and the fire’s work is complete, after seven days, it becomes light water; after fourteen days, it transforms into purple powder; after twenty-one days, the five colors manifest, with red within and yellow without, resembling window dust. After refining it with fire for two years—six hundred days passing through the four seasons and the winter solstice twice—it reaches completion."

At first, after ten months of refining, the elixir sheds its embryonic form and achieves the initial grade, capable of congealing mercury into silver. When shaped into pills and ingested, it can dispel illness. After two years, those who consume it will prolong their years and extend their lifespan, with white hair turning black again. After three years, taking but a *daogui* of it allows one to wander carefree through famous mountains and traverse the four seas. Those who attain earthly immortality by consuming half a dose of the initial-grade elixir can transform endlessly, appearing and vanishing at will, riding flying dragons, and ascending to heaven in broad daylight.

Generally, after sixteen stages of refinement, this elixir reaches the middle grade, granting the taker longevity. By the day the elixir is complete, the five metals, eight minerals, yellow sprouts, and the sovereign and ministerial ingredients will have merged inseparably. After a thousand days of work, it becomes the superior-grade *Returning Elixir*. Guard it carefully and do not show it to the unworthy. Should one encounter a person whose form, *qi*, cultivation, and conduct align with the Dao, transmit it to them.

Liu received the elixir formula and returned to Misty Mountain, where he built a chamber to refine it. After three years, he succeeded. He was still in Shu during the third year of Emperor Xuanzong of Tang’s *Kaicheng* era. He left behind an untitled account to instruct later generations, then entered Mount Qingcheng and vanished without a trace.

Li Zhongnan
Li Deyu favored consuming cinnabar. A Daoist who claimed to be Li Zhongnan, residing on Mount Luofu, said to him, "My lord, you may take cinnabar pills, but they will only hasten your lifespan." From his sleeve, he produced a small jade elephant, about the size of a fist, and said, "To refine cinnabar, place *Goulou* crystal beneath the elephant’s trunk. The elephant will ingest the cinnabar and regurgitate it, only then may it be consumed. This is the essence of the Great Yang, condensed for thirty thousand years—I now offer it to you. Remember loyalty and filial piety, lest you incur misfortune." He then produced a golden elephant, saying, "This is the female, paired with the jade one."

Zanhuang (Li Deyu) verified each detail without error. After consuming the elixir, his complexion grew youthful, and his beard and temples turned black as lacquer. He then sought rare ingredients, dispatching hundreds of people. Later, when exiled to the Ghost Gate Pass in the south, he encountered the Daoist, who angrily demanded the two elephants back, saying, "You ignored my warning—this is your due." The minister prostrated himself in apology. As they reached Eel Pond, a storm darkened the sky, and the jade elephant flew from the boat, its radiance illuminating the heavens, while the golden elephant plunged into the water. When Deyu reached Zhuya, he died in regret.

Thus it is known: the elephant is a great beast of the south; *Goulou* is a treasure of Zhuya; Mount Luofu is a coastal mountain; and Li Zhongnan was beyond Deyu’s reach. (Zanhuang was Li Deyu, who in the second year of Emperor Xuanzong’s *Dazhong* era was demoted to *Sima* of Chaozhou. In the ninth month of autumn, he was further reduced to *Sihu* of Yazhou and died there.) As for the Daoist, none ever knew which immortal he was.

Willow-Green
In the late *Dazhong* era of Emperor Xuanzong of Tang, there was an extraordinary man called Willow-Green. One day, he suddenly died, and after burial, a purple aura appeared above his grave. When opened, his coffin contained only a green staff. Upon inspection, it was revealed to be the source of the aura.

Li Hao
Li Hao, styled Taisu, was of unknown origin and dwelled in Peony Plateau of Mount Qingcheng. He once traveled with Master Erzhu, composing a *Pu Sa Man* poem for him and a hundred verses on the Great Elixir, which circulated in the world. Later, his whereabouts became unknown, though some claimed his entire household ascended as immortals. One of his poems reads:

*Before heaven and earth divided, I alone endured,*
*Embracing the Four Symbols, I established the cosmos.*
*Seek the Returning Elixir here,*
*For herein lies the gate of supreme mystery.*

*Boil stone, refine gold, and temper the Great Primal,*
*Immortals do not lightly transmit such arts.*
*Whoever grasps the principle of Nothingness*
*Seizes the power of creation itself.*

*A hundred verses, wild yet profound,*
*Transmitted to fellow Daoists to dispel doubt.*
*The Flowery Pond is true divine water,*
*And that water is originally white gold.*

*Fashion white gold into a crucible,*
*Then conceal it as mercury invades.*
*When mercury consumes the golden vessel for a full year,*
*It yields numinous cinnabar, like the moon’s essence.*

Zhang Ci
In the early *Xiantong* era of Emperor Yizong of Tang, the scholar Zhang Ci failed the imperial examinations and later traveled extensively along the Yangtze and Huai rivers. He possessed Daoist arts and cultivated *qi* while abstaining from grain. One of his poems reads:

*How can I bear the golden crow*
*That flies ceaselessly overhead?*
*The red furnace slowly refines the medicine,*
*Yet how can a jade countenance endure?*
*This year, flowers bloom on the branch;*
*Next year, leaves fall from the tree.*
*Better to drink wine,*
*Morning and night, again and again.*

When invited to drink, if the occasion pleased him, he would cut two or three paper butterflies, blow on them with his breath, and they would fly in formation. Later, he ascended to heaven in Jiangnan, leaving behind a poem:

*Zhang Ci, Zhang Ci, you never understood—*
*All the world’s scriptures were within your belly.*
*Your body roamed the mundane world,*
*While your heart soared beyond the heavens.*

Li Lao
Li Lao’s family practiced medicine for generations, and he was skilled at playing the zither, claiming to have mastered Ji Kang’s art. Once, while drunk, he fell into a dry well. Wandering, he arrived at a cave gate inscribed *Mystic Capital Grotto*, where he saw a Daoist playing the zither, performing *Guangling San*. The Daoist said, "This is your composition. Ji Kang was your former life." He then offered Li a drink of stone marrow and took a plain book from the shelf, revealing a formula for *Thirty-Six Wind White Pills*. The Daoist said, "Take this back, prepare the medicine, and heal the world. When your merit is complete, return here." He instructed Li to close his eyes, and when he opened them, he was outside the north gate of Qingzhou. Upon returning home, he found his family had already ended their mourning. It was the third year of Emperor Xizong of Tang’s *Qianfu* era.

Li then prepared the medicine and treated illnesses, with none failing to recover. Years later, he lost his appetite and ceased eating grain. One day, he went to visit the dry well and never returned, suspected to have found the path and ascended as an immortal.

**Chen Yunsheng**
Chen Yunsheng entered Mount Longhu. During the *Tianyou* era of Emperor Aidi of Tang, he was seen on Mount Magu, having been away from home for seventy years, yet his appearance remained unchanged. The prefect welcomed him and kept him in the prefectural seat. One night, as they sat together, Chen remarked, "The oranges of Fengcheng are fine—I find myself longing for them." In an instant, he plucked several hundred and presented them. The people of the time called him an immortal.

**Xu Que**
Master Xu Que of the Perfected, at the end of the Tang, wandered to Zhaoxian Abbey on Mount Heng. On the wall, he left a song:

The great furnace forges human nature and life,
Tools differ, yet fate is fixed.
Demons and specters scheme with supernatural arts,
But their schemes corrupt, never righteous.

Young boys first learning their way,
Who knows the sun and moon rise east and set west?
Yet by the might of the myriad spirits,
The moon may be moved south, the sun north.

Jade is jade, stone is stone,
The radish cast in deep mud remains unrecognized.
Deng Tong starved to death, Yan Ling stayed poor—
Were emperors truly without men of power?

A true man, unrecognized, should not cling to others,
Climbing dragons or riding phoenixes wastes the spirit.

Several days after inscribing this, he ascended to immortality.

**The Orange Elder**

The Elder was a man of Bana, his surname unknown. His family owned an orange grove, and after the frost, all the oranges were harvested—save for two large ones, each the size of a four-*dou* jar. The people of Ba ordered them plucked, yet their weight was no different from ordinary oranges. When cut open, each contained two elders, their hair, beards, and brows thick and full, their skin and bodies ruddy and luminous. They sat facing each other, playing *xiangqi*. Standing just over a foot tall, they chatted and laughed as if at ease. After finishing their game, one elder said, "You owe me ten taels of the seventh daughter of the Sea Dragon Spirit’s hair, twelve branches of *zhi*□□*huang*, a bolt of purple silk gauze, and two doses of *xiaoshi* from Crimson Terrace Mountain." The other replied, "You owe me nine *hu* of jade dust from Yingzhou, four cups of Mother A’s marrow-congealing wine, eight pairs of *mi* socks from Mother A’s daughter Bear Cub, and □ *zi* of the Void-Sustaining Dragon’s gossamer stockings." Another said, "Master Yu, when you return to your thatched hut on Mount Qingcheng, repay me then." One elder remarked, "Master Wang promised to come but never did. The joy of the orange is no less than that of Shang Mountain, though we cannot root ourselves firmly within it." Another said, "I am famished. I must eat some dragon-root jerky." From his sleeve, he drew a grass root, round and an inch in diameter, its shape twisting like a dragon, its fine hairs distinct in every crevice. He peeled and ate it, and as he did, it replenished itself. After finishing, he rinsed it with water, and it transformed into a dragon. The four mounted it, and as their feet stirred the clouds, a sudden storm darkened the sky. Their whereabouts became unknown.

An Old Man by the Roadside
The old man was the paternal granduncle of Pei Hang, a *sim*a.

From Luoyang to Zhengzhou, midway through the journey, Pei dismounted and heard a sound from the roadside. Pushing through the brush, he searched beneath a thorn thicket and found a wounded crane with drooping wings, its wing joints as if broken, its feathers gone, and its cries strange. Suddenly, an old man in white, leaning on a staff, approached from several dozen paces away and asked, "Young sir, how is it that you pity this crane? If you apply human blood to its wounds, it may yet fly again."

Pei, who had long followed the Dao and was of a lofty and carefree nature, promptly replied, "I would not hesitate to offer the blood from my arm." The old man said, "Your resolve is indeed strong, but only the blood of one who has lived three lifetimes as a human will suffice. You were not human in your past life, but in Luoyang, only Hulu Sheng has lived three lifetimes as a man." He continued, "If your journey is not urgent, might you go to Luoyang and seek out Hulu Sheng?"

Pei gladly set off and, before two nights had passed, arrived in Luoyang. He found Hulu Sheng and recounted the matter. Hulu Sheng replied, "This is no difficulty." He opened a plain wooden box and took out a stone vessel, no larger than two fingers. With a needle, he pricked Pei’s arm and let the blood drip into the vessel until it was full. Handing it to Pei, he said, "Say nothing of this."

When Pei returned to the crane, the old man was already there. Delighted, he exclaimed, "Truly, you are a man of your word." He then had Pei apply all the blood to the crane’s wounds, saying they were now bound by fate, and invited Pei, "My home is not far from here. Will you not stay a while?" Pei, sensing the old man was no ordinary person, addressed him as "Elder." Following him for several *li*, they arrived at a hamlet of bamboo groves and thatched cottages, where hemp stalks lay scattered in the courtyard.

Pei, parched with thirst, asked for tea. The old man pointed to a clay jar and said, "There is a little liquid inside. You may take some." Pei looked into the jar and saw a single apricot pit, large as a bamboo hat, filling its mouth. He scooped out the liquid—pure white—and drank deeply, his hunger and thirst vanishing. The taste was like almond cream.

Pei, now certain the old man was a reclusive immortal, bowed and begged to serve him. The old man replied, "You have a minor official post in the mortal world, and even if you abandon it, you will not fulfill your aspirations. The worthy do indeed attain something, though you have long wandered with me unawares. Now, I have a message I must entrust to you." He handed Pei a plain wooden box, large as a bowl, warning, "Do not open it in secret."

He then led Pei to see the crane’s injuries, where feathers had already begun to grow. Turning to Pei, he said, "The apricot nectar you drank will make you weep for your nine clans of kin. Beware of wine and lust." Later, on his return to Luoyang, Pei grew restless on the road and was about to open the box when from each of its four corners emerged the head of a red serpent. He delivered the message to his uncle, who opened it to find an object like a measure of dried barley rice. Later, his uncle traveled to Wangwu Mountain and was never heard from again. Pei lived to the age of ninety-seven.

The Old Man of Mount Zhongnan
Chen Jiqing, a man of Jiangnan, had passed the imperial examinations but remained in Chang’an for ten years without returning home. One day, at the Green Dragon Temple, he called on a monk but did not find him. Resting by the brazier...

A certain Old Man of Mount Zhongnan was also waiting for the monk, and by chance sat for a long while. On the wall hung a map of the world. Jiqing traced the road to Jiangnan and sighed, "If I could but return by this, I would not regret my lack of success." The Old Man replied, "What difficulty is there?" Breaking off a bamboo leaf from before the steps, he placed it upon the map in the midst of the Wei River and said to Chen, "Fix your gaze here, and you shall arrive." Jiqing stared intently—suddenly, the Wei River surged with towering waves, and a great boat appeared. In a daze, he boarded the vessel, which sped forward with astonishing swiftness.

As they passed the Chan Grotto Temple, he inscribed a poem:
*"When the frosted crane cries, the evening wind howls sharp,
A flock of crows gathers once more in the cold woods.
Here I moor my oar to chant in sorrow,
Alone before the Lotus Peak I stand."*

The next day, they reached Tong Pass, where he added the closing lines of another poem:
*"I have made my shameful plan to return—
Yet better this than never to return at all."*

In little more than ten days, he reached home, where his brothers, wife, and children welcomed him with great joy. After two nights, he told his wife, "The examination date draws near; I cannot stay long." He boarded the boat again and composed a poem to bid her farewell:
*"Wine poured deepens sorrow with each drink,
Poems written blend with tears as I sing."*

Then, in a fleeting gust, he vanished. His family, astonished, could only marvel. In an instant, he found himself once more at the Wei River, hastening straight to Green Dragon Temple, where the Old Man still sat wrapped in his coarse robe, and the monk had yet to return. Jiqing bowed in thanks and asked, "Was this not a dream?" The Old Man replied, "In time, you will know for yourself."

A month later, his family came to visit and recounted the whole affair—all the poems he had inscribed were still there, preserved in the valley’s beauty.

The Valley Scholar sat for the imperial examinations multiple times. Later, he suddenly fell into madness, wandering the streets and chanting:

*"A thatched hut once stood,
Still tended with care,
Yet wild winds howl—
Eaves torn, beams split,
Carved brackets sway and sing,
Soon to collapse.
Walls crumble to scattered dust,
The master never returns."*

He later died of illness, and when his coffin was opened for burial, it was found to be empty.

**The Deer-Man**
In Tangzhou, a hunter shot a deer deep in the mountains, only to find it was a man. The man called out to the hunter, "I have hidden in these mountains since the early Sui. Today, I was fated to die by your hand. Only place me among the rocks." The hunter agreed, but when he turned back briefly, the man had already expired. Returning ten days later, the hunter found the body gone.

**Liu Jian**
Liu Jian, a man of Zizhou, was a Daoist adept. Clad in hempen robes and a black headscarf, he feigned foolishness and ignorance. He was deeply filial to his mother, and their home stood by a pond. One day, he suddenly carried his mother up a mountain. That very night, a great flood rose over ten feet, and people began to suspect and marvel at him.

Later, he moved several *li* from the city, carving out a cave dwelling for himself while building a small chamber nearby for his mother. Morning and evening, he would emerge only to check on her rest and meals before returning to his cave to sit in silence. For over a decade, scholars and officials who sought to meet him would enter his cave, but he would not exchange a single word. If questioned, he would not answer, only repeating, *"Hasten your cultivation, hasten your cultivation."*

After his mother passed, he arranged her burial. One day, he vanished into the sky, leaving no trace.

**The Man in White**
Li, Vice-Commissioner of Jiangling, failed the imperial examinations and traveled to Huayin, where he encountered a man in white who asked, "Would you like to know your future?" The man wrote three sealed letters, instructing, "Open them only in dire need."

After five or six more failed attempts, Li fell into poverty. He said, "The immortal’s letter may now be opened." He burned incense and broke the seal, which read: *"Sit before the monastery in Qingzhou."* Li went there, and after a short while, the abbot appeared, asking, "Do you recognize Magistrate Li of Songzi?" The vice-commissioner replied, "He was my father." The abbot said, "Years ago, your father entrusted two thousand strings of cash to this monastery, a debt that weighed on his heart. I now return it to you." Li loaded the money and returned home.

Years passed without success in the examinations. He said, "This concerns my entire life—time for the second letter." It read: *"On such-and-such a day, ride through the western market and pause."* On that day, he went, and from a tower below, someone called out, "The examining minister, the Vice-Director, requires a thousand strings of cash to secure your success." Li ascended and met the man, who made a firm agreement. The following year, he indeed passed the examinations and later rose to the rank of Vice-Commissioner in the Palace Administration.

One day, he suffered severe heart pain and opened the third letter, which read: *"On such-and-such a day, Vice-Commissioner Li of Jiangling will suffer heart pain—settle your family affairs."* Two days later, he died.

**The Craftsman of Fangzhou**

The Craftsman of Fangzhou

In Fangzhou’s Zhushan County, a recluse’s household had a well dug over a thousand feet deep, yet no water was found. As the craftsman felt along the walls, he entered another realm of heaven and earth, with its own sun and moon, which bore a placard reading *Celestial Cassia Mountain*. Inside the gate stood two youths—fair of tooth and lustrous of hair, their feet delicate and unshod, their caps not yet donned—who asked, "Why have you come here?" The craftsman recounted his story in full. Presently, a messenger in flowing robes arrived and declared, "Send him off with propriety." They led him to a spring where he bathed, then rinsed his mouth with its clear, sweet waters, which tasted as intoxicating as wine.

After half a day’s journey, he reached a kingdom whose palaces and halls were all of gold and jade. The city gates bore an inscription: *Ladder-to-Immortality Land*. The craftsman asked, "What is this place?" They replied, "All who first attain immortality are sent here to cultivate for seven hundred thousand days before ascending to the heavens, where they wander Jade Capital Penglai, Kunlun, and Guye."

He then climbed the mountain in search of a path. A gatekeeper said, "Though you have been here but a moment, a dozen years have passed. The old tunnel can no longer be found. We must petition for the key to the Heavenly Pass to guide you back through the Celestial Gate." In an instant, clouds carried him back to Fangzhou. When he inquired after the recluse’s household, he was told, "Three or four years have already passed." Thereafter, the craftsman ate no grain, and none knew his whereabouts.

The River Elder was skilled in playing the long flute and could produce the cries of dragons. Later, while traveling, he rested beneath a large pagoda tree by the roadside near the Jade Plate Bean Pavilion in Minxiang. That night, he saw a figure towering several *zhang* tall, who said, "I took you for a *niuji* by the pagoda, but you are a *Bi Zhuo* by the jar." Then, pointing to the tree, he added, "The Second Young Master from Jingshan Lodge has come to visit his elder brother." Soon after, someone descended from the tree. At dawn, the elder went to Jingshan Lodge and saw a pagoda tree ten *wei* in girth in the courtyard. Suspecting it harbored a divine being, he said, "I have long sought the Dao but never met a master. If the tree spirit is willing, I beg for your guidance." The spirit replied, "Simply enter Mount Ke and seek Master Bao the Immortal; you will surely attain transcendence." The elder entered the mountain and indeed encountered the immortal master, who instructed him to play the flute.
