As he blew, a single breath carried pure emptiness, the five notes rang clear and resonant, summoning springs to gush forth, drawing crows to fly low, shaking withered leaves from their branches, and coaxing light clouds from the peaks. The immortal master said, "Your art has reached perfection, but what you play is a bamboo flute. I now gift you a flute of fine jade. After playing it for three years, you will summon dragons from the caves. They will bring you the Water Elixir; swallow it, and you will become a Water Immortal, sparing you the need for my medicine—for you bear the destiny of *Qin Gao*."

Three years later, the elder played the flute atop a tower at Yueyang Temple. Sure enough, a dragon transformed into a man and presented him with the elixir. The elder consumed it, his visage reverted to youth, and he entered water without getting wet, thus becoming a Water Immortal.

Hong Zhi was a Daoist whose surname was Hong and given name Zhi, though his origins were unknown. From youth, he was broadly learned and well-versed in the classics, as well as the mysteries of astrology, cosmology, medicine, and pharmacology, mastering each to its utmost. Yet he remained obscure, and when others urged him to seek favor at the gates of the powerful to advance himself, he replied, "Fine gold and beautiful jade are not things to be hawked for credit." He never went. Later, reflecting on the dreamlike impermanence of the world, he renounced it as insubstantial and became a Daoist, withdrawing to seclusion on Mount Lu. He often rode a blue ox as he came and went, earning the name "Blue Ox Daoist." Living in the mountains, he wore clothing of grass, ate wild plants, and devoted himself to ascetic practice. After some time, he unexpectedly encountered an extraordinary person who taught him divine formulas. From then on, he could command the Six *Jia* spirits, summon gods and ghosts, and perform myriad transformations beyond count.

One day, he returned to his hometown, carrying a small basket. The villagers, unaware of his attainment, invited him to drink. He emptied every dish and platter, then drew from his basket dried meats, roasted delicacies, dates, and chestnuts to share. All who sat with him ate their fill, and those who took from him were sated to surfeit, marveling and questioning him. He only smiled and did not answer. Later, staying at an inn on a cold night, people saw him wearing only thin garments and no bedding or extra clothes. They secretly watched him through the door and saw him take a pillow and quilt from his small basket, covering himself as he lay down. Everything he needed was there, and he carried it all away again when he left. Then the people knew he had attained the Dao, saying, "Master Hong is not like the rest of us." And they all revered him.

Later, after his elixir was perfected and he ascended as an immortal, the place where he had dwelled was named Green Ox Valley, and his altar site remains there to this day.

Sang Jufeng of White Deer Grotto was a recluse surnamed Sang, named Jufeng, though his origins were unknown. He called himself a *jinshi*. Crude in nature and disposition, he kept himself apart from human sentiment. Once, while lodging at the Purple Ultimate Palace in Guizhou, he bought a length of tripe to fill his meal, then washed it in a vinegar pot with water he had drawn. The Daoist priests found this strange and refused to lend him their pots and cauldrons, so he glared at them in anger. On a winter night in the refectory, only one bed was provided, and the wind and frost cut to the bone through the gaps in the windows on all sides. Jufeng removed his cloth robe, hung it on a rack, and slept soundly in the nude, much to the shock of those around him.

Later, he visited various palaces and paid homage to the Prince of Nanping, wearing one straw sandal and one hemp shoe, calling himself a "wild man." When asked what the "ornamental baton" in the *Zuo Tradition* was, he replied, "A tray of dates, tossed and eaten." All his other answers followed in this manner. Later, in Jiangxia, he reverted to his former madness and unruliness. The military commissioner □ Jian ordered his guards to strip him and expel him from the territory. When he reached Star Lake, he leapt into the air and soared away.

A client general from Jingzhou was dispatched on a mission to Wuchang and reported all he had witnessed. Thereafter, Jufeng spent much time in the northern lands, and whenever he paid his respects, he would inscribe his sleeve with: "Sang Jufeng, Provincial Graduate of the White Deer Grotto in Mount Lu." Many mocked him, yet none knew where he ultimately settled.

Daoist Sima Jiao
Daoist Sima Jiao, also named Ningzheng and Shouzhong, was skilled in arts of unknown origin. He often wandered along the Yangtze, wearing a hempen cap and straw sandals, covering a thousand *li* in a day. His garments remained perpetually new, untouched by wear, and none dared approach whatever he struck. He could feign death, his body swelling and rotting with stench, only to revive moments later.

Once, he stayed at the Kaiyuan Abbey in Chizhou. From Xuanzhou, he traveled to Shezhou, where Daoist Shao Xiumo also journeyed. Upon reaching the city, Sima Jiao proposed they travel together, but Xiumo avoided him and set off first. When Xiumo stopped to rest at an inn in a garrison town, Sima Jiao had already arrived. Xiumo concealed himself to observe and saw Jiao enter another shop, summon the innkeeper, and drink with him. Soon after, Jiao insulted the man, who at first politely declined but was eventually forced to strike back. They grappled until Jiao suddenly collapsed, appearing dead—his body cold, his complexion altered. The entire market gathered to gawk. The villagers bound the innkeeper, searched his person, and recorded his testimony, preparing to send him to the prefecture. As evening fell, they decided to wait until dawn. After midnight, a cry arose from the inn: "Sima Jiao is gone!" Only then did the people realize he had feigned death, and they released the innkeeper.

The next day, Xiumo resumed his journey. After traveling over a hundred *li*, he asked someone, "When did Master Sima pass through here?" The reply: "He went by early this morning." The following day, after another hundred *li*, he asked again and was told, "He passed yesterday morning." Upon reaching Shezhou, the answer was the same. Wherever he traveled among the prefectures along the Yangtze, whenever he lodged at an inn, he would announce before departing, "I cannot take my bamboo utensils with me; I shall burn them." The innkeeper would protest, "The wind is strong, and the bamboo hut is low and cramped—you cannot set a fire!" Ignoring their pleas, Jiao would grow angry, light a fire inside, and stand at the door with a great staff, striking anyone who dared approach. Strong as he was, none dared advance. Soon the flames roared through the gaps in the bamboo roof. The crowd panicked, but when the fire subsided, Jiao’s bamboo utensils were reduced to ash, the bed he had lain on was charred, yet the mat beneath remained unscorched.

Zhu Ao, a legal officer in Chizhou, once received a visit from Sima Jiao, who told him, "Your complexion is ill—you will fall sick. I shall leave now. If, in your illness, you call my true name, I may respond." Zhu dismissed his words, but ten days later, he indeed fell gravely ill with fever. Suddenly recalling Jiao’s warning, he revered him as a divine being and bowed in prayer, invoking his aid. Earlier, during his illness, Zhu had seen a figure at his bedside—a minor clerk named Chen, who wielded a *ruyi* scepter and ordered him to attend Zhu. Zhu had rebuked and dismissed him. No one but his family was permitted inside. Now, in a daze, Zhu saw Chen holding a bowl of medicine. After drinking it, he felt his mind clear and his body ease. He called to his family, "The medicine Chen brought was most effective—bring more!" His family gasped, "We barred him from entering; how could Chen have come?" Then Zhu realized it was Sima Jiao’s divine intervention. From that day, his illness gradually improved.

Once, Sima Jiao resided at an abbey in Shezhou, suffering severely from dysentery. The abbey’s superiors planned to report his condition to the authorities, but first sought his opinion. Jiao grew furious: "My illness is nearly cured—why trouble them?" Yet his condition worsened. Unable to refuse, the abbey’s head reported to the county magistrate, who sent someone to inquire. Jiao demanded, "How did you know of my illness?" When the messenger relayed this, Jiao flew into a rage. He rose at once, dressed, and strode into the mountains, moving as swiftly as if on level ground. Over ten days later, he returned with a great staff, seeking the abbey’s head to strike him. The Daoist priests bowed and pleaded for mercy, and he relented.

Later, in the market of Hongzhou, he bought fresh food. A child shouted, "Daoist eating fresh!" Enraged, Jiao hurled an object at the child, striking his forehead and drawing blood. Patrolmen seized Jiao and brought him before the garrison commander, who, upon hearing his name, rejoiced and tried to persuade him. Jiao instead unleashed a torrent of abuse. Infuriated, the commander had him beaten dozens of times. Jiao remarked to others, "If he had struck me fifteen times, I would have lived fifteen days; ten times, ten days." Soon after, he died as foretold.

Thereafter, he dwelled at the Jianji Abbey on Mount Lu, exploring daily. Even the steepest peaks and cliffs, where others dared not tread, he traversed as easily as flat ground. Later, he lay drunk for days without rising. Before his death, he placed a staff in his coffin. When they buried him and later opened the coffin, they found it empty—only the staff remained.

*Comprehensive Mirror of Perfected Immortals Who Embodied the Dao, Scroll Forty-Four* (conclusion)
*Comprehensive Mirror of Perfected Immortals Who Embodied the Dao, Scroll Forty-Five*

Master Lü Cha—Lü Yan, styled Dongbin and known as Master Pure Yang—is traditionally said to have hailed from Dongping. Another account places his birth in Yongle Town, Puji County, Henan Prefecture of the Western Capital, the present-day Hedong Prefecture of Hezhong. His great-grandfather, Lü Yanzhi, served the Tang and rose to Military Commissioner of Zhedong. His grandfather, Lü Wei, passed the imperial examinations and, during the reign of Emperor Dezong in the Zhenyuan era, advanced to Vice Minister of Rites before retiring as Prefect of Tanzhou. He had four sons: Lü Wen, styled Huaguang, who became Prefect of Quzhou; Lü Gong, who served as Judicial Administrator of the Lingnan Prefecture; Lü Jian, who was a Censor; and Lü Rang, who held the post of Right Mentor to the Crown Prince. Some say he later became Prefect of Haizhou. The Master was Lü Rang’s son.

On the fourteenth day of the fourth month in the twelfth year of the Zhenyuan era (796 CE), he was born beneath a forest of trees. From childhood, he was exceptionally bright, reciting ten thousand words a day. In the second year of the Kaicheng era under Emperor Wenzong (837 CE), he passed the imperial examinations. At the time of his success, he was forty-two years old, with the bearing of a dragon and the eyes of a phoenix, his temples sparse and refined—a countenance of metal and water. He wore a Huayang cap and a carefree robe, his appearance resembling that of Zhang Liang and evoking the likeness of the Grand Historian.

Later, while traveling on Mount Lu, he encountered an extraordinary figure who imparted to him the secret of longevity. Another account states that during the Huichang era of Emperor Wuzong, he twice sat for the imperial examinations without success. While journeying toward Mount Hua in Chang’an, he rested at a wineshop. Presently, a man with a long beard and green eyes arrived from the west and also stopped to rest. The two shared a meal, and the bearded stranger prepared the fire himself. The Master sat basking in the sun and, without realizing it, fell asleep. In his dream, he passed the imperial examinations, ascended through the ranks, and held illustrious office. His memorials to the throne met with approval, and he was appointed to the Hanlin Academy, entered the Grand Secretariat, and was promoted to the emperor’s retinue. Soon after, he was named to the highest echelons of government.

Having served at court for over thirty years, he once made an error in his audience with the emperor and was punished. Stripped of his rank, he was exiled south beyond the Yangtze. On the road, he encountered wind and snow, his servants and horses utterly spent. Desolate and alone, he sighed to himself. Suddenly, he awoke from his dream—the bearded stranger’s millet was still not cooked. The man laughed abruptly and said, *"The yellow grain is not yet done, yet in a single dream you’ve reached Huaxu."* The Master exclaimed in surprise, *"How did you know I had a dream?"* The bearded man replied, *"The dream you just had—wealth and honor are no cause for joy, poverty and lowliness no cause for sorrow. In the grand scheme, success and failure, glory and disgrace, long life and early death, gain and loss—from ancient times to the present, all are but a dream. Wealth and honor are a pleasant dream; poverty and lowliness, a nightmare. Long life is a pleasant dream; early death, a nightmare. The dream you just had was indeed a pleasant one—yet one misstep, and it turns into a nightmare. You already know this well. High rank is but an empty name; riches are like a fire of retribution. Gold and jewels are external things; children and grandchildren belong to others. When a single breath departs, the four elements scatter—what then remains truly enduring?"*

He then inscribed a poem on the wall. The Master, deeply enlightened, bowed and said, *"You are truly an extraordinary man. May I ask your name and homeland?"* The bearded man replied, *"I am Zhongli Quan, the world’s idlest wanderer, dwelling on Mount Zhongnan. If you have awakened, you may follow me."* Thereupon, the Master abandoned his Confucian studies and became his disciple, traveling with him until he attained the Dao.

In the first year of Guangming during the reign of Emperor Xizong (880 CE), he met Master Cui, who transmitted to him the *Mirror of Medicinal Elixirs*, enabling him to cultivate life and nature with flawless precision. Thereafter, he often wandered between Xiangtan, Mount Heng, and E, unknown to others. Once, he inscribed a poem on Yueyang Tower:

*At dawn I roam the Northern Peak, by dusk the verdant Wu,*
*My sleeve enfolds a green serpent—bold my qi and true.*
*Thrice to Yueyang I’ve come, yet none know my face,*
*Reciting aloud, I soar past Dongting’s embrace.*

Many of his poems and essays remain in the world, glimpsed in the *Anthology of True Constancy*. He also composed *Alchemical Secrets*, *Expounding the Orthodox Discourse*, and *The Sword Collection*, each imbued with profound principles, bequeathed to later seekers. Later, he journeyed south to Baling, then west to Guanzhong, ascending to immortality at Purple Pole Mountain. Another account holds that he passed through Jiangzhou, ascended Yellow Crane Tower, and on the twentieth day of the fifth month at noon, ascended to heaven, the year unknown.

In his own autobiography, he wrote: *"I am a native of Jingzhao. In the late Tang, I repeatedly sat for the imperial examinations but failed. While traveling on Mount Hua, I met Zhongli Quan, who transmitted the art of extending life. Later, I encountered the Perfected One of Bitter Bamboo, who taught me the method of sun-moon conjunction. Meeting Zhongli again, I fully grasped the wonders of the golden elixir. At fifty, my Dao was perfected. First, I delivered Guo Shang’ao; second, I delivered the immortal maiden Zhao, whose dharma name was He. Both were quick of wit, so I taught them the method of returning to the root and restoring life. I often roamed between the two Zhe provinces, Bianjing, and Qiao Commandery—my height five feet two inches, my face sallow and fair, my nose straight and prominent, with a mole beneath my left eye the size of a chopstick tip. I usually wore a white-lined robe and hempen sandals. My transformations are unfathomable. The world says I sell ink and fly swords to take men’s heads—I hear this and smile. In truth, I possess three swords: one severs affliction, one severs greed and gluttony, and one severs lust for beauty. Such is my swordsmanship. Those who transmit my spirit do not equal those who transmit my method; those who transmit my method do not equal those who transmit my conduct. How can one who acts contrary to these attain the Dao, even if we walk hand in hand? After my ascension, I often descended among men to transform and deliver them. Disciples of immortality come and go, hidden and revealed, beyond measure or recognition. The details of my earlier and later sojourns among men are recorded in various texts."*

On the twenty-eighth day of the seventh month in the first year of Xuanhe during the reign of Emperor Huizong of Song (1119 CE), an imperial edict was issued: *"We, in Our desire to guide the people toward the Great Dao, honor those immortals whose deeds are recorded in the annals. The Bureau of Sacrifices has reviewed the records and bestowed fitting titles. The Perfected Lord Lü, concealing his radiance and dwelling in distant lands, now graces Our court with his presence. We sigh in admiration at this auspicious sign and confer upon him a name and title. May the divine not perish, and may Our favor be witnessed."* Thus, he was specially enfeoffed as *Perfected Lord of Wondrous Communication*. In the sixth year of Zhiyuan during the reign of Emperor Shizu of Yuan (1269 CE), he was further honored as *Perfected Lord of Pure Yang, Expounder of the Orthodox and Admonisher of Transformation*.

Minister Dao Yi remarked: *"Lü Yan abandoned profit and renounced fame, roaming beyond the world. His spirit manifested the Dao’s transformations, cutting off all ties to the mundane. Consider his poem: ‘Thrice to Yueyang I’ve come, yet none know my face, / Reciting aloud, I soar past Dongting’s embrace.’ Those who hear of his deeds are delighted. As the *Dao De Jing* says: ‘Those who know me are few; thus, I am noble.’ This truly describes Lü Yan."*

**Shi Jianwu**
Shi Jianwu, styled Xisheng and sobriquet Huayang, was a native of Fen Shui in Mu Prefecture. His family had long resided by the Seven Li Rapids of Yanling. From youth, he sat for the imperial examinations and studied the *Book of Rites*, gaining renown for his poetry. Drawn to misty peaks and enamored of the immortals’ art of light ascent, he passed the imperial examinations in the fifteenth year of Yuanhe during the reign of Emperor Xianzong of Tang (820 CE). The chief examiner was Li Jian, Minister of Rites. The assigned rhapsody topic was *The Great Soup*, to be composed without harmonizing flavors. His poem *Early Spring’s Lingering Snow* topped the list, alongside Yao Kang and Yuan Hui, who later gained fame for their poetry and prose. Jianwu alone did not enter officialdom. Zhang Ji, Academician of the Imperial Archives, presented him with a poem: *Though you’ve gained an empty name, it clings not to your frame.* Another poem, *Seeing Off the Recluse Returning East*, contained the line: *You’ve bent to win high fame, now idle wherever you roam.* Thus, Xisheng’s poems referred to himself as *a graduate of Yuanhe, a hermit of Changqing*—for the year after his success in the examinations, the era name changed to Changqing, and he withdrew, never to return.

In the reign of Emperor Wenzong of Tang (827–840 CE), he journeyed from Yanling into the Western Mountains to seek the Dao and dwell in quietude. Initially, Xisheng met Master Jingyang, who transmitted to him the five secrets of inner elixir refinement and the divine formulas of outer alchemy. Later, he encountered Lü Dongbin again, who taught him the great Dao of inner refinement and the golden liquid’s return to cinnabar. Thereafter, he permanently secluded himself in the Western Mountains. Today, about a mile west of the mountain lies Banana Spring. Ascending the stone steps, one finds the site of his study hall, with the stone chamber still standing. A few of the old cypresses he planted remain. His surviving poems and essays are numerous, though less than forty percent of his works are preserved in the mountains. Some of his admonitions to Yanling were inscribed on stone, reading: *"Behold the carved words upon this rock."*

Qiongshan’s Bai Yuchan postscript to *The Collected Works of Shi Huayang* states: Li Zhen often transmitted the secrets of the Taiyi knife-point fire talismans to Zhongli Quan, and Zhongli Quan passed them to Lü Dongbin. Lü was Shi’s master. Shi had a foremost disciple, Li Wenying. In the past, Master Shi imparted to Li sixteen characters, rarely known to the world: *"One wondrous spirit abides; the Dharma-realm is perfectly pervaded. Departing from all extremes, truly grasp the center."* I chanced upon these words and thus shared them with Hu Xizhen, that he might fill the lacuna.

Yang Wuwei’s poem inscribed in the stone chamber reads:
*"From the Jade Capital, high above the golden roster, I departed;
Returning in a white deer-drawn carriage to this stone retreat.
Behind the mountain, a hidden path leads to the Heavenly Treasure Grotto;
Before my eyes lies the dwelling of an earthbound immortal.
At times, a dog’s bark pierces the clear night snow;
Looking back, the red dust teems with frogs in the well.
Five hundred years have passed since men last trod this path—
Above Banana Spring, mist and rosy clouds are locked in embrace."*

Xu Jun
Xu Jun styled himself a man of Penglai in the Eastern Sea. His speech was refined, always drawing from the classics and histories, quick-witted yet profound. He often recited to himself:
*"I once saw the First Emperor bridge the stones across the sea,
While sea gods toiled, swelling the tides in alarm.
Though Penglai lies far beyond the waves, hard to reach,
Ascending the Three Clarities is not so distant."*
He always wore a gourd at his waist, poled a small boat, and drifted upon Ezhu, upstream to the Three Xiang, downstream through the Five Lakes. Often, he would trade fish at riverside markets for wine, then recite verses with locals before departing, his hair turned white. Those fond of marvels claimed to have known him for decades, yet his countenance never aged. When playfully detained and asked to name the weight of his catch, he would fish for a moment and pull up a fish matching the requested measure, astonishing all. If he saw someone ill, he would take medicine from his gourd to cure them. The pills were as small as sesame seeds; he forbade ingestion, insisting they be ground in wine and applied to the chest and abdomen, whereupon the illness would vanish—always miraculously effective. When asked if the medicine could be taken orally, he replied, *"It can, but once swallowed, one loses all taste for food."* Dao seekers who took a single pill went ten years without eating, though they still required wine and water to sustain themselves; their complexions remained rosy, their teeth and hair unaged. Many who received his medicine lived to eighty or ninety. Lu Shan’s Qian Lang repeatedly took his pills and attained great longevity. Today, fishermen on the rivers and lakes sometimes glimpse him; when pursued, his boat flees like the wind, impossible to approach—he is a water immortal.

Qian Lang
The recluse Qian Lang, styled Neiguang, was a native of Hongzhou’s Nanchang. In his youth, he dwelled on West Mountain, studying diligently with noble integrity. He passed the Five Classics examination, held successive official posts, and was renowned for his uprightness; upon leaving office, he left behind fond memories, and contemporary opinion praised him. During Emperor Wenzong’s reign in the Tang, he served as Vice Commissioner of Annan in the early Kaicheng era, later becoming Minister of the Court of Imperial Entertainments before retiring to Lu Shan. Indifferent to worldly affairs, he loved the Dao and became a disciple of Mount Song’s Daoist Xu Jun, mastering the arts of replenishing the brain and returning to the origin, as well as the methods of ingesting and refining elixirs for longevity. In Emperor Zhaozong’s time, Qian Tang’s Prince of Pengcheng, Qian Liu, admired Lang’s attainment of the Dao and long life, and invited him to Qian Tang to serve as his master. By then, Lang was already over one hundred fifty years old, yet his complexion remained youthful, his step light. Several of his great-grandsons had entered officialdom through the classics examinations, serving as high ministers, their hair already white. One day, Lang suddenly announced his farewell: *"I have lived in this world for many years, but now I am summoned by the Upper Clarity and must depart."* Soon after, his breath ceased. For days, his countenance remained serene as in life; when lifted into the coffin, his body was as light as an empty robe—he had achieved liberation in the flesh. His great-grandsons told others, *"Our great-grandfather lived to be over one hundred seventy years old."*

Yang Yunwai
Yang Yunwai, styled Muxian, was a native of Xuzhou. His family had long served in the military, but Yunwai, born with exceptional intelligence, alone disdained the life of armor and weapons. Nearing adulthood, he informed his parents of his wish to become a Daoist. His parents could not dissuade him from his resolve.

At the time, a ruined hermitage stood in the barren mountains, and Yunwai went to dwell there. Soon, a stranger appeared and pointed out a place, saying, *"Beneath lies a cache of coins. You lack food—take what you need."* Later, the stranger also imparted Daoist teachings to Yunwai. Thereupon, his spiritual insight suddenly deepened, and he gained the ability to fast, as well as to tame tigers and wolves. When his parents missed him, Yunwai would return home, yet others saw him still residing in the hermitage—all were greatly astonished.

After a long stay, he departed to wander Mount Lu, where he came and went among a pack of tigers. He traveled through many grotto-heavens. In the final years of Emperor Xuanzong of Tang’s *Dazhong* era, he settled in the gorges, reaching Wanzhou’s Stone City Mountain. Tigers abounded there, yet he sat in meditation among them day and night. The mountain was high and waterless, but soon a spring suddenly welled forth. Before long, he arrived at Yunsheng Abbey in Yun’an.

During Emperor Yizong’s *Xiantong* era, he told others, *"My homeland will face disaster."* That year, in the tenth month, Pang Xun’s rebellion erupted in Pengcheng. Later, under Emperor Xizong’s *Qianfu* reign, Huang Chao rose in Cao and Pu, his influence spreading across the land. The gorges, however, were perilous and remote, and the people relied on their seclusion to feel secure. One day, Yunwai lay drunk in the marketplace, sighing in sorrow, *"This place will see much slaughter—what is to be done?"* Later, when war broke out in the gorges, the very lands Yunwai had left became sites of massacre, blood staining the earth crimson.

In the second year of *Guangqi*, Yunwai visited a young man named Yuan in the town and told him, *"I once owed a debt to the Wang family of Baishui, which I have yet to fully repay—I must settle it."* In the second month, the Wangs indeed rose in rebellion, raiding Yunsheng Abbey. Yunwai met his end, struck down by a blade. Yuan retrieved his body, which appeared as it had in life. Later, some claimed to have seen him traveling between Fangling and Yun’an. The nephew of Li Wenbiao, the prefectural inspector of Yun’an, also encountered him in Chengdu. When Yuan opened the coffin to look, only a short hempen robe remained.

A stele stands at Yunsheng Abbey in Yun’an, its inscription composed by Du Guangting.

Wang Changyu
Wang Changyu was a native of Zizhou.

Wang Changyu served as a prison officer in the prefectural yamen. Once, he ate a pig’s trotter for breakfast but did not finish it, so he put it away. Later, his wife and concubine hid it, and by evening, when they were about to retrieve it, the maidservant Honglian reported its disappearance. Changyu suspected theft and subjected her to flogging. Unable to endure the pain, she falsely confessed. His wife then produced the trotter and said, *"I was only testing you. When you interrogate prisoners, do you not act the same way?"* Changyu was deeply moved and enlightened. From then on, he overturned many wrongful convictions, and his conduct gradually aligned with the Dao.

Soon after, an old man selling medicine in the market claimed it could exterminate rats. Yet for days, no one purchased any. Changyu pitied him and, whenever he encountered the old man, would invite him home for meals. This continued for some time until the old man asked in surprise, *"Does your household suffer from many rats?"* Changyu replied, *"I pity you for making no sales, so I invite you to dine—not to poison rats."* The medicine remained untouched. The old man said, *"Simply use it. The rats may not die."* Changyu returned home, placed the medicine in the food, and rats gathered in great numbers. After eating, they all transformed into wagtails and flew away. Changyu was astonished and went to seek the old man, but he had vanished.

Not long after, a Daoist wandered drunk through the market, clad in strange robes. The people called him the "Fallen Immortal." At the time, Bai Zhaosi governed Shuchuan as military commissioner, and Liu Pi, in rebellion, had forbidden night travel—any caught after dark were put to death. Changyu, serving as a garrison officer in charge of the right district, passed through his jurisdiction one night when he saw a man in strange robes. Upon closer inspection, he recognized the Fallen Immortal. Concealing him without reporting, Changyu helped him home.

Once sober, the Fallen Immortal cursed, *"I had two bolts of fine silk, three taels of silver, and two thousand coins—now they’re gone. It must have been you!"* Changyu did not argue but repaid him the exact amount. The Fallen Immortal took the money and left, saying, *"One day, you will see me on the Lu River."*

Years later, the authorities summoned former officials to transport tax silk, and Changyu was assigned to escort a shipment of silk to Luzhou. On the road to Jiang’an, he encountered two Daoists armed with blades, bows, and arrows. Trembling with fear, Changyu dared not advance. The Daoists called out, *"Is that you? Do not be afraid—we are the Fallen Immortal."* They led Changyu to their dwelling, served him wine, and afterward returned the gold and silk he had once given, saying, *"This was prepared for you today."* With these, Changyu repaid the silk shipment, covering the shortfall, and returned with the official documents.

The Daoist then instructed Changyu: *"Do you know that the yang essence forms the spirit, the yin essence forms the soul, and the union of the two gives rise to divine clarity? The spirit acts through the body, and the body lives by the spirit—when the spirit departs, the body perishes."* Changyu replied, *"I do not understand. I would gladly receive your teaching."* The Daoist said, *"The spirit preserves the body through the Dao, and through arts, it extends your destiny."* He then transmitted the secret of the *Red Dragon Great Elixir*, adding, *"The rat poison you once used was the foundation of external alchemy. Cultivated with fire for three years and consumed, it grants immortality."* He bestowed upon Changyu the name *Yi Xuanzi*.

Calling his attendants, the Daoist presented Changyu with a horse. Though bridleless, it galloped like lightning, soaring straight toward the heavens. In an instant, they reached a towering peak—then, as if stumbling, they stood upon level ground. The horse suddenly spoke: *"I am the dragon of this pool. Do you still recall the elixir formula I taught you?"* It then expounded further. When it finished, the horse leapt into the pool and transformed into a dragon, vanishing in a spray of foam.

Soon after, a woodcutter arrived. Changyu asked where he was, and the man replied, *"Shuchuan."* Changyu inquired the way back, returned to the prefecture, and petitioned for exemption from further service. Thereafter, he refined the elixir on Changping Mountain in the northern outskirts and Fenghuang Mountain in the west. When the pill was complete, he ascended lightly into the heavens. This occurred on the ninth day of the ninth month in the thirteenth year of Emperor Xuanzong’s *Dazhong* era.

**Er Zhu Dong**
Er Zhu Dong, styled Tongwei, was of unknown origin.

In his youth, Er Zhu Dong encountered an extraordinary person who transmitted to him the Dao of returning to the primordial and embracing the One, along with the formula for refining the great elixir of immortality. Thus, he styled himself *Guīyuánzǐ* ("Return-to-the-Origin Master"). During the reign of Emperor Yizong of Tang, he arrived at Pengzhou. The prefecture boasted the Greater and Lesser Peng Mountains, where, according to legend, a man in the time of King Mu of Zhou had carved wood into a sheep, mounted it, and ascended as an immortal. Tongwei remarked, *"This place shares its name with the three mountains of the Eastern Sea, and here, too, lies the path of the sheep-riding immortal. Perhaps I shall attain the Dao here."* He climbed vines, scaled sheer cliffs, and discovered a stone chamber, overjoyed. *"This will suffice for my work,"* he declared. After some time, he departed and sold medicines in the region between Shu and Han. His movements were as light as if riding the void. Often, he would consume congealed blood and washed intestines, drink wine, and recite poetry, leaving others baffled. At the inns where he lodged, the hosts would nightly hear strange creaking sounds from his room. Peering in, they saw his body rise from the bed until it struck the roof beam. Later, they waited until he was drunk and stealthily dusted his abdomen with powder. At dawn, they found it clinging to the rafters, gleaming white. Someone once retrieved an object like a sparrow’s egg from a withered corpse and showed it to Tongwei. He said, *"This is likely the residue of one who consumed the divine elixir but failed to refine it properly. The pure yin dissolved entirely, leaving no yang to accompany it, and thus it congealed in the cinnabar field. If a woman swallows it, she will bear an extraordinary child."* Indeed, a woman who ingested the egg gave birth to a boy whose divine radiance dazzled the sun, filling the room with a wondrous fragrance.

During the *Dashun* era of Emperor Zhaozong of Tang, when Wang Jian besieged Chengdu, Tongwei was also there. His host, distressed, said, *"Jian has sworn that on the day the city falls, he will slaughter all without exception. What is to be done?"* Tongwei replied, *"Do not worry."* He spread out a bamboo mat, gathered Jian and his entire army into it, and they appeared no larger than a swarm of ants. Jian and his troops saw a divine being riding a black cloud, who rebuked them, *"If you dare harm a single hair of my people, your doom will follow."* Terrified, Jian and his men prostrated themselves, crying, *"We dare not!"* When Jian entered Chengdu, he indeed restrained his troops. The markets remained unchanged, and the people were spared. Tongwei then traveled to Guozhou.

Once, in a drunken stupor at the Tianfeng Hermitage, he vomited his elixir into the well, saying, *"This will become a fine medicine."* To this day, those suffering from ailments in the scorching summer recover upon drinking from it. Zhu Feng Mountain in Guozhou, to the south of the prefecture, was the site where Zhu Xian and Li Chunfeng had cultivated their arts. One day, Tongwei said to his friend, the local man Zhang Hongzhi, *"I have long neglected my audience with the Primordial, and now I must hasten to the Xie Immortals’ Mountain to pay homage to the Celestial Pole."* It was a clear winter night, the water clock nearing midnight, when a sudden blizzard descended. Hongzhi, fearing Tongwei would freeze, waited until the last watch before venturing out to find him. He saw Tongwei clad in a single layer of clothing, standing on the outer path, holding up a jade tablet and saying, *"I was on my way to pay homage to the Primordial when I fell by this stream. Listen—the sound of my impact on the boulder must have split it. Go and see."* Hongzhi looked, and indeed, the stone was cleft. Nearby lay a man who had died from drink. Tongwei administered a medicine, and the man immediately revived.

Having spoken thus, Tongwei entered the netherworld. The magistrate there commanded him to return at once, saying, *"A decree from the Perfected One grants you an extension of one twelve-year cycle."* Hongzhi, deeply shaken, begged to be initiated into the Dao. Tongwei replied, *"The celestial fish on your thigh is upside-down—this bodes no good. Only in your next life may you succeed."* Hongzhi’s thigh bore a birthmark shaped like a fish, its head naturally pointing upward; now, indeed, it had inverted.

Tongwei prepared a single elixir pill from cinnabar of Danyang, demanding twelve thousand coins in payment. The prefect summoned him to perform the ritual, but Tongwei said, *"The prefect’s gold is abundant—nothing less than one million two hundred thousand coins will suffice."* Enraged, the prefect accused him of deceiving the masses. He had Tongwei sealed in a bamboo casket and sunk into the river.

At the upper reaches of Fuling, two men were fishing from a boat. When they cast their net, they marveled at its weight. Drawing it in, they found Tongwei inside, his appearance unchanged. The fishermen exclaimed, *"Surely this is no ordinary man—has he entered samadhi?"* They struck a bronze bowl to rouse him. After a moment, Tongwei opened his eyes and gazed at the two, asking, *"Who are you? How far is it from here to Tongliang? Is there a place called Sandu?"* They replied, *"We are from the Two Rivers of Baishi, fishermen of these waters. Tongliang lies four hundred li from here. Eastward from this point is Dengdu County, where the sacred mountain of Pingshan and the immortal abode of Xiandu Temple stand."*

Tongwei said, *"My master told me that when I reached Sandu and saw white stones float upon the water, I would ascend as an immortal—this must be the sign."* Earlier, upon reaching the riverbank, Tongwei had cast many white stones into the water, waiting for them to float, though none understood his purpose.

Having stepped ashore, Tongwei addressed the two fishermen calmly: *"You seem like men of the Dao—have you received any transmission?"* They answered, *"Long ago, we learned the essence of the Three Ones from an immortal of Haishan, refining yang to dissolve yin for many years now."* Tongwei then called for wine, and they drank deeply. He divided his elixir and shared it with them. As they reached the lychee orchard below, banners and regalia descended from the heavens, bearing the three of them aloft upon the clouds.

In Fuzhou, amidst the rocky peaks of Songping, Master Erzhu had planted pines. The stones of the mountain bore the patterns of pine trees, and those who gathered them prayed for fine, naturally formed designs. Later, Tongwei reappeared in the world at Xianjing in Chengdu, where a Daoist encountered him.

According to the *Supplement to the Histories of the Five Dynasties*, Master Erzhu’s merit and conduct were so profound that an extraordinary man gave him a single pill, saying, *"When you see a floating stone, swallow it, and the immortal’s Way will be yours."* The master followed the instruction, casting every stone he encountered into the water. Later, while traveling through the gorges and preparing to cross the river, an old man with a boat of ant-like proportions waited for him. When asked his surname, the old man replied, *"Shi."* Asked to which land he belonged, he answered, *"Fuzhou."*

The master suddenly attained enlightenment, swallowed the pill, and immediately ascended in lightness. **Ying Jing**—Ying Jing’s origins remain unknown. During the reign of Emperor Xizong of Tang, he served as magistrate of Dengfeng, where his governance was benevolent. When Huang Chao invaded the eastern capital, his forces dispatched troops to raid the subordinate counties. The officials and people of Dengfeng were seized with terror, at a loss for what to do. The magistrate said, *"Our district has no armory, no weapons, no grain—how can we defend ourselves?"* He then evacuated the entire county to Mount Songgao, making the mountain itself their fortress. When the rebels pursued them, the magistrate fought in person, defending the people to the death. The rebels withdrew, and the people of Dengfeng were preserved. Later, the magistrate resigned his post to study the Dao and ultimately departed as an immortal. He concealed his surname, becoming known only by his given name, hence called *Magistrate Jing*. During the Yuanyou era of Emperor Zhezong of Song, Liu Ji often encountered him on Mount Songgao—his bearing was untrammeled and vast. Magistrate Jing once transmitted the Dao to Huang Pengshi, as recorded in Pengshi’s own account. Peng, whose personal name was Gefei, was a native of Chi. He rose to the rank of *erqianshi*. From youth, he admired purity and loftiness. Before long, he also met Magistrate Jing at Feixian Cliff on Mount Dapeng. Thereafter, he visited frequently. Magistrate Jing was delighted, clapping his hands in laughter as they drank over a *dou* of wine together. Yet whether seated or standing, he would vanish in an instant, traversing a thousand *li* in the blink of an eye—his movements were unfathomable. One day, Magistrate Jing visited Gefei, and Master Lü arrived floating through the air to join them. They sat together in conversation. Gefei hastily rose, bowed twice, and begged for instruction. The True Man said, *"You already have a teacher."* Gefei’s resolve was not steadfast, and in the end, he failed to succeed—all as Magistrate Jing had foretold, dying of illness.

*Comprehensive Mirror of Perfected Immortals Through the Ages Who Embodied the Dao, Scroll Forty-Five* (conclusion)
*Comprehensive Mirror of Perfected Immortals Through the Ages Who Embodied the Dao, Scroll Forty-Six*

King Immortal Wang

During the Tianfu era of Emperor Zhaozong of the Tang, King Immortal Wang wandered from Shangdang, passing through the Beina Pass of the Hou clan and entering Mount Song. His mind was vast and empty, his spirit serene and boundless. Though he mingled with fellow practitioners, none knew his purpose. He drifted without attachment, finding joy in stillness and silence. Eventually, he roamed freely through the forests and valleys, losing all sense of direction. At the time, people thought nothing of it.

Over a year later, his disciples—the Daoist priests—and his younger brother Quan journeyed from Huguan, Taihang, Nanchi, and the peaks of Song and Sha, visiting every temple and abode he had passed through, searching for him. At last, they found the Immortal King in a secluded cliff on the northwest of Mount Song. He sat upright within a cavernous hollow, composed and motionless. The cliff towered nearly a hundred *ren* high, its sheer walls impossible to scale. His disciples lit incense, gazed upon him in reverence, and wept with longing, unable to bear leaving. Suddenly, the Immortal King spoke: *"The Most High, recognizing my past minor merits, has appointed me as Immortal Elder of Shaoshi. The paths of immortals and mortals diverge—do not grieve."* With these words, he ascended into the sky.

At that time, the Daoist priests of Songyang—Jiao Yinhuang, Sun Xuanming, Fei Jingyan, and Luo Yingzhi—together offered incense and flowers, gazing toward the cliffside chamber in solemn reverence.

Li Sheng

Li Sheng, styled Yunju, claimed to be from Jiangxia. He was born during the reign of Emperor Dezong of the Tang.

In his youth, Li Sheng was keenly perceptive. As he matured, he mastered a wide range of texts, possessed a quick and eloquent literary talent, and could compose verses extemporaneously. By nature, he was lofty and archaic in spirit. He studied under a Daoist priest of Shaoshi Mountain, learning the arts of refining *qi* and nurturing the body. He often wore plain cloth and wandered throughout the realm.

During that time, Yuan Qi served as regional inspector of eastern Zhejiang, and Bai Juyi governed Qiantang. Both, having been old friends of Sheng, admired his literary skill and Daoist arts, and invited him to be their guest. At a gathering, they asked him: *"You live in an age of great peace—why not seek honor and emolument instead of remaining a commoner for so long?"* He replied: *"I am not burdened by worldly entanglements."* Even when summoned to office, he refused.

Then he slowly recited:
*"Born in a Confucian age amid peace,
The black cap weighs heavy, the plain cloth is light.
Who would chase fame and profit on the world’s path?
I serve the Jade Emperor and return to the Upper Clarity."*

Yuan and Bai marveled at him. They kept him for over a year with poetry and wine, but he eventually departed for other travels, and none knew his whereabouts.

In the first year of Guangming during the reign of Emperor Xizong, after Huang Chao’s rebellion had thrown the realm into chaos, only the lands south of the Yangtze remained somewhat stable. Tian Yue, the military governor of Wanling, was fond of Daoist arts. Fifty years earlier, elders in Wanling had known Sheng as a child, and when he arrived, they remarked that his appearance had not changed since then—people found this extraordinary. Yue welcomed him and treated him with even greater reverence as a master. Sheng was lithe and vigorous, appearing no older than forty, with jet-black hair, square pupils, and teeth as sharp as rows of jujube pits. He enjoyed eating stone lotus seeds, biting through a *sheng*’s worth in an instant, snapping each in two—a feat no one could imitate. He could drink two *dou* of wine without becoming drunk, fast to cultivate *qi*, and stand in snow wearing only a single layer of clothing while his complexion grew ever more ruddy. At times, he would extend his middle finger toward a lamp over a *zhang* away, and the flame would flicker as if blown by a draft through a crack. No one knew what elixirs he consumed.

When asked about the arts of Daoism and longevity, he always deflected with vague replies. One day, he suddenly told others: *"I am weary of this endless strife of war—it would be better to depart."* At that time, Emperor Zhaozong had been usurped by Zhu Quanzhong. Upon hearing this, Sheng was indignant. The next day, he suddenly ceased breathing, his complexion unchanged. When they lifted him into the coffin, only his empty clothes remained. He was one hundred and forty-seven years old.

Within a month, Tian Lin’s army met defeat, and disaster struck. Sheng had already sensed this beforehand and departed, having once spoken of it to others. All who recalled his words marveled at him as an extraordinary man. Later, there were repeated sightings of him in Shu, appearing as he had before.

Yi Yongchang
Yi Yongchang’s origins were unknown. In the late Tang, he donned a feathered cloak and roamed the lands south of the Yangtze. Wild and unrestrained in his drinking, the world called him "Madman Yi." His wife, though young, was skilled in music and needlework, mastering all their subtleties. When wealthy young men teased her with words or laughter, her demeanor remained unyielding, as if untouchable. Yongchang loved composing *Wang Jiangnan* lyrics, and the couple would sing them in harmony, heedless of those around them. They often spent nights in abandoned temples or ruined shrines.

Once, he died in Liling, yet in the Tianyou era of Emperor Aidi, he appeared in Nancheng County of Jianchang. One evening, both he and his wife suddenly perished. The garrison commander, surnamed Ding, buried them together by the roadside with a strip of medicinal herbs. A year later, the commander arrived in Zhongling. One day, beneath the market stalls of the northern quarter, he saw Yongchang and his wife singing *Wang Jiangnan*. Yongchang accompanied the commander to a tavern, where they drank heavily. Intoxicated, the couple linked arms and sang loudly as they left the city and crossed the river. Arriving at Youwei Temple, they inscribed the temple wall, signing themselves as the "Divine King of the Crimson Dragon of the Upper Realm." Then they entered the western mountains and were never seen again.

Hu Erlang
Hu Erlang once saw a Daoist lying drunk in the middle of a thoroughfare in Chengdu. Taking pity on him, Erlang would, whenever the Daoist was inebriated, prop his head with a stone. One day, the Daoist awoke to find Erlang beside him. Moved by his kindness, he urged him to cultivate the Dao and sang to admonish him:

*To fathom the principle of cinnabar,*
*Its mysteries lie nowhere to be found.*
*Yet lead and mercury never depart,*
*For gold emerges from water unbound.*

*When gold is refined, water must be near,*
*But water meets earth—its rise is no more.*
*Only with fire’s timing, precise and clear,*
*Can the elixir’s subtle truth restore.*

*In this world, death’s certainty is plain,*
*Yet men cling to crimson and purple vain.*
*How can they know time slips like a fleeting spark,*
*And think life’s glow will never dark?*

*Why not turn your heart to the supreme Way,*
*And cease chasing years that fade away?*
*You drown in wine, lost in drunken delight,*
*Yet the mirror reveals your withering plight.*

*Heed my words, Erlang, take them to heart,*
*For the land of immortals is never apart.*
*All I’ve said is but this—do not delay,*
*Nor cling to luxury, refusing to stray.*

*Your kindness has moved me to speak with care,*
*Turn back now, seek the path to repair.*
*These verses I sing, though brief, bridge past and now,*
*From ancient days to this very brow.*

Erlang said, "May I know your name?"
The Daoist replied, "I am Erzhu."

The Daoist then went to a butcher’s stall, bought pig’s blood to fill intestines, placed them in a vat, and had Erlang eat them. Erlang found the taste sweet and savory, realizing then that the Daoist was no ordinary man. After the Daoist departed, Erlang too transformed. When his family prepared for burial, they marveled at the lightness of his coffin. Opening it, they found only a bamboo staff inside.

Zhang Ao—Zhang Ao, of unknown origin, attained the Dao in the late Tang. After ascending as an immortal, he often visited the chamber of Master Li Chengying of the Jade Bureau’s Huadong Grotto. In the ninth month of the fifth year of Emperor Shenzong’s Xining reign, he also sold medicine in the marketplace, unrecognized by all. When scholar-officials encountered him on the road, they were struck by his composed demeanor, his refusal to bow in greeting, and his majestic bearing—unlike other medicine vendors. The next day, they learned he was the Master, yet he had vanished without a trace.

Chengying, styled Yingzhi, could foretell fortune and misfortune. When Minister Zhao Qingxian was appointed magistrate of Jiangyuan, Chengying once said, "In such-and-such a year, you will enter Shu." Later, it came to pass. When Zhao was later transferred to oversee transport in Zizhong, Chengying again said, "You will be moved to Chengdu." And so it was. Prefect Nie Zhongyou of Hanzhou deeply wished to summon Chengying, but he refused, remarking, "This man’s celestial prison star stirs." In the end, Nie could not secure his presence. None of Chengying’s predictions ever failed to prove true, for he had received teachings from the Master.

Li Mengfu

Li Mengfu, of unknown origin, resided in Nanchang during the early Kaiping era of the Later Liang Taizu. Free-spirited and unrestrained, he often hung a fish from his fishing rod and sang the *Fisherman’s Song*. His lyrics were ever-renewed, and people vied to purchase them, using the money he earned to enter taverns. At times, he would break the ice and plunge into the water; upon emerging, his breath steamed like vapor. When conversing with others, he composed poems extemporaneously.

At the time, Zhong Chuan governed Nanchang, and Li Qiong, the prefect of Guizhou, sent a letter to Zhong, saying: "Mengfu is my younger brother; I would be grateful if you could send him home." Zhong ordered a search for him in the markets and inns, but his whereabouts were already unknown.

Master Yue Zichang

Master Yue, whose given name was Zichang, was a native of Hailing. During the Kaiping era of the Later Liang Taizu, his household brewed fine wine, and he was fond of the Dao. Whenever guests arrived, he would offer them drink. Even if someone disguised themselves in Daoist robes, Master Yue would still pour them wine.

Later, a Daoist arrived and exclaimed in surprise: "You serve each person only three *sheng* of wine—how could that suffice for me?" Master Yue asked: "How much can you drink?" The Daoist replied: "My drinking knows no bounds." Yue then let him drink freely. By evening, the Daoist was so drunk that he fell into a vat and died. Fearing the consequences, Master Yue secretly sealed the vat and buried it along with its stand.

Three days later, a fragrant aroma arose, and the Daoist emerged from the burial site. When they opened the grave, they found the wine vat, its contents now a deep crimson hue, with an extraordinary, intoxicating fragrance. Master Yue rejoiced, saying: "This extraordinary man has made my home a dwelling for immortals!" He and his family drank the wine to the last drop, then all ascended into the clouds and departed. Only his nephew fell to the ground, crying: "Those who eat garlic cannot ascend!" Yet even he lived to be over a hundred years old. Later, a Temple of Heavenly Celebration was built on the site.

Wu Hanxu, the Daoist—styled Heling—possessed an air of refined elegance and never descended the mountain. He passed his days in intoxication, yet kept no cooking utensils, so the common folk called him "Wu the Drunkard." Fond of sleep, he would go for ten-day stretches without eating. He often said: "If one wishes for leisure, one must first be idle; diligence leaves no room for leisure." Though he had never studied literature, he suddenly composed an *Ascension Song*:

*A decree from the Jade Emperor appoints me to immortal office—*
*The dragon spouts clouds, the phoenix lends its strength.*
*Before my eyes, pavilions and terraces appear in an instant,*
*With strange grasses and wondrous flowers beyond recognition.*
*I gaze upon the world from the Great Veil,*
*The world no larger than the palm of my hand.*
*Had I not hastened to ascend,*
*I would have been swept away to Yingzhou in a single moment.*

In the second year of the Later Tang Emperor Li Congke’s Qingtai reign, he ascended.

There was also an eremitic scholar from Ketao, the Iron-Crowned Master Fan, who admired Heling’s Way. He would often ride a white ox to visit him. The Chu king Ma Xifan once took him as his teacher. Later, when Ma Xifan succeeded to the throne, the Master vanished without a trace.

Li Yunqing
Li Yunqing’s origins are unknown.

Li Yunqing was broadly learned in the classics and histories and excelled in poetry, leaving behind *Twenty Scrolls from the Mountain Studio*. Though eminent officials repeatedly summoned him to office, he declined every appointment. He often said: "The loftiest immortals and transcendent beings must strictly observe precepts and conduct, and secretly perform deeds to aid all beings." Thus, he turned his mind to the healing arts to save lives. His spirit was keen and perceptive; whenever he prescribed medicine, he never took life, using only minerals, plants, and trees. He remarked that the formulas transmitted by ancient immortals to later generations sometimes included insects and fish as ingredients, and that those who could not act with such restraint should take heed. He first lived in reclusion on West Mountain, later moving to the northern foothills of Mount Lu. From regions spanning several provinces and a thousand *li*, those seeking his medical aid filled his gate, yet he accepted no gifts of gold or silk. He abstained from desire and forswore meat. His dwelling stood near the Temple of the Nine Heavens’ Messenger, and each dawn and dusk he prayed: "I, so-and-so, use medicine to relieve the suffering of the people, seeking no power or profit. May I never waver in this resolve through all future lives. O luminous and all-knowing spirit, grant me your protection." He lived on the mountain for over sixty years, his complexion golden and radiant, his gaze piercing. Those who knew him all said it was the result of his hidden merits.

One day, while following herb-gatherers deep into the mountains, he suddenly saw a man in a round cap and purple robe. The man bowed and said: "I am the spirit of this mountain. The Perfected King of the Nine Heavens’ Messenger has sent me with a command: in recognition of your merit in aiding beings, I am to bestow upon you the Great Clarity Nine-Flower Divine Elixir and the Jade Script of the Heavenly Emperor of the Grand Tenuity’s *Flying Celestial Net and Earthly Register*. From now on, you must sever all contact with the world of men and devote yourself wholly to cultivation." Li Yunqing bowed again and asked: "May I be permitted to see the Nine Heavens’ Messenger?" The spirit replied: "Though you have abstained from desire and meat, you still engage with the world’s people, and your defiled *qi* has not yet been purified—you may not see him." Then, placing the divine elixir and jade script in his hands, the spirit vanished.

From that time on, Li Yunqing withdrew far from the world. He built a chamber in the emptiness of Shengzhi Peak, and from the reign of Emperor Muzong of the Great Tang to the second year of Tongguang in the Later Tang, on the first day of the eighth month, he ascended to immortality in broad daylight.

Zhang Jianming
Zhang Jianming was a man of Yan.

In his youth, Zhang Jianming traveled through the Hebei region as a scholar of Confucian learning, but later left to become a Daoist. He mastered the teachings of Laozi and Zhuang Zhou. In the ninth month of the fourth year of Tianfu in the reign of Emperor Gaozu of Later Jin (a *jihai* year, on the *xinmao* day), the emperor summoned him for an audience and asked: "Can the Daoist Way govern the state?" He replied: "The Dao is that which is spoken of as wondrously pervading the ten thousand things, and virtue is that which is praised as embracing the Two Modes. One who attains its ultimate may dwell in stillness between mat and couch, yet govern heaven and earth." The emperor marveled at his words and invited him into the inner palace to lecture on the *Daodejing*, appointing him as his teacher.

One day, Jianming suddenly heard the sounding of the time-drum in the palace and said: "Does Your Majesty hear the drum? Its sound is but one, yet among the five notes and twelve pitches, the drum has none. Yet it is the drum that harmonizes them. The One is the root of the ten thousand affairs. One who can preserve the One may govern all under heaven." The emperor approved of this.

On the fifth day of the fifth month of the fifth year, he was granted the title *Master of Penetrating the Mysterious*. Later, his whereabouts became unknown.

Minister Dao Yi remarked: "Zhang Jianming may be called one who delved deeply into the Dao. Observe his answer to the emperor’s question: 'One who attains its ultimate may dwell in stillness between mat and couch, yet govern heaven and earth.' The *Daodejing* states: 'Without stepping outside, one knows all under heaven; without peering through the window, one sees the Dao of heaven. The farther one goes, the less one knows.' Thus the sage knows without traveling, names without seeing—precisely this meaning. Again, he answered: 'One who can preserve the One may govern all under heaven.' All this derives from the *Daodejing*."

He Yuan
He Yuan’s origins are unknown. He served the Later Jin as Vice Director of the Ministry of Works and attained the Dao without dying. When Emperor Zhenzong of Song was en route to perform the Feng sacrifices at Mount Tai, the Vice Director of the Ministry of Works paid his respects by the roadside, bowed deeply, and departed. By evening, when the imperial procession reviewed the list of those who had presented themselves, the emperor was greatly astonished.

The poems left at his farewell read thus:

First:
Sober days grow few, drunken days many,
Chanting the wind, savoring the Dao—lofty and steep.
The deep palace knows not a lone minister’s cares;
Amid the world’s tangled affairs, what can wine do?

Second:
Thrice serving the court, his merits stand alone, towering;
Though aged, his concern for the people’s plight never wanes.
Would that the eight directions share one intoxication!
This heart—how could the world ever know?

An imperial edict ordered officials to seek him out, but he could not be found.

In the early Tian Sheng era of Emperor Renzong’s reign, his disciple Yu Cheng journeyed to the capital to present images of the Buddha and Laozi, valued at hundreds of thousands. There was also a man named Qiao Quan, who in his youth contracted leprosy. Leaving his home, he abandoned himself in the wild mountains. There he met the Vice Director of the Ministry of Works, who taught him to eat pine fat, gradually instructing him in the Dao. At eighty, he ascended and descended mountains as if flying. He often traveled with the Vice Director, once crossing a river in Wei by walking upon its waters.

In the early Yuan You era of Emperor Zhezong’s reign, Quan came to the eastern capital and met Su Shi, styled Zizhan. He said: “My master once traveled in Mizhou and met you on the road to Changshan. He seemed pleased with you.” Zizhan detained him, but he would not stay. He said: “My master has appointed to meet me at Mount Meng on the Lantern Festival.” Zizhan composed a poem to send Quan off, and also wrote five quatrains to send to the Vice Director.

From then on, none in the world ever saw the Vice Director again.

Guo Shuxian
Guo Shuxian was a native of Luoyang and lived during the Five Dynasties. From youth he was skilled in composition, excelled in calligraphy and philology, and mastered the Nine Classics. At seven, he passed the child prodigy examination.

Later, during the Later Han, the Duke of Xiangyin summoned him as an aide. Previously, he had quarreled with his clerk Dong Yi over an affair and left in indignation. The founding ancestor of the Later Zhou later appointed him as a *Zhouyi* Academician. At the beginning of the Song dynasty, he clashed with Supervising Censor Fu Zhaowen in anger at the court hall and was demoted to serve as Registrar of Qianzhou. When his term expired, he resigned and never again took office. Roaming freely between Qi, Yong, Shaan, and Luo, he would address anyone he met—whether noble or base—simply as "Miao." If he came upon mountains and rivers, he would linger for ten days without leaving. At times, he would fast for nearly a hundred days without eating. In the height of summer, he would expose his body to the sun, yet his clothes remained dry of sweat. In the depths of winter, he would break the ice to bathe, and only when the ice began to melt would he emerge. Emperor Taizong, having long heard of his name, summoned him back to the capital and lodged him in the quarters of Palace Attendant Dou Shenxing. Shuxian had a long, fine beard, but one day he shaved it all off. Shenxing, startled, asked the reason, to which Shuxian replied: "Merely to imitate the frown." Shenxing flew into a rage. Taizong, deeming him lacking in restraint, appointed him as a minor official at the Directorate of Education and moved him out to the National University.

He indulged further in wine and spoke freely of current affairs, leading to his demotion to Dengzhou. Upon reaching Qizhou and arriving at Linyi, he said to the escorting officer: "I am departing." Thereupon, he halted by the roadside and dug a pit just large enough to fit his face. Peering into it, he died, and his body was interred by the wayside. Months later, his old acquaintances exhumed and reburied him, finding only his clothes and cap remaining—his body had vanished. This was a case of *shijie* (corpse liberation).

**Chen Tao**
Chen Tao, a native of Shupu, was fond of learning from a young age and skilled in astronomy, as well as in composing odes and hymns. Foreseeing that the Southern Tang ruler Li’s reign was in decline, he abandoned all aspirations for officialdom. Instead, he built a hermitage on West Mountain, finding joy in chanting poetry and devoting himself to self-cultivation. His *Miscellaneous Poems of Leisurely Living* survive to this day. During the *Kaibao* era of the Song Taizu, a man once saw an old man with a topknot and clad in coarse cloth, accompanied by an alchemist, entering the city to refine medicines. With the money they earned, they would purchase fresh food, gather by the furnace, and eat and drink together as if no one else were present. When drunk, they would sing, and people took them for Tao and his wife—or claimed he had already attained immortality. Today, the Xiangcheng Temple on West Mountain still houses his reading hall.

**Sun Cheng**
Sun Cheng’s origins are unknown. He was skilled in poetry and could foresee fortune and misfortune. Upon visiting Mount Lu, he inscribed a poem on the Temple of the Nine Celestial Messengers:
*Alone I enter the dark palace to pay homage to the Perfected,
Burning incense not for my lowly, impoverished self.
On both banks of the Qinhuai, bones pile like sand,
At Ganpu, a thousand households’ blood stains the dust.
Who is master of Mount Lu’s clouds and mist?
To whom do Tiger Creek’s wind and moon belong?
The Prefect of Jiujiang, loyal to his king’s cause,
Would do well to dispatch celestial troops across the strategic ford.*

Within a few years, Jinling fell into chaos, and Jiujiang was heavily besieged. The people suffered terribly, and the events unfolded exactly as his poetic prophecy had foretold. Later, he died in Nanchang. When his body was cast into the river, it floated upstream against the current. All who witnessed this marveled, believing he had attained the Dao and departed as a *shijie* immortal.

**Xu Jian**
Xu Jian, styled Jieshi, was a native of Lujiang.

Some accounts claim Xu Jian was a descendant of Yin Mu, the former Chief Clerk of Jin Japan. Though his appearance was uncouth and strange, standing seven feet tall, he habitually wore a hempen turban and straw sandals, his short robe barely reaching his knees. Possessing no worldly goods, he carried only a cloth sack upon his back. By nature, he loved wine and excelled at composition, particularly delighting in chanting poetry. Once, he presented a memorial to the Southern Tang ruler, and later submitted poems to the Academician Xu Xuan, only to leave in disdain. He lived without regard for seasons, always holding a large fan, styling himself the "Wild Man of Jiangnan." Upon the fan, he inscribed a quatrain:

*Chanting but to express the wonders within my breast,*
*Drinking, I forget both fame and name’s bequest.*
*My heart’s sole wish: eternal leisure with verse and wine,*
*A stream’s wind and moon to share in purity divine.*

He also inscribed a poem at the Abbey of Simplicity and Tranquility:

*Ever grieved the true Dao’s thousand-year concealment,*
*Yet this grotto-heaven grants free roaming content.*
*Ancient pines cast their hues o’er the silent altar’s peace,*
*Phoenix and crane depart, the Milky Way’s heights increase.*
*The Maos’ well runs cold, alchemical elixirs long spent,*
*The Xuanzong stele lies broken, dreams of immortality rent.*
*Clearly, a path to longevity exists—*
*Why sigh o’er graying temples midst the red dust’s bliss?*

During the Qiande era of the Song Taizu, his collected works circulated widely. By nature, he was quiet and reserved, indifferent to fame. His dwelling was never fixed; he often stayed at the Abbey of Simplicity and Tranquility or White Deer Grotto, leaving no trace of his comings and goings. Whenever he felt the need to bathe, he would enter a mountain stream or ravine fully clothed, emerging to dry his garments upon the rocks. To this day, the "Xu Jian Drying Stone" remains in the great ravine of the Abbey of Simplicity. He owned a tripod cauldron with a three-*sheng* capacity; whenever he caught fish, he would cook or roast them whole, scales and entrails intact, without washing or seasoning. Once done, he would eat them at once.

He shared a close friendship with Fan Ruoshui. When Fan crossed northward and, during the Taiping Xingguo era of the Great Song, oversaw transport in Jiangnan, he encountered Xu Jian at the Abbey of Simplicity. Urging him to accept an official salary, Xu Jian frowned and remained silent. Fan then cut three hundred strings of cash from his stipend as wine money and presented the voucher to him. Xu Jian accepted without thanks. For half a year, he never spoke a word. When others pleaded on Fan’s behalf, he would buy wine and fish, drinking merrily until dancing in drunkenness. If someone borrowed the voucher to visit the government office, he would comply. When Fan was about to retire and sought the return of the old voucher, it had vanished without a trace. Such was his carefree and self-assured manner.

Later, he traveled to Mount Mao or Mount Jiuhua, following his whims, leaving others unable to fathom his intentions. He was never seen cooking a meal. Once, in Yangxian, he crossed the Western Ford one day, suddenly striding across the waves as if walking on land. The onlookers were astonished, deeming him a divine being. In the final years of the Jingde era of Emperor Zhenzong, he died in Jinling. Over a year later, the Vice Minister of War, Chen Jing, moored his boat on the Qinhuai River and remarked that two days prior, he had seen Xu Jian visit him at Hongjing Well, his calling card still in hand. Yet when he searched the seat, nothing remained. People believed he had attained *shijie* and departed as an immortal.

Shen Lin

Shen Lin, styled Tingrui, was a native of Junyang and the second son of Shen Bin, a Minister of Personnel in the Tang dynasty. From childhood, his conduct was extraordinary, and he was deeply fond of the principles of stillness and non-being. His filial piety was profound; when his father died, he built a hut by the grave and remained there for three years, during which turtledoves gathered at the tomb. Later, he abandoned his wife to study the Dao on Mount Magu—or, as some say, Mount Yusun. He always wore a single hempen robe, undeterred by wind or snow. When people gave him new clothes, he often passed them on to the poor or discarded them. Fond of wine and skilled in poetry, his contemporaries called him "Shen the Daoist."

He would stride directly into prefectural or county offices, taking a seat unannounced. One day, as the magistrate was hearing a case, Lin arrived drunk. The magistrate teased him, asking, *"Shen the Daoist, when will your Dao be perfected?"* Lin immediately wrote on the magistrate’s desk:

*Why ask when my Dao will be complete?*
*The Purple Court and Clear Capital await their time.*
*No one knows the herbs I dig by hand,*
*Nor sees the immortal bones within this mortal frame.*
*With talismans I send dragons and serpents fleeing,*
*With seals I shift seas and mountains at will.*
*One day, who shall lead the way to the cinnabar clouds?*
*The Azure Lad shall guide the chariot, purple mists trailing behind.*

He could walk hundreds of *li* in a day, traveling between Mount Yusun and Floating Cloud Mountain, resting in forests or sleeping under the open sky. During the *Baoda* era of the Southern Tang, he arrived at the Refined Contemplation Abbey on Mount Yusun, where he donned the cap and robe of a Daoist adept, entered seclusion to cultivate *qi*, and was rarely seen. On the fifteenth day of the first month in the second year of the *Yongxi* era of Emperor Taizong of Song, at midday, he adjusted his cap and robe, closed the door, burned incense, and sat in meditation. Clenching his fists, he departed this world.

His fellow Daoists buried his remains west of the Massed Jade Peaks, east of Iron Pillar Ridge. Twenty days later, a Daoist from the same mountain, Zeng Zhaoying, came to visit Mount Yusun. On the road, he encountered Lin, who, when asked where he was going, replied, *"I am making a brief visit to the Mysterious Capital, then shall soon enter Mount Lu."* He left two volumes of the *Scripture of Salvation* and a poem for Zhaoying:

*North, south, east, west—matters of the world,*
*Do people ever meet again?*
*Once I dwelt on Jade Bamboo Peak,*
*Now I return to the Mysterious Capital.*
*Clouds drift boundless across the sky,*
*The sound of springs falls on lone stones.*
*In the cinnabar clouds, I have an appointment—*
*I go to gather calamus and sweet flag.*

Zhaoying, struck by his extraordinary words, hurried to the abbey to inquire. His disciples said, *"He has ascended as a feathered immortal."* Zhaoying showed them the scripture and poem, and all recognized his handwriting, astonished. Zhaoying and his brother went to the burial site and found a slip of paper by the grave, bearing a poem:

*In vain we toil at burial before Jade Mountain,*
*Who knows the cicada has already shed its husk?*
*It must be that the primordial spirit has returned to the Purple Court,*
*No lingering soul remains in the Yellow Springs.*
*The medicine bag holds only the alchemical formula,*
*The world retains but the writings of enlightenment.*
*How lamentable are the affairs of this fleeting life, past and present—*
*Beneath Northern Yu Mountain, the grass grows lush.*

When they examined the grave, they found an opening about a *chi* wide, opening to the left, containing only an empty coffin. Some said he had attained *shijie*. Many in the south knew of him.

He once sent a poem to his old friend Chen Zhizhou:

*Since we parted, parting makes reunion rare.*
*The golden crucible melts the red sun,*
*The cinnabar field nurtures purple mushrooms.*
*To visit you is hard to arrange,*
*Yet how could I not hold you in my thoughts?*
*Do not envy the bustle of worldly affairs—*
*How long can a hundred years last?*

Zhizhou later passed the imperial examinations during the *Duangong* era and was appointed as a magistrate in Hengyang, where he remained until his death.

The *Annals of the Southern Tang* records: Shen Bin’s second son, Tingrui, possessed Daoist arts. Fond of wine and abstaining from grain, he wore a single hempen robe through cold and heat for decades without change. He could walk hundreds of *li* in a day, resting in forests or sleeping under the stars, often on Mount Yusun or Floating Cloud Mountain. Though he aged, he did not decline, and his end remains unknown.

**Huang Wanhui**

The Daoist Huang Wanhui of Mount Wu often healed people with talismans and medicines. When the Lord of Shu, Wang Jian, summoned him, he spread grass upon the water’s surface and drifted upstream, arriving in Chengdu in a single day.

---

**Volume 46 of *Comprehensive Mirror of Perfected Immortals Who Embodied the Dao* concludes here.**
**Volume 47 of *Comprehensive Mirror of Perfected Immortals Who Embodied the Dao***

**Chen Tuan**

The Master’s surname was Chen, his given name Tuan, his courtesy name Tunan, and his sobriquet Fuyaozi. A native of Zhenyuan in Bozhou, he hailed from the same village as Laozi—though some say he was from Chongrong in Puzhou, likely a later place of retreat. From birth, he could not speak.

When he was four or five, he played by the banks of the Wo River. A woman in blue robes took him into her arms and nursed him, and from that moment, he could speak, his intelligence surpassing others. As he grew, he mastered the classics and histories at a glance—some say he abandoned childish games from the time he first tied up his hair. By fifteen, he had thoroughly studied the *Book of Songs*, the *Book of Rites*, calligraphy, mathematics, and even medical texts on prescriptions.

After his parents’ deaths, the Master said: *"What I have learned thus far suffices only to record names. I shall abandon this path, ascend the peak of Mount Tai, and beneath the towering pines, discuss the Dharma of transcendence with Anqi and Huangshi. Together, we shall compound the elixir of immortality. How could I bear to wallow in worldly flattery, trapped in the cycle of birth and death?"* He then distributed all his family’s wealth to others, keeping only an iron cauldron before departing.

The scholar-officials of the Tang, drawn to his pure spirit, longed to meet him. To them, his presence was like the rare appearance of a comet or iridescent clouds, and they vied to catch a glimpse. Yet the Master refused all their overtures. Thus, he severed ties with worldly affairs, donning a rustic cap and hempen robes. He sang as he walked, sat in joy, and wandered through markets as if entering an empty realm. Sometimes he ascended wine towers, other times he lodged in roadside inns, often roaming between the capital and the provinces.

Later, Emperor Mingzong of Later Tang heard of his reputation and personally penned an edict summoning him. When the Master arrived, he greeted the emperor with a deep bow. Mingzong treated him with even greater reverence, bestowing upon him the title *Qingxu Hermit* and gifting him three palace ladies. The Master submitted a memorial in gratitude, writing:

*"The renowned courtesans of Zhao, the virtuous ladies of the Han court—graceful in bearing, born of good families. Once they entered the deep palace, they enjoyed long years of wealth and honor. Once celestial beings, now fallen among mortals. Your servant dares not keep them in his private residence and has respectfully housed them in a separate lodge. My nature is like that of the deer or the elk—rootless as duckweed, drifting like a cloud before the wind, adrift as a boat without moorings. I return them to the imperial precincts."*

He also composed a poem for the emperor’s perusal:

*"Snow for flesh and jade for bones—
I thank Your Majesty for this gift.
Yet this hermit harbors no dreams of Wu Gorge;
why trouble the clouds and rain to descend from Yang Terrace?"*

Having submitted the memorial and poem via the palace eunuch, he departed at once. Thereafter, he wandered freely among mountains and rivers. He once claimed to have met Sun Junfang and the Recluse in Deerskin, who told him that the Nine-Chambered Cliff of Mount Wudang was an ideal place for seclusion. He went there to dwell, practicing breath cultivation and grain avoidance, living in tranquil silence for over twenty years. He composed the *Eighty-One Chapters on the Mysteries of the Finger and the Elixir*, the *Fifty Poems on Entering the Chamber and Returning with the Cinnabar*, and the *Fishing Pond Collection* of over ten thousand characters—all meticulously expounding the wonders of the Dao and encompassing the ultimate truth.

One night, as he stood in his courtyard, a golden figure holding a sword appeared and called out: *"Your Dao is complete. You shall have a place of return and fulfillment."* The Master replied: *"The golden figure speaks of a place of return—autumn is the season when the myriad things gather and return. Shall I then withdraw to the West?"* By this time, he was already over seventy.
