Soon after, he moved to Mount Hua, where he found the ruins of the ancient Cloud Terrace Abbey. Clearing the overgrowth, he made it his home, fulfilling the prophecy of his "place of return." At the time, tigers in the region were preying on people. When the Master arrived, he rebuked the tigers and ordered them to leave, and from then on, they ceased their attacks.

During the Kaiyuan era of the Tang, a man named Li Qi lived as a recluse in Huayang. Though his complexion retained the bloom of youth, he could traverse hundreds of *li* in an instant. He befriended the Master, and they exchanged poems. The Master often shut his door and lay abed for months without rising. During the Xiande era of Emperor Shizong of Zhou, a visitor peered through his window and saw only dust-covered boards, hearing only the cries of beasts and crows.

A woodcutter on the mountain’s slope came upon a body covered in hardened dust. Drawing near, he realized it was the Master. He pressed a hand to the Master’s chest and found it still warm. After a long while, the Master’s breath returned. Rising, he said: *"I was in the midst of a deep sleep—why disturb me?"*

The prefect of the region, Luo Yanwei, reported this to the emperor. Shizong summoned the Master to the palace. After more than a month, he finally rose. The emperor questioned him about the arts of alchemy.

The Master replied: *"Your Majesty rules the Four Seas and ought to devote yourself to governance—why fixate on such trifling arts?"* (The *Comprehensive Mirror in Aid of Governance* records: *"Your Majesty is the Son of Heaven, with the duty of ordering the realm—what need is there for this?"*) Shizong did not take offense. He appointed the Master as Remonstrance Grandee, but the Master firmly declined. The emperor bestowed upon him the title "Master of White Clouds" and sent him back to the mountains, decreeing that local officials regularly inquire after him.

Though the Master possessed the talent to order the world, he lived through the chaos of the Five Dynasties. Each time he heard of a dynastic revolution, he would knit his brows and sigh. He once wrote a poem:

*Ten years my tracks have trod the red dust,*
*Yet turning, green hills haunt my dreams.*
*Though purple streets bloom bright with glory,*
*What sleep compares? Though gates be gilded, poverty is richer.*
*I grieve to hear the sword and spear propping up a tottering lord,*
*And chafe to listen to pipes and songs that deafen the drunk.*
*I’ll take my old books back to my old retreat—*
*Where wildflowers bloom and birds cry, spring is the same as ever.*

One day, riding a donkey through Huayin, he heard that Emperor Taizu of Song had ascended the throne. He laughed aloud: *"Now the realm is settled at last!"* Thereupon he withdrew to Mount Hua and did not emerge again. When Taizu summoned him, he did not go. Only at the beginning of the Xingguo era did he finally answer the call.

Emperor Taizong sent him a poem:

*Once you emerged from white clouds in a former age,*
*Then vanished, your traces lost to all.*
*If now you’ll heed the court’s decree,*
*I’ll grant you all Three Peaks as your own.*

As the Master neared the capital, he petitioned for a quiet chamber to rest. The emperor granted him lodging at the Jianlong Abbey. There he shut his door and slept soundly for over a month before rising. By imperial edict, he was received in the Yanying Hall dressed in a Huayang cap, straw sandals, and a trailing sash, accorded the rites due a guest. The emperor seated him and conversed with him at length.

At the time, the emperor was preparing to campaign against Hedong. The Master urged him to desist, but the army had already been mobilized. Displeased by his counsel, the emperor ordered him to sleep in the imperial park. When the troops returned in defeat, after more than a hundred days, the Master begged to return to the mountains.

In the fourth year of the Taiping Xingguo era, he came again, now declaring that Hedong could be taken. When the imperial army launched its second campaign, it indeed captured Liu Jiyuan and annexed Bingzhou. The emperor remarked to his chief minister Song Qi and others: *"Bo has been a recluse on Mount Hua for over forty years. Judging by his age, he must be well over a hundred, yet his discourse is lofty."*

The emperor sent an emissary to escort him, and the chief ministers Qi and others asked in leisurely tones: *"Master, having attained the Way of profound silence, can you teach it to others?"* The Master replied: *"I know nothing of the principles of breathing and nourishing life, nor of the arts of immortality and alchemy. I have no esoteric techniques to transmit. Even if one were to ascend to heaven in broad daylight, what benefit would it bring to the world’s teachings? Our sagely emperor is learned in past and present, deeply versed in the causes of order and chaos. He is truly a sovereign of the Dao, benevolent and enlightened—this is an age when ruler and ministers, sharing virtue, bring governance to fruition. Diligence in cultivation cannot surpass this."*

Qi and the others praised his words and reported them to the emperor, who esteemed him all the more. He issued a decree:

*"The recluse Chen Chuan of Mount Hua has dwelt in seclusion among hills and caves, his heart set beyond the world, savoring the rich flavor of the Dao. In the former Zhou dynasty, he was sought out in his hidden retreat and once answered the summons of the imperial tablet, yet his heart ever followed the wild geese into the distant sky. Since then, many years have passed."*

This time, he once again spoke of lofty and remote matters, yet came to grace the imperial court with his presence. Without a fitting title, how could his pure example be made manifest? Thus, he was granted the honorific *Master of Rare Serenity*.

The emperor repeatedly exchanged poems with him. The emperor asked: *"Can the governance of the realm today compare to that of Yao and Shun in ancient times?"*
The Master replied: *"Their earthen steps stood but three feet high, their thatched roofs untrimmed—such simplicity seems beyond reach. Yet if one governs with pure stillness, then even now may be an age of Yao and Shun."*
The emperor approved of his answer. He then sent his sons to meet the Master, who secretly revealed to them that the Mandate of Heaven truly rested with the Sagely Emperor.

The emperor wished to appoint him *Grand Master for Admonition*, but the Master firmly declined and begged to return to his mountain. He presented a poem:

*"From the wild marshes, our August Emperor’s decree—
A soaring rooster of the Chen clan, I chart my southern flight.
For ten years, a guest among the Three Peaks,
A single man of leisure beneath the Four Seas.
Worldly ways have ever been shallow,
Yet in poetry, my spirit finds its truth.
I beg to keep my nature, wild as deer,
For where is there I would not serve as subject?"*

Knowing he could not be detained, the emperor hosted a farewell banquet in the side hall and ordered the two chief ministers to attend, composing poems to honor his departure. He also bestowed upon him tortoise-and-crane emblems, saddled horses, and bolts of silk, and instructed Governor Wang Zuo of Huayang to visit him regularly to inquire after his needs.

Those who sought his counsel, treating him as a teacher with reverence, were too numerous to count. Later, the emperor again dispatched an imperial messenger to the mountain to summon the Master. The Master said: *"I am deeply grateful for Your Majesty’s grace, but I humbly request to remain on Mount Hua."*
His resolve was unshakable. The messenger returned and reported his words, whereupon the emperor sent another envoy bearing a handwritten edict, tea, and medicinal herbs, instructing the local prefect and magistrate to present him with gifts and repeatedly invite him with an honor guard of soft-littered carriages.

The Master then submitted a memorial in gratitude:

*"Your earnest and gracious decree fills a single sheet with meticulous script;
Your boundless imperial favor bestows medicines worth ten thousand in gold.
I lift my gaze in awe of Your Majesty’s benevolence,
And bow in deepening gratitude.
I am but a man of leisure in this flourishing age,
A scholar of the Tang court.
When the Way of Yao prospered, Xu You was indulged in his reclusion;
When the Han dynasty thrived, the Four Greybeards were cherished—
Virtuous recluses have never been absent in any era.
Yet I, with a body like withered wood and a heart like dead ashes,
Understand neither the depths of benevolence nor the subtleties of propriety.
I wear robes of tattered lotus leaves, a cap of cast-off clogs,
My limbs sprouting blue-green fur, my feet bare of straw sandals.
Were I to stand before Your Majesty’s throne,
I would only bring ridicule upon your sagely wisdom.
I pray Your Majesty turn your celestial ear elsewhere,
That I may remain hidden in these mountains.
In this age that honors the worthy, you surpass even the ancients.
Yet these crimson edicts, borne by phoenixes,
Disturb this idle heart, now detained by white clouds.
I drink from the old stream’s waters,
Feast on the wind beneath the pines,
Savor the purity of sun and moon,
And laugh carefree beyond the clouds.
Following my nature’s joy, what more need I say?
My spirit soars beyond the world,
My flesh and bones float amidst the mist.
Though I have delved into the root and sprout of the supreme Dao,
And fully steeped myself in the soil and waters of the sagely realm,
I dare not hope for Your Majesty’s continued favor,
But only beg you to heed this foolish wish."*

The Master’s knowledge of classics and history was vast, and he was especially profound in the study of the *Yi*. He could discern character and judge affairs, distinguishing the sagely from the common. When the future Emperor Taizu and Emperor Taizong of the Song were still in obscurity, they once accompanied Minister Zhao Zhongxian through the markets of Chang’an. The Master entered a wineshop with them. The minister took the seat of honor, but the Master said: *"You are but a minor star in the Purple Forbidden Enclosure—how dare you occupy the highest place?"*

When Emperor Shizong of Zhou and the future Emperor Taizu walked together, the Master remarked: *"Beyond the city walls, there are omens of three emperors."*

When Chong Fang first became his disciple, the Master said: *"If you encounter an enlightened ruler, your name will resound in the celestial court. Yet a name is a vessel of beauty across the ages, and the Creator is ever jealous of it—yours will one day be marred by some calamity."* His words proved true.

When Lord Zhang Yong of Zhongding was still a commoner, the Master met him and marveled at his extraordinary qualities.

Lord Zhang said: *"Would you grant me half of Mount Hua to dwell upon?"*
The Master replied: *"For you, it would be fitting. But as we parted, he presented him with a brush and paper."*
Lord Zhang understood his meaning and said: *"This is to entangle me in worldly affairs."*
The Master’s parting poem read:
*"My journey to Shu was but a common thing,
Yet like quenching flames with song and dance, I rushed in vain.
If granted the fair lands of the southeast,
I should still thank the gray at my temples."*

Later, Lord Zhang indeed passed the imperial examinations, his name resounding across the realm. As he prepared to depart for Jiannan, he sent a poem to the Master:
*"Foolish, I would not dwell in forests and springs,
But must purify the currents to serve my lord.
Today I hasten southward like a shooting star—
Turning back, I shame the clouds of Mount Hua."*

Upon his return, he wrote another:
*"Men hold office and glory in high esteem;
Seeing me return in haste, they lined the roads to greet me.
Yet the hermit of Mount Hua must laugh—
My innocence lost for an empty name."*

In his later years, Lord Zhang developed a carbuncle on his head. As he was appointed governor of Shengzhou, every poem the Master had gifted him proved prophetic.

Minister Chen Yaozhi of Kangsu, having passed the imperial examinations, paid a visit to the Master. Among those present was a Daoist with a topknot, his manner haughty. Fixing his gaze on Minister Chen, he repeated: *"Nan’an."*
Then he departed without another word.
Minister Chen was deeply perplexed and asked: *"Who was that?"*
The Master replied: *"Zhongli Zi."*
Minister Chen, still bewildered, wished to pursue him, but the Master smiled and said: *"He is already thousands of *li* away."*
Minister Chen asked: *"What did ‘Nan’an’ mean?"*
The Master replied: *"You will understand in time."*

Later, when Minister Chen was overseeing grain transport in Min, he passed through a village during his inspection. There, he heard a peasant woman call to her son: *"Go to Nan’an and hurry your father home."*
Minister Chen was astonished and asked where Nan’an was. Upon investigation, he found it was a ruined monastery. A stele read: *"On such-and-such a year and month, the master of Nan’an entered nirvana; his true body is enshrined here."* The date coincided with Minister Chen’s own birth.

Wang Shize of Qingyuan, along with Han Jiansu and Remonstrance Official Zhao, visited the Master together. Shize, acting as a servant, bowed at the foot of the steps.
The Master said: *"He who humiliates others humiliates himself."*
He then invited Shize to sit at the right hand of the other gentlemen, saying: *"In the future, you alone will surpass them all—just as in this gathering."*
The following year, Shize indeed ranked first, while the others trailed behind.

The Master could also foresee men’s thoughts. In his study hung a large gourd on the wall. The Daoist Jia Xiufu coveted it but said nothing.
The Master said to Xiufu: *"You came for no other reason than to seek my gourd."*
He called a servant to fetch it and gave it to him.

There was a man named Guo Hang who, in his youth, lived at the foot of Mount Hua. One night, he lodged at the abbey. At midnight, the Master called to him, urging him to return home at once. Guo hesitated, daunted by the distance, so the Master accompanied him. After one or two *li*, they encountered a man wailing to report Guo’s mother’s death. Only then did Guo grasp the Master’s warning. The Master gave him medicine, instructing him to hasten home—it might still save her. Upon arrival, he found her already dead, but after administering the medicine, she revived.

When Remonstrance Official Xu Zhongxuan was dismissed from office, the governor of Chengdu sent a letter and gifts to inquire about his fortune. The Master summoned his disciple Jia Desheng and said: *"Write my reply: ‘After this departure, the Gentleman will not emerge again.’"*
Soon after, Xu indeed passed away.

Later, the Master seldom received visitors, though he would occasionally wander to Huayin. When Magistrate Wang Mu of Huayin heard of his arrival, he rushed to the gate in disarray to welcome him. After they sat, the Master said: *"I have not drunk for a long time and now crave a little wine."*
Magistrate Wang replied: *"I have fine wine, as if I knew you were coming. I ordered the vessels washed and the feast prepared."*
After drinking, Magistrate Wang asked: *"Master, when you dwell among the cliffs and streams, where do you rest, and who guards your abode when you are away?"*
The Master smiled faintly and took up his brush to write a poem:
*"My palace is the heights of Mount Hua,
Where I stride the dawn winds, soaring through the void.
No golden locks secure my terraces—
When I return, the white clouds seal them anew."*

Magistrate Wang received the poem and, ashamed, expressed his gratitude.
The Master said: *"In another year, you will face great disaster. I came this time with the intent to save you. If you govern as you have, though misfortune may strike, the divine principle will protect you."*
Magistrate Wang had indeed been upright, honest, and cautious in office, treating the people as his children and sparing them the rod. His nature was also keen and perceptive.
The Master then produced a pill and said: *"This may shield you from next year’s calamity."*
Magistrate Wang rose, bowed twice, and accepted the medicine, swallowing it. They drank until midnight, when the Master excused himself to the privy. After a long while, he did not return, and when they searched, he had vanished.

Later, when Magistrate Wang was transferred back to the capital, his horse suddenly bolted, throwing him into the Bian River. Skilled swimmers rescued him, and he narrowly escaped death.

The Master would sometimes visit the homes of commoners at the foot of the mountain. Even now, there are those who claim to have seen him. Today, the Abbey of the Master still stands in Xihua.

Once, the Master often associated with Cui Gu of the mountain’s foothills. A scholar named Jin Li, who often roamed the mountains and rivers, visited Cui Gu and said: *"I wish to meet Master Xiyi through you."*
Cui Gu replied: *"Wait a while. The Master is sleeping now; you may see him when he awakens."*
Jin Li asked: *"When will that be?"*

Cui Gu said: *"Sometimes half a year, sometimes three or four months—lately, not even a full month passes. You have somewhere to go, so depart for now. Come again another day."*
Jin Li thus left. Over a year later, he roamed Hua Mountain once more and met Cui Gu, who happened to be with the Master, who had just arrived. Jin Li prostrated himself in reverence and then addressed the Master: *"When I last traveled to Hua Mountain, I wished to meet you, but you were asleep and had not yet awakened. Does sleep, too, follow the Dao? I beg you to instruct me and reveal what I have yet to comprehend."*

The Master let out a sound, shrugged his shoulders, drew in his feet, raised his face, and said with a sigh: *"I did not expect you to be so frail and petty. If you cannot even recognize the nature of rising, resting, sleeping, and dwelling, how can you hope to escape the cycle of birth and death, to leap free from the wheel of rebirth? Now, you eat your fill in ease, fretting only that your clothing and food are not abundant enough. When hungry, you eat; when weary, you sleep. Your snores resound far and wide, and you wake several times a night—fame, profit, sensual pleasures, and sounds muddle your spirit, while rich wines and fatty meats dull your heart and will. This is the sleep of the vulgar world.*

*But the sleep of the perfected one is different: he seals his golden breath and drinks the jade elixir. The Gate of Metal stands firm and cannot be opened; the Earthen Door is shut and cannot be unlatched. The Azure Dragon guards the Green Palace; the White Tiger crouches in the Western Chamber. True qi circulates within the Cinnabar Pool; divine water flows through the five viscera. He summons Jia and Ding to mark the hours and calls upon the hundred spirits to guard his chamber. Only then does his spirit emerge from the Nine Palaces, roaming freely through the azure and emerald realms, treading the void as if it were solid ground, ascending as if descending. Gently, he soars with auspicious winds; lightly, he drifts among idle clouds, appearing and vanishing. He sits in the Purple Court of Kunlun, traverses blessed lands and grotto-heavens, savors the essence of sun and moon, and delights in the sublime vistas of mist and rosy clouds. He visits immortals to discuss the principles beyond the mundane and makes distant journeys with transcendent beings. He watches the seas shrink to dust and points at yin and yang, letting out a long whistle. When he wishes to return, his feet tread upon the pure wind, and his body floats upon the fading light.*

*Thus, in his sleep, he is unaware of the passage of years and months, nor does he fear the shifting of mountains and valleys. Since you have asked, I shall compose a poem for you:*

*Ordinary men hold nothing dear,*
*Yet sleep they prize above all.*
*The world deems it mere repose,*
*But soul departs while form lies still.*
*Awake, they know not what transpired—*
*Greed stirs the heart anew.*
*How laughable, those in the dust,*
*Who know not life itself is dream.*

*Another poem says:*
*The perfected one dreams no dreams,*
*Yet his dreams are journeys divine.*
*The true man sleeps not at all,*
*Or sleeps amid floating clouds.*
*Within the crucible, elixir endures;*
*Within the gourd, another heaven.*
*To know the sleep within the dream—*
*This is the foremost mystery of men.*

*Great dreams bring great awakening; small dreams, small awakening. My sleep is true sleep; my dream, true dream—not the dreams of the world."*

The Master said: *"I shall not sleep for long. Do not go anywhere. Visit me another day, and I will let you witness true sleep."*
The Master then departed, leaving Jin Li stunned, as if awakening from drunkenness. He left without realizing it and returned home.

Another day, he visited the Master again. The Master discoursed on the secrets of nurturing life, expounding the subtlest gates and illuminating the mysteries of the Great Profundity. He said: *"On such-and-such a day, I shall sleep. Come then."*
Jin Li arrived as appointed, only to find the Master already asleep. He saw the Master lying on his back, breath flowing without pause, his complexion radiant and rosy. Jin Li bowed at the bedside and departed.

On yet another day, a visitor came to see the Master, who happened to be sleeping. Beside him stood an immortal, carefully listening to his breathing. With an ink brush, the immortal traced marks on paper—several times over, until the page was covered in indiscernible black strokes. The visitor, puzzled, asked about it. The immortal replied: *"That is the Master’s ‘Primal Chaos Score,’ composed in the tune of Huaxu."*

In his leisure, the Master enjoyed roaming. When moved by inspiration, he would chant verses, and upon encountering a scene, he would compose lines.

Once, he inscribed a poem on West Peak that read:
*"For love of West Peak’s beauty, my chanting head stays raised all day.
Rock flowers bloom in crimson ranks, while stream waters flow in jade array.
For nights on end, they bar the crescent moon; half the vale knows no sunset’s ray.
I bid the reclusive wanderer take heed—this place is the land of immortals indeed."*

Another couplet of his:
*"At midnight, celestial fragrance drifts into the ravine;
The west wind scatters lotuses from the ridge’s height.
Vainly do I cherish the palm’s imprint nearing the azure sky—
None remain to sigh for the mighty spirit’s might."*

At times, the Master would encounter the Hairy Maiden and present her with poems, such as:
*"The herb sprouts fail to fill the bamboo basket’s space,
Yet still you climb the perilous peak’s sheer face.
Pointing back toward the path of return,
Together we enter the emerald haze’s turn."*

And another:
*"Once you broke pine boughs to fashion a jeweled comb,
Then wove the indolent leaves into a gauze gown’s hem.
At times, when asked of Qin palace affairs,
You laugh, plucking immortal blooms to gaze at the vast expanse’s stem."*

The reclusive Lu Dongbin of Guanzhong possessed Daoist arts, traversing hundreds of miles in an instant—so the world deemed him a divine immortal. He often visited the Master’s study, exchanging verses as friends do.

Once, during a spring month, the Master strolled along the stony banks of Hua Mountain’s waters when he saw Master Gourd, Red Pine, and Lu Dongbin arrive in succession. The four immortals had barely begun their discourse when an earth spirit presented a tray of fruit and a vessel of wine. After drinking to half-intoxication, each composed a poem.

The Master said:
*"Spring’s warmth has half-opened the clustered blooms;
I wander idly upon the stone’s smooth looms.
Once I reined jade bridles at the golden gates,
Now I tread green sands and mossy mats.
How many years have passed in cave-bound sleep?
Alone, I drink a thousand cups of rosy sweep.
Meet others—speak not of mortal affairs,
But laugh and point to the drifting clouds’ layers."*

Master Gourd said:
*"Within my gourd, pavilions rise,
Where flowers bloom through all four skies.
At leisure, I sip nectar fine;
When drunk, I rest on mossy vine.
Carefree, I chase no fame or gain,
Unsullied by the world’s dark stain.
Meet others—speak not of mortal affairs,
But laugh and point to the drifting clouds’ layers."*

Red Pine said:
*"Just left my bamboo hut on Southern Peak,
Passing by my old retreat on Celestial Peak.
The cave’s fine wine has just matured,
While roadside flowers bloom half-cured.
My bones are not of mortal make,
Nor is your talent of earthly stake.
Meet others—speak not of mortal affairs,
But laugh and point to the drifting clouds’ layers."*

Lu Dongbin said:
*"Fallen so low, I’ve come to this place,
Through how many blossoms’ bloom and grace?
When bored, I pawn my coins for wine,
Then drink a thousand cups—or ten thousand fine.
I’ve wandered eighty-one days free,
Drunk, I’ve climbed Mao’s altar high.
Meet others—speak not of mortal affairs,
But laugh and point to the drifting clouds’ layers."*

One day, the Master said to Jia Desheng: *"A distinguished guest will arrive today—go quickly and announce me."* Soon after, a man in a short hemp robe and blue headscarf knocked at the gate. Before Jia could report, the visitor vanished in an instant. The Master hastily ordered pursuit, and after chasing for over a *li*, they encountered an old man clad in deerskin. The Master asked: *"Has the one who passed earlier gone far?"* The old man replied: *"That was the immortal Li Babai, who moves eight hundred *li* in a single stride."* As his words ended, the old man also disappeared.

The Master then realized the deerskin-clad elder was Li Ruan, the White Deer Master of Great Clarity who had attained the Dao.

The Master said: *"I cannot remain named in this world any longer."*

In the first year of the *Duangong* era, he spoke to his disciples one day:

"Next year after the Zhongyuan Festival, I shall journey to Mount Emei. The following year, I shall send my disciples to carve a stone chamber in Zhangchao Valley. Once completed, I went to inspect it and said: 'Though the stone rivals Mount Taihua, this valley remains a finer place. Shall I return here in the end?' I then drafted my final memorial, which read in part: *'This servant’s allotted time has come; though loath to leave the sagely court, I shall shed my form on the twenty-second day of the tenth month this year beneath Lotus Peak in Zhangchao Valley.'*

I also composed a memorial petition, the words of which none saw, and sent Jia Desheng with a tortoise-and-crane saddle and horse to present it at court. The Emperor alone perused it at length, then returned the tortoise-and-crane saddle and horse to Desheng, bestowing upon him a purple robe and the honorific title *Wu Zhen* ('Awakened to Reality'). He further granted five million coins to construct the North Star Hall, that my vow might be fulfilled.

When I first resolved to depart, I had lamps and candles lit all night within the stone chamber. At the appointed time, I passed away resting my cheek upon my left hand. After seven days, my complexion remained unchanged, and my limbs still warm. A five-colored cloud veiled the valley’s mouth, lingering for a full month without dissipating. I lived to the age of one hundred and eighteen.

I entrusted Desheng to succeed me in overseeing the abbey. My elucidation of the *Book of Changes* was transmitted in several characters to Mu Bochang, who passed it to Li Tingzhi, who in turn taught Kangjie (Shao Yaofu). Shao taught the study of images to Zhong Fang, who transmitted it to Xu Jian of Lujiang, who then taught Fan—thus this lineage spread throughout the south.

Later, an imperial emissary arrived at Mount Emei, where a visitor in imposing robes and cap sought an audience, calling himself Dongming Zhuanxiang. He spoke at length of matters concerning Mount Hua. After several days, the emissary realized: *'This is Master Chen of Mount Hua!'* He hastily ordered the man summoned, but he had already vanished without a trace.

During the Xiangfu era, Emperor Zhenzong, returning from the Feng and Sui sacrifices, visited Yuntai Palace a second time. Gazing upon my portrait, he decreed the abbey’s fields exempt from taxes. He summoned the Daoist Jia Desheng and bestowed purple robes upon Wu Zihua and others, commanding them to build halls for the Sacred Ancestor, Emperor Zhenzong’s natal star, and the Three Celestial Palaces. My likeness was also painted upon the northern wall.

Earlier, during the Yongxi era, I had told Jia Desheng: *'When I depart, behind the Hall of the Elder Lord you will see a divine being clad in black robes and cap. He is the North Star, the Purple Tenuity Emperor of Open Unity. You must use the gifts previously bestowed to erect a North Star Hall.'* I further said: *'In former times, Princess Jinxian of the Tang used this place as a sanctuary for prayer. Now that I have again encountered the North Star, this abbey shall flourish—only you shall inherit it.'* When Emperor Zhenzong later visited, it was indeed thirty years hence, and Desheng fulfilled this destiny.

Such foreknowledge of things to come was but one of many such instances."

Chen Daoyi remarked: Master Chen Tuan embodied the Dao and its virtue, using sleep to navigate the world. When woodcutters touched his chest, they found him in deep slumber, saying, *"Why disturb me?"* Summoned to the palace by Empress Dowager Song, he slept soundly against the door for over a month. His sobriquet "Hermit of Profound Obscurity" aptly captured his essence. Yet his reliance on sleep must have held deeper meaning. As the *Dao De Jing* states: *"The multitude are bright and clear; I alone am dim and dull. The multitude are sharp and keen; I alone am muddled and confused."* Was this not the very principle behind Chen Tuan’s sleep?

Su Chengyin, a Daoist of Longxing Abbey in Zhenyang, was well-versed in the teachings of Laozi and Zhuangzi and skilled in nurturing life. In the intercalary fifth month of the second year of the Kaibao era, Emperor Taizu sojourned in Zhenyang and summoned him to ascend the palace hall. The emperor said: *"Master, though over eighty, you appear youthful. You must know the art of nurturing life—teach it to me."* Chengyin replied: *"My method of nurturing life is nothing more than focused contemplation and refining qi. But the way of nurturing life for emperors differs from this. As Laozi said: ‘If I practice non-action, the people will transform themselves; if I am without desire, the people will be upright of their own accord.’ Non-action and desirelessness, concentrating the spirit in the Great Harmony—this is the Dao by which the Yellow Emperor and Emperor Yao ruled long and prosperously."* The emperor praised his words and bestowed upon him generous gifts.

*From the Comprehensive Mirror of the August Dynasty.*

In the winter of the tenth month, on the day *guimao*, of the fifth year of the *Kaibao* era, Emperor Taizu issued an edict commanding the Commissioner of Merit and Virtue, together with Liu Ruozhuo, the Daoist Registrar of the Left Street, to assemble the Daoists of the capital and examine their learning. Those who failed to arrive or were unprepared were all dismissed.

Ruozhuo, a native of Shu, styled himself Master Huagai. Skilled in the practice of *qi*-absorption, he remained vigorous past ninety, his steps light and swift. Whenever drought or flood struck, he was invariably summoned to the palace, where he would erect an altar and perform rites of supplication—his methods precise and meticulous.

Zhang Bai, styled Xubai, called himself Master Baiyun, a man of Qinghe. Quiet and composed, he was broadly learned and capable in literary composition. Having twice failed the imperial examinations, he encountered the death of a parent and wept, saying to himself: *"Office is for nurturing one’s kin—now that my kin are gone, why seek office?"* Thereupon he abandoned grain and ceased eating, devoting himself to cultivating *qi* and preserving spirit. He studied all the texts of the Daoist tradition without exception.

During the *Kaibao* era of Emperor Taizu, he traveled south to Jingzhou. At the time, his fellow townsman Han Keci served as Prefectural Governor, and warmly welcomed him. As the court was then engaged in punitive expeditions against Jiang and Wu, with military and state affairs in turmoil, Zhang doffed his scholar’s robes and became a Daoist. He proceeded to Wuling and took lodging at the Longxing Abbey. The prefectural governor, Vice-Director Liu Chi, and the military supervisor Zhang Yanfu treated him with profound respect. Once, he presented Yanfu with a mirror of his own crafting, saying: *"Keep this—it can ward off evil."*

Zhang concealed his true attainment, spending his days in drunken dissipation, unrestrained and unconcerned. When drunk in the marketplace, he would point at strangers and strangers alike, hurling insults—yet his words invariably struck at the hidden faults of others, so that those of discernment often marveled at him. Whenever he encountered wind or snow, if he felt cold, he would break the ice and plunge into deep water, sitting calmly for the entire day before emerging. His clothes would be soaked, his body steaming like a boiling cauldron, yet in the time it took to glance about, all was dry.

At times, he would playfully challenge others: standing upright, he would have several ruffians push and pull him with all their might, yet he would not budge in the slightest. Or he would stretch out one leg, ordering three or four men to lift it—though they strained with all their strength, the leg remained unmoved.

He often frequented the Cui family’s tavern, drinking without limit. One day, the tavern keeper complained to Master Cui: *"Whenever this venerable master comes, the patrons drink twice as much as usual, yet our profits are less."* Upon hearing this, Master Cui refused to accept a single coin from him.

One day, Zhang wrote on the tavern wall:
*"By the Cui family’s tavern by Wuling Stream—*
*On earth there is none, but in heaven it’s found.*
*A southern Daoist drinks several *dou*—*
*Beyond drunkenness, white clouds at the cavern’s mouth."*

From then on, the number of patrons doubled.

The Southern Marchmount Daoists Tang Yunsheng and Wei Yingshi, also men of the Dao in that era, admired him and often kept his company. Zhang was quick-witted and rich in talent, his thoughts flowing like a spring. Within a few days, he composed three hundred poems on the theme of *"Spring Scenery in Wuling,"* each beginning with the line *"Within the spring scenery of Wuling..."* One read:
*"Within the spring scenery of Wuling,*
*Twelve taverns rise in tiers.*
*Only when thoroughly drunk do I turn my head—*
*Meeting others, I lazily nod.*
*Right and wrong, I care not at all;*
*Fame and profit, suddenly cast aside.*
*Wearing a star-crowned hat,*
*I drift and sink with the world’s flow."*

Zhang’s extemporaneous verses were always coherent and reasonable, unlike the words of an ordinary drunken madman.

Later, he suddenly fell ill and urgently told the abbey’s superintendent: *"I will not recover. Do not cremate me—I fear my kin and acquaintances in the village will come searching. Bury me outside the western gate according to common custom."* With these words, he departed this life. For several nights afterward, his limbs remained supple as in life, and a rare fragrance filled the room.

The city’s gentry and common folk gathered for days to witness the spectacle. The Cui family purchased a coffin, and the military overseer Zhang Yanfu donated his own salary to inter him as he had requested. Barely a month later, a hole appeared in the burial mound. Soon after, Yanfu was again dispatched on a mission to Jianghuai, where an old servant encountered Bai on the Kai Ming Bridge in Weiyang. Bai asked whether Fang Jian was still present, then added, "This mirror, too, will not remain long." The servant returned and recounted the meeting, prompting Yanfu to doubt: "He has been dead for some time—what did you truly see?" He then searched for the mirror and, upon close inspection, found it crumbled at his touch.

Another official, Yu An of Dingzhou, was sent to Yangzhou on public business and also met Bai, who carried a large gourd selling medicine. Bai urgently summoned Yu to drink at a tavern, reminiscing about their past travels in Wuling. When Yu prepared to depart days later, Bai said, "Deliver a letter for me to thank the Cui family." Upon Yu’s return, he delivered the letter, and the Cui family, astonished, immediately opened the coffin—only to find it empty.

Bai annotated *The Scripture of the Daoist Ascension, Disaster Dispelling, and Lifespan Protection*, interspersing it with hymns. The first hymn read:
*"The Supreme’s original truth,*
*Within emptiness, the spirit resides.*
*If the heart can comprehend,*
*Above the head, none abide."*

The final hymn read:
*"The heart doubts, following myriad realms,*
*In realms, it clings to the heart’s threads.*
*The Dao is not ‘being’ nor ‘non-being,’*
*Only then is the edge of seeds transcended."*

He also composed *The Pointers to the Mystery* and a collection of heptasyllabic verse, titled *The Alchemical Terrace Collection*, all of which circulated in the world.

---

**The Daoist of Primal Chaos**
During the days when the Song emperors Taizu and Taizong still concealed their brilliance, they once befriended a Daoist who had no fixed name, calling himself Primal Chaos or sometimes True Nothingness. After Taizu ascended the throne, the Daoist was no longer seen. On the Shangsi Festival, while the emperor was performing the purification rites by the western pond, the Daoist bowed to Taizu and said, "I rejoice in your well-being since we last parted." The emperor hastily received him, and their meeting was as it had always been—they clasped hands and drank heartily. The emperor asked, "How much longer is my lifespan?" The Daoist replied, "If the night of the twentieth day of the tenth month this year is clear, you may extend it by a twelve-year cycle. If not, make swift preparations." The emperor kept him in the rear gardens, where he was sometimes seen lodging in a magpie’s nest in the trees, vanishing for days at a time.

On the appointed day, the emperor ascended the Great Clarity Pavilion to observe the celestial omens. That evening, the sky was indeed clear, stars gleaming brilliantly. The emperor’s heart rejoiced, but suddenly dark clouds gathered, the heavens and earth transformed, and hail and snow fell violently. He descended the pavilion with his staff, urgently ordered the palace gates unlocked, and summoned the Prince of Kaifeng—Taizong. He led him into the grand chamber, where they drank wine together. All palace attendants were dismissed, and from afar, the flickering candlelight revealed Taizong repeatedly rising from his seat in an unbearable manner. When the drinking concluded, the palace clepsydra struck the third watch, and snow had already accumulated several inches deep. The emperor, holding his pillar-axe, struck the snow and turned to Taizong, saying, "Well done, well done." He then loosened his belt and retired to bed, his snores resounding like thunder. As the fifth watch approached, all was silent—he had already passed. Taizong received the posthumous edict and ascended the throne.

---

**Ding Shaowei**
In the third year of Taiping Xingguo during the reign of Emperor Taizong of the Song, on the *yimao* day of the fourth month, the Daoist Ding Shaowei of True Source from Mount Hua was summoned to the capital. Shaowei was skilled in *qi*-absorption and longevity techniques, ranking alongside Chen Tuan. However, Shaowei’s aspirations were pure and refined, while Tuan indulged in wine and unrestrained freedom. Though their residences were close, they never visited one another. Shaowei presented the emperor with golden elixir, giant *astragalus*, southern *lingzhi*, and black *lingzhi*, staying for several months before being sent back.

*From* The Comprehensive Mirror of the August Dynasty

**Chen Huazi**

**Chen Huazi**

Chen Huazi attained the Dao on Mount Qingcheng. He would often cut paper flowers to sell in the market, using the proceeds only to buy wine. He befriended Chen Tuan, and the two frequently visited Mount Qingcheng, where people often saw them.

*End of Volume 47 of* The Comprehensive Mirror of Perfected Immortals Who Embodied the Dao
*Volume 48*

**Zhang Qizhen**

Zhang Qizhen, styled Qiyi, was a native of Qiantang. Orphaned in youth, he followed Master Hu of the Upper Clarity Abbey, wandering through Jiang and Zhe, ascending Mount Kuaiji, exploring the Grotto of Yu, and traversing Jinyun. He journeyed to Red City to seek the Dao, carrying a basket as he accompanied him. At the time, Celestial Master Zhu resided on Mount Tiantai. Observing Qizhen’s pure bones and square pupils, he esteemed him and ordained him as a Daoist. After a long while, Qizhen returned to Qiantang and dwelled at the True Sage Abbey on Mount Wu.

In the fifth year of Xiande during the reign of Emperor Shizong of the Zhou, he received the *Zhengyi Mengwei Lingbao* register from Master Fan of Great Primordiality. Thereafter, he perused all the scriptures of the Purple Rosette and Jade Hairpin without exception, and his name resounded throughout Jiang and Zhe. King Zhongyi, devoted to the Dao and its methods, would hold the Three Registers Fast and entrusted Qizhen with overseeing the rites. Nobles and high officials also revered and admired him.

During the Taiping Xingguo era of the Song, Emperor Taizong ordered the authorities to establish the Taiyi Abbey in the empire’s southeast. He summoned the realm’s pure and disciplined scholars to reside there, and Qizhen was selected. Shortly after, a grand purification rite was held in the palace, and he was summoned for an audience. His responses pleased the emperor, who bestowed upon him a purple robe. The emperor, noting that Daoist scriptures contained errors, ordered the Daoist registrars of the Two Streets to select accomplished scholars for their correction, and Qizhen was again chosen. Upon completion, he was granted the title *Master of Primordial Stillness*.

On the eleventh day of the first month in the third year of Jingde during the reign of Emperor Zhenzong, as he prepared for sleep, a red-robed official bearing a tally arrived at his bedside and said, “By command, Zhang, you must swiftly purify yourself and proceed to your duties there.” At dawn, he summoned his disciple Xu Sijian and said, “I am about to depart. Remember this.” Twenty-five days later, he bathed and, in perfect tranquility, returned to the True. He was seventy-one years old. The following day, his spirit was conveyed to the city’s east. His limbs were soft and supple, and sweat glistened upon his face. When cremated, he yielded over a *sheng* of pearls, dark and lustrous.

Prime Minister Qian Weiyan said to his disciples, “This is what the Buddhists call *śarīra*. In the immortal scriptures, it is said to be the congealed essence of *jing* and *qi*. The *Scripture of Pacing the Void* states: *Śarīra radiates golden splendor, as the dragon carriage arrives in reverence.*”

The master was by nature reticent, his heart untouched by fame or profit. He was only fond of literature, tireless even in old age. He hand-copied over five hundred volumes of classics, histories, masters, and collections. Skilled in cursive and clerical scripts, as well as chess, he concealed his brilliance and restrained himself. Once, as he sat alone in his pavilion, birds alighted upon his lap—so profound was his harmony with things, his mind free of scheming.

**Zhang Yuanhua**

The Daoist Zhang Yuanhua, origin unknown, styled himself *Master of the Canopy of Hua*. While traveling in Ruzhou, the people of Ru invited him to preside over the North Pole Abbey. Outwardly, he cultivated compassion and kindness, and the people of Ru were all pleased with him. Yet none knew what esoteric practices he pursued; he blended with the world and harmonized his light, never setting himself apart.

When someone offered oil lamps for the North Pole Hall, Yuanhua filled a large basin with water, floated eight lamps upon it, and arranged them in the pattern of the stars. The Dipper’s handle turned with the dawn and dusk. When the people of the prefecture requested purification rites, young and old alike prepared with the same intent, yet before they could invite him, the master would arrive at dawn. If someone intended to make a request but their husband and wife suddenly quarreled, or if their children were disobedient, even if they came to invite him, he would perceive their discord, refuse to go, and merely admonish them before sending them away.

Beside the abbey lay an orchard and vegetable garden. Villagers would wait for him to leave before stealing from it, yet upon reaching the garden, they would find the master already there. Such instances of his foresight were many.

Marshal Zhou of the prefecture was on the best terms with the master, yet he never learned what arts he had been taught. Once, on New Year’s Day, the master carried a reed torch, circling the streets and alleys. Though it took several moments to complete the circuit, the torch’s embers remained as if freshly lit. When people marveled and inquired, he replied, “There are plague demons here. I am driving them away.” The people thought him mad and did not believe him. But in summer, a violent epidemic broke out beyond the city, while within, rich and poor alike remained unharmed. He saved people with talismans and medicines, using whatever he received for the abbey’s rites.

One day, a guest invited him to a tavern. Yuanhua declined, saying he did not drink. Later, when the guest offered meat, he again refused, citing his ordination register. The guest grew angry, but Yuanhua gazed intently at him and knew he was no human. He said, “Return briefly to the abbey. I beg you to wait a moment, and I will meet you again.” Taking his sword, he lured the guest beyond the city, ordered him to sit, and slew him—it was a demon. Its hair was vermilion, its face indigo, and its back as thin as that of a five- or seven-year-old child. He held up its head for the people to see, saying, “This demon repeatedly caused harm. I slew it to rid the people of a scourge.” He then piled firewood in the thoroughfare and burned it, the stench lingering for days.

One night, the people of the prefecture all dreamed that Yuanhua came to bid them farewell, saying, “I am traveling afar for a time. Take care.” That very night, he vanished in his sleep. At dawn, those who came to visit found that all, young and old, had witnessed the same. In the early years of Taiping Xingguo during the reign of Emperor Taizong of the Song, the scholar An Hongjian lodged in the prefecture. Arrogant and self-important, he claimed no one could match his talents. Yet upon meeting Yuanhua, he bowed in reverence and joined the ranks of his disciples.

After the burial, when the coffin was lifted, it was exceedingly heavy, as if iron or stone rolled within. Hongjian ordered wine and offered prayers, and gradually it grew lighter. When they opened the coffin at the gravesite, they found a hole in the crown of the head, large enough to admit an arm.

Those with discernment remarked, "This is the molting of a cicada." Shortly after, a traveler arrived from Heyin, selling pomegranates at Rufen. On the road, he encountered a Daoist who said, "I am the abbot Zhang of Rufen. I entrust you with a letter." He also purchased several dozen pomegranates, offering them at the North Pole Hall. The traveler agreed. Upon arrival, the disciples said, "This letter is indeed our master’s true hand." They led the traveler to the portrait hall, where he exclaimed, "The one I saw earlier differs not at all from this image." To this day, the people of Ru depict his likeness and honor him. He once composed *The Secret of Returning Elixir* and two short lyrics, which, along with his deeds in cultivating the Dao, have been passed down through the ages.

Zhang Qiwu and Li Zhen were natives of Yan. Gentle and restrained, Qiwu never offended others. He traveled through Ke and Xiang. During the Chunhua reign of Emperor Taizong of the Song, he arrived in Jiangling. Stricken by illness, he lodged outside the Gong’an Gate. Though impoverished, he never turned away guests. One day, a Daoist visited, introducing himself as Zhang Qiwu of Longxi, seeking shelter from Zhen. Zhen agreed, though ashamed of his poverty and inability to provide. The Daoist said, "This poor Daoist eats nothing. A few measures of wine each day would be a generous gift." Zhen consented. The Daoist drank in the marketplace, unbothered even by butchers and wine-sellers. He returned only after nightfall, drunkenly cursing Zhen, who paid no mind and treated him even more kindly. Another day, the Daoist returned utterly drunk, stumbling into Zhen’s bedchamber. He awoke only at dusk, vomiting filth that soiled everything. The servants grew angry and sought to restrain him, but Zhen stopped them, saying, "Why reproach a drunken man?" At dawn, the Daoist prepared to leave and said to Zhen, "I am deeply grateful for your kindness. Might you now see me off for a few *li*?" Zhen accompanied him for nearly ten *li*. The Daoist said, "I am no ordinary man, though I bear a slight debt. I have wandered the world for fifty years and never met one as benevolent and generous as you. I wish to offer you a minor art." Zhen asked what it was, and he replied, "The art of transmuting base metals into gold." Zhen said, "My fate is meager; I dare not accept. I pray you understand." The Daoist smiled vaguely and said, "Your Way is beyond my reach." Then he drew a hairpin, wielding it as a sword, and declared, "Let us part here." He slashed the earth, which split at his touch. He stepped into the fissure, and the ground closed behind him. Zhen marveled, and from that day forth, the Daoist vanished, never to be seen again.

Zhang Wumeng, styled Lingyin and known as Master Hongmeng, was a native of Aoya in Fengxiang. Tall of stature and refined in bearing, he favored tranquility and lived simply into old age. His father was a scholar who withdrew from official life. He had two sons, Wumeng being the elder, renowned for his filial piety in his hometown. Upon coming of age, he entrusted his inheritance to his younger brother and entered Mount Hua, forming bonds with Zhong Fang and Liu Haichan as fellow seekers beyond the mundane. He studied under Master Chen Xiyi, from whom Wumeng gleaned subtle teachings. After some time, he traveled to Tiantai, ascended Chicheng, and dwelled at Qiongtai Abbey. There, he practiced the methods of the Red Pine Immortal’s guiding and stretching, and Anqi’s returning elixir. Over a decade or so, his inner cultivation found expression in song and verse, culminating in a hundred poems titled *The Return to the Origin*. Xia Yingong, while serving as prefect of Taizhou, entered the mountains and met him. He obtained this collection and brought it back to the capital. At the time, Minister Wang Jifu was seeking recluses, and Yingong presented *The Return to the Origin* to him. Before long, it was brought to the emperor’s attention. Emperor Zhenzong of the Song summoned Wumeng for an audience and inquired about the path to longevity.

Wumeng replied, "Your servant is but a rustic. In the mountains, I merely recite the *Laozi* and the *Book of Changes*—I know nothing beyond these." The emperor commanded him to expound the *Changes*, and he discoursed on the hexagram *Modesty*. The emperor asked, "Why do you speak only of *Modesty*?" Wumeng answered, "When the realm is in a time of great abundance, it is fitting to preserve it with modesty." The emperor was pleased with his explanation and appointed him Left Gentleman for Writing. Wumeng firmly declined, saying, "Your Majesty’s virtue rivals that of Yao and Shun—surely the mountains and forests can accommodate one Chaofu or Xu You?" Thereupon, he took up residence at Xusheng Abbey in Jianlong.

Later, the emperor summoned him to lecture on *The Return to the Origin*. Wumeng said, "The state is like the body. When the mind is without contrivance, the qi harmonizes; when the qi harmonizes, the myriad treasures coalesce. When the mind is contrived, the qi becomes disordered; when the qi is disordered, the essence and splendor scatter. This is the great purport of *The Return to the Origin*." He briefly expounded on a dozen or so poems before withdrawing. Envoys were sent to bestow gold and silk, but he declined them all, begging to return to the mountains. The emperor then conferred upon him the title *Master of Unfettered Drinking*, but he refused this as well. The emperor composed a song to send him on his way, its lyrics reading:

*"The Primal Origin’s teaching holds pure essence,
Seen not, heard not, yet ever present.
Only the enlightened attain this truth,
Roaming beyond the world in profound obscurity.
Floating clouds shift without fixed form,
Flowing waters take no constant shape.
On a whim, he left the valleys,
To discourse on the real before the royal court.
With the wind, he grasped the宗旨,
Returning to rock-pillowed ease, his nature fulfilled.
Jade and silk, caps and tassels—he holds none dear,
A long song alone honors his homeward path."*

Minister Wang Jifu invited him to his private residence, intending to detain him with hospitality. Wumeng said, "Even the Son of Heaven I have declined—you, sir, are but a minister; why trouble yourself to keep me?" The next day, he departed. An edict was issued commanding Taizhou to provide him with the stipend of a Left Gentleman for Writing to support his old age, but upon reaching the mountains, he did not claim it. From beginning to end, he maintained such integrity.

He possessed the arts of alchemy but kept them secret. After residing at Qiongtai for another decade, he withdrew to Crane Pond on Mount Zhongnan. Some time later, he wandered to Mount Song, drifted along the Xiang and Han rivers, and arrived at Baoning and Shouning Monasteries in Jinling, where he shut his door and did not emerge. When scholars sought him out for instruction, he feigned deafness, and thereafter, worldly affairs scarcely concerned him. Yet he was broadly learned in antiquity and the present, mastering the hundred schools of thought, as well as maps, classics, and minor histories, recalling them with perfect clarity. Two students attended his desk for many years before he eventually ordained them as Daoist priests.

Wumeng lived to ninety-nine and passed away in Jinling. Three days after his death, a white qi surged from the crown of his head, rising over three feet high before gradually dissipating. When placed in the coffin, his limbs remained supple, his fingernails did not darken, and his chest retained warmth. Magistrate Shi Junyu Qi sent an official to inter him before the stupa of Chan Master Wukong. A collection of his *Qiongtai Poems* circulated in the world.

Master Bixu Chen Jingyuan once ranked among his disciples and attained the profound purport of the Lao-Zhuang teachings.

**Master Cheng the Immortal**
Master Cheng the Immortal’s origins are unknown. In Zizhou, he ascended to heaven in broad daylight. Xing Qi, the prefect, reported the event in full to Emperor Zhenzong. His descendants remain alive to this day.

Tu Dingci

Tu Dingci was a native of Longmou Village in Liangshan, Pengzhou. His Tu clan ancestors had resided there for generations since Meng Zhixiang’s occupation of Shu. He tilled the land himself and amassed a fortune of a hundred gold pieces. During the Xianping era of Emperor Zhenzong of the Song, Dingci served in corvée labor for the prefecture. Once, while transporting silk and cloth through the pass, he lodged for the night at an inn in Huayin. There, he encountered a scholar who introduced himself as Shu Zhuan. They exchanged bows and sat together, their conversation flowing so harmoniously that they drank together for an entire day. As Dingci prepared to depart, the scholar said, “I am Chen Tuan. I chanced upon you here because you possess extraordinary bones.” Overcome with joy and awe, Dingci could scarcely contain himself. He earnestly sought esoteric arts, but the scholar replied, “The Way does not prize the extraordinary. Simply conserve your spirit and avoid internal harm from likes and dislikes—that is sufficient.” Then, drawing a *daogui* of medicine from his sleeve, he said, “Take this, and you shall live a hundred years.” The next day, Dingci sought him again, but the scholar had vanished.

Upon returning west, Dingci abandoned worldly pursuits and carved a stone chamber into the southern mountain where he lived. The cliff was perilously steep, towering dozens of *ren* high, and onlookers’ hair stood on end at the sight. Yet Dingci scaled the wooden ladders and traversed the rocky paths as effortlessly as level ground. Initially, the stone chamber was dry, and he suffered from a lack of water. Whenever he chanted an incantation, a sweet spring would flow forth as promised. He often kept a flock of crows, and with a single call into the wind, thousands would gather, circling and alighting tamely around him.

In summer, he would carry his spinning wheel to bask on the rocks, calling it “welcoming the cold.” In winter’s bitter freeze, he wore only a single layer of silk. Once, while traveling in Chengdu, he visited the monk Xi Bai. When the meal was served, he consumed an entire vessel of salt—several *jin* in weight—astonishing all present. The alchemist Wang He shared drinks with him, and Dingci alone downed several *dou* without losing composure. He also pulverized several *sheng* of ginger and scallions, mixing them into his food. Whenever guests arrived and casually mentioned a craving for some delicacy, he would invariably procure it in abundance for them to share. Though his guests were sated, he would not cease.

Once, when his family estate became the subject of a lawsuit, the case was transferred to Yanqu for trial. Nearly a year passed in prison, yet he never once prepared provisions, nor did his accusers dare confront him. The warden, too, refused to yield, unable to extract the truth, and so released Dingci from confinement.

Dingci immediately went to the riverbank north of the city, to the Luohan Monastery. Atop a sheer cliff stood an ancient tree, and he climbed it, refusing to descend for seven days. When people called to him, he replied: "I will not come down. You may shoot me with arrows if you wish—if not, stones will do." Yet no one dared press him. On the eighth day, without being summoned, he descended of his own accord and returned to the place of trial, where an imperial pardon arrived.

Later, he requested to become a Daoist. Each mid-spring, when people took purgative medicines, he would go to the river, stand naked on a small shoal, and let the water enter his body through the seven orifices, calling it "flushing the intestines."

Once, two young merchants were at Tuobai Stream when one suddenly collapsed from heatstroke and died. Dingci took an iron needle and struck it into the man’s forehead with a single hammer blow, driving it in over an inch. In an instant, the man revived. The next year, the merchant brought goods as thanks, but Dingci refused to accept them. He stored away five hundred thousand coins, his shoulder load secured tightly.

The family was forbidden from taking or using his money without permission, though his descendants never understood his reasoning. A month before his death, he returned home from his chamber. He told his family: "Throughout my life, whenever I purchased goods worth a hundred coins, I always gave more than the asking price. If the seller questioned the excess, I would reward their integrity with the extra money. Yet in all my years, not a single person did so—such is the greed of the world today."

One day, he summoned his family before him and said: "I am ninety-three years old. What am I waiting for if not death?" He asked for croton seeds and ate them—two hundred at first. When nothing happened, he ate another hundred after a short while. A slight purging followed, and then he sat upright and passed away. The family gathered around, weeping, but he revived and said: "Stop. I fear you will struggle with the funeral arrangements." After explaining everything, he departed once more. For several nights, his youthful complexion remained unchanged, as if still alive. When the time came for burial, his coffin was remarkably light. Those who knew the signs believed it to be a *shijie*—a liberation from the corpse.

In the stone chamber where he had lived, the sounds of flutes and drums were sometimes heard. His son became a Left Attendant-in-Ordinary, and several of his grandsons passed the imperial examinations.

**Guo Shangaong**

Guo Shangaong, whose origins are unknown, once worked as a hired laborer in the Song dynasty during the *Tianxi* era of Emperor Zhenzong, washing dishes in a teahouse by the Bianzhou Bridge. One day, a man in a blue headscarf and plain robe sat drinking tea. His bearing was imposing, his presence awe-inspiring, and he kept glancing at Guo. Suspecting the man was extraordinary, Guo discreetly observed the sword hidden in his sleeve. Guo thought to himself: *This must be Master Lü.* When the man left, Guo rushed forward and knelt before him, saying: "I have encountered you at last, Master. I wish to serve you as your attendant."

Master Lü ignored him and walked away. Guo followed at a distance until they reached a wooden plank. Lü turned and asked: "Do you truly wish to serve me?" Guo nodded eagerly. Lü said: "Then receive my sword." Guo stretched out his neck in readiness. As Lü raised the blade to strike, Guo cried out—and Lü vanished. Guo found himself patrolling the *Baiwan* Granary, where he was arrested by guards, beaten with a staff, and driven away.

From then on, he wandered every secluded corner within and beyond the capital. Whenever he saw someone, he would stare intently for a long while before leaving.

When questioned, he would reply: "I am searching for Master Lü." For over a decade thereafter, his whereabouts remained unknown.

In the final years of Emperor Renzong’s Tiansheng era, an official named Zhao resided in a private estate in Yicheng Town, Cizhou. One day, a beggar in tattered robes arrived. Bowing twice before Zhao, he said: "I am Guo Shang’ao." Zhao recognized him and asked: "Have you seen Master Lü?" Guo replied: "I have traveled the realm without finding him. Now my allotted time nears its end, so I have come to beg a small coffin to shelter my remains." Zhao thought him delusional and asked: "When will it end?" Guo said: "Tomorrow at noon." Zhao replied: "If so, I shall buy you a coffin." Guo added: "And I beg you to bore a hole in the coffin’s head, through which a bamboo pole may be inserted to allow the passage of qi." Though Zhao assented, he remained unconvinced.

The next day at noon, Guo bathed himself with drawn water, lay beneath a locust tree, and expired. Astonished, Zhao had a coffin made. As bamboo was scarce in Heshuo, he took an old umbrella handle, hollowed it out, and inserted it into the coffin’s head before placing it on the riverbank. Fearing disturbance by foxes or dogs, he reinforced it with brambles and piled stones.

That autumn, heavy rains swelled the river, which receded only after several days. Fearing the coffin might have been swept away, Zhao hastened to inspect it with his staff—only to find the coffin open and the body gone.

---

Master Bao Yi, whose given name was Bao Yi, hailed from Liangdang in Fengzhou. His father had relocated to Puchi in Liangquan, where the family lived by farming and sericulture. At twelve, while herding cattle, the Master encountered an old man who asked: "Are you hungry?" The Master did not answer but merely nodded. The old man reached into his bag, took out food resembling a radish but sweet in taste, and gave it to him. He also gave him a staff and a gourd ladle containing medicine—peas, in fact—which he instructed the Master to administer to others. Those suffering from new or chronic illnesses who took it recovered without exception.

After eating the radish himself, the Master no longer craved cooked food. Some time later, he wandered to the western gate of the capital’s Balou Monastery. A monk there asked: "Do you wish to leave the household life?" The Master replied: "Yes." The monk said: "Go see the head monk and ask him to recommend you." Arriving at a thatched pavilion behind the monastery’s rear gate, he fell into a deep sleep for several days. Another monk passed by, saw him, and asked where he had come from. The monk then led him inside.

As they passed the Nirvana Hall, they heard groans. The Master asked: "Who is that?" The monk replied: "A novice has been ill for days; the epidemic is severe." The Master poured medicine from his gourd—peas—and had the novice swallow them with freshly drawn water. Immediately, the novice broke into a sweat as if freshly bathed, and by evening, he had recovered. The monks marveled, and word spread throughout the city. Soon, those seeking medicine thronged like a marketplace, yet the gourd’s supply never ran dry.

The Master accepted nothing in return, giving all offerings to the abbot for distribution to night patrols and inspecting officials. Though they knew he was no charlatan, the growing crowds could not be restrained. The matter was reported to the court.

At the time, Emperor Zhenzong’s imperial procession was away on an eastern ritual journey, and Chancellor Xiang remained in the capital as acting regent. He secretly sent men to verify the Master’s abilities and dispatched a swift memorial to the emperor’s temporary court. Soon, an edict arrived, ordering the Master to be housed in a secluded Daoist abode. He was thus installed in the fasting quarters of the Taiyi Palace.

Once settled, officials strictly guarded the premises, striking watchman’s clappers to ensure his safety. Daoists Hu Taiyi and others were assigned to attend him with food and drink. Yet each day, the Master ate only three or four dates and chestnuts. After more than a month, the imperial procession returned.

The emperor summoned him for an audience. Zhenzong patted his back and said, "You share Our surname." Thereupon, he had the Master tonsured and ordained as a Daoist, bestowing upon him the name Baoyi. Before long, the Master sought to return home. The emperor presented him with a gold-plated, silver-inlaid dragon-headed staff, a bronze vermilion-sealed parrot cup, medicinal herbs, and the like. He also dispatched the eunuch Zhang Maoxian and the Daoist Hu Dayi to escort him to Mount Shimen, where a True Seclusion Abbey was specially built as his place of transcendence. Each year, he was granted ordination robes and purple vestments.

During the Qingli era of Emperor Renzong, he suddenly ceased his repose. By the Xuanhe era, the Master returned to the capital and lodged in his former retreat at the Taiyi Palace. He submitted a memorial recounting his past, petitioning to restore the imperial favors bestowed by the late emperor. Renzong, who had long known the Master’s reputation, approved his request in full upon reading the memorial. However, the censors and remonstrators vehemently opposed it, and the Master, though twice summoned to the capital, spent his days drinking wine without ever becoming intoxicated, consuming only a few vegetables and fruits.

In the Jiayou era, he eagerly sought to return home, repeatedly expressing fear of water obstructions. After his departure, by mid-autumn, a great flood indeed occurred. One day, he sent his disciple Pu Weifu into the prefectural city to purchase medicine, but the disciple overstayed his return. The Master gathered his disciples and said, "I wish to journey to the capital to pay respects to Minister Zhang Pu, but Weifu has not yet returned." Suddenly feeling weary, he lay down and passed away, aged seventy-eight. For a hundred days, his limbs remained warm, and for a long time, his abode emitted a yellow radiance. This continued for three years before his disciples finally interred him. The staff he had used was the very one Zhenzong had exchanged for the dragon-headed one, and all the other gifts he had received remained intact.

Those who recognized him said the old man he had encountered was none other than Master Zhang Guo. For there is a cave to the west of the prefecture where, according to legend, Zhang Guo had once secluded himself.

Wu Baoyi was a native of Jiankang.

Wu Baoyi began his service as an attendant to the Daoists of Mount Mao. At the monastery stood a bell, which was struck at appointed times to summon the assembled Daoists. During the Jianlong era of Emperor Taizu of the Song, he suddenly encountered a perfected being and attained the Dao. His comings and goings became unfathomable, and people called him the "Immortal Youth."

The Huayang Daoist Zhu Ziying was well-versed in the alchemical classics. Emperor Zhenzong bestowed upon him the title "Master of Observing the Mysterious" and honored him with lavish gifts to invite him to court. Upon hearing of Ziying’s impending journey, the Immortal Youth sent him a letter:

*Baoyi addresses you: Truly, to laugh and wander in an age of peace, lightly scorning wealth and nobility—how can the luxuriant cinnamon of the cinnabar grove conceal the radiance of the bright moon? How can the sheer cliffs of the green mountains detain the nearness of the white clouds? Words are insufficient; the Dao resides within. Form and spirit [missing character] part, hidden among the Three Mountains, while name and surname are already renowned across the Four Seas. What constancy do years and months hold? What is there to seek in lead and mercury? If one lingers in hesitation, one will only end in decline. The pearl is round and perfect in its beauty; the crimson snow congeals and is naturally so. In the marketplace, who is not thus? In the mountains, who is thus? Water accumulates to become the sea; qi accumulates to become spirit. It is not that I know you well—say little, speak no more. Baoyi sells medicines, but what do profit and fame matter? Harmonizing with the light while dwelling among the common—how could the Dao and the worldly be distinct? Lightly ascend and travel; cultivate longevity. The Dao lies in much that is so. Roam carefree among the clouds and waters, never exposing the celestial mechanism. The knowing find speech difficult; the practicing see for themselves. I write these earnest words in place of idle conversation. A single day feels like two autumns; a foot’s distance spans ten thousand miles. The yang qi is like smoke; the desolate outskirts resemble water. Guard your harmony and equilibrium. Let this suffice—no further inquiries. Now, by means of this letter, I convey a fragment of my heart. When it arrives before the mountain, may it fulfill the crane’s longing. Respectfully submitted.*

He also appended a poem:
*The sagely sovereign seeks those beyond the world,*
*Summoning them to the golden palace to meet the numinous perfected.*
*I alone wish not to make my name known—*
*Green waters and blue mountains are the Dao I cherish.*

Before Ziying had finished reading, the messenger holding the letter vanished, leaving him astonished.

---

**Master Zhu Ziying**
Master Zhu Ziying, styled Yinzhi, was a native of Zhuyang Village in Juyong. At the age of eight or nine, he herded cattle in Guogan Village and could summon cranes, which some deemed inauspicious. His parents abandoned him, and he entered the Dao, becoming a disciple of the Daoist Zhu Wenji of Yuchen Abbey. At eleven, he was ordained as a Daoist and lived with Instructor Zhang Shaoying on Mount Jijin, abstaining from grains. His sandals often filled the doorway. The Master remarked, "That they come from near and far to tread upon our assembly—is this not too much ado?" Thereafter, he alternated between morning rituals on the altar and evening crossings of the river, intending to pay homage to the Primordial One at Bo She and the Celestial Master on Mount Qingcheng.

He encountered an old man who instructed him to close his eyes, saying, "Hold fast to my staff." He felt only the treetops brushing his feet. When he opened his eyes, he found himself seated at the foot of Mount Qingcheng, where he was taught the arts of the Golden Crucible, the Ninefold Transmutation, and the Flying Essence Sword. The old man said, "The world knows me as Chen Tie Jiao—I am he." With these words, the old man vanished.

The Master, considering the Daoist canon of the Three Maos incomplete and corrupted, traveled to Lai Xiang to collate and carve the ancient edition of the *Supreme Clarity*. After more than a year, a Daoist surnamed Wu inquired of him, "Are you willing to go?" The Master replied, "How dare I not obey?" In the blink of an eye, a clamor filled his ears, and suddenly he beheld a bustling scene. The Daoist turned to him and said, "This is Hezhong Prefecture." Soon they reached the Yellow River, where the waters parted to allow safe passage. The Master followed, treading as if on level ground. Upon reaching the opposite shore, the Daoist joyfully declared, "A trustworthy man is teachable—I am the Water Star Youth. This journey has already reached its destination, crossing into the Great Yin. Though secluded and remote, it is not weary of profound depths. We shall meet again in another time." He then turned and departed.

The Master returned to his former mountain, where he obtained the seal of the Nine Elders of the Immortal Capital and tirelessly aided others. Before long, during the selection of Daoists for the Jade Clarity Luminous Response Abbey, Xue Ying, a gentleman of meritorious conduct and Vice Minister of the Ministry of Works, recommended the Master’s name to the court. The imperial court dispatched an envoy to summon him, but he submitted a memorial declining the invitation.

At the time, the emperor had not yet established an heir. An emissary, Ren Wenqing, was sent with precious incense to conduct a ritual, and the Master was commanded to submit a memorial praying for an heir. Empress Zhangsheng Mingsu then dreamed of dozens of feathered immortals descending with a celestial official, who said, "This is the fourth emperor of the Song." (See *Records of Sagely Governance*; a stele on Mount Mao attests to this.) When Emperor Renzong succeeded to the throne, envoys were sent twice to the prefecture and county, pressing him urgently. Unable to refuse further, he accepted the appointment and resided in the Zhaoying Abbey, where he was treated with great favor.

Wang Qinruo, the abbey’s superintendent, delighted in the Master’s brief audience at the jade palace and exchanged poems with him. After repeatedly submitting memorials, the Master was permitted to decline the position. Ding Wei, the Military Commissioner and Governor of Shengzhou, also composed a poem to see him off as he returned to the mountains. Thereafter, he lived in seclusion, claiming illness and refusing to rise.

During the reign of Empress Mingsu, envoys were frequently sent to present incense and conduct rituals for the protection of the emperor’s person. She also sent a personal letter with a pair of gold-inlaid bowls, saying they were used by the emperor in his childhood. For the Daoist community, she established a manor, where the imperial ink and gifts remain preserved.

Upon receiving the scriptures and methods of the Supreme Clarity, the emperor honored the Master from afar as his preceptor in ordination and bestowed upon him the title "Master of Observing the Mysterious." The Immortal Youth again sent a letter and a poem, urging him to further conceal his brilliance.

Today, the altar of the memorial, the cinnabar cauldron, and the bestowed bell still stand beside the Qian Yuan Abbey in the secluded corner of Mount Mao. This was his former retreat, where the stele *Luminous Radiance of the Reclusive Immortal* records his immortal traces in detail.

---

**Immortal Li**
Le Shi served the Song dynasty as an Imperial Censor of the Western Capital. Once, he dreamed of being summoned by the Celestial Emperor. Soon, he beheld magnificent palaces, and the Emperor said, "The ruler seeks an heir; I shall choose one for him." After a moment, someone arrived, and the Emperor declared, "The Central Plains seek an heir—go, and do not refuse." The man kowtowed repeatedly, begging to be excused, but the Emperor said, "Go!" He then departed in compliance.

Those standing in attendance beside him said, "This is the Barefoot Immortal Li of the Southern Marchmount." He was often deep in wine. The following year, Emperor Renzong was indeed born.

Another time, the Sacred Palace stood in the east of Luoyang, where the ancestral spirit-tablets of the imperial clan were enshrined. On the twenty-ninth day of the third month in the eighth year of Renzong’s Jiayou era, as the day’s water-clock ran dry, people saw an array of feathered guards lining the road. Last of all came a man clad in a russet robe, holding a yellow canopy, riding a horse to the palace gates—then he vanished. The next day, the palace gates stood wide open, and the locks on all the halls’ doors had unbolted themselves. Soon after, Emperor Renzong ascended as an immortal.

Liu Congshan
Liu Congshan, styled Shuntian and styled himself the Master of Vastness, was a native of Western Luoyang. His family had never served in office; his father had registered his household in Xiangfu of Bian. From childhood, Congshan was bright and quick-witted, with a refined love for Daoist learning. During the Xiangfu era of Emperor Zhenzong of the Song, he studied under the Daoist Wang Taihe at the Jianlong Abbey. In the fifth year, he passed the examination and became a Daoist priest. Poor in worldly goods, he sought only alms to support his parents. Through bitter cold and scorching heat, he never rested, earning universal praise for his filial piety.

In the first year of Renzong’s Tiansheng era, on the Qian Yuan Festival, he was bestowed a purple robe. In the second year, sixth month, he was appointed by imperial decree to serve as abbot of the Jingling Palace. In the third year, eighth month, the emperor and the empress dowager wished to confer the Dharma lineage. They summoned the Master of Observing the Wondrous, Zhu Ziying—a Master of the Great Cavern of the Three Maos—at the Golden Register Altar of the Jade Purity Radiant Response Palace. Another edict was issued, selecting over fifty scholars of the scriptures, diligent and devout in their practice, to receive transmission together at the altar. Congshan was among the first. He was further bestowed the robes, crown, shoes, sword, and sash of the Orthodox Unity lineage. Thereafter, the emperor strictly observed filial sacrifices, honoring his ancestors in due season. He specially dispatched envoys to instruct Congshan to recite incantations over food offerings before the spirit-tablets on the late emperor’s death anniversary, and to compile the *Three Caverns’ Scriptures, Chants, and Hymns* to present to the immortal carriage. Soon after, he submitted the *Incantation for Offering Food*. The emperor commended him and granted him the title *Master of Complete Simplicity*. The text was then distributed to all abbeys and temples. The ritual of incanting over food offerings began with Congshan.
