When the Yanning Palace was completed, the emperor ordered the composition of inscriptions for the Five Treasuries of the Sacred Images. Many responded to the imperial call, but only Congshan’s submission met with approval. His text was engraved on tablets of gold and jade. During the Jingyou era, he requested to return to his original abbey. Shortly after, as the spirit-carriages of Empress Dowager Zhangxian and Empress Dowager Zhanghui departed the capital, he served as a Dharma master, delivering lectures and praises along the route.

In the second year of the Zhihe era, the first month of the yiwei year, Emperor Renzong fell ill. Congshan was summoned to the Great Celebration Hall to perform the jiao offering and submit memorials. The emperor ordered his ministers to bow in his stead. That night, as Congshan prostrated himself to present the memorial, the emperor suddenly worsened. His eyes closed for several moments, and the court was thrown into panic. After a long while, Congshan finally rose and said, "The memorial has reached the Supreme. There is a decree from the Celestial Emperor to recall the imperial carriage." Soon after, the emperor revived. He immediately issued a proclamation asking, "Who is General Ge?" Congshan replied, "Beneath the Three Heavenly Gates, there is a deity called General Ge." Another proclamation followed: "Quickly set up an altar and make offerings." The next day, the emperor’s health was restored. He told his attendants, "Last night, I dreamed I arrived at the Heavenly Gate. A certain General Ge said, 'The Emperor is not yet fated to come.' He urgently lent me a horse to send me back, and I awoke."

Later, an edict ordered the eunuch Mai Chengxin to build the Ge General Abbey southwest of the Suburban Altar. It was adorned with gold and jade, and Congshan was bestowed imperial robes, mats, gold, and silk. The emperor wished to grant him a title, but he firmly declined. In the early Jiayou era, the Daoist Registrars of the Left and Right Streets recommended him for a Daoist office. The emperor approved the memorial and appointed him Acting Supervisor of the Right Street, though he declined. Unable to refuse, he accepted the command.

In the summer of the fifth year, the people suffered from a great flood. He again submitted a memorial at the Funing Hall, and the emperor exempted them from taxes to relieve their suffering.

Congshan rose from Acting Supervisor of the Right Street to Vice Registrar. In his daily life, he recited the *Jade Purity*, *Root of Origins*, *Western Ascension*, and *Yellow Court* scriptures. As for absorbing qi and refining form, he practiced these diligently as well.

When Emperor Yingzong ascended the throne, the prime minister Han Qi again requested that a title be bestowed upon him, but he declined once more. On the twenty-eighth day of the seventh month in the third year of Emperor Shenzong’s Xining era, after bathing, he gathered his disciples before him and said, "I await the great wind. When it comes, I shall depart." Soon after, he passed away as he had foretold, at the age of eighty-one.

Later, a traveler saw Congshan riding a white horse like a soaring bird, who said, "Tell my disciples I have appeared to you." Thus, it was known that he had achieved liberation in the flesh.

He compiled *Rituals for Offerings* and *Formulae for Memorials*, which circulated in the world.

Master Lan Fang
Master Lan Fang, styled Yuandao, was a native of Bozhou. Elders of the prefecture said that from their childhood, they had seen the master, whose appearance remained unchanged to the present day. His hair cascaded to the ground, black and lustrous. His skin was like congealed fat, his brows and eyes widely spaced, his lips as if layered with cinnabar, his teeth like rows of jade. His demeanor was gentle and kind; in all his interactions, great or small, he won hearts with harmony.

When drunk, he would wander into taverns. If he encountered the destitute begging by the roadside, he would reach into his robe and scatter a handful of coins to them. He was fond of dispensing medicine, relieving the suffering of the sick.

Emperor Renzong of the Song, having heard of the master’s reputation, specially summoned him to the palace hall, granted him a seat, and bestowed tea and medicine. He was lodged in the Fragrant Grove Garden. Soon after, he requested to leave and was granted the title *Master of Nurturing Simplicity of the Southern Marchmount*. He resided at the Zhaoxian Abbey on the Southern Marchmount.

At that time, the scholar Jia Changchao presented the master with a poem:

*Imperial favor deeply graces the hermit’s frame,*
*His Daoist robe should be girded with kudzu as a kerchief.*
*Beneath the Peak of Fire, drunk beneath the bright moon,*
*At the source of the Xiang’s waters, angling for purple scales.*
*Once he saw the sea peach bear three fruits,*
*Yet knows not how many springs the red bean has seen.*
*When one day my work is done and I depart,*
*I shall be the spirit-bridge’s one who kneels to your sandals.*

The master replied:

*Recently, I begged the enlightened lord to free this body,*
*No harm in wearing a black kerchief beneath the pines.*
*Wild wine brims in the cup, floating jade foam,*
*Freshly angled stream fish, brocaded in scales.*
*After the night the crow fled the dark palace,*
*The dragon’s child in the cavern nurtures eternal spring.*

If my palace might find one of like mind,
Two more would join the paradise within our gourd.

The master had a disciple named Chen Tongsou, who asked why, without merit and practice, one could not reach the realm of immortals. The master replied: "In ancient times, those who cultivated merit and practice feared others would know; today, those who cultivate merit and practice fear others will not know. This is why their merit and practice remain shallow, and they ultimately achieve nothing."

When Li Guan, later a Gentleman of the Ministry of Rites, was still a presented scholar, he traveled to Mount Nanyue. Passing through Changsha, he drank at a tavern beneath the banner-pole when suddenly a man carrying a bamboo case and bearing tools for nails and hinges approached him and said: "You are going to Mount Nanyue. When you see Master Yangsu, ask him on my behalf: *How does one emerge from ten months of spiritual gestation?*" Li Guan arrived at Mount Nanyue and relayed this to the master, who exclaimed in great surprise: "Did the man have a white mole between his brows?" Li Guan replied: "Yes." The master sighed: "That was Master Hai Chan. I have nurtured the sacred embryo to completion, yet I fear I lack the means to bring it forth. None but he can fulfill my Dao."

One night, the master lodged alone in the upper chamber. As he spoke with someone, an attendant peeped through a hole in the window and saw the room filled with crimson light. The next day, a guest inquired about it, and the master said: "My teacher, Perfected Lord Liu, passed by on his rain-making journey and lingered to speak with me for a moment."

One day, after bathing, the master summoned his attendants and said: "I am now one hundred and seventy-two years old. How could I still cling to titles and honors? Yet I do not wish to refuse the sagely emperor’s intent. Now, I shall depart." With that, he passed away in an instant.

The master often traveled to western Shu but would also come to Hunan and Hubei from time to time. Even now, people occasionally see him. Another account says: Li Guan of Yuxi, while traveling to Mount Nanyue to visit Lan Yangsu, encountered a man on the road carrying tools for nails and hinges. The man asked: "Are you not Li Guan, going to Mount Nanyue to see Lan Yangsu?" Li Guan replied: "Yes." The man continued: "Then I beg you to deliver a message to Master Lan: *Liu, the Recluse, inquires of you—how does one emerge from ten months of spiritual gestation?*" After Li Guan met Lan and recounted the man’s words, Lan asked: "Did he have a white mole between his brows?" Li Guan said: "He did." Lan replied: "That was Liu Haichan. I have nurtured the sacred embryo to completion, yet none but he can help me attain fruition." Li Guan then said: "Master Liu inquired of you—how does one emerge from ten months of spiritual gestation?" Lan clapped his hands and laughed heartily. Suddenly, a rumbling like distant thunder was heard from above, and a figure radiant as snow and moonlight, indistinguishable from Lan, ascended straight into the clouds. Lan had already departed. Li Guan burned incense, sighed in awe, and withdrew. This was the same Master of Long Whistles of Mount Nanyue, whose flesh-body statue remains preserved there.

*Comprehensive Mirror of Perfected Immortals Through the Ages, Scroll Forty-Eight (concluded)*
*Comprehensive Mirror of Perfected Immortals Through the Ages, Scroll Forty-Nine*

Master Hou

Master Hou—his origins unknown—peddled medicines in the capital during the Qingli era of Emperor Renzong’s reign. He appeared to be over forty, with neither beard nor brows, as though afflicted by some wind-borne malady. His body bore tumors and growths that bulged across his flesh. He wandered the streets and markets, selling his remedies, though few purchased them. Often seen half-drunk, he spent his nights among beggars.

There was a man named Ma Yuan, devoted to self-cultivation, who regarded Master Hou with deep suspicion. One day, he followed him. It was midsummer when Master Hou left, bribing the gatekeeper with several pieces of gold to enter a walled garden. From a distance, Ma Yuan watched as Master Hou reached the northwest bank of a pond, stripped off his clothes, and entered the water, diving and surfacing with evident delight. Ma Yuan drew closer and saw a toad as large as a mat, its eyes glowing like fire. Startled, he retreated. Soon after, Master Hou emerged, dressed himself, and departed. Ma Yuan bowed to him, and Master Hou laughed, saying, “Did you see me just now?” Ma Yuan replied, “Yes.” Master Hou then summoned him to a tavern and said, “I am one who ingests qi, yet I am fond of the imperial capital’s fine wine and have lingered here too long.” From his gourd, he produced a single pill and said, “Take this, and it will grant you a lifespan of a hundred years.” They drank until nightfall, then parted ways, and Master Hou was never seen again. Later, someone arrived from Shu and reported seeing Master Hou selling medicines in the market.

Zhang Jiuge

Zhang Jiuge’s origins were likewise unknown. During the Qingli era of Emperor Renzong’s reign, he was seen in the capital, wandering the streets by day and begging for alms. If he received more than he needed, he would give the excess to others. At night, he often slept in abandoned buildings or among refuse heaps. Even in the depths of winter, he wore only a single layer of cloth, his face streaked with dirt, yet many claimed he possessed the Dao.

One day, the Prince of Yan ascended a tower and saw a group of children following Zhang Jiuge along the road. The prince summoned him and asked, “Do you possess the Dao?” Zhang replied, “No.” The prince then asked, “What arts do you practice?”

He replied, “I have only learned the art of carefree living.” The prince laughed and offered him a cup of wine. Another day, they met again, and the prince gave him a jug of wine.

Over a year later, Zhang Jiuge came to the palace gate and said to the gatekeeper, “Simply tell the prince that Zhang Jiuge has come to bid him farewell.” The gatekeeper refused to announce him, so Zhang Jiuge hurried inside. The prince, hearing the commotion, summoned the gatekeeper, who explained that it was Zhang Jiuge. The prince immediately called for him, and Zhang Jiuge said, “I once received your gift of wine and am now about to travel far, so I have come to take my leave.” The prince ordered his attendants to pour wine for him. Zhang Jiuge then said, “I have a small trick I would like to perform to amuse you. May I?” The prince asked, “What trick?” Zhang Jiuge replied, “I need a bolt of silk and a pair of golden scissors.” The prince ordered that a bolt of yellow gauze and a pair of scissors be brought. Zhang Jiuge took the gauze, folded it repeatedly, and cut it into the shapes of bees and butterflies. As he cut, each took flight. In moments, the gauze was entirely gone, and the bees and butterflies numbered beyond count—some alighted on the prince’s sleeves, others clustered on the hairpins of the palace ladies, while the rest scattered and fluttered about the courtyard. The prince, astonished and delighted, watched in wonder. After a while, Zhang Jiuge said, “Lest I lose your silk, I shall call them back.” He summoned them one by one, and they returned, re-forming into the bolt of gauze. Only one corner of the silk bore a small tear, like the trace of a butterfly—one had been caught by a palace lady. The prince asked, “Can this butterfly be returned?” Zhang Jiuge replied, “No. If it had come when called, it could have, but now it is too late. Let it remain as a token of this marvel.” The prince then asked, “How long will I live?” Zhang Jiuge answered, “Your Highness’s lifespan will match the steadfastness of the pagoda at Kaibao Temple.” They drank more wine, and then he departed. Later, when the pagoda was destroyed by fire, the prince also passed away, fulfilling Zhang Jiuge’s prophecy. Afterward, he was seen in the regions of Hunan and Hubei, his bearing unchanged.

An Changqi

An Changqi was a native of Gongcheng in Zhaozhou. In his youth, he sat for the imperial examinations. During the Huangyou era of Emperor Renzong’s reign, after the court pacified Nong Zhigao and extended rewards to the two Guang regions, all those who had previously taken the examinations at the Ministry of Rites were granted a special court examination. Through this, Changqi obtained an official post as the sheriff of Yongding in Hengzhou. Later, he resigned due to some matter and never again sought office. Instead, he roamed the lands of Guangdong alone with a young servant, wandering freely among the mountains and rivers.

A fellow candidate from the same examination, Hu Jun, a native of Qujiang, served as the magistrate of Haifeng in Huizhou during the Jiayou era. Changqi visited him and stayed for quite some time. During their drinking sessions, he often performed playful tricks to amuse the company. Once, he tied several knots in a piece of paper, covered it, and recited an incantation. After a long while, the vessel began to move, and when he slowly lifted the cover, the knots had transformed into mice, gnawing and moving about as if real. When he covered them again, they reverted to their original form as knotted paper.

At times, he would chew mountain herbs and spit them out for others to see, and they would appear like sticky malt sugar. Sometimes, he would stay awake all night. On one occasion, he pointed to his servant and said to others, “Do not underestimate this boy. One day, he will accompany me in reclusion.”

In the second year of Emperor Yingzong’s Zhiping reign, Changqi again brought his servant to travel to Xia Shan Temple in Qingyuan County, Guangzhou. He said to the monks, “I have long heard of the Harmonious Light Cave on Xia Shan and have come to visit.” He then set off with his servant and did not return for several days. The monks suspected they had been devoured by tigers and led several monks and servants to search everywhere, but found no trace of them. Before the cave, they saw a poem inscribed on the stone wall:

*I bid farewell to the orchid tent,*
*The apes refrain from mournful cries.*
*With zither and books, I find my joy,*
*Who among friends would vie for ties?*
*Though elixirs for red turtles exist,*
*A ladder to blue clouds lies apart.*
*On Xia Shan I briefly dwell—*
*None may compare to Boyi and Shuqi.*

Below it was written: *Inscribed by An Changqi, former magistrate of Yongding County, Hengzhou.*

**Daoist Chen Jingyuan**
Daoist Chen Jingyuan, styled Taixu, with the teacher’s name Zhenjing, called himself Bixuzi. A native of Nancheng in Jianchang, he studied under Daoist Han Zhizhi of Gaoyou. Later, he left his teacher and traveled to Tiantai Mountain, where he met Master Hongmeng, Zhang Wumeng, who transmitted secret arts to him. From childhood, he read voraciously and never tired of learning even in old age. He personally collated and transcribed all Daoist texts, dedicating years to the task. Initially, he traveled to the capital and resided at Li Quan Abbey, where the community invited him to lecture. Emperor Shenzong of Song, having heard of his reputation, ordered a grand *jiao* ritual to be held there and commanded him to compose *qingci* hymns for presentation. Upon submission, the emperor praised them and summoned him to an audience at Tianzhang Pavilion, bestowing upon him his current teacher’s name. He was also granted a change of ceremonial robes and promoted to Vice Daoist Registrar of the Left and Right Streets.

In the *jimao* year, he petitioned to return to Mount Lu to bury his parents. The emperor granted him silver to assist in the endeavor. His luggage contained nothing else—one hundred bundles were all classics of history and philosophy. In his residence, he separated Daoist, Confucian, and medical texts into distinct halls, and when scholars from all directions came to study under him, he assigned them to halls matching their disciplines, engaging in rigorous discussion. Thus, each person could fully pursue their learning. He employed two servants, named Huangjing and Gouqi, who were docile and untroublesome—truly the attendants of a man of the Dao.

The ministers Wang Anshi and Wang Gui enjoyed his company. When Jingyuan first returned to Mount Lu, he bid farewell to Anshi, who asked the reason for his departure. Jingyuan replied, “I am but a rustic, yet now I bear official duties, with bureaucratic responsibilities and suspicions at every turn. It would be better to return to Mount Lu.” Anshi recorded his words on his desk:

*An official’s duties weigh heavy,*
*Each matter invites suspicion’s gaze.*
*My wild nature cannot endure this—*
*To Mount Lu I return, away.*

He later added: *Zhenjing spoke thus.*

Jingyuan excelled in regular script, modeling his work after Wang Xizhi’s *Yue Yi Lun* and *Huangting Jing*, as well as Ouyang Xun’s *Huadu Temple Stele*. At seventy, he bathed, changed his clothes, uttered a final phrase, let out a long whistle, and passed away seated upright. His words were:

*Once I entrusted to harmony,*
*Now I shed this form.*
*Neither transformed nor born anew,*
*I return to my true abode.*

The world then realized he had undergone *shijie* (corporeal liberation). His extant works include a two-volume commentary on the *Dao De Jing*, a two-volume *Collected Essentials of Laozi’s Treasury*, a ten-volume commentary on *Zhuangzi*, a hundred-volume *Biographies of Eminent Recluses*, a twenty-volume literary collection, *Pronunciation and Meaning of the Great Cavern Scripture*, and *Collected Commentaries on the Scripture of Salvation through the Numinous Treasure*.

**Liu Xuanying**
Liu Xuanying, styled Zongcheng, was called Haichanzi. Originally named Cao, styled Zhaoyuan, he later changed his name upon attaining the Dao. A native of Guangling in Yan territory (some say of the Great Liao), he passed the imperial examinations in classics and served as prime minister to Liu Shouguang, ruler of Yan. Fond of theories on nature and destiny, he revered the teachings of the Yellow Emperor and Laozi. One day, a Daoist arrived for an audience. Haichan invited him to sit in the main hall and treated him with the courtesy due a guest. When asked his name and lineage, the Daoist did not respond, only calling himself Zhengyangzi. Haichan humbly sought his instruction, and the Daoist expounded on the principles of purity and non-action, as well as the essentials of the Golden Elixir of midnight return.

After finishing, the Daoist requested ten goose eggs and ten copper coins. Placing one coin on the table, he stacked the eggs atop it like a pagoda. Haichan marveled and exclaimed, “How precarious!” The Daoist replied, “For one dwelling in the realm of honor and emolument, treading the ground of woe and peril, the danger is far greater than this.” He then took all the coins, split them in two, and tossed them aside before departing. Haichan was profoundly awakened.

That night, he ordered his household to prepare a feast and discarded his gold and jade. The next morning, he resigned his seal, left the court, and donned Daoist robes. He wrote a poem:

*I cast off the burning house of three thousand fingers,*
*Dismissed the ten thousand households of armed guards.*
*—A record of what transpired then.*

One day, he abruptly left Yan territory, drifting far to the Qin River. He refined the Elixir before Mount Taihua and concealed himself near Zhongnan, his light veiled and hidden, so none could fathom his whereabouts. (Some say he was prime minister of Yan and suddenly awakened one day, abandoning his office to study the Dao.) Later, he met Lü Dongbin and received the secret instructions of the Golden Elixir. Thereafter, he traveled between Zhongnan and Taihua. He also befriended Zhang Wumeng and Zhong Fang, visiting Master Chen Tuan as a fellow of the unseen world. He composed poetry, and his collections circulated in the world. His verses on cultivation, such as the *Returning Gold Chapter*, also spread widely.

Later, he secluded himself on Phoenix Mountain in Daizhou. In the ninth year of Emperor Renzong’s Tiansheng era, he journeyed through famous mountains, leaving traces wherever he went. One day, at Shouning Abbey in the prefecture, he inscribed ten old poems, including:

*Drunk, I stride through white clouds,*
*Brandishing a bronze tail upside-down.*
*Leading a green-eyed servant,*
*He shoulders a slender gourd.*
*I speak of affairs from the Qin era,*
*My home by Ge Hong’s well.*
*Not reading the Yellow Court Scripture,*
*How could I tend the Dragon-Tiger Crucible?*
*Standing alone in the city’s midst,*
*Unsought by the vulgar.*
*I wish to take my thunderbolt zither,*
*And ascend Lotus Peak.*

Amidst the azure heavens, he bought ten oxen, tilled half a *qing* of streamside fields. Planting groves to brew cloud-white wine—all was the realm of immortals. Drunk, he lay beneath pine shade, idly crossed White Cloud Ridge. To go was to go at once, straight into the glow of autumn’s rosy mist.

There, he painted his own likeness beside it, gathered his robes to inscribe four characters: *Tortoise and Crane Together Live Long*. He signed: *"Liu, Idle Citizen of Guangling."* When he came to Phoenix Mountain’s Laiyi Abbey, he again painted his portrait, brushing in flying-white script the four characters: *Pure Peace, Fortune, Longevity*. Of the Five Stars he depicted, only the Earth Mansion remained. In his self-portrait, he wore a loose headscarf and yellow robe, a wine gourd slung from his right shoulder, a cloth sack dangling from his left—patched where threadbare, his bearing serene, his words unhurried. Those who saw it knew at once he was a man of the Dao.

Once, at Chengdu’s Green Ram Abbey, he splashed ink to form the four characters: *Longevity Mountain, Fortune Sea*. Though the two sites lay far apart—Shouning to Laiyi barely two stages, while Western Shu to Daizhou spanned thousands of *li*—he inscribed them at the same hour, demonstrating the marvel of divided form and scattered radiance, the boundless transformations of spirit.

When his elixir was complete, his corpse dissolved in liberation: a white mist rose from his crown, transmuting into a crane that soared heavenward. The *Complete Perfection Tradition* records: he descended to the world on the twenty-fourth day of the twelfth month, ascended on the twenty-seventh day of the eleventh month. The year is unrecorded. In the sixth year of the Zhiyuan era of the Great Yuan, he was posthumously enfeoffed as *Illuminated Awakening, Vast Dao Perfected Lord*. Zhang Yongcheng—Zhang Boduan, a man of Tiantai.

In his youth, he studied everything under heaven, wandering like clouds and water along the shores. In later years, though he had received the teachings of the Primordial Dao, they remained incomplete, so he diligently sought instruction, journeying across the four directions. In the second year of the Xining era of Emperor Shenzong of the Song, when Academician Lu Gongtan was stationed in Yidu, Zhang followed him to Shu. There he encountered Liu Haichan, who transmitted to him the oral instructions on the firing times of the Golden Elixir and the Reverted Cinnabar. Thus he changed his name to Yongcheng, styled himself Pingshu, and took the sobriquet Ziyang. After his cultivation bore fruit, he composed the *Awakening to Reality*, which circulated in the world.

Once, there was a monk who practiced the precepts, concentration, and wisdom, believing himself to have attained the supreme essence of Chan. He could enter samādhi and project his spirit, covering hundreds of *li* in an instant. One day, he met Ziyang, and their aspirations harmonized. Ziyang asked, “Can the Chan master accompany me on a journey to a distant place today?” The monk replied, “Certainly.” Ziyang said, “I shall follow your command.” The monk said, “Let us go together to Yangzhou to see the jade flower.” Ziyang agreed.

Thereupon, Ziyang and the monk sat facing each other in a narrow chamber, closing their eyes in cross-legged meditation, both projecting their spirits. No sooner had Ziyang arrived at the place than the monk had already preceded him, circling the flower three times. Ziyang said, “Today, having come here with the Chan master, let each of us pluck a flower as a token.” The monk and Ziyang each plucked a flower and returned. After a short while, Ziyang and the monk stretched and awoke. Ziyang asked, “Chan master, where is your jade flower?” The monk’s sleeves were empty, but Ziyang held the jade flower in his hand, and they laughed as they examined it. Ziyang said, “Nowadays, those who study Chan or cultivate immortality—people like the two of us—are rarely seen. From this day forth, Ziyang and the monk became the closest of friends.

Later, a disciple asked Ziyang, “That Chan master and our teacher both projected your spirits to the same place. Why was there a difference in plucking the flower?” Ziyang replied, “My Great Dao of the Golden Elixir unites both nature and life, so when it gathers, it forms a body, and when it scatters, it becomes *qi*. Wherever it goes, the true spirit manifests in form—this is called the *yang* spirit. His cultivation, however, sought quick results, neglecting the refinement of life and focusing solely on the cultivation of nature. Thus, wherever he went, no form or shadow was seen—this is called the *yin* spirit.”

The disciple said, “Understood.”

Ziyang often said, “The Daoist school establishes its teachings on the foundation of life, so it speaks in detail of life and briefly of nature. The Buddhist school establishes its teachings on the foundation of nature, so it speaks in detail of nature and briefly of life. Yet nature and life are originally inseparable, and Daoism and Buddhism are fundamentally the same. That Śākyamuni was born in the Western lands—he too attained the Dao of the Golden Elixir, uniting nature and life, which is the supreme Dharma. Thus he was called the Golden Immortal, Fu Dashi. A poem says:

*For what reason did he sit on Snow Mountain for six years?*
*Only to harmonize* qi *and spirit.*
*In a hundred moments, one breath—*
*Then you know the Great Dao is the whole body.*

Zhongli Quanyang also said, ‘Bodhidharma faced the wall for nine years before transcending the inner court; the World-Honored One meditated in stillness for six years before emerging from the mundane cage.’ From this, it is clear that Śākyamuni united nature and life, yet his projection of the *yin* spirit in samādhi was merely the practice of the Two Vehicles in seated meditation. Alas, his spirit belonged to *yin*, its dwelling unstable, requiring constant migration. A single misguided thought, and it would penetrate another’s spirit, entering a different womb—how then could Buddhahood be attained? This is precisely what our tradition calls the fifth rank of *gui* immortals.

The *gui* immortal is the lowest of the five immortals. Though it transcends within *yin*, its spirit lacks clarity, its ghostly gate has no name, and the Three Mountains bear no record of it. Though it does not enter the cycle of rebirth, it can scarcely return to Penglai or Yingzhou, ultimately having no place to go but to seize another’s body or enter a new womb. Those who cultivate in this way, failing to awaken to the Great Dao at the outset, seek quick results. Their bodies are like withered wood, their minds like dead ashes, their consciousness turned inward, their will undivided. In samādhi, they project a *yin* spirit—a ghost of pure numinosity, not a true *yang* immortal. Because their will remains undivided, their *yin* spirit does not scatter, hence the name *gui* immortal. Though called an immortal, it is in truth a ghost. Thus, the divine immortals do not recognize it.

Śākyamuni also said, ‘Only by the Buddha Vehicle can one attain extinction; there is no other vehicle.’ And again, ‘In the world, there is no second vehicle by which one attains extinction—only the single Buddha Vehicle can achieve it.’ Śākyamuni’s rejection of the Two Vehicles is the same as our tradition’s rejection of *gui* immortals. Alas, people’s capacities and measures differ, which is why the Buddhist school speaks of the Three Vehicles, and the Daoist school distinguishes five ranks of immortals and three thousand six hundred side doors.

Zhongli the Perfected said:
*Three thousand six hundred wondrous gates,*
*Each disciple clings to one as root.*
*Who knows the little secret of divine immortality*
*Lies beyond those three thousand six hundred doors?*

This is precisely what Śākyamuni meant by ‘Only by the single Buddha Vehicle can one attain extinction.’

Another account states: During the Zhiping era of Emperor Yingzong, Academician Lu Gong was appointed military governor of Guilin. He summoned Ziyang to his headquarters to manage confidential affairs. When Lu was transferred to another post, Ziyang followed him. Finally, when Lu passed away in Chengdu, Ziyang wandered to Qin and Long. After a long time, he served Ma Mo, styled Chuhou, in Hedong.

When Chuhou was summoned to court and about to depart, Ziyang presented him with the *Wuzhen Pian* (*Awakening to Reality*), saying: "All that I have learned in my life is contained herein. I hope you will circulate this book, for there may be those who, through it, will grasp its meaning." Later, when Chuhou was appointed Intendant of the Guangnan Transport Circuit, Ziyang again accompanied him on his travels.

On the fifteenth day of the third month in the fifth year of the Yuanfeng era, he sat cross-legged and passed away, having lived ninety-nine years. A verse on his liberation through the corpse (*shijie*) reads:
*The four great elements dissolve,*
*Floating clouds now void.*
*The wondrous One remains,*
*Permeating the Dharma realm.*

A devoted Chan disciple cremated his body, yielding hundreds and thousands of *śarīra* relics—some as large as *ying* seeds, all shimmering in emerald and gold. When his disciples arrived, he pointed to them and said: "These are what the Daoist texts call *śarīra* gleaming with golden splendor."

Seven years later, Liu Fengzhen encountered Ziyang on Wangwu Mountain, where he left behind a poem before departing.

During the Zhenghe era of Emperor Huizong, Ziyang once announced his name and sought an audience with Minister Huang Mianzhang of Yanping. Huang had long transmitted the Way of Rongcheng and was deeply devoted to alchemy, though he was already advanced in years. Their conversation failed to resonate, and Ziyang left. Later, he sent a letter to Huang, recounting extraordinary matters.

His grandson Quan saw the letter but kept its contents secret, revealing little. In broad strokes, Ziyang claimed that in a former life, both he and Huang had dwelled in the Purple Tenuity Heavenly Palace as the Nine August Perfected Ones. Due to an error in collating the registers of kalpic destinies, they were banished to the human realm. Of those visible in the celestial wall today, only six stars remain—three others lie concealed in radiant obscurity: Yongcheng, Mianzhong, and Master Wei-Yang. Yongcheng was the Perfected Man of Purple Yang, Mianzhong was called Purple Origin, and Master Yu was known as Purple Splendor. All the officials once banished with them have already returned to the Pure Capital, while Yongcheng has further attained the rank of immortal. Only Mianzhong remains mired in the sea of officialdom, destined to be reborn among men for ten lifetimes—nine of which have now passed. Should he persist in delusion and be bound again to the dust in his next life, he will sink into a different realm of existence, with no hope of ascension. Ziyang, moved by their former bond as immortals, strove to deliver him, yet Huang ultimately failed to awaken. Upon his death, he was merely called the Old Man of Purple Origin.

The Nine August Ones are not recorded in the heavenly palaces—they are but faint stars. Ziyang had many disciples, among them the Daoist of White Dragon Grotto, Liu the Perfected, whose name was Fengzhen. He ascended in broad daylight, and was none other than Liu Douzi of Jiankang Prefecture.

As for Ma Ziran, his origins remain unknown.

In his youth, Ma Ziran practiced the methods of cultivating truth and refining qi. At the age of sixty-four, he arrived at a wineshop in Jianchang, where he encountered four Daoist adepts. Though their robes were patched a hundred times, their bearing was majestic. A youth stood beside them, and Ziran inquired after their names. They replied: "Master Zhongli, Master Lü, Liu Haichan, and Chen Qizi." Ziran was greatly astonished and hurried forward to bow before them.

Perfected Zhongli said: "Your bone and qi are unlike those of ordinary men. For decades, I have sought one worthy of instruction, yet none compare to you." Soon after, he departed with Masters Lü and Chen, saying: "You have found your teacher." Only Haichan remained, and he revealed to Ziran the secrets of the Golden Elixir, saying:

"In the profound and obscure, there is essence.
In the vague and indistinct, there is substance.
This substance is no ordinary substance;
This essence is no ordinary essence.
Heaven attains it and becomes clear;
Earth attains it and becomes tranquil;
Man attains it and becomes numinous.
One who can embrace the Origin and guard the One,
Turn the Celestial Gate and revolve the Earth’s Axis,
Will cause yin and yang to unite and Qian and Kun to merge.

Thus, open the gates of Kan and Li,
Let dragon and tiger devour one another,
Enter the transformations of Wu and Ji—
This is the numinous treasure of the highest heavens,
The subtlety within subtlety.

This method is within reach of all,
Yet most are blinded by ignorance and dulled by desire,
Sunk in the mire of love and craving.
Some grasp it yet fail to penetrate its depths:
They sit in breathless solitude, fixating the spirit into delusion;
They swallow saliva to moisten the throat,
Practice daoyin to exhaust the body,
Fast to the point of inner collapse,
Or expel and absorb qi to invite wind and evil.
Externally, they waste themselves refining lead and mercury;
Internally, they debauch themselves with yin elixirs.
Thus, their center remains unrefined, their spirit unpreserved.
From vigor they hasten to old age,
From old age to death—
Swift as six steeds racing through a crack in the wall.
How lamentable!

You must seek essence in the profound and obscure,
Seek substance in the vague and indistinct,
So that form and spirit penetrate one another,
And you merge with the Dao in truth."

Ziran heard his words and took him as his teacher, thereby attaining the Way. Later, he wandered to Mount Lu, where he slept soundly upon a rock for over sixty days. A passerby, seeing him, was startled and woke him. Soon after, he departed, entering Mount Hezao, ascending the Purple Chamber, and visiting the Realm of Pure Emptiness.

At times, he would wander the market streets, clad in a straw raincoat, wearing a bamboo hat and conical hat, carrying a large iron ladle to beg for coins. He bought wine, and when drunk, roamed freely among the mountains and marshes. Later, his whereabouts became unknown.

Shi Tai
Shi Tai was a native of Changzhou. His courtesy name was Dezhi, and his sobriquets were Yaolin and Cuixuanzi. He encountered Zhang Ziyang and obtained the Way of the Golden Elixir. Initially, Ziyang had received the Dao from Liu Haichan, who said: "One day, if someone removes your official seals and shackles for you, you shall transmit this Way to them; I permit no others." Later, Ziyang transmitted it to three unworthy recipients and suffered three calamities. He swore never to recklessly transmit it again and composed the *Awakening to Reality*, circulating it in the world, saying: "If those with innate immortal temperament and Daoist bones read it and awaken on their own, it is as if Heaven itself has bestowed it—this is no reckless transmission by man."

Midway, he incurred the wrath of the Prefect of Fengzhou, who pressed charges against him, leading to his imprisonment. Exiled, he passed through the region of He, where a great snow fell. He drank wine with his escorts in a village tavern.

In the depths of the forest, he came upon a tavern. After exchanging bows, they took their seats, and he was invited to join the others at their table. Gazing around with a smile, he saw that the guests were already merry. One of them had not yet begun to drink, so he said, "Why not come and join us?" Thus they drank together, and as the wine flowed freely, he was asked the reason for his journey. He told them everything in full. Reflecting on this, Yaolin said, "Prefect Deng is an old friend of mine. He delights in virtue and forgets rank, and would not think a thousand *li* too far to come to my aid. Since there is now a reason, this journey may yet be spared." Ziyang earnestly entreated his escorts to permit this, and they agreed. Together they traveled to He. Yaolin went ahead to see the Prefect, and through this meeting, Ziyang was spared. Grateful for this kindness, Ziyang said, "If I do not repay this debt, how can I be called a man? You have studied the Dao all your life but have never heard its true teachings. Now I shall transmit the method of the Elixir to you." Yaolin bowed in thanks and reverently received the transmission, devoting himself to diligent cultivation. When his Dao was accomplished, he composed the *Returning to the Origin* and circulated it in the world. He lived to the age of one hundred and thirty-seven and achieved *shijie* on the fifteenth day of the eighth month in the twenty-eighth year of the Shaoxing reign of Emperor Gaozong of the Song. He left behind a verse:

*Thunder cracks the mud-pellet cave of the skull,*
*The true body rides the fire-dragon.*
*Who knows who struck the blow—*
*Shattering the great void of empty space.*

Two years later, Yi Jie once again saw Yaolin on Mount Luofu.

---

**Xue Daoguang**
Xue Daoguang, also named Shi, and also named Daoyuan, was a native of Yingzushan in Shanfu. Some say he was from Guizhou and styled Taiyuan. He had once been a monk, with the Dharma name Zixian, and was also called the Venerable Master of Biling. Wandering as a cloud, he stayed at Kai Fu Temple in Chang’an, where he studied under the elder Xiuyan. Yan posed a question to test his Daoist insight: "Before the golden rooster crows, how can there be no sound?" He also studied under the monk Ruhuan, who asked, "What is the talk that transcends Buddhas and Patriarchs?" The answer—"A sesame cake, round and full"—struck him like a bitter plum, and he suddenly awakened. He composed a verse:

*The creaking follows the sound,*
*Yet when it arises, it does not come from another.*
*Suddenly, he knew with clarity:*
*The withered branch sings the song of no-birth,*
*The mud-snake in the well dances with a broken branch.*

The two elders affirmed his realization. From then on, he thoroughly awakened to the supreme, perfectly luminous, and true essential Dharma. His responses were swift and incisive, and he was equally versed in both Chan teachings and doctrinal exegesis. Moreover, he had a refined interest in the Golden Elixir and the cultivation of life. In the winter of the fifth year of the Chongning reign of Emperor Huizong of the Song (the year *bingxu*), he was staying in Qing Town of Na County, listening to a Buddhist lecture at a temple. There he encountered Yaolin of Fufeng County in Fengxiang Prefecture and Shi Tai, styled Dezhi, a posthouse attendant, who was then eighty-five years old. Though advanced in years, his complexion was rosy, and his spirit and bearing were extraordinary. At night, he sewed his own clothes. Zixian found him remarkable and happened to recite a poem by Zhang Pingshu. Shi replied with delight, "Do you know this man? He is my teacher." He recounted in full how Ziyang had transmitted the Dao. Zixian then bowed in reverence and took refuge, requesting to become his disciple. In the end, he studied the Returning Elixir, receiving the oral transmission of its true essentials. Shi cautioned him to go to a bustling metropolis and rely on those of means to accomplish this. Zixian then came to the capital, cast off his monk’s robes, and donned a scholar’s turban and gown. Veiling his light, he blended with the world and single-mindedly pursued this endeavor. He annotated the *Awakening to Reality*, composed the *Restoring Life* and the *Song of the Elixir Marrow*, and circulated them in the world. When Zixian’s Dao was accomplished, he lived to the age of one hundred and fourteen and achieved *shijie* on the ninth day of the ninth month in the second year of the Shaoxi reign of Emperor Guangzong. He left behind a verse:

*The iron horse gallops into the sea,*
*The mud-snake soars into the sky.*
*The path to the three isles of Penglai—*
*Originally, it was not in the west.*

The following year, Sha Daozhao again saw Zixian on Mount Huotong.

---

**Chen Nan**
Chen Nan, styled Nanmu and known as Cuixu, was a native of Baishuiyan in Boluo County, Huizhou.

Chen Nan made his living by crafting coiled trays and bucket hoops, drifting among the common folk, unknown to others. He composed the *Song of the Coiled Tray* and the *Song of the Bucket Hoop*.

The *Song of the Coiled Tray* reads:
*All day it coils, round and round,*
*At its heart, earth holds the honored place.*
*How much grinding and turning it endures—*
*Yet within, no trace of axe or chisel remains.*

The *Song of the Bucket Hoop* reads:
*The leaky teaches the leakless,*
*Yet how does the water flow through?*
*Once perfectly sealed and whole,*
*Within and without, all is true emptiness.*

Such was the sudden awakening in his words—his spiritual capacity may well be imagined. Later, he received the *Taiyi Daogui Golden Elixir Method* from the Venerable Master of Biling, and the *Jingxiao Great Thunder Jade Book* from the divine being of Limu Mountain. Whenever people sought talismanic water, Cuixu would knead earth and give it to them, and many illnesses were cured, so people called him "Chen Mud-Pill."

During the Zhenghe era of Emperor Huizong of the Song, he was appointed *Tiju* of the Daoist Records Bureau. Later, he returned to Luofu Mountain and propagated his Daoist arts in the world. Wherever he went, he exorcised spirits for people. In Chaoyang, a family’s daughter suffered from fox possession, her madness unchecked. Cuixu used a thunder talisman to slay the black fox demon. At times, he would let his hair down and run, covering four or five hundred *li* in a day. His clothes were tattered and patched, his body caked with dust and grime.

He would eat dog meat and drink to utter drunkenness all day, his whereabouts unfathomable. Yet he aided people and benefited creatures, with effects too numerous to recount. Once in Cangwu, when the prefecture prayed for rain amid drought, people feared death from heatstroke. Cuixu descended into the deep pool wielding an iron whip, driving the dragon forth. In an instant, dark clouds gathered on all sides, thunder and rain clashed, and the land received ample moisture, yielding a bountiful harvest. Passing by Sanda’s Dayi Ford, where the torrential currents raged and no boats dared cross, Cuixu floated across on his bamboo hat. While traveling on the road to Qin and Guan, he encountered a band of robbers who beat and left him for dead. Three days later, the robbers dispersed, and he revived. In Changsha, the military commissioner arrested and sent him to Yongzhou. Within a few nights, he returned to Changsha. At midnight, he would sit and swallow mercury, and by the next morning, he would spit it out as silver. He would give it to his disciples but pay it no further heed.

Cuixu often claimed to have lived forty-three years, yet there were those who had seen him across four generations. People in Huguang would ask him for poems, and verses would flow from his mouth in perfect coherence, though he refused to write them down himself, leaving the reason forever unexplained. His *Miaowu Complete Collection* circulated in the world, as did his *Luofu Cuixu’s Chants*. He transmitted his elixir methods to Qiongshan’s Bai Yuchan, who always attended him in his comings and goings.

In the sixth year of Emperor Ningzong’s Jiading era—some say the fourth year—on the fourteenth day of the fourth month, Cuixu attended the Crane Assembly in Zhangzhou. He told the assembly’s host, “I shall perform a corpse-liberation within this gathering.” The host took it lightly. Cuixu then left four lines, instructing Bai Yuchan to inscribe them:

*Thunder crashes atop my crown,*
*Chaos falls to earth without a trace.*
*Today I find the path and go,*
*Riding a hornless fire-dragon.*

At the time, Bai Yuchan was in attendance at Liangshan in Zhangzhou. Cuixu entered the water with an old man carrying a wooden bucket, leaning on a chair’s corner, and vanished. The old man had left an axe on the ground earlier; when they searched for it again, the axe was gone as well. Bai Yuchan sighed, “This is a water-liberation.” That same day, a magistrate named Ge in Tanzhou’s Ningxiang County saw him. Cuixu had long been close with the magistrate’s father and sent a letter with him to deliver to his father in Chaozhou. Only later did they realize that on that day, he had performed corpse-liberation here while appearing there.

Cuixu transmitted the Dao to three disciples: Ju Jiusi, Sha Dianxu, and Bai Yuchan. Master Bai Yuchan’s surname was Bai. His mother named him Yuchan after a dream, and his courtesy names were Yuezhongfu and Ruhui. His family was originally from Min, but as his grandfather had served in Qiongzhou, he was born in Hainan. Thus, he styled himself Haiqiongzi, or “Master of the Hainan Sea,” or Hainan Ye, “Old Man of Hainan,” or Qiongshan Daoren, “Daoist of Qiong Mountain,” or Pin’an, or Wuyi Sanren, “Wanderer of Mount Wuyi,” or Shenxiao Sanli, “Scattered Clerk of the Divine Empyrean.” From childhood, he excelled in the imperial examinations, but in adulthood, he wandered beyond the world and received the Dao of Cuixu, Master Chen Mud-Pill. At the time, scholar-officials wished to recommend him for special recruitment, but he declined.

After attaining the Dao, he subsisted on vegetables and abstained from grains for nine full years, yet scholars from all directions flocked to him like hairs on an ox. As for the broad outlines of his comings and goings, the general scope of his writings and teachings, and the numinous and wondrous aspects of his conduct—these are all recorded in various texts.

Initially, Master Bai served Master Cuixu for nine years before receiving his Dao. Whenever Master Cuixu wandered beyond the world, he was always accompanied by Master Bai. After Master Cuixu shed his mortal form in Linzhang, Master Bai then traveled alone among the mountains of Luofu, Huotong, Wuyi, Longhu, Tiantai, Jinhua, and Jiuri. Though his hair was unkempt, his feet bare, and his sleeves tattered, his spirit remained clear and his qi vibrant, no different from a youth in his prime. He delighted in wine but was never seen drunk. Well-versed in Confucian texts, he thoroughly grasped Chan principles. His words flowed as finished compositions, his writing unmarred by corrections. Though he carried no paper on his person, his brushstrokes filled the land. His large cursive script appeared as if dragons and serpents danced across the page. Skilled in seal and clerical scripts, he was especially adept at plum and bamboo paintings, though he rarely practiced them. When asked to depict his own likeness, he would complete it in a few strokes—no professional artist could match his skill.

Having received the Shangqing registers, he performed the rituals of the various ranks, with his mastery of the Great Thunder of the Capital Heaven being most renowned. The thunder seal he used was always kept at his elbow. Wherever he went to pray or perform exorcisms, extraordinary responses invariably followed. His timely pronouncements on fortune and misfortune startled even the deaf and vulgar. His name reached the imperial court, and though offered imperial favors for his reclusive cultivation, he merely smiled and declined. Those who wished to follow him in his wanderings were never granted the opportunity.

Once, while in the capital and strolling by West Lake, he fell into the water at dusk. The boatman was greatly alarmed and searched the lake in circles, but Master Bai was nowhere to be found. By dawn, however, he was seen upon the water, still slightly tipsy. On another day, a man wielding a blade pursued and threatened him. Master Bai rebuked him, and the assailant dropped his weapon and fled. Master Bai called out, “Come back, do not be afraid,” and promptly returned the blade to him. The people of the capital spoke of him as one who entered water without getting wet and encountered weapons without harm.

Later, he roamed freely among famous mountains, and none knew his whereabouts. Liu Houcun’s preface to *Wang Yinliu’s Nine Books on Learning* claims that Bai died young, which is incorrect. Some say he achieved liberation by means of the corpse in Haifeng County.

**Peng Si**
Peng Si, styled Jiyi, hailed from a prominent family of Sanshan that had produced generations of high officials. From his youth, he was renowned for his literary talent. After passing the mid-level imperial examinations, he remained indifferent to officialdom.

Having served Master Hai Qiong, Bai Yuchan, he received the transmission of the Supreme Unity’s *daogui* fire talismans, the writings on the Nine Cauldrons’ golden lead and cinnabar mercury, and the *Zixiao* texts on summoning wind and thunder. Returning home, he composed the *Ode to Crane Grove*, and later wrote a poem:

*I bought a leaf-like boat on Luo River—*
*glory and rank melt like wax, ah, let them go.*
*No trailing tail to beg for pity,*
*I early resolved to be ash-hearted, no schemes for office.*
*I’ve learned to plow White Marsh like Zhuangzi,*
*content to wait for the green ox like Lord Guan.*
*What use is the daogui? Who would understand?*
*Only the bright moon and clear wind nod in approval.*

At his residence, Crane Grove Retreat, he daily delighted his mind with the teachings of Confucius and Laozi. Using talismans to treat illnesses, he saved many lives. The local gentry, upon witnessing this, repeatedly urged him to enter officialdom, but his resolve remained unshaken. Yet his learning was vast and profound, his aspirations lofty and pure—surpassing even the filial and incorrupt of ancient times. When those in power sought to recommend him to the court as a reclusive worthy, he demurred and declined. Thenceforth, he shut his door all day, severing all social ties. Matters of livelihood and family scarcely crossed his mind. His wife, Pan Ruizhu, shared his resolve, and from dawn to dusk, they devoted themselves solely to cultivation. When Peng Si felt inspired, he would compose poetry or drink wine, always drinking to profound intoxication before stopping. If ghosts or spirits afflicted someone, he would cure them with cinnabar talismans, and they would recover. His deep immersion in the Daoist arts, his ability to summon wind and thunder with a whistle, earned him widespread admiration. Later, he achieved liberation by means of the corpse in Fuzhou. Today, Phoenix Hill’s Crane Grove Abbey still stands east of the city.

**Zhu Ju**
Zhu Ju, styled Cuiyang, was born into a family from Wangjiang in Anqing, Huai West, though his ancestors had left no mark on their era. At his birth, his mother, Madam Yan, dreamed of swallowing a star as large and bright as a bushel. After fifteen months of pregnancy, she grew anxious. One day, she encountered a Daoist at her doorstep holding an object like an orange. The Daoist said, “Eat this, and your child will be born.” Overjoyed, she accepted it. When she asked his name, the Daoist produced a fan from his sleeve, upon which were written the characters *Ju Junzi* (“Master Orange”). “That is my name,” he said. With that, he vanished. Soon after, Zhu Ju was born, on the twenty-sixth day of the eleventh lunar month in the *renxu* year. His father, struck by the marvel, named him *Juzi* (“Orange Child”). By the age of six, he had lost both parents. Gifted and intelligent from birth, Zhu Ju aspired to Confucian scholarship, excelling especially in the *Book of Changes* and numerology. He believed the mysteries of alchemical transformation were fully contained therein. Twice he passed the provincial examinations but never realized his ambition for the imperial degree.

Delighted by the study of Daoist and Buddhist scriptures, Zhu Ju later gazed at his reflection by the water’s edge and was suddenly struck with enlightenment. From that moment, he scorned fame and profit, yearning instead for cultivation and refinement. Wherever he traveled, he would ascend renowned mountains and scenic sites, ever seeking a master to guide him into the Dao.

In the *wuzi* year, he journeyed to Boluo in Hui Prefecture. One day, amid the dust of the road, he encountered a Daoist who clutched an orange, his manner wild as if mad. Singing and laughing as he walked, the Daoist chanted:
*“Orange, orange, orange—none know its worth.
Only one surnamed Zhu shall grasp its truth.”*
The crowd was astonished, none understanding his meaning. Zhu Ju alone felt a stirring within and followed him to a secluded spot beyond the outskirts. There, he bowed and asked, “Are you not the True Man Ju Junzi?”

The Daoist started in surprise. “Who are you?”
Zhu Ju gave his name, and the Daoist suddenly recalled the events of years past. “What is it you truly desire?” he asked. “Wealth or rank—choose either, and I shall grant it.”
Zhu Ju smiled and replied, “Worldly wealth and rank are like vomit upon the sea or clouds in the sky—gathering and scattering without constancy. But I have heard that the immortals possess the secret of eternal life, the marvel of bone-transformation and the return of yang. Might I be permitted to hear of this?”

The Daoist fell silent, offering no answer. Zhu Ju wept and pleaded again, “By past-life fortune, I have met a transcendent master. Though I am foolish and unworthy, I beg you to bestow your illumination.”
The Daoist then spoke to him, saying, “The breath—it is the self’s heart, the primordial *qi*, the root of emptiness and the master of creation. Its rising and falling, its parting and merging, all arise from the heart. The reason beings lose their original nature, revolving through the six paths and drifting among the four births, is their failure to comprehend this heart. Thus, the ancient immortals and sages sought only to make people understand this heart. To understand the heart is to see one’s own nature; to see one’s own nature is to be not far from sagehood. If this heart remains unenlightened, it is not the wondrous Dao of supreme, perfect awakening.”

At these words, Zhu Ju was as if lost in a daze. The Daoist then pointed to a great boulder before the mountain and instructed him to return at dawn the next day, saying, “I shall then deliver you.” Zhu Ju went repeatedly, but the Daoist was already seated upon the stone. “Why are you late?” he asked. Zhu Ju, ashamed, apologized and withdrew. When he returned at midnight, the Daoist said, “Now is the time for your coming.”

There, beneath heaven and earth, they swore a solemn pact. The Daoist imparted to him the secrets of the nine cauldrons, the elixir knife, the fire talismans, the texts of the Five Thunders and the Jade Script, the methods of the Nine-Eight Flying Spirit Yang Dao, and the oral transmissions of the heart-mind. He charged Zhu Ju to build a hut on Mount Wankong and cultivate according to these teachings. “Later, a child will come to you,” he said. “You must transmit the Dao to him, that he may succeed you. Grant this to no other.” When his work was complete, the Daoist promised to sponsor his ascent to the heavens.

Zhu Ju bowed in gratitude. The Daoist then rose upon the clouds and slowly departed. This Daoist was none other than Ju Junzi, the same who had appeared to Zhu Ju’s mother, and his style was Jiuxia. Jiuxia’s own master was Chen Niuwan of Cuixu.

Zhu Ju reverently followed his instructions, entering Mount Wankong to build a hut and cultivate. Later, those who climbed the mountain saw a child, pure and white as jade, washing his hands by the Wanshui River before the hut. His movements were swift as a shooting star. When they followed him into the hut, he vanished without a trace, leaving only Zhu Ju seated solemnly within. All declared that the child was Zhu Ju’s manifestation in infant form.

Later, troubled by bandits, Zhu Ju entered Min and traveled to Boluo in Hui Prefecture. There, a fellow townsman named Chen Liu stayed with him, and for a time, Zhu Ju lingered, drinking wine and indulging in meat and fish without restraint. Some, astonished, asked, “Master, you once observed such strict abstinence—why now do you indulge so freely?”
Zhu Ju replied, “I mingle with the world, blending my light and harmonizing with the dust, not wishing to set myself apart. Have you not heard of the fish and the tiger? If a fish leaves its school and leaps onto the shore, it dies; if a tiger leaves the mountains and enters the marketplace, it is captured. My heart is one with the Dao, transcending all illusions. The subtlety of the supreme principle lies in having a body beyond the body—thus, it is not for the worldly to comprehend.”

Zhu Ju remained in Hui for three years. One day, as the weather turned bitterly cold, he suddenly said to Chen Liu, “I shall soon depart. Why not prepare for me?”
Chen Liu could not fathom his meaning. The next day, Zhu Ju sat in transformation within the inn. Chen Liu and the innkeeper carried his body outside, where it miraculously turned green and yielded over ten strings of cash, which they used for his burial rites. The following day, Zhu Ju revived.

Several days later, he entered the city and said to Chen Liu, “Today, I shall stand in transformation before the county yamen.” Chen Liu followed his instructions. After the transformation, they molded his form in clay, and over a thousand spectators gathered in awe. Suddenly, a drunken clerk from Boluo pushed forward, shouting, “You faked a seated transformation before—now you fake a standing one!” He seized a stool and struck the clay figure, which crumbled to the ground. Only then did the crowd realize that Zhu Ju had demonstrated a divine transformation and achieved liberation through the corpse.

This occurred on the thirteenth day of the eleventh lunar month in the second year of the *Chunyou* reign of Emperor Lizong of the Song. Zhu Ju had a disciple named Zheng Ruzi, whose style was Cuifang.

*Comprehensive Mirror of Perfected Immortals and Those Who Embodied the Dao Through the Ages*, Scroll Forty-Nine (conclusion)
*Comprehensive Mirror of Perfected Immortals and Those Who Embodied the Dao Through the Ages*, Scroll Fifty

Yang Yi

Yang Yi, a native of Rongde, lived in reclusion and never entered official service, earning the name "Recluse." His father, Han Qiong, served as magistrate of Heyang during the *Xiande* reign of Emperor Shizong of the Later Zhou. Upon retirement, an abscess erupted on his thigh, and Yang Yi personally sucked the wound. After more than a year, Han Qiong fully recovered, and Yang Yi’s filial piety became widely known.

The Recluse possessed profound gravity and extraordinary ambition, amassing wealth to the scale of tens of millions. He told his son, Jiansu, “Divide my estate into three parts: one to honor the Old Buddha, one to relieve the destitute, and one to succor our clan. You shall manage my affairs, for I intend to depart.” Thereupon, he left directly to pay homage to Master Xiyi on Mount Hua. The master imparted to him the essentials of the Dao and, at their parting, fed him a pellet of elixir the size of a mustard seed. Yang Yi returned to his village and thereafter abstained from food.

One day, he cast a hundred catties of gold from a high terrace into the river, declaring, “Wealth is not to be coveted. May my descendants be virtuous and kind.” Thereafter, he grew ever more reticent. Whenever heavy rain fell, he would lie beneath the eaves, letting the torrents pour over his head until the storm passed. In winter’s bitter cold, he drew water to bathe, his body steaming as if with inner fire. At the age of eighty-eight, he achieved transformation.

Fifty years later, he suddenly appeared to his nephew Ji, saying, “Your fate is nearing its end.” And so it came to pass.

*By Li Jianfu*

Li Jianfu’s origins are unknown. During the early years of the Taiping Xingguo era under Emperor Taizong of the Song, he traveled to Pengchi and took up residence at Kaiyuan Monastery, yet the monastery’s abbot did not think him extraordinary. One day, when asked to draw his sword, he unsheathed it from between his brows, its blade flashing like lightning. He plucked the blade with his fingers, singing and dancing all the while. Then, he returned it to its place between his brows. The abbot was greatly astonished and thereafter treated him with profound respect. Soon after, he died of drunkenness on the road, and the local authorities arranged his burial. Not long after, he was seen in a neighboring prefecture, and those who had been close to him returned to open his coffin—only to find it empty.

Zhao Lingyun’s origins are likewise unknown. During the Yongxi era of Emperor Taizong of the Song, he served as magistrate of Mo County in Mo Prefecture. When a severe drought struck, his prayers went unanswered. Sighing deeply, he declared, “As magistrate, I have brought such drought upon the land that soon there will be no grain left. How can I go on living?” He piled firewood in the courtyard, donned a Daoist robe, and holding a tablet, burned incense as he prayed to the August Emperor: “If it does not rain within three days, I shall immolate myself.” Three days passed, the sky remained clear without a wisp of cloud, and he hastened to the pyre. Just as he was about to light the fire, clouds gathered, thunder roared, and a great rain fell, extinguishing the flames. A five-colored cloud descended over the pyre, and he, along with a young attendant from the county, ascended upon it. Later, the people built Zhao the Immortal’s Altar on that very spot.

Qutu Wuwei, styled Wubuwei, was of unknown lineage. It is said that during the Five Dynasties period, he obtained Daoist scriptures and took the name Master Harmonious Spirit. He taught that guarding the essence of lead could bring about transformation. When the Honorable Zhang Zhongding was young and traveling in the eastern capital, he lodged at the same inn as Master Harmonious Spirit. At first, he did not recognize him, but the master took a liking to him and met him daily at a tavern. As they prepared to part, they drank deeply and became intoxicated. Zhongding said, “We have shared this brief encounter, yet I do not know who you are. How shall I recognize you in the future?” The master replied, “I am a recluse. Why should I have a name? If you press me, I am called Harmonious Spirit. One day, you will see me in Chengdu.” During the reign of Emperor Huizong of the Song, Zhongding was appointed governor of Chengdu and recalled the master’s words with wonder. Though he entered Shu twice more and searched for him, he could not find him. Later, while overseeing the construction of Tianqing Abbey and the Wangxian Pavilion, he would often pause his work to wander there, sitting in meditation all day in hopes of an encounter, but to no avail. As his term neared its end, he made one last visit, resolved to abandon hope. At dusk, he strolled beyond the hemp fields and found a narrow path leading inward. Following it, he came upon a small abbey. The walls surrounding it were painted with images of ancient figures, though dust and grime obscured them. He swept the walls and examined them, discovering among them a figure in feathered robes who bore a striking resemblance to the man he had seen at the inn. The inscription read: Harmonious Spirit. Zhongding was overcome with dismay. Thereafter, no one ever saw the master again.

In Lizhou’s Miangu County stands Wunu Mountain, named after Li Wunu. Its sheer cliffs rise like knife cuts, and within them is a cave too high to ascend. It is said that during the Five Dynasties, the Perfected Lord Qu ascended to immortality from there.

Shuai Zilian was a farmer from Mount Heng, simple and unrefined to the point that others called him “Shuai the Ox.” Later, he entered Nanyue Abbey and became a Daoist. Seven *li* southwest of the abbey stood Zixu Pavilion, the former altar of Lady Wei of the Wei. Other Daoists shunned its desolation, but he delighted in living there. No one ever saw what he did, though he was fond of wine and often lay drunk in the mountain forests.

A great storm arrived, yet he remained unaware; tigers and wolves passed before him, yet they did him no harm. Later, when the Vice Minister of Rites, Lord Wang You, was sent to govern Changsha, he received an imperial edict to offer prayers at Nanyue and visit the altar of Lady Wei. The master was just then drunk and unable to rise. Gazing fixedly, he said, “This rustic Daoist loves wine and cannot always obtain it, so he drinks to excess whenever he can.” The officials grew angry at him. But Lord Wang, perceiving something extraordinary in him, had him carried into his carriage and taken home. After more than a month, the master remained indifferent and said nothing. Wang then sent him back to the mountain, saying, “The revered master conceals his brilliance within, his depths unfathomable. Now I shall present him with a poem as a gift.” Soon after, as Wang forgot his cares and napped in the daytime, he dreamed the master came to demand the poem. He then composed two quatrains, wrote them on a board, and placed it in the pavilion. The other Daoists were astonished and said, “How did Shuai the Ox come by this?”

On the twenty-seventh day of the sixth month in the fifth year of Taiping Xingguo under Emperor Taizong of Song, he suddenly told those in the abbey, “I am about to depart for another place. The pavilion cannot be left unattended—quickly summon my successor.” The others were even more astonished and said, “The weather is so hot—where could Shuai the Ox be going?” When they hurried to look, he had already died. Only then did they marvel, saying, “Shuai the Ox even knew the hour of his death.” He was buried at the foot of the mountain.

Before long, the monk Shoucheng of Nantai Temple, returning from the Eastern Capital, saw the master outside Nanxun Gate, his spirit serene and his bearing free. Shoucheng asked why he had left the mountain, and he replied, “Merely wandering at leisure.” He then entrusted Shoucheng with a letter to deliver in thanks to Master Li of Hengyue. When Shoucheng returned and learned of the master’s death, he realized it was the very day he had seen him. They opened his tomb to look, and found only his staff and sandals.

**Liu Xiyue**
Liu Xiyue, styled Xiufeng, was a native of Zhangzhou. In his youth, he studied Confucianism and three times sat for the prefectural examinations as a *jinshi* candidate. During the Danggong era of Emperor Taizong of Song, he left the Confucian path to become a Daoist and resided in the Laozi Abbey in the Western Capital.

At sixty-four, he encountered an extraordinary person and attained the Dao, thereafter styling himself the "Master of Radiant Clarity." He once remarked, "After scarcely a decade of diligent practice, others marveled that the years had not aged me." A full twelve-year cycle passed, and he felt as though renewed. He also composed a poem:

*Through the twin passes along the spine to the crown’s gate,*
*This is the root of the path of cultivation.*

One day, he took his leave. His disciples said, "You are old—where will you go?" Xiufeng did not answer. He bathed, changed his clothes, and lay upon a mat in his chamber. In an instant, a sound arose both within and without, and a golden cicada flew forth—then Xiufeng was nowhere to be found. He had left behind over thirty poems, which circulated in the world.

**Mu Ruozhuo**
Mu Ruozhuo’s native place and the circumstances of his entry into officialdom remain unknown. During the Danggong era of Emperor Taizong of Song, he served as magistrate of Fei County in Raozhou. On the night of the full moon in the eighth month, he feasted with guests in the county courtyard. After the banquet, alone in his private quarters, he suddenly heard the strains of pipes and strings descending from the clouds. Soon after, a youth bearing a jade casket arrived on a cloud, saying, "The Supreme Emperor has decreed: Mu Ruozhuo possesses hidden virtue and no flaw in conduct; he is summoned to ascend to the Southern Palace and join the ranks of the immortals." Ruozhuo then burned incense, bowed in reverence, and ascended to receive the decree. Together with the youth, he rose into the heavens and departed. His subordinates rushed to inform his family, but it was already too late. Only the lingering fragrance of celestial incense and the lingering echoes of music in the empty sky remained. The people of the county painted his likeness and revered it with great devotion.

**Lü Dalang**
Lü Dalang was a native of Cheng’an in Daming.

The Lü family had once been wealthy, but by the time Dalang reached adulthood, he had squandered their fortune in dissipation—yet without the slightest trace of regret. During the Jingde era of Emperor Zhenzong of the Song, he suddenly fell into madness. Wandering through the markets of Zhang, he would snatch and devour any cakes he saw; even pear cores discarded by the roadside, he would pick up and eat. Later, a Daoist priest led him into the mountains. Dalang verbally agreed, though his heart could not forget his family. The priest said, "You may return, but take these dozen gourds and place your robes and cap upon the bed. At night, sever the gourds with your sword, then hang the blade upon the door and flee at once—do not look back." Dalang returned home and, as the priest had instructed, cut the gourds. When he glanced back, he saw all his family members beheaded. Weeping, he departed. At dawn, his family found Dalang dead, a noose around his neck, hanging from the door. They buried him. Months later, a villager from Anyang arrived bearing a letter from Dalang; the family was astonished. When they opened his room, they found the very sword he had left behind.

**Wang Ding**
Wang Ding was a native of Xiangyang. Initially, he eked out a living through medicine and divination to support his wife and children. He once wrote a poem:
*There is a mountain wife, there is a brother too,*
*Now casting lots, now healing—such is my trade.*

Later, he met Master Zhongli and attained the Dao. He composed another poem:
*For eighteen years I sifted truth from falsehood’s tide,*
*Today at last I meet the sages of Han’s reign.*
Thereafter, he styled himself Wang Tongzi, and no one ever saw him eat or drink. One day, walking along the riverbank, someone noticed two reflections in the water. Perplexed, they asked him the reason. He replied, "Would you like to see them again?" After a moment, more than ten appeared, lingering before vanishing.

During the Xiangfu era of Emperor Zhenzong of the Song, Wang Ding was summoned to the imperial palace. Clad in hempen robes and straw sandals, he made only a long bow before the throne. Later, he departed, and none knew his whereabouts. His writings on cultivating the Dao circulated in the world.

**Liu Fang**
Liu Fang, styled Zhongming, was a native of Suanzao. Initially, he served as a clerk in the prime minister’s office, and through accumulated merit, was promoted to Left Palace Attendant. Soon after, he sighed and said: *"To be an official is but vain toil. I shall purify my inner self, cast off the dust and grime of the world, and wander in the company of Anqi and Xianmen."* Thereupon, he secluded himself in a humble lane of the Eastern Capital, devoting himself solely to clothing and feeding those who suffered cold and hunger, and providing medicine and stone needles for their ailments—yet he never ventured forth.

Gradually, high officials and influential figures heard of his name and wished to meet Zhongming, but he remained inaccessible. Many came to seek him out, and Zhongming grew increasingly displeased. Later, when the imperial nurse died, Zhongming suddenly felt the urge to withdraw far away, saying: *"Now I am unencumbered."* He then journeyed south to Mount Heng, where he visited Master Yangsu, Lan Yuandao. He proceeded further to Bangzhou.

At the time, his younger cousin Zhi served as an administrator in Qingzhou and invited Zhongming to stay at his home. Zhongming replied: *"I fled from the clamor of ledgers and cudgels—how could I return to dwell with you?"* Instead, he took residence in a monastic lodge on the eastern mountain. The monk Daojue remarked to Zhongming in surprise: *"I have burned oil before the Tathāgata for twenty years—my merit must be boundless."* Zhongming said: *"This differs from what I have heard of cultivation. You use your body as the lampstand, your precepts as the oil, and your mind as the vessel of illumination, shining upon all ignorance. The ancient Buddha of Blazing Lamp was such a one."* Daojue marveled greatly at his words.

After residing there for over a hundred days, Zhongming bid farewell to Zhi and departed, saying: *"I now roam the world at will, making fine mountains my dwelling and white clouds my homeland. I only regret you cannot accompany me."* Later, in a monastery in Nankang, he achieved liberation through the corpse. His disciple Ding remained by the monastery, and when a county magistrate came to pay his respects, a voice from the coffin called out: *"Cease oppression, sever ignorance, reject bribes, and judge no case unjustly."* The magistrate, startled, departed.

Hou Yongxian, upon arriving in Ruizhou, saw Zhongming in the marketplace, clad in kudzu fiber and selling medicine. Jian Youcong, who had once encountered him in the Eastern Capital, asked: *"Master, you achieved liberation through the corpse—why are you here?"* Zhongming replied: *"From non-being into being, from liberation to returning to the true—this is but my ordinary affair. Why be surprised?"* Youcong said: *"When I lived in seclusion with you, your face was like red jade, while I am but rotting bones. Do you not think of me?"* Zhongming said: *"At fifty, though I aspired to the Dao, my foundation was like a dilapidated house—its beams crooked, its roof leaking, barely enduring for a time. As for Vase Master, at seventy, he spent his life fond of lawsuits, aiding others in litigation, depleting his hidden virtue. What more is there to say?"* With that, he strode away. Youcong pursued him, and Zhongming said: *"You may return."*

I am but a solitary cloud, a wild crane—how could you ever reach me? With that, he departed, and none knew where he went.

During the Qingli era of Emperor Renzong of the Song, a recluse traveled to Mount Tai in the east and called upon Registrar Guo Jifu. Once seated, Guo examined his calling card and saw the name Luo Daocheng. Asking of his hometown, the recluse replied: *"A man of Bang."*

Guo detained him for a drink, whereupon the recluse said: *"I have long wished to wander the eastern lands. Arriving at Mount Tai some days prior, I have already traversed its narrow paths. Yet by day’s end, I shall return south."* He then borrowed brush and paper to compose a poem:

*Drawn by the spirit’s allure, I wandered east by chance,*
*The jade-green peaks stand cold, layering autumn’s advance.*
*Ascending to the heights where peace and vastness reign,*
*Roots coil and stretch to bind a dozen states in chain.*

He then wrote a matching verse:

*My tracks drift with the clouds and waters, wandering free,*
*Where summer valleys hold a chill more keen than autumn’s glee.*
*Even apes and crows, by nature bound to old affection,*
*Turn back to the seaside states with one swift retrofection.*

As he took his leave, Guo dispatched a servant to see him off. Upon reaching the inn, the recluse composed another poem and handed it to the clerk, saying:

*A white mule bears me swift as racing clouds,*
*Wherever I alight, my idle verses linger near.*
*If you would know my name and whence I spring,*
*Behold the stone beneath Bangyang’s mountain clear.*

Later, inquiries in Bang revealed: *"There stands a temple to Perfected Lord Luo, who attained the Dao and rode a white mule in his travels. The mule’s likeness remains carved upon the cliffside to this day."*

Zeng Zhijing
Zeng Zhijing was a native of Luling.

In his youth, he drank no wine nor ate meat, steadfast and solemn, speaking little. Upon reaching adulthood, he left to become a Daoist, deepening his silence and withdrawing further from the world. Suddenly, a stranger of extraordinary bearing passed by and transmitted the Dao to him. From then on, he shut his door and practiced grain avoidance for five or six years. The stranger returned to observe him and said, "Not yet." He spoke with him briefly before departing. Several years later, the stranger reappeared and said, "Now it is time." Thereupon, Zeng Zhijing unsealed his gate and opened his windows. When others glimpsed him, his bearing was as though carved of jade.

In the spring of the second year of Zhihe during the reign of Emperor Renzong of Song, he suddenly told his disciples: "In the ninth month, I shall journey to Mount Heng. The appointed hour beyond this world must not be missed." When the time came, he sat upright and transformed. After his burial, at the onset of winter, peach blossoms bloomed vividly beside his grave. Soon after, a letter from Zeng Zhijing arrived from Mount Heng, exhorting his disciples to cultivate the Dao.

Guizhenzi
Tang Zizheng was a native of Guizhou. During the reign of Emperor Yingzong of Song in the Zhiping era, he traveled to the capital to take the imperial examinations.
