En route to Quanzhou, he hired a porter to carry his heavy luggage. The man moved as swiftly as a bird in flight, always staying a hundred paces ahead even when Tang urged his horse to gallop. Fearing the porter might flee, Tang dismissed him. That very day, the porter covered the two thousand seven hundred *li* from Quanzhou to Tangzhou, arriving by midday. He left a letter with the post station clerk, saying, "When the scholar Tang from Guizhou arrives, deliver this to him." Tang arrived over a month later. The clerk handed him the letter, inscribed: *Presented to Scholar Tang of Guizhou, respectfully sealed by Guizhenzi.* Upon opening it, he found only a poem:

*In Yuanzhou we met, then parted for Quanzhou,*
*Failing to encounter the master, your Dao remains unperfected.*
*Most men seek wealth and rank with all their heart,*
*Yet in the end, none may learn the immortal’s art.*
*Dispense the elixirs in your basket without cease,*
*Guard the cinnabar in your tortoise-shell, do not transmit it amiss.*
*When the horned dragon’s feast is prepared,*
*Come then to the yellow cliffs beyond the forest springs.*

Tang inquired about the man’s appearance—it was none other than the porter he had hired. The day the letter was left was the very day the porter had been dismissed in Quanzhou. Later, Tang accompanied his family to Yongzhou. In the third year of Xining during the reign of Emperor Shenzong (the year *bingchen*), bandits from Jiaozhi raided Yongzhou, and Tang’s entire household perished—this was the "horned dragon" foretold.

Sun Xiling
Sun Xiling’s native place is unknown, nor is the era in which he lived.

During the *Zhiping* reign of Emperor Yingzong of the Song, the Palace Attendant Chen Yun oversaw the wine bureau in Quzhou. By then, he was over seventy, his hair fallen and his teeth lost. Sun Xiling visited him, clad in tattered robes, and Chen looked upon him with disdain. Suddenly, Sun produced a small knife’s measure of powder and bade Chen rub it on his teeth. Chen did not believe it would work. Another day, he used it to clean his upper teeth, and his family, seeing him, laughed: "Why blacken your beard now?" Chen, startled, fetched a mirror and saw his whiskers had indeed turned dark as lacquer. Removing his headwrap, he found his hair had grown several inches, and his lost teeth had begun to sprout anew. After this, Sun vanished without a trace.

---

Zhou Guan
Zhou Guan claimed to be from Jiaodong and, though eighty years old, styled himself "Wooden Wild Goose." Skilled in composition, he wandered the West Mountains of Hongzhou. Fond of wine and unrestrained, he wore coarse hempen cloth. If someone gave him money, he would go to a tavern to drink his fill, scattering the rest without a care. For over fifty years, the people of the West Mountains saw him come and go, his face unchanged from the first day. When Daoist adepts sought him out, he would curse them, ensuring they could not draw near.

He kept a gourd, filling it with wine, and loved to compose poetry. One day, he visited the Longquan Abbey in Fengxin, where a Daoist played the zither for the entire community. Zhou covered himself with a mat and suddenly pounded on the door, shouting. The Daoist, startled, asked what was wrong, and Zhou laughed: "I’ve just composed a fine couplet—let me tell you." The Daoist, taken aback, asked to hear it, and Zhou traced the words in the air as he recited:
*"Plucking strings wears the nails thin,*
*Lying beneath a mat flattens beard and chin."*

Later, in Yuanzhou, he saw a townsman named Li about to travel afar and wished to drink with him. Li hesitated, so Zhou pointed to a cauldron boiling medicine and sang mockingly:
*"Heaven made you dull, fit only to be a pot,*
*Even with three legs, you cannot walk a lot.*
*Though ears you have, you heed no truth,*
*Only love to linger in the fire’s ruth."*

In the first year of *Xining* during the reign of Emperor Shenzong (the year *jiachen*), Zhou arrived at the Shitou Market in Yuzhang. There, he met an old friend, Zhang, who prepared food and wine and lodged him at an inn. At midnight, the innkeeper heard the clamor of carriages and horses outside, but upon looking, saw nothing—only Zhou’s outer door stood ajar, and he lay within, gasping faintly. Drawing near, they found him already dead. The next day, the matter was reported to Wu Gao, the magistrate of Xinjian County, who came to examine the body. Zhou’s flesh was soft and clean as if alive, and when they lifted him, his abdomen gurgled. The county clerk, Liu Chunchen, ordered him encoffined and buried.

Zhang returned home, where his younger brother greeted him at the gate, saying: "Zhou Xi passed by at dawn, saying he was off to the Twin Peaks." Only then did they realize Zhou had not truly died. Zhou’s *Huayang Collection*, in three volumes, never left his side, day or night, and no one had ever seen it. On the day of his death, Chunchen took possession of it. He praised its prose as perilously bold yet well-ordered.

Chunchen wrote a poem in remembrance:
*"At eighty, a wine immortal of the West Mountains,*
*Wearing straw sandals, his hempen robe threadbare.*
*Once shed, his mortal coil left the dust behind—*
*In the Great Ultimate’s light, time forgot its snare."*

Later, someone encountered Zhou in the eastern capital. He sent a letter to Li, saying: "Next year on the Mid-Autumn night, I shall pay you a visit." On the appointed day, he indeed arrived at Li’s home. Finding Li away on business, Zhou wrote in white earth upon the door and departed:
*"This Mid-Autumn night, I come as promised last year.*
*No sign of the broken-legged pot—*
*With a flick of the finger, all is bare."*

Later, Li fell from his horse and broke a leg.

---

Liu Yuanzhen
Liu Yuanzhen, styled Zizhi, was a native of Yeyuan. His family had long been farmers. Once, while playing chess with a guest, Zizhi was napping beneath an apricot tree outside the village. Suddenly, he awoke and told his father in alarm: "Just now, a Daoist master taught me chess in a dream and fed me apricots." From that day on, he refused to eat. When he grew older, he left home and roamed among the mountains and waters of Zhongnan. Soon after, he took up residence in an abandoned Buddhist shrine in the Shaling Valley.

In the depths of winter, he went bare-bodied, covering only his front and back with leaves. At times, the sounds of reed pipes, flutes, bells, and chimes would fill the air as a host of immortals descended into his chamber.

Once, while traveling with others along the road, he saw a rider pass by. Zizhi addressed him, saying, "I pray you remember the people." The rider departed, and his companions asked the reason. Zizhi replied, "That was the spirit of Mount Hua. The August Emperor, seeing that the wheat harvest was bountiful yet the people did not cherish it, ordered that a tithe of one in ten be collected. I pleaded on behalf of the people." He then added, "You should hasten forward and rest at the roadside inn ahead." Soon after, the sky erupted in violent rain, thunder, and wind, ruining a tenth of the wheat.

People gradually came to regard him with awe, and the prefect of the region built him a hut. Zizhi then began refining the elixir on the ridge, laboring for nine years. He instructed those living nearby, "When my elixir is nearly complete, you must beat the gongs and drums to aid me." The neighbors rushed to bring gongs and drums, and indeed, a strange beast appeared, fleeing in terror. Zizhi took the elixir and submerged it in a spring. After a year, he retrieved it and distributed it among the neighbors. Those who consumed it all lived to be over a hundred years old.

During the Yuanfeng era of Emperor Shenzong of the Song, Zizhi took leave of his neighbors, saying, "The August Emperor has summoned me; I must bid you farewell." That day, at noon, a cloud like a rainbow descended before his hut. Zizhi mounted it and departed.

There was a man named Liu Yi who became Zizhi’s disciple and mastered the Dao of guarding the One and preserving the Three.

---

Chen Taichu
Chen Taichu, the son of a townsman from Meishan, studied alongside Su Dongpo. At the age of eight, he became a disciple of the Daoist Zhang Yijian, who praised him highly. While Dongpo passed the imperial examinations and became a presented scholar, Taichu served as a minor official in the prefecture.

Later, when Dongpo was exiled to Huangzhou, a Daoist from Meishan named Lu Weizhong arrived from Shu, reporting that Taichu had already attained liberation. Wu Shidao, a man from Shu, served as prefect of Hanzhou, and Taichu went to stay with him. On New Year’s Day, he sought clothing, food, and money from Shidao, then bade him farewell. Taking all he had received, he distributed it among the poor of the city. He returned and sat beneath the halberd gate, where he passed away.

Shidao sent soldiers to carry him outside the city for cremation. The soldiers cursed, "What kind of Daoist is this, making us carry a corpse on New Year’s Day?" Taichu opened his eyes slightly and smiled, saying, "No need to trouble you further." He then walked from the halberd gate to the Jinyan Bridge, where he sat cross-legged and departed. The entire city witnessed smoke and flames rising, and a Daoist named Chen ascended into the void.

---

Ma Xuande
Ma Xuande’s origins are unknown. He once served as a Gentleman for Announcement of Virtue.

During the Xining reign of Emperor Shenzong of the Song, Song Ruogu served as Vice Prefect of Qilan Prefecture. One day, as he sat in quiet repose, Xuande sent a gray-haired servant with a calling card, followed shortly by Xuande himself. He wore a triple-mountain cap and a purple crane-feather cloak. Once seated, he said, "I have long since retired from worldly affairs. Hearing of your lifelong admiration for the Dao, I came to see you. I dwell on Mount Baodu. You should visit me there in a month’s time." Ruogu, unable to fathom his meaning, vaguely assented with a murmur: "Very well." After Xuande departed, Ruogu kept the appointed time and, following his official duties to inspect the horse pastures, arrived at Mount Baodu—still unaware of any prior engagement with Xuande. His subordinates warned, "The paths are treacherous and distant; we cannot proceed." Ruogu replied, "This is an imperial command—how can we refuse?" He urged his driver onward, pressing forward until they reached the sheer cliffs. There, a young attendant appeared, relaying Xuande’s invitation. Only then did Ruogu realize with astonishment. Pushing through brambles, he followed the attendant as tigers and wolves prowled the path. Deep in the mountains stood a thatched hut. Xuande received him at the gate and led him inside, where a simple meal of wild herbs was laid out. A furnace in the room glowed brightly. Xuande pointed to it and said, "I have refined the Great Elixir, and its completion is near. Your arrival here is no mere chance." He took two pills and gave them to Ruogu to consume. Ruogu bowed low and departed. When he turned back, the towering cliffs and ancient trees were veiled in mist and clouds.

At the time, Ruogu was sixty-two, his beard and temples already gray. Upon returning to his lodgings and gazing into a mirror, he found his hair had turned black again. Soon after, he left Qilan and traveled to the Eastern Capital. While visiting a monastery in Xiangguo, a Daoist in the crowd called out, "You carry the Great Elixir within you—guard it well." With those words, the Daoist vanished. Ruogu’s family was wealthy, with many concubines, and he could not adhere to the Daoist’s warnings. At over eighty years of age, he suddenly spat forth a crimson light and died.

---

Hu Yongzong
The Daoist Hu Yongzong, styled Chongzhenzi, renounced the world in his youth and devoted himself to cultivation. He was registered at the Taiping Xingguo Abbey on Mount Lu. During the Xining reign of Emperor Shenzong of the Song, a Daoist in tattered robes and worn shoes, announcing his name, strode uninvited into the abbey’s treasury hall as if no one were present. The other Daoists ignored him and left, but Hu greeted him and offered him a seat on a small bed, engaging him in unhurried conversation. Struck by the visitor’s extraordinary presence, Hu treated him with heightened courtesy. The Daoist then asked for wine and drank deeply before inviting Hu to join him outside at an inn. Hu declined, citing the late hour, and the Daoist parted with a hearty laugh, stroking his beard. The next morning, as Hu entered the city to pay respects to the prefect, he arrived at the gate before it opened. The Daoist emerged from the city, smiling as he passed. When the gatekeepers returned before the third watch, they reported, "A Daoist has been waiting here since earlier—we do not know who he is." Hu found this strange.

Years later, the Daoist arrived at the abbey carrying two gourds slung on a hemp rope, calling himself the "Guest of the Great Song." He and Hu engaged in refined conversation. When Hu asked about the gourds, the Daoist replied, "They hold my traveling provisions." Pouring them out, he revealed gold and silver. "Do you desire these?" he asked. Hu answered, "I seek only the Way of longevity." The Daoist then took some silver to buy wine, which they shared as he orally transmitted the profound Dao. As dusk fell, he carved into the earth, poured wine into the hollow, rinsed his mouth, and mixed the saliva with soil to form an ink. He blew on it, and it hardened with a resonant *clink* as he placed it on the table. "Consuming this can cure illness and grant immortality," he said. After another drink, Hu became drunk and collapsed. When he awoke, a strange fragrance filled the room, and a spring bubbled from the carved earth—no trace of the Daoist remained. Hu ground the ink into wine and drank it. His chronic ailments vanished instantly, and though he lived past seventy, his appearance remained youthful, his capacity for wine undiminished.

From then on, he gradually withdrew from worldly affairs. One day, he left a poem behind and shed his mortal form. Today, the abbey still holds the "Ink Immortal Spring," its waters sweet and inexhaustible in all seasons. Left Minister Wang An, Vice Minister Song Boyou, and other eminent figures have exchanged poems and inscriptions in his honor, recorded in the *Collected Poems of the Abbey’s Illustrious Worthies*. An account titled *The Immortal Encounter of Master Hu* is preserved in old records and stele inscriptions.

---

Huang Zhiwei
Huang Zhiwei, styled Mingdao, was a Daoist of the Taiping Xingguo Abbey on Mount Lu. His nature was serene and unassuming, his bearing imposing. During the Yuanfeng reign of Emperor Shenzong of the Song, he was appointed Keeper of the Palace, responsible for tending the sacred flames.

One day, Master Cui of Mount Qian, known as the Embodier of the Dao, came to visit. In their discourse on the marvels of the Mud-Pill Palace of Myriad Spirits and the single grain of the elixir knife, Huang was then transmitted the Way of the Nine Grains of Divine Millet and the principles of Golden Liquor and Sunken Radiance. Thereafter, he wandered as if drifting, now steady, now stumbling, his demeanor unbound and without routine. The people called him "Yellow Wind Master." He then composed the *Song of Huang the Mad*, which was recorded in his biography. Fond of wine, he would often sing loudly when drunk, and after singing, fall into wild abandon. He would frequently stand on the Bridge of Morning Audience before the abbey, shouting sharply as if rebuking someone. His robe was patched a hundred times, yet he paid no heed to his bare exposure. In the depths of winter or the height of summer, he remained untroubled by cold or heat. When scholars or officials bestowed gifts upon him, he would scatter them with his own hands. Sometimes he dwelled in the mountains, sometimes he roamed the cities, always carrying two cloth sacks. Whatever he encountered—cakes, pastries, medicines, or the like—he would toss into the sacks without distinction, yet they emitted no foul odor, earning them the name "Brocade Fragrance." Once, as a great snow fell and the forests and valleys turned white, the roof of his dwelling alone remained free of snow. He would often point to the altar by the wall of his chamber and tell others, "This is my path to Shu." Though he had never studied books, his speech was rich with historical tales. Though untrained in letters, his utterances were always lofty and wondrous. He befriended Cai Zigao of Hou Brook, Sima Zhibai, Cui Fengzi, and Gao Chijiao, among others. In the final years of Emperor Huizong’s Chongning reign, he surpassed ninety years of age, yet his appearance remained that of a maiden, his skin like jade. His mad antics persisted as before, and his capacity for wine did not wane. At the end of the Xuanhe era, an imperial summons was issued, but he did not rise.

When the authorities pressed him further, he traveled as far as Jiujiang, where he declared, *"Now there are two Sons of Heaven. What business have I there?"* Soon after, Emperor Qinzong ascended the throne, and an amnesty reached his temple. Before the fire broke out, the Master had planted mugwort and sow thistle in the Caifang Hall, saying, *"Next year, it will be settled."* The following year, when Han Shiqing’s rebel forces indeed burned the palace, it was on the very day the plants had been sown. His predictions of fortune and misfortune invariably proved true.

When the Master ascended as a feathered immortal, he was interred beside the temple. Years later, a traveler returned from Shu and reported, *"Huang Fengzi is now in Shu. I met him in Chengdu yesterday, and he entrusted me with this letter for his family."* The crowd was skeptical, but upon opening the box, they found only a list of Daoist names preserved from the chaos of war. They then opened the coffin to find only his robes and sandals inside.

**Bi Dao’ning**
Bi Dao’ning, a Daoist of Taiping Xingguo Abbey on Mount Lu, styled himself Kangshu. From childhood, he was quick-witted, with a refined and striking appearance. He could recite any classic after a single reading. During Emperor Zhezong’s Shaosheng era, he traveled through Jiang and Zhe.

One day, he arrived at Qianshan, where he encountered a fangshi. The man silently grasped his intent and said: *"To cultivate the Dao, one must refine the spirit and nurture qi; alchemical texts are but the ladder and bridge to enter the Way. If you cast aside worldly distractions and refine your spirit and qi with precision, you will naturally commune with the true and attain spiritual clarity."* Then, pointing by the water, he said: *"When water is still, its form is straight; when the heart is tranquil, the spirit is at peace—you must take this as your mirror."* Thereupon, he bestowed upon Bi a cinnabar elixir, saying: *"One day, we shall meet again beneath Shengzhi Peak."* With a bow, he departed, vanishing as if into thin air.

That very day, Bi returned to the mountain. It so happened that the position of vice-abbot at the abbey was vacant, and the prefectural authorities appointed him to fill it. Soon after, he petitioned for leave to build a hermitage to the right of the abbey, where he excavated a pond to store water, naming it *Qingxin* ("Pure Renewal"). Each day, he shut his door to preserve his spirit and recited one fascicle of the *Scripture of Salvation*.

On the third day of the first month in the seventh year of Emperor Huizong’s Xuanhe reign, a white-robed mountain recluse came to visit. Reminiscing about their past encounter, the recluse imparted to him the *Qin Yuan Chun* lyric:

*A single grain of golden elixir,*
*large as a millet seed,*
*descends in deep meditation to gestate the embryo.*
*Harness the root of yin and yang,*
*bind the eastern dragon and western tiger,*
*congeal the golden water,*
*and plant it deep in chosen earth.*
*After nine years without depletion,*
*the three fields’ work complete,*
*you shall ascend, qi perfected and whole.*

The furnace and cauldron open, the primal transformation is stolen—relying on the ancestral essence of spontaneity, all depends on the true talent of the numinous terrace. Cast aside attachment to the dusty world. The corpse’s spirit awakens the Hall of Light, yet the infant remains unborn. Fortunate was our meeting by the Huai’s banks, where the sacred elixir was bestowed, and the profound intent personally entrusted, urging ascent to the immortal’s ranks. When shall we meet again? A lofty gathering amidst clouds and waters, or further along the mist-laden paths of transcendence? In this world of men, let kings and nobles, however exalted, share the same fate as withered weeds.

Four days after receiving this lyric, he adjusted his robes, sat upright, and passed away. To this day, the right chamber of the *Yangsu* Hall in the abbey bears the plaque *Qingxin* ("Pure Renewal"), and the pond remains.

**Tian Duanyan**
Tian Duanyan was a native of Qi and Lu. In his youth, he passed the imperial examinations. During Emperor Huizong’s *Chongning* era, he served as *Qianshu Pan* in the Southern Military Prefecture. Before long, a death-row prisoner became the subject of dispute between him and Prefect Lü Jiawen; he immediately hung his official robes at the prefectural gate and departed. He entered Mount Yuan’an and dwelled in the *Qingxi* Retreat. Each morning, he would venture into the valleys, returning only at dusk. After over a hundred days, he suddenly failed to return to *Qingxi*. The monks sent someone to search for him and found him lying upon a rock, two tigers guarding his side—none dared approach. Thereafter, his whereabouts became unknown.

Years later, clad in coarse hemp and straw sandals, carrying a pot on his back, he visited his brother-in-law Xing Shu, styled *Heshu*, in Luoyang. By then, he was already over eighty, yet his face retained a youthful glow, his beard and hair lush and dark. The scholar-officials of Luoyang all sought his company. The master conversed and laughed freely with all who met him; when asked how he attained the Dao, he would not answer. In the late *Zhenghe* era, he was encountered in the outskirts of Xiang and Deng, his appearance unchanged.

**Liu Bozi**
Liu Bozi was a native of Qingzhou.

Liu Bozi would lean on a staff and, without fail, journey to Luoyang each year to admire the blossoms. Once, when Prime Minister Zhang summoned him from Jinghu, Bozi was drinking with a guest beneath the Market Bridge. Hearing the grand procession of carriages and cavalry pass by, the guest rose to watch, but Bozi tugged at his sleeve, urging him to keep drinking. He composed a poem:

*An exiled official, summoned from Huxiang to the capital—*
*What honor in the feasting and farewells!*
*Far better to drink with you beneath the Market Bridge,*
*And spare oneself the world’s alarms of favor and disgrace.*

Chen Yingzhong, who had long admired him, presented him with lyrics in long and short lines:

*Withered wood in form, drifting clouds in life,*
*Twice a year you come to the capital.*
*Then, on a whim, you wander back,*
*Idly viewing Luoyang’s flowers.*

*I hear the finest spring returns in crimson shoes,*
*Yet in the end, all fades to mud and sand.*
*Where words fail, flowers bloom and wither—*
*Not like the path I tread.*

*Youth slips away, unheld;*
*Hunger and cold my constant lot.*
*Wherever I roam, there is home.*
*This bright moon, flawless from the start,*
*Follows its portion—winter furs or summer hemp—*
*Never seeking the Red Water’s golden sprouts.*
*Who knows that with my springtime staff and a laugh,*
*I speak of cinnabar?*

During the *Zhenghe* era of Emperor Huizong of Song, he lodged at Xingguo Temple. People estimated his age at around one hundred forty or fifty. For thirty years, he had stayed at the inn of Zhang Dalang near Xinmen in the capital, sitting daily by the Xiangguo Temple’s east gate, yet none among the inn’s patrons recognized him.

**Shuiqiuzi**
Shuiqiuzi was a native of Zhenzhou. He first studied Confucianism but later encountered a perfected one and abandoned his home. Thenceforth, he roamed freely, indulging in wine, unknown to others.

During the *Xuanhe* era of Emperor Huizong of Song, a man named Xu Wenzhong resided in the eastern capital. One of his soldiers, whose feet had been severely burned by a carriage, met a Daoist who gave him medicine, allowing him to walk again. The soldier sought out the Daoist to thank him, but the man had since feigned madness, eating damp paper and winter melon seeds daily. When asked why, he replied, *"Winter melon digests easily; damp paper is hard to dissolve."* When questioned about the Dao, he said, *"Stillness and simplicity—that is all."*

Xu Wenzhong thus gained some understanding of his teachings and grew fond of them in his heart. Before long, he encountered Shuiqiuzi and bowed twice, seeking instruction. Shuiqiuzi said:

*"Man is a temporary convergence of the four great elements, mingled in the realm of impermanence. Transformation gives rise to qi, and qi transforms into form. Form takes the heart as its ruler, for the heart is the abode of spirit. Spirit follows resolve; without resolve, it follows intention. Resolve that attains unity is called essence. Only the utmost essence under heaven can unite the resolve and spirit of all under heaven. When essence and spirit merge as one without separation, transformation lies within one’s grasp. This is the Dao of longevity and enduring vision. Thus, the heart must not be left restless and shallow. As long as emotions do not cling to things, things cannot obstruct you."*

Thereupon, Wenzhong had a great awakening and said: *"Intention resides in the spleen, and the spleen, numbered five, corresponds to earth. Water is stilled by earth, and fire is quelled by earth—is this not how essence, spirit, and intention unite as one?"*

Later, Shuiqiuzi ascended to the Tianqing Cloister and departed as an immortal from atop a tree. Wenzhong rose to the rank of sixth-grade official, but his ultimate fate remains unknown.

*Comprehensive Mirror of Perfected Immortals Through the Ages Who Embodied the Dao, Scroll Fifty—Concluded*
*Comprehensive Mirror of Perfected Immortals Through the Ages Who Embodied the Dao, Scroll Fifty-One*

Zhang Xu bai, styled Zhixiang, was a native of Nanyang in Dengzhou and was registered as a Daoist priest at the Taiyi Palace. Standing six feet tall with a fine beard, he was by nature serene and dignified, well-versed in the arts of Taiyi and the Six Ren divination. He devoted himself to the study of the elixir cauldron and, encountering an extraordinary person, received esoteric instructions. He claimed his former life was that of Master Zhang Bai of Wuling. His disciples compared the date of Wuling’s liberation through the corpse with the time of Xu bai’s birth, finding them to align as precisely as tallying tokens.

Wuling had been fond of wine in life, and there was a poem that read:
*"By Wuling’s stream, Cui’s family wine—*
*On earth, none; in heaven, it’s found.*
*A southern Daoist drinks a dou,*
*Then sleeps drunk by the deep cave’s mouth, wrapped in white clouds."*

Xu bai was also skilled in drinking. Emperor Huizong of the Song, recognizing his exceptional Daoist cultivation, would summon him and invariably drink several cups with him. Even when intoxicated, Xu bai grew only more reverent. The emperor cherished him and appointed him to oversee the Longde Taiyi Palace. Within the palace, he expanded and adorned four halls—Hongdao, Zhenxue, Huibin, and Yinzhen—and established several hermitages, such as Chaoran, Zhidao, and Yunji, along with over ten small pavilions, all inscribed with imperial calligraphy. The plaques were mounted on silk, framed with antique brocade, their secluded elegance and splendor unmatched among all palaces. Despite enjoying the emperor’s favor for a long time, he never once displayed the slightest arrogance. Every day brought new imperial gifts and honors.

One day, six swift messengers delivered three vermilion boxes as imperial gifts. Upon opening them, all were found to contain gold dust. As he bowed to receive them, his expression showed no delight. He said, "These are the possessions of the court, not for those who follow the Dao. I shall merely store them away."

At the end of the Xuanhe era, a great thunderstorm struck in summer, and three dragons leapt from the eaves of the Xuanhe Hall and soared away. The emperor, alarmed, summoned Xu Ba and asked, "Is this not an omen?" Xu Ba replied, "May Your Majesty cultivate virtue to avert it."

In his youth, Xu Ba had studied medicine, and those who sought his treatment often recovered swiftly. After the emperor abdicated, Emperor Qinzong summoned him and treated him with even greater favor. All the scriptures printed at the imperial court, as well as the talismans and medicines stored in the Three Pavilions, were bestowed upon him, their transport filling carts for days on end.

When the Jin forces invaded the capital, they heard of his name and searched for him urgently. Once found, he was carried in a litter to the Nanxun Gate, where the various tribesmen vied to bear him, all treating him as an immortal. After being captured and held for four years, when the Jin returned to Suiyang and their scouts entered the city, the Daoists of Tianqing Abbey all fled. The Jin halted them, saying, "Among you are many extraordinary men—none shall be harmed." They then asked the assembled Daoists, "Do you know Master Zhang Xubai? He arrived in our land, and one day abruptly told the tribal chiefs, 'On such-and-such a day, I shall depart.' Your customs follow the Buddhist cremation rites, but Daoists forbid them. I hope you will bury my coffin deep in the earth.' On the appointed day, he indeed passed away."

Throughout his life, Xu Ba rose in rank to Grand Master of the Supreme Void, Attendant of the Harmonious Hall, and Feathered Guest of the Golden Gate. He entered and left the imperial palace under the sign of a jade tablet. Among the nine Attendants of the Imperial Presence were Lin Lingjiang, Wang Yunchen, Xu Zhichang, Dong Nanyun, Li Derou, Wang Chongdao, Shao Ruoyu, and Wang Wenqing. Only Lin Lingjiang, Wang Yunchen, and Xu Ba were Feathered Guests of the Golden Gate.

He resided in the Longde Taiyi Palace for ten years, never leaving without imperial summons. When visitors sought an audience, he would always receive them, and all guests were formally welcomed in the main hall. He never once called at the gates of the powerful. When attending the emperor, he would discourse on the Dao all day without uttering a word on current affairs. If asked, he would say, "Affairs of state are the domain of the chief ministers—such matters are not for the likes of us to know."

Master Liu Bian'gong, Liu Bian'gong of Binzhou, was devoted to the Dao from his youth...

An elderly man passed by his home and remarked, "Skilled at mending iron." The Master said, "My tripod is broken—can you mend it?" The old man replied, "If a man’s body can be mended, how much more a tripod?" The Master, recognizing him as no ordinary man, promptly bowed twice. The old man then gave him an elixir to consume. From that time on, he abandoned all worldly affairs and dug a cave-chamber to dwell in. Those who wished to see him entered through a small opening, yet none formed a true bond with him.

Emperor Huizong of Song thrice dispatched envoys to summon him, but he resolutely declined. The emperor, holding him in even greater esteem, bestowed upon him the title *Master of Lofty Virtue*. The Master was versed in all books yet had never labored over study. When conversing with others, he invariably spoke of the essentials of the *Doctrine of the Mean* and the great Way, often declaring: "In clarity and quiescence, free from the burdens of external things, the spirit remains whole and the guard unbroken—bees and scorpions cannot poison, cold and heat cannot assail. How then do men of this world harm themselves with desires, harm their descendants with wealth, harm others with governance, and harm the world with learning? Later generations, forgetting the root of their own longevity, never awaken. How much better to flow as one with Heaven and Earth above and below—would this not bring true joy to the heart?"

At the beginning of Emperor Qinzong’s *Jingkang* era, the Master left his homeland, traveling through Ba and Shu, floating along the rivers and lakes of Jiang and Zhe, and gazing upon Mount Heng and the Xiang—perhaps with the intent to engage with the world. In Shu, he gained two disciples, Deng and Chai, whom he thereafter kept by his side. Upon reaching Wu, he encountered Li Jici of Tonglu and transmitted to him a book of methods. Jici practiced them with utmost devotion, and the Way was fulfilled in him. The Master once petitioned Master Zhongli to seek aid in advancing Jici’s attainment, saying, "His nose aligns with the Three Swords, his brain refines the Nine Elixirs." Jici’s wife had long been blind; when the Master passed by, Jici spat on his hand and wiped her eyes, and her sight was restored.

The Master once made an appointment with Jici to attend the Crane Assembly at Mount Mao the following spring. Jici arrived as promised, where hundreds of cranes gathered on the mountain. Searching for the Master, he saw only the two disciples, Deng and Chai. When he asked them, they pointed among the crowd to a man of towering spirit and bearing, saying, "That is the Master." Jici said, "How different he is from before!"

The alchemist said, "The Master has already undergone the bone-transformation." He produced a piece of the Master’s former bone and showed it to Jici, who has kept it to this day. On the mountain was the Hua Yang Cave, where rocks stood like screens, winding in several layers, with unfathomable pools below. The Master entered with Jici and said, "From here, I shall follow the Yellow Perfected One to wander Mount Luofu." He never emerged again. Some say he now resides on Mount Qingcheng in Shu, though none may see him.

Liu Yuandao
Liu Yuandao, styled Jingchu, was a native of Kaifeng Prefecture. His family had long served as military officers, but Yuandao alone admired the teachings of Zhuangzi and Laozi. In his youth, he became a disciple of the Daoist Li Juyan, donning the yellow cap. His nature was simple, pure, and magnanimous; though offended, he never retaliated. Fond of reading, beyond the Daoist Canon, he recited the Nine Classics, philosophers, and histories with perfect fluency. In the company of guests and friends, he seemed incapable of speech, yet when questioned on matters, his responses were as swift as an echo.

When Emperor Huizong of the Song first promoted Daoism, he issued an edict to collect lost Daoist texts from across the realm, ordering Daoists to collate and authenticate them at the Bureau of Calligraphy and Painting. Yuandao was the first selected for this task. Thereafter, he gradually rose through the ranks, serving as Recorder of the Daoist Registry, then as Registrar of the Left and Right Streets, and eventually as Grand Master of the Supreme Void and Custodian of the Jade Pearl Hall’s Registers. Beyond his official duties, he never altered a single matter to curry favor, earning the admiration of scholar-officials. Whenever he attended the inner Daoist rituals or was summoned to the private palace to discourse on the Way, he received lavish rewards. Yet whatever Yuandao received, he immediately distributed. One day, when several Daoist officials, including Lin Lingjiang, attended the emperor’s side, His Majesty presented treasures and allowed each to take what they desired. Yuandao alone chose only a bronze incense burner.

When the Jurchen invaded the capital, they coveted gold and silk. Daoist clergy were thoroughly searched, and those found with contraband faced imprisonment. Only Yuandao, known to possess nothing, was left unquestioned. By nature, he disdained Buddhism. After the Jurchen violated the realm, some turned to Buddhism in desperation. When asked, "His Majesty so revered the Dao—why has this befallen us?" Yuandao replied, "Emperor Wu of Liang offered himself as a slave to the monks and melted weapons into Daoist implements, yet he could not escape the siege of Hou Jing. Was that also the result of serving the Buddha?" The questioner bowed in assent and withdrew.

Later, Yuandao withdrew from public life. Occasionally, he was seen among the people.

Dong Nanyun, Daoist Record
Dong Nanyun, styled Xuanming, was of lofty and pure Daoist practice, revered by his disciples. A year before the Jurchen breached the capital, he suddenly declared, “I dreamed of immortal youths presenting a yellow writ to summon me as Master of Yanfeng.” The following day, he ascended without illness, having lived over seventy years, yet his countenance remained as that of a man in his forties or fifties.

Daoist Wang Bingwen
Wang Bingwen, styled Yanheng, was registered at Mount Lu’s Taiping Xingguo Abbey. After attaining the Dao, he traveled to the capital. At the time, the court was constructing the Shenxiao Wanshou Abbey, where he was granted purple robes and appointed Master of Ceremonies. Suddenly, a fangshi arrived and, seeing a *Zhouyi* on his desk, cast milfoil stalks and declared, “This place shall face military calamity. You are not fated to remain—best avoid it.” He then imparted the essentials of “preserving the Three and guarding the One,” along with the secrets of the Yellow Emperor and Bian Que. Wang resigned his post and returned to the mountains. In the fourth year of Emperor Gaozong’s Jianyan reign, the abbey was destroyed by rebel forces. The following year, after the bandits retreated, those who admired his sense of duty urged him to take charge. Wang thus assumed a deputy role amid the ashes. After several years of effort, the abbey’s halls and images gleamed anew in gold and azure.

He then resigned from his duties at the abbey and secluded himself at home for over thirty years, naming his residence the Hall of Three-in-One and thus styling himself Master of the Three-in-One. Daily he studied the Daoist Canon, mastered esoteric formulas, and devoted himself to medicine, with no other pursuits. On the night of the Lantern Festival in the second year of Emperor Xiaozong’s Qiandao reign, he dreamed of a divine being who declared: “The Celestial Emperor has commanded you to preside over the Great Flushing Grotto of Mount Hua. He bestows upon you a grain of Returning-Soul Elixir to restore your spirit and replenish your primordial qi. The officials of the Divine Radiance and White Horse Bureaus shall escort you into the grotto.” With these words, he awoke.

The next morning, he told his disciples: “The mortal world is no longer a place to dwell—I shall depart.” He then took the fourteen fascicles of *Collected Manifestations of Sagely Cures*, the *Divine Resolutions of the Perfected Lord of the Western Marchmount*, the *Complete Pulse Classic*, and the *Secret Formulas of the Purple Court for Audience with the Dipper*, and entrusted them to his grand-disciple Qin Zhixiang and others. On the first day of the second month, he bathed, changed his robes, and passed away in perfect serenity. The prefect of the prefecture, Kang Fuwen, composed a eulogy in his honor, recording the events of Taiping Xingguo Abbey.

Liu Lie
Daoist Liu Lie, styled Master of the Hollow Valley, was born after his mother dreamed an extraordinary dream. As he grew, his talents surpassed the ordinary. He studied at Taiping Xingguo Abbey on Mount Lu, keeping his associations pure. Nobles and high officials marveled at his countenance, which bore the unspoiled air of high antiquity, and declared him destined for the Dao.

In the sixth year of the Shaoxing reign of Emperor Gaozong of the Song, he built a thatched hermitage and named it "True Unity." Each day, he sat upright, poring over the Daoist Canon, classics, and histories, committing all to memory at a glance. Scholars and officials sought his acquaintance. Master Zhu Xi of the Huian School discussed the *Book of Changes* with him and expounded on the principles of returning elixir, later leaving this poem:

*I have read the hundred chapters on returning elixir,*
*The master’s brush, too, speaks at length.*
*The primal mechanism lies hidden in the classics,*
*Yet the highest truth resides in the blink of an eye.*
*If the two horses truly serve as my charioteers,*
*The five sprouts will naturally grow in my garden.*
*Tomorrow, riding a crane, I shall ascend the mountain—*
*With whom then shall I discuss these matters?*

Zhang Xiaoxiang, upon their first meeting, presented him with a poem:

*Within the blessed land lies a small grotto-heaven,*
*Where immortals refine their spirits in seclusion.*
*Only the Hollow Valley knows its joy,*
*For the fire-timing of the* Cantong qi *is wondrously natural.*

Ministers of state such as Luo Dian, Wang Yan of the Ministry of Personnel, the two eminent officials Feng Xi and Feng Yi, and Vice Minister Yue of the Ministry of Rites all visited to discuss the *Book of Changes*, exchanging verses and poetic replies.

In the first year of the Longxing reign of Emperor Xiaozong, he annotated the *Correct Classic of the Zhou Changes* and compiled the *Comprehensive Essentials of the Six Ren*. Journeying to the capital to present these works, he was granted an imperial audience, questioned on the Dao, and honored with a banquet. Later, he dwelt in the mountains for a decade. In the ninth year of the Qiandao reign, in the sixth month, he abstained from food for over forty days, drinking only fragrant water. On the fourteenth day of the seventh month, he personally delivered twenty-five fascicles of *Secret Instructions for Ascending to Perfection* and nine fascicles of *Upper Scriptures* to the abbey’s archivist. The following day, on the Zhongyuan Festival, he left a poem in his own hand, which read in part:

*The Hollow Valley Master now seeks to shed his form and leave the world,*
*To sweep aside worldly dust and hasten to the boundless realm of mist and clouds,*
*Where he shall merge with the Dao in profound unity.*

On the sixteenth night, he walked under the moon to the summit of Green Ox Grotto on Mount Lu, sat upright, and passed away. His works include *A Hundred Chapters on Returning Elixir*, miscellaneous poems and essays, *Exegesis on the Book of Changes*, and *Essential Diagrams of Successive Dynasties’ Rulers and Ministers*, all of which circulated in the world.

---

Lan Qiao
Lan Qiao, styled Zisheng, was a native of Longchuan in Xunzhou. His mother, née Chen, had no sons until she prayed at Mount Luofu and conceived. When her time came, she dreamed of immortals’ cranes alighting at her home, and that very night gave birth to Qiao amid a radiant glow in the room. At twelve, he could already compose poetry. A physiognomist told Chen, “Your son has extraordinary bones. If he pursues an official career, he will rise to the rank of general or minister; if he cultivates the Dao, he will become an immortal.” Qiao replied, “General or minister is not worth aspiring to—what I desire is to ascend lightly.”

From then on, he sought out Daoist texts to read, but lamented the lack of companions in study. Taking leave of his mother, he traveled to the Jiang-Huai region and reached the capital. After seven years, he returned and said to his mother, “Your son is by nature a wanderer of rivers and lakes. If I have returned, it is only out of concern for you.” From his gourd, he produced a single elixir and offered it to her, saying, “Take this, and you will live long without illness.” After staying for over a year, he set out again, leaving several catties of gold for his mother with the words, “This was refined through the breath of true qi. Treasure and use it, for I shall not return.”

Wu Ziye of Chaozhou encountered him in the capital. On a sweltering day, they climbed the Bian Bridge to buy melons. Qiao said, “The dust defiles my melon—let us gaze at it from the water.” With that, he leapt into the river. Wu leaned over the moonlit water to watch, and from time to time melon rinds floated to the surface, intact. By nightfall, Qiao had not emerged. Wu went to his lodging to check, only to find him sound asleep, snoring like thunder. Slowly opening his eyes, Qiao said, “I waited for you in the waves to eat melon. Why did you take so long?” Wu then realized Qiao had attained the Dao. Bowing in shame and gratitude, he became his disciple and attended to his needs.

Later, Qiao wandered to Luoyang, clad in a patched robe. Whenever he entered a tavern, he would drink several *dou* of wine. He could place a hundred sheets of paper beneath his feet and have people pull them out one by one without tearing a single one—so light was his body. He told others, “I am an immortal from Mount Luofu. From here, I shall ascend to heaven.”

One day, while selling medicine outside the city, he again placed paper beneath his feet and bade onlookers take it. When the last sheet was drawn, his feet rose into the air. Amid swirling winds and gathering clouds, he ascended. Cranes in formation flew from the south, and as he rose, they vanished from sight. The sound of pipes and flutes lingered in the air, and he was heard reciting a poem by Li Taibai:

*Gazing down, I see the Master is beyond reach,*
*Craning my neck, I yearn for him in vain, my heart broken.*

His mother lived to ninety-seven before passing away. On the day of her burial, woodcutters and herders heard weeping at her grave. Those who understood knew of his comings and goings.

Prefect Zheng of Yingzhou wrote his biography.

---

Shen Donglao

In Wuxing’s Donglin, there lived a man named Shen Donglao, famed for brewing the Eight Immortals’ White Wine. One day, a guest calling himself the Returning Daoist arrived at his gate with a deep bow, saying: “I have heard your white wine has just matured, and have come from afar to visit. I beg for a taste to quench my thirst.” It was the nineteenth day of the eighth month in the first year of Emperor Shenzong of Song’s Xining reign.

Donglao, seeing the guest’s refined bearing and noble spirit, rose at once to greet him. Observing his jade-green eyes, which gleamed with light, he conversed with him and found his voice clear and resonant. The Returning Daoist spoke with mastery of the rise and fall of dynasties, the principles of Laozi and Zhuangzi, and the teachings of Buddhism, leaving no doubt he was no ordinary mortal. Donglao brought out over ten wine vessels and, at the feast, said: “I have heard you are a skilled drinker. I wish to offer the first toast with the tripod vessel—what say you?” The Daoist replied: “Among drinking vessels, the bell and tripod are largest, followed by the gourd cup and conch shell, while the pear-blossom and banana-leaf cups are smallest. Bid your attendants pour in order, from smallest to largest, and I shall drink accordingly.” He laughed and added: “Like Gu Kaizhi eating sugarcane, I shall enter ever finer realms.” He further agreed that once the cycle was complete, they would begin anew, ever changing vessels, keeping his cup perpetually full. “Thus,” he smiled, “the wine in my cup shall never be empty.” He drained each cup as soon as it was set before him, and they took turns toasting one another.

The Daoist then asked Donglao to play the zither, and he sang in harmony with the melody. They also played weiqi for amusement, but after only a few moves, the Daoist swept the pieces away, laughing: “I fear the game would end only when the axe handle rots.” From noon until dusk, the Daoist drank several *dou* of wine without showing any signs of intoxication.

That evening, the moon was faint, the autumn heat lingered, and mosquitoes still swarmed. As attendants held candles to drive them away, one flame was accidentally extinguished. The Daoist then took a bamboo branch, dipped it in the leftover wine, and planted it in a distant wall. In an instant, all the mosquitoes flocked to the spot, leaving the drinking area entirely free of them. Donglao, eager to learn, asked to be taught the method of driving away mosquitoes. The Daoist replied: “Drink first. Such minor arts are hardly worth mentioning.” He then said: “I have heard you possess the arts of alchemy but have never misused them. You are also deeply filial and righteous, and have performed many hidden good deeds. This is why I have sought you out today—to awaken you to greater things.”

Donglao then inquired about the methods of attaining longevity and lightness of body. The Daoist replied: “This body, composed of the four great elements, cannot suddenly depart from its form. The greatest matters are life and death, departure and abiding. If you know where death abides, your spirit will be born there.” Donglao adjusted his robes and rose to thank him for his instruction. The Daoist said: “This is what the ancients called the highest and most ultimate state.” He added: “Five years from now, we shall meet again. On that day, you will depart this world. However, your deepest attachment is to your son, Shen Jie, whom you will not see at the moment of your passing. When that time comes, you will know it in advance. Be careful not to let your thoughts waver, lest you lose your true nature.” Donglao nodded in understanding.

They drank until dawn, by which time the wine in the jars had turned to mere dregs, with not a drop left to drink. The Daoist said: “I have not lingered in Zhejiang for a long time. Today, I came for your sake and shall leave a poem as a parting gift.” He tore the skin of a pomegranate from the table, wrote on the hut’s wall with it, and the characters, pale yellow at first, gradually darkened. The poem read:

*The western neighbor, though rich, is never satisfied;*
*Donglao, though poor, finds joy in abundance.*
*He brews white wine to welcome good guests,*
*And scatters gold to collect books.*

Then, bidding Donglao farewell, he opened the gate to see him off. As dawn broke, they walked hand in hand, laughing and making plans to meet again in the future. At the stone bridge west of the house—now called the Returning Immortal Bridge—the Daoist crossed first, riding the wind away, vanishing without a trace.

Four years later, on the evening of the Mid-Autumn Festival, Donglao fell slightly ill. He gathered his clansmen and told them: “The Returning Daoist once said to me on this day four years ago: ‘Five years from now, we shall meet again, and on that day, you will depart.’ I thought he meant next year, but this is the fifth year of Xining. Shen Jie is also away in the capital seeking an official post. The Daoist’s words must refer to today.” When the appointed day arrived, he passed away. All that the Daoist had foretold came to pass. Today, in Huzhou, there stands the Returning Immortal Temple, where his traces remain.

---

In the fourth year of the reign, Cai Yuanchang, having just passed the imperial examinations, served as a patrol officer in Qiantang. One evening, as he rested at an inn in Tang Village, a Daoist of imposing stature sought an audience. Cai, who had always enjoyed meeting masters of the esoteric arts, hastily welcomed him and conversed over wine before the Daoist departed. The next night, Cai lodged elsewhere and saw the Daoist again. The following evening, as he moored at Xin Village, the Daoist reappeared. They drank several *dou* of wine, and the Daoist earnestly requested: “I cannot return tonight. May I stay here?” Cai initially refused, but after repeated pleas, he reluctantly agreed. They shared a bed, with Cai on the outer side and the Daoist within. The Daoist warned: “If anyone comes searching for me in the middle of the night, do not tell them I am here.”

Cai suspected the Daoist was a fugitive criminal, and that officers might come to arrest him. As a patrol officer, it would be improper to harbor him, yet he had no choice. He tossed and turned until the third watch, unable to sleep. Then, he heard voices outside the inn. Soon, the crowd grew louder, and they forced the door open.

They demanded: “Chariot Four is here—how did he get in?” One exclaimed in fury, “I’ll seize him from the bed!” Another cautioned: “If we harm the man outside as well, the Emperor will surely be enraged. We may incur punishment.” Cai, seized with terror, sat up and called to his attendants, but not one answered. The Daoist slept soundly, unmoved even when shaken. Outside, someone muttered: “He’s slipped past us again for sixty years—how strange, how strange!” After much murmuring, a sound arose from within the room like the rustling of tens of thousands of bamboo papers being peeled. Then, all fell silent.

Only then did Cai’s attendants respond. When asked what they had seen, none knew anything. The Daoist rose calmly and bowed in thanks: “I am Chariot Four. Thanks to you, I have escaped this great peril and may live another sixty years—this was my third deliverance. From now on, I have nothing to fear. You are destined for the highest ranks of mortal office, and that is how I evaded capture. Had it been otherwise, we would both have perished.” He added, “I have no way to repay you. I possess an elixir that can transmute copper, iron, bronze, and silver. Would you like it?” Cai refused, but the Daoist pressed a lump of dried mercury into his hand, saying: “Use this in times of dire need.” As dawn approached, he took his leave and was never seen again.

Cai later recounted the tale to his second son, Xiu. After Cai’s death, Xiu fled with his family to Guangxi, where the elixir sustained them. Cai’s guest, Chen Bing, who once served as prefect of Xiang Commandery, also knew the full story.

Zhang Jing
Zhang Yu, styled Yinzhi, was a native of Chengdu. From childhood, he stood apart from others, his genius surpassing all. In the intervals of his scholarly pursuits, he delved deeply into the subtleties of the *Yi*.

While annotating the *Canon of Supreme Mystery* up to its ninth scroll, Zhang Yu suddenly dozed off in broad daylight and dreamed of Yang Xiong, who said: “The *Supreme Mystery* is like a floating pagoda—thirteen scrolls in all. You have annotated but nine; how can the celestial mechanism be so easily divulged?” Yu awoke, deeply unsettled by the strangeness of it.

Later, he briefly completed the tenth scroll and presented it to Emperor Shenzong of Song, who, delighted, offered him a noble title. Yu declined, and was instead enfeoffed as the Recluse of Serene Retreat. He was on close terms with Shao Yong, styled Kangjie.

Once, while traveling to Jinyan Bridge in Guanghan, he encountered a boy of twelve reciting poetry. Delighted, Yu took him home, renamed him Jing Tong, and often studied the *Scripture of the Yellow Court*. Each time he finished reading, the boy would secretly peer at the text.

One day, a youth in blue robes arrived bearing a letter. Yu accepted it, but the messenger vanished. On the envelope was written: “From Zhenyi Zi, a commoner of the Southern Marchmount, to the Recluse of Serene Retreat in the Western Prefecture.” Inside was but a single poem:

*Unfulfilled, the mountain’s chant,
Yet worldly echoes reach my ear.
Laughter and speech lose their true sense,
Dust and filth defile the spirit’s robe.
Return to plant southern land’s mushrooms,
Transmute northern Qi’s gold bright.
A thousand days of diligent toil—
Jade groves arise of their own right.*

Later, while wandering by West Stream, Yu happened to lift his foot, and an extraordinary man, Li Shining, came to visit. Yu hastily said: “My foot was washed in West Stream’s flowing waters.” Li instantly replied: “My hand holds the poem sent from the Southern Marchmount.” Yu, startled, laughed and asked: “How did you know?” Li answered: “I have known for some time.” Before leaving, Li said: “I go ahead to the Southern Marchmount; you should come soon.” Thereafter, Li was never seen again.

One day, Jing Tong announced his departure. Yu asked: “Where do you go?” The boy replied: “I go ahead to the Southern Marchmount to await you, Master.” Yu asked: “How do you know?” The boy answered: “I have known for some time.” A month after the boy sat down and vanished, Yu bid farewell to his acquaintances and achieved liberation through the corpse.

Yu had once refined an elixir, and after ingesting it, his form dissolved like a cicada’s molting shell. To this day, he is occasionally seen on the Southern Marchmount.

Duan Guyan composed an elegy, of which a fragment reads:

*Liberation through the corpse—hard to trace,
A golden crucible left in empty space.
The great hermit of the West is gone,
The Lesser Star of the Northern Dipper dims its place.*

Zhang Xianliang also wrote a poem:

*From the Western Sea, a name of might,
Or so they say—discarded age, a cicada’s flight.
On Green City, immortals’ bonds were tied,
Yet suddenly the hermit’s star sank from the sky.
The golden crucible forged true mercury’s art,
The Jade Hall passed on the* Canon of Supreme Mystery’s *part.
A kindred spirit in life, my debt runs deep—
Ashamed, my talent fails to carve his stele.*

In the fourth year of the Xining reign of Emperor Shenzong of the Song, the xin-hai year, a military officer named Li □, serving as the Hengzhou Pacification Commissioner, ventured deep into Mount Jiuyi. The path became impassable, so he dismounted and took lodging in a villager’s home. Gazing ahead, he saw a column of azure mist rising straight into the sky from a distant ridge. Pointing, he asked the villagers what it was, but none could say.

Li marked the spot and later told Li Yanyang, a scholar who had long struggled in the imperial examinations and harbored a fondness for the strange. Yanyang, drawn to the arts of immortality through the teachings of the Yellow Emperor and Laozi, was delighted by the news. He packed provisions and set out with Li. Scaling the verdant slopes, they suddenly came upon a level stretch where several thatched cottages stood. Entering, they found an old man seated in quiet repose. Startled, he asked, “How did you come here? This place is beyond mortal reach.”

“We came seeking the Dao,” Yanyang replied.

The old man smiled, gestured for them to sit, and inquired after their names. “I am a man of the late Tang,” he said, “who fled the world to dwell here. My surname is Xing, but I no longer wish my given name to be known.” Yanyang suspected he might be Xing Hepu, but the old man shook his head. He then asked about the current dynasty, unaware that it was now the Song, and even the emperor’s name. Yanyang recounted the lineage of the Xining reign, and the old man nodded in acknowledgment.

When Yanyang pressed him about the place, the old man remained silent. Returning with more supplies, Yanyang visited again. The old man welcomed him warmly and kept him for five days, teaching him only the arts of breath regulation and qi refinement. When weary of speech, he would take up his zither and play, filling the hall with the roar of thunder and crashing waves, the echoes lingering without end.

From then on, Yanyang returned repeatedly, and the old man received him as an old friend, no longer questioning his visits. Yanyang began to inquire about deeper matters, but the old man replied, “These secrets are not easily spoken. I am reviewing celestial records, and there is a set time for this work. Your visits disrupt my tasks—do not come again. I, too, will soon depart this place.”

Glancing at the books, Yanyang asked, “Even immortals use such things?” The old man replied, “Is there an immortal who does not know writing? These are all transcribed from the Jade Chambers, assigned by those who strike the registers of destiny. Once used, they are returned and reissued.”

At last, they parted, and the old man presented Yanyang with twelve poems. Two are recorded here:

*Silent, leaning on the armrest, shoulders relaxed as pines,
A mind of ten thousand ages, solitary and divine.
At times, three scrolls of seal script spread like contracts,
A single hairpin star stirs when the cap is donned anew.
The Azure Lad departs to urge the trees of Southern Mountain,
The rustic guest seeks the scriptures of the Northern Emperor.
The Dao of Heaven needs no peering through the window—
The mountains at the gate stand green, a sight to behold.*

*Worldly achievements and fame are not worth debate,
Best to enter the Gate of Truth while still young.
Like Zhuangzi’s butterfly, all is but a dream,
Yet you are a descendant of the Historian of a thousand years.
Distinguish inner and outer in the* Yellow Court*,
Do not entrust the secrets of* Zhouyi *to the* Qian *and* Kun *trigrams.
When in future years the hills and valleys shift,
I shall still dwell in Penglai—my home remains.*

The seal script was ancient, and Yanyang could not decipher it. He never returned again. It took him eighteen years to fully unravel the characters.

Yanyang attained some mastery of the Dao and now wanders between Xiang and Heng, unknown to others. Wang Xingzhi wrote *A Record of Immortal Xing*.

The Daoist Jia Shanxiang, styled Hongju, was a native of Pengzhou. Skilled in conversation and fond of the zither and wine, he blended seamlessly with the world while silently pursuing cultivation. Su Dongpo once visited him and presented a verse:

*Body like the plantain,
Heart like the lotus,
A hundred joints unobstructed,
Ten thousand apertures luminous.
Coming as one,
Departing as eighty-four thousand.*

The closing lines read: “Hongju’s reply.”

Jia Shanxiang replied: “This old Daoist has no such elaborate reckonings.”

During the reign of Emperor Zhezong of the Song, Shanxiang composed *Records of the Dragon’s Leisure* and *Biographies of Eminent Daoists*, which circulated in the world. One day, at the Supreme Clarity Palace in Bozhou, a gathering requested him to lecture on the *Supreme Cavernous Numinous Treasure Scripture for the Salvation of Humanity*. After expounding the scripture twice, the blind regained their sight. Among the assembly was an old woman, over seventy years of age, who had lost her vision for thirty years—upon hearing the scripture’s meaning, her sight was suddenly restored. Later, on the eve of the ritual offering, she dreamed of a host of divine officials transmitting the Supreme Lord’s decree, bestowing upon her immortal robes and appointing Shanxiang as the master of the Supreme Clarity Palace. Several days afterward, she ascended in transcendence. Zhang Shangying composed *A Record of True Wanderings*, compiling these events.

**Zhou Shiqing**
Zhou Shiqing was a native of Pucheng in Jianzhou. In the early Yuanyou era of Emperor Zhezong of the Song, he journeyed to the capital to sit for the provincial examinations. En route, he encountered a Daoist who spoke at length, whereupon he took his disciple into Youguo Mountain to refine the elixir. His reputation spread far and wide, and scholar-officials passing beneath the mountain never failed to visit him. When Lü Jifu was transferred from Jian’an to Xuanzhou, he suffered from a foot ailment that rendered him unable to walk and came to pay his respects to Zhou.

Zhou invited Lü to extend his leg forward, then directed his qi upon it while having others fan the area. After a short while, Lü’s foot ailment flared with searing heat that rose to his heart, but before long the pain subsided. Zhou remained on the mountain for twenty years, and his elixir neared completion. One evening, a violent storm erupted with thunderous lightning. At dawn, when he inspected the alchemical furnace, the elixir was gone. Unprepared for this, Zhou projected his spirit in search of it, telling his wife: “I must depart briefly. I shall return in seven days—do not presume I am dead and burn my body.” His wife followed his instructions.

Zhou had long been close with a monk who had built a hut on another mountain. Hearing of Zhou’s death, the monk came to offer condolences and strongly urged his wife, saying: “Those who cultivate the Dao regard the body as no more than dung and dirt. Since he is gone, why cling to it?” The wife, believing the monk’s words, wept as she burned the body. The next day, Zhou returned—only to find no form left to reanimate. From the void, he rebuked his wife sharply before departing.

Some time later, the monk returned. When the wife recounted what had happened, he said: “I had just received news of his passing and came for that reason. I was not here the other day.” Then they realized it had been a demon in disguise. Later, Zhou’s family placed his portrait in the monk’s abbey, where a daily attendant tended the incense and invariably found four coins on the ground. Zhou also left behind a vat of vinegar that never spoiled, even after a long time.

**Liu Datou**

Secretary Mi, passing through Xu Yi’s vegetarian feast, was a man of Qin. During the Shaosheng era of Emperor Zhe of the Song, he traveled to the capital for an official posting. Passing through Luozhong, it was bitterly cold, and a beggar stood by the roadside. Moved by compassion, Mi searched his basket and found three hundred coins, which he gave to the beggar in full. The beggar did not thank him at first, but after walking some dozen paces, he turned back and called out from behind Mi’s horse: “I am grateful to you, sir, for your kindness in saving my life. When you reach the capital one day, I hope you will visit the home of Liu Datou in Bamboo Register Lane.” Mi agreed.

Upon arriving in the capital, he had forgotten the earlier words. One day, while visiting a relative, he passed through a narrow alley. Asking those nearby, he was told, “This is Bamboo Register Lane.” Then Mi recalled the beggar’s words. He knocked on the door and called for Liu Datou three times. Datou came out to greet him, saying, “You are a man of honor, sir, to visit this humble old man.” He bowed and seated Mi in a small pavilion, then called his wife to come out and greet him. She bowed and said, “Had I not met you, sir, the other day, I would have become a starving brick.” He promptly ordered wine to be prepared, though the tray held only a few large peaches. After three rounds of drinking, Mi took his leave.

The beggar said, “I am poor and lowly and have nothing to offer, but I wish to present you with these peaches.” Mi tucked them into his sleeve and departed. Upon returning to his lodging, he felt them grow increasingly heavy, until he could no longer bear the weight.

He examined them and found they were all pure gold. When he returned to the place, the dwelling was empty.

*End of Scroll Fifty-One of the Comprehensive Mirror of True Immortals Who Embodied the Dao Through the Ages*

**Scroll Fifty-Two of the Comprehensive Mirror of True Immortals Who Embodied the Dao Through the Ages**

**Liu Hun Kang**

Liu Hun Kang, styled Zhitong, was a native of Jinling. None of his ancestors had ever served as officials. His mother, née Zhu, dreamed on the evening of the second day of the twelfth month of the second year of Jingyou of the reign of Emperor Renzong of the Song—a night when Lord Mao descended—that a feathered immortal entered her chamber. Upon waking, she gave birth to Hun Kang.

At the age of thirteen, he apprenticed under Taoist priest Tang Hanxiang of the Taihe Abbey in his home prefecture. In the fifth year of Jiayou, he passed the scriptural examination and became a Daoist priest. Shedding worldly concerns, he delved into Daoist texts day and night, attaining a profound understanding of the esoteric principles of the *Dongjing* scriptures.

Distressed by the lack of enlightened masters in the world, he let his hair loose and ascended the altar, taking Heaven as his ultimate guide. Later, he heard that Taoist Mao Fengrou of the Three Mao Mountains had partially mastered the Dao of the Wondrous Lord Zhu, so he went to study under him. Mao, struck by his exceptional qualities at first sight, transmitted to him the entire corpus of the *Great Cavern Scriptures*.

He then built a hut on Jijin Peak to reside in. One day, a feathered immortal visited his dwelling and, pointing to the eastern corner of the hut, said to him, “Dwell here, embrace the spirit and guard the center, and let your virtue and kindness extend to others. Then you shall be without shame before those who came before you.” Turning to Hun Kang’s forehead, he asked, “This is a place of non-action, the very essence of the Dao, and must not bear any blemish.” He pressed his hand upon it, and by the next day, the scar had vanished.

From then on, Hun Kang diligently practiced deeds that benefited others, and his reputation was revered far and wide. During the reign of Emperor Zhezong, he was summoned to the capital and granted the name Yuanfu Abbey for his residence. When Emperor Huizong ascended the throne, he was called to court. *The Comprehensive Mirror of Events in the Imperial Court* records: “Hun Kang was a man of integrity, deeply respected by Emperor Shenzong, and thus the emperor held him in high regard.”

In the second year of the *Mingdao* era, he requested to return to the mountains. In the seventh month, an edict was issued in response to a memorial by Master Zhu Ziying of the Wondrous Observation, granting him the title of Jade-Carved Immortal of the Nine Elders of the Celestial Capital and bestowing upon him the honorific *Baozhen Guanmiao Xiansheng* (Master of Preserved Perfection and Wondrous Observation). In the seventh month of the fifth year, his title was elevated to *Baozhen Guanmiao Chonghe Xiansheng* (Master of Preserved Perfection, Wondrous Observation, and Harmonious Emptiness).

In the second year of *Daguan*, he, along with Taoist priest Xu Shenxi of Taizhou and Celestial Master Zhang Xujing, convened at the Shangqing Chuxiang Palace, where each was granted a Daoist abbey to reside in. Soon after, he shed his mortal form. In the fifth month, he was posthumously conferred the title of *Grand Master of the Palace with Gold Seal and Purple Ribbon*.

The beginnings and endings of his extraordinary life are fully recorded on his grand stele.

Wang Quan, styled Zizhen, was a native of Yangping in Fengxiang. His father had passed the imperial examinations, and all his brothers became *jinshi*; only Quan delighted in seclusion and the Dao. One day, while walking in the countryside, he rested in a melon patch. A peasant woman approached to beg for melons, her breasts swelling to her belly. Quan knew she was no ordinary person and asked her surname. She replied, “I am Xiao Sanniang.” Quan took melons, placed them in her basket, and gave them to her. As she ate, she offered him the remainder, asking, “May you taste them?” Quan accepted and ate without hesitation. The woman said, “You are teachable. The Divine Immortal Haichanzi now resides here and will initiate worthy disciples. Tomorrow, I shall take you to meet him.”

Upon meeting Haichan, the master said, “You have encountered me by virtue of your past karmic affinity.” He commanded Quan to kneel for a long while, transmitted the supreme Dao, bestowed the elixir formula, and admonished him to accumulate merit and virtuous deeds. Quan then returned home to inform his mother and sent his wife away. He wandered through famous mountains. At one time, high ministers recommended his worthiness, and he was granted the title *Chongxu Recluse*.

In the third year of *Yuanfu* during the reign of Emperor Zhezong of Song, he traveled again to Mount Mao. Earlier, a stone cavern on Central Peak had suddenly opened—the so-called Convenient Gate of Huayang Grotto-Heaven mentioned in the *Zhen’gao*—which had remained sealed for a thousand years. Moreover, sweet dew had repeatedly descended. The Daoist priest Liu Hunkang said, “An extraordinary person must be coming.” Soon after, Quan arrived and received the *Shangqing Register*. That night, celestial music was heard floating in the air. He stayed for over a year. One day, he dreamed of two heavenly beings and hundreds of yellow-robed messengers riding white tigers to welcome him. Mounting a tiger, he traversed perilous heights and entered the stone cavern through the Convenient Gate that had opened earlier. Looking around, he saw golden courts and jade halls. Two azure-clad youths entered to announce his arrival to Lord Mao. He bowed twice in audience. The Lord asked, “You have been greatly labored.” Quan replied, “The Emperor has already appointed you as Vice-Director of the Huayang Grotto-Heaven’s Office of Destiny.” Thereupon, he was urged to return with a golden exhortation.

Upon awakening, he bid farewell to Hunkang, saying, “My allotted years are nearly spent, and I have received what I was meant to. From here, I depart.” He then addressed the Daoist monk Ge Chong, saying, “I dare to burden you with my passing.” He foretold that on the seventeenth day of the eighth month, he would shed his mortal form. When the day arrived, he donned his robes and cap, sat upright, and passed away. This occurred in the *Jianzhong Jingguo* era of Emperor Huizong’s reign, at the age of sixty-one.

Xu Shouxin, the Divine Elder, was a native of Hailing.

He served as a laborer at the Temple of Heavenly Celebration, clad in tattered robes and dragging hempen sandals, sometimes walking barefoot. Throughout the day, he did nothing but hold vigil, sprinkle water, and sweep, all while reciting the *Scripture of Salvation for the Multitudes* without cease.

A Daoist named Xu Yuanji arrived from elsewhere, afflicted with a severe and repulsive case of leprosy. The others loathed him and banished him to a thatched hut behind the temple. The Divine Elder alone attended to him. When Xu Yuanji later died, the Divine Elder begged for coins to prepare his funeral. Afterward, he returned to the thatched hut and wept for three days. Emerging, he feigned madness, and gradually, strange occurrences began to manifest. The people revered him as divine, calling him the Divine Elder, and only then did they realize he had attained the Dao from the leprous Daoist.

When the temple ran out of food, the Divine Elder said, “I shall seek provisions for you.” He entered the main hall, lay down for a long while, then emerged and told the assembled Daoists, “It is coming.” Soon after, those bearing rice on their shoulders arrived in such numbers that they jostled one another.

When someone offered silver as an offering, the Divine Elder placed it on his bed. A thief, learning of its absence, broke in through the unlocked door, only to see the Divine Elder sitting upright on the bed with a stern countenance. The thief fled in terror. From then on, people from all directions came to inquire about disasters and omens.

Lü Huici, styled Jifu, was traveling to the capital after observing mourning rites when he took a detour to visit the Divine Elder. The Divine Elder fled in alarm, but Jifu pursued him. The Divine Elder turned and said, “Guard well, guard well.” Jifu bowed and departed. Upon returning to court, he was soon demoted to Prefect of Shanzhou due to some affair.

Jiang Zhiqi, styled Yingshu, was overseeing the transport of grain in Jianghuai when he proposed digging a canal for shipping. Fearing the presence of impassable stone, he hesitated, uncertain of what to do, and sought the Divine Elder’s counsel. The Divine Elder, seeing him approach, called out, “Dig if you must—what sort of man are you?” Yingshu marveled and said, “A remarkable man indeed.” The canal was subsequently dug as planned.

When Emperor Zhezong fell ill, he dispatched Zhefu to offer incense. The Divine Elder inscribed a talisman, which Jifu presented to the court. Shortly afterward, Emperor Huizong ascended the throne.

In the early *Chongning* era, the court summoned him, but he refused to go. They forcibly carried him to the Eastern Capital, yet he could not be detained. Thus, they reverently sent him back, and in Hailing, they built the Xianyuan Wanshou Palace for him to reside in. At the end of the *Daguan* era, he departed through *shijie*.

**Zhang Runzi**
Zhang Runzi’s origins are unknown.

Zhang Runzi often wandered among the peaks of Mount Song, where he worked for various Daoist abbeys yet refused to accept even a single coin in payment. He wore straw sandals and patched robes, unchanged through winter’s cold and summer’s heat. When he spoke to others, he would say, “The human body must be nourished and moistened.” People failed to grasp his meaning and simply called him “Runzi.” If pressed to explain, he would respond with nonsense, his words beyond comprehension. A poem attributed to him circulates in the world:

At Qi’s ford, I delved to find the great Dao’s root,
Emaciated in form yet steadfast in will, silent and dim.
Gentle rain drifts along Kunlun’s path,
Mighty winds roar at the gates of the vast sea.
Sun and moon’s qi mingles, warming the golden crucible,
Heaven and earth’s trigrams stir, the jade furnace stays warm.
This principle must be refined in life,
Lest you, like the common folk, debate it only after death.

After some time, he left to work for the Li family of Xinzheng in Zhengzhou. In the third year of the *Chongning* era of Emperor Huizong of Song, he took leave of the Li family, leaving behind a verse:

Diligent in study from the start,
Achievement comes with ease.
The body remains ever moist,
A hundred seas never run dry.
The Dao hides in primordial darkness,
Living on coarse fare, dwelling in humble huts.
When essence and merit are complete,
I return to my pure capital.

That day, he told his disciples, “The Jade Emperor has issued a decree—I ascend to heaven.” Soon after, above a great locust tree to the southeast of his dwelling, five-colored clouds gathered, and celestial music resounded. Runzi rode the clouds away.

**Wang Ji**
Wang Ji was an old soldier from Shanzhou.

In the scorching heat of midsummer, he would often sit exposed to the blazing sun, and in the depths of winter, he would submerge himself in stream waters, only his head visible—so the people of the region often praised him as one possessing the Dao. In the early years of the *Chongning* era of Emperor Huizong of Song, when Wanqi Xu’s father served as prefect of Shanzhou, Ji happened to visit Xu. Xu invited him into the library and offered him wine. When the wine was finished, Ji took up a brush from the desk and wrote out an efficacious prescription, requiring only one or two ingredients, yet capable of curing even the most intractable illnesses.

Xu was still young at the time and did not hold him in high regard, casually discarding the prescription. One day, Ji came to Xu and said, “Your lordship has repeatedly harmed your spleen and stomach with rich food and wine, and thus fallen ill. I shall teach you a massage technique, but take care not to reveal my words.” Soon after, he suddenly told Xu, “I shall be leaving.” The next day, he passed away, and some prepared his body for burial.

Several months later, he was seen in a neighboring prefecture. When his grave was opened upon his return, only the shoes he had worn remained. From that year onward, Xu lived to nearly seventy, his cheeks like peach blossoms, his appetite ever increasing. Even when he drank heavily until midnight, the method Ji had taught him proved effective. Only then did Xu regret that in his youth he had failed to recognize this extraordinary man and seek to learn from him the secrets of longevity and enduring vision. What Xu had received, not even his elder brother—who later became a *Canzhizhengshi*—was permitted to know.

**Zhu Dabo**
