Zhu Dabo—his origins unknown—once served as a laborer in the household of Gui Anshi of Guixi in Xinzhou. Outwardly, he appeared dull-witted, yet he performed his duties with utmost care. One day, he returned from outside with unusual bearing and declared, “Just now, a Daoist gave me medicine, and now I no longer need to eat.” Anshi tested him, and it proved true. From then on, whether beneath the scorching summer sun or lying upon winter ice, he continued his labor as before. The Gui family began to hold him in higher regard and wished to treat him as a guest, but Dabo declined, saying, “I shall remain a laborer here; when the year is complete, I will depart.”

Years later, in the third year of the *Daguan* era of Emperor Huizong of Song, he suddenly told Anshi, “At White Flower Crag, some ten *li* from here, someone has summoned me. Would the master accompany me?” Anshi followed him at once. Before they arrived, the sound of flutes and strings filled the air, and crimson clouds densely shrouded the mountain. Anshi was still gazing in astonishment when Dabo took his leave. Before his words were finished, he had vanished.

Liu Yi

Liu Yi was a native of Lantian in Jingzhao. For sixty years, he dwelt in reclusion at Zizhi Hermitage, his skin like jade and his countenance robust. He could drink several *dou* of wine without losing composure, ascending steep peaks and descending perilous slopes as though treading level ground. In the early years of the *Xuanhe* era of the Song, word of him reached the capital, and Emperor Huizong dispatched envoys to summon him. It was a time of torrential autumn rains, the mud so deep it swallowed the ankles; yet Yi walked on foot while the mounted envoys could not keep pace. Upon arriving at the Eastern Capital, Huizong received him with great courtesy, though Yi found no pleasure in it and earnestly sought to return to the mountains. He often stayed at the monastic retreat of Huayan Creek. At the end of the *Xuanhe* era, he said to his disciples, “Why do the mountains, rivers, grasses, and trees reek so foully? I loathe it.” Then he departed through *shijie*. When they prepared to bury him, his body was like a cast-off cicada shell. Later, when war erupted, his disciples finally marveled at his words.

Wei Erweng and Wei Erxi were hereditary farmers of Leize in Puzhou. The village elders had known them since childhood, yet their appearance remained as that of men over seventy. Clad in a single hempen robe, a palm-leaf fan in hand, they walked with the aid of a staff.

They had never studied writing, yet their pupils gleamed like stars, and they could inscribe characters as fine as fly heads. From time to time, they spoke to others of fortune and misfortune, and the villagers came to hold them in some reverence. One midwinter, someone presented the two elders with unrefined cloth. A thief, having learned of this, came to their dwelling at nightfall. The two elders called out his name in greeting: “Do you seek our instruction?” Then they tossed him the cloth. The thief, astonished, bowed twice in apology and departed.

Earlier, in Youcheng, there had been an old man named Wang Laozhi. Huizong once dreamed of him and summoned him to the Eastern Capital that very day. Soon after, the emperor heard of the two elders and dispatched envoys to bring them to court. The envoys found their hut but heard only the thunderous snoring of the two elders—no trace of their forms could be seen. Fearing they could not fulfill their mission, the envoys pleaded urgently. The two elders were indeed in their hut, yet when pressed to depart, they vanished without a trace. The envoys could not bring them to court and returned with only a single ode. Its words read:

Now I enter the mountains,
to escape this clamor and vexation.
Guarded by petty clerks,
courted by high officials—
how could they exchange for my joy,
the pure leisure beyond the world?
Nurturing the true, preserving *qi*,
seven reversals, nine returns.
The golden elixir complete,
I ascend the immortal’s altar.
Vermilion towers of Penglai,
jade gates and golden barriers.
Whoever would learn from me—
the cloud-path is no hardship.

At the beginning of the *Xuanhe* era, they suddenly departed through *shijie*. The villagers gathered to bury them, but when they lifted the coffin, it felt empty. Opening it, they found only a poem hidden at the head, which read:

Beware the fire-field’s heart-master,
lest caution slip once the path is complete.
To guard Kan and Li is the subtlest art;
pursuing fame and profit brings only torment.
If you grasp the method of Crimson Clouds,
the road leads to the Purple Palace’s immortals.

Master Wang Laozhi bore the surname Wang and the given name Laozhi, a native of Linquan in Pu Prefecture. He once encountered the Perfected Master Zhongli, who transmitted to him the essential oral instructions of internal alchemy, and thus became renowned for his mastery of the Daoist arts.

In Yizhou, an official sought to serve at his side and sent a trusted acquaintance to convey his intent. The Master responded with a poem:

*A man long retired, old and worn,*
*has planted mulberry and hemp by the hundred.*
*All were twisted into being by the tip of a brush—*
*on every branch, a wronged soul clings.*

He resolutely refused to receive the man.

In Pu, a scholar of glib tongue sought to confound him with words and went to visit. The Master’s dwelling was encircled by high embankments, with only a dog’s door for entry and exit. The scholar crawled through and began to speak at length. Suddenly, he noticed a whirlpool forming on the ground, which swiftly grew to several feet across, revealing scales within as large as a bushel. The Master said to the scholar, “Go home at once—any delay will bring you extraordinary misfortune.” The scholar hastily departed, but before he had traveled five *li*, thunder, lightning, and hail erupted violently. His horse crouched motionless, so he took shelter in an earthen chamber. Gazing toward the Master’s thatched hut, he prostrated himself a hundred times and begged for his life, narrowly escaping harm.

In the ninth month of the third year of the *Zhenghe* era of Emperor Huizong of Song, an imperial edict commanded the prefectures and counties to urgently dispatch him to the capital. There, he was bestowed the title *Master of Penetrating Mystery*. In the first month of the fourth year, his title was expanded to *Perfected Master of Observing the Subtle, Illuminating the True, and Penetrating Mystery*.

Though the Master spurned official emoluments, he would at times deliver forthright admonitions to the Son of Heaven. One day, Emperor Huizong summoned him into the inner palace, where Empress Xiansu was also present. The Master abruptly produced a sheet of paper and declared, “In days to come, Your Majesty and the Empress will both face calamity. I shall depart in death and will not live to see it. I possess the *Mirror of Heaven and Earth* method, which may be used to avert misfortune through supplication. Yet you must also cultivate virtue—only then can Heaven’s will be turned.”

The Master instructed, “Cast the *Mirror of Heaven and Earth* according to my method, and suspend each with five-colored tassels above your bedchambers. After my death, whenever you sit beneath the mirror, recall my words. Day by day, reflect on how to dissolve misfortune before it takes shape.” The Emperor assented to his proposal.

A decree was issued to halt all artisans’ work, and once the mirrors were completed, they were presented to the throne. The Master then returned to Puyang, where he passed away. The *Comprehensive Mirror of the August Dynasty: Record of Events* states: “In the tenth month of the fourth year of Xuanhe, on the day *xinsi*, *Perfected Master of Observing the Subtle, Illuminating the True, and Penetrating Mystery* Wang Laozhi died. The court bestowed gold for his burial and posthumously honored him as *Grand Master for Proper Consultation*.” The *Record of Xuanhe* adds: “Wherever the Master dwelled, flowers would bloom upon the earth, called ‘earth brocade.’ During the Jingkang disaster wrought by the northern tribes, the two palaces treasured and clung to the mirrors, sighing over his foresight and how he had guided the sovereign onto the right path.”

**Li Sigong**
Li Sigong, styled Jingyuan, was a native of Jishui in Luling. In his youth, he entered the Kai Ming Abbey to study, later passing the scriptural examinations and donning the cap and robe of a Daoist adept. His aspirations and conduct were extraordinary. Often, he would wander freely among mountains and rivers, exchanging any money he earned for wine, sometimes drinking alone in the marketplace. Though he lived past seventy, his appearance showed no signs of aging. He rarely spoke to others, and none knew what practices he had cultivated.

In the fourth year of Zhenghe under Emperor Huizong, he roamed to Luochuan, often lodging at a wineshop by Xixi Bridge. An elderly woman there found him most unusual and would offer him wine to drink, never asking whether he had paid or not. This continued for years without fail. One day, he suddenly told her, “I must soon depart. I thank you for your generous care and shall leave a letter in return.” He drank again, becoming drunk, and spent the night at the inn. The next morning, when others arose and looked upon him, he had already departed in transformation. His body remained warm as if alive, and a fragrant scent filled the room. Word spread, and his kin were hastily summoned to enshroud and bury him in the garden behind the inn.

A month later, a traveler arrived from Mount Heng, saying that on the road he had chanced upon Jingyuan. Even the woodcutters recognized him, for he wore the same robes and cap as before. He entrusted the traveler with a letter to thank the wine-seller and his family. Later, when his kin gathered to open the tomb and coffin, they found no corpse within—only a bamboo staff tied with a silk cord.

**Rongyang**
Rongyang, a native of Dongping, often ground ink in the marketplace, where people called him “Second Master.” Later, he traveled to Shu and arrived at Meixian County. There, he accompanied a prefectural official to ascend the King Yue Tower. That night, a roof tile fell, and Second Master said, “A defeated ghost did this.” The official asked the guards, who replied, “When the tower was repaired some time ago, a carpenter fell to his death.” The official was greatly astonished.

Soon after, Second Master addressed Prefect Zhao, saying, “You should leave at once, or disaster will befall you.” The following year, the southern barbarians breached the frontier defenses and invaded Shu. All below the prefect were punished.

In the early years of Xuanhe under Emperor Huizong, a decree was issued to seek extraordinary individuals. The regional inspector reported Rongyang’s name, and the court ordered him to travel by post carriage to the Eastern Capital. Second Master said, “The times are as they are. What more can I do?”

The regional inspector pressed him, and unable to refuse, he set out on the journey. Upon arrival, Emperor Huizong inquired about his learning, but he gave no answer. The emperor then bestowed upon him one hundred thousand coins and sent him home. Second Master returned to Shu, living in seclusion without eating, drinking only wine from time to time. Once, while drinking with Ma Qian, a student from Chengdu, at a tavern, he raised his sleeve as if summoning something. Moments later, coins emerged from his sleeve, filling the table, before vanishing. Counting them, the sum matched exactly the cost of the wine. When he encountered the sick, he would take a wooden branch about a foot long, breathe upon it, and place it on the afflicted area. Soon after, he would retrieve it, cast it to the ground, and trample it—or sometimes discard it entirely—and the patient would invariably recover. Some, however, suffered from eye pain and cried out. Second Master would say, “I have shared my vision with you.” He would then open his eyes wide and instruct the sufferer to gaze into them. As Second Master’s gaze fixed upon them, they could scarcely see, and their pain would subside.

One day, he brought Zheng Zicheng’s ink to the home of Liu Changyuan’s father. When Liu’s father ground it, it turned into gleaming gold. Liu later said, “I have known Second Master for forty years, and he has always had the vigor of youth, never aging. He often spoke of affairs from the Sui, Tang, and Five Dynasties eras.” Some said, “Second Master was skilled in the arts of *moving essence and transforming qi*.”

During the Shaoxing reign of Emperor Gaozong, Rong Yi entered Shu as *Commissioner of Tea and Horses* and remarked, “Second Master was the elder brother of my great-grandfather.” Thus, he was five generations his senior. It was also said, “When the transport commissioner of Yidu was slandered, Second Master followed him. At that time, he was already over a hundred and twenty years old, residing in Small Hemp Creek on Mount Qingcheng.” He passed away during the Shaoxing era. His lifespan spanned many decades.

Wang Shujian, styled Zhidao, was a native of She in Huizhou. In the eighteenth year of the Shaoxing reign of Emperor Gaozong of the Song, he served as Vice Minister of the Court of Agriculture and was appointed Commissioner of Finance for Hubei. Once, he attended a banquet hosted by the general Tian Shizhong. Arriving last, he found the transport commissioner and the prefect of E already seated, playing chess with a Daoist known as Master Ri Mu, who was also present. Upon seeing Wang, the Daoist bowed and said, “It has been long since we last met—are you in good health?” Wang, startled, replied, “We have never met before—why do you speak of a long separation?” The Daoist said, “You have now become a man of high rank and have forgotten. Do you not recall the inn on the road to Xuanzhou, where we spoke of Niu Qizhang’s affairs?” Wang suddenly rose and bowed in acknowledgment. The Daoist then departed. Wang turned to the other guests and said, “In the fifth year of Chongning during the reign of Emperor Huizong, I passed the imperial examinations and was appointed as an instructor in Xuanzhou. In the winter, I traveled alone to assume my post and lodged at a small village inn, where there was only one room, already occupied by a scholar. As night had fallen and I could not proceed further, I had no choice but to push open the door and enter. I said, ‘I have arrived at dusk and must share this room with you—would that be acceptable?’”

The scholar was squatting by the fire when he turned and said, “Very well.” After a long while, he suddenly asked, “Have you ever read the *Old Book of Tang*?” I replied with irritation, “Though my learning is meager, how could I be so ignorant?” He then smiled and said, “Do you recall the biography of Niu Sengru?” Finding his words incoherent, I grew angry and refused to answer. The scholar said, “My words are not idle—you are the reincarnation of Sengru. In your past life, you were the Military Commissioner of Wuchang, and as your allotted span was not yet exhausted, you are destined to return in this life. In the future, your official rank and emoluments will largely be in those lands.”

I found this extraordinary and suspected he was a physiognomist. When I asked his name, he replied slowly, “Do you know of one called Yong Xiaowen?” I am he. Since being rejected at the palace examination in the early years of Chongning, I have wandered among mountains and forests, having encountered something by chance. When I pressed him on his arts, he refused to speak, and we spent the night facing each other, discussing only the Great Dao. At dawn, he departed, and I never saw him again. People in Shu all said he had died, but upon seeing the Daoist’s appearance today, I realize it was Master Yong. His bearing was no different from forty years ago—truly a man who had attained the Dao.” All the guests at the table were astonished.

Later, Wang served as Transport Commissioner of Hubei, then as Prefect of Ezhou, and as Intendant, spending many years in Wuchang. Mu Sheng, styled Guangmo, often traveled between the He and Mian rivers, speaking to others only of literature and calligraphy, never of other matters, so none knew him as an extraordinary man. Shen Jun, styled Daoyuan, also knew him and said, “During the Zhenghe era, when a Daoist preached before the emperor, the emperor remarked that he had attained half the mastery of Lin Lingsu, hence his surname Mu.”

Huangfu Huan, styled Zhiyuan, was a native of Kaifeng. By nature, he was serene and indifferent, possessing keen insight and remarkable vision. In his leisure from examination studies, he was especially skilled in the Three Mysteries. Knowing his fate, he did not seek office and instead became a Daoist adept. He studied at the Taiyi Palace in the eastern capital, his conduct upright yet enigmatic.

In the first year of the Zhenghe era of Emperor Huizong, when the court promoted Daoist learning, the master turned toward the Dao. The following year, he took the examination at the Imperial Academy and placed first. The emperor read his essay and appointed him Golden Altar Gentleman, but he declined and requested the title of “Free and Unfettered Gentleman.” Donning rustic attire, he traveled to Xiluo, where he met the perfected one, Feng Yeren, and obtained the essentials of the Dao. Later, he journeyed to Mount Heng and resided at the Lingxu Terrace of the Huizhen Abbey. Before long, he was summoned to court and lived in the Hermits’ Lodge of the Taiyi Palace. Later, he requested to return to the mountains and passed away in meditation by the Ru River.

The Fennel Daoist
In the final years of the Zhenghe era, Lin Lingsu lectured at the Baolu Palace, drawing thousands of Daoist and lay followers, all cupping their cheeks in reverence. Only one Daoist stood before him with glaring eyes. Lin, surprised by his lack of bowing, rebuked him, “What abilities do you possess?” The Daoist replied, “None.” Lin said, “If you have no abilities, why are you here?”

The Daoist replied, “If you possess all abilities, why then are you here?”

At that time, Emperor Huizong was listening from behind the curtain. Intrigued, he summoned the Daoist and asked what abilities he truly possessed. The Daoist answered, “Your servant can nurture and grow all things.” The emperor immediately ordered his attendants to fetch seeds from the Daoist abbey, and they returned with a handful of fennel seeds, which were handed to the Daoist. Two imperial guards were assigned to oversee him as he planted them at the foot of Genyue, and he was kept under watch in the abbey overnight. By the third watch, he had vanished without a trace. The next morning, the fennel was found to have flourished into a lush thicket.

Zou Baoguang
Zou Baoguang, in his youth, was registered as a Daoist at the Chongxu Abbey on Mount Luofu. During the Xuanhe era of Emperor Huizong’s reign, his fame reached the imperial court, and he was summoned to the Ningshen Hall to demonstrate his arts. Seven Daoists accompanied him, then suddenly disappeared. When the emperor asked who they were, Baoguang replied, “Your servant dwells in the mountains practicing swordsmanship—these seven were ancient pines.” The emperor, astonished, appointed him Gentleman of Jintan.

Gong Yuanzheng
Gong Yuanzheng, styled Duanben, was a native of Wuling. Though poor, he loved learning, studying classics even while tilling the fields. Later, he became a Daoist, his nature simple and sincere, his devotion to the Dao wholehearted. He oversaw the construction of a grand abbey hall, with towering pavilions, expansive halls, and layered corridors, their gold and azure hues gleaming. With his own hands, he planted tens of thousands of pines and cedars.

When the abbey was completed, the emperor bestowed upon it the plaque "Wanshou" and granted Gong the title "Master Chongyi." He presided over the abbey for forty years, never once taking a meal apart from the community. One day, he summoned his disciples and said, “Within five days, I shall depart.” On the fourth day, he sat upright and recited the *Daodejing* of Laozi. As dawn broke, he passed away with solemn composure, during the Xuanhe era of Emperor Huizong of the Song.

Shen Ruoji
Shen Ruoji, a native of Lin’an, built a thatched hut on Maoshan, dedicating himself to dispensing medicine. During the Xuanhe era of Emperor Huizong of the Song, he was summoned to court and granted the title "Master Dongyuan." Once, he pointed to a vacant plot east of Huayang Cave and said, “When I die, bury me here.” His disciples protested, citing the low and damp terrain, but he paid no heed. When he passed away in the fifteenth year of the Shaoxing era of Emperor Gaozong, his disciples followed his instructions and dug six feet into the ground, uncovering a stone slab inscribed with six characters: “Shen Gong’s seat and sword lie here.” Those who witnessed it marveled.

Zhang Dan
Xu Fengyuan of Quzhou resided on Xiashan in the prefecture. In his youth, he enjoyed the company of those beyond the mundane world. A Daoist named Zhang Dan passed by and was invited to stay at his gate. Zhang’s attire was simple—only a dark green cloth jacket—with nothing beneath his Daoist robe, even in the depths of winter. On moonlit nights, he would take his iron flute into the mountains and play until dawn. Xu Fengyuan studied the *Yijing* and once shut himself away to calculate the *Dayan* numbers but could not grasp the method. Zhang called to him from the next room, “Young scholar, this is not something you can comprehend. Tomorrow, I will explain it to you.” The next day, Zhang taught him the steps of the *guituo* and other methods, through which the life and death, timing, and the rise and fall of all things—from utensils and plants to birds and beasts—could be determined. Xu tested these methods, and they proved unfailingly accurate.

Zhang was fond of wine and often spent entire days drinking in the marketplace, returning only when thoroughly drunk, though his purse was always empty. People said he could transmute *gen* to sustain himself. Xu wished to gauge his capacity and summoned four skilled drinkers to take turns drinking with him. From dawn to dusk, all were drunk, yet Zhang remained unaffected. That night, he entered his room, and from outside, Xu saw him lying beneath the wall, his feet propped against it, his unbound hair hanging into a tile basin, with wine dripping from his temples. Xu’s grandfather, Xu Dequan, was over seventy. Zhang said, “Elder, next May you will face a great calamity. Hurry and use my method to avert it, and you may extend your life by ten years.” The Xu family did not believe him, thinking the Daoist merely sought to frighten them with his words, and so they ignored him. The moment the words left their lips, Zhang knew and immediately departed, entering Luohan Temple in the city.

The following May, Dequan fell ill, and only then did Xu seek Zhang’s aid, but he refused to come. Soon after, Dequan died.

Zhang had a disciple, a mendicant monk, to whom he secretly entrusted a painted scroll of an ox. Whenever he amused himself with guests, he would say, “Hang this picture on the wall, and soon grass will sprout beside it. After a long while, the ox may eat it all, or leave half uneaten, scattering dung upon the ground—ready to be swept away.”

Later, he gave the ox scroll to the mendicant and instructed him to purchase forty-nine *jin* of hemp, twisting it into a thick rope. He charged him, saying, “When I die, do not encoffin me. Wrap me from shoulder to foot with this rope, dig a pit in the empty ground behind the temple, and bury me in a flaming pyre. After seven days, open it once to check.” The mendicant faithfully followed his command. On the seventh day, when they opened the pit, Zhang’s face glowed like fresh cinnabar. By the forty-ninth day, they had opened it seven times, finding only the hemp rope and a pair of worn shoes—his body had vanished.

Xu once presented him with a poem:
*“The iron flute loves fire, wind, and moonlit nights,
A single robe defies the snow and frost.
If you ask how many years I’ve wandered,
I’ll laugh and point to pines and bamboos—not yet steadfast.”*
Zhang inscribed it in large characters on a bolt of silk, his brushwork bold and striking. He also wrote out the method for refining mercury on another bolt of silk and gave it to Xu. After Xu’s death, many in the village sought his written methods, but his son, Menggen, unwilling to disclose them, gathered and burned them all.

**Zhang Gong**
Zhang Gong of Bian was an unsuccessful imperial examination candidate. His family was very poor, but his mother’s clan, the Gongs, had long practiced medicine, so he too was skilled in prescriptions. He set up an apothecary shop behind the Yichun Gate, though his remedies sold poorly.

One morning, as he dressed, combed his hair, and washed his face, he saw a Daoist approaching with the rising sun, his gaze piercing and unblinking. The Daoist strode directly into the shop, glanced around, and without a bow, shook out his robes and sat upon the dais.

Zhang grew quite indignant at the Daoist’s arrogance and, his face darkening, demanded his origin. The Daoist replied, “Ask not whence I come—my purpose is simply to see you.” Zhang thought him a madman, of which the capital had no shortage. He tossed a coin at him and waved him away. The Daoist laughed and said, “I seek nothing from others. I came to instruct you because you possess the makings of a Dao adept. Why reject me so harshly?”

Zhang, suddenly enlightened, hurriedly donned his cap and sash and stepped out to speak with him. When the conversation turned to matters of the immortals, the Daoist expounded with such profound subtlety that Zhang heard what he had never heard before. Filled with shame and remorse, he said, “I am a vulgar man, my eyes clouded and my heart deluded. Since you, Immortal Sir, have deigned to visit me, I beg you to teach me to the end.”

The Daoist asked, “What do you seek?”
Zhang replied, “My family is poor, and we often go without congee. If I could be sated without eating, that would be my worldly wish.”

Just then, a vendor arrived with steamed jujubes. The Daoist took the coin Zhang had earlier thrown, bought seven of them, and said, “The immortals do not approve of avoiding grain altogether, but abstaining from grains eliminates dross and turbidity. Without dross and turbidity, there is no leakage, and from this, one may enter the Dao. Zhang Zifang and others relied on elixirs to stave off hunger—how misguided they were! If you desire this Way, can you henceforth refrain from lust? One who does not indulge in lust finds worldly desires naturally stilled. When worldly desires are stilled, one possesses the talent of an immortal.”

He then took the seven jujubes, gazed at them intently, and breathed upon them, saying, “Eat these, and you may go without food for life. If others compel you to eat, there is no prohibition. Should you later wish to abstain again, do as before. However, you have an aged mother, a wife, and children—you cannot yet follow me. Yet since you have eaten these seven jujubes, you shall have seven dreams, as I foretell. When you have fulfilled your filial duties and seen your children married, and if you can still abstain from food, what more will you seek? Then you should leave the world behind and seek a famous mountain. Find a stone cavern deep and wide enough to contain you, and seal its entrance with piled stones. Let no thoughts arise; sit, walk, or stand within it, and you will discover wondrous delights. In half a dozen years, your body will shed its shell like a cicada, and you will roam freely beyond the Six Directions. Beyond that, I cannot speak to you today.”

With these words, he gathered his robes and rose. Zhang pressed him to stay, but the Daoist refused. He stepped out the door, and when Zhang looked again, he was nowhere to be seen. Zhang then realized he was no ordinary man and remained disconsolate for months. He found the smell of food nauseating and soon ceased eating altogether. After two years, he passed neither stool nor urine, yet his spirit was clear and bright, his steps light and swift. He often tested his strength, walking from dawn to dusk around the outskirts of the capital five times—covering several hundred *li*. The seven dreams he experienced unfolded exactly as the Daoist had foretold.

His mother had suffered from hemorrhoids for twenty years, and no medicine had cured her. Zhang gave her the remaining pits of the seven jujubes, and she recovered in a single night. Having renounced intimacy, he regarded his wife as a stranger. His wife, née Guo, was of a stern disposition; her resentment and distress led to her death. His family grew increasingly anxious and suspicious, urging him to eat, but the food he took would only turn and come back up. Sometimes he ate, sometimes he did not. Friends who doubted his sincerity locked him in a room to test him, yet he felt no hardship. When summoned by physicians, he would bring medicine and go, but upon arrival, he would sit beside the patient’s bed, remaining for ten days or even a month without so much as a sip of water or a grain of rice. He delighted in drinking and composing poetry, and though he reached sixty, his complexion remained that of a young man.

After his mother’s death, his whereabouts became unknown. Li Fangshu wrote this account. Li Jian annotated.

In Jinan there lived a man named Li Yuan, styled Dingguo, who resided in the barracks of Lin’an Prefecture. He supported himself by gathering students for instruction, and in his leisure, he roamed freely among the lakes and mountains. Once, he visited the present-day Temple of Mercy. Passing over the Long Bridge, he lost his way along a bamboo-lined path and came upon a Daoist in blue robes playing a carved zither beneath the trees. Yuan bowed to him, and the Daoist asked where he was going. "I am on my way to the Temple of Contending Mercy to pay homage to the Five Hundred Arhats," he replied. The Daoist said, "There is no need to go just yet. Come, share a meal with me." He then roasted some pine nuts and ate them; they were most delicious. Suddenly, wind and rain darkened the sky, and the Daoist vanished without a trace. Yuan, alarmed and fearful, crouched among the trees. After a short while, the rain ceased, and he found his way out. Upon reaching the temple gate, he felt his body light and his spirit unburdened, his steps as swift as if he were flying. Returning home, he no longer consumed food or drink.

His elder cousin, named Mo and styled Dayou, served as a tutor in the palace of a prince. When Dayou was about to depart for his post, he sent a servant to deliver a letter. The servant saw that Yuan’s complexion was like peach blossoms and that he had attained the ability to fast. He relayed this to Dayou. By the time Dayou arrived, however, Yuan had already left, wandering to Mount Mao. Later, it was heard that he had entered Shu and concealed himself on Mount Qingcheng. Dayou, then serving as Transport Commissioner of the Zizhou Circuit, dispatched someone to Mei Prefecture to inquire after him. The prefect of Mei replied in a letter that several years earlier, Yuan had ascended lightly upon the clouds and departed, leaving behind only a painted likeness.

Jiang Fengzi was originally a resident of Shaoyang. By nature, he was simple and forthright, speaking without restraint. He paid no heed to worldly affairs, and if he noticed even a minor flaw in someone, regardless of their status, he would confront them directly.

Wandering to Mount Heng, he saw the precipitous Central Ridge and, on impulse, began to cultivate it, though none knew where he took lodging or sustenance. One day, a woodcutter suddenly appeared—his head wrapped in a blue kerchief, firewood upon his back—who offered him alms, saying, "After a thousand hardships, one still cannot secure enough to eat. Take this single pill; swallow it, and your strength will suffice." From then on, he drank only water. He cast off all clothing, heedless of cold or heat, and the people called him "Fengzi." Roaming the lakes and rivers of Hunan, he often lay sprawled across the roads, and though men of power and rank could not bend him, nor poison harm him, nor tigers and wolves injure him, he would mutter to himself, leaving others unable to fathom his meaning.

**Mo the Daoist**
Mo the Daoist was a native of Rongzhou who dwelled in Stone Grotto. He entered the mountains, and none knew how many years he had spent there; when asked, he himself would not speak of his age. Elders in the foothills, some eighty or ninety years old, recalled seeing him in his prime when they were young, yet his appearance—his face, beard, and temples—remained unchanged. His vigor was robust, and he scaled mountains as swiftly as if flying. He drank when drink was offered, ate when food was given, yet at times fasted for days, undeterred by cold or heat. Alone in his thatched hut, with no attendant by his side, he would often sit through the night upon the rocky ledge of Flying Cloud Peak. Tigers would linger nearby, and he did not drive them away; they would depart only at dawn. When high officials and nobles traveled to the mountains seeking him, they rarely found him. Many left poems for him, and he was still alive as late as the final years of Emperor Lizong of Song.

*Concluding Record of Perfected Immortals Through the Ages Who Embodied the Dao, Volume 52*
*Perfected Immortals Through the Ages Who Embodied the Dao, Volume 53*

Master Lin Lingjiang, surnamed Lin, originally named Lingjiang, styled Tongsou, was a native of Yongjia in Wenzhou. His family was poor and of humble station. One night, his mother, returning home, felt a red cloud envelop her body and thus conceived. After twenty-four months of pregnancy, one evening she dreamed of sunlight entering the chamber. A divine being clad in a green robe and jade belt, with eyes radiating sunlight, held a brush and announced: "Tomorrow, I shall borrow this dwelling." The following day, dark clouds gathered on all sides, and three claps of thunder resounded—Master Lin was born. Golden light filled the room, and his appearance was extraordinary. At the age of five, he remained silent. On the fifth day of the fifth month, a great storm arose, and a Daoist wearing a green jade crown and a cloud-patterned robe entered unannounced. Seeing the Master, he rejoiced and said: "Long have I not beheld you; I have come especially to pay my respects." They gazed at each other, clapped their hands, and laughed heartily as the Daoist departed. The Master pursued him in vain, but from that moment, he could speak. His words were well-founded, free of childish prattle. At seven, he studied books, composed poetry with some skill, and memorized ten thousand characters a day. When Su Dongpo Shì came to visit and presented him with an almanac to read, the Master perused it once without error. Dongpo marveled and said: "Your intelligence surpasses mine; wealth and rank await you." The Master smiled and replied: "My aspirations differ from yours." Dongpo asked: "What are your aims?" The Master said: "To be enfeoffed as a marquis in life and have a temple erected after death is not true nobility. A marquis’s title is but an empty name, and temple offerings do not elevate one beyond the realm of lesser spirits. My wish is to become a divine immortal—that is my ambition."

By the time he neared thirty, the Master had mastered the Confucian and Daoist classics. His aspirations turned to purity and emptiness, and his discourse was lofty, far removed from worldly concerns. Early on, while traveling in the western capital, he encountered a Daoist surnamed Zhao, with whom he associated for several years. One day, the Daoist suddenly said: "My allotted time draws near. I must take leave of you for now, but I entrust my later affairs to your care." Seven days later, he indeed died in a guesthouse, and the Master personally bathed and buried him. The Daoist left behind twenty-five strings of bronze coins, which the Master used in full, neither exceeding nor falling short. In the Daoist’s satchel were three volumes of books, their fine script like pearls, inscribed with celestial seal characters that no one could decipher. Divided into nineteen sections and wrapped in crimson silk, they bore the inscription: "Bestowed upon Lin." The title on the volumes read *Jade Writ of the Divine Empyrean Altar*. They contained methods of divine immortals’ transformations, incantations for summoning clouds and rain, talismans for driving away lesser spirits, and techniques for commanding the myriad spirits. At the end of the volumes was an account of twenty-five strings of coins, each item matching precisely. After receiving the *Jade Writ*, the Master’s spirit suddenly awakened. He perceived ghosts and gods, recited incantations and talismans, commanded thunder and lightning, and captured malevolent demons. He cured illnesses for others, and his efficacy was immediate. Whether dispelling plagues or subduing temple spirits, nothing he undertook failed.

The following year, the Master arrived at a wineshop in Yueyang and again saw the Daoist Zhao, who said: "I am Zhao Sheng, disciple of the Han Celestial Master. The *Five-Thunder Jade Writ* I once bestowed upon you must be practiced with care and not lightly disclosed. Today, the Lord of the Eastern Florescence, the Divine Empyrean Sovereign and Grand Thunder Judge, faces peril, and I must go to his aid." On the night of the Mid-Autumn Festival in the fifth year of Chongning, Emperor Huizong of Song dreamed of journeying to the Divine Empyrean Palace and attending the Jade Emperor’s court. He was summoned into a carriage with an escort of attendants, ascending through the void. As he neared the Gate of the Golden Palace, he saw immortal officials, jade lads, and armored warriors standing guard. Then, a figure in a star crown and ritual robe, holding a jade tablet, led the Emperor through the gate. Above it hung a vermilion plaque with golden characters: "Gate of the Divine Empyrean Jade Palace." To the west stood another gate, above which a plaque read: "Hall of Azure Radiance." The hall was bathed in golden light so dazzling it could not be gazed upon directly. Passing through a small courtyard with vermilion doors and golden studs, they came to the Jade Pivot Institute. Offices and bureaus were arrayed in order, and officials conducted themselves with solemnity. A crimson-robed clerk welcomed the Emperor and led him inside, bowing as he said: "This was once the Emperor’s former residence. Please be seated in the eastern seat and await a moment." Soon, a jade lad ushered the Emperor to an audience with the Jade Emperor. The Emperor prostrated himself twice in reverence, and from amidst the golden light, a decree was transmitted: "Rectify the state’s affairs, remove treacherous ministers, employ the loyal and worthy, and safeguard the ancestral altars." The Emperor bowed twice more, then withdrew to meet the crimson-robed clerk, who escorted him out of the Gate of the Golden Palace. Once more, a seven-jeweled chariot and attendants were provided, and the Emperor descended from the Heavenly Gate for over a hundred paces. There, he saw a Daoist in blue robes and a blue headscarf, riding a blue ox upward. His followers all had ghostly faces; two rock-bell ghosts with four eyes, wielding whips, led the way, while others bore swords and halberds, their procession solemn. Arriving before the imperial carriage, they cracked their whips and cried "Long live the Emperor!" The Emperor halted his carriage and inquired of the Daoist, who replied: "Today, I have had the fortune of beholding Your Majesty’s celestial countenance." With that, he rode his blue ox up through the Heavenly Gate. The Emperor awoke and recorded the dream.

In the second year of Daguan, the fourth month, an imperial edict sought Daoist masters throughout the realm. Master Liu Hun Kang of Mount Mao submitted a memorial, saying: "Your servant, in his foolishness, has nothing to offer that might satisfy Your Majesty’s wishes. Yet there is a divine immortal living in the world, Lin Lingjiang of Yongjia—why has the edict come so late?" The Emperor immediately dispatched envoys to seek him, but the Master declined to rise. By the sixth month of the sixth year of Zhenghe, the Emperor visited the Eastern Palace of the Great Unity. He instructed the Daoist Registrar Xu Zhichang to memorialize: "The Daoist Lin Lingjiang of Wenzhou is currently residing in a Daoist abbey. His appearance and speech are extraordinary, and he has repeatedly spoken of matters concerning the Divine Empyrean, though none can comprehend them. He once composed a *Song of the Divine Empyrean*, which he inscribed on the wall. I have transcribed it and now present it for Your Majesty’s perusal." Upon reading the text, filled with the wondrous words of immortals, the Emperor was greatly pleased and ordered Xu Zhichang to bring Lin Lingfu into his presence. The Emperor asked: "What arts and techniques do you possess?" The Master replied: "Your servant understands the affairs of Heaven above, the world of men in between, and the earthly realm below."

The Emperor gazed upon the Master, whose bearing and appearance seemed as if he had known him before. The Emperor asked: "Have you served in office before? Have we met in the past?" The Master replied: "On the Mid-Autumn Festival in years past, when I attended court before the Jade Emperor, I beheld Your Majesty’s celestial countenance and paid homage to your sagely presence." The Emperor said: "Now I recall—it was you who rode the blue-green ox. Where is the ox now?" The Master answered: "The blue-green ox is pastured in a foreign land, but it shall return before long." The Emperor marveled greatly and personally inscribed a new name for him, Ling Su, bestowing the title Master of Penetrating Reality and Attaining the Numinous. He was summoned to the palace at all hours to revise and compile Daoist histories, scriptural catalogs, and registers for the numinous altars.

The Emperor treated him as his teacher, specially constructing the Abbey of Penetrating Reality as his residence. He established the Abbey of Flourishing Treasures, built the Pavilion of Benevolent Relief, and distributed talismans and medicines. Next, he opened the Register Altar of the Divine Empyrean. When the Divine Empyrean Palace was completed, the Emperor led his ministers, including Cai Jing, to celebrate its inauguration. After the morning audience concluded, the Emperor led the hundred officials on a tour, declaring: "From the Five Gates of Proclaiming Virtue come the myriad states." Cai Jing and the others pondered deeply but could find no response. The Emperor turned to Lin and asked: "Can you complete the couplet?" The Master answered without hesitation: "The single prefecture of the Divine Empyrean governs all heavens." The Emperor was overjoyed.

The Master was commissioned to revise the *Yellow Register* and *Blue Offering* rituals, arrange the sacred ranks of the Three Realms, and collate the alchemical classics and philosophical texts. On the seventh day of each month, he ascended the teaching seat, while the Prince of Liang, imperial nobles, and civil and military officials gathered to hear him expound the *Three Caverns’ Daoist Scriptures*. At times, the Emperor himself would attend, seated below the dais.

From this time onward, the people of the Eastern Capital came to know the reverence of the Dao. As *The Comprehensive Mirror of the August Dynasty* records: In the seventh year of the Zhenghe era, the Daoist Lin Lingsu arrived in the capital. In the second month, the Emperor ascended the *Upper Clarity Treasure Lots Abbey* and commanded Master Lin Lingsu of Penetrating Reality to lecture on the *Daoist Scriptures* and the *Record of the Birth of the Jade Clarity Divine Empyrean King*. Thousands of cranes soared and cried out for a long while.

The Master compiled the *Nine Heavens’ Secret Writings*, inscribed in dragon scripts and phoenix seals, along with the *Nine Grades of Thunder Rites*, presenting them as the *Jade Chapters* to the throne. Formerly, the Celestial Master of Han possessed the *Divine Empyrean Thunder Writings* in twenty scrolls, along with six *Thunder Seals of the Celestial Department* bearing eight-angled thunder patterns. By the eighth-generation Celestial Master, only ten scrolls remained, along with the seal scripts of the six seals and the fire-traced seal script of the Jin era. At the founding of the dynasty, Zhang Shouzhen encountered the *Lan Saintly Perfected Lord*, who transmitted five scrolls to him.

The Emperor desired to obtain the complete *Thunder Writings* and *Golden Scriptures* to include in the *Daoist Canon*, but they could not be found. The Master, in a state of meditative flight, petitioned the *Jade Flower Heavenly Worthy* to report to the August Emperor, beseeching to view the thunder scripts and the seals of the *Thunder Bureau*. The Emperor dispatched the *Six Ding Jade Maidens* to bestow the seals upon him: one *Heavenly Altar Jade Seal*, one *Divine Empyrean Successor of the Teaching and Master Seal*, one *Director-General of Thunder Lords Seal*, and one *Celestial Department Thunder Bureau Seal*—all as hard as iron and stone, neither gold nor jade—along with five scrolls of the *Thunder Writings* for Lingsu to examine.

The Master bowed in gratitude, clasped the seals to his breast, and returned. He then submitted the *Thunder Writings* to the throne for presentation, thereby obtaining the complete collection.

In the seventh month of the seventh year of the Zhenghe era, the kingdom of Goryeo indeed presented a green ox to the capital, filling the Emperor with boundless joy. The hundred officials offered their congratulations, and the Emperor immediately bestowed upon the Master the honor of riding the beast into court. The Master thereupon composed a *Song of the Green Ox*, its opening lines reading: *"In the autumn of Zhenghe ding-you, with the west wind blowing, / The Son of Heaven bestowed upon me a ride on the green ox."* He presented the completed poem to the throne, and the Emperor was greatly pleased.

In the eighth month, the Master again compiled and submitted the *Record of the Bright Points of the Canonical Framework*, for which the Emperor rewarded him with funds for printing. In the first year of the Chonghe era, as the foundation for the *Hall of the Three Pure Ones* was being laid at Mount Hua, a massive stone casket was unearthed, containing a single volume of *Thunder Writings and Dharma Scripts*—inscribed on golden silkworm paper. When brought before the Emperor, it matched the *Thunder Writings* the Master had presented the previous year, not a single character differing. The Emperor exclaimed in delight, *"How divinely wise and sagely perceptive is Lingsu, to have memorized it so!"*

The Emperor then personally composed a *blue-green memorial* within the palace precincts, sealing it in secret for submission. The following day, he summoned the Master and inquired, *"You have claimed to know the affairs of Heaven—did my memorial of last night reach its destination?"* The Master replied, *"The memorial did not reach, for a single character was mistakenly written in green, and the *Divine Officials* intercepted it."* He recited the details of the submission, and the Emperor, patting the Master’s back, declared, *"Truly, you are a perceptive immortal!"* He then bestowed upon him the title *Master of the Jade Truth, Duke of the Divine Empyrean Palace, Lord Lin*.

Later, the Emperor sighed and said, *"I often wonder where the soul of the late Empress has gone. I have heard that in the time of Emperor Ming of Tang, Master Ye was able to summon the spirit of Yang the Supreme Perfection—could you do the same?"* The Master replied, *"I humbly accept Your Majesty’s decree."* That night, he performed the rites, sending forth talismans to summon her. His memorial reported: *"The Empress now resides in the *Jade Flower Palace*, feasting with the Queen Mother of the West. Upon hearing Your Majesty’s summons, she instantly mounted a green phoenix and arrived."*

After a time, an otherworldly fragrance filled the air, celestial blossoms rained down, and ethereal music resounded through the heavens—then the Empress appeared. The Emperor gazed upon her closely; she was no different from when she lived, save that her immortal robes and jade slippers differed from mortal attire. The Empress addressed the Emperor, saying, *"I was once a celestial official in charge of affairs, but at a gathering in the Divine Empyrean, I became enamored with the mortal realm and was punished, banished to the world of men. Now my karmic debt is repaid, and I have returned to my former post. Grateful for Your Majesty’s gracious summons, I hastened here upon receiving your command. I urge you to heed this warning: the coming bing-wu rebellion may yet be averted if you uphold the Great Dao, cast aside extravagance, employ the loyal and good, eradicate treacherous factions, cultivate virtue, and execute Tong and Cai. Otherwise, great disaster will befall you. I fear for Your Majesty’s future—if you persist in negligence, you will sink into ruin. Should you mend your ways, we may yet meet again in the Jade Palace."*

With that, she departed.

The Emperor asked, *"What was your position when you served among the immortals?"*
She replied, *"Your servant was the Yin Spirit of the Purple Void Primordial Sovereign, and Your Majesty is the Eastern Radiance Emperor-Lord."*

The Emperor said, *"None in the palace—neither my ministers nor my attendants—dared speak a word."*
She answered, *"Lady Mingjie is the Purple Void Mystic Numinous Lady; Empress Wang is the Flower-Offering Bodhisattva; the Crown Prince is the Venerable Arhat of Tortoise Mountain; Cai Jing is the Great Demon Chief of the Second Cavern of the Six Northern Hells; Tong Guan is the Flying Heaven Great Demon Mother; Master Lin is the Sovereign of the Divine Empyrean and concurrently the Grand Thunderclap Judge; and Xu Zhichang is the Giant Toad Spirit of the Eastern Sea."*

The Emperor then asked about the fate of his dynasty, but she remained silent for a long while before saying, *"Heaven’s decree is fixed. I dare not linger."* With that, she gradually faded from sight.

The Master had once accompanied the Emperor in spirit-flight to the Azure Flower Palace, ascending to the Moon Palace and traversing blessed grotto-heavens, visiting all without exception. Whenever he performed rituals or supplications, auspicious clouds and celestial cranes would gather. In times of drought, he would summon wind and thunder, calling forth clouds and rain. In the fifth month, he was bestowed the title *Master of Penetrating Truth and Attaining the Numinous, Wondrous Primordial One* and appointed Grand Master of the Palace with the rank of Attendant Minister. In the ninth month, he was specially granted the rank of True Official and exempted from routine inspections. In the tenth month, three days before the Heavenly Tranquility Festival, he conducted a grand longevity ritual and memorialized the throne to invite the Emperor’s presence. At the third watch, they beheld the Terrace of Luxuriant Mist, where the Celestial Worthy of the Dao and all the immortals descended in person to extend the Emperor’s lifespan. The Emperor, having purified himself with fasting and ablutions, observed the wondrous event alongside the Three Palaces, the Nine Ministers, and the imperial princes.

That night, the sky was cloudless, the moon bright, and the wind clear. First, celestial fragrance filled the air, and cranes soared above as five-colored clouds gathered and ascended. The sound of immortal music and the chime of jade pendants resounded. More than five *zhang* above the ground, within a radiant void, pavilions and palaces materialized, surrounded by celestial soldiers, jade maidens, and golden lads bearing banners and incense. At the center hung a jade plaque inscribed in golden script: *Terrace of Luxuriant Mist*. None present could see it save the Emperor and Zhang Xujing.

The Emperor offered incense and bowed twice, then summoned the Crown Prince to behold it. After a long while, the Crown Prince said, *"It is the Pagoda of the Great Sage of Sizhou."* The Emperor grew furious and ordered the eunuchs to drive him out, decreeing that the Crown Prince was no longer permitted to attend the Divine Empyrean rituals.

The Emperor said to the Master, *"The Crown Prince was once the Venerable Arhat of Tortoise Mountain—a sage. Why is he so ignorant of the Dao?"*
The Master replied, *"In his past life as an arhat, he upheld the precepts, endured humiliation, and cultivated patience. Though reborn as a nobleman, he retains filial piety but does not grasp the profound mysteries. I beg Your Majesty not to reproach the Crown Prince."*

In the eleventh month, the Master was appointed Attendant of the Harmonious Void Hall. In the twelfth month, he oversaw the construction of the Hall of the Protective Sage. The Emperor said, *"I wish to behold the true image of the Dark Warrior."*
The Master replied, *"Allow me to petition with Heavenly Master Xujing."*

They fasted in the hall overnight. At noon the next day, black clouds blotted out the sun, and a great thunderclap resounded as a flash of light revealed a colossal black tortoise and serpent filling the courtyard. The Emperor offered incense and bowed twice, praying, *"I humbly beseech the Perfected Lord of the Primordial to deign to descend and grant me the blessing of a glimpse of your true form."* With another thunderclap, the tortoise and serpent vanished, leaving only a single vast foot filling the courtyard. The Emperor again offered incense and bowed, saying, *"By the compassion of the Sagely Ancestor of the Mysterious Origin, who has deigned to descend, I would be overjoyed to behold even a fraction of your true form."*

In an instant, the deity manifested—a figure over a *zhang* tall, majestic and serene, with unbound hair, a black robe trailing to the ground, golden armor, voluminous sleeves, a jade belt, and a sword at his wrist. His feet were bare, a halo crowned his head, and ribbons fluttered about him. He stood for a long while, during which the Emperor was able to sketch his likeness. The court painters were then summoned to complete the portrait, but before they finished, the deity vanished. The next day, a ritual of thanksgiving was held.

Cai Jing memorialized, *"I fear the Perfected Lord does not easily descend among mortals. In the past, Emperor Taizong commanded Zhang Shouzhen to summon him, and a portrait was made, sealed in a casket and stored in the palace archives, unseen by any minister. I beg that it be retrieved for comparison to verify its authenticity."* The imperial decree was issued, and the Taizong-era seal remained intact. When opened, the portrait matched the current manifestation in every detail. The Emperor was overjoyed.

He then invited the Seven Perfected of the Northern Dipper and their two envoys, who descended upon a golden bridge. (Their appearance was not recorded in paintings.) The Emperor gazed upon and bowed to the Seven Perfected, who spoke from the Dipper, saying, *"Hasten to withdraw to safety. Do not indulge in extravagance. Exercise sagely judgment and do not let treacherous villains lead you to ruin."* With that, they ascended into the heavens.

That night, the Emperor was delighted and invited Xujing and the Master to a banquet. Afterward, they strolled beneath a pavilion in the palace, where they saw a stele inscribed *Stele of the Treacherous Faction of the Yuanyou Era*. The Master and Xujing read it, bowed their heads in reverence, and requested paper and brush to inscribe a poem:

*"Su and Huang no longer write as men of letters,
While Tong and Cai are hailed as pillars of the state.
For thirty years, no verdict has been settled—
Who, then, are the true traitors?"*

The next day, the Emperor showed the poem to Grand Preceptor Cai Jing. Cai was terrified, prostrating himself and begging to be dismissed, but the Emperor refused.

The Master had a chamber with windows on two sides, a door at the front, and a wall at the back—his place of retreat. Inside stood two chairs, and the room was always locked, forbidden to all. Even when the Emperor visited, he was not permitted entry. Cai Jing grew suspicious and sent the Eight Guards to spy on it. They reported seeing a yellow silk canopy, a dragon bed embroidered with gold, and crimson chairs and tables.

Cai memorialized, *"Master Lin harbors usurping ambitions. I beg Your Majesty to inspect the chamber personally; I will accompany you and point out the evidence. If my words prove false, I will accept death a myriad times over."*

The Emperor then visited the Master’s quarters. The Master received him with due ceremony, and the Emperor entered the chamber with Cai Jing. They unsealed the lock and opened the door, finding only whitewashed walls, bright windows, and two chairs—nothing else.

Cai Jing, trembling with fear, kowtowed and begged for forgiveness. The Master asked the reason, and the Emperor said, "Cai Jing deserves execution." The Master memorialized, pleading for clemency. Then, pointing to the wall in the chamber, he invited the Emperor to examine it closely. The Emperor scrutinized it and found a small talisman—a talisman of the Golden Tower and Jade Hall. Beneath it was depicted a yellow silk canopy, no larger than a coin, with fine characters inscribed above: *"Seat of the Heavenly Honored One."* The Master said, "This humble servant often invites the Jade Flower Heavenly Honored One to descend and sit here; how could I dare to usurp such a place?" The Emperor laughed and said, "You play your games well."

The Emperor then said, "I have heard that Emperor Wu of Han once summoned the Queen Mother of the West to descend and instruct him in the Dao. I wish to see the Queen Mother of the West—can you bring her here?" The Master replied, "I humbly accept Your Majesty’s command." He then burned a small talisman in the incense burner. After a moment, the Queen Mother descended with her jade maidens, riding upon clouds, appearing just as mortal women do. She sat facing the Emperor and, turning to the Master, asked, "What is the occasion today that merits such a special summons?" The Master replied, "The Son of Heaven reveres the Dao and wishes to meet the Primordial Lady."

The Emperor rose, took incense, and bowed twice. The Queen Mother said, "The Lord of Eastern Florescence excuses you from bowing." The Emperor said, "To behold your immortal countenance today is an honor spanning ten thousand kalpas and a thousand lifetimes. If you have any guidance to offer, I would humbly receive your sagely compassion." The Queen Mother replied, "For such matters, you may consult the Attendant of the Celestial Palace, Master Lin, and the Heavenly Master Zhang Xujing; they can help you escape great calamity."

The Emperor said, "Since the Primordial Lady has descended, would you not bestow some teaching?" The Queen Mother then presented the Emperor with a divine elixir for his protection and well-being, saying, "Watch for treacherous ministers, relocate the capital to Chang’an, and follow the precedents of the Grand Progenitors Taizu and Taizong. Though minor disasters may occur, they will not become great catastrophes. If you do not heed this, you will regret it when it is too late." With these words, she departed.

One day, the Crown Prince ascended the hall and memorialized, "Lin Lingsu practices sorcery; I implore Your Majesty to execute him. Your subject daily reflects that his arts are vast and inconceivable. If Your Majesty does not believe this, I beg you summon the Dharma Masters now in the capital to contend with Lin Lingsu in magic, that we may distinguish the heterodox from the orthodox."

At that time, fourteen men gathered in the Hall of Concentrated Spirit. The Emperor summoned the Crown Prince, the various princes, and the assembled ministers to observe. Master Lin spat forth a mouthful of water, which transformed into a five-colored cloud. Within it, a hundred cranes took flight, circling before the hall, while golden dragons and lions mingled among the clouds. The others memorialized, "This is nothing extraordinary—mere paper dragons and cranes. Permit us to recite the Great Divine Gaze, and these dragons and cranes shall fall to the ground, revealed as paper."

The Crown Prince, hearing this, rejoiced and said, "If this proves true, then Lin Lingsu’s arts are false, and he deserves execution." Yet even as they spoke in admiration, of the fourteen, only two could still recite the incantation; the rest were struck dumb, their faces ashen as death. The Crown Prince rebuked Master Lin, saying, "If any of these men die, you shall restore their lives." Having uttered the spell, he inhaled, and at once the cranes and dragons multiplied by the hundreds, obscuring the sun and veiling the clouds.

The Emperor said, "This display is ineffective. What other arts do you possess?" The twelve men prostrated themselves in terror, while the remaining two memorialized, "Your subjects can inhale boiling water." Water was brought and measured; indeed, they did so. The Crown Prince lifted a basin of water before the Emperor and called Master Lin to witness. Master Lin drew in a breath and blew into the water, which instantly turned clear and froze into ice.

The Emperor reproached them, saying, "Our court has treated you with great generosity; how dare you utter such reckless words?" Master Lin memorialized, "I beg that a thousand catties of charcoal be burned into a fiery cavern, its embers glowing red throughout. I request to enter it with these two men to test our arts." After some time, the fiery cavern was prepared. Master Lin said, "I beg to enter first, and that the two men follow." He stepped into the flames, yet his robes remained untouched.

The others prostrated themselves, wailing and pleading with the Crown Prince, "We beg for our lives! We willingly don the cap and hold the tablet, to serve and obey." The Crown Prince descended the hall and bowed, beseeching that the Crown Prince’s memorial be accepted to atone for their offenses. By imperial decree, their crimes were pardoned, but as Dao Jian and the other two were Chinese subjects who had deceived their sovereign, they were sent to the Kaifeng Prefecture to be branded on the face and banished to the frontier, where they were made examples before the people.

On the eighth day of the first month of the first year of the Xuanhe era, an edict was issued renaming all Buddhist monks as "Virtuous Scholars." Master Lin submitted a memorial, saying, "Your subject is but a rustic of the mountains and forests, mistakenly favored by Your Majesty’s grace. If the name of the Sangha is altered, it will surely incur widespread resentment. I beg to return to my homeland as a commoner." The imperial decree did not permit this, nor would it entertain further petitions.

In the fifth month, a great flood assailed the capital. The Emperor commanded Master Lin to address it. Master Lin memorialized, "This flood is difficult to control; it is Heaven’s will to admonish Your Majesty. Moreover, this flood arises from the Crown Prince. I dare not reveal Heaven’s design, but if you test this by having the Crown Prince pay homage, you may believe it." The Crown Prince was then ordered to ascend the city walls, where he burned imperial incense and bowed four times. The waters receded by a *zhang*. By nightfall, the flood had entirely subsided. The people of the capital all declared it the virtue of the Crown Prince.

Master Lin then memorialized, "When I first received Heaven’s mandate to come, it was to dispel the yin demons for Your Majesty, sever the strange and uncanny, exalt the Divine Empyrean, establish the *Baolu*, revere the Great Dao, and assist the loyal and worthy. Yet now, Cai Jing, the chief of ghosts, is entrusted with great authority, while Tong Guan, the nation’s traitor, is given command of the imperial guard."

The state’s affairs are left unattended, and extravagance has grown excessive. The comet’s passage goes unheeded—Your Majesty has not accumulated virtuous deeds to avert its omen; the Great Unity has departed from its palace, yet Your Majesty has not relocated the capital to evade its portent. The hearts of the people are the dwelling of Heaven. Though the August Heaven is high, the hearts of men are easily moved, and thus cultivating human affairs may align with Heaven’s will. The Dipper and the Seal are as one. The great reckoning cannot be escaped—how could one know there is a calendar beyond its appointed term?

I now bid farewell to Your Imperial Countenance, never again to gaze upon the celestial visage. Beware the years *bingwu* and *dingwei*, when weapons shall surge forth, blood shall stain a myriad *li*, and Heaven’s favor shall not suffice to protect the Two Palaces. Does Your Majesty not recall the verse from Yuan Tiangang’s *Tui Bei Tu*?

*"Two dynasties’ emperors laugh with glee,
Leading their ministers across Meng Ford.
Hands clasped, they find no path to advance or retreat—
To leave or not to leave, sorrow consumes them."*

This humble servant, Ling Su, suffers from illness and begs to return his bones to his homeland. Another edict was issued, refusing his plea.

That winter, the entire Censorate memorialized that Lin Lingsu had recklessly proposed relocating the capital, deluding the imperial ear with omens, abolishing Buddhist teachings, and slandering high ministers. Upon hearing this, the Master laughed heartily and summoned his disciples along with the supervising palace officials, declaring, "The gifts bestowed by successive imperial decrees—some three hundred cartloads—have been sealed since last year under the *Thousand-Character Classic* numbering system, with meticulous records kept. Not a single item has been used; all may be returned to the palace." He then called for a single boy to carry his robes and bedding, and strode out through the nation’s gates, ignoring all summons to return.

The *Eastern Capital Records* of Emperor Huizong’s reign in Wenzhou states: "In the eleventh month of the first year of the *Xuanhe* era, on the day *yimao*, sacrifices were offered to the August Heavenly Emperor at the State Altar. A general amnesty was proclaimed throughout the realm, and Lin Lingsu was permitted to return to his mountain."

During his time in the capital, the Master, though approached by chief ministers and imperial princes, neither engaged in conversation nor received guests. Only when the Celestial Master of Emptiness and Stillness arrived would he open his door and speak with him through day and night. Beyond this, there was only Zhang Ruhui, the Eastern and Western Palace Attendant, who had once served at Tongzhen Abbey. They walked together when traveling and shared the same seat when resting. Of all the masters of the Daoist teachings, only Zhang had grasped their subtleties. After returning home, they resided together in Yongjia.

In the eighth month of the first year of the *Xuanhe* era, the Master suddenly presented a memorial to the prefect, requesting its submission. He then took leave of the provincial officials, his kinsmen, and his neighbors, saying, "The dusty world is not a place for long attachment—moreover, great calamity is soon to strike. I must now depart."

On the fifteenth day of the month, the full moon having risen, the Master summoned Zhang Ruhui and said: "I now entrust my lineage of the Dao to you. You alone still possess the Six Seals and Nine Talismans, along with the wondrous divine mechanisms of the Six Ding. All these I now transmit to you—pass them down through the generations to but one person, and let them never be lightly disclosed." He also handed over a strand of seven-jeweled plain beads, saying: "If the Emperor should send for these, deliver them without delay. In the future, you shall render great loyalty to the court and preserve your integrity. For now, we part—but we shall meet again in the Divine Empyrean." With these words, he called for paper and brush and wrote a verse:

*Forty-five years of toil in this fleeting life,*
*Worldly fame soared high, yet all was but vanity.*
*I recall but the old path to the Divine Empyrean—*
*On the mid-autumn moon, at the third watch of night.*

Having written this, he lit a censer of incense. It was precisely the third watch; the moon shone bright, and the wind was still. Suddenly, a clap of thunder resounded, and the Master sat in transformation and departed. He had previously designated his burial site outside the city walls and instructed Master Zhang and his disciples: "Dig five feet deeper beneath the original grave. When you see the tortoise and serpent, lower the coffin. If five-colored qi emerges, do not wait to cover the earth—flee a hundred paces at once." His disciples followed his words. Indeed, the mountain split and rocks burst asunder, and his whereabouts became unknown.

When the Emperor heard of this, he gasped in astonishment and grief, composing a eulogy:

Alas! The living are but temporary forms; the dead return to truth. Those who embody the Dao are enlightened beings—how could one who dies in an instant be counted among the awakened? Swiftly he came, and in an instant he departed. Neither coming nor going did he allow his form to burden him; neither life nor death did he deem worldly glory worthy of cherishing. Such is the way of transcending life and death, of comprehending the principle of illusion and transformation—only a divine minister could achieve this.

Alas! The divine minister’s life was no true life. Heaven had lent him to aid in its transformative work, to assist the state and succor the people. His death was no true death—he returned to Heaven, where the Great Dao is fulfilled, and the deluded masses are awakened. His spirit congealed in the purity of celestial truth; his body dissolved, leaving only a trace in the world’s reckoning. Riding the clouds and mist, mounted upon the sun and moon, he roams the peaks of Penglai and Yingzhou, strides the jade steps of the Purple Void—beyond all mortal measure.

Now, I command the local officials to observe the rites of the human realm and offer this sacrifice before his coffin. If his spirit remains undimmed, may he partake of this honor and favor.

Decree: Upon the ascension of Attendant Lin of the Divine Empyrean, the local officials shall conduct the funeral rites as prescribed. The attending officials shall select a site for his resting place. The gold vessels from his belongings shall be sold to fund a grand Yellow Register Daoist ritual lasting a month. Any shortfall shall be covered by the provincial treasury. A memorial shall be submitted, and no negligence or delay shall be tolerated. Another official shall be dispatched to oversee the matter, ensuring it aligns with Our will and Our enduring regard for him.

He was posthumously bestowed a sacred title of ninety-five characters: *Highest Divine Empyrean Jade Clarity Palace, Right Ultimate Western Terrace Divine Minister; Thunder and Lightning Jade Pivot, Primordial Radiance, Universal Transformation Heavenly Master; Penetrating Clarity, Literary Elegance, Contracting the Primordial, Responding to the True Transmission, Dao-Supporter and Teaching-Patriarch; Golden Gate Feathered Adept; Harmonious Attendant of the Divine Empyrean Hall; Special Advance Grand Preceptor, Equal to the Three Dukes, Participant in the Deliberations of the Secretariat-Chancellery; Pillar of the State; Duke of the Lu Commandery; with a fief of eight thousand one hundred households and a real fief of three thousand households; granted the Purple Jade Square Talisman, Master of Penetrating Truth, Reaching the Numinous, Primordial Wonder, and Protecting the State—Lin Lingsu.*

In the first year of the *Jingkang* era, Emperor Yuansheng ascended the throne. As foretold, he first sent for the seven-jeweled plain beads. Then, he dispatched envoys to oversee the prefect, commandant, and local officials in excavating the tomb. For three days, they searched in vain—only scattered boulders, a howling black wind, torrential rain, lightning, and thunderclaps were seen. Faces could not be discerned amid the chaos; monstrous beasts and giant serpents emerged. The guards recorded the events in detail and submitted a memorial. Emperor Yuansheng, greatly alarmed, sent envoys bearing imperial incense to Wenzhou, instructing the local officials to conduct a grand Daoist ritual and offer apologies. He further decreed the posthumous title *Master of Penetrating Truth and Reaching the Numinous* and ordered his portrait painted and enshrined in the Tianqing Abbey, where it remains to this day.

The original account was embellished by Academician Geng Yanchi with ornate prose, replete with allusions and profound intent—understandable only to the most learned scholars. Here, I have rendered the facts in plain language, that both Daoist priests and common folk may know of the Master’s divine nature.

I once held office in the western capital when the Master presented me with a sealed manuscript. Upon seeing it, he said: "Later, you shall be involved in a restoration. If you encounter the rebels of the *Spring-Head Wood Gathering*, retire from office, open this manuscript, and follow its instructions—you may escape great calamity and attain long life. Otherwise, we shall meet again in Chaoyang, at the old post station. By then, regret will be too late." At the time, I did not take his words seriously, nor did I remember the teachings in the manuscript. Later, while investigating official matters, I indeed encountered the rebels of the *Spring-Head Wood Gathering* and was exiled to a distant island. Passing through Chaoyang Station, as I approached the post pavilion, I saw a youth in fine robes with a radiant complexion enter the station. Gazing closely, I recognized him—it was the Master. Smiling, he asked: "Were my words untrue?" Only then did I realize the Master was a true immortal.

Thus, I have revised this biography to present it to later generations. Respectfully recorded by Zhao Ding, former Left Vice Director of the Department of State Affairs.

Master Wang Wenqing, whose surname was Wang and given name Wenqing, styled Shudao, was originally from Nanfeng in Jianchang, Jiangyou. He was born on the seventeenth day of the second month in the eighth year of Yuanyou during the reign of Emperor Zhezong of Song, at the hour of *hai*.

From birth, he was divinely extraordinary; as he grew, he became keenly intelligent. He once composed a poem containing the lines: *"Red dust’s wealth and rank I do not crave, / The Purple Mansion’s true immortals I aspire to join."* One day, he suddenly told his father: "Last night, I dreamed I arrived at a place where towers and pavilions stood in lush array. A great serpent coiled upon the ground, and I stepped upon its head. The serpent reared up, nearly ascending to the heavens." His father said: "You shall continue our immortal lineage."

Thereafter, Master Wang’s nature inclined toward purity and emptiness; his will was set on nurturing simplicity. He neither coveted fame nor profit, keeping far from worldly toil. He delighted in wandering through sacred realms and scenic lands, roaming the earth with a simple headscarf and staff. In the early years of Emperor Huizong’s *Xuanhe* reign, as he was about to cross the Yangzi River, he encountered an extraordinary man who taught him the method of *flying memorials* to petition the emperor and the scripture for commanding wind and thunder. At every auspicious hour, he would send up *flying memorials* and silently pay homage to the Supreme Emperor. When he summoned thunder to pray for rain or rebuked the winds and clouds, his commands were obeyed. If long rains required clearing, the skies would promptly brighten; if deep winter demanded snow, six-petaled flakes would drift from the heavens. When households were plagued by malevolent spirits, he would dispatch divine generals to expel them, bringing peace to the afflicted. Yet he often concealed his fame and avoided praise, drifting through life with poetry and wine, unknown to the vulgar masses.

Previously, Attendant of the Imperial Chamber Lin Lingsu memorialized Emperor Huizong, stating that the Master was none other than the Celestial Scribe of the Three Heavens, overseer of civil officials, who had descended into the mortal realm to assist in the transformation of purity and tranquility. Eighteen imperial edicts were issued, and the realm was scoured for his whereabouts, yet none knew his location. The emperor’s uncle, the Surveillance Commissioner, fell ill during his inspection tour in Gaoyou Prefecture, and physicians proved ineffective. He encountered the Master and sought his talismanic water, by which he recovered. At first, the Master concealed his name, and only upon earnest entreaty was he revealed to be Wang Wenqing. Upon returning to court, the uncle first memorialized the marvels of the transcendent.

In the seventh month of the fourth year of the Xuanhe era, the emperor personally brushed an imperial rescript and dispatched it to the Master’s residence, extolling his virtue and power, honoring his non-action, and sending Attendant of the Imperial Chamber Dong Zhongyun as an Envoy of Inquiry, along with local surveillance officials and prefectural governors, to formally invite him with due ceremony and escort him to the capital. Upon the Master’s arrival, he presented the profound transformation of the Dao of non-action, greatly delighting the imperial countenance. The emperor lodged him in the Nine Yangs Assembly of Perfected Palace and dispatched envoys in an unbroken stream. He bestowed upon him a golden saddle and imperial steed, dragon tea and jade wine, rare treasures and exotic fruits, gold, coin, and silks—all of which the Master declined and returned.

The Master was commanded to enter the Pure Palace, where he advised on the sprinkling of water and sweeping. The emperor presented him with a sword and alms bowl and led him into the inner palace for libations. The palace women hung gold coins in countless numbers, but upon exiting the palace gate, he scattered them all upon the ground, declaring, “A true transcendent.” The emperor further inquired whether malevolent spirits plagued the palace. The Master memorialized, “There is a spirit in the southeast corner of the palace.” The emperor asked, “How may it be expelled?” The Master replied, “Your servant will inscribe a talisman.” After completing the talisman, he instructed a messenger to swiftly carry it to the Rear Slaughterhouse Gate and cast it into the flowing waters, awaiting its effects. The emperor acted as advised.

Later, a report came: “The talisman entered the water as if seized by someone.” The Master further memorialized, “After a while, thunder will resound—this is certain.” The emperor was deeply astonished.

Indeed, thunder split open a great juniper tree in the palace’s southeast corner, killing a giant python several *zhang* in length, severed in two. The emperor was overjoyed.
