Earlier, at Jingkou, there stood the Temple of the Fox King, established by the founding emperor of the Stone Ancestry and venerated for many years. One day, fire erupted within the temple, reducing it entirely to ashes and turning it into a grassy field. Chancellor Zhang Tianjue, who governed with virtue, had over a thousand Fox King temples demolished. After Tianjue’s dismissal, fox spirits banded together, infiltrating the palace to steal vessels and treasures, bewitching the palace women. Some scaled mountains, others roamed the halls, perpetrating all manner of mischief, leading to the deaths of not a few favored concubines.

Thus, on the day the Master arrived at court, the emperor first addressed him, to which the Master memorialized: “May Your Majesty remain serene and silent, allowing your servant to expel and subdue them. I request that within the northeast gate of the capital, a three-tiered Thunder Altar be constructed, with an iron cauldron installed within.” When night fell under a bright moon, the Master, wielding his sword, ascended the altar, casting talismans and roaring incantations. Wind and thunder raged, and the heavens darkened. By midnight, Daoist officials witnessed marshals binding several ghosts—clad in striped robes—and driving them into the altar’s center. The Master covered the cauldron’s mouth with talismanic paper, performed his rites, and buried it in the earth, causing all to tremble. At dawn, he entered to memorialize that the fox spirits had been restrained, and from then on, no harm would come. “However, in the Jade Pool, there lurks a black fish from the Liang dynasty, which has transformed into a monstrous being. The fox spirits ride this fish, assuming dragon-like forms to enter the palace, startling and harming the imperial consorts. Now that it has been slain, I request that eunuchs be dispatched to inter it at the Ghost Gate, ensuring its permanent eradication.”

The emperor personally visited the Jade Pool and found a dead fish over a *zhang* long. He marveled for a long while, then ordered the construction of a hall and Daoist abbey encircling the Fox-Restraining Altar, bestowing upon it the name *Office of the Controller of Destiny*. The Master was appointed to oversee its affairs, visiting every five days to burn incense and conduct rituals upon the altar. The Master further presented twelve talismans, which were inscribed upon copper, iron, and stone and concealed within the twelve directional positions of the imperial palace to expel and slay the spirits of flowers, stones, grasses, and trees.

Later, when Yangzhou suffered a prolonged drought, the emperor summoned the Master to pray for rain. The Master memorialized, requesting the Sword and Water Vessel. Upon receiving the imperial bestowal of the vessel and sword, the Master spat a mouthful of water and intoned: “By the command of the Great Song Emperor, your servant prays for rain—rain to shroud the land in mist, wind to uproot trees. Let a thousand *li* of Yangzhou be thoroughly drenched. Borrow three *chi* from the Yellow River. Hasten, as the law commands!” Several days later, the governor of Yangzhou memorialized that rain had indeed fallen, though it was yellow and turbid. The emperor asked why the sweet rain had turned yellow. The Master replied: “The Jiang, Huai, and Ji Rivers are all forbidden by the Celestial Emperor, but the Yellow River is not. Thus it is so.” The emperor exclaimed in delight: “Divine indeed!”

In the seventh month of the seventh year of the Xuanhe era, an edict was issued appointing Master Wang Wenqing of the Subtle Dao of Emptiness as Grand Master of the Supreme Simplicity, Registrar of the Hall of Concentrated Spirit, and Gentleman for Court Discussion of the Right, with the additional titles of Compiler of Texts and Participant in the Imperial Procession. Shortly after, he was further appointed Attendant of the Hall of Concentrated Spirit, later assuming concurrent oversight of the Nine Yang Palace of Total Perfection and the Office of the Controller of Destiny.

His father, Wang Zhao, was posthumously honored as Gentleman for Rendering Service; his mother, née Jiang, as Lady of Great Propriety. The Master submitted a memorial requesting leave to return to the mountains, to wander in seclusion, to merge with the Dao of the Imperial Unity, and to recite the *True Scripture of the Great Cavern* to prolong the emperor’s lifespan. The emperor did not consent. He further instructed the Master to wear a golden square talisman every five days, entering the various palace halls to consecrate water, purify filth, expel evil, cure illness, and expound upon the Dao and virtue. The emperor dispatched the eunuch Huang Yao to command the Master to perform the Great Rites of the Southern Altar of Refinement at the Guangde Palace, delivering the souls of the deceased. That night, the Master cast talismans to summon the palace women harmed by the fox spirits, each appearing in turn. He also produced the *Celestial Treasure Record* to deliver the living, which the emperor greatly revered.

In the eleventh month, when the Bright Hall rites were to be held, excessive rain fell. The emperor summoned the Master and said: “Whenever the Bright Hall rites are conducted, rain and snow freeze, damaging the ceremonial objects and guards. This time, I specially commission the Immortal Minister to pray for clear skies at the Nine Yang Palace of Total Perfection.” The Master agreed. From the day of rehearsal until the conclusion of the Bright Hall rites, the skies remained perfectly clear. The following day, the emperor sat in the Hall of Azure Splendor and summoned the Master. Addressing his ministers, he declared: “The clear skies during this Bright Hall rite were truly the work of Wang Wenqing.” He then issued an edict appointing him, as before, Grand Master of the Supreme Simplicity and Attendant of the Hall of Concentrated Spirit, with the additional titles of Master of the Subtle Dao of Emptiness, Gentleman of the Great Center, Grand Master for Court Discussion, and Participant in the Secretariat, overseeing the affairs of the Daoist clergy.

His father was again posthumously honored as Gentleman for Consultation; his mother as Lady of Great Propriety; his wife, née Ping, as Lady of Propriety; his uncle, Wang Shen, as Gentleman for Rendering Trust; and his younger brother, Ciqing, as Gentleman of Meritorious Achievement, with the same qualifications as those granted for service at the Southern Suburban Sacrifice.

The Master submitted another memorial, stating: “I beg that a wise and sagacious commander be appointed to guard against the malevolent *qi* in the northwest. I also request leave to return to the mountains in my old age.” The imperial rescript read: “How could a celestial minister of the Jade Palace speak of retirement? Your request is denied.” The Jurchen rebels grew rampant, the imperial armies suffered defeat—just as the Master had forewarned.

The emperor then bestowed twenty sticks of incense, instructing the Master to descend with them to both the capital and the provinces to pacify the realm and safeguard the imperial altars. The Master received the incense and returned to his abbey. The emperor dispatched the eunuch Huang Yao with a sealed vermilion document containing imperial incense, to be burned at the Jade Emperor’s Hall of the Nine Yang Palace of Total Perfection. Shortly after, the emperor specially summoned the Master to report on the response. Within an hour, successive messengers arrived, summoning the Master into the palace. The emperor inquired about the response to the vermilion document. The Master, shedding tears, memorialized: “In the memorial, Your Majesty expressed the wish that a virtuous ruler would emerge to govern the realm beyond the Huai River, offering my own life in gratitude for the response.” The imperial reply stated: “If there is to be change, let there be no regret.”

The emperor further inquired, “Master, what is the principle behind this?” The Master secretly memorialized, and the emperor deeply assented.

On the twenty-third day of the twelfth month, the emperor abdicated in favor of the Eastern Palace. The Master entered the court to offer congratulations. Several days later, he burned incense and departed the capital.

In the fourth month of the first year of Jingkang under Emperor Qinzong, the Master hastened to court to request leave to return home and attend to his mother, his words earnest and sincere. The emperor granted his petition.

In the thirteenth year of Shaoxing under Emperor Gaozong, an imperial edict summoned the Master, but he did not go. One day, Magistrate Shao Tai of Shaowu, while passing through the county under Prefect Xu Dexiu’s governance, visited the Master. The Master said, “Shaowu has suffered a great drought.” He then silently prayed at the emperor’s abode, where he saw the so-called *Huiying* deity kneeling before the jade steps, pleading forcefully for the people. The emperor explained that such matters followed a fixed number. The *Huiying* deity insisted, “That prefecture is poor and barren; the people cannot go a single day without grain.” His entreaties were so urgent that he ultimately secured the request, and the year yielded a harvest. When Prefect Xu returned to his office and recounted the matter, the local gentry and commoners unanimously renovated the temple, expanding its halls and deepening their reverence. The *Huiying Record* provides a full account of these events.

In the twenty-second year of Shaoxing, the Master one day said to his disciple Zhu Zhiqing, “I shall soon withdraw into seclusion.” He then took his ritual texts and seal impressions into the stone grotto of Junfeng Mountain and concealed them, exhorting the local earth deity to guard them until a practitioner of the Dao encountered them.

On the twenty-first day of the eighth month in the twenty-third year of Shaoxing (the *guiyou* year), the Master took leave of the county magistrate and bid farewell to his acquaintances. On the twenty-third day, he rose early and composed a verse on his coffin, saying:
*“This body is but a loan,
The pine planks no more real.
To fool the eyes of the vulgar,
I leap beyond the red dust.”*
Having recited this, he concealed himself and departed in the Hall of Alchemical Practice of Xu Jingyang at the Qingdu Abbey of the county. At that moment, a clap of thunder resounded, and the Master thus transcended. His disciples—Xiong the Mountain Man, Ping Jingzong, Yuan Tingzhi, and others—entombed him at Tortoise Hill.

The following year, in the third month, a Daoist named Guo from Longhu Mountain arrived in the county and reported that on the night of the Lantern Festival, he had attended a ritual offering in the imperial palace, where the Master had lingered for three days before departing. Later, a traveler returning from Chengdu Prefecture encountered the Master on the road to Shu. He also inquired whether anyone had received the Master’s transmission of the Daoist arts.

*Comprehensive Mirror of Perfected Immortals Through the Ages Who Embodied the Dao, Scroll Fifty-Three—Concluded.*
